segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Reed had been dead nine years: it was in this chamber he breathed his last; here he lay in state; hence his coffin was borne by the undertaker’s men; and, since that day, a sense of dreary consecration had guarded it from frequent intrusion.

events.text_segment:
They went, shutting the door, and locking it behind them.
The red-room was a square chamber, very seldom slept in, I might say never, indeed, unless when a chance influx of visitors at Gateshead Hall rendered it necessary to turn to account all the accommodation it contained: yet it was one of the largest and stateliest chambers in the mansion. A bed supported on massive pillars of mahogany, hung with curtains of deep red damask, stood out like a tabernacle in the centre; the two large windows, with their blinds always drawn down, were half shrouded in festoons and falls of similar drapery; the carpet was red; the table at the foot of the bed was covered with a crimson cloth; the walls were a soft fawn colour with a blush of pink in it; the wardrobe, the toilet-table, the chairs were of darkly polished old mahogany. Out of these deep surrounding shades rose high, and glared white, the piled-up mattresses and pillows of the bed, spread with a snowy Marseilles counterpane. Scarcely less prominent was an ample cushioned easy-chair near the head of the bed, also white, with a footstool before it; and looking, as I thought, like a pale throne.
This room was chill, because it seldom had a fire; it was silent, because remote from the nursery and kitchen; solemn, because it was known to be so seldom entered. The house-maid alone came here on Saturdays, to wipe from the mirrors and the furniture a week’s quiet dust: and Mrs. Reed herself, at far intervals, visited it to review the contents of a certain secret drawer in the wardrobe, where were stored divers parchments, her jewel-casket, and a miniature of her deceased husband; and in those last words lies the secret of the red-room—the spell which kept it so lonely in spite of its grandeur.
Mr. Reed had been dead nine years: it was in this chamber he breathed his last; here he lay in state; hence his coffin was borne by the undertaker’s men; and, since that day, a sense of dreary consecration had guarded it from frequent intrusion.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: They exited, closing and locking the door behind them. The red-room was a spacious, square chamber, very infrequently used for sleeping—in fact, almost never, unless an unusual number of guests at Gateshead Hall required the use of every available space. Despite this, it was one of the largest and most impressive rooms in the manor. A grand bed with substantial mahogany pillars, draped in deep red damask curtains, occupied the center like a shrine. The two large windows, with their blinds perpetually lowered, were partially obscured by swags and drapes of the same fabric. The floor was covered by a red carpet, and the table at the foot of the bed was draped in crimson cloth. The walls were a gentle fawn color with a hint of pink. The wardrobe, dressing table, and chairs were crafted from dark, gleaming old mahogany. Standing out against these dark surroundings were the high stack of white mattresses and pillows on the bed, covered by a bright white Marseilles bedspread. Almost as noticeable was a large, well-padded armchair near the head of the bed, also white, with a footstool in front of it, which I perceived as resembling a pale throne. This room felt cold because it was rarely warmed by a fire, quiet because of its distance from the nursery and kitchen, and solemn due to its known infrequent occupancy. Only the housemaid entered on Saturdays to dust the mirrors and furniture. Mrs. Reed herself occasionally visited to access a particular hidden drawer in the wardrobe containing various papers, her jewelry box, and a miniature of her late husband. In these last items lies the reason the red-room remained so solitary despite its magnificence—it was linked to the memory of her deceased husband. Mr. Reed had died nine years prior; he had taken his last breath in this chamber, where his body lay in state, and from which his coffin was carried away by the undertakers. Since that day, a sense of gloomy sanctity had shielded it from being often disturbed.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
They left the room, closing and locking the door behind them. The red-room was a rarely used square chamber—in fact, it was almost never slept in, except when a sudden influx of guests at Gateshead Hall forced every available room into service. Despite this, it was among the grandest and most spacious rooms in the house. At the center stood a bed with heavy mahogany posts, draped in rich red damask curtains, resembling a shrine. The two large windows, usually with their blinds pulled down, were partially hidden by matching draperies. The floor was covered with a red carpet, and the table at the foot of the bed had a crimson cloth on it. The walls were a soft tan, tinged with pink; the wardrobe, dressing table, and chairs were made of dark, polished old mahogany. Amidst these deep shades, the bed’s white mattresses and pillows, covered by a snowy Marseilles bedspread, stood out strikingly. Likewise, a large, cushioned easy chair near the head of the bed—also white and with a footstool in front—was prominent, resembling a pale throne in my eyes.

The room felt cold because it rarely had a fire; it was quiet due to its distance from the nursery and kitchen; and it had a solemn atmosphere because it was so rarely entered. Only the housemaid visited on Saturdays, to clean the mirrors and furniture of a week’s dust undisturbed by activity. Mrs. Reed came in herself only occasionally, to examine the contents of a secret drawer in the wardrobe where she kept legal papers, her jewelry box, and a miniature portrait of her late husband. That last item held the room’s true secret—that it remained uninhabited and somber despite its splendor.

Mr. Reed had been dead for nine years. This was the chamber where he died; where his body was laid out; and from where his coffin was carried away by undertakers. Since that day, a melancholy sense of sanctity had kept the room mostly unused.

events.title: Confronting a Ghostly Reflection
detailed_summary: Jane remains on a low ottoman near the marble chimney-piece, the imposing bed looming before her.
She observes her surroundings: the tall, dark wardrobe to her right with its subtly shifting reflections, and the heavily curtained windows to her left.
A large looking-glass positioned between the windows reflects the empty majesty of the bed and the room.
Uncertain whether the door had been locked, Jane summons her courage, gets up, and verifies that it is indeed securely fastened, making her feel as confined as in a jail.
As she returns to her seat, her gaze is involuntarily drawn to the looking-glass, exploring the depths it reveals.
Everything in the reflection appears colder and more somber than in reality.
She sees a 'strange little figure'—her own reflection—with a pale face and arms standing out against the gloom, and glittering, fearful eyes that move while all else is still.
This image strikes her as a real spirit, akin to the tiny phantoms from Bessie's stories—half fairy, half imp—that were said to appear to belated travelers in desolate places.
Affected by this self-perception, Jane returns to her stool.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My seat, to which Bessie and the bitter Miss Abbot had left me riveted, was a low ottoman near the marble chimney-piece; the bed rose before me; to my right hand there was the high, dark wardrobe, with subdued, broken reflections varying the gloss of its panels; to my left were the muffled windows; a great looking-glass between them repeated the vacant majesty of the bed and room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I returned to my stool.

events.text_segment: My seat, to which Bessie and the bitter Miss Abbot had left me riveted, was a low ottoman near the marble chimney-piece; the bed rose before me; to my right hand there was the high, dark wardrobe, with subdued, broken reflections varying the gloss of its panels; to my left were the muffled windows; a great looking-glass between them repeated the vacant majesty of the bed and room. I was not quite sure whether they had locked the door; and when I dared move, I got up and went to see. Alas! yes: no jail was ever more secure. Returning, I had to cross before the looking-glass; my fascinated glance involuntarily explored the depth it revealed. All looked colder and darker in that visionary hollow than in reality: and the strange little figure there gazing at me, with a white face and arms specking the gloom, and glittering eyes of fear moving where all else was still, had the effect of a real spirit: I thought it like one of the tiny phantoms, half fairy, half imp, Bessie’s evening stories represented as coming out of lone, ferny dells in moors, and appearing before the eyes of belated travellers. I returned to my stool.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Pinned to my low seat near the marble fireplace by Bessie and the harsh Miss Abbot, I faced the prominent bed. To my right stood the tall, dim wardrobe, its polished surfaces showing indistinct, broken reflections. To my left were the heavily draped windows, and between them, a large mirror duplicated the empty grandeur of the bed and the room. Uncertain if the door was secured, I cautiously rose and checked; tragically, it was locked as firmly as any prison. As I went back, I had to pass the mirror, and my gaze was involuntarily drawn into the depth it presented. Everything within that illusory space seemed colder and gloomier than in reality. The peculiar small figure staring back at me, with its pale face and arms distinct against the darkness and fearful, flickering eyes within an otherwise motionless form, appeared genuinely spectral. I thought it resembled the small spirits, part fey, part mischievous creature, that Bessie's evening tales depicted emerging from lonely, bracken-filled valleys on the moors to appear before travellers caught out late. I resumed my place on the stool.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Bessie and the stern Miss Abbot had left me fastened to my seat, which was a small ottoman close to the marble fireplace. Directly in front of me stood the bed; to my right was a tall, dark wardrobe, its polished surface catching faint, uneven reflections. On my left were the curtained windows, and between them a large mirror reflected the grand emptiness of the bed and the room. I wasn’t certain if they had locked the door, so when I found the courage to move, I got up to check. Unfortunately, they had; the room felt as secure as a prison. As I walked back, I had to pass the mirror; my eyes were drawn to the depth it showed. Everything in the glass appeared colder and darker than reality. The strange little figure I saw there, with a pale face and arms shining against the shadow, and fearful, glinting eyes moving in an otherwise motionless scene, seemed like a real ghost. It reminded me of the tiny spirits in Bessie’s stories, part fairy and part imp, that appeared to lost travelers on the moors. I went back to my seat.

events.title: Meditations on Injustice and Alienation
detailed_summary: Jane acknowledges a superstitious feeling but notes that her anger and rebellious spirit are still potent, preventing her from succumbing immediately to fear.
She actively tries to suppress a surge of troubling memories before the present dismal reality can overwhelm her.
Her mind becomes crowded with thoughts of John Reed's tyranny, his sisters' proud indifference, Mrs. Reed's aversion to her, and the servants' biased treatment.
She internally questions why she is perpetually suffering, browbeaten, accused, and condemned.
She despairs at her inability to ever please anyone and the futility of trying to win favor.
Jane contrasts her situation with that of the Reed children: Eliza, headstrong and selfish, is respected.
Georgiana, despite a spoiled temper, acrid spite, and insolent demeanor, is universally indulged, her beauty seemingly granting her indemnity for all faults.

John Reed is never thwarted, much less punished, for his various cruelties and misdeeds—killing birds, setting dogs on sheep, destroying plants, and disrespecting his mother—yet he remains Mrs. Reed's 'own darling.'
In stark contrast, Jane, who strives to commit no fault and fulfill every duty, is consistently labeled naughty, tiresome, sullen, and sneaking.
Her head still aches and bleeds from the blow and fall inflicted by John, for which he received no reproof, while she was universally condemned for her self-defense.
Her reason, forced into precocious action by the agonizing injustice, cries out against it.
This sense of injustice, coupled with her resolve, prompts thoughts of desperate escape, such as running away or even self-starvation.
Jane reflects on the profound mental tumult and insurrection of her heart during that dreary afternoon, fought in 'darkness' and 'dense ignorance.'
At the time, she could not comprehend the reasons for her suffering, but now, with hindsight, the cause is clear to her.
She recognizes herself as a 'discord' at Gateshead Hall, fundamentally different from everyone there, lacking any harmony with Mrs. Reed, her children, or their chosen servants.
She acknowledges that if they did not love her, she reciprocated that lack of affection.

She reasons that they were not bound to care for someone so alien in temperament, capacity, and propensities—a 'useless thing' incapable of serving their interests or adding to their pleasure, and a 'noxious thing' harboring indignation and contempt for their treatment and judgment.

Jane believes that had she been a more sanguine, brilliant, careless, exacting, handsome, or romping child—even if equally dependent and friendless—Mrs. Reed would have found her presence more tolerable, her children would have shown more fellowship, and the servants would have been less inclined to use her as a scapegoat.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Superstition was with me at that moment; but it was not yet her hour for complete victory: my blood was still warm; the mood of the revolted slave was still bracing me with its bitter vigour; I had to stem a rapid rush of retrospective thought before I quailed to the dismal present.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I know that had I been a sanguine, brilliant, careless, exacting, handsome, romping child—though equally dependent and friendless—Mrs. Reed would have endured my presence more complacently; her children would have entertained for me more of the cordiality of fellow-feeling; the servants would have been less prone to make me the scapegoat of the nursery.

events.text_segment:
Superstition was with me at that moment; but it was not yet her hour for complete victory: my blood was still warm; the mood of the revolted slave was still bracing me with its bitter vigour; I had to stem a rapid rush of retrospective thought before I quailed to the dismal present.
All John Reed’s violent tyrannies, all his sisters’ proud indifference, all his mother’s aversion, all the servants’ partiality, turned up in my disturbed mind like a dark deposit in a turbid well. Why was I always suffering, always browbeaten, always accused, for ever condemned? Why could I never please? Why was it useless to try to win any one’s favour? Eliza, who was headstrong and selfish, was respected. Georgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and insolent carriage, was universally indulged. Her beauty, her pink cheeks and golden curls, seemed to give delight to all who looked at her, and to purchase indemnity for every fault. John no one thwarted, much less punished; though he twisted the necks of the pigeons, killed the little pea-chicks, set the dogs at the sheep, stripped the hothouse vines of their fruit, and broke the buds off the choicest plants in the conservatory: he called his mother “old girl,” too; sometimes reviled her for her dark skin, similar to his own; bluntly disregarded her wishes; not unfrequently tore and spoiled her silk attire; and he was still “her own darling.” I dared commit no fault: I strove to fulfil every duty; and I was termed naughty and tiresome, sullen and sneaking, from morning to noon, and from noon to night.
My head still ached and bled with the blow and fall I had received: no one had reproved John for wantonly striking me; and because I had turned against him to avert farther irrational violence, I was loaded with general opprobrium.
“Unjust!—unjust!” said my reason, forced by the agonising stimulus into precocious though transitory power: and Resolve, equally wrought up, instigated some strange expedient to achieve escape from insupportable oppression—as running away, or, if that could not be effected, never eating or drinking more, and letting myself die.
What a consternation of soul was mine that dreary afternoon! How all my brain was in tumult, and all my heart in insurrection! Yet in what darkness, what dense ignorance, was the mental battle fought! I could not answer the ceaseless inward question—why I thus suffered; now, at the distance of—I will not say how many years, I see it clearly.
I was a discord in Gateshead Hall: I was like nobody there; I had nothing in harmony with Mrs. Reed or her children, or her chosen vassalage. If they did not love me, in fact, as little did I love them. They were not bound to regard with affection a thing that could not sympathise with one amongst them; a heterogeneous thing, opposed to them in temperament, in capacity, in propensities; a useless thing, incapable of serving their interest, or adding to their pleasure; a noxious thing, cherishing the germs of indignation at their treatment, of contempt of their judgment. I know that had I been a sanguine, brilliant, careless, exacting, handsome, romping child—though equally dependent and friendless—Mrs. Reed would have endured my presence more complacently; her children would have entertained for me more of the cordiality of fellow-feeling; the servants would have been less prone to make me the scapegoat of the nursery.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: At that specific moment, a sense of fear or superstition began to creep in, though it hadn't fully overwhelmed me yet. My spirit was still strong, like that of a rebellious slave, giving me sharp, bracing energy. I had to fight off a quick surge of memories about the past before I could fully yield to the bleakness of the present situation. All the harsh oppression from John Reed, his sisters' arrogant lack of concern, his mother's dislike, and the servants' unfair favouritism surfaced in my troubled mind like dark sediment stirred up in murky water. I wondered why I was constantly suffering, always being bossed around, endlessly accused, and perpetually judged. Why could I never please anyone? Why was it pointless to try and win anyone's approval? Eliza, who was stubborn and selfish, was treated with respect. Georgiana, who had a bad temper, intense spitefulness, and a critical, rude attitude, was always indulged. Her beauty, her rosy cheeks and golden curls, seemed to delight everyone who saw her and protected her from consequences for any mistake. No one opposed John, much less punished him, even though he killed pigeons, little pea-chicks, sicked dogs on sheep, stripped the fruit from hothouse vines, and broke buds off the best plants in the conservatory. He even called his mother names like "old girl," sometimes mocked her for her dark skin which resembled his own, openly ignored her wishes, and often tore or ruined her silk clothes; yet, he remained "her own darling." I dared not make any mistakes; I tried my best to fulfill every duty, and despite this, I was called naughty and tiresome, sullen and secretive, from morning until night. My head still hurt and was bleeding from the blow and the fall I had experienced. No one had reprimanded John for senselessly hitting me; and because I had defended myself against him to prevent further unreasonable violence, I was universally condemned. "Unfair!—unfair!" my reason cried out, pushed by the intense pain into a sharp, albeit temporary, moment of clarity. This strong feeling also prompted me to come up with some drastic plan for escaping the unbearable oppression, such as running away, or if that wasn't possible, stopping eating and drinking and letting myself die. What extreme confusion and distress my soul was in during that miserable afternoon! How my mind was in turmoil and my heart in revolt! Yet, the internal struggle was fought in such ignorance and lack of understanding! I couldn't answer the persistent inner question about why I was suffering like this. Now, many years later, I understand it clearly. I was an outsider at Gateshead Hall; I didn't fit in with anyone there. I had nothing in common with Mrs. Reed, her children, or the staff she preferred. Just as they didn't love me, I felt little love for them. They weren't obligated to feel affection for someone who couldn't connect with any of them—someone fundamentally different in temperament, ability, and inclinations; someone they saw as useless, incapable of benefiting them or adding to their happiness; even someone harmful, harboring seeds of anger at how they treated her and contempt for their judgment. I know that if I had been a cheerful, lively, carefree, demanding, attractive, playful child—even if still dependent and friendless—Mrs. Reed would have tolerated my presence more easily; her children would have felt more camaraderie towards me; and the servants would have been less likely to make me the scapegoat in the nursery.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: At that moment, superstition affected me, but it hadn’t completely overcome me yet: I still felt strong, fueled by the defiant spirit of someone who refuses subjugation; I had to fight back a flood of memories before I gave in to the misery of my current situation. All of John Reed’s cruelty, his sisters’ haughty coldness, his mother’s dislike, and the servants’ bias resurfaced in my troubled thoughts, like muck rising in a cloudy well. Why was I always the one punished, mistreated, and blamed? Why couldn’t I ever make anyone happy? Why was trying to gain favor always fruitless? Eliza, headstrong and selfish, was respected; Georgiana, spoiled and spiteful, was always indulged because her beauty charmed everyone and seemed to excuse her every fault. John, whose behavior was far worse—hurting animals, damaging property, insulting his mother—was never challenged or punished; in fact, he remained his mother’s favorite. Meanwhile, I, who tried hard to do what was right, was called bad and tiresome all the time. My head still throbbed from the blow I’d received from John, yet nobody scolded him for hitting me unprovoked; instead, because I defended myself, I was attacked by everyone. My sense of justice cried out that this was unfair, and in my desperation, I considered desperate means to escape—running away, or even refusing food and drink until I died. That bleak afternoon, my inner turmoil was immense—my mind in chaos, my heart in rebellion—yet I struggled in darkness, not understanding why I suffered so much. Only years later did I realize the truth: I was an outsider in Gateshead Hall, fundamentally different from the Reeds and their servants. They didn’t love me, but I didn’t love them either. Why would they care for someone so unlike themselves, who could do nothing to further their interests or bring them joy, and who resented their treatment? If I had been a lively, attractive, easygoing child, even as dependent and lonely, Mrs. Reed and her children might have tolerated me better, and the servants might not have blamed me for every mishap.

events.title: Descending into Fear and Pondering Mr. Reed's Spirit
detailed_summary: As daylight begins to fade from the red-room around four o'clock, with the afternoon transitioning into a dreary twilight, Jane feels a growing chill and a decline in her courage.
The continuous sound of rain against the staircase window and the wind howling in the nearby grove contribute to the oppressive atmosphere.
Her habitual feelings of humiliation, self-doubt, and forlorn depression start to overwhelm her diminishing anger.
She begins to internalize the accusations of wickedness, recalling her recent suicidal thought of starving herself as evidence of her criminality.
Jane questions her fitness for death and whether the vault under Gateshead Church, where Mr. Reed is buried, offers an inviting end.
This thought leads her to dwell on the memory and idea of Mr. Reed with an increasing sense of dread.

Though she cannot recall him personally, she is aware that he was her mother's brother, who had taken her in as a parentless infant and, in his final moments, had extracted a promise from Mrs. Reed to raise and maintain her as one of her own children.
Jane reflects that Mrs. Reed probably believed she had fulfilled this promise as best as her nature allowed.

She considers how burdensome it must have been for Mrs. Reed to be bound by such a pledge to care for a 'strange child she could not love,' an 'uncongenial alien' permanently intruding on her family, especially after her husband's death.
A singular notion dawns on Jane: she is unshakeably convinced that Mr. Reed, had he lived, would have treated her kindly.

As she observes the white bed and shadowed walls, occasionally glancing at the dimly gleaming mirror, she starts to recall stories about the spirits of the dead who, troubled by the violation of their last wishes, revisit earth to punish the perjured and avenge the oppressed.

She begins to imagine that Mr. Reed's spirit, distressed by the injustices done to his sister's child, might leave its resting place—be it the church vault or the unknown world of the departed—and appear before her in that very chamber.

Jane suppresses her tears and sobs, afraid that any overt display of violent grief might awaken a preternatural voice to comfort her or conjure a haloed face from the gloom, an idea that, while theoretically consoling, she feels would be terrifying if realized.
With all her strength, she endeavors to stifle this thought and remain firm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Daylight began to forsake the red-room; it was past four o’clock, and the beclouded afternoon was tending to drear twilight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This idea, consolatory in theory, I felt would be terrible if realised: with all my might I endeavoured to stifle it—I endeavoured to be firm.

events.text_segment:
Daylight began to forsake the red-room; it was past four o’clock, and the beclouded afternoon was tending to drear twilight. I heard the rain still beating continuously on the staircase window, and the wind howling in the grove behind the hall; I grew by degrees cold as a stone, and then my courage sank. My habitual mood of humiliation, self-doubt, forlorn depression, fell damp on the embers of my decaying ire. All said I was wicked, and perhaps I might be so; what thought had I been but just conceiving of starving myself to death? That certainly was a crime: and was I fit to die? Or was the vault under the chancel of Gateshead Church an inviting bourne? In such vault I had been told did Mr. Reed lie buried; and led by this thought to recall his idea, I dwelt on it with gathering dread. I could not remember him; but I knew that he was my own uncle—my mother’s brother—that he had taken me when a parentless infant to his house; and that in his last moments he had required a promise of Mrs. Reed that she would rear and maintain me as one of her own children. Mrs. Reed probably considered she had kept this promise; and so she had, I dare say, as well as her nature would permit her; but how could she really like an interloper not of her race, and unconnected with her, after her husband’s death, by any tie? It must have been most irksome to find herself bound by a hard-wrung pledge to stand in the stead of a parent to a strange child she could not love, and to see an uncongenial alien permanently intruded on her own family group.
A singular notion dawned upon me. I doubted not—never doubted—that if Mr. Reed had been alive he would have treated me kindly; and now, as I sat looking at the white bed and overshadowed walls—occasionally also turning a fascinated eye towards the dimly gleaming mirror—I began to recall what I had heard of dead men, troubled in their graves by the violation of their last wishes, revisiting the earth to punish the perjured and avenge the oppressed; and I thought Mr. Reed’s spirit, harassed by the wrongs of his sister’s child, might quit its abode—whether in the church vault or in the unknown world of the departed—and rise before me in this chamber. I wiped my tears and hushed my sobs, fearful lest any sign of violent grief might waken a preternatural voice to comfort me, or elicit from the gloom some haloed face, bending over me with strange pity. This idea, consolatory in theory, I felt would be terrible if realised: with all my might I endeavoured to stifle it—I endeavoured to be firm.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
As daylight faded from the red-room, passing four o'clock into a cloudy, gloomy afternoon, I heard the constant rain hitting the staircase window and the wind howling in the trees behind the house. Gradually, I felt myself turn as cold as stone, and my bravery disappeared. My usual feelings of being put down, unsure of myself, and sadly depressed washed over the faint remnants of my anger. Everyone said I was bad, and maybe I was; just a moment ago, I was thinking about starving myself to death. That was definitely a sin, and was I ready to die? Was the tomb under the altar area of Gateshead Church a desirable destination? I'd been told Mr. Reed was buried there. Thinking of this made me remember him, and thinking about him filled me with increasing fear. I couldn't remember what he looked like, but I knew he was my uncle, my mother's brother, who had taken me into his home as a baby with no parents. I knew that before he died, he had made Mrs. Reed promise to raise and support me as one of her own kids. Mrs. Reed probably believed she had kept this promise, and to be fair, I guess she did as well as she possibly could given her personality. But how could she truly like an outsider, not related to her family, and with no connection to her after her husband's death? It must have been incredibly difficult for her to feel obligated by a promise she didn't want to make, having to act like a mother to a strange child she couldn't love, and seeing someone she didn't get along with constantly forced into her family life.
A strange idea came into my mind. I was certain, always certain, that if Mr. Reed were alive, he would have treated me well. Now, sitting and looking at the white bed and the dark walls, sometimes glancing with fascination at the dimly lit mirror, I started remembering stories about dead people disturbed in their graves when their final wishes weren't followed. They supposedly returned to Earth to punish those who broke their promises and help those who were wronged. I thought maybe Mr. Reed's ghost, upset by how his sister's child was being treated, might leave its resting place—whether in the church tomb or the unknown world of the dead—and appear before me in this room. I dried my tears and quieted my crying, afraid that showing such strong sorrow might call up a supernatural voice to comfort me, or reveal a glowing face from the darkness, leaning over me with strange pity. While this idea seemed comforting in theory, I felt it would be terrifying if it actually happened. I tried my hardest to stop thinking about it; I tried to be strong.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: As daylight faded from the red-room and the clouded afternoon turned into a gloomy twilight, I became aware of the persistent sound of rain against the staircase window and the wind howling behind the hall. I gradually grew as cold as stone, and my courage gave way. My usual feelings of shame, self-doubt, and loneliness smothered the last sparks of my anger. Everyone said I was wicked—perhaps I was; after all, I had just thought about starving myself to death, which was certainly wrong. Was I ready to die? Was the burial vault at Gateshead Church—where I'd been told Mr. Reed was buried—a place I wanted to go? Remembering this, I contemplated Mr. Reed. Though I couldn't recall him personally, I knew he was my uncle who'd taken me in as a baby after my parents died. He’d made Mrs. Reed promise to raise me as her own child. She probably believed she'd kept her word as far as she could, but how could she truly care for someone unrelated to her, especially after her husband’s death? It must have been hard for her to feel obligated to care for a child she couldn't love, always having a foreign presence among her family. A strange thought occurred to me: I never doubted Mr. Reed would have been kind if he’d lived. While looking at the white bed and shadowy walls, sometimes glimpsing at the dim mirror, I recalled stories of unsettled spirits returning to punish those who broke their dying wishes. I wondered if Mr. Reed’s spirit, troubled by my mistreatment, might appear in this room. I wiped away my tears and tried to stifle my sobs, afraid that any show of grief might summon something supernatural—a comforting voice or a pitying face from the gloom. Though the idea seemed comforting, in reality it would have terrified me, so I tried to suppress it and remain strong.

events.title: The Terrifying Light and Desperate Panic
detailed_summary: Shaking her hair from her eyes, Jane lifts her head and attempts to survey the dark room with boldness.
At this precise moment, a gleam of light appears on the wall.
She initially questions if it's a ray of moonlight penetrating an opening in the blind but dismisses the idea, as moonlight is stationary, whereas this light moved.
As she gazes, the light glides upwards to the ceiling and quivers above her head.
Jane later conjectures that this streak of light was most likely a gleam from a lantern being carried across the lawn outside.
However, at that moment, her mind already primed for horror and her nerves shaken by agitation, she interprets the swift, darting beam as a herald of an impending vision from another world.
Her heart begins to beat thickly, her head grows hot, and a sound fills her ears, which she believes to be the rushing of wings.
She feels something near her, feels oppressed and suffocated, and her endurance finally breaks down.
Overcome with terror, Jane rushes to the door and shakes the lock in a desperate effort to escape.
Steps are heard running along the outer passage, the key turns in the lock, and Bessie and Miss Abbot enter the red-room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Shaking my hair from my eyes, I lifted my head and tried to look boldly round the dark room; at this moment a light gleamed on the wall.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Steps came running along the outer passage; the key turned, Bessie and Abbot entered.

events.text_segment: Shaking my hair from my eyes, I lifted my head and tried to look boldly round the dark room; at this moment a light gleamed on the wall. Was it, I asked myself, a ray from the moon penetrating some aperture in the blind? No; moonlight was still, and this stirred; while I gazed, it glided up to the ceiling and quivered over my head. I can now conjecture readily that this streak of light was, in all likelihood, a gleam from a lantern carried by some one across the lawn: but then, prepared as my mind was for horror, shaken as my nerves were by agitation, I thought the swift darting beam was a herald of some coming vision from another world. My heart beat thick, my head grew hot; a sound filled my ears, which I deemed the rushing of wings; something seemed near me; I was oppressed, suffocated: endurance broke down; I rushed to the door and shook the lock in desperate effort. Steps came running along the outer passage; the key turned, Bessie and Abbot entered.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Tossing my hair back from my face, I raised my head, attempting to survey the dim room bravely. Just then, a light shone on the wall. Could it be, I wondered, a beam from the moon entering through a gap in the curtain? No, moonlight is steady, and this light moved; as I watched, it slid upwards towards the ceiling and trembled above me. Now, I can easily guess that this line of light was probably from a lantern someone was carrying across the grass. However, at that moment, with my mind primed for terror and my nerves jangled by fear, I believed the rapidly moving beam was a sign of a supernatural appearance from another realm. My pulse quickened dramatically, my head felt hot, and my ears buzzed with a sound I imagined were beating wings. Something felt close by; I felt overwhelmed and unable to breathe. My self-control failed; I sprinted to the door and rattled the lock in a frantic attempt to get out. Footsteps hurried down the hallway outside; the key turned, and Bessie and Abbot came in.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Pushing my hair away from my face, I raised my head and tried to bravely look around the dark room; at that moment, a light flickered on the wall. I wondered if it was moonlight slipping through an opening in the window covering, but it wasn't, because the moon casts a steady light and this one moved. As I watched, the beam slid up to the ceiling and trembled above me. Looking back now, I realize it was probably the light of a lantern as someone walked across the lawn. But at the time, my fearful mind and unsettled nerves made me believe it was the sign of a supernatural apparition. My heart pounded, my head felt feverish, and I heard a noise I imagined was wings rustling. Something felt close to me; I felt overwhelmed and unable to breathe. My self-control collapsed; I ran to the door and desperately shook the lock. Footsteps hurried along the hallway outside; the key turned, and Bessie and Abbot came in.

events.title: Dismissal of Fear and Jane's Collapse After Renewed Imprisonment
detailed_summary: Upon entering, Bessie asks Jane if she is ill.
Miss Abbot exclaims about the 'dreadful noise' Jane made, stating it went 'quite through me.'
Jane cries out, begging to be taken out of the red-room and allowed into the nursery.
Bessie questions her further, asking if she is hurt or if she has seen something.
Jane, now holding onto Bessie's hand (which Bessie does not pull away), explains that she saw a light and thought a ghost was about to appear.
Miss Abbot dismisses Jane's fear with disgust, declaring that Jane screamed out on purpose merely to bring them all there, attributing it to her 'naughty tricks.'
Another voice, belonging to Mrs. Reed, peremptorily demands to know what is happening.

Mrs. Reed appears in the corridor, her cap askew and her gown rustling, and reminds Abbot and Bessie of her explicit orders that Jane Eyre should be left in the red-room until she herself came to her.
Bessie attempts to justify their presence by explaining that 'Miss Jane screamed so loud, ma'am.'
Mrs. Reed's only response is 'Let her go,' and she instructs Jane to release Bessie's hand, asserting that such attempts at manipulation will not succeed.
Mrs. Reed expresses her abhorrence of 'artifice,' particularly in children, and states her intention to demonstrate that such tricks will not work.
She then sentences Jane to an additional hour in the red-room, stipulating that her release is conditional upon perfect submission and stillness.
Jane pleads desperately, 'O aunt! have pity! Forgive me! I cannot endure it—let me be punished some other way! I shall be killed if—'
Mrs. Reed curtly silences her, finding Jane's violent distress 'most repulsive.'
Jane perceives that in Mrs. Reed's eyes, she is a precocious actress, a distasteful combination of virulent passions, a mean spirit, and dangerous duplicity.

After Bessie and Abbot have retreated, Mrs. Reed, impatient with Jane's now frantic anguish and wild sobs, abruptly thrusts her back into the red-room and locks the door without any further discussion.
Jane hears Mrs. Reed sweeping away, and soon after her departure, Jane believes she experienced a 'species of fit,' as unconsciousness overcame her, closing the scene.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Miss Eyre, are you ill?” said Bessie.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I heard her sweeping away; and soon after she was gone, I suppose I had a species of fit: unconsciousness closed the scene.

events.text_segment:
“Miss Eyre, are you ill?” said Bessie.
“What a dreadful noise! it went quite through me!” exclaimed Abbot.
“Take me out! Let me go into the nursery!” was my cry.
“What for? Are you hurt? Have you seen something?” again demanded Bessie.
“Oh! I saw a light, and I thought a ghost would come.” I had now got hold of Bessie’s hand, and she did not snatch it from me.
“She has screamed out on purpose,” declared Abbot, in some disgust. “And what a scream! If she had been in great pain one would have excused it, but she only wanted to bring us all here: I know her naughty tricks.”
“What is all this?” demanded another voice peremptorily; and Mrs. Reed came along the corridor, her cap flying wide, her gown rustling stormily. “Abbot and Bessie, I believe I gave orders that Jane Eyre should be left in the red-room till I came to her myself.”
“Miss Jane screamed so loud, ma’am,” pleaded Bessie.
“Let her go,” was the only answer. “Loose Bessie’s hand, child: you cannot succeed in getting out by these means, be assured. I abhor artifice, particularly in children; it is my duty to show you that tricks will not answer: you will now stay here an hour longer, and it is only on condition of perfect submission and stillness that I shall liberate you then.”
“O aunt! have pity! Forgive me! I cannot endure it—let me be punished some other way! I shall be killed if—”
“Silence! This violence is all most repulsive:” and so, no doubt, she felt it. I was a precocious actress in her eyes; she sincerely looked on me as a compound of virulent passions, mean spirit, and dangerous duplicity.
Bessie and Abbot having retreated, Mrs. Reed, impatient of my now frantic anguish and wild sobs, abruptly thrust me back and locked me in, without farther parley. I heard her sweeping away; and soon after she was gone, I suppose I had a species of fit: unconsciousness closed the scene.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: “Miss Eyre, are you feeling unwell?” Bessie inquired. “What a terrible noise! It went right through me!” Abbot exclaimed. “Take me out! Let me go to the nursery!” I cried out. “Why? Are you injured? Have you seen something?” Bessie questioned again. “Oh! I saw a light, and I thought a spirit would appear.” I had now grabbed Bessie’s hand, and she did not pull it away from me. “She screamed on purpose,” declared Abbot with annoyance. “And what a scream! If she had been in severe pain, one might have excused it, but she only wanted to draw us all here: I know her mischievous tricks.” “What is going on?” demanded another voice sternly; and Mrs. Reed came along the corridor, her cap askew, her dress rustling loudly. “Abbot and Bessie, I believe I instructed that Jane Eyre should be left in the red-room until I came to her myself.” “Miss Jane screamed so loudly, ma’am,” Bessie pleaded. “Release her,” was the only response. “Let go of Bessie’s hand, child: be certain you will not succeed in escaping by these methods. I despise deceit, especially in children; it is my duty to show you that trickery will not work: you will now remain here an hour longer, and only on the condition of complete compliance and stillness shall I free you then.” “Oh, Aunt! Please have mercy! Forgive me! I cannot bear it—let me be punished differently! I will be killed if—” “Silence! This violent display is utterly repulsive:” and that was undoubtedly how she felt. To her eyes, I was an overly dramatic actress; she genuinely saw me as a combination of intense emotions, a low character, and dangerous dishonesty. After Bessie and Abbot had withdrawn, Mrs. Reed, impatient with my now frantic distress and wild weeping, abruptly pushed me back in and locked me up, without further discussion. I heard her walking away; and soon after she was gone, I assume I experienced a sort of fit: unconsciousness ended the scene.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Bessie asked me if I was feeling unwell, and Abbot was startled by the loud sound I had made, saying it disturbed her. I cried out, begging to be taken to the nursery. Bessie questioned if I was hurt or if I had seen something frightening. I explained that I had seen a light and feared a ghost might appear, grabbing Bessie's hand for comfort, and she allowed it. Abbot, however, dismissed my distress, accusing me of screaming deliberately just to get everyone's attention and calling it one of my usual misbehaviors. Suddenly, Mrs. Reed appeared, demanding to know what was happening, her presence marked by her disheveled cap and rustling gown. Reminding Abbot and Bessie of her instructions to keep me in the red-room, Mrs. Reed dismissed Bessie's attempt at defending me and ordered her to let go of my hand, saying that such tricks would not work and that I needed to learn this lesson. She decreed that I would stay in the room for an additional hour and would only be released if I behaved perfectly in the meantime. I pleaded desperately for forgiveness and begged for a different punishment, fearing that staying would be unbearable. Mrs. Reed cut me off sternly, calling my behavior repulsive and viewing me as deceitful and troublesome. Finally, Bessie and Abbot left, and Mrs. Reed, annoyed by my desperate sobbing, pushed me back in and locked the door behind her. After she left, I eventually lost consciousness, ending the ordeal.

events.title: Waking to Confusion and Temporary Solace with Mr. Lloyd
detailed_summary: Jane awakens from what feels like a frightful nightmare, disoriented by a red glare and muffled sounds, experiencing intense terror and confusion.
She slowly becomes aware that someone is gently handling and supporting her in a sitting position, a tenderness she has never before experienced, and she rests her head, feeling a measure of ease.

Her bewilderment dissipates, and she recognizes her surroundings: her own bed in the nursery, the red glare as the nursery fire, Bessie standing nearby, and a gentleman, Mr. Lloyd the apothecary, seated by her pillow.
The presence of Mr. Lloyd, an individual not connected to Gateshead or Mrs. Reed, brings Jane an unexpected and profound sense of relief, protection, and security.
After Jane identifies him by name, Mr. Lloyd offers a comforting smile and reassures her, then instructs Bessie to ensure Jane is not disturbed during the night.
Mr. Lloyd's departure causes the room to darken and Jane's heart to sink again, as his presence had felt like a shield; an inexpressible sadness overwhelms her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next thing I remember is, waking up with a feeling as if I had had a frightful nightmare, and seeing before me a terrible red glare, crossed with thick black bars.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I felt so sheltered and befriended while he sat in the chair near my pillow; and as he closed the door after him, all the room darkened and my heart again sank: inexpressible sadness weighed it down.

events.text_segment:
The next thing I remember is, waking up with a feeling as if I had had a frightful nightmare, and seeing before me a terrible red glare, crossed with thick black bars. I heard voices, too, speaking with a hollow sound, and as if muffled by a rush of wind or water: agitation, uncertainty, and an all-predominating sense of terror confused my faculties. Ere long, I became aware that some one was handling me; lifting me up and supporting me in a sitting posture, and that more tenderly than I had ever been raised or upheld before. I rested my head against a pillow or an arm, and felt easy.
In five minutes more the cloud of bewilderment dissolved: I knew quite well that I was in my own bed, and that the red glare was the nursery fire. It was night: a candle burnt on the table; Bessie stood at the bed-foot with a basin in her hand, and a gentleman sat in a chair near my pillow, leaning over me.
I felt an inexpressible relief, a soothing conviction of protection and security, when I knew that there was a stranger in the room, an individual not belonging to Gateshead, and not related to Mrs. Reed. Turning from Bessie (though her presence was far less obnoxious to me than that of Abbot, for instance, would have been), I scrutinised the face of the gentleman: I knew him; it was Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary, sometimes called in by Mrs. Reed when the servants were ailing: for herself and the children she employed a physician.
“Well, who am I?” he asked.
I pronounced his name, offering him at the same time my hand: he took it, smiling and saying, “We shall do very well by-and-by.” Then he laid me down, and addressing Bessie, charged her to be very careful that I was not disturbed during the night. Having given some further directions, and intimated that he should call again the next day, he departed; to my grief: I felt so sheltered and befriended while he sat in the chair near my pillow; and as he closed the door after him, all the room darkened and my heart again sank: inexpressible sadness weighed it down.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The next sensation I recall is waking up feeling as though I'd suffered a terrible dream, confronting a terrifying red glow intersected by thick dark bars. I also heard voices speaking hollowly, as if muffled by rushing wind or water; this turmoil, uncertainty, and overriding dread overwhelmed my senses. Before long, I became aware that someone was touching me, lifting and supporting me in a sitting position, and doing so with a gentleness I had never experienced before. I leaned my head against what felt like a cushion or an arm and felt comfortable. In another five minutes, the fog of confusion lifted; I clearly understood I was in my own bed, and the red light was from the nursery fire. It was nighttime; a candle burned on the table; Bessie stood at the foot of the bed with a basin, and a gentleman sat nearby, leaning over me. I felt an immense wave of relief, a calming certainty of safety and protection, upon realizing there was a stranger in the room, someone not connected to Gateshead or Mrs. Reed. Turning my attention from Bessie (whose presence bothered me far less than, say, Abbot's would have), I carefully observed the gentleman's face; I recognized him. It was Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary Mrs. Reed sometimes called upon when the servants were ill; for herself and the children, she used a different physician. 'Alright, who am I?' he asked. I stated his name and offered him my hand simultaneously; he accepted it, smiling and saying, 'We will be perfectly fine in a while.' Then he laid me back down and told Bessie to ensure I was absolutely not disturbed during the night. After providing some further instructions and indicating he would return the following day, he left, much to my dismay. I had felt so sheltered and supported while he sat by my pillow, and as he shut the door behind him, the room seemed to darken, and my heart sank again, burdened by profound sadness.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: The following thing I recall is waking up, feeling as though I’d just emerged from a terrifying nightmare, and seeing a harsh red glow before me, streaked with thick, dark shadows. I also heard muffled voices that sounded as though they came through wind or moving water, all of which left me overwhelmed with fear and confusion. Soon, I realized that someone was carefully lifting me and helping me to sit up more gently than I had ever been treated before. Resting my head on either a pillow or an arm, I felt comforted. In a few more minutes, the confusion faded, and I understood that I was lying in my own bed, with the red glow coming from the nursery fire. It was nighttime: a candle burned on the table; Bessie stood at the foot of my bed holding a basin, and a man sat reclining near my pillow. I felt an immense sense of relief and safety when I realized that there was a stranger—someone not from Gateshead or related to Mrs. Reed—in the room. I glanced away from Bessie (whose presence I found tolerable, especially compared to Abbot) and studied the gentleman. I answered his name and shook his hand, which he accepted while smiling and reassuring me that things would soon be better. I was sorry to see him go; I’d felt protected while he sat near me, but as he shut the door, the room seemed to grow darker and a deep sadness returned, weighing on my heart.

events.title: Bessie's Uneasy Kindness and Jane's Night of Terror
detailed_summary: Bessie addresses Jane with unusual softness, asking if she feels able to sleep or if she would like anything to eat or drink, which Jane declines.
Emboldened by Bessie's unwonted civility, Jane asks what is wrong with her. Bessie suggests she fell sick from crying so much in the red-room.

Bessie then goes to the housemaid's apartment, and Jane overhears her telling Sarah that she is too frightened to stay alone with Jane, fearing Jane might die and wondering if she saw something supernatural, adding that Mrs. Reed had been too severe.

Jane, only pretending to be asleep, listens as Bessie and Sarah whisper together for half an hour about frightening supernatural occurrences—a figure in white, a black dog, mysterious raps, and a light over a grave.

After Bessie and Sarah fall asleep and the fire and candle extinguish, Jane endures the remainder of the long night in a state of ghastly wakefulness, her senses strained by an overwhelming and child-like dread.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Do you feel as if you should sleep, Miss?” asked Bessie, rather softly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: For me, the watches of that long night passed in ghastly wakefulness; ear, eye, and mind were alike strained by dread: such dread as children only can feel.

events.text_segment:
“Do you feel as if you should sleep, Miss?” asked Bessie, rather softly.
Scarcely dared I answer her; for I feared the next sentence might be rough. “I will try.”
“Would you like to drink, or could you eat anything?”
“No, thank you, Bessie.”
“Then I think I shall go to bed, for it is past twelve o’clock; but you may call me if you want anything in the night.”
Wonderful civility this! It emboldened me to ask a question.
“Bessie, what is the matter with me? Am I ill?”
“You fell sick, I suppose, in the red-room with crying; you’ll be better soon, no doubt.”
Bessie went into the housemaid’s apartment, which was near. I heard her say—
“Sarah, come and sleep with me in the nursery; I daren’t for my life be alone with that poor child to-night: she might die; it’s such a strange thing she should have that fit: I wonder if she saw anything. Missis was rather too hard.”
Sarah came back with her; they both went to bed; they were whispering together for half-an-hour before they fell asleep. I caught scraps of their conversation, from which I was able only too distinctly to infer the main subject discussed.
“Something passed her, all dressed in white, and vanished”—“A great black dog behind him”—“Three loud raps on the chamber door”—“A light in the churchyard just over his grave,” &c., &c.
At last both slept: the fire and the candle went out. For me, the watches of that long night passed in ghastly wakefulness; ear, eye, and mind were alike strained by dread: such dread as children only can feel.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Bessie gently inquired, 'Do you think you might be able to sleep, Miss?' I barely dared to reply, anticipating a potentially harsh follow-up. 'I will attempt to.' 'Would you care for something to drink, or perhaps a bite to eat?' she asked. 'No, thank you, Bessie,' I replied. 'In that case, I believe I will retire to bed, as it is now after midnight; however, please feel free to summon me if you require anything during the night.' This display of remarkable politeness was surprising and encouraged me to venture a question. 'Bessie,' I asked, 'what is wrong with me? Am I unwell?' 'You became ill, I presume, from weeping so much in the red room,' she explained, 'you will undoubtedly recover shortly.' Bessie then moved to the housemaid's adjacent room. I overheard her saying, 'Sarah, come and share the nursery bed with me; I absolutely cannot be alone with that poor girl tonight: she could potentially pass away; it was so peculiar that she had that seizure: I can't help but wonder if she witnessed something. The mistress was quite harsh on her.' Sarah returned alongside her; they both settled into bed; they continued whispering to each other for about thirty minutes before finally drifting off. I managed to overhear fragments of their discussion, and from these, I could infer the primary topic being talked about with unfortunate clarity. The snippets included phrases like—'Something went past her, clad entirely in white, and disappeared'—'A large black dog following him'—'Three distinct knocks on the bedroom door'—'A light in the graveyard right above his burial spot,' and other similar remarks. Eventually, they both fell asleep; the fire died down, and the candle's flame extinguished. As for me, the hours of that prolonged night were spent in terrifying sleeplessness; my hearing, sight, and thoughts were equally burdened by intense fear: a type of fear experienced solely by children.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Bessie spoke gently and asked me if I felt like sleeping. I was almost afraid to reply because I thought she might respond harshly, but I said I would try. She offered me something to eat or drink, but I declined. Bessie then said she was going to bed since it was after midnight, but told me to call her if I needed anything during the night. Her kindness encouraged me to ask her what was wrong with me and if I was ill. She replied that I had likely made myself sick crying in the red-room, but would soon recover. Eventually, they both fell asleep, and the fire and candle went out. I, however, stayed awake, terrified throughout the night, my senses tensed with the kind of intense fear only a child can experience.

events.title: The Red-Room's Lasting Impact and Jane's Persistent Misery
detailed_summary: Jane reflects that the traumatic incident in the red-room did not lead to any severe or prolonged physical illness, but it did administer a shock to her nerves, the repercussions of which she feels to this day.

She mentally addresses Mrs. Reed, acknowledging the profound mental suffering inflicted upon her but simultaneously expressing a sense of obligation to forgive her, believing Mrs. Reed acted out of ignorance, intending to uproot supposed bad tendencies rather than intentionally causing deep emotional harm.
The following day, by noon, Jane is dressed and sitting by the nursery hearth, feeling physically weak and broken down.
Her predominant suffering, however, is an unutterable wretchedness of mind, which causes silent tears to flow continuously, one following another as soon as it's wiped away.

She muses that she ought to have been happy, given the absence of the Reeds (who were out with their mother) and Abbot (sewing elsewhere), and Bessie's occasional words of unusual kindness, but her shattered nerves prevent any sense of calm or pleasure from taking hold.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No severe or prolonged bodily illness followed this incident of the red-room; it only gave my nerves a shock of which I feel the reverberation to this day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: but, in fact, my racked nerves were now in such a state that no calm could soothe, and no pleasure excite them agreeably.

events.text_segment:
No severe or prolonged bodily illness followed this incident of the red-room; it only gave my nerves a shock of which I feel the reverberation to this day. Yes, Mrs. Reed, to you I owe some fearful pangs of mental suffering, but I ought to forgive you, for you knew not what you did: while rending my heart-strings, you thought you were only uprooting my bad propensities.
Next day, by noon, I was up and dressed, and sat wrapped in a shawl by the nursery hearth. I felt physically weak and broken down: but my worse ailment was an unutterable wretchedness of mind: a wretchedness which kept drawing from me silent tears; no sooner had I wiped one salt drop from my cheek than another followed. Yet, I thought, I ought to have been happy, for none of the Reeds were there, they were all gone out in the carriage with their mama. Abbot, too, was sewing in another room, and Bessie, as she moved hither and thither, putting away toys and arranging drawers, addressed to me every now and then a word of unwonted kindness. This state of things should have been to me a paradise of peace, accustomed as I was to a life of ceaseless reprimand and thankless fagging; but, in fact, my racked nerves were now in such a state that no calm could soothe, and no pleasure excite them agreeably.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The terrifying experience in the red-room did not result in a severe or lasting physical sickness, but it inflicted a nervous shock whose effects I still feel today. Indeed, Mrs. Reed, I hold you accountable for some agonizing instances of emotional torment, though I should forgive you because you likely didn't fully grasp the pain you caused; you believed you were merely rooting out my bad habits when you were actually tearing my heart apart. By noon the next day, I was dressed and sitting near the nursery fireplace, wrapped in a shawl. Physically, I felt frail and exhausted, but my primary suffering was an indescribable mental anguish that made me weep silently and continuously; as soon as I wiped one tear, another would fall. Despite this, I considered that I ought to have felt happy, as the Reed children were absent, having gone out with their mother in the carriage. Abbot was busy sewing in another room, and Bessie spoke to me with unusual kindness occasionally as she tidied toys and arranged drawers. This situation should have been a haven of peace for me, given my usual life of constant criticism and thankless labor; however, my damaged nerves were in such a state that no amount of calm could soothe them, nor could any pleasant stimulus bring them agreeable excitement.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: The incident in the red-room did not leave me with any lasting or serious illness; it simply gave my nerves a jolt that I still remember. Mrs. Reed, you caused me intense emotional pain, but I ought to forgive you, because you didn’t understand the effects of your actions: when you broke my spirit, you thought you were only correcting my faults. The day after, I got up around noon, dressed, and sat by the nursery fire wrapped in a shawl. Though my body was weak and exhausted, my greatest suffering was a profound misery that made me cry quietly; each tear I wiped away was quickly replaced by another. Oddly, I thought I should have felt content, because the Reed family was out and I was alone, with Abbot in another room and Bessie treating me with unusual kindness as she worked. This should have seemed like a peaceful haven to someone used to constant scolding and thankless chores, but in reality, my nerves were so strained that nothing could comfort or please me.

events.title: Anhedonia: Rejected Comforts and Lost Literary Magic
detailed_summary: Bessie returns from the kitchen with a tart for Jane, served on a special, brightly painted china plate adorned with a bird of paradise, an object Jane had long admired and wished to examine closely but was always denied.

This precious plate is now placed on Jane's knee, and she is kindly invited to eat the pastry, but the favor, like many long-deferred wishes, arrives too late; Jane finds herself unable to eat the tart.
The once-vibrant plumage of the bird and the colors of the flowers on the plate seem strangely faded to her, and she puts both the plate and tart aside.

Bessie then asks if Jane would like a book, and the word 'book' provides a momentary stimulus, prompting Jane to request 'Gulliver's Travels' from the library, a book she had previously cherished and read repeatedly with delight.

Jane had considered Swift's narrative as factual, finding in it a deeper interest than fairy tales, and had genuinely believed in the existence of Lilliput and Brobdingnag, hoping one day to visit them.

However, when the cherished volume is placed in her hands, its familiar pictures and narrative, which had always charmed her, now appear eerie and dreary; the giants seem like gaunt goblins, the pigmies malevolent imps, and Gulliver a desolate wanderer in dreadful regions.
Unable to derive any comfort or pleasure, Jane closes the book and places it on the table next to the uneaten tart, a testament to her profound anhedonia.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Bessie had been down into the kitchen, and she brought up with her a tart on a certain brightly painted china plate, whose bird of paradise, nestling in a wreath of convolvuli and rosebuds, had been wont to stir in me a most enthusiastic sense of admiration; and which plate I had often petitioned to be allowed to take in my hand in order to examine it more closely, but had always hitherto been deemed unworthy of such a privilege.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I closed the book, which I dared no longer peruse, and put it on the table, beside the untasted tart.

events.text_segment: Bessie had been down into the kitchen, and she brought up with her a tart on a certain brightly painted china plate, whose bird of paradise, nestling in a wreath of convolvuli and rosebuds, had been wont to stir in me a most enthusiastic sense of admiration; and which plate I had often petitioned to be allowed to take in my hand in order to examine it more closely, but had always hitherto been deemed unworthy of such a privilege. This precious vessel was now placed on my knee, and I was cordially invited to eat the circlet of delicate pastry upon it. Vain favour! coming, like most other favours long deferred and often wished for, too late! I could not eat the tart; and the plumage of the bird, the tints of the flowers, seemed strangely faded: I put both plate and tart away. Bessie asked if I would have a book: the word book acted as a transient stimulus, and I begged her to fetch Gulliver’s Travels from the library. This book I had again and again perused with delight. I considered it a narrative of facts, and discovered in it a vein of interest deeper than what I found in fairy tales: for as to the elves, having sought them in vain among foxglove leaves and bells, under mushrooms and beneath the ground-ivy mantling old wall-nooks, I had at length made up my mind to the sad truth, that they were all gone out of England to some savage country where the woods were wilder and thicker, and the population more scant; whereas, Lilliput and Brobdignag being, in my creed, solid parts of the earth’s surface, I doubted not that I might one day, by taking a long voyage, see with my own eyes the little fields, houses, and trees, the diminutive people, the tiny cows, sheep, and birds of the one realm; and the corn-fields forest-high, the mighty mastiffs, the monster cats, the tower-like men and women, of the other. Yet, when this cherished volume was now placed in my hand—when I turned over its leaves, and sought in its marvellous pictures the charm I had, till now, never failed to find—all was eerie and dreary; the giants were gaunt goblins, the pigmies malevolent and fearful imps, Gulliver a most desolate wanderer in most dread and dangerous regions. I closed the book, which I dared no longer peruse, and put it on the table, beside the untasted tart.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Bessie had gone down to the kitchen and returned carrying a tart on a particularly bright china plate. This plate featured a bird of paradise nestled among morning glories and rosebuds, a design that used to inspire great admiration in me. I had often asked if I could hold the plate myself to look at it closely, but until now, I had never been thought worthy of such a privilege. This treasured plate was now placed on my lap, and I was kindly told to eat the small, tender pastry on it. What an empty gesture! Like many long-delayed and much-desired favors, it arrived too late! I couldn't bring myself to eat the tart; even the bird's feathers and the flowers' colors seemed strangely dull. I pushed both the plate and the tart away. Bessie asked if I wanted a book; the word 'book' stirred a brief flicker of interest, and I asked her to get 'Gulliver's Travels' from the library. I had read this book many times before with great enjoyment. I saw it as a factual account and found it more profoundly interesting than fairy tales. This was because, after searching for elves in vain among foxgloves, under mushrooms, and in ivy-covered old walls, I had sadly concluded that they had all left England for some wilder, thicker-forested, and less populated land. In contrast, I truly believed Lilliput and Brobdingnag were real places on Earth and was sure that one day, after a long journey, I could personally see the tiny fields, houses, trees, people, cows, sheep, and birds of Lilliput, and the giant cornfields, huge dogs, enormous cats, and towering men and women of Brobdingnag. However, when this favorite book was now put into my hands—when I turned its pages and looked at its wonderful illustrations hoping to find the magic I had always found before—everything felt unsettling and miserable. The giants appeared as gaunt monsters, the little people seemed spiteful and terrifying demons, and Gulliver was simply a lonely wanderer in truly frightening and dangerous places. I closed the book, unable to read it further, and set it on the table next to the tart I had not eaten.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Bessie had been to the kitchen and returned with a tart on a brightly decorated china plate, which featured a beautiful bird surrounded by flowers. I had always admired this plate and often asked to hold it and look at it more closely, but had never been allowed to do so until now. The cherished plate was set on my lap, and I was warmly encouraged to eat the delicate pastry. Yet this kindness, long anticipated but now finally granted, was wasted, for it arrived too late—I had no appetite for the tart, and the colors on the plate’s bird and flowers seemed dull and lifeless to me. Disheartened, I set both the plate and the tart aside. Bessie then offered to bring me a book, and hearing the word "book" briefly lifted my spirits. I asked her to fetch 'Gulliver’s Travels,' a favorite of mine, which I always read with eagerness, believing its stories to be true facts. It fascinated me more deeply than fairy tales, since I had searched in vain for elves in gardens and woods, and sadly concluded that they must have left England altogether. However, I was convinced that Lilliput and Brobdingnag were actual places I might visit one day and see their wonders for myself. Yet now, when Bessie placed the beloved book in my hands and I looked at its familiar pictures, I no longer found their old enchantment; the giants appeared as frightening monsters, the little people as threatening creatures, and Gulliver as a lonely figure in ominous places. I set aside the book, unwilling to read further, and put it on the table next to the untouched tart.

events.title: Bessie's Melancholy Songs Reflect Jane's Inner State
detailed_summary: After finishing her tidying, Bessie opens a drawer filled with silk and satin scraps and begins making a new bonnet for Georgiana's doll, all while singing.
She first sings "In the days when we went gipsying," a song Jane had previously enjoyed with lively delight due to Bessie's sweet voice.

Now, however, though Bessie's voice remains sweet, Jane finds an indescribable sadness in its melody; the refrain "A long time ago," when sung softly and lingeringly, sounds like the saddest part of a funeral hymn.

Bessie then transitions to another ballad, this one overtly doleful, detailing the plight of a poor orphan child facing a long, weary journey through wild mountains, under a moonless, dreary twilight.

The song's lyrics speak of being sent far and lonely, of hard-hearted men, but also of kind angels watching over, and God's mercy providing protection, comfort, and hope, promising a heavenly home even if the child falls or is misguided.
The song concludes with the affirmation that God is a friend to the poor orphan child.
As Bessie finishes singing, she tells Jane not to cry, a comment that Jane feels demonstrates a complete lack of understanding of the depth of her morbid suffering.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Bessie had now finished dusting and tidying the room, and having washed her hands, she opened a certain little drawer, full of splendid shreds of silk and satin, and began making a new bonnet for Georgiana’s doll.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Come, Miss Jane, don’t cry,” said Bessie as she finished.

events.text_segment:
Bessie had now finished dusting and tidying the room, and having washed her hands, she opened a certain little drawer, full of splendid shreds of silk and satin, and began making a new bonnet for Georgiana’s doll. Meantime she sang: her song was—
“In the days when we went gipsying,
    A long time ago.”
I had often heard the song before, and always with lively delight; for Bessie had a sweet voice,—at least, I thought so. But now, though her voice was still sweet, I found in its melody an indescribable sadness. Sometimes, preoccupied with her work, she sang the refrain very low, very lingeringly; “A long time ago” came out like the saddest cadence of a funeral hymn. She passed into another ballad, this time a really doleful one.
“My feet they are sore, and my limbs they are weary;
    Long is the way, and the mountains are wild;
Soon will the twilight close moonless and dreary
    Over the path of the poor orphan child.

Why did they send me so far and so lonely,
    Up where the moors spread and grey rocks are piled?
Men are hard-hearted, and kind angels only
    Watch o’er the steps of a poor orphan child.

Yet distant and soft the night breeze is blowing,
    Clouds there are none, and clear stars beam mild,
God, in His mercy, protection is showing,
    Comfort and hope to the poor orphan child.

Ev’n should I fall o’er the broken bridge passing,
    Or stray in the marshes, by false lights beguiled,
Still will my Father, with promise and blessing,
    Take to His bosom the poor orphan child.

There is a thought that for strength should avail me,
    Though both of shelter and kindred despoiled;
Heaven is a home, and a rest will not fail me;
    God is a friend to the poor orphan child.”
“Come, Miss Jane, don’t cry,” said Bessie as she finished.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
After finishing cleaning and organizing the room and washing her hands, Bessie retrieved some vibrant scraps of silk and satin from a small drawer and began crafting a new bonnet for Georgiana's doll. As she worked, she sang the song, 'In the days when we went gipsying, A long time ago.' I had heard this song many times before and always found it quite enjoyable because Bessie had a pleasant voice, or at least, I believed she did. However, on this occasion, despite her voice remaining sweet, I detected an undefinable sorrow in the tune. At times, engrossed in her task, she would sing the concluding part, 'A long time ago,' softly and slowly, making it sound as mournful as a funeral dirge. She then transitioned to another ballad, this one genuinely sorrowful.
'My feet are aching, and my limbs feel tired;
 The path is long, and the mountains are wild;
 Soon the moonless, gloomy twilight will fall
 Over the way of the poor orphan child.

 Why was I sent so far away and alone,
 Up where the moors extend and grey rocks are stacked?
 People are cruel, and only kind angels
 Watch over the steps of a poor orphan child.

 Yet the night breeze blows gently and distantly,
 There are no clouds, and the bright stars shine softly,
 God, in His mercy, is offering protection,
 Comfort and hope to the poor orphan child.

 Even if I stumble crossing the broken bridge,
 Or get lost in the marshes, led astray by false lights,
 Still, my Father, with promise and blessing,
 Will welcome the poor orphan child into His embrace.

 There is a thought that should give me strength,
 Even though I am stripped of shelter and family;
 Heaven is a home, and a resting place awaits me;
 God is a friend to the poor orphan child.'
When she finished, Bessie said, 'Now, Miss Jane, don't cry.'

She then moved on to another, even sadder song: “My feet they are sore, and my limbs they are weary...,” which told of a tired and lonely orphan child wandering in the wild, comforted only by angels and the hope of God’s care.
