Are you fond of it?” “I like Revelations, and the book of Daniel, and Genesis and Samuel, and a little bit of Exodus, and some parts of Kings and Chronicles, and Job and Jonah.” “And the Psalms? I hope you like those?” “No, sir.” “No? oh, appalling! I have a little boy, younger than you, who knows six Psalms by heart: and when you ask him which he would rather have, a gingerbread-nut to eat or a verse of a Psalm to learn, he says: ‘Oh! the verse of a Psalm! angels sing Psalms;’ he says, ‘I wish to be a little angel here below;’ he then receives two nuts as compensation for his young piety.” “Psalms are not interesting,” I commented. “That proves you have a wicked heart; and you must pray to God to change it: to give you a new and pure one: to remove your heart of stone and give you a heart of flesh.” I was about to propose a question concerning the method by which that operation of changing my heart was to be carried out, when Mrs. Reed intervened, telling me to sit down; she then proceeded to conduct the conversation herself.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I walked down the stairs slowly. For almost three months, no one had summoned me to see Mrs. Reed; having been kept in the nursery for so long, the breakfast room, dining room, and drawing room felt like intimidating places to me, and I was afraid to enter them. I found myself alone in the hall, facing the door to the breakfast room, and I paused, feeling nervous and shaking. Fear, caused by unfair punishment, had made me weak and cowardly in those days! I was too scared to go back to the nursery and just as scared to go into the parlor; for about ten minutes I stood there, anxiously hesitant. Then, the loud ringing of the breakfast-room bell forced me to act—I had to go in.

I wondered to myself, as I struggled to turn the stiff doorknob, “Who wants to see me? Will I find only Aunt Reed inside, or someone else—perhaps a man or a woman?” Eventually, the handle turned, and I opened the door. As I curtsied low and looked up, I saw what looked at first like a black pillar – it was in fact a tall, thin person dressed in black, standing upright like a column; his stern face resembled a carved statue head placed atop a column. Mrs. Reed was sitting by the fire as usual, and she motioned for me to come closer. She introduced me to the severe-looking stranger, saying, “This is the little girl I asked you about.”

The man slowly turned his head towards me and studied me with sharp-looking grey eyes under bushy brows. In a deep voice, he solemnly said, “She’s small—how old is she?”

“Ten.”

“So old?” he asked doubtfully, still examining me closely. After some moments, he asked, “What’s your name, little girl?”

“Jane Eyre, sir,” I replied. Looking up, I thought he seemed very tall, though perhaps that was just because I was so little. His features were large and his whole appearance was severe and strict.

“Well, Jane Eyre, are you a good child?”

There was no way I could answer yes—everyone in my world thought the opposite—so I stayed silent. Mrs. Reed responded with a meaningful shake of her head, adding, “The less we say about that, the better, Mr. Brocklehurst.”

“That's unfortunate! She and I must talk,” he said, and then sat himself in the armchair opposite Mrs. Reed. “Come here,” he ordered.

I crossed the rug, and he positioned me right in front of him. From this close, his face looked even more striking – a very large nose, a wide mouth, and big, prominent teeth.

“No sight is sadder than a naughty child,” he began, “especially a naughty little girl. Do you know where wicked people go when they die?”

“They go to hell,” I replied promptly, giving the answer expected of me.

“And what is hell? Can you explain?”

“A pit full of fire.”

“And would you like to fall into that pit, and burn there forever?”

“No, sir.”

“What must you do to avoid going there?”

I thought for a moment, and then—though I knew it was the wrong answer—replied, “I must stay healthy, and not die.”

“How can you be sure to stay healthy? Younger children die every day. Just a day or two ago I buried a five-year-old child—a good child whose soul is now in heaven. I fear the same could not be said of you if you were to die now.”

Since I couldn’t convince him otherwise, I only looked down at his big feet on the rug and sighed, wishing I could be far away.

“I hope that sigh comes from your heart, and that you regret causing trouble to your kind benefactress.”

“Benefactress! Benefactress!” I repeated to myself, “They all call Mrs. Reed my benefactress; if that’s what a benefactress is, it is not a pleasant thing.”

“Do you say your prayers in the morning and at night?” he continued.

“Yes, sir.”

“Do you read your Bible?”

“Sometimes.”

“Do you enjoy it? Do you like reading it?”

“I like Revelation, Daniel, Genesis, Samuel, and a little of Exodus, and some of Kings and Chronicles, as well as Job and Jonah.”

“And what about the Psalms? I hope you enjoy reading those?”

“No, sir.”

“No? How shocking! I have a little boy, younger than you, who knows six Psalms by heart; when asked if he’d prefer a gingerbread nut or a verse of a Psalm, he always chooses the Psalm. He says, ‘Angels sing Psalms; I want to be a little angel here on earth.’ As a reward for his piety he actually gets two nuts.”

“I don’t find Psalms interesting,” I replied.

“That shows you have a wicked heart, and you must pray to God to change it—ask him to give you a new, clean one; to replace your hard heart with one of flesh.”

I was about to ask how this change of heart was supposed to happen, but Mrs. Reed interrupted, telling me to sit down. She then took over the conversation herself.

events.title: Mrs. Reed's Accusations and Lowood's Grim Prospect
detailed_summary: Mrs. Reed addresses Mr. Brocklehurst, referencing her earlier letter and stating that Jane does not possess the character she would wish for.

She requests that if Jane is admitted to Lowood school, the superintendent and teachers be instructed to keep a strict watch on her, especially to guard against her primary fault: a tendency towards deceit.
Mrs. Reed explicitly states this in Jane's hearing, warning her not to attempt to mislead Mr. Brocklehurst.

Jane is profoundly hurt by this public accusation, recognizing it as characteristic of Mrs. Reed's inherent cruelty towards her; she feels that Mrs. Reed is deliberately sabotaging her prospects in this new environment by creating an unfavorable impression.
Jane perceives herself being unjustly transformed into an artful and noxious child in Mr. Brocklehurst's eyes, feeling powerless to counter the damage.

Mr. Brocklehurst concurs that deceit is a grave fault in a child, equating it with falsehood and warning of eternal punishment, and assures Mrs. Reed that Jane will be carefully monitored at Lowood by Miss Temple and the teachers.
Mrs. Reed further expresses her desire for Jane to be educated in a manner befitting her dependent status, emphasizing that she should be made useful and kept humble.
She also stipulates that Jane should spend her vacations at Lowood, with Mr. Brocklehurst's permission.
Mr. Brocklehurst commends Mrs. Reed's decisions as judicious, highlighting humility as a key Christian virtue fostered at Lowood.

He proudly recounts a recent incident where his daughter, Augusta, after visiting the school, commented on how quiet, plain, and almost like poor children the Lowood girls appeared, with their simple hairstyles and attire, as evidence of his success in curbing worldly pride.
Mrs. Reed expresses her complete approval of this harsh regime, stating it is precisely the system she sought for a child like Jane and emphasizing her belief in consistency.
Mr. Brocklehurst affirms that consistency in plain living—simple food, attire, accommodations, and hardy habits—is the guiding principle at Lowood.
Mrs. Reed seeks final assurance that Jane will be accepted as a pupil and trained according to her position and prospects.
Mr. Brocklehurst confirms Jane's admission, likening Lowood to a 'nursery of chosen plants' and hoping Jane will prove grateful for this 'inestimable privilege.'
Mrs. Reed declares her intention to send Jane as soon as possible, expressing her eagerness to be relieved of a responsibility she found increasingly burdensome.
Mr. Brocklehurst acknowledges this and bids good morning, explaining he will return to his home in a week or two and will notify Miss Temple to expect a new pupil.

Before departing, Mr. Brocklehurst hands Jane a thin pamphlet titled the 'Child’s Guide,' specifically directing her to read a section about 'the awfully sudden death of Martha G——, a naughty child addicted to falsehood and deceit.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Mr. Brocklehurst, I believe I intimated in the letter which I wrote to you three weeks ago, that this little girl has not quite the character and disposition I could wish: should you admit her into Lowood school, I should be glad if the superintendent and teachers were requested to keep a strict eye on her, and, above all, to guard against her worst fault, a tendency to deceit.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With these words Mr. Brocklehurst put into my hand a thin pamphlet sewn in a cover, and having rung for his carriage, he departed.

events.text_segment:
“Mr. Brocklehurst, I believe I intimated in the letter which I wrote to you three weeks ago, that this little girl has not quite the character and disposition I could wish: should you admit her into Lowood school, I should be glad if the superintendent and teachers were requested to keep a strict eye on her, and, above all, to guard against her worst fault, a tendency to deceit. I mention this in your hearing, Jane, that you may not attempt to impose on Mr. Brocklehurst.”
Well might I dread, well might I dislike Mrs. Reed; for it was her nature to wound me cruelly; never was I happy in her presence; however carefully I obeyed, however strenuously I strove to please her, my efforts were still repulsed and repaid by such sentences as the above. Now, uttered before a stranger, the accusation cut me to the heart; I dimly perceived that she was already obliterating hope from the new phase of existence which she destined me to enter; I felt, though I could not have expressed the feeling, that she was sowing aversion and unkindness along my future path; I saw myself transformed under Mr. Brocklehurst’s eye into an artful, noxious child, and what could I do to remedy the injury?
“Nothing, indeed,” thought I, as I struggled to repress a sob, and hastily wiped away some tears, the impotent evidences of my anguish.
“Deceit is, indeed, a sad fault in a child,” said Mr. Brocklehurst; “it is akin to falsehood, and all liars will have their portion in the lake burning with fire and brimstone; she shall, however, be watched, Mrs. Reed. I will speak to Miss Temple and the teachers.”
“I should wish her to be brought up in a manner suiting her prospects,” continued my benefactress; “to be made useful, to be kept humble: as for the vacations, she will, with your permission, spend them always at Lowood.”
“Your decisions are perfectly judicious, madam,” returned Mr. Brocklehurst. “Humility is a Christian grace, and one peculiarly appropriate to the pupils of Lowood; I, therefore, direct that especial care shall be bestowed on its cultivation amongst them. I have studied how best to mortify in them the worldly sentiment of pride; and, only the other day, I had a pleasing proof of my success. My second daughter, Augusta, went with her mama to visit the school, and on her return she exclaimed: ‘Oh, dear papa, how quiet and plain all the girls at Lowood look, with their hair combed behind their ears, and their long pinafores, and those little holland pockets outside their frocks—they are almost like poor people’s children! and,’ said she, ‘they looked at my dress and mama’s, as if they had never seen a silk gown before.’”
“This is the state of things I quite approve,” returned Mrs. Reed; “had I sought all England over, I could scarcely have found a system more exactly fitting a child like Jane Eyre. Consistency, my dear Mr. Brocklehurst; I advocate consistency in all things.”
“Consistency, madam, is the first of Christian duties; and it has been observed in every arrangement connected with the establishment of Lowood: plain fare, simple attire, unsophisticated accommodations, hardy and active habits; such is the order of the day in the house and its inhabitants.”
“Quite right, sir. I may then depend upon this child being received as a pupil at Lowood, and there being trained in conformity to her position and prospects?”
“Madam, you may: she shall be placed in that nursery of chosen plants, and I trust she will show herself grateful for the inestimable privilege of her election.”
“I will send her, then, as soon as possible, Mr. Brocklehurst; for, I assure you, I feel anxious to be relieved of a responsibility that was becoming too irksome.”
“No doubt, no doubt, madam; and now I wish you good morning. I shall return to Brocklehurst Hall in the course of a week or two: my good friend, the Archdeacon, will not permit me to leave him sooner. I shall send Miss Temple notice that she is to expect a new girl, so that there will be no difficulty about receiving her. Good-bye.”
“Good-bye, Mr. Brocklehurst; remember me to Mrs. and Miss Brocklehurst, and to Augusta and Theodore, and Master Broughton Brocklehurst.”
“I will, madam. Little girl, here is a book entitled the ‘Child’s Guide’; read it with prayer, especially that part containing ‘An account of the awfully sudden death of Martha G——, a naughty child addicted to falsehood and deceit.’”
With these words Mr. Brocklehurst put into my hand a thin pamphlet sewn in a cover, and having rung for his carriage, he departed.

Humility is a Christian virtue, and one especially suitable for the students at Lowood. Therefore, I instruct that particular attention be paid to cultivating it among them. I have considered the best ways to suppress worldly pride in them, and just recently, I had a pleasing demonstration of my success. My second daughter, Augusta, visited the school with her mother, and upon returning, she exclaimed: ‘Oh, dear papa, how calm and plain all the girls at Lowood appear, with their hair neatly combed behind their ears, their long aprons, and those small cotton pockets on the outside of their dresses—they look almost like poor people’s children! And,’ she added, ‘they stared at my dress and mama’s as if they had never seen a silk gown before.' Mrs. Reed responded, 'This is exactly the situation I approve of. Had I searched throughout England, I could hardly have found a system more precisely suited to a child like Jane Eyre. Consistency, my dear Mr. Brocklehurst; I believe in consistency in all matters.' 'Consistency, madam,' Mr. Brocklehurst agreed, 'is the most important Christian duty, and it has been observed in every arrangement related to the founding of Lowood: simple meals, plain clothing, basic living conditions, and active, hardy habits. This is the standard practice for the institution and its residents.' 'Quite right, sir. May I then be sure that this child will be accepted as a student at Lowood and educated according to her status and expectations?' 'Madam, you may rest assured: she will be placed in that breeding ground for selected individuals, and I trust she will be thankful for the immense privilege of being chosen.' 'Then I will send her as soon as possible, Mr. Brocklehurst; for, I must tell you, I am eager to be relieved of a responsibility that had become too burdensome.' 'Undoubtedly, undoubtedly, madam; and now I wish you good morning. I will return to Brocklehurst Hall within a week or two; my good friend, the Archdeacon, won't allow me to depart sooner. I will send word to Miss Temple that she should expect a new girl, so there will be no trouble with her admission. Good-bye.' 'Good-bye, Mr. Brocklehurst; please give my regards to Mrs. and Miss Brocklehurst, and to Augusta and Theodore, and Master Broughton Brocklehurst.' 'I will, madam. Little girl,' he said to me, 'here is a book titled the ‘Child’s Guide’; read it diligently, especially the section containing ‘An account of the terribly sudden death of Martha G——, a disobedient child prone to lying and deceit.’' With these words, Mr. Brocklehurst placed a thin stitched pamphlet into my hand, and after ringing for his carriage, he departed.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Mrs. Reed addressed Mr. Brocklehurst, reminding him of her letter from three weeks prior, in which she mentioned that Jane's character and disposition did not meet her expectations. She requested that if Jane were admitted to Lowood School, the staff should watch her closely, especially to prevent her from acting deceitfully, which she referred to as Jane's greatest flaw. Mrs. Reed spoke this in Jane's presence to discourage Jane from trying to deceive Mr. Brocklehurst. Jane felt justified in fearing and disliking Mrs. Reed, since she always seemed intent on hurting her; nothing Jane did ever pleased her, and her efforts were consistently met with such harsh words. Hearing this accusation directed at her in front of a stranger was especially painful to Jane. She sensed that Mrs. Reed was destroying any hope she might have for this new chapter in her life and was paving the way for others to treat her unkindly. Jane imagined that, in Mr. Brocklehurst's eyes, she was becoming a crafty and troublesome child, and she wondered what she could do to fix this injustice—but realized there was nothing she could do, as she tried to stifle her tears.

Mr. Brocklehurst then remarked that deceit is a serious vice in a child, as it is close to lying, which is condemned in the Bible. He reassured Mrs. Reed that Jane would be watched, promising to instruct Miss Temple and the teachers accordingly. Mrs. Reed went on to express her wish for Jane to be raised in a way fitting her future, kept useful and humble, and for her to remain at Lowood during holidays. Mr. Brocklehurst agreed with Mrs. Reed, saying her decisions were wise and that humility was especially important for Lowood’s pupils. He shared a story about his own daughter, Augusta, who visited Lowood and remarked how plainly the girls dressed, noting they looked almost like poor children. Mrs. Reed approved of such an environment, insisting that consistency is important. Mr. Brocklehurst replied that consistency is a key Christian virtue, and explained that everything at Lowood—from the simple food and plain dress, to the basic accommodations and active lifestyle—reflected this principle.

Mrs. Reed confirmed that Jane would be accepted at Lowood and trained according to her background and needs, to which Mr. Brocklehurst agreed and expressed the hope that Jane would appreciate the opportunity. Mrs. Reed said she would send Jane to Lowood as soon as possible, relieved to relinquish the responsibility. Mr. Brocklehurst bid farewell, mentioning he would soon return to Brocklehurst Hall, and that he would inform Miss Temple to expect Jane. As he left, he handed Jane a book titled 'Child's Guide,' advising her to read, especially the section about a girl who died suddenly because of her dishonesty, and then departed after calling his carriage.

events.title: Jane's Passionate Confrontation and Mrs. Reed's Defeat
detailed_summary: After Mr. Brocklehurst leaves, Jane and Mrs. Reed are alone in silence for several minutes, Jane watching Mrs. Reed sew.

Jane provides a detailed description of Mrs. Reed's physical appearance: a robust woman in her mid-thirties, square-shouldered, strong-limbed, with a somewhat large face, developed jaw, low brow, prominent chin, regular mouth and nose, ruthless eyes under light brows, dark skin, and nearly flaxen hair. She is noted as being an exact, clever manager, with a strong constitution, well-dressed, and possessing a commanding presence.
Jane, holding the tract about the lying child, reflects on the recent conversation and Mrs. Reed's damning words, feeling each one acutely and a surge of resentment building within her.
Mrs. Reed looks up, her eyes meeting Jane's, and with suppressed irritation, orders her out of the room and back to the nursery.
Jane gets up, goes to the door, but then turns back, crosses the room, and walks directly up to Mrs. Reed, feeling an irresistible compulsion to speak.

She declares forcefully that she is not deceitful, stating that if she were, she would feign affection for Mrs. Reed. Instead, she proclaims her intense dislike for Mrs. Reed, surpassed only by her dislike for John Reed, and suggests the pamphlet about the liar is more suited for Georgiana, whom Jane accuses of being the one who tells lies.
Mrs. Reed's hands remain still on her work, her icy gaze fixed on Jane, as she asks, in a tone more suited to an adult adversary than a child, if Jane has more to say.
Provoked by Mrs. Reed's coldness, Jane, trembling with ungovernable excitement, continues her tirade.

She expresses her gladness at not being related to Mrs. Reed, vows never to call her 'aunt' again, never to visit her as an adult, and to tell anyone who asks that the mere thought of Mrs. Reed makes her sick and that she was treated with miserable cruelty.
When Mrs. Reed demands how Jane dares to say such things, Jane retorts that she dares because it is the truth.
She accuses Mrs. Reed of believing her to be without feelings and capable of surviving without love or kindness, which Jane insists she cannot, and calls Mrs. Reed pitiless.

Jane passionately recounts the traumatic incident of being locked in the red-room, a punishment for John Reed's unprovoked assault, and vows to tell this exact story to anyone who inquires. She concludes by calling Mrs. Reed a bad, hard-hearted, deceitful woman.
As she finishes, Jane experiences an extraordinary sense of freedom and triumph, as if an invisible restraint has shattered.
Mrs. Reed appears frightened by Jane's outburst; her work slips from her knee, she lifts her hands, rocks back and forth, and her face contorts as if she might cry.
Mrs. Reed attempts to placate Jane, asking what is wrong, why she is trembling so, and if she would like some water.
Jane curtly refuses.
Mrs. Reed then asks if there is anything else Jane wishes for, assuring her of a desire to be her friend.
Jane rejects this, reminding Mrs. Reed of the negative character assessment given to Mr. Brocklehurst and threatening to inform everyone at Lowood about Mrs. Reed's true nature and actions.
Mrs. Reed tries to dismiss Jane's understanding, claiming children must be corrected for their faults.
Jane cries out fiercely that deceit is not her fault.
Mrs. Reed concedes Jane is passionate and urges her to return to the nursery and lie down, calling her 'dear'.
Jane rejects the endearment, states she cannot lie down, and demands to be sent to school soon, as she hates living at Gateshead.
Mrs. Reed murmurs quietly to herself that she will indeed send Jane to school soon, then gathers her work and abruptly leaves the room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Reed and I were left alone: some minutes passed in silence; she was sewing, I was watching her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I will indeed send her to school soon,” murmured Mrs. Reed sotto voce; and gathering up her work, she abruptly quitted the apartment.

events.text_segment:
Mrs. Reed and I were left alone: some minutes passed in silence; she was sewing, I was watching her. Mrs. Reed might be at that time some six or seven and thirty; she was a woman of robust frame, square-shouldered and strong-limbed, not tall, and, though stout, not obese: she had a somewhat large face, the under jaw being much developed and very solid; her brow was low, her chin large and prominent, mouth and nose sufficiently regular; under her light eyebrows glimmered an eye devoid of ruth; her skin was dark and opaque, her hair nearly flaxen; her constitution was sound as a bell—illness never came near her; she was an exact, clever manager; her household and tenantry were thoroughly under her control; her children only at times defied her authority and laughed it to scorn; she dressed well, and had a presence and port calculated to set off handsome attire.
Sitting on a low stool, a few yards from her arm-chair, I examined her figure; I perused her features. In my hand I held the tract containing the sudden death of the Liar, to which narrative my attention had been pointed as to an appropriate warning. What had just passed; what Mrs. Reed had said concerning me to Mr. Brocklehurst; the whole tenor of their conversation, was recent, raw, and stinging in my mind; I had felt every word as acutely as I had heard it plainly, and a passion of resentment fomented now within me.
Mrs. Reed looked up from her work; her eye settled on mine, her fingers at the same time suspended their nimble movements.
“Go out of the room; return to the nursery,” was her mandate. My look or something else must have struck her as offensive, for she spoke with extreme though suppressed irritation. I got up, I went to the door; I came back again; I walked to the window, across the room, then close up to her.
Speak I must: I had been trodden on severely, and must turn: but how? What strength had I to dart retaliation at my antagonist? I gathered my energies and launched them in this blunt sentence—
“I am not deceitful: if I were, I should say I loved you; but I declare I do not love you: I dislike you the worst of anybody in the world except John Reed; and this book about the liar, you may give to your girl, Georgiana, for it is she who tells lies, and not I.”
Mrs. Reed’s hands still lay on her work inactive: her eye of ice continued to dwell freezingly on mine.
“What more have you to say?” she asked, rather in the tone in which a person might address an opponent of adult age than such as is ordinarily used to a child.
That eye of hers, that voice stirred every antipathy I had. Shaking from head to foot, thrilled with ungovernable excitement, I continued—
“I am glad you are no relation of mine: I will never call you aunt again as long as I live. I will never come to see you when I am grown up; and if any one asks me how I liked you, and how you treated me, I will say the very thought of you makes me sick, and that you treated me with miserable cruelty.”
“How dare you affirm that, Jane Eyre?”
“How dare I, Mrs. Reed? How dare I? Because it is the truth. You think I have no feelings, and that I can do without one bit of love or kindness; but I cannot live so: and you have no pity. I shall remember how you thrust me back—roughly and violently thrust me back—into the red-room, and locked me up there, to my dying day; though I was in agony; though I cried out, while suffocating with distress, ‘Have mercy! Have mercy, Aunt Reed!’ And that punishment you made me suffer because your wicked boy struck me—knocked me down for nothing. I will tell anybody who asks me questions, this exact tale. People think you a good woman, but you are bad, hard-hearted. You are deceitful!”
Ere I had finished this reply, my soul began to expand, to exult, with the strangest sense of freedom, of triumph, I ever felt. It seemed as if an invisible bond had burst, and that I had struggled out into unhoped-for liberty. Not without cause was this sentiment: Mrs. Reed looked frightened; her work had slipped from her knee; she was lifting up her hands, rocking herself to and fro, and even twisting her face as if she would cry.
“Jane, you are under a mistake: what is the matter with you? Why do you tremble so violently? Would you like to drink some water?”
“No, Mrs. Reed.”
“Is there anything else you wish for, Jane? I assure you, I desire to be your friend.”
“Not you. You told Mr. Brocklehurst I had a bad character, a deceitful disposition; and I’ll let everybody at Lowood know what you are, and what you have done.”
“Jane, you don’t understand these things: children must be corrected for their faults.”
“Deceit is not my fault!” I cried out in a savage, high voice.
“But you are passionate, Jane, that you must allow: and now return to the nursery—there’s a dear—and lie down a little.”
“I am not your dear; I cannot lie down: send me to school soon, Mrs. Reed, for I hate to live here.”
“I will indeed send her to school soon,” murmured Mrs. Reed sotto voce; and gathering up her work, she abruptly quitted the apartment.

Mrs. Reed was likely around thirty-six or thirty-seven years old at this time. She possessed a sturdy build, with broad shoulders and strong limbs; she wasn't tall but was plump without being excessively large. Her face was rather substantial, featuring a very pronounced and solid lower jaw, a low forehead, a large and jutting chin, and a relatively standard mouth and nose. Beneath her light-colored eyebrows, her eyes held no trace of pity. Her skin was dark and lacked transparency, and her hair was nearly flaxen. Her health was perfectly robust—she was never ill. She was an efficient and shrewd manager, maintaining complete command over her household and tenants; only her children occasionally defied her authority and mocked it. She dressed elegantly and had a bearing and posture that enhanced attractive clothing. Sitting on a low stool a short distance from her armchair, I studied her appearance and examined her features. In my hand, I held the booklet describing the sudden death of a Liar, a story that had been presented to me as a suitable warning. The recent events, what Mrs. Reed had just said about me to Mr. Brocklehurst, and the entire exchange between them were fresh, raw, and painful in my mind. I had felt every word as intensely as I had clearly heard it, and a surge of anger was now building within me. Mrs. Reed glanced up from her work; her gaze settled on mine, and her fingers stopped their quick movements simultaneously. "Leave the room; go back to the nursery," she instructed. My look, or something else about me, must have seemed offensive to her, as she spoke with intense, though controlled, irritation. I stood up and walked towards the door; then I returned, moved to the window, crossed the room, and finally approached her closely. I felt compelled to speak; I had been severely mistreated and needed to push back. But how? What power did I possess to strike back at her? I gathered my resolve and expressed it in this direct statement: "I am not deceitful. If I were, I would say I loved you; but I declare I do not love you. I dislike you more than anyone in the world except John Reed. And this book about the liar, you should give it to your daughter, Georgiana, because she is the one who tells lies, not me." Mrs. Reed's hands remained motionless on her work; her cold eye continued to stare icily at mine. "What else do you have to say?" she inquired, using a tone more suited to addressing an adult opponent than a child. That gaze, that voice, stirred every negative feeling I had. Shaking from head to foot, filled with uncontrollable emotion, I continued: "I am glad you are no relation of mine. I will never call you aunt again as long as I live. I will never come to see you when I am grown up. And if anyone asks me how I liked you, and how you treated me, I will say the very thought of you makes me sick, and that you treated me with miserable cruelty." "How dare you claim that, Jane Eyre?" "How dare I, Mrs. Reed? How dare I? Because it is the truth. You think I have no feelings, and that I can manage without any love or kindness at all; but I cannot live like that. And you have no pity. I will remember how you roughly and violently pushed me back into the red-room and locked me up there until my dying day, even though I was in agony, even though I cried out, suffocating with distress, 'Have mercy! Have mercy, Aunt Reed!' And that punishment you made me suffer because your wicked boy struck me—knocked me down for nothing. I will tell this precise story to anyone who asks me questions. People think you are a good woman, but you are bad, hard-hearted. You are the deceitful one!" Before I had finished this response, my spirit began to expand, to rejoice, with the most unusual sense of freedom and triumph I had ever experienced. It felt as though an unseen restraint had snapped, and I had struggled out into unexpected liberty. This feeling was not without reason: Mrs. Reed looked startled; her sewing had slid from her lap; she was raising her hands, rocking back and forth, and even contorting her face as if she might cry. "Jane, you are mistaken. What is wrong with you? Why are you trembling so violently? Would you like some water?" "No, Mrs. Reed." "Is there anything else you want, Jane? I assure you, I want to be your friend." "Not you. You told Mr. Brocklehurst I had a bad character, a deceitful nature; and I'll make sure everyone at Lowood knows what you are, and what you have done." "Jane, you don't understand these matters. Children must be corrected for their faults." "Deceit is not my fault!" I exclaimed in a fierce, high voice. "But you are passionate, Jane, you must admit that. Now, go back to the nursery—there's a dear—and lie down for a little while." "I am not your dear; I cannot lie down. Send me to school soon, Mrs. Reed, because I hate living here." "I will indeed send her to school soon," Mrs. Reed murmured quietly; and gathering up her work, she abruptly left the room.

Her face was broad, with a heavy, pronounced jaw, low forehead, and a strong chin. Her nose and mouth were ordinary, but her pale eyebrows framed cold, pitiless eyes; her skin was dark, her hair almost light blond, and she had a constitution that seemed immune to illness. She managed her household efficiently, controlling both staff and tenants, only her children occasionally defied her. She dressed stylishly and carried herself in a way that suited fine clothes. Sitting on a low stool close to her, I studied her appearance, the sharp features, and held in my hand a tract about the sudden death of a liar—meant as a warning for me. The recent conversation between Mrs. Reed and Mr. Brocklehurst still stung; I felt furious and wronged. Mrs. Reed paused her sewing to look at me, her gaze icy. "Leave the room; go back to the nursery," she commanded, her voice tight with anger, likely because she found my look insolent. I rose, went to the door, but then returned, moving restlessly, until I stood by her. I felt compelled to speak up—her treatment had pushed me too far. Mustering my courage, I said bluntly: "I am not deceitful. If I were, I would say I loved you, but I do not; I dislike you more than anyone, except John Reed. This story about the liar is more suited for your daughter Georgiana, for she lies, not me." Mrs. Reed did not respond, just gazed at me coldly, her hands still. I will always remember how you threw me into the red-room and locked me up, despite my suffering, because John attacked me for no reason. I shall tell everyone the truth. Mrs. Reed appeared frightened, her hands trembling, her face contorted as if she might cry. She asked what was wrong with me, why I trembled, whether I wanted some water, or if I wished for anything else, claiming she wanted to be my friend. I replied that I did not want her friendship and would tell everyone at Lowood about her cruelty and lies. She insisted children must be corrected, but I protested that deceit was not my flaw. She accused me of being passionate and told me to return to the nursery and rest. I answered that I was not her dear, couldn't rest, and wanted to go to school because I hated living there. Softly, Mrs. Reed agreed to send me to school soon, then hastily left the room with her sewing.

events.title: Victory's Bitter Aftertaste and Bessie's Comfort
detailed_summary: Jane is left alone, feeling like the victor of her recent confrontation.

She initially experiences a sense of elation, but this fierce pleasure quickly subsides, replaced by the pang of remorse and the chill of reaction that follow such an uncontrolled outburst against an elder.
She reflects on her state of mind, comparing her earlier fury to a blazing heath and her subsequent desolation to the same heath after the flames have died, now black and blasted.
Jane acknowledges tasting vengeance for the first time, finding it initially warm and racy like aromatic wine, but with a metallic, corroding aftertaste, as if poisoned.
She feels a fleeting impulse to seek Mrs. Reed's pardon but knows from experience and instinct that this would only lead to doubled scorn and re-ignite her own turbulent emotions.
Jane yearns to cultivate better faculties than fierce speech and to find nourishment for less fiendish feelings than somber indignation.
She attempts to read some Arabian tales but finds herself unable to concentrate, her thoughts dominated by the recent events.
She steps out into the shrubbery, finding the black frost unbroken by sun or breeze, but the silent trees and congealed relics of autumn offer no solace.
Leaning against a gate, looking into an empty, blanched field under an opaque, grey sky with occasional snowflakes, Jane feels wretched and repeatedly whispers, 'What shall I do?'
Suddenly, she hears Bessie's clear voice calling her for lunch.
Though recognizing Bessie's voice, Jane doesn't move until Bessie's light step approaches.
Bessie chides Jane for not coming when called, but her presence, even though somewhat cross as usual, seems cheerful to Jane compared to her brooding thoughts.
Having triumphed over Mrs. Reed, Jane feels less inclined to care about Bessie's transitory anger and more disposed to bask in her youthful lightheartedness.
Impulsively, Jane puts her arms around Bessie and asks her not to scold.
This unusually frank and fearless action pleases Bessie, who remarks on Jane being a 'strange child,' a 'little roving, solitary thing,' and asks if she is going to school.
Jane nods, and Bessie asks if she will be sorry to leave 'poor Bessie.'
Jane questions Bessie's care for her, noting her frequent scolding.

Bessie explains she scolds because Jane is 'such a queer, frightened, shy little thing' and advises her to be bolder, also acknowledging that Jane is 'rather put upon' and mentioning her own mother's sympathy for Jane's situation.

Bessie then shares good news: Mrs. Reed and the young ladies and Master John will be out for tea that afternoon, and Jane shall have tea with Bessie. Bessie will ask the cook to bake a little cake for Jane, and afterwards, Jane will help Bessie look over her drawers in preparation for packing her trunk, as Mrs. Reed intends for Jane to leave Gateshead in a day or two, and Jane can choose which toys to take.
Jane asks Bessie to promise not to scold her anymore until she leaves.
Bessie agrees, on the condition that Jane is very good and not afraid of her, particularly her occasional sharp tone.
Jane reflects that she will probably never be afraid of Bessie again, being used to her, and will soon have a new set of people to dread.
Bessie warns that if Jane dreads them, they will dislike her. Jane then asks if Bessie dislikes her.
Bessie confesses that she does not dislike Jane and, in fact, believes she is fonder of Jane than of the others.
Jane observes that Bessie doesn't often show this fondness. Bessie calls Jane a 'little sharp thing' and notes her new, venturesome way of talking.
Jane attributes her boldness to her impending departure and is about to mention her confrontation with Mrs. Reed but decides against it.
When Bessie asks if Jane is glad to leave her, Jane replies, 'Not at all, Bessie; indeed, just now I’m rather sorry.'
Bessie teases Jane about her cool manner and playfully challenges her for a kiss, which Jane willingly gives.
Comforted, Jane follows Bessie into the house. The afternoon passes in peace and harmony.
In the evening, Bessie tells Jane some of her most enchanting stories and sings some of her sweetest songs, bringing a rare moment of happiness into Jane's life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was left there alone—winner of the field.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Even for me life had its gleams of sunshine.

events.text_segment:
I was left there alone—winner of the field. It was the hardest battle I had fought, and the first victory I had gained: I stood awhile on the rug, where Mr. Brocklehurst had stood, and I enjoyed my conqueror’s solitude. First, I smiled to myself and felt elate; but this fierce pleasure subsided in me as fast as did the accelerated throb of my pulses. A child cannot quarrel with its elders, as I had done; cannot give its furious feelings uncontrolled play, as I had given mine, without experiencing afterwards the pang of remorse and the chill of reaction. A ridge of lighted heath, alive, glancing, devouring, would have been a meet emblem of my mind when I accused and menaced Mrs. Reed: the same ridge, black and blasted after the flames are dead, would have represented as meetly my subsequent condition, when half-an-hour’s silence and reflection had shown me the madness of my conduct, and the dreariness of my hated and hating position.
Something of vengeance I had tasted for the first time; as aromatic wine it seemed, on swallowing, warm and racy: its after-flavour, metallic and corroding, gave me a sensation as if I had been poisoned. Willingly would I now have gone and asked Mrs. Reed’s pardon; but I knew, partly from experience and partly from instinct, that was the way to make her repulse me with double scorn, thereby re-exciting every turbulent impulse of my nature.
I would fain exercise some better faculty than that of fierce speaking; fain find nourishment for some less fiendish feeling than that of sombre indignation. I took a book—some Arabian tales; I sat down and endeavoured to read. I could make no sense of the subject; my own thoughts swam always between me and the page I had usually found fascinating. I opened the glass-door in the breakfast-room: the shrubbery was quite still: the black frost reigned, unbroken by sun or breeze, through the grounds. I covered my head and arms with the skirt of my frock, and went out to walk in a part of the plantation which was quite sequestrated; but I found no pleasure in the silent trees, the falling fir-cones, the congealed relics of autumn, russet leaves, swept by past winds in heaps, and now stiffened together. I leaned against a gate, and looked into an empty field where no sheep were feeding, where the short grass was nipped and blanched. It was a very grey day; a most opaque sky, “onding on snaw,” canopied all; thence flakes fell at intervals, which settled on the hard path and on the hoary lea without melting. I stood, a wretched child enough, whispering to myself over and over again, “What shall I do?—what shall I do?”
All at once I heard a clear voice call, “Miss Jane! where are you? Come to lunch!”
It was Bessie, I knew well enough; but I did not stir; her light step came tripping down the path.
“You naughty little thing!” she said. “Why don’t you come when you are called?”
Bessie’s presence, compared with the thoughts over which I had been brooding, seemed cheerful; even though, as usual, she was somewhat cross. The fact is, after my conflict with and victory over Mrs. Reed, I was not disposed to care much for the nursemaid’s transitory anger; and I was disposed to bask in her youthful lightness of heart. I just put my two arms round her and said, “Come, Bessie! don’t scold.”
The action was more frank and fearless than any I was habituated to indulge in: somehow it pleased her.
“You are a strange child, Miss Jane,” she said, as she looked down at me; “a little roving, solitary thing: and you are going to school, I suppose?”
I nodded.
“And won’t you be sorry to leave poor Bessie?”
“What does Bessie care for me? She is always scolding me.”
“Because you’re such a queer, frightened, shy little thing. You should be bolder.”
“What! to get more knocks?”
“Nonsense! But you are rather put upon, that’s certain. My mother said, when she came to see me last week, that she would not like a little one of her own to be in your place.—Now, come in, and I’ve some good news for you.”
“I don’t think you have, Bessie.”
“Child! what do you mean? What sorrowful eyes you fix on me! Well, but Missis and the young ladies and Master John are going out to tea this afternoon, and you shall have tea with me. I’ll ask cook to bake you a little cake, and then you shall help me to look over your drawers; for I am soon to pack your trunk. Missis intends you to leave Gateshead in a day or two, and you shall choose what toys you like to take with you.”
“Bessie, you must promise not to scold me any more till I go.”
“Well, I will; but mind you are a very good girl, and don’t be afraid of me. Don’t start when I chance to speak rather sharply; it’s so provoking.”
“I don’t think I shall ever be afraid of you again, Bessie, because I have got used to you, and I shall soon have another set of people to dread.”
“If you dread them they’ll dislike you.”
“As you do, Bessie?”
“I don’t dislike you, Miss; I believe I am fonder of you than of all the others.”
“You don’t show it.”
“You little sharp thing! you’ve got quite a new way of talking. What makes you so venturesome and hardy?”
“Why, I shall soon be away from you, and besides”—I was going to say something about what had passed between me and Mrs. Reed, but on second thoughts I considered it better to remain silent on that head.
“And so you’re glad to leave me?”
“Not at all, Bessie; indeed, just now I’m rather sorry.”
“Just now! and rather! How coolly my little lady says it! I dare say now if I were to ask you for a kiss you wouldn’t give it me: you’d say you’d rather not.”
“I’ll kiss you and welcome: bend your head down.” Bessie stooped; we mutually embraced, and I followed her into the house quite comforted. That afternoon lapsed in peace and harmony; and in the evening Bessie told me some of her most enchanting stories, and sang me some of her sweetest songs. Even for me life had its gleams of sunshine.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I was left alone, having won the confrontation. It was the toughest struggle I'd ever faced and my initial triumph. I stood for a moment on the rug where Mr. Brocklehurst had stood and savored my isolated victory. Initially, I smiled to myself and felt a surge of elation; however, this intense satisfaction subsided as quickly as my rapid heartbeat returned to normal. A child cannot openly defy their elders as I had done, nor can they unleash their fierce emotions without constraint, as I had done with mine, without subsequently experiencing the pain of regret and the dampening effect of reaction. My state of mind when I was accusing and threatening Mrs. Reed could fittingly be compared to a patch of burning heath, vibrant, flickering, and all-consuming. In contrast, my condition afterwards, when a mere half-hour of quiet and introspection revealed the folly of my actions and the bleakness of my disliked and resentful situation, would have been just as aptly represented by that same patch of heath, now blackened and devastated after the flames had died. I had tasted vengeance for the first time. Initially, it seemed like flavorful wine upon swallowing, warm and sharp; however, its aftertaste was metallic and biting, leaving me with a sensation as if I had been poisoned. I would gladly have gone and asked Mrs. Reed for forgiveness now, but I knew, partly from past experience and partly instinctively, that doing so would only lead her to reject me with increased contempt, thereby reigniting every turbulent impulse within me. I yearned to employ a better capability than sharp words; I yearned to find sustenance for an emotion less malevolent than sullen anger. I picked up a book of Arabian tales; I sat down and attempted to read. I could not make sense of the content; my own thoughts constantly intruded between me and the page I usually found captivating. I opened the glass door in the breakfast room; the shrubbery was completely still. The severe frost held sway, unbroken by sun or breeze, throughout the grounds. I pulled the skirt of my dress over my head and arms and went outside to walk in a very secluded part of the planted area. However, I found no joy in the quiet trees, the fallen pine cones, the frozen remnants of autumn – the reddish-brown leaves swept into piles by past winds and now solidified together. I leaned against a gate and looked into an empty field where no sheep were grazing, where the short grass was bitten and pale. It was a very grey day; a dense sky, threatening snow, covered everything. Occasional snowflakes fell from it, landing on the hard path and the pale, frosted field without melting. I stood there, quite a miserable child, whispering to myself repeatedly, "What should I do? What should I do?" Suddenly, I heard a clear voice call, "Miss Jane! Where are you? Come to lunch!" I knew perfectly well it was Bessie, but I didn't move. Her light steps came quickly down the path. "You naughty little thing!" she exclaimed. "Why don't you come when you are called?" Bessie's presence, when contrasted with the brooding thoughts I had been dwelling on, seemed cheerful, even though, as usual, she was somewhat irritable. The truth was, after my conflict with and victory over Mrs. Reed, I was not inclined to mind the nursemaid's fleeting irritation; instead, I was inclined to enjoy her youthful cheerfulness. I simply put my arms around her and said, "Come, Bessie! Don't scold." This action was more open and courageous than any I was accustomed to performing; for some reason, it pleased her. "You are a peculiar child, Miss Jane," she remarked, looking down at me. "A little wandering, solitary creature. And you are going to school, I presume?" I nodded. "And you won't be sad to leave poor Bessie?" "What does Bessie care about me? She is always scolding me." "Because you're such an odd, timid, shy little thing. You ought to be bolder." "What! To get more blows?" "Nonsense! But you are rather picked on, that's for sure. My mother said, when she visited me last week, that she would not want one of her own little ones to be in your situation. Now, come inside, and I have some good news for you." "I don't believe you do, Bessie." "Child! What do you mean? Why do you fix such sad eyes on me? Well, the mistress and the young ladies and Master John are going out for tea this afternoon, and you shall have tea with me. I'll ask the cook to bake you a small cake, and then you can help me sort through your drawers because I have to pack your trunk soon. The mistress intends for you to leave Gateshead in a day or two, and you can choose which toys you'd like to take with you." "Bessie, you must promise not to scold me anymore until I leave." "Alright, I will; but remember, you must be a very good girl and don't be afraid of me. Don't jump when I happen to speak rather sharply; it's so irritating." "I don't think I shall ever be afraid of you again, Bessie, because I have become used to you, and I shall soon have a different group of people to fear." "If you fear them, they'll dislike you." "Just as you do, Bessie?" "I don't dislike you, Miss; I believe I am fonder of you than of all the others." "You don't show it." "You sharp little thing! You have developed a completely new way of talking. What makes you so daring and firm?" "Well, I shall soon be away from you, and besides"—I was about to say something about what had transpired between me and Mrs. Reed, but on second thought, I decided it was better to remain quiet on that matter. "And so you're happy to leave me?" "Not at all, Bessie; in fact, right now I'm rather regretful." "Right now! And rather! How coolly my little lady expresses it! I dare say now if I were to ask you for a kiss, you wouldn't give it to me; you'd say you'd prefer not to." "I'll kiss you readily; bend your head down." Bessie stooped; we hugged one another, and I followed her into the house feeling quite comforted. That afternoon passed peacefully and harmoniously; and in the evening, Bessie recounted some of her most captivating stories and sang me some of her most beautiful songs. Even for me, life had its brief moments of happiness.

I stood by a gate looking into an empty, gray, snow-dusted field, feeling miserable, asking myself over and over, "What shall I do?" Suddenly, I heard Bessie calling for me to come to lunch. I didn’t move, but she soon found me, chiding me playfully. Compared to my brooding, Bessie seemed cheerful, even if she was a little annoyed. We talked a little more, and she brightened things by inviting me to have tea with her later, promising a treat and letting me choose which toys to pack when I left Gateshead. She advised me not to be fearful, saying if I was, people might dislike me. She teased me about my boldness, and I explained that it was because I’d soon be leaving. She asked if I was happy to be going, but I honestly said I was a bit sorry at that moment. She joked about my cool tone and asked for a kiss—I gladly gave her one, and we warmed to each other. I went back inside with her, comforted, and spent a peaceful afternoon. That evening, she told me stories and sang songs, and I realized that even for me, there were moments of happiness in life.

events.title: Jane's Departure from Gateshead and Bittersweet Farewell to Bessie
detailed_summary: Jane awakens before dawn on the day of her departure from Gateshead, having already dressed by moonlight.
Bessie, the only other person awake, prepares breakfast for Jane in the nursery, but Jane is too excited to eat.
Bessie packs some biscuits for Jane's journey and helps her with her outdoor clothing.
When passing Mrs. Reed's room, Bessie suggests Jane bid her farewell.
Jane recounts Mrs. Reed's visit the previous night, where Mrs. Reed advised Jane not to disturb her and to remember her as her 'best friend,' a claim Jane silently rejected by turning away.
Bessie considers Jane's silent rejection wrong, but Jane asserts that Mrs. Reed has been her enemy.
Jane exclaims a final goodbye to Gateshead as they leave the house.
On the dark and cold walk to the porter's lodge, Bessie carries a lantern.
The coach arrives, and Jane clings to Bessie with kisses before being lifted inside by the guard.
Bessie tearfully implores the guard to take good care of Jane.
The coach departs, marking Jane's separation from Bessie and Gateshead, heading towards an unknown future.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Five o’clock had hardly struck on the morning of the 19th of January, when Bessie brought a candle into my closet and found me already up and nearly dressed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus was I severed from Bessie and Gateshead; thus whirled away to unknown, and, as I then deemed, remote and mysterious regions.

events.text_segment:
Five o’clock had hardly struck on the morning of the 19th of January, when Bessie brought a candle into my closet and found me already up and nearly dressed. I had risen half-an-hour before her entrance, and had washed my face, and put on my clothes by the light of a half-moon just setting, whose rays streamed through the narrow window near my crib. I was to leave Gateshead that day by a coach which passed the lodge gates at six A.M. Bessie was the only person yet risen; she had lit a fire in the nursery, where she now proceeded to make my breakfast. Few children can eat when excited with the thoughts of a journey; nor could I. Bessie, having pressed me in vain to take a few spoonfuls of the boiled milk and bread she had prepared for me, wrapped up some biscuits in a paper and put them into my bag; then she helped me on with my pelisse and bonnet, and wrapping herself in a shawl, she and I left the nursery. As we passed Mrs. Reed’s bedroom, she said, “Will you go in and bid Missis good-bye?”
“No, Bessie: she came to my crib last night when you were gone down to supper, and said I need not disturb her in the morning, or my cousins either; and she told me to remember that she had always been my best friend, and to speak of her and be grateful to her accordingly.”
“What did you say, Miss?”
“Nothing: I covered my face with the bedclothes, and turned from her to the wall.”
“That was wrong, Miss Jane.”
“It was quite right, Bessie. Your Missis has not been my friend: she has been my foe.”
“O Miss Jane! don’t say so!”
“Good-bye to Gateshead!” cried I, as we passed through the hall and went out at the front door.
The moon was set, and it was very dark; Bessie carried a lantern, whose light glanced on wet steps and gravel road sodden by a recent thaw. Raw and chill was the winter morning: my teeth chattered as I hastened down the drive. There was a light in the porter’s lodge: when we reached it, we found the porter’s wife just kindling her fire: my trunk, which had been carried down the evening before, stood corded at the door. It wanted but a few minutes of six, and shortly after that hour had struck, the distant roll of wheels announced the coming coach; I went to the door and watched its lamps approach rapidly through the gloom.
“Is she going by herself?” asked the porter’s wife.
“Yes.”
“And how far is it?”
“Fifty miles.”
“What a long way! I wonder Mrs. Reed is not afraid to trust her so far alone.”
The coach drew up; there it was at the gates with its four horses and its top laden with passengers: the guard and coachman loudly urged haste; my trunk was hoisted up; I was taken from Bessie’s neck, to which I clung with kisses.
“Be sure and take good care of her,” cried she to the guard, as he lifted me into the inside.
“Ay, ay!” was the answer: the door was slapped to, a voice exclaimed “All right,” and on we drove. Thus was I severed from Bessie and Gateshead; thus whirled away to unknown, and, as I then deemed, remote and mysterious regions.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Around five o'clock on the morning of January 19th, Bessie entered my small room with a candle, discovering I was already awake and almost dressed. I had gotten up thirty minutes earlier and used the light from a half-moon, visible through the narrow window by my bed, to wash and dress. That day, I was scheduled to leave Gateshead on a coach that would pass the main gates at 6 AM. Bessie was the only other person awake; she had lit a fire in the nursery and was preparing my breakfast there. I was too excited about the journey to eat much, which is typical for children in such situations. Bessie tried to persuade me to eat some of the boiled milk and bread she had made, but when I couldn't, she wrapped some biscuits in paper for my bag. She helped me put on my coat and bonnet, then, wrapping a shawl around herself, we left the nursery. As we walked past Mrs. Reed's bedroom, she asked if I wanted to go in and say goodbye. I refused, explaining that Mrs. Reed had visited my bedside the previous evening after Bessie had gone down for supper and told me not to disturb her or my cousins in the morning. She had also instructed me to remember her as my greatest supporter and to speak of her and be grateful accordingly. Bessie asked how I had responded. I said I hadn't; I had just pulled the covers over my face and turned away from her towards the wall. Bessie thought this was wrong, but I insisted it was right, stating that Mrs. Reed had not been a friend but an enemy. Bessie objected, saying 'Oh, Miss Jane! Don't say that!' As we went through the hall and out the front door, I exclaimed, 'Goodbye to Gateshead!' The moon had set, and it was very dark. Bessie carried a lantern whose light shone on the wet steps and the gravel path, softened by the recent thaw. The winter morning was raw and cold, causing my teeth to chatter as I hurried down the drive. There was a light on in the porter's lodge, and when we reached it, we found the porter's wife starting her fire. My trunk, which had been brought down the night before, stood tied up by the door. It was only a few minutes before six, and shortly after the hour struck, the distant sound of rolling wheels signaled the approaching coach. I went to the door and watched its lamps quickly appear out of the darkness. The porter's wife asked if I was traveling alone, and Bessie confirmed I was, stating the distance was fifty miles. 'What a distance!' exclaimed the porter's wife, 'I'm surprised Mrs. Reed isn't afraid to trust her alone so far.' The coach pulled up to the gates, with its four horses and a top full of passengers. The guard and coachman were urging haste. My trunk was loaded, and I clung to Bessie, kissing her neck before being taken from her. As the guard lifted me inside, she called out to him, 'Make sure you take good care of her!' 'Alright!' he replied. The door was shut quickly, a voice called out 'All right,' and we began to move. In this way, I was separated from Bessie and Gateshead, swiftly carried away to places I didn't know, which at the time seemed distant and mysterious to me.
