I had gotten up half an hour before she arrived, washed my face, and put on my clothes by the remaining moonlight coming through the window near my bed. I was set to leave Gateshead that day on a coach scheduled to pass the lodge gates at six o'clock. At that hour, Bessie was the only other person awake; she had made a fire in the nursery and was now preparing my breakfast there. Excitement over the trip took away my appetite, as is often the case with children, and I could not eat. Bessie tried to persuade me to take a few spoonfuls of the milk and bread she’d made, but when I refused, she wrapped some biscuits in paper and placed them in my bag. She helped me into my coat and hat, wrapped herself in a shawl, and together we left the nursery. As we neared Mrs. Reed’s bedroom, Bessie asked if I wanted to say goodbye, but I declined, explaining that Mrs. Reed had visited me the night before while Bessie was at supper, telling me not to disturb her or my cousins in the morning and reminding me to always speak well of her and be grateful. Bessie asked how I had responded, and I told her I had simply hidden my face and turned away, insisting that Mrs. Reed had not been a friend to me but an enemy, though Bessie protested this. Passing through the house, I called out goodbye to Gateshead. It was still dark and cold, the moon had set, and Bessie carried a lantern as we went over wet steps and a soggy gravel path from the thaw. I shivered in the winter air as we hurried down the driveway. When we arrived at the porter’s lodge, his wife was starting her fire and my trunk was already waiting, having been brought down the previous evening. It was almost six o’clock when we heard the approaching coach. I watched its lamps grow brighter through the darkness as it came near. The porter’s wife asked if I was traveling alone and how far I had to go, and was surprised that Mrs. Reed would send me off by myself for fifty miles. When the coach arrived with its four horses and crowded roof, the guard and coachman hurried everyone along. My trunk was loaded up, and I hugged Bessie tightly before being lifted into the coach. She asked the guard to look after me, and after he agreed, the door closed, and the coach set off. This was how I was separated from Bessie and Gateshead and carried off toward places that seemed to me distant and mysterious.

events.title: The Arduous Journey and Unsettling Arrival at Lowood
detailed_summary: Jane's memory of the journey is vague, marked only by its perceived extraordinary length and the vast distance covered.
The coach traverses several towns, stopping in a large one where passengers alight to dine.
Jane is taken into an inn by the guard, who offers her dinner, but she has no appetite and is left alone in a grand, imposing room.
In the room, Jane feels a strong sense of unease and fears being kidnapped, a notion instilled by Bessie's stories.
The journey continues, and as evening approaches, Jane becomes acutely aware of her increasing distance from Gateshead, the landscape transforming into hills and woods.
Overcome by the journey, Jane eventually falls asleep to the sound of the wind.
She is awakened by the coach's sudden stop; the door opens, and a servant-like woman inquires if a girl named Jane Eyre is present.
Jane confirms her identity, is lifted from the coach, her trunk is unloaded, and the vehicle departs swiftly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I remember but little of the journey; I only know that the day seemed to me of a preternatural length, and that we appeared to travel over hundreds of miles of road.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I answered “Yes,” and was then lifted out; my trunk was handed down, and the coach instantly drove away.

events.text_segment:
I remember but little of the journey; I only know that the day seemed to me of a preternatural length, and that we appeared to travel over hundreds of miles of road. We passed through several towns, and in one, a very large one, the coach stopped; the horses were taken out, and the passengers alighted to dine. I was carried into an inn, where the guard wanted me to have some dinner; but, as I had no appetite, he left me in an immense room with a fireplace at each end, a chandelier pendent from the ceiling, and a little red gallery high up against the wall filled with musical instruments. Here I walked about for a long time, feeling very strange, and mortally apprehensive of some one coming in and kidnapping me; for I believed in kidnappers, their exploits having frequently figured in Bessie’s fireside chronicles. At last the guard returned; once more I was stowed away in the coach, my protector mounted his own seat, sounded his hollow horn, and away we rattled over the “stony street” of L——.
The afternoon came on wet and somewhat misty: as it waned into dusk, I began to feel that we were getting very far indeed from Gateshead: we ceased to pass through towns; the country changed; great grey hills heaved up round the horizon: as twilight deepened, we descended a valley, dark with wood, and long after night had overclouded the prospect, I heard a wild wind rushing amongst trees.
Lulled by the sound, I at last dropped asleep; I had not long slumbered when the sudden cessation of motion awoke me; the coach-door was open, and a person like a servant was standing at it: I saw her face and dress by the light of the lamps.
“Is there a little girl called Jane Eyre here?” she asked. I answered “Yes,” and was then lifted out; my trunk was handed down, and the coach instantly drove away.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: My memory of the journey is limited; I recall only that the day felt exceptionally long and that our travel seemed to cover vast distances. We journeyed through several towns, and in one sizable place, the stagecoach paused. The horses were unhitched, and the passengers got off to dine. I was led into an inn where the guard suggested I eat, but lacking appetite, he left me in an enormous room. This room had a fireplace at each end, a large chandelier hanging from the ceiling, and a small, high red gallery along one wall containing musical instruments. I spent a long time walking around in this room, feeling very strange and intensely worried that someone might come in and kidnap me, a fear based on Bessie's frequent stories about kidnappers' deeds. Eventually, the guard returned. I was helped back into the coach, my protector took his position, blew his horn, and we rattled away through the stone streets of L——. The afternoon became damp and slightly misty; as it faded into twilight, I started to feel we were getting quite far from Gateshead. We stopped passing through towns; the landscape changed, with large grey hills rising around the horizon. As darkness deepened, we descended into a valley thick with woods, and long after night had obscured the view, I heard a wild wind sweeping through the trees. The sound lulled me, and I finally fell asleep. I hadn't slept long when I was woken by the coach stopping abruptly. The coach door was open, and a person who appeared to be a servant was standing there. The light from the lamps showed me her face and clothing. "Is there a little girl called Jane Eyre here?" she asked. I replied "Yes," and she then lifted me out. My trunk was handed down, and the coach drove away immediately.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I remember very little about the trip itself; all I recall is that the day seemed unusually long and it felt like we travelled hundreds of miles. We went through a number of towns, and in one particularly large town, the coach stopped so the passengers and horses could rest. I was brought into an inn, where the guard encouraged me to have some lunch, but I didn’t feel hungry. He left me alone in a huge room with fireplaces at both ends, a ceiling chandelier, and a small red gallery high on the wall filled with musical instruments. I wandered around this room for quite some time, feeling uneasy and fearful someone might come in and abduct me, as Bessie’s stories had made me believe in kidnappers. Eventually, the guard came back; I was put back in the coach, he took his seat, blew his horn, and we continued rattling through the stony streets of L——.

Later, it began to rain and mist settled in as afternoon turned to evening. As it grew dark, I sensed that we were getting farther and farther from Gateshead. We stopped passing through towns, the scenery changed, and gray hills appeared around us. At dusk, we went down into a wooded valley, and after night fell, I could hear a wild wind blowing through the trees.

Soothed by the sound, I finally fell asleep, but was soon awakened when the coach stopped. The door opened and a woman, looking like a servant, stood there. I could see her face and dress in the lamplight. She asked if there was a girl named Jane Eyre, and when I said yes, I was lifted out, my luggage handed to me, and the coach drove away.

events.title: Jane's First Evening at Lowood and Encounter with Miss Temple
detailed_summary: Stiff and bewildered from the journey, Jane surveys her new surroundings, finding herself in a dark, rainy, and windy environment.
She follows her guide through a door in a wall, which is then locked, into a large complex with some lit windows.
The servant leads Jane into a room with a fire and leaves her by herself.
Jane warms her numb fingers and observes the parlor, finding it comfortable though not as grand as Gateshead's drawing-room.
A tall, grave lady with dark features (Miss Temple) enters carrying a light, followed closely by another woman (Miss Miller).
Miss Temple remarks on Jane's youth for undertaking such a journey alone and notes her tired appearance.
She kindly asks if Jane is tired and hungry, instructing Miss Miller to arrange supper for her.
Learning Jane is an orphan, Miss Temple inquires about her parents' demise, her age, name, and basic educational skills like reading, writing, and sewing.
Miss Temple gently touches Jane's cheek, expresses a hope that Jane will be a good child, and dismisses her with Miss Miller.
Jane is more significantly impressed by Miss Temple's voice, look, and air than by Miss Miller, whom she perceives as an ordinary, hurried under-teacher.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was stiff with long sitting, and bewildered with the noise and motion of the coach: gathering my faculties, I looked about me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Miss Miller was more ordinary; ruddy in complexion, though of a careworn countenance; hurried in gait and action, like one who had always a multiplicity of tasks on hand: she looked, indeed, what I afterwards found she really was, an under-teacher.

events.text_segment:
I was stiff with long sitting, and bewildered with the noise and motion of the coach: gathering my faculties, I looked about me. Rain, wind, and darkness filled the air; nevertheless, I dimly discerned a wall before me and a door open in it; through this door I passed with my new guide: she shut and locked it behind her. There was now visible a house or houses—for the building spread far—with many windows, and lights burning in some; we went up a broad pebbly path, splashing wet, and were admitted at a door; then the servant led me through a passage into a room with a fire, where she left me alone.
I stood and warmed my numbed fingers over the blaze, then I looked round; there was no candle, but the uncertain light from the hearth showed, by intervals, papered walls, carpet, curtains, shining mahogany furniture: it was a parlour, not so spacious or splendid as the drawing-room at Gateshead, but comfortable enough. I was puzzling to make out the subject of a picture on the wall, when the door opened, and an individual carrying a light entered; another followed close behind.
The first was a tall lady with dark hair, dark eyes, and a pale and large forehead; her figure was partly enveloped in a shawl, her countenance was grave, her bearing erect.
“The child is very young to be sent alone,” said she, putting her candle down on the table. She considered me attentively for a minute or two, then further added—
“She had better be put to bed soon; she looks tired: are you tired?” she asked, placing her hand on my shoulder.
“A little, ma’am.”
“And hungry too, no doubt: let her have some supper before she goes to bed, Miss Miller. Is this the first time you have left your parents to come to school, my little girl?”
I explained to her that I had no parents. She inquired how long they had been dead: then how old I was, what was my name, whether I could read, write, and sew a little: then she touched my cheek gently with her forefinger, and saying, “She hoped I should be a good child,” dismissed me along with Miss Miller.
The lady I had left might be about twenty-nine; the one who went with me appeared some years younger: the first impressed me by her voice, look, and air. Miss Miller was more ordinary; ruddy in complexion, though of a careworn countenance; hurried in gait and action, like one who had always a multiplicity of tasks on hand: she looked, indeed, what I afterwards found she really was, an under-teacher.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Stiff from the long journey and disoriented by the coach's noise and motion, I gathered my thoughts and looked around. Rain, wind, and darkness filled the air, but I could dimly see a wall in front of me with an open door. I went through this door with the person guiding me; she closed and locked it after us. Now I could see a building, or perhaps several connected buildings, stretching far with many windows, some showing lights. We walked up a wide, wet, pebbly path and entered through a door. The servant then led me down a corridor into a room with a fire, where I remained by myself. I stood and warmed my cold fingers at the fire, then I surveyed the room. There was no candle, but the flickering firelight occasionally revealed wallpaper, a carpet, curtains, and polished mahogany furniture. It was a parlour, not as large or grand as the drawing-room at Gateshead, but comfortable. I was trying to figure out what a picture on the wall depicted when the door opened and someone carrying a light entered, followed closely by another person. The first was a tall lady with dark hair, dark eyes, and a pale, broad forehead. A shawl partly covered her figure; her expression was serious, and her posture upright. "The child is very young to travel alone," she said, setting her candle on the table. She studied me carefully for a couple of minutes, then added, "She should probably go to bed soon; she looks tired. Are you tired?" she asked, placing her hand on my shoulder. "A little, ma'am." "And hungry too, I'm sure. Let her have some supper before bed, Miss Miller. Is this the first time you've left your parents to come to school, my little girl?" I explained that I had no parents. She asked how long they had been deceased, then my age, my name, and if I could read, write, and sew a little. Then she gently touched my cheek with her fingertip and, saying she hoped I would be a good child, sent me away with Miss Miller. The lady I had just left was likely around twenty-nine years old; the one accompanying me seemed younger by several years. The first lady made an impression on me with her voice, look, and demeanor. Miss Miller was plainer; she had a ruddy complexion but a tired-looking face, and she moved and acted quickly, like someone who always had many tasks to handle. Indeed, she appeared to be what I later learned she truly was: an under-teacher.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After sitting for a long time, my body felt stiff and my mind was confused by the loud noises and constant movement of the coach. As I regained my senses, I looked around and saw that it was rainy, windy, and dark outside. Still, I could faintly see a wall with an open door in it, and I followed my new guide through this door. She closed and locked it behind us. Ahead, I could see a large building with many windows, some of which were lit. We walked up a wide, wet, gravel path and entered through another door. The servant brought me down a hallway into a room with a fire, where I was left on my own.

I stood by the fire to warm my cold hands and glanced around the room. There were no candles, but the flickering light from the hearth let me make out wallpaper on the walls, carpet, curtains, and polished mahogany furniture. It was a sitting room—smaller and less grand than the drawing-room at Gateshead, but still comfortable. As I was trying to figure out a painting on the wall, the door opened and two people entered, one carrying a light.

The first woman was tall, with dark hair, dark eyes, and a pale, broad forehead. She was partly wrapped in a shawl, had a serious expression, and stood upright. She said, "The child is very young to be sent alone," as she put her candle on the table, studying me carefully for a moment. Then she added that I should go to bed soon, as I looked tired, and asked if I was, touching my shoulder.

"A little, ma'am," I replied.

She guessed I was hungry as well and said I should have some supper before bed. Then, addressing me as "my little girl," she asked if this was my first time leaving my parents to go to school. I explained I had no parents. She asked when they had died, my age, my name, and whether I could read, write, or sew. She gently touched my cheek and hoped I would be good, then sent me away with Miss Miller.

The woman I left behind was probably about twenty-nine years old, while Miss Miller seemed younger. The first woman left a strong impression on me; Miss Miller, in contrast, looked more ordinary, with a ruddy, tired face, and seemed rushed, as if she always had many tasks to do. She looked—as I later learned was true—like a junior teacher.

events.title: Introduction to Lowood's Communal Life and Evening Routine
detailed_summary: Miss Miller leads Jane through the extensive and irregularly laid out building.
They arrive at a wide, long room where numerous girls, aged from nine to twenty, are seated on benches, all dressed uniformly in brown frocks and holland pinafores.
The room is filled with the sound of the girls whispering their lessons for the next day.
Miss Miller directs Jane to sit on a bench near the door.
Miss Miller then calls for the monitors to collect the lesson books and put them away.
Following this, the monitors are instructed to fetch supper trays.
Each tray contains portions of an unidentified food (later revealed as oaten cake) and a pitcher of water with a communal mug.
Jane, though thirsty, cannot bring herself to eat due to a combination of excitement and fatigue.
After the meal, Miss Miller reads prayers, and the girls file out in pairs to the dormitory.
Overwhelmed by tiredness, Jane barely notices the features of the very long bedroom.
She is to share a bed with Miss Miller, who helps her undress; Jane quickly falls asleep in the dark and silent room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Led by her, I passed from compartment to compartment, from passage to passage, of a large and irregular building; till, emerging from the total and somewhat dreary silence pervading that portion of the house we had traversed, we came upon the hum of many voices, and presently entered a wide, long room, with great deal tables, two at each end, on each of which burnt a pair of candles, and seated all round on benches, a congregation of girls of every age, from nine or ten to twenty.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When laid down I glanced at the long rows of beds, each of which was quickly filled with two occupants; in ten minutes the single light was extinguished, and amidst silence and complete darkness I fell asleep.

events.text_segment:
Led by her, I passed from compartment to compartment, from passage to passage, of a large and irregular building; till, emerging from the total and somewhat dreary silence pervading that portion of the house we had traversed, we came upon the hum of many voices, and presently entered a wide, long room, with great deal tables, two at each end, on each of which burnt a pair of candles, and seated all round on benches, a congregation of girls of every age, from nine or ten to twenty. Seen by the dim light of the dips, their number to me appeared countless, though not in reality exceeding eighty; they were uniformly dressed in brown stuff frocks of quaint fashion, and long holland pinafores. It was the hour of study; they were engaged in conning over their to-morrow’s task, and the hum I had heard was the combined result of their whispered repetitions.
Miss Miller signed to me to sit on a bench near the door, then walking up to the top of the long room she cried out—
“Monitors, collect the lesson-books and put them away!”
Four tall girls arose from different tables, and going round, gathered the books and removed them. Miss Miller again gave the word of command—
“Monitors, fetch the supper-trays!”
The tall girls went out and returned presently, each bearing a tray, with portions of something, I knew not what, arranged thereon, and a pitcher of water and mug in the middle of each tray. The portions were handed round; those who liked took a draught of the water, the mug being common to all. When it came to my turn, I drank, for I was thirsty, but did not touch the food, excitement and fatigue rendering me incapable of eating: I now saw, however, that it was a thin oaten cake shared into fragments.
The meal over, prayers were read by Miss Miller, and the classes filed off, two and two, upstairs. Overpowered by this time with weariness, I scarcely noticed what sort of a place the bedroom was, except that, like the schoolroom, I saw it was very long. To-night I was to be Miss Miller’s bed-fellow; she helped me to undress: when laid down I glanced at the long rows of beds, each of which was quickly filled with two occupants; in ten minutes the single light was extinguished, and amidst silence and complete darkness I fell asleep.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Guided by her, I moved through various compartments and hallways within a large and irregular building. We eventually emerged from the complete and rather bleak silence that had filled the part of the house we had just passed through, and encountered the low drone of many voices. Soon after, we entered a wide, elongated room. This room contained large tables, with two placed at each end, on which a pair of candles burned. Seated all around on benches was a group of girls of all ages, from around nine or ten up to twenty. In the dim candlelight, their number seemed immense to me, although there were actually no more than eighty. They were uniformly dressed in old-fashioned brown fabric dresses and long white aprons. It was study time; they were occupied with memorizing their lessons for the following day, and the buzzing sound I'd heard was the collective result of their quiet repetitions. Miss Miller indicated for me to sit on a bench near the door. Then, walking to the end of the long room, she called out, "Monitors, collect the lesson books and put them away!" Four tall girls stood up from different tables and went around gathering the books before removing them. Miss Miller then issued another command: "Monitors, fetch the supper trays!" The tall girls left and returned shortly, each carrying a tray holding servings of something I didn't recognize, along with a pitcher of water and a mug in the center of each tray. The portions were passed out. Those who wished to drink took some water using the common mug. When it was my turn, I drank, as I was thirsty, but I didn't touch the food. Excitement and exhaustion made me unable to eat. I did, however, then see that it was a thin oatcake broken into pieces. After the meal, Miss Miller read prayers, and the classes exited the room, filing upstairs in pairs. By now, overcome with tiredness, I hardly noticed what the bedroom looked like, except that it was very long, similar to the schoolroom. That night, I was assigned to be Miss Miller's bedmate; she assisted me in undressing. Once I was in bed, I looked at the long rows of beds, each of which was quickly filled by two occupants. Within ten minutes, the only light was put out, and surrounded by silence and complete darkness, I fell asleep.

The silence we encountered in that part of the house was soon replaced by the lively sounds of many voices as we entered a spacious, long room. The dim candlelight made them seem countless, though there were actually around eighty, all dressed in old-fashioned brown dresses with long aprons. It was study hour, and the girls were quietly reciting their lessons for the next day, creating the collective hum I had heard earlier. Miss Miller motioned for me to sit near the door, then called out for the monitors to gather the lesson-books, which four tall girls did. She then instructed the monitors to bring in the supper trays. The same girls left and returned with trays carrying portions of an unknown food and pitchers of water. The food was passed around, as was a shared mug for water. When it was my turn, I drank some water since I was thirsty, but I didn't eat the food due to my exhaustion and excitement; I soon realized it was just thin oatcake broken into pieces. After supper, Miss Miller read prayers and the girls left the room in pairs to go upstairs. I was so tired that I barely noticed the dormitory, except for its length, and tonight I was to share a bed with Miss Miller. She helped me undress, and as I lay down, I saw the row of beds, quickly filled two to a bed. Within ten minutes, the only light was put out, and in the darkness and silence, I fell asleep.

events.title: A Grim Morning: Cold, Discipline, and Inedible Breakfast
detailed_summary: Jane's night passes quickly, her exhaustion preventing dreams; she wakes once to the sound of a storm and Miss Miller's presence beside her.
A loud bell rouses the girls before dawn into a bitterly cold dormitory.
Jane reluctantly gets up, dresses while shivering, and has to wait for an opportunity to wash due to the limited number of basins.
Another bell summons them to the cold, dimly lit schoolroom for prayers led by Miss Miller.
Following prayers, Miss Miller calls for classes to form, leading to a few minutes of chaos before order is established.
Jane is assigned to the lowest class, assembled near the door.
The morning's lessons begin with repeating the day's Collect, reciting Scripture, and a protracted hour-long Bible reading.
By the end of this exercise, daylight has fully arrived, and a bell signals breakfast, a prospect Jane eagerly anticipates due to her hunger.
The refectory is a large, low-ceilinged, gloomy room where basins of hot food emit an uninviting smell.
A universal expression of discontent arises from the students as they recognize the odor of burnt porridge.
A sharply dressed, morose-looking upper teacher, not Miss Miller, commands silence.
Jane observes Miss Temple's absence and notes Miss Miller and a foreign-looking French teacher at the tables.
After a lengthy grace and a hymn, the teachers are served tea, and the students begin their meal.
Jane, famished, initially eats a couple of spoonfuls without noticing the taste, but soon realizes the porridge is nauseating.
She sees other girls also struggling to consume the burnt food, and ultimately, no one manages to eat a proper breakfast.
Thanks are offered for the largely uneaten meal, another hymn is sung, and the students leave the refectory for the schoolroom.
As Jane leaves, she sees one teacher taste the porridge, and observes the shared displeasure on the faces of the other teachers, one of whom whispers about its shameful quality.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night passed rapidly: I was too tired even to dream; I only once awoke to hear the wind rave in furious gusts, and the rain fall in torrents, and to be sensible that Miss Miller had taken her place by my side.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She looked at the others; all their countenances expressed displeasure, and one of them, the stout one, whispered— “Abominable stuff! How shameful!”

events.text_segment:
The night passed rapidly: I was too tired even to dream; I only once awoke to hear the wind rave in furious gusts, and the rain fall in torrents, and to be sensible that Miss Miller had taken her place by my side. When I again unclosed my eyes, a loud bell was ringing; the girls were up and dressing; day had not yet begun to dawn, and a rushlight or two burned in the room. I too rose reluctantly; it was bitter cold, and I dressed as well as I could for shivering, and washed when there was a basin at liberty, which did not occur soon, as there was but one basin to six girls, on the stands down the middle of the room. Again the bell rang: all formed in file, two and two, and in that order descended the stairs and entered the cold and dimly lit schoolroom: here prayers were read by Miss Miller; afterwards she called out—
“Form classes!”
A great tumult succeeded for some minutes, during which Miss Miller repeatedly exclaimed, “Silence!” and “Order!” When it subsided, I saw them all drawn up in four semicircles, before four chairs, placed at the four tables; all held books in their hands, and a great book, like a Bible, lay on each table, before the vacant seat. A pause of some seconds succeeded, filled up by the low, vague hum of numbers; Miss Miller walked from class to class, hushing this indefinite sound.
A distant bell tinkled: immediately three ladies entered the room, each walked to a table and took her seat; Miss Miller assumed the fourth vacant chair, which was that nearest the door, and around which the smallest of the children were assembled: to this inferior class I was called, and placed at the bottom of it.
Business now began: the day’s Collect was repeated, then certain texts of Scripture were said, and to these succeeded a protracted reading of chapters in the Bible, which lasted an hour. By the time that exercise was terminated, day had fully dawned. The indefatigable bell now sounded for the fourth time: the classes were marshalled and marched into another room to breakfast: how glad I was to behold a prospect of getting something to eat! I was now nearly sick from inanition, having taken so little the day before.
The refectory was a great, low-ceiled, gloomy room; on two long tables smoked basins of something hot, which, however, to my dismay, sent forth an odour far from inviting. I saw a universal manifestation of discontent when the fumes of the repast met the nostrils of those destined to swallow it; from the van of the procession, the tall girls of the first class, rose the whispered words—
“Disgusting! The porridge is burnt again!”
“Silence!” ejaculated a voice; not that of Miss Miller, but one of the upper teachers, a little and dark personage, smartly dressed, but of somewhat morose aspect, who installed herself at the top of one table, while a more buxom lady presided at the other. I looked in vain for her I had first seen the night before; she was not visible: Miss Miller occupied the foot of the table where I sat, and a strange, foreign-looking, elderly lady, the French teacher, as I afterwards found, took the corresponding seat at the other board. A long grace was said and a hymn sung; then a servant brought in some tea for the teachers, and the meal began.
Ravenous, and now very faint, I devoured a spoonful or two of my portion without thinking of its taste; but the first edge of hunger blunted, I perceived I had got in hand a nauseous mess; burnt porridge is almost as bad as rotten potatoes; famine itself soon sickens over it. The spoons were moved slowly: I saw each girl taste her food and try to swallow it; but in most cases the effort was soon relinquished. Breakfast was over, and none had breakfasted. Thanks being returned for what we had not got, and a second hymn chanted, the refectory was evacuated for the schoolroom. I was one of the last to go out, and in passing the tables, I saw one teacher take a basin of the porridge and taste it; she looked at the others; all their countenances expressed displeasure, and one of them, the stout one, whispered—
“Abominable stuff!
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The night went quickly. I was too exhausted to even dream, waking only once to the sound of strong wind gusts and pouring rain, realizing that Miss Miller was now sleeping next to me. When I opened my eyes again, a loud bell was ringing; the other girls were awake and getting dressed. It wasn't quite dawn yet, and a couple of small lights (rushlights) were burning in the room. I got up unwillingly because it was very cold. I shivered while getting dressed as best I could and washed whenever a basin became available, which wasn't often since there was only one basin for six girls on the stands in the middle of the room. The bell rang again; everyone lined up in pairs and went down the stairs into the cold, dimly lit schoolroom. Miss Miller led prayers there, and then she announced, "Form your classes!" For several minutes, there was a lot of noise, with Miss Miller repeatedly calling for "Silence!" and "Order!" Once things settled down, I saw everyone arranged in four half-circles in front of four chairs by four tables. Each girl had a book, and a large book, like a Bible, was placed on each table in front of the empty seat. A few seconds of quiet followed, filled only by the low, indistinct murmur of voices counting or reciting; Miss Miller walked among the groups, trying to quiet this general sound. A faraway bell chimed, and immediately three ladies entered the room. Each went to a table and sat down. Miss Miller took the fourth empty chair, which was the one closest to the door and around which the youngest children were gathered. I was called to join this lowest class and placed at the very back of it. The day's activities began. We recited the daily Collect, then some Bible verses, followed by a long session of reading Bible chapters, which lasted for an hour. By the time this reading finished, it was fully daylight. The persistent bell rang for the fourth time, and the classes were organized and marched into another room for breakfast. How relieved I was to see the possibility of getting something to eat! I felt almost ill from hunger, having eaten so little the previous day. The dining hall (refectory) was a large, low-ceilinged, gloomy room. On two long tables, there were steaming bowls of a hot dish which, unfortunately and to my disappointment, smelled quite unappetizing. I saw widespread expressions of displeasure as the smell of the food reached the girls who were supposed to eat it. From the front of the line, the older girls in the first class, came quiet whispers: "Horrible! The porridge is burned again!" A voice sharply ordered, "Silence!" It wasn't Miss Miller's, but that of one of the senior teachers, a small, dark woman who was smartly dressed but looked rather stern. She took her place at the head of one table, while a more cheerful-looking lady presided over the other. I looked around for the teacher I had seen first the night before, but she wasn't there. Miss Miller sat at the foot of the table where I was placed, and an elderly, unfamiliar-looking lady, who I later learned was the French teacher, occupied the corresponding seat at the other table. A lengthy grace was said, followed by a hymn being sung. Then, a servant brought tea for the teachers, and the meal started. Extremely hungry and now feeling very weak, I ate a spoonful or two of my portion without paying attention to the taste. But once the initial intense hunger lessened, I realized I was eating a disgusting mess. Burnt porridge is nearly as bad as rotten potatoes; even starvation makes one sick of it quickly. Spoons moved slowly; I watched each girl taste her food and try to swallow it, but in most cases, they soon gave up. Breakfast was over, and practically no one had eaten. After giving thanks for the meal we didn't get and singing another hymn, we left the refectory for the schoolroom. I was among the last to leave, and as I passed the tables, I saw one teacher sample a bowl of the porridge. She looked at the others; they all looked displeased, and one of them, the heavier-set one, muttered, "Awful stuff!"

Even hunger couldn't make it palatable. The girls ate slowly, many giving up after just a taste. Soon breakfast was over, but hardly anyone had eaten. We gave thanks for the meal we hadn't really received and sang another hymn. The room emptied back into the schoolroom. As I left, I saw a teacher taste the porridge; exchanging looks with the others, their faces all showed displeasure, and the plumper teacher whispered, 'Horrible stuff!"

events.title: Post-Breakfast Discontent and Miss Temple's Compassionate Intervention
detailed_summary: A fifteen-minute interval of 'glorious tumult' occurs in the schoolroom, during which students freely and loudly complain about the inedible breakfast.
Miss Miller is present and hears some girls mention Mr. Brocklehurst's name, to which she reacts with a disapproving headshake but does not try to quell the general anger, likely sharing it.
At nine o'clock, Miss Miller restores order, and the upper teachers return to their posts, though an air of anticipation lingers.
The eighty students, plainly dressed with severely combed hair, sit motionless and erect.
Jane observes the teachers—the stout one coarse, the dark one fierce, the foreigner harsh, and Miss Miller overworked—finding none particularly appealing.
Suddenly, the entire school rises simultaneously as Miss Temple enters the room.
Jane is captivated by Miss Temple's appearance in daylight: tall, fair, with kind brown eyes, dark curly hair, refined features, and a purple dress accented with a gold watch.
Miss Temple, identified as the superintendent of Lowood, commences a geography lesson with the first class, while other classes resume their studies under other teachers.
Lessons in history, grammar, writing, arithmetic, and music (taught by Miss Temple to older girls) continue until noon.
When the clock strikes twelve, Miss Temple rises to address the students.

She acknowledges their unsatisfactory breakfast and announces that she has ordered a lunch of bread and cheese for everyone, taking personal responsibility for this decision, which surprises the other teachers.
The bread and cheese are promptly served, bringing much delight and relief to the entire school.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A quarter of an hour passed before lessons again began, during which the schoolroom was in a glorious tumult; for that space of time it seemed to be permitted to talk loud and more freely, and they used their privilege.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bread and cheese was presently brought in and distributed, to the high delight and refreshment of the whole school.

events.text_segment:
A quarter of an hour passed before lessons again began, during which the schoolroom was in a glorious tumult; for that space of time it seemed to be permitted to talk loud and more freely, and they used their privilege. The whole conversation ran on the breakfast, which one and all abused roundly. Poor things! it was the sole consolation they had. Miss Miller was now the only teacher in the room: a group of great girls standing about her spoke with serious and sullen gestures. I heard the name of Mr. Brocklehurst pronounced by some lips; at which Miss Miller shook her head disapprovingly; but she made no great effort to check the general wrath; doubtless she shared in it.
A clock in the schoolroom struck nine; Miss Miller left her circle, and standing in the middle of the room, cried—
“Silence! To your seats!”
Discipline prevailed: in five minutes the confused throng was resolved into order, and comparative silence quelled the Babel clamour of tongues. The upper teachers now punctually resumed their posts: but still, all seemed to wait. Ranged on benches down the sides of the room, the eighty girls sat motionless and erect; a quaint assemblage they appeared, all with plain locks combed from their faces, not a curl visible; in brown dresses, made high and surrounded by a narrow tucker about the throat, with little pockets of holland (shaped something like a Highlander’s purse) tied in front of their frocks, and destined to serve the purpose of a work-bag: all, too, wearing woollen stockings and country-made shoes, fastened with brass buckles. Above twenty of those clad in this costume were full-grown girls, or rather young women; it suited them ill, and gave an air of oddity even to the prettiest.
I was still looking at them, and also at intervals examining the teachers—none of whom precisely pleased me; for the stout one was a little coarse, the dark one not a little fierce, the foreigner harsh and grotesque, and Miss Miller, poor thing! looked purple, weather-beaten, and over-worked—when, as my eye wandered from face to face, the whole school rose simultaneously, as if moved by a common spring.
What was the matter? I had heard no order given: I was puzzled. Ere I had gathered my wits, the classes were again seated: but as all eyes were now turned to one point, mine followed the general direction, and encountered the personage who had received me last night. She stood at the bottom of the long room, on the hearth; for there was a fire at each end; she surveyed the two rows of girls silently and gravely. Miss Miller approaching, seemed to ask her a question, and having received her answer, went back to her place, and said aloud—
“Monitor of the first class, fetch the globes!”
While the direction was being executed, the lady consulted moved slowly up the room. I suppose I have a considerable organ of veneration, for I retain yet the sense of admiring awe with which my eyes traced her steps. Seen now, in broad daylight, she looked tall, fair, and shapely; brown eyes with a benignant light in their irids, and a fine pencilling of long lashes round, relieved the whiteness of her large front; on each of her temples her hair, of a very dark brown, was clustered in round curls, according to the fashion of those times, when neither smooth bands nor long ringlets were in vogue; her dress, also in the mode of the day, was of purple cloth, relieved by a sort of Spanish trimming of black velvet; a gold watch (watches were not so common then as now) shone at her girdle. Let the reader add, to complete the picture, refined features; a complexion, if pale, clear; and a stately air and carriage, and he will have, at least, as clearly as words can give it, a correct idea of the exterior of Miss Temple—Maria Temple, as I afterwards saw the name written in a prayer-book intrusted to me to carry to church.
The superintendent of Lowood (for such was this lady) having taken her seat before a pair of globes placed on one of the tables, summoned the first class round her, and commenced giving a lesson on geography; the lower classes were called by the teachers: repetitions in history, grammar, &c., went on for an hour; writing and arithmetic succeeded, and music lessons were given by Miss Temple to some of the elder girls. The duration of each lesson was measured by the clock, which at last struck twelve. The superintendent rose—
“I have a word to address to the pupils,” said she.
The tumult of cessation from lessons was already breaking forth, but it sank at her voice. She went on—
“You had this morning a breakfast which you could not eat; you must be hungry:—I have ordered that a lunch of bread and cheese shall be served to all.”
The teachers looked at her with a sort of surprise.
“It is to be done on my responsibility,” she added, in an explanatory tone to them, and immediately afterwards left the room.
The bread and cheese was presently brought in and distributed, to the high delight and refreshment of the whole school.

They presented an unusual sight, all with their simple hair combed back from their faces, not a single curl visible; they wore brown dresses with high necks and a small collar, and little bags made of canvas (resembling a Highlander's pouch) tied in front of their dresses to serve as work-bags. They all also wore woollen socks and country-made shoes fastened with brass buckles. Over twenty of these girls in uniform were fully grown, or young women; the clothing didn't suit them and made even the most attractive ones look peculiar.I continued observing them, occasionally glancing at the teachers – none of whom I found particularly appealing; the plump one seemed a bit rough, the dark one rather harsh, the foreign teacher looked unpleasant and strange, and poor Miss Miller appeared red-faced, weathered, and exhausted – when, as my gaze moved from face to face, the entire school stood up simultaneously, as if activated by a single mechanism.What was happening? I hadn't heard any command given and felt bewildered. Before I could collect my thoughts, the classes were seated again. But since everyone's eyes were now fixed on one spot, mine followed the general direction and landed on the person who had received me the previous evening. She stood at the end of the long room by the hearth; there was a fire at both ends. She silently and seriously surveyed the two lines of girls. Miss Miller approached her, seemingly asking a question, and after getting an answer, went back to her place and announced loudly, 'Monitor of the first class, bring the globes!'While this instruction was being carried out, the lady consulted slowly moved up the room. I believe I have a strong capacity for reverence, as I still feel the sense of admiring awe with which my eyes followed her movements. Seen now in full daylight, she appeared tall, fair, and well-proportioned; brown eyes with a gentle light in their pupils, surrounded by a delicate fringe of long lashes, softened the fairness of her broad forehead; on each temple, her very dark brown hair was styled in round clusters of curls, following the fashion of that era, when smooth hair or long hanging curls were not in style; her dress, also in the current mode, was of purple cloth, adorned with a kind of Spanish-style black velvet trim; a gold watch (watches were less common then than now) gleamed at her waist. To complete the image, the reader should imagine refined features, a clear complexion though pale, and a dignified bearing and posture. With these details, one can form, as accurately as words allow, a correct picture of Miss Temple's appearance – Maria Temple, as I later saw her name written in a prayer-book I was given to carry to church.The superintendent of Lowood (as this lady was) took her seat before a pair of globes placed on a table and called the first class around her, beginning a geography lesson. The lower classes were called by their teachers; repetitions in history, grammar, and so on, continued for an hour; writing and arithmetic followed, and Miss Temple gave music lessons to some of the older girls. The duration of each lesson was timed by the clock, which eventually struck twelve. The superintendent rose. 'I have something to say to the students,' she announced.The noise of lessons ending was already beginning, but it subsided at the sound of her voice. She continued, 'This morning you had a breakfast you couldn't eat; you must be hungry. I have ordered that a lunch of bread and cheese be served to everyone.'The teachers looked at her with a kind of astonishment.'It is my responsibility,' she added to them in an explanatory tone, and immediately afterwards, she left the room.The bread and cheese was soon brought in and distributed, much to the delight and refreshment of the entire school.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Fifteen minutes went by before lessons resumed, and during this time the schoolroom was filled with noisy excitement; conversation was allowed to be louder and more free, which everyone took advantage of, mainly talking about the unappetizing breakfast, which they all heavily criticized. This was their only means of comfort. Miss Miller was the sole teacher present, surrounded by some older girls who spoke with grave and sullen expressions. I overheard someone mention Mr. Brocklehurst, which made Miss Miller shake her head disapprovingly, though she didn't try hard to stop the group's complaints—likely because she felt the same way. 

At nine o'clock, the classroom clock chimed; Miss Miller moved to the center and called for silence and order. The students quickly organized themselves and returned to near silence, quelling the earlier chaos. Other teachers soon resumed their places, but everyone seemed to be waiting for something. The eighty girls sat straight and still on benches lining the room, looking rather peculiar in their simple brown dresses, high necklines, white collars, little front-tied pockets, woolen stockings, and locally made shoes with brass buckles. Over twenty of them were actually young women, and the severe uniform seemed odd and unflattering on them all, even the prettiest.

As I studied both girls and teachers—finding the teachers rather unappealing, with one stout and rough, another dark and fierce, a foreigner harsh and odd-looking, and poor Miss Miller looking worn and weather-beaten—suddenly, everyone in the school rose at once without any apparent command. Confused, I saw they soon sat again, all eyes fixed on one spot: the woman who had greeted me the previous evening. Standing by the fire at the far end, she silently observed the students. Miss Miller approached her to ask something, and after getting an answer, returned and instructed, “Monitor of the first class, fetch the globes!”

As the globes were brought, the lady slowly walked up the room, and I was filled with a sense of respectful awe. In daylight, she appeared tall, graceful, with fair skin, brown eyes shining kindly, and finely shaped features. Her dark brown hair was styled in neat curls around her temples, fashionably dressed in purple with black velvet trim, and she wore a gold watch at her waist. To complete the picture: her elegant presence and clear, if pale, complexion captured a sense of refinement. This was Miss Temple—Maria Temple, as I later learned from a prayer book she entrusted to me for church.

Miss Temple, the superintendent, seated herself by the globes and gathered the first class around her for a geography lesson, while the other teachers led the younger classes in history, grammar, and similar subjects for an hour. Writing and arithmetic followed, and Miss Temple also gave music lessons to some of the older girls. The clock marked the end of lessons at noon. Miss Temple stood and addressed everyone, her mere voice calming the growing excitement:

“Your breakfast this morning was inedible; you must be hungry. I have ordered bread and cheese to be served to everyone.”

Her statement surprised the teachers, but she explained she took responsibility, then left. Soon, the food was served, greatly delighting and refreshing the whole school.

events.title: Garden Reflections and Jane's First Conversation with Helen Burns
detailed_summary: Following the special lunch, the students are directed to the garden for recreation, donning coarse straw bonnets and grey cloaks.
Jane observes the walled, wintry garden with its small, barren plots, finding the drizzly, foggy day inclement for outdoor activity.
While stronger girls play actively, many paler, thinner ones, some coughing, huddle in the verandah for warmth.
Jane, feeling lonely but accustomed to isolation, leans against a pillar, observing and reflecting on her displaced past and uncertain future.
She contemplates the Lowood Institution building and the inscription above a door, which includes a biblical verse from St. Matthew.
A nearby cough leads Jane to a girl intently reading a book titled 'Rasselas.'
Breaking from her usual reserve, Jane asks the girl if her book is interesting.
The girl (Helen Burns) allows Jane to examine the book, but Jane finds its serious content less appealing than its title.
Jane then inquires about the meaning of 'Lowood Institution' and the inscription.
Helen explains that Lowood is a charity school for orphans, where a nominal fee is supplemented by subscriptions from benevolent individuals.
Helen identifies Naomi Brocklehurst as the founder of the new part of the building and her son, Mr. Brocklehurst, as the current treasurer and manager who oversees everything, including provisions.
She clarifies that Miss Temple is not the owner but is accountable to Mr. Brocklehurst.
Helen names the other teachers: Miss Smith (in charge of needlework), Miss Scatcherd (history and grammar), and Madame Pierrot (French).
When Jane presses Helen about her happiness and opinions of the teachers, Helen gently curtails the questioning, stating she has answered enough and wishes to read.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The order was now given “To the garden!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But at that moment the summons sounded for dinner; all re-entered the house.

events.text_segment:
The order was now given “To the garden!” Each put on a coarse straw bonnet, with strings of coloured calico, and a cloak of grey frieze. I was similarly equipped, and, following the stream, I made my way into the open air.
The garden was a wide inclosure, surrounded with walls so high as to exclude every glimpse of prospect; a covered verandah ran down one side, and broad walks bordered a middle space divided into scores of little beds: these beds were assigned as gardens for the pupils to cultivate, and each bed had an owner. When full of flowers they would doubtless look pretty; but now, at the latter end of January, all was wintry blight and brown decay. I shuddered as I stood and looked round me: it was an inclement day for outdoor exercise; not positively rainy, but darkened by a drizzling yellow fog; all under foot was still soaking wet with the floods of yesterday. The stronger among the girls ran about and engaged in active games, but sundry pale and thin ones herded together for shelter and warmth in the verandah; and amongst these, as the dense mist penetrated to their shivering frames, I heard frequently the sound of a hollow cough.
As yet I had spoken to no one, nor did anybody seem to take notice of me; I stood lonely enough: but to that feeling of isolation I was accustomed; it did not oppress me much. I leant against a pillar of the verandah, drew my grey mantle close about me, and, trying to forget the cold which nipped me without, and the unsatisfied hunger which gnawed me within, delivered myself up to the employment of watching and thinking. My reflections were too undefined and fragmentary to merit record: I hardly yet knew where I was; Gateshead and my past life seemed floated away to an immeasurable distance; the present was vague and strange, and of the future I could form no conjecture. I looked round the convent-like garden, and then up at the house—a large building, half of which seemed grey and old, the other half quite new. The new part, containing the schoolroom and dormitory, was lit by mullioned and latticed windows, which gave it a church-like aspect; a stone tablet over the door bore this inscription:—
LOWOOD INSTITUTION.

This portion was rebuilt A.D. ——, by Naomi Brocklehurst,
of Brocklehurst Hall, in this county.
“Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.”—St. Matt. v. 16.
I read these words over and over again: I felt that an explanation belonged to them, and was unable fully to penetrate their import. I was still pondering the signification of “Institution,” and endeavouring to make out a connection between the first words and the verse of Scripture, when the sound of a cough close behind me made me turn my head. I saw a girl sitting on a stone bench near; she was bent over a book, on the perusal of which she seemed intent: from where I stood I could see the title—it was “Rasselas;” a name that struck me as strange, and consequently attractive. In turning a leaf she happened to look up, and I said to her directly—
“Is your book interesting?” I had already formed the intention of asking her to lend it to me some day.
“I like it,” she answered, after a pause of a second or two, during which she examined me.
“What is it about?” I continued. I hardly know where I found the hardihood thus to open a conversation with a stranger; the step was contrary to my nature and habits: but I think her occupation touched a chord of sympathy somewhere; for I too liked reading, though of a frivolous and childish kind; I could not digest or comprehend the serious or substantial.
“You may look at it,” replied the girl, offering me the book.
I did so; a brief examination convinced me that the contents were less taking than the title: “Rasselas” looked dull to my trifling taste; I saw nothing about fairies, nothing about genii; no bright variety seemed spread over the closely-printed pages. I returned it to her; she received it quietly, and without saying anything she was about to relapse into her former studious mood: again I ventured to disturb her—
“Can you tell me what the writing on that stone over the door means? What is Lowood Institution?”
“This house where you are come to live.”
“And why do they call it Institution? Is it in any way different from other schools?”
“It is partly a charity-school: you and I, and all the rest of us, are charity-children. I suppose you are an orphan: are not either your father or your mother dead?”
“Both died before I can remember.”
“Well, all the girls here have lost either one or both parents, and this is called an institution for educating orphans.”
“Do we pay no money? Do they keep us for nothing?”
“We pay, or our friends pay, fifteen pounds a year for each.”
“Then why do they call us charity-children?”
“Because fifteen pounds is not enough for board and teaching, and the deficiency is supplied by subscription.”
“Who subscribes?”
“Different benevolent-minded ladies and gentlemen in this neighbourhood and in London.”
“Who was Naomi Brocklehurst?”
“The lady who built the new part of this house as that tablet records, and whose son overlooks and directs everything here.”
“Why?”
“Because he is treasurer and manager of the establishment.”
“Then this house does not belong to that tall lady who wears a watch, and who said we were to have some bread and cheese?”
“To Miss Temple? Oh, no! I wish it did: she has to answer to Mr. Brocklehurst for all she does. Mr. Brocklehurst buys all our food and all our clothes.”
“Does he live here?”
“No—two miles off, at a large hall.”
“Is he a good man?”
“He is a clergyman, and is said to do a great deal of good.”
“Did you say that tall lady was called Miss Temple?”
“Yes.”
“And what are the other teachers called?”
“The one with red cheeks is called Miss Smith; she attends to the work, and cuts out—for we make our own clothes, our frocks, and pelisses, and everything; the little one with black hair is Miss Scatcherd; she teaches history and grammar, and hears the second class repetitions; and the one who wears a shawl, and has a pocket-handkerchief tied to her side with a yellow ribband, is Madame Pierrot: she comes from Lisle, in France, and teaches French.”
“Do you like the teachers?”
“Well enough.”
“Do you like the little black one, and the Madame ——?—I cannot pronounce her name as you do.”
“Miss Scatcherd is hasty—you must take care not to offend her; Madame Pierrot is not a bad sort of person.”
“But Miss Temple is the best—isn’t she?”
“Miss Temple is very good and very clever; she is above the rest, because she knows far more than they do.”
“Have you been long here?”
“Two years.”
“Are you an orphan?”
“My mother is dead.”
“Are you happy here?”
“You ask rather too many questions. I have given you answers enough for the present: now I want to read.”
But at that moment the summons sounded for dinner; all re-entered the house.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The command was then given to go to the garden. Everyone put on a rough straw bonnet with brightly coloured fabric ties and a grey woollen cloak. I dressed the same way and joined the crowd heading outside into the open air. The garden was a large enclosed area surrounded by walls so high they blocked any view beyond. A covered walkway extended along one side, and wide paths ran alongside a central area divided into many small plots. These plots were allocated for the students to tend as their own gardens. When filled with flowers, they would no doubt be attractive, but now, in late January, everything looked dead and brown from the winter. I felt a shiver standing and looking around; it was an unpleasant day for being outdoors. It wasn't actively raining, but a misty yellow fog obscured the light, and the ground was still waterlogged from the previous day's rain. The healthier girls ran around and played energetic games, while some frail and thin ones gathered in the covered verandah for protection and warmth. Among these, as the thick fog chilled their bodies, I often heard the sound of a deep cough. Until this point, I hadn't spoken to anyone, and no one seemed to notice me. I felt quite alone, but I was used to this feeling of isolation, and it didn't bother me much. I leaned against a verandah pillar, wrapped my grey cloak tightly around me, and tried to ignore the external cold that bit at me and the internal pangs of hunger. I occupied myself with observing and contemplating. My thoughts were too vague and disconnected to be worth describing; I barely grasped where I was. Gateshead and my former life seemed incredibly distant, the present felt undefined and strange, and I couldn't even guess at the future. I looked around the garden, which felt like a convent's, and then up at the house. It was a large structure, half of which appeared grey and ancient, while the other half looked brand new. The new section, containing the schoolroom and dormitory, had windows with multiple sections and lattice work, giving it a church-like appearance. A stone plaque above the door bore the inscription: LOWOOD INSTITUTION. This section was rebuilt in the year ----, by Naomi Brocklehurst, of Brocklehurst Hall, in this county. 'Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.' --St. Matt. v. 16. I read these words repeatedly, feeling they held significance I couldn't fully grasp. I was still pondering the meaning of 'Institution' and trying to connect the initial words with the Bible verse when I heard a cough nearby and turned my head. I saw a girl sitting on a stone bench nearby, hunched over a book she seemed engrossed in. From where I stood, I could see the title was 'Rasselas,' a name I found odd and therefore intriguing. As she turned a page, she happened to look up, and I immediately asked her, 'Is your book interesting?' I had already planned to ask her to lend it to me later. 'I like it,' she responded after a brief pause during which she studied me. 'What is it about?' I continued. I hardly knew how I found the courage to start a conversation with a stranger; it went against my usual cautious nature. But I think her reading struck a sympathetic chord within me, because I also enjoyed reading, though my taste was for frivolous and childish stories; I couldn't grasp or appreciate serious or complex material. 'You can look at it,' the girl replied, offering me the book. I took it, and a quick look confirmed that the content was less appealing than the title. 'Rasselas' struck my simple taste as boring; I saw no mention of fairies or genies, and the densely printed pages lacked any sense of exciting variety. I gave it back to her; she accepted it quietly and was about to return to her reading without comment. I decided to interrupt her again: 'Can you explain the writing on that stone above the door? What is Lowood Institution?' 'This is the house where you've come to live.' 'And why is it called an Institution? Is it different from other schools in some way?' 'It's partly a charity school; you, me, and all the others here are charity children. I assume you're an orphan: are either of your parents deceased?' 'Both died before I can remember.' 'Well, all the girls here have lost at least one parent, and this place is known as an institution for educating orphans.' 'So we don't pay anything? They support us for free?' 'We pay, or our guardians pay, fifteen pounds a year for each student.' 'Then why are we called charity children?' 'Because fifteen pounds isn't enough to cover board and teaching, and the shortfall is covered by donations.' 'Who donates?' 'Various kind-hearted ladies and gentlemen in this area and in London.' 'Who was Naomi Brocklehurst?' 'She was the lady who funded the construction of the new part of this building, as the tablet indicates, and whose son oversees and manages everything here.' 'Why?' 'Because he is the treasurer and manager of the establishment.' 'So this house doesn't belong to that tall lady who wears a watch, the one who said we would get bread and cheese?' 'You mean Miss Temple? Oh, no! I wish it did; she has to answer to Mr. Brocklehurst for everything she does. Mr. Brocklehurst is in charge of buying all our food and clothing.' 'Does he live here?' 'No, he lives two miles away, at a large estate.' 'Is he a good man?' 'He is a clergyman, and people say he does a great deal of good.' 'Did you say that tall lady was called Miss Temple?' 'Yes.' 'And what are the other teachers called?' 'The one with rosy cheeks is Miss Smith; she supervises the sewing and cutting, because we make our own clothes, our dresses, coats, and everything. The short one with dark hair is Miss Scatcherd; she teaches history and grammar and hears the second class recite lessons. And the one wearing a shawl with a handkerchief tied to her side with a yellow ribbon is Madame Pierrot; she is from Lisle, in France, and teaches French.' 'Do you like the teachers?' 'Well enough.' 'Do you like the short dark one, and Madame -- I can't pronounce her name like you do.' 'Miss Scatcherd is easily angered; you have to be careful not to provoke her. Madame Pierrot is a reasonably decent person.' 'But Miss Temple is the best, isn't she?' 'Miss Temple is very good and very smart; she stands out from the others because she knows much more than they do.' 'Have you been here long?' 'Two years.' 'Are you an orphan?' 'My mother is deceased.' 'Are you happy here?' 'You're asking quite a lot of questions. I've answered enough for now; I want to read.' But just then, the bell rang for dinner, and everyone went back inside the house.

The garden was a large, walled enclosure with high walls that prevented us from seeing anything outside. There was a covered walkway on one side, wide paths, and the central area was divided into many small garden plots, each cared for by a pupil. In winter, the beds looked barren and lifeless. It was a cold, gloomy day with damp ground from yesterday's rain. Some of the stronger girls played, but others who looked sickly gathered in the verandah for warmth, and I heard them coughing. I hadn't spoken to anyone and no one spoke to me, but loneliness was familiar to me and didn't trouble me. I leaned against a pillar, wrapped myself tighter in my cloak, and tried to ignore my cold and hunger by watching the others and thinking. My thoughts were vague; the past felt far away, and the present was uncertain. I looked at the building, part old and part new, with church-like windows in the new section and a stone sign reading 'Lowood Institution,' mentioning Naomi Brocklehurst and a Bible verse. I pondered its meaning when someone coughed nearby. It was a girl reading a book called 'Rasselas.' Curious, I asked if she liked her book and what it was about. She let me look at it, but I found it boring. Next, I asked her about the sign—what was Lowood Institution, was it a charity? She explained that it was a partly charitable school for orphans like us, supported by fees and donations from kind people, with Mr. Brocklehurst managing it. Miss Temple, the lady I’d seen, was in charge under Mr. Brocklehurst, and there were other teachers too: Miss Smith, Miss Scatcherd, and Madame Pierrot. She described each one. I asked if she’d been there long and if she was happy. She replied she’d been there two years, and then wanted to return to her reading, but just then, we were called in for dinner.

events.title: Helen's Public Humiliation and the Austere End to Jane's First Day
detailed_summary: The students return indoors for dinner, which consists of an unappetizing mix of potatoes and shredded meat, leaving Jane to wonder about the consistency of such poor fare.
After dinner, lessons recommence and continue until five o'clock.
The most significant event of the afternoon for Jane is witnessing Helen Burns being publicly disgraced by Miss Scatcherd during a history class.
Helen is made to stand in the middle of the large schoolroom, a punishment Jane considers deeply humiliating, especially for a girl of Helen's apparent age (thirteen or older).
To Jane's astonishment, Helen endures the punishment with remarkable composure, showing no signs of distress or shame, though she appears grave.
Jane internally questions Helen's ability to bear the humiliation so firmly, contrasting it with how she imagines her own reaction would be one of overwhelming shame.
Jane speculates that Helen's mind is elsewhere, perhaps lost in daydreams or memories, not focused on her present situation or surroundings.
At five P.M., another small meal is served: a mug of coffee and half a slice of brown bread, which Jane eats with relish despite still feeling hungry.
A brief period of recreation is followed by study, then a final serving of water and oat-cake, prayers, and finally bed.
Jane concludes her reflections on this as the end of her first day at Lowood.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The odour which now filled the refectory was scarcely more appetising than that which had regaled our nostrils at breakfast: the dinner was served in two huge tin-plated vessels, whence rose a strong steam redolent of rancid fat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such was my first day at Lowood.

events.text_segment:
The odour which now filled the refectory was scarcely more appetising than that which had regaled our nostrils at breakfast: the dinner was served in two huge tin-plated vessels, whence rose a strong steam redolent of rancid fat. I found the mess to consist of indifferent potatoes and strange shreds of rusty meat, mixed and cooked together. Of this preparation a tolerably abundant plateful was apportioned to each pupil. I ate what I could, and wondered within myself whether every day’s fare would be like this.
After dinner, we immediately adjourned to the schoolroom: lessons recommenced, and were continued till five o’clock.
The only marked event of the afternoon was, that I saw the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah dismissed in disgrace by Miss Scatcherd from a history class, and sent to stand in the middle of the large schoolroom. The punishment seemed to me in a high degree ignominious, especially for so great a girl—she looked thirteen or upwards. I expected she would show signs of great distress and shame; but to my surprise she neither wept nor blushed: composed, though grave, she stood, the central mark of all eyes. “How can she bear it so quietly—so firmly?” I asked of myself. “Were I in her place, it seems to me I should wish the earth to open and swallow me up. She looks as if she were thinking of something beyond her punishment—beyond her situation: of something not round her nor before her. I have heard of day-dreams—is she in a day-dream now? Her eyes are fixed on the floor, but I am sure they do not see it—her sight seems turned in, gone down into her heart: she is looking at what she can remember, I believe; not at what is really present. I wonder what sort of a girl she is—whether good or naughty.”
Soon after five P.M. we had another meal, consisting of a small mug of coffee, and half-a-slice of brown bread. I devoured my bread and drank my coffee with relish; but I should have been glad of as much more—I was still hungry. Half-an-hour’s recreation succeeded, then study; then the glass of water and the piece of oat-cake, prayers, and bed. Such was my first day at Lowood.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The smell in the dining hall for dinner was hardly more appealing than the one from breakfast; the meal itself was served in two large metal containers, releasing a strong steam smelling of spoiled fat. The food turned out to be a mix of unremarkable potatoes and strange, brown-tinged pieces of meat, all cooked together. Each student received a fairly large helping of this mixture. I ate what I could and wondered if this would be the typical meal every day. Immediately after dinner, we went back to the schoolroom; lessons resumed and continued until five o'clock. The only notable event that afternoon was witnessing Miss Scatcherd dismiss the girl I had spoken with on the porch from her history class in disgrace, making her stand in the center of the large schoolroom as punishment. The penalty struck me as extremely humiliating, especially for a girl her age – she appeared to be thirteen or older. I expected her to show clear signs of distress and shame, but to my surprise, she neither cried nor blushed. Calm, though serious, she stood there, the focal point of everyone's attention. 'How can she endure it so calmly, so steadfastly?' I asked myself. 'If I were in her situation, I feel I would wish the ground would open up and swallow me. She seems to be thinking about something beyond her punishment, beyond her current circumstances – something not immediately around her or in front of her. I've heard of daydreaming – is she doing that now? Her eyes are focused on the floor, but I'm certain they aren't seeing it; her gaze seems turned inward, descended into her heart. I believe she's looking at memories, not at what is actually present. I wondered what kind of girl she was – whether she was good or bad.' Shortly after 5 P.M., we had another meal, which consisted of a small cup of coffee and half a slice of brown bread. I eagerly ate my bread and drank my coffee, finding it pleasant; however, I would have liked more – I was still hungry. This was followed by half an hour of free time, then study, then a glass of water and a piece of oatcake, prayers, and finally, bed. That summarizes my first day at Lowood.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: The smell that now filled the dining hall was hardly more inviting than the one we experienced at breakfast; dinner was brought out in two large tin containers, from which rose a strong vapor filled with the scent of spoiled fat. The food turned out to be mediocre potatoes mixed with odd pieces of tough, old meat, all cooked together. Each student was given a generous portion of this dish. I ate as much as I could manage and wondered if this would be the daily meal. After dinner, we went straight back to the classroom, where lessons resumed and lasted until five o’clock. The only noteworthy event that afternoon was witnessing the girl I had spoken with earlier in the verandah being reprimanded by Miss Scatcherd during history class and made to stand in the middle of the room as punishment. This seemed an especially humiliating penalty for someone her age—she appeared to be at least thirteen. I expected her to show signs of embarrassment or sorrow, but to my surprise, she remained calm and serious, showing neither tears nor blushes as all eyes watched her. I asked myself how she could endure such a public punishment so composedly, when I thought I would want to disappear if it were me. She looked as if her thoughts were elsewhere, disconnected from her situation. I wondered if she was lost in a daydream, for her gaze was downward, but I suspected she was absorbed in her memories rather than looking at the floor. I found myself curious about her character—was she well-behaved or troublesome? Not long after five o’clock, we had another meal that consisted of a small cup of coffee and half a slice of brown bread. I ate and drank eagerly, but I would have liked more, since I was still hungry. We then had half an hour for recreation, followed by more study; after that, a glass of water and a piece of oatcake, prayers, and finally, bed. That was how my first day at Lowood ended.

events.title: Frozen Mornings and Scant Rations at Lowood
detailed_summary: The day began with the usual early start, but the severe cold had frozen the water in the washing pitchers, forcing the girls to skip washing.
A harsh north-east wind had blown all night, causing shivers even in bed and solidifying the water.
The narrator found the lengthy period of prayers and Bible reading intensely cold, feeling almost unbearable.
Breakfast finally arrived, and the porridge, unlike previous occasions, was not burnt and thus edible.
However, the portion size was disappointingly small, leaving the narrator wishing for more.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next day commenced as before, getting up and dressing by rushlight; but this morning we were obliged to dispense with the ceremony of washing; the water in the pitchers was frozen.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: How small my portion seemed! I wished it had been doubled.

events.text_segment:
The next day commenced as before, getting up and dressing by rushlight; but this morning we were obliged to dispense with the ceremony of washing; the water in the pitchers was frozen. A change had taken place in the weather the preceding evening, and a keen north-east wind, whistling through the crevices of our bedroom windows all night long, had made us shiver in our beds, and turned the contents of the ewers to ice.
Before the long hour and a half of prayers and Bible-reading was over, I felt ready to perish with cold. Breakfast-time came at last, and this morning the porridge was not burnt; the quality was eatable, the quantity small. How small my portion seemed! I wished it had been doubled.

However, this morning we were forced to skip the washing routine because the water in the pitchers had frozen solid. A change in the weather had occurred the evening before, and a sharp north-east wind, which had blown and whistled through the cracks in our bedroom windows throughout the night, had caused us to shiver in our beds and turned the contents of the washbasins to ice. Before the long ninety minutes of prayers and Bible reading concluded, I felt ready to perish from the cold. Breakfast finally arrived, and this morning the porridge was not burnt; its quality was edible, but the amount was small. My portion seemed so tiny! I wished I had received twice as much.
