I typically tried to save part of this rare treat for myself, but was always forced to share the rest. The Sunday evening routine involved reciting the Church Catechism and chapters five to seven of St. Matthew by memory, followed by listening to a long sermon read by Miss Miller, who was clearly tired as she kept stifling yawns. Frequently, several young girls, too sleepy to stay awake, would fall off their benches during the proceedings. If that happened, they were made to stand in the middle of the schoolroom until the sermon ended, though sometimes they’d be so tired they collapsed there as well, and then would be propped up on stools. I haven’t mentioned Mr. Brocklehurst’s visits yet; this was because he was away for most of my first month at the school, possibly staying longer with his friend the archdeacon, which I found a relief given my personal dread of him. However, inevitably, he did return.

events.title: Mr. Brocklehurst's Arrival and Mundane Scrutiny
detailed_summary: One afternoon, after three weeks at Lowood, while the narrator was struggling with a math problem, she saw a familiar gaunt figure pass the window.
Her instinctual recognition was confirmed when the entire school, including teachers, rose in unison, signaling Mr. Brocklehurst's entrance.
Mr. Brocklehurst, appearing even more stern and rigid than before, stood beside Miss Temple.
The narrator felt dismayed, remembering Mrs. Reed's malicious descriptions of her to him and his promise to inform the school of her supposed wickedness.
She had been constantly anxious about this promised denunciation, and now the moment seemed to have arrived.
As Mr. Brocklehurst spoke quietly to Miss Temple, the narrator listened anxiously, expecting to be condemned.

However, his initial words were about practical school matters: the quality of thread and needles he had purchased, instructions for Miss Smith about darning needles, and a complaint about the poor mending of woolen stockings he had observed on a previous visit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One afternoon (I had then been three weeks at Lowood), as I was sitting with a slate in my hand, puzzling over a sum in long division, my eyes, raised in abstraction to the window, caught sight of a figure just passing: I recognised almost instinctively that gaunt outline; and when, two minutes after, all the school, teachers included, rose en masse, it was not necessary for me to look up in order to ascertain whose entrance they thus greeted.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And, O ma’am! I wish the woollen stockings were better looked to!—when I was here last, I went into the kitchen-garden and examined the clothes drying on the line; there was a quantity of black hose in a very bad state of repair: from the size of the holes in them I was sure they had not been well mended from time to time.”

events.text_segment:
One afternoon (I had then been three weeks at Lowood), as I was sitting with a slate in my hand, puzzling over a sum in long division, my eyes, raised in abstraction to the window, caught sight of a figure just passing: I recognised almost instinctively that gaunt outline; and when, two minutes after, all the school, teachers included, rose en masse, it was not necessary for me to look up in order to ascertain whose entrance they thus greeted. A long stride measured the schoolroom, and presently beside Miss Temple, who herself had risen, stood the same black column which had frowned on me so ominously from the hearthrug of Gateshead. I now glanced sideways at this piece of architecture. Yes, I was right: it was Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever.
I had my own reasons for being dismayed at this apparition; too well I remembered the perfidious hints given by Mrs. Reed about my disposition, &c.; the promise pledged by Mr. Brocklehurst to apprise Miss Temple and the teachers of my vicious nature. All along I had been dreading the fulfilment of this promise,—I had been looking out daily for the “Coming Man,” whose information respecting my past life and conversation was to brand me as a bad child for ever: now there he was.
He stood at Miss Temple’s side; he was speaking low in her ear: I did not doubt he was making disclosures of my villainy; and I watched her eye with painful anxiety, expecting every moment to see its dark orb turn on me a glance of repugnance and contempt. I listened too; and as I happened to be seated quite at the top of the room, I caught most of what he said: its import relieved me from immediate apprehension.
“I suppose, Miss Temple, the thread I bought at Lowton will do; it struck me that it would be just of the quality for the calico chemises, and I sorted the needles to match. You may tell Miss Smith that I forgot to make a memorandum of the darning needles, but she shall have some papers sent in next week; and she is not, on any account, to give out more than one at a time to each pupil: if they have more, they are apt to be careless and lose them. And, O ma’am! I wish the woollen stockings were better looked to!—when I was here last, I went into the kitchen-garden and examined the clothes drying on the line; there was a quantity of black hose in a very bad state of repair: from the size of the holes in them I was sure they had not been well mended from time to time.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
About three weeks after I had arrived at Lowood, one afternoon, while I was struggling with a long division problem and gazing absently towards the window with my slate in hand, I saw a shape moving past. I immediately recognized that thin figure. Just two minutes later, when everyone in the school, including the teachers, stood up together, I knew exactly who had entered without needing to lift my head. The familiar tall, dark form that had looked at me so sternly from the fireplace rug at Gateshead strode across the classroom and came to a stop next to Miss Temple, who had also risen. I cautiously glanced at this imposing figure. Yes, I was correct: it was Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in an overcoat, appearing even taller, skinnier, and more rigid than I remembered.

I had good reason to be unsettled by this appearance. I remembered all too well Mrs. Reed's malicious suggestions about my personality and other matters, and Mr. Brocklehurst's promise to inform Miss Temple and the staff about my supposed poor character. I had been dreading the fulfillment of this promise constantly, expecting the arrival of the "Coming Man" daily, whose account of my past would permanently brand me as a bad child. Now, he was here.

He stood beside Miss Temple, speaking softly into her ear. I had no doubt he was sharing details of my supposed wickedness. I watched her eyes with painful anxiety, anticipating that any moment her dark gaze would turn towards me with a look of disgust and scorn. I listened as well, and since I was seated near the front of the room, I managed to catch most of what he said. The content of his words immediately eased my fears.

"I believe, Miss Temple," he began, "the thread I purchased in Lowton will be suitable. I felt it was just the right quality for the cotton undergarments, and I matched the needles accordingly. Please tell Miss Smith that I forgot to note down the darning needles, but I will send some packs next week. She is absolutely not to give out more than one needle per student at a time; if they have more, they tend to be careless and lose them. And, Madam, I really wish the woollen socks were better attended to! When I visited last, I went to the kitchen garden and inspected the clothes drying on the line. There was a significant number of black socks in very poor condition; the size of the holes made it clear they hadn't been properly mended regularly."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
One afternoon, after I had been at Lowood for three weeks, I was trying to do a long division problem on my slate. As I glanced absently out the window, I caught sight of a familiar, thin figure passing by; I recognized it immediately. A couple of minutes later, the entire school, including the teachers, stood up at once, and I didn't even have to look to know who had just arrived. The person walked with long strides across the schoolroom and soon stood next to Miss Temple, who also stood up. This was the same severe figure—the 'black column'—who had intimidated me back at Gateshead. I looked at him out of the corner of my eye and saw I was right: it was Mr. Brocklehurst, dressed in his overcoat, appearing even taller, thinner, and more stern than before.

His appearance filled me with dread, because I remembered all too well what Mrs. Reed had said about my character and how Mr. Brocklehurst had promised her to warn the teachers about my supposed faults. I had been anxious ever since, expecting this moment when my reputation would be ruined by his report, and now here he was.

He began speaking quietly to Miss Temple, and I was certain he was telling her about my alleged misbehavior. I watched her nervously, waiting to see if she would look at me with disgust. From where I sat, I could hear much of what he said, and fortunately, it turned out to be harmless for now. He was only discussing practical matters: he thought some thread he had bought would be good for sewing the girls’ underclothes, and mentioned he’d send more darning needles next week, insisting that only one needle be issued per pupil to avoid loss. He also expressed concern about the poor condition of the woolen stockings, complaining that the girls were careless and the repairs weren’t being done regularly.

events.title: Mr. Brocklehurst's Doctrine of Deprivation and Miss Temple's Stoicism
detailed_summary: Miss Temple assured Mr. Brocklehurst that his directives regarding school supplies would be followed.
Mr. Brocklehurst then criticized the provision of two clean tuckers a week to some girls, though Miss Temple explained it was a special exception for an outing.
He further questioned Miss Temple about an unauthorized lunch of bread and cheese served twice, for which Miss Temple took responsibility, explaining the breakfast had been inedible.
Mr. Brocklehurst delivered a lengthy reprimand, stating his educational philosophy was to make the girls hardy and self-denying, not accustomed to luxury.

He argued that spoiled meals should be seen as opportunities for spiritual growth and fortitude, referencing the sufferings of early Christians and martyrs, and Christ's teachings about spiritual nourishment over physical.
He accused Miss Temple of nurturing the girls' 'vile bodies' while starving their 'immortal souls' by providing comfort food.
During his speech, Miss Temple, initially looking down, gazed forward with an increasingly cold, marble-like expression, her features hardening into severe immobility.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He paused.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Miss Temple had looked down when he first began to speak to her; but she now gazed straight before her, and her face, naturally pale as marble, appeared to be assuming also the coldness and fixity of that material; especially her mouth, closed as if it would have required a sculptor’s chisel to open it, and her brow settled gradually into petrified severity.

events.text_segment:
He paused.
“Your directions shall be attended to, sir,” said Miss Temple.
“And, ma’am,” he continued, “the laundress tells me some of the girls have two clean tuckers in the week: it is too much; the rules limit them to one.”
“I think I can explain that circumstance, sir. Agnes and Catherine Johnstone were invited to take tea with some friends at Lowton last Thursday, and I gave them leave to put on clean tuckers for the occasion.”
Mr. Brocklehurst nodded.
“Well, for once it may pass; but please not to let the circumstance occur too often. And there is another thing which surprised me; I find, in settling accounts with the housekeeper, that a lunch, consisting of bread and cheese, has twice been served out to the girls during the past fortnight. How is this? I looked over the regulations, and I find no such meal as lunch mentioned. Who introduced this innovation? and by what authority?”
“I must be responsible for the circumstance, sir,” replied Miss Temple: “the breakfast was so ill prepared that the pupils could not possibly eat it; and I dared not allow them to remain fasting till dinner-time.”
“Madam, allow me an instant. You are aware that my plan in bringing up these girls is, not to accustom them to habits of luxury and indulgence, but to render them hardy, patient, self-denying. Should any little accidental disappointment of the appetite occur, such as the spoiling of a meal, the under or the over dressing of a dish, the incident ought not to be neutralised by replacing with something more delicate the comfort lost, thus pampering the body and obviating the aim of this institution; it ought to be improved to the spiritual edification of the pupils, by encouraging them to evince fortitude under the temporary privation. A brief address on those occasions would not be mistimed, wherein a judicious instructor would take the opportunity of referring to the sufferings of the primitive Christians; to the torments of martyrs; to the exhortations of our blessed Lord Himself, calling upon His disciples to take up their cross and follow Him; to His warnings that man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God; to His divine consolations, ‘If ye suffer hunger or thirst for My sake, happy are ye.’ Oh, madam, when you put bread and cheese, instead of burnt porridge, into these children’s mouths, you may indeed feed their vile bodies, but you little think how you starve their immortal souls!”
Mr. Brocklehurst again paused—perhaps overcome by his feelings. Miss Temple had looked down when he first began to speak to her; but she now gazed straight before her, and her face, naturally pale as marble, appeared to be assuming also the coldness and fixity of that material; especially her mouth, closed as if it would have required a sculptor’s chisel to open it, and her brow settled gradually into petrified severity.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: He stopped speaking. Miss Temple responded, assuring him, "Your instructions will be followed, sir." He went on, addressing her, "Also, ma'am, the laundress informed me that a few girls are using two clean neck scarves each week. This is excessive; the regulations permit only one." "I believe I can clarify that matter, sir," Miss Temple said. "Agnes and Catherine Johnstone had an invitation to have tea with some acquaintances in Lowton last Thursday, and I allowed them to wear clean neck scarves for that specific event." Mr. Brocklehurst gave a nod. "Alright, this one instance can be overlooked," he conceded, "but please ensure this situation doesn't happen frequently. Furthermore, something else caught me by surprise," he added. "While reviewing the housekeeper's accounts, I discovered that a meal of bread and cheese was provided to the girls on two occasions over the last two weeks. Why is this? I examined the school's rules and found no mention of a meal called lunch. Who initiated this change, and by whose permission?" "I must take responsibility for that situation, sir," Miss Temple replied. "The morning meal was so poorly prepared that the students were unable to eat it, and I couldn't bring myself to let them go without food until the evening meal." "Madam, permit me a moment," he began. "You understand that my goal in educating these girls is not to get them used to comforts and excess, but rather to make them resilient, enduring, and able to deny themselves. If they experience any minor, unplanned food issue, like a ruined meal or a dish that's undercooked or overcooked, this problem shouldn't be fixed by giving them something nicer to make up for the discomfort, which would spoil their bodies and undermine the school's purpose. Instead, it should be used as an opportunity for the students' spiritual growth by urging them to show strength during the temporary lack. A short speech on such occasions would be fitting, where a wise teacher could reference the hardships faced by early Christians, the agony endured by martyrs, the calls from our Lord Himself for His followers to bear their burdens and accompany Him, His caution that people need more than just food to survive, but also guidance from God, and His comforting words, 'Blessed are you if you suffer hunger or thirst because of Me.' Oh, madam, when you provide bread and cheese to these children instead of inedible porridge, you might satisfy their earthly bodies, but you barely consider how you are depriving their eternal souls!" Mr. Brocklehurst stopped speaking once more, possibly emotional. Miss Temple had lowered her gaze when he first started addressing her. However, she now stared directly ahead, and her face, which was naturally as pale as marble, seemed to be taking on the same coldness and stillness as the stone. This was particularly true of her mouth, which was shut tight as if it needed a sculptor's tool to pry it open, and her forehead slowly became fixed in a rigid, stone-like sternness.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He stopped speaking for a moment. 

Miss Temple responded, "Your instructions will be followed, sir."

Mr. Brocklehurst continued, "I've been told by the laundress that some girls are receiving two clean collars per week, which is more than the regulations permit—they are allowed only one."

Miss Temple explained, "I can clarify that, sir. Agnes and Catherine Johnstone were asked to tea by friends in Lowton last Thursday, so I allowed them to wear clean collars for the occasion."

Mr. Brocklehurst nodded and said, "I'll let it go this time, but please make sure it doesn't happen often. Another thing surprised me: when settling accounts, I noticed that bread and cheese have been given as lunch to the girls twice in the past two weeks. According to the rules, lunch is not an approved meal. Who authorized this, and on what grounds?"

Miss Temple replied, "I take responsibility, sir. The breakfast was so badly made that the girls couldn't eat it, and I couldn't allow them to go hungry until dinner."

Mr. Brocklehurst interrupted her: "Madam, my purpose in educating these girls is not to let them become accustomed to comfort and luxury, but to teach them to be tough, patient, and self-denying. If they suffer a minor disappointment with their food, such as a spoiled meal, we shouldn't make up for it by giving them something nicer, which only indulges them and defeats the purpose of this school. Instead, such moments should be used for spiritual growth, encouraging them to show endurance in the face of temporary lack. A short talk in which the teacher refers to the suffering of early Christians, the martyrdom of saints, or the teachings of our Lord—who advised His followers to bear their burdens, reminded them that people do not live on bread alone, and promised blessings to those who starve for His sake—would be much more appropriate. By giving these girls bread and cheese instead of burned porridge, you feed their physical needs but neglect their spiritual well-being."

Mr. Brocklehurst paused again, perhaps moved by his own emotions. Miss Temple, who had looked down at first, now stared straight ahead. Her face, usually pale, had become cold and rigid like marble—her mouth pressed tightly closed and her brow settling into stern stillness.

events.title: The Controversy Over Curly Hair and Austere Grooming Standards
detailed_summary: While surveying the school, Mr. Brocklehurst's attention was suddenly caught by a girl with curly red hair.
He pointed her out to Miss Temple, demanding to know why she had curled hair, calling it a defiance of the institution's principles and an open conformity to worldly fashion.
Miss Temple quietly explained that Julia Severn's hair curled naturally.
Mr. Brocklehurst dismissed this, asserting that nature should not be conformed to and that he desired the girls to be 'children of Grace' with plainly arranged hair.
He ordered that Julia's hair be cut off entirely and stated he would send a barber the next day.
He then identified other girls with 'too much' hair, instructing a tall girl to turn around and ordering the entire first form to face the wall.
Miss Temple subtly concealed a smile before giving the order, and the narrator observed the girls' disapproving expressions, noting Mr. Brocklehurst's ignorance of their inner defiance.
After scrutinizing the girls, Mr. Brocklehurst pronounced that all their 'top-knots' must be removed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meantime, Mr. Brocklehurst, standing on the hearth with his hands behind his back, majestically surveyed the whole school.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All those top-knots must be cut off.”

events.text_segment:
Meantime, Mr. Brocklehurst, standing on the hearth with his hands behind his back, majestically surveyed the whole school. Suddenly his eye gave a blink, as if it had met something that either dazzled or shocked its pupil; turning, he said in more rapid accents than he had hitherto used—
“Miss Temple, Miss Temple, what—what is that girl with curled hair? Red hair, ma’am, curled—curled all over?” And extending his cane he pointed to the awful object, his hand shaking as he did so.
“It is Julia Severn,” replied Miss Temple, very quietly.
“Julia Severn, ma’am! And why has she, or any other, curled hair? Why, in defiance of every precept and principle of this house, does she conform to the world so openly—here in an evangelical, charitable establishment—as to wear her hair one mass of curls?”
“Julia’s hair curls naturally,” returned Miss Temple, still more quietly.
“Naturally! Yes, but we are not to conform to nature; I wish these girls to be the children of Grace: and why that abundance? I have again and again intimated that I desire the hair to be arranged closely, modestly, plainly. Miss Temple, that girl’s hair must be cut off entirely; I will send a barber to-morrow: and I see others who have far too much of the excrescence—that tall girl, tell her to turn round. Tell all the first form to rise up and direct their faces to the wall.”
Miss Temple passed her handkerchief over her lips, as if to smooth away the involuntary smile that curled them; she gave the order, however, and when the first class could take in what was required of them, they obeyed. Leaning a little back on my bench, I could see the looks and grimaces with which they commented on this manoeuvre: it was a pity Mr. Brocklehurst could not see them too; he would perhaps have felt that, whatever he might do with the outside of the cup and platter, the inside was further beyond his interference than he imagined.
He scrutinised the reverse of these living medals some five minutes, then pronounced sentence. These words fell like the knell of doom—
“All those top-knots must be cut off.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: From the fireplace, Mr. Brocklehurst stood with his hands behind his back, grandly observing the entire school. Suddenly, his gaze seemed startled, as if seeing something either astonishing or offensive. He quickly turned and, speaking faster than before, asked, 'Miss Temple, Miss Temple, who is that girl with curly hair? Red hair, ma'am, curled - curled all over?' He pointed at the girl with his shaking cane, referring to her as an 'awful object'. Miss Temple calmly replied, 'It is Julia Severn.' 'Julia Severn, ma'am!' Brocklehurst exclaimed. 'And why does she, or anyone else, have curled hair? How can she so openly imitate the world here, in a charitable religious school, by having such a mass of curls, going against all the rules and beliefs of this place?' Miss Temple, even more quietly, responded, 'Julia's hair curls naturally.' 'Naturally!' he retorted. 'Yes, but we must not follow nature; I want these girls to be spiritually pure. And why such a large amount? I have repeatedly stated that I want hair styled neatly, modestly, simply. Miss Temple, that girl's hair must be completely cut off; I will send a barber tomorrow. And I see others with far too much of this unnecessary growth - that tall girl, tell her to turn around. Tell the entire first form to stand up and face the wall.' Miss Temple discreetly wiped her lips with her handkerchief, as if to hide a slight, unwilling smile. However, she gave the command, and when the first class understood what was required, they complied. Leaning back slightly on my bench, I observed their expressions and gestures as they reacted to this order. It was unfortunate Mr. Brocklehurst couldn't see them too; he might have realised that, no matter what he did to their outward appearance, their inner thoughts were much harder for him to influence than he imagined. He closely examined the turned backs of these living 'medals' for about five minutes before declaring his judgment. These words sounded ominous, like a death knell: 'All those elaborate hairstyles must be cut off.'
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
While Mr. Brocklehurst stood by the fireplace with his hands clasped behind him, he surveyed the room authoritatively. Suddenly, he was startled by something his gaze landed on, and he spoke more quickly than before: “Miss Temple, who is that girl with curled hair? Red and full of curls?” he asked, pointing his cane while his hand trembled. Miss Temple calmly answered, “She is Julia Severn.” 

Mr. Brocklehurst exclaimed, “Julia Severn! Why does she, or anyone, have curled hair? Why does she flaunt such a worldly style in this godly, charitable school by wearing her hair in curls?” Miss Temple explained, “Julia’s hair curls naturally.” 

He retorted, “Naturally! But we’re not to follow nature; I want the girls here to be models of Grace. I have often said the hair should be simple and modest. That girl’s hair must be cut off; I’ll arrange for a barber tomorrow. Others also have excessive hair—like that tall girl. Make her turn around. All of the first group, stand up and face the wall.” Suppressing a smile, Miss Temple gave the instruction, and once the first class understood, they complied. Leaning back, I noticed their expressions and silent reactions; it was unfortunate Mr. Brocklehurst missed this, as he might have realized that outward discipline couldn’t reach their inner thoughts. After a period of inspecting the girls from behind, he gave his verdict: “All those hair buns must be cut off.”

events.title: Hypocrisy Unveiled: The Arrival of the Lavishly Dressed Brocklehurst Women
detailed_summary: Miss Temple appeared to want to object to the hair-cutting decree.

Mr. Brocklehurst continued, asserting he served a master whose kingdom was not of this world and that his mission was to suppress fleshly desires in the girls, teaching them modesty rather than vanity like braided hair.
His lecture was interrupted by the entrance of three lavishly dressed ladies: his wife and two daughters.

Their attire, featuring velvet, silk, furs, fashionable hats with ostrich plumes, and elaborately curled hair (including a false front of curls on the elder Mrs. Brocklehurst), stood in stark contrast to his sermon on simplicity and austerity.
Miss Temple received the Brocklehurst ladies respectfully and seated them in places of honor.
It was revealed they had accompanied Mr. Brocklehurst and had been inspecting the upstairs rooms while he dealt with staff.
The Brocklehurst women then began to criticize Miss Smith regarding the linen and dormitories, but the narrator's attention was diverted by other concerns.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They now proceeded to address divers remarks and reproofs to Miss Smith, who was charged with the care of the linen and the inspection of the dormitories: but I had no time to listen to what they said; other matters called off and enchanted my attention.

events.text_segment:
Miss Temple seemed to remonstrate.
“Madam,” he pursued, “I have a Master to serve whose kingdom is not of this world: my mission is to mortify in these girls the lusts of the flesh; to teach them to clothe themselves with shame-facedness and sobriety, not with braided hair and costly apparel; and each of the young persons before us has a string of hair twisted in plaits which vanity itself might have woven; these, I repeat, must be cut off; think of the time wasted, of—”
Mr. Brocklehurst was here interrupted: three other visitors, ladies, now entered the room. They ought to have come a little sooner to have heard his lecture on dress, for they were splendidly attired in velvet, silk, and furs. The two younger of the trio (fine girls of sixteen and seventeen) had grey beaver hats, then in fashion, shaded with ostrich plumes, and from under the brim of this graceful head-dress fell a profusion of light tresses, elaborately curled; the elder lady was enveloped in a costly velvet shawl, trimmed with ermine, and she wore a false front of French curls.
These ladies were deferentially received by Miss Temple, as Mrs. and the Misses Brocklehurst, and conducted to seats of honour at the top of the room. It seems they had come in the carriage with their reverend relative, and had been conducting a rummaging scrutiny of the room upstairs, while he transacted business with the housekeeper, questioned the laundress, and lectured the superintendent. They now proceeded to address divers remarks and reproofs to Miss Smith, who was charged with the care of the linen and the inspection of the dormitories: but I had no time to listen to what they said; other matters called off and enchanted my attention.

events.title: Jane's Accidental Exposure and Public Denunciation as a Liar
detailed_summary: While Mr. Brocklehurst and Miss Temple were conversing, the narrator had been trying to avoid notice by hiding her face with her slate.
Her attempt failed when the slate slipped from her hand and crashed loudly, drawing everyone's attention to her.
Mr. Brocklehurst immediately identified her as a careless girl and the new pupil, stating he had something to say about her.
He loudly commanded the child who broke the slate to come forward.
Paralyzed by fear, the narrator was pushed forward by two older girls and gently guided to Mr. Brocklehurst's feet by Miss Temple, who whispered that it was an accident and she wouldn't be punished.
This kindness felt like a betrayal to the narrator, who anticipated being exposed as a hypocrite due to Mrs. Reed's slanders, fueling her anger.
Mr. Brocklehurst ordered a high stool to be brought, and the narrator was placed upon it, elevated to his eye level, aware of his proximity and the opulent attire of his family below her.
After clearing his throat, Mr. Brocklehurst addressed his family, teachers, and students, drawing their attention to the narrator.
He acknowledged her youth and ordinary appearance, then dramatically declared that, despite this, the 'Evil One' had found a servant in her.
Following a pause, he continued his denunciation, calling her a 'little castaway' and an 'alien' not part of the true flock.
He instructed everyone to shun her, avoid her company, and exclude her from their activities.
He charged the teachers to watch her closely, scrutinize her words and actions, and punish her physically to save her soul, if possible.
He culminated his speech by dramatically declaring that the narrator, a child from a Christian land, was 'a liar!'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hitherto, while gathering up the discourse of Mr. Brocklehurst and Miss Temple, I had not, at the same time, neglected precautions to secure my personal safety; which I thought would be effected, if I could only elude observation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Teachers, you must watch her: keep your eyes on her movements, weigh well her words, scrutinise her actions, punish her body to save her soul: if, indeed, such salvation be possible, for (my tongue falters while I tell it) this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut—this girl is—a liar!”

events.text_segment:
Hitherto, while gathering up the discourse of Mr. Brocklehurst and Miss Temple, I had not, at the same time, neglected precautions to secure my personal safety; which I thought would be effected, if I could only elude observation. To this end, I had sat well back on the form, and while seeming to be busy with my sum, had held my slate in such a manner as to conceal my face: I might have escaped notice, had not my treacherous slate somehow happened to slip from my hand, and falling with an obtrusive crash, directly drawn every eye upon me; I knew it was all over now, and, as I stooped to pick up the two fragments of slate, I rallied my forces for the worst. It came.
“A careless girl!” said Mr. Brocklehurst, and immediately after—“It is the new pupil, I perceive.” And before I could draw breath, “I must not forget I have a word to say respecting her.” Then aloud: how loud it seemed to me! “Let the child who broke her slate come forward!”
Of my own accord I could not have stirred; I was paralysed: but the two great girls who sat on each side of me, set me on my legs and pushed me towards the dread judge, and then Miss Temple gently assisted me to his very feet, and I caught her whispered counsel—
“Don’t be afraid, Jane, I saw it was an accident; you shall not be punished.”
The kind whisper went to my heart like a dagger.
“Another minute, and she will despise me for a hypocrite,” thought I; and an impulse of fury against Reed, Brocklehurst, and Co. bounded in my pulses at the conviction. I was no Helen Burns.
“Fetch that stool,” said Mr. Brocklehurst, pointing to a very high one from which a monitor had just risen: it was brought.
“Place the child upon it.”
And I was placed there, by whom I don’t know: I was in no condition to note particulars; I was only aware that they had hoisted me up to the height of Mr. Brocklehurst’s nose, that he was within a yard of me, and that a spread of shot orange and purple silk pelisses and a cloud of silvery plumage extended and waved below me.
Mr. Brocklehurst hemmed.
“Ladies,” said he, turning to his family, “Miss Temple, teachers, and children, you all see this girl?”
Of course they did; for I felt their eyes directed like burning-glasses against my scorched skin.
“You see she is yet young; you observe she possesses the ordinary form of childhood; God has graciously given her the shape that He has given to all of us; no signal deformity points her out as a marked character. Who would think that the Evil One had already found a servant and agent in her? Yet such, I grieve to say, is the case.”
A pause—in which I began to steady the palsy of my nerves, and to feel that the Rubicon was passed; and that the trial, no longer to be shirked, must be firmly sustained.
“My dear children,” pursued the black marble clergyman, with pathos, “this is a sad, a melancholy occasion; for it becomes my duty to warn you, that this girl, who might be one of God’s own lambs, is a little castaway: not a member of the true flock, but evidently an interloper and an alien. You must be on your guard against her; you must shun her example; if necessary, avoid her company, exclude her from your sports, and shut her out from your converse. Teachers, you must watch her: keep your eyes on her movements, weigh well her words, scrutinise her actions, punish her body to save her soul: if, indeed, such salvation be possible, for (my tongue falters while I tell it) this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut—this girl is—a liar!”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Previously, while I was trying to absorb what Mr. Brocklehurst and Miss Temple were saying, I was also taking steps to ensure my own safety, which I believed depended on remaining unnoticed. To achieve this, I had positioned myself far back on the bench and, pretending to be occupied with my arithmetic problem, held my slate in front of my face. I might have successfully avoided detection, had my unreliable slate not somehow slipped from my grasp. It fell with a noticeable crash, instantly drawing everyone's attention to me. I knew then that my efforts to hide had failed. As I bent to collect the broken pieces, I braced myself for the worst. It arrived. “A careless girl!” Mr. Brocklehurst exclaimed, adding immediately, “Ah, I see it is the new pupil.” Before I could even catch my breath, he continued, “I must remember I have something to say concerning her.” Then, addressing the room loudly – it seemed deafening to me! – he commanded, “Let the child who broke her slate come forward!” I was too petrified to move on my own. I was paralyzed. However, the two taller girls sitting beside me lifted me to my feet and gently pushed me towards the fearsome judge. Miss Temple then softly guided me the rest of the way to where he stood, and I caught her quiet advice: “Don’t be afraid, Jane, I saw it was an accident; you will not be punished.” Her kind whisper felt like a sharp jab to my heart. I thought, “In just another moment, she will see me as a hypocrite and despise me.” A wave of anger towards Reed, Brocklehurst, and others surged through me with this realization. I was certainly not like Helen Burns. Mr. Brocklehurst pointed to a very tall stool that a monitor had just left and ordered, “Fetch that stool.” It was brought. “Place the child upon it.” I was lifted onto it by someone; I wasn't in a state to notice who. I was only aware that I had been hoisted up to approximately the level of Mr. Brocklehurst’s nose, that he was only about a yard away, and that a wide display of shot orange and purple silk cloaks and a mass of shimmering feathery hats belonging to his family spread out and fluttered below me. Mr. Brocklehurst cleared his throat. Turning to his family, Miss Temple, the teachers, and the students, he announced, “Ladies, Miss Temple, teachers, and children, you all see this girl?” Of course they did; I felt their eyes focused on me like magnifying glasses burning my skin. He continued, “You see she is still young; you observe she has the typical appearance of a child; God has kindly given her the form He gives to everyone; no obvious physical flaw marks her as peculiar. Who would imagine that the Devil has already made her his tool and agent? Yet, I regret to state, this is the case.” There was a pause, during which I began to calm my trembling nerves and accept that there was no turning back; the difficult situation had to be endured firmly. “My dear children,” the stern, dark-clad clergyman went on sadly, “this is a somber, a mournful occasion; for it is now my duty to warn you that this girl, who could potentially be one of God’s innocent lambs, is a lost soul. She is not a true member of the flock, but clearly an intruder and an outsider. You must be wary of her; you must avoid following her bad example; if needed, stay away from her, exclude her from your games, and cease conversing with her. Teachers, you must monitor her; keep a close watch on her actions, carefully consider her words, scrutinize everything she does, and discipline her physically to save her soul – if, indeed, such salvation is even possible for her, because (my voice trembles as I tell you) this girl, this child, born in a Christian country, is worse than many young pagans who pray to Brahma and kneel before Juggernaut – this girl is... a liar!”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Up until now, as I listened to Mr. Brocklehurst and Miss Temple speak, I was careful to protect myself by trying to avoid being noticed. To do this, I sat quietly at the back of the bench and pretended to concentrate on my arithmetic, holding my slate so that my face was hidden. I might have succeeded in going unnoticed if my slate hadn’t slipped from my hands, falling loudly to the floor and drawing everyone’s attention to me. I realized then that it was hopeless. As I bent down to pick up the pieces of my broken slate, I prepared myself for whatever might come next. It happened at once. 

“Such carelessness!” exclaimed Mr. Brocklehurst, and then added, “Ah, it’s the new student.” Without giving me a chance to recover, he continued, “I have something to say about her.” Then, in a voice that sounded booming to my ears, he said, “Will the girl who broke her slate come forward?”

I was frozen with fear and couldn’t move on my own, but the two older girls sitting beside me helped me stand and pushed me toward Mr. Brocklehurst. Miss Temple kindly guided me the rest of the way to him and whispered, “Don’t worry, Jane, I saw it was an accident; you won’t be punished.” The kindness in her words pierced me deeply. I thought, “In a moment, she’ll despise me for a hypocrite,” and I felt a surge of anger toward Mrs. Reed, Mr. Brocklehurst, and everyone else responsible for my distress. I was not like Helen Burns.

Mr. Brocklehurst instructed, “Bring that stool,” pointing to a tall one from which a student had just stood up. It was brought over. “Have the girl stand on it.” I was lifted onto it—I can’t recall by whom—as I was in such shock I couldn’t pay attention to details. I was now raised to the level of Mr. Brocklehurst’s face, with many well-dressed ladies and girls looking up at me from below.

Mr. Brocklehurst cleared his throat. “Ladies,” he addressed his family, “Miss Temple, staff, and pupils, do you see this girl?” Of course they did; I could feel everyone’s eyes burning into me.

“You can see she is just a child like the rest of you, with no unusual deformity. Yet, sadly, I must inform you that she is already under the influence of evil.”

He paused, and I started to regain my composure, realizing I had to face what would happen next with determination.

“My dear children,” continued Mr. Brocklehurst solemnly, “this is truly sad, for I must caution you that this girl, who might have been an innocent, is nonetheless to be considered a castaway—not one of the good flock but an outsider. You must beware of her and avoid following her example—even keep away from her, not including her in your activities or conversations. Teachers, closely monitor her behavior and discipline her in the hope that her soul might be saved, although I doubt it. For, though she comes from a Christian country—worse than a heathen child—this girl is, I regret to say, a liar!”

events.title: Aftermath of Denunciation, Mr. Brocklehurst's Departure, and Helen Burns's Silent Support
detailed_summary: During a ten-minute pause after the accusation, the narrator observed the Brocklehurst women dabbing their eyes with handkerchiefs in a display of feigned shock.

Mr. Brocklehurst resumed, claiming his information came from Jane's 'benefactress' (Mrs. Reed), whom he praised as pious and charitable, alleging Jane repaid this kindness with terrible ingratitude, forcing Mrs. Reed to send her to Lowood for reformation.
Concluding his speech, Mr. Brocklehurst instructed his family, they rose, bowed to Miss Temple, and departed.
As he left, he ordered that Jane remain on the stool for another half-hour and that no one speak to her for the rest of the day.
Jane felt utterly exposed and shamed, but as she struggled with overwhelming emotions, Helen Burns walked past.
Helen lifted her eyes to Jane, and the look imparted a strange, uplifting sensation, giving Jane strength as if from a martyr or hero.
Buoyed by this silent support, Jane mastered her hysteria, lifted her head, and stood firmly.
Helen then briefly interacted with Miss Smith about her work, was reprimanded, returned to her seat, and smiled at Jane again as she passed.
The narrator reflects on Helen's smile, recognizing it as an expression of fine intellect and true courage, a light that illuminated her features.

She notes the irony that Helen, who possessed such inner strength and angelic qualities, wore a badge for untidiness and had recently been condemned to a bread-and-water dinner by Miss Scatcherd for a blotted exercise, highlighting how some people only perceive minor flaws and miss true brilliance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now came a pause of ten minutes, during which I, by this time in perfect possession of my wits, observed all the female Brocklehursts produce their pocket-handkerchiefs and apply them to their optics, while the elderly lady swayed herself to and fro, and the two younger ones whispered, “How shocking!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such is the imperfect nature of man! such spots are there on the disc of the clearest planet; and eyes like Miss Scatcherd’s can only see those minute defects, and are blind to the full brightness of the orb.

events.text_segment:
Now came a pause of ten minutes, during which I, by this time in perfect possession of my wits, observed all the female Brocklehursts produce their pocket-handkerchiefs and apply them to their optics, while the elderly lady swayed herself to and fro, and the two younger ones whispered, “How shocking!”
Mr. Brocklehurst resumed.
“This I learned from her benefactress; from the pious and charitable lady who adopted her in her orphan state, reared her as her own daughter, and whose kindness, whose generosity the unhappy girl repaid by an ingratitude so bad, so dreadful, that at last her excellent patroness was obliged to separate her from her own young ones, fearful lest her vicious example should contaminate their purity: she has sent her here to be healed, even as the Jews of old sent their diseased to the troubled pool of Bethesda; and, teachers, superintendent, I beg of you not to allow the waters to stagnate round her.”
With this sublime conclusion, Mr. Brocklehurst adjusted the top button of his surtout, muttered something to his family, who rose, bowed to Miss Temple, and then all the great people sailed in state from the room. Turning at the door, my judge said—
“Let her stand half-an-hour longer on that stool, and let no one speak to her during the remainder of the day.”
There was I, then, mounted aloft; I, who had said I could not bear the shame of standing on my natural feet in the middle of the room, was now exposed to general view on a pedestal of infamy. What my sensations were, no language can describe; but just as they all rose, stifling my breath and constricting my throat, a girl came up and passed me: in passing, she lifted her eyes. What a strange light inspired them! What an extraordinary sensation that ray sent through me! How the new feeling bore me up! It was as if a martyr, a hero, had passed a slave or victim, and imparted strength in the transit. I mastered the rising hysteria, lifted up my head, and took a firm stand on the stool. Helen Burns asked some slight question about her work of Miss Smith, was chidden for the triviality of the inquiry, returned to her place, and smiled at me as she again went by. What a smile! I remember it now, and I know that it was the effluence of fine intellect, of true courage; it lit up her marked lineaments, her thin face, her sunken grey eye, like a reflection from the aspect of an angel. Yet at that moment Helen Burns wore on her arm “the untidy badge;” scarcely an hour ago I had heard her condemned by Miss Scatcherd to a dinner of bread and water on the morrow because she had blotted an exercise in copying it out. Such is the imperfect nature of man! such spots are there on the disc of the clearest planet; and eyes like Miss Scatcherd’s can only see those minute defects, and are blind to the full brightness of the orb.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: There was a ten-minute break during which I, now fully alert, watched all the Brocklehurst women pull out their handkerchiefs and dab their eyes, while the older woman rocked back and forth and the two younger ones whispered in shock. Mr. Brocklehurst then continued, explaining that he had learned this information from her former guardian, a devout and kind woman who had adopted Jane when she was an orphan and raised her as her own child. However, the unhappy girl had repaid this kindness and generosity with such profound ingratitude that her excellent patroness was eventually forced to separate her from her own young children, fearing Jane's wicked influence would corrupt them. She sent Jane here to be reformed, much like the ancient Jews sent their sick to the healing pool of Bethesda; and Mr. Brocklehurst implored the teachers and superintendent not to let her remain untouched by the school's influence. After this grand declaration, Mr. Brocklehurst adjusted his coat button, murmured something to his family, who stood up, bowed to Miss Temple, and then the important group swept out of the room with dignity. As he turned at the door, my judge announced, 'Let her remain on that stool for another half hour, and no one is to speak to her for the rest of the day.' So there I stood, elevated for all to see; I, who had claimed I couldn't bear the shame of merely standing on the floor in the center of the room, was now publicly exposed on a platform of disgrace. My feelings at that moment are impossible to describe; but just as they overwhelmed me, stifling my breath and tightening my throat, a girl approached and walked past me. As she went by, she raised her eyes and looked at me. What a peculiar light shone in them! What an extraordinary sensation that look sent through me! How this new feeling lifted my spirits! It felt as though a brave hero or martyr had passed a slave or victim, giving strength during the passage. I managed to control my rising panic, lifted my head, and stood firmly on the stool. Helen Burns asked Miss Smith a trivial question about her work, was scolded for the minor inquiry, returned to her spot, and smiled at me again as she passed. What a smile! I remember it still, and I know it radiated from a brilliant mind and true courage; it illuminated her distinct features, her thin face, and her deep-set grey eye, like the reflection of an angel's face. Yet, at that very moment, Helen Burns wore the 'untidy badge' on her arm; barely an hour earlier, I had heard Miss Scatcherd condemn her to a dinner of bread and water the next day because she had smeared a page while copying an exercise. This illustrates the flawed nature of humanity; such imperfections exist even on the brightest stars, and eyes like Miss Scatcherd’s can only perceive these tiny defects, blind to the star's complete radiance.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After a ten-minute silence, during which I regained my composure, I noticed all the female Brocklehursts pulling out their handkerchiefs to dab at their eyes, while the older lady rocked herself, and the two younger women whispered to each other how appalling everything was. Then Mr. Brocklehurst began to speak again. He explained that my benefactress— the charitable woman who had raised me as her own child after I was orphaned— had been forced to separate me from her family because my ingratitude was so intense and awful that she feared I would corrupt her children's goodness. She had sent me to this school to be reformed, just like in the Bible when the sick were brought to the healing pool of Bethesda; he urged the teachers not to let my presence ruin the school. Concluding his speech, Mr. Brocklehurst fastened his coat, murmured to his family, and they all grandly left the room after bowing to Miss Temple. At the door, Mr. Brocklehurst added that I should remain standing on the stool for another half an hour and that no one should speak to me for the rest of the day.

I was left on display, elevated on a stool, feeling humiliated and exposed. My feelings were indescribable, and as overwhelming emotion threatened to overtake me, a girl passed by, looking at me with eyes full of a strange, inspiring light. That gaze gave me strength, like a hero giving courage to a victim. I controlled my emotions, held my head high, and resolved to stand firm. Helen Burns then asked Miss Smith a small question about her work, was gently rebuked for it, returned to her seat, and smiled at me—a smile I will never forget, as it radiated intelligence and real bravery, lighting up her thin, marked features and grey eyes to appear almost angelic. Ironically, Helen herself was being punished: she wore the 'untidy' badge on her arm and had recently been sentenced by Miss Scatcherd to a meager dinner for a minor mistake. This shows how flawed people are; even the brightest soul can be unfairly judged by those who only see small faults, missing the person’s true goodness.

events.title: Jane's Despair and Helen's Spiritual Consolation
detailed_summary: Jane, dismissed from school, descends into the dusky schoolroom and is overwhelmed by grief, collapsing onto the floor.
She weeps, lamenting her dashed hopes of achieving goodness, friendship, and respect at Lowood, despite recent academic successes and Miss Temple's encouragement.
Feeling crushed, Jane wishes for death.
Helen Burns approaches Jane, bringing her coffee and bread, which Jane refuses, too distraught to eat.
Helen sits silently beside the weeping Jane, offering a comforting presence.
Jane questions Helen why she stays with someone publicly branded a liar.
Helen minimizes the significance of the eighty people who heard the accusation compared to the vast world population.
She suggests that most at Lowood pity Jane rather than despise her, noting Mr. Brocklehurst's lack of popularity and that his favoritism would have created enemies for Jane.
Helen advises that perseverance in good behavior will eventually reveal the underlying friendly feelings of others.
She offers a profound philosophical comfort, stating that a clear conscience provides companionship even if the whole world were to hate Jane.
Jane passionately declares her intense need for human love, willing to endure physical pain for genuine affection from Helen or Miss Temple.
Helen gently admonishes Jane for her excessive focus on human love and impulsiveness, reminding her of spiritual resources and a divine presence.
Helen describes an invisible world of spirits commissioned to guard humans and God's eventual reward for the innocent after death, implying earthly suffering is transient and should not overwhelm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Ere the half-hour ended, five o’clock struck; school was dismissed, and all were gone into the refectory to tea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Why, then, should we ever sink overwhelmed with distress, when life is so soon over, and death is so certain an entrance to happiness—to glory?”

events.text_segment:
Ere the half-hour ended, five o’clock struck; school was dismissed, and all were gone into the refectory to tea. I now ventured to descend: it was deep dusk; I retired into a corner and sat down on the floor. The spell by which I had been so far supported began to dissolve; reaction took place, and soon, so overwhelming was the grief that seized me, I sank prostrate with my face to the ground. Now I wept: Helen Burns was not here; nothing sustained me; left to myself I abandoned myself, and my tears watered the boards. I had meant to be so good, and to do so much at Lowood: to make so many friends, to earn respect and win affection. Already I had made visible progress: that very morning I had reached the head of my class; Miss Miller had praised me warmly; Miss Temple had smiled approbation; she had promised to teach me drawing, and to let me learn French, if I continued to make similar improvement two months longer: and then I was well received by my fellow-pupils; treated as an equal by those of my own age, and not molested by any; now, here I lay again crushed and trodden on; and could I ever rise more?
“Never,” I thought; and ardently I wished to die. While sobbing out this wish in broken accents, some one approached: I started up—again Helen Burns was near me; the fading fires just showed her coming up the long, vacant room; she brought my coffee and bread.
“Come, eat something,” she said; but I put both away from me, feeling as if a drop or a crumb would have choked me in my present condition. Helen regarded me, probably with surprise: I could not now abate my agitation, though I tried hard; I continued to weep aloud. She sat down on the ground near me, embraced her knees with her arms, and rested her head upon them; in that attitude she remained silent as an Indian. I was the first who spoke—
“Helen, why do you stay with a girl whom everybody believes to be a liar?”
“Everybody, Jane? Why, there are only eighty people who have heard you called so, and the world contains hundreds of millions.”
“But what have I to do with millions? The eighty I know despise me.”
“Jane, you are mistaken: probably not one in the school either despises or dislikes you: many, I am sure, pity you much.”
“How can they pity me after what Mr. Brocklehurst has said?”
“Mr. Brocklehurst is not a god: nor is he even a great and admired man: he is little liked here; he never took steps to make himself liked. Had he treated you as an especial favourite, you would have found enemies, declared or covert, all around you; as it is, the greater number would offer you sympathy if they dared. Teachers and pupils may look coldly on you for a day or two, but friendly feelings are concealed in their hearts; and if you persevere in doing well, these feelings will ere long appear so much the more evidently for their temporary suppression. Besides, Jane”—she paused.
“Well, Helen?” said I, putting my hand into hers: she chafed my fingers gently to warm them, and went on—
“If all the world hated you, and believed you wicked, while your own conscience approved you, and absolved you from guilt, you would not be without friends.”
“No; I know I should think well of myself; but that is not enough: if others don’t love me I would rather die than live—I cannot bear to be solitary and hated, Helen. Look here; to gain some real affection from you, or Miss Temple, or any other whom I truly love, I would willingly submit to have the bone of my arm broken, or to let a bull toss me, or to stand behind a kicking horse, and let it dash its hoof at my chest—”
“Hush, Jane! you think too much of the love of human beings; you are too impulsive, too vehement; the sovereign hand that created your frame, and put life into it, has provided you with other resources than your feeble self, or than creatures feeble as you. Besides this earth, and besides the race of men, there is an invisible world and a kingdom of spirits: that world is round us, for it is everywhere; and those spirits watch us, for they are commissioned to guard us; and if we were dying in pain and shame, if scorn smote us on all sides, and hatred crushed us, angels see our tortures, recognise our innocence (if innocent we be: as I know you are of this charge which Mr. Brocklehurst has weakly and pompously repeated at second-hand from Mrs. Reed; for I read a sincere nature in your ardent eyes and on your clear front), and God waits only the separation of spirit from flesh to crown us with a full reward. Why, then, should we ever sink overwhelmed with distress, when life is so soon over, and death is so certain an entrance to happiness—to glory?”

events.title: Miss Temple's Kind Inquiry and Jane's Defence
detailed_summary: Jane feels calmed by Helen's words but also senses an inexpressible sadness in Helen, momentarily concerned for her friend.
Resting her head on Helen's shoulder, Jane embraces her, and they sit in silence.
Miss Temple enters the room, her figure illuminated by moonlight, and finds the two girls together.
She summons Jane to her room, kindly allowing Helen to accompany them.
They navigate passages and a staircase to Miss Temple's apartment, which is warm and cheerful with a fire.
Miss Temple asks Jane if she has cried away her grief, to which Jane responds that the wrongful accusation prevents her from doing so, fearing everyone will think her wicked.
Miss Temple reassures Jane that she will be judged by her actions and encourages her to continue behaving well.
She then inquires about the identity of Jane's benefactress, Mrs. Reed.
Jane explains her relationship to Mrs. Reed, clarifying that her aunt took her in reluctantly due to a promise made to Jane's dying uncle.
Miss Temple informs Jane that, like an accused criminal, she has the right to defend herself against the charge of falsehood.
She instructs Jane to recount her story truthfully, without additions or exaggerations.
Jane, resolved to be moderate and correct, reflects for a few minutes and then narrates her sad childhood.
Mindful of Helen's advice against resentment, Jane's account is more subdued and less bitter than usual, making it sound more credible.
Jane feels that Miss Temple fully believes her narrative as she speaks.
During her story, Jane mentions Mr. Lloyd's visit after the terrifying red-room incident, a memory still vivid and painful for her.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: for nothing could soften in my recollection the spasm of agony which clutched my heart when Mrs. Reed spurned my wild supplication for pardon, and locked me a second time in the dark and haunted chamber.

events.text_segment:
I was silent; Helen had calmed me; but in the tranquillity she imparted there was an alloy of inexpressible sadness. I felt the impression of woe as she spoke, but I could not tell whence it came; and when, having done speaking, she breathed a little fast and coughed a short cough, I momentarily forgot my own sorrows to yield to a vague concern for her.
Resting my head on Helen’s shoulder, I put my arms round her waist; she drew me to her, and we reposed in silence. We had not sat long thus, when another person came in. Some heavy clouds, swept from the sky by a rising wind, had left the moon bare; and her light, streaming in through a window near, shone full both on us and on the approaching figure, which we at once recognised as Miss Temple.
“I came on purpose to find you, Jane Eyre,” said she; “I want you in my room; and as Helen Burns is with you, she may come too.”
We went; following the superintendent’s guidance, we had to thread some intricate passages, and mount a staircase before we reached her apartment; it contained a good fire, and looked cheerful. Miss Temple told Helen Burns to be seated in a low arm-chair on one side of the hearth, and herself taking another, she called me to her side.
“Is it all over?” she asked, looking down at my face. “Have you cried your grief away?”
“I am afraid I never shall do that.”
“Why?”
“Because I have been wrongly accused; and you, ma’am, and everybody else, will now think me wicked.”
“We shall think you what you prove yourself to be, my child. Continue to act as a good girl, and you will satisfy us.”
“Shall I, Miss Temple?”
“You will,” said she, passing her arm round me. “And now tell me who is the lady whom Mr. Brocklehurst called your benefactress?”
“Mrs. Reed, my uncle’s wife. My uncle is dead, and he left me to her care.”
“Did she not, then, adopt you of her own accord?”
“No, ma’am; she was sorry to have to do it: but my uncle, as I have often heard the servants say, got her to promise before he died that she would always keep me.”
“Well now, Jane, you know, or at least I will tell you, that when a criminal is accused, he is always allowed to speak in his own defence. You have been charged with falsehood; defend yourself to me as well as you can. Say whatever your memory suggests is true; but add nothing and exaggerate nothing.”
I resolved, in the depth of my heart, that I would be most moderate—most correct; and, having reflected a few minutes in order to arrange coherently what I had to say, I told her all the story of my sad childhood. Exhausted by emotion, my language was more subdued than it generally was when it developed that sad theme; and mindful of Helen’s warnings against the indulgence of resentment, I infused into the narrative far less of gall and wormwood than ordinary. Thus restrained and simplified, it sounded more credible: I felt as I went on that Miss Temple fully believed me.
In the course of the tale I had mentioned Mr. Lloyd as having come to see me after the fit: for I never forgot the, to me, frightful episode of the red-room: in detailing which, my excitement was sure, in some degree, to break bounds; for nothing could soften in my recollection the spasm of agony which clutched my heart when Mrs. Reed spurned my wild supplication for pardon, and locked me a second time in the dark and haunted chamber.
