It was located at the opposite end of the building, but I knew the way. The clear summer moon's light shining through various passage windows helped me find it easily. As I neared the area with the fever patients, a smell of camphor and burnt vinegar alerted me, and I quickly hurried past its door, worried the night nurse might hear me. I was terrified of being caught and sent back, because seeing Helen was imperative—I had to hug her one last time before she passed away, give her a final kiss, and share one last conversation. I went down one set of stairs, crossed a section of the lower floor, managed to open and close two doors quietly, and then reached another flight of steps. After climbing these, Miss Temple's room was directly in front of me. Light showed through the keyhole and from under the door, and the area was profoundly still. Approaching, I found the door slightly open, likely to let fresh air into the stuffy sickroom. Without hesitation, driven by urgent impulses and with my soul and senses intensely stirred, I pushed the door further open and looked inside. My eyes searched for Helen, dreading to find her dead. Next to Miss Temple's bed, partially hidden by its white curtains, was a small cot. I could see the shape of a body under the covers, but the face was concealed by the fabric. The nurse I had spoken to earlier in the garden was asleep in an armchair, and a dim, untrimmed candle burned on the table. Miss Temple wasn't there; I later learned she had been called to attend to a delirious patient in the fever room. I moved closer, then paused beside the cot. My hand was on the curtain, but I chose to speak before pulling it back, still hesitant to face the possibility of seeing a corpse. "Helen!" I whispered softly, "Are you awake?" She stirred, pulled back the curtain, and I saw her face, which was pale and thin but completely calm. She looked so little changed that my fear immediately vanished.

Her room was at the far end of the building, but I remembered the way. The bright, clear moonlight shining through the windows helped me navigate easily. As I neared the sickroom, a strong smell of camphor and burnt vinegar alerted me, so I hurried past, anxious that the nurse on duty might hear me. I was terrified of being caught and sent back; I desperately needed to see Helen and hold her one last time before she died—to share a final kiss and exchange a last word.

events.title: Helen's Peaceful Acceptance of Death and Final Conversation with Jane
detailed_summary: Helen, speaking in her characteristic gentle voice, asked if it could really be Jane.
Observing Helen's calmness, Jane briefly thought that perhaps Helen was not going to die and that others were mistaken.
Jane climbed into Helen's crib and kissed her. Helen's forehead, cheeks, hand, and wrist were cold and thin, yet she smiled as she used to.
Helen inquired why Jane had come at such a late hour.
Jane explained that she had heard Helen was very ill and could not rest until she had spoken with her.
Helen responded that Jane had come to say goodbye and was likely just in time.
When Jane asked if Helen was going somewhere, like home, Helen replied that she was going to her "long home—my last home."
Jane was deeply upset. Helen experienced a coughing spell, after which she lay exhausted for a few minutes.
Noticing Jane's bare feet, Helen urged her to lie down beside her and share the quilt for warmth.
Jane complied, and Helen placed an arm over her as Jane snuggled close.
After a period of silence, Helen whispered that she was very happy and implored Jane not to grieve her death, as there was nothing to be sad about.
She described her illness as a gentle and gradual process, free from pain, and stated her mind was at peace.

Helen believed no one would miss her greatly, noting her father's recent remarriage, and felt that dying young would save her from significant future suffering, as she doubted her ability to navigate the world successfully.
Jane pressed Helen about her destination, asking if she could see it or knew what it was.
Helen affirmed her strong faith, saying she was going to God, her Creator, who would preserve what He made.
She expressed complete trust in God's power and goodness, eagerly anticipating her reunion with Him.
Jane then asked if Helen was certain of heaven's existence and the soul's journey there after death.

Helen confirmed her belief in a future state and God's benevolence, entrusting her immortal soul to Him without apprehension, viewing God as her father and friend whom she loved and who loved her in return.
When Jane asked if they would meet again after her own death, Helen reassured her that she too would arrive in the same realm of happiness, welcomed by the same universal Parent.
Jane silently questioned the reality of this region, holding Helen tighter, feeling she was dearer than ever.
Helen then softly expressed her comfort and sleepiness, asking Jane to stay with her.
Jane promised she would not leave. Helen asked if Jane was warm, they exchanged goodnights and kisses, and both soon fell asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Can it be you, Jane?” she asked, in her own gentle voice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She kissed me, and I her, and we both soon slumbered.

events.text_segment:
“Can it be you, Jane?” she asked, in her own gentle voice.
“Oh!” I thought, “she is not going to die; they are mistaken: she could not speak and look so calmly if she were.”
I got on to her crib and kissed her: her forehead was cold, and her cheek both cold and thin, and so were her hand and wrist; but she smiled as of old.
“Why are you come here, Jane? It is past eleven o’clock: I heard it strike some minutes since.”
“I came to see you, Helen: I heard you were very ill, and I could not sleep till I had spoken to you.”
“You came to bid me good-bye, then: you are just in time probably.”
“Are you going somewhere, Helen? Are you going home?”
“Yes; to my long home—my last home.”
“No, no, Helen!” I stopped, distressed. While I tried to devour my tears, a fit of coughing seized Helen; it did not, however, wake the nurse; when it was over, she lay some minutes exhausted; then she whispered—
“Jane, your little feet are bare; lie down and cover yourself with my quilt.”
I did so: she put her arm over me, and I nestled close to her. After a long silence, she resumed, still whispering—
“I am very happy, Jane; and when you hear that I am dead, you must be sure and not grieve: there is nothing to grieve about. We all must die one day, and the illness which is removing me is not painful; it is gentle and gradual: my mind is at rest. I leave no one to regret me much: I have only a father; and he is lately married, and will not miss me. By dying young, I shall escape great sufferings. I had not qualities or talents to make my way very well in the world: I should have been continually at fault.”
“But where are you going to, Helen? Can you see? Do you know?”
“I believe; I have faith: I am going to God.”
“Where is God? What is God?”
“My Maker and yours, who will never destroy what He created. I rely implicitly on His power, and confide wholly in His goodness: I count the hours till that eventful one arrives which shall restore me to Him, reveal Him to me.”
“You are sure, then, Helen, that there is such a place as heaven, and that our souls can get to it when we die?”
“I am sure there is a future state; I believe God is good; I can resign my immortal part to Him without any misgiving. God is my father; God is my friend: I love Him; I believe He loves me.”
“And shall I see you again, Helen, when I die?”
“You will come to the same region of happiness: be received by the same mighty, universal Parent, no doubt, dear Jane.”
Again I questioned, but this time only in thought. “Where is that region? Does it exist?” And I clasped my arms closer round Helen; she seemed dearer to me than ever; I felt as if I could not let her go; I lay with my face hidden on her neck. Presently she said, in the sweetest tone—
“How comfortable I am! That last fit of coughing has tired me a little; I feel as if I could sleep: but don’t leave me, Jane; I like to have you near me.”
“I’ll stay with you, dear Helen: no one shall take me away.”
“Are you warm, darling?”
“Yes.”
“Good-night, Jane.”
“Good-night, Helen.”
She kissed me, and I her, and we both soon slumbered.

She kissed me, and I kissed her back, and soon we were both asleep.

events.title: Discovery of Helen's Death and Its Aftermath
detailed_summary: Jane was awakened by daylight and an unusual sensation of movement; she found herself in the arms of the nurse, who was carrying her back to the dormitory.
She received no reprimand for having left her bed, as the household staff had more pressing matters to attend to.
Her many questions at the time went unanswered.
A day or two later, Jane learned the full circumstances: Miss Temple, on returning to her own room at dawn, had discovered Jane asleep in the small crib.
Jane's face was resting against Helen Burns's shoulder, and her arms were wrapped around Helen's neck.
While Jane had been sleeping, Helen had passed away.
The narrative concludes with the information that Helen is buried in Brocklebridge churchyard.
For fifteen years following her death, her grave was marked only by a simple grassy mound.
However, a grey marble tablet now identifies the spot, inscribed with Helen's name and the word "Resurgam."

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I awoke it was day: an unusual movement roused me; I looked up; I was in somebody’s arms; the nurse held me; she was carrying me through the passage back to the dormitory.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her grave is in Brocklebridge churchyard: for fifteen years after her death it was only covered by a grassy mound; but now a grey marble tablet marks the spot, inscribed with her name, and the word “Resurgam.”

events.text_segment:
When I awoke it was day: an unusual movement roused me; I looked up; I was in somebody’s arms; the nurse held me; she was carrying me through the passage back to the dormitory. I was not reprimanded for leaving my bed; people had something else to think about; no explanation was afforded then to my many questions; but a day or two afterwards I learned that Miss Temple, on returning to her own room at dawn, had found me laid in the little crib; my face against Helen Burns’s shoulder, my arms round her neck. I was asleep, and Helen was—dead.
Her grave is in Brocklebridge churchyard: for fifteen years after her death it was only covered by a grassy mound; but now a grey marble tablet marks the spot, inscribed with her name, and the word “Resurgam.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I awoke in daylight to the sound of unusual activity and discovered I was being carried by the nurse back through the passage to the dormitory. I wasn't scolded for having left my bed, as people were preoccupied with other matters, and my numerous questions went unanswered at the time. Nevertheless, a couple of days later, I learned that Miss Temple had found me asleep in the small cot when she returned to her room at dawn, with my face resting on Helen Burns's shoulder and my arms wrapped around her neck. I was asleep, but Helen had passed away. Her grave is located in Brocklebridge churchyard; for fifteen years after her death, it was marked only by a grassy mound, but now a grey marble tablet stands there, bearing her name and the inscription "Resurgam."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: When I woke up, it was daylight. Some sudden movement startled me, and I realized I was being held by someone—the nurse, who was carrying me through the hallway back to the dormitory. No one scolded me for getting out of bed because everyone was distracted by other concerns. At that time, they didn’t answer any of the questions I kept asking. A few days later, I found out what had happened: when Miss Temple went back to her room at sunrise, she saw me lying in the crib, my face resting on Helen Burns’s shoulder and my arms around her neck. I had been asleep, but Helen had passed away. Helen is buried in the Brocklebridge churchyard; for fifteen years after she died, there was only a grassy mound over her grave. Now there is a gray marble tablet with her name and the word “Resurgam” engraved on it.

events.title: Lowood's Reformation and Jane's Eight-Year Tenure
detailed_summary: The narrator announces a shift in her autobiographical style, moving from a detailed account of her first ten years to a more condensed summary of the subsequent eight years, focusing only on events of significant interest.
Following the devastating typhus fever outbreak at Lowood, public attention was drawn to the school's conditions.

An inquiry revealed numerous issues: the unhealthy location, the poor quality and insufficient quantity of food, the use of brackish water, and the wretched state of the pupils' clothing and accommodations.
These discoveries resulted in public indignation, which was mortifying for Mr. Brocklehurst but ultimately beneficial for Lowood institution.
Several affluent and charitable individuals contributed to constructing a new, more suitable building in a better location.
New regulations were implemented, leading to improvements in the students' diet and clothing.
The management of the school's finances was entrusted to a committee.
Mr. Brocklehurst, due to his wealth and connections, retained his position as treasurer but was assisted by gentlemen with more compassionate and broader perspectives.
His role as inspector was also shared, ensuring a balanced approach that combined reason with discipline, comfort with frugality, and compassion with integrity.
Under these reforms, Lowood evolved into a genuinely useful and commendable institution.
The narrator remained at Lowood for eight years after its regeneration: six years as a pupil and two years as a teacher.
She attests to the value and importance of the institution during her time there in both capacities.
Her life over these eight years was consistent but not unhappy, primarily because it was filled with activity and intellectual pursuits.
She had access to an excellent education, developed a fondness for some subjects, and was driven by a desire to excel in all, greatly enjoying pleasing her teachers, especially those she loved.
She made full use of the opportunities provided, eventually rising to become the top student in her class.
Subsequently, she took on the role of teacher, which she performed with dedication for two years.
However, at the end of this two-year period as a teacher, she underwent a significant personal change.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hitherto I have recorded in detail the events of my insignificant existence: to the first ten years of my life I have given almost as many chapters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In time I rose to be the first girl of the first class; then I was invested with the office of teacher; which I discharged with zeal for two years: but at the end of that time I altered.

events.text_segment:
Hitherto I have recorded in detail the events of my insignificant existence: to the first ten years of my life I have given almost as many chapters. But this is not to be a regular autobiography: I am only bound to invoke Memory where I know her responses will possess some degree of interest; therefore I now pass a space of eight years almost in silence: a few lines only are necessary to keep up the links of connection.
When the typhus fever had fulfilled its mission of devastation at Lowood, it gradually disappeared from thence; but not till its virulence and the number of its victims had drawn public attention on the school. Inquiry was made into the origin of the scourge, and by degrees various facts came out which excited public indignation in a high degree. The unhealthy nature of the site; the quantity and quality of the children’s food; the brackish, fetid water used in its preparation; the pupils’ wretched clothing and accommodations—all these things were discovered, and the discovery produced a result mortifying to Mr. Brocklehurst, but beneficial to the institution.
Several wealthy and benevolent individuals in the county subscribed largely for the erection of a more convenient building in a better situation; new regulations were made; improvements in diet and clothing introduced; the funds of the school were intrusted to the management of a committee. Mr. Brocklehurst, who, from his wealth and family connections, could not be overlooked, still retained the post of treasurer; but he was aided in the discharge of his duties by gentlemen of rather more enlarged and sympathising minds: his office of inspector, too, was shared by those who knew how to combine reason with strictness, comfort with economy, compassion with uprightness. The school, thus improved, became in time a truly useful and noble institution. I remained an inmate of its walls, after its regeneration, for eight years: six as pupil, and two as teacher; and in both capacities I bear my testimony to its value and importance.
During these eight years my life was uniform: but not unhappy, because it was not inactive. I had the means of an excellent education placed within my reach; a fondness for some of my studies, and a desire to excel in all, together with a great delight in pleasing my teachers, especially such as I loved, urged me on: I availed myself fully of the advantages offered me. In time I rose to be the first girl of the first class; then I was invested with the office of teacher; which I discharged with zeal for two years: but at the end of that time I altered.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Until now, I have detailed the occurrences of my rather insignificant existence; I've dedicated nearly as many chapters to the first decade of my life as there were years. But this account isn't meant to be a conventional autobiography. I only feel obligated to call upon Memory when I'm certain her recollections will be interesting to the reader. Therefore, I will now pass quickly over a period of eight years, mentioning it almost in silence. Just a few sentences are needed to maintain the narrative thread.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Up to now, I have described the details of my rather unremarkable life, dedicating nearly as many chapters to my first ten years as the years themselves. However, this is not intended to be a traditional autobiography; I will only recount memories that seem likely to interest the reader. Therefore, I will largely skip over the next eight years of my life, mentioning only the essentials to maintain continuity. After the typhus outbreak had wreaked havoc at Lowood School, it eventually subsided, but only after its severity and high number of victims attracted public scrutiny to the institution. Investigations were conducted into why the illness had spread, and information came to light that caused public outrage—the unhealthy location of the school, the poor quality and quantity of food, contaminated water, and inadequate clothing and living conditions were all revealed. This exposure, though humiliating for Mr. Brocklehurst, led to improvements for the school. Several wealthy and charitable local people donated generously to build better facilities in a healthier setting; new rules were established, and improvements were made to food and clothing. Control of the school's finances was placed in the hands of a committee. Mr. Brocklehurst, due to his wealth and social standing, remained as treasurer, but was joined in his responsibilities by men who were more broad-minded and compassionate, and his inspector role was also shared by those who combined fairness and kindness with discipline. Thanks to these reforms, the school became a respected and valuable institution over time. I stayed there after these changes for eight years—six as a student and two as a teacher—and I can vouch for its worth and significance in both roles. My life during that period was routine, but not unhappy, as it was filled with purpose. I had access to an excellent education, enjoyed many of my studies, wanted to excel, and found pleasure in pleasing my teachers, particularly those I cared for, which motivated me. I made the most of these opportunities, eventually becoming the top student, then spending two years as a teacher, performing my duties enthusiastically. But after those two years, things changed for me.

events.title: Miss Temple's Departure and Jane's Yearning for Change
detailed_summary: Miss Temple had remained the superintendent of Lowood throughout all its transformations.

The narrator attributes the best part of her learning to Miss Temple's instruction and cherished her friendship and companionship as a constant solace, viewing her as a mother, governess, and, more recently, a friend.
Miss Temple married a clergyman, described as an excellent man, and relocated with him to a distant county, which meant she was lost to the narrator.
From the day of Miss Temple's departure, the narrator felt a profound change in herself; every established feeling and association that had made Lowood somewhat of a home disappeared with her.
She recognized that she had absorbed some of Miss Temple's nature and many of her habits, resulting in more harmonious thoughts and seemingly better-regulated emotions.
She had committed herself to duty and order, living a quiet life and believing herself content, appearing disciplined and subdued to others and usually to herself.
However, destiny, in the form of Miss Temple's marriage to the Reverend Mr. Nasmyth, came between them.
The narrator witnessed Miss Temple, dressed for travel, getting into a post-chaise shortly after the wedding ceremony.
She watched the carriage ascend a hill and vanish, then retreated to her room, spending most of the half-holiday granted for the occasion in solitude.
While walking and reflecting in her room, initially believing she was merely mourning her loss, she discovered that a transformative process had occurred within her during that afternoon.

She felt that her mind had shed all it had borrowed from Miss Temple, or rather, that Miss Temple had taken the serene atmosphere with her, leaving the narrator in her own natural state, feeling the stirrings of old emotions.
It was not that a support had been removed, but rather that a motive for her tranquility was gone.

Her world, for some years confined to Lowood and its systems, now seemed limiting as she recalled the vastness of the real world, with its varied hopes, fears, sensations, and excitements awaiting those courageous enough to explore it.

Opening her window, she looked out at the familiar surroundings of Lowood but her gaze was drawn to the distant blue peaks, which she longed to surmount, viewing everything within Lowood's confines as prison-like.
She traced a white road winding into the distance, yearning to follow it, and recalled her initial journey to Lowood, a time that now felt like an age ago.
She reflected on her complete isolation during vacations, never having been summoned to Gateshead by Mrs. Reed or visited by any family members, and having no communication with the outside world.
Her entire existence had been defined by school rules, duties, habits, and faces, which she now realized was insufficient.
The routine of eight years became unbearable in a single afternoon; she craved liberty, then change and stimulus, and finally, in desperation, cried out for at least a new form of servitude.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Temple, through all changes, had thus far continued superintendent of the seminary: to her instruction I owed the best part of my acquirements; her friendship and society had been my continual solace; she had stood me in the stead of mother, governess, and, latterly, companion.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Then,” I cried, half desperate, “grant me at least a new servitude!”

events.text_segment:
Miss Temple, through all changes, had thus far continued superintendent of the seminary: to her instruction I owed the best part of my acquirements; her friendship and society had been my continual solace; she had stood me in the stead of mother, governess, and, latterly, companion. At this period she married, removed with her husband (a clergyman, an excellent man, almost worthy of such a wife) to a distant county, and consequently was lost to me.
From the day she left I was no longer the same: with her was gone every settled feeling, every association that had made Lowood in some degree a home to me. I had imbibed from her something of her nature and much of her habits: more harmonious thoughts: what seemed better regulated feelings had become the inmates of my mind. I had given in allegiance to duty and order; I was quiet; I believed I was content: to the eyes of others, usually even to my own, I appeared a disciplined and subdued character.
But destiny, in the shape of the Rev. Mr. Nasmyth, came between me and Miss Temple: I saw her in her travelling dress step into a post-chaise, shortly after the marriage ceremony; I watched the chaise mount the hill and disappear beyond its brow; and then retired to my own room, and there spent in solitude the greatest part of the half-holiday granted in honour of the occasion.
I walked about the chamber most of the time. I imagined myself only to be regretting my loss, and thinking how to repair it; but when my reflections were concluded, and I looked up and found that the afternoon was gone, and evening far advanced, another discovery dawned on me, namely, that in the interval I had undergone a transforming process; that my mind had put off all it had borrowed of Miss Temple—or rather that she had taken with her the serene atmosphere I had been breathing in her vicinity—and that now I was left in my natural element, and beginning to feel the stirring of old emotions. It did not seem as if a prop were withdrawn, but rather as if a motive were gone: it was not the power to be tranquil which had failed me, but the reason for tranquillity was no more. My world had for some years been in Lowood: my experience had been of its rules and systems; now I remembered that the real world was wide, and that a varied field of hopes and fears, of sensations and excitements, awaited those who had courage to go forth into its expanse, to seek real knowledge of life amidst its perils.
I went to my window, opened it, and looked out. There were the two wings of the building; there was the garden; there were the skirts of Lowood; there was the hilly horizon. My eye passed all other objects to rest on those most remote, the blue peaks; it was those I longed to surmount; all within their boundary of rock and heath seemed prison-ground, exile limits. I traced the white road winding round the base of one mountain, and vanishing in a gorge between two; how I longed to follow it farther! I recalled the time when I had travelled that very road in a coach; I remembered descending that hill at twilight; an age seemed to have elapsed since the day which brought me first to Lowood, and I had never quitted it since. My vacations had all been spent at school: Mrs. Reed had never sent for me to Gateshead; neither she nor any of her family had ever been to visit me. I had had no communication by letter or message with the outer world: school-rules, school-duties, school-habits and notions, and voices, and faces, and phrases, and costumes, and preferences, and antipathies—such was what I knew of existence. And now I felt that it was not enough; I tired of the routine of eight years in one afternoon. I desired liberty; for liberty I gasped; for liberty I uttered a prayer; it seemed scattered on the wind then faintly blowing. I abandoned it and framed a humbler supplication; for change, stimulus: that petition, too, seemed swept off into vague space: “Then,” I cried, half desperate, “grant me at least a new servitude!”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Miss Temple consistently held the role of headmistress at the school throughout all the changes. I credited her teaching with the most significant part of my education; her friendship and company provided constant comfort. She served as a mother, teacher, and later, a friend to me. Around this time, she married and moved with her husband (a clergyman, an excellent man, almost worthy of such a wife) to a faraway county, resulting in her absence from my life.
From the moment she left, I was fundamentally changed. With her went every stable feeling, every connection that had made Lowood feel somewhat like a home. I had absorbed some of her character and many of her habits from her: my thoughts became more harmonious, and my feelings seemed better regulated, becoming part of my inner self. I had committed to duty and order; I was quiet; I believed I was content. To others, and usually even to myself, I appeared disciplined and compliant.
However, fate, in the form of the Reverend Mr. Nasmyth, separated Miss Temple and me. I watched her, dressed for travel, get into a carriage soon after the wedding. I saw the carriage climb the hill and disappear over the top, then I went back to my room and spent most of the half-holiday, given in celebration of the wedding, alone there.
I spent most of the time walking around the room. I thought I was just regretting my loss and figuring out how to cope. But when I finished thinking and saw that the afternoon was over and evening was well underway, I had another realization: that during that time, I had undergone a transformation. My mind had shed everything it had adopted from Miss Temple—or rather, she had taken with her the calm atmosphere I had been breathing while near her. Now, I was left in my natural state and started feeling the stirring of old emotions again. It didn't feel like a support had been removed, but more like the purpose had vanished. It wasn't that I could no longer be calm, but that there was no longer a reason to be calm. For several years, my world had been confined to Lowood; my experience was limited to its rules and routines. Now, I remembered that the real world was vast, and that a diverse landscape of hopes and fears, sensations and excitements, awaited those brave enough to venture into it and seek true understanding of life amidst its dangers.
I went to my window, opened it, and looked out. There were the two sections of the building, the garden, the edge of the Lowood grounds, and the distant hills. My gaze moved past everything else to settle on the furthest points, the blue peaks. Those were what I yearned to cross. Everything within their boundary of rock and moor seemed like prison territory, limits of exile. I followed the white road winding around the base of one mountain and disappearing into a valley between two others. How I longed to follow it further! I remembered the time I had traveled that very road in a carriage. I recalled coming down that hill at dusk. It felt like an age had passed since the day I first arrived at Lowood, and I had not left since. All my school breaks had been spent at the school; Mrs. Reed had never sent for me to Gateshead, nor had she or any of her family ever visited me. I had had no communication by letter or message with the outside world. School rules, school duties, school habits and ideas, voices, faces, phrases, clothes, preferences, and dislikes—this was the extent of my knowledge of existence. And now I felt it wasn't enough. I grew weary of eight years of routine in a single afternoon. I craved freedom; I gasped for freedom; I offered a prayer for freedom; it seemed scattered on the faint wind blowing. I abandoned that hope and formed a more modest plea: for change, for stimulation. That request, too, seemed swept away into empty space. 'Then,' I cried, half-desperate, 'grant me at least a new form of servitude!'

At this time, though, she got married and moved far away with her husband, a clergyman who was nearly deserving of her, and as a result I lost her from my life.

I had absorbed some of her temperament and many of her habits: my thoughts were more peaceful, my feelings more balanced. I had embraced duty and order, was quiet, and believed myself content. To others and mostly to myself, I seemed calm and well-controlled.

But fate intervened with the arrival of the Rev. Mr. Nasmyth, and I watched Miss Temple in her travel clothes leave in a carriage soon after she married. I observed the coach disappear over a hill, then went to my room and spent most of the special half-holiday given that day alone.

I paced the room and at first thought I was only mourning the loss and trying to figure out how to cope. But as the afternoon faded into evening, I realized I had changed: everything I had taken from Miss Temple seemed to vanish, or rather, she had left and taken with her the calm atmosphere I’d thrived in. I felt like I was returning to my true self, and old feelings began to stir. It didn’t feel as if I lost a support, but rather my reason for being composed was gone. I opened my window and looked out: the school buildings, the garden, the edges of Lowood, and far in the distance, the blue hills. My gaze lingered most on those distant peaks; I ached to climb beyond them. Everything within Lowood’s boundaries now felt confining. I traced the winding road along the mountain and wished to follow it further. I recalled travelling that road before, arriving at Lowood years ago, and realized I hadn’t left since—my holidays were all spent at school, Mrs. Reed never called me back nor visited. There was no contact with the outside world; my life consisted only of school routines, rules, faces, conversation, tastes, and dislikes. That was my whole existence. But it no longer satisfied me; eight years of monotony became unbearable in one afternoon. I craved freedom—I even prayed for it, but it felt like my plea was lost on the breeze. So, I asked instead for change or excitement, but that request too seemed to dissolve. Desperately I pleaded, if not liberty, then at least let me serve somewhere new.

events.title: The Resolution to Seek a New Servitude
detailed_summary: A bell signaling supper interrupted the narrator's intense reflections, calling her downstairs.

She was unable to return to her train of thought until bedtime, and even then, her roommate, a teacher, engaged her in prolonged small talk, preventing her from focusing on the subject she longed to revisit.
The narrator wished for sleep to silence her roommate, Miss Gryce.
She felt that if she could only return to the idea she had at the window, some inventive solution for her situation might emerge.
Eventually, Miss Gryce, a heavy Welshwoman, began to snore, a sound previously considered a nuisance but now welcomed by the narrator as it signified freedom from interruption.
Her half-forgotten thought about a 'new servitude' immediately resurfaced.
She mentally soliloquized that the phrase 'a new servitude' held promise because it sounded practical and attainable, unlike grander, more elusive concepts like Liberty or Excitement.
She reasoned that serving was a tangible action; having served at Lowood for eight years, her current desire was simply to serve in a different place.
She questioned if this desire was feasible and concluded that the goal itself was not too difficult, if only she could devise the means to achieve it.
She sat up in bed on the chilly night, wrapped her shoulders in a shawl, and concentrated intensely on finding a way forward.
She defined her need: a new place, a new house, new faces, and new circumstances, considering this a realistic aspiration.
She pondered how people typically find new positions, thinking of friends, but acknowledged she had none.
She considered those who must rely on themselves and wondered about their resources.
Unable to find an answer, she mentally commanded her brain to find a solution quickly.
Her mind worked intensely but chaotically for nearly an hour without producing any clear result.
Feeling feverish from the fruitless effort, she got out of bed, paced the room, looked at the stars, shivered from cold, and returned to bed.
Upon lying down again, the solution came to her mind quietly and naturally: those seeking situations advertise, and she must advertise in the local paper, the shire Herald.
Initially unsure how to proceed with advertising, clear and prompt replies formed in her mind.

She conceptualized the process: enclose the advertisement and payment in a letter to the Herald's editor, post it at Lowton, and have responses addressed to 'J.E.' at the Lowton post office, where she could inquire after a week.
She reviewed this plan multiple times until it was firmly established in her mind in a clear, practical form.
Feeling satisfied with her scheme, she finally fell asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here a bell, ringing the hour of supper, called me downstairs.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I felt satisfied, and fell asleep.

events.text_segment:
Here a bell, ringing the hour of supper, called me downstairs.
I was not free to resume the interrupted chain of my reflections till bedtime: even then a teacher who occupied the same room with me kept me from the subject to which I longed to recur, by a prolonged effusion of small talk. How I wished sleep would silence her. It seemed as if, could I but go back to the idea which had last entered my mind as I stood at the window, some inventive suggestion would rise for my relief.
Miss Gryce snored at last; she was a heavy Welshwoman, and till now her habitual nasal strains had never been regarded by me in any other light than as a nuisance; to-night I hailed the first deep notes with satisfaction; I was debarrassed of interruption; my half-effaced thought instantly revived.
“A new servitude! There is something in that,” I soliloquised (mentally, be it understood; I did not talk aloud). “I know there is, because it does not sound too sweet; it is not like such words as Liberty, Excitement, Enjoyment: delightful sounds truly; but no more than sounds for me; and so hollow and fleeting that it is mere waste of time to listen to them. But Servitude! That must be matter of fact. Any one may serve: I have served here eight years; now all I want is to serve elsewhere. Can I not get so much of my own will? Is not the thing feasible? Yes—yes—the end is not so difficult; if I had only a brain active enough to ferret out the means of attaining it.”
I sat up in bed by way of arousing this said brain: it was a chilly night; I covered my shoulders with a shawl, and then I proceeded to think again with all my might.
“What do I want? A new place, in a new house, amongst new faces, under new circumstances: I want this because it is of no use wanting anything better. How do people do to get a new place? They apply to friends, I suppose: I have no friends. There are many others who have no friends, who must look about for themselves and be their own helpers; and what is their resource?”
I could not tell: nothing answered me; I then ordered my brain to find a response, and quickly. It worked and worked faster: I felt the pulses throb in my head and temples; but for nearly an hour it worked in chaos; and no result came of its efforts. Feverish with vain labour, I got up and took a turn in the room; undrew the curtain, noted a star or two, shivered with cold, and again crept to bed.
A kind fairy, in my absence, had surely dropped the required suggestion on my pillow; for as I lay down, it came quietly and naturally to my mind:—“Those who want situations advertise; you must advertise in the ——shire Herald.”
“How? I know nothing about advertising.”
Replies rose smooth and prompt now:—
“You must enclose the advertisement and the money to pay for it under a cover directed to the editor of the Herald; you must put it, the first opportunity you have, into the post at Lowton; answers must be addressed to J.E., at the post-office there; you can go and inquire in about a week after you send your letter, if any are come, and act accordingly.”
This scheme I went over twice, thrice; it was then digested in my mind; I had it in a clear practical form: I felt satisfied, and fell asleep.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A bell signaling supper called me downstairs, interrupting my reflections until it was time for bed. Even then, the teacher sharing my room prevented me from returning to my thoughts with her continuous chatter. I desperately wished she would fall asleep, feeling that if I could just revisit the idea I had while standing at the window, a creative solution might present itself. Finally, Miss Gryce, a large Welsh woman whose regular snoring had always been a nuisance, began to snore. Tonight, I welcomed her deep, habitual noises with relief; I was finally free from interruption, and my half-faded thought immediately returned. "A new position! There is something real in that," I reflected silently. "I know it's real because it doesn't sound overly pleasant; it's not like words such as Liberty, Excitement, or Enjoyment, which sound delightful but are just sounds to me—so empty and fleeting that listening to them is a waste of time. But Servitude! That must be a tangible reality. Anyone can serve; I've served here for eight years. Now all I desire is to serve somewhere else. Can I not achieve this much of my own will? Is the idea not possible? Yes, yes—the outcome isn't the main difficulty; the challenge is just having a mind sharp enough to uncover the means of achieving it." I sat up in bed to try and stimulate this brain of mine. It was a cold night, so I wrapped a shawl around my shoulders and resumed thinking as hard as I could. "What is it I want?" I asked myself. "A different situation, in a different setting, among different people, under different circumstances. I want this because desiring anything better is pointless. How do people manage to find new positions? They probably ask friends, I suppose; I have no friends. There are many others without friends who must find opportunities for themselves and be their own help; what is their resource?" I couldn't answer; nothing came to mind. I then ordered my brain to find a quick answer. It worked faster and faster; I could feel the pulses throbbing in my head and temples, but for nearly an hour, my thoughts were chaotic, producing no result. Agitated from the futile effort, I got out of bed, took a short walk around the room, pulled back the curtain, noted a couple of stars, shivered from the cold, and then got back into bed. Surely, while I was up, a kind fairy must have placed the needed suggestion on my pillow, for as I lay down, it came to me calmly and naturally: "Those who are looking for employment advertise; you must place an advertisement in the --shire Herald." "How?" I wondered, "I know nothing about advertising." Answers came smoothly and promptly now: "You must place the advertisement and the necessary payment in an envelope addressed to the editor of the Herald. Post it at Lowton at the first opportunity you have. Replies should be directed to J.E. at the post office there. You can go and inquire there about a week after you send your letter to see if any have arrived, and proceed accordingly." I reviewed this plan two or three times; it was now clear and organized in my mind, taking a practical form. Feeling content, I drifted off to sleep.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
At that moment, the bell signaling supper rang, so I had to go downstairs. I couldn't pick up my interrupted thoughts until bedtime, but even then, the teacher who shared my room distracted me with endless chatter, making it impossible for me to focus on what I really wanted to think about. I just wished she would fall asleep so I could have some peace. I felt that if only I could return to the idea that last entered my mind by the window, maybe I'd come up with a good idea to help myself. Eventually, Miss Gryce, my heavyset Welsh roommate, began to snore. Ordinarily, I found her snoring annoying, but tonight it was welcomed because it meant she wouldn’t interrupt me anymore, and immediately my half-formed thought returned.  

“A new kind of work! There's something about that,” I thought to myself. “It doesn’t sound pleasant like ‘freedom’ or ‘excitement’ or ‘enjoyment’—those are just attractive words to me, with no real substance. But ‘servitude’ is practical and real. Anyone can serve; I’ve been serving here for eight years. All I want is to serve in a different place. Can’t I get that much control over my life? Isn’t it possible? Yes—if only I can figure out a way to achieve it.”

Trying to stimulate my thinking, I sat up in bed, wrapped a shawl around my shoulders because it was cold, and concentrated hard. “What do I want? A new job, in a different household, among unfamiliar people, in a new situation—because there’s no point in hoping for something better than that. How do people get new positions? I suppose they ask friends. But I don’t have any friends. Many people are in the same boat; they have to rely on themselves, so what do they do?”

I had no answers. I demanded my mind to find a solution quickly, but though my thoughts raced and pounded away, for almost an hour I came up with nothing. Frustrated and restless, I got up, paced my room, looked at the stars from the window, shivered in the cold, then went back to bed. 

By some stroke of good luck, as soon as I lay down, the answer appeared in my mind: “People who want jobs place advertisements; you should advertise in the ——shire Herald.”

“But how? I know nothing about putting in ads.”

Now, answers came to me clearly: “You must write your advertisement, include the payment, and send it all to the editor of the Herald. Put it in the post at Lowton as soon as you can. Ask that replies be addressed to J.E., at the post office there; check back about a week later and see if you have any responses.”

I went over this plan several times until I had it memorized and understood. At last, feeling content, I was able to fall asleep.

events.title: Advertising for a New Position and Anxious Anticipation
detailed_summary: The narrator was up at the earliest light of day, having written, enclosed, and addressed her advertisement before the school's rising bell.

The advertisement described 'a young lady accustomed to tuition' (referencing her two years as a teacher) seeking a position in a private family with children under fourteen (as she, being barely eighteen, felt unsuited to older pupils).
It stated her qualifications to teach standard English education subjects, along with French, Drawing, and Music, which was considered a comprehensive list at the time.
The advertisement requested replies be addressed to 'J.E., Post-office, Lowton, shire.'
This document remained locked in her drawer all day.
After tea, she requested and received permission from the new superintendent to go to Lowton, ostensibly to run errands for herself and fellow teachers.
She undertook the two-mile walk on a wet evening, though the days were still long.
After visiting a couple of shops, she mailed her letter at the post-office and returned through heavy rain, drenched but with a sense of relief.
The following week felt exceedingly long as she waited for responses.
Eventually, the week ended, and towards the close of a pleasant autumn day, she found herself once again walking the picturesque route to Lowton.
Despite the beauty of the path along the beck and through the dale, her thoughts were preoccupied with the letters that might, or might not, be waiting for her.
Her stated reason for this trip was to be measured for a pair of shoes, which she attended to first.
Afterward, she crossed the quiet street from the shoemaker's to the post-office, which was managed by an elderly woman wearing horn spectacles and black mittens.
The narrator asked if there were any letters for 'J.E.'
The old woman peered at her, then searched through a drawer for a prolonged period, causing the narrator's hopes to diminish.
Finally, after scrutinizing a document for nearly five minutes, the woman presented it across the counter with an inquisitive and mistrustful glance; it was addressed to J.E.
When asked if there was only one, the woman confirmed there were no more.
The narrator pocketed the letter and turned towards Lowood, unable to open it immediately as school rules required her return by eight, and it was already half-past seven.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: With earliest day, I was up: I had my advertisement written, enclosed, and directed before the bell rang to rouse the school; it ran thus:—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I could not open it then; rules obliged me to be back by eight, and it was already half-past seven.

events.text_segment:
With earliest day, I was up: I had my advertisement written, enclosed, and directed before the bell rang to rouse the school; it ran thus:—
“A young lady accustomed to tuition” (had I not been a teacher two years?) “is desirous of meeting with a situation in a private family where the children are under fourteen” (I thought that as I was barely eighteen, it would not do to undertake the guidance of pupils nearer my own age). “She is qualified to teach the usual branches of a good English education, together with French, Drawing, and Music” (in those days, reader, this now narrow catalogue of accomplishments, would have been held tolerably comprehensive). “Address, J.E., Post-office, Lowton, ——shire.”
This document remained locked in my drawer all day: after tea, I asked leave of the new superintendent to go to Lowton, in order to perform some small commissions for myself and one or two of my fellow-teachers; permission was readily granted; I went. It was a walk of two miles, and the evening was wet, but the days were still long; I visited a shop or two, slipped the letter into the post-office, and came back through heavy rain, with streaming garments, but with a relieved heart.
The succeeding week seemed long: it came to an end at last, however, like all sublunary things, and once more, towards the close of a pleasant autumn day, I found myself afoot on the road to Lowton. A picturesque track it was, by the way; lying along the side of the beck and through the sweetest curves of the dale: but that day I thought more of the letters, that might or might not be awaiting me at the little burgh whither I was bound, than of the charms of lea and water.
My ostensible errand on this occasion was to get measured for a pair of shoes; so I discharged that business first, and when it was done, I stepped across the clean and quiet little street from the shoemaker’s to the post-office: it was kept by an old dame, who wore horn spectacles on her nose, and black mittens on her hands.
“Are there any letters for J.E.?” I asked.
She peered at me over her spectacles, and then she opened a drawer and fumbled among its contents for a long time, so long that my hopes began to falter. At last, having held a document before her glasses for nearly five minutes, she presented it across the counter, accompanying the act by another inquisitive and mistrustful glance—it was for J.E.
“Is there only one?” I demanded.
“There are no more,” said she; and I put it in my pocket and turned my face homeward: I could not open it then; rules obliged me to be back by eight, and it was already half-past seven.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I woke up with the first hint of daylight. Before the school bell rang to wake everyone, I had written, sealed, and addressed my advertisement. It read as follows: "A young woman with experience teaching" (I had taught for two years) "is seeking a position with a private family. The children should be under fourteen" (I felt that at barely eighteen, I shouldn't teach students close to my own age). "She is capable of instructing in the standard subjects of a good English education, plus French, Drawing, and Music" (at that time, dear reader, this list of skills, which seems limited now, was considered quite extensive). "Please reply to J.E., Post-office, Lowton, --shire." I kept this paper hidden in my drawer all day. After dinner, I requested permission from the new supervisor to go to Lowton to run a few errands for myself and some other teachers; permission was quickly granted. I went. It was a two-mile walk, and the evening was damp, but the days were still long. I stopped at a couple of stores, dropped the letter in the post office, and returned through heavy rain, my clothes soaked, but my heart felt lighter. The next week felt slow, but eventually, like everything else in the world, it ended. Once again, as a lovely autumn day neared its close, I found myself walking towards Lowton. The path itself was quite scenic, following the stream and winding through the beautiful valley curves. However, that day I was more preoccupied with the possibility of letters waiting for me in the small town than with the beauty of the fields and water. My official reason for this trip was to get fitted for new shoes. So, I completed that task first. Once finished, I crossed the clean, quiet little street from the shoemaker's to the post office. It was run by an elderly woman who wore horn-rimmed glasses on her nose and black gloves on her hands. "Are there any letters for J.E.?" I inquired. She peered at me over her glasses, then opened a drawer and rummaged through its contents for a considerable time, so long that my hope began to fade. Finally, after holding a document up to her glasses for nearly five minutes, she handed it across the counter, giving me another questioning and suspicious look. It was addressed to J.E. "Is this the only one?" I asked. "There are no others," she replied. I placed it in my pocket and started heading back. I couldn't open it yet; rules required me to be back by eight, and it was already half-past seven.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: At the break of dawn, I got up early and prepared my advertisement—writing it out, enclosing it, and addressing it before the school’s morning bell rung. My ad stated: 'A young lady with experience in teaching' (after all, I’d taught for two years) 'seeks a position in a private household, caring for children under fourteen' (since I was not yet eighteen, teaching children close to my own age wouldn’t be ideal). 'She can instruct in the standard English subjects, as well as French, Drawing, and Music' (at that time, this would have been considered a well-rounded education). 'Replies to J.E., Post-office, Lowton, ——shire.' I kept this advert locked in my drawer all day. After dinner, I asked the new head of the school for permission to go to Lowton to run a few errands for myself and some colleagues; she agreed, and I set out. It was a two-mile journey on a rainy evening, but since the days were long, I managed to visit a couple of shops, mail my letter, and return in the downpour—soaked, but feeling relieved. The following week dragged on, but eventually ended as all things do, and again, on a pleasant autumn evening, I found myself walking to Lowton. The route was scenic, running beside a stream and through the most beautiful parts of the valley; still, my thoughts were preoccupied with wondering if any replies awaited me at the small town post office, rather than admiring the scenery. My main reason for this trip was to have my feet measured for new shoes, which I took care of first. 'Is that all?' I asked. 'No more,' she replied. I pocketed the letter and headed home; I didn’t open it yet, as the rules required me to return by eight, and it was already half-past seven.

events.title: Receiving and Contemplating the Thornfield Offer
detailed_summary: Upon her return to Lowood, various duties awaited the narrator: supervising the girls during their study hour, leading prayers, and seeing them to bed, followed by supper with the other teachers.
Even when they retired for the night, her roommate, Miss Gryce, was still present.
With only a short piece of candle remaining, the narrator feared Miss Gryce would talk until it burned out.
Fortunately, Miss Gryce's heavy supper induced sleep, and she was snoring before the narrator had finished undressing.
With an inch of candle still left, the narrator took out her letter.
The seal bore the initial 'F.'; she broke it and read the brief contents.
The letter inquired if 'J.E.', who advertised in the previous Thursday's Herald, possessed the stated qualifications and could provide satisfactory references regarding character and competence.
If so, a position could be offered with one pupil, a little girl under ten years of age, at a salary of thirty pounds per annum.
J.E. was requested to send references, name, address, and all particulars to 'Mrs. Fairfax, Thornfield, near Millcote, shire.'
The narrator examined the document at length, noting the old-fashioned and somewhat uncertain handwriting, like that of an elderly lady.
This detail was reassuring, as she had a private fear of getting into trouble by acting independently, and she strongly wished for a respectable outcome.
She felt that an elderly lady would be a positive element in her new endeavor.
She envisioned Mrs. Fairfax in a black gown and widow’s cap, possibly stern but polite, a model of elderly English respectability.
She presumed Thornfield was the name of Mrs. Fairfax's house, imagining it as a neat, orderly place, though she couldn't picture its layout.
Recalling her geography, she located Millcote and the shire, noting it was seventy miles closer to London than her current remote location, which she considered an advantage.
She longed for a place with life and movement; Millcote was a large manufacturing town, which she thought would provide a complete change, and thus be beneficial.
While not particularly drawn to the imagery of chimneys and smoke, she reasoned that Thornfield would likely be situated some distance from the town itself.
At this point, the candle stub fell into the socket, and the wick extinguished.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Various duties awaited me on my arrival: I had to sit with the girls during their hour of study; then it was my turn to read prayers; to see them to bed: afterwards I supped with the other teachers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Here the socket of the candle dropped, and the wick went out.

events.text_segment:
Various duties awaited me on my arrival: I had to sit with the girls during their hour of study; then it was my turn to read prayers; to see them to bed: afterwards I supped with the other teachers. Even when we finally retired for the night, the inevitable Miss Gryce was still my companion: we had only a short end of candle in our candlestick, and I dreaded lest she should talk till it was all burnt out; fortunately, however, the heavy supper she had eaten produced a soporific effect: she was already snoring before I had finished undressing. There still remained an inch of candle: I now took out my letter; the seal was an initial F.; I broke it; the contents were brief.
“If J.E., who advertised in the ——shire Herald of last Thursday, possesses the acquirements mentioned, and if she is in a position to give satisfactory references as to character and competency, a situation can be offered her where there is but one pupil, a little girl, under ten years of age; and where the salary is thirty pounds per annum. J.E. is requested to send references, name, address, and all particulars to the direction:—
“Mrs. Fairfax, Thornfield, near Millcote, ——shire.”
I examined the document long: the writing was old-fashioned and rather uncertain, like that of an elderly lady. This circumstance was satisfactory: a private fear had haunted me, that in thus acting for myself, and by my own guidance, I ran the risk of getting into some scrape; and, above all things, I wished the result of my endeavours to be respectable, proper, en règle. I now felt that an elderly lady was no bad ingredient in the business I had on hand. Mrs. Fairfax! I saw her in a black gown and widow’s cap; frigid, perhaps, but not uncivil: a model of elderly English respectability. Thornfield! that, doubtless, was the name of her house: a neat orderly spot, I was sure; though I failed in my efforts to conceive a correct plan of the premises. Millcote, ——shire; I brushed up my recollections of the map of England; yes, I saw it; both the shire and the town. ——shire was seventy miles nearer London than the remote county where I now resided: that was a recommendation to me. I longed to go where there was life and movement: Millcote was a large manufacturing town on the banks of the A——: a busy place enough, doubtless: so much the better; it would be a complete change at least. Not that my fancy was much captivated by the idea of long chimneys and clouds of smoke—“but,” I argued, “Thornfield will, probably, be a good way from the town.”
Here the socket of the candle dropped, and the wick went out.

events.title: Securing the Governess Role and Preparing for Departure
detailed_summary: The following day, the narrator knew she had to take further steps and could no longer keep her plans to herself if she wanted them to succeed.
She sought and was granted an audience with the superintendent during the midday break.
She informed the superintendent of her prospect of a new situation where the salary would be double her current earnings at Lowood (which was only £15 per annum).
She requested the superintendent's assistance in broaching the subject with Mr. Brocklehurst or the committee and to ascertain if they would allow her to use them as references.
The superintendent kindly agreed to act as a go-between in the matter.
The next day, the superintendent presented the affair to Mr. Brocklehurst, who stipulated that Mrs. Reed, as the narrator's natural guardian, must be contacted.
A note was accordingly sent to Mrs. Reed, who replied that the narrator 'might do as I pleased: she had long relinquished all interference in my affairs.'
This note was circulated among the committee members.
After what felt like a very tedious delay to the narrator, formal permission was granted for her to improve her situation if possible.

An assurance was added that, due to her consistently good conduct as both pupil and teacher at Lowood, a testimonial of her character and capacity, signed by the institution's inspectors, would be provided to her promptly.
She received this testimonial about a month later, forwarded a copy to Mrs. Fairfax, and subsequently received a reply from Mrs. Fairfax.
Mrs. Fairfax's letter stated her satisfaction and set a date a fortnight away for the narrator to begin her post as governess at Thornfield.
The narrator then busied herself with preparations for her departure, and the two weeks passed quickly.
Her wardrobe was not extensive but sufficient for her needs, and the last day was adequate for packing her trunk—the same one she had brought from Gateshead eight years prior.

With her trunk corded and labeled, awaiting the carrier who would take it to Lowton, and her own departure scheduled for early the next morning to meet the coach, she completed her final arrangements.
She had brushed her travel dress, prepared her bonnet, gloves, and muff, and checked her drawers for any forgotten items.
Having nothing more to do, she sat down to rest but found herself too excited to do so, despite being active all day.

A phase of her life was concluding that night, with a new one beginning the next day, making sleep impossible; she felt compelled to remain awake and alert while this significant change was happening.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Next day new steps were to be taken; my plans could no longer be confined to my own breast; I must impart them in order to achieve their success.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A phase of my life was closing to-night, a new one opening to-morrow: impossible to slumber in the interval; I must watch feverishly while the change was being accomplished.

events.text_segment:
Next day new steps were to be taken; my plans could no longer be confined to my own breast; I must impart them in order to achieve their success. Having sought and obtained an audience of the superintendent during the noontide recreation, I told her I had a prospect of getting a new situation where the salary would be double what I now received (for at Lowood I only got £15 per annum); and requested she would break the matter for me to Mr. Brocklehurst, or some of the committee, and ascertain whether they would permit me to mention them as references. She obligingly consented to act as mediatrix in the matter. The next day she laid the affair before Mr. Brocklehurst, who said that Mrs. Reed must be written to, as she was my natural guardian. A note was accordingly addressed to that lady, who returned for answer, that “I might do as I pleased: she had long relinquished all interference in my affairs.” This note went the round of the committee, and at last, after what appeared to me most tedious delay, formal leave was given me to better my condition if I could; and an assurance added, that as I had always conducted myself well, both as teacher and pupil, at Lowood, a testimonial of character and capacity, signed by the inspectors of that institution, should forthwith be furnished me.
This testimonial I accordingly received in about a month, forwarded a copy of it to Mrs. Fairfax, and got that lady’s reply, stating that she was satisfied, and fixing that day fortnight as the period for my assuming the post of governess in her house.
I now busied myself in preparations: the fortnight passed rapidly. I had not a very large wardrobe, though it was adequate to my wants; and the last day sufficed to pack my trunk,—the same I had brought with me eight years ago from Gateshead.
The box was corded, the card nailed on. In half-an-hour the carrier was to call for it to take it to Lowton, whither I myself was to repair at an early hour the next morning to meet the coach. I had brushed my black stuff travelling-dress, prepared my bonnet, gloves, and muff; sought in all my drawers to see that no article was left behind; and now having nothing more to do, I sat down and tried to rest. I could not; though I had been on foot all day, I could not now repose an instant; I was too much excited. A phase of my life was closing to-night, a new one opening to-morrow: impossible to slumber in the interval; I must watch feverishly while the change was being accomplished.

One phase of my life was ending tonight, and a new one was beginning tomorrow. It was impossible to sleep during this interval; I had to stay awake, eagerly anticipating the change as it happened.
