events.title: Bessie's Unexpected Visit and Revelations from the Past
detailed_summary: While the narrator was wandering anxiously in the lobby, a servant informed her that someone downstairs wished to see her.
Assuming it was the carrier for her trunk, she hurried downstairs without further inquiry.
As she passed the half-open door of the teachers' sitting-room on her way to the kitchen, someone ran out.
An individual stopped her, took her hand, and exclaimed they were sure it was her and could recognize her anywhere.
The narrator looked and saw a woman dressed like a well-attired servant, matronly yet still youthful, with dark hair and eyes, and a lively complexion.
The woman, with a half-recognized voice and smile, asked if the narrator had forgotten her, addressing her as 'Miss Jane.'
Recognizing her, the narrator embraced and kissed her rapturously, repeatedly exclaiming 'Bessie!'
Bessie, half-laughing and half-crying, accompanied her into the parlor, where a little boy of about three years old stood by the fire.
Bessie introduced the boy as her son.
The narrator learned Bessie had been married for nearly five years to Robert Leaven, the coachman, and also had a little girl named Jane.
Bessie now lived at the lodge at Gateshead, as the old porter had left.
The narrator eagerly asked for news about everyone at Gateshead, inviting Bessie to sit and her son, Bobby, to sit on her knee, though Bobby preferred to stay with his mother.

Bessie (now Mrs. Leaven) observed that Miss Jane had not grown very tall or stout, speculating she hadn't been well-fed at school, and commented that Miss Reed (Eliza) was much taller and Miss Georgiana much broader.

When asked, Bessie confirmed Georgiana was very handsome and had been admired in London, where a young lord fell in love with her; they planned to elope but were discovered and stopped, with Miss Reed (Eliza) being the one to find them out, possibly due to envy. Now the sisters constantly quarreled.

Regarding John Reed, Bessie reported he was not doing well, having failed at college (been 'plucked') and, despite his uncles wanting him to study law, he was too dissipated for them to make much of him.
She described John as very tall, considered fine-looking by some, but with thick lips.
Mrs. Reed looked well enough physically but seemed uneasy in her mind, displeased with John's conduct and his excessive spending.
Bessie explained she hadn't been sent by Mrs. Reed but had long wanted to see Jane and decided to visit upon hearing Jane had written and was leaving for another part of the country.
Jane, laughing, said she feared Bessie was disappointed in her, perceiving that Bessie's affectionate gaze lacked admiration.
Bessie responded frankly that Jane was 'genteel enough' and looked like a lady, which was as much as she had expected, as Jane was 'no beauty as a child.'
Jane smiled at this honest assessment, acknowledging its truth but admitting it wasn't entirely without impact, as most eighteen-year-olds wish to be pleasing.
Bessie, by way of comfort, suggested Jane must be clever and asked about her accomplishments, specifically if she could play the piano.
Upon learning Jane could play 'a little,' Bessie opened the piano in the room and asked for a tune; Jane played a waltz or two, charming Bessie.
Bessie exclaimed that the Miss Reeds couldn't play as well and that she always knew Jane would surpass them in learning. She then inquired if Jane could draw.
Jane pointed to one of her watercolor landscapes over the chimney-piece, a gift to the superintendent who had framed it.
Bessie admired the painting greatly, declaring it as fine as anything the Miss Reeds' drawing-master could produce, and far beyond the young ladies' own abilities. She then asked about French.
Jane confirmed she could both read and speak French, and also work on muslin and canvas.
Bessie declared Jane 'quite a lady' and expressed confidence in her success regardless of her relations' notice.
Bessie then mentioned something she wanted to ask: if Jane had ever heard from her father's relatives, the Eyres.
Jane replied she never had.

Bessie recalled that Mrs. Reed always described the Eyres as poor and despicable, but Bessie believed they might be poor yet still gentry like the Reeds. She then revealed a significant piece of information.

Nearly seven years prior, a Mr. Eyre had come to Gateshead asking to see Jane. Mrs. Reed told him Jane was at school fifty miles away. He seemed very disappointed as he couldn't stay, being on his way to a foreign country on a ship sailing from London in a day or two. Bessie described him as looking 'quite a gentleman' and believed he was Jane's father's brother.
When Jane asked about the foreign country, Bessie mentioned it was an island thousands of miles away where they make wine, which the butler had told her.
Jane suggested 'Madeira?' and Bessie confirmed that was the exact word.

Mr. Eyre had not stayed long at Gateshead; Mrs. Reed had been very dismissive towards him, later calling him a 'sneaking tradesman.' Bessie added that her husband, Robert, believed he was a wine-merchant.
Jane agreed this was very likely, or perhaps he was a clerk or agent to a wine-merchant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Miss,” said a servant who met me in the lobby, where I was wandering like a troubled spirit, “a person below wishes to see you.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Very likely,” I returned; “or perhaps clerk or agent to a wine-merchant.”

events.text_segment:
“Miss,” said a servant who met me in the lobby, where I was wandering like a troubled spirit, “a person below wishes to see you.”
“The carrier, no doubt,” I thought, and ran downstairs without inquiry. I was passing the back-parlour or teachers’ sitting-room, the door of which was half open, to go to the kitchen, when some one ran out—
“It’s her, I am sure!—I could have told her anywhere!” cried the individual who stopped my progress and took my hand.
I looked: I saw a woman attired like a well-dressed servant, matronly, yet still young; very good-looking, with black hair and eyes, and lively complexion.
“Well, who is it?” she asked, in a voice and with a smile I half recognised; “you’ve not quite forgotten me, I think, Miss Jane?”
In another second I was embracing and kissing her rapturously: “Bessie! Bessie! Bessie!” that was all I said; whereat she half laughed, half cried, and we both went into the parlour. By the fire stood a little fellow of three years old, in plaid frock and trousers.
“That is my little boy,” said Bessie directly.
“Then you are married, Bessie?”
“Yes; nearly five years since to Robert Leaven, the coachman; and I’ve a little girl besides Bobby there, that I’ve christened Jane.”
“And you don’t live at Gateshead?”
“I live at the lodge: the old porter has left.”
“Well, and how do they all get on? Tell me everything about them, Bessie: but sit down first; and, Bobby, come and sit on my knee, will you?” but Bobby preferred sidling over to his mother.
“You’re not grown so very tall, Miss Jane, nor so very stout,” continued Mrs. Leaven. “I dare say they’ve not kept you too well at school: Miss Reed is the head and shoulders taller than you are; and Miss Georgiana would make two of you in breadth.”
“Georgiana is handsome, I suppose, Bessie?”
“Very. She went up to London last winter with her mama, and there everybody admired her, and a young lord fell in love with her: but his relations were against the match; and—what do you think?—he and Miss Georgiana made it up to run away; but they were found out and stopped. It was Miss Reed that found them out: I believe she was envious; and now she and her sister lead a cat and dog life together; they are always quarrelling—”
“Well, and what of John Reed?”
“Oh, he is not doing so well as his mama could wish. He went to college, and he got—plucked, I think they call it: and then his uncles wanted him to be a barrister, and study the law: but he is such a dissipated young man, they will never make much of him, I think.”
“What does he look like?”
“He is very tall: some people call him a fine-looking young man; but he has such thick lips.”
“And Mrs. Reed?”
“Missis looks stout and well enough in the face, but I think she’s not quite easy in her mind: Mr. John’s conduct does not please her—he spends a deal of money.”
“Did she send you here, Bessie?”
“No, indeed: but I have long wanted to see you, and when I heard that there had been a letter from you, and that you were going to another part of the country, I thought I’d just set off, and get a look at you before you were quite out of my reach.”
“I am afraid you are disappointed in me, Bessie.” I said this laughing: I perceived that Bessie’s glance, though it expressed regard, did in no shape denote admiration.
“No, Miss Jane, not exactly: you are genteel enough; you look like a lady, and it is as much as ever I expected of you: you were no beauty as a child.”
I smiled at Bessie’s frank answer: I felt that it was correct, but I confess I was not quite indifferent to its import: at eighteen most people wish to please, and the conviction that they have not an exterior likely to second that desire brings anything but gratification.
“I dare say you are clever, though,” continued Bessie, by way of solace. “What can you do? Can you play on the piano?”
“A little.”
There was one in the room; Bessie went and opened it, and then asked me to sit down and give her a tune: I played a waltz or two, and she was charmed.
“The Miss Reeds could not play as well!” said she exultingly. “I always said you would surpass them in learning: and can you draw?”
“That is one of my paintings over the chimney-piece.” It was a landscape in water colours, of which I had made a present to the superintendent, in acknowledgment of her obliging mediation with the committee on my behalf, and which she had framed and glazed.
“Well, that is beautiful, Miss Jane! It is as fine a picture as any Miss Reed’s drawing-master could paint, let alone the young ladies themselves, who could not come near it: and have you learnt French?”
“Yes, Bessie, I can both read it and speak it.”
“And you can work on muslin and canvas?”
“I can.”
“Oh, you are quite a lady, Miss Jane! I knew you would be: you will get on whether your relations notice you or not. There was something I wanted to ask you. Have you ever heard anything from your father’s kinsfolk, the Eyres?”
“Never in my life.”
“Well, you know Missis always said they were poor and quite despicable: and they may be poor; but I believe they are as much gentry as the Reeds are; for one day, nearly seven years ago, a Mr. Eyre came to Gateshead and wanted to see you; Missis said you were at school fifty miles off; he seemed so much disappointed, for he could not stay: he was going on a voyage to a foreign country, and the ship was to sail from London in a day or two. He looked quite a gentleman, and I believe he was your father’s brother.”
“What foreign country was he going to, Bessie?”
“An island thousands of miles off, where they make wine—the butler did tell me—”
“Madeira?” I suggested.
“Yes, that is it—that is the very word.”
“So he went?”
“Yes; he did not stay many minutes in the house: Missis was very high with him; she called him afterwards a ‘sneaking tradesman.’ My Robert believes he was a wine-merchant.”
“Very likely,” I returned; “or perhaps clerk or agent to a wine-merchant.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A servant encountered me in the hallway, where I was pacing restlessly, and informed me that someone downstairs wanted to see me. Assuming it was the carrier, I quickly headed down without asking any questions. As I passed the back-parlour, which also served as the teachers' lounge, with its door ajar, someone rushed out. “It’s definitely her! I’d know her anywhere!” exclaimed the person who halted my progress and took my hand. I looked closely and saw a woman dressed like a respectable servant, looking mature but still youthful, quite attractive with dark hair and eyes, and a vibrant complexion. She asked, in a voice and with a smile that were somewhat familiar, “Well, do you remember me, Miss Jane? I don’t think you’ve completely forgotten.” In an instant, I was hugging and kissing her with joy, repeating only, “Bessie! Bessie! Bessie!” She responded with a mix of laughter and tears, and we went into the parlour together. By the fireplace stood a little boy, about three years old, wearing a plaid outfit. Bessie immediately said, “That’s my son.” “So, you’re married, Bessie?” I asked. “Yes, almost five years now, to Robert Leaven, the coachman. And besides Bobby here, I have a little girl I named Jane.” “And you’re not living at Gateshead Hall anymore?” “I live in the lodge; the old gatekeeper is gone.” “Alright, how is everyone there? Tell me everything about them, Bessie, but please sit down first. And Bobby, won’t you come sit on my lap?” Bobby, however, preferred to stay close to his mother. “You haven’t grown much taller, Miss Jane, or wider,” Mrs. Leaven commented. “I expect they didn’t feed you particularly well at school. Miss Reed is much taller than you, and Miss Georgiana is twice your width.” “Georgiana is pretty, I presume, Bessie?” “Very. She went to London with her mother last winter and everyone admired her. A young lord even fell in love with her, but his family opposed the marriage. And can you believe it? He and Miss Georgiana planned to elope, but they were discovered and stopped. Miss Reed was the one who found them out – I think she was jealous. Now she and her sister are always fighting, like cats and dogs.” “And what about John Reed?” “Oh, he’s not doing as well as his mother hoped. He went to college and failed, or ‘got plucked’ I think they call it. Then his uncles wanted him to be a lawyer, but he’s so wild and irresponsible, I don’t think he’ll ever amount to much.” “What does he look like?” “He’s very tall. Some people say he’s handsome, but he has really thick lips.” “And Mrs. Reed?” “The mistress looks healthy enough in the face, but I don’t think she’s content. Mr. John’s behaviour upsets her, and he spends a great deal of money.” “Did she send you here, Bessie?” “No, not at all. But I’ve wanted to see you for a long time. When I heard you’d written and were moving away, I decided I had to come and see you before you were completely out of reach.” “I’m afraid I’ve disappointed you, Bessie,” I said with a laugh. I could see that while Bessie’s look showed affection, it certainly didn’t show admiration. “No, Miss Jane, not exactly. You’re proper enough; you look like a lady, and that’s as much as I ever expected from you. You weren’t a beauty as a child.” I smiled at Bessie’s honest reply. I knew it was true, but I must admit I wasn’t entirely unaffected by it. At eighteen, most people want to be appealing, and knowing one’s appearance isn’t likely to help that desire is anything but pleasant. “I suppose you’re clever, though,” Bessie continued, offering comfort. “What can you do? Can you play the piano?” “A little.” There was a piano in the room. Bessie went and opened it, then asked me to play something for her. I played a couple of waltzes, and she was delighted. “The Miss Reeds couldn’t play that well!” she said proudly. “I always said you’d be smarter than them. And can you draw?” “That landscape above the fireplace is one of my paintings.” It was a watercolour I had given to the superintendent as thanks for her help with the committee regarding me; she had it framed and glazed. “Wow, that’s beautiful, Miss Jane! That picture is as good as anything Miss Reed’s drawing teacher could do, let alone the young ladies themselves, who are nowhere near that good. And have you learned French?” “Yes, Bessie, I can both read and speak it.” “And you can do embroidery on fine cloth and canvas?” “Yes, I can.” “Oh, you’re completely a lady, Miss Jane! I knew you would be. You’ll succeed whether your relatives acknowledge you or not. There was something else I wanted to ask. Have you ever heard anything from your father’s family, the Eyres?” “Never.” “Well, you know the mistress always said they were poor and looked down upon. They might be poor, but I think they’re just as much gentry as the Reeds. Because one day, nearly seven years ago, a Mr. Eyre came to Gateshead asking to see you. The mistress said you were at school fifty miles away. He seemed very disappointed because he couldn’t stay; he was going on a sea voyage to a foreign country, and his ship was sailing from London in a day or two. He looked like a proper gentleman, and I believe he was your father’s brother.” “What foreign country was he going to, Bessie?” “An island thousands of miles away where they make wine – the butler told me…” “Madeira?” I suggested. “Yes, that’s it – that’s the exact word.” “So he went?” “Yes, he didn’t stay long. The mistress was very haughty with him; she later called him a ‘shifty tradesman.’ My Robert thinks he was a wine merchant.” “That’s very likely,” I replied. “Or perhaps a clerk or agent for one.”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: As I wandered anxiously through the hallway, a servant approached and informed me, "Miss, someone downstairs wants to see you." Assuming it was the carrier, I hurried down without asking further questions. On my way to the kitchen, as I passed the partially open door of the teachers' sitting-room, a woman suddenly emerged and caught hold of me, exclaiming, "It's her, I'm sure! I'd recognize her anywhere!" Pausing, I saw before me a neatly dressed servant woman, with a matronly yet youthful appearance, striking features, black hair and eyes, and a lively complexion. With a familiar smile and voice, she asked me if I hadn't forgotten her, calling me Miss Jane. Realizing who she was, I excitedly hugged and kissed her, overjoyed to see Bessie again. She laughed and cried at the same time, and we both entered the sitting-room, where her little three-year-old boy stood by the fire. Bessie introduced the child as her son, Bobby, and told me she had been married for nearly five years to Robert Leaven the coachman, and that she also had a daughter named Jane. She explained she now lived at the lodge since the old porter had left. Curious about all the people at Gateshead, I invited her to sit and asked for news, but little Bobby chose to stay close to his mother rather than sit with me. Bessie remarked that I hadn't become much taller or stouter and compared me to the Reed girls, who were much more physically imposing. She confirmed that Georgiana was very pretty and had caused a stir in London, even attracting a young lord, though the relationship was stopped when Eliza Reed, possibly motivated by jealousy, discovered their plans to elope, leading to ongoing quarrels between the sisters. As for John Reed, Bessie explained he hadn't turned out as well as his mother hoped; he failed at college, rejected plans to study law, and lived a wasteful life, disappointing his family. When I asked about his appearance, she told me he was tall and considered handsome by some, but had thick lips. Mrs. Reed, she said, looked well but seemed troubled, especially by John's spending habits. Bessie clarified that she came to see me of her own accord, wishing to visit me before I left for another part of the country. Lightheartedly, I asked if she was disappointed in how I'd turned out, admitting that at eighteen I still cared about such things. Bessie honestly told me I looked as much like a lady as she had expected, though I was never a beauty as a child. She then asked about my accomplishments; I played a few tunes for her on the piano, which pleased her, and showed her a painting of mine, which she praised highly. She inquired whether I'd learned French and sewing, and upon hearing I had, congratulated me on my progress and confidence that I would succeed regardless of whether my relatives acknowledged me. Changing the subject, Bessie asked if I'd ever heard from my father's family, the Eyres. I said I had not. She recounted that some years ago, a Mr. Eyre—believed to be my father's brother—visited Gateshead to see me, but was unable to because I was away at school. He was about to depart on a voyage to a distant island known for wine-making—Madeira, I guessed. Bessie recalled that Mrs. Reed called him a "sneaking tradesman" afterward, though Bessie's husband Robert believed he was a wine-merchant or perhaps just an agent. I agreed that it was possible.

events.title: Farewell to Bessie and Journey to a New Life
detailed_summary: Jane and Bessie continued their conversation about past times for another hour before Bessie had to depart.
Jane saw Bessie again briefly the following morning in Lowton while she was awaiting the coach.
Their final parting occurred at the door of the Brocklehurst Arms in Lowton.
Each then went her own way: Bessie set off towards Lowood Fell to catch the transport back to Gateshead.
Jane boarded the vehicle that was to take her towards her new responsibilities and a new chapter of her life in the unfamiliar area of Millcote.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Bessie and I conversed about old times an hour longer, and then she was obliged to leave me: I saw her again for a few minutes the next morning at Lowton, while I was waiting for the coach.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I mounted the vehicle which was to bear me to new duties and a new life in the unknown environs of Millcote.

We parted finally at the door of the Brocklehurst Arms there: each went her separate way; she set off for the brow of Lowood Fell to meet the conveyance which was to take her back to Gateshead, I mounted the vehicle which was to bear me to new duties and a new life in the unknown environs of Millcote.

events.title: Arrival at Millcote Inn and Anxious Wait
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jane Eyre, introduces herself in a room at the George Inn in Millcote, having arrived after a lengthy sixteen-hour journey from Lowton.
Despite the seemingly comfortable accommodations, Jane experiences significant anxiety because no one has arrived to meet her as she had anticipated.
She reminisces about her hopeful search for a carriage to Thornfield upon her arrival and her inquiry to a waiter about anyone asking for Miss Eyre, which yielded no positive news.
Consequently, she requested a private room and now waits alone, her mind filled with unsettling doubts and apprehensions about her situation.

Jane reflects on the profound and disquieting sensation of being utterly alone and uncertain in the world, a feeling common to inexperienced youth, noting how this is somewhat mitigated by the excitement of adventure and a sense of pride, yet predominantly overshadowed by fear as time passes without any contact.
After about half an hour of solitary waiting, she resolves to ring the bell for assistance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A new chapter in a novel is something like a new scene in a play; and when I draw up the curtain this time, reader, you must fancy you see a room in the George Inn at Millcote, with such large figured papering on the walls as inn rooms have; such a carpet, such furniture, such ornaments on the mantelpiece, such prints, including a portrait of George the Third, and another of the Prince of Wales, and a representation of the death of Wolfe.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I bethought myself to ring the bell.

events.text_segment:
A new chapter in a novel is something like a new scene in a play; and when I draw up the curtain this time, reader, you must fancy you see a room in the George Inn at Millcote, with such large figured papering on the walls as inn rooms have; such a carpet, such furniture, such ornaments on the mantelpiece, such prints, including a portrait of George the Third, and another of the Prince of Wales, and a representation of the death of Wolfe. All this is visible to you by the light of an oil lamp hanging from the ceiling, and by that of an excellent fire, near which I sit in my cloak and bonnet; my muff and umbrella lie on the table, and I am warming away the numbness and chill contracted by sixteen hours’ exposure to the rawness of an October day: I left Lowton at four o’clock A.M., and the Millcote town clock is now just striking eight.
Reader, though I look comfortably accommodated, I am not very tranquil in my mind. I thought when the coach stopped here there would be some one to meet me; I looked anxiously round as I descended the wooden steps the “boots” placed for my convenience, expecting to hear my name pronounced, and to see some description of carriage waiting to convey me to Thornfield. Nothing of the sort was visible; and when I asked a waiter if any one had been to inquire after a Miss Eyre, I was answered in the negative: so I had no resource but to request to be shown into a private room: and here I am waiting, while all sorts of doubts and fears are troubling my thoughts.
It is a very strange sensation to inexperienced youth to feel itself quite alone in the world, cut adrift from every connection, uncertain whether the port to which it is bound can be reached, and prevented by many impediments from returning to that it has quitted. The charm of adventure sweetens that sensation, the glow of pride warms it; but then the throb of fear disturbs it; and fear with me became predominant when half-an-hour elapsed and still I was alone. I bethought myself to ring the bell.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Starting a new part of a story is like unveiling a fresh scene in a play. So, when I reveal this new setting, dear reader, picture yourself in a room at the George Inn in Millcote. Imagine walls covered in that large, patterned wallpaper typical of inns, along with the usual carpet, furnishings, and decorations on the mantelpiece. There are prints on the wall, including portraits of King George III and the Prince of Wales, plus a depiction of General Wolfe's death. You can see all of this illuminated by the light of an oil lamp hanging from the ceiling and a warm, excellent fire, beside which I am sitting wrapped in my cloak and bonnet. My muff and umbrella are on the table. I'm trying to get rid of the cold numbness I've felt after spending sixteen hours exposed to the chilly, raw October air. I left Lowton at 4:00 AM, and the clock in Millcote is now just striking eight.

Reader, although I appear to be comfortably settled, I am far from feeling peaceful internally. I expected someone to be here to meet me when the coach arrived. As I stepped down the wooden steps the attendant placed, I looked around anxiously, hoping to hear my name called and see a carriage waiting to take me to Thornfield. Nothing of the kind was present. When I asked a waiter if anyone had inquired about a Miss Eyre, the answer was no. Therefore, my only option was to ask to be shown to a private room, and here I am, waiting, while various worries and anxieties fill my mind.

It's a peculiar feeling for a young person without much experience to find themselves completely alone in the world, disconnected from all ties, unsure if they will reach their intended destination, and facing numerous obstacles preventing them from going back to where they came from. The excitement of an adventure adds a pleasant aspect to this feeling, and a sense of pride gives it warmth. However, then the jolt of fear disrupts it, and fear became the strongest emotion for me when half an hour passed and I was still by myself. I decided I should ring the bell.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Beginning a new chapter in a novel feels much like starting a new act in a play. Imagine, dear reader, as I lift the curtain on this scene, that you find yourself in a room at the George Inn in Millcote. The walls are covered with the kind of busy patterned wallpaper typical of inns, accompanied by suitable carpets, furniture, and mantlepiece decorations. There are pictures on the walls, including portraits of George III and the Prince of Wales, as well as an illustration of Wolfe’s death. All of this is illuminated by an oil lamp hanging from the ceiling and a bright fire nearby. I’m seated close to the fire in my cloak and bonnet, with my muff and umbrella on the table, trying to recover from sixteen hours spent out in the chilly October weather. I left Lowton at 4 a.m., and it’s now eight as the clock in Millcote chimes.

Even though I appear to be settled comfortably, my mind is uneasy. I expected someone would meet me when the coach arrived, so I scanned the area eagerly as I stepped down, hoping to hear my name and see a carriage ready to take me to Thornfield. But no such person or vehicle was there. When I asked a waiter if anyone had come to ask about Miss Eyre, he said no. With no other choice, I asked for a private room, where I’m now waiting, my mind plagued with doubts and worries.

For someone young and inexperienced, it is a peculiar feeling to be truly alone in the world, cut off from all familiar ties, unsure if your journey’s end can be reached and unable to return to where you came from. While a spirit of adventure makes the feeling more bearable, and a sense of pride adds some warmth, fear still overrides these emotions—and the longer I waited alone, the more that fear took hold. After half an hour, I decided to ring the bell.

events.title: Inquiry about Thornfield and Departure by Carriage
detailed_summary: Jane summons a waiter and inquires if a place named Thornfield exists in the vicinity.
The waiter, initially uncertain, quickly returns to confirm Jane's identity as Miss Eyre and informs her that someone is indeed waiting for her.
Filled with anticipation, Jane hurries to the inn's passage, where she observes a man standing by an open door and a one-horse conveyance in the lamplit street.
The man addresses her somewhat abruptly, identifying her trunk and loading it onto the vehicle.
Before they depart, Jane ascertains that Thornfield is approximately six miles away, a journey estimated to take about an hour and a half.
The man secures the carriage door, takes his seat outside, and they commence their journey at a relaxed speed, affording Jane ample opportunity for contemplation.

She reflects on her prospective employer, Mrs. Fairfax, hoping she is not overly grand or imposing like Mrs. Reed, and comforts herself with the thought that she can always seek alternative employment if the situation proves unsuitable, wondering about their progress.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Is there a place in this neighbourhood called Thornfield?” I asked of the waiter who answered the summons.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: How far are we on our road now, I wonder?”

events.text_segment:
“Is there a place in this neighbourhood called Thornfield?” I asked of the waiter who answered the summons.
“Thornfield? I don’t know, ma’am; I’ll inquire at the bar.” He vanished, but reappeared instantly—
“Is your name Eyre, Miss?”
“Yes.”
“Person here waiting for you.”
I jumped up, took my muff and umbrella, and hastened into the inn-passage: a man was standing by the open door, and in the lamp-lit street I dimly saw a one-horse conveyance.
“This will be your luggage, I suppose?” said the man rather abruptly when he saw me, pointing to my trunk in the passage.
“Yes.” He hoisted it on to the vehicle, which was a sort of car, and then I got in; before he shut me up, I asked him how far it was to Thornfield.
“A matter of six miles.”
“How long shall we be before we get there?”
“Happen an hour and a half.”
He fastened the car door, climbed to his own seat outside, and we set off. Our progress was leisurely, and gave me ample time to reflect; I was content to be at length so near the end of my journey; and as I leaned back in the comfortable though not elegant conveyance, I meditated much at my ease.
“I suppose,” thought I, “judging from the plainness of the servant and carriage, Mrs. Fairfax is not a very dashing person: so much the better; I never lived amongst fine people but once, and I was very miserable with them. I wonder if she lives alone except this little girl; if so, and if she is in any degree amiable, I shall surely be able to get on with her; I will do my best; it is a pity that doing one’s best does not always answer. At Lowood, indeed, I took that resolution, kept it, and succeeded in pleasing; but with Mrs. Reed, I remember my best was always spurned with scorn. I pray God Mrs. Fairfax may not turn out a second Mrs. Reed; but if she does, I am not bound to stay with her! let the worst come to the worst, I can advertise again. How far are we on our road now, I wonder?”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I asked the waiter who came to the door if there was a place called Thornfield nearby. "Thornfield? I don't know, ma'am; I'll check at the bar." He went away but returned immediately. "Is your name Miss Eyre?" "Yes." "Someone is here waiting for you." I quickly stood up, grabbed my muff and umbrella, and hurried into the inn corridor. A man was standing by the open door, and I could faintly see a one-horse vehicle in the street illuminated by a lamp. Seeing me, the man pointed to my trunk in the passage and said rather abruptly, "This must be your luggage, I assume?" "Yes." He lifted it onto the vehicle, which was a type of small carriage, and then I got in. Before he closed the door, I inquired how far it was to Thornfield. "About six miles." "How long will it take us to get there?" "Probably an hour and a half." He fastened the carriage door, climbed onto his seat outside, and we started off. Our journey was slow, giving me plenty of time to think. I was glad to finally be so close to my destination, and as I leaned back comfortably, despite the carriage being simple rather than fancy, I reflected at ease. I thought, "Considering how plain the servant and carriage are, I suppose Mrs. Fairfax isn't a very flashy person. That's good; I was only ever around grand people once, and it made me very unhappy. I wonder if she lives alone apart from this little girl. If so, and if she is reasonably pleasant, I'm sure I can get along with her. I'll try my best; it's a shame that trying your best doesn't always work out. At Lowood, I did make that decision, stuck to it, and managed to please others. But with Mrs. Reed, I recall my best efforts were always met with contempt. I hope to God Mrs. Fairfax doesn't turn out to be like Mrs. Reed; but if she does, I'm not obligated to stay! If the worst happens, I can advertise again. How far along are we now, I wonder?"

I wondered how much farther we had to go.

events.title: Journey Observations and Arrival at Thornfield Hall
detailed_summary: Jane peers out of the carriage window and notes that Millcote appears to be a significantly larger town than Lowton.
She perceives the current region as more densely populated and vibrant, though lacking the picturesque and romantic qualities of Lowood.
The journey proceeds slowly due to difficult road conditions and misty weather, taking longer than the initially suggested hour and a half.
Eventually, the driver announces that they are nearing Thornfield.
Jane observes a church and the lights of a village or hamlet before the carriage passes through a set of gates.
They travel up a driveway and arrive before a large house, where a single candlelit window pierces the darkness.
A maid-servant opens the front door; Jane alights from the carriage and enters the residence.
The maid guides her through a hall into a room brightly lit by both a fire and candles.

In this cozy setting, Jane sees a small, neat elderly woman in a widow's cap, knitting by the fire with a cat at her feet, embodying an ideal of domestic comfort and offering a reassuring initial encounter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I let down the window and looked out; Millcote was behind us; judging by the number of its lights, it seemed a place of considerable magnitude, much larger than Lowton.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A more reassuring introduction for a new governess could scarcely be conceived; there was no grandeur to overwhelm, no stateliness to embarrass; and then, as I entered, the old lady got up and promptly and kindly came forward to meet me.

events.text_segment:
I let down the window and looked out; Millcote was behind us; judging by the number of its lights, it seemed a place of considerable magnitude, much larger than Lowton. We were now, as far as I could see, on a sort of common; but there were houses scattered all over the district; I felt we were in a different region to Lowood, more populous, less picturesque; more stirring, less romantic.
The roads were heavy, the night misty; my conductor let his horse walk all the way, and the hour and a half extended, I verily believe, to two hours; at last he turned in his seat and said—
“You’re noan so far fro’ Thornfield now.”
Again I looked out: we were passing a church; I saw its low broad tower against the sky, and its bell was tolling a quarter; I saw a narrow galaxy of lights too, on a hillside, marking a village or hamlet. About ten minutes after, the driver got down and opened a pair of gates: we passed through, and they clashed to behind us. We now slowly ascended a drive, and came upon the long front of a house: candlelight gleamed from one curtained bow-window; all the rest were dark. The car stopped at the front door; it was opened by a maid-servant; I alighted and went in.
“Will you walk this way, ma’am?” said the girl; and I followed her across a square hall with high doors all round: she ushered me into a room whose double illumination of fire and candle at first dazzled me, contrasting as it did with the darkness to which my eyes had been for two hours inured; when I could see, however, a cosy and agreeable picture presented itself to my view.
A snug small room; a round table by a cheerful fire; an arm-chair high-backed and old-fashioned, wherein sat the neatest imaginable little elderly lady, in widow’s cap, black silk gown, and snowy muslin apron; exactly like what I had fancied Mrs. Fairfax, only less stately and milder looking. She was occupied in knitting; a large cat sat demurely at her feet; nothing in short was wanting to complete the beau-ideal of domestic comfort. A more reassuring introduction for a new governess could scarcely be conceived; there was no grandeur to overwhelm, no stateliness to embarrass; and then, as I entered, the old lady got up and promptly and kindly came forward to meet me.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Lowering the window, I looked outside. Millcote was now behind us, and judging by the number of lights, it appeared to be a significantly sized place, much larger than Lowton. From what I could see, we were now on what seemed like an open common, though houses were spread throughout the area. I sensed we had arrived in a different kind of place than Lowood – more densely populated and less scenic, more lively and less peaceful.The roads were difficult to travel on, and the night was foggy. My driver let his horse walk the entire way, stretching the hour and a half journey, I genuinely believe, to two full hours. Finally, he turned and spoke, saying, "You're not very far from Thornfield now."I looked out again: we were driving past a church; I could see its short, wide tower against the sky, and its bell was ringing the quarter hour. I also saw a faint line of lights on a distant hillside, indicating a village or small settlement. About ten minutes later, the driver got down and opened a set of gates. We went through, and they closed loudly behind us. We then slowly drove up a path and approached the long facade of a house. Light shone from one bay window with curtains; all the other windows were dark. The carriage stopped at the main entrance, which was opened by a maid. I stepped out and went inside."Please come this way, ma'am," the maid said, and I followed her across a square hall with tall doors surrounding it. She led me into a room where the combined light from the fire and candles initially blinded me, a stark contrast to the darkness my eyes had grown used to for two hours. However, once my vision adjusted, I saw a pleasant and comfortable scene.It was a comfortable, small room with a round table next to a cheerful fire. In a high-backed, old-fashioned armchair sat a remarkably neat little elderly lady. She wore a widow's cap, a black silk dress, and a spotless white muslin apron. She looked exactly like I had imagined Mrs. Fairfax, only less imposing and with a gentler appearance. She was busy knitting, and a large cat sat calmly at her feet. In short, the scene perfectly embodied the ideal of domestic comfort. It's hard to imagine a more welcoming first impression for a new governess; there was no grandness to intimidate, no formality to make me feel awkward. And then, as I entered, the old lady stood up and came forward quickly and kindly to greet me.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I lowered the carriage window and gazed outside; we had left Millcote behind us and, based on its many lights, it seemed much bigger than Lowton. Now we appeared to be crossing open common land, but there were houses dotted all around. I felt we were in a place unlike Lowood—more crowded, less scenic; livelier but less charming. The roads were rough, and a night mist hung in the air. My driver let his horse go slowly, so the journey stretched from the expected hour and a half to nearly two hours. Eventually, he turned and told me we were close to Thornfield. I looked out again and saw we were passing a church; its low, broad tower stood against the sky, and its bell was ringing the quarter hour. I also spotted a string of lights on a hill, showing where a village or hamlet was. After about ten more minutes, the driver stopped, got out, and opened some gates; we went through and the gates closed loudly behind us. We went slowly up a drive and soon came to the long front of a house. Light shone from one curtained window but the rest were dark. The carriage stopped at the main door, which a maid opened; I got out and entered. The maid said, “Will you walk this way, ma’am?” and I followed her through a square hallway with tall doors on all sides. She led me into a room bright with fire and candlelight, which at first dazzled me after the hours in the dark. As my eyes adjusted, I saw a comfortable, welcoming scene: a small cozy room, a round table by a warm fire, and an old-fashioned high-backed armchair. Seated there was a tidy little elderly woman in a widow’s cap, black silk dress, and white apron—just as I’d imagined Mrs. Fairfax, though gentler and less imposing. She was quietly knitting, with a calm cat by her feet; nothing was missing from this ideal picture of domestic comfort. A new governess could hardly have wished for a warmer welcome—there was no intimidating grandeur, no stiffness, and as I entered, the old lady immediately got up and kindly greeted me.

events.title: Warm Welcome from Mrs. Fairfax and Clarification about Miss Varens
detailed_summary: The elderly lady, introducing herself as Mrs. Fairfax, greets Jane with kindness, showing concern for her well-being after the tedious journey and inviting her to warm herself by the fire.
Jane confirms she is speaking to Mrs. Fairfax.
Mrs. Fairfax solicitously assists Jane with her shawl and bonnet, then instructs a servant, Leah, to prepare some hot negus and sandwiches.
She assures Jane that her luggage will be attended to, treating her with a warmth more befitting a guest than an employee.

Jane is pleasantly surprised by this unexpectedly cordial reception, which contrasts sharply with her past experiences and her understanding of the typical treatment of governesses, though she remains cautiously optimistic.
Mrs. Fairfax personally clears space on the table for the tray of refreshments and serves Jane herself.
Feeling somewhat disoriented by receiving more attention than she is accustomed to, especially from an employer, Jane inquires if she will meet Miss Fairfax that evening.
Mrs. Fairfax, who is slightly hard of hearing, initially misunderstands but then clarifies that Jane's future pupil is named Miss Varens.
Jane learns that Mrs. Fairfax has no daughter and decides against asking further questions about Miss Varens' relationship to her at that moment, trusting she will find out in due course.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “How do you do, my dear? I am afraid you have had a tedious ride; John drives so slowly; you must be cold, come to the fire.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I should have followed up my first inquiry, by asking in what way Miss Varens was connected with her; but I recollected it was not polite to ask too many questions: besides, I was sure to hear in time.

events.text_segment:
“How do you do, my dear? I am afraid you have had a tedious ride; John drives so slowly; you must be cold, come to the fire.”
“Mrs. Fairfax, I suppose?” said I.
“Yes, you are right: do sit down.”
She conducted me to her own chair, and then began to remove my shawl and untie my bonnet-strings; I begged she would not give herself so much trouble.
“Oh, it is no trouble; I dare say your own hands are almost numbed with cold. Leah, make a little hot negus and cut a sandwich or two: here are the keys of the storeroom.”
And she produced from her pocket a most housewifely bunch of keys, and delivered them to the servant.
“Now, then, draw nearer to the fire,” she continued. “You’ve brought your luggage with you, haven’t you, my dear?”
“Yes, ma’am.”
“I’ll see it carried into your room,” she said, and bustled out.
“She treats me like a visitor,” thought I. “I little expected such a reception; I anticipated only coldness and stiffness: this is not like what I have heard of the treatment of governesses; but I must not exult too soon.”
She returned; with her own hands cleared her knitting apparatus and a book or two from the table, to make room for the tray which Leah now brought, and then herself handed me the refreshments. I felt rather confused at being the object of more attention than I had ever before received, and, that too, shown by my employer and superior; but as she did not herself seem to consider she was doing anything out of her place, I thought it better to take her civilities quietly.
“Shall I have the pleasure of seeing Miss Fairfax to-night?” I asked, when I had partaken of what she offered me.
“What did you say, my dear? I am a little deaf,” returned the good lady, approaching her ear to my mouth.
I repeated the question more distinctly.
“Miss Fairfax? Oh, you mean Miss Varens! Varens is the name of your future pupil.”
“Indeed! Then she is not your daughter?”
“No,—I have no family.”
I should have followed up my first inquiry, by asking in what way Miss Varens was connected with her; but I recollected it was not polite to ask too many questions: besides, I was sure to hear in time.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"How are you, my dear? I worry the journey was long and boring for you; John drives at such a slow pace. You must be freezing—come warm yourself by the fire." 

"Are you Mrs. Fairfax?" I asked.

"Yes, that's right. Please, have a seat."

She showed me to her own chair and started to take off my shawl and undo my bonnet, but I insisted she need not trouble herself so much.

"It's no trouble at all. I expect your hands are nearly frozen. Leah, please prepare some hot negus and a few sandwiches—here are the storeroom keys."

She pulled a large bunch of keys from her pocket and gave them to the servant.

"Now, come closer to the fire," she said. "You have your luggage with you, haven't you, dear?"

"Yes, ma'am."

"I'll have it taken to your room," she replied, hastening out of the room.

"She is treating me like a guest," I thought to myself. "I hadn’t expected such a warm welcome; I thought they would be more cold and stiff. This is not what I heard about how governesses are usually treated, but I shouldn’t be too quick to celebrate."

She soon returned, cleared her knitting and some books from the table to make space for the tray Leah had brought, and personally handed me the refreshments. I found it a bit awkward to receive so much attention—more than I’d ever been given before, especially from someone who was my employer and superior. But since Mrs. Fairfax seemed to think nothing of it, I decided to accept her kindness calmly.

After I’d eaten, I asked, "Will I meet Miss Fairfax tonight?"

"What did you say, dear? I’m a little hard of hearing," the kindly lady said, leaning closer to me.

I repeated my question louder.

"Miss Fairfax? Oh, you mean Miss Varens! That is the name of your future pupil."

"Really? Then she isn’t your daughter?"

"No, I have no children."

I wanted to ask more about Miss Varens’ connection to Mrs. Fairfax, but remembered it would not be polite to press for details, and that I’d learn more soon enough.

events.title: Mrs. Fairfax's Hope for Companionship and Jane's Peaceful First Night
detailed_summary: Mrs. Fairfax expresses her delight at Jane's arrival, looking forward to having companionship to alleviate her solitude, particularly during the winter months.
She describes Thornfield as a distinguished old hall, albeit somewhat neglected in recent years, and mentions her servants—Leah, John, and his wife—with whom she cannot converse on equal terms.
She recalls her feelings of melancholy during the previous harsh winter, which were somewhat eased by the arrival of young Adela Varens and her nurse, who brought a sense of liveliness to the house.
Jane feels a genuine warmth towards Mrs. Fairfax upon hearing her speak and sincerely hopes that her company will indeed prove agreeable.

Considering the late hour (midnight), Mrs. Fairfax suggests Jane should retire, offering her a small, comfortable room adjacent to her own, which she believes Jane will prefer to the larger, more somber front chambers.
Jane expresses her gratitude for Mrs. Fairfax's considerate choice and, feeling weary from her long journey, readily agrees to go to her room.
Once alone and having secured her door, Jane feels a profound sense of safety and gratitude in her new surroundings.
She kneels by her bedside to offer thanks for the kindness she has received and to pray for guidance and strength in her new path.
Overcome with weariness yet content, she soon falls into a deep and sound sleep, awakening to broad daylight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I am so glad,” she continued, as she sat down opposite to me, and took the cat on her knee; “I am so glad you are come; it will be quite pleasant living here now with a companion.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At once weary and content, I slept soon and soundly: when I awoke it was broad day.

events.text_segment:
“I am so glad,” she continued, as she sat down opposite to me, and took the cat on her knee; “I am so glad you are come; it will be quite pleasant living here now with a companion. To be sure it is pleasant at any time; for Thornfield is a fine old hall, rather neglected of late years perhaps, but still it is a respectable place; yet you know in winter-time one feels dreary quite alone in the best quarters. I say alone—Leah is a nice girl to be sure, and John and his wife are very decent people; but then you see they are only servants, and one can’t converse with them on terms of equality: one must keep them at due distance, for fear of losing one’s authority. I’m sure last winter (it was a very severe one, if you recollect, and when it did not snow, it rained and blew), not a creature but the butcher and postman came to the house, from November till February; and I really got quite melancholy with sitting night after night alone; I had Leah in to read to me sometimes; but I don’t think the poor girl liked the task much: she felt it confining. In spring and summer one got on better: sunshine and long days make such a difference; and then, just at the commencement of this autumn, little Adela Varens came and her nurse: a child makes a house alive all at once; and now you are here I shall be quite gay.”
My heart really warmed to the worthy lady as I heard her talk; and I drew my chair a little nearer to her, and expressed my sincere wish that she might find my company as agreeable as she anticipated.
“But I’ll not keep you sitting up late to-night,” said she; “it is on the stroke of twelve now, and you have been travelling all day: you must feel tired. If you have got your feet well warmed, I’ll show you your bedroom. I’ve had the room next to mine prepared for you; it is only a small apartment, but I thought you would like it better than one of the large front chambers: to be sure they have finer furniture, but they are so dreary and solitary, I never sleep in them myself.”
I thanked her for her considerate choice, and as I really felt fatigued with my long journey, expressed my readiness to retire. She took her candle, and I followed her from the room. First she went to see if the hall-door was fastened; having taken the key from the lock, she led the way upstairs. The steps and banisters were of oak; the staircase window was high and latticed; both it and the long gallery into which the bedroom doors opened looked as if they belonged to a church rather than a house. A very chill and vault-like air pervaded the stairs and gallery, suggesting cheerless ideas of space and solitude; and I was glad, when finally ushered into my chamber, to find it of small dimensions, and furnished in ordinary, modern style.
When Mrs. Fairfax had bidden me a kind good-night, and I had fastened my door, gazed leisurely round, and in some measure effaced the eerie impression made by that wide hall, that dark and spacious staircase, and that long, cold gallery, by the livelier aspect of my little room, I remembered that, after a day of bodily fatigue and mental anxiety, I was now at last in safe haven. The impulse of gratitude swelled my heart, and I knelt down at the bedside, and offered up thanks where thanks were due; not forgetting, ere I rose, to implore aid on my further path, and the power of meriting the kindness which seemed so frankly offered me before it was earned. My couch had no thorns in it that night; my solitary room no fears. At once weary and content, I slept soon and soundly: when I awoke it was broad day.

Yet, you know, being completely alone in the best rooms can feel quite bleak during winter. When I say alone, Leah is certainly a good girl, and John and his wife are very decent people; but you see, they are just servants, and you can’t converse with them as equals. You have to maintain a certain distance to uphold your authority. A child instantly brings a house to life. Now that you are here, I shall be quite cheerful.” Listening to the kind lady speak, my heart genuinely warmed to her. They have better furniture, certainly, but they are so grim and isolated, I never sleep in them myself.” I thanked her for her thoughtful choice and, feeling truly exhausted from my long journey, said I was ready to retire. A wave of gratitude swelled in my chest, and I knelt by the bed to offer thanks where they were due, not forgetting, before I rose, to ask for guidance on my future path and the strength to deserve the kindness so freely offered before it was earned. My bed held no discomforts that night; my solitary room held no fears. Tired but content, I fell asleep quickly and deeply. When I woke, it was full daylight.

events.title: Morning Reflections and First Exploration of Thornfield's Exterior
detailed_summary: Upon waking, Jane finds her room bright and cheerful, a pleasant departure from the austerity of Lowood, which lifts her spirits and fills her with optimism for a new phase of her life.
She muses on the prospect of future happiness and new experiences, though these remain vague in her mind.
Jane dresses with care, focusing on neatness despite the simplicity of her wardrobe, and reflects on her innate desire to present herself well and her past regrets concerning her physical appearance.
She acknowledges her aspirations for conventional beauty and her feelings about her own plain features, recognizing an underlying, though then unarticulated, reason for these desires.
Once ready, feeling she will make a respectable enough appearance, she decides to leave her room, hoping to meet Mrs. Fairfax and her new pupil without causing any aversion.
She descends to the hall, taking note of its imposing and stately characteristics, acknowledging her unfamiliarity with such grandeur.
Jane steps outside into the fine autumn morning and surveys the exterior of Thornfield Hall.

She describes the mansion as a three-story structure, a gentleman's manor-house rather than a nobleman's seat, with battlements that give it a picturesque quality, set against the backdrop of a rookery.

Her gaze takes in the surrounding grounds: a large meadow with prominent old thorn trees (which clearly inspired the name Thornfield), and tranquil hills that seem to provide a secluded atmosphere despite the proximity to the bustling town of Millcote.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A little hamlet, whose roofs were blent with trees, straggled up the side of one of these hills; the church of the district stood nearer Thornfield: its old tower-top looked over a knoll between the house and gates.

events.text_segment:
The chamber looked such a bright little place to me as the sun shone in between the gay blue chintz window curtains, showing papered walls and a carpeted floor, so unlike the bare planks and stained plaster of Lowood, that my spirits rose at the view. Externals have a great effect on the young: I thought that a fairer era of life was beginning for me, one that was to have its flowers and pleasures, as well as its thorns and toils. My faculties, roused by the change of scene, the new field offered to hope, seemed all astir. I cannot precisely define what they expected, but it was something pleasant: not perhaps that day or that month, but at an indefinite future period.
I rose; I dressed myself with care: obliged to be plain—for I had no article of attire that was not made with extreme simplicity—I was still by nature solicitous to be neat. It was not my habit to be disregardful of appearance or careless of the impression I made: on the contrary, I ever wished to look as well as I could, and to please as much as my want of beauty would permit. I sometimes regretted that I was not handsomer; I sometimes wished to have rosy cheeks, a straight nose, and small cherry mouth; I desired to be tall, stately, and finely developed in figure; I felt it a misfortune that I was so little, so pale, and had features so irregular and so marked. And why had I these aspirations and these regrets? It would be difficult to say: I could not then distinctly say it to myself; yet I had a reason, and a logical, natural reason too. However, when I had brushed my hair very smooth, and put on my black frock—which, Quakerlike as it was, at least had the merit of fitting to a nicety—and adjusted my clean white tucker, I thought I should do respectably enough to appear before Mrs. Fairfax, and that my new pupil would not at least recoil from me with antipathy. Having opened my chamber window, and seen that I left all things straight and neat on the toilet table, I ventured forth.
Traversing the long and matted gallery, I descended the slippery steps of oak; then I gained the hall: I halted there a minute; I looked at some pictures on the walls (one, I remember, represented a grim man in a cuirass, and one a lady with powdered hair and a pearl necklace), at a bronze lamp pendent from the ceiling, at a great clock whose case was of oak curiously carved, and ebon black with time and rubbing. Everything appeared very stately and imposing to me; but then I was so little accustomed to grandeur. The hall-door, which was half of glass, stood open; I stepped over the threshold. It was a fine autumn morning; the early sun shone serenely on embrowned groves and still green fields; advancing on to the lawn, I looked up and surveyed the front of the mansion. It was three storeys high, of proportions not vast, though considerable: a gentleman’s manor-house, not a nobleman’s seat: battlements round the top gave it a picturesque look. Its grey front stood out well from the background of a rookery, whose cawing tenants were now on the wing: they flew over the lawn and grounds to alight in a great meadow, from which these were separated by a sunk fence, and where an array of mighty old thorn trees, strong, knotty, and broad as oaks, at once explained the etymology of the mansion’s designation. Farther off were hills: not so lofty as those round Lowood, nor so craggy, nor so like barriers of separation from the living world; but yet quiet and lonely hills enough, and seeming to embrace Thornfield with a seclusion I had not expected to find existent so near the stirring locality of Millcote. A little hamlet, whose roofs were blent with trees, straggled up the side of one of these hills; the church of the district stood nearer Thornfield: its old tower-top looked over a knoll between the house and gates.

I believed that a more promising period of life was beginning for me, one that would include both enjoyable experiences and pleasures, as well as challenges and hard work. My abilities, stimulated by the change of environment and the new opportunities for hope, seemed fully awakened. I couldn't specifically say what exactly they anticipated, but it was something positive, perhaps not right away, but at some undefined point in the future. I got up and dressed carefully. Though I had to dress simply because all my clothes were made very plainly, I was naturally inclined to be neat. I sometimes regretted not being more attractive; I occasionally wished I had rosy cheeks, a straight nose, and a small, pretty mouth. I wanted to be tall, dignified, and have a well-developed figure. I felt it was a misfortune that I was so small, so pale, and had such irregular and prominent features. And why did I have these desires and regrets? It would be difficult to articulate. I couldn't clearly explain it to myself at the time, yet I did have a reason, and a perfectly logical, natural one at that. However, after smoothing my hair meticulously and putting on my simple black dress—which, despite its plainness, fit quite well—and adjusting my clean white collar, I felt I would be presentable enough to meet Mrs. Fairfax and that my new pupil wouldn't immediately recoil from me in dislike. After opening my room window and ensuring everything on the dressing table was tidy, I ventured out. Walking along the long, carpeted hallway, I went down the slippery oak stairs. Then I reached the main hall. I paused there for a minute, looking at some paintings on the walls (I recall one showed a stern man in armor, and another a lady with powdered hair and a pearl necklace), at a bronze lamp hanging from the ceiling, and at a large clock whose intricately carved oak case was darkened like ebony from age and polishing. Everything struck me as very grand and impressive, but then I was so unaccustomed to luxury. The front door, which was partly glass, was open, and I stepped across the threshold. It was a beautiful autumn morning. The early sun shone gently on the brown woodlands and still green fields. Stepping onto the lawn, I looked up and surveyed the front of the mansion. It was three stories high, of substantial but not immense proportions—more a gentleman's large house than a nobleman's vast estate. Battlements along the top gave it a picturesque appearance. Its grey facade stood out well against the background of a rookery, whose cawing inhabitants were now flying. They flew over the lawn and grounds towards a large meadow, which was separated by a sunken fence and contained many large, old thorn trees, strong, gnarled, and as thick as oaks, which immediately clarified how the mansion got its name. Further off were hills, not as high as those around Lowood, nor as rocky, nor as isolating barriers from the outside world. Yet, they were quiet and solitary hills nonetheless, seeming to enclose Thornfield in a seclusion I hadn't expected to find so close to the busy area of Millcote. A small cluster of houses, their roofs blending with trees, sprawled up the side of one of these hills. The local church was nearer to Thornfield; its old tower peak was visible over a small hill between the house and the gates.

The change in environment awakened my senses and hope, though I couldn’t clearly say what I anticipated, only that I looked forward to something good, someday in the future. 

I got up and dressed carefully. My wardrobe was modest and simple, but I always tried to present myself neatly. I cared about how I looked and the impression I made on others, wishing I was more attractive—wishing for rosy cheeks, a straight nose, a petite mouth, a taller, graceful figure—instead of being small, pale, and with distinct, irregular features. After opening my window and tidying my room, I left.

I passed through a long hallway with a thick carpet and carefully descended slippery oak stairs to the hall. I paused to look at some paintings—one of a severe man in armor, another of a lady with powdered hair and pearls—a hanging bronze lamp, and an ornate old oak clock. Everything seemed magnificent and formal to me, though I wasn't used to such grandeur. The hall door stood open, half-glass, and I stepped outside. A small village with houses blended among trees climbed one hillside; the district church, closer to Thornfield, overlooked a rise between the house and the entrance gates.

events.title: Crucial Revelations: Mr. Rochester's Ownership and Mrs. Fairfax's True Role
detailed_summary: While Jane is outside enjoying the fresh morning air and observing Thornfield Hall, Mrs. Fairfax appears at the doorway.
Mrs. Fairfax greets Jane with an affable kiss and handshake, remarking on her early rising and inquiring about her initial impressions of Thornfield.

She expresses a concern that the estate might deteriorate unless Mr. Rochester, its owner, decides to reside there permanently or at least visit more frequently, as large properties require the proprietor's presence.
Jane is taken aback to learn about Mr. Rochester and his ownership of Thornfield, as she had mistakenly assumed Mrs. Fairfax was the mistress of the house.
Mrs. Fairfax clarifies her actual position: she is merely the housekeeper and manager, with a distant familial connection to the Rochesters through her late husband, a clergyman.
She explains that the current Mr. Rochester's mother was a Fairfax, but she does not presume upon this connection and regards herself as an ordinary housekeeper.
Furthermore, Mrs. Fairfax reveals that Jane's pupil, Adèle, is Mr. Rochester's ward, and it was he who tasked her with finding a governess for the child.

This revelation makes Jane realize that Mrs. Fairfax, like herself, is a dependant. This understanding pleases Jane, as it establishes a genuine equality between them, making her feel her position is all the more free.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was yet enjoying the calm prospect and pleasant fresh air, yet listening with delight to the cawing of the rooks, yet surveying the wide, hoary front of the hall, and thinking what a great place it was for one lonely little dame like Mrs. Fairfax to inhabit, when that lady appeared at the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The equality between her and me was real; not the mere result of condescension on her part: so much the better—my position was all the freer.

events.text_segment:
I was yet enjoying the calm prospect and pleasant fresh air, yet listening with delight to the cawing of the rooks, yet surveying the wide, hoary front of the hall, and thinking what a great place it was for one lonely little dame like Mrs. Fairfax to inhabit, when that lady appeared at the door.
“What! out already?” said she. “I see you are an early riser.” I went up to her, and was received with an affable kiss and shake of the hand.
“How do you like Thornfield?” she asked. I told her I liked it very much.
“Yes,” she said, “it is a pretty place; but I fear it will be getting out of order, unless Mr. Rochester should take it into his head to come and reside here permanently; or, at least, visit it rather oftener: great houses and fine grounds require the presence of the proprietor.”
“Mr. Rochester!” I exclaimed. “Who is he?”
“The owner of Thornfield,” she responded quietly. “Did you not know he was called Rochester?”
Of course I did not—I had never heard of him before; but the old lady seemed to regard his existence as a universally understood fact, with which everybody must be acquainted by instinct.
“I thought,” I continued, “Thornfield belonged to you.”
“To me? Bless you, child; what an idea! To me! I am only the housekeeper—the manager. To be sure I am distantly related to the Rochesters by the mother’s side, or at least my husband was; he was a clergyman, incumbent of Hay—that little village yonder on the hill—and that church near the gates was his. The present Mr. Rochester’s mother was a Fairfax, and second cousin to my husband: but I never presume on the connection—in fact, it is nothing to me; I consider myself quite in the light of an ordinary housekeeper: my employer is always civil, and I expect nothing more.”
“And the little girl—my pupil!”
“She is Mr. Rochester’s ward; he commissioned me to find a governess for her. He intended to have her brought up in ——shire, I believe. Here she comes, with her ‘bonne,’ as she calls her nurse.” The enigma then was explained: this affable and kind little widow was no great dame; but a dependent like myself. I did not like her the worse for that; on the contrary, I felt better pleased than ever. The equality between her and me was real; not the mere result of condescension on her part: so much the better—my position was all the freer.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
I was still enjoying the peaceful scene and pleasant fresh air, still delighting in the sound of the rooks cawing, still observing the extensive, old-looking front of the hall, and considering what a vast dwelling it was for one solitary elderly woman like Mrs. Fairfax to live in, when she appeared at the entrance.
“What! Outside already?” she remarked. “You seem to be an early riser.” I approached her and was greeted with an affectionate kiss and a handclasp.
“How do you find Thornfield?” she inquired. I told her I liked it immensely.
“Yes,” she said, “it’s an attractive spot; but I fear it will fall into disrepair unless Mr. Rochester decides to come and live here permanently; or, at least, visit somewhat more often: large residences and impressive grounds require the owner’s presence.”
“Mr. Rochester!” I exclaimed. “Who is he?”
“He is the proprietor of Thornfield,” she replied calmly. “Were you not aware he was named Rochester?”
Of course I was not—I had never encountered his name before; but the elderly lady appeared to consider his existence a universally known fact, something everyone must instinctively be familiar with.
“I had thought,” I continued, “that Thornfield belonged to you.”
“To me? Goodness, child; what an idea! To me! I am only the housekeeper—the manager. To be sure, I am distantly related to the Rochesters on my mother’s side, or rather, my husband was; he was a clergyman, the incumbent of Hay—that small village over there on the hill—and that church near the gates was his. The current Mr. Rochester’s mother was a Fairfax, and a second cousin to my husband: but I never presume upon that connection—in fact, it means nothing to me; I regard myself purely in the role of a standard housekeeper: my employer is always courteous, and I expect nothing more.”
“And the little girl—my pupil!”
“She is Mr. Rochester’s ward; he entrusted me with finding a governess for her. He had intended for her to be brought up in ——shire, I believe. Here she comes now, with her ‘bonne,’ as she refers to her nurse.” The mystery was then solved: this amiable and kind little widow was no grand lady; but a dependent just as I was. I did not think less of her for that; on the contrary, I felt more content than ever. The equality between us was genuine; not merely the result of condescension on her part: so much the better—my status felt all the freer.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I was still taking in the peaceful view and enjoying the fresh air, listening with pleasure to the rooks as they called, and gazing at the old, expansive facade of the house, musing on how large a place it was for someone as solitary as Mrs. Fairfax to live in alone, when she appeared at the doorway. 

"Already outside?" she remarked. "I see you're an early riser." I approached her and she greeted me warmly with a kiss and a handshake. 

"What do you think of Thornfield?" she asked, and I told her I liked it a lot. 

"Yes, it is a nice place," she agreed, "but I'm afraid it will start to fall into neglect unless Mr. Rochester decides to live here more often, or at least visit more regularly; such big estates need their owner's oversight."

"Mr. Rochester!" I echoed. "Who is that?"

"He's the owner of Thornfield," she replied calmly. "Didn't you know his name was Rochester?"

I hadn't—I had never heard of him—but Mrs. Fairfax seemed to think everyone should naturally know about him.

"I thought Thornfield was yours," I continued.

"Mine? Oh no, what a notion! I'm only the housekeeper, the manager. I do have distant family ties to the Rochesters on the mother's side, or rather, my late husband did—he was the priest in Hay, the little village over there, and the nearby church was his. The current Mr. Rochester's mother was a Fairfax, a distant cousin to my husband, but I never act on that connection; it means nothing to me. I'm simply the housekeeper, and my employer always treats me politely—that's all I expect."

"And the little girl I'm to teach?"

"She's Mr. Rochester's ward; he asked me to find her a governess. He planned to have her raised in ——shire, I think. Here she comes now with her nurse, whom she calls her 'bonne.'" With that, the mystery was resolved: this amiable widow was not the mistress of the house, but rather an employee like myself. I liked her all the more for it; knowing we were truly equals, not just thanks to her kindness, gave me greater ease in my position.

events.title: Meeting Adèle Varens: Introduction to Pupil and Her French Background
detailed_summary: While Jane is processing the new information about Mrs. Fairfax, a young girl, Adèle Varens, accompanied by her attendant, Sophie, comes running across the lawn.
Mrs. Fairfax introduces Adèle to Jane, identifying Jane as her new teacher who will help her become a clever woman.
Adèle, speaking in French, points to Jane and identifies her to Sophie as her governess.
Jane is initially surprised by the French conversation but is pleased to find her knowledge of the language, cultivated through consistent practice, allows her to understand.
Adèle, a child of about seven or eight with pale features and abundant curly hair, quickly becomes animated upon discovering Jane speaks French, chattering fluently about various topics.
She recounts her sea journey with Sophie and Mr. Rochester, mentioning their seasickness and a subsequent stay at a grand hotel in a large city before arriving at Thornfield.
Mrs. Fairfax checks if Jane can follow Adèle's rapid French, which Jane confirms she can.
At Mrs. Fairfax's suggestion, Jane inquires about Adèle's parents.
Adèle shares that she previously lived with her mother, who taught her dancing and singing, but her mother has since passed away, or, as Adèle puts it, 'gone to the Holy Virgin.'

Adèle then offers a sample of her accomplishments, singing a song about a forsaken lover—a choice Jane finds unusually melancholic for a child—and reciting a fable by La Fontaine with remarkable skill, demonstrating careful prior instruction by her mother.

Adèle explains that after her mother's departure, she lived for a short time with a Madame Frédéric, who was not related to her, before Mr. Rochester invited her to England. She expresses disappointment that he has since left, as he was always kind to her.
