It was a beautiful, calm, but very cold day, and after spending the entire morning sitting in the library, I felt restless. Mrs. Fairfax had just finished writing a letter that needed to be mailed, so I put on my bonnet and cloak and offered to take it to Hay myself—a walk of about two miles, which seemed like a pleasant way to spend a winter afternoon. Making sure Adèle was settled comfortably by the fireside in Mrs. Fairfax’s sitting room, with her best wax doll (normally wrapped in silver paper in a drawer) and a storybook to keep her amused, and after answering her fond farewell—"Come back soon, my good friend, dear Mademoiselle Jeannette"—with a kiss, I set off. 

The ground was hard with frost, the air completely still, and I was alone on the road. I walked quickly at first to warm myself, then slowed down to enjoy and reflect on the particular quiet pleasure the time and place offered me. It was three o’clock, and as I passed under the church belfry, the bell tolled; the scene was especially appealing because of the fading daylight and the low, pale sun moving across the sky. I was a mile from Thornfield, walking along a lane known in summer for wild roses, in autumn for nuts and blackberries, and even now adorned with bright red hips and haws. Its greatest winter charm was its solitude and the stillness of the bare trees. Even if there was a breeze, nothing rustled, since there were no evergreens, and the hawthorn and hazel bushes were as quiet as the pale, worn stones that paved the middle of the path. Fields stretched out on either side, empty of livestock, and the occasional little brown bird in the hedge resembled a single russet leaf left behind. 

The lane climbed steadily all the way to Hay. Upon reaching the halfway point, I stopped to rest on a stile leading into a field. Wrapping my cloak around me and tucking my hands into a muff, I didn’t feel the cold despite the sharp frost, as shown by a sheet of ice over the path where a small stream had spilled and frozen after a recent thaw. From my seat I could see Thornfield Hall below, its grey, battlemented structure standing out in the valley, with its woods and dark rookery rising against the western sky. I stayed there until the sun set crimson and clear through the trees, then turned and headed east.

events.title: Mysterious Approach in the Twilight and a
detailed_summary: With the sun down, the rising moon appears, initially pale but gradually brightening, looking over the village of Hay, which is about a mile distant.
Despite the distance, the absolute stillness of the evening allows Jane to hear the faint murmurs of life from Hay and the subtle flow of unseen currents of air or water in the surrounding dales.
The profound calm of the evening makes even the most distant sounds, like the tinkle of streams or the sough of wind, clearly audible.
This peaceful atmosphere is suddenly broken by a rude noise: a distinct, metallic tramping sound that effaces the softer sounds of nature.
Jane identifies the sound as an approaching horse on the causeway, still hidden by the windings of the lane but drawing nearer.
As she waits, seated on the stile because the path is narrow, her mind recalls Bessie's nursery tales about a North-of-England spirit called a 'Gytrash'.
This spirit was said to haunt solitary paths in the form of a horse, mule, or large dog, sometimes encountering belated travelers, much like the horse now approaching her in the dusk.
Jane reflects that her maturing youth lends a new vividness and intensity to these childhood stories as she anticipates the horse's appearance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the hill-top above me sat the rising moon; pale yet as a cloud, but brightening momentarily, she looked over Hay, which, half lost in trees, sent up a blue smoke from its few chimneys: it was yet a mile distant, but in the absolute hush I could hear plainly its thin murmurs of life.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As this horse approached, and as I watched for it to appear through the dusk, I remembered certain of Bessie’s tales, wherein figured a North-of-England spirit called a “Gytrash,” which, in the form of horse, mule, or large dog, haunted solitary ways, and sometimes came upon belated travellers, as this horse was now coming upon me.

events.text_segment:
On the hill-top above me sat the rising moon; pale yet as a cloud, but brightening momentarily, she looked over Hay, which, half lost in trees, sent up a blue smoke from its few chimneys: it was yet a mile distant, but in the absolute hush I could hear plainly its thin murmurs of life. My ear, too, felt the flow of currents; in what dales and depths I could not tell: but there were many hills beyond Hay, and doubtless many becks threading their passes. That evening calm betrayed alike the tinkle of the nearest streams, the sough of the most remote.
A rude noise broke on these fine ripplings and whisperings, at once so far away and so clear: a positive tramp, tramp, a metallic clatter, which effaced the soft wave-wanderings; as, in a picture, the solid mass of a crag, or the rough boles of a great oak, drawn in dark and strong on the foreground, efface the aërial distance of azure hill, sunny horizon, and blended clouds where tint melts into tint.
The din was on the causeway: a horse was coming; the windings of the lane yet hid it, but it approached. I was just leaving the stile; yet, as the path was narrow, I sat still to let it go by. In those days I was young, and all sorts of fancies bright and dark tenanted my mind: the memories of nursery stories were there amongst other rubbish; and when they recurred, maturing youth added to them a vigour and vividness beyond what childhood could give. As this horse approached, and as I watched for it to appear through the dusk, I remembered certain of Bessie’s tales, wherein figured a North-of-England spirit called a “Gytrash,” which, in the form of horse, mule, or large dog, haunted solitary ways, and sometimes came upon belated travellers, as this horse was now coming upon me.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Perched on the hilltop above me, the ascending moon, initially as pale as a cloud but growing brighter each moment, cast its light towards Hay. The town, partially concealed by trees, emitted thin trails of blue smoke from its few chimneys. Although it was still a mile away, the profound quiet allowed me to clearly distinguish the faint sounds of life emanating from it. My ears also picked up the sound of flowing water; I couldn't pinpoint the exact valleys or depths, but I knew there were many hills beyond Hay, likely crisscrossed by numerous streams. The stillness of the evening made both the nearby streams' tinkle and the distant ones' soft murmur audible. A harsh sound abruptly interrupted these delicate, clear whisperings, so distinct yet so remote. It was a definite tramping and metallic clatter, which overwhelmed the soft, flowing sounds, much like how, in a painting, a solid rock or the rugged trunks of large oak trees, depicted darkly and strongly in the foreground, erase the airy distance of blue hills, sunlit horizons, and blended clouds where colours subtly transition. The commotion was on the paved road; a horse was approaching. Although hidden by the winding lane, it was getting closer. I was just about to leave the stile, but as the path was narrow, I remained seated to let it pass. At that age, I was young, and my mind was filled with all sorts of fantasies, both cheerful and somber. Nursery rhymes and other old stories were part of this mental jumble, and when they resurfaced, my maturing mind added a strength and clarity to them that childhood could never provide. As this horse drew nearer and I watched for it to emerge from the twilight, I recalled some of Bessie’s stories, which featured a North-of-England spirit called a 'Gytrash.' This creature, taking the shape of a horse, mule, or large dog, was said to haunt lonely roads and sometimes appear to late travellers, just as this horse was now coming towards me.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Above me, on the hilltop, the moon was just rising—pale like a cloud but growing brighter with each moment. She gazed across Hay, which was mostly hidden among trees, a blue smoke curling up from the few chimneys. Though Hay was still a mile away, the silence was so complete that its faint signs of life reached my ears. I could also sense the movement of water in unseen valleys and depths beyond Hay, where many hills and likely many small streams wound their way. The peace of the evening made audible even the tinkling of the closest brooks and the faint sighs of the most distant.

Suddenly, a harsh noise disrupted these delicate sounds, both distant and clear: a steady tramping and metallic clattering that overwhelmed the gentle murmurs. It was as if, in a painting, a solid rock or the thick trunk of an oak, drawn bold and dark in the foreground, blocked out the dreamy blue hills and glowing horizon behind them.

The commotion came from the road—a horse was coming, its approach still hidden by the winding lane. I was about to leave the stile, but since the path was narrow, I waited for the rider to pass. I was young then, my mind full of all kinds of wild imaginings—the remnants of childhood tales mingled with the more vivid thoughts of growing up. As the horse neared and I strained to see it in the gathering dusk, I recalled some of Bessie’s old stories. Among them was the North-of-England specter known as the "Gytrash," a creature said to take the form of a horse, mule, or large dog and haunt lonely roads, sometimes appearing to travelers who were out late, just as this horse was now coming toward me.

events.title: The Rider's Fall and Jane's Initial Offer of Help
characters: The Traveler (later identified as Mr. Rochester)
detailed_summary: Before the horse comes into view, a large black and white dog, fitting one description of Bessie's Gytrash, glides out from under the hedge and passes Jane quietly without stopping.

The horse follows, carrying a rider, and the presence of a human being immediately dispels Jane's supernatural fancies, as she believes the Gytrash is always solitary and goblins wouldn't inhabit ordinary human forms.
Jane concludes it is simply a traveler taking a shortcut.
Moments after the rider passes, Jane hears a sliding sound, an exclamation of 'What the deuce is to do now?', and a clattering tumble.
She realizes the man and horse have fallen, having slipped on a sheet of ice that glazed the causeway.
The dog bounds back to the scene, barks loudly upon seeing its master's predicament and hearing the horse groan, then runs up to Jane, as if summoning the only help available.
Jane obeys the dog's implicit plea and walks towards the traveler, who is by then struggling to free himself from his fallen steed.
Observing his vigorous efforts, she assumes he might not be badly hurt but still asks if he is injured.
The man appears to be swearing or muttering something that prevents him from immediately answering her.
Jane repeats her offer of assistance, asking if she can do anything.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was very near, but not yet in sight; when, in addition to the tramp, tramp, I heard a rush under the hedge, and close down by the hazel stems glided a great dog, whose black and white colour made him a distinct object against the trees.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Can I do anything?” I asked again.

events.text_segment:
It was very near, but not yet in sight; when, in addition to the tramp, tramp, I heard a rush under the hedge, and close down by the hazel stems glided a great dog, whose black and white colour made him a distinct object against the trees. It was exactly one form of Bessie’s Gytrash—a lion-like creature with long hair and a huge head: it passed me, however, quietly enough; not staying to look up, with strange pretercanine eyes, in my face, as I half expected it would. The horse followed,—a tall steed, and on its back a rider. The man, the human being, broke the spell at once. Nothing ever rode the Gytrash: it was always alone; and goblins, to my notions, though they might tenant the dumb carcasses of beasts, could scarce covet shelter in the commonplace human form. No Gytrash was this,—only a traveller taking the short cut to Millcote. He passed, and I went on; a few steps, and I turned: a sliding sound and an exclamation of “What the deuce is to do now?” and a clattering tumble, arrested my attention. Man and horse were down; they had slipped on the sheet of ice which glazed the causeway. The dog came bounding back, and seeing his master in a predicament, and hearing the horse groan, barked till the evening hills echoed the sound, which was deep in proportion to his magnitude. He snuffed round the prostrate group, and then he ran up to me; it was all he could do,—there was no other help at hand to summon. I obeyed him, and walked down to the traveller, by this time struggling himself free of his steed. His efforts were so vigorous, I thought he could not be much hurt; but I asked him the question—
“Are you injured, sir?”
I think he was swearing, but am not certain; however, he was pronouncing some formula which prevented him from replying to me directly.
“Can I do anything?” I asked again.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Although not yet visible, I could tell it was close by the sound of footsteps. Suddenly, in addition to the rhythmic tread, I heard something moving quickly under the hedge. A large dog, strikingly black and white against the trees, glided out near the hazel bushes. It looked exactly like the description of a 'Gytrash' Bessie used to tell—a beast resembling a lion with shaggy fur and a massive head. Yet, it passed me without incident, not pausing to fix me with eerie, unnatural eyes as I half-expected it might. Following the dog was a tall horse carrying a rider. The sight of the human instantly broke my fantastical notion. A Gytrash, in my understanding, was always solitary; while spirits might inhabit animals, they wouldn't seek refuge in an ordinary human form. So, this wasn't a Gytrash after all, but simply a traveler using the shortcut towards Millcote. He continued on, and I resumed my walk. After only a few steps, I heard a sliding noise, a cry of 'What the deuce is to do now?', and a loud clatter behind me, which made me stop. The man and his horse had fallen, having slipped on the sheet of ice covering the path. The dog raced back and, seeing his master in trouble and hearing the horse groan, barked so loudly that the sound, deep from his large size, echoed across the evening hills. He sniffed around the fallen pair, then came running to me—there was no one else around to call for help. I followed his lead and went back to the traveler, who was by then struggling to free himself from the horse. His movements were so strong that I doubted he was seriously injured, but I asked him, 'Are you hurt, sir?' I believe he was cursing, though I'm not certain. At any rate, he was saying something that prevented him from answering me right away. 'Can I do anything?' I repeated.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: It was very close, but I couldn't see it yet. Then, alongside the footsteps, I heard a rush in the hedge. Suddenly, a large black and white dog slipped quietly past the hazel bushes, its coloring making it stand out against the trees. It looked just like the creature Bessie had told stories about—a lion-like animal with long hair and a big head. However, it passed by me calmly, not even glancing at me with strange, almost supernatural eyes as I half expected. Then came the horse—a tall animal ridden by a man. The sight of a human broke any sense of enchantment at once. The Gytrash of legend was always alone; nothing ever rode it. Spirits, I believed, might inhabit animal forms, but they wouldn't care to take on an ordinary human body. So, this wasn't some mythical beast—just a traveler taking a shortcut to Millcote. He passed, and I kept walking. After a few steps, I heard a sliding noise, an exclamation—“What the deuce is to do now?”—and a crashing fall that made me stop. Both man and horse had slipped on the icy path and fallen. The dog ran back, and upon hearing his master's distress and the horse's groan, began barking loudly, the sound echoing through the hills due to his large size. Sniffing around the fallen man and horse, the dog then ran up to me, as there was no one else around to help. I followed his lead and went to the traveler, who by then was struggling to free himself from his horse. His actions seemed strong, so I assumed he wasn't badly hurt, but I still asked, “Are you injured, sir?” I think he was swearing, though I wasn't sure; in any case, he was muttering something and didn't answer immediately. I asked again, “Can I do anything?”

events.title: A Tense Interaction and Jane's Revelation as the Governess
detailed_summary: The traveler, having managed to rise, curtly instructs Jane to stand aside while he deals with his horse.
After a struggle, the horse is back on its feet and the dog quieted; the traveler then examines his foot and leg, clearly in pain, and sits down on the stile Jane had previously occupied.
Feeling a desire to be useful, Jane approaches him again, offering to fetch assistance from either Thornfield Hall or Hay if he is injured.
He declines, stating he has no broken bones, only a sprain, but an involuntary 'Ugh!' escapes him as he tests his foot.

In the dim light of dusk and the waxing moon, Jane observes him more closely: a man of middle height, broad-chested, with a dark face, stern features, a heavy brow, and currently ireful eyes; she estimates his age to be around thirty-five.

Jane feels no fear of him, nor much shyness, reflecting that she would have been far more intimidated by a handsome, heroic-looking young gentleman, a type she has never truly encountered or spoken to.
She notes that his frown and general roughness paradoxically put her at ease, allowing her to persist in her offer of help even when he seems to wave her away.
Jane firmly states that she cannot consider leaving him alone in the solitary lane at such a late hour until she sees he is fit to mount his horse.
He looks at her properly for the first time and questions her, asking where she comes from and suggesting she should be at home.
Jane explains she lives nearby ('just below') and is not afraid of being out late in the moonlight, reiterating her offer to go to Hay for him, as she is going there anyway to post a letter.
He inquires if 'just below' refers to Thornfield Hall, which is visible in the moonlight.
Upon her confirmation, he asks whose house it is, and she replies, 'Mr. Rochester’s.'
He then asks if she knows Mr. Rochester, and she admits she has never seen him, leading him to deduce Mr. Rochester is not resident.
After she cannot tell him Mr. Rochester's whereabouts, he observes her simple black attire and seems puzzled about her social standing, prompting Jane to clarify, 'I am the governess.'
The traveler repeats 'the governess' thoughtfully, as if the information is significant or surprising, while scrutinizing her clothing again.

events.text_segment:
“You must just stand on one side,” he answered as he rose, first to his knees, and then to his feet. I did; whereupon began a heaving, stamping, clattering process, accompanied by a barking and baying which removed me effectually some yards’ distance; but I would not be driven quite away till I saw the event. This was finally fortunate; the horse was re-established, and the dog was silenced with a “Down, Pilot!” The traveller now, stooping, felt his foot and leg, as if trying whether they were sound; apparently something ailed them, for he halted to the stile whence I had just risen, and sat down.
I was in the mood for being useful, or at least officious, I think, for I now drew near him again.
“If you are hurt, and want help, sir, I can fetch some one either from Thornfield Hall or from Hay.”
“Thank you: I shall do: I have no broken bones,—only a sprain;” and again he stood up and tried his foot, but the result extorted an involuntary “Ugh!”
Something of daylight still lingered, and the moon was waxing bright: I could see him plainly. His figure was enveloped in a riding cloak, fur collared and steel clasped; its details were not apparent, but I traced the general points of middle height and considerable breadth of chest. He had a dark face, with stern features and a heavy brow; his eyes and gathered eyebrows looked ireful and thwarted just now; he was past youth, but had not reached middle-age; perhaps he might be thirty-five. I felt no fear of him, and but little shyness. Had he been a handsome, heroic-looking young gentleman, I should not have dared to stand thus questioning him against his will, and offering my services unasked. I had hardly ever seen a handsome youth; never in my life spoken to one. I had a theoretical reverence and homage for beauty, elegance, gallantry, fascination; but had I met those qualities incarnate in masculine shape, I should have known instinctively that they neither had nor could have sympathy with anything in me, and should have shunned them as one would fire, lightning, or anything else that is bright but antipathetic.
If even this stranger had smiled and been good-humoured to me when I addressed him; if he had put off my offer of assistance gaily and with thanks, I should have gone on my way and not felt any vocation to renew inquiries: but the frown, the roughness of the traveller, set me at my ease: I retained my station when he waved to me to go, and announced—
“I cannot think of leaving you, sir, at so late an hour, in this solitary lane, till I see you are fit to mount your horse.”
He looked at me when I said this; he had hardly turned his eyes in my direction before.
“I should think you ought to be at home yourself,” said he, “if you have a home in this neighbourhood: where do you come from?”
“From just below; and I am not at all afraid of being out late when it is moonlight: I will run over to Hay for you with pleasure, if you wish it: indeed, I am going there to post a letter.”
“You live just below—do you mean at that house with the battlements?” pointing to Thornfield Hall, on which the moon cast a hoary gleam, bringing it out distinct and pale from the woods that, by contrast with the western sky, now seemed one mass of shadow.
“Yes, sir.”
“Whose house is it?”
“Mr. Rochester’s.”
“Do you know Mr. Rochester?”
“No, I have never seen him.”
“He is not resident, then?”
“No.”
“Can you tell me where he is?”
“I cannot.”
“You are not a servant at the hall, of course. You are—” He stopped, ran his eye over my dress, which, as usual, was quite simple: a black merino cloak, a black beaver bonnet; neither of them half fine enough for a lady’s-maid. He seemed puzzled to decide what I was; I helped him.
“I am the governess.”
“Ah, the governess!” he repeated; “deuce take me, if I had not forgotten! The governess!” and again my raiment underwent scrutiny.

Still, I stayed to witness what happened. It ended well; the horse was upright again, and the dog was silenced with a command, “Down, Pilot!” The traveler then bent to feel his foot and leg, as if checking for soundness; they seemed injured, as he limped to the low wall I had been sitting on and sat down. Feeling perhaps helpful, or maybe just intrusive, I approached him again. “If you’re hurt and need help, sir, I can get someone from either Thornfield Hall or Hay.” “Thank you; I’ll manage. No broken bones—just a sprain,” he replied, standing again to test his foot, but the attempt elicited an involuntary groan, “Ugh!” Some daylight lingered, and the moon was growing bright, allowing me to see him clearly. He was wrapped in a riding cloak with a fur collar and steel clasps; I couldn’t see the fine details, but I could make out his general build, medium height and broad chest. He had a dark, stern face with a heavy brow; his eyes and drawn-together eyebrows looked angry and thwarted just then; he was past his youth but hadn't reached middle age, perhaps around thirty-five. I had rarely seen a handsome youth and never spoken to one. But his frown and rough manner made me feel at ease. I stayed put when he motioned for me to leave and declared, “Sir, I can’t bring myself to leave you alone in this isolated lane so late until I’m sure you’re able to ride your horse.” He looked at me when I said this; he hadn’t really turned his eyes towards me before. “I think you should be at home yourself,” he said, “if you live in this area. Where are you from?” “From just below; and I’m not at all afraid of being out late with the moonlight. I’ll gladly run over to Hay for you if you wish; in fact, I’m going there anyway to post a letter.” “You live just below—do you mean that house with the battlements?” he asked, pointing towards Thornfield Hall, which the moon illuminated with a pale glow, making it stand out clearly from the woods that, in contrast to the western sky, now appeared as a mass of shadow. “Yes, sir.” “Whose house is it?” “Mr. Rochester’s.” “Do you know Mr. Rochester?” “No, I have never seen him.” “He isn’t living there currently, then?” “No.” “Can you tell me where he is?” “I cannot.” “You’re not a servant at the hall, of course. You are—” He stopped, his eyes examining my simple dress: a black merino cloak, a black beaver bonnet; neither was suitable for a lady’s maid. He seemed unsure what I was; I clarified, “I am the governess.” “Ah, the governess!” he repeated; “Hang it, I’d completely forgotten! The governess!” and he examined my clothing again.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He told me to move aside, which I did as he got up from the ground. There was then a noisy commotion: heavy movement, the clatter of hooves, and loud barking, which forced me to retreat a few paces, but I didn't leave completely—I wanted to see what would happen. Eventually, the horse got back to its feet, and the dog calmed down after being scolded. The traveler bent down to check his foot and leg, clearly in discomfort, as he limped over to the stile I had just come from and sat down. 

Feeling eager to be of assistance—or at least to do something helpful—I went over to him again. I offered to fetch aid from either Thornfield Hall or the nearby town of Hay if he needed help. He thanked me but declined, saying it was only a sprain, no broken bones. He got to his feet again and tested his injured foot, but he couldn't hide a pained reaction. 

With some daylight left and the moon getting brighter, I could see him quite well. He was wearing a riding cloak with a fur collar and metal clasp. He appeared to be of average height and broad-shouldered. His face was dark, his features stern, and he had thick eyebrows drawn together in irritation. He clearly wasn't young anymore, but not yet middle-aged—about thirty-five, I guessed. I felt neither afraid nor particularly shy around him. Had he been a very handsome and polished young man, I probably wouldn't have dared speak to him so freely or offer help; I admired such qualities from afar, but sensed instinctively that such people could never relate to me, and I would've avoided them. 

If this stranger had been cheerful or kind in his response, I would have left him alone. But his sternness instead made me feel comfortable enough to stay. Even when he motioned for me to go, I told him that I couldn't leave him alone in such a lonely spot at night until I knew he could ride his horse again. This, I noticed, was the first time he really looked at me. 

He suggested I ought to be at home if I lived nearby, and asked where I came from. I explained I lived just down the road and that I didn't mind being out late at night; I was, in fact, headed to Hay to mail a letter, and could fetch help if he needed. 

He gestured towards Thornfield Hall and asked if I lived there. I confirmed, and he asked whose house it was—Mr. Rochester's. When he asked if I knew Mr. Rochester, I told him I had never met him. Then he asked if Mr. Rochester lived there; I said he did not. He asked where Mr. Rochester was; I couldn’t say. Then, studying my plain clothing, he tried to guess my position and assumed I wasn’t a servant. I clarified for him that I was the governess. At this, he exclaimed about forgetting there was a governess, and examined my appearance again.

events.title: Jane Assists the Injured Traveler to Mount His Horse
detailed_summary: After a couple of minutes, the traveler rises from the stile, his face showing pain as he tries to move.
He tells Jane he cannot send her for help but asks if she would be kind enough to assist him a little herself.
He first inquires if she has an umbrella he could use as a makeshift walking stick, but she does not.
He then directs her to take his horse's bridle and lead the animal to him, asking if she is afraid to do so.
Jane admits to herself that she would normally be afraid to touch a horse alone, but being told to do it, she feels disposed to obey.
She puts down her muff and approaches the tall steed, struggling to catch its bridle as the spirited animal resists her efforts, making her fearful of its trampling hooves.
The traveler watches her unsuccessful attempts for some time and eventually laughs.
He comments that since 'the mountain will never be brought to Mahomet,' she must help 'Mahomet go to the mountain,' and asks her to come to him.
When she approaches, he apologizes, stating necessity compels him to make her useful, then lays a heavy hand on her shoulder and, leaning on her for support, limps to his horse.
Once he has the bridle, he masters the horse quickly and springs into the saddle, grimacing with pain as the movement wrenches his sprained ankle.
He bites his lip, then asks Jane to hand him his whip, which lies under the hedge.
After she retrieves and gives it to him, he thanks her and instructs her to make haste with her letter to Hay and return as fast as she can.
With a touch of his spurred heel, his horse rears and then bounds away, the dog following, and all three quickly disappear from sight.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:

“Like heath that, in the wilderness,
    The wild wind whirls away.”

events.text_segment:
In two minutes he rose from the stile: his face expressed pain when he tried to move.
“I cannot commission you to fetch help,” he said; “but you may help me a little yourself, if you will be so kind.”
“Yes, sir.”
“You have not an umbrella that I can use as a stick?”
“No.”
“Try to get hold of my horse’s bridle and lead him to me: you are not afraid?”
I should have been afraid to touch a horse when alone, but when told to do it, I was disposed to obey. I put down my muff on the stile, and went up to the tall steed; I endeavoured to catch the bridle, but it was a spirited thing, and would not let me come near its head; I made effort on effort, though in vain: meantime, I was mortally afraid of its trampling fore-feet. The traveller waited and watched for some time, and at last he laughed.
“I see,” he said, “the mountain will never be brought to Mahomet, so all you can do is to aid Mahomet to go to the mountain; I must beg of you to come here.”
I came. “Excuse me,” he continued: “necessity compels me to make you useful.” He laid a heavy hand on my shoulder, and leaning on me with some stress, limped to his horse. Having once caught the bridle, he mastered it directly and sprang to his saddle; grimacing grimly as he made the effort, for it wrenched his sprain.
“Now,” said he, releasing his under lip from a hard bite, “just hand me my whip; it lies there under the hedge.”
I sought it and found it.
“Thank you; now make haste with the letter to Hay, and return as fast as you can.”
A touch of a spurred heel made his horse first start and rear, and then bound away; the dog rushed in his traces; all three vanished,
“Like heath that, in the wilderness,
    The wild wind whirls away.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: After two minutes, he got up from the stone step, wincing in pain as he attempted to move. 'I cannot send you to get help,' he stated, 'but you could assist me a bit yourself, if you wouldn't mind.' 'Yes, sir,' I replied. 'Do you happen to have an umbrella I could use as a walking stick?' he asked. 'No,' I answered. 'Please try to grasp my horse's reins and guide him over to me; you're not scared, are you?' Ordinarily, I would have been afraid to touch a horse when I was alone, but when directed to do so, I felt compelled to obey. I placed my hand-warmer on the stile and approached the large animal. I attempted to grab the bridle, but the horse was lively and wouldn't allow me near its head. I made repeated efforts, though without success; meanwhile, I was terrified of its front hooves. The traveler watched patiently for a time, then eventually chuckled. 'I see,' he remarked, 'the mountain isn't going to come to Mahomet, so the only option is for you to assist Mahomet in reaching the mountain; I must ask you to come here.' I walked towards him. 'Forgive me,' he continued, 'but circumstances require me to make use of your help.' He placed a heavy hand on my shoulder and, leaning on me somewhat heavily, hobbled over to his horse. Once he had hold of the bridle, he quickly gained control and mounted, making a pained face as he did so, for it twisted his strained joint. 'Now,' he said, releasing his lower lip from being tightly bitten, 'just pass me my riding whip; it's over there under the hedge.' I searched for it and found it. 'Thank you; now please hurry to Hay with the letter and return as quickly as you can.' With a nudge of a spurred heel, his horse first flinched and stood on its hind legs, then bolted away. The dog ran close behind it; all three disappeared, 'Like scattered heather, in the wild expanse, The gusty wind sweeps hence.'
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Within a couple of minutes, he got up from the stile, his face showing discomfort as he moved. "I can't ask you to go for help," he said, "but you might be able to assist me a little, if you're willing." 
"Yes, sir," I replied.
"Do you have an umbrella that I could use as a walking stick?"
"No."
"Try to grab hold of my horse's bridle and lead him over; you aren't scared, are you?"
Normally I would've been too frightened to touch a horse by myself, but since he'd instructed me, I felt compelled to try. I set my muff down on the stile and approached the tall horse. I tried to take hold of the bridle, but the horse was lively and didn't let me near its head; I made several attempts, but failed each time. All the while, I was deeply afraid that the horse might step on me. The traveler observed for a while, and eventually laughed.
"I see," he said, "the mountain will never come to Mahomet; so all you can do is help Mahomet go to the mountain. I must ask you to come over here."
I went to him. "Pardon me," he continued, "I have no choice but to put you to use." He placed a strong hand on my shoulder and, using me for support, hobbled over to his horse. Once he had the bridle, he quickly gained control and mounted the saddle; he grimaced with pain, as the movement aggravated his injury.
"Now," he said, releasing his bitten lower lip, "please hand me my whip; it's under the hedge there."
I found it and gave it to him.
"Thank you; now hurry on with the letter to Hay, and come back as quickly as possible."
With a nudge from his spurred heel, the horse sprang and reared, then galloped off; the dog followed, and in moments, all three disappeared—
"Like heath that, in the wilderness, The wild wind whirls away."

events.title: Reflections on the Encounter and Reluctant Return to Thornfield
detailed_summary: Jane picks up her muff and continues her walk, reflecting on the recent incident.
She considers it an event of no great moment, romance, or intrinsic interest, yet acknowledges that it marked a distinct change in one hour of her otherwise monotonous life.
She feels a sense of satisfaction from having been needed and having provided assistance, pleased to have done something active, however trivial and transitory.
The traveler's face—masculine, dark, strong, and stern—is a new and different kind of image in her memory gallery.
This image remains with her as she enters Hay, posts her letter, and walks quickly downhill all the way back to Thornfield.
Upon reaching the stile again, she stops for a minute, looking and listening, with a fleeting idea that the horse and rider might reappear, but sees only the quiet landscape.
A light kindling in a Thornfield window reminds her that she is late, and she hurries onward.
Jane confesses a strong reluctance to re-enter Thornfield, associating the return with a descent into stagnation and the quelling of the faint excitement from her walk.

She feels the 'viewless fetters' of her uniform and too-still existence, an existence whose privileges of security and ease she is becoming incapable of appreciating due to her yearning for more dynamic experiences.
She likens her desire for change to a man tired of an 'easy chair' wishing for a long walk.

Lingering outside the gates and on the lawn, she feels drawn away from the gloomy house towards the expansive night sky, the ascending moon, and the stars, which make her heart tremble and veins glow.
The striking of the hall clock abruptly recalls her to earth, and she turns from the celestial view, opens a side-door, and goes inside.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I took up my muff and walked on.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Little things recall us to earth; the clock struck in the hall; that sufficed; I turned from moon and stars, opened a side-door, and went in.

events.text_segment:
I took up my muff and walked on. The incident had occurred and was gone for me: it was an incident of no moment, no romance, no interest in a sense; yet it marked with change one single hour of a monotonous life. My help had been needed and claimed; I had given it: I was pleased to have done something; trivial, transitory though the deed was, it was yet an active thing, and I was weary of an existence all passive. The new face, too, was like a new picture introduced to the gallery of memory; and it was dissimilar to all the others hanging there: firstly, because it was masculine; and, secondly, because it was dark, strong, and stern. I had it still before me when I entered Hay, and slipped the letter into the post-office; I saw it as I walked fast down-hill all the way home. When I came to the stile, I stopped a minute, looked round and listened, with an idea that a horse’s hoofs might ring on the causeway again, and that a rider in a cloak, and a Gytrash-like Newfoundland dog, might be again apparent: I saw only the hedge and a pollard willow before me, rising up still and straight to meet the moonbeams; I heard only the faintest waft of wind roaming fitful among the trees round Thornfield, a mile distant; and when I glanced down in the direction of the murmur, my eye, traversing the hall-front, caught a light kindling in a window: it reminded me that I was late, and I hurried on.
I did not like re-entering Thornfield. To pass its threshold was to return to stagnation; to cross the silent hall, to ascend the darksome staircase, to seek my own lonely little room, and then to meet tranquil Mrs. Fairfax, and spend the long winter evening with her, and her only, was to quell wholly the faint excitement wakened by my walk,—to slip again over my faculties the viewless fetters of an uniform and too still existence; of an existence whose very privileges of security and ease I was becoming incapable of appreciating. What good it would have done me at that time to have been tossed in the storms of an uncertain struggling life, and to have been taught by rough and bitter experience to long for the calm amidst which I now repined! Yes, just as much good as it would do a man tired of sitting still in a “too easy chair” to take a long walk: and just as natural was the wish to stir, under my circumstances, as it would be under his.
I lingered at the gates; I lingered on the lawn; I paced backwards and forwards on the pavement; the shutters of the glass door were closed; I could not see into the interior; and both my eyes and spirit seemed drawn from the gloomy house—from the grey hollow filled with rayless cells, as it appeared to me—to that sky expanded before me,—a blue sea absolved from taint of cloud; the moon ascending it in solemn march; her orb seeming to look up as she left the hill-tops, from behind which she had come, far and farther below her, and aspired to the zenith, midnight dark in its fathomless depth and measureless distance; and for those trembling stars that followed her course; they made my heart tremble, my veins glow when I viewed them. Little things recall us to earth; the clock struck in the hall; that sufficed; I turned from moon and stars, opened a side-door, and went in.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
I picked up my hand muff and continued walking. For me, the event was finished and gone; in a way, it wasn't a major incident, had no romance, and wasn't particularly interesting. Yet, it marked a change in one single hour of my monotonous life. My assistance was needed and requested; I provided it. I was pleased to have accomplished something; even though the act was minor and brief, it was still an active deed, and I was tired of an entirely passive existence. The new face, too, was like a fresh image added to my collection of memories, and it was unlike any other picture hanging there. Firstly, because it was a man's face, and secondly, because it was dark, strong, and serious. I still saw it in my mind when I reached Hay and dropped the letter into the post-office. I pictured it as I walked quickly downhill all the way home. When I arrived at the stile, I stopped for a moment, looked around and listened, half-expecting that a horse's hooves might sound on the path again, and that a rider in a cloak, with a large, Gytrash-like dog, might reappear. I saw only the hedge and a pollard willow in front of me, standing still and upright under the moonbeams. I heard only the faintest whisper of wind drifting irregularly among the trees around Thornfield, which was a mile distant. When I looked down towards the direction of that soft sound, my gaze, sweeping across the front of the house, spotted a light turning on in a window. It reminded me that I was late, and I hurried on.
I didn't look forward to re-entering Thornfield. Crossing its threshold meant returning to stagnation; walking through the quiet hall, climbing the dark staircase, going to my solitary little room, and then meeting the calm Mrs. Fairfax, and spending the long winter evening only with her, meant completely suppressing the slight excitement my walk had awakened. It meant letting the invisible chains of a uniform and overly still existence settle back upon my abilities; an existence whose very advantages of security and comfort I was becoming unable to value. How beneficial it would have been for me at that time to have been tossed about in the challenges of an uncertain, struggling life, and to have learned through difficult and harsh experience to long for the calm I was now complaining about! Yes, it would have been just as good for me as a long walk would be for a man tired of sitting still in a "too easy chair"; and my desire to move and experience things, given my circumstances, was just as natural as his would be.
I paused at the gates; I lingered on the lawn; I walked back and forth on the path. The shutters of the glass door were closed; I couldn't see inside. Both my eyes and my spirit seemed drawn away from the gloomy house—which appeared to me like a grey, empty space filled with dark, unlit rooms—towards the sky spread out before me. It was a blue expanse completely free of clouds, with the moon ascending it in a dignified procession. Her light seemed to look upwards as she left the hilltops she had emerged from, leaving them further and further below her, and aimed for the highest point of the sky, which was midnight dark in its immeasurable depth and vast distance. And as for those faint stars that followed her path, they made my heart tremble and my veins glow when I looked at them. Small things bring us back to reality; the clock in the hall struck. That was sufficient; I turned away from the moon and stars, opened a side door, and went in.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I picked up my muff and continued on my way. The event had happened and passed—meaningless, lacking excitement or real importance, yet it brought a change to an otherwise uneventful day. Someone needed help and I provided it; though minor and fleeting, it felt good to have taken action, as I was tired of always being passive. The stranger’s face was added to my mental gallery of memories—it stood out because it was a man’s, and because it was dark, strong, and severe. I kept seeing his face in my mind as I entered Hay and posted the letter, and as I hurried back home. Reaching the stile, I paused, listening and half expecting to once again hear a horse or see a rider and dog, but only the hedge and a willow tree met my gaze, lit by the moon. I heard only the faint wind through the trees around Thornfield, far off, and when I glanced that way, I saw light in a window, reminding me I was late, so I hurried on.

I wasn’t eager to return to Thornfield—going back meant resuming my dull routines: crossing the silent hall, climbing the dark stairs, going to my small, lonely room, and spending the long winter night with only calm Mrs. Fairfax. This routine snuffed out the brief excitement I’d found on my walk, trapping me again in the invisible restraints of a safe but monotonous life. I realized I was growing unable to appreciate even the security and comfort I had. I thought how beneficial it might have been to experience the hardships of an uncertain, challenging life—just as a man bored by an easy chair might crave a long walk, it made sense that I wished for change.

I hesitated at the gates, on the lawn, and walked up and down the path. The shutters over the glass door were closed, so I couldn’t see inside. Both my eyes and thoughts were drawn away from the gloomy, hollow-feeling house to the sky above—a wide, flawless blue with the moon calmly rising higher, climbing from the hills, aiming for the zenith, trailed by trembling stars. These stirred my feelings, making my heart quiver and my blood quicken. But small disturbances bring us back to reality—the clock struck in the hall, calling me back. I turned away from the sky, went to the side-door, and entered the house.

events.title: Unexpected Welcome and a Familiar Dog Inside Thornfield
detailed_summary: Upon entering Thornfield, Jane finds the hall not dark but suffused with a warm glow from the high-hung bronze lamp, a light that also illuminates the lower steps of the oak staircase.
This ruddy shine originates from the great dining-room, whose double doors are open, revealing a genial fire, marble hearth, brass fire-irons, purple draperies, and polished furniture.
She glimpses a group near the mantelpiece and becomes aware of a cheerful mingling of voices, among which she believes she can distinguish Adèle's tones, just before the dining-room door closes.
Jane hastens to Mrs. Fairfax's room, where she finds a fire lit but no candle and no sign of Mrs. Fairfax.
Instead, sitting upright on the rug and gazing gravely at the fire, she beholds a great black and white long-haired dog, identical to the 'Gytrash' she encountered in the lane.
The resemblance is so striking that she instinctively calls out 'Pilot,' whereupon the dog gets up, comes to her, and sniffs her.
Jane caresses him, and he wags his tail, but she finds him an eerie creature to be alone with and wonders about his unexpected presence in the house.
She rings the bell, wanting a candle and also an explanation for the dog's appearance.
Leah, the housemaid, enters the room in response to the bell.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The hall was not dark, nor yet was it lit, only by the high-hung bronze lamp; a warm glow suffused both it and the lower steps of the oak staircase.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Leah entered.

events.text_segment:
The hall was not dark, nor yet was it lit, only by the high-hung bronze lamp; a warm glow suffused both it and the lower steps of the oak staircase. This ruddy shine issued from the great dining-room, whose two-leaved door stood open, and showed a genial fire in the grate, glancing on marble hearth and brass fire-irons, and revealing purple draperies and polished furniture, in the most pleasant radiance. It revealed, too, a group near the mantelpiece: I had scarcely caught it, and scarcely become aware of a cheerful mingling of voices, amongst which I seemed to distinguish the tones of Adèle, when the door closed.
I hastened to Mrs. Fairfax’s room; there was a fire there too, but no candle, and no Mrs. Fairfax. Instead, all alone, sitting upright on the rug, and gazing with gravity at the blaze, I beheld a great black and white long-haired dog, just like the Gytrash of the lane. It was so like it that I went forward and said—“Pilot,” and the thing got up and came to me and snuffed me. I caressed him, and he wagged his great tail; but he looked an eerie creature to be alone with, and I could not tell whence he had come. I rang the bell, for I wanted a candle; and I wanted, too, to get an account of this visitant. Leah entered.

events.title: The Master's Arrival Revealed and the Mystery of the Encounter Solved
detailed_summary: Jane immediately asks Leah about the dog's identity.
Leah explains that the dog, Pilot, arrived with 'master.'
When Jane seeks clarification, Leah specifies, 'With master—Mr. Rochester—he is just arrived.'
Jane expresses her surprise and inquires if Mrs. Fairfax is with him.

Leah confirms that Mrs. Fairfax and Miss Adèle are indeed in the dining room with Mr. Rochester. She adds that John has gone to fetch a surgeon because Mr. Rochester has had an accident: his horse fell, and his ankle is sprained.
Jane, connecting the pieces, asks if the horse fell in Hay Lane.
Leah affirms that it did, stating the horse slipped on some ice while coming downhill.
Realizing the full situation, Jane requests a candle from Leah.
Leah brings the candle and is followed into the room by Mrs. Fairfax, who repeats the news of Mr. Rochester's arrival and his accident.
Mrs. Fairfax further informs Jane that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, has arrived and is currently attending to Mr. Rochester.

Mrs. Fairfax then hurries out to give orders about tea, while Jane goes upstairs to remove her outdoor attire, the identity of the stranger she assisted now fully revealed to her as her employer, Mr. Rochester.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What dog is this?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Leah brought it; she entered, followed by Mrs. Fairfax, who repeated the news; adding that Mr. Carter the surgeon was come, and was now with Mr. Rochester: then she hurried out to give orders about tea, and I went upstairs to take off my things.

events.text_segment:
“What dog is this?”
“He came with master.”
“With whom?”
“With master—Mr. Rochester—he is just arrived.”
“Indeed! and is Mrs. Fairfax with him?”
“Yes, and Miss Adèle; they are in the dining-room, and John is gone for a surgeon; for master has had an accident; his horse fell and his ankle is sprained.”
“Did the horse fall in Hay Lane?”
“Yes, coming down-hill; it slipped on some ice.”
“Ah! Bring me a candle will you Leah?”
Leah brought it; she entered, followed by Mrs. Fairfax, who repeated the news; adding that Mr. Carter the surgeon was come, and was now with Mr. Rochester: then she hurried out to give orders about tea, and I went upstairs to take off my things.

Leah then revealed that Mr. Rochester had suffered an accident; his horse had fallen, causing him to sprain his ankle, and John had been dispatched to fetch a surgeon. When I asked if the fall occurred in Hay Lane, Leah confirmed it did, explaining the horse slipped on ice while descending the hill. I then requested a candle. Leah brought it in, followed by Mrs. Fairfax, who reiterated the news of the accident and added that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, was now with Mr. Rochester. Mrs. Fairfax then hurried off to give instructions regarding tea, and I went upstairs to remove my outdoor garments.

Mrs. Fairfax then quickly left to arrange tea, while I went upstairs to remove my outerwear.

events.title: Thornfield's New Rhythm and Adèle's Excitement
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester's arrival transforms Thornfield Hall from a quiet, church-like place into a bustling household, a change Jane Eyre finds herself appreciating.
The library is repurposed as a reception room, so Jane establishes a new schoolroom upstairs.
Adèle is too excited and distracted to focus on her lessons, constantly seeking glimpses of Mr. Rochester.
She eagerly anticipates a present Mr. Rochester hinted he might have for her in his luggage.
Adèle reveals that Mr. Rochester inquired about his new governess, asking for her name and a description, which Adèle confirmed as accurate (small, slender, somewhat pale).

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Rochester, it seems, by the surgeon’s orders, went to bed early that night; nor did he rise soon next morning.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: J’ai dit qu’oui: car c’est vrai, n’est-ce pas, mademoiselle?”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Rochester, it seems, by the surgeon’s orders, went to bed early that night; nor did he rise soon next morning. When he did come down, it was to attend to business: his agent and some of his tenants were arrived, and waiting to speak with him.
Adèle and I had now to vacate the library: it would be in daily requisition as a reception-room for callers. A fire was lit in an apartment upstairs, and there I carried our books, and arranged it for the future schoolroom. I discerned in the course of the morning that Thornfield Hall was a changed place: no longer silent as a church, it echoed every hour or two to a knock at the door, or a clang of the bell; steps, too, often traversed the hall, and new voices spoke in different keys below; a rill from the outer world was flowing through it; it had a master: for my part, I liked it better.
Adèle was not easy to teach that day; she could not apply: she kept running to the door and looking over the banisters to see if she could get a glimpse of Mr. Rochester; then she coined pretexts to go downstairs, in order, as I shrewdly suspected, to visit the library, where I knew she was not wanted; then, when I got a little angry, and made her sit still, she continued to talk incessantly of her “ami, Monsieur Edouard Fairfax de Rochester,” as she dubbed him (I had not before heard his prenomens), and to conjecture what presents he had brought her: for it appears he had intimated the night before, that when his luggage came from Millcote, there would be found amongst it a little box in whose contents she had an interest.
“Et cela doit signifier,” said she, “qu’il y aura là dedans un cadeau pour moi, et peut-être pour vous aussi, mademoiselle. Monsieur a parlé de vous: il m’a demandé le nom de ma gouvernante, et si elle n’était pas une petite personne, assez mince et un peu pâle. J’ai dit qu’oui: car c’est vrai, n’est-ce pas, mademoiselle?”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Apparently, following the surgeon's orders, Mr. Rochester retired early that night and did not wake up early the following morning. Upon descending, he immediately attended to business matters, as his agent and several tenants had arrived and were waiting to speak with him. Consequently, Adèle and I had to leave the library, as it was now needed daily to receive visitors. A fire was started in an upstairs room, where I moved our books and arranged it to become our new schoolroom. During the morning, I noticed that Thornfield Hall felt considerably altered; instead of its former quietness, it now frequently echoed with knocks at the door or the ringing of the bell every hour or two. People often walked through the hall, and new voices could be heard from downstairs. It was as if a stream from the outside world was flowing through it; the house now had a master. Personally, I preferred it this way. Adèle was difficult to teach that day; she struggled to concentrate. She repeatedly ran to the door and peered over the banisters, hoping to catch sight of Mr. Rochester. Then she invented excuses to go downstairs, which I strongly suspected were attempts to get into the library, a place I knew she shouldn't be. When I eventually became a little annoyed and insisted she remain seated, she continued talking incessantly about her 'friend, Monsieur Edouard Fairfax de Rochester,' as she nicknamed him (I had not heard his first names previously), and speculating about the gifts he might have brought her. It seems he had hinted the previous evening that when his luggage arrived from Millcote, it would contain a small box with something in it that would interest her. 'And that must mean,' she said, 'that there will be a gift for me inside, and perhaps for you too, Mademoiselle. Monsieur spoke about you: he asked me the name of my governess, and if she wasn't a small person, quite thin and a little pale. I said yes, because that's true, isn't it, Mademoiselle?'

When he did finally appear, it was because he had business to attend to; his agent and some tenants had arrived and were waiting to meet him. As a result, Adèle and I had to leave the library, since it would now be used daily as a room to receive visitors. I set up a fire in a room upstairs, moved our books there, and arranged it to serve as our new schoolroom. During the morning, I noticed that Thornfield Hall felt different: it was no longer as quiet as a church but instead was frequently interrupted by knocks on the door or the ringing of the bell; I also heard footsteps crossing the hall and unfamiliar voices speaking downstairs. The outside world was starting to enter the house now that it had its master back, and to me, this made Thornfield more appealing. Adèle was difficult to teach that day; she was distracted and unable to concentrate, continually running to the door and peering over the banisters hoping to catch sight of Mr. Rochester. She made up reasons to go downstairs—likely hoping to sneak into the library, though she was not supposed to go there. When I became a bit exasperated and made her stay put, she wouldn’t stop talking about her 'friend,' Mr. Edouard Fairfax de Rochester (the first time I’d heard his full name), and speculated about what gifts he might have brought her. Evidently, he had told her the night before that when his luggage arrived from Millcote, there would be a small box in it intended for her. "And that must mean," she said, "there will be a present for me inside, and perhaps for you too, mademoiselle. Monsieur spoke about you: he asked me my governess’s name, and whether she was a small, slim, and rather pale person. I said yes—because it’s true, isn’t it, mademoiselle?"

events.title: An Unexpected Invitation to Tea and Preparations
detailed_summary: After a snowy afternoon in the schoolroom, Jane allows Adèle to go downstairs, sensing Mr. Rochester is available.
While Jane is lost in thought by the fireside, Mrs. Fairfax enters and interrupts her reverie.
Mrs. Fairfax extends an invitation from Mr. Rochester for Jane and Adèle to join him for tea in the drawing-room.
A discussion ensues about Jane changing her dress for the occasion; Mrs. Fairfax emphasizes that she always dresses for the evening when Mr. Rochester is present.
Jane complies, changing into her black silk dress, her best one, and fastening a pearl brooch given by Miss Temple, feeling a degree of trepidation about the formal summons.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I and my pupil dined as usual in Mrs. Fairfax’s parlour; the afternoon was wild and snowy, and we passed it in the schoolroom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I let Mrs. Fairfax precede me into the dining-room, and kept in her shade as we crossed that apartment; and, passing the arch, whose curtain was now dropped, entered the elegant recess beyond.

events.text_segment:
I and my pupil dined as usual in Mrs. Fairfax’s parlour; the afternoon was wild and snowy, and we passed it in the schoolroom. At dark I allowed Adèle to put away books and work, and to run downstairs; for, from the comparative silence below, and from the cessation of appeals to the door-bell, I conjectured that Mr. Rochester was now at liberty. Left alone, I walked to the window; but nothing was to be seen thence: twilight and snowflakes together thickened the air, and hid the very shrubs on the lawn. I let down the curtain and went back to the fireside.
In the clear embers I was tracing a view, not unlike a picture I remembered to have seen of the castle of Heidelberg, on the Rhine, when Mrs. Fairfax came in, breaking up by her entrance the fiery mosaic I had been piercing together, and scattering too some heavy unwelcome thoughts that were beginning to throng on my solitude.
“Mr. Rochester would be glad if you and your pupil would take tea with him in the drawing-room this evening,” said she: “he has been so much engaged all day that he could not ask to see you before.”
“When is his tea-time?” I inquired.
“Oh, at six o’clock: he keeps early hours in the country. You had better change your frock now; I will go with you and fasten it. Here is a candle.”
“Is it necessary to change my frock?”
“Yes, you had better: I always dress for the evening when Mr. Rochester is here.”
This additional ceremony seemed somewhat stately; however, I repaired to my room, and, with Mrs. Fairfax’s aid, replaced my black stuff dress by one of black silk; the best and the only additional one I had, except one of light grey, which, in my Lowood notions of the toilette, I thought too fine to be worn, except on first-rate occasions.
“You want a brooch,” said Mrs. Fairfax. I had a single little pearl ornament which Miss Temple gave me as a parting keepsake: I put it on, and then we went downstairs. Unused as I was to strangers, it was rather a trial to appear thus formally summoned in Mr. Rochester’s presence. I let Mrs. Fairfax precede me into the dining-room, and kept in her shade as we crossed that apartment; and, passing the arch, whose curtain was now dropped, entered the elegant recess beyond.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
As was customary, Adèle and I ate lunch in Mrs. Fairfax’s sitting room. The afternoon was blustery and snowy, so we spent it in the classroom. When it got dark, I allowed Adèle to finish her studies and chores and go downstairs. Based on the reduced noise from below and the lack of rings at the doorbell, I suspected Mr. Rochester was now free. Once I was alone, I walked to the window, but I couldn't see anything outside. The combined effect of twilight and falling snow obscured the air, hiding even the bushes on the lawn. I closed the curtain and returned to sit by the fire.
While staring into the bright embers, I was picturing a scene that reminded me of a picture I'd seen of Heidelberg Castle on the Rhine. Just then, Mrs. Fairfax entered, interrupting the fiery image I was constructing and also dispersing some heavy, unwelcome thoughts that were starting to crowd my solitary mind.
She announced, "Mr. Rochester would like you and your pupil to join him for tea in the drawing-room this evening. He's been so busy all day that he couldn't ask to see you sooner."
I asked, "What time is tea?"
"Oh, six o’clock," she replied. "He keeps early hours in the country. You should probably change your dress now. I’ll help you with it. Here’s a candle."
"Is it necessary to change my dress?" I questioned.
"Yes, you really should," she advised. "I always dress up for the evening when Mr. Rochester is present."
This added formality seemed rather grand. Nevertheless, I went to my room, and with Mrs. Fairfax’s help, I swapped my black woollen gown for one of black silk. It was the best and only spare dress I owned, apart from a light grey one which, according to my simple Lowood ideas of dressing, I considered too fancy for anything but very special occasions.
"You need a brooch," Mrs. Fairfax remarked. I had a small pearl pin that Miss Temple had given me as a farewell gift. I put it on, and then we headed downstairs. Not being used to company, appearing formally summoned into Mr. Rochester’s presence felt somewhat daunting. I let Mrs. Fairfax walk ahead of me into the dining-room, staying slightly behind her as we crossed it. We then passed through the arched doorway, where the curtain was now drawn, and entered the elegant space beyond.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
My student and I ate our meal as we usually did in Mrs. Fairfax’s sitting room. The weather outside was stormy and filled with snow, so we spent the afternoon inside the schoolroom. As it grew dark, I let Adèle put away her lessons and go downstairs, since things were quieter below and I guessed that Mr. Rochester was finally free from his business. When I was alone, I walked over to the window, but the thick snow and fading light made it impossible to see anything outside—not even the bushes on the lawn were visible. I drew the curtains and went back to sit by the fire.

As I watched the glowing embers, I started to imagine a scene like a painting I once saw of Heidelberg Castle on the Rhine. Mrs. Fairfax entered unexpectedly, breaking my concentration and dispelling the troubling thoughts that had started to fill my mind in the solitude.

She said, “Mr. Rochester would like you and your student to join him for tea in the drawing-room this evening. He’s been busy all day and couldn’t invite you sooner.”

I asked, “When does he have tea?”

“At six o’clock,” she replied. “He prefers to keep early hours while in the country. You should change your dress now, and I’ll come with you to help fasten it. Here’s a candle.”

I questioned if changing my dress was truly necessary.

She answered, “Yes, you should. I always dress for the evening when Mr. Rochester is here.”

Though this extra formality felt a bit grand, I went to my room and, with Mrs. Fairfax’s help, changed from my black cloth dress into my black silk one—the nicest alternative I owned, apart from a light grey dress that I thought too elegant to wear on anything but very special occasions, according to what I’d learned about dressing at Lowood.

Mrs. Fairfax noted, “You need a brooch.” I had a small pearl brooch that Miss Temple had given me as a farewell gift, so I put it on. Then we went downstairs together. Since I wasn’t used to being around strangers, I felt a bit nervous about being formally invited into Mr. Rochester’s presence. I let Mrs. Fairfax lead the way into the dining room, staying close behind her as we crossed the room, passed under the archway with its curtain now lowered, and entered the elegant space beyond.

events.title: An Icy Reception and Jane's Quiet Scrutiny
detailed_summary: Upon entering the drawing-room, Jane observes the scene: Pilot the dog by a superb fire, Adèle kneeling near him, and Mr. Rochester reclining on a couch.

Jane meticulously studies Mr. Rochester's features, noting his broad, jetty eyebrows, square forehead, decisive nose, grim mouth, and athletic, though not graceful, physique, concluding his face is more remarkable for character than beauty.
Mr. Rochester initially seems oblivious to their presence, not lifting his head as they approach.
Mrs. Fairfax quietly announces Miss Eyre's presence.
Mr. Rochester offers a forced, stiff bow and, in an impatient yet formal tone, requests Miss Eyre be seated, conveying an air of indifference.
Jane feels surprisingly unembarrassed by his abruptness, finding his eccentricity piquant and feeling interested to see how he will proceed.
Mr. Rochester remains silent and motionless, like a statue.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Two wax candles stood lighted on the table, and two on the mantelpiece; basking in the light and heat of a superb fire, lay Pilot—Adèle knelt near him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He went on as a statue would, that is, he neither spoke nor moved.

events.text_segment:
Two wax candles stood lighted on the table, and two on the mantelpiece; basking in the light and heat of a superb fire, lay Pilot—Adèle knelt near him. Half reclined on a couch appeared Mr. Rochester, his foot supported by the cushion; he was looking at Adèle and the dog: the fire shone full on his face. I knew my traveller with his broad and jetty eyebrows; his square forehead, made squarer by the horizontal sweep of his black hair. I recognised his decisive nose, more remarkable for character than beauty; his full nostrils, denoting, I thought, choler; his grim mouth, chin, and jaw—yes, all three were very grim, and no mistake. His shape, now divested of cloak, I perceived harmonised in squareness with his physiognomy: I suppose it was a good figure in the athletic sense of the term—broad chested and thin flanked, though neither tall nor graceful.
Mr. Rochester must have been aware of the entrance of Mrs. Fairfax and myself; but it appeared he was not in the mood to notice us, for he never lifted his head as we approached.
“Here is Miss Eyre, sir,” said Mrs. Fairfax, in her quiet way. He bowed, still not taking his eyes from the group of the dog and child.
“Let Miss Eyre be seated,” said he: and there was something in the forced stiff bow, in the impatient yet formal tone, which seemed further to express, “What the deuce is it to me whether Miss Eyre be there or not? At this moment I am not disposed to accost her.”
I sat down quite disembarrassed. A reception of finished politeness would probably have confused me: I could not have returned or repaid it by answering grace and elegance on my part; but harsh caprice laid me under no obligation; on the contrary, a decent quiescence, under the freak of manner, gave me the advantage. Besides, the eccentricity of the proceeding was piquant: I felt interested to see how he would go on.
He went on as a statue would, that is, he neither spoke nor moved.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The room was lit by two wax candles on the table and two on the mantelpiece. Pilot the dog was comfortably settled near a large, warm fire, with Adèle kneeling beside him. Mr. Rochester was partially lying on a couch, his foot propped on a cushion, watching Adèle and the dog; the firelight illuminated his face clearly. I immediately recognized the traveller by his wide, dark eyebrows, and his square forehead, which looked even squarer because of his horizontally styled black hair. I identified his determined-looking nose, notable more for character than attractiveness, and his full nostrils, which I thought indicated a temper. His stern mouth, chin, and jaw were all undoubtedly grim. Without his cloak, I saw that his build had the same angularity as his face; I supposed it was a good, athletic physique—broad-chested and narrow-waisted, though not tall or graceful. Mr. Rochester must have seen Mrs. Fairfax and me come in, but he seemed disinclined to acknowledge us immediately, as he didn't look up as we approached. "Here is Miss Eyre, sir," Mrs. Fairfax said quietly. He acknowledged this with a bow but kept his eyes on the dog and child. "Let Miss Eyre be seated," he said. There was something in his strained, stiff bow and impatient yet formal tone that seemed to say, "Why should I care if Miss Eyre is here? I'm not in the mood to speak to her right now." I sat down feeling completely at ease. A very polite greeting would likely have flustered me, as I couldn't have responded with matching grace and elegance. However, his harsh mood didn't impose any burden on me; on the contrary, reacting calmly to his odd behaviour gave me the advantage. Plus, his peculiar actions were intriguing; I was interested to see what he would do next. He did nothing at all, remaining motionless and silent, like a statue.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Two wax candles were lit on the table, with another pair on the mantelpiece. Pilot enjoyed the warmth and glow of a splendid fire, while Adèle knelt beside him. Mr. Rochester, half lying on a couch and with his foot propped up on a cushion, was watching Adèle and Pilot; the firelight illuminated his face. I could tell it was my travelling companion by his thick dark eyebrows and his broad forehead, which looked even broader because of how his black hair was brushed across it. I could pick out his firm, striking nose—it was notable for its character rather than its looks—as well as his pronounced nostrils, which I thought suggested a quick temper. His mouth, chin, and jaw were all stern and forbidding. In his indoor clothing, I saw that his physique matched his rugged face: broad-shouldered and lean at the waist, he was sturdily built—the figure of an athlete, though not tall or particularly elegant.

Even though Mrs. Fairfax and I had entered, Mr. Rochester seemed to ignore us, not raising his head as we approached. "Here is Miss Eyre, sir," Mrs. Fairfax said gently. He gave a formal bow, eyes still fixed on the child and the dog. "Let Miss Eyre be seated," he said. There was something stiff and brief in his bow, and an impatient undertone in his voice, suggesting that he did not care whether I was there at all and had no inclination to speak to me at the moment.

I took a seat calmly, untroubled by his manner. A display of perfect politeness might have unsettled me, since I could not have matched it with equal poise. His abrupt and unpredictable behavior put no pressure on me—in fact, his oddness made me feel at ease and even gave me an advantage. Moreover, his unusual conduct intrigued me, and I wondered what he would do next. He remained as motionless and silent as a statue.

events.title: Mr. Rochester's Probing Questions and Jane's Composed Replies
detailed_summary: Mrs. Fairfax attempts to engage Mr. Rochester in conversation, expressing sympathy about his business pressures and sprain, but he curtly responds by requesting tea.
Jane is tasked with handing Mr. Rochester his cup of tea.
Adèle seizes the moment to ask Mr. Rochester if there is a gift for Miss Eyre in his luggage.
Mr. Rochester gruffly questions Jane about her expectations and fondness for presents, his eyes dark and piercing.
Jane thoughtfully replies that presents are complex and require consideration before forming an opinion on their nature.
Rochester contrasts Jane's reservedness with Adèle's directness in demanding gifts.
Jane explains her reticence by stating she has less claim to a gift than Adèle, being a stranger who has done nothing to deserve acknowledgement.
Rochester dismisses her modesty, stating he has observed her diligent efforts with Adèle, whose improvement is Jane's true reward or 'cadeau'.
He then drinks his tea in silence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Fairfax seemed to think it necessary that some one should be amiable, and she began to talk.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Humph!” said Mr. Rochester, and he took his tea in silence.

events.text_segment:
Mrs. Fairfax seemed to think it necessary that some one should be amiable, and she began to talk. Kindly, as usual—and, as usual, rather trite—she condoled with him on the pressure of business he had had all day; on the annoyance it must have been to him with that painful sprain: then she commended his patience and perseverance in going through with it.
“Madam, I should like some tea,” was the sole rejoinder she got. She hastened to ring the bell; and when the tray came, she proceeded to arrange the cups, spoons, &c., with assiduous celerity. I and Adèle went to the table; but the master did not leave his couch.
“Will you hand Mr. Rochester’s cup?” said Mrs. Fairfax to me; “Adèle might perhaps spill it.”
I did as requested. As he took the cup from my hand, Adèle, thinking the moment propitious for making a request in my favour, cried out—
“N’est-ce pas, monsieur, qu’il y a un cadeau pour Mademoiselle Eyre dans votre petit coffre?”
“Who talks of cadeaux?” said he gruffly. “Did you expect a present, Miss Eyre? Are you fond of presents?” and he searched my face with eyes that I saw were dark, irate, and piercing.
“I hardly know, sir; I have little experience of them: they are generally thought pleasant things.”
“Generally thought? But what do you think?”
“I should be obliged to take time, sir, before I could give you an answer worthy of your acceptance: a present has many faces to it, has it not? and one should consider all, before pronouncing an opinion as to its nature.”
“Miss Eyre, you are not so unsophisticated as Adèle: she demands a ‘cadeau,’ clamorously, the moment she sees me: you beat about the bush.”
“Because I have less confidence in my deserts than Adèle has: she can prefer the claim of old acquaintance, and the right too of custom; for she says you have always been in the habit of giving her playthings; but if I had to make out a case I should be puzzled, since I am a stranger, and have done nothing to entitle me to an acknowledgment.”
“Oh, don’t fall back on over-modesty! I have examined Adèle, and find you have taken great pains with her: she is not bright, she has no talents; yet in a short time she has made much improvement.”
“Sir, you have now given me my ‘cadeau;’ I am obliged to you: it is the meed teachers most covet—praise of their pupils’ progress.”
“Humph!” said Mr. Rochester, and he took his tea in silence.
