He added that although I am not attractive any more than he is handsome, looking puzzled becomes me. Furthermore, it is practical because it diverts my sharp eyes away from his face and keeps them occupied with the patterns on the rug. He encouraged me to continue puzzling, announcing, "Young lady, I feel like being sociable and talkative tonight." With that statement, he got up from his chair and stood with his arm resting on the marble fireplace. In this stance, both his figure and face were clearly visible. His chest was remarkably broad, almost disproportionate to the length of his limbs. I am certain most people would have considered him unattractive. Yet, his bearing held such unconscious pride, his manner such ease, and his expression such complete disregard for his own physical appearance, combined with such arrogant faith in the power of other qualities, whether inherent or acquired, to compensate for a lack of simple personal appeal, that when observing him, one couldn't help but share his indifference and, even in a vague, uncertain way, believe in his self-assurance. "I feel like being sociable and talkative tonight," he repeated, "and that's precisely why I summoned you. The fire and the chandelier weren't enough company for me, nor would Pilot have been, as none of them can converse. Adèle is somewhat better, but still far from adequate. Mrs. Fairfax is the same. I am convinced you can satisfy my need for company if you are willing. You perplexed me the first evening I asked you to come down here. I've almost forgotten you since then; other thoughts have pushed yours out of my mind. But tonight, I am determined to relax, to dismiss whatever bothers me and recall what is pleasant. It would please me now to engage you in conversation—to learn more about you—so speak." Instead of speaking, I smiled, and it wasn't a particularly agreeable or compliant smile either. "Speak," he insisted. "About what, sir?" I asked. "Whatever you wish. I leave the choice of both the subject and the way you discuss it entirely to you." Consequently, I remained seated and said nothing. I thought to myself, "If he expects me to talk just for the sake of talking and showing off, he will discover he has addressed the wrong person." "You are silent, Miss Eyre." I remained silent. He tilted his head slightly towards me and, with a swift, single glance, seemed to penetrate my eyes. "Stubborn?" he said, "and annoyed. Ah, that fits. I phrased my request in a ridiculous, almost rude manner. Miss Eyre, I apologize. The truth is, once and for all, I have no desire to treat you as an inferior. That is," he corrected himself, "I only claim the kind of superiority that naturally arises from a twenty-year age difference and a century's advantage in experience. This is legitimate, and I maintain it, as Adèle would say. And it is by virtue of this superiority, and this alone, that I request you have the kindness to talk to me a little now and divert my thoughts, which are troubled by dwelling on a single point—eating away at me like a rusty nail." He had condescended to offer an explanation, nearly an apology, and I was not unmoved by his graciousness and didn't wish to appear so. "I am willing to entertain you, if I can, sir—quite willing. But I cannot introduce a subject because how would I know what would interest you? Ask me questions, and I will do my utmost to answer them."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"You look rather confused, Miss Eyre; and although neither of us would be called attractive, being puzzled actually suits you. Besides, it distracts your keen eyes from staring at my face and instead focuses them on the carpet's embroidery, so continue wondering. Tonight, I feel sociable and talkative." After saying this, he stood up from his chair and leaned his arm on the marble mantelpiece, making his figure, including his broad chest and somewhat unbalanced proportions, quite visible. Most people would likely have considered him unattractive, but there was such unselfconscious pride in his bearing, an easy confidence, an utter disregard for his appearance, and a strong trust in his other qualities to make up for a lack of good looks, that anyone observing him would naturally mirror that indifference and, even without knowing why, share in his self-assurance.

"I'm feeling sociable and talkative tonight," he said again, "and that's why I called for you: the fire and the chandelier aren't enough company. Nor is Pilot—the dog can’t talk. Adèle is a bit better, but still not quite enough; Mrs. Fairfax the same. I believe you could entertain me if you want to: you intrigued me the first night you came here. I almost forgot about you since then, as other matters took over my mind; but tonight, I want some relaxation—to forget my troubles and focus on what's pleasant. I'd enjoy drawing you out and getting to know you better, so please, speak." Instead of answering, I simply smiled, and it wasn't a particularly shy or agreeable smile.

"Go on, speak," he insisted.

"About what, sir?" I asked.

"Whatever you wish. Choose the topic and how you discuss it—it's entirely up to you." So I stayed quiet; I thought, "If he expects me to talk just for the sake of it, and to show off, he's chosen the wrong person."

"You're silent, Miss Eyre," he remarked. I still said nothing. He leaned his head a bit towards me and glanced quickly into my eyes.

"Are you being stubborn? And a bit annoyed? I deserve that. I asked you in a strange, even rude way. Miss Eyre, I apologize. Honestly, I don't want to treat you as an inferior: except" (he corrected himself), "I do claim the upper hand simply by being twenty years older and much more experienced. That's legitimate, as Adèle would say, and it's only by that right that I ask you to please talk to me for a while and distract me from thoughts that are bothering me—eating away at me like rust."

He had explained himself, even apologized, and I appreciated his humility and wanted to show it.

"I'm happy to entertain you, sir, if I can, but I can't think of a topic—how should I know what would interest you? If you ask questions, I'll try my best to answer."

events.title: A Spirited Debate on Authority, Formality, and Frankness
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester begins by asking Jane if she agrees with his asserted right to be masterful and abrupt based on his age and worldly experience.
Jane's initial evasive response irritates him, prompting him to demand a clear answer.
Jane then states that she does not believe his age or experience alone grant him the right to command her; true superiority depends on how one has utilized such advantages.
Rochester acknowledges her quick response but humorously rejects its application to himself, admitting his own poor use of these advantages.
He then asks if, setting aside superiority, she will accept his orders without feeling offended by his tone.
Jane smiles, privately reflecting on the peculiarity of a master who pays her yet concerns himself with her feelings about his commands.
Rochester, noticing her smile, urges her to voice her thoughts.
Jane observes that few employers would trouble themselves about whether their paid subordinates were piqued by their orders.
Feigning to have forgotten her salary, Rochester asks if she will tolerate his 'hectoring' on that 'mercenary ground.'
Jane declines this basis but readily agrees on the grounds that he did forget her salary and, more importantly, that he cares about the comfort of a dependent.
She also agrees to dispense with many conventional forms, asserting she can distinguish between informality, which she appreciates, and insolence, which she would never tolerate.
Rochester scoffs at her generalization about 'free-born' people submitting to anything for a salary but expresses his approval of her frank and sincere answer, noting its rarity.
He adds, however, that her unique mould is a gift of Nature, not her own merit, and that he is yet to discover if she possesses balancing flaws.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Then, in the first place, do you agree with me that I have a right to be a little masterful, abrupt, perhaps exacting, sometimes, on the grounds I stated, namely, that I am old enough to be your father, and that I have battled through a varied experience with many men of many nations, and roamed over half the globe, while you have lived quietly with one set of people in one house?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And then, after all, I go too fast in my conclusions: for what I yet know, you may be no better than the rest; you may have intolerable defects to counterbalance your few good points.”

events.text_segment:
“Then, in the first place, do you agree with me that I have a right to be a little masterful, abrupt, perhaps exacting, sometimes, on the grounds I stated, namely, that I am old enough to be your father, and that I have battled through a varied experience with many men of many nations, and roamed over half the globe, while you have lived quietly with one set of people in one house?”
“Do as you please, sir.”
“That is no answer; or rather it is a very irritating, because a very evasive one. Reply clearly.”
“I don’t think, sir, you have a right to command me, merely because you are older than I, or because you have seen more of the world than I have; your claim to superiority depends on the use you have made of your time and experience.”
“Humph! Promptly spoken. But I won’t allow that, seeing that it would never suit my case, as I have made an indifferent, not to say a bad, use of both advantages. Leaving superiority out of the question, then, you must still agree to receive my orders now and then, without being piqued or hurt by the tone of command. Will you?”
I smiled: I thought to myself Mr. Rochester is peculiar—he seems to forget that he pays me £30 per annum for receiving his orders.
“The smile is very well,” said he, catching instantly the passing expression; “but speak too.”
“I was thinking, sir, that very few masters would trouble themselves to inquire whether or not their paid subordinates were piqued and hurt by their orders.”
“Paid subordinates! What! you are my paid subordinate, are you? Oh yes, I had forgotten the salary! Well then, on that mercenary ground, will you agree to let me hector a little?”
“No, sir, not on that ground; but, on the ground that you did forget it, and that you care whether or not a dependent is comfortable in his dependency, I agree heartily.”
“And will you consent to dispense with a great many conventional forms and phrases, without thinking that the omission arises from insolence?”
“I am sure, sir, I should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary.”
“Humbug! Most things free-born will submit to anything for a salary; therefore, keep to yourself, and don’t venture on generalities of which you are intensely ignorant. However, I mentally shake hands with you for your answer, despite its inaccuracy; and as much for the manner in which it was said, as for the substance of the speech; the manner was frank and sincere; one does not often see such a manner: no, on the contrary, affectation, or coldness, or stupid, coarse-minded misapprehension of one’s meaning are the usual rewards of candour. Not three in three thousand raw school-girl-governesses would have answered me as you have just done. But I don’t mean to flatter you: if you are cast in a different mould to the majority, it is no merit of yours: Nature did it. And then, after all, I go too fast in my conclusions: for what I yet know, you may be no better than the rest; you may have intolerable defects to counterbalance your few good points.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. Rochester began by asking if I agreed that he had the right to be somewhat authoritative, abrupt, or even demanding sometimes, based on his claim that he was old enough to be my father, had vast and varied experiences interacting with many people across numerous countries, and had travelled extensively, in contrast to my quiet, confined life with one group in a single location. I replied simply, "Do as you please, sir." He found this irritating and evasive, insisting on a clearer response. I stated my belief that his right to command me did not stem merely from being older or more worldly than I; rather, any claim to superiority depended on how he had utilized his time and experiences. He reacted with a grunt, calling my answer quick but refusing to accept it, as it wouldn't justify his own conduct, acknowledging he had made poor use of his advantages. Setting aside the issue of superiority, he asked if I would still agree to accept his orders occasionally without feeling offended or upset by his tone of command. I smiled internally, thinking how odd Mr. Rochester was, seemingly forgetting that I was paid an annual salary of £30 precisely for receiving his instructions. Noticing my smile, he prompted me to speak. I remarked that few masters would bother to ask if their paid employees were bothered or hurt by their directives. "Paid subordinates!" he exclaimed, surprised. "So, you are my paid subordinate? Oh yes, I'd forgotten the salary!" He then asked if, purely on the basis of that financial arrangement, I would tolerate him being somewhat overbearing. I refused to agree on that basis, but readily consented because he *had* forgotten the salary and demonstrated concern for a dependent's comfort. He then inquired if I would agree to overlook many conventional formalities and expressions without assuming their absence indicated rudeness. I assured him I would never confuse informality with insolence, stating I quite liked the former but that no one truly independent would tolerate the latter, even for money. He dismissed this as nonsense, claiming most independent individuals would endure anything for payment, and advised me to stick to my own limited knowledge rather than making broad, uninformed statements. Nevertheless, he added that he mentally approved of my answer despite its inaccuracy, appreciating both its content and its frank, sincere delivery, a quality he rarely encountered, finding affectation, coldness, or dull misunderstanding more common reactions to honesty. He suggested that not one in a thousand inexperienced governesses would have responded as I had. However, he clarified he wasn't flattering me; if I was different from most, he saw it as innate rather than earned merit, concluding by saying he might be judging me too quickly and that, for all he knew, I might have significant flaws counteracting my good qualities.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: First, do you concede that I have a right to be a bit domineering, abrupt, or demanding at times, based on my reasons: I’m old enough to be your father, and I’ve experienced much of the world, meeting many people and traveling far, while your life has been sheltered in a single home among the same people? "Do as you wish, sir." "That’s not an answer—it’s evasive and quite vexing. Please answer directly." "I don’t believe, sir, that your age or worldliness gives you the right to order me about; your authority should rely on how you’ve used your time and experience." "Well said. But I can’t accept that, since I haven’t used my age or experience all that well. Putting authority aside, you still need to accept my directions from time to time, without being offended by how I give them. Can you do that?" I smiled, thinking Mr. Rochester is unusual—he seems to overlook that he pays me £30 a year for following his instructions. "That smile is fine," he noted, noticing my fleeting expression immediately, "but say something too." "I was considering, sir, that not many employers care if their paid employees are offended by orders." "Paid employees! Oh, so you’re my paid subordinate? I forgot about your pay! So on that basis, will you let me boss you a bit?" "No, sir, not for that reason; but because you forgot and actually care about your employee’s comfort, I gladly agree." "And will you be alright if we skip a lot of formalities, without thinking I’m being rude?" "I’m sure, sir, I’d never confuse informality with rudeness: I actually prefer informality, but no one truly free would endure rudeness, not even for a salary." "Nonsense! Most free people will endure anything for money; so keep your opinion to yourself and don’t generalize. Still, I mentally congratulate you for your answer and how you spoke it—it was honest and open, which is rare. Usually, frankness is met with pretension, coldness, or simple misunderstanding. Hardly any young, inexperienced governess would have answered as you did. Still, I’m not flattering you: if you’re different from most, it’s not due to any merit—it’s just your nature. And I’m perhaps judging too quickly; for all I know, you might have faults that outweigh your virtues."

events.title: Rochester's Confessions of a Troubled Past and a Disturbing Resolve
detailed_summary: Jane silently reflects that Mr. Rochester might also have his share of faults, a thought he seems to perceive from her glance.
Rochester readily concedes he has many faults and does not wish to excuse them, suggesting his own past actions make him unfit to judge others.
He reveals he was pushed onto a 'wrong tack' at twenty-one and never truly recovered, though he believes he could have been a much better, more 'stainless' person, like Jane.
He openly envies her clear conscience and untainted memory, deeming such a state an 'exquisite treasure.'
When Jane inquires about his memory at eighteen, he confirms it was then clear and that he considered himself her equal at that age.
He confesses that while nature intended him for good, he has fallen short, clarifying he is not a villain but a 'commonplace sinner,' shaped more by circumstance than inherent evil.
He explains his candor by saying people instinctively confide in Jane, sensing her capacity for sympathetic listening without judgment.
Jane expresses surprise at his insight into her character. Rochester continues, feeling he can speak as freely as if writing in a diary.
He admits he failed to rise above adverse fate, instead growing desperate and degenerating, now feeling no better than the 'vicious simpletons' he despises.
Expressing profound regret, he warns Jane about remorse, calling it 'the poison of life.'

Jane proposes repentance as a cure, but Rochester insists reformation is the true remedy, though he feels hindered from achieving it. He then declares his intention to seek pleasure, regardless of cost, since happiness is denied him.
Jane cautions that this path will lead to further degeneration. Rochester dismisses her concern, suggesting he can find 'sweet, fresh pleasure.'
Jane counters that such pleasure will ultimately bring bitterness and pain.
Rochester derides her warning as born of inexperience, asserting she has no right to 'preach' to him.
Jane calmly reminds him of his own earlier words linking error to remorse.
Rochester then speaks of a recurring notion, not an error, but an 'inspiration,' an 'angel of light,' which he feels compelled to welcome into his heart.
Jane, sensing from his troubled expression that this 'inspiration' is not benign, urges him to distrust it.

Rochester challenges her ability to distinguish true divine messengers from deceptions and declares she is not his 'conscience-keeper,' then appears to mentally embrace this invisible 'pilgrim,' claiming it has already brought him solace and will transform his heart from a charnel house to a shrine.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And so may you,” I thought.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Now,” he continued, again addressing me, “I have received the pilgrim—a disguised deity, as I verily believe. Already it has done me good: my heart was a sort of charnel; it will now be a shrine.”

events.text_segment:
“And so may you,” I thought. My eye met his as the idea crossed my mind: he seemed to read the glance, answering as if its import had been spoken as well as imagined—
“Yes, yes, you are right,” said he; “I have plenty of faults of my own: I know it, and I don’t wish to palliate them, I assure you. God wot I need not be too severe about others; I have a past existence, a series of deeds, a colour of life to contemplate within my own breast, which might well call my sneers and censures from my neighbours to myself. I started, or rather (for like other defaulters, I like to lay half the blame on ill fortune and adverse circumstances) was thrust on to a wrong tack at the age of one-and-twenty, and have never recovered the right course since: but I might have been very different; I might have been as good as you—wiser—almost as stainless. I envy you your peace of mind, your clean conscience, your unpolluted memory. Little girl, a memory without blot or contamination must be an exquisite treasure—an inexhaustible source of pure refreshment: is it not?”
“How was your memory when you were eighteen, sir?”
“All right then; limpid, salubrious: no gush of bilge water had turned it to fetid puddle. I was your equal at eighteen—quite your equal. Nature meant me to be, on the whole, a good man, Miss Eyre; one of the better kind, and you see I am not so. You would say you don’t see it; at least I flatter myself I read as much in your eye (beware, by-the-bye, what you express with that organ; I am quick at interpreting its language). Then take my word for it,—I am not a villain: you are not to suppose that—not to attribute to me any such bad eminence; but, owing, I verily believe, rather to circumstances than to my natural bent, I am a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the poor petty dissipations with which the rich and worthless try to put on life. Do you wonder that I avow this to you? Know, that in the course of your future life you will often find yourself elected the involuntary confidant of your acquaintances’ secrets: people will instinctively find out, as I have done, that it is not your forte to tell of yourself, but to listen while others talk of themselves; they will feel, too, that you listen with no malevolent scorn of their indiscretion, but with a kind of innate sympathy; not the less comforting and encouraging because it is very unobtrusive in its manifestations.”
“How do you know?—how can you guess all this, sir?”
“I know it well; therefore I proceed almost as freely as if I were writing my thoughts in a diary. You would say, I should have been superior to circumstances; so I should—so I should; but you see I was not. When fate wronged me, I had not the wisdom to remain cool: I turned desperate; then I degenerated. Now, when any vicious simpleton excites my disgust by his paltry ribaldry, I cannot flatter myself that I am better than he: I am forced to confess that he and I are on a level. I wish I had stood firm—God knows I do! Dread remorse when you are tempted to err, Miss Eyre; remorse is the poison of life.”
“Repentance is said to be its cure, sir.”
“It is not its cure. Reformation may be its cure; and I could reform—I have strength yet for that—if—but where is the use of thinking of it, hampered, burdened, cursed as I am? Besides, since happiness is irrevocably denied me, I have a right to get pleasure out of life: and I will get it, cost what it may.”
“Then you will degenerate still more, sir.”
“Possibly: yet why should I, if I can get sweet, fresh pleasure? And I may get it as sweet and fresh as the wild honey the bee gathers on the moor.”
“It will sting—it will taste bitter, sir.”
“How do you know?—you never tried it. How very serious—how very solemn you look: and you are as ignorant of the matter as this cameo head” (taking one from the mantelpiece). “You have no right to preach to me, you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries.”
“I only remind you of your own words, sir: you said error brought remorse, and you pronounced remorse the poison of existence.”
“And who talks of error now? I scarcely think the notion that flittered across my brain was an error. I believe it was an inspiration rather than a temptation: it was very genial, very soothing—I know that. Here it comes again! It is no devil, I assure you; or if it be, it has put on the robes of an angel of light. I think I must admit so fair a guest when it asks entrance to my heart.”
“Distrust it, sir; it is not a true angel.”
“Once more, how do you know? By what instinct do you pretend to distinguish between a fallen seraph of the abyss and a messenger from the eternal throne—between a guide and a seducer?”
“I judged by your countenance, sir, which was troubled when you said the suggestion had returned upon you. I feel sure it will work you more misery if you listen to it.”
“Not at all—it bears the most gracious message in the world: for the rest, you are not my conscience-keeper, so don’t make yourself uneasy. Here, come in, bonny wanderer!”
He said this as if he spoke to a vision, viewless to any eye but his own; then, folding his arms, which he had half extended, on his chest, he seemed to enclose in their embrace the invisible being.
“Now,” he continued, again addressing me, “I have received the pilgrim—a disguised deity, as I verily believe. Already it has done me good: my heart was a sort of charnel; it will now be a shrine.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I thought to myself, "And the same applies to you." My eyes met his just as this idea occurred to me; he seemed to understand the look, responding as if I had spoken the thought aloud. "Yes, yes, you're right," he said. "I have plenty of faults of my own; I know it and don't want to excuse them, I assure you. Heaven knows I shouldn't be too harsh on others; I have a past life, a history of actions, a character to examine within myself that should make me direct my sneers and criticisms towards myself, not my neighbors. I started, or rather (because, like others who have messed up, I like to blame bad luck and circumstances partly) was forced onto a wrong path at twenty-one and haven't found the right one since. But I could have been very different; I could have been as good as you—wiser—almost as pure. I envy your peace of mind, your clear conscience, your untainted memory. Young woman, a memory without stain or corruption must be a precious treasure—an endless source of refreshing purity, wouldn't you agree?" "What was your memory like when you were eighteen, sir?" "Perfectly fine then; clear, healthy; no surge of foul water had turned it into a stinking mess. I was your equal at eighteen—quite your equal. Nature intended me to be, overall, a good man, Miss Eyre; one of the better kind, and you see I'm not. You might say you don't see it; at least, I think I see that in your eyes (be careful, by the way, what you express with that organ; I'm quick at reading its language). But take my word for it—I'm not a villain; don't think that—don't assign such a terrible status to me. But, I truly believe, more because of circumstances than my natural inclination, I am a common, ordinary sinner, completely familiar with all the trivial, insignificant pleasures that the rich and useless use to try and feel alive. Are you surprised I admit this to you? Know that throughout your future life, you will often find yourself unintentionally becoming the confidante of your acquaintances' secrets. People will sense instinctively, as I have, that your strength isn't in talking about yourself, but in listening to others talk about themselves. They will also feel that you listen without malicious contempt for their lack of discretion, but with a kind of natural sympathy; it's no less comforting and encouraging just because it's expressed so subtly." "How do you know?—how can you guess all this, sir?" "I know it well; therefore, I speak almost as freely as if I were writing my thoughts in a diary. You would say I should have been superior to circumstances; yes, I should have—I should have; but you see I wasn't. When fate wronged me, I lacked the wisdom to stay calm; I became desperate, and then I declined. Now, when some foolish, immoral person disgusts me with their cheap vulgarity, I can't convince myself that I am better than them; I'm forced to admit that they and I are on the same level. I wish I had stood firm—God knows I do! Dread remorse when you are tempted to make a mistake, Miss Eyre; remorse is the poison of life." "Repentance is said to be its cure, sir." "It is not its cure. Reformation might be its cure, and I could reform—I still have the strength for that—if—but what's the point of thinking about it, restricted, burdened, cursed as I am? Besides, since happiness is completely out of my reach, I have a right to get pleasure out of life; and I *will* get it, no matter the cost." "Then you will decline even further, sir." "Possibly; yet why should I, if I can find sweet, fresh pleasure? And I may find it as sweet and fresh as the wild honey the bee gathers on the moor." "It will sting—it will taste bitter, sir." "How do you know?—you've never tried it. How very serious—how very solemn you look; and you know as little about the matter as this cameo head" (picking one up from the mantelpiece). "You have no right to preach to me, you beginner, who haven't even entered life's door and know absolutely nothing of its secrets." "I am only reminding you of your own words, sir; you said error leads to remorse, and you called remorse the poison of existence." "And who is talking about error now? I hardly think the idea that just flickered through my mind was an error. I believe it was more an inspiration than a temptation; it was very pleasant, very calming—I know that. Here it comes again! It's no devil, I assure you; or if it is, it has taken the form of an angel of light. I think I must welcome such a beautiful guest when it asks to enter my heart." "Distrust it, sir; it is not a true angel." "Once again, how do you know? By what intuition do you claim to tell the difference between a fallen angel from the depths and a messenger from God—between a guide and a tempter?" "I judged by your face, sir, which looked troubled when you said the suggestion had returned. I feel sure it will cause you more unhappiness if you listen to it." "Not at all—it carries the most wonderful message in the world. As for the rest, you are not my keeper of conscience, so don't trouble yourself. Here, come in, lovely wanderer!" He said this as if speaking to a vision visible only to him; then, folding his arms, which he had partially extended, across his chest, he seemed to embrace the invisible being within them. "Now," he continued, turning back to me, "I have welcomed the pilgrim—a deity in disguise, I truly believe. It has already done me good; my heart was like a tomb; it will now be a sacred place."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"And so may you," I thought to myself. As our eyes met, he seemed to sense my thought and responded as if I’d spoken aloud—

"Yes, yes, you’re correct," he admitted. "I have many faults; I’m well aware and don’t try to excuse them. Truly, I have no right to judge others harshly, since my own life gives me plenty to reflect on critically. My past is full of actions and experiences that should turn my mockery inward rather than toward others. At twenty-one, whether through my own failings or misfortune, I went astray and never found my way back. But I could have been different, perhaps just as good as you—wiser, almost as blameless. I envy your calm, your clear conscience, your untainted memory. A memory without marks or stains must be a wonderful treasure—an endless source of comfort. Don’t you think so?"

"What was your memory like at eighteen, sir?" I asked.

"Spotless then—pure and healthy; nothing had yet corrupted it. I was just like you at that age. Nature intended me to be a good man, Miss Eyre—one of the better sort. But as you see, I haven’t become that. You might say you don’t see it, and I think I saw that in your eyes (be careful, by the way, as I’m good at reading expressions). Still, believe me—I’m not a villain, far from it. More from circumstances than from my nature, I became an ordinary sinner, indulging in the same trivial pastimes that the wealthy use to fill their empty lives. Does it surprise you that I admit this? You should know—as you go through life, many people will confide in you their secrets. Like me, they’ll sense that you listen deeply and kindly, not judging. You seem to find your strength not in talking about yourself but in being a compassionate listener, even if it’s a quiet and gentle sympathy."

"How can you know this, sir? How do you guess it?"

"I know it well, which is why I’m speaking as freely as if I were writing in a diary. You might think I should have risen above my circumstances, and perhaps I should have—but I didn’t. When fate treated me unfairly, I panicked and lost my way. Now, whenever I see someone behaving badly, I can’t pretend I’m any better. I wish I’d resisted—God, I do! Miss Eyre, beware of remorse. Remorse is life’s poison."

"Repentance is said to cure it, sir."

"Repentance is not the cure—reform might be. I could change; I still have the strength for it—if only… But what’s the use, weighed down as I am? Besides, since happiness is beyond my reach, I’m entitled to whatever joy I can find, whatever the cost."

"That may cause you to degrade yourself even more, sir."

"Perhaps. But why should it, if the pleasure is pure and sweet? Maybe I can find happiness as fresh as wild honey on the moors."

"It will hurt you—it will become bitter."

"How would you know? You’ve never experienced it. You look so serious and earnest, but you’re as naïve as this cameo" (he picked one up from the mantel). "You can’t preach to me, when you’ve hardly begun to live or to understand its complexities."

"I only remind you of your own words: you said mistakes bring remorse, and remorse is poison."

"And who’s talking about mistakes now? I don’t truly think the thought on my mind was a mistake—it felt more like inspiration, warm and soothing. It’s back again! It’s no demon, or if it is, it disguises itself as an angel. I think I have to let such a comforting guest into my heart."

"Distrust it, sir; it’s not a true angel."

"Again, how do you know? By what instinct do you claim to tell the difference between a fallen angel and a true messenger—a guide and a tempter?"

"I saw your troubled expression, sir, when you said the thought had come back. I’m sure that listening to it will only bring you more suffering."

"No, not at all—it brings the gentlest message. In any case, you’re not my conscience; don’t worry yourself. Welcome, then, my lovely invisible visitor!"

He said this to something only he could see, and folded his arms across his chest as if to embrace the unseen being.

Then he turned to me and said, "I’ve accepted this visitor—a god in disguise, I believe. Already I feel better; my heart, which was once like a tomb, feels now like a shrine."

events.title: Unsettling Resolutions, Adèle's Transformation, and a Cryptic Farewell
detailed_summary: Jane confesses her inability to follow Rochester's abstract discourse but reiterates her understanding of his regret for his imperfections and 'sullied memory.' She suggests that with consistent effort, he could achieve self-approval and build a new, positive store of recollections.
Rochester commends her sentiment but enigmatically remarks he is currently 'paving hell with energy,' laying down 'good intentions' he believes are as 'durable as flint.'

He proclaims his future associates and pursuits will be significantly improved, 'as pure ore is than foul dross,' and that he has just passed an unalterable internal law decreeing his new aims and motives as 'right.'
Jane questions the validity of actions requiring a 'new statute' to be legalized. Rochester insists that 'unheard-of combinations of circumstances demand unheard-of rules.'
When Jane calls this maxim dangerous and prone to abuse, Rochester swears by his 'household gods' not to misuse it, while acknowledging his human fallibility.
Jane argues that fallible humans should not claim the divine power of decreeing any 'strange, unsanctioned line of action' as right. Rochester confirms her words: 'Let it be right.'
Feeling the conversation has become too obscure and unsettling, Jane rises, intending to take Adèle to bed.
Rochester accuses her of being afraid of his 'Sphynx-like' talk. Jane denies fear but admits to bewilderment and a desire to avoid speaking foolishly.

He observes that her Lowood experiences still constrain her, making her fear being natural, but predicts she will learn to be so with him. He likens her inner spirit to a 'vivid, restless, resolute captive' bird that would soar if freed.

He detains her, explaining he has been observing Adèle, whom he calls a 'curious study,' and anticipates her imminent return in a new dress will be a 'shock' to his feelings, as she will resemble a 'miniature of Céline Varens.'
Adèle enters, transformed in a short, full-skirted rose-colored satin dress and floral wreath, dancing and asking if her attire is pleasing.
She performs a theatrical curtsy to Rochester, thanking him and asking if this is how her mother behaved.

Rochester affirms this with bitter precision, commenting that 'maman' similarly charmed his money. He refers to Adèle as a 'French floweret' he keeps, partly for expiation, disliking the 'blossom' when it so closely resembles its 'artificial' root, which thrived only on 'gold dust.'
He dismisses Jane with a promise to explain everything one day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “To speak truth, sir, I don’t understand you at all: I cannot keep up the conversation, because it has got out of my depth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I’ll explain all this some day. Good-night.”

events.text_segment:
“To speak truth, sir, I don’t understand you at all: I cannot keep up the conversation, because it has got out of my depth. Only one thing, I know: you said you were not as good as you should like to be, and that you regretted your own imperfection;—one thing I can comprehend: you intimated that to have a sullied memory was a perpetual bane. It seems to me, that if you tried hard, you would in time find it possible to become what you yourself would approve; and that if from this day you began with resolution to correct your thoughts and actions, you would in a few years have laid up a new and stainless store of recollections, to which you might revert with pleasure.”
“Justly thought; rightly said, Miss Eyre; and, at this moment, I am paving hell with energy.”
“Sir?”
“I am laying down good intentions, which I believe durable as flint. Certainly, my associates and pursuits shall be other than they have been.”
“And better?”
“And better—so much better as pure ore is than foul dross. You seem to doubt me; I don’t doubt myself: I know what my aim is, what my motives are; and at this moment I pass a law, unalterable as that of the Medes and Persians, that both are right.”
“They cannot be, sir, if they require a new statute to legalise them.”
“They are, Miss Eyre, though they absolutely require a new statute: unheard-of combinations of circumstances demand unheard-of rules.”
“That sounds a dangerous maxim, sir; because one can see at once that it is liable to abuse.”
“Sententious sage! so it is: but I swear by my household gods not to abuse it.”
“You are human and fallible.”
“I am: so are you—what then?”
“The human and fallible should not arrogate a power with which the divine and perfect alone can be safely intrusted.”
“What power?”
“That of saying of any strange, unsanctioned line of action,—‘Let it be right.’”
“‘Let it be right’—the very words: you have pronounced them.”
“May it be right then,” I said, as I rose, deeming it useless to continue a discourse which was all darkness to me; and, besides, sensible that the character of my interlocutor was beyond my penetration; at least, beyond its present reach; and feeling the uncertainty, the vague sense of insecurity, which accompanies a conviction of ignorance.
“Where are you going?”
“To put Adèle to bed: it is past her bedtime.”
“You are afraid of me, because I talk like a Sphynx.”
“Your language is enigmatical, sir: but though I am bewildered, I am certainly not afraid.”
“You are afraid—your self-love dreads a blunder.”
“In that sense I do feel apprehensive—I have no wish to talk nonsense.”
“If you did, it would be in such a grave, quiet manner, I should mistake it for sense. Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre? Don’t trouble yourself to answer—I see you laugh rarely; but you can laugh very merrily: believe me, you are not naturally austere, any more than I am naturally vicious. The Lowood constraint still clings to you somewhat; controlling your features, muffling your voice, and restricting your limbs; and you fear in the presence of a man and a brother—or father, or master, or what you will—to smile too gaily, speak too freely, or move too quickly: but, in time, I think you will learn to be natural with me, as I find it impossible to be conventional with you; and then your looks and movements will have more vivacity and variety than they dare offer now. I see at intervals the glance of a curious sort of bird through the close-set bars of a cage: a vivid, restless, resolute captive is there; were it but free, it would soar cloud-high. You are still bent on going?”
“It has struck nine, sir.”
“Never mind,—wait a minute: Adèle is not ready to go to bed yet. My position, Miss Eyre, with my back to the fire, and my face to the room, favours observation. While talking to you, I have also occasionally watched Adèle (I have my own reasons for thinking her a curious study,—reasons that I may, nay, that I shall, impart to you some day). She pulled out of her box, about ten minutes ago, a little pink silk frock; rapture lit her face as she unfolded it; coquetry runs in her blood, blends with her brains, and seasons the marrow of her bones. ‘Il faut que je l’essaie!’ cried she, ‘et à l’instant même!’ and she rushed out of the room. She is now with Sophie, undergoing a robing process: in a few minutes she will re-enter; and I know what I shall see,—a miniature of Céline Varens, as she used to appear on the boards at the rising of—But never mind that. However, my tenderest feelings are about to receive a shock: such is my presentiment; stay now, to see whether it will be realised.”
Ere long, Adèle’s little foot was heard tripping across the hall. She entered, transformed as her guardian had predicted. A dress of rose-coloured satin, very short, and as full in the skirt as it could be gathered, replaced the brown frock she had previously worn; a wreath of rosebuds circled her forehead; her feet were dressed in silk stockings and small white satin sandals.
“Est-ce que ma robe va bien?” cried she, bounding forwards; “et mes souliers? et mes bas? Tenez, je crois que je vais danser!”
And spreading out her dress, she chasséed across the room till, having reached Mr. Rochester, she wheeled lightly round before him on tip-toe, then dropped on one knee at his feet, exclaiming—
“Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonté;” then rising, she added, “C’est comme cela que maman faisait, n’est-ce pas, monsieur?”
“Pre-cise-ly!” was the answer; “and, ‘comme cela,’ she charmed my English gold out of my British breeches’ pocket. I have been green, too, Miss Eyre,—ay, grass green: not a more vernal tint freshens you now than once freshened me. My Spring is gone, however, but it has left me that French floweret on my hands, which, in some moods, I would fain be rid of. Not valuing now the root whence it sprang; having found that it was of a sort which nothing but gold dust could manure, I have but half a liking to the blossom, especially when it looks so artificial as just now. I keep it and rear it rather on the Roman Catholic principle of expiating numerous sins, great or small, by one good work. I’ll explain all this some day. Good-night.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Honestly, sir," I replied, "I don't understand you at all; I can't keep up with the conversation because it's beyond my understanding. I only grasp two things: you admitted you weren't as good as you wished and regretted your flaws, and you implied that a tainted past is a constant burden. It seems to me that with significant effort, you could eventually become someone you approve of. By resolving to change your thoughts and actions starting today, within a few years, you could build up a new, pure set of memories you could look back on with pleasure." "Well thought, rightly said, Miss Eyre," he responded, "and right now, I'm energetically making good intentions, though I might as well be paving the way to hell with them. I'm setting down resolutions I believe are as strong as rock. My companions and activities will certainly be different from now on." "And better?" I asked. "And better – as much better as pure metal is than worthless waste. You seem to doubt me, but I don't doubt myself. I know my goal and my reasons, and at this moment, I declare them both right, like a law as unbreakable as those of ancient empires." "They can't be right, sir," I countered, "if they need a new rule to make them lawful." "They are right, Miss Eyre, even if they absolutely require a new rule," he insisted. "Extraordinary circumstances demand extraordinary regulations." "That sounds like a dangerous principle, sir," I observed, "because it's clear it could easily be misused." "Wise words indeed!" he exclaimed. "And it is. But I swear by all I hold dear that I won't misuse it." "You are human and capable of error." "I am, and so are you. What does that matter?" "Those who are human and fallible shouldn't claim a power that can only be safely given to the divine and perfect." "What power?" he asked. "The power to declare any unusual, unapproved course of action as 'right'." "'Let it be right' – those are the exact words," he said. "You've spoken them." "Then I hope it *may* be right," I said as I stood up, feeling it was pointless to continue a discussion that was completely unclear to me. Also, I was aware that I couldn't fully understand his character, at least not yet, and I felt the uncertainty and vague sense of insecurity that comes with realizing your own ignorance. "Where are you going?" he asked. "To put Adèle to bed; it's past her bedtime." "You're afraid of me because I talk like a Sphinx." "Your language is puzzling, sir," I admitted, "but though I'm confused, I'm certainly not afraid." "You *are* afraid – your pride fears making a mistake." "In that sense, I do feel cautious – I have no desire to speak nonsense." "If you did, you'd do it in such a serious, quiet way, I'd mistake it for wisdom. Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre? Don't bother to answer – I see you laugh rarely, but you are capable of laughing very joyfully. Believe me, you are no more naturally severe than I am naturally wicked. The restrictions from Lowood still cling to you somewhat, controlling your expressions, muffling your voice, and limiting your movements. You fear, in the presence of a man, a fellow being – or a father, or a master, or whatever you see me as – to smile too cheerfully, speak too freely, or move too quickly. But, I think eventually you will learn to be natural with me, as I find it impossible to be formal with you. Then your looks and movements will show more liveliness and variety than they dare show now. I occasionally glimpse a curious bird through the closely spaced bars of a cage: a vibrant, restless, determined captive is there; if only it were free, it would soar to the clouds. Are you still set on leaving?" "It has struck nine, sir," I replied. "Never mind – wait a minute; Adèle isn't ready for bed yet. My position here, Miss Eyre, with my back to the fire and facing the room, allows me to observe. While talking to you, I've also been occasionally watching Adèle (I have my own reasons for finding her an interesting subject – reasons I may, indeed, shall, tell you someday). About ten minutes ago, she took a little pink silk dress out of her box; joy lit up her face as she unfolded it. Coquetry is in her nature, mixed with her thoughts, and runs through her very being. 'I must try it on!' she exclaimed in French, 'and immediately!' And she rushed out of the room. She's now with Sophie, getting dressed. She'll be back in a few minutes, and I know what I'll see – a miniature of Céline Varens, just as she used to look on stage when the curtain rose – But never mind that. However, my deepest feelings are about to be tested; that's my premonition. Stay now to see if it comes true." Soon after, Adèle's small footsteps were heard tripping across the hall. She entered, transformed just as her guardian had predicted. Instead of the brown dress she wore before, she had on a rose-coloured satin dress, very short and as full as possible in the skirt. A circlet of rosebuds adorned her forehead, and her feet were clad in silk stockings and tiny white satin sandals. "Does my dress fit well?" she cried in French, bounding forward; "and my shoes? and my stockings? Look, I think I'm going to dance!" And spreading out her dress, she glided across the room until she reached Mr. Rochester. She twirled lightly on her toes in front of him, then dropped to one knee at his feet, exclaiming, "Sir, I thank you a thousand times for your kindness." Then, rising, she added, "That's how Mama used to do it, wasn't it, sir?" "Precisely!" he answered. "And 'that's how' she charmed my English money out of my British pockets. I've been foolish too, Miss Eyre – yes, completely naive. No fresher youthful colour brightens you now than once brightened me. My youthful period is gone, however, but it has left me with that French girl to care for, and sometimes I wish I could be rid of her. Not valuing the source she came from now, having discovered she was only interested in money, I only half care for the child, especially when she looks as artificial as she does now. I keep and raise her more out of a sense of duty, like a Catholic performing a good work to atone for many sins, big or small. I'll explain all this someday. Good-night."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
To be honest, sir, I don’t really follow what you’re saying. I can’t keep up with this conversation as it’s beyond my understanding. The one thing I do get is that you said you’re not the person you want to be, that you’re disappointed in your own flaws; and I understand that you mentioned having a tainted memory is a constant burden. I think that if you really tried, you could eventually become someone you respect; and if you set your mind today to change your thoughts and actions, in a few years you’d have a collection of good memories to look back on happily.”

“Well spoken, Miss Eyre, and right now, I’m making strong efforts, as if paving a road to hell.”

“Sir?”

“I’m laying out good intentions, strong as stone. My friends and interests will certainly be different going forward.”

“And better ones?”

“Much better—like pure metal compared to impure waste. You doubt me, but I don’t doubt myself: I know what I want and why. I now make an unchangeable rule, as firm as ancient law, that both my aims and motives are good.”

“They can’t be if it takes a new law to make them acceptable.”

“They are, Miss Eyre, even if they do need a new law: unusual situations call for unusual rules.”

“That sounds like a dangerous principle, sir; it seems easy to misuse.”

“Wise words! That’s true, but I vow not to abuse it.”

“You’re only human and can make mistakes.”

“I am, and so are you—what then?”

“People who are human and make mistakes shouldn’t claim powers only divine and perfect beings should have.”

“What power is that?”

“The power to declare any odd, unapproved action to be right.”

“‘Let it be right’—those are exactly your words.”

“So be it, I said, as I got up, thinking it was pointless to keep talking since I couldn’t understand him, and realizing his character was beyond what I could grasp, leaving me with a vague sense of uncertainty that comes from not knowing.”

“Where are you going?”

“To put Adèle to bed; it’s past her bedtime.”

“You’re scared of me because I speak in riddles.”

“Your words are puzzling, sir: but though I’m confused, I’m not afraid.”

“You are afraid—your pride fears making a mistake.”

“In that way, yes—I don’t want to say anything foolish.”

“If you did, you’d do it so seriously I might think it made sense. Do you ever laugh, Miss Eyre? Don’t answer—I can see you laugh rarely, but you can laugh happily: you’re not naturally strict, any more than I’m naturally bad. The discipline from Lowood still holds you back; controlling your expressions, quieting your voice, restricting how you move. You hesitate to smile, speak openly, or move quickly around a man or authority. Over time, I think you’ll act yourself with me, as I can’t be formal with you; then your looks and movements will be more lively and expressive than now. Occasionally, I catch a glimpse of a lively bird behind the bars of a cage: there’s an energetic, determined captive in you; if it were free, it would fly high. You still want to leave?”

“It’s nine o’clock, sir.”

“No matter—wait a bit: Adèle isn’t ready for bed yet. Standing here by the fire, facing the room, I notice things as we talk. I’ve also been watching Adèle (I have my reasons for finding her interesting, which I’ll explain to you one day). About ten minutes ago, she took out a pink silk dress; she looked delighted as she unfolded it; showing off seems natural to her. ‘I must try it on this instant!’ she cried and ran from the room. She’s with Sophie now, getting dressed: soon she’ll come back; and I know what I’ll see—a little version of Céline Varens as she used to look when the curtains rose—never mind that. Still, I feel my emotions are about to be put to the test. Stay and see if I’m right.”

Soon, Adèle’s light footsteps were heard in the hall. She entered, changed just as Mr. Rochester anticipated. Where there had been a brown dress, there was now a short, full rose-colored satin one; she wore a crown of rosebuds, silk stockings, and small white satin shoes.

“Does my dress look nice?” she cried, dancing forward; “And my shoes? And my stockings? Watch, I think I’ll dance!”

She spread her dress, skipped across the room to Mr. Rochester, spun on tiptoe, then knelt at his feet, saying—

“Sir, thank you a thousand times for your kindness”; then, getting up, she added, “This is what Mama used to do, isn’t it, sir?”

“Exactly!” he replied. “And just like that she charmed money out of my pocket. I too have been naïve, Miss Eyre—very naïve: as fresh as the spring that once freshened me, but is now gone. All I have left is this French child, which sometimes I wish I could be rid of. Since I now know her origins needed only money to flourish, I care little for them, and don’t like the child much when she seems so artificial as now. I raise her now more as a sort of penance for my sins. I’ll explain this all to you another time. Good night.”

events.title: Rochester Begins Recounting His Affair with Céline Varens
detailed_summary: During an afternoon walk in the grounds, while Adèle plays nearby, Mr. Rochester decides to explain Adèle's origins to Jane Eyre.
He reveals that Adèle is the daughter of Céline Varens, a French opera-dancer with whom he once shared what he termed a "grande passion."
Rochester recounts how Céline professed an even greater passion for him, leading him to believe he was her idol despite his own perception of his ugliness.
He admits to being greatly flattered by this supposed preference from the "Gallic sylph" for her "British gnome."
As a result, he established Céline in an hotel, providing her with servants, a carriage, and expensive gifts, thus starting on a path to ruin himself in a conventional way.
He describes an evening when he called on Céline unexpectedly.
Finding her absent, he waited in her boudoir, initially noting the perfumed air, which he then dismisses as more a scent of musk and amber than anything sacred.
Feeling overwhelmed by the fragrances, he decided to open a window and step out onto the balcony.
He describes the serene, moonlit, and gaslit night and, after sitting down, pauses his narrative to light a cigar in the present moment with Jane.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Rochester did, on a future occasion, explain it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I will take one now, if you will excuse me.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Rochester did, on a future occasion, explain it. It was one afternoon, when he chanced to meet me and Adèle in the grounds: and while she played with Pilot and her shuttlecock, he asked me to walk up and down a long beech avenue within sight of her.
He then said that she was the daughter of a French opera-dancer, Céline Varens, towards whom he had once cherished what he called a “grande passion.” This passion Céline had professed to return with even superior ardour. He thought himself her idol, ugly as he was: he believed, as he said, that she preferred his “taille d’athlète” to the elegance of the Apollo Belvidere.
“And, Miss Eyre, so much was I flattered by this preference of the Gallic sylph for her British gnome, that I installed her in an hotel; gave her a complete establishment of servants, a carriage, cashmeres, diamonds, dentelles, &c. In short, I began the process of ruining myself in the received style, like any other spoony. I had not, it seems, the originality to chalk out a new road to shame and destruction, but trode the old track with stupid exactness not to deviate an inch from the beaten centre. I had—as I deserved to have—the fate of all other spoonies. Happening to call one evening when Céline did not expect me, I found her out; but it was a warm night, and I was tired with strolling through Paris, so I sat down in her boudoir; happy to breathe the air consecrated so lately by her presence. No,—I exaggerate; I never thought there was any consecrating virtue about her: it was rather a sort of pastille perfume she had left; a scent of musk and amber, than an odour of sanctity. I was just beginning to stifle with the fumes of conservatory flowers and sprinkled essences, when I bethought myself to open the window and step out on to the balcony. It was moonlight and gaslight besides, and very still and serene. The balcony was furnished with a chair or two; I sat down, and took out a cigar,—I will take one now, if you will excuse me.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. Rochester recounted this story on a later occasion. It occurred one afternoon when he encountered me and Adèle outdoors. While Adèle played with her dog Pilot and her shuttlecock nearby, he suggested we walk along a long avenue lined with beech trees, staying within her view. He then disclosed that Adèle's mother was a French opera performer named Céline Varens, for whom he had previously held what he termed a "grande passion," or intense attraction. Céline, he added, had claimed to feel an even stronger passion for him in return. Despite his plain appearance, he believed he was her idol, saying he thought she preferred his 'athletic build' to the classical beauty of the Apollo Belvidere statue. "And, Miss Eyre," he continued, "I was so flattered by this preference shown by the French 'sylph' for her English 'gnome' that I rented a hotel suite for her, provided a full household staff, a carriage, expensive items like cashmeres, diamonds, and lace, among other things. In essence, I started the typical process of financially ruining myself, just like any other naive fool. It seems I lacked the creativity to invent a new path to embarrassment and destruction, but instead followed the old one with foolish precision, not deviating from the usual course. As I deserved, I met the same fate as other 'spoonies.' By chance, I visited one evening when Céline wasn't expecting me and found she was out. However, it was a warm night, and I was weary from walking around Paris, so I decided to wait in her boudoir. I was initially pleased to breathe the air recently touched by her presence. No, I'm exaggerating; I never believed there was anything sacred about her. It was more like the smell of her strong perfume, a mix of musk and amber, that filled the air, not an aura of holiness. I was just starting to feel suffocated by the heavy scent of hothouse flowers and sprayed fragrances when I thought to open the window and step onto the balcony. It was lit by both moonlight and gaslight and was very still and peaceful. The balcony had a couple of chairs; I sat down and took out a cigar—I'll have one now, if you don't mind."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: At a later time, Mr. Rochester clarified the situation. One afternoon, he happened upon me and Adèle in the gardens; while Adèle played nearby, he invited me to walk with him along a long beech-lined path where she could still be seen. He then revealed that Adèle was the daughter of a French opera dancer named Céline Varens, with whom he had once been deeply infatuated. Céline claimed to care for him with even greater passion than he felt for her. Despite considering himself unattractive, he believed she preferred his sturdy, athletic build over more traditional beauty. Mr. Rochester confessed to being so pleased by Céline’s preference for him, an awkward Englishman, that he set her up in a hotel with a household of servants, a carriage, expensive clothing, and jewelry. Essentially, he began to squander his wealth in a common, foolish manner, taking the same path to ruin as many others before him. Predictably, he was rewarded with the fate he deserved. One night, when Céline was not expecting him, he stopped by her place but found her out. Feeling tired after wandering Paris, he waited in her luxurious sitting room, not because of any holiness about her but rather a lingering perfumed scent. Finding the room stuffy with fragrant flowers and perfumes, he decided to open a window and step onto the balcony. It was a calm night, lit by both moon and gaslight, so he sat outside, took a seat, and began to smoke a cigar—just as he said he would in that moment, asking permission to do so.

events.title: The Discovery of Céline's Betrayal
detailed_summary: After lighting his cigar, Mr. Rochester continues his story to Jane.
He reminisces about enjoying chocolates and smoking on Céline's balcony, observing carriages heading towards the nearby opera-house.
He then saw an elegant carriage, one he had gifted to Céline, arrive at the hotel.
His heart pounded with anticipation as the carriage stopped and Céline alighted.
He instantly recognized her by her small foot, visible as she stepped from the carriage, despite her being cloaked on a warm evening.

Just as he was about to murmur a term of endearment to her from the balcony, another cloaked figure, a man identified by his spurred heel and hatted head, jumped out of the carriage after Céline and followed her into the hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here ensued a pause, filled up by the producing and lighting of a cigar; having placed it to his lips and breathed a trail of Havannah incense on the freezing and sunless air, he went on—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: that was a hatted head which now passed under the arched porte cochère of the hotel.

events.text_segment:
Here ensued a pause, filled up by the producing and lighting of a cigar; having placed it to his lips and breathed a trail of Havannah incense on the freezing and sunless air, he went on—
“I liked bonbons too in those days, Miss Eyre, and I was croquant—(overlook the barbarism)—croquant chocolate comfits, and smoking alternately, watching meantime the equipages that rolled along the fashionable streets towards the neighbouring opera-house, when in an elegant close carriage drawn by a beautiful pair of English horses, and distinctly seen in the brilliant city-night, I recognised the ‘voiture’ I had given Céline. She was returning: of course my heart thumped with impatience against the iron rails I leant upon. The carriage stopped, as I had expected, at the hotel door; my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) alighted: though muffed in a cloak—an unnecessary encumbrance, by-the-bye, on so warm a June evening—I knew her instantly by her little foot, seen peeping from the skirt of her dress, as she skipped from the carriage-step. Bending over the balcony, I was about to murmur ‘Mon ange’—in a tone, of course, which should be audible to the ear of love alone—when a figure jumped from the carriage after her; cloaked also; but that was a spurred heel which had rung on the pavement, and that was a hatted head which now passed under the arched porte cochère of the hotel.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A pause followed, during which he took out and lit a cigar. After putting it to his mouth and exhaling the fragrant smoke into the cold, dark air, he continued speaking. "Back then, Miss Eyre," he said, "I also enjoyed sweets. I was crunching on chocolate drops (forgive the foreign word) and smoking interchangeably, while observing the carriages traveling down the stylish streets towards the nearby opera house. It was then, in a fancy enclosed carriage pulled by two fine English horses, clearly visible in the bright city lights at night, that I spotted the vehicle I had given to Céline. She was coming back. Naturally, my heart pounded impatiently against the iron railing I was leaning on. Just as I expected, the carriage halted at the hotel entrance. My 'flame' (which is the perfect term for a lover met at the opera) stepped out. Although she was wrapped in a cloak – quite unnecessary, incidentally, on such a warm June night – I recognised her immediately by her small foot, visible beneath her dress hem as she gracefully dismounted. Leaning over the balcony, I prepared to whisper 'My angel' – in a voice, naturally, intended only for a lover's ears – when another person quickly exited the carriage right after her. This person was also cloaked, but a spurred boot clicked on the ground, and a head wearing a hat then went under the hotel's arched entrance."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: There was a pause while he took out a cigar, lit it, and after releasing a curl of smoke into the cold, gloomy air, he continued speaking. "Back then, Miss Eyre, I was fond of sweets and often ate chocolate candies between puffs of smoke, watching the carriages passing by on their way to the opera. Among them, I spotted the carriage I'd gifted to Céline, shining in the city lights, pulled by a fine pair of English horses. My heart beat quickly as it stopped at the hotel entrance, just as I’d guessed. Céline, my beloved, got out—although she was wrapped in a cloak, which seemed excessive for such a warm June night, I recognized her immediately by the glimpse of her small foot as she exited. As I leaned over the balcony about to softly call her ‘Mon ange’—for her ears only—a second figure, also cloaked, leapt out after her. I noticed the sound of a spur on the pavement and saw a hat disappear under the hotel’s arched doorway."

events.title: Rochester Reflects on Jane's Inexperience and Life's Tumults
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester directly questions Jane about her experiences with jealousy and love, concluding she has felt neither.
He suggests her soul is still dormant and that a significant emotional shock is yet to awaken it.
He contrasts her current, seemingly tranquil life with the inevitable future turmoils he foresees for her.
He warns Jane that she will eventually encounter a perilous and chaotic phase in her life.
He predicts that she will either be destroyed by these challenges or be guided by a powerful force into a calmer state, similar to his own present condition.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You never felt jealousy, did you, Miss Eyre?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: as I am now.

events.text_segment: “You never felt jealousy, did you, Miss Eyre? Of course not: I need not ask you; because you never felt love. You have both sentiments yet to experience: your soul sleeps; the shock is yet to be given which shall waken it. You think all existence lapses in as quiet a flow as that in which your youth has hitherto slid away. Floating on with closed eyes and muffled ears, you neither see the rocks bristling not far off in the bed of the flood, nor hear the breakers boil at their base. But I tell you—and you may mark my words—you will come some day to a craggy pass in the channel, where the whole of life’s stream will be broken up into whirl and tumult, foam and noise: either you will be dashed to atoms on crag points, or lifted up and borne on by some master-wave into a calmer current—as I am now.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The speaker asks if Miss Eyre has ever felt jealousy, immediately deciding she couldn't have since she has never experienced love. He claims her emotions are dormant, like a sleeping soul, awaiting a significant event to awaken them. He suggests she believes life will continue as smoothly as her youth has, floating along obliviously to potential dangers (like hidden rocks or crashing waves). However, he warns her that she will eventually reach a difficult, chaotic point where life's course is violently disrupted, full of turmoil and noise. At this point, she will either be utterly destroyed by the challenges or be carried by a powerful influence into a more peaceful state, just as he feels he has been.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: You've never known jealousy, have you, Miss Eyre? Of course not—I don't even need to ask—because you've never known love. Those are both feelings you have yet to discover; your spirit is still dormant, waiting for the impact that will awaken it. Right now, you imagine that life will always move smoothly and quietly for you, just as it has so far. With your eyes closed and your ears covered, you're unaware of the dangers lying just ahead, or the crashing waves that threaten below. But I'm telling you now—remember what I say—one day you'll find yourself at a difficult and dangerous point, where life will suddenly become chaotic and turbulent. Then, you'll either be shattered by the hardship or carried forward by a powerful force into a calmer, more peaceful state, just as I have been.

events.title: Rochester's Anguished Outburst Regarding Thornfield and His New Resolve
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester expresses a sudden appreciation for the current day's atmosphere and the stern beauty of Thornfield.
He acknowledges its antiquity and seclusion, yet immediately contrasts this with his long-held and ongoing abhorrence for the place, comparing it to a plague-house.
His internal conflict becomes physically manifest as he grinds his teeth, stops walking abruptly, and strikes his boot against the ground, gripped by a hateful thought.
Jane observes a maelstrom of negative emotions—pain, shame, ire, impatience, disgust, detestation—fighting for dominance in his expression.
This turmoil resolves into a hard, cynical, and resolute look, petrifying his features.
He explains to Jane that he was metaphorically confronting his destiny, personified as a hag from Macbeth, who dared him to find happiness at Thornfield.
He defiantly declares his intention to like Thornfield and his resolve to break through any obstacles to achieve happiness and goodness.
He vows to become a better man, viewing hindrances that others might see as insurmountable as mere trifles.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I like this day; I like that sky of steel; I like the sternness and stillness of the world under this frost.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I will esteem but straw and rotten wood.”

events.text_segment:
“I like this day; I like that sky of steel; I like the sternness and stillness of the world under this frost. I like Thornfield, its antiquity, its retirement, its old crow-trees and thorn-trees, its grey façade, and lines of dark windows reflecting that metal welkin: and yet how long have I abhorred the very thought of it, shunned it like a great plague-house? How I do still abhor—”
He ground his teeth and was silent: he arrested his step and struck his boot against the hard ground. Some hated thought seemed to have him in its grip, and to hold him so tightly that he could not advance.
We were ascending the avenue when he thus paused; the hall was before us. Lifting his eye to its battlements, he cast over them a glare such as I never saw before or since. Pain, shame, ire, impatience, disgust, detestation, seemed momentarily to hold a quivering conflict in the large pupil dilating under his ebon eyebrow. Wild was the wrestle which should be paramount; but another feeling rose and triumphed: something hard and cynical: self-willed and resolute: it settled his passion and petrified his countenance: he went on—
“During the moment I was silent, Miss Eyre, I was arranging a point with my destiny. She stood there, by that beech-trunk—a hag like one of those who appeared to Macbeth on the heath of Forres. ‘You like Thornfield?’ she said, lifting her finger; and then she wrote in the air a memento, which ran in lurid hieroglyphics all along the house-front, between the upper and lower row of windows, ‘Like it if you can! Like it if you dare!’
“‘I will like it,’ said I; ‘I dare like it;’ and” (he subjoined moodily) “I will keep my word; I will break obstacles to happiness, to goodness—yes, goodness. I wish to be a better man than I have been, than I am; as Job’s leviathan broke the spear, the dart, and the habergeon, hindrances which others count as iron and brass, I will esteem but straw and rotten wood.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: He expressed his pleasure with the frosty day, the metallic sky, and the world's harsh, still atmosphere under the frost. He added that he liked Thornfield Manor itself, appreciating its age, secluded location, old trees, grey stone front, and dark windows reflecting the sky. Yet, he mused on how long he had previously detested the very idea of the place, avoiding it as if it were diseased. He started to say how he still felt the hatred, but stopped abruptly, grinding his teeth and kicking the ground. It seemed a painful, hated thought had seized him, preventing him from moving forward. We were walking up the drive towards the house when he stopped. Looking up at the house's battlements, he stared with an intensity I had never witnessed. His large pupil, beneath his dark eyebrow, seemed to contain a struggle of emotions like pain, shame, anger, frustration, revulsion, and hatred. These feelings fiercely competed for dominance. But a different, tougher, cynical, and determined feeling emerged and won out. It quelled his intense emotion and hardened his expression. He then continued speaking, explaining that during his pause, he was confronting his destiny, personified as a witch resembling those from Macbeth, standing by a beech tree. He described her asking if he liked Thornfield and then writing a challenging message across the house's facade: 'Like it if you can! Like it if you dare!' He responded that he would and dared to like it. Then, he added moodily, he would keep his promise and overcome obstacles to his happiness and, importantly, his goodness. He stated his desire to improve himself, to be a better person than he had been or currently was. He concluded by using the analogy of Job's leviathan, which could break weapons of iron and brass, saying he would treat hindrances that others found formidable as mere straw and rotten wood.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I enjoy days like this, with the cold, metallic sky, and the crisp, silent stillness that the frost brings. I’m fond of Thornfield—its age, its seclusion, the ancient crow and thorn trees, its grey frontage, and the row of dark windows reflecting that hard sky. Yet, for so long, just thinking of Thornfield has repulsed me; I’ve avoided it as though it were cursed. Even now, I can’t help but loathe it—" He stopped abruptly, clenched his teeth, and kicked at the frozen earth, seemingly overtaken by an unpleasant thought that held him frozen in place as we walked up the drive with the hall in front of us. He looked up at Thornfield’s battlements with a fierce look in his eyes, one I’d never seen before—pain, shame, anger, impatience, disgust, and hatred all flickered in his gaze, battling for dominance. Eventually, a tougher, more determined expression took over, hardening his features before he spoke again: "In those moments of silence, Miss Eyre, I was bargaining with my fate. She appeared to me by that beech tree, like one of Macbeth’s witches, and said, ‘You like Thornfield?’ Then she traced a cryptic warning in the air across the front of the house, ‘Like it if you can! Like it if you dare!’ ‘I will like it,’ I insisted, ‘I dare.’ And so—I’ll keep my promise. I’ll overcome every barrier to find happiness and goodness—yes, to be better than I have been or am now. Just as Job’s leviathan broke through weapons others thought impenetrable, I’ll treat obstacles as if they’re nothing more than straw and rotting wood.”

events.title: Rochester Concludes Céline's Story and Explains Adèle's Arrival at Thornfield
detailed_summary: Adèle interrupts Mr. Rochester's intense monologue by running before him with her shuttlecock, prompting a harsh dismissal from him.
After Rochester falls silent, Jane gently prompts him to resume his story about Céline Varens.
Rochester, recovering from his abstraction, acknowledges Jane's role as his confidante, praising her discretion and unique mind, which he believes is impervious to corruption.
He recounts remaining on the balcony, drawing a curtain to create a hidden vantage point to observe Céline and her companion.
He describes seeing Céline and her lover, a young, brainless vicomte whom Rochester despised, enter her boudoir.
The recognition of such a rival instantly extinguished Rochester's love and jealousy, replacing them with scorn for Céline's choice.
He found their subsequent conversation frivolous, mercenary, and heartless, more wearying than enraging.
During their talk, Céline and the vicomte insulted Rochester, with Céline particularly mocking his physical appearance—a stark contrast to her previous feigned admiration for his 'masculine beauty'.
Adèle interrupts again with a message that Rochester's agent has called.

Pressed for time, Rochester quickly summarizes the end of the affair: he confronted Céline and her lover, dismissed Céline with some money for her immediate needs, and scheduled a duel with the vicomte.
The following morning, he met and shot the vicomte in the arm.
He then reveals that six months before the breakup, Céline had presented Adèle to him, claiming the child was his daughter, a claim he doubts due to lack of resemblance.
Years later, after Céline abandoned Adèle to elope with a musician, Rochester, though disbelieving his paternity, took the destitute child from Paris to be raised at Thornfield.
He concludes by asking Jane if this knowledge of Adèle's illegitimate origins will make her want to leave her position as governess.
