events.text_segment:
Adèle here ran before him with her shuttlecock. “Away!” he cried harshly; “keep at a distance, child; or go in to Sophie!” Continuing then to pursue his walk in silence, I ventured to recall him to the point whence he had abruptly diverged—
“Did you leave the balcony, sir,” I asked, “when Mdlle. Varens entered?”
I almost expected a rebuff for this hardly well-timed question, but, on the contrary, waking out of his scowling abstraction, he turned his eyes towards me, and the shade seemed to clear off his brow. “Oh, I had forgotten Céline! Well, to resume. When I saw my charmer thus come in accompanied by a cavalier, I seemed to hear a hiss, and the green snake of jealousy, rising on undulating coils from the moonlit balcony, glided within my waistcoat, and ate its way in two minutes to my heart’s core. Strange!” he exclaimed, suddenly starting again from the point. “Strange that I should choose you for the confidant of all this, young lady; passing strange that you should listen to me quietly, as if it were the most usual thing in the world for a man like me to tell stories of his opera-mistresses to a quaint, inexperienced girl like you! But the last singularity explains the first, as I intimated once before: you, with your gravity, considerateness, and caution were made to be the recipient of secrets. Besides, I know what sort of a mind I have placed in communication with my own: I know it is one not liable to take infection: it is a peculiar mind: it is a unique one. Happily I do not mean to harm it: but, if I did, it would not take harm from me. The more you and I converse, the better; for while I cannot blight you, you may refresh me.” After this digression he proceeded—
“I remained in the balcony. ‘They will come to her boudoir, no doubt,’ thought I: ‘let me prepare an ambush.’ So putting my hand in through the open window, I drew the curtain over it, leaving only an opening through which I could take observations; then I closed the casement, all but a chink just wide enough to furnish an outlet to lovers’ whispered vows: then I stole back to my chair; and as I resumed it the pair came in. My eye was quickly at the aperture. Céline’s chamber-maid entered, lit a lamp, left it on the table, and withdrew. The couple were thus revealed to me clearly: both removed their cloaks, and there was ‘the Varens,’ shining in satin and jewels,—my gifts of course,—and there was her companion in an officer’s uniform; and I knew him for a young roué of a vicomte—a brainless and vicious youth whom I had sometimes met in society, and had never thought of hating because I despised him so absolutely. On recognising him, the fang of the snake Jealousy was instantly broken; because at the same moment my love for Céline sank under an extinguisher. A woman who could betray me for such a rival was not worth contending for; she deserved only scorn; less, however, than I, who had been her dupe.
“They began to talk; their conversation eased me completely: frivolous, mercenary, heartless, and senseless, it was rather calculated to weary than enrage a listener. A card of mine lay on the table; this being perceived, brought my name under discussion. Neither of them possessed energy or wit to belabour me soundly, but they insulted me as coarsely as they could in their little way: especially Céline, who even waxed rather brilliant on my personal defects—deformities she termed them. Now it had been her custom to launch out into fervent admiration of what she called my ‘beauté mâle:’ wherein she differed diametrically from you, who told me point-blank, at the second interview, that you did not think me handsome. The contrast struck me at the time and—”
Adèle here came running up again.
“Monsieur, John has just been to say that your agent has called and wishes to see you.”
“Ah! in that case I must abridge. Opening the window, I walked in upon them; liberated Céline from my protection; gave her notice to vacate her hotel; offered her a purse for immediate exigencies; disregarded screams, hysterics, prayers, protestations, convulsions; made an appointment with the vicomte for a meeting at the Bois de Boulogne. Next morning I had the pleasure of encountering him; left a bullet in one of his poor etiolated arms, feeble as the wing of a chicken in the pip, and then thought I had done with the whole crew. But unluckily the Varens, six months before, had given me this filette Adèle, who, she affirmed, was my daughter; and perhaps she may be, though I see no proofs of such grim paternity written in her countenance: Pilot is more like me than she. Some years after I had broken with the mother, she abandoned her child, and ran away to Italy with a musician or singer. I acknowledged no natural claim on Adèle’s part to be supported by me, nor do I now acknowledge any, for I am not her father; but hearing that she was quite destitute, I e’en took the poor thing out of the slime and mud of Paris, and transplanted it here, to grow up clean in the wholesome soil of an English country garden. Mrs. Fairfax found you to train it; but now you know that it is the illegitimate offspring of a French opera-girl, you will perhaps think differently of your post and protégée: you will be coming to me some day with notice that you have found another place—that you beg me to look out for a new governess, &c.—Eh?”

Now, it had been her habit to praise what she called my 'manly beauty' profusely, differing completely from you, who told me frankly during our second meeting that you didn't think I was handsome. That contrast struck me at the time and—" Adèle ran up again at this point. "Monsieur, John just came to say your agent has arrived and wishes to see you." "Ah! In that case, I must shorten the story." Opening the window, I walked in on them. Mrs. Fairfax found you to educate her. But now that you know she's the illegitimate child of a French opera-girl, you'll perhaps feel differently about your job and your student; you'll likely come to me soon saying you've found another position, asking me to look for a new governess, etc.—Right?"

events.title: Jane's Reassurance to Rochester and Her Deepening Private Reflections
detailed_summary: Jane firmly tells Mr. Rochester that Adèle's origins will not make her leave; instead, her knowledge of Adèle being effectively parentless strengthens her resolve to care for the child.
She expresses a preference for Adèle's situation over that of a spoiled child from a wealthy family.
Mr. Rochester acknowledges her viewpoint before they head indoors.
Jane, however, stays out a little longer, playing with Adèle and Pilot.
Indoors, Jane holds Adèle on her knee for an hour, allowing her to talk freely, observing some superficial maternal traits but also appreciating Adèle's good qualities.
She searches Adèle's features for any resemblance to Mr. Rochester but finds none, thinking a likeness might have made him fonder of the child.
Later that night, alone, Jane reflects on Mr. Rochester's narrative, finding his intense emotional reaction to Thornfield more perplexing than the actual story of his affair.
She views his decision to confide in her as a mark of respect for her discretion.
Jane notes that Mr. Rochester's behavior towards her has become more consistently kind and welcoming in recent weeks.
She feels that their evening conversations are sought by him for his own pleasure as much as for her benefit, and she delights in the new ideas and perspectives he shares.
His open manner has eased her own restraint, drawing her closer to him, sometimes feeling more like a relative than an employer.
This evolving relationship has brought her significant happiness, improved her health, and filled a void in her life.
Jane realizes she no longer perceives Mr. Rochester as ugly; gratitude and pleasant associations have made his face the one she most likes to see.
She remains aware of his faults—pride, sarcasm, harshness, and moodiness—but attributes them to past misfortunes, believing in his inherent goodness.
She admits to feeling deep sympathy for his unspoken sorrows and wishes she could alleviate them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No: Adèle is not answerable for either her mother’s faults or yours: I have a regard for her; and now that I know she is, in a sense, parentless—forsaken by her mother and disowned by you, sir—I shall cling closer to her than before.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I cannot deny that I grieved for his grief, whatever that was, and would have given much to assuage it.

events.text_segment:
“No: Adèle is not answerable for either her mother’s faults or yours: I have a regard for her; and now that I know she is, in a sense, parentless—forsaken by her mother and disowned by you, sir—I shall cling closer to her than before. How could I possibly prefer the spoilt pet of a wealthy family, who would hate her governess as a nuisance, to a lonely little orphan, who leans towards her as a friend?”
“Oh, that is the light in which you view it! Well, I must go in now; and you too: it darkens.”
But I stayed out a few minutes longer with Adèle and Pilot—ran a race with her, and played a game of battledore and shuttlecock. When we went in, and I had removed her bonnet and coat, I took her on my knee; kept her there an hour, allowing her to prattle as she liked: not rebuking even some little freedoms and trivialities into which she was apt to stray when much noticed, and which betrayed in her a superficiality of character, inherited probably from her mother, hardly congenial to an English mind. Still she had her merits; and I was disposed to appreciate all that was good in her to the utmost. I sought in her countenance and features a likeness to Mr. Rochester, but found none: no trait, no turn of expression announced relationship. It was a pity: if she could but have been proved to resemble him, he would have thought more of her.
It was not till after I had withdrawn to my own chamber for the night, that I steadily reviewed the tale Mr. Rochester had told me. As he had said, there was probably nothing at all extraordinary in the substance of the narrative itself: a wealthy Englishman’s passion for a French dancer, and her treachery to him, were every-day matters enough, no doubt, in society; but there was something decidedly strange in the paroxysm of emotion which had suddenly seized him when he was in the act of expressing the present contentment of his mood, and his newly revived pleasure in the old hall and its environs. I meditated wonderingly on this incident; but gradually quitting it, as I found it for the present inexplicable, I turned to the consideration of my master’s manner to myself. The confidence he had thought fit to repose in me seemed a tribute to my discretion: I regarded and accepted it as such. His deportment had now for some weeks been more uniform towards me than at the first. I never seemed in his way; he did not take fits of chilling hauteur: when he met me unexpectedly, the encounter seemed welcome; he had always a word and sometimes a smile for me: when summoned by formal invitation to his presence, I was honoured by a cordiality of reception that made me feel I really possessed the power to amuse him, and that these evening conferences were sought as much for his pleasure as for my benefit.
I, indeed, talked comparatively little, but I heard him talk with relish. It was his nature to be communicative; he liked to open to a mind unacquainted with the world glimpses of its scenes and ways (I do not mean its corrupt scenes and wicked ways, but such as derived their interest from the great scale on which they were acted, the strange novelty by which they were characterised); and I had a keen delight in receiving the new ideas he offered, in imagining the new pictures he portrayed, and following him in thought through the new regions he disclosed, never startled or troubled by one noxious allusion.
The ease of his manner freed me from painful restraint: the friendly frankness, as correct as cordial, with which he treated me, drew me to him. I felt at times as if he were my relation rather than my master: yet he was imperious sometimes still; but I did not mind that; I saw it was his way. So happy, so gratified did I become with this new interest added to life, that I ceased to pine after kindred: my thin crescent-destiny seemed to enlarge; the blanks of existence were filled up; my bodily health improved; I gathered flesh and strength.
And was Mr. Rochester now ugly in my eyes? No, reader: gratitude, and many associations, all pleasurable and genial, made his face the object I best liked to see; his presence in a room was more cheering than the brightest fire. Yet I had not forgotten his faults; indeed, I could not, for he brought them frequently before me. He was proud, sardonic, harsh to inferiority of every description: in my secret soul I knew that his great kindness to me was balanced by unjust severity to many others. He was moody, too; unaccountably so; I more than once, when sent for to read to him, found him sitting in his library alone, with his head bent on his folded arms; and, when he looked up, a morose, almost a malignant, scowl blackened his features. But I believed that his moodiness, his harshness, and his former faults of morality (I say former, for now he seemed corrected of them) had their source in some cruel cross of fate. I believed he was naturally a man of better tendencies, higher principles, and purer tastes than such as circumstances had developed, education instilled, or destiny encouraged. I thought there were excellent materials in him; though for the present they hung together somewhat spoiled and tangled. I cannot deny that I grieved for his grief, whatever that was, and would have given much to assuage it.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
“No,” I replied, “Adèle isn’t accountable for her mother's shortcomings or yours. I care for her, and knowing she is, in a way, without parents—left by her mother and rejected by you, sir—I will feel even closer to her now. Why would I favor the spoiled darling of a rich family, who would likely view her governess as a nuisance, over a solitary little orphan who looks to her for friendship?”
“Ah, so that is your perspective!” he said. “Very well, I must go inside now, and you too; it’s getting dark.”
However, I stayed outside for a few more minutes with Adèle and Pilot. We ran together and played battledore and shuttlecock. When we eventually went in, and I had taken off her hat and coat, I sat her on my lap and kept her there for an hour, letting her talk freely. I didn't even scold her for some minor liberties and insignificant remarks she sometimes made when she was given attention, which revealed a rather shallow character, possibly inherited from her mother, and not quite suited to the English temperament. Still, she had her good points, and I was determined to fully appreciate them. I searched her face for any resemblance to Mr. Rochester but found none; no feature or expression suggested a family connection. It was a shame; if she had resembled him, he might have cared for her more.
It wasn’t until I had retired to my room for the night that I calmly reconsidered the story Mr. Rochester had shared. As he himself had noted, there was probably nothing truly remarkable about the story itself – a wealthy Englishman’s infatuation with a French dancer and her subsequent betrayal were undoubtedly common occurrences in society. However, there was something distinctly peculiar about the sudden, intense emotional reaction that overwhelmed him just as he was expressing his current contentment and his renewed pleasure in the old house and its surroundings. I pondered this incident with bewilderment, but finding it inexplicable for the moment, I turned my thoughts to how my employer treated me. The trust he chose to place in me seemed like an acknowledgement of my discretion, and I accepted and valued it as such. For some weeks now, his behavior towards me had been more consistent than it was initially. I never felt I was in his way; he didn't have periods of freezing arrogance. When we met unexpectedly, the encounter seemed welcome; he always had a kind word and sometimes a smile for me. When I was formally invited to see him, I was greeted with a warmth that made me feel I genuinely had the ability to entertain him, and that these evening discussions were desired as much for his enjoyment as for my instruction.
Indeed, I spoke relatively little, but I enjoyed listening to him talk immensely. It was in his nature to be open; he liked showing a mind unfamiliar with the world glimpses of its events and customs (I mean not the corrupt or wicked parts, but those interesting because of their grand scale or unusual nature). And I took great pleasure in receiving the new perspectives he offered, imagining the new scenes he painted, and following his thoughts through the new territories he revealed, never disturbed or upset by any offensive implication.
His relaxed manner freed me from uncomfortable self-consciousness. The friendly honesty, proper yet warm, with which he treated me, drew me closer to him. At times, I felt he was more like a relative than my employer. Yet, he could still be demanding sometimes, but I didn't mind; I saw it was just his way. I became so happy and fulfilled by this new element in my life that I stopped longing for family. My seemingly narrow fate appeared to broaden; the empty parts of existence were filled. My physical health improved; I gained weight and strength.
And was Mr. Rochester now unattractive in my eyes? No, reader. Gratitude and many pleasant, cheerful experiences made his face the sight I liked best, and his presence in a room was more comforting than the brightest fire. Yet, I hadn't forgotten his flaws; in fact, I couldn't, because he often displayed them. He was proud, sarcastic, and harsh towards people he considered inferior in any way. In my private thoughts, I knew his great kindness to me was offset by unfair harshness to many others. He was also moody, and inexplicably so. More than once, when summoned to read to him, I found him sitting alone in his library, head resting on his folded arms; and when he looked up, a sullen, almost malevolent, frown darkened his features. But I believed that his moodiness, his harshness, and his past moral mistakes (I say past, as he seemed reformed now) originated from some cruel turn of fortune. I believed he was naturally a man with better inclinations, higher principles, and purer tastes than those developed by circumstances, instilled by education, or encouraged by destiny. I thought he possessed excellent potential qualities, even though currently they seemed somewhat damaged and disordered. I cannot deny that I felt sorrow for his pain, whatever it was, and would have given a great deal to relieve it.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
No: Adèle shouldn't be blamed for either her mother's or your mistakes. Why would I ever prefer some pampered child from a rich family, who would resent her governess, over a lonely little orphan who looks to her governess as a friend?

"So that's how you see it! Well, I need to go inside now, and you should too; it's getting dark."

But I lingered outside a little longer with Adèle and Pilot—racing and playing battledore and shuttlecock. When we finally went in and I took off her hat and coat, I let her sit on my lap for an hour, listening to her talk freely—even permitting little lapses in behavior that showed some superficial traits, perhaps inherited from her mother, which might not sit well with an English mindset. Nevertheless, she had good qualities, and I was eager to recognize all that was positive in her. I searched for any resemblance between her and Mr. Rochester in her face and expressions, but there was none; nothing suggested a family link. It was a pity—if there'd been a likeness, perhaps he would care more for her.

It wasn’t until I retired to my own room that night that I carefully considered the story Mr. Rochester had told me. As he said, there wasn't anything very remarkable about the plot itself—a rich Englishman's infatuation with a French dancer who then betrayed him is no uncommon story in society. But the intense outburst of emotion that overtook him while he was expressing his contentedness with Thornfield and its surroundings was certainly odd. I pondered on this, though, finding it inexplicable for now, I set it aside to reflect on Mr. Rochester's behavior towards me. The trust he showed me felt like a compliment to my judgment, and I accepted it as such. Recently, he had behaved more consistently with me than before. I didn't feel like an inconvenience to him; he didn't become suddenly cold. Unexpected meetings always seemed welcome to him; he always had a kind word or even a smile for me. When I was formally invited to see him, he greeted me warmly enough to make me feel that I brought him enjoyment, and that these evening conversations were as much for his amusement as for my improvement.

I usually talked little, but I enjoyed listening to him. He was naturally talkative, eager to give me insights into the world—by which I mean fascinating aspects, not wicked ones—and I took great pleasure in absorbing these new ideas, picturing what he described, and following his thoughts to new and exciting places, never upset by any inappropriate references.

His relaxed manner put me at ease. His friendly candor, both appropriate and warm, endeared him to me. At times, I felt he was almost like family rather than just my employer; he could still be commanding, but I didn't mind, recognizing it as part of his character. With this new interest in my life, I found myself much happier, no longer longing for relatives; life felt fuller, my physical health improved, and I grew stronger.

Did I still find Mr. Rochester unattractive? No, dear reader: gratitude and countless pleasant memories made his face the one I liked to see most; his presence cheered me more than a glowing fire. Still, I hadn't forgotten his faults—nor could I, for he was always reminding me of them. He was proud, sarcastic, and severe toward those below him. Secretly, I was aware that his great kindness to me came with an unjust harshness to others. He was also moody; I sometimes found him alone in his library, brooding, and when he looked up, his expression could be sullen, even almost hostile. But I believed his moodiness, harshness, and past moral failings (which I think he has overcome) all stemmed from some misfortune. I thought him, at heart, a good man—naturally noble and pure, even if circumstance, upbringing, or fate had not encouraged these traits. I believed he had great potential, though currently it was somewhat marred. I pitied his unhappiness, whatever its cause, and would have done much to ease it.

events.title: Mysterious Nocturnal Disturbance and Jane's Discovery of the Fire
detailed_summary: Lying in bed, Jane is unable to sleep, her thoughts consumed by Mr. Rochester's earlier emotional outburst about Thornfield and his destiny.
She worries about his aversion to the house and the possibility of his leaving again soon.
A vague, lugubrious murmur from above startles her, adding to her unease in the darkness.
After the clock strikes two, she hears what sounds like fingers sweeping against her chamber door.
Her frightened call, "Who is there?" receives no answer.
She briefly considers the possibility that the sound was made by Pilot, which offers a fleeting moment of calm.
Just as she feels sleep approaching, she is terrified by a low, suppressed, demonic laugh that seems to come from her very keyhole.
Rising to investigate, she sees nothing, but the unnatural sound is repeated, confirming it originates from behind her door panels.
She then hears gurgling, moaning, and the sound of footsteps retreating up the gallery towards the third-storey staircase, followed by a door opening and closing.
Suspecting Grace Poole and wondering if she is possessed, Jane feels compelled to seek Mrs. Fairfax.
Upon opening her door, she is surprised to find a candle burning in the gallery and is then alarmed by the dim, smoky air and a strong smell of burning.
She discovers smoke billowing from Mr. Rochester's slightly ajar bedroom door.
Instantly forgetting her other concerns, Jane rushes into his chamber to find the bed curtains ablaze and Mr. Rochester lying motionless in a deep sleep amidst the fire and smoke.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Though I had now extinguished my candle and was laid down in bed, I could not sleep for thinking of his look when he paused in the avenue, and told how his destiny had risen up before him, and dared him to be happy at Thornfield.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the midst of blaze and vapour, Mr. Rochester lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.

events.text_segment:
Though I had now extinguished my candle and was laid down in bed, I could not sleep for thinking of his look when he paused in the avenue, and told how his destiny had risen up before him, and dared him to be happy at Thornfield.
“Why not?” I asked myself. “What alienates him from the house? Will he leave it again soon? Mrs. Fairfax said he seldom stayed here longer than a fortnight at a time; and he has now been resident eight weeks. If he does go, the change will be doleful. Suppose he should be absent spring, summer, and autumn: how joyless sunshine and fine days will seem!”
I hardly know whether I had slept or not after this musing; at any rate, I started wide awake on hearing a vague murmur, peculiar and lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above me. I wished I had kept my candle burning: the night was drearily dark; my spirits were depressed. I rose and sat up in bed, listening. The sound was hushed.
I tried again to sleep; but my heart beat anxiously: my inward tranquillity was broken. The clock, far down in the hall, struck two. Just then it seemed my chamber-door was touched; as if fingers had swept the panels in groping a way along the dark gallery outside. I said, “Who is there?” Nothing answered. I was chilled with fear.
All at once I remembered that it might be Pilot, who, when the kitchen-door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found his way up to the threshold of Mr. Rochester’s chamber: I had seen him lying there myself in the mornings. The idea calmed me somewhat: I lay down. Silence composes the nerves; and as an unbroken hush now reigned again through the whole house, I began to feel the return of slumber. But it was not fated that I should sleep that night. A dream had scarcely approached my ear, when it fled affrighted, scared by a marrow-freezing incident enough.
This was a demoniac laugh—low, suppressed, and deep—uttered, as it seemed, at the very keyhole of my chamber door. The head of my bed was near the door, and I thought at first the goblin-laugher stood at my bedside—or rather, crouched by my pillow: but I rose, looked round, and could see nothing; while, as I still gazed, the unnatural sound was reiterated: and I knew it came from behind the panels. My first impulse was to rise and fasten the bolt; my next, again to cry out, “Who is there?”
Something gurgled and moaned. Ere long, steps retreated up the gallery towards the third-storey staircase: a door had lately been made to shut in that staircase; I heard it open and close, and all was still.
“Was that Grace Poole? and is she possessed with a devil?” thought I. Impossible now to remain longer by myself: I must go to Mrs. Fairfax. I hurried on my frock and a shawl; I withdrew the bolt and opened the door with a trembling hand. There was a candle burning just outside, and on the matting in the gallery. I was surprised at this circumstance: but still more was I amazed to perceive the air quite dim, as if filled with smoke; and, while looking to the right hand and left, to find whence these blue wreaths issued, I became further aware of a strong smell of burning.
Something creaked: it was a door ajar; and that door was Mr. Rochester’s, and the smoke rushed in a cloud from thence. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an instant, I was within the chamber. Tongues of flame darted round the bed: the curtains were on fire. In the midst of blaze and vapour, Mr. Rochester lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.

"Why is this?" I pondered. "What makes him feel estranged from this place? Will he be leaving again soon? Mrs. Fairfax mentioned he rarely stayed longer than two weeks at a time, yet he's now been residing here for eight weeks. If he departs, the change will be sorrowful. Imagine if he were gone through spring, summer, and autumn; how cheerless sunshine and pleasant days will seem!" I'm unsure if I had actually slept after these thoughts; at any rate, I was jolted wide awake by a faint, peculiar, and mournful murmur that seemed to come from directly above me. However, I was not destined to sleep that night. A dream had barely begun when it was startled away, scared off by a truly bone-chilling incident. This was a devilish laugh – low, stifled, and deep – which seemed to come right from the keyhole of my door. My headboard was close to the door, and at first, I thought the fiendish laughter was beside my bed, or even crouching by my pillow. But I rose, looked around, and saw nothing. My initial instinct was to get up and secure the bolt; my next was to again call out, "Who's there?" Something gurgled and moaned. A door had recently been added to enclose that staircase; I heard it open and close, and then all was quiet. "Was that Grace Poole? And is she possessed?" I wondered. As I looked left and right, trying to find where the blue trails were coming from, I also noticed a strong smell of burning. A sound of creaking: it was a door slightly open, and that door was Mr. Rochester's. A cloud of smoke poured out from there. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole or the laugh. In an instant, I was inside the room. Tongues of flame were leaping around the bed; the curtains were on fire. Amidst the blaze and smoke, Mr. Rochester lay motionless, deeply asleep.

My first urge was to lock it; then I called out again, “Who is there?” Something made a gurgling, moaning sound. I wondered if it was Grace Poole and if she was somehow possessed. I couldn’t stay alone—so I hurriedly put on a dress and shawl, unlocked my door, and stepped out, my hand shaking. There was a candle burning outside on the hall mat, which surprised me, and the air was filled with smoke. Looking around for the source, I smelled burning. A door creaked open—it was Mr. Rochester’s—and smoke poured out. Forgetting all about Mrs. Fairfax, Grace Poole, or the laugh, I rushed into his room. Flames were climbing around the bed and the curtains were on fire. In the midst of the smoke and flames, Mr. Rochester lay sound asleep, unmoving.

events.title: Jane Extinguishes the Fire and Rescues Rochester
detailed_summary: Jane urgently cries out to Mr. Rochester and shakes him, but he only murmurs, having been stupefied by the smoke.
With the bedsheets already kindling, Jane acts decisively, rushing to his basin and ewer, which are fortunately filled with water.
She douses the bed and Mr. Rochester with the water, then flies to her own room for her water-jug, returning to further drench the couch and successfully extinguish the flames.
The combined sounds of the quenched fire, a pitcher she flings aside, and the copious amount of water finally rouse Mr. Rochester.
Awakening in darkness and soaked, he exclaims, asking if there is a flood.
Jane informs him of the fire, assures him he is now safe from it, and says she will fetch a candle.
Mr. Rochester, recognizing Jane's voice, demands to know what she has done to him, calling her a witch and asking if she plotted to drown him.
Jane calmly repeats her intention to get a candle and urges him to get up, suggesting that someone has indeed plotted something.
Mr. Rochester tells her to wait for two minutes while he finds dry garments before she brings the candle.
Jane retrieves the candle from the gallery; Mr. Rochester takes it and surveys the blackened, scorched bed and water-drenched room, asking what happened and who caused it.
Jane briefly explains the sequence of events: the strange laugh, the retreating footsteps, the smell of fire leading her to his room, the state she found him in, and her actions to put out the fire.
Mr. Rochester listens with great seriousness, his expression showing more concern than surprise, and he remains silent for a moment after Jane finishes speaking.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Wake! wake!” I cried.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He listened very gravely; his face, as I went on, expressed more concern than astonishment; he did not immediately speak when I had concluded.

events.text_segment:
“Wake! wake!” I cried. I shook him, but he only murmured and turned: the smoke had stupefied him. Not a moment could be lost: the very sheets were kindling, I rushed to his basin and ewer; fortunately, one was wide and the other deep, and both were filled with water. I heaved them up, deluged the bed and its occupant, flew back to my own room, brought my own water-jug, baptized the couch afresh, and, by God’s aid, succeeded in extinguishing the flames which were devouring it.
The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher which I flung from my hand when I had emptied it, and, above all, the splash of the shower-bath I had liberally bestowed, roused Mr. Rochester at last. Though it was now dark, I knew he was awake; because I heard him fulminating strange anathemas at finding himself lying in a pool of water.
“Is there a flood?” he cried.
“No, sir,” I answered; “but there has been a fire: get up, do; you are quenched now; I will fetch you a candle.”
“In the name of all the elves in Christendom, is that Jane Eyre?” he demanded. “What have you done with me, witch, sorceress? Who is in the room besides you? Have you plotted to drown me?”
“I will fetch you a candle, sir; and, in Heaven’s name, get up. Somebody has plotted something: you cannot too soon find out who and what it is.”
“There! I am up now; but at your peril you fetch a candle yet: wait two minutes till I get into some dry garments, if any dry there be—yes, here is my dressing-gown. Now run!”
I did run; I brought the candle which still remained in the gallery. He took it from my hand, held it up, and surveyed the bed, all blackened and scorched, the sheets drenched, the carpet round swimming in water.
“What is it? and who did it?” he asked.
I briefly related to him what had transpired: the strange laugh I had heard in the gallery: the step ascending to the third storey; the smoke,—the smell of fire which had conducted me to his room; in what state I had found matters there, and how I had deluged him with all the water I could lay hands on.
He listened very gravely; his face, as I went on, expressed more concern than astonishment; he did not immediately speak when I had concluded.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: “Wake up! Wake up!” I shouted. I shook him, but he only mumbled and turned over; the smoke had made him groggy. Not a moment could be lost; the very bedclothes were catching fire. I grabbed his washbasin and pitcher; fortunately, one was wide and the other deep, and both were full of water. I lifted them, poured the water over the bed and the person in it, ran back to my room, fetched my own water jug, doused the bed again, and, with divine assistance, managed to put out the flames that were consuming it. The sound of the fire being extinguished, the noise of a pitcher I dropped after emptying it, and especially the splash from the generous soaking I’d given him, finally roused Mr. Rochester. Although it was dark now, I knew he was awake because I heard him loudly cursing when he found himself lying in a puddle. “Is there a flood?” he exclaimed. “No, sir,” I answered; “but there was a fire; please get up; you are completely soaked now; I will bring you a candle.” “In the name of all the little folk in Christendom, is that Jane Eyre?” he demanded. “What have you done to me, you witch, you sorceress? Is anyone else in the room with you? Did you plot to drown me?” “I will bring you a candle, sir; and, for heaven’s sake, get up. Someone has planned something; you must discover who and what it is without delay.” “Fine! I’m up now; but don’t you dare get a candle yet; wait a couple of minutes until I find some dry clothes, if there are any—yes, here is my dressing-gown. Now go!” I did run; I brought the candle that was still in the gallery. And who did it?” he inquired. I briefly told him what had occurred: the strange laugh I had heard in the gallery; the sound of footsteps going up to the third floor; the smoke—the smell of fire that had led me to his room; the state in which I had found things there, and how I had covered him with all the water I could find. He listened very seriously; as I continued, his face showed more worry than surprise; he did not speak immediately after I finished.

events.title: Rochester's Investigation, Instructions for Secrecy, and Intense Gratitude to Jane
detailed_summary: Jane offers to call Mrs. Fairfax, but Mr. Rochester firmly refuses, stating Mrs. Fairfax can do nothing and should be left to sleep.
He similarly rejects Jane's suggestion to wake Leah or John and his wife, instructing her to simply be still.
He offers Jane his cloak for warmth and tells her to sit and wait while he leaves for a few minutes with the candle, saying he must visit the "second storey."
Jane waits in total darkness, feeling cold and weary, and considers disobeying his order not to rouse anyone.
Mr. Rochester returns, appearing pale and very gloomy, and announces that he has "found it all out" and that the situation is as he suspected.
He cryptically questions Jane about whether she saw anything when she opened her chamber door; she replies that she only saw the candlestick on the ground.
He then asks if she has heard the odd laugh before, and Jane confirms she has, attributing it to Grace Poole, whom she describes as a singular person.
Mr. Rochester affirms her guess, agreeing that Grace Poole is indeed very singular.
He states he will reflect on the matter and expresses his gladness that Jane is the only other person aware of the night's precise events, trusting her discretion.
He tells Jane to return to her room, saying he will sleep on the library sofa, and notes the time is near four.
As Jane says good-night and begins to depart, Mr. Rochester expresses surprise at her leaving so abruptly.
He exclaims that she saved his life from a horrible death and cannot leave without a word of acknowledgment, insisting on at least a handshake.
He takes her hand, first in one of his, then in both, expressing profound pleasure in owing her such an immense debt, stating that with her, the obligation feels different, not a burden.
Words seem to tremble on his lips, but he restrains himself from speaking them.
Jane attempts to dismiss any notion of debt or obligation.
Mr. Rochester continues, saying he always knew she would do him good, citing the expression in her eyes when they first met, which struck him deeply.
He calls her his "cherished preserver" and bids her good-night with unusual energy in his voice and look.
Jane, stating she is cold, attempts to leave again, but he continues to hold her hand.
She then uses the excuse of thinking she hears Mrs. Fairfax moving, which prompts him to relax his grip, allowing her to depart.
Jane returns to her bed but is too agitated for sleep, tossed on a metaphorical sea of trouble and joy, envisioning a hopeful shore but being continually driven back by a counteracting force.
Overwhelmed by her feverish state, she rises as soon as day dawns.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Shall I call Mrs. Fairfax?” I asked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Too feverish to rest, I rose as soon as day dawned.

events.text_segment:
“Shall I call Mrs. Fairfax?” I asked.
“Mrs. Fairfax? No; what the deuce would you call her for? What can she do? Let her sleep unmolested.”
“Then I will fetch Leah, and wake John and his wife.”
“Not at all: just be still. You have a shawl on. If you are not warm enough, you may take my cloak yonder; wrap it about you, and sit down in the arm-chair: there,—I will put it on. Now place your feet on the stool, to keep them out of the wet. I am going to leave you a few minutes. I shall take the candle. Remain where you are till I return; be as still as a mouse. I must pay a visit to the second storey. Don’t move, remember, or call any one.”
He went: I watched the light withdraw. He passed up the gallery very softly, unclosed the staircase door with as little noise as possible, shut it after him, and the last ray vanished. I was left in total darkness. I listened for some noise, but heard nothing. A very long time elapsed. I grew weary: it was cold, in spite of the cloak; and then I did not see the use of staying, as I was not to rouse the house. I was on the point of risking Mr. Rochester’s displeasure by disobeying his orders, when the light once more gleamed dimly on the gallery wall, and I heard his unshod feet tread the matting. “I hope it is he,” thought I, “and not something worse.”
He re-entered, pale and very gloomy. “I have found it all out,” said he, setting his candle down on the washstand; “it is as I thought.”
“How, sir?”
He made no reply, but stood with his arms folded, looking on the ground. At the end of a few minutes he inquired in rather a peculiar tone—
“I forget whether you said you saw anything when you opened your chamber door.”
“No, sir, only the candlestick on the ground.”
“But you heard an odd laugh? You have heard that laugh before, I should think, or something like it?”
“Yes, sir: there is a woman who sews here, called Grace Poole,—she laughs in that way. She is a singular person.”
“Just so. Grace Poole—you have guessed it. She is, as you say, singular—very. Well, I shall reflect on the subject. Meantime, I am glad that you are the only person, besides myself, acquainted with the precise details of to-night’s incident. You are no talking fool: say nothing about it. I will account for this state of affairs” (pointing to the bed): “and now return to your own room. I shall do very well on the sofa in the library for the rest of the night. It is near four:—in two hours the servants will be up.”
“Good-night, then, sir,” said I, departing.
He seemed surprised—very inconsistently so, as he had just told me to go.
“What!” he exclaimed, “are you quitting me already, and in that way?”
“You said I might go, sir.”
“But not without taking leave; not without a word or two of acknowledgment and good-will: not, in short, in that brief, dry fashion. Why, you have saved my life!—snatched me from a horrible and excruciating death! and you walk past me as if we were mutual strangers! At least shake hands.”
He held out his hand; I gave him mine: he took it first in one, then in both his own.
“You have saved my life: I have a pleasure in owing you so immense a debt. I cannot say more. Nothing else that has being would have been tolerable to me in the character of creditor for such an obligation: but you: it is different;—I feel your benefits no burden, Jane.”
He paused; gazed at me: words almost visible trembled on his lips,—but his voice was checked.
“Good-night again, sir. There is no debt, benefit, burden, obligation, in the case.”
“I knew,” he continued, “you would do me good in some way, at some time;—I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you: their expression and smile did not”—(again he stopped)—“did not” (he proceeded hastily) “strike delight to my very inmost heart so for nothing. People talk of natural sympathies; I have heard of good genii: there are grains of truth in the wildest fable. My cherished preserver, good-night!”
Strange energy was in his voice, strange fire in his look.
“I am glad I happened to be awake,” I said: and then I was going.
“What! you will go?”
“I am cold, sir.”
“Cold? Yes,—and standing in a pool! Go, then, Jane; go!” But he still retained my hand, and I could not free it. I bethought myself of an expedient.
“I think I hear Mrs. Fairfax move, sir,” said I.
“Well, leave me:” he relaxed his fingers, and I was gone.
I regained my couch, but never thought of sleep. Till morning dawned I was tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy. I thought sometimes I saw beyond its wild waters a shore, sweet as the hills of Beulah; and now and then a freshening gale, wakened by hope, bore my spirit triumphantly towards the bourne: but I could not reach it, even in fancy—a counteracting breeze blew off land, and continually drove me back. Sense would resist delirium: judgment would warn passion. Too feverish to rest, I rose as soon as day dawned.

He sharply refused, asking why on earth I would call her and what she could possibly do, telling me to let her sleep undisturbed. I then offered to fetch Leah, John, and his wife. He stopped me immediately, telling me to stay put. He pointed out I had a shawl, but if that wasn't enough, I could use his cloak nearby. He helped me wrap it around myself and told me to sit in the armchair and place my feet on the stool to keep them dry. He informed me he would be leaving for a few minutes, taking the candle, and that I should remain exactly where I was until he returned, keeping perfectly quiet. He needed to go up to the second floor. He reiterated that I must not move or call anyone. He left, and I watched the light diminish. He moved very quietly along the corridor, opened the staircase door with minimal sound, closed it behind him, and the last bit of light vanished, leaving me in complete darkness. I was on the verge of disobeying Mr. Rochester, despite the potential for his displeasure, when the light dimly reappeared on the gallery wall, and I heard his bare feet on the matting. I hoped it was him, not something worse. He returned, looking pale and very serious. "I've discovered everything," he said, putting the candle on the washstand. "It's just as I suspected." "How, sir?" I asked. He didn't answer, but stood with his arms crossed, looking at the floor. After a few moments, he asked in a peculiar tone, "Did you say you saw anything when you opened your bedroom door? I forget." "No, sir, only the candlestick on the floor," I replied. "But you heard a strange laugh? You've likely heard that laugh before, or something similar?" he probed. "Yes, sir," I confirmed, "There's a woman who sews here named Grace Poole; she laughs that way. She's quite an unusual person." "Precisely. Grace Poole—you've figured it out. She is, as you said, unusual—very. Well, I will think about this. In the meantime, I'm glad you're the only person besides myself who knows the exact details of what happened tonight. You aren't a careless talker, so keep it to yourself. I will explain this situation" (gesturing towards the bed). "Now go back to your room. I'll manage perfectly well on the library sofa for the rest of the night. It's nearly four; the servants will be up in two hours." "Good-night, then, sir," I said as I began to leave. He seemed surprised—quite inconsistently, given he'd just told me to go. "What!" he exclaimed, "Are you leaving me already, and like that?" "You told me I could go, sir," I explained. "But not without saying goodbye; not without a word or two of thanks and good wishes; not, in short, in such a brief, cold manner. Why, you saved my life! Pulled me back from a terrible and agonizing death! And you walk past me as if we barely know each other! At least shake hands." He offered his hand; I gave him mine. He took it first in one hand, then in both of his. "You've saved my life. I am pleased to owe you such a tremendous debt. I cannot say more. No other living soul could have been a welcome creditor for such a service, but you—it's different. I don't feel burdened by your help, Jane." He paused, gazing at me. Words seemed to tremble on his lips, almost visible, but his voice failed him. "Good-night again, sir. There's no debt, favour, burden, or obligation involved," I insisted. "I knew," he continued, "you would do me good somehow, someday. I saw it in your eyes when I first saw you; their expression and smile didn't—" (he stopped again) "didn't" (he rushed on) "strike delight deep into my heart for no reason. People speak of natural connections; I've heard of helpful spirits; there's some truth even in the wildest tales. My cherished rescuer, good-night!" His voice held strange intensity, his gaze strange fire. "I'm glad I happened to be awake," I said, and started to go again. "What! You are going?" he pressed. "I'm cold, sir." "Cold? Yes—and standing in water! Go, then, Jane; go!" But he still held my hand, and I couldn't free it. I thought of a way. "I think I hear Mrs. Fairfax moving, sir," I said. "Well, leave me," he said, loosening his grip, and I was free to leave. I returned to my bed but had no thought of sleep. Until morning broke, I felt like I was on a turbulent, restless sea, where waves of trouble rolled beneath swells of joy. Sometimes I imagined seeing a distant shore beyond the wild waters, as beautiful as the hills of Beulah, and now and then, a refreshing wind, stirred by hope, carried my spirit triumphantly towards that destination. But I couldn't reach it, not even in my imagination—a contrary breeze blew from the land, constantly pushing me back. My common sense resisted my feverish excitement; my judgment warned my emotions. Too agitated to rest, I got up as soon as dawn appeared.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Should I wake Mrs. Fairfax?" I inquired.
"Mrs. Fairfax? No, why would you do that? She can't help; let her sleep."
"Maybe I'll get Leah, or wake John and his wife."
"No, don't bother — just stay quiet. You're wearing a shawl, but if you're cold, use my cloak over there; wrap it around yourself and sit in the armchair. Here, I'll put it on you. Now put your feet on the stool to keep them dry. I'm going to step away for a bit and take the candle. Stay put until I return and be very quiet. I have to check something on the next floor. Don't move or call anyone."

He left, and I watched the candle’s light disappear as he moved quietly along the gallery, opened the staircase door with barely any sound, and closed it behind him, leaving me in complete darkness. I listened hard, but heard nothing. Time dragged on, and I grew cold and tired, even with the cloak. Since I wasn’t supposed to wake anyone, I didn’t see the point in staying. I was about to risk angering Mr. Rochester by ignoring his instructions when finally the light returned faintly along the gallery, and I heard his quiet footsteps. I hoped it was him—and nothing worse.

He returned, looking pale and grim. “I figured everything out,” he said, putting his candle on the washstand. “Just as I suspected.”
“Really, sir?” I asked.
He didn’t answer at first, just stood with his arms folded, gazing at the floor. After a moment, he asked, sounding strange,
“I forget, when you opened your bedroom door, did you see anything?”
“No, sir; just the candlestick on the ground.”
“But you heard a strange laugh? You’ve heard that laugh before?”
“Yes, sir. There's a seamstress here named Grace Poole—she laughs like that. She’s an odd woman.”
“Exactly. Grace Poole. You figured it out; she is very peculiar. I’ll think about all this. In the meantime, I’m glad only you and I know the details of what happened tonight. You can be discreet: say nothing about it. I’ll take responsibility for the state of things in here,” he said, pointing to the bed. “Now, go back to your room. I’ll sleep on the library sofa for the rest of the night. It’s nearly four in the morning; in two hours the servants will be up.”

“Goodnight, sir,” I said as I left.
He seemed surprised—odd, since he’d just told me to go.
“What! Leaving me already, and like that?”
“You said I could go, sir.”
“But not so abruptly, without a word or any warmth. You saved my life—from a terrible death!—and now you walk away as if we’re strangers! Please, shake my hand.”
He offered his hand, and I took it; first with one hand, then both of his.
“You’ve saved my life. I’m glad to owe you so much. I feel differently about this debt with you; it feels like no burden. Thank you, Jane.”
He paused, looking at me; words hovered on his lips, but he stopped himself.

“Goodnight again, sir. You owe me nothing.”
“I knew you’d help me somehow, someday; I saw it in your eyes when we first met. Their look and smile weren’t meaningless.” Again he paused, then continued quickly, “People talk about natural sympathies; I’ve heard of guardian spirits. Even wild stories have some truth. Thank you, my cherished savior—goodnight!”
His words and expression were intense and passionate.
“I’m simply glad I was awake,” I replied, preparing to go.
“What! are you going?”
“I’m cold, sir.”
“Cold? In that case, and standing in a puddle, go, Jane!” But he still held on to my hand and wouldn’t let go. I thought of a way out.
“I think I hear Mrs. Fairfax stirring, sir,” I said.
“Fine, you can go,” he said, letting me loose, and I left.

I returned to my bed, but couldn’t sleep. Restlessly, I tossed in anxiety and troubled happiness until morning. Sometimes I thought I could see a sweet, hopeful shore beyond the turbulent sea in my mind, and hope would lift my spirits, but reality always brought me back. My reason restrained my feelings. Too restless to sleep, I got up as soon as daylight appeared.

events.title: Anxious Morning and Grace Poole's Unsettling Calm
detailed_summary: Jane experiences a mix of anticipation and apprehension about encountering Mr. Rochester following the previous night's dramatic events.
She expects him to visit the schoolroom, but the morning proceeds normally.
Jane overhears the servants discussing the fire in Mr. Rochester's room, expressing relief he wasn't harmed and commenting on the danger of lit candles and his presence of mind with the water-jug.
Later, Jane observes that Mr. Rochester's room has been tidied, though the bed hangings are gone.
She sees Leah cleaning smoke-dimmed windows and, upon entering further, discovers Grace Poole calmly sewing new curtain rings by the bedside.

Jane is astonished by Grace's composed demeanor, noting her usual staid appearance and lack of any sign of guilt or fear, despite Jane's belief that Grace attempted murder and was confronted by Mr. Rochester.
Grace Poole looks up at Jane without any emotional reaction and offers a standard, placid greeting before resuming her sewing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I both wished and feared to see Mr. Rochester on the day which followed this sleepless night: I wanted to hear his voice again, yet feared to meet his eye.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She said “Good morning, Miss,” in her usual phlegmatic and brief manner; and taking up another ring and more tape, went on with her sewing.

events.text_segment:
I both wished and feared to see Mr. Rochester on the day which followed this sleepless night: I wanted to hear his voice again, yet feared to meet his eye. During the early part of the morning, I momentarily expected his coming; he was not in the frequent habit of entering the schoolroom, but he did step in for a few minutes sometimes, and I had the impression that he was sure to visit it that day.
But the morning passed just as usual: nothing happened to interrupt the quiet course of Adèle’s studies; only soon after breakfast, I heard some bustle in the neighbourhood of Mr. Rochester’s chamber, Mrs. Fairfax’s voice, and Leah’s, and the cook’s—that is, John’s wife—and even John’s own gruff tones. There were exclamations of “What a mercy master was not burnt in his bed!” “It is always dangerous to keep a candle lit at night.” “How providential that he had presence of mind to think of the water-jug!” “I wonder he waked nobody!” “It is to be hoped he will not take cold with sleeping on the library sofa,” &c.
To much confabulation succeeded a sound of scrubbing and setting to rights; and when I passed the room, in going downstairs to dinner, I saw through the open door that all was again restored to complete order; only the bed was stripped of its hangings. Leah stood up in the window-seat, rubbing the panes of glass dimmed with smoke. I was about to address her, for I wished to know what account had been given of the affair: but, on advancing, I saw a second person in the chamber—a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains. That woman was no other than Grace Poole.
There she sat, staid and taciturn-looking, as usual, in her brown stuff gown, her check apron, white handkerchief, and cap. She was intent on her work, in which her whole thoughts seemed absorbed: on her hard forehead, and in her commonplace features, was nothing either of the paleness or desperation one would have expected to see marking the countenance of a woman who had attempted murder, and whose intended victim had followed her last night to her lair, and (as I believed), charged her with the crime she wished to perpetrate. I was amazed—confounded. She looked up, while I still gazed at her: no start, no increase or failure of colour betrayed emotion, consciousness of guilt, or fear of detection. She said “Good morning, Miss,” in her usual phlegmatic and brief manner; and taking up another ring and more tape, went on with her sewing.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
The day after that sleepless night, I felt a mix of anticipation and apprehension about seeing Mr. Rochester. I longed to hear his voice again but was hesitant to look him in the eye. Throughout the early part of the morning, I kept expecting him to appear. He didn't often visit the schoolroom, but he occasionally stopped by for a few minutes, and I had a strong feeling he would do so today.
However, the morning proceeded just as usual, with nothing disturbing the routine of Adele's lessons. The only unusual thing was, shortly after breakfast, I heard a commotion near Mr. Rochester's room. I could hear the voices of Mrs. Fairfax, Leah, the cook (John's wife), and even John's rough voice. They were exclaiming things like, "It's a miracle master wasn't burned alive in his bed!" "It's always risky leaving a candle lit at night." "How fortunate he was quick-witted enough to think of using the water jug!" "I can't believe he didn't wake anyone!" "Hopefully, he won't catch a cold from sleeping on the library sofa," and similar remarks.
After a lot of chatter, I heard sounds of cleaning and tidying up. When I went downstairs for dinner and passed the room, I saw through the open door that everything was back in perfect order, except the bed no longer had its curtains. Leah was standing on the window seat, wiping the smoke-stained glass. I was about to speak to her, wanting to know what explanation was being given for the incident, but as I stepped closer, I noticed a second person in the room. It was a woman sitting on a chair by the bed, sewing rings onto new curtains. This woman was Grace Poole.
She sat there, looking as serious and quiet as ever, dressed in her usual brown dress, checked apron, white handkerchief, and cap. She was completely focused on her sewing, her mind seemingly absorbed in the work. On her stern forehead and ordinary face, there was no trace of the paleness or desperation one might expect from a woman who had tried to commit murder, whose intended victim had (as I believed) followed her to her room the previous night and accused her of the crime she planned. I was astonished and confused. She looked up while I was still staring at her. There was no sudden movement, no change in her complexion to show emotion, awareness of guilt, or fear of being caught. She simply said, "Good morning, Miss," in her typically calm and brief way, then picked up another ring and more tape and went back to her sewing.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After a sleepless night, I felt both anxious and eager to see Mr. Rochester the next day: I longed to hear him speak, but was nervous about meeting his gaze. Throughout the early morning, I repeatedly thought he might appear—though he rarely came into the schoolroom, he occasionally did for a short while, and I was convinced he would do so that day. Nevertheless, the morning unfolded as it always did—Adèle's lessons carried on without disturbance. Shortly after breakfast, however, I heard a commotion near Mr. Rochester’s room. Mrs. Fairfax, Leah, the cook (John’s wife), and even John himself were there, all talking. They were saying things like, "It's a miracle the master wasn't burned in his bed!" "It's risky to leave a candle burning overnight." "Thank goodness he thought to use the water-jug!" and "Surprising no one woke up!" as well as wishing he wouldn't catch cold after having to sleep on the library sofa.

After their conversation, I could hear cleaning noises, things being restored to normal. On my way down to lunch, I glanced through the open door of Mr. Rochester’s room, noting that order had returned—apart from the missing bedhangings. Leah was polishing the smoke-stained window glass. I intended to ask her about what had happened, but noticed a second figure—a woman seated by the bed, attaching rings to new curtains. It was Grace Poole.

She sat there, quiet and composed as always, dressed in her brown dress, checkered apron, white scarf, and cap. She seemed utterly focused on her sewing, with no sign of paleness or agitation that would suggest guilt—a surprising thing, since I believed she had tried to murder Mr. Rochester and had been confronted by him the night before. I was stunned and could hardly believe it. She glanced up at me, but her face showed no alarm, no change in color, no hint of fear or guilt. Calmly, she greeted me as usual, then continued her work without pause.

events.title: Jane Confronts Grace Poole: A Battle of Wits
detailed_summary: Jane resolves to probe Grace Poole's seemingly impenetrable composure.
She inquires if anything happened, mentioning the servants' earlier talk.
Grace calmly explains that Mr. Rochester fell asleep reading with a lit candle, causing the curtains to catch fire, but he managed to extinguish it with water.
Jane, skeptical, quietly asks if Mr. Rochester woke anyone or if anyone heard him.
Grace, examining Jane warily, suggests the servants sleep too far away and that Mrs. Fairfax, being elderly, sleeps heavily.
Grace then pointedly suggests that Jane, being young and a light sleeper, might have heard something.
Jane admits she heard a noise, initially thinking it was the dog Pilot, but then clarifies she is certain she heard a strange laugh.
Grace, maintaining perfect composure, dismisses this, stating it's unlikely Mr. Rochester would laugh in such danger and suggests Jane must have been dreaming.
Jane, provoked by Grace's coolness, insists she was not dreaming.
Grace inquires if Jane has told Mr. Rochester about the laugh, and if Jane looked out into the gallery.
Jane, suspecting Grace is trying to discover what she knows, states she bolted her door.
Grace then questions Jane's usual habit of bolting her door, making Jane suspect Grace is planning something and wants to know her routines.
Jane, angered, retorts that she previously didn't feel the need to bolt her door but will ensure it's secure in the future.

Grace agrees this is wise, delivering a lengthy, demure speech about the general quietness of the neighborhood, the value of the house's contents, the few servants, and the wisdom of taking precautions like bolting doors, rather than solely relying on Providence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I will put her to some test,” thought I: “such absolute impenetrability is past comprehension.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And here she closed her harangue: a long one for her, and uttered with the demureness of a Quakeress.

events.text_segment:
“I will put her to some test,” thought I: “such absolute impenetrability is past comprehension.”
“Good morning, Grace,” I said. “Has anything happened here? I thought I heard the servants all talking together a while ago.”
“Only master had been reading in his bed last night; he fell asleep with his candle lit, and the curtains got on fire; but, fortunately, he awoke before the bed-clothes or the wood-work caught, and contrived to quench the flames with the water in the ewer.”
“A strange affair!” I said, in a low voice: then, looking at her fixedly—“Did Mr. Rochester wake nobody? Did no one hear him move?”
She again raised her eyes to me, and this time there was something of consciousness in their expression. She seemed to examine me warily; then she answered—
“The servants sleep so far off, you know, Miss, they would not be likely to hear. Mrs. Fairfax’s room and yours are the nearest to master’s; but Mrs. Fairfax said she heard nothing: when people get elderly, they often sleep heavy.” She paused, and then added, with a sort of assumed indifference, but still in a marked and significant tone—“But you are young, Miss; and I should say a light sleeper: perhaps you may have heard a noise?”
“I did,” said I, dropping my voice, so that Leah, who was still polishing the panes, could not hear me, “and at first I thought it was Pilot: but Pilot cannot laugh; and I am certain I heard a laugh, and a strange one.”
She took a new needleful of thread, waxed it carefully, threaded her needle with a steady hand, and then observed, with perfect composure—
“It is hardly likely master would laugh, I should think, Miss, when he was in such danger: You must have been dreaming.”
“I was not dreaming,” I said, with some warmth, for her brazen coolness provoked me. Again she looked at me; and with the same scrutinising and conscious eye.
“Have you told master that you heard a laugh?” she inquired.
“I have not had the opportunity of speaking to him this morning.”
“You did not think of opening your door and looking out into the gallery?” she further asked.
She appeared to be cross-questioning me, attempting to draw from me information unawares. The idea struck me that if she discovered I knew or suspected her guilt, she would be playing of some of her malignant pranks on me; I thought it advisable to be on my guard.
“On the contrary,” said I, “I bolted my door.”
“Then you are not in the habit of bolting your door every night before you get into bed?”
“Fiend! she wants to know my habits, that she may lay her plans accordingly!” Indignation again prevailed over prudence: I replied sharply, “Hitherto I have often omitted to fasten the bolt: I did not think it necessary. I was not aware any danger or annoyance was to be dreaded at Thornfield Hall: but in future” (and I laid marked stress on the words) “I shall take good care to make all secure before I venture to lie down.”
“It will be wise so to do,” was her answer: “this neighbourhood is as quiet as any I know, and I never heard of the hall being attempted by robbers since it was a house; though there are hundreds of pounds’ worth of plate in the plate-closet, as is well known. And you see, for such a large house, there are very few servants, because master has never lived here much; and when he does come, being a bachelor, he needs little waiting on: but I always think it best to err on the safe side; a door is soon fastened, and it is as well to have a drawn bolt between one and any mischief that may be about. A deal of people, Miss, are for trusting all to Providence; but I say Providence will not dispense with the means, though He often blesses them when they are used discreetly.” And here she closed her harangue: a long one for her, and uttered with the demureness of a Quakeress.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I decided to test her, thinking, "Such total lack of reaction is impossible to understand." I greeted her, "Good morning, Grace. Did something happen? I thought I heard all the servants talking earlier." She replied, "Master was reading in bed last night and fell asleep with his candle lit. The curtains caught fire, but luckily, he woke up before the bedding or wood caught and managed to put out the flames with the water from the ewer." I murmured, "A strange event!" Then, looking directly at her, I asked, "Did Mr. Rochester not wake anyone? Did no one hear him?" She looked up at me again, and this time there was a hint of awareness in her expression. She seemed to study me cautiously before answering, "The servants sleep quite far away, Miss, so they likely wouldn't hear. Mrs. Fairfax's room and yours are closest to master's, but Mrs. Fairfax said she heard nothing. Older people often sleep soundly." She paused, then added with a seemingly casual but pointed tone, "But you are young, Miss, and I imagine you're a light sleeper. Perhaps you heard a noise?" "I did," I said, lowering my voice so Leah, who was still cleaning the windows, couldn't hear. "At first, I thought it was Pilot, but Pilot doesn't laugh, and I'm certain I heard a laugh, and it was a strange one." She picked up a new length of thread, waxed it carefully, threaded her needle steadily, and then commented with complete calm, "It's not very likely master would be laughing when he was in such danger, I think, Miss. You must have been dreaming." "I was not dreaming," I said, feeling a surge of annoyance at her cool insolence. She looked at me again with the same searching, knowing gaze. "Have you told master that you heard a laugh?" she asked. "I haven't had a chance to speak to him this morning." "You didn't consider opening your door and looking into the gallery?" she pressed. She seemed to be questioning me closely, trying to trick me into revealing information. It occurred to me that if she realised I knew or suspected her involvement, she might try some of her malicious tricks on me. I thought it best to be cautious. "On the contrary," I said, "I bolted my door." "So you don't usually bolt your door every night before bed?" "Villain!" I thought, "She wants to know my habits to plan her schemes!" Indignation overcame caution again. I replied sharply, "Until now, I often forgot to fasten the bolt; I didn't think it necessary. I wasn't aware of any danger or trouble to fear at Thornfield Hall, but from now on" (and I emphasised these words) "I will make sure everything is secure before I lie down." "That would be a sensible thing to do," she replied. "This area is as quiet as any I know, and I've never heard of anyone trying to rob the hall since it was built, even though there are hundreds of pounds worth of silver plate, as everyone knows. And you see, for such a large house, there are very few servants because master hasn't lived here much, and when he does come, being a bachelor, he doesn't need much waiting on. But I always think it's better to be safe than sorry; a door is quickly fastened, and it's wise to have a bolted door between you and any potential trouble. Many people, Miss, rely entirely on Providence, but I say Providence helps those who help themselves, though He often blesses careful efforts." With that, she finished her speech, which was unusually long for her and delivered with the solemnity of a Quaker.
