events.title: Jane's Puzzlement Over Grace and Eager Anticipation for Rochester
detailed_summary: As Jane stands dumbfounded by Grace's self-possession, the cook enters to announce dinner for the servants.
Grace Poole requests her pint of porter, pudding, a bit of meat, and cheese to be sent up on a tray, declining to come down for sago at that time.
The cook then informs Jane that Mrs. Fairfax is waiting for her, prompting Jane's departure.
During dinner, Jane is too preoccupied with Grace Poole's enigmatic character and her unaccountable position at Thornfield to pay much attention to Mrs. Fairfax's account of the fire.
She wonders why Mr. Rochester hasn't had Grace arrested or dismissed, especially after seemingly acknowledging her guilt the previous night, and why he has sworn Jane to secrecy.
Jane puzzles over the hold Grace seems to have over the proud Mr. Rochester, preventing him from acting even when his life was threatened.

She briefly considers if a past romantic connection could explain it, but dismisses the idea due to Grace's plain and matronly appearance, though she muses on Grace's potential past youth and strong character.
A fleeting thought suggests Mr. Rochester might appreciate her, Jane, despite her lack of conventional beauty, recalling his recent kind words and manner.
Adèle, noticing Jane's flushed cheeks and trembling fingers, asks what is wrong.
Jane attributes her state to the heat from stooping, while her thoughts continue to race.
She forces herself to reject the degrading suspicions about Grace Poole, affirming her own sense of self-worth as a 'lady,' and noting her improved appearance and spirits due to brighter hopes.
As evening nears, Jane’s earlier fear of meeting Mr. Rochester transforms into an impatient desire, driven by unfulfilled expectation and a wish to discuss Grace Poole.

She eagerly anticipates his summons, wanting to question him directly about Grace's alleged attempt on his life and his reasons for secrecy, feeling confident in her ability to navigate such a conversation without overstepping.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I still stood absolutely dumfoundered at what appeared to me her miraculous self-possession and most inscrutable hypocrisy, when the cook entered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Retaining every minute form of respect, every propriety of my station, I could still meet him in argument without fear or uneasy restraint; this suited both him and me.

events.text_segment:
I still stood absolutely dumfoundered at what appeared to me her miraculous self-possession and most inscrutable hypocrisy, when the cook entered.
“Mrs. Poole,” said she, addressing Grace, “the servants’ dinner will soon be ready: will you come down?”
“No; just put my pint of porter and bit of pudding on a tray, and I’ll carry it upstairs.”
“You’ll have some meat?”
“Just a morsel, and a taste of cheese, that’s all.”
“And the sago?”
“Never mind it at present: I shall be coming down before teatime: I’ll make it myself.”
The cook here turned to me, saying that Mrs. Fairfax was waiting for me: so I departed.
I hardly heard Mrs. Fairfax’s account of the curtain conflagration during dinner, so much was I occupied in puzzling my brains over the enigmatical character of Grace Poole, and still more in pondering the problem of her position at Thornfield and questioning why she had not been given into custody that morning, or, at the very least, dismissed from her master’s service. He had almost as much as declared his conviction of her criminality last night: what mysterious cause withheld him from accusing her? Why had he enjoined me, too, to secrecy? It was strange: a bold, vindictive, and haughty gentleman seemed somehow in the power of one of the meanest of his dependents; so much in her power, that even when she lifted her hand against his life, he dared not openly charge her with the attempt, much less punish her for it.
Had Grace been young and handsome, I should have been tempted to think that tenderer feelings than prudence or fear influenced Mr. Rochester in her behalf; but, hard-favoured and matronly as she was, the idea could not be admitted. “Yet,” I reflected, “she has been young once; her youth would be contemporary with her master’s: Mrs. Fairfax told me once, she had lived here many years. I don’t think she can ever have been pretty; but, for aught I know, she may possess originality and strength of character to compensate for the want of personal advantages. Mr. Rochester is an amateur of the decided and eccentric: Grace is eccentric at least. What if a former caprice (a freak very possible to a nature so sudden and headstrong as his) has delivered him into her power, and she now exercises over his actions a secret influence, the result of his own indiscretion, which he cannot shake off, and dare not disregard?” But, having reached this point of conjecture, Mrs. Poole’s square, flat figure, and uncomely, dry, even coarse face, recurred so distinctly to my mind’s eye, that I thought, “No; impossible! my supposition cannot be correct. Yet,” suggested the secret voice which talks to us in our own hearts, “you are not beautiful either, and perhaps Mr. Rochester approves you: at any rate, you have often felt as if he did; and last night—remember his words; remember his look; remember his voice!”
I well remembered all; language, glance, and tone seemed at the moment vividly renewed. I was now in the schoolroom; Adèle was drawing; I bent over her and directed her pencil. She looked up with a sort of start.
“Qu’avez-vous, mademoiselle?” said she. “Vos doigts tremblent comme la feuille, et vos joues sont rouges: mais, rouges comme des cerises!”
“I am hot, Adèle, with stooping!” She went on sketching; I went on thinking.
I hastened to drive from my mind the hateful notion I had been conceiving respecting Grace Poole; it disgusted me. I compared myself with her, and found we were different. Bessie Leaven had said I was quite a lady; and she spoke truth—I was a lady. And now I looked much better than I did when Bessie saw me; I had more colour and more flesh, more life, more vivacity, because I had brighter hopes and keener enjoyments.
“Evening approaches,” said I, as I looked towards the window. “I have never heard Mr. Rochester’s voice or step in the house to-day; but surely I shall see him before night: I feared the meeting in the morning; now I desire it, because expectation has been so long baffled that it is grown impatient.”
When dusk actually closed, and when Adèle left me to go and play in the nursery with Sophie, I did most keenly desire it. I listened for the bell to ring below; I listened for Leah coming up with a message; I fancied sometimes I heard Mr. Rochester’s own tread, and I turned to the door, expecting it to open and admit him. The door remained shut; darkness only came in through the window. Still it was not late; he often sent for me at seven and eight o’clock, and it was yet but six. Surely I should not be wholly disappointed to-night, when I had so many things to say to him! I wanted again to introduce the subject of Grace Poole, and to hear what he would answer; I wanted to ask him plainly if he really believed it was she who had made last night’s hideous attempt; and if so, why he kept her wickedness a secret. It little mattered whether my curiosity irritated him; I knew the pleasure of vexing and soothing him by turns; it was one I chiefly delighted in, and a sure instinct always prevented me from going too far; beyond the verge of provocation I never ventured; on the extreme brink I liked well to try my skill. Retaining every minute form of respect, every propriety of my station, I could still meet him in argument without fear or uneasy restraint; this suited both him and me.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I remained utterly astonished by what seemed to me her incredible composure and highly mysterious deceitfulness when the cook came in. “Mrs. Poole,” the cook said, speaking to Grace, “the servants’ dinner is almost ready; will you come down?” “No; just place my small measure of porter and a bit of dessert on a tray, and I will take it up myself.” “Would you like some meat?” “Just a tiny piece, and a taste of cheese, that’s all.” “And the sago?” “Don’t worry about it for now; I’ll be coming downstairs before evening tea and I’ll make it myself then.” At this point, the cook turned to me, saying Mrs. Fairfax was waiting for me, so I left. I barely paid attention to Mrs. Fairfax’s description of the curtain fire during dinner, as I was so preoccupied trying to figure out Grace Poole’s puzzling nature, and even more so pondering her status at Thornfield and questioning why she hadn’t been arrested that morning, or at the very least, dismissed from her employer’s service. Last night, he had practically stated his certainty of her guilt; what unknown reason stopped him from accusing her? Why had he also told me to keep it a secret? It was odd: a brave, vengeful, and proud gentleman appeared to be somewhat under the control of one of his lowest employees; so much so, that even when she attempted to harm him, he didn’t dare to publicly accuse her of the act, much less punish her for it. If Grace had been young and attractive, I might have suspected that gentler feelings than caution or fear influenced Mr. Rochester’s actions regarding her; but, given her plain and mature appearance, that idea couldn’t be entertained. “However,” I thought, “she was young once; her youth would have coincided with her master’s. Mrs. Fairfax once mentioned she had been here for many years. I don’t believe she could ever have been pretty, but for all I know, she might possess originality and strength of character to make up for a lack of physical appeal. Mr. Rochester appreciates decisive and unusual personalities; Grace is certainly unusual. What if a past whim (an impulse quite likely for a nature as sudden and impulsive as his) has placed him under her control, and she now exerts a hidden influence over his actions, a consequence of his own mistake, which he cannot break free from and dares not ignore?” But, having reached this point of speculation, Mrs. Poole’s stout, flat figure and unattractive, harsh, even common face came back so clearly to my mind’s eye that I concluded, “No; impossible! My assumption cannot be right. Yet,” whispered the inner voice that speaks within our hearts, “you aren’t beautiful either, and perhaps Mr. Rochester approves of you; at any rate, you have often felt as if he did; and last night—remember his words; remember his look; remember his voice!” I recalled everything clearly; his language, gaze, and tone seemed vividly present at that moment. I was now in the classroom; Adèle was drawing; I leaned over her and guided her pencil. She looked up with a slight start. “What is wrong, miss?” she asked. “Your fingers are trembling like a leaf, and your cheeks are red—but, red like cherries!” “I am warm, Adèle, from bending down!” She resumed her drawing; I continued my thinking. I hurried to rid my mind of the unpleasant idea I had been considering about Grace Poole; it disgusted me. I compared myself to her and found we were different. Bessie Leaven had said I was quite a lady; and she was right—I was a lady. And now I looked much better than when Bessie saw me; I had more colour and fullness, more vitality, more spirit, because my hopes were brighter and my joys were keener. “Evening is approaching,” I remarked, looking towards the window. “I haven’t heard Mr. Rochester’s voice or footsteps in the house today; but surely I will see him before night. I dreaded meeting him this morning; now I wish for it, because the waiting has been so prolonged that it has become impatient.” When darkness actually fell, and Adèle left me to play in the nursery with Sophie, I did indeed intensely desire it. I listened for the bell ringing below; I listened for Leah coming up with a message; I sometimes imagined I heard Mr. Rochester’s own step, and I turned to the door, expecting it to open and let him in. The door stayed shut; only darkness entered through the window. Still, it wasn’t late; he often sent for me at seven or eight o’clock, and it was only six. Surely I wouldn’t be completely disappointed tonight, when I had so much I wanted to say to him! I wanted to bring up the topic of Grace Poole again and hear his answer; I wanted to ask him directly if he truly believed it was she who had made that dreadful attempt last night; and if so, why he was keeping her wickedness a secret. It hardly mattered if my curiosity annoyed him; I knew the pleasure of irritating and then calming him in turn; it was one I particularly enjoyed, and a reliable intuition always prevented me from going too far; I never ventured beyond the point of provocation; I liked to test my skill on the very edge. Maintaining every small detail of respect, every proper aspect of my position, I could still engage him in discussion without fear or uncomfortable restraint; this suited both him and me.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I remained completely astonished by Grace Poole's extraordinary calmness and her mysterious dishonesty, when the cook came in and asked Grace to come down for the servants' dinner. Grace declined, asking instead for her meal to be sent up on a tray, specifying what she wanted and saying she would return later to prepare some sago herself. The cook then told me Mrs. Fairfax was waiting, so I left. Throughout dinner, I barely listened to Mrs. Fairfax’s explanation of the fire in the curtains; my mind was preoccupied with wondering about Grace Poole's secretive nature and her presence at Thornfield. I couldn't understand why she hadn't been fired or arrested after Mr. Rochester’s implied accusation the previous night, or why he asked me to keep quiet about it. It was odd that such a powerful man seemed under the sway of one of his lowliest employees, to the point of not punishing her openly after such a serious incident. If Grace had been attractive, I might have thought Mr. Rochester was influenced by affection, but given her plain appearance, that idea seemed impossible. Still, I wondered if some past mistake had given her power over him, explaining his reluctance to confront her. But when I considered her unremarkable looks again, the idea seemed implausible. Yet, an inner voice reminded me I wasn't beautiful either, and perhaps Mr. Rochester liked me nevertheless, especially considering his words and behavior the previous evening, which I remembered vividly. While in the schoolroom with Adèle drawing, she noticed my trembling hands and flushed cheeks, which I blamed on bending over her work. Ashamed of my unpleasant thoughts about Grace, I reassured myself of our differences and my own improved appearance and spirits since arriving at Thornfield. As evening approached, I realized Mr. Rochester had not been seen all day but hoped to see him before nightfall. As it got dark and Adèle left, I grew more eager to see him, listening for sounds of his coming. When he didn’t appear, I thought about all the things I wanted to discuss with him, particularly about Grace Poole and why he kept her actions secret, even though it might annoy him. I enjoyed our conversations and debates, always making sure not to push him too far, maintaining proper respect while still engaging him intellectually, a dynamic that suited us both.

events.title: Mr. Rochester's Sudden Departure and Disquieting News
detailed_summary: Jane hears footsteps and Leah appears, not with a message from Mr. Rochester, but to say tea is ready in Mrs. Fairfax's room.
Jane goes downstairs, hoping it brings her closer to Mr. Rochester's presence.
Mrs. Fairfax remarks on Jane's small appetite at dinner and her flushed, feverish appearance, expressing concern for her well-being.
Jane insists she feels perfectly well.
As Mrs. Fairfax draws the blind against the deepening dusk, she casually mentions Mr. Rochester has had a favorable day for his journey.
Jane is shocked, stating she was unaware he had gone out.
Mrs. Fairfax explains that Mr. Rochester left immediately after breakfast for the Leas, Mr. Eshton's estate, about ten miles away.
She mentions a large party is assembled there, including notable figures like Lord Ingram and Sir George Lynn.
When Jane asks if he'll return that night, Mrs. Fairfax replies that he likely won't return for a week or more, as such fashionable gatherings tend to last.

Mrs. Fairfax adds that gentlemen like Mr. Rochester, who is talented and lively, are usually in high demand at such social events, suggesting he is a general favorite, especially with ladies, his social skills and status compensating for any perceived lack in appearance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A tread creaked on the stairs at last.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Gentlemen especially are often in request on such occasions; and Mr. Rochester is so talented and so lively in society, that I believe he is a general favourite: the ladies are very fond of him; though you would not think his appearance calculated to recommend him particularly in their eyes: but I suppose his acquirements and abilities, perhaps his wealth and good blood, make amends for any little fault of look.”

events.text_segment:
A tread creaked on the stairs at last. Leah made her appearance; but it was only to intimate that tea was ready in Mrs. Fairfax’s room. Thither I repaired, glad at least to go downstairs; for that brought me, I imagined, nearer to Mr. Rochester’s presence.
“You must want your tea,” said the good lady, as I joined her; “you ate so little at dinner. I am afraid,” she continued, “you are not well to-day: you look flushed and feverish.”
“Oh, quite well! I never felt better.”
“Then you must prove it by evincing a good appetite; will you fill the teapot while I knit off this needle?” Having completed her task, she rose to draw down the blind, which she had hitherto kept up, by way, I suppose, of making the most of daylight, though dusk was now fast deepening into total obscurity.
“It is fair to-night,” said she, as she looked through the panes, “though not starlight; Mr. Rochester has, on the whole, had a favourable day for his journey.”
“Journey!—Is Mr. Rochester gone anywhere? I did not know he was out.”
“Oh, he set off the moment he had breakfasted! He is gone to the Leas, Mr. Eshton’s place, ten miles on the other side Millcote. I believe there is quite a party assembled there; Lord Ingram, Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and others.”
“Do you expect him back to-night?”
“No—nor to-morrow either; I should think he is very likely to stay a week or more: when these fine, fashionable people get together, they are so surrounded by elegance and gaiety, so well provided with all that can please and entertain, they are in no hurry to separate. Gentlemen especially are often in request on such occasions; and Mr. Rochester is so talented and so lively in society, that I believe he is a general favourite: the ladies are very fond of him; though you would not think his appearance calculated to recommend him particularly in their eyes: but I suppose his acquirements and abilities, perhaps his wealth and good blood, make amends for any little fault of look.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Finally, footsteps were heard on the stairs. Leah showed up, but only to let me know that tea was ready in Mrs. Fairfax's room. I went there, glad simply to be going downstairs, as I thought it might bring me nearer to where Mr. Rochester was. "You must be hungry," the kind lady said when I arrived; "you hardly ate anything at dinner. I'm afraid," she continued, "you don't look well today; you seem flushed and to have a fever." "Oh, I'm perfectly fine! I've never felt better." "Then prove it by showing a good appetite; would you please fill the teapot while I finish this row?" After finishing, she got up to lower the blind, which she had kept open, presumably to take advantage of the light, even though twilight was now quickly turning into complete darkness. "The weather is good tonight," she remarked, looking out, "although there are no stars; Mr. Rochester generally had a favorable day for his travels." "Travels! Has Mr. Rochester gone somewhere? I didn't know he had left." "Oh, he left right after breakfast! He's gone to the Leas, Mr. Eshton's estate, ten miles beyond Millcote. I understand there's quite a gathering there; Lord Ingram, Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and others." "Do you expect him back tonight?" "No, not tonight or tomorrow either; I expect he'll probably stay for a week or longer: when elegant, fashionable people gather, they enjoy such sophistication and fun, with everything needed for pleasure and entertainment, so they aren't quick to leave. Gentlemen are particularly in demand at these times; and Mr. Rochester is so witty and engaging socially that I think he is very well-liked by everyone: the ladies are quite fond of him; even though you might not think his appearance would specifically appeal to them: but I imagine his knowledge and abilities, perhaps his money and good family name, make up for any slight physical flaws.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Eventually, a footstep was heard on the stairs. Leah appeared, but only to let me know that tea was ready in Mrs. Fairfax’s room. I went downstairs, happy for the chance, as I thought it might bring me closer to Mr. Rochester.

"You must want your tea," Mrs. Fairfax said when I joined her, "since you ate so little at dinner. I hope you’re not feeling unwell; you look a bit flushed."

"Oh, I’m quite well, never better," I replied.

"Well, you’ll have to prove it by eating well; will you pour the tea while I finish my knitting?" She soon finished and got up to pull down the blind, which had been left up to get as much daylight as possible, although it was now almost completely dark outside.

"It’s a fair night," she commented while looking through the window, "though there are no stars. Mr. Rochester had good weather for his journey." 

"Journey? Has Mr. Rochester gone somewhere? I didn’t realize he was out."

"He left right after breakfast," she explained. "He’s gone to the Leas, Mr. Eshton’s estate, about ten miles past Millcote. There’s a party there—Lord Ingram, Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and others."

"Will he be back tonight?"

"No, nor tomorrow, I expect. He’ll likely be gone for at least a week. When people of fashion gather like that, with so much to entertain and amuse them, they rarely want to part quickly. The gentlemen especially are in great demand, and Mr. Rochester is so lively and talented in company that he’s very popular. The ladies are very fond of him, though you wouldn’t think his looks alone would appeal to them, but I suppose his accomplishments, intelligence, and perhaps his fortune and family compensate for any lack of handsomeness."

events.title: The Dazzling Description of Blanche Ingram
detailed_summary: Jane inquires if there are ladies present at the Leas.
Mrs. Fairfax confirms the presence of Mrs. Eshton and her daughters, and notably, the Honourable Blanche and Mary Ingram, whom she describes as very beautiful.
She recalls seeing Blanche Ingram six or seven years prior, at age eighteen, during a Christmas ball Mr. Rochester hosted.

Mrs. Fairfax paints a picture of a lavishly decorated and brilliantly lit dining room filled with about fifty guests from prominent county families, with Miss Ingram being the undisputed 'belle of the evening.'

Prompted by Jane, Mrs. Fairfax provides a detailed description of Blanche Ingram's appearance: tall with a fine bust and sloping shoulders, a long, graceful neck, an olive complexion that was dark and clear, noble features, and large, black, brilliant eyes similar to Mr. Rochester's.
She further describes Blanche's magnificent raven-black hair, styled with a crown of thick plaits and long, glossy curls.
Blanche was dressed in pure white, with an amber-colored scarf artfully arranged across her shoulder and breast, and an amber flower in her hair that complemented her dark curls.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Are there ladies at the Leas?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She wore an amber-coloured flower, too, in her hair: it contrasted well with the jetty mass of her curls.”

events.text_segment:
“Are there ladies at the Leas?”
“There are Mrs. Eshton and her three daughters—very elegant young ladies indeed; and there are the Honourable Blanche and Mary Ingram, most beautiful women, I suppose: indeed I have seen Blanche, six or seven years since, when she was a girl of eighteen. She came here to a Christmas ball and party Mr. Rochester gave. You should have seen the dining-room that day—how richly it was decorated, how brilliantly lit up! I should think there were fifty ladies and gentlemen present—all of the first county families; and Miss Ingram was considered the belle of the evening.”
“You saw her, you say, Mrs. Fairfax: what was she like?”
“Yes, I saw her. The dining-room doors were thrown open; and, as it was Christmas-time, the servants were allowed to assemble in the hall, to hear some of the ladies sing and play. Mr. Rochester would have me to come in, and I sat down in a quiet corner and watched them. I never saw a more splendid scene: the ladies were magnificently dressed; most of them—at least most of the younger ones—looked handsome; but Miss Ingram was certainly the queen.”
“And what was she like?”
“Tall, fine bust, sloping shoulders; long, graceful neck: olive complexion, dark and clear; noble features; eyes rather like Mr. Rochester’s: large and black, and as brilliant as her jewels. And then she had such a fine head of hair; raven-black and so becomingly arranged: a crown of thick plaits behind, and in front the longest, the glossiest curls I ever saw. She was dressed in pure white; an amber-coloured scarf was passed over her shoulder and across her breast, tied at the side, and descending in long, fringed ends below her knee. She wore an amber-coloured flower, too, in her hair: it contrasted well with the jetty mass of her curls.”

events.title: Blanche's Talents and Speculation on Rochester's Interest
detailed_summary: Jane asks if Blanche Ingram was greatly admired.
Mrs. Fairfax confirms she was, not only for her beauty but also for her accomplishments, noting that Blanche sang, accompanied by a gentleman on the piano.
Crucially, Mrs. Fairfax reveals that Blanche and Mr. Rochester sang a duet together.
Jane expresses surprise, as she was unaware Mr. Rochester could sing, to which Mrs. Fairfax praises his fine bass voice and excellent musical taste.

Regarding Miss Ingram's voice, Mrs. Fairfax describes it as very rich and powerful, stating she sang delightfully and also played music afterwards, which Mr. Rochester, a good judge, deemed remarkably good.
Jane then inquires why such a beautiful and accomplished lady is not yet married.
Mrs. Fairfax speculates it might be due to a lack of large fortunes for her and her sister, as the family estates were mostly entailed to the eldest son.
Jane wonders why no wealthy nobleman, such as Mr. Rochester himself, has taken an interest in her, given his riches.
Mrs. Fairfax acknowledges Mr. Rochester's wealth but points out the considerable age difference, with him being nearly forty and Blanche only twenty-five.
Jane dismisses the age gap as insignificant, noting more unequal matches occur daily.

Mrs. Fairfax, while conceding the point, expresses doubt that Mr. Rochester would consider such a union, then changes the subject by observing Jane's lack of appetite and Jane requests another cup of tea.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “She was greatly admired, of course?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “No: I am too thirsty to eat. Will you let me have another cup?”

events.text_segment:
“She was greatly admired, of course?”
“Yes, indeed: and not only for her beauty, but for her accomplishments. She was one of the ladies who sang: a gentleman accompanied her on the piano. She and Mr. Rochester sang a duet.”
“Mr. Rochester? I was not aware he could sing.”
“Oh! he has a fine bass voice, and an excellent taste for music.”
“And Miss Ingram: what sort of a voice had she?”
“A very rich and powerful one: she sang delightfully; it was a treat to listen to her;—and she played afterwards. I am no judge of music, but Mr. Rochester is; and I heard him say her execution was remarkably good.”
“And this beautiful and accomplished lady, she is not yet married?”
“It appears not: I fancy neither she nor her sister have very large fortunes. Old Lord Ingram’s estates were chiefly entailed, and the eldest son came in for everything almost.”
“But I wonder no wealthy nobleman or gentleman has taken a fancy to her: Mr. Rochester, for instance. He is rich, is he not?”
“Oh! yes. But you see there is a considerable difference in age: Mr. Rochester is nearly forty; she is but twenty-five.”
“What of that? More unequal matches are made every day.”
“True: yet I should scarcely fancy Mr. Rochester would entertain an idea of the sort. But you eat nothing: you have scarcely tasted since you began tea.”
“No: I am too thirsty to eat. Will you let me have another cup?”

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"She was very much admired, wasn’t she?" 
"Yes, absolutely. People appreciated not just her looks, but also her talents. She was among the ladies who sang, with a gentleman playing the piano to accompany her. She even performed a duet with Mr. Rochester." 
"Mr. Rochester? I didn't know he could sing." 
"Oh, he has a wonderful deep voice and a real appreciation for music." 
"And what kind of voice does Miss Ingram have?" 
"Her voice is strong and lovely; listening to her was a real pleasure. She also played music afterwards. I’m no expert, but Mr. Rochester is, and he said she performed excellently." 
"So this accomplished and beautiful woman isn’t married yet?" 
"Apparently not. I think neither she nor her sister have much money—the family estate mostly went to their eldest brother." 
"But I’m surprised no wealthy man has pursued her—someone like Mr. Rochester. He’s wealthy, isn’t he?" 
"Oh yes, very. But there’s quite an age gap: Mr. Rochester is almost forty, while she’s only twenty-five." 
"That doesn’t matter—a lot of couples have bigger differences." 
"True, but I doubt Mr. Rochester would consider it. But you’re not eating anything—you’ve hardly touched your food since tea began." 
"No, I’m too thirsty to eat. Would you pour me another cup?"

events.title: Jane's Bitter Self-Reproach and Disillusionment
detailed_summary: Jane is about to further discuss the likelihood of a match between Mr. Rochester and Blanche when Adèle's entrance shifts the conversation.
Once alone, Jane meticulously reviews the information she has gathered, scrutinizing her heart's thoughts and feelings, and attempting to discipline her straying imagination with common sense.
She mentally arraigns herself, with Memory testifying to the hopes and sentiments she had nurtured since the previous night and for the past fortnight.
Reason presents a clear, unadorned account of how she had forsaken reality for an idealized fantasy.
Jane pronounces a harsh judgment upon herself, declaring that no greater fool than Jane Eyre had ever existed, nor a more fantastic idiot who had feasted on sweet lies and mistaken poison for nectar.
She directly addresses herself, questioning her delusion of being a favorite of Mr. Rochester or important to him in any way, finding her folly sickening.

She rebukes herself for deriving pleasure from what she now sees as ambiguous tokens of preference from a man of higher social standing to a dependent, calling herself a 'poor stupid dupe' for not being wiser.

She feels shame for replaying the previous night's brief scene with him and for being flattered by his praise of her eyes, recognizing the danger for any woman to be flattered by a superior who cannot marry her, or to cultivate an unreturned secret love.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was about again to revert to the probability of a union between Mr. Rochester and the beautiful Blanche; but Adèle came in, and the conversation was turned into another channel.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It does good to no woman to be flattered by her superior, who cannot possibly intend to marry her; and it is madness in all women to let a secret love kindle within them, which, if unreturned and unknown, must devour the life that feeds it; and, if discovered and responded to, must lead, ignis-fatuus-like, into miry wilds whence there is no extrication.

events.text_segment:
I was about again to revert to the probability of a union between Mr. Rochester and the beautiful Blanche; but Adèle came in, and the conversation was turned into another channel.
When once more alone, I reviewed the information I had got; looked into my heart, examined its thoughts and feelings, and endeavoured to bring back with a strict hand such as had been straying through imagination’s boundless and trackless waste, into the safe fold of common sense.
Arraigned at my own bar, Memory having given her evidence of the hopes, wishes, sentiments I had been cherishing since last night—of the general state of mind in which I had indulged for nearly a fortnight past; Reason having come forward and told, in her own quiet way, a plain, unvarnished tale, showing how I had rejected the real, and rabidly devoured the ideal;—I pronounced judgment to this effect:—
That a greater fool than Jane Eyre had never breathed the breath of life; that a more fantastic idiot had never surfeited herself on sweet lies, and swallowed poison as if it were nectar.
“You,” I said, “a favourite with Mr. Rochester? You gifted with the power of pleasing him? You of importance to him in any way? Go! your folly sickens me. And you have derived pleasure from occasional tokens of preference—equivocal tokens shown by a gentleman of family and a man of the world to a dependent and a novice. How dared you? Poor stupid dupe!—Could not even self-interest make you wiser? You repeated to yourself this morning the brief scene of last night?—Cover your face and be ashamed! He said something in praise of your eyes, did he? Blind puppy! Open their bleared lids and look on your own accursed senselessness! It does good to no woman to be flattered by her superior, who cannot possibly intend to marry her; and it is madness in all women to let a secret love kindle within them, which, if unreturned and unknown, must devour the life that feeds it; and, if discovered and responded to, must lead, ignis-fatuus-like, into miry wilds whence there is no extrication.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I was about to bring up the likelihood of Mr. Rochester and the lovely Blanche getting married again, but Adèle arrived, shifting our conversation to a different topic. Once alone again, I reviewed the information I had gathered. I looked inward, examining my thoughts and emotions, and made a determined effort to force back any straying notions, which had wandered through the limitless, unmapped territory of imagination, into the secure realm of common sense. Holding myself accountable, I let my Memory present evidence of the hopes, desires, and feelings I had nurtured since the previous night—of the general state of mind I had allowed myself for nearly two weeks. Then Reason stepped forward and, in her quiet way, told a simple, truthful account, revealing how I had rejected reality and greedily embraced fantasy. Based on this, I reached the following conclusion about myself: that no one who had ever lived was a greater fool than Jane Eyre; that no more ridiculous simpleton had ever overindulged in pleasant lies and swallowed poison as if it were a sweet drink. "You," I told myself, "a favorite of Mr. Rochester's? You gifted with the ability to please him? You significant to him in any way? Stop! Your foolishness repulses me. And you took pleasure from occasional signs of favor—ambiguous hints shown by a well-born man of the world towards a dependent and a novice. How could you? You poor, stupid victim! Couldn't even looking out for yourself make you wiser? Did you replay this morning the brief scene from last night? Hide your face and be ashamed! He complimented your eyes, did he? You blind idiot! Open your misty eyes and see your own cursed lack of sense! Being flattered by your superior, who absolutely cannot intend to marry you, does no woman any good. And it is sheer madness for any woman to let a secret love start within them, which, if it isn't returned and remains unknown, will consume the life that harbors it. If it is discovered and reciprocated, like a misleading marsh-light, it must lead into muddy, wild places from which there is no escape.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I was about to once again think about the likelihood of Mr. Rochester marrying the lovely Blanche, but Adèle entered and the conversation shifted. Left alone, I reconsidered what I had learned and examined my own feelings and thoughts, trying firmly to bring any wild fantasies back into control with reason. I judged myself, recalling the hopes and feelings I had indulged in for nearly two weeks, and with logic, recognized how I had ignored reality and chased after unrealistic dreams. I concluded that no one could be more foolish or more lost in fantasy than I, Jane Eyre, who had fed herself on sweet deceptions and mistaken them for happiness. I rebuked myself: Did I really believe I could be important to Mr. Rochester, or that I could please him? Such thoughts were foolish, and any pleasure I gained from his ambiguous gestures was naive, given our different social positions. I scolded myself for even recalling his compliments, feeling ashamed at my gullibility. I realized it is dangerous for any woman to be flattered by a man who could never marry her and madness to nurture a secret love that, if unreturned, will consume her, and if returned, could lead only to grief and ruin.

events.title: A Governess's Grim Resolve: The Two Portraits
detailed_summary: Jane, addressing herself sternly, outlines a plan for self-correction.
She resolves that the next day she will look in the mirror and draw her own portrait in chalk, meticulously and honestly, without softening any flaws or irregularities.
Under this stark self-portrait, she will write the caption: 'Portrait of a Governess, disconnected, poor, and plain.'
Following this, she will take a piece of smooth ivory and her finest art supplies to create a contrasting image.

She will meticulously paint the loveliest face imaginable, based on Mrs. Fairfax's description of Blanche Ingram, including her raven hair and 'oriental eye,' consciously avoiding using Mr. Rochester as a model and suppressing all sentiment or regret.
This idealized portrait will depict Blanche's noble features, graceful form, elegant attire of lace and satin, and jewelry, and will be titled 'Blanche, an accomplished lady of rank.'
Jane's intention is that, in the future, whenever she finds herself imagining Mr. Rochester thinks well of her, she will take out these two pictures and compare them.

She will then remind herself that while Mr. Rochester might realistically win the love of a noble lady like Blanche if he tried, it is highly unlikely he would waste serious thought on someone as 'indigent and insignificant' as herself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Listen, then, Jane Eyre, to your sentence: to-morrow, place the glass before you, and draw in chalk your own picture, faithfully, without softening one defect; omit no harsh line, smooth away no displeasing irregularity; write under it, ‘Portrait of a Governess, disconnected, poor, and plain.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Mr. Rochester might probably win that noble lady’s love, if he chose to strive for it; is it likely he would waste a serious thought on this indigent and insignificant plebeian?’”

events.text_segment:
“Listen, then, Jane Eyre, to your sentence: to-morrow, place the glass before you, and draw in chalk your own picture, faithfully, without softening one defect; omit no harsh line, smooth away no displeasing irregularity; write under it, ‘Portrait of a Governess, disconnected, poor, and plain.’
“Afterwards, take a piece of smooth ivory—you have one prepared in your drawing-box: take your palette, mix your freshest, finest, clearest tints; choose your most delicate camel-hair pencils; delineate carefully the loveliest face you can imagine; paint it in your softest shades and sweetest lines, according to the description given by Mrs. Fairfax of Blanche Ingram; remember the raven ringlets, the oriental eye;—What! you revert to Mr. Rochester as a model! Order! No snivel!—no sentiment!—no regret! I will endure only sense and resolution. Recall the august yet harmonious lineaments, the Grecian neck and bust; let the round and dazzling arm be visible, and the delicate hand; omit neither diamond ring nor gold bracelet; portray faithfully the attire, aërial lace and glistening satin, graceful scarf and golden rose; call it ‘Blanche, an accomplished lady of rank.’
“Whenever, in future, you should chance to fancy Mr. Rochester thinks well of you, take out these two pictures and compare them: say, ‘Mr. Rochester might probably win that noble lady’s love, if he chose to strive for it; is it likely he would waste a serious thought on this indigent and insignificant plebeian?’”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Listen, Jane Eyre, to the task I am setting for you: tomorrow, stand before the mirror and sketch a self-portrait with chalk, ensuring it is completely accurate and shows every imperfection; do not smooth over any harsh lines or unsightly flaws. Label this drawing, 'Portrait of a Governess: isolated, poor, and plain.' Afterwards, take a piece of smooth ivory from your drawing kit, prepare your paints and finest brushes, and carefully depict the most beautiful face you can imagine. Paint it using your softest colors and most elegant lines, following the description Mrs. Fairfax gave of Blanche Ingram. Remember her dark, curly hair and captivating eyes. (Stop focusing on Mr. Rochester! Stay disciplined! No crying, no sentiment, no sadness! Only logic and resolve will be tolerated.) Recall her dignified yet graceful features, her classical neck and bust; show her lovely, radiant arm and delicate hand; make sure to include her diamond ring and gold bracelet; truthfully represent her attire—the airy lace, gleaming satin, elegant scarf, and golden rose. Label this one, 'Blanche: An Accomplished Lady of High Society.' From now on, whenever you might imagine that Mr. Rochester has positive thoughts about you, take out these two pictures and compare them. Say to yourself, 'Mr. Rochester could probably win the love of that noble lady if he made the effort; is it conceivable he would spend a serious thought on this poor and unimportant common person?'
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Listen, Jane Eyre, to your judgment: tomorrow, look at yourself in a mirror and make a chalk drawing of your own face, capturing every feature honestly without hiding any flaws or smoothing out any imperfections. Write beneath it, 'Portrait of a Governess, isolated, poor, and plain.' Next, take a piece of smooth ivory from your art supplies, prepare your best paints and finest brushes, and create the most beautiful face you can imagine, using Mrs. Fairfax’s description of Blanche Ingram as your guide. Remember her dark curls and striking eyes—don’t start imagining Mr. Rochester! Stay focused and avoid any emotional responses. Paint her elegant features, her classical neck and shape, her dazzling arm and delicate hand, including her diamond ring and gold bracelet. Accurately represent her luxurious dress of lace and satin, as well as her graceful accessories, and label this portrait, 'Blanche, an accomplished lady of noble status.' Then, whenever you are tempted to think that Mr. Rochester might care for you, take these two portraits and compare them, reminding yourself that it is far more likely he would pursue the love of such a distinguished lady rather than waste attention on someone as poor and unremarkable as yourself.

events.title: Art as Austerity: Finding Calm in Self-Imposed Discipline
detailed_summary: Jane firmly decides to implement her plan of creating the two contrasting portraits, and this resolution brings her a sense of calm, enabling her to fall asleep.
She fulfills her promise: within a couple of hours, she sketches her own portrait in crayons.
In less than two weeks, she completes an ivory miniature of an imaginary Blanche Ingram.
The resulting image of Blanche is lovely, and when compared to Jane's own chalk portrait, the contrast is as stark as her self-control desired.
Jane finds that this artistic exercise has been beneficial, keeping her mind and hands occupied.
More importantly, the task has helped to strengthen and solidify the new, harsher impressions and disciplined mindset she wished to permanently instill in her heart.
She soon recognizes the value of this self-imposed emotional discipline, believing it has equipped her to face subsequent events with a decent composure that she might otherwise have lacked.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I’ll do it,” I resolved: and having framed this determination, I grew calm, and fell asleep.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ere long, I had reason to congratulate myself on the course of wholesome discipline to which I had thus forced my feelings to submit. Thanks to it, I was able to meet subsequent occurrences with a decent calm, which, had they found me unprepared, I should probably have been unequal to maintain, even externally.

events.text_segment:
“I’ll do it,” I resolved: and having framed this determination, I grew calm, and fell asleep.
I kept my word. An hour or two sufficed to sketch my own portrait in crayons; and in less than a fortnight I had completed an ivory miniature of an imaginary Blanche Ingram. It looked a lovely face enough, and when compared with the real head in chalk, the contrast was as great as self-control could desire. I derived benefit from the task: it had kept my head and hands employed, and had given force and fixedness to the new impressions I wished to stamp indelibly on my heart.
Ere long, I had reason to congratulate myself on the course of wholesome discipline to which I had thus forced my feelings to submit. Thanks to it, I was able to meet subsequent occurrences with a decent calm, which, had they found me unprepared, I should probably have been unequal to maintain, even externally.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I decided, "I will do this," and having made up my mind, I felt peaceful and went to sleep. I kept my word. It took only an hour or two to sketch my own portrait in crayons, and within less than two weeks, I had finished a small ivory painting of an imaginary Blanche Ingram. This miniature looked quite beautiful, and when compared to the charcoal sketch of myself, the difference was exactly what my self-control aimed for. I found this task helpful; it kept me occupied, both mentally and physically, and helped me solidify the new feelings I wanted to make a permanent part of myself. Before long, I was grateful for this tough emotional discipline I had forced myself through. Thanks to it, I could face later events with a calm dignity, something I probably wouldn't have been able to manage, not even outwardly, if I hadn't been prepared.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I decided I would do it, and once I made up my mind, I calmed down and went to sleep. I stuck to my promise. Within a couple of hours, I drew a portrait of myself with crayons, and in less than two weeks, I finished painting a small ivory miniature of an imagined Blanche Ingram. The portrait turned out to be very attractive, and when set beside my own chalk likeness, the difference between the two was just what I wanted. Doing this work was good for me: it kept me occupied and helped strengthen the new feelings I hoped to firmly instill in myself. Soon, I was glad I had made myself go through this healthy exercise, because it allowed me to handle later events with a calmness I might not have managed if I hadn't been prepared.

events.title: Jane's Internal Struggle and News of Rochester's Return
detailed_summary: Weeks pass without news of Mr. Rochester, causing Jane to feel a growing sense of disappointment.
Jane internally disciplines herself for her emotional investment, reminding herself of her station and the unsuitability of her feelings for Mr. Rochester, who is of a different social order.
She resolves to maintain her composure, focus on her duties, and accept that her affections would be unwelcome.
Despite her resolve, thoughts of leaving Thornfield occasionally surface.
After more than two weeks, Mrs. Fairfax receives a letter announcing Mr. Rochester's impending return.
Jane experiences a noticeable physical reaction—flushing and trembling—to the news, which she attributes to her hot beverage.
Mrs. Fairfax reveals that Mr. Rochester will arrive in three days, accompanied by a party of guests.
Orders are given for extensive preparations, including readying all the best rooms and hiring additional staff for the occasion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A week passed, and no news arrived of Mr. Rochester: ten days, and still he did not come.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And Mrs. Fairfax swallowed her breakfast and hastened away to commence operations.

events.text_segment:
A week passed, and no news arrived of Mr. Rochester: ten days, and still he did not come. Mrs. Fairfax said she should not be surprised if he were to go straight from the Leas to London, and thence to the Continent, and not show his face again at Thornfield for a year to come; he had not unfrequently quitted it in a manner quite as abrupt and unexpected. When I heard this, I was beginning to feel a strange chill and failing at the heart. I was actually permitting myself to experience a sickening sense of disappointment; but rallying my wits, and recollecting my principles, I at once called my sensations to order; and it was wonderful how I got over the temporary blunder—how I cleared up the mistake of supposing Mr. Rochester’s movements a matter in which I had any cause to take a vital interest. Not that I humbled myself by a slavish notion of inferiority: on the contrary, I just said—
“You have nothing to do with the master of Thornfield, further than to receive the salary he gives you for teaching his protégée, and to be grateful for such respectful and kind treatment as, if you do your duty, you have a right to expect at his hands. Be sure that is the only tie he seriously acknowledges between you and him; so don’t make him the object of your fine feelings, your raptures, agonies, and so forth. He is not of your order: keep to your caste, and be too self-respecting to lavish the love of the whole heart, soul, and strength, where such a gift is not wanted and would be despised.”
I went on with my day’s business tranquilly; but ever and anon vague suggestions kept wandering across my brain of reasons why I should quit Thornfield; and I kept involuntarily framing advertisements and pondering conjectures about new situations: these thoughts I did not think to check; they might germinate and bear fruit if they could.
Mr. Rochester had been absent upwards of a fortnight, when the post brought Mrs. Fairfax a letter.
“It is from the master,” said she, as she looked at the direction. “Now I suppose we shall know whether we are to expect his return or not.”
And while she broke the seal and perused the document, I went on taking my coffee (we were at breakfast): it was hot, and I attributed to that circumstance a fiery glow which suddenly rose to my face. Why my hand shook, and why I involuntarily spilt half the contents of my cup into my saucer, I did not choose to consider.
“Well, I sometimes think we are too quiet; but we run a chance of being busy enough now: for a little while at least,” said Mrs. Fairfax, still holding the note before her spectacles.
Ere I permitted myself to request an explanation, I tied the string of Adèle’s pinafore, which happened to be loose: having helped her also to another bun and refilled her mug with milk, I said, nonchalantly—
“Mr. Rochester is not likely to return soon, I suppose?”
“Indeed he is—in three days, he says: that will be next Thursday; and not alone either. I don’t know how many of the fine people at the Leas are coming with him: he sends directions for all the best bedrooms to be prepared; and the library and drawing-rooms are to be cleaned out; I am to get more kitchen hands from the George Inn, at Millcote, and from wherever else I can; and the ladies will bring their maids and the gentlemen their valets: so we shall have a full house of it.” And Mrs. Fairfax swallowed her breakfast and hastened away to commence operations.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A week went by without any word from Mr. Rochester; ten days passed, and he still had not returned. Mrs. Fairfax speculated that he might head straight from the Leas gathering to London and then to the Continent, potentially staying away from Thornfield for a full year, noting that he had often departed in such sudden ways before. Hearing this, I started to feel a strange coldness and weakness in my chest. I realized I was letting myself feel a painful sense of disappointment, but I quickly regained control of my thoughts and remembered my principles. It was surprisingly easy to overcome that temporary lapse and correct the error of assuming Mr. Rochester's movements were something I had any important reason to care about. It wasn't that I felt humbly inferior; rather, I told myself, “Your only connection to Thornfield's master is the salary he pays you for tutoring his ward, and you should be grateful for the respectful and kind treatment you have a right to expect if you perform your duties well. Be certain that is the only bond he truly acknowledges between you two, so don't focus your intense feelings, your joys, sorrows, and so forth, on him. He belongs to a different social rank than you; stick to your own place and have enough self-respect not to lavish the fullness of your love, spirit, and energy where such a gift is neither wanted nor would be valued.” I calmly resumed my daily tasks, but vague ideas about why I should leave Thornfield kept surfacing in my mind from time to time. I found myself constantly formulating potential job advertisements and considering new positions, thoughts I didn't try to suppress; I figured they could develop and yield results if they were capable. Mr. Rochester had been gone for over two weeks when the mail brought a letter for Mrs. Fairfax. “It’s from the master,” she announced, looking at the address. “Now I expect we'll find out whether he's coming back or not.” While she broke the seal and read the letter, I continued drinking my coffee during breakfast. It was hot, and I blamed the sudden rush of heat to my face on that. I chose not to think about why my hand trembled and why I accidentally poured half the contents of my cup into my saucer. “Well, sometimes I think we're too quiet, but we're likely to be quite busy now, at least for a little while,” Mrs. Fairfax remarked, still holding the note in front of her glasses. Before allowing myself to ask for details, I tied the bow on Adèle’s pinafore, which had come undone, and helped her to another roll, refilling her milk mug. Then I asked casually, “Mr. Rochester probably isn't returning soon, I suppose?” “Indeed he is,” she replied. “In three days, he says; that will be next Thursday. And he won’t be alone. I don’t know how many of the distinguished guests from the Leas will be accompanying him. He has sent instructions for all the best bedrooms to be made ready, and the library and drawing-rooms need cleaning. I have to hire more kitchen staff from the George Inn in Millcote and anywhere else I can find them. The ladies will bring their personal maids and the gentlemen their valets, so the house will be completely full.” After saying this, Mrs. Fairfax quickly finished her breakfast and hurried off to begin the preparations.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
A week went by without any word from Mr. Rochester, and after ten days he still hadn’t returned. Mrs. Fairfax commented that she wouldn’t be surprised if he traveled from Leas straight to London and then abroad, not returning to Thornfield for a year—he had left suddenly like this before. Hearing this, I began to feel a cold disappointment, but quickly pulled myself together and reminded myself of my place. I told myself that my only connection to Mr. Rochester was my employment as Adèle’s governess, and the respectful treatment he gave me for doing my job well. I resolved not to let my feelings dwell on him, remembering the distance between our positions, and not to waste my affection where it was neither wanted nor appropriate. I continued my daily work calmly, but the idea of leaving Thornfield kept crossing my mind, and I found myself thinking about new jobs, letting those thoughts develop as they would.

More than two weeks had passed when Mrs. Fairfax received a letter during breakfast. She said it was from Mr. Rochester, and we’d now know when—or if—to expect his return. As she read it, I stayed busy with my coffee, trying to ignore the sudden flush and shaky hands that came over me. Mrs. Fairfax remarked that our quiet days might soon be over, as the note instructed that many preparations needed to be made—more hands hired, rooms prepared, and staff enlisted—because Mr. Rochester would be back in three days, bringing several guests with him. She quickly finished her meal and set to work getting ready for their arrival.

events.title: Frenzied Preparations and Ominous Observations of Grace Poole
detailed_summary: The subsequent three days are marked by intense and thorough cleaning and preparations throughout Thornfield, surpassing Jane's previous standards of the house's upkeep.
Adèle is filled with excitement at the prospect of company, enthusiastically preparing her wardrobe with Sophie and enjoying newfound freedom to play.
Jane is recruited by Mrs. Fairfax to assist in the storeroom with culinary tasks, where she learns to make various elaborate dishes.
Amidst the flurry of activity, Jane is periodically disquieted by sightings of Grace Poole, who moves stealthily from her locked third-story room.

Grace Poole's daily routine involves a brief descent to the kitchen for meals and porter, after which she retreats to her isolated upper chamber, spending most of her time alone sewing and, Jane imagines, laughing to herself.
Jane finds it peculiar that no one else in the household appears to notice or question Grace Poole's strange habits or her solitary existence.

Jane overhears a conversation between Leah and a charwoman about Grace, learning that she earns substantial wages, saves her money, and performs a job that is considered difficult and not for everyone.
The conversation abruptly ends when Leah notices Jane, reinforcing Jane's suspicion that she is being intentionally kept ignorant of a secret within Thornfield.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The three days were, as she had foretold, busy enough.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All I had gathered from it amounted to this,—that there was a mystery at Thornfield; and that from participation in that mystery I was purposely excluded.

events.text_segment:
The three days were, as she had foretold, busy enough. I had thought all the rooms at Thornfield beautifully clean and well arranged; but it appears I was mistaken. Three women were got to help; and such scrubbing, such brushing, such washing of paint and beating of carpets, such taking down and putting up of pictures, such polishing of mirrors and lustres, such lighting of fires in bedrooms, such airing of sheets and feather-beds on hearths, I never beheld, either before or since. Adèle ran quite wild in the midst of it: the preparations for company and the prospect of their arrival, seemed to throw her into ecstasies. She would have Sophie to look over all her “toilettes,” as she called frocks; to furbish up any that were “passées,” and to air and arrange the new. For herself, she did nothing but caper about in the front chambers, jump on and off the bedsteads, and lie on the mattresses and piled-up bolsters and pillows before the enormous fires roaring in the chimneys. From school duties she was exonerated: Mrs. Fairfax had pressed me into her service, and I was all day in the storeroom, helping (or hindering) her and the cook; learning to make custards and cheese-cakes and French pastry, to truss game and garnish desert-dishes.
The party were expected to arrive on Thursday afternoon, in time for dinner at six. During the intervening period I had no time to nurse chimeras; and I believe I was as active and gay as anybody—Adèle excepted. Still, now and then, I received a damping check to my cheerfulness; and was, in spite of myself, thrown back on the region of doubts and portents, and dark conjectures. This was when I chanced to see the third-storey staircase door (which of late had always been kept locked) open slowly, and give passage to the form of Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief; when I watched her glide along the gallery, her quiet tread muffled in a list slipper; when I saw her look into the bustling, topsy-turvy bedrooms,—just say a word, perhaps, to the charwoman about the proper way to polish a grate, or clean a marble mantelpiece, or take stains from papered walls, and then pass on. She would thus descend to the kitchen once a day, eat her dinner, smoke a moderate pipe on the hearth, and go back, carrying her pot of porter with her, for her private solace, in her own gloomy, upper haunt. Only one hour in the twenty-four did she pass with her fellow-servants below; all the rest of her time was spent in some low-ceiled, oaken chamber of the second storey: there she sat and sewed—and probably laughed drearily to herself,—as companionless as a prisoner in his dungeon.
The strangest thing of all was, that not a soul in the house, except me, noticed her habits, or seemed to marvel at them: no one discussed her position or employment; no one pitied her solitude or isolation. I once, indeed, overheard part of a dialogue between Leah and one of the charwomen, of which Grace formed the subject. Leah had been saying something I had not caught, and the charwoman remarked—
“She gets good wages, I guess?”
“Yes,” said Leah; “I wish I had as good; not that mine are to complain of,—there’s no stinginess at Thornfield; but they’re not one fifth of the sum Mrs. Poole receives. And she is laying by: she goes every quarter to the bank at Millcote. I should not wonder but she has saved enough to keep her independent if she liked to leave; but I suppose she’s got used to the place; and then she’s not forty yet, and strong and able for anything. It is too soon for her to give up business.”
“She is a good hand, I daresay,” said the charwoman.
“Ah!—she understands what she has to do,—nobody better,” rejoined Leah significantly; “and it is not every one could fill her shoes—not for all the money she gets.”
“That it is not!” was the reply. “I wonder whether the master—”
The charwoman was going on; but here Leah turned and perceived me, and she instantly gave her companion a nudge.
“Doesn’t she know?” I heard the woman whisper.
Leah shook her head, and the conversation was of course dropped. All I had gathered from it amounted to this,—that there was a mystery at Thornfield; and that from participation in that mystery I was purposely excluded.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
The next three days unfolded just as she had predicted, filled with activity. I had believed Thornfield's rooms were already perfectly clean and orderly, but apparently, I was incorrect. Three women were hired to help, and the extent of the cleaning was unprecedented in my experience: intense scrubbing, brushing, paint washing, carpet beating, taking down and rehanging pictures, polishing mirrors and light fixtures, lighting fires in bedrooms, and warming sheets and duvets by the hearths. Adèle became completely unrestrained amidst all this; the anticipation of visitors and their imminent arrival seemed to send her into fits of joy. She insisted Sophie examine all her 'toilettes' (as she called her dresses), to spruce up any that were 'worn out', and to air and arrange the new ones. For her part, Adèle did nothing but dance around the front rooms, leap onto and off the beds, and sprawl on the mattresses, piled-up bolsters, and pillows in front of the huge fires roaring in the fireplaces. She was excused from her lessons. Mrs. Fairfax enlisted my help, and I spent my entire day in the storeroom, assisting (or perhaps hindering) her and the cook. I learned to prepare custards, cheesecakes, and French pastries, to truss game birds, and decorate dessert platters.

The guests were expected on Thursday afternoon, arriving in time for dinner at six. During this interval, I had no opportunity for brooding or fanciful thoughts; in fact, I believe I was as energetic and cheerful as anyone, except for Adèle. Nevertheless, every so often, my good spirits were unexpectedly dampened, and I was involuntarily drawn back to my realm of uncertainties, premonitions, and somber suspicions. This occurred when I happened to see the door to the third-story staircase (which had been consistently locked recently) slowly open, allowing Grace Poole to emerge, looking proper in her neat cap, white apron, and neckerchief. I would watch her glide along the corridor, her quiet steps muffled by her soft slippers. I saw her glance into the bustling, chaotic bedrooms, perhaps offering a brief instruction to a cleaning woman on the proper way to polish a grate, clean a marble mantelpiece, or remove stains from wallpaper, and then move on. She would descend to the kitchen once daily, eat her meal, calmly smoke a pipe by the fire, and then return, carrying her stout ale for her private comfort in her somber upper dwelling. She spent only one hour out of twenty-four with the other servants downstairs; the rest of her time was spent in a low-ceilinged, oak-paneled room on the second floor. There she sat and sewed, likely laughing dismally to herself, as solitary as a prisoner in a dungeon.

The most peculiar aspect was that, apart from myself, no one else in the house seemed to notice or be surprised by her habits. No one discussed her position or duties, nor did anyone express pity for her solitude or isolation. However, on one occasion, I did overhear a portion of a conversation about Grace between Leah and one of the cleaning women. Leah had said something I didn't catch, and the charwoman commented—
“I assume she earns good wages?”
“Yes,” Leah replied, “I wish mine were as good; not that I have cause to complain—Thornfield is not stingy with pay—but they are not even one-fifth of what Mrs. Poole receives. And she is saving up; she visits the bank in Millcote every quarter. It wouldn't surprise me if she has saved enough to be independent should she choose to leave. But I suppose she has become accustomed to the place. Plus, she's not forty yet, and she's strong and capable of anything. It's too early for her to retire.”
“I'm sure she's skilled at her job,” said the cleaning woman.
“Ah, she certainly knows what she needs to do—no one does it better,” Leah rejoined pointedly, “and not everyone could manage her role—not even for all the money she gets.”
“That’s true!” came the reply. “I wonder if the master—”
The charwoman was about to continue, but here Leah turned and saw me, immediately nudging her companion.
“Does she not know?” I heard the woman whisper.
Leah shook her head, and naturally, the conversation ceased. All I gleaned from this exchange was that Thornfield held a secret, and that I was intentionally being kept out of it.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
The three days were as busy as predicted. Although I initially thought Thornfield Hall was spotless and well-ordered, I soon realized I was wrong. Three extra women were hired to assist, and the level of cleaning and preparation was like nothing I had ever seen: scrubbing, brushing, washing paint, beating carpets, rearranging pictures, polishing mirrors and chandeliers, lighting fires in every bedroom, and airing out bedding in front of roaring hearths. Adèle was overjoyed by all the activity, thrilled about the guests’ upcoming arrival. She had Sophie check all her dresses, spruce up the old ones, and arrange the new. Adèle herself just danced around the rooms, jumped on beds, and lounged on the heaps of pillows and mattresses next to the blazing fires. She was excused from lessons, while Mrs. Fairfax had enlisted my help in the storeroom, so I spent my days assisting her and the cook, learning how to prepare fancy pastries and desserts, and help with game and garnishes.

The guests were due to arrive Thursday afternoon for dinner at six. In the meantime, I was so occupied I had no time for idle daydreams, and felt as energetic and cheerful as anyone, apart from Adèle. Still, at times, my happiness was disrupted, particularly when I noticed the door to the third-story staircase—formerly always locked—creak open to let Grace Poole pass. In her neat cap, apron, and kerchief, Grace would glide silently along the corridor, sometimes stopping at the chaotic bedrooms to offer advice to the cleaning women before heading downstairs. Each day, she would eat her meal in the kitchen, quietly smoke a pipe by the fire, and then return upstairs with her own pot of ale for company, spending almost all her time alone in a small, upper room, sewing and—perhaps—laughing to herself, as isolated as any prisoner.

Curiously, I was the only person in the house who seemed to notice or wonder about Grace’s solitary habits; no one else discussed her role or pitied her loneliness. I once heard part of a conversation between Leah and a cleaning woman about Grace. The charwoman asked if Grace was well-paid, and Leah confirmed she was, wishing for such wages herself, though hers weren’t bad. She mentioned Grace saved her money and regularly deposited it in the bank, and that Grace could be independent if she left, but perhaps she simply liked Thornfield, was still young and strong, and not ready to stop working. The charwoman acknowledged Grace’s skill, and Leah agreed, implying Grace’s work was exceptional and not easily replaced, regardless of pay. Just as the charwoman was about to comment on ‘the master,’ Leah noticed me nearby and quickly ended the conversation. All I gleaned from this was that a mystery existed at Thornfield, one I was clearly not allowed to share in.

events.title: Anticipation and the Guests' Grand Arrival
detailed_summary: By Thursday, all preparations are meticulously completed, and Thornfield Hall presents an immaculate and inviting appearance.
Mrs. Fairfax attires herself formally to receive the guests, and Adèle is also dressed for the occasion, although Jane doubts she will be introduced that day.
Jane intends to remain secluded in the schoolroom, which she regards as her personal sanctuary.
As evening falls on a pleasant spring day, Mrs. Fairfax expresses some anxiety over the guests' delayed arrival for the scheduled dinner.
A servant, John, announces from the gate that the party is approaching.
Adèle excitedly rushes to the window, and Jane follows, careful to position herself where she can observe without being seen.
The guests make their grand entrance: four equestrians, notably Mr. Rochester riding alongside a lady with prominent dark ringlets, followed by two open carriages filled with other guests.
Mrs. Fairfax identifies the lady with Mr. Rochester as Miss Ingram and hastens to her duties below.
Jane gently restrains an eager Adèle, explaining that she must not appear before the ladies unless specifically summoned, which briefly brings Adèle to tears.
The sounds of arrival permeate the hall, with Mr. Rochester's distinct voice audible as he welcomes his guests.
The guests proceed upstairs to their rooms, prompting Adèle to remark that they are changing their attire, and she wistfully recalls similar social events from her past in France.
