events.text_segment:
Thursday came: all work had been completed the previous evening; carpets were laid down, bed-hangings festooned, radiant white counterpanes spread, toilet tables arranged, furniture rubbed, flowers piled in vases: both chambers and saloons looked as fresh and bright as hands could make them. The hall, too, was scoured; and the great carved clock, as well as the steps and banisters of the staircase, were polished to the brightness of glass; in the dining-room, the sideboard flashed resplendent with plate; in the drawing-room and boudoir, vases of exotics bloomed on all sides.
Afternoon arrived: Mrs. Fairfax assumed her best black satin gown, her gloves, and her gold watch; for it was her part to receive the company,—to conduct the ladies to their rooms, &c. Adèle, too, would be dressed: though I thought she had little chance of being introduced to the party that day at least. However, to please her, I allowed Sophie to apparel her in one of her short, full muslin frocks. For myself, I had no need to make any change; I should not be called upon to quit my sanctum of the schoolroom; for a sanctum it was now become to me,—“a very pleasant refuge in time of trouble.”
It had been a mild, serene spring day—one of those days which, towards the end of March or the beginning of April, rise shining over the earth as heralds of summer. It was drawing to an end now; but the evening was even warm, and I sat at work in the schoolroom with the window open.
“It gets late,” said Mrs. Fairfax, entering in rustling state. “I am glad I ordered dinner an hour after the time Mr. Rochester mentioned; for it is past six now. I have sent John down to the gates to see if there is anything on the road: one can see a long way from thence in the direction of Millcote.” She went to the window. “Here he is!” said she. “Well, John” (leaning out), “any news?”
“They’re coming, ma’am,” was the answer. “They’ll be here in ten minutes.”
Adèle flew to the window. I followed, taking care to stand on one side, so that, screened by the curtain, I could see without being seen.
The ten minutes John had given seemed very long, but at last wheels were heard; four equestrians galloped up the drive, and after them came two open carriages. Fluttering veils and waving plumes filled the vehicles; two of the cavaliers were young, dashing-looking gentlemen; the third was Mr. Rochester, on his black horse, Mesrour, Pilot bounding before him; at his side rode a lady, and he and she were the first of the party. Her purple riding-habit almost swept the ground, her veil streamed long on the breeze; mingling with its transparent folds, and gleaming through them, shone rich raven ringlets.
“Miss Ingram!” exclaimed Mrs. Fairfax, and away she hurried to her post below.
The cavalcade, following the sweep of the drive, quickly turned the angle of the house, and I lost sight of it. Adèle now petitioned to go down; but I took her on my knee, and gave her to understand that she must not on any account think of venturing in sight of the ladies, either now or at any other time, unless expressly sent for: that Mr. Rochester would be very angry, &c. “Some natural tears she shed” on being told this; but as I began to look very grave, she consented at last to wipe them.
A joyous stir was now audible in the hall: gentlemen’s deep tones and ladies’ silvery accents blent harmoniously together, and distinguishable above all, though not loud, was the sonorous voice of the master of Thornfield Hall, welcoming his fair and gallant guests under its roof. Then light steps ascended the stairs; and there was a tripping through the gallery, and soft cheerful laughs, and opening and closing doors, and, for a time, a hush.
“Elles changent de toilettes,” said Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement; and she sighed.
“Chez maman,” said she, “quand il y avait du monde, je le suivais partout, au salon et à leurs chambres; souvent je regardais les femmes de chambre coiffer et habiller les dames, et c’était si amusant: comme cela on apprend.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Thursday dawned, with all preparations finished the night before. Rugs were spread out, bed curtains were hung elegantly, pristine white bedspreads were in place, vanity areas were arranged, furniture was polished, and flowers were arranged in vases. Both the bedrooms and main reception rooms looked impeccably clean and cheerful. The entrance hall was also thoroughly cleaned, and the large carved clock, along with the stairway's steps and handrails, shone like glass. In the dining room, the buffet gleamed with polished silverware, and in the drawing-room and sitting-room, exotic flowers bloomed in vases throughout. The afternoon arrived, and Mrs. Fairfax donned her finest black satin dress, gloves, and gold watch. Her role was to welcome the guests and show the ladies to their rooms. Adèle was also to get dressed, although I doubted she would be presented to the company, at least that day. Still, to make her happy, I allowed Sophie to dress her in a short, full muslin dress. I didn't need to change my attire; I wouldn't be expected to leave the schoolroom, which had become my sanctuary—a comforting haven in challenging times. It had been a gentle, clear spring day, one of those days in late March or early April that arrive like shining messengers of summer. It was nearing its close now, but the evening air was surprisingly warm, and I worked in the schoolroom with the window open. 'It's getting late,' announced Mrs. Fairfax, entering with the rustle of her dress. 'I'm glad I scheduled dinner an hour later than Mr. Rochester suggested; it's past six already. I've sent John down to the gates to see if anyone is approaching on the road; you can see quite far towards Millcote from there.' She walked over to the window. 'Here he is!' she exclaimed. 'Well, John,' she called out, leaning from the window, 'any news?' 'They are coming, ma'am,' he replied. 'They will be here in ten minutes.' Adèle darted to the window. I followed, making sure to stand to one side, hidden by the curtain, so I could observe without being seen. The ten minutes John mentioned felt incredibly long, but eventually, we heard wheels. Four riders galloped up the drive, followed by two open carriages. Veils fluttered and plumes waved within the vehicles. Two of the horsemen were young, stylish gentlemen; the third was Mr. Rochester on his black horse, Mesrour, with Pilot running ahead. Riding beside him was a lady, and they were the first pair of the group. Her purple riding habit nearly touched the ground, and her veil flowed long in the wind. Intertwined with its sheer folds, and visible through them, were lustrous black ringlets. 'Miss Ingram!' cried Mrs. Fairfax, and she quickly descended to her receiving position. The procession, following the curve of the drive, swiftly rounded the corner of the house, and I could no longer see it. Adèle then pleaded to go downstairs, but I held her on my lap and explained firmly that she must under no circumstances try to approach the ladies, either now or later, unless she was explicitly summoned. I warned her that Mr. Rochester would be very displeased. She shed 'some natural tears' upon hearing this, but seeing my serious expression, she finally agreed to wipe them away. A cheerful commotion was now audible in the hall: gentlemen's deep voices and ladies' clear, musical tones blended pleasantly. Distinctly audible above the rest, though not loud, was the resonant voice of the master of Thornfield Hall, welcoming his elegant guests into his home. Then light footsteps ascended the stairs, followed by light, quick steps along the gallery, soft, happy laughter, and the sound of doors opening and closing, before a period of quiet. 'They are changing their clothes,' said Adèle, who had followed every sound attentively, and she sighed. 'At my mother's house,' she added in French, 'when we had guests, I would follow them everywhere, to the sitting-room and their rooms. Often I watched the ladies' maids style and dress the ladies, and it was so entertaining; you learn so much that way.'
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Thursday arrived: all the preparations had been finished the night before; the carpets were placed, the beds made up with shining white covers, the dressing tables arranged, furniture polished, and vases filled with flowers. Every room looked as tidy and inviting as possible. The entrance hall was also scrubbed clean, and both the large clock and the staircase railings gleamed. In the dining room, the sideboard glittered with silverware, while the drawing-room and boudoir were decorated with exotic flowers in vases.

By afternoon, Mrs. Fairfax dressed in her finest black satin dress, gloves, and wore her gold watch, ready to welcome the guests and show the ladies to their rooms. Adèle was also to be dressed up, despite my doubt that she would meet the guests that day; still, to make her happy, I let Sophie put her in a nice muslin dress. As for myself, I didn’t have to change—I would remain in the schoolroom, my private sanctuary and a place of comfort during times of stress.

The day itself was calm and pleasant, typical of early spring. As the warm evening approached, I sat working in the schoolroom with the window open.

Mrs. Fairfax entered with a gentle rustle. "It’s getting late," she said. "I’m glad I arranged dinner to be an hour later than Mr. Rochester suggested, since it’s after six now. I’ve sent John to the gate to see if anyone is approaching; from there, he should have a good view towards Millcote." She went to the window. "Here he comes! Well, John, any news?"

"They’re coming, ma’am," he replied. "They’ll arrive in ten minutes."

Adèle hurried to the window and I joined her, standing aside behind the curtain so I could watch unseen. The ten minutes felt endless, but at last we heard wheels, and four riders galloped up the drive, followed by two open carriages adorned with billowing veils and waving feathers. Two of the riders were young and dashing, the third was Mr. Rochester on his black horse, Mesrour, with Pilot the dog running ahead. Next to him rode a lady; they were in the lead. She wore a purple riding dress that nearly touched the ground, her long veil streaming behind, interwoven with shiny black curls.

"Miss Ingram!" exclaimed Mrs. Fairfax, hurrying to the main hall.

The group followed the driveway, rounding the corner, and I lost sight of them. Adèle begged to go downstairs, but I took her on my lap and explained firmly she must not appear before the guests unless invited, as Mr. Rochester would not allow it. She cried quietly at first, but seeing I was serious, she agreed at last.

Excited sounds filled the hall: deep voices of men and bright voices of women mingled cheerfully, with Mr. Rochester’s resonant tone standing out as he welcomed everyone. Light footsteps went up the stairs, laughs and conversations echoed, doors opened and shut, and then there was a brief quiet.

"They are changing their clothes," said Adèle, who listened closely to everything. She sighed and added, "When there were visitors at my mother’s house, I followed her everywhere—to the drawing room and the guests’ rooms. I used to watch the maids dress and style the ladies’ hair, and it was such fun. That’s how you learn."

events.title: A Covert Mission for Sustenance and Distant Observations of Festivities
detailed_summary: Adèle mentions her hunger, compelling Jane to venture downstairs in search of food for the child.
Jane navigates through the bustling kitchen and servants' hall, which are in a state of organized commotion due to ongoing dinner preparations for the newly arrived guests.
She successfully procures a cold chicken, bread, and tarts from the larder and makes a swift return.
While returning to the gallery, Jane narrowly avoids an encounter with the ladies emerging from their chambers by retreating into a dark, windowless section of the corridor.

From her hiding spot, she observes the ladies as they pass, impressed by their elegant attire and their aura of subdued vivacity, which leaves her with an unprecedented sense of high-born sophistication.
Jane finds Adèle peeking from the schoolroom, captivated by the sight of the beautiful ladies and expressing a hopeful wish that Mr. Rochester might send for them.
Jane tempers Adèle's expectations for the evening and provides her with the procured dinner, which effectively diverts the hungry child's attention.
Jane reflects on the wisdom of having secured food, as the household staff were too preoccupied with the guests to attend to their needs.
She permits Adèle to stay up much later than usual, telling her stories, because Adèle is too stimulated by the sounds of the party below to consider sleeping.
Later, Jane takes Adèle to the gallery, where they listen to music emanating from the drawing-room; Jane focuses intently, trying to discern Mr. Rochester's voice amidst the medley of sounds.
Around eleven o'clock, after Adèle has fallen asleep leaning against her, Jane carries the child to bed, noting that the party downstairs continued until nearly one in the morning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Don’t you feel hungry, Adèle?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies sought their chambers.

events.text_segment:
“Don’t you feel hungry, Adèle?”
“Mais oui, mademoiselle: voilà cinq ou six heures que nous n’avons pas mangé.”
“Well now, while the ladies are in their rooms, I will venture down and get you something to eat.”
And issuing from my asylum with precaution, I sought a back-stairs which conducted directly to the kitchen. All in that region was fire and commotion; the soup and fish were in the last stage of projection, and the cook hung over her crucibles in a frame of mind and body threatening spontaneous combustion. In the servants’ hall two coachmen and three gentlemen’s gentlemen stood or sat round the fire; the abigails, I suppose, were upstairs with their mistresses; the new servants, that had been hired from Millcote, were bustling about everywhere. Threading this chaos, I at last reached the larder; there I took possession of a cold chicken, a roll of bread, some tarts, a plate or two and a knife and fork: with this booty I made a hasty retreat. I had regained the gallery, and was just shutting the back-door behind me, when an accelerated hum warned me that the ladies were about to issue from their chambers. I could not proceed to the schoolroom without passing some of their doors, and running the risk of being surprised with my cargo of victualage; so I stood still at this end, which, being windowless, was dark: quite dark now, for the sun was set and twilight gathering.
Presently the chambers gave up their fair tenants one after another: each came out gaily and airily, with dress that gleamed lustrous through the dusk. For a moment they stood grouped together at the other extremity of the gallery, conversing in a key of sweet subdued vivacity: they then descended the staircase almost as noiselessly as a bright mist rolls down a hill. Their collective appearance had left on me an impression of high-born elegance, such as I had never before received.
I found Adèle peeping through the schoolroom door, which she held ajar. “What beautiful ladies!” cried she in English. “Oh, I wish I might go to them! Do you think Mr. Rochester will send for us by-and-by, after dinner?”
“No, indeed, I don’t; Mr. Rochester has something else to think about. Never mind the ladies to-night; perhaps you will see them to-morrow: here is your dinner.”
She was really hungry, so the chicken and tarts served to divert her attention for a time. It was well I secured this forage, or both she, I, and Sophie, to whom I conveyed a share of our repast, would have run a chance of getting no dinner at all: every one downstairs was too much engaged to think of us. The dessert was not carried out till after nine; and at ten footmen were still running to and fro with trays and coffee-cups. I allowed Adèle to sit up much later than usual; for she declared she could not possibly go to sleep while the doors kept opening and shutting below, and people bustling about. Besides, she added, a message might possibly come from Mr. Rochester when she was undressed; “et alors quel dommage!”
I told her stories as long as she would listen to them; and then for a change I took her out into the gallery. The hall lamp was now lit, and it amused her to look over the balustrade and watch the servants passing backwards and forwards. When the evening was far advanced, a sound of music issued from the drawing-room, whither the piano had been removed; Adèle and I sat down on the top step of the stairs to listen. Presently a voice blent with the rich tones of the instrument; it was a lady who sang, and very sweet her notes were. The solo over, a duet followed, and then a glee: a joyous conversational murmur filled up the intervals. I listened long: suddenly I discovered that my ear was wholly intent on analysing the mingled sounds, and trying to discriminate amidst the confusion of accents those of Mr. Rochester; and when it caught them, which it soon did, it found a further task in framing the tones, rendered by distance inarticulate, into words.
The clock struck eleven. I looked at Adèle, whose head leant against my shoulder; her eyes were waxing heavy, so I took her up in my arms and carried her off to bed. It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies sought their chambers.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Are you hungry, Adèle?" I asked. 
"Yes, mademoiselle: it's been five or six hours since we last ate," she replied.
"Alright, while the ladies are getting ready in their rooms, I'll slip downstairs to find you something to eat." 
I carefully left our safe spot and searched for a back staircase that led directly to the kitchen. That area was bustling with activity; the soup and fish were just about done, and the cook was working furiously, on the verge of exhaustion. In the servants' hall, two coachmen and three male staff members lounged around the fire; I assumed the maids were upstairs with the ladies, and the new hires from Millcote were hurrying about everywhere. Navigating through this commotion, I eventually reached the larder, from which I took a cold chicken, a bread roll, some tarts, and grabbed some plates with utensils. With my bounty collected, I quickly made my way back. I returned to the hallway and was just closing the door behind me when I noticed that the noise around me was increasing – the ladies were coming out of their rooms. I couldn’t get to the schoolroom without passing some of their doors and risk being discovered carrying the food. So I waited at the far, dark end of the passage, since the sun had set and it was now twilight. 

Soon, the ladies emerged from their rooms, one by one, dressed elegantly and shining in the dim light. They gathered for a moment, chatting in soft excited voices, then descended the stairs so gracefully it was like watching mist slide down a hill. Their collective presence impressed me with a sense of refined beauty I’d never experienced before. 

I found Adèle peeking through the schoolroom door. "What beautiful ladies!" she exclaimed in English. "Oh, I wish I could go to them! Do you think Mr. Rochester will invite us after dinner?" 
"No, I don't think so; Mr. Rochester is occupied tonight. Don’t mind the ladies for now; perhaps you’ll see them tomorrow. Here’s your dinner."
She was indeed hungry, and the chicken and tarts distracted her for a while. It’s good I’d managed this raid, as otherwise Adèle, Sophie, and I might not have eaten at all – everyone downstairs was too busy to think of us. Dessert wasn’t served until after nine, and even at ten, the footmen were still running around with trays and cups. I let Adèle stay up later than usual; she said she couldn’t sleep with all the noise and movement in the house – doors opening, people talking. She also mentioned she might miss a message from Mr. Rochester if she was undressed when it came: “et alors quel dommage!”

I told her stories for as long as she would listen, then, for a change, took her out into the gallery. The hall lamp was now lit, and she enjoyed looking over the railing and watching the servants go back and forth. Later in the evening, we heard music coming from the drawing-room, where the piano had been moved. Adèle and I sat together at the top of the stairs to listen. Soon a lady began to sing, her voice blending beautifully with the piano. After the solo, there was a duet, then a glee, in between which came happy, lively conversations. I listened for a while, realizing I was focused on trying to identify Mr. Rochester’s voice among the others, attempting to catch his words despite the indistinctness of distance.

At eleven o’clock, I noticed Adèle was dozing on my shoulder, so I carried her to bed. The men and ladies didn’t return to their rooms until nearly one."

events.title: An Unwanted Summons: Jane's Invitation to the Drawing-Room
detailed_summary: The following day, the visiting party engages in an excursion to a nearby site, with Jane witnessing both their departure and return.
Jane observes Miss Ingram as the sole lady participating in horse riding, noting that Mr. Rochester consistently rides by her side, slightly separated from the rest of the group.
She points this out to Mrs. Fairfax, suggesting it as evidence of Mr. Rochester's preference for Miss Ingram, a notion Mrs. Fairfax had previously downplayed.
Mrs. Fairfax concedes that Mr. Rochester likely admires Miss Ingram.
Jane further remarks that Miss Ingram appears to reciprocate his attention, expressing a wish to get a clearer view of Miss Ingram's face.

Mrs. Fairfax then informs Jane that she will indeed see Miss Ingram that evening, revealing that Mr. Rochester has requested Adèle's presence in the drawing-room after dinner, accompanied by Miss Eyre.
Jane expresses her reluctance, suspecting the invitation is merely a polite gesture on Mr. Rochester's part.

Mrs. Fairfax recounts her prior conversation with Mr. Rochester, in which he insisted on Jane's attendance, stating it was his 'particular wish' and even threatening to personally fetch her if she showed resistance.
Feeling compelled, Jane reluctantly agrees to attend, despite her discomfort with the prospect.

Mrs. Fairfax, having excused herself from attending, advises Jane on a strategy to enter the drawing-room discreetly before the ladies return from dinner, thereby avoiding a formal and potentially awkward entrance.
Mrs. Fairfax speculates that the guests will likely stay for about two or three weeks.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next day was as fine as its predecessor: it was devoted by the party to an excursion to some site in the neighbourhood.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Perhaps two or three weeks, certainly not more. After the Easter recess, Sir George Lynn, who was lately elected member for Millcote, will have to go up to town and take his seat; I daresay Mr. Rochester will accompany him: it surprises me that he has already made so protracted a stay at Thornfield.”

events.text_segment:
The next day was as fine as its predecessor: it was devoted by the party to an excursion to some site in the neighbourhood. They set out early in the forenoon, some on horseback, the rest in carriages; I witnessed both the departure and the return. Miss Ingram, as before, was the only lady equestrian; and, as before, Mr. Rochester galloped at her side; the two rode a little apart from the rest. I pointed out this circumstance to Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me—
“You said it was not likely they should think of being married,” said I, “but you see Mr. Rochester evidently prefers her to any of the other ladies.”
“Yes, I daresay: no doubt he admires her.”
“And she him,” I added; “look how she leans her head towards him as if she were conversing confidentially; I wish I could see her face; I have never had a glimpse of it yet.”
“You will see her this evening,” answered Mrs. Fairfax. “I happened to remark to Mr. Rochester how much Adèle wished to be introduced to the ladies, and he said: ‘Oh! let her come into the drawing-room after dinner; and request Miss Eyre to accompany her.’”
“Yes; he said that from mere politeness: I need not go, I am sure,” I answered.
“Well, I observed to him that as you were unused to company, I did not think you would like appearing before so gay a party—all strangers; and he replied, in his quick way—‘Nonsense! If she objects, tell her it is my particular wish; and if she resists, say I shall come and fetch her in case of contumacy.’”
“I will not give him that trouble,” I answered. “I will go, if no better may be; but I don’t like it. Shall you be there, Mrs. Fairfax?”
“No; I pleaded off, and he admitted my plea. I’ll tell you how to manage so as to avoid the embarrassment of making a formal entrance, which is the most disagreeable part of the business. You must go into the drawing-room while it is empty, before the ladies leave the dinner-table; choose your seat in any quiet nook you like; you need not stay long after the gentlemen come in, unless you please: just let Mr. Rochester see you are there and then slip away—nobody will notice you.”
“Will these people remain long, do you think?”
“Perhaps two or three weeks, certainly not more. After the Easter recess, Sir George Lynn, who was lately elected member for Millcote, will have to go up to town and take his seat; I daresay Mr. Rochester will accompany him: it surprises me that he has already made so protracted a stay at Thornfield.”

events.title: Entering the Drawing-Room: Jane's Detailed Observations of the Society Ladies
detailed_summary: Jane experiences considerable apprehension as the appointed time for her appearance in the drawing-room with Adèle draws near.
Adèle, who had been in a state of high excitement all day, becomes remarkably composed and serious during Sophie's dressing ministrations, and once ready, sits with perfect demureness.
Jane quickly attires herself in her finest dress, a silver-grey gown, and her sole ornament, a pearl brooch.
They utilize a less conspicuous entrance to the drawing-room, finding it unoccupied but warmly lit by a fire and candles, and adorned with flowers.
Adèle, still under a solemn impression, quietly takes a seat on a footstool indicated by Jane, who positions herself by a window-seat and attempts to read.
Adèle approaches Jane and requests a flower to enhance her attire; Jane, with a mix of amusement and sympathy for the child's earnest preoccupation with dress, fastens a rose onto her sash.
The ladies enter from the adjoining dining room. Jane rises and curtseys; her gesture is met with a few nods from some, while others simply stare at her.
Jane observes the group of eight ladies, noting their graceful movements and the way their voluminous attire seems to magnify their presence.
She identifies and mentally describes Mrs. Eshton and her two daughters, Amy (small, naive, and piquant) and Louisa (taller and more elegant).
Lady Lynn is characterized as a large, imposing, and haughty figure, richly dressed. In contrast, Mrs. Colonel Dent appears less flamboyant but more genuinely ladylike, with a gentle demeanor.

The most distinguished figures are the Dowager Lady Ingram and her daughters, Blanche and Mary, all of whom are exceptionally tall. The Dowager possesses a commanding physical presence but is marked by an almost unbearable haughtiness in her expression and bearing.
Jane scrutinizes Blanche Ingram with keen interest, comparing her appearance to Mrs. Fairfax's description and her own mental image, and pondering her suitability as a match for Mr. Rochester.

Blanche's physical attributes align with the descriptions, but her facial features, while youthful, reflect her mother's pride, albeit with a satirical rather than saturnine quality, evident in her frequent laughter and haughty lip.
Blanche engages Mrs. Dent in a discussion on botany, subtly showcasing her knowledge while highlighting Mrs. Dent's lack thereof. She also demonstrates her musical abilities and fluent French.
Mary Ingram has a milder countenance than her sister but lacks vivacity and expressiveness, appearing static and reserved.

Jane remains undecided about whether Miss Ingram would be Mr. Rochester's choice, acknowledging her accomplishments and majestic air but concluding that she needs to observe them together to form a definite opinion.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And did I now think Miss Ingram such a choice as Mr. Rochester would be likely to make? I could not tell—I did not know his taste in female beauty. If he liked the majestic, she was the very type of majesty: then she was accomplished, sprightly. Most gentlemen would admire her, I thought; and that he did admire her, I already seemed to have obtained proof: to remove the last shade of doubt, it remained but to see them together.

events.text_segment:
It was with some trepidation that I perceived the hour approach when I was to repair with my charge to the drawing-room. Adèle had been in a state of ecstasy all day, after hearing she was to be presented to the ladies in the evening; and it was not till Sophie commenced the operation of dressing her that she sobered down. Then the importance of the process quickly steadied her, and by the time she had her curls arranged in well-smoothed, drooping clusters, her pink satin frock put on, her long sash tied, and her lace mittens adjusted, she looked as grave as any judge. No need to warn her not to disarrange her attire: when she was dressed, she sat demurely down in her little chair, taking care previously to lift up the satin skirt for fear she should crease it, and assured me she would not stir thence till I was ready. This I quickly was: my best dress (the silver-grey one, purchased for Miss Temple’s wedding, and never worn since) was soon put on; my hair was soon smoothed; my sole ornament, the pearl brooch, soon assumed. We descended.
Fortunately there was another entrance to the drawing-room than that through the saloon where they were all seated at dinner. We found the apartment vacant; a large fire burning silently on the marble hearth, and wax candles shining in bright solitude, amid the exquisite flowers with which the tables were adorned. The crimson curtain hung before the arch: slight as was the separation this drapery formed from the party in the adjoining saloon, they spoke in so low a key that nothing of their conversation could be distinguished beyond a soothing murmur.
Adèle, who appeared to be still under the influence of a most solemnising impression, sat down, without a word, on the footstool I pointed out to her. I retired to a window-seat, and taking a book from a table near, endeavoured to read. Adèle brought her stool to my feet; ere long she touched my knee.
“What is it, Adèle?”
“Est-ce que je ne puis pas prendre une seule de ces fleurs magnifiques, mademoiselle? Seulement pour completer ma toilette.”
“You think too much of your ‘toilette,’ Adèle: but you may have a flower.” And I took a rose from a vase and fastened it in her sash. She sighed a sigh of ineffable satisfaction, as if her cup of happiness were now full. I turned my face away to conceal a smile I could not suppress: there was something ludicrous as well as painful in the little Parisienne’s earnest and innate devotion to matters of dress.
A soft sound of rising now became audible; the curtain was swept back from the arch; through it appeared the dining-room, with its lit lustre pouring down light on the silver and glass of a magnificent dessert-service covering a long table; a band of ladies stood in the opening; they entered, and the curtain fell behind them.
There were but eight; yet, somehow, as they flocked in, they gave the impression of a much larger number. Some of them were very tall; many were dressed in white; and all had a sweeping amplitude of array that seemed to magnify their persons as a mist magnifies the moon. I rose and curtseyed to them: one or two bent their heads in return, the others only stared at me.
They dispersed about the room, reminding me, by the lightness and buoyancy of their movements, of a flock of white plumy birds. Some of them threw themselves in half-reclining positions on the sofas and ottomans: some bent over the tables and examined the flowers and books: the rest gathered in a group round the fire: all talked in a low but clear tone which seemed habitual to them. I knew their names afterwards, and may as well mention them now.
First, there was Mrs. Eshton and two of her daughters. She had evidently been a handsome woman, and was well preserved still. Of her daughters, the eldest, Amy, was rather little: naïve, and child-like in face and manner, and piquant in form; her white muslin dress and blue sash became her well. The second, Louisa, was taller and more elegant in figure; with a very pretty face, of that order the French term minois chiffoné: both sisters were fair as lilies.
Lady Lynn was a large and stout personage of about forty, very erect, very haughty-looking, richly dressed in a satin robe of changeful sheen: her dark hair shone glossily under the shade of an azure plume, and within the circlet of a band of gems.
Mrs. Colonel Dent was less showy; but, I thought, more lady-like. She had a slight figure, a pale, gentle face, and fair hair. Her black satin dress, her scarf of rich foreign lace, and her pearl ornaments, pleased me better than the rainbow radiance of the titled dame.
But the three most distinguished—partly, perhaps, because the tallest figures of the band—were the Dowager Lady Ingram and her daughters, Blanche and Mary. They were all three of the loftiest stature of women. The Dowager might be between forty and fifty: her shape was still fine; her hair (by candle-light at least) still black; her teeth, too, were still apparently perfect. Most people would have termed her a splendid woman of her age: and so she was, no doubt, physically speaking; but then there was an expression of almost insupportable haughtiness in her bearing and countenance. She had Roman features and a double chin, disappearing into a throat like a pillar: these features appeared to me not only inflated and darkened, but even furrowed with pride; and the chin was sustained by the same principle, in a position of almost preternatural erectness. She had, likewise, a fierce and a hard eye: it reminded me of Mrs. Reed’s; she mouthed her words in speaking; her voice was deep, its inflections very pompous, very dogmatical,—very intolerable, in short. A crimson velvet robe, and a shawl turban of some gold-wrought Indian fabric, invested her (I suppose she thought) with a truly imperial dignity.
Blanche and Mary were of equal stature,—straight and tall as poplars. Mary was too slim for her height, but Blanche was moulded like a Dian. I regarded her, of course, with special interest. First, I wished to see whether her appearance accorded with Mrs. Fairfax’s description; secondly, whether it at all resembled the fancy miniature I had painted of her; and thirdly—it will out!—whether it were such as I should fancy likely to suit Mr. Rochester’s taste.
As far as person went, she answered point for point, both to my picture and Mrs. Fairfax’s description. The noble bust, the sloping shoulders, the graceful neck, the dark eyes and black ringlets were all there;—but her face? Her face was like her mother’s; a youthful unfurrowed likeness: the same low brow, the same high features, the same pride. It was not, however, so saturnine a pride! she laughed continually; her laugh was satirical, and so was the habitual expression of her arched and haughty lip.
Genius is said to be self-conscious. I cannot tell whether Miss Ingram was a genius, but she was self-conscious—remarkably self-conscious indeed. She entered into a discourse on botany with the gentle Mrs. Dent. It seemed Mrs. Dent had not studied that science: though, as she said, she liked flowers, “especially wild ones;” Miss Ingram had, and she ran over its vocabulary with an air. I presently perceived she was (what is vernacularly termed) trailing Mrs. Dent; that is, playing on her ignorance; her trail might be clever, but it was decidedly not good-natured. She played: her execution was brilliant; she sang: her voice was fine; she talked French apart to her mamma; and she talked it well, with fluency and with a good accent.
Mary had a milder and more open countenance than Blanche; softer features too, and a skin some shades fairer (Miss Ingram was dark as a Spaniard)—but Mary was deficient in life: her face lacked expression, her eye lustre; she had nothing to say, and having once taken her seat, remained fixed like a statue in its niche. The sisters were both attired in spotless white.
And did I now think Miss Ingram such a choice as Mr. Rochester would be likely to make? I could not tell—I did not know his taste in female beauty. If he liked the majestic, she was the very type of majesty: then she was accomplished, sprightly. Most gentlemen would admire her, I thought; and that he did admire her, I already seemed to have obtained proof: to remove the last shade of doubt, it remained but to see them together.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Feeling quite nervous, I anticipated the moment when I was to escort my young charge, Adèle, to the drawing-room. Adèle had been excitedly looking forward to being introduced to the ladies that evening, and she only calmed down once Sophie began helping her get dressed. The seriousness of the dressing process quickly focused her, and by the time her curls were neatly arranged, her pink satin dress was on, her long sash tied, and her lace mittens adjusted, she looked extremely serious. There was no need to tell her to be careful with her clothes; once dressed, she sat primly in her small chair, making sure to lift her satin skirt to prevent wrinkles, and promised not to move until I was ready. I was ready quickly: I put on my best dress, the silver-grey one bought for Miss Temple’s wedding but never worn since, smoothed my hair, and attached my only decoration, the pearl brooch. We went downstairs.
Luckily, the drawing-room could be entered through a separate door, not through the saloon where the dinner party was seated. We found the room empty; a large fire was burning quietly on the marble fireplace, and wax candles shone brightly alone amongst the beautiful flowers decorating the tables. The crimson curtain hung over the archway; although this drapery provided only a slight barrier from the group in the adjoining saloon, they spoke softly enough that we could only hear a gentle murmur of conversation.
Adèle, still appearing quite solemn, sat silently on the footstool I showed her. I moved to a window seat, picked up a book from a nearby table, and attempted to read. Adèle brought her stool over to my feet; after a short while, she touched my knee.
“What is it, Adèle?”
“May I not take just one of these beautiful flowers, mademoiselle? Only to complete my outfit.”
“You think too much about your appearance, Adèle; but you may have a flower.” I took a rose from a vase and pinned it onto her sash. She let out a sigh of immense satisfaction, as if her happiness was now complete. I turned my head away to hide a smile I couldn't help; there was something both amusing and a little sad about the intensity and natural focus on clothes in the little Parisian girl.
A quiet sound of people rising was now audible; the curtain was pulled back from the archway; the dining room appeared through it, with its lit chandelier casting light on the silver and glass of a magnificent dessert service covering a long table; a group of ladies stood in the opening; they came in, and the curtain fell shut behind them.
There were only eight ladies, yet their entrance somehow created the impression of a much larger group. Some were very tall; many wore white; and all had an abundance of clothing that seemed to enlarge their figures, like how mist makes the moon look bigger. I stood up and curtseyed to them; a couple of them slightly bowed their heads in return, while the others simply stared at me.
They spread out around the room, their light, buoyant movements reminding me of a flock of white birds. Some positioned themselves in relaxed poses on the sofas and ottomans; some leaned over the tables, examining the flowers and books; the rest gathered together around the fire; they all spoke in a quiet but distinct manner that seemed natural to them. I learned their names later, and I may as well list them now.
First, there was Mrs. Eshton and her two daughters. She had clearly been attractive and remained well-preserved. Of her daughters, the elder, Amy, was rather short: innocent and childlike in appearance and behaviour, and with a charming figure; her white muslin dress and blue sash suited her well. The second, Louisa, was taller and more gracefully shaped; with a very pretty face of the type the French describe as having a charming irregularity; both sisters were as fair as lilies.
Lady Lynn was a large, heavy woman of about forty, very upright, very arrogant-looking, richly dressed in a satin dress with a shimmering effect: her dark hair shone brightly under a blue feather and within a band of jewels.
Mrs. Colonel Dent was less ostentatious, but in my opinion, more refined. She had a slender figure, a pale, gentle face, and fair hair. Her black satin dress, her scarf of expensive foreign lace, and her pearl jewelry appealed to me more than the colourful display of the titled lady.
However, the three most noticeable figures—partly, perhaps, because they were the tallest in the group—were the Dowager Lady Ingram and her daughters, Blanche and Mary. They were all three exceptionally tall women. The Dowager was probably between forty and fifty: her shape was still good; her hair (at least in the candle-light) still black; her teeth, too, seemed still flawless. Most people would have called her a magnificent woman for her age: and she was, undoubtedly, physically speaking; but her posture and expression conveyed an almost unbearable arrogance. She had strong features and a double chin that merged into a thick neck: these features struck me as not just swollen and dark, but even marked with pride; and the chin was held unnaturally high by the same principle. She also had a sharp, hard gaze: it brought Mrs. Reed to mind; she spoke affectedly; her voice was deep, her tone very formal, very bossy—very unpleasant, in short. A red velvet dress and a turban made of some Indian fabric embroidered with gold, she likely believed, gave her a truly regal dignity.
Blanche and Mary were the same height—straight and tall as poplar trees. Mary was too thin for her height, but Blanche was perfectly formed, like a goddess. Naturally, I observed her with particular interest. Firstly, I wanted to see if her appearance matched Mrs. Fairfax’s description; secondly, whether it resembled the mental picture I had created of her; and thirdly—I must admit!—whether she looked like someone I imagined Mr. Rochester might be attracted to.
As far as her physical appearance went, she corresponded exactly, both to my picture and Mrs. Fairfax’s description. The impressive chest, the sloping shoulders, the graceful neck, the dark eyes, and the black curls were all there;—but her face? Her face resembled her mother’s; a youthful, unlined version: the same low forehead, the same prominent features, the same pride. It was not, however, such a severe pride! she laughed constantly; her laugh was mocking, and that was also the usual expression on her curved, proud lips.
It is said that brilliant people are self-aware. I cannot say if Miss Ingram was brilliant, but she was remarkably self-conscious. She began a conversation about botany with the gentle Mrs. Dent. It seemed Mrs. Dent had not studied that subject; although, as she mentioned, she enjoyed flowers, “especially wild ones;” Miss Ingram had, and she recited technical terms with an air of expertise. I soon realised she was what is commonly called 'trailing' Mrs. Dent; that is, exploiting her lack of knowledge; her method might have been clever, but it was certainly not kind. She played piano; her performance was excellent; she sang; her voice was lovely; she spoke French privately to her mother; and she spoke it well, fluently and with a good accent.
Mary had a softer and more open face than Blanche; softer features too, and skin a few shades lighter (Miss Ingram was as dark as a Spaniard)—but Mary lacked vitality: her face was expressionless, her eyes dull; she had nothing to say, and once she had taken her seat, she remained still like a statue in its niche. Both sisters were dressed in immaculate white.
And did I now think Miss Ingram was the type of person Mr. Rochester would likely choose? I couldn’t tell—I didn't know his preferences in female beauty. If he liked a commanding presence, she was the epitome of it: also, she was accomplished and lively. Most gentlemen would admire her, I thought; and that he did admire her, I felt I had already seen evidence of: to completely eliminate any doubt, it remained only to see them together.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
As the time approached for me to join the ladies in the drawing-room with Adèle, I felt a bit nervous. Adèle had been overjoyed all day at the thought of being introduced to the assembled guests, but only became calm once Sophie started helping her dress. The seriousness of getting ready for the occasion quickly grounded her, and by the time her hair was arranged in soft, neat curls, her pink satin dress was on, the sash tied, and her lace gloves in place, she looked very earnest and composed. There was no need to remind her to keep tidy; once ready, she sat quietly on her chair, carefully lifting her dress so it wouldn't wrinkle, and promised me she would stay put until I was ready to go. I didn't take long: I put on my best grey dress, bought for Miss Temple's wedding but never worn since, arranged my hair, put on my simple pearl brooch, and we made our way downstairs.

Luckily, there was a way into the drawing-room that avoided the saloon where everyone was still dining. We reached an empty room, where a bright fire burned on the marble hearth, wax candles lit the space, and flowers decorated the tables. A crimson curtain separated us from the neighbouring saloon; though it was a thin barrier, the guests' voices were so soft that only a gentle hum could be heard.

Adèle, still under the weight of the occasion, sat silently on a stool I showed her. I went to the window, picked up a book, and tried to read. Soon, Adèle brought her stool next to me and touched my knee. 

“What is it, Adèle?” I asked.

She asked in French if she could have one of the lovely flowers to complete her outfit. I told her she thought too much about her appearance, but let her have a rose, which I pinned onto her sash. She sighed with deep satisfaction, as if now she was perfectly happy. I turned away to hide my smile, finding her devotion to dressing both amusing and a little exasperating.

Before long, the sound of people rising from dinner could be heard. The curtain was pulled aside, revealing the dining-room crowded with elegant dessert settings under bright lights. A group of ladies entered the drawing-room. Though there were only eight, their presence made them seem like more. Many were tall, dressed in white, and their grand attire gave them an even grander appearance. I stood and curtsied; a couple nodded in return, the rest simply stared at me.

As they moved about the room gracefully, I was reminded of delicate birds. Some reclined on sofas, some examined the flowers and books on the tables, while others gathered by the fire—all speaking in a soft, polished tone. I later learned their names and will mention them now.

There was Mrs. Eshton and her two daughters. Mrs. Eshton was still striking, and her daughters were both attractive and fair. Amy, the eldest, was petite and childlike, charmingly dressed in a white muslin gown with a blue sash. Louisa was taller and more elegant, with a pretty, animated face.

Lady Lynn was a large, imposing woman of about forty, standing straight and proud, richly dressed in shimmering satin, her dark hair shining beneath a blue plume and a jeweled headband. 

Mrs. Colonel Dent was less extravagant, but seemed, to me, the more refined of the two. She was slender, with a pale, gentle face and fair hair. Her simple black dress, fine lace scarf, and pearl jewelry were more appealing to me than Lady Lynn's colorful outfit.

The most distinguished ladies—perhaps because they were the tallest—were the Dowager Lady Ingram and her two daughters, Blanche and Mary. All three were exceptionally tall. The Dowager, likely between forty and fifty, was still shapely with seemingly black hair and perfect teeth, but her look was marred by pronounced arrogance. She had strong features and a rigidly upright posture, with an intense, hard gaze reminiscent of Mrs. Reed. Her voice was deep and pompous, and her crimson velvet dress with an ornate gold turban completed her regal, somewhat intimidating appearance.

Blanche and Mary, both dressed in spotless white, stood as tall as poplars. Mary was thinner and paler, her features softer but her expression lifeless. Blanche was more robust, with noble features and dark hair, perfectly fitting the picture Mrs. Fairfax had painted—and the one I had imagined. However, though beautiful and lively, pride clouded her face and her laughter was often mocking. Blanche was confident, almost to the point of arrogance. She showed off her knowledge of botany in a conversation with Mrs. Dent, using her expertise to subtly belittle her companion's ignorance. She also played and sang skillfully, and spoke fluent French to her mother.

Mary, for her part, was milder in appearance than Blanche, but much less lively, speaking little and remaining statue-like once seated.

I wondered whether Miss Ingram would suit Mr. Rochester's taste. She certainly fit the description of majesty and accomplishment that many men found attractive, and it seemed clear he admired her—but to be certain, I needed to see them together.

events.title: Adèle's Social Success and Jane's Resurgent, Secret Love for Rochester
detailed_summary: Adèle, far from remaining still, rises upon the ladies' entry, greets them with a formal reverence, and speaks to them politely.

Her reception varies: Miss Ingram regards her mockingly, calling her a 'little puppet'; Lady Lynn identifies her as Mr. Rochester's ward; Mrs. Dent kindly takes her hand and kisses her; and the Eshton sisters declare her charming.
Adèle is then invited to a sofa where she sits between the young ladies, captivating their attention, as well as that of Mrs. Eshton and Lady Lynn, with her animated chatter.
Coffee is served, and the gentlemen are summoned to join the ladies. Jane positions herself in a shaded area, hoping to remain unnoticed.
The gentlemen enter, presenting an imposing collective appearance. Jane notes the dashing Lynn brothers, the soldierly Colonel Dent, the distinguished Mr. Eshton, and the tall, listless Lord Ingram.

Mr. Rochester enters last. Although Jane is not looking directly at the entrance, she is intensely aware of his arrival, and memories of their last significant encounter, where she felt a close connection to his emotions, flood her mind.

She feels the profound chasm that has developed between them since then, expecting no acknowledgment from him. He indeed takes a seat across the room and begins conversing with some of the ladies without looking at her.
Once his attention is engaged elsewhere, Jane finds her gaze involuntarily drawn to his face, experiencing a mixture of acute pleasure and poignant agony as she observes him.

She reflects on his unconventional features, which hold an irresistible allure for her, and acknowledges that her love for him, which she had tried to suppress, has powerfully resurfaced at this renewed sight of him.
Comparing Mr. Rochester to his guests, she finds them lacking his intrinsic strength and character, even if others might deem them more conventionally attractive.
She observes Mr. Rochester's smile, which transforms his stern features, and feels a profound sense of kinship with him, believing they share an understanding that transcends social barriers.

Jane reaffirms her deep love for him, despite recognizing the necessity of concealing her sentiments and the unlikelihood of her feelings being reciprocated in a way that could bridge their differences.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: You are not to suppose, reader, that Adèle has all this time been sitting motionless on the stool at my feet: no; when the ladies entered, she rose, advanced to meet them, made a stately reverence, and said with gravity—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I must, then, repeat continually that we are for ever sundered:—and yet, while I breathe and think, I must love him.”

events.text_segment:
You are not to suppose, reader, that Adèle has all this time been sitting motionless on the stool at my feet: no; when the ladies entered, she rose, advanced to meet them, made a stately reverence, and said with gravity—
“Bon jour, mesdames.”
And Miss Ingram had looked down at her with a mocking air, and exclaimed, “Oh, what a little puppet!”
Lady Lynn had remarked, “It is Mr. Rochester’s ward, I suppose—the little French girl he was speaking of.”
Mrs. Dent had kindly taken her hand, and given her a kiss. Amy and Louisa Eshton had cried out simultaneously—
“What a love of a child!”
And then they had called her to a sofa, where she now sat, ensconced between them, chattering alternately in French and broken English; absorbing not only the young ladies’ attention, but that of Mrs. Eshton and Lady Lynn, and getting spoilt to her heart’s content.
At last coffee is brought in, and the gentlemen are summoned. I sit in the shade—if any shade there be in this brilliantly-lit apartment; the window-curtain half hides me. Again the arch yawns; they come. The collective appearance of the gentlemen, like that of the ladies, is very imposing: they are all costumed in black; most of them are tall, some young. Henry and Frederick Lynn are very dashing sparks indeed; and Colonel Dent is a fine soldierly man. Mr. Eshton, the magistrate of the district, is gentleman-like: his hair is quite white, his eyebrows and whiskers still dark, which gives him something of the appearance of a “père noble de théâtre.” Lord Ingram, like his sisters, is very tall; like them, also, he is handsome; but he shares Mary’s apathetic and listless look: he seems to have more length of limb than vivacity of blood or vigour of brain.
And where is Mr. Rochester?
He comes in last: I am not looking at the arch, yet I see him enter. I try to concentrate my attention on those netting-needles, on the meshes of the purse I am forming—I wish to think only of the work I have in my hands, to see only the silver beads and silk threads that lie in my lap; whereas, I distinctly behold his figure, and I inevitably recall the moment when I last saw it; just after I had rendered him, what he deemed, an essential service, and he, holding my hand, and looking down on my face, surveyed me with eyes that revealed a heart full and eager to overflow; in whose emotions I had a part. How near had I approached him at that moment! What had occurred since, calculated to change his and my relative positions? Yet now, how distant, how far estranged we were! So far estranged, that I did not expect him to come and speak to me. I did not wonder, when, without looking at me, he took a seat at the other side of the room, and began conversing with some of the ladies.
No sooner did I see that his attention was riveted on them, and that I might gaze without being observed, than my eyes were drawn involuntarily to his face; I could not keep their lids under control: they would rise, and the irids would fix on him. I looked, and had an acute pleasure in looking,—a precious yet poignant pleasure; pure gold, with a steely point of agony: a pleasure like what the thirst-perishing man might feel who knows the well to which he has crept is poisoned, yet stoops and drinks divine draughts nevertheless.
Most true is it that “beauty is in the eye of the gazer.” My master’s colourless, olive face, square, massive brow, broad and jetty eyebrows, deep eyes, strong features, firm, grim mouth,—all energy, decision, will,—were not beautiful, according to rule; but they were more than beautiful to me; they were full of an interest, an influence that quite mastered me,—that took my feelings from my own power and fettered them in his. I had not intended to love him; the reader knows I had wrought hard to extirpate from my soul the germs of love there detected; and now, at the first renewed view of him, they spontaneously arrived, green and strong! He made me love him without looking at me.
I compared him with his guests. What was the gallant grace of the Lynns, the languid elegance of Lord Ingram,—even the military distinction of Colonel Dent, contrasted with his look of native pith and genuine power? I had no sympathy in their appearance, their expression: yet I could imagine that most observers would call them attractive, handsome, imposing; while they would pronounce Mr. Rochester at once harsh-featured and melancholy-looking. I saw them smile, laugh—it was nothing; the light of the candles had as much soul in it as their smile; the tinkle of the bell as much significance as their laugh. I saw Mr. Rochester smile:—his stern features softened; his eye grew both brilliant and gentle, its ray both searching and sweet. He was talking, at the moment, to Louisa and Amy Eshton. I wondered to see them receive with calm that look which seemed to me so penetrating: I expected their eyes to fall, their colour to rise under it; yet I was glad when I found they were in no sense moved. “He is not to them what he is to me,” I thought: “he is not of their kind. I believe he is of mine;—I am sure he is—I feel akin to him—I understand the language of his countenance and movements: though rank and wealth sever us widely, I have something in my brain and heart, in my blood and nerves, that assimilates me mentally to him. Did I say, a few days since, that I had nothing to do with him but to receive my salary at his hands? Did I forbid myself to think of him in any other light than as a paymaster? Blasphemy against nature! Every good, true, vigorous feeling I have gathers impulsively round him. I know I must conceal my sentiments: I must smother hope; I must remember that he cannot care much for me. For when I say that I am of his kind, I do not mean that I have his force to influence, and his spell to attract; I mean only that I have certain tastes and feelings in common with him. I must, then, repeat continually that we are for ever sundered:—and yet, while I breathe and think, I must love him.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Please understand, reader, that Adèle wasn't just sitting still at my feet all this time. No, when the ladies came in, she got up, went to greet them, curtsied formally, and said seriously, "Good morning, ladies." Miss Ingram looked down at her mockingly and called her "Oh, what a little doll!" Lady Lynn commented, "She must be Mr. Rochester's ward, the little French girl he mentioned." Mrs. Dent kindly held her hand and kissed her. Amy and Louisa Eshton simultaneously exclaimed, "What a darling child!" They then invited her to a sofa where she now sat between them, constantly chatting in a mix of French and broken English. She was capturing the attention of not only the young ladies but also Mrs. Eshton and Lady Lynn, and was being thoroughly indulged. Finally, coffee arrived, and the gentlemen were called in. I sat partly hidden by the window-curtain, finding what little shade I could in the brightly lit room. The archway opened again; they entered. The men, like the women, made a strong collective impression. They were all dressed in black, mostly tall, some young. Henry and Frederick Lynn were certainly very lively and attractive. Colonel Dent was a distinguished soldier. Mr. Eshton, the local magistrate, was gentlemanly; his completely white hair contrasted with his still dark eyebrows and whiskers, giving him a somewhat theatrical noble father appearance. Lord Ingram, like his sisters, was very tall and handsome, but he shared Mary's indifferent and tired expression. He seemed to have more physical size than energy or mental sharpness. And where was Mr. Rochester? He came in last. I wasn't looking at the arch, but I still saw him enter. I tried to focus my attention on my knitting needles, on the stitches of the purse I was making; I wanted only to think about my work and see only the silver beads and silk threads in my lap. However, I clearly saw him and couldn't help but remember the last time I had seen him, right after I had done him what he considered a crucial favour. Then, holding my hand and looking down at my face, his eyes had surveyed me with a heart full of emotion ready to spill over, emotions in which I felt a part. How close I had felt to him at that moment! What had happened since then to change our relationship and positions so much? Yet now, how distant, how estranged we were! So estranged that I didn't expect him to come and speak to me. I wasn't surprised when, without looking at me, he took a seat across the room and began talking to some of the ladies. As soon as I saw that his attention was fixed on them and I could look without being seen, my eyes were uncontrollably drawn to his face. I couldn't keep my eyelids down; they would lift, and my gaze would fix on him. I looked, and found a sharp pleasure in doing so – a precious yet painful pleasure, like pure gold with a sharp point of suffering. It was like the pleasure a dying-of-thirst man might feel knowing the well he has crawled to is poisoned, yet still bends down and drinks the divine water anyway. It is absolutely true that "beauty is in the eye of the beholder." My master's pale, olive complexion, his square, solid forehead, thick, dark eyebrows, deep eyes, strong features, firm, serious mouth – everything about him spoke of energy, resolve, and will – were not beautiful by conventional standards. But they were more than beautiful to me; they held an interest, an influence that completely dominated me, taking control of my feelings and binding them to him. I had not intended to love him. The reader knows I had worked hard to remove any beginnings of love I found in my soul, and now, seeing him again for the first time, they sprang up spontaneously, green and strong! He made me love him without even looking at me. I compared him to his guests. How did the dashing charm of the Lynns, the tired elegance of Lord Ingram, or even Colonel Dent's military distinction compare to Rochester's look of natural vigour and genuine strength? I felt no connection to their appearance or expressions, yet I could imagine that most people would call them attractive, handsome, and impressive, while describing Mr. Rochester as having harsh features and looking sad. I saw them smile and laugh – it meant nothing. The light of the candles had as much soul as their smiles, and the sound of a bell had as much meaning as their laughter. Then I saw Mr. Rochester smile – his stern features softened; his eyes became both bright and gentle, his gaze both probing and sweet. He was speaking to Louisa and Amy Eshton at that moment. I was surprised to see them react calmly to a look that seemed so intense to me. I expected their eyes to drop, their faces to blush under it. Yet, I was glad when I saw they were unaffected. "He is not the same to them as he is to me," I thought. "He is not of their kind. I believe he is of mine; I am sure he is – I feel related to him – I understand the language of his face and movements. Although social class and wealth separate us greatly, I have something in my mind and heart, in my blood and nerves, that connects me mentally to him. Did I say a few days ago that I had nothing to do with him except receive my salary? Did I forbid myself from thinking of him as anything other than an employer? That was wrong against nature! Every good, true, strong feeling I have instinctively gathers around him. I know I must hide my emotions; I must suppress hope. I must remember that he cannot care deeply for me. For when I say I am of his kind, I don't mean I have his power to influence or his ability to attract. I only mean that I share certain tastes and feelings with him. I must, then, keep reminding myself that we are forever divided – and yet, as long as I live and think, I must love him.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Do not think, reader, that Adèle sat idle at my feet the whole time; instead, as soon as the ladies entered, she got up, greeted them with a dignified curtsy and a serious 'Bon jour, mesdames.' Miss Ingram glanced at her mockingly and called her a 'little puppet,' while Lady Lynn speculated, 'She must be Mr. Rochester’s ward—the French girl he mentioned.' Mrs. Dent gave her a warm welcome with a handshake and a kiss. The Eshton sisters exclaimed in unison how adorable she was and drew her over to the couch. There, Adèle sat nestled between them, happily chatting in a mix of French and broken English, basking in the attention and being thoroughly indulged by the ladies, Mrs. Eshton, and Lady Lynn.

After a while, coffee was served and the men were called in. I sat quietly, half hidden by a curtain in the brightly lit room. The gentlemen, dressed in black and mostly tall and impressive, entered. Henry and Frederick Lynn were quite striking, Colonel Dent looked every bit the soldier, and Mr. Eshton, with white hair and dark eyebrows and whiskers, reminded me of a dignified stage father. Lord Ingram was tall and handsome but carried the same disinterested expression as his sisters; he seemed more about height than spirit or intellect.

Mr. Rochester entered last. Though not looking at the door, I noticed his arrival. I tried to focus on my work, occupied myself with my sewing, and attempted to pay attention only to the silver beads and silk threads in my lap. But his presence was unmistakable, and I couldn’t help but remember the last time I’d seen him, when he held my hand, grateful for my help, and regarded me with deep emotion I shared. We had seemed so close then, but now, we were so distant—I didn’t expect him to even speak to me. Not surprisingly, he sat across the room and talked to other ladies, not acknowledging me.

Noticing that his attention was elsewhere, I allowed myself to look at him. I experienced a sharp, bittersweet delight—like someone dying of thirst who drinks from a poisoned well, finding the water tragically wonderful.

The saying “beauty is in the eye of the beholder” rang true for me. Mr. Rochester’s pale olive skin, strong features, and determined mouth might not fit conventional standards of beauty, but to me, he was more than beautiful; his presence enthralled me, capturing my feelings completely. Although I had tried hard to extinguish my affection for him, seeing him again rekindled them instantly, stronger than before. He captivated me without even noticing me.

Comparing him to the other men—the refined Lynns, the elegant Lord Ingram, even the gallant Colonel Dent—their appeal seemed shallow compared to Mr. Rochester’s genuine strength and character. Others might call them more attractive, while describing Mr. Rochester as harsh and somber, but their smiles and laughter meant little to me. In contrast, his smile softened his features and illuminated his eyes, making them both intense and kindly as he spoke to Louisa and Amy Eshton. I was surprised they did not react as I would; it confirmed that he meant something different to me than to them. I sensed a kinship with him: despite our differences in status and fortune, I felt our minds and hearts had something in common. I chastised myself for thinking of him as only my employer, realizing that my true and deep feelings for him would be impossible to ignore. I acknowledged I must hide these emotions, never expecting he could care for me, since I lacked his power and allure—I only shared some similar traits and sensibilities. Despite knowing we could never be together, I could not help but love him while I lived and breathed.

events.title: Governesses Denigrated: Blanche Ingram's Scornful Diatribe
detailed_summary: The drawing-room atmosphere becomes animated as coffee is served and guests engage in various conversations and interactions.
Blanche Ingram, who had been standing apart, approaches Mr. Rochester, who is also solitary near the fireplace.
She initiates a conversation by questioning his apparent fondness for children, gesturing towards Adèle, and inquiring about how he came to have charge of her.
Mr. Rochester explains that Adèle was left in his care and that sending her to school was too expensive.

Blanche then draws attention to Jane, partially concealed by a window-curtain, remarking that employing a governess must be equally or more costly. Jane, overhearing, hopes for a glance from Mr. Rochester, but he does not look her way.
Mr. Rochester indifferently dismisses the topic of financial considerations.

Blanche seizes the opportunity to launch into a derogatory discourse on governesses, recounting her and her sister Mary's experiences with numerous governesses whom she describes as 'detestable,' 'ridiculous,' and 'incubi.'
The Dowager Lady Ingram chimes in, expressing her own aversion to governesses and claiming to have suffered 'martyrdom' from their incompetence and caprice.

Mrs. Dent quietly reminds the Dowager of Jane's presence. The Dowager dismisses the concern, stating she hopes the critique might benefit Jane, and further comments that Jane's physiognomy reveals 'all the faults of her class.'
When Mr. Rochester pointedly asks what these faults are, the Dowager suggests Blanche can elaborate.
Blanche continues her diatribe, labeling governesses a 'nuisance' and gleefully recounting pranks she and her brother Theodore played on their former governesses, especially a Madame Joubert.
Lord Ingram corroborates his sister's account, recalling how they would mock their governess's perceived ignorance.

Blanche then details how they 'persecuted' a tutor, Mr. Vining, whom they suspected of a romantic interest in one of the governesses, ultimately leading to their dismissal due to her mother deeming the situation to have an 'immoral tendency.'
The Dowager Lady Ingram affirms her strict disapproval of any liaisons between governesses and tutors in a well-regulated household.
Blanche mockingly summarizes the purported dangers of such relationships and then declares the subject closed.
Amy Eshton attempts to share a more positive experience with a kind former governess.

Blanche sarcastically cuts short this line of conversation, fearing an 'abstract of the memoirs of all the governesses extant,' and decisively moves to introduce a new topic, seeking Mr. Rochester's support.
Mr. Rochester concurs, and Blanche takes it upon herself to lead the conversation in a new direction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Coffee is handed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Then on me be the onus of bringing it forward. Signior Eduardo, are you in voice to-night?”

events.text_segment:
Coffee is handed. The ladies, since the gentlemen entered, have become lively as larks; conversation waxes brisk and merry. Colonel Dent and Mr. Eshton argue on politics; their wives listen. The two proud dowagers, Lady Lynn and Lady Ingram, confabulate together. Sir George—whom, by-the-bye, I have forgotten to describe,—a very big, and very fresh-looking country gentleman, stands before their sofa, coffee-cup in hand, and occasionally puts in a word. Mr. Frederick Lynn has taken a seat beside Mary Ingram, and is showing her the engravings of a splendid volume: she looks, smiles now and then, but apparently says little. The tall and phlegmatic Lord Ingram leans with folded arms on the chair-back of the little and lively Amy Eshton; she glances up at him, and chatters like a wren: she likes him better than she does Mr. Rochester. Henry Lynn has taken possession of an ottoman at the feet of Louisa: Adèle shares it with him: he is trying to talk French with her, and Louisa laughs at his blunders. With whom will Blanche Ingram pair? She is standing alone at the table, bending gracefully over an album. She seems waiting to be sought; but she will not wait too long: she herself selects a mate.
Mr. Rochester, having quitted the Eshtons, stands on the hearth as solitary as she stands by the table: she confronts him, taking her station on the opposite side of the mantelpiece.
“Mr. Rochester, I thought you were not fond of children?”
“Nor am I.”
“Then, what induced you to take charge of such a little doll as that?” (pointing to Adèle). “Where did you pick her up?”
“I did not pick her up; she was left on my hands.”
“You should have sent her to school.”
“I could not afford it: schools are so dear.”
“Why, I suppose you have a governess for her: I saw a person with her just now—is she gone? Oh, no! there she is still, behind the window-curtain. You pay her, of course; I should think it quite as expensive,—more so; for you have them both to keep in addition.”
I feared—or should I say, hoped?—the allusion to me would make Mr. Rochester glance my way; and I involuntarily shrank farther into the shade: but he never turned his eyes.
“I have not considered the subject,” said he indifferently, looking straight before him.
“No, you men never do consider economy and common sense. You should hear mama on the chapter of governesses: Mary and I have had, I should think, a dozen at least in our day; half of them detestable and the rest ridiculous, and all incubi—were they not, mama?”
“Did you speak, my own?”
The young lady thus claimed as the dowager’s special property, reiterated her question with an explanation.
“My dearest, don’t mention governesses; the word makes me nervous. I have suffered a martyrdom from their incompetency and caprice. I thank Heaven I have now done with them!”
Mrs. Dent here bent over to the pious lady and whispered something in her ear; I suppose, from the answer elicited, it was a reminder that one of the anathematised race was present.
“Tant pis!” said her Ladyship, “I hope it may do her good!” Then, in a lower tone, but still loud enough for me to hear, “I noticed her; I am a judge of physiognomy, and in hers I see all the faults of her class.”
“What are they, madam?” inquired Mr. Rochester aloud.
“I will tell you in your private ear,” replied she, wagging her turban three times with portentous significancy.
“But my curiosity will be past its appetite; it craves food now.”
“Ask Blanche; she is nearer you than I.”
“Oh, don’t refer him to me, mama! I have just one word to say of the whole tribe; they are a nuisance. Not that I ever suffered much from them; I took care to turn the tables. What tricks Theodore and I used to play on our Miss Wilsons, and Mrs. Greys, and Madame Jouberts! Mary was always too sleepy to join in a plot with spirit. The best fun was with Madame Joubert: Miss Wilson was a poor sickly thing, lachrymose and low-spirited, not worth the trouble of vanquishing, in short; and Mrs. Grey was coarse and insensible; no blow took effect on her. But poor Madame Joubert! I see her yet in her raging passions, when we had driven her to extremities—spilt our tea, crumbled our bread and butter, tossed our books up to the ceiling, and played a charivari with the ruler and desk, the fender and fire-irons. Theodore, do you remember those merry days?”
“Yaas, to be sure I do,” drawled Lord Ingram; “and the poor old stick used to cry out, ‘Oh you villains childs!’—and then we sermonised her on the presumption of attempting to teach such clever blades as we were, when she was herself so ignorant.”
“We did; and, Tedo, you know, I helped you in prosecuting (or persecuting) your tutor, whey-faced Mr. Vining—the parson in the pip, as we used to call him. He and Miss Wilson took the liberty of falling in love with each other—at least Tedo and I thought so; we surprised sundry tender glances and sighs which we interpreted as tokens of ‘la belle passion,’ and I promise you the public soon had the benefit of our discovery; we employed it as a sort of lever to hoist our dead-weights from the house. Dear mama, there, as soon as she got an inkling of the business, found out that it was of an immoral tendency. Did you not, my lady-mother?”
“Certainly, my best. And I was quite right: depend on that: there are a thousand reasons why liaisons between governesses and tutors should never be tolerated a moment in any well-regulated house; firstly—”
“Oh, gracious, mama! Spare us the enumeration! Au reste, we all know them: danger of bad example to innocence of childhood; distractions and consequent neglect of duty on the part of the attached—mutual alliance and reliance; confidence thence resulting—insolence accompanying—mutiny and general blow-up. Am I right, Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park?”
“My lily-flower, you are right now, as always.”
“Then no more need be said: change the subject.”
Amy Eshton, not hearing or not heeding this dictum, joined in with her soft, infantine tone: “Louisa and I used to quiz our governess too; but she was such a good creature, she would bear anything: nothing put her out. She was never cross with us; was she, Louisa?”
“No, never: we might do what we pleased; ransack her desk and her workbox, and turn her drawers inside out; and she was so good-natured, she would give us anything we asked for.”
“I suppose, now,” said Miss Ingram, curling her lip sarcastically, “we shall have an abstract of the memoirs of all the governesses extant: in order to avert such a visitation, I again move the introduction of a new topic. Mr. Rochester, do you second my motion?”
“Madam, I support you on this point, as on every other.”
“Then on me be the onus of bringing it forward. Signior Eduardo, are you in voice to-night?”
