"Where did you find her?" "I didn't find her; she was left with me." "You should have sent her to school." "I couldn't afford it; schools are very expensive." "Well, I suppose you have a governess for her? I saw someone with her just now—has she left? Oh, no! There she is, still behind the window curtain. You pay her, of course. I'd think that's just as costly—if not more so—because you have both of them to support." I was afraid—or perhaps I hoped—that mentioning me would make Mr. Rochester look my way, and I automatically pulled back further into the shadows, but he didn't turn his eyes. "I haven't thought about it," he said without interest, looking straight ahead. "No, you men never consider saving money or using common sense. You should hear my mother talk about governesses. Mary and I must have had at least twelve in our time. Half of them were awful, the rest were silly, and all were burdens—weren't they, Mother?" "Did you speak, dear?" The young lady, acknowledged as her mother's special charge, repeated her question, adding an explanation. "Darling, don't mention governesses; the word makes me anxious. I've suffered terribly from their inability and moods. Thank goodness I'm finished with them now!" Mrs. Dent then leaned towards the devout lady and whispered something to her. Based on the response, I assume it was a reminder that one of the despised group was present. "Too bad!" her Ladyship said. "I hope it does her some good!" Then, in a quieter voice, but still loud enough for me to hear, she added, "I noticed her. I am good at judging faces, and I see all the typical flaws of her type in hers." "What are those faults, Madam?" Mr. Rochester asked out loud. "I'll tell you privately," she replied, shaking her turban three times with significant meaning. "But my curiosity will be gone soon; it wants to be satisfied now." "Ask Blanche; she is closer to you than I am." "Oh, don't send him to me, Mother! I only have one word for the whole lot: they are a nuisance. Not that I ever suffered much from them; I made sure to turn the tables. The tricks Theodore and I used to play on our Miss Wilsons, and Mrs. Greys, and Madame Jouberts! Mary was always too tired to join in scheming enthusiastically. Madame Joubert was the most fun. Miss Wilson was a weak, sickly person, tearful and depressed, not worth the effort of defeating, really. And Mrs. Grey was crude and didn't react; nothing bothered her. But poor Madame Joubert! I can still picture her in her furious rages when we had pushed her to the limit—spilled our tea, crumbled our bread and butter, thrown our books up to the ceiling, and made a terrible noise with the ruler, desk, fireguard, and poker." She turned to Lord Ingram. "Theodore, do you remember those enjoyable times?" "Yes, I certainly do," Lord Ingram drawled. "And the poor old woman used to shout, 'Oh you villains childs!'—and then we would lecture her about daring to try and teach clever people like us when she was so ignorant herself." "We did! And, Tedo, you know I helped you in bothering (or tormenting) your pale tutor, Mr. Vining—the parson in the dumps, as we called him. He and Miss Wilson took the liberty of falling in love with each other—at least, Tedo and I thought so. We caught several gentle glances and sighs that we took to be signs of 'love,' and I promise you, the public soon learned about our discovery. We used it as a way to push our unwanted tutors out of the house. Dear Mother here, as soon as she heard about it, decided it was morally questionable. Didn't you, Mother dear?" "Absolutely, my dearest. And I was completely right, believe me. There are countless reasons why relationships between governesses and tutors should never be allowed for a moment in any well-run home. Firstly—" "Oh, please, Mother! Don't list them all! Besides, we all know them: the risk of setting a bad example for innocent children; the distractions and resulting neglect of duties by the couple; their mutual support and trust, which leads to arrogance and rebellion, and a general disaster. Am I right, Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park?" "My lovely girl, you are right now, as always." "Then nothing more needs to be said. Change the subject." Amy Eshton, either not hearing or ignoring this command, added in her soft, childish voice, "Louisa and I used to tease our governess too, but she was such a good person; she'd put up with anything. Nothing upset her. She was never cross with us, was she, Louisa?" "No, never. We could do whatever we wanted; rummage through her desk and sewing box, and turn her drawers inside out, and she was so kind-hearted, she would give us anything we asked for." "I suppose now," said Miss Ingram, curling her lip mockingly, "we're going to hear summaries of the lives of every governess who ever existed. To avoid such a tiresome process, I propose we introduce a new topic again. Mr. Rochester, do you second my proposal?" "Madam, I support you on this matter, as on every other." "Then I will take on the responsibility of introducing it. Signior Eduardo, are you ready to sing tonight?"
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Coffee is served, and now that the men have joined the group, the women are cheerful and chatty. Colonel Dent and Mr. Eshton are debating politics while their wives listen. Lady Lynn and Lady Ingram, both grand dames, are deep in discussion. Sir George—a large, healthy-looking country gentleman I’ve yet to describe—stands in front of their couch, holding his coffee and occasionally joining the talk. Mr. Frederick Lynn sits next to Mary Ingram, showing her pictures from a lavish book; she looks on and smiles at times but barely speaks. Lord Ingram, tall and composed, leans on the back of lively Amy Eshton’s chair; she looks up and talks incessantly, enjoying his company more than that of Mr. Rochester. Henry Lynn has found a seat at Louisa’s feet on an ottoman, which Adèle shares; he attempts to speak French with Adèle, while Louisa laughs at his mistakes. Meanwhile, Blanche Ingram stands alone, gracefully examining an album at the table. It looks as if she is waiting for someone to approach, but she will not wait long; she tends to choose her companion herself.

Mr. Rochester, now away from the Eshtons, stands alone by the fireplace, mirroring Blanche’s solitary position across from him at the mantelpiece. She addresses him:

“Mr. Rochester, I didn’t think you liked children?”
“Nor do I.”
“Then why did you take responsibility for a little doll like her?” she asks, referring to Adèle. “Where did you find her?”
“I didn’t pick her up; she was left to me.”
“You ought to have sent her to school.”
“I couldn’t afford it; schools are too expensive.”
“You must have a governess for her—I saw someone with her just now—there she is behind the window curtain. You pay her, of course. I imagine that is just as costly, if not more, since you must support them both.”

I wondered (or hoped) that this mention of me would make Mr. Rochester look my way, and I drew further into the shadows; but he didn’t glance at me.

“I haven’t thought about it,” he replied indifferently, staring straight ahead.

“No, you men never do think of saving money or using common sense. You should hear my mother on the topic of governesses. I’m sure Mary and I have had at least a dozen in our time; half were awful, the others ridiculous, and all of them burdens—weren’t they, mama?”

"Did you speak, my dear?"

The young lady pressed her question, explaining further.

"My dear, don’t mention the subject of governesses; the word makes me nervous. I’ve suffered so much from their incompetence and whims. Thank Heaven I’m finished with them!"

Mrs. Dent leaned over and whispered something to this pious lady, likely reminding her that one of the criticized group was present.

"So much the better!" said her Ladyship. "I hope it does her good!" She then continued in a lower but still audible voice, "I observed her; I’m good at reading faces, and I see every fault of her class in hers."

"What are those faults?" asked Mr. Rochester aloud.

"I’ll tell you privately," she answered, moving her headdress for emphasis.

"But I’m curious now; tell me."

"Ask Blanche; she’s closer."

"Please don’t refer him to me, mother! I have only one thing to say about governesses; they’re a nuisance. Not that I ever had much trouble with them; I always managed to get my way. Theodore and I used to play tricks on Miss Wilson, Mrs. Grey, and Madame Joubert. Mary was too sleepy to help with our pranks. The best times were with Madame Joubert: Miss Wilson was sickly and too sad to bother overpowering, and Mrs. Grey was coarse and unbothered by our tricks. But Madame Joubert, she’d rage whenever we pushed her limits—spilling tea, making a mess, throwing books, and banging things about. Theodore, do you remember those fun times?"

"Yes, certainly," replied Lord Ingram. "Poor old stick used to cry out, ‘Oh, you little villains!’—then we’d lecture her for daring to teach such clever children when she was so ignorant."

"We did, and, Theo, you know, I helped go after your tutor, pale Mr. Vining. He and Miss Wilson seemed to fall in love—or we thought they did; we noticed glances and sighs, which we took as signs, and made sure everyone else did too. We used this discovery to get them removed. Once mother caught wind of this, she found it immoral. Didn’t you, mother?"

"Of course, my dear. I had good reason: relationships between governesses and tutors mustn’t be tolerated in a proper house; firstly—"

"Oh, please, mother! Spare us the list! Anyway, we all know why: it’s a risk to the children, distracts from duty, encourages alliances, builds confidence, invites insolence, leads to rebellion and upheaval. Am I right, Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park?"

"Of course, you are, my flower."

"Then we needn’t say more; let’s talk about something else."

Amy Eshton, either not hearing or ignoring this, chimed in with a gentle voice: "Louisa and I teased our governess too; but she was so kind, she tolerated anything: nothing angered her; wasn’t that so, Louisa?"

"Yes, never; we could do as we pleased—go through her belongings, and she’d give us anything we wanted."

"I suppose," said Miss Ingram sarcastically, "we’re about to hear the life stories of every governess ever. To prevent that, I suggest we change the topic. Mr. Rochester, do you agree?"

"Madam, I stand with you on this and all other points."

"Then I’ll bring up a new subject. Signior Eduardo, can you sing tonight?"

events.title: Blanche's Imperious Performance and Rochester's Captivating Song
detailed_summary: Blanche, addressing Mr. Rochester with the theatrical title 'Signior Eduardo,' playfully commands him to prepare his vocal organs for her 'royal service.'
A flirtatious repartee follows, with Mr. Rochester readily complying with her grandiloquent requests.

Blanche seats herself at the piano, expressing disdain for the historical figure Rizzio and a preference for the more roguish 'black Bothwell,' asserting that a man is uninteresting without 'a spice of the devil.'
Mr. Rochester jokingly asks the gentlemen present which of them most resembles Bothwell, to which Colonel Dent suggests Rochester himself.
Miss Ingram commences a brilliant piano prelude, her words and demeanor calculated to impress and perhaps startle her audience with her audaciousness.
She vehemently expresses her contempt for contemporary young men, deeming them feeble, overly cautious, and excessively concerned with their appearance.
She proclaims that beauty is the exclusive domain of women, while men should aspire only to strength and valor, advocating a life of hunting, shooting, and fighting.
After a dramatic pause, Blanche declares her marital intentions: her husband must be a foil to her, not a competitor, and she will demand his undivided homage.
She then instructs Mr. Rochester to sing a Corsair-song, a genre she professes to adore, urging him to perform it 'con spirito.'
Their witty banter continues, with Rochester vowing obedience and Blanche playfully threatening punishment if his performance displeases her.
Jane, who had considered leaving, finds herself captivated and rooted to the spot by the sound of Mr. Rochester's singing voice.
She is deeply moved by his mellow and powerful bass, which she feels conveys his own emotions and strength, resonating directly with her heart.
She remains until the song is finished and the general conversation resumes, only then quietly making her exit through a nearby side-door.

events.text_segment:
“Donna Bianca, if you command it, I will be.”
“Then, signior, I lay on you my sovereign behest to furbish up your lungs and other vocal organs, as they will be wanted on my royal service.”
“Who would not be the Rizzio of so divine a Mary?”
“A fig for Rizzio!” cried she, tossing her head with all its curls, as she moved to the piano. “It is my opinion the fiddler David must have been an insipid sort of fellow; I like black Bothwell better: to my mind a man is nothing without a spice of the devil in him; and history may say what it will of James Hepburn, but I have a notion, he was just the sort of wild, fierce, bandit hero whom I could have consented to gift with my hand.”
“Gentlemen, you hear! Now which of you most resembles Bothwell?” cried Mr. Rochester.
“I should say the preference lies with you,” responded Colonel Dent.
“On my honour, I am much obliged to you,” was the reply.
Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude, commenced a brilliant prelude; talking meantime. She appeared to be on her high horse to-night; both her words and her air seemed intended to excite not only the admiration, but the amazement of her auditors: she was evidently bent on striking them as something very dashing and daring indeed.
“Oh, I am so sick of the young men of the present day!” exclaimed she, rattling away at the instrument. “Poor, puny things, not fit to stir a step beyond papa’s park gates: nor to go even so far without mama’s permission and guardianship! Creatures so absorbed in care about their pretty faces, and their white hands, and their small feet; as if a man had anything to do with beauty! As if loveliness were not the special prerogative of woman—her legitimate appanage and heritage! I grant an ugly woman is a blot on the fair face of creation; but as to the gentlemen, let them be solicitous to possess only strength and valour: let their motto be:—Hunt, shoot, and fight: the rest is not worth a fillip. Such should be my device, were I a man.”
“Whenever I marry,” she continued after a pause which none interrupted, “I am resolved my husband shall not be a rival, but a foil to me. I will suffer no competitor near the throne; I shall exact an undivided homage: his devotions shall not be shared between me and the shape he sees in his mirror. Mr. Rochester, now sing, and I will play for you.”
“I am all obedience,” was the response.
“Here then is a Corsair-song. Know that I doat on Corsairs; and for that reason, sing it con spirito.”
“Commands from Miss Ingram’s lips would put spirit into a mug of milk and water.”
“Take care, then: if you don’t please me, I will shame you by showing how such things should be done.”
“That is offering a premium on incapacity: I shall now endeavour to fail.”
“Gardez-vous en bien! If you err wilfully, I shall devise a proportionate punishment.”
“Miss Ingram ought to be clement, for she has it in her power to inflict a chastisement beyond mortal endurance.”
“Ha! explain!” commanded the lady.
“Pardon me, madam: no need of explanation; your own fine sense must inform you that one of your frowns would be a sufficient substitute for capital punishment.”
“Sing!” said she, and again touching the piano, she commenced an accompaniment in spirited style.
“Now is my time to slip away,” thought I: but the tones that then severed the air arrested me. Mrs. Fairfax had said Mr. Rochester possessed a fine voice: he did—a mellow, powerful bass, into which he threw his own feeling, his own force; finding a way through the ear to the heart, and there waking sensation strangely. I waited till the last deep and full vibration had expired—till the tide of talk, checked an instant, had resumed its flow; I then quitted my sheltered corner and made my exit by the side-door, which was fortunately near.

events.title: An Unexpected Encounter and Rochester's Perplexing Command
detailed_summary: Exiting the drawing-room, Jane pauses in a narrow passage to retie a loose sandal, kneeling for the purpose.
As she does so, the dining-room door opens, and she rises hastily to find herself unexpectedly face to face with Mr. Rochester.
He inquires after her well-being, to which she responds affirmatively.
He then questions her absence from the drawing-room and why she did not approach him.
Jane, choosing politeness over a potential retort, explains that she did not wish to disturb him as he appeared to be engaged in conversation.
Mr. Rochester asks about her activities during his absence, and she replies that she has been teaching Adèle as usual.
He remarks that she appears paler than before, an observation he made upon first seeing her, and presses her about what might be troubling her.
Jane insists that nothing is wrong and denies having caught a cold on the night she assisted him after his fall.
He instructs her to return to the drawing-room, stating that she is 'deserting too early.'
Jane offers the excuse that she is tired.
Mr. Rochester observes her closely and asserts that she is also 'a little depressed,' urging her to confide in him.
Jane continues to deny being depressed, but he insists, noting the unshed tears in her eyes and one that has fallen.
He expresses a wish to understand the cause of her distress but cites the constraints of time and the risk of being overheard by servants.
He excuses her for that evening but firmly commands her to appear in the drawing-room every evening for the duration of his guests' stay, emphasizing that it is his personal wish.
He then instructs her to go and send Sophie for Adèle, beginning to bid her 'Good-night, my—' before abruptly stopping himself, biting his lip, and departing.

events.text_segment:
Thence a narrow passage led into the hall: in crossing it, I perceived my sandal was loose; I stopped to tie it, kneeling down for that purpose on the mat at the foot of the staircase. I heard the dining-room door unclose; a gentleman came out; rising hastily, I stood face to face with him: it was Mr. Rochester.
“How do you do?” he asked.
“I am very well, sir.”
“Why did you not come and speak to me in the room?”
I thought I might have retorted the question on him who put it: but I would not take that freedom. I answered—
“I did not wish to disturb you, as you seemed engaged, sir.”
“What have you been doing during my absence?”
“Nothing particular; teaching Adèle as usual.”
“And getting a good deal paler than you were—as I saw at first sight. What is the matter?”
“Nothing at all, sir.”
“Did you take any cold that night you half drowned me?”
“Not the least.”
“Return to the drawing-room: you are deserting too early.”
“I am tired, sir.”
He looked at me for a minute.
“And a little depressed,” he said. “What about? Tell me.”
“Nothing—nothing, sir. I am not depressed.”
“But I affirm that you are: so much depressed that a few more words would bring tears to your eyes—indeed, they are there now, shining and swimming; and a bead has slipped from the lash and fallen on to the flag. If I had time, and was not in mortal dread of some prating prig of a servant passing, I would know what all this means. Well, to-night I excuse you; but understand that so long as my visitors stay, I expect you to appear in the drawing-room every evening; it is my wish; don’t neglect it. Now go, and send Sophie for Adèle. Good-night, my—” He stopped, bit his lip, and abruptly left me.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A narrow passage then led into the main hall. As I crossed it, I felt my sandal had loosened, so I stopped to fasten it, kneeling for this purpose on the mat at the base of the stairs. I heard the dining room door open, and a gentleman emerged. Quickly getting up, I found myself directly in front of him: it was Mr. Rochester. "How are you?" he asked. "I am quite well, sir," I replied. "Why didn't you come and speak to me in the room?" I considered whether I could have turned the question back on the person asking it, but I chose not to take such a liberty. I responded, "I didn't wish to interrupt you, as you appeared busy, sir." "What have you been doing while I was away?" "Nothing in particular; teaching Adèle as usual." "And looking considerably paler than you were – I noticed it instantly. What's wrong?" "Nothing at all, sir." "Did you catch a cold that night you almost drowned me?" "Not in the least." "Return to the drawing-room; you're leaving too early." "I am tired, sir." He looked at me for a minute. "And a little downcast," he said. "What about? Tell me." "Nothing – nothing, sir. I am not downcast." "But I insist that you are; so downcast that a few more words would bring tears to your eyes – indeed, they are present now, bright and glistening; and a tear has slipped from your lash and fallen onto the flagstones. If I had the time, and wasn't dreading some chatty, pompous servant passing by, I would find out what all this means. Well, tonight I will excuse you; but be aware that as long as my visitors are here, I expect you to be present in the drawing-room every evening. It is my instruction; do not disregard it. Now go, and send Sophie to get Adèle. Good night, my..." He paused, bit his lip, and left me abruptly.
