Just then, I heard the dining-room door open and saw a gentleman step out. I quickly stood up and found myself face to face with Mr. Rochester.

He greeted me, asking how I was. I replied that I was well. Then he questioned why I hadn't approached him in the other room. Though I felt tempted to point out that he could've done the same, I kept that thought to myself and instead said I didn't want to disturb him since he seemed busy.

He asked what I'd done while he was away, and I replied that I had just been teaching Adèle as usual. He noted that I looked much paler than before and asked what was wrong. I assured him nothing was wrong, nor had I caught a cold the night I saved him from nearly drowning.

Mr. Rochester instructed me to return to the drawing-room, saying I was leaving too soon. I told him I was tired. He looked at me for a moment, then remarked that I seemed rather down and asked why. I insisted there was nothing wrong, but he was adamant, saying I seemed so sad that I might cry, and he even saw a tear fall. He said that if he had more time and wasn't worried about servants overhearing, he would try to find out what was troubling me. For the night, he excused me but told me that while his visitors were there, he expected me in the drawing-room every evening and not to neglect this. Then he told me to send Sophie for Adèle, started to say good night, but suddenly stopped, bit his lip, and left.

events.title: A Lively Thornfield and Charade Preparations
detailed_summary: Thornfield Hall is described as bustling with life and activity, a stark contrast to its earlier quietness, filled with guests, their maids, and valets.
Even rainy weather doesn't dampen spirits, with indoor amusements becoming more lively.
Preparations begin for an evening of charades, a game unfamiliar to Jane.
Servants rearrange the dining room, while ladies, assisted by their maids, gather costumes from the house's wardrobes, guided by Mrs. Fairfax.
Mr. Rochester selects his team for charades, including Miss Ingram, the Misses Eshton, and Mrs. Dent.
Mr. Rochester asks Jane if she will play, but she declines, and he does not pressure her.
Mr. Eshton suggests Jane join the other team, but Lady Ingram dismisses the idea, commenting that Jane appears too unintelligent for such games.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Merry days were these at Thornfield Hall; and busy days too: how different from the first three months of stillness, monotony, and solitude I had passed beneath its roof!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “No,” I heard her say: “she looks too stupid for any game of the sort.”

events.text_segment:
Merry days were these at Thornfield Hall; and busy days too: how different from the first three months of stillness, monotony, and solitude I had passed beneath its roof! All sad feelings seemed now driven from the house, all gloomy associations forgotten: there was life everywhere, movement all day long. You could not now traverse the gallery, once so hushed, nor enter the front chambers, once so tenantless, without encountering a smart lady’s-maid or a dandy valet.
The kitchen, the butler’s pantry, the servants’ hall, the entrance hall, were equally alive; and the saloons were only left void and still when the blue sky and halcyon sunshine of the genial spring weather called their occupants out into the grounds. Even when that weather was broken, and continuous rain set in for some days, no damp seemed cast over enjoyment: indoor amusements only became more lively and varied, in consequence of the stop put to outdoor gaiety.
I wondered what they were going to do the first evening a change of entertainment was proposed: they spoke of “playing charades,” but in my ignorance I did not understand the term. The servants were called in, the dining-room tables wheeled away, the lights otherwise disposed, the chairs placed in a semicircle opposite the arch. While Mr. Rochester and the other gentlemen directed these alterations, the ladies were running up and down stairs ringing for their maids. Mrs. Fairfax was summoned to give information respecting the resources of the house in shawls, dresses, draperies of any kind; and certain wardrobes of the third storey were ransacked, and their contents, in the shape of brocaded and hooped petticoats, satin sacques, black modes, lace lappets, &c., were brought down in armfuls by the abigails; then a selection was made, and such things as were chosen were carried to the boudoir within the drawing-room.
Meantime, Mr. Rochester had again summoned the ladies round him, and was selecting certain of their number to be of his party. “Miss Ingram is mine, of course,” said he: afterwards he named the two Misses Eshton, and Mrs. Dent. He looked at me: I happened to be near him, as I had been fastening the clasp of Mrs. Dent’s bracelet, which had got loose.
“Will you play?” he asked. I shook my head. He did not insist, which I rather feared he would have done; he allowed me to return quietly to my usual seat.
He and his aids now withdrew behind the curtain: the other party, which was headed by Colonel Dent, sat down on the crescent of chairs. One of the gentlemen, Mr. Eshton, observing me, seemed to propose that I should be asked to join them; but Lady Ingram instantly negatived the notion.
“No,” I heard her say: “she looks too stupid for any game of the sort.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: These days at Thornfield Hall were enjoyable and full of activity, a stark contrast to the first three months I had spent there in quietness, sameness, and isolation. All feelings of sadness and negative associations seemed to have vanished from the house, replaced by constant energy and motion throughout the day. Now, when you walked through the gallery, which used to be silent, or entered the front rooms, once empty, you would inevitably encounter a well-dressed lady's maid or a fashionable valet. The kitchen, butler’s pantry, servants’ hall, and the main entrance hall were equally full of life. The drawing-rooms were only deserted when the clear skies and pleasant sunshine of the warm spring weather drew their occupants outdoors into the grounds. Even when the weather turned bad and it rained continuously for several days, it didn't dampen the spirits; indoor activities simply became more energetic and diverse because outdoor fun was impossible. I was curious about what they planned to do on the first evening when a different kind of amusement was suggested. They mentioned 'playing charades,' a term I didn't understand due to my lack of knowledge. The servants were called in, the dining tables were moved away, the lights were rearranged, and chairs were set up in a semicircle facing the archway. While Mr. Rochester and the other gentlemen were directing these preparations, the ladies were rushing up and down stairs summoning their maids. Mrs. Fairfax was consulted for information about the house's supply of shawls, dresses, and fabrics of any sort. Certain wardrobes on the third floor were searched, and their contents, such as brocaded and hooped petticoats, satin jackets, black bonnets, lace trims, and so on, were brought down in large quantities by the maids. Then, items were selected, and the chosen pieces were taken to the small room next to the drawing-room. Meanwhile, Mr. Rochester had gathered the ladies around him again and was choosing members for his team. He declared, "Miss Ingram is definitely on my team," and then named the two Misses Eshton and Mrs. Dent. He looked at me; I happened to be standing nearby because I had been fixing the clasp of Mrs. Dent's bracelet, which had come undone. "Will you play?" he asked. I shook my head in refusal. He didn't insist, which I had somewhat feared he might do; he allowed me to return quietly to my usual seat. He and those he had chosen then went behind the curtain. The other group, led by Colonel Dent, sat down on the curved arrangement of chairs. One of the gentlemen, Mr. Eshton, seeing me, appeared to suggest that I should be invited to join them, but Lady Ingram immediately dismissed the idea. "No," I overheard her say, "she seems too dull for any game like that."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Life at Thornfield Hall became lively and full of activity, a stark contrast to the quiet, uneventful, and lonely first months I had spent there. All traces of sadness had vanished from the house, and every space bustled with energy. Whereas once the galleries and front rooms were silent and empty, now one was sure to meet finely dressed maids or stylish valets. Every part of the house—the kitchen, butler’s pantry, servants’ hall, and entrance—was lively, and people only left the main rooms when the pleasant spring weather encouraged them outside. Even when rain kept everyone indoors, the cheerful spirit endured and indoor amusements grew even more varied and spirited as a result. 

One evening, a new entertainment was suggested: playing charades, a term I did not understand. The servants were summoned, dining tables moved, lights rearranged, and chairs arranged in a semicircle. The men supervised the preparations while the women hurried to fetch costumes, with Mrs. Fairfax consulted about available garments and wardrobe storage upstairs opened to supply decorative clothing. Selected items were taken to a small sitting room beside the drawing room for use in the game.

Meanwhile, Mr. Rochester gathered the ladies around him and selected participants for his team, including Miss Ingram, the two Misses Eshton, and Mrs. Dent. When he looked at me and asked if I would like to take part, I declined, and he did not press further, allowing me to return to my usual place. As the chosen group moved behind the curtain and the other team arranged themselves on the chairs, one gentleman seemed to suggest I join their party, but Lady Ingram immediately dismissed the idea, saying she thought I was not clever enough for this kind of game.

events.title: The First Charade: "Bride"
detailed_summary: The first charade begins with Sir George Lynn dressed in a white sheet, holding a large book, and Amy Eshton in Mr. Rochester's cloak, also with a book.
Adèle joyfully scatters flowers.
Miss Ingram appears as a bride, veiled and wreathed in roses, accompanied by Mr. Rochester.
Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, also in white, stand behind them.
A silent pantomime of a marriage ceremony is performed.
After a brief consultation, Colonel Dent's team correctly guesses the word: "Bride."

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Ere long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Rochester bowed, and the curtain fell.

events.text_segment:
Ere long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up. Within the arch, the bulky figure of Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise chosen, was seen enveloped in a white sheet: before him, on a table, lay open a large book; and at his side stood Amy Eshton, draped in Mr. Rochester’s cloak, and holding a book in her hand. Somebody, unseen, rang the bell merrily; then Adèle (who had insisted on being one of her guardian’s party), bounded forward, scattering round her the contents of a basket of flowers she carried on her arm. Then appeared the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her head, and a wreath of roses round her brow; by her side walked Mr. Rochester, and together they drew near the table. They knelt; while Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, dressed also in white, took up their stations behind them. A ceremony followed, in dumb show, in which it was easy to recognise the pantomime of a marriage. At its termination, Colonel Dent and his party consulted in whispers for two minutes, then the Colonel called out—
“Bride!” Mr. Rochester bowed, and the curtain fell.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Soon after, a bell chimed, and the curtain was raised. Inside the arched opening, the large figure of Sir George Lynn, another of Mr. Rochester’s choices, was visible, wrapped in a white sheet. In front of him, a big book lay open on a table, and next to him stood Amy Eshton, covered by Mr. Rochester's cloak and holding a book. An unseen person happily rang the bell, and then Adèle (who had insisted on being part of her guardian’s group) dashed forward, scattering the contents of a flower basket she carried. Following her, the impressive figure of Miss Ingram appeared, dressed in white with a long veil on her head and a wreath of roses encircling her brow. Mr. Rochester walked alongside her, and together they moved towards the table. They knelt, while Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, also in white, took their places behind them. A silent ceremony followed, clearly mimicking a marriage. When it concluded, Colonel Dent and his group quietly conferred for two minutes, then the Colonel announced loudly, “Bride!” Mr. Rochester bowed, and the curtain fell.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Soon, a bell rang and the curtain opened. Inside the archway, Sir George Lynn—also chosen by Mr. Rochester—appeared, covered in a white sheet. In front of him was a large book open on a table, and beside him stood Amy Eshton, wearing Mr. Rochester’s cloak and holding a book. Someone out of sight rang the bell cheerfully, bringing Adèle—who had insisted on joining her guardian’s group—darting forward, scattering flowers from her basket. Then the striking figure of Miss Ingram entered, dressed in white, with a long veil and a wreath of roses on her head; at her side was Mr. Rochester. The two approached the table together and knelt, as Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, also dressed in white, stood behind them. They then performed a silent ceremony, clearly acting out a wedding. After it ended, Colonel Dent and his group whispered among themselves briefly. Then the Colonel called out, “Bride!” Mr. Rochester bowed, and the curtain came down.

events.title: The Second Charade: Eliezer and Rebecca
detailed_summary: The second charade scene is more elaborate, featuring a large marble basin transported from the conservatory.
Mr. Rochester is costumed as an Eastern emir, with shawls and a turban, his appearance suiting the role.
Miss Ingram enters dressed in oriental attire, her arms bare, carrying a pitcher on her head, embodying an Israelitish princess.
She pantomimes approaching the basin to fill her pitcher.
Mr. Rochester's character then accosts her, making a request; she offers him a drink from her pitcher.
He produces a casket with jewelry, and she acts out astonishment and admiration as he adorns her with bracelets and earrings.
The scene represents Eliezer and Rebecca, lacking only the camels.
The guessing party struggles to identify the word or syllable and requests to see the entire tableau for the word.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A considerable interval elapsed before it again rose.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Colonel Dent, their spokesman, demanded “the tableau of the whole;” whereupon the curtain again descended.

events.text_segment:
A considerable interval elapsed before it again rose. Its second rising displayed a more elaborately prepared scene than the last. The drawing-room, as I have before observed, was raised two steps above the dining-room, and on the top of the upper step, placed a yard or two back within the room, appeared a large marble basin, which I recognised as an ornament of the conservatory—where it usually stood, surrounded by exotics, and tenanted by gold fish—and whence it must have been transported with some trouble, on account of its size and weight.
Seated on the carpet, by the side of this basin, was seen Mr. Rochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on his head. His dark eyes and swarthy skin and Paynim features suited the costume exactly: he looked the very model of an Eastern emir, an agent or a victim of the bowstring. Presently advanced into view Miss Ingram. She, too, was attired in oriental fashion: a crimson scarf tied sash-like round the waist: an embroidered handkerchief knotted about her temples; her beautifully-moulded arms bare, one of them upraised in the act of supporting a pitcher, poised gracefully on her head. Both her cast of form and feature, her complexion and her general air, suggested the idea of some Israelitish princess of the patriarchal days; and such was doubtless the character she intended to represent.
She approached the basin, and bent over it as if to fill her pitcher; she again lifted it to her head. The personage on the well-brink now seemed to accost her; to make some request:—“She hasted, let down her pitcher on her hand, and gave him to drink.” From the bosom of his robe he then produced a casket, opened it and showed magnificent bracelets and earrings; she acted astonishment and admiration; kneeling, he laid the treasure at her feet; incredulity and delight were expressed by her looks and gestures; the stranger fastened the bracelets on her arms and the rings in her ears. It was Eliezer and Rebecca: the camels only were wanting.
The divining party again laid their heads together: apparently they could not agree about the word or syllable the scene illustrated. Colonel Dent, their spokesman, demanded “the tableau of the whole;” whereupon the curtain again descended.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
A significant pause occurred before the scene was presented again. The second showing was more elaborately prepared than the first. The drawing-room, as mentioned previously, was elevated two steps above the dining-room. At the edge of the upper step, positioned a few feet back, was a large marble basin. I recognized it as an item from the conservatory, where it was usually found surrounded by exotic plants and containing goldfish. Its size and weight suggested it must have been moved with considerable difficulty.
Sitting on the floor next to the basin was Mr. Rochester, dressed in shawls and wearing a turban. His dark eyes, tanned skin, and 'Heathen' features were perfectly suited to the attire; he looked exactly like an Eastern ruler, possibly an agent or intended victim of execution by strangulation. Next, Miss Ingram came into view. She was also dressed in an oriental style, with a red scarf tied like a sash around her waist, and an embroidered cloth knotted around her temples. Her beautifully formed arms were bare, with one raised to support a pitcher balanced gracefully on her head. Her build, facial features, skin tone, and overall appearance brought to mind an ancient Israelite princess from biblical times, which was clearly the character she aimed to portray.
She approached the basin and leaned over it as if to fill her pitcher, then lifted it back to her head. The figure by the basin then appeared to speak to her, making a request. "She quickly lowered her pitcher onto her hand and offered him a drink." He then produced a small box from within his robe, opened it, and displayed magnificent bracelets and earrings. She showed surprise and admiration. Kneeling, he placed the precious items at her feet; her expressions and movements conveyed disbelief mixed with delight. The stranger fastened the bracelets onto her arms and the earrings onto her ears. It was the scene of Eliezer and Rebecca, only the camels were missing.
The group attempting to guess the tableau huddled together again; they seemed unable to agree on which word or syllable the scene represented. Colonel Dent, acting as their spokesperson, requested to see "the tableau of the entire word," and the curtain then fell once more.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: After a significant pause, the curtain rose again, revealing a more detailed scene than before. The drawing-room, which was higher than the dining-room by two steps, had, at the top, a large marble basin that I recognized from the conservatory, where it was usually surrounded by exotic plants and goldfish. Moving it must have been quite an effort due to its size and weight. Sitting on the carpet next to the bowl was Mr. Rochester, dressed in shawls and wearing a turban, looking like an Eastern ruler with his dark eyes and complexion. Soon, Miss Ingram appeared, dressed in a similar Eastern style: a red scarf wrapped around her waist, a decorated handkerchief on her head, and her bare arms—with one holding a jug balanced on her head. Her overall look suggested she was playing the part of a biblical princess, likely Rebecca. She approached the basin as if to fill her jug, then lifted it to her head again. Mr. Rochester, by the basin, seemed to speak to her and make a request. She lowered her jug and gave him a drink. He then took out a box from his robe, showing her beautiful bracelets and earrings, which she admired with surprise. Kneeling, he presented the jewelry to her, and she showed amazement and happiness. He then put the bracelets on her arms and the earrings in her ears, enacting the story of Eliezer and Rebecca—though camels were missing from the scene. The group trying to guess couldn't decide on the word or phrase the tableau represented. Colonel Dent, their leader, asked for the entire tableau, so the curtain fell again.

events.title: The Third Charade Solved: "Bridewell"
detailed_summary: The third charade scene reveals a starkly different setting: a portion of the drawing-room with a simple table and chair, dimly lit by a lantern.
Mr. Rochester appears heavily disguised, with a begrimed face, disordered clothes, and a desperate expression, fetters clanking on his wrists.
Colonel Dent quickly solves the charade, exclaiming "Bridewell!"

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On its third rising only a portion of the drawing-room was disclosed; the rest being concealed by a screen, hung with some sort of dark and coarse drapery.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Bridewell!” exclaimed Colonel Dent, and the charade was solved.

events.text_segment:
On its third rising only a portion of the drawing-room was disclosed; the rest being concealed by a screen, hung with some sort of dark and coarse drapery. The marble basin was removed; in its place, stood a deal table and a kitchen chair: these objects were visible by a very dim light proceeding from a horn lantern, the wax candles being all extinguished.
Amidst this sordid scene, sat a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground. I knew Mr. Rochester; though the begrimed face, the disordered dress (his coat hanging loose from one arm, as if it had been almost torn from his back in a scuffle), the desperate and scowling countenance, the rough, bristling hair might well have disguised him. As he moved, a chain clanked; to his wrists were attached fetters.
“Bridewell!” exclaimed Colonel Dent, and the charade was solved.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Upon its third ascent, the stage revealed only a section of the drawing-room, the rest being obscured by a screen covered in some kind of dark, coarse fabric. The elegant marble basin had been removed, replaced by a simple wooden table and a chair typical of a kitchen. These items were illuminated by the very faint light emanating from a horn lantern, as all the wax candles had been extinguished. In the centre of this bleak setting sat a man, his hands clenched on his knees and his gaze fixed on the floor. I knew it was Mr. Rochester, although his identity was almost hidden by his dirty face, dishevelled attire (his coat hanging loose from one arm as if it had been violently torn), his desperate and angry expression, and his rough, bristly hair. When he moved, a chain rattled, indicating that restraints were attached to his wrists. Colonel Dent's cry of “Bridewell!” instantly clarified the meaning of the scene.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: When the curtain rose for the third time, only part of the drawing-room could be seen, while the rest was hidden by a screen draped in heavy, dark fabric. The usual marble basin was gone and, instead, there was a simple wooden table and a kitchen chair, barely illuminated by the faint glow from a lantern, since all the wax candles had been put out. Amid this grim setting sat a man, his fists clenched on his knees and his gaze fixed on the floor. Despite his dirty face, messy clothes (his coat hanging off as if ripped in a struggle), fierce expression, and wild hair that could have concealed his identity, I recognized Mr. Rochester. When he moved, the sound of chains was heard—his wrists were shackled. "Bridewell!" cried Colonel Dent, uncovering the answer to the charade.

events.title: Post-Charade Reflections: Jane's Love and Ingram's Flaws
detailed_summary: After the charades, Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram re-enter, with her complimenting his acting, particularly his portrayal of the highwayman.
They engage in flirtatious banter related to his charade costume and her preference for roguish heroes, with Rochester reminding her they were 'married' in the charade.
Jane's attention shifts from the performances to observing Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram's interactions.
She notes their whispered conversations and exchanged glances, which evoke a strong emotional response in her.
Jane confesses her enduring love for Mr. Rochester, despite his apparent neglect and his focus on Miss Ingram.
She observes Miss Ingram's scornful attitude towards her and Rochester's evident courtship of the proud lady.
Jane reflects that these circumstances inspire despair but not jealousy, as she deems Miss Ingram intellectually and emotionally inferior.
She notes Miss Ingram's lack of genuineness, originality, and true feeling, particularly her unkindness towards Adèle.
Jane perceives that Mr. Rochester is keenly aware of Miss Ingram's defects and lacks true passion for her, which is the source of Jane's own pain; she believes Ingram cannot truly captivate him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A sufficient interval having elapsed for the performers to resume their ordinary costume, they re-entered the dining-room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: she could not charm him.

events.text_segment:
A sufficient interval having elapsed for the performers to resume their ordinary costume, they re-entered the dining-room. Mr. Rochester led in Miss Ingram; she was complimenting him on his acting.
“Do you know,” said she, “that, of the three characters, I liked you in the last best? Oh, had you but lived a few years earlier, what a gallant gentleman-highwayman you would have made!”
“Is all the soot washed from my face?” he asked, turning it towards her.
“Alas! yes: the more’s the pity! Nothing could be more becoming to your complexion than that ruffian’s rouge.”
“You would like a hero of the road then?”
“An English hero of the road would be the next best thing to an Italian bandit; and that could only be surpassed by a Levantine pirate.”
“Well, whatever I am, remember you are my wife; we were married an hour since, in the presence of all these witnesses.” She giggled, and her colour rose.
“Now, Dent,” continued Mr. Rochester, “it is your turn.” And as the other party withdrew, he and his band took the vacated seats. Miss Ingram placed herself at her leader’s right hand; the other diviners filled the chairs on each side of him and her. I did not now watch the actors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; my attention was absorbed by the spectators; my eyes, erewhile fixed on the arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs. What charade Colonel Dent and his party played, what word they chose, how they acquitted themselves, I no longer remember; but I still see the consultation which followed each scene: I see Mr. Rochester turn to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to him; I see her incline her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek; I hear their mutual whisperings; I recall their interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.
I have told you, reader, that I had learnt to love Mr. Rochester: I could not unlove him now, merely because I found that he had ceased to notice me—because I might pass hours in his presence, and he would never once turn his eyes in my direction—because I saw all his attentions appropriated by a great lady, who scorned to touch me with the hem of her robes as she passed; who, if ever her dark and imperious eye fell on me by chance, would withdraw it instantly as from an object too mean to merit observation. I could not unlove him, because I felt sure he would soon marry this very lady—because I read daily in her a proud security in his intentions respecting her—because I witnessed hourly in him a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing rather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness, captivating, and in its very pride, irresistible.
There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though much to create despair. Much too, you will think, reader, to engender jealousy: if a woman, in my position, could presume to be jealous of a woman in Miss Ingram’s. But I was not jealous: or very rarely;—the nature of the pain I suffered could not be explained by that word. Miss Ingram was a mark beneath jealousy: she was too inferior to excite the feeling. Pardon the seeming paradox; I mean what I say. She was very showy, but she was not genuine: she had a fine person, many brilliant attainments; but her mind was poor, her heart barren by nature: nothing bloomed spontaneously on that soil; no unforced natural fruit delighted by its freshness. She was not good; she was not original: she used to repeat sounding phrases from books: she never offered, nor had, an opinion of her own. She advocated a high tone of sentiment; but she did not know the sensations of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were not in her. Too often she betrayed this, by the undue vent she gave to a spiteful antipathy she had conceived against little Adèle: pushing her away with some contumelious epithet if she happened to approach her; sometimes ordering her from the room, and always treating her with coldness and acrimony. Other eyes besides mine watched these manifestations of character—watched them closely, keenly, shrewdly. Yes; the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself, exercised over his intended a ceaseless surveillance; and it was from this sagacity—this guardedness of his—this perfect, clear consciousness of his fair one’s defects—this obvious absence of passion in his sentiments towards her, that my ever-torturing pain arose.
I saw he was going to marry her, for family, perhaps political reasons, because her rank and connections suited him; I felt he had not given her his love, and that her qualifications were ill adapted to win from him that treasure. This was the point—this was where the nerve was touched and teased—this was where the fever was sustained and fed: she could not charm him.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: After a suitable time for the performers to change back into their regular clothes, they returned to the dining room. Mr. Rochester led in Miss Ingram, who was complimenting his acting. She said to him, "You know, out of the three parts, I liked you best in the last one. Oh, if only you had been born a few years earlier, what a dashing gentleman-highwayman you would have been!" He asked, turning his face towards her, "Has all the soot been washed off my face?" "Sadly, yes," she replied, "and more's the pity! Nothing could have suited your complexion better than that villain's makeup." "So you'd approve of a criminal from the road?" "An English highwayman would be the next best thing to an Italian bandit, and only a Levantine pirate could surpass that." "Well, whatever I am," Mr. Rochester said, "remember you are my wife; we were married an hour ago, with everyone here as witnesses." She giggled, and her face flushed. "Now, Dent," Mr. Rochester continued, "it's your turn." As the first group withdrew, he and his party took the empty seats. Miss Ingram positioned herself at her leader's right side; the other fortune-tellers occupied the chairs around them. I no longer watched the actors; I wasn't waiting with interest for the performance to start. My attention was captivated by the audience. My eyes, which had been fixed on the archway, were now irresistibly drawn to the curved line of chairs. I do not recall what charade Colonel Dent and his group performed, what word they chose, or how they fared. But I still remember the discussion that followed each scene: I see Mr. Rochester turning to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to him; I see her tilt her head towards him until her dark curls nearly touched his shoulder and brushed his cheek; I hear their whispered conversations; I recall the glances they exchanged; and even some of the emotion the sight stirred in me returns to memory now. I have told you, reader, that I had grown to love Mr. Rochester. I could not stop loving him now, simply because I found that he no longer paid attention to me—because I could spend hours in his presence, and he would never once look my way—because I saw all his focus claimed by a grand lady who disdained touching me with the hem of her garment as she passed; who, if by chance her dark, haughty eyes ever met mine, would immediately avert them as from an object too insignificant to notice. I could not stop loving him because I was certain he would soon marry this very lady—because I observed in her daily a proud confidence in his intentions towards her—because I witnessed hourly in him a style of courtship which, though casual and preferring to be pursued than to pursue, was nonetheless captivating in its very casualness and irresistible in its very pride. There was nothing in these circumstances to diminish or extinguish my love, although there was much to cause despair. Much too, you might think, reader, to stir up jealousy: if a woman in my humble situation could even dare to be jealous of a woman in Miss Ingram's high station. But I was not jealous, or only very rarely; the nature of the pain I suffered could not be described by that word. Miss Ingram was beneath the level that could provoke jealousy; she was too inferior to arouse that feeling. Pardon the apparent contradiction; I mean what I say. She was very flashy but lacked authenticity; she had a fine appearance and many impressive accomplishments, but her mind was shallow, and her heart was naturally barren. Nothing blossomed spontaneously in that soil; no genuine, unforced fruit delighted with its freshness. She was not good; she was not original. She often repeated eloquent phrases from books and never offered, nor possessed, an opinion of her own. She advocated for noble sentiments but did not understand the feelings of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were not in her character. She revealed this too often by giving excessive expression to a spiteful aversion she had conceived against little Adèle, pushing her away with some contemptuous insult if she happened to approach her, sometimes ordering her out of the room, and always treating her with coldness and harshness. Other eyes besides mine observed these revelations of character—watched them closely, keenly, shrewdly. Yes; her future groom, Mr. Rochester himself, kept his intended under constant scrutiny. And it was from this insight—this guardedness of his—this perfect, clear understanding of his intended's flaws—this obvious lack of strong feeling in his sentiments towards her—that my ever-present, painful suffering arose. I saw he was going to marry her for family, perhaps political reasons, because her status and connections suited him. I sensed he had not given her his love and that her qualities were ill-suited to win that treasure from him. This was the key point—this was where my nerves were touched and tormented—this was what fueled and sustained my anguish: she could not truly captivate him.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After enough time had passed for the performers to change back into regular clothes, they returned to the dining room. Mr. Rochester escorted Miss Ingram, who was praising his performance. She remarked, 'You know, of the three roles, I liked your last one best. If only you had lived a few years earlier, you’d have made a dashing highwayman!' Rochester joked, asking if all the makeup had been removed from his face, to which she lamented that it had, as the look suited him. They traded playful banter about his suitability as a highwayman or pirate, and Rochester reminded her that, according to their earlier charade, they had just been married in front of everyone. Miss Ingram laughed and blushed at this. Next, Rochester called on Colonel Dent’s group to perform. As the previous group vacated their seats, Rochester’s group took their places, with Miss Ingram sitting beside him. The other performers sat alongside them. At this point, my interest in watching the acts faded; instead, I observed the audience, my attention drawn to the seated group rather than the stage. I don’t recall what play Colonel Dent’s team put on or which word they enacted, but I can still picture the conversations after each scene: Rochester speaking with Miss Ingram, her head leaning towards him so her dark curls nearly touched him, their whispers and exchanged glances vivid in my memory, as well as the feelings these scenes stirred for me.
I had already confessed, reader, that I loved Mr. Rochester: I couldn’t stop loving him just because he no longer paid me any attention—because I could spend hours near him without a glance in my direction—because all his focus was on a grand lady who ignored me and would shrink away from even the most accidental contact. I couldn’t stop loving him, even though I believed he would soon marry this lady—because I saw every day in her a proud confidence that he intended to propose—and each day I witnessed in him a style of courtship that, though offhand and prefering to be pursued rather than pursue, was nonetheless captivating and compelling in its indifference and pride.
Nothing in these circumstances could diminish my affection, though they did create hopelessness. You, reader, might think such a situation would give rise to jealousy, but that wasn’t exactly my pain; Miss Ingram didn’t even inspire jealousy in me. She was not worthy of it—beneath it. Admittedly, she was impressive and accomplished, but I found her shallow and insincere. Her mind was weak, her heart empty; nothing genuine or spontaneous came from her. She wasn’t kind or original; she repeated phrases from books and lacked independent thought. She promoted lofty ideals but was incapable of true empathy or compassion. Her lack of real feelings was obvious, especially in how she treated Adèle with cruelty and disdain, sometimes even banishing the child from the room. I was not alone in noticing these flaws—others, including Mr. Rochester, watched her closely. It was apparent that, while he may have planned to marry her for social or political reasons, he did not love her; she lacked the qualities that could ever earn his regard. This was the most painful truth: despite appearances, she could not truly captivate him.

events.title: Jane's Deepening Analysis of Love, Marriage, and Rochester's Character
detailed_summary: Jane imagines her reaction if Rochester had genuinely loved Miss Ingram or if Ingram had been a worthy woman, suggesting she might have found peace in their happiness or her admiration.
However, witnessing Miss Ingram's failing attempts to fascinate Rochester, while Ingram remains oblivious and self-satisfied, causes Jane ceaseless agitation and restraint.
Jane believes she understands how Rochester could be won, contrasting Ingram's overt efforts with the potential for a quieter, more genuine connection.
She questions Ingram's affection for Rochester, seeing her elaborate airs as a sign of insincerity.
Jane recalls moments when Rochester showed a softer, more natural expression, not elicited by artifice, and believes his wife could be immensely happy if she knew how to please him.
Jane reflects on Rochester's decision to marry for social and financial reasons, initially surprised but now less judgmental, attributing it to their upbringing and societal norms.
She admits to growing lenient towards Rochester's faults, no longer seeing them negatively but as piquant aspects of his character.

Jane is increasingly intrigued by a mysterious, occasionally visible depth in Rochester's eyes, a quality that once frightened her but now fascinates her, wishing she could understand it as his future wife might.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: If she had managed the victory at once, and he had yielded and sincerely laid his heart at her feet, I should have covered my face, turned to the wall, and (figuratively) have died to them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Instead of wishing to shun, I longed only to dare—to divine it; and I thought Miss Ingram happy, because one day she might look into the abyss at her leisure, explore its secrets and analyse their nature.

events.text_segment:
If she had managed the victory at once, and he had yielded and sincerely laid his heart at her feet, I should have covered my face, turned to the wall, and (figuratively) have died to them. If Miss Ingram had been a good and noble woman, endowed with force, fervour, kindness, sense, I should have had one vital struggle with two tigers—jealousy and despair: then, my heart torn out and devoured, I should have admired her—acknowledged her excellence, and been quiet for the rest of my days: and the more absolute her superiority, the deeper would have been my admiration—the more truly tranquil my quiescence. But as matters really stood, to watch Miss Ingram’s efforts at fascinating Mr. Rochester, to witness their repeated failure—herself unconscious that they did fail; vainly fancying that each shaft launched hit the mark, and infatuatedly pluming herself on success, when her pride and self-complacency repelled further and further what she wished to allure—to witness this, was to be at once under ceaseless excitation and ruthless restraint.
Because, when she failed, I saw how she might have succeeded. Arrows that continually glanced off from Mr. Rochester’s breast and fell harmless at his feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have quivered keen in his proud heart—have called love into his stern eye, and softness into his sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons a silent conquest might have been won.
“Why can she not influence him more, when she is privileged to draw so near to him?” I asked myself. “Surely she cannot truly like him, or not like him with true affection! If she did, she need not coin her smiles so lavishly, flash her glances so unremittingly, manufacture airs so elaborate, graces so multitudinous. It seems to me that she might, by merely sitting quietly at his side, saying little and looking less, get nigher his heart. I have seen in his face a far different expression from that which hardens it now while she is so vivaciously accosting him; but then it came of itself: it was not elicited by meretricious arts and calculated manoeuvres; and one had but to accept it—to answer what he asked without pretension, to address him when needful without grimace—and it increased and grew kinder and more genial, and warmed one like a fostering sunbeam. How will she manage to please him when they are married? I do not think she will manage it; and yet it might be managed; and his wife might, I verily believe, be the very happiest woman the sun shines on.”
I have not yet said anything condemnatory of Mr. Rochester’s project of marrying for interest and connections. It surprised me when I first discovered that such was his intention: I had thought him a man unlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in his choice of a wife; but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the parties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either him or Miss Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled into them, doubtless, from their childhood. All their class held these principles: I supposed, then, they had reasons for holding them such as I could not fathom. It seemed to me that, were I a gentleman like him, I would take to my bosom only such a wife as I could love; but the very obviousness of the advantages to the husband’s own happiness offered by this plan convinced me that there must be arguments against its general adoption of which I was quite ignorant: otherwise I felt sure all the world would act as I wished to act.
But in other points, as well as this, I was growing very lenient to my master: I was forgetting all his faults, for which I had once kept a sharp look-out. It had formerly been my endeavour to study all sides of his character: to take the bad with the good; and from the just weighing of both, to form an equitable judgment. Now I saw no bad. The sarcasm that had repelled, the harshness that had startled me once, were only like keen condiments in a choice dish: their presence was pungent, but their absence would be felt as comparatively insipid. And as for the vague something—was it a sinister or a sorrowful, a designing or a desponding expression?—that opened upon a careful observer, now and then, in his eye, and closed again before one could fathom the strange depth partially disclosed; that something which used to make me fear and shrink, as if I had been wandering amongst volcanic-looking hills, and had suddenly felt the ground quiver and seen it gape: that something, I, at intervals, beheld still; and with throbbing heart, but not with palsied nerves. Instead of wishing to shun, I longed only to dare—to divine it; and I thought Miss Ingram happy, because one day she might look into the abyss at her leisure, explore its secrets and analyse their nature.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Had she achieved an immediate triumph, with him completely surrendering his heart to her, I would have metaphorically covered my face, turned away, and ceased to exist for them. If Miss Ingram had been a virtuous and dignified woman, possessing strength, passion, kindness, and good judgment, I would have faced a significant internal battle against two intense emotions—envy and hopelessness. After having my heart painfully consumed by these feelings, I would have admired her, acknowledged her superiority, and remained quiet for the remainder of my days. The more undeniable her excellence, the deeper my admiration would have been, and the more genuinely peaceful my acceptance. But given the actual circumstances, witnessing Miss Ingram's persistent attempts to charm Mr. Rochester and seeing them repeatedly fail—while she remained oblivious to her failures, deluding herself that every effort succeeded, and narcissistically congratulating herself on achievements when her arrogance and smugness only pushed away the object of her desires—observing this kept me in a state of perpetual inner turmoil combined with strict self-restraint. This was because I could see how she might have succeeded where she failed. The attempts that repeatedly bounced harmlessly off Mr. Rochester's emotional defenses and fell inconsequentially at his feet could, I knew, have deeply affected his proud heart, sparked affection in his stern eyes, and softened his mocking expression, had they been delivered with greater skill. Or even better, a silent connection, without overt efforts, might have won him over. 'Why can she not influence him more, given her proximity?' I wondered. 'Surely she doesn't truly care for him, or her affection isn't genuine! If it were, she wouldn't need to overuse her smiles, flash her glances incessantly, or contrive such elaborate mannerisms and excessive graces. It seems to me that she might get closer to his heart simply by sitting quietly beside him, saying little and looking less. I have seen a very different look on his face than the one it wears now while she is so energetically talking to him. But that look came naturally; it wasn't elicited by artificial tricks or calculated strategies. One only had to accept it – answer his questions without pretension, address him when necessary without false expressions – and it would deepen, becoming warmer and more benevolent, like a comforting sunbeam. How will she manage to please him when they are married? I don't believe she will succeed, yet it is possible, and his wife could, I truly think, be the happiest woman alive.' I haven't yet criticized Mr. Rochester's plan to marry for wealth and status. It surprised me initially to learn this was his intention; I had thought him someone unlikely to be swayed by such common motivations in choosing a spouse. However, the more I considered the backgrounds, upbringing, etc., of both individuals, the less I felt justified in judging or blaming either him or Miss Ingram for adhering to principles and ideas likely instilled in them since childhood. Their entire social class upheld these values, so I assumed they had reasons for doing so that I couldn't comprehend. It seemed to me that, were I a gentleman like him, I would marry only someone I could love. But the very obviousness of the benefits to the husband's personal happiness offered by his plan convinced me there must be reasons against its universal adoption that I was unaware of; otherwise, I felt sure everyone would act as I wished to act. But in this, as in other respects, I was becoming much more forgiving towards my master. I was forgetting all his faults, which I had once watched closely. I had formerly tried to understand every aspect of his character, taking the negative with the positive, and forming a balanced judgment by fairly weighing both. Now, I saw no negatives. The sarcasm that had once put me off, the harshness that had startled me, now seemed merely like sharp spices in a fine dish—their presence was intense, but their absence would make things seem comparatively bland. And as for that vague quality—was it sinister or sad, scheming or despondent?—that would occasionally appear to a careful observer in his eye, only to disappear before one could fully grasp the strange depth it partially revealed; that quality which used to make me fearful and recoil, as if I had been exploring volcanic-looking hills and suddenly felt the ground shake and saw it crack open: I still saw that quality at times, and with a racing heart, but no longer with trembling nerves. Instead of wanting to avoid it, I only yearned to confront it—to understand its mystery. And I considered Miss Ingram fortunate, because one day she might leisurely gaze into that abyss, explore its secrets, and analyze their nature.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
If Miss Ingram had quickly won Mr. Rochester's heart and he had sincerely offered his love to her, I would have been so overwhelmed that I would have retreated from their lives, feeling as though I had emotionally died to them. Had she been genuinely good and admirable—possessing strength, passion, and kindness—I would have had a painful internal battle against jealousy and despair. After enduring that ordeal, I would have respected and admired her goodness, accepting the situation with lasting calm, the more so if she were clearly superior. But as things actually were, I saw Miss Ingram repeatedly try, and fail, to captivate Mr. Rochester, all the while unaware of her lack of success, believing she had charmed him when her pride and self-importance only pushed him away further. Observing this filled me with a mix of restless energy and rigid self-control.

Seeing her fail, I realized how someone else might succeed; her efforts fell flat against Mr. Rochester, but in the hands of a more skilled person, those same actions might have touched his heart, inspired affection, and softened his demeanor. Or perhaps, without obvious effort, a true connection could have been made in silence. I wondered why she could not reach him, even though she was so close; perhaps she did not really care for him, or not enough. If she truly loved him, she would not have to try so hard with forced smiles, constant looks, or elaborate manners. I felt she might have reached him more deeply just by quietly being with him. I had seen his face soften in the past through simple, natural interaction—no manipulation involved—which made him kinder and warmer. I doubted she would make him happy in marriage, though I believed it was possible, and that his wife could be the happiest woman alive.

I have yet to criticize Mr. Rochester for considering marriage based on social gain and connections. I was surprised when I realized this was his plan, as I thought he would not be swayed by such common motives. But the more I considered their social standing and upbringing, the less I felt justified in judging either him or Miss Ingram for acting according to the expectations instilled in them since childhood. These values were shared by their entire class, so they must have reasons I didn't understand. Personally, I believed I would only marry for love, but since this seemed such an obvious path to happiness, I supposed there must be reasons why others did not do the same—otherwise, surely everyone would act as I wished to.

In general, I noticed I was becoming much more forgiving towards Mr. Rochester, no longer watching for his flaws as carefully as I once had. I used to weigh the good with the bad to form a fair judgment, but now I overlooked his faults entirely. The sarcasm and harshness that once put me off now seemed like spices—making his character more lively, and without them, he might even seem dull. As for the mysterious quality in his expression—sometimes sinister or sorrowful, cunning or sad—that used to frighten me, I still saw it on occasion, but with curiosity rather than fear. Instead of wishing to avoid it, I wanted to understand and explore it. I even thought Miss Ingram fortunate, imagining she might someday have the opportunity to uncover and examine these depths fully.

events.title: An Unexpected Arrival: Mr. Mason
detailed_summary: While Jane is absorbed in her thoughts about Rochester and Ingram, the rest of the party engages in their own amusements and conversations.
Rochester and Ingram remain the center of attention, their absence leading to a noticeable dullness.
One wet afternoon, with Rochester away in Millcote on business, the party's planned walk to a gypsy camp is postponed.
The guests occupy themselves with billiards, cards, and reading; Blanche Ingram listlessly lounges with a novel.
As dusk approaches, Adèle excitedly announces Rochester's return, but it is a post-chaise, not his usual mode of travel.
Miss Ingram rushes to the window, momentarily inconveniencing Jane, then moves away with a disdainful look upon noticing her.
A stranger, not Rochester, alights from the chaise: a tall, fashionable man.
Miss Ingram expresses annoyance at the false alarm, blaming Adèle and glaring at Jane.
The newcomer, Mr. Mason, introduces himself, explaining he is an old friend of Rochester's and intends to wait for him.
Jane observes Mason: polite, with an unusual accent, sallow complexion, regular but somehow displeasing features, and a vacant look in his eyes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meantime, while I thought only of my master and his future bride—saw only them, heard only their discourse, and considered only their movements of importance—the rest of the party were occupied with their own separate interests and pleasures.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His features were regular, but too relaxed: his eye was large and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant life—at least so I thought.

events.text_segment:
Meantime, while I thought only of my master and his future bride—saw only them, heard only their discourse, and considered only their movements of importance—the rest of the party were occupied with their own separate interests and pleasures. The Ladies Lynn and Ingram continued to consort in solemn conferences, where they nodded their two turbans at each other, and held up their four hands in confronting gestures of surprise, or mystery, or horror, according to the theme on which their gossip ran, like a pair of magnified puppets. Mild Mrs. Dent talked with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; and the two sometimes bestowed a courteous word or smile on me. Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and Mr. Eshton discussed politics, or county affairs, or justice business. Lord Ingram flirted with Amy Eshton; Louisa played and sang to and with one of the Messrs. Lynn; and Mary Ingram listened languidly to the gallant speeches of the other. Sometimes all, as with one consent, suspended their by-play to observe and listen to the principal actors: for, after all, Mr. Rochester and—because closely connected with him—Miss Ingram were the life and soul of the party. If he was absent from the room an hour, a perceptible dulness seemed to steal over the spirits of his guests; and his re-entrance was sure to give a fresh impulse to the vivacity of conversation.
The want of his animating influence appeared to be peculiarly felt one day that he had been summoned to Millcote on business, and was not likely to return till late. The afternoon was wet: a walk the party had proposed to take to see a gipsy camp, lately pitched on a common beyond Hay, was consequently deferred. Some of the gentlemen were gone to the stables: the younger ones, together with the younger ladies, were playing billiards in the billiard-room. The dowagers Ingram and Lynn sought solace in a quiet game at cards. Blanche Ingram, after having repelled, by supercilious taciturnity, some efforts of Mrs. Dent and Mrs. Eshton to draw her into conversation, had first murmured over some sentimental tunes and airs on the piano, and then, having fetched a novel from the library, had flung herself in haughty listlessness on a sofa, and prepared to beguile, by the spell of fiction, the tedious hours of absence. The room and the house were silent: only now and then the merriment of the billiard-players was heard from above.
It was verging on dusk, and the clock had already given warning of the hour to dress for dinner, when little Adèle, who knelt by me in the drawing-room window-seat, suddenly exclaimed—
“Voilà Monsieur Rochester, qui revient!”
I turned, and Miss Ingram darted forwards from her sofa: the others, too, looked up from their several occupations; for at the same time a crunching of wheels and a splashing tramp of horse-hoofs became audible on the wet gravel. A post-chaise was approaching.
“What can possess him to come home in that style?” said Miss Ingram. “He rode Mesrour (the black horse), did he not, when he went out? and Pilot was with him:—what has he done with the animals?”
As she said this, she approached her tall person and ample garments so near the window, that I was obliged to bend back almost to the breaking of my spine: in her eagerness she did not observe me at first, but when she did, she curled her lip and moved to another casement. The post-chaise stopped; the driver rang the door-bell, and a gentleman alighted attired in travelling garb; but it was not Mr. Rochester; it was a tall, fashionable-looking man, a stranger.
“How provoking!” exclaimed Miss Ingram: “you tiresome monkey!” (apostrophising Adèle), “who perched you up in the window to give false intelligence?” and she cast on me an angry glance, as if I were in fault.
Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the new-comer entered. He bowed to Lady Ingram, as deeming her the eldest lady present.
“It appears I come at an inopportune time, madam,” said he, “when my friend, Mr. Rochester, is from home; but I arrive from a very long journey, and I think I may presume so far on old and intimate acquaintance as to instal myself here till he returns.”
His manner was polite; his accent, in speaking, struck me as being somewhat unusual,—not precisely foreign, but still not altogether English: his age might be about Mr. Rochester’s,—between thirty and forty; his complexion was singularly sallow: otherwise he was a fine-looking man, at first sight especially. On closer examination, you detected something in his face that displeased, or rather that failed to please. His features were regular, but too relaxed: his eye was large and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant life—at least so I thought.

Gentle Mrs. Dent conversed with kind Mrs. Eshton, occasionally offering me a polite word or smile. Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and Mr. Eshton discussed politics, local county matters, or legal affairs. Lord Ingram flirted with Amy Eshton; Louisa played and sang with one of the Messrs. Lynn; and Mary Ingram listened listlessly to the compliments of the other Mr. Lynn. At times, the entire group paused their separate activities to watch and listen to the main figures, Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram (due to her close connection with him), as they were undeniably the central focus and energy of the gathering. If he was absent from the room for even an hour, a noticeable dullness seemed to settle over the guests, and his return was sure to instantly re-energise the conversation. His absence seemed particularly noticeable one day when he was called away to Millcote on business and wasn't expected back until late. The afternoon was rainy, so a planned walk to see a recently established gypsy camp on a common near Hay had to be cancelled. Some of the gentlemen had gone to the stables; the younger guests were playing billiards in the billiard room. The dowagers, Mrs. Ingram and Mrs. Lynn, found comfort in a quiet card game. Blanche Ingram, after brushing off attempts by Mrs. Dent and Mrs. Eshton to engage her in conversation with disdainful silence, first played some melancholic tunes on the piano. Then, retrieving a novel from the library, she threw herself onto a sofa in a display of arrogant boredom, intending to pass the tedious hours of Rochester's absence by reading fiction. The room and the house were quiet, with only the occasional sound of laughter from the billiard players upstairs. It was getting close to dusk, and the clock had already indicated it was time to get ready for dinner, when little Adèle, who was kneeling beside me on the window seat in the drawing-room, suddenly cried out, "Look, Mr. Rochester is coming back!" I turned, and Miss Ingram sprang forward from her sofa. The others also looked up from what they were doing, as at that moment, the sound of carriage wheels crunching on the wet gravel and splashing horse hooves became audible. A post-chaise was approaching. "What reason can he have for returning in that manner?" exclaimed Miss Ingram. "He rode Mesrour (the black horse), didn't he, when he left? And Pilot was with him - what has he done with the animals?" As she spoke, her tall figure and voluminous dress came so close to the window that I had to lean back, almost straining my back. In her eagerness, she didn't notice me at first, but when she did, she curled her lip and moved to another window. The post-chaise stopped, the driver rang the doorbell, and a gentleman dressed in travelling clothes stepped out; however, it wasn't Mr. Rochester. It was a tall, stylish-looking man, a stranger. "How frustrating!" cried Miss Ingram. "You annoying little monkey!" (addressing Adèle), "who put you in the window to give false information?" And she shot me an angry look, as if I were somehow responsible. Some talking was heard in the hall, and soon the newcomer entered. He bowed to Lady Ingram, seemingly considering her the most senior lady present. "It appears I arrive at an inconvenient time, madam," he said, "as my friend, Mr. Rochester, is away from home. But I am at the end of a very long journey, and I believe I can presume upon our old and close acquaintance enough to make myself at home here until he returns." His manner was polite. His speaking accent struck me as slightly unusual, not quite foreign, but not entirely English either. His age seemed comparable to Mr. Rochester's, between thirty and forty. His complexion was notably sallow. Otherwise, he was a handsome man, particularly at first glance. Upon closer inspection, you could detect something in his face that was displeasing, or rather, failed to please. His features were regular, but lacked firmness. His eye was large and well-shaped, but the expression in it was bland and empty - at least, that was my impression.

events.title: Learning About Mr. Mason and the Gypsy's Appearance
detailed_summary: After dinner, Jane observes Mr. Mason further, finding his appearance even less agreeable, noting an unsettled yet inanimate quality and a meaningless wandering eye.
She mentally contrasts him sharply with Mr. Rochester, likening Mason to a gander or sheep and Rochester to a falcon or guardian dog, pondering their unlikely friendship.
Louisa Eshton and Mary Ingram discuss Mr. Mason, finding him beautiful and charming, praising his features.
Jane overhears the gentlemen's conversation and learns the newcomer is Mr. Mason, recently arrived from a hot country, explaining his sallowness and preference for sitting near the fire.
Mentions of Jamaica, Kingston, and Spanish Town reveal his residence in the West Indies, where he first met Mr. Rochester, a new detail about Rochester's travels for Jane.
While Jane muses on this, Mr. Mason shivers and asks for more coal.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The sound of the dressing-bell dispersed the party.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Would you like to see her?”

events.text_segment:
The sound of the dressing-bell dispersed the party. It was not till after dinner that I saw him again: he then seemed quite at his ease. But I liked his physiognomy even less than before: it struck me as being at the same time unsettled and inanimate. His eye wandered, and had no meaning in its wandering: this gave him an odd look, such as I never remembered to have seen. For a handsome and not an unamiable-looking man, he repelled me exceedingly: there was no power in that smooth-skinned face of a full oval shape: no firmness in that aquiline nose and small cherry mouth; there was no thought on the low, even forehead; no command in that blank, brown eye.
As I sat in my usual nook, and looked at him with the light of the girandoles on the mantelpiece beaming full over him—for he occupied an arm-chair drawn close to the fire, and kept shrinking still nearer, as if he were cold, I compared him with Mr. Rochester. I think (with deference be it spoken) the contrast could not be much greater between a sleek gander and a fierce falcon: between a meek sheep and the rough-coated keen-eyed dog, its guardian.
He had spoken of Mr. Rochester as an old friend. A curious friendship theirs must have been: a pointed illustration, indeed, of the old adage that “extremes meet.”
Two or three of the gentlemen sat near him, and I caught at times scraps of their conversation across the room. At first I could not make much sense of what I heard; for the discourse of Louisa Eshton and Mary Ingram, who sat nearer to me, confused the fragmentary sentences that reached me at intervals. These last were discussing the stranger; they both called him “a beautiful man.” Louisa said he was “a love of a creature,” and she “adored him;” and Mary instanced his “pretty little mouth, and nice nose,” as her ideal of the charming.
“And what a sweet-tempered forehead he has!” cried Louisa,—“so smooth—none of those frowning irregularities I dislike so much; and such a placid eye and smile!”
And then, to my great relief, Mr. Henry Lynn summoned them to the other side of the room, to settle some point about the deferred excursion to Hay Common.
I was now able to concentrate my attention on the group by the fire, and I presently gathered that the new-comer was called Mr. Mason; then I learned that he was but just arrived in England, and that he came from some hot country: which was the reason, doubtless, his face was so sallow, and that he sat so near the hearth, and wore a surtout in the house. Presently the words Jamaica, Kingston, Spanish Town, indicated the West Indies as his residence; and it was with no little surprise I gathered, ere long, that he had there first seen and become acquainted with Mr. Rochester. He spoke of his friend’s dislike of the burning heats, the hurricanes, and rainy seasons of that region. I knew Mr. Rochester had been a traveller: Mrs. Fairfax had said so; but I thought the continent of Europe had bounded his wanderings; till now I had never heard a hint given of visits to more distant shores.
I was pondering these things, when an incident, and a somewhat unexpected one, broke the thread of my musings. Mr. Mason, shivering as some one chanced to open the door, asked for more coal to be put on the fire, which had burnt out its flame, though its mass of cinder still shone hot and red. The footman who brought the coal, in going out, stopped near Mr. Eshton’s chair, and said something to him in a low voice, of which I heard only the words, “old woman,”—“quite troublesome.”
“Tell her she shall be put in the stocks if she does not take herself off,” replied the magistrate.
“No—stop!” interrupted Colonel Dent. “Don’t send her away, Eshton; we might turn the thing to account; better consult the ladies.” And speaking aloud, he continued—“Ladies, you talked of going to Hay Common to visit the gipsy camp; Sam here says that one of the old Mother Bunches is in the servants’ hall at this moment, and insists upon being brought in before ‘the quality,’ to tell them their fortunes. Would you like to see her?”

He mentioned Mr. Rochester’s dislike of the relentless heat, storms, and rainy weather typical of that area. I knew Mr. Rochester had travelled—Mrs. Fairfax had said so—but I assumed he had only visited Europe; I had never heard of him journeying further until now.

I was reflecting on all this when something unexpected interrupted my thoughts. Mr. Mason, shivering as someone opened the door, asked for more coal to be added to the fire, which had lost its flame, though the embers still glowed red. ‘Wait—don’t send her away, Eshton,’ Colonel Dent interjected. ‘She might be useful; perhaps we should consult with the ladies.’ Then, raising his voice to address the room, he added, ‘Ladies, you mentioned wanting to visit the gypsy camp at Hay Common; Sam tells us that one of the old Mother Bunches is in the servants’ hall right now and insists on being brought before you all to tell your fortunes. Would you like to see her?’

events.title: The Gypsy's Conditions and Miss Ingram's Consultation
detailed_summary: Lady Ingram objects to allowing the gypsy, calling her a low impostor.
The footman reports the gypsy is persistent and refuses to leave the servants' hall until she can tell the 'quality' their fortunes.
Mrs. Eshton asks what the gypsy wants, and is told she insists on telling fortunes.
The Misses Eshton inquire about her appearance; she is described as shockingly ugly.
The younger gentlemen are eager to see her for amusement.
Mrs. Lynn and Dowager Ingram express disapproval of the idea.
Blanche Ingram, however, overrules her mother, stating her curiosity to have her fortune told and orders the gypsy to be brought forward.
The younger members of the party echo Blanche's demand.
The footman hesitates, mentioning the gypsy's rough appearance, but is commanded by Miss Ingram to fetch her.
Anticipation fills the room, but Sam returns saying the gypsy will not appear before the 'vulgar herd' and must see individuals privately in a separate room.
Blanche Ingram insists on seeing the gypsy alone in the library.
Sam is sent to prepare the library, and then announces the gypsy is ready and asks who will be first.
Colonel Dent offers to check on the gypsy first, but Sam returns saying the gypsy will only see young, single ladies.
Miss Ingram declares she will go first and proceeds to the library despite her mother's pleas.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Surely, colonel,” cried Lady Ingram, “you would not encourage such a low impostor?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A comparative silence ensued.

events.text_segment:
“Surely, colonel,” cried Lady Ingram, “you would not encourage such a low impostor? Dismiss her, by all means, at once!”
“But I cannot persuade her to go away, my lady,” said the footman; “nor can any of the servants: Mrs. Fairfax is with her just now, entreating her to be gone; but she has taken a chair in the chimney-corner, and says nothing shall stir her from it till she gets leave to come in here.”
“What does she want?” asked Mrs. Eshton.
“‘To tell the gentry their fortunes,’ she says, ma’am; and she swears she must and will do it.”
“What is she like?” inquired the Misses Eshton, in a breath.
“A shockingly ugly old creature, miss; almost as black as a crock.”
“Why, she’s a real sorceress!” cried Frederick Lynn. “Let us have her in, of course.”
“To be sure,” rejoined his brother; “it would be a thousand pities to throw away such a chance of fun.”
“My dear boys, what are you thinking about?” exclaimed Mrs. Lynn.
“I cannot possibly countenance any such inconsistent proceeding,” chimed in the Dowager Ingram.
“Indeed, mama, but you can—and will,” pronounced the haughty voice of Blanche, as she turned round on the piano-stool; where till now she had sat silent, apparently examining sundry sheets of music. “I have a curiosity to hear my fortune told: therefore, Sam, order the beldame forward.”
“My darling Blanche! recollect—”
“I do—I recollect all you can suggest; and I must have my will—quick, Sam!”
“Yes—yes—yes!” cried all the juveniles, both ladies and gentlemen. “Let her come—it will be excellent sport!”
The footman still lingered. “She looks such a rough one,” said he.
“Go!” ejaculated Miss Ingram, and the man went.
Excitement instantly seized the whole party: a running fire of raillery and jests was proceeding when Sam returned.
“She won’t come now,” said he. “She says it’s not her mission to appear before the ‘vulgar herd’ (them’s her words). I must show her into a room by herself, and then those who wish to consult her must go to her one by one.”
“You see now, my queenly Blanche,” began Lady Ingram, “she encroaches. Be advised, my angel girl—and—”
“Show her into the library, of course,” cut in the “angel girl.” “It is not my mission to listen to her before the vulgar herd either: I mean to have her all to myself. Is there a fire in the library?”
“Yes, ma’am—but she looks such a tinkler.”
“Cease that chatter, blockhead! and do my bidding.”
Again Sam vanished; and mystery, animation, expectation rose to full flow once more.
“She’s ready now,” said the footman, as he reappeared. “She wishes to know who will be her first visitor.”
“I think I had better just look in upon her before any of the ladies go,” said Colonel Dent.
“Tell her, Sam, a gentleman is coming.”
Sam went and returned.
“She says, sir, that she’ll have no gentlemen; they need not trouble themselves to come near her; nor,” he added, with difficulty suppressing a titter, “any ladies either, except the young, and single.”
“By Jove, she has taste!” exclaimed Henry Lynn.
Miss Ingram rose solemnly: “I go first,” she said, in a tone which might have befitted the leader of a forlorn hope, mounting a breach in the van of his men.
“Oh, my best! oh, my dearest! pause—reflect!” was her mama’s cry; but she swept past her in stately silence, passed through the door which Colonel Dent held open, and we heard her enter the library.
A comparative silence ensued.
