events.title: Reactions to the Gypsy: Miss Ingram's Displeasure and Others' Amazement
detailed_summary: While Miss Ingram is with the gypsy, Lady Ingram frets, Miss Mary Ingram expresses fear, and Amy and Louisa Eshton are nervously amused.
After about fifteen minutes, Miss Ingram returns from the library.
She meets the guests' eager curiosity with a cold, rebuffing demeanor, looking neither flustered nor amused, and silently retakes her seat.
When questioned by her family and the Eshtons, she dismisses their excitement, stating she saw a common gypsy who told her typical fortunes and that her whim was gratified.

Miss Ingram then picks up a book, refusing further conversation, but Jane observes her for half an hour, noting she doesn't turn a page and her expression grows darker and more dissatisfied, suggesting the fortune-telling affected her negatively despite her feigned indifference.
Mary Ingram, Amy Eshton, and Louisa Eshton, though wishing to go, dare not go alone to the gypsy.
After negotiations via Sam, the footman, they are granted permission to see the gypsy as a group of three.
Their visit is noisy, filled with giggling and shrieks, and they return after about twenty minutes, appearing half-scared.
They exclaim that the gypsy is 'something not right' and knows all about them.
They reveal the gypsy told them of childhood incidents, described personal belongings, and even divined their thoughts and the names of those they liked best, as well as their deepest wishes.
The gentlemen press for more details on these last points but receive only blushes and evasions, while the older ladies express concern and offer smelling salts.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Lady Ingram thought it “le cas” to wring her hands: which she did accordingly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The matrons, meantime, offered vinaigrettes and wielded fans; and again and again reiterated the expression of their concern that their warning had not been taken in time; and the elder gentlemen laughed, and the younger urged their services on the agitated fair ones.

events.text_segment:
Lady Ingram thought it “le cas” to wring her hands: which she did accordingly. Miss Mary declared she felt, for her part, she never dared venture. Amy and Louisa Eshton tittered under their breath, and looked a little frightened.
The minutes passed very slowly: fifteen were counted before the library-door again opened. Miss Ingram returned to us through the arch.
Would she laugh? Would she take it as a joke? All eyes met her with a glance of eager curiosity, and she met all eyes with one of rebuff and coldness; she looked neither flurried nor merry: she walked stiffly to her seat, and took it in silence.
“Well, Blanche?” said Lord Ingram.
“What did she say, sister?” asked Mary.
“What did you think? How do you feel? Is she a real fortune-teller?” demanded the Misses Eshton.
“Now, now, good people,” returned Miss Ingram, “don’t press upon me. Really your organs of wonder and credulity are easily excited: you seem, by the importance of you all—my good mama included—ascribe to this matter, absolutely to believe we have a genuine witch in the house, who is in close alliance with the old gentleman. I have seen a gipsy vagabond; she has practised in hackneyed fashion the science of palmistry and told me what such people usually tell. My whim is gratified; and now I think Mr. Eshton will do well to put the hag in the stocks to-morrow morning, as he threatened.”
Miss Ingram took a book, leant back in her chair, and so declined further conversation. I watched her for nearly half-an-hour: during all that time she never turned a page, and her face grew momently darker, more dissatisfied, and more sourly expressive of disappointment. She had obviously not heard anything to her advantage: and it seemed to me, from her prolonged fit of gloom and taciturnity, that she herself, notwithstanding her professed indifference, attached undue importance to whatever revelations had been made her.
Meantime, Mary Ingram, Amy and Louisa Eshton, declared they dared not go alone; and yet they all wished to go. A negotiation was opened through the medium of the ambassador, Sam; and after much pacing to and fro, till, I think, the said Sam’s calves must have ached with the exercise, permission was at last, with great difficulty, extorted from the rigorous Sibyl, for the three to wait upon her in a body.
Their visit was not so still as Miss Ingram’s had been: we heard hysterical giggling and little shrieks proceeding from the library; and at the end of about twenty minutes they burst the door open, and came running across the hall, as if they were half-scared out of their wits.
“I am sure she is something not right!” they cried, one and all. “She told us such things! She knows all about us!” and they sank breathless into the various seats the gentlemen hastened to bring them.
Pressed for further explanation, they declared she had told them of things they had said and done when they were mere children; described books and ornaments they had in their boudoirs at home: keepsakes that different relations had presented to them. They affirmed that she had even divined their thoughts, and had whispered in the ear of each the name of the person she liked best in the world, and informed them of what they most wished for.
Here the gentlemen interposed with earnest petitions to be further enlightened on these two last-named points; but they got only blushes, ejaculations, tremors, and titters, in return for their importunity. The matrons, meantime, offered vinaigrettes and wielded fans; and again and again reiterated the expression of their concern that their warning had not been taken in time; and the elder gentlemen laughed, and the younger urged their services on the agitated fair ones.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Lady Ingram decided it was appropriate to wring her hands, which she proceeded to do. Miss Mary stated that, for her part, she felt she could never dare to go. Amy and Louisa Eshton quietly giggled and seemed a little scared. The minutes passed very slowly; fifteen had gone by before the library door opened again. Miss Ingram returned to where we were gathered, coming through the archway. Would she laugh? Would she treat it as a joke? Everyone looked at her with eager curiosity, and she responded to their gaze with one of coldness and dismissal. She looked neither upset nor cheerful. She walked rigidly to her seat and sat down in silence. “Well, Blanche?” Lord Ingram asked. “What did she say, sister?” Mary inquired. “What did you think? How do you feel? Is she a real fortune-teller?” the Misses Eshton demanded. “Now, now, calm down, everyone,” Miss Ingram replied, “don't crowd me. Honestly, your capacity for wonder and belief is easily stirred. It seems, judging by the importance you all—including my good mother—are giving this matter, that you truly believe we have a genuine witch in the house who is in league with the devil. I have seen a common travelling woman; she has performed the tired, usual tricks of palm reading and told me what such people typically say. My curiosity has been satisfied; and now I think Mr. Eshton would be wise to put the old woman in the public stocks tomorrow morning, as he threatened.” Miss Ingram picked up a book, leaned back in her chair, and thus indicated she would not discuss the matter further. I watched her for nearly half an hour. Throughout that time, she didn't turn a single page, and her face became progressively darker, more discontented, and more bitterly expressive of disappointment. She had clearly not heard anything favourable, and it appeared to me, from her prolonged state of gloom and silence, that she herself, despite claiming indifference, attached excessive importance to whatever predictions had been given to her. In the meantime, Mary Ingram, Amy and Louisa Eshton declared they were too afraid to go alone, and yet they all wished to go. A negotiation was arranged through the messenger, Sam, and after much pacing back and forth, until I believe Sam's leg muscles must have ached from the effort, permission was finally, with great difficulty, obtained from the strict fortune-teller for the three of them to visit her together. Their visit was not as quiet as Miss Ingram's had been; we heard excited giggling and small screams coming from the library. After about twenty minutes, they burst the door open and ran across the hall as if they were completely terrified. “I am certain she is something not normal!” they all exclaimed together. “She told us such things! She knows everything about us!” and they collapsed breathlessly into the various seats the gentlemen quickly brought for them. When pressed for more details, they explained she had told them about things they had said and done when they were just children; described books and decorative items they had in their private rooms at home; and mentioned mementos given to them by different relatives. They insisted that she had even guessed their thoughts and had whispered in the ear of each the name of the person she cared about most in the world, and informed them of what they most wished for. At this point, the gentlemen made earnest requests for further information on these last two points; but in response to their persistence, they only received blushes, exclamations, trembling, and nervous giggling. Meanwhile, the older ladies offered smelling salts and used their fans, repeatedly stating their concern that their warning had not been taken in time. The older gentlemen laughed, and the younger ones eagerly offered their help to the agitated young ladies.

Lord Ingram asked, 'Well, Blanche?' and Mary wanted to know what happened. The Eshton girls also questioned her about the fortune-teller. Miss Ingram told everyone not to interrogate her, teasing them for believing so easily, including her mother, that a real witch was present. She explained that she had simply met a gypsy who told her the usual things fortune-tellers say, and that now she was satisfied, suggesting that Mr. Eshton should lock the woman up the next morning as threatened. Then she picked up a book, leaned back, and refused to talk further. The narrator watched Miss Ingram for almost half an hour; she didn’t turn a page and her mood became increasingly sour and disappointed, indicating she hadn’t heard anything favorable, and in spite of pretending not to care, she was affected by what the fortune-teller had said.

events.title: Jane is Summoned by the Gypsy
detailed_summary: Amidst the commotion caused by the three young ladies' return from the gypsy, Sam, the footman, quietly approaches Jane.
He informs Jane that the gypsy has declared there is another young, single lady in the room who has not yet visited her, and the gypsy insists on seeing everyone before leaving.
Sam assumes this must be Jane, as there is no one else fitting the description.
He asks Jane what he should tell the gypsy.
Jane readily agrees to go, pleased by the unexpected chance to satisfy her own curiosity.
She slips out of the drawing-room unnoticed, as the company is preoccupied with the three agitated young women, and closes the door quietly.
Sam offers to wait in the hall in case Jane gets frightened.
Jane declines his offer, stating she is not afraid but is very interested and excited by the prospect.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the midst of the tumult, and while my eyes and ears were fully engaged in the scene before me, I heard a hem close at my elbow: I turned, and saw Sam.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Nor was I; but I was a good deal interested and excited.

events.text_segment:
In the midst of the tumult, and while my eyes and ears were fully engaged in the scene before me, I heard a hem close at my elbow: I turned, and saw Sam.
“If you please, miss, the gipsy declares that there is another young single lady in the room who has not been to her yet, and she swears she will not go till she has seen all. I thought it must be you: there is no one else for it. What shall I tell her?”
“Oh, I will go by all means,” I answered: and I was glad of the unexpected opportunity to gratify my much-excited curiosity. I slipped out of the room, unobserved by any eye—for the company were gathered in one mass about the trembling trio just returned—and I closed the door quietly behind me.
“If you like, miss,” said Sam, “I’ll wait in the hall for you; and if she frightens you, just call and I’ll come in.”
“No, Sam, return to the kitchen: I am not in the least afraid.” Nor was I; but I was a good deal interested and excited.

He said, "Excuse me, miss, but the gypsy insists there is another young unmarried lady present who hasn't seen her yet, and she vows she will not depart until she has spoken to everyone. I believed it must be you; there is no one else fitting the description. What message should I give her?" I responded, "Oh, I will definitely go," happy for the sudden chance to satisfy my strong curiosity. I left the room unnoticed by anyone, as the company was clustered together around the three trembling people who had just returned, and I shut the door quietly behind me. Sam offered, "If you prefer, miss, I can wait for you in the hall; and if she scares you, simply call, and I will enter." I told him, "No, Sam, return to the kitchen; I am not scared in the least." And I wasn't; however, I was quite interested and stirred up.

I turned and saw Sam. He said, "Excuse me, miss, the gypsy says there's still a young unmarried lady here she hasn't seen, and she refuses to leave until she has. I figured that must be you, since there's no one else it could be. What should I tell her?" I replied, "Oh, I'll go, definitely," happy for the chance to satisfy my growing curiosity. I slipped out, unnoticed by the others who were all distracted by the three people who had returned in a state of alarm, and quietly shut the door behind me. Sam then offered, "If you want, miss, I'll wait for you in the hall; if she scares you, just call and I'll come in." I reassured him, "No, Sam, go back to the kitchen. I’m not afraid at all." And truly, I wasn't frightened, but I was quite intrigued and excited.

events.title: Initial Encounter with the Mysterious Gipsy
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jane, enters the library to find a woman dressed as a gipsy, whom she refers to as a Sibyl, sitting by the fire and reading a small black book.
Jane warms her hands, feeling surprisingly calm, and observes the gipsy's appearance, noting her red cloak, black bonnet, and partially obscured, strange face with elf-locks and a direct gaze.
The gipsy abruptly asks Jane if she desires to have her fortune told.
Jane responds dismissively, stating her lack of belief in such practices, which the gipsy claims to have anticipated from Jane's very footsteps.
A brief, sharp dialogue ensues where Jane parries the gipsy's insinuations, denying that she is cold, sick, or silly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The library looked tranquil enough as I entered it, and the Sibyl—if Sibyl she were—was seated snugly enough in an easy-chair at the chimney-corner.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I’m not silly.”

events.text_segment:
The library looked tranquil enough as I entered it, and the Sibyl—if Sibyl she were—was seated snugly enough in an easy-chair at the chimney-corner. She had on a red cloak and a black bonnet: or rather, a broad-brimmed gipsy hat, tied down with a striped handkerchief under her chin. An extinguished candle stood on the table; she was bending over the fire, and seemed reading in a little black book, like a prayer-book, by the light of the blaze: she muttered the words to herself, as most old women do, while she read; she did not desist immediately on my entrance: it appeared she wished to finish a paragraph.
I stood on the rug and warmed my hands, which were rather cold with sitting at a distance from the drawing-room fire. I felt now as composed as ever I did in my life: there was nothing indeed in the gipsy’s appearance to trouble one’s calm. She shut her book and slowly looked up; her hat-brim partially shaded her face, yet I could see, as she raised it, that it was a strange one. It looked all brown and black: elf-locks bristled out from beneath a white band which passed under her chin, and came half over her cheeks, or rather jaws: her eye confronted me at once, with a bold and direct gaze.
“Well, and you want your fortune told?” she said, in a voice as decided as her glance, as harsh as her features.
“I don’t care about it, mother; you may please yourself: but I ought to warn you, I have no faith.”
“It’s like your impudence to say so: I expected it of you; I heard it in your step as you crossed the threshold.”
“Did you? You’ve a quick ear.”
“I have; and a quick eye and a quick brain.”
“You need them all in your trade.”
“I do; especially when I’ve customers like you to deal with. Why don’t you tremble?”
“I’m not cold.”
“Why don’t you turn pale?”
“I am not sick.”
“Why don’t you consult my art?”
“I’m not silly.”

The woman, whom they called the Sibyl (though I wasn't sure if that was accurate), sat comfortably in an easy chair by the fireplace. She wore a red cloak and a black bonnet, or more accurately, a broad-brimmed gipsy hat secured under her chin with a striped handkerchief. An unlit candle stood on the table. She was leaning over the fire, seemingly reading from a small black book that looked like a prayer book, using the firelight. As she read, she mumbled the words to herself, as many older women do. She didn't stop immediately when I came in; she seemed to want to finish the section. I stood on the rug and warmed my hands, which were rather chilled from sitting far from the drawing-room fire. I felt as composed now as I ever did; truly, there was nothing in the gipsy's look to disrupt one's calmness. She closed her book and slowly looked up. Her hat brim partially obscured her face, but as she raised it, I could see her face was peculiar. It looked entirely brown and dark. Tangles of hair (like 'elf-locks') jutted out from under a white band that went beneath her chin and came half over her cheeks, or rather her jaws. Her eye immediately met mine with a bold and direct stare. "Well, and you've come for your fortune told?" she asked, her voice as firm as her gaze and as rough as her features. "I don't care about it, mother; you can do as you please, but I should warn you, I have no belief in it." "How insolent of you to say so! I expected it; I heard it in your steps as you crossed the doorway." "Did you? You have sharp hearing." "I do, and keen eyesight, and a quick mind." "You must need all of them for your profession." "I do, especially with clients like you. Why aren't you trembling?" "I'm not cold." "Why aren't you turning pale?" "I'm not ill." "Why aren't you asking me to practice my art?" "I'm not foolish."

As I entered, the library was calm, and the Sibyl—if she was truly a Sibyl—sat comfortably in an armchair by the fire. She leaned over the fire, seemingly reading from a small black book that resembled a prayer-book, lit only by the flames; she murmured the words as she read, as elderly women often do. I felt as calm as ever, for nothing about the gypsy's look disturbed me. She finally closed her book and looked up at me slowly; her face was partially hidden by her hat but as she lifted her head I saw it was unusual—brown and black, with wild, tangled hair poking out from under a white band tied beneath her chin and along her jaws; her eyes met mine directly and fearlessly. "So, you want your fortune told?" she asked, her voice as strong and rough as her appearance.

"I don't really care for it, ma'am; you may do as you like, but I should tell you I'm not a believer."

"Typical for you to say that," she replied. "I expected it—I could tell from your footsteps as you walked in."

"Could you? You must be observant."

"I am: I have sharp eyes, ears, and mind."

"I suppose you need those for your work."

"Absolutely: especially with customers like you. Why aren't you nervous?"

"I'm not cold."

"Why don't you look pale?"

"I'm not ill."

"Why don't you ask for my fortune-telling?"

"I'm not foolish."

events.title: The Gipsy's Pronouncements on Jane's Character
detailed_summary: The gipsy laughs, lights a short black pipe, and after smoking for a moment, contradicts Jane by asserting that she is indeed cold, sick, and silly.
When Jane challenges her to substantiate these claims, the gipsy elaborates.
She explains Jane is 'cold' because her solitary existence prevents her inner warmth from being kindled by human connection.
She describes Jane as 'sick' because she remains distant from love, characterized as the most profound human emotion.
She deems Jane 'silly' for not actively pursuing happiness, which the gipsy claims is readily available to her, despite any suffering Jane endures.
The gipsy emphasizes that Jane is in a unique position, very close to attaining happiness, with all the necessary elements present but needing a catalyst to combine them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The old crone “nichered” a laugh under her bonnet and bandage; she then drew out a short black pipe, and lighting it began to smoke.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Chance laid them somewhat apart; let them be once approached and bliss results.”

events.text_segment:
The old crone “nichered” a laugh under her bonnet and bandage; she then drew out a short black pipe, and lighting it began to smoke. Having indulged a while in this sedative, she raised her bent body, took the pipe from her lips, and while gazing steadily at the fire, said very deliberately—
“You are cold; you are sick; and you are silly.”
“Prove it,” I rejoined.
“I will, in few words. You are cold, because you are alone: no contact strikes the fire from you that is in you. You are sick; because the best of feelings, the highest and the sweetest given to man, keeps far away from you. You are silly, because, suffer as you may, you will not beckon it to approach, nor will you stir one step to meet it where it waits you.”
She again put her short black pipe to her lips, and renewed her smoking with vigour.
“You might say all that to almost any one who you knew lived as a solitary dependent in a great house.”
“I might say it to almost any one: but would it be true of almost any one?”
“In my circumstances.”
“Yes; just so, in your circumstances: but find me another precisely placed as you are.”
“It would be easy to find you thousands.”
“You could scarcely find me one. If you knew it, you are peculiarly situated: very near happiness; yes, within reach of it. The materials are all prepared; there only wants a movement to combine them. Chance laid them somewhat apart; let them be once approached and bliss results.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The elderly woman let out a quiet chuckle beneath her head covering and bandaged face. She then produced a small black pipe, lit it, and began to smoke. After enjoying this calming activity for a while, she straightened her hunched posture, took the pipe from her mouth, and, staring intently into the fire, stated very slowly and deliberately: "You are feeling distant; you are unwell; and you are being foolish." I challenged her, saying, "Prove it." She replied, "I will, concisely. You are distant because you are by yourself; you lack the connection that would ignite the fire within you. You are unwell because the noblest and most cherished human emotion, love, is far from you. You are being foolish because, despite your suffering, you refuse to invite it closer or take any action to meet it where it awaits." She put her small black pipe back to her lips and resumed smoking vigorously. I commented, "You could say all of that about nearly anyone you know who lives as a solitary dependent in a large house." She responded, "I could say it about almost anyone, but would it be accurate for almost anyone?" I pressed, "In my situation." "Yes," she agreed, "exactly, in *your* situation. But find me another person placed precisely as you are." I argued, "It would be easy to find thousands." She countered, "You would struggle to find even one. If you understood it, your position is quite unusual: very close to happiness, yes, within its grasp. All the components are ready; only a movement is needed to bring them together. Fate placed them somewhat apart; let them be brought closer just once, and joy will follow."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
The elderly woman chuckled quietly beneath her hat and bandages, then pulled out a small black pipe, lit it, and began to smoke. After enjoying her pipe for a short time, she straightened up, removed the pipe from her mouth, and, looking intently at the fire, spoke slowly: "You are cold; you are ill; and you are foolish." 

I replied, "Prove it."

She answered, "I will, briefly. You are cold because you are alone; there’s no one to draw out the warmth inside you. You are sick because the best and noblest feelings a person can have are absent from your life. You are foolish because, no matter how you suffer, you refuse to call these feelings to you, or to take a single step to meet them, even though they wait nearby."

She put her pipe back in her mouth and smoked energetically.

I said, "You could tell that to almost anyone you knew who lived alone and was dependent in a large house."

She replied, "I could say it to most people, but would it be true for most?"

"In my position, yes."

"Exactly, in your circumstances. But find me someone else in exactly your situation."

"It would be easy to find thousands."

"You would be lucky to find even one. Your situation is unique: you are close to happiness; happiness is within your reach. Everything you need is in place; it just takes a single act to bring it all together. Fate put these pieces a bit apart; just move toward them, and you’ll be happy."

events.title: From Palmistry to Physiognomy: Seeking Jane's Destiny
detailed_summary: Jane expresses her inability to understand riddles and requests a more direct explanation from the gipsy.
The gipsy then asks to see Jane's palm, a request Jane complies with after giving the gipsy a shilling as payment.
The gipsy briefly examines Jane's palm but dismisses it as too fine and uninformative, stating that destiny is not inscribed there.
Jane concurs with this assessment.
The gipsy then asserts that destiny is revealed in the facial features—forehead, eyes, and mouth—and instructs Jane to kneel and look up so her face can be examined.
Jane complies, remarking that this approach feels more authentic and that her belief in the gipsy is starting to grow.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I don’t understand enigmas.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I shall begin to put some faith in you presently.”

events.text_segment:
“I don’t understand enigmas. I never could guess a riddle in my life.”
“If you wish me to speak more plainly, show me your palm.”
“And I must cross it with silver, I suppose?”
“To be sure.”
I gave her a shilling: she put it into an old stocking-foot which she took out of her pocket, and having tied it round and returned it, she told me to hold out my hand. I did. She approached her face to the palm, and pored over it without touching it.
“It is too fine,” said she. “I can make nothing of such a hand as that; almost without lines: besides, what is in a palm? Destiny is not written there.”
“I believe you,” said I.
“No,” she continued, “it is in the face: on the forehead, about the eyes, in the lines of the mouth. Kneel, and lift up your head.”
“Ah! now you are coming to reality,” I said, as I obeyed her. “I shall begin to put some faith in you presently.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I admitted I was bad at interpreting mysteries and had never been able to solve riddles. The fortune-teller suggested if I wanted clearer answers, I should show her my hand. I asked if I was expected to pay, specifically to cross her palm with silver, and she confirmed it was necessary. I gave her a shilling. She placed it inside an old stocking-foot she pulled from her pocket, tied it up, and put it away before instructing me to extend my hand, which I did. She leaned close to my palm, examining it intently but without making contact. She declared it was too delicate and lacked enough lines for her to read; she questioned the significance of a palm, stating fate wasn't written there. I agreed with her assessment. She went on to explain that destiny was actually found in the face – on the forehead, around the eyes, and in the lines of the mouth. She then told me to kneel and raise my head. As I did, I remarked that this approach felt more genuine and that I was starting to believe her a little.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: "I never could solve riddles or puzzles," I said. "If you want me to be clearer, let me see your palm," she replied. "And I suppose I need to pay you?" I asked. "Of course," she responded. I handed her a shilling, which she put into an old sock she pulled from her pocket, tied it up, and returned it. Then she asked me to hold out my hand, and, without touching, she closely examined my palm. "It's too delicate," she remarked. "There are hardly any lines—nothing to read. Anyway, fate isn't written in hands." "I believe you," I replied. She went on, "No, destiny is seen in the face—on the forehead, around the eyes, in the mouth's lines. Kneel and lift your head." "Now this is becoming real," I said as I complied. "I might soon start believing you."

events.title: The Gipsy Probes Jane's Feelings, Focusing on Mr. Rochester
detailed_summary: As Jane kneels, the gipsy manipulates the fire, casting Jane's face in light while her own remains obscured.
The gipsy muses aloud about Jane's inner thoughts and feelings while observing the affluent guests, implying a lack of meaningful interaction between Jane and them.
Jane admits to occasional tiredness or sleepiness but denies feeling sad, stating her only hope is to save enough to start her own school.
The gipsy considers this ambition meager and reveals knowledge of Jane's habits, such as her window-seat vigils, attributing this information to Mrs. Poole, which startles Jane.
The gipsy continues to probe Jane about her interest in the social dynamics, particularly if she singles out individuals or observes their courtships, which generally lead to marriage.
Jane professes indifference to these romantic themes.
The gipsy specifically challenges this by mentioning a lady smiling at a gentleman Jane might esteem.
Jane denies any significant acquaintance with the gentlemen, including Mr. Rochester, whom she notes is currently absent.

The gipsy scoffs at this evasion and directly brings Mr. Rochester into the conversation, questioning if Jane has observed the attention he receives and the frequent discussions about his potential marriage.
Jane becomes increasingly perplexed by the gipsy's intimate knowledge and pointed questions, feeling as if an unseen entity has been scrutinizing her innermost self.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I knelt within half a yard of her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: One unexpected sentence came from her lips after another, till I got involved in a web of mystification; and wondered what unseen spirit had been sitting for weeks by my heart watching its workings and taking record of every pulse.

events.text_segment:
I knelt within half a yard of her. She stirred the fire, so that a ripple of light broke from the disturbed coal: the glare, however, as she sat, only threw her face into deeper shadow: mine, it illumined.
“I wonder with what feelings you came to me to-night,” she said, when she had examined me a while. “I wonder what thoughts are busy in your heart during all the hours you sit in yonder room with the fine people flitting before you like shapes in a magic-lantern: just as little sympathetic communion passing between you and them as if they were really mere shadows of human forms, and not the actual substance.”
“I feel tired often, sleepy sometimes, but seldom sad.”
“Then you have some secret hope to buoy you up and please you with whispers of the future?”
“Not I. The utmost I hope is, to save money enough out of my earnings to set up a school some day in a little house rented by myself.”
“A mean nutriment for the spirit to exist on: and sitting in that window-seat (you see I know your habits)—”
“You have learned them from the servants.”
“Ah! you think yourself sharp. Well, perhaps I have: to speak truth, I have an acquaintance with one of them, Mrs. Poole—”
I started to my feet when I heard the name.
“You have—have you?” thought I; “there is diablerie in the business after all, then!”
“Don’t be alarmed,” continued the strange being; “she’s a safe hand is Mrs. Poole: close and quiet; any one may repose confidence in her. But, as I was saying: sitting in that window-seat, do you think of nothing but your future school? Have you no present interest in any of the company who occupy the sofas and chairs before you? Is there not one face you study? one figure whose movements you follow with at least curiosity?”
“I like to observe all the faces and all the figures.”
“But do you never single one from the rest—or it may be, two?”
“I do frequently; when the gestures or looks of a pair seem telling a tale: it amuses me to watch them.”
“What tale do you like best to hear?”
“Oh, I have not much choice! They generally run on the same theme—courtship; and promise to end in the same catastrophe—marriage.”
“And do you like that monotonous theme?”
“Positively, I don’t care about it: it is nothing to me.”
“Nothing to you? When a lady, young and full of life and health, charming with beauty and endowed with the gifts of rank and fortune, sits and smiles in the eyes of a gentleman you—”
“I what?”
“You know—and perhaps think well of.”
“I don’t know the gentlemen here. I have scarcely interchanged a syllable with one of them; and as to thinking well of them, I consider some respectable, and stately, and middle-aged, and others young, dashing, handsome, and lively: but certainly they are all at liberty to be the recipients of whose smiles they please, without my feeling disposed to consider the transaction of any moment to me.”
“You don’t know the gentlemen here? You have not exchanged a syllable with one of them? Will you say that of the master of the house!”
“He is not at home.”
“A profound remark! A most ingenious quibble! He went to Millcote this morning, and will be back here to-night or to-morrow: does that circumstance exclude him from the list of your acquaintance—blot him, as it were, out of existence?”
“No; but I can scarcely see what Mr. Rochester has to do with the theme you had introduced.”
“I was talking of ladies smiling in the eyes of gentlemen; and of late so many smiles have been shed into Mr. Rochester’s eyes that they overflow like two cups filled above the brim: have you never remarked that?”
“Mr. Rochester has a right to enjoy the society of his guests.”
“No question about his right: but have you never observed that, of all the tales told here about matrimony, Mr. Rochester has been favoured with the most lively and the most continuous?”
“The eagerness of a listener quickens the tongue of a narrator.” I said this rather to myself than to the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice, manner, had by this time wrapped me in a kind of dream. One unexpected sentence came from her lips after another, till I got involved in a web of mystification; and wondered what unseen spirit had been sitting for weeks by my heart watching its workings and taking record of every pulse.

'I often feel weary, sometimes sleepy, but rarely unhappy,' I replied. 'Then you must have some hidden hope to lift your spirits and excite you with thoughts of the future?' she probed. She reassured me that Mrs. Poole was trustworthy. Then she asked if, when I sat there, I thought only of my future school, or if I took any interest in any of the guests—was there anyone I observed more closely? I answered that I liked to observe everyone, but sometimes watched those whose interactions seemed to tell a story, usually of courtship and marriage, though I didn't care much for these themes. She pressed further, asking about my feelings towards any specific gentleman, like the master of the house. I replied that Mr. Rochester was away and that regardless, I barely knew the other men, nor did their interactions with the ladies matter to me. She pointedly mentioned the many smiles given to Mr. Rochester and asked if I’d noticed, suggesting he was often the subject of romantic attention. I responded that a keen listener encourages more storytelling, but the gypsy’s odd manner had drawn me into a dreamlike state where I wondered if some unseen presence had been observing and recording my feelings.

events.title: Physiognomic Analysis and the Gipsy's Passionate Outburst
detailed_summary: The gipsy remarks on Mr. Rochester's apparent engagement with his companions, asking if Jane has noticed his gratitude for their company; Jane denies detecting gratitude.
The gipsy presses further, suggesting Jane has witnessed love and envisioned Mr. Rochester's marriage, which Jane ambiguously refutes.

Jane tries to redirect the conversation back to her own fortune, but the gipsy first confirms that Mr. Rochester is indeed expected to marry Miss Ingram soon, adding a cryptic remark about a recent conversation that unsettled Miss Ingram regarding the Rochester estate.
Jane again insists on hearing her own fortune.
The gipsy responds that Jane's fortune is uncertain due to conflicting traits but assures her that happiness is available if she chooses to accept it.

Instructing Jane to kneel once more, the gipsy analyzes her features: her eyes (soft, feeling, sad from loneliness, yet proud), her mouth (made for expression and affection), and her brow (indicating self-respect, independence, and a mind ruled by reason and conscience).
The gipsy then launches into a fervent monologue, seemingly reflecting on her own intentions to nurture happiness and earn gratitude, guided by reason and conscience, without causing pain or remorse.
This passionate speech ends with the gipsy admitting to a state of 'exquisite delirium' and abruptly concluding the session, telling Jane the 'play is played out' and instructing her to leave.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Eagerness of a listener!” repeated she: “yes; Mr. Rochester has sat by the hour, his ear inclined to the fascinating lips that took such delight in their task of communicating; and Mr. Rochester was so willing to receive and looked so grateful for the pastime given him; you have noticed this?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Rise, Miss Eyre: leave me; ‘the play is played out.’”

events.text_segment:
“Eagerness of a listener!” repeated she: “yes; Mr. Rochester has sat by the hour, his ear inclined to the fascinating lips that took such delight in their task of communicating; and Mr. Rochester was so willing to receive and looked so grateful for the pastime given him; you have noticed this?”
“Grateful! I cannot remember detecting gratitude in his face.”
“Detecting! You have analysed, then. And what did you detect, if not gratitude?”
I said nothing.
“You have seen love: have you not?—and, looking forward, you have seen him married, and beheld his bride happy?”
“Humph! Not exactly. Your witch’s skill is rather at fault sometimes.”
“What the devil have you seen, then?”
“Never mind: I came here to inquire, not to confess. Is it known that Mr. Rochester is to be married?”
“Yes; and to the beautiful Miss Ingram.”
“Shortly?”
“Appearances would warrant that conclusion: and, no doubt (though, with an audacity that wants chastising out of you, you seem to question it), they will be a superlatively happy pair. He must love such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady; and probably she loves him, or, if not his person, at least his purse. I know she considers the Rochester estate eligible to the last degree; though (God pardon me!) I told her something on that point about an hour ago which made her look wondrous grave: the corners of her mouth fell half an inch. I would advise her blackaviced suitor to look out: if another comes, with a longer or clearer rent-roll,—he’s dished—”
“But, mother, I did not come to hear Mr. Rochester’s fortune: I came to hear my own; and you have told me nothing of it.”
“Your fortune is yet doubtful: when I examined your face, one trait contradicted another. Chance has meted you a measure of happiness: that I know. I knew it before I came here this evening. She has laid it carefully on one side for you. I saw her do it. It depends on yourself to stretch out your hand, and take it up: but whether you will do so, is the problem I study. Kneel again on the rug.”
“Don’t keep me long; the fire scorches me.”
I knelt. She did not stoop towards me, but only gazed, leaning back in her chair. She began muttering,—
“The flame flickers in the eye; the eye shines like dew; it looks soft and full of feeling; it smiles at my jargon: it is susceptible; impression follows impression through its clear sphere; where it ceases to smile, it is sad; an unconscious lassitude weighs on the lid: that signifies melancholy resulting from loneliness. It turns from me; it will not suffer further scrutiny; it seems to deny, by a mocking glance, the truth of the discoveries I have already made,—to disown the charge both of sensibility and chagrin: its pride and reserve only confirm me in my opinion. The eye is favourable.
“As to the mouth, it delights at times in laughter; it is disposed to impart all that the brain conceives; though I daresay it would be silent on much the heart experiences. Mobile and flexible, it was never intended to be compressed in the eternal silence of solitude: it is a mouth which should speak much and smile often, and have human affection for its interlocutor. That feature too is propitious.
“I see no enemy to a fortunate issue but in the brow; and that brow professes to say,—‘I can live alone, if self-respect, and circumstances require me so to do. I need not sell my soul to buy bliss. I have an inward treasure born with me, which can keep me alive if all extraneous delights should be withheld, or offered only at a price I cannot afford to give.’ The forehead declares, ‘Reason sits firm and holds the reins, and she will not let the feelings burst away and hurry her to wild chasms. The passions may rage furiously, like true heathens, as they are; and the desires may imagine all sorts of vain things: but judgment shall still have the last word in every argument, and the casting vote in every decision. Strong wind, earthquake-shock, and fire may pass by: but I shall follow the guiding of that still small voice which interprets the dictates of conscience.’
“Well said, forehead; your declaration shall be respected. I have formed my plans—right plans I deem them—and in them I have attended to the claims of conscience, the counsels of reason. I know how soon youth would fade and bloom perish, if, in the cup of bliss offered, but one dreg of shame, or one flavour of remorse were detected; and I do not want sacrifice, sorrow, dissolution—such is not my taste. I wish to foster, not to blight—to earn gratitude, not to wring tears of blood—no, nor of brine: my harvest must be in smiles, in endearments, in sweet—That will do. I think I rave in a kind of exquisite delirium. I should wish now to protract this moment ad infinitum; but I dare not. So far I have governed myself thoroughly. I have acted as I inwardly swore I would act; but further might try me beyond my strength. Rise, Miss Eyre: leave me; ‘the play is played out.’”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: “An eager listener!” she repeated, “Yes, Mr. Rochester has spent hours with his ear close to those captivating lips that clearly enjoyed communicating so much. And Mr. Rochester was so willing to hear and seemed so thankful for the entertainment she provided; you noticed this, didn't you?” “Thankful! I don't recall seeing thankfulness on his face.” “Seeing! So you analysed him? What did you see, if not gratitude?” I didn't respond. “You've seen love, haven't you? And looking ahead, you've pictured him married and his bride being happy?” “Hmm, not exactly. Your fortune-telling ability seems to miss the mark sometimes.” “What on earth did you see, then?” “Never mind that. I came here to ask questions, not to reveal things about myself. Is it known that Mr. Rochester is getting married?” “Yes, to the beautiful Miss Ingram.” “Soon?” “All signs point to that conclusion, and undoubtedly (even though you, with surprising boldness, seem to doubt it), they will be an incredibly happy couple. He must surely love such an attractive, noble, witty, and accomplished lady, and she probably loves him, or if not him, at least his money. I know she considers the Rochester estate highly desirable, although (Heaven help me!) I said something to her about that about an hour ago that made her look very serious; the corners of her mouth dropped half an inch. I'd advise her dark-complexioned admirer to be cautious; if someone with a larger or clearer income arrives, he's finished.” “But, madam, I didn't come to hear about Mr. Rochester's future; I came to hear about my own, and you haven't told me anything.” “Your future is still uncertain. When I examined your face, some features contradicted others. Fate has assigned you a measure of happiness, I know that. I knew it before coming here tonight. Fate has carefully set it aside for you. I saw it happen. It depends on you reaching out and claiming it, but whether you will do so is the question I'm contemplating. Kneel on the rug again.” “Please don't keep me long; the fire is too hot.” I knelt down. She didn't lean towards me but just stared, leaning back in her chair. She began murmuring quietly, “There's a flicker in the eye; the eye shines like dew; it looks soft and full of feeling; it seems amused by my words. It's sensitive; impressions pass through its clear surface easily. When it stops smiling, it looks sad; an unconscious weariness rests on the lid, indicating sadness resulting from loneliness. It turns away from me; it won't allow further close inspection. With a teasing look, it seems to deny the truth of the things I've already found—to reject being seen as both sensitive and unhappy. Its pride and reserve only confirm my assessment. The eye is promising. As for the mouth, it sometimes enjoys laughter; it is inclined to express everything the mind thinks, though I expect it would remain silent about much that the heart feels. Expressive and adaptable, it was never meant to be confined by the perpetual silence of solitude. It is a mouth that should speak often and smile frequently, receiving human affection from those it talks to. That feature is also favourable. I see no obstacle to a happy outcome except in the brow. And that brow seems to say, 'I can live alone if self-respect and circumstances require me to. I don't need to compromise my principles to gain happiness. I have an inner strength within me that can sustain me even if all external pleasures are withheld or offered only at a price I cannot afford.' The forehead declares, 'Reason is firmly in control, guiding everything and preventing emotions from breaking loose and rushing her into dangerous situations. Passions may rage fiercely, like untamed forces, as they are, and desires may imagine all sorts of foolish things, but judgment will still have the final word in every debate and the decisive vote in every choice. Strong winds, earthquake tremors, and fire may pass by, but I will follow the guidance of that quiet inner voice which interprets the dictates of conscience.' Well spoken, forehead; your declaration shall be respected. I have made my plans—which I believe are the correct ones—and in them I have taken into account the demands of conscience and the advice of reason. I know how quickly youth would fade and beauty perish if, in the happiness offered, even one trace of shame or one hint of regret were found. And I do not want sacrifice, sorrow, or destruction—that is not what I desire. I want to nurture, not destroy—to earn gratitude, not cause deep suffering. No, not even tears of sadness. My reward must come from smiles, affection, and pleasant things. That's enough. I think I'm speaking in a kind of intense dreamlike state. I would like to extend this moment indefinitely, but I must not. So far, I have maintained complete control of myself. I have acted exactly as I internally vowed I would, but going further might test me beyond my ability. Stand up, Miss Eyre. Leave me; 'the performance is over.'
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
She repeated, "Eagerness in a listener! Yes, Mr. Rochester would sit for ages, listening intently to the charming lips that delighted in talking, and he seemed so eager for it and so grateful for the pleasure given; haven't you noticed that?" 

I replied, "Grateful? I don't recall ever seeing gratitude on his face."

She said, "So you have studied his expression? What did you notice if not gratitude?"

I stayed quiet. 

She continued, "You saw love, didn't you? And you've pictured him married, with his bride happy?"

"Not exactly," I answered. "Your fortune-telling isn't always accurate."

"Well then, what do you think you saw?"

"That's not why I'm here; I came to ask questions, not to confess. Is it true Mr. Rochester is getting married?"

"Yes, to the lovely Miss Ingram."

"Soon?"

"It looks that way, and, despite your doubtful tone, they surely will make a very happy pair. He must love such a beautiful, clever, and accomplished woman; and I'm sure she at least loves his wealth if not him. I'm positive she finds the Rochester estate highly desirable—though I told her something an hour ago that made her look very serious: she stopped smiling. I'd advise Mr. Rochester to be careful—if someone with more money comes along, she's likely to leave him."

"But, mother, I'm not here to learn about Mr. Rochester's future—I'm interested in mine, and you haven't told me anything."

"Your future is still uncertain; when I looked at your face, I saw contradictions. Fate has granted you some happiness, I know that for sure. I saw it set aside for you, and now it's up to you to reach out and take it. Whether you will, that's what I'm trying to figure out. Kneel again on the rug."

"Don't keep me waiting; the fire is too hot."

I knelt. She didn't bend over me, just stared from her chair and began murmuring,

"The eyes flicker with the flame; they shine softly and sensitively, and smile at my nonsense; they're susceptible, emotions passing through clearly; when they stop smiling, they're sad, weighted down by loneliness. They turn from me; they don't want my scrutiny; the look almost denies the feelings I've already noticed—refusing to admit either sensitivity or sadness, but that just confirms my opinion. The eyes are favourable.

"The mouth laughs and wants to share ideas, though I'm sure it wouldn't speak of everything the heart feels. Expressive and lively, it's not meant for silence or solitude. It's a mouth meant for talking and smiling, for affection. That's a good sign too.

"The only possible obstacle is the brow: it's saying, 'I can live alone if I must. I won't buy happiness at the cost of self-respect. I have inner resources to survive if everything else is withheld or comes at too high a price.' The forehead insists that reason is in control and will not let emotions lead to disaster. Passions may rage, but judgment has the last say. Through turmoil, conscience will guide."

"Well said, brow. I respect your resolution. I've planned rightly, considering conscience and reason. I know how quickly youth would fade if happiness contained even a drop of shame or remorse. I want gratitude, not pain, in return. My rewards must be smiles, affection, sweetness—that's enough. I'm in a kind of happy daze. I'd love to hold onto this moment forever, but I shouldn't. So far, I've kept my resolve; to go further might be too much. Stand up, Miss Eyre: we're finished here."

events.title: The Gipsy's Disguise Unravels, Revealing Mr. Rochester
detailed_summary: Jane is left in a state of confusion, feeling as though she might be dreaming, as the gipsy's voice, accent, and gestures suddenly become unmistakably familiar.
She stands up but hesitates to leave, scrutinizing the gipsy, who attempts to pull her disguise tighter.
Jane's attention is drawn to the gipsy's outstretched hand, which she realizes is not old and withered but youthful and supple; she then spots a recognizable ring on the little finger.
Looking again at the gipsy's face, Jane sees that the bonnet has been removed and the bandage displaced, revealing the person beneath.
A familiar voice, now clearly identifiable, asks Jane if she recognizes him.
Jane requests that the red cloak also be removed for full confirmation.
After a brief struggle with a knotted string, which Jane advises him to break, Mr. Rochester emerges from his gipsy costume.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Where was I?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And Mr. Rochester stepped out of his disguise.

events.text_segment:
Where was I? Did I wake or sleep? Had I been dreaming? Did I dream still? The old woman’s voice had changed: her accent, her gesture, and all were familiar to me as my own face in a glass—as the speech of my own tongue. I got up, but did not go. I looked; I stirred the fire, and I looked again: but she drew her bonnet and her bandage closer about her face, and again beckoned me to depart. The flame illuminated her hand stretched out: roused now, and on the alert for discoveries, I at once noticed that hand. It was no more the withered limb of eld than my own; it was a rounded supple member, with smooth fingers, symmetrically turned; a broad ring flashed on the little finger, and stooping forward, I looked at it, and saw a gem I had seen a hundred times before. Again I looked at the face; which was no longer turned from me—on the contrary, the bonnet was doffed, the bandage displaced, the head advanced.
“Well, Jane, do you know me?” asked the familiar voice.
“Only take off the red cloak, sir, and then—”
“But the string is in a knot—help me.”
“Break it, sir.”
“There, then—‘Off, ye lendings!’” And Mr. Rochester stepped out of his disguise.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I felt disoriented, questioning if I was awake or asleep, or if I was currently dreaming or had been. The old woman's voice shifted; her way of speaking, her gestures, and everything about her were as familiar to me as my own face reflected in a mirror or the sound of my own speech. I got up but remained in place. I observed her; I poked the fire and looked again. Yet, she pulled her bonnet and head covering more closely around her face and signaled for me to leave once more. The glow from the fire illuminated her outstretched hand. Now alert and seeking understanding, I immediately focused on that hand. It was not at all the withered hand of an old person but a smooth, curved limb with graceful, evenly shaped fingers. A noticeable ring sparkled on the little finger, and bending forward, I examined it and recognized a jewel I had seen countless times before. I looked at the face again; it was no longer turned away. Instead, the bonnet had been removed, the bandage displaced, and the head inclined forward. "Well, Jane, do you recognize me?" the well-known voice asked. "Just take off the red cloak, sir, and then—" I replied. "But the tie is knotted—assist me," he said. "Break it, sir," I suggested. "There, then—'Discard these temporary garments!'" And Mr. Rochester emerged from his disguise.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Where was I? Was I awake or asleep? Had I been dreaming, or was I still dreaming? The old woman’s voice had changed; her mannerisms and gestures were as familiar to me as my own reflection or my own speech. I stood up, but did not leave. I glanced around; I poked at the fire, looked again: but she pulled her bonnet and her bandage tighter around her face, and again gestured for me to go. The light from the fire lit up her extended hand: now on guard and attentive for details, I immediately observed that hand. It was not the withered hand of age, but rather a full, smooth hand, with shapely fingers; a wide ring sparkled on the pinky, and as I bent closer, I recognized a jewel I had seen countless times. I looked again at the face, which was now turned toward me—the bonnet was removed, the bandage slipped off, and the head leaned forward. 

"Well, Jane, do you know me?" asked the familiar voice. 

"Just take off the red cloak, sir, and then—"

"But the string is knotted—help me."

"Break it, sir."

"There you go—‘Off with these disguises!’” And Mr. Rochester stepped out from his concealment.

events.title: Confrontation and the Ominous News of Mason's Arrival
detailed_summary: Jane expresses her astonishment at Mr. Rochester's peculiar stratagem.
Mr. Rochester seeks validation for his performance, asking if Jane thought it was well executed.
Jane suggests his portrayal of a gipsy was unconvincing to her, accusing him of attempting to manipulate her into revealing her thoughts by speaking nonsense, which she deems unfair.

Mr. Rochester asks for Jane's forgiveness. Jane states she needs time to reflect but admits she had suspected a masquerade from the start, noting the gipsy's uncharacteristic speech and efforts to hide her face, though she had initially suspected Mrs. Poole rather than Mr. Rochester.
Mr. Rochester then inquires about the activities and conversation of the guests in the drawing-room, and Jane speculates they are discussing the gipsy.
He urges her to stay and recount what they said about him.
Jane, noting the late hour, attempts to depart and then informs Mr. Rochester of the arrival of a stranger, a Mr. Mason from the West Indies, who claims to know him and is awaiting his return.
The news causes a visible and profound shock in Mr. Rochester, who was in the process of taking Jane's hand.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now, sir, what a strange idea!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Rochester was standing near me; he had taken my hand, as if to lead me to a chair.

events.text_segment:
“Now, sir, what a strange idea!”
“But well carried out, eh? Don’t you think so?”
“With the ladies you must have managed well.”
“But not with you?”
“You did not act the character of a gipsy with me.”
“What character did I act? My own?”
“No; some unaccountable one. In short, I believe you have been trying to draw me out—or in; you have been talking nonsense to make me talk nonsense. It is scarcely fair, sir.”
“Do you forgive me, Jane?”
“I cannot tell till I have thought it all over. If, on reflection, I find I have fallen into no great absurdity, I shall try to forgive you; but it was not right.”
“Oh, you have been very correct—very careful, very sensible.”
I reflected, and thought, on the whole, I had. It was a comfort; but, indeed, I had been on my guard almost from the beginning of the interview. Something of masquerade I suspected. I knew gipsies and fortune-tellers did not express themselves as this seeming old woman had expressed herself; besides I had noted her feigned voice, her anxiety to conceal her features. But my mind had been running on Grace Poole—that living enigma, that mystery of mysteries, as I considered her. I had never thought of Mr. Rochester.
“Well,” said he, “what are you musing about? What does that grave smile signify?”
“Wonder and self-congratulation, sir. I have your permission to retire now, I suppose?”
“No; stay a moment; and tell me what the people in the drawing-room yonder are doing.”
“Discussing the gipsy, I daresay.”
“Sit down!—Let me hear what they said about me.”
“I had better not stay long, sir; it must be near eleven o’clock. Oh, are you aware, Mr. Rochester, that a stranger has arrived here since you left this morning?”
“A stranger!—no; who can it be? I expected no one; is he gone?”
“No; he said he had known you long, and that he could take the liberty of installing himself here till you returned.”
“The devil he did! Did he give his name?”
“His name is Mason, sir; and he comes from the West Indies; from Spanish Town, in Jamaica, I think.”
Mr. Rochester was standing near me; he had taken my hand, as if to lead me to a chair.

He asks if he pulled it off well, saying, "But it was well-executed, wasn't it? Don't you agree?" Jane comments, "You must have handled the ladies quite skillfully." Rochester retorts, "But not with you?" Jane clarifies, "You didn't behave like a fortune-teller with me." He questions, "What part did I play, then? Myself?" "No," she replies, "some inexplicable one. Frankly, I believe you were trying to provoke a reaction from me, perhaps to reveal something – you were speaking nonsense to encourage me to do the same. That's hardly fair, sir." Rochester asks, "Do you forgive me, Jane?" She responds, "I can't say until I've considered everything. If, after thinking, I find I didn't make too great a fool of myself, I'll try to forgive you; but it wasn't right." He concedes, "Oh, you were very proper—very cautious, very sensible." Jane reflected, concluding that she had indeed been careful overall, which was reassuring. She admitted she had been wary almost from the moment the conversation began. She suspected some sort of deception. She knew that real gypsies and fortune-tellers didn't speak the way the person disguised as an old woman had, and she had noticed the fake voice and the effort to hide the face. However, her thoughts had been preoccupied with Grace Poole, whom she regarded as a living puzzle, a deep mystery. She had never considered that it might be Mr. Rochester. He then asked, "Well," what are you thinking about? What does that serious smile mean?" Jane replied, "Amazement and satisfaction with myself, sir. I assume I may leave now?" "No," he said, "stay a moment; and tell me what the people in the drawing-room are doing." "Discussing the gypsy, I imagine," she offered. "Sit down!" he commanded, "Let me hear what they said about me." Jane hesitated, "I shouldn't stay long, sir; it must be close to eleven. Oh, are you aware, Mr. Rochester, that a visitor has arrived here since you departed this morning?" "A stranger!" he exclaimed, surprised, "no; who could it be? I wasn't expecting anyone; has he left?" "No," she explained, "he mentioned he had known you for a long time and felt he could take the liberty of staying here until you returned." "The devil he did!" Rochester burst out, "Did he give his name?" "His name is Mason, sir," Jane replied, "and he is from the West Indies; from Spanish Town, in Jamaica, I believe." Mr. Rochester was standing near her, and he had taken her hand, as if to guide her to a chair.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"That’s quite an odd notion to have, sir!"
"But I pulled it off well, didn’t I? Don’t you agree?"
"You must have fooled the ladies successfully."
"But not you?"
"You didn’t really pretend to be a gypsy when you spoke to me."
"Then what was I pretending to be? Myself?"
"No, you took on some strange role. Honestly, I think you were just trying to get a reaction out of me, to make me talk nonsense since you were speaking nonsense yourself. That’s hardly fair."
"Will you forgive me, Jane?"
"I’m not sure yet. I need to think about it first. If I decide I didn’t make too much of a fool of myself, then I’ll try to forgive you. But it still wasn’t right."
"But you were perfectly proper and sensible."
I thought about it and, overall, I agreed—I hadn’t behaved badly. That was reassuring, especially since I had suspected something was off from the start. I knew fortune-tellers didn’t talk like that, and I recognized the fake voice and the efforts to hide her face. events.title: Rochester's Profound Distress and Jane's Supportive Role
detailed_summary: Upon hearing Jane's words about Mr. Mason and the West Indies, Mr. Rochester's smile vanishes, he grips her wrist tightly, and his complexion turns deathly pale as he repeats the name and place in a robotic tone.
He confesses to Jane that he has suffered a significant blow and stumbles, prompting Jane to offer her support.
He accepts, sits down, and has Jane sit beside him, chafing her hand while looking at her with a deeply troubled expression.
Mr. Rochester expresses a longing to escape to a secluded island with only Jane, free from his troubles and painful memories.
Jane earnestly offers her complete devotion and service, and he promises to seek her help if needed.
He then requests that Jane fetch him a glass of wine from the dining room, where the guests are having supper, and to observe Mr. Mason's presence and demeanor.
Jane complies, finding the party lively and cheerful. Mr. Mason is seen conversing merrily. She notes Miss Ingram's disapproving glance as she pours the wine.
Returning to the library, Jane finds Mr. Rochester has regained some composure.
He takes the wine from her, makes a toast to her as his 'ministrant spirit,' and drinks it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I spoke he gave my wrist a convulsive grip; the smile on his lips froze: apparently a spasm caught his breath.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He swallowed the contents and returned it to me.

events.text_segment:
As I spoke he gave my wrist a convulsive grip; the smile on his lips froze: apparently a spasm caught his breath.
“Mason!—the West Indies!” he said, in the tone one might fancy a speaking automaton to enounce its single words; “Mason!—the West Indies!” he reiterated; and he went over the syllables three times, growing, in the intervals of speaking, whiter than ashes: he hardly seemed to know what he was doing.
“Do you feel ill, sir?” I inquired.
“Jane, I’ve got a blow; I’ve got a blow, Jane!” He staggered.
“Oh, lean on me, sir.”
“Jane, you offered me your shoulder once before; let me have it now.”
“Yes, sir, yes; and my arm.”
He sat down, and made me sit beside him. Holding my hand in both his own, he chafed it; gazing on me, at the same time, with the most troubled and dreary look.
“My little friend!” said he, “I wish I were in a quiet island with only you; and trouble, and danger, and hideous recollections removed from me.”
“Can I help you, sir?—I’d give my life to serve you.”
“Jane, if aid is wanted, I’ll seek it at your hands; I promise you that.”
“Thank you, sir. Tell me what to do,—I’ll try, at least, to do it.”
“Fetch me now, Jane, a glass of wine from the dining-room: they will be at supper there; and tell me if Mason is with them, and what he is doing.”
I went. I found all the party in the dining-room at supper, as Mr. Rochester had said; they were not seated at table,—the supper was arranged on the sideboard; each had taken what he chose, and they stood about here and there in groups, their plates and glasses in their hands. Every one seemed in high glee; laughter and conversation were general and animated. Mr. Mason stood near the fire, talking to Colonel and Mrs. Dent, and appeared as merry as any of them. I filled a wine-glass (I saw Miss Ingram watch me frowningly as I did so: she thought I was taking a liberty, I daresay), and I returned to the library.
Mr. Rochester’s extreme pallor had disappeared, and he looked once more firm and stern. He took the glass from my hand.
“Here is to your health, ministrant spirit!” he said. He swallowed the contents and returned it to me.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: When I spoke, he gripped my wrist tightly in a sudden spasm; his smile disappeared, and it seemed as though he couldn't catch his breath. He repeated the words "Mason!—the West Indies!" three times in a voice that sounded mechanical, like a speaking automaton, becoming visibly paler, almost ash-white, between each repetition. He appeared confused and hardly aware of his actions. I asked if he felt unwell. "Jane," he exclaimed, "I've been hit; I've been struck, Jane!" He swayed unsteadily. "Oh, please lean on me, sir." "Jane, you offered me your support once before; I need it now." "Yes, sir, absolutely; and my arm too." He sat down and motioned for me to sit beside him. He held my hand in both of his, rubbing it, while looking at me with a deeply troubled and sorrowful expression. "My dear friend," he said, "I wish I were on a peaceful island with just you, far away from any problems, dangers, or unpleasant memories." "Can I help you, sir? I would do anything to serve you." "Jane, if I require assistance, I will ask you for it; I promise you that." "Thank you, sir. Just tell me what to do—I will certainly attempt it." "Now, Jane, please fetch me a glass of wine from the dining room. They will be having supper in there. Also, check if Mason is among them and what he is doing." I went. I found everyone in the dining room at supper, just as Mr. Rochester had mentioned. They weren't seated at the table; the meal was served on the sideboard, and people had helped themselves, standing around in groups holding their plates and glasses. Everyone seemed very cheerful, with lively general conversation and laughter. Mr. Mason was near the fireplace, talking to Colonel and Mrs. Dent, appearing as happy as the others. I poured a glass of wine (I noticed Miss Ingram watching me with a frown as I did this, probably thinking I was being presumptuous), and I returned to the library. Mr. Rochester was no longer extremely pale; he looked firm and serious again. He took the glass from my hand. "To your health, my helpful spirit!" he said. He quickly drank the contents and handed the glass back to me.

As I spoke, he gripped my wrist tightly; his smile vanished, and he almost seemed unable to breathe. 

"Mason!—the West Indies!" he exclaimed, his voice mechanical, repeating the names several times, getting paler each time he paused. He appeared disoriented.

"Are you feeling unwell, sir?" I asked.

"Jane, I’ve just had a shock; a real shock!" He swayed unsteadily.

"Let me help you, sir."

"You once offered me your shoulder, Jane; may I lean on it now?"

"Of course, sir, and you may take my arm, too."

He sat down and asked me to sit next to him, taking my hand in both of his and rubbing it for comfort, while looking at me with a troubled, sorrowful expression.

"My dear friend," he said, "I wish I were on a peaceful island with only you for company, and all my worries and fears far away."

"Can I help you, sir? I’d do anything for you," I said.

"If I need help, Jane, I promise you will be the one I ask."

"Thank you, sir. Just tell me what to do, and I will try my best."

"For now, Jane, bring me a glass of wine from the dining room. Check if Mason is with the others and see what he’s doing."

I went and found everyone in the dining room, enjoying supper as Mr. Rochester had described. They weren’t sitting at the table, but helping themselves from the sideboard, mingling in cheerful groups with plates and glasses. Laughter and lively conversation filled the room. Mr. Mason was by the fire, happily talking to Colonel and Mrs. Dent. I poured a glass of wine (noticing Miss Ingram frowning at me, likely thinking I was overstepping), and returned to the library.

Mr. Rochester’s color had returned, and he looked resolute once again. He took the wine from me.

"To your health, kind spirit!" he said before drinking and handing the glass back.

events.title: Testing Loyalty, Summoning Mason, and an Uneasy Resolution
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester asks Jane about the atmosphere in the dining room, specifically if the guests, including Mason, appear serious or aware of anything unusual.
Jane reassures him that everyone is merry and lighthearted.
Mr. Rochester then presents Jane with hypothetical scenarios of social ostracism, questioning how she would react if his guests were to scorn him.
Jane firmly states her loyalty, asserting she would defend him, stay by his side to comfort him, and disregard any social condemnation.

Pleased with her responses, Mr. Rochester instructs Jane to go to Mr. Mason, quietly inform him of Rochester's return and request to see him, and then escort Mason to the library before leaving them alone.
Jane carries out his command, enduring the curious stares of the guests as she delivers the message to Mason and leads him to the library.
After ushering Mason in, Jane retreats upstairs.

Later that night, from her bed, Jane hears the visitors retiring to their rooms and distinguishes Mr. Rochester's voice cheerfully directing Mason to his room, a sound that calms her anxieties and allows her to sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What are they doing, Jane?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I was soon asleep.

events.text_segment:
“What are they doing, Jane?”
“Laughing and talking, sir.”
“They don’t look grave and mysterious, as if they had heard something strange?”
“Not at all: they are full of jests and gaiety.”
“And Mason?”
“He was laughing too.”
“If all these people came in a body and spat at me, what would you do, Jane?”
“Turn them out of the room, sir, if I could.”
He half smiled. “But if I were to go to them, and they only looked at me coldly, and whispered sneeringly amongst each other, and then dropped off and left me one by one, what then? Would you go with them?”
“I rather think not, sir: I should have more pleasure in staying with you.”
“To comfort me?”
“Yes, sir, to comfort you, as well as I could.”
“And if they laid you under a ban for adhering to me?”
“I, probably, should know nothing about their ban; and if I did, I should care nothing about it.”
“Then, you could dare censure for my sake?”
“I could dare it for the sake of any friend who deserved my adherence; as you, I am sure, do.”
“Go back now into the room; step quietly up to Mason, and whisper in his ear that Mr. Rochester is come and wishes to see him: show him in here and then leave me.”
“Yes, sir.”
I did his behest. The company all stared at me as I passed straight among them. I sought Mr. Mason, delivered the message, and preceded him from the room: I ushered him into the library, and then I went upstairs.
At a late hour, after I had been in bed some time, I heard the visitors repair to their chambers: I distinguished Mr. Rochester’s voice, and heard him say, “This way, Mason; this is your room.”
He spoke cheerfully: the gay tones set my heart at ease. I was soon asleep.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. Rochester inquired, "What are they occupied with, Jane?" I replied, "They are laughing and conversing, sir." He asked, "Do they not appear serious and mysterious, as if they've heard something strange?" I confirmed, "Not at all; they are full of jokes and cheerfulness." He then asked about Mr. Mason, to which I responded, "He was also laughing." Mr. Rochester posed a hypothetical question: "If all these individuals were to come together and express contempt towards me, what would your reaction be, Jane?" I stated, "I would try to remove them from the room, sir, if possible." He offered a slight smile. "But if I were to approach them, and they simply regarded me with coldness, whispered derisively among themselves, and then left me one by one, what then? Would you accompany them?" I answered, "I believe not, sir; I would find more satisfaction in remaining with you." He questioned, "To provide me comfort?" "Yes, sir," I affirmed, "to comfort you to the best of my ability." "And if they were to ostracize you for supporting me?" he pressed. I replied, "I likely wouldn't know about their ban; and if I did, I would be indifferent to it." "So," he concluded, "you would dare face disapproval for my sake?" "I would dare it," I said, "for any friend deserving of my loyalty; as I am certain you are." He then instructed, "Now, return to the room; quietly approach Mr. Mason and whisper in his ear that Mr. Rochester is here and wishes to see him. Escort him here and then depart." "Yes, sir," I replied. I followed his command. The entire company stared at me as I walked directly through their midst. I found Mr. Mason, delivered the message, and walked ahead of him out of the room. I guided him into the library and then went upstairs. Much later, after I had been in bed for some time, I heard the visitors retire to their chambers. I recognized Mr. Rochester's voice, hearing him say, "This way, Mason; this is your room." He sounded cheerful; his light tone calmed my heart. I soon fell asleep.

“No, not at all—they’re joking and cheerful.”

“He was laughing as well.”
