“So you would risk criticism for my sake?”
“I would risk it for any friend I felt deserved my loyalty, as you do, sir.”
“Now, go back into the room, go quietly to Mason, and whisper to him that Mr. Rochester is here and wants to see him. Bring him here and then leave me.”
“Yes, sir.”
I did as he asked. Everyone watched me as I passed them. I found Mr. Mason, gave him the message, and led him out of the room. I brought him into the library and then went upstairs.
Later that night, after I had gone to bed, I heard the guests returning to their rooms. I recognized Mr. Rochester’s voice saying, “This way, Mason; here’s your room.”
He sounded happy, and his cheerful tone reassured me, so I quickly fell asleep.

events.title: A Terrifying Midnight Disturbance and Rochester's Composure
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jane Eyre, is awakened by the full moon shining into her room.
As she reaches to draw the curtain, a horrifying, shrill cry echoes through Thornfield Hall, seemingly from the third storey.
Jane hears sounds of a struggle and a muffled voice crying for help, specifically calling for Rochester.
A chamber door opens, someone runs along the gallery, another step is heard, something falls, and then silence ensues.
Jane quickly dresses and emerges from her room to find the gallery filled with alarmed guests, all wondering about the source of the noise.
Colonel Dent notes Mr. Rochester's absence from his room.
Mr. Rochester appears with a candle, having come from the upper storey, and is immediately surrounded by anxious guests, including Miss Ingram.
He dismisses the incident as a servant having a nightmare, attributing it to an excitable nature and a frightening dream.
Rochester firmly urges everyone back to their rooms, using a mix of reassurance and command to restore order.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had forgotten to draw my curtain, which I usually did, and also to let down my window-blind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And so, by dint of alternate coaxing and commanding, he contrived to get them all once more enclosed in their separate dormitories.

events.text_segment:
I had forgotten to draw my curtain, which I usually did, and also to let down my window-blind. The consequence was, that when the moon, which was full and bright (for the night was fine), came in her course to that space in the sky opposite my casement, and looked in at me through the unveiled panes, her glorious gaze roused me. Awaking in the dead of night, I opened my eyes on her disk—silver-white and crystal clear. It was beautiful, but too solemn: I half rose, and stretched my arm to draw the curtain.
Good God! What a cry!
The night—its silence—its rest, was rent in twain by a savage, a sharp, a shrilly sound that ran from end to end of Thornfield Hall.
My pulse stopped: my heart stood still; my stretched arm was paralysed. The cry died, and was not renewed. Indeed, whatever being uttered that fearful shriek could not soon repeat it: not the widest-winged condor on the Andes could, twice in succession, send out such a yell from the cloud shrouding his eyrie. The thing delivering such utterance must rest ere it could repeat the effort.
It came out of the third storey; for it passed overhead. And overhead—yes, in the room just above my chamber-ceiling—I now heard a struggle: a deadly one it seemed from the noise; and a half-smothered voice shouted—
“Help! help! help!” three times rapidly.
“Will no one come?” it cried; and then, while the staggering and stamping went on wildly, I distinguished through plank and plaster:—
“Rochester! Rochester! for God’s sake, come!”
A chamber-door opened: some one ran, or rushed, along the gallery. Another step stamped on the flooring above and something fell; and there was silence.
I had put on some clothes, though horror shook all my limbs; I issued from my apartment. The sleepers were all aroused: ejaculations, terrified murmurs sounded in every room; door after door unclosed; one looked out and another looked out; the gallery filled. Gentlemen and ladies alike had quitted their beds; and “Oh! what is it?”—“Who is hurt?”—“What has happened?”—“Fetch a light!”—“Is it fire?”—“Are there robbers?”—“Where shall we run?” was demanded confusedly on all hands. But for the moonlight they would have been in complete darkness. They ran to and fro; they crowded together: some sobbed, some stumbled: the confusion was inextricable.
“Where the devil is Rochester?” cried Colonel Dent. “I cannot find him in his bed.”
“Here! here!” was shouted in return. “Be composed, all of you: I’m coming.”
And the door at the end of the gallery opened, and Mr. Rochester advanced with a candle: he had just descended from the upper storey. One of the ladies ran to him directly; she seized his arm: it was Miss Ingram.
“What awful event has taken place?” said she. “Speak! let us know the worst at once!”
“But don’t pull me down or strangle me,” he replied: for the Misses Eshton were clinging about him now; and the two dowagers, in vast white wrappers, were bearing down on him like ships in full sail.
“All’s right!—all’s right!” he cried. “It’s a mere rehearsal of Much Ado about Nothing. Ladies, keep off, or I shall wax dangerous.”
And dangerous he looked: his black eyes darted sparks. Calming himself by an effort, he added—
“A servant has had the nightmare; that is all. She’s an excitable, nervous person: she construed her dream into an apparition, or something of that sort, no doubt; and has taken a fit with fright. Now, then, I must see you all back into your rooms; for, till the house is settled, she cannot be looked after. Gentlemen, have the goodness to set the ladies the example. Miss Ingram, I am sure you will not fail in evincing superiority to idle terrors. Amy and Louisa, return to your nests like a pair of doves, as you are. Mesdames” (to the dowagers), “you will take cold to a dead certainty, if you stay in this chill gallery any longer.”
And so, by dint of alternate coaxing and commanding, he contrived to get them all once more enclosed in their separate dormitories.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I had forgotten to pull my curtains and window-blind closed, which I usually did. As a result, when the full, bright moon (because the night was clear) reached the part of the sky opposite my window and shone through the uncovered glass, its powerful light woke me up. Waking up in the middle of the night, I saw its perfectly clear, silvery disk. It was beautiful but unsettlingly serious. I sat up slightly and reached out my arm to close the curtain. Suddenly, I heard an absolutely horrifying scream! The peace and quiet of the night was violently broken by a wild, piercing shriek that echoed throughout Thornfield Hall. My heart stopped, my body froze; my extended arm couldn't move. The scream faded and wasn't repeated. Indeed, whatever creature made that terrifying sound couldn't possibly do it again quickly; not even the largest condor on the Andes could produce such a shout twice in a row from its nest hidden in the clouds. Whatever made that noise would need to rest before attempting it again. It came from the third floor, directly above me. And yes, from the room right above mine, I now heard what sounded like a desperate struggle and someone frantically shouting for help three times in quick succession. Then, while the sounds of stumbling and stomping continued chaotically through the floor and ceiling, I could make out the voice calling, "Rochester! Rochester! For the love of God, come!" A bedroom door opened, and someone ran or rushed along the corridor. Another set of footsteps pounded on the floor above, then something fell, and silence returned. Although fear made my limbs tremble, I managed to get dressed and leave my room. Everyone else was awake; startled exclamations and fearful whispers came from every room; doors opened one after another, and people peered out. The gallery filled with residents who had left their beds. Gentlemen and ladies alike were asking confusedly, "Oh! What is it?" "Who's hurt?" "What's happened?" "Bring a light!" "Is it fire?" "Are there robbers?" "Where should we go?" Without the moonlight, they would have been in total darkness. They ran back and forth, huddled together; some cried, some stumbled, the chaos was complete. "Where in the world is Rochester?" shouted Colonel Dent. "He's not in his bed." "Here! Here!" came the reply. "Everyone, calm down; I'm coming." And Mr. Rochester appeared at the end of the gallery with a candle, having just come down from the upper floor. One of the ladies immediately rushed to him and grabbed his arm; it was Miss Ingram. "What dreadful event has occurred?" she asked. "Speak! Let us know the worst immediately!" "But don't pull me over or choke me," he replied, as the Misses Eshton were now also clinging to him, and the two older ladies, wrapped in large white dressing gowns, were approaching him like ships under full sail. "Everything's fine! Everything's fine!" he announced. "It's just a practice run of a dramatic scene. Ladies, keep back, or I might get angry." He looked angry indeed, with sparks in his dark eyes. Making an effort to calm himself, he added, "A servant had a nightmare; that's all. She's a sensitive, nervous person; she undoubtedly mistook her dream for a ghost or something similar and fainted from fright. Now, I need to see you all back into your rooms, because I can't attend to her until the house is settled. Gentlemen, please set an example for the ladies. Miss Ingram, I'm sure you will show yourself superior to pointless fears. Amy and Louisa, go back to your rooms like the little doves you are. Mesdames" (to the older ladies), "you will definitely catch a severe cold if you stay in this chilly corridor any longer." And so, by using a combination of gentle persuasion and firm commands, he successfully got them all back into their individual bedrooms.

I had forgotten to close my curtain and lower my window-blind as I usually did, so when the full, bright moon reached the spot directly opposite my window, its clear, shining light woke me. I found myself staring at the dazzling whiteness of the moon, which was lovely but struck me as rather grave. As I sat up and reached for the curtain, a piercing cry shattered the stillness and comfort of the night throughout Thornfield Hall. I was so terrified I felt frozen, unable to move, as the scream faded away. It was so intense, I doubted if any creature could make such a noise twice in a row; certainly, whoever had screamed needed time to recover. The sound had come from the third floor, passing above me. I then heard what sounded like a fierce struggle in the room overhead, followed by a muffled voice frantically yelling for help three times and then, desperately, calling, "Rochester! For God’s sake, come!" Suddenly a door above opened, hurried footsteps resounded, something heavy fell, and all went quiet.

Still trembling with fear, I hastily put on some clothes and left my room. The other guests had also been woken: everywhere, doors opened and anxious people gathered in confusion, muttering, "What has happened? Who is hurt? Is it a fire? Are there thieves?" Amid the commotion, since there were no lights apart from the moon, everyone stumbled about in panic. Colonel Dent yelled, anxious because he couldn't find Mr. Rochester, to which a voice replied that he was coming. Mr. Rochester entered, holding a candle and having just come from upstairs. Miss Ingram hurried to his side, demanding to know what terrible event had happened, but he joked that if everyone clung to him, he’d be strangled or pulled down, for several ladies were surrounding him.

Trying to calm the crowd, Rochester explained that it was just a servant with a nightmare, and that her fears had gotten the best of her. He told everyone to return to their rooms, assuring them there was no real danger. With gentle persuasion and firm instructions, he managed to shepherd everyone back to where they belonged.

events.title: Jane's Vigil and Rochester's Summons
detailed_summary: Jane retreats to her room unnoticed, but does not go back to bed.
She dresses carefully, convinced by the sounds she heard that Rochester's explanation was a fabrication to calm his guests.
Jane anticipates that some further event must follow the cry and struggle she witnessed.
She waits by her window for a long time, observing the silent grounds as stillness returns to Thornfield Hall.
As the moon sets and she feels the cold, Jane decides to lie down on her bed fully dressed.
While stooping to remove her shoes, she hears a quiet tap at her door.
Jane asks if she is needed, and Mr. Rochester's voice confirms it, asking if she is up and dressed.
She affirms, and he quietly tells her to come out.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I did not wait to be ordered back to mine, but retreated unnoticed, as unnoticed I had left it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Rochester stood in the gallery holding a light.

events.text_segment:
I did not wait to be ordered back to mine, but retreated unnoticed, as unnoticed I had left it.
Not, however, to go to bed: on the contrary, I began and dressed myself carefully. The sounds I had heard after the scream, and the words that had been uttered, had probably been heard only by me; for they had proceeded from the room above mine: but they assured me that it was not a servant’s dream which had thus struck horror through the house; and that the explanation Mr. Rochester had given was merely an invention framed to pacify his guests. I dressed, then, to be ready for emergencies. When dressed, I sat a long time by the window looking out over the silent grounds and silvered fields and waiting for I knew not what. It seemed to me that some event must follow the strange cry, struggle, and call.
No: stillness returned: each murmur and movement ceased gradually, and in about an hour Thornfield Hall was again as hushed as a desert. It seemed that sleep and night had resumed their empire. Meantime the moon declined: she was about to set. Not liking to sit in the cold and darkness, I thought I would lie down on my bed, dressed as I was. I left the window, and moved with little noise across the carpet; as I stooped to take off my shoes, a cautious hand tapped low at the door.
“Am I wanted?” I asked.
“Are you up?” asked the voice I expected to hear, viz., my master’s.
“Yes, sir.”
“And dressed?”
“Yes.”
“Come out, then, quietly.”
I obeyed. Mr. Rochester stood in the gallery holding a light.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Instead of waiting for instructions to return to my room, I withdrew without being noticed, just as I had arrived. However, I did not go to bed; on the contrary, I began to dress myself carefully. I believed the sounds and words I heard after the scream were probably only heard by me, as they came from the room directly above mine. Nevertheless, they convinced me it wasn't a servant's dream that had caused such terror throughout the house, and that Mr. Rochester's explanation was simply a fabricated story to reassure his guests. So, I got dressed to be prepared for any potential crisis. After dressing, I sat by the window for a long time, gazing out over the silent grounds and moonlit fields, waiting for something, though I didn't know what. It seemed impossible that the strange cry, struggle, and call would not be followed by some event. But stillness returned; every sound and movement gradually faded away, and in about an hour, Thornfield Hall was once more as silent as a desert. It was as if sleep and night had reasserted their control. In the meantime, the moon descended, about to set. Not wishing to remain sitting in the cold darkness, I decided to lie down on my bed, still dressed. I left the window and moved softly across the carpet; as I stooped to remove my shoes, a discreet hand tapped softly at the door. "Is someone requesting me?" I inquired. "Are you awake?" asked the voice I anticipated, my master's. "Yes, I am, sir." "And are you dressed?" "Yes." "Then come out, quietly." I did as he asked. Mr. Rochester was standing in the gallery with a light.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I didn't wait for anyone to tell me to return to my room; I slipped away quietly, just as I had left unnoticed before. I didn't go straight to bed, though—quite the opposite. I dressed myself with care, feeling sure that the noises and voices I'd heard after that terrifying scream were real and hadn’t been noticed by anyone else, since they’d come from the room above me. That made me realize the terror in the house wasn't just the result of a servant's nightmare, and Mr. Rochester's explanation was only meant to reassure the guests. I got ready so I'd be prepared if anything else happened. Once I was dressed, I sat beside the window for a long while, looking out at the quiet grounds and moonlit fields, not sure what I expected but feeling certain something must follow all the commotion. 

But it grew silent again; all sounds faded, and within about an hour, Thornfield Hall was as quiet as ever, as if everyone was sleeping and the night was peaceful once more. The moon was setting, and rather than stay in the cold and dark, I decided to lie down on my bed fully clothed. As I left the window and quietly made my way across the room to take off my shoes, I heard a careful tap on the door. 

“Am I needed?” I asked. 

“Are you awake?” came the voice I’d expected—my master’s. 

“Yes, sir.” 

“And are you dressed?” 

“Yes.” 

“Then come out quietly.” 

I did as he said and found Mr. Rochester waiting for me in the hallway with a light.

events.title: Ascent to the Third Floor and the Secret Within
detailed_summary: Rochester tells Jane he needs her and instructs her to follow him quietly.
She follows him up the gallery and stairs to the dark corridor of the third storey.
He whispers, asking if she has a sponge and volatile salts in her room, and sends her to fetch them.
Jane retrieves the items and returns to find Rochester waiting with a key.
He asks if she gets sick at the sight of blood, and she believes she will not, though untested.
Rochester takes her hand, commenting on its warmth and steadiness, then unlocks a small black door.
Jane recognizes the room from her initial tour of the house; a tapestry is looped up, revealing a previously hidden door.
This inner door is open, light shines from within, and Jane hears a snarling, snatching sound, like a quarreling dog.
Rochester enters the inner apartment, and his entrance is met with a shout of laughter that ends in Grace Poole's distinctive cackle, confirming her presence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I want you,” he said: “come this way: take your time, and make no noise.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A shout of laughter greeted his entrance; noisy at first, and terminating in Grace Poole’s own goblin ha! ha! She then was there.

events.text_segment:
“I want you,” he said: “come this way: take your time, and make no noise.”
My slippers were thin: I could walk the matted floor as softly as a cat. He glided up the gallery and up the stairs, and stopped in the dark, low corridor of the fateful third storey: I had followed and stood at his side.
“Have you a sponge in your room?” he asked in a whisper.
“Yes, sir.”
“Have you any salts—volatile salts?”
“Yes.”
“Go back and fetch both.”
I returned, sought the sponge on the washstand, the salts in my drawer, and once more retraced my steps. He still waited; he held a key in his hand: approaching one of the small, black doors, he put it in the lock; he paused, and addressed me again.
“You don’t turn sick at the sight of blood?”
“I think I shall not: I have never been tried yet.”
I felt a thrill while I answered him; but no coldness, and no faintness.
“Just give me your hand,” he said: “it will not do to risk a fainting fit.”
I put my fingers into his. “Warm and steady,” was his remark: he turned the key and opened the door.
I saw a room I remembered to have seen before, the day Mrs. Fairfax showed me over the house: it was hung with tapestry; but the tapestry was now looped up in one part, and there was a door apparent, which had then been concealed. This door was open; a light shone out of the room within: I heard thence a snarling, snatching sound, almost like a dog quarrelling. Mr. Rochester, putting down his candle, said to me, “Wait a minute,” and he went forward to the inner apartment. A shout of laughter greeted his entrance; noisy at first, and terminating in Grace Poole’s own goblin ha! ha! She then was there.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: He instructed me, saying, “I need you; come this way, move quietly and take your time.” My thin slippers allowed me to step as softly as a cat on the matted floor. He moved silently up the gallery and the stairs, stopping in the dimly lit, low corridor of the significant third floor. I had followed close behind and stood beside him. He whispered, asking, “Do you have a sponge in your room?” “Yes, sir,” I replied. “Do you possess any smelling salts—volatile salts?” “Yes,” I confirmed. “Go back and retrieve both,” he directed. I returned, found the sponge on the washstand and the salts in my drawer, and came back again. He was still waiting, holding a key. Approaching one of the small, black doors, he inserted the key into the lock. He paused before speaking to me again. “Are you able to handle the sight of blood without feeling ill?” I responded, feeling a tremor but no sensation of coldness or weakness, “I believe so; I’ve never been tested before.” “Just give me your hand,” he requested, “We shouldn’t risk you fainting.” I placed my fingers in his. He commented, “Warm and steady,” before turning the key and opening the door. I saw a room I recalled from when Mrs. Fairfax showed me around the house; it was covered in tapestry. However, the tapestry was now pulled back in one area, revealing a door that had previously been hidden. This door was open, and light streamed from the room within. From there, I heard a growling, snapping noise, almost like dogs fighting. Mr. Rochester placed his candle down and told me, “Wait a minute,” then proceeded into the inner apartment. His entrance was met with a burst of laughter, initially loud and concluding with Grace Poole’s distinctive, ghoulish ‘ha! ha!’ So, it was her who was present.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He said to me, "I want you. Come this way, but go slowly and quietly." My slippers were so thin that I could move quietly across the carpeted floor, making hardly a sound. He moved smoothly down the hall, then up the stairs, and stopped in a low, dark hallway on the third floor—the one with a troubling reputation. I followed and stood next to him. Whispering, he asked, "Do you have a sponge in your room?" I replied that I did. "How about volatile salts?" he continued. I confirmed I had those too. He told me to go back and get them, so I did—retrieving the sponge from the washstand and the salts from a drawer—then returned to him. He was waiting, a key in hand, and as we approached one of the small, black doors, he inserted the key but paused to ask, "You're not going to faint at the sight of blood?" I answered that I didn't think I would, since I'd never been tested. I felt a shiver as I replied, but wasn't cold or weak. He said, "Give me your hand; I don't want you passing out." I placed my hand in his, and he observed that it was warm and steady. Then he unlocked and opened the door.

Inside, I recognized a room Mrs. Fairfax had previously shown me; it was lined with tapestry, though some now hung up to reveal a hidden door. That door was now open, with light coming from within. I heard a growling, snapping noise, like angry dogs. Setting down his candle, Mr. Rochester told me to wait and walked into this inner room. Laughter erupted at his entry, loud at first, ending with Grace Poole's weird, familiar laugh—she was indeed inside.

events.text_segment:
He made some sort of arrangement without speaking, though I heard a low voice address him: he came out and closed the door behind him.
“Here, Jane!” he said; and I walked round to the other side of a large bed, which with its drawn curtains concealed a considerable portion of the chamber. An easy-chair was near the bed-head: a man sat in it, dressed with the exception of his coat; he was still; his head leant back; his eyes were closed. Mr. Rochester held the candle over him; I recognised in his pale and seemingly lifeless face—the stranger, Mason: I saw too that his linen on one side, and one arm, was almost soaked in blood.
“Hold the candle,” said Mr. Rochester, and I took it: he fetched a basin of water from the washstand: “Hold that,” said he. I obeyed. He took the sponge, dipped it in, and moistened the corpse-like face; he asked for my smelling-bottle, and applied it to the nostrils. Mr. Mason shortly unclosed his eyes; he groaned. Mr. Rochester opened the shirt of the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged: he sponged away blood, trickling fast down.
“Is there immediate danger?” murmured Mr. Mason.
“Pooh! No—a mere scratch. Don’t be so overcome, man: bear up! I’ll fetch a surgeon for you now, myself: you’ll be able to be removed by morning, I hope. Jane,” he continued.
“Sir?”
“I shall have to leave you in this room with this gentleman, for an hour, or perhaps two hours: you will sponge the blood as I do when it returns: if he feels faint, you will put the glass of water on that stand to his lips, and your salts to his nose. You will not speak to him on any pretext—and—Richard, it will be at the peril of your life if you speak to her: open your lips—agitate yourself—and I’ll not answer for the consequences.”
Again the poor man groaned; he looked as if he dared not move; fear, either of death or of something else, appeared almost to paralyse him. Mr. Rochester put the now bloody sponge into my hand, and I proceeded to use it as he had done. He watched me a second, then saying, “Remember!—No conversation,” he left the room. I experienced a strange feeling as the key grated in the lock, and the sound of his retreating step ceased to be heard.

events.title: Jane's Isolated Vigil and Ominous Reflections
detailed_summary: Jane finds herself locked in a mysterious third-storey room, attending to a bloody spectacle, with the thought of a 'murderess,' Grace Poole, nearby causing her to shudder.
She resolves to maintain her post, watching Mason's ghastly face and continually wiping away blood.

The candlelight wanes, and shadows darken the room, playing on the antique tapestry and a cabinet carved with the twelve apostles and a crucifix, which seem to come alive in the flickering light, suggesting figures like Luke, St. John, and a menacing Judas.
Jane listens for any movement from Grace Poole's room, hearing only three distinct sounds at long intervals: a creaking step, a renewed snarling noise, and a deep human groan.
Her thoughts turn to the nature of the crime and mystery haunting Thornfield, questioning what creature, masked as an ordinary woman, could produce such demonic and predatory sounds.
She wonders how Mason became entangled in this horror, why he was attacked, and why he was in that part of the house.
Jane reflects on Mason's submissiveness to Rochester's enforced concealment and Rochester's own pattern of smothering violent incidents in secrecy.
She recalls Rochester's extreme distress upon Mason's arrival, contrasting it with his current ability to control Mason easily.
Jane remembers Rochester's earlier fear and agitation, realizing the gravity of the situation that could so deeply affect him.
She anxiously awaits Rochester's return as Mason's condition seems to worsen, her efforts to revive him appearing futile.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here then I was in the third storey, fastened into one of its mystic cells; night around me; a pale and bloody spectacle under my eyes and hands; a murderess hardly separated from me by a single door: yes—that was appalling—the rest I could bear; but I shuddered at the thought of Grace Poole bursting out upon me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It could not have lasted more than two hours: many a week has seemed shorter.

events.text_segment:
Here then I was in the third storey, fastened into one of its mystic cells; night around me; a pale and bloody spectacle under my eyes and hands; a murderess hardly separated from me by a single door: yes—that was appalling—the rest I could bear; but I shuddered at the thought of Grace Poole bursting out upon me.
I must keep to my post, however. I must watch this ghastly countenance—these blue, still lips forbidden to unclose—these eyes now shut, now opening, now wandering through the room, now fixing on me, and ever glazed with the dulness of horror. I must dip my hand again and again in the basin of blood and water, and wipe away the trickling gore. I must see the light of the unsnuffed candle wane on my employment; the shadows darken on the wrought, antique tapestry round me, and grow black under the hangings of the vast old bed, and quiver strangely over the doors of a great cabinet opposite—whose front, divided into twelve panels, bore, in grim design, the heads of the twelve apostles, each enclosed in its separate panel as in a frame; while above them at the top rose an ebon crucifix and a dying Christ.
According as the shifting obscurity and flickering gleam hovered here or glanced there, it was now the bearded physician, Luke, that bent his brow; now St. John’s long hair that waved; and anon the devilish face of Judas, that grew out of the panel, and seemed gathering life and threatening a revelation of the arch-traitor—of Satan himself—in his subordinate’s form.
Amidst all this, I had to listen as well as watch: to listen for the movements of the wild beast or the fiend in yonder side den. But since Mr. Rochester’s visit it seemed spellbound: all the night I heard but three sounds at three long intervals,—a step creak, a momentary renewal of the snarling, canine noise, and a deep human groan.
Then my own thoughts worried me. What crime was this, that lived incarnate in this sequestered mansion, and could neither be expelled nor subdued by the owner?—what mystery, that broke out now in fire and now in blood, at the deadest hours of night? What creature was it, that, masked in an ordinary woman’s face and shape, uttered the voice, now of a mocking demon, and anon of a carrion-seeking bird of prey?
And this man I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger—how had he become involved in the web of horror? and why had the Fury flown at him? What made him seek this quarter of the house at an untimely season, when he should have been asleep in bed? I had heard Mr. Rochester assign him an apartment below—what brought him here! And why, now, was he so tame under the violence or treachery done him? Why did he so quietly submit to the concealment Mr. Rochester enforced? Why did Mr. Rochester enforce this concealment? His guest had been outraged, his own life on a former occasion had been hideously plotted against; and both attempts he smothered in secrecy and sank in oblivion! Lastly, I saw Mr. Mason was submissive to Mr. Rochester; that the impetuous will of the latter held complete sway over the inertness of the former: the few words which had passed between them assured me of this. It was evident that in their former intercourse, the passive disposition of the one had been habitually influenced by the active energy of the other: whence then had arisen Mr. Rochester’s dismay when he heard of Mr. Mason’s arrival? Why had the mere name of this unresisting individual—whom his word now sufficed to control like a child—fallen on him, a few hours since, as a thunderbolt might fall on an oak?
Oh! I could not forget his look and his paleness when he whispered: “Jane, I have got a blow—I have got a blow, Jane.” I could not forget how the arm had trembled which he rested on my shoulder: and it was no light matter which could thus bow the resolute spirit and thrill the vigorous frame of Fairfax Rochester.
“When will he come? When will he come?” I cried inwardly, as the night lingered and lingered—as my bleeding patient drooped, moaned, sickened: and neither day nor aid arrived. I had, again and again, held the water to Mason’s white lips; again and again offered him the stimulating salts: my efforts seemed ineffectual: either bodily or mental suffering, or loss of blood, or all three combined, were fast prostrating his strength. He moaned so, and looked so weak, wild, and lost, I feared he was dying; and I might not even speak to him.
The candle, wasted at last, went out; as it expired, I perceived streaks of grey light edging the window curtains: dawn was then approaching. Presently I heard Pilot bark far below, out of his distant kennel in the courtyard: hope revived. Nor was it unwarranted: in five minutes more the grating key, the yielding lock, warned me my watch was relieved. It could not have lasted more than two hours: many a week has seemed shorter.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I was located on the third floor, confined within one of its mysterious rooms. Night surrounded me. Before my eyes and hands lay a man, pale and bleeding, a terrible sight. A woman who had committed violence was close by, with only a single door separating us. This was truly frightening – I could endure the rest, but the mere idea of Grace Poole suddenly confronting me made me tremble. However, I knew I had to stay at my post. I had to watch this dreadful face – the still, blue lips that couldn't part, the eyes that sometimes closed, sometimes opened to look around the room, sometimes settled on me, always vacant with terror. I had to repeatedly put my hand into the basin of bloody water and clean away the dripping blood. I had to see the light of the untrimmed candle grow weaker as I performed my task, the shadows deepening on the old, patterned tapestry around me, turning black under the drapes of the huge old bed, and flickering oddly over the doors of a large cabinet opposite. This cabinet's front was divided into twelve sections, each bearing a grim representation of one of the twelve apostles' heads, framed within its panel. Above them, at the top, was a black crucifix with a dying Christ figure. Depending on where the shifting darkness and flickering light fell, sometimes the bearded face of Luke seemed to frown, sometimes St. John's long hair appeared to move, and sometimes the evil face of Judas seemed to emerge from the panel, as if coming to life and hinting at the ultimate betrayer – Satan himself, appearing in the form of his follower. Amidst all this, I had to listen as well as watch, straining to hear any movements of the violent creature or demon in the adjacent room. But since Mr. Rochester's visit, she seemed quiet, as if under a spell. All night, I heard only three sounds at long intervals: a floorboard creaking, a brief recurrence of that animalistic snarling, and a deep human groan. My own thoughts also troubled me. What kind of crime was this, residing physically within this secluded house, something the owner couldn't remove or control? What secret was this, manifesting violently now as fire, now as blood, in the deepest hours of the night? What sort of being was it, appearing as a normal woman, whose voice could sound like a mocking devil one moment and a scavenging bird the next? And this man I was attending to – this ordinary, calm visitor – how had he become entangled in this horrifying situation? Why had the violent woman attacked him? What reason brought him to this part of the house at such an unusual hour, when he should have been asleep in the room Mr. Rochester had given him downstairs? And why, now, was he so passive after the attack or betrayal he had suffered? Why did he so calmly accept the secrecy Mr. Rochester insisted upon? Why did Mr. Rochester demand this secrecy? His guest had been brutally assaulted, and Rochester's own life had been previously threatened in a dreadful plot; yet, he buried both incidents in secrecy and tried to make them forgotten! Lastly, I observed that Mr. Mason was submissive to Mr. Rochester; the latter's strong will completely controlled the former's passive nature. The few words they exchanged confirmed this. It was clear that in their past interactions, Mason's yielding disposition had always been influenced by Rochester's forceful energy. So, then, why had Mr. Rochester shown such alarm when he heard of Mr. Mason's arrival? Why had the mere name of this compliant person – whom Rochester could now command like a child – affected him, just hours ago, as if lightning had struck a tree? Oh! I couldn't forget his appearance and paleness when he whispered, “Jane, I've been hit—I've been hit, Jane.” I couldn't forget the tremor in the arm he rested on my shoulder. It must have been something serious to so affect the determined spirit and vigorous body of Fairfax Rochester. “When will he come? When will help arrive?” I thought desperately, as the night seemed endless, and my injured patient weakened, moaned, and grew sicker. Neither daylight nor assistance came. Again and again, I held water to Mason's pale lips; again and again, I offered him the stimulating salts. My efforts seemed useless. It appeared that physical pain, emotional distress, blood loss, or all three combined, were rapidly exhausting his strength. He moaned constantly and looked so weak, agitated, and lost that I feared he was dying, yet I was not permitted to speak to him. Finally, the candle burned down and went out. As it died, I saw faint lines of grey light along the window curtains, indicating dawn was approaching. Soon after, I heard Pilot barking far below from his kennel in the courtyard; hope returned. And it was well-founded. Within five more minutes, the sound of the key scraping and the lock turning told me my watch was over. It could not have lasted more than two hours, yet many a week has felt shorter than that period.

Meanwhile, disturbing thoughts filled my mind. What crime was embodied here in this isolated mansion—one the owner could neither drive out nor suppress? What mystery flared up at night in fire and blood? What creature, appearing as a normal woman, had the voice sometimes of a mocking demon, sometimes of a scavenger bird? And this quiet, ordinary-looking man I cared for—how did he get caught up in this horror? Why did this mad attack happen to him? Why was he even here in this part of the house at such an hour, instead of his assigned rooms below? And why did he submit so passively to Mr. Rochester’s order to keep everything secret? Why did Mr. Rochester insist on hiding these terrible incidents? He and his guest had both been victims—why did he bury it in silence? I could also tell Mr. Mason was deeply influenced by Mr. Rochester, who had complete power over him; their brief conversation had made that obvious. I couldn’t forget the look on his face when he confided to me, trembling and pale, that he’d been dealt a dreadful blow. It was serious, to move such a strong, determined spirit. As the night seemed to drag on endlessly, while my patient worsened and there was still no sign of help or daylight, I kept repeating to myself, 'When will he come? When will he come?' I offered water and smelling salts to Mason repeatedly, but nothing helped—he seemed to grow weaker and more delirious from pain, fear, or blood loss, and I worried he might die, yet I couldn’t even speak to him. The candle finally burned out, and as it died, I saw the first pale dawn at the window. Soon, Pilot the dog barked in the distant courtyard below, lifting my hopes—and rightly so, as within five minutes I heard the key turning and the lock opening, signaling my watch was finally over. The ordeal can’t have lasted more than two hours, but it felt far longer.

events.title: Dawn, the Surgeon, and Gruesome Revelations
detailed_summary: As the candle burns out, Jane perceives the first light of dawn and hears Pilot barking, reviving her hope.
Mr. Rochester returns with a surgeon, Carter, instructing him to work quickly as they have only half an hour.
Rochester dismisses Carter's concern about Mason's fitness to be moved, insisting the injury is not serious and Mason is merely nervous.
He opens the curtains and blinds, letting in daylight, which cheers Jane as she sees the advanced state of dawn.
Mason faintly tells Rochester he fears he is done for, but Rochester reassures him he will be fine in a fortnight.
Carter, after examining the wound, confirms there is no immediate danger but notes Mason has lost a lot of blood and expresses a wish he had arrived sooner.
The surgeon then discovers the flesh on the shoulder is torn as well as cut, and that teeth marks are present, not just a knife wound.
Mason murmurs that 'she' bit him and worried him like a tigress when Rochester got the knife from her.
Rochester chides Mason for not grappling with her immediately, but Mason describes the situation as frightful and unexpected, as 'she' had seemed quiet initially.
Rochester reminds Mason he had warned him to be on guard and calls his attempt to see 'her' alone at night mere folly.
Mason explains he thought he could do some good, to which Rochester reacts impatiently but refrains from further critique due to Mason's suffering.
Carter attends to another wound on Mason's arm, also finding teeth marks.
Mason reveals that 'she' sucked his blood and threatened to drain his heart.
Jane observes a profound expression of disgust, horror, and hatred contort Rochester's face, though he only speaks to silence Richard.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Rochester entered, and with him the surgeon he had been to fetch.
“Now, Carter, be on the alert,” he said to this last: “I give you but half-an-hour for dressing the wound, fastening the bandages, getting the patient downstairs and all.”
“But is he fit to move, sir?”
“No doubt of it; it is nothing serious; he is nervous, his spirits must be kept up. Come, set to work.”
Mr. Rochester drew back the thick curtain, drew up the holland blind, let in all the daylight he could; and I was surprised and cheered to see how far dawn was advanced: what rosy streaks were beginning to brighten the east. Then he approached Mason, whom the surgeon was already handling.
“Now, my good fellow, how are you?” he asked.
“She’s done for me, I fear,” was the faint reply.
“Not a whit!—courage! This day fortnight you’ll hardly be a pin the worse of it: you’ve lost a little blood; that’s all. Carter, assure him there’s no danger.”
“I can do that conscientiously,” said Carter, who had now undone the bandages; “only I wish I could have got here sooner: he would not have bled so much—but how is this? The flesh on the shoulder is torn as well as cut. This wound was not done with a knife: there have been teeth here!”
“She bit me,” he murmured. “She worried me like a tigress, when Rochester got the knife from her.”
“You should not have yielded: you should have grappled with her at once,” said Mr. Rochester.
“But under such circumstances, what could one do?” returned Mason. “Oh, it was frightful!” he added, shuddering. “And I did not expect it: she looked so quiet at first.”
“I warned you,” was his friend’s answer; “I said—be on your guard when you go near her. Besides, you might have waited till to-morrow, and had me with you: it was mere folly to attempt the interview to-night, and alone.”
“I thought I could have done some good.”
“You thought! you thought! Yes, it makes me impatient to hear you: but, however, you have suffered, and are likely to suffer enough for not taking my advice; so I’ll say no more. Carter—hurry!—hurry! The sun will soon rise, and I must have him off.”
“Directly, sir; the shoulder is just bandaged. I must look to this other wound in the arm: she has had her teeth here too, I think.”
“She sucked the blood: she said she’d drain my heart,” said Mason.
I saw Mr. Rochester shudder: a singularly marked expression of disgust, horror, hatred, warped his countenance almost to distortion; but he only said—

The flesh on the shoulder is torn as well as cut. This wound wasn't made with a knife; teeth have been involved here!" "She bit me," Mason murmured. "She mauled me like a wild cat when Rochester took the knife from her." "You should not have given up; you should have grappled with her immediately," said Mr. Rochester. "But under such circumstances, what could one do?" Mason replied. "Oh, it was terrifying!" he added, shuddering. "And I didn't expect it; she looked so calm at first." "I warned you," his friend replied. "I said—be cautious when you go near her. Besides, you could have waited until tomorrow, and had me with you; it was pure folly to attempt the interview tonight, and alone." "I thought I could have done some good." "You thought! You thought!" Rochester exclaimed, expressing impatience. "However, you have suffered, and are likely to suffer enough for not taking my advice; so I will say no more. Carter—hurry!—hurry! The sun will rise soon, and I must have him gone." "Right away, sir; the shoulder is just bandaged. I must attend to this other wound on the arm; I believe she has also used her teeth here." "She bit and sucked the blood," said Mason. "She said she would drain my heart." I saw Mr. Rochester visibly react with a shiver; a remarkably intense expression of disgust, horror, and hatred distorted his face almost unrecognizably; but he only said—
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Mr. Rochester came in, accompanied by the surgeon he had gone to fetch. He told the surgeon, Carter, to work quickly, giving him only half an hour to treat the wound, bandage it, and get the patient downstairs. Carter asked if the patient was fit to be moved, and Mr. Rochester reassured him, saying it was not a serious injury, only that the patient was nervous and needed his spirits kept up. As Mr. Rochester opened the curtains and let in more daylight, Jane noticed with relief that dawn was breaking. Rochester then addressed Mason, the injured man, who weakly commented that he feared he was badly hurt. Rochester dismissed his worries, assuring him that in two weeks he would be as well as ever and that he had only lost some blood. Carter also tried to reassure Mason, but noted with concern that the wound was torn as well as cut, indicating teeth marks rather than a knife wound. Mason confirmed that the woman bit him and attacked him like a wild animal when Rochester took the knife from her. Rochester admonished Mason for not defending himself, to which Mason replied he hadn't expected her to turn violent since she seemed calm at first. Rochester reminded him he had warned him to be careful and criticized him for not waiting until the next day when he could have accompanied him. Mason said he thought he could help. Rochester, losing patience, told him his suffering was punishment enough for not listening. Carter continued tending the wounds, noticing more bite marks, and Mason mentioned that the woman bit him in the arm as well, claiming she would drain his heart. Rochester was visibly disturbed by this, but only responded briefly.

events.title: Hastened Preparations for a Secret Departure
detailed_summary: Rochester curtly tells Mason to be silent and not repeat the 'gibberish' he heard.
Mason expresses his wish to forget, and Rochester suggests that leaving the country and thinking of 'her' as dead will help.
Mason finds it impossible to forget the night's events.
Rochester urges Mason to have energy, then directs Jane to fetch a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief from his dressing-room, praising her nimbleness.
Jane retrieves the items and returns.
Rochester instructs her to wait on the other side of the bed while he helps Mason dress, indicating she might be needed again.
He asks Jane if anyone was stirring downstairs when she went for the clothes; she confirms all was still.
Rochester assures Mason (Dick) they will get him away quietly for everyone's sake, stating his long effort to avoid exposure.
He directs Carter to help Mason with his waistcoat and asks about Mason's furred cloak.
Jane is sent to Mr. Mason's room to fetch the cloak.
Upon her return, Rochester sends Jane on another errand to his room for a small phial and glass from his toilet-table, again praising her quiet movements.
Jane quickly brings the vessels.
Rochester announces his intention to administer a cordial himself, taking responsibility for it, describing it as something he got from an Italian charlatan in Rome, potent but for occasional use.
He has Jane add a little water to the glass and wet the lip of the phial.
He measures twelve drops of a crimson liquid and presents it to Mason, telling him to drink it for courage.
Mason, though hesitant and asking if it will harm him, obeys.
After Mason is dressed, he appears pale but no longer bloody.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Come, be silent, Richard, and never mind her gibberish: don’t repeat it.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was dressed now: he still looked pale, but he was no longer gory and sullied.

events.text_segment:
“Come, be silent, Richard, and never mind her gibberish: don’t repeat it.”
“I wish I could forget it,” was the answer.
“You will when you are out of the country: when you get back to Spanish Town, you may think of her as dead and buried—or rather, you need not think of her at all.”
“Impossible to forget this night!”
“It is not impossible: have some energy, man. You thought you were as dead as a herring two hours since, and you are all alive and talking now. There!—Carter has done with you or nearly so; I’ll make you decent in a trice. Jane” (he turned to me for the first time since his re-entrance), “take this key: go down into my bedroom, and walk straight forward into my dressing-room: open the top drawer of the wardrobe and take out a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief: bring them here; and be nimble.”
I went; sought the repository he had mentioned, found the articles named, and returned with them.
“Now,” said he, “go to the other side of the bed while I order his toilet; but don’t leave the room: you may be wanted again.”
I retired as directed.
“Was anybody stirring below when you went down, Jane?” inquired Mr. Rochester presently.
“No, sir; all was very still.”
“We shall get you off cannily, Dick: and it will be better, both for your sake, and for that of the poor creature in yonder. I have striven long to avoid exposure, and I should not like it to come at last. Here, Carter, help him on with his waist-coat. Where did you leave your furred cloak? You can’t travel a mile without that, I know, in this damned cold climate. In your room?—Jane, run down to Mr. Mason’s room,—the one next mine,—and fetch a cloak you will see there.”
Again I ran, and again returned, bearing an immense mantle lined and edged with fur.
“Now, I’ve another errand for you,” said my untiring master; “you must away to my room again. What a mercy you are shod with velvet, Jane!—a clod-hopping messenger would never do at this juncture. You must open the middle drawer of my toilet-table and take out a little phial and a little glass you will find there,—quick!”
I flew thither and back, bringing the desired vessels.
“That’s well! Now, doctor, I shall take the liberty of administering a dose myself, on my own responsibility. I got this cordial at Rome, of an Italian charlatan—a fellow you would have kicked, Carter. It is not a thing to be used indiscriminately, but it is good upon occasion: as now, for instance. Jane, a little water.”
He held out the tiny glass, and I half filled it from the water-bottle on the washstand.
“That will do;—now wet the lip of the phial.”
I did so; he measured twelve drops of a crimson liquid, and presented it to Mason.
“Drink, Richard: it will give you the heart you lack, for an hour or so.”
“But will it hurt me?—is it inflammatory?”
“Drink! drink! drink!”
Mr. Mason obeyed, because it was evidently useless to resist. He was dressed now: he still looked pale, but he was no longer gory and sullied.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: “Richard, please be quiet and don’t pay attention to her nonsensical talk; don’t repeat it,” Rochester urged. Richard replied, “I wish I could forget it.” Rochester suggested he would forget once he left the country and returned to Spanish Town, advising him to consider her dead and buried, or better yet, not think of her at all. Mason insisted, “Impossible to forget this night!” “It’s not impossible; summon some strength, man,” Rochester argued. “You thought you were as good as dead two hours ago, and now you’re fully alive and speaking. There!—Carter is finished with you, or almost; I’ll get you looking presentable in a moment. Jane,” he said, addressing me for the first time since coming back in, “take this key: go downstairs to my bedroom, walk straight through to my dressing-room: open the top drawer of the wardrobe and get a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief: bring them here; and be quick.” I went, found the place he mentioned, got the items, and returned with them. “Now,” he instructed, “move to the other side of the bed while I help him get ready; but don’t leave the room: you might be needed again.” I withdrew as instructed. “Was anyone awake downstairs when you went down, Jane?” Mr. Rochester asked a moment later. “No, sir; everything was very quiet.” “We’ll get you away quietly, Dick: and it will be better for both your sake and that of the poor creature over there. I’ve worked hard for a long time to avoid exposure, and I wouldn’t want it to happen now. Here, Carter, help him put on his waistcoat. Where did you leave your furred cloak? I know you can’t travel even a mile without that in this dreadful cold. In your room?—Jane, run down to Mr. Mason’s room—the one next to mine—and fetch a cloak you’ll see there.” Again, I ran the errand and returned, carrying a huge cloak lined and trimmed with fur. “Now, I have another task for you,” said my tireless master; “you must go back to my room. What a blessing you’re wearing quiet shoes, Jane! A noisy messenger wouldn’t do at this moment. You must open the middle drawer of my toilet-table and get a small bottle and a small glass you’ll find there—quickly!” I hurried there and back, bringing the requested containers. “That’s good! Now, Doctor, I’ll take the liberty of giving him a dose myself, taking full responsibility. I got this medicine in Rome from an Italian swindler—a man you, Carter, would have despised. It’s not something to use often, but it’s good on occasion: like now, for example. Jane, a little water.” He held out the tiny glass, and I filled it halfway from the water bottle on the washstand. “That will do;—now wet the rim of the bottle.” I did so; he measured twelve drops of a dark red liquid and gave it to Mason. “Drink, Richard: it will give you the courage you’re lacking, for about an hour.” “But will it hurt me?—is it likely to cause inflammation?” “Drink! drink! drink!” Mr. Mason obeyed, as it was clearly useless to resist. He was now dressed; he still looked pale, but he was no longer bloody or soiled.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Please, Richard, keep quiet and ignore her rambling; don’t repeat any of it." 
"I wish I could erase it from my memory," he replied. 
"Once you’ve left and gone back to Spanish Town, you’ll forget all about her; you can think of her as gone—or better, simply don’t think of her again."
"There’s no way I’ll forget what happened tonight!"
"Nonsense. Just pull yourself together. Not long ago you felt as lifeless as a fish, and now you’re speaking just fine. Look—Carter’s just about finished patching you up; I’ll help tidy you up in a moment. Jane," (for the first time, he addressed me since re-entering), "take this key, go to my bedroom, walk into my dressing-room, open the top drawer in my wardrobe and bring back a clean shirt and neck cloth. Hurry now."
I followed his instructions, found what he asked for, and returned quickly.
"Alright," he said, "go stand on the other side of the bed while I get him dressed. Don’t leave the room though—stay close in case I need you again."
I did as he said.
"Jane, did you see anyone downstairs when you went?" Mr. Rochester asked.
"No, sir; it was totally quiet."
"We’ll manage to get you out quietly, Dick; it’s best for you, and for the poor lady over there too. I’ve tried long enough to keep things hidden, and I don’t want it all revealed now. Carter, help him with his waistcoat. Where’s your fur cloak? You’ll need it in this cold. Is it in your room?—Jane, please go to Mr. Mason’s room, the one next to mine, and bring the cloak you find there."
I ran off again and returned with a large, fur-lined cloak.
"One more job for you," said my tireless employer, "Head back to my room. It’s lucky you wear soft shoes, Jane! A heavy-footed messenger wouldn’t do right now. Open the middle drawer of my dressing table and bring me a small bottle and a glass you’ll see—quickly!"
I fetched them and brought them back.
"Good! Now, doctor, I’ll take responsibility for giving him a dose myself. I bought this tonic in Rome from a shady Italian—a man you’d have kicked, Carter. It’s not for general use, but in a case like this, it’s beneficial. Jane, some water, please."
He handed me the little glass, and I half-filled it with water.
"That’s enough; now dampen the mouth of the bottle."
I did, and he measured twelve drops of a red liquid and handed it to Mr. Mason.
"Drink, Richard; this will give you some courage for a while."
"Are you sure it won’t harm me? Is it dangerous?"
"Just drink!"
Mr. Mason obeyed, seeing it was pointless to argue. By now he was fully dressed; he still looked pale but no longer bloodied and disheveled.

events.title: Mason's Covert Exit and Rochester's Lingering Burden
detailed_summary: After allowing Mason to sit for three minutes post-drink, Rochester helps him to his feet.
With Carter supporting Mason's other shoulder, Rochester encourages him to step out.
Mason remarks that he feels better.
Rochester instructs Jane to go ahead to the backstairs, unbolt the side-passage door, and inform the waiting post-chaise driver to be ready, also telling her to hem if anyone is about.
It is half-past five; Jane finds the kitchen dark and silent and unbolts the door quietly.
The yard is quiet, gates open, and a post-chaise with a driver is waiting outside.
Jane informs the driver, then observes the early morning stillness, noting drawn curtains and distant sounds of birds and horses.
Mason appears, supported by Rochester and the surgeon, walking with tolerable ease, and is helped into the chaise, followed by Carter.
Rochester instructs Carter to care for Mason at his house until he is well, promising to visit.
Mason, revived by the fresh air, asks Fairfax (Rochester) to ensure 'she' is taken care of tenderly, then bursts into tears.
Rochester affirms he does his best and will continue to do so, then shuts the chaise door, and the vehicle departs.
Rochester, after closing and barring the yard gates, expresses a wish for an end to 'all this'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Rochester let him sit three minutes after he had swallowed the liquid; he then took his arm—“
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yet would to God there was an end of all this!” added Mr. Rochester, as he closed and barred the heavy yard-gates.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Rochester let him sit three minutes after he had swallowed the liquid; he then took his arm—
“Now I am sure you can get on your feet,” he said—“try.”
The patient rose.
“Carter, take him under the other shoulder. Be of good cheer, Richard; step out—that’s it!”
“I do feel better,” remarked Mr. Mason.
“I am sure you do. Now, Jane, trip on before us away to the backstairs; unbolt the side-passage door, and tell the driver of the post-chaise you will see in the yard—or just outside, for I told him not to drive his rattling wheels over the pavement—to be ready; we are coming: and, Jane, if any one is about, come to the foot of the stairs and hem.”
It was by this time half-past five, and the sun was on the point of rising; but I found the kitchen still dark and silent. The side-passage door was fastened; I opened it with as little noise as possible: all the yard was quiet; but the gates stood wide open, and there was a post-chaise, with horses ready harnessed, and driver seated on the box, stationed outside. I approached him, and said the gentlemen were coming; he nodded: then I looked carefully round and listened. The stillness of early morning slumbered everywhere; the curtains were yet drawn over the servants’ chamber windows; little birds were just twittering in the blossom-blanched orchard trees, whose boughs drooped like white garlands over the wall enclosing one side of the yard; the carriage horses stamped from time to time in their closed stables: all else was still.
The gentlemen now appeared. Mason, supported by Mr. Rochester and the surgeon, seemed to walk with tolerable ease: they assisted him into the chaise; Carter followed.
“Take care of him,” said Mr. Rochester to the latter, “and keep him at your house till he is quite well: I shall ride over in a day or two to see how he gets on. Richard, how is it with you?”
“The fresh air revives me, Fairfax.”
“Leave the window open on his side, Carter; there is no wind—good-bye, Dick.”
“Fairfax—”
“Well what is it?”
“Let her be taken care of; let her be treated as tenderly as may be: let her—” he stopped and burst into tears.
“I do my best; and have done it, and will do it,” was the answer: he shut up the chaise door, and the vehicle drove away.
“Yet would to God there was an end of all this!” added Mr. Rochester, as he closed and barred the heavy yard-gates.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: After the patient had consumed the liquid, Mr. Rochester allowed him to remain seated for three minutes. Taking his arm, he then instructed, "Now I'm confident you can stand on your feet," urging him to "try." The patient stood. "Carter," Rochester directed, "assist him under the other arm. Be brave, Richard; move along—that's it!" "I definitely feel better," Mr. Mason commented. "I'm sure you do. Now, Jane, hasten ahead of us down the back stairs; unlock the door leading to the side passage and tell the driver of the post-chaise you'll find in the yard—or just outside, since I told him not to drive his noisy wheels over the paving—to be prepared; we are coming. And, Jane, if anyone is present, come to the bottom of the stairs and clear your throat softly." It was then half-past five, with the sun on the verge of rising; however, the kitchen remained dark and quiet. The side-passage door was secured; I opened it as quietly as possible. The entire yard was still, but the large gates were standing wide open, and a post-chaise, with the horses already harnessed and the driver seated on the box, was positioned just outside. I approached him and informed him the gentlemen were approaching; he nodded in response. I then looked around carefully and listened intently. The tranquility of early morning sleep pervaded everywhere; the curtains were still drawn over the windows of the servants' quarters; tiny birds were just starting to chirp in the orchard trees, which were white with blossoms, their branches drooping like pale garlands over the wall that enclosed one side of the yard. The carriage horses occasionally stamped their feet in their closed stables; everything else was motionless. The gentlemen soon appeared. Mason, supported by Mr. Rochester and the surgeon, seemed able to walk with reasonable ease. They helped him into the chaise; Carter entered afterward. "Take care of him," Mr. Rochester instructed Carter, "and keep him at your residence until he has fully recovered. I will ride over in a day or two to check on his condition. Richard, how are you doing?" "The fresh air is restoring me, Fairfax." "Leave the window open on his side, Carter; there is no wind—farewell, Dick." "Fairfax—" "Yes, what is it?" "Ensure she is looked after; see that she is treated as gently as can be; make sure she—" He broke off, bursting into tears. "I am doing my utmost; I have done it, and I will continue to do so," came the reply. He closed the chaise door, and the carriage departed. "Oh, that all this were finally over!" Mr. Rochester added, as he closed and barred the heavy yard gates.

With the surgeon Carter supporting Mason on his other side, they helped him walk. Mason commented that he was feeling better, and Rochester agreed.
