events.title: Orchard Confidences: Rochester's Hypothetical Plea and Moral Dilemma
detailed_summary: Rochester slowly walks towards an orchard door, and Jane, thinking he is done with her, prepares to return to the house.
He calls her name again, having opened a portal to the orchard, and invites her in for some fresh air, calling the house a dungeon.
Jane politely disagrees, seeing it as a splendid mansion, but Rochester dismisses her perception as inexperienced glamour, describing the house's apparent beauty as deceptive.
He contrasts the house with the orchard, which he describes as real, sweet, and pure.
They walk through the orchard, filled with fruit trees and old-fashioned flowers, fresh in the early morning sun.
Rochester asks Jane if she would like a flower and offers her a half-blown rose.
He asks if she likes the sunrise and the calm atmosphere, which she affirms.
He acknowledges the strange night she has passed and notes her paleness, asking if she was afraid when left alone with Mason.
Jane admits she was afraid of someone coming from the inner room (Grace Poole's).
Rochester reassures her she was safe, as he had locked the door and had the key, comparing himself to a shepherd protecting his lamb.
Jane asks if Grace Poole will continue to live at Thornfield, and Rochester tells her not to worry about it.
She expresses concern for his safety while Grace Poole remains, but he tells her not to fear.
Jane questions if the danger he apprehended is gone, and he replies he cannot be sure until Mason is out of England, describing his life as standing on a 'crater-crust'.

Jane observes Mason seems easily led by Rochester, but Rochester explains that while Mason won't defy him intentionally, he could unintentionally cause great harm with a careless word, thus Rochester must keep Mason ignorant of this possibility.
He admits to puzzling Jane and calls her his 'little friend'.
Jane expresses her contentment in serving and obeying him in what is right.

Rochester acknowledges her genuine contentment but notes she would resist if asked to do wrong, becoming 'immutable as a fixed star', and admits she too has power over him, which is why he dare not show his vulnerabilities.
Jane reassures him he is as safe from her as from Mason.
They reach an arbour, and Rochester invites her to sit, which she does after a slight hesitation.
He proposes to put a hypothetical case to her, asking her to imagine herself as a wild, indulged boy who commits a significant 'error' in a foreign land, with lifelong consequences.
This error, not a crime, makes life insupportable, leading to unusual measures for relief, yet misery persists.
The hypothetical person, after years of exile and seeking happiness in heartless pleasure, returns home and finds a new acquaintance embodying all the good qualities sought for years.
This society revives and regenerates, creating a desire to recommence life more worthily.
Rochester asks if this person is justified in overleaping a conventional obstacle to attain this end.
He pauses for Jane's answer, but she is at a loss.
He repeats his query: is the repentant man justified in defying world opinion to secure this regenerative companionship and peace of mind?

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This done, he moved with slow step and abstracted air towards a door in the wall bordering the orchard.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:
Again Mr. Rochester propounded his query:
“Is the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man justified in daring the world’s opinion, in order to attach to him for ever this gentle, gracious, genial stranger, thereby securing his own peace of mind and regeneration of life?”

events.text_segment:
This done, he moved with slow step and abstracted air towards a door in the wall bordering the orchard. I, supposing he had done with me, prepared to return to the house; again, however, I heard him call “Jane!” He had opened the portal and stood at it, waiting for me.
“Come where there is some freshness, for a few moments,” he said; “that house is a mere dungeon: don’t you feel it so?”
“It seems to me a splendid mansion, sir.”
“The glamour of inexperience is over your eyes,” he answered; “and you see it through a charmed medium: you cannot discern that the gilding is slime and the silk draperies cobwebs; that the marble is sordid slate, and the polished woods mere refuse chips and scaly bark. Now here” (he pointed to the leafy enclosure we had entered) “all is real, sweet, and pure.”
He strayed down a walk edged with box, with apple trees, pear trees, and cherry trees on one side, and a border on the other full of all sorts of old-fashioned flowers, stocks, sweet-williams, primroses, pansies, mingled with southernwood, sweet-briar, and various fragrant herbs. They were fresh now as a succession of April showers and gleams, followed by a lovely spring morning, could make them: the sun was just entering the dappled east, and his light illumined the wreathed and dewy orchard trees and shone down the quiet walks under them.
“Jane, will you have a flower?”
He gathered a half-blown rose, the first on the bush, and offered it to me.
“Thank you, sir.”
“Do you like this sunrise, Jane? That sky with its high and light clouds which are sure to melt away as the day waxes warm—this placid and balmly atmosphere?”
“I do, very much.”
“You have passed a strange night, Jane.”
“Yes, sir.”
“And it has made you look pale—were you afraid when I left you alone with Mason?”
“I was afraid of some one coming out of the inner room.”
“But I had fastened the door—I had the key in my pocket: I should have been a careless shepherd if I had left a lamb—my pet lamb—so near a wolf’s den, unguarded: you were safe.”
“Will Grace Poole live here still, sir?”
“Oh yes! don’t trouble your head about her—put the thing out of your thoughts.”
“Yet it seems to me your life is hardly secure while she stays.”
“Never fear—I will take care of myself.”
“Is the danger you apprehended last night gone by now, sir?”
“I cannot vouch for that till Mason is out of England: nor even then. To live, for me, Jane, is to stand on a crater-crust which may crack and spue fire any day.”
“But Mr. Mason seems a man easily led. Your influence, sir, is evidently potent with him: he will never set you at defiance or wilfully injure you.”
“Oh, no! Mason will not defy me; nor, knowing it, will he hurt me—but, unintentionally, he might in a moment, by one careless word, deprive me, if not of life, yet for ever of happiness.”
“Tell him to be cautious, sir: let him know what you fear, and show him how to avert the danger.”
He laughed sardonically, hastily took my hand, and as hastily threw it from him.
“If I could do that, simpleton, where would the danger be? Annihilated in a moment. Ever since I have known Mason, I have only had to say to him ‘Do that,’ and the thing has been done. But I cannot give him orders in this case: I cannot say ‘Beware of harming me, Richard;’ for it is imperative that I should keep him ignorant that harm to me is possible. Now you look puzzled; and I will puzzle you further. You are my little friend, are you not?”
“I like to serve you, sir, and to obey you in all that is right.”
“Precisely: I see you do. I see genuine contentment in your gait and mien, your eye and face, when you are helping me and pleasing me—working for me, and with me, in, as you characteristically say, ‘all that is right:’ for if I bid you do what you thought wrong, there would be no light-footed running, no neat-handed alacrity, no lively glance and animated complexion. My friend would then turn to me, quiet and pale, and would say, ‘No, sir; that is impossible: I cannot do it, because it is wrong;’ and would become immutable as a fixed star. Well, you too have power over me, and may injure me: yet I dare not show you where I am vulnerable, lest, faithful and friendly as you are, you should transfix me at once.”
“If you have no more to fear from Mr. Mason than you have from me, sir, you are very safe.”
“God grant it may be so! Here, Jane, is an arbour; sit down.”
The arbour was an arch in the wall, lined with ivy; it contained a rustic seat. Mr. Rochester took it, leaving room, however, for me: but I stood before him.
“Sit,” he said; “the bench is long enough for two. You don’t hesitate to take a place at my side, do you? Is that wrong, Jane?”
I answered him by assuming it: to refuse would, I felt, have been unwise.
“Now, my little friend, while the sun drinks the dew—while all the flowers in this old garden awake and expand, and the birds fetch their young ones’ breakfast out of the Thornfield, and the early bees do their first spell of work—I’ll put a case to you, which you must endeavour to suppose your own: but first, look at me, and tell me you are at ease, and not fearing that I err in detaining you, or that you err in staying.”
“No, sir; I am content.”
“Well then, Jane, call to aid your fancy:—suppose you were no longer a girl well reared and disciplined, but a wild boy indulged from childhood upwards; imagine yourself in a remote foreign land; conceive that you there commit a capital error, no matter of what nature or from what motives, but one whose consequences must follow you through life and taint all your existence. Mind, I don’t say a crime; I am not speaking of shedding of blood or any other guilty act, which might make the perpetrator amenable to the law: my word is error. The results of what you have done become in time to you utterly insupportable; you take measures to obtain relief: unusual measures, but neither unlawful nor culpable. Still you are miserable; for hope has quitted you on the very confines of life: your sun at noon darkens in an eclipse, which you feel will not leave it till the time of setting. Bitter and base associations have become the sole food of your memory: you wander here and there, seeking rest in exile: happiness in pleasure—I mean in heartless, sensual pleasure—such as dulls intellect and blights feeling. Heart-weary and soul-withered, you come home after years of voluntary banishment: you make a new acquaintance—how or where no matter: you find in this stranger much of the good and bright qualities which you have sought for twenty years, and never before encountered; and they are all fresh, healthy, without soil and without taint. Such society revives, regenerates: you feel better days come back—higher wishes, purer feelings; you desire to recommence your life, and to spend what remains to you of days in a way more worthy of an immortal being. To attain this end, are you justified in overleaping an obstacle of custom—a mere conventional impediment which neither your conscience sanctifies nor your judgment approves?”
He paused for an answer: and what was I to say? Oh, for some good spirit to suggest a judicious and satisfactory response! Vain aspiration! The west wind whispered in the ivy round me; but no gentle Ariel borrowed its breath as a medium of speech: the birds sang in the tree-tops; but their song, however sweet, was inarticulate.
Again Mr. Rochester propounded his query:
“Is the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man justified in daring the world’s opinion, in order to attach to him for ever this gentle, gracious, genial stranger, thereby securing his own peace of mind and regeneration of life?”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
After doing this, he slowly walked towards a gate in the garden wall near the orchard with a distant look. I thought he was finished with me and prepared to go back to the house. However, I heard him call my name, "Jane!" He had opened the gate and was waiting for me there.

"Come somewhere fresh for a little while," he said. "That house is nothing more than a prison. Don't you feel that way?"

"It seems like a magnificent manor to me, sir."

"Inexperience blinds you," he replied. "You're seeing it through a magical filter. You can't tell that the so-called gold is actually grime, the silk curtains are cobwebs, the marble is just cheap slate, and the polished wood is merely scrap chips and rough bark. But here," he indicated the leafy area we had entered, "everything is genuine, pleasant, and unspoiled."

He walked down a path lined with boxwood hedges, with apple, pear, and cherry trees on one side and a border on the other filled with traditional flowers like stocks, sweet-williams, primroses, pansies, mixed with southernwood, sweet-briar, and various aromatic herbs. They were as vibrant as a sequence of April showers and sunshine followed by a lovely spring morning could make them. The sun was just appearing in the colourful east, its light illuminating the twisting, dewy orchard trees and shining down the quiet paths beneath them.

"Jane, would you like a flower?"

He picked a half-open rose, the first on the bush, and offered it to me.

"Thank you, sir."

"Do you like this sunrise, Jane? The sky with its high, light clouds that are bound to disappear as the day gets warmer—this calm and soothing air?"

"I do, very much."

"You had an unusual night, Jane."

"Yes, sir."

"And it made you look pale. Were you scared when I left you alone with Mason?"

"I was afraid someone might come out of the inner room."

"But I had locked the door. I had the key in my pocket. I would have been a negligent shepherd if I had left a lamb—my special lamb—so close to a wolf's den, unprotected. You were safe."

"Will Grace Poole continue to live here, sir?"

"Oh, yes! Don't worry yourself about her. Put the matter out of your mind."

"Still, it seems to me your life is barely safe while she remains."

"Don't worry—I will look after myself."

"Is the danger you anticipated last night over now, sir?"

"I can't guarantee that until Mason is out of England, and perhaps not even then. For me, Jane, living is like standing on a volcanic crust that could crack and erupt fire at any moment."

"But Mr. Mason seems easily influenced. Your power over him is clearly strong, sir. He would never defy you or intentionally harm you."

"Oh, no! Mason won't challenge me; nor, knowing the consequence, would he harm me. But unintentionally, he might, in an instant, with a single careless word, deprive me, if not of life, then forever of happiness."

"Tell him to be careful, sir. Let him know what you fear, and show him how to avoid the danger."

He laughed cynically, quickly took my hand, and just as quickly dropped it.

"If I could do that, you simple girl, where would the danger be? Instantly gone. Ever since I've known Mason, all I've had to say is, 'Do that,' and it's done. But I cannot give him orders in this situation. I cannot say, 'Be careful about harming me, Richard,' because it is crucial that I keep him unaware that he can cause me harm. Now you look puzzled, and I'll puzzle you further. You are my little friend, aren't you?"

"I enjoy serving you, sir, and obeying you in all that is right."

"Precisely; I see that you do. I see genuine happiness in your manner, your eyes, and your face when you are assisting and pleasing me—working for and with me, in what you characteristically call 'all that is right.' Because if I asked you to do something you thought was wrong, there would be no light-footed movement, no quick, skilled help, no lively gaze or animated face. My friend would then turn to me, quiet and pale, and say, 'No, sir; that is impossible. I cannot do it, because it is wrong,' and would become as unmoving as a star. Well, you too have influence over me and could injure me. Yet I dare not reveal where I am vulnerable, for fear that, loyal and friendly as you are, you might wound me immediately."

"If you have no more to fear from Mr. Mason than you do from me, sir, you are very secure."

"God grant that is true! Here, Jane, is an arbour; sit down."

The arbour was an archway in the wall covered in ivy. It contained a rustic bench. Mr. Rochester sat on it, leaving space for me, but I remained standing before him.

"Sit," he said. "The bench is long enough for two. You don't hesitate to take a seat beside me, do you? Is that wrong, Jane?"

I replied by sitting down; I felt refusing would have been unwise.

"Now, my little friend, while the sun absorbs the dew—while all the flowers in this old garden awaken and open, and the birds bring breakfast to their young from Thornfield, and the early bees do their first tasks—I will present you with a hypothetical situation, which you must try to imagine is happening to you. But first, look at me and tell me you are comfortable and not worried that I am wrong to keep you, or that you are wrong to stay."

"No, sir; I am content."

"Very well then, Jane, use your imagination. Suppose you were no longer a well-raised and disciplined girl, but a wild boy spoiled from childhood. Picture yourself in a distant foreign land. Imagine that you commit a major mistake there—the nature or reasons don't matter—but one whose consequences will follow you throughout your life and spoil your entire existence. Note, I am not saying a crime; I am not talking about shedding blood or any other guilty act that could make the perpetrator subject to the law. My word is error. Over time, the results of your action become completely unbearable. You take steps to find relief—unconventional steps, but neither illegal nor blameworthy. Still, you are unhappy, for hope has abandoned you just as you reach the threshold of life. Your sun at noon is darkened by an eclipse that you feel will not end until sunset. Bitter and unpleasant memories have become the only sustenance for your mind. You wander from place to place, seeking rest in exile and happiness in pleasure—by which I mean heartless, physical pleasure—the kind that dulls the mind and withers feelings. Weary in heart and soul, you return home after years of self-imposed exile. You meet a new acquaintance—how or where doesn't matter. You find in this stranger many of the good and shining qualities you have searched for for twenty years and never before encountered. And they are all fresh, healthy, pure, and unspoiled. Such companionship revives and renews you. You feel better days returning—higher desires, purer emotions. You want to start your life over and spend the remainder of your days in a way more fitting for an immortal being. To achieve this aim, are you justified in disregarding a social obstacle—a purely conventional barrier that your conscience doesn't approve of, nor your judgment sanction?"

He paused for an answer, and what could I say? Oh, for some helpful spirit to suggest a sensible and satisfying reply! A futile wish! The west wind whispered in the ivy around me, but no gentle spirit borrowed its breath to speak. The birds sang in the treetops, but their song, however sweet, was unclear.

Mr. Rochester repeated his question:

"Is the man who has strayed and sinned, but who now seeks peace and repents, justified in defying the world's opinion in order to bind to himself forever this gentle, kind, cheerful stranger, thereby securing his own peace of mind and a renewed life?"
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After doing so, he slowly walked toward a door in the orchard wall, looking lost in thought. Thinking our conversation was over, I began to head back to the house, but then he called out, “Jane!” He’d opened the door and was standing there, waiting for me. 

“Step out here for a while, where it’s fresh,” he invited. “That house feels like a prison—don’t you agree?”

“I think it’s a magnificent mansion, sir,” I replied.

“You’re still inexperienced,” he said. “You view it through the eyes of youth—it appears enchanting. What you see as luxury is just an illusion: gold that’s really slime, fine fabrics that are actually cobwebs, marble that is just plain slate, polished wood that’s nothing but scraps and bark. Out here,” he indicated the lush orchard we entered, “everything is genuine, sweet, and pure.”

We strolled down a path lined with box hedges, apple, pear, and cherry trees on one side, and on the other, a border filled with traditional flowers—stocks, sweet-williams, primroses, pansies—mixed with fragrant herbs like southernwood and sweet-briar. Thanks to recent rains and a beautiful morning, everything was fresh. The sun rose in a mottled sky, lighting up the dewy orchard trees and serene pathways beneath them.

“Jane, would you like a flower?” he asked, picking the first rosebud from a bush and handing it to me.

“Thank you, sir.”

“Do you like this sunrise, Jane? The sky with its high, wispy clouds that will disappear as it gets warmer—the calm, pleasant air?”

“I do, very much.”

“You had an unusual night, Jane.”

“Yes, sir.”

“You look pale—were you afraid when I left you alone with Mason?”

“I feared someone might come out of the inner room.”

“But the door was locked, and I had the key. I wouldn’t leave my lamb—my dear pet lamb—unguarded near a wolf’s den. You were safe.”

“Will Grace Poole still live here, sir?”

“Oh yes! Don’t worry about her—just put her from your mind.”

“But surely your safety isn’t guaranteed with her here.”

“I’ll look after myself—don’t worry.”

“Has the danger you were worried about last night passed?”

“I can’t be completely sure until Mason leaves England, maybe not even then. Living, for me, is like standing on a volcano that could erupt at any time.”

“But Mr. Mason seems easy to manage; you clearly have influence over him. He’d never defy or purposely harm you.”

“That’s true. Mason won’t defy or intentionally hurt me, but he might accidentally cause me to lose not my life, but my happiness. Just one careless word…"

“Warn him, sir; let him know the danger so he can avoid it.”

He laughed bitterly, quickly grabbed my hand, then let it go. "If only it were that simple! Ever since knowing Mason, all I’ve needed to do is say, ‘do that,’ and he would. But with this, I can’t command him. I can’t warn him not to harm me, because he mustn’t know I’m vulnerable. You look puzzled—let me confound you more. You’re my little friend, aren’t you?”

“I’m happy to help and obey you in all things right, sir.”

“Yes, you are. I see how content you are when you do so—if I asked you to do wrong, though, you’d refuse. Then you’d be quiet, pale, and unchanging, insisting, ‘No, sir, I can’t—it’s wrong.’ Even you could harm me, so I can’t show where I’m vulnerable, lest you strike—even if you are faithful.”

“If you’re as safe from Mason as from me, sir, then you’ve nothing to fear.”

“Let’s hope so! Here, Jane, is an arbour; sit down.”

The arbour was an ivy-covered alcove in the wall, with a rustic bench. Mr. Rochester sat, leaving room for me, but I hesitated.

“Sit,” he urged. “The bench is big enough for both. You don’t mind sitting beside me, do you? Is that improper, Jane?”

I sat beside him, realizing to refuse would be unwise.

“Now, while the sun dries the dew, the flowers open, and the birds and bees are about their business, let’s imagine a situation. But first, are you comfortable with me, Jane—you don’t fear you’re doing wrong by staying?”

“No, sir, I’m content.”

“All right. Imagine you’re not a well-raised, disciplined girl, but a spoiled boy, allowed every indulgence since childhood. Picture yourself in a distant land where you make a serious mistake—not a crime, not bloodshed or anything against the law, but a grave error with life-long consequences. In time, this error becomes unbearable, so you take unusual steps to find relief—not illegal or immoral, but still you are unhappy; hope deserts you, your life is eclipsed. Your memories are bitter; you wander in exile seeking peace in fleeting pleasures. You return home after years away and meet someone new—someone who finally has all the good qualities you’ve searched for. Their presence renews you, gives you hope and better feelings. You long to start over and live more worthily. To do that, would you be right to bypass a mere social barrier—a custom your conscience and reason don’t approve—in order to secure your happiness?”

He paused. I didn’t know what to say; I wished for advice, but only the wind and birds answered, in meaningless whispers and songs.

Mr. Rochester asked again: “Is the wandering, sinful man—now penitent and seeking rest—justified in defying society’s opinion, if it means joining himself forever to this gentle, virtuous person, and thus regaining peace and a new life?”

events.title: Jane's Counsel, Rochester's Evasion, and a Deceptive Farewell
detailed_summary: Jane responds that a person's repose or reformation should not depend on a fellow human, advising looking to a higher power for strength and solace.
Rochester argues that God ordains the instrument for such work and implies he has found his instrument for cure.
He pauses, looking eagerly at Jane, but then his tone and expression shift to harshness and sarcasm.
He abruptly asks Jane if she thinks marrying Miss Ingram would regenerate him, given her noticed 'tender penchant' for Miss Ingram.
Rochester gets up, walks to the end of the path, and returns humming.
He remarks on Jane's paleness from her vigil and asks if she curses him for disturbing her rest, which she denies.
They shake hands; he notes her cold fingers, recalling they were warmer the previous night.
He asks when she will watch with him again, and she replies, 'Whenever I can be useful, sir.'
He suggests the night before his wedding, saying he won't be able to sleep and would want her company to talk about his 'lovely one,' whom Jane now knows.
Jane agrees, and Rochester praises Miss Ingram as 'a rare one' and 'a real strapper'.
He then spots Dent and Lynn in the stables and directs Jane to go in through the shrubbery via a wicket gate.
They part ways, and Jane hears Rochester cheerfully telling Dent and Lynn that Mason left before sunrise, with Rochester having risen at four to see him off.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Sir,” I answered, “a wanderer’s repose or a sinner’s reformation should never depend on a fellow-creature.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I rose at four to see him off.”

events.text_segment:
“Sir,” I answered, “a wanderer’s repose or a sinner’s reformation should never depend on a fellow-creature. Men and women die; philosophers falter in wisdom, and Christians in goodness: if any one you know has suffered and erred, let him look higher than his equals for strength to amend and solace to heal.”
“But the instrument—the instrument! God, who does the work, ordains the instrument. I have myself—I tell it you without parable—been a worldly, dissipated, restless man; and I believe I have found the instrument for my cure in—”
He paused: the birds went on carolling, the leaves lightly rustling. I almost wondered they did not check their songs and whispers to catch the suspended revelation; but they would have had to wait many minutes—so long was the silence protracted. At last I looked up at the tardy speaker: he was looking eagerly at me.
“Little friend,” said he, in quite a changed tone—while his face changed too, losing all its softness and gravity, and becoming harsh and sarcastic—“you have noticed my tender penchant for Miss Ingram: don’t you think if I married her she would regenerate me with a vengeance?”
He got up instantly, went quite to the other end of the walk, and when he came back he was humming a tune.
“Jane, Jane,” said he, stopping before me, “you are quite pale with your vigils: don’t you curse me for disturbing your rest?”
“Curse you? No, sir.”
“Shake hands in confirmation of the word. What cold fingers! They were warmer last night when I touched them at the door of the mysterious chamber. Jane, when will you watch with me again?”
“Whenever I can be useful, sir.”
“For instance, the night before I am married! I am sure I shall not be able to sleep. Will you promise to sit up with me to bear me company? To you I can talk of my lovely one: for now you have seen her and know her.”
“Yes, sir.”
“She’s a rare one, is she not, Jane?”
“Yes, sir.”
“A strapper—a real strapper, Jane: big, brown, and buxom; with hair just such as the ladies of Carthage must have had. Bless me! there’s Dent and Lynn in the stables! Go in by the shrubbery, through that wicket.”
As I went one way, he went another, and I heard him in the yard, saying cheerfully—
“Mason got the start of you all this morning; he was gone before sunrise: I rose at four to see him off.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
“Sir,” I replied, “a person finding peace or changing their ways shouldn't rely on another human being. People die; wise individuals err, and good people fail in their virtue. If someone you know has suffered and made mistakes, they should look beyond their equals for the strength to improve and the comfort to heal.”
“But the tool—the tool! God, who performs the work, chooses the means. I myself—and I’ll tell you plainly—have been a worldly, wild, and restless man; and I believe I’ve found the means for my recovery in—”
He paused. The birds kept singing, the leaves continued their soft rustling. I was almost surprised they didn't stop their sounds to hear his upcoming revelation, but they would have had a long wait, as the silence stretched on for many minutes. Eventually, I looked up at the slow speaker; he was watching me intently.
“Little friend,” he said, his tone completely different—his face also changed, losing its gentle, serious look and becoming harsh and mocking—“you’ve noticed my apparent fondness for Miss Ingram, haven’t you? Don’t you think if I married her, she’d reform me completely?”
He stood up immediately, walked to the far end of the path, and came back humming a tune.
“Jane, Jane,” he said, stopping in front of me, “you look quite pale from your late nights. Aren’t you angry at me for disturbing your rest?”
“Angry at you? No, sir.”
“Shake hands to confirm that. Your fingers are cold! They were warmer last night when I touched them by the door of that mysterious room. Jane, when will you stay up with me again?”
“Whenever I can be useful, sir.”
“For instance, the night before I get married! I’m sure I won’t be able to sleep. Will you promise to stay up with me and keep me company? I can talk to you about my beloved, now that you’ve met and know her.”
“Yes, sir.”
“She’s a remarkable woman, isn’t she, Jane?”
“Yes, sir.”
“A robust one—a truly strong woman, Jane: tall, healthy-looking, and attractive; with hair just like the women of ancient Carthage must have had. Good heavens! There are Dent and Lynn at the stables! Go inside through the shrubbery, using that small gate.”
As I went one way, he went the other, and I heard him in the yard, saying cheerfully—“Mason got ahead of all of you this morning; he was gone before sunrise. I got up at four to see him off.”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Sir," I replied, "one should not base a wanderer’s rest or a sinner’s redemption on another human. People die; even wise philosophers can err, and Christians can fail morally. If someone you know has suffered and made mistakes, they should seek support and healing from a higher power than other people."

He responded, "But the tool—the tool! God, who carries out the work, chooses the tool. I confess to you plainly, I have been a worldly, self-indulgent, and uneasy man; and I think I may have found my cure through—" He broke off. Birds kept singing, and the leaves kept whispering. I almost wondered they didn’t stop to listen for his unfinished confession; but the silence stretched on for several minutes. At last, I looked up at him; he was gazing at me intently.

He said, in a tone that had changed, his face now harsh and mocking, “You’ve seen my fondness for Miss Ingram. Don’t you think, if I married her, she’d certainly reform me?”

He suddenly got up, walked to the far end of the path, and when he returned, he was humming a tune.

“Jane, Jane,” he said, stopping in front of me, “you look very pale from lack of sleep: aren’t you angry with me for keeping you up?”

“Angry with you? No, sir.”

“Shake my hand to assure me. Your hands are so cold! They were warmer last night when I touched them at the mysterious room’s door. Jane, when will you keep watch with me again?”

“Any time I can be of help, sir.”

“For example, the night before my wedding! I’m sure I won’t be able to sleep. Will you promise to stay up with me and keep me company? I can talk to you about my bride-to-be, since you’ve met her now.”

“Yes, sir.”

“She’s a remarkable woman, isn’t she, Jane?”

“Yes, sir.”

“A fine, strong woman: tall, robust, and lively; with hair like the women of ancient Carthage might have had. Oh! Dent and Lynn are in the stables! Go in via the shrubbery, through that gate.”

As I went one way, he went another, and I heard him call out cheerily in the yard, “Mason beat all of you this morning; he left before sunrise: I got up at four to see him off.”

events.title: Ominous Dreams and a Somber Messenger
detailed_summary: The narrator reflects on the mysterious nature of presentiments, sympathies, and signs, stating a personal belief in their existence.
A childhood memory is recounted: Bessie Leaven dreamed of a child, which was considered a bad omen, and shortly after, Bessie's younger sister died.
The narrator reveals having dreamt of an infant nightly for the past week, in various forms and moods, causing growing nervousness.
These recurring dreams were present on the night a cry was heard, and on the following afternoon, the narrator was summoned to Mrs. Fairfax's room.
Awaiting the narrator is a man dressed in deep mourning, who appears to be a gentleman's servant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Presentiments are strange things! and so are sympathies; and so are signs; and the three combined make one mystery to which humanity has not yet found the key.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On repairing thither, I found a man waiting for me, having the appearance of a gentleman’s servant: he was dressed in deep mourning, and the hat he held in his hand was surrounded with a crape band.

events.text_segment:
Presentiments are strange things! and so are sympathies; and so are signs; and the three combined make one mystery to which humanity has not yet found the key. I never laughed at presentiments in my life, because I have had strange ones of my own. Sympathies, I believe, exist (for instance, between far-distant, long-absent, wholly estranged relatives asserting, notwithstanding their alienation, the unity of the source to which each traces his origin) whose workings baffle mortal comprehension. And signs, for aught we know, may be but the sympathies of Nature with man.
When I was a little girl, only six years old, I one night heard Bessie Leaven say to Martha Abbot that she had been dreaming about a little child; and that to dream of children was a sure sign of trouble, either to one’s self or one’s kin. The saying might have worn out of my memory, had not a circumstance immediately followed which served indelibly to fix it there. The next day Bessie was sent for home to the deathbed of her little sister.
Of late I had often recalled this saying and this incident; for during the past week scarcely a night had gone over my couch that had not brought with it a dream of an infant, which I sometimes hushed in my arms, sometimes dandled on my knee, sometimes watched playing with daisies on a lawn, or again, dabbling its hands in running water. It was a wailing child this night, and a laughing one the next: now it nestled close to me, and now it ran from me; but whatever mood the apparition evinced, whatever aspect it wore, it failed not for seven successive nights to meet me the moment I entered the land of slumber.
I did not like this iteration of one idea—this strange recurrence of one image, and I grew nervous as bedtime approached and the hour of the vision drew near. It was from companionship with this baby-phantom I had been roused on that moonlight night when I heard the cry; and it was on the afternoon of the day following I was summoned downstairs by a message that some one wanted me in Mrs. Fairfax’s room. On repairing thither, I found a man waiting for me, having the appearance of a gentleman’s servant: he was dressed in deep mourning, and the hat he held in his hand was surrounded with a crape band.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Premonitions, deep connections between individuals (sympathies), and omens (signs) are all strange phenomena. Together, they form a mystery that humanity hasn't yet solved. I've always taken premonitions seriously because I've experienced unusual ones myself. I believe sympathies exist, such as between distant relatives who are completely estranged but still connected by their shared ancestry in ways we can't fully grasp. Perhaps signs are simply nature's way of empathizing with humans. When I was just six years old, I remember hearing Bessie Leaven tell Martha Abbot that dreaming of a child was a definite predictor of trouble for the dreamer or their family. That comment might have faded from my memory if an event hadn't immediately occurred that permanently embedded it there. The very next day, Bessie was called home because her younger sister was dying. Recently, I've often recalled this saying and incident, especially since the past week brought nightly dreams of an infant. In these dreams, I would sometimes cradle the baby, sometimes bounce it on my knee, watch it playing with flowers on the grass, or splashing in water. One night the child cried, the next it laughed; sometimes it cuddled close, other times it ran away. But regardless of the apparition's mood or appearance, it appeared to me for seven consecutive nights as soon as I entered sleep. This constant repetition of the same idea, this strange reappearance of one image, bothered me, making me anxious as bedtime and the hour of the vision approached. It was this dream-baby companion I was awakened from on the moonlit night when I heard the cry. The following afternoon, I was called downstairs because someone wanted to see me in Mrs. Fairfax's room. Upon arriving, I found a man waiting, who seemed to be a gentleman's servant. He was dressed entirely in black, and the hat he held had a mourning band around it.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Premonitions are peculiar things, as are feelings of sympathy and various signs; together, they form a riddle that humankind has yet to solve. I have never ridiculed premonitions because I’ve experienced odd ones myself. I’m convinced that sympathies truly exist—such as those between distant and estranged relatives, who, despite their separation, still demonstrate a deep connection through their common origin. These sympathetic bonds often elude human understanding. Signs might simply be ways that Nature shows its sympathy for humanity. When I was a young girl of six, I overheard Bessie Leaven tell Martha Abbot she dreamt about a child, saying that such a dream was a sure omen of trouble, either for oneself or one’s family. Normally, I might have forgotten this comment, if not for the shocking event that immediately followed: Bessie was called home the next day to be with her dying little sister. Recently, I kept remembering that statement and what happened afterwards, because nearly every night that past week, I had dreamed of an infant—sometimes soothing it, sometimes playing with it, sometimes watching it among flowers, or seeing it by the water. On some nights it cried, on others it laughed; sometimes it clung to me, sometimes it tried to get away, but for seven nights straight, as soon as I fell asleep, this vision appeared. I became uneasy with this repeated dream and grew anxious as nighttime approached. It was from such a dream that I awoke on a moonlit night when I heard a cry—then, the next day, I was called to Mrs. Fairfax’s room. There, I met a man who looked like a gentleman’s servant, dressed in mourning, holding a hat with a black band around it.

events.title: Tragic News from Gateshead and a Summons
detailed_summary: The visitor introduces himself as Robert Leaven, formerly a coachman for Mrs. Reed at Gateshead, whom Jane faintly recalls.
Jane remembers him and asks after Bessie, his wife, who Robert reports is well and has recently had their third child.
When Jane inquires about the Reed family, Robert regretfully informs her they are in great trouble.
He reveals that Mr. John Reed died a week prior in London.
Robert elaborates on John Reed's dissolute life, his ruin of health and fortune, his debts, jail time, and his mother's repeated assistance.
He recounts John's recent desperate demand for money from his mother and his subsequent shocking death, rumored to be suicide.
The news of John's death and its manner caused Mrs. Reed, already in poor health and stressed by financial woes, to suffer a stroke.
Mrs. Reed was speechless for three days, then began trying to say Jane's name, eventually clearly asking for Jane Eyre to be brought to her.
Bessie, unsure of Mrs. Reed's lucidity but insistent, convinced the Reed sisters to send for Jane.
Robert requests Jane to prepare to accompany him back to Gateshead the next morning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I daresay you hardly remember me, Miss,” he said, rising as I entered; “but my name is Leaven: I lived coachman with Mrs. Reed when you were at Gateshead, eight or nine years since, and I live there still.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I left Gateshead yesterday: and if you can get ready, Miss, I should like to take you back with me early to-morrow morning.”

events.text_segment:
“I daresay you hardly remember me, Miss,” he said, rising as I entered; “but my name is Leaven: I lived coachman with Mrs. Reed when you were at Gateshead, eight or nine years since, and I live there still.”
“Oh, Robert! how do you do? I remember you very well: you used to give me a ride sometimes on Miss Georgiana’s bay pony. And how is Bessie? You are married to Bessie?”
“Yes, Miss: my wife is very hearty, thank you; she brought me another little one about two months since—we have three now—and both mother and child are thriving.”
“And are the family well at the house, Robert?”
“I am sorry I can’t give you better news of them, Miss: they are very badly at present—in great trouble.”
“I hope no one is dead,” I said, glancing at his black dress. He too looked down at the crape round his hat and replied—
“Mr. John died yesterday was a week, at his chambers in London.”
“Mr. John?”
“Yes.”
“And how does his mother bear it?”
“Why, you see, Miss Eyre, it is not a common mishap: his life has been very wild: these last three years he gave himself up to strange ways, and his death was shocking.”
“I heard from Bessie he was not doing well.”
“Doing well! He could not do worse: he ruined his health and his estate amongst the worst men and the worst women. He got into debt and into jail: his mother helped him out twice, but as soon as he was free he returned to his old companions and habits. His head was not strong: the knaves he lived amongst fooled him beyond anything I ever heard. He came down to Gateshead about three weeks ago and wanted missis to give up all to him. Missis refused: her means have long been much reduced by his extravagance; so he went back again, and the next news was that he was dead. How he died, God knows!—they say he killed himself.”
I was silent: the tidings were frightful. Robert Leaven resumed—
“Missis had been out of health herself for some time: she had got very stout, but was not strong with it; and the loss of money and fear of poverty were quite breaking her down. The information about Mr. John’s death and the manner of it came too suddenly: it brought on a stroke. She was three days without speaking; but last Tuesday she seemed rather better: she appeared as if she wanted to say something, and kept making signs to my wife and mumbling. It was only yesterday morning, however, that Bessie understood she was pronouncing your name; and at last she made out the words, ‘Bring Jane—fetch Jane Eyre: I want to speak to her.’ Bessie is not sure whether she is in her right mind, or means anything by the words; but she told Miss Reed and Miss Georgiana, and advised them to send for you. The young ladies put it off at first; but their mother grew so restless, and said, ‘Jane, Jane,’ so many times, that at last they consented. I left Gateshead yesterday: and if you can get ready, Miss, I should like to take you back with me early to-morrow morning.”

He stood as I entered and said, “You probably don’t remember me, Miss, but my name is Leaven. I was the coachman for Mrs. Reed when you lived at Gateshead eight or nine years ago, and I still work there.”

“Oh, Robert! How are you? I do remember you—you used to let me ride Miss Georgiana’s pony sometimes. And how is Bessie? Aren’t you married to her now?”

“Yes, Miss. Bessie and I are married, thank you. She’s doing well and gave birth to our third child about two months ago; mother and baby are both healthy.”

“How is the family at the house, Robert?”

“I’m sorry, Miss, but they are not doing well right now—they’re having serious troubles.”

“Is anyone dead?” I asked, noticing his mourning attire. He, too, looked down at the black ribbon on his hat and replied, “Mr. John died last week in his rooms in London.”

“Mr. John?”

“Yes.”

“How is his mother coping?”

“Well, Miss Eyre, it’s really a terrible situation. Mr. John lived recklessly for the past three years, and his death was terrible.”

“Bessie told me he was not doing well.”

“He couldn’t have been worse. He ruined his health and wasted his inheritance with bad company. He ended up in debt and even jail; his mother bailed him out twice. As soon as he was free, he went back to his old habits. He wasn’t mentally strong, and the people around him took advantage of him. About three weeks ago, he came to Gateshead and demanded that his mother hand over everything to him. She refused, especially as her finances were already drained by his behavior. He left, and soon after came the news that he had died. Apparently, he took his own life.”

I was shocked by these tragic events, and Robert continued: “Mrs. Reed herself has been in poor health; she had gained weight but not strength. The stress of money troubles and fear of poverty were wearing her down. Learning about Mr. John's death and how it happened was too much and brought on a stroke. She couldn't speak for three days; but by Tuesday, she seemed a little better and kept trying to say something, gesturing to my wife and mumbling. Yesterday, Bessie realized she was trying to say your name. Eventually Bessie understood her saying, ‘Bring Jane—fetch Jane Eyre: I want to speak to her.’ Bessie is not sure if she is fully aware or truly means it, but she told Miss Reed and Miss Georgiana and suggested you be sent for. At first, the young ladies delayed, but their mother became so uneasy and repeated your name so many times that they ended up agreeing. I left Gateshead yesterday, Miss, and if you can be ready, I’d like to take you back with me early tomorrow morning.”

events.title: Requesting Leave and a Complex Farewell with Mr. Rochester
detailed_summary: Jane agrees to go and seeks Mr. Rochester to request leave, finding him playing billiards with Miss Ingram and other guests.
Jane approaches Mr. Rochester, enduring a haughty, dismissive look from Miss Ingram.
Mr. Rochester follows Jane from the room, making a strange face.
Jane requests leave to visit a sick lady, Mrs. Reed at Gateshead, revealing Mrs. Reed is her aunt by marriage.
Mr. Rochester expresses surprise, recalling Jane previously claimed to have no relations; Jane clarifies she has none who would acknowledge her and that Mrs. Reed had cast her off.
He mentions hearing of the Reeds, including the reprobate John and the beautiful Georgiana.
Jane confirms John's death by suicide and its impact on his mother.
Mr. Rochester initially questions the utility of her journey but eventually consents, asking her to promise to return and not stay longer than a week, a promise Jane hesitates to make fully.
He inquires about her travel arrangements and finances, noting he hasn't paid her salary yet.

Discovering she has only five shillings, he offers her fifty pounds, which she declines, accepting only the ten pounds due to her after some playful haggling where he initially tries to give her less to ensure her return.
Jane raises the matter of Adèle needing to go to school due to Mr. Rochester's impending marriage.
Mr. Rochester reacts with a bizarre expression, agrees Adèle must go to school, and sarcastically suggests Jane must go to the devil.
Jane states she must find another situation; Rochester forbids her to advertise, promising to find a position for her himself.
He insists she trusts him with this task, provided she and Adèle are gone before his bride arrives.
Their farewell is somewhat strained and awkward, with Rochester finding Jane's simple 'Farewell' too cold, before he abruptly leaves at the dinner bell.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Yes, Robert, I shall be ready: it seems to me that I ought to go.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The dinner-bell rang, and suddenly away he bolted, without another syllable: I saw him no more during the day, and was off before he had risen in the morning.

events.text_segment:
“Yes, Robert, I shall be ready: it seems to me that I ought to go.”
“I think so too, Miss. Bessie said she was sure you would not refuse: but I suppose you will have to ask leave before you can get off?”
“Yes; and I will do it now;” and having directed him to the servants’ hall, and recommended him to the care of John’s wife, and the attentions of John himself, I went in search of Mr. Rochester.
He was not in any of the lower rooms; he was not in the yard, the stables, or the grounds. I asked Mrs. Fairfax if she had seen him;—yes: she believed he was playing billiards with Miss Ingram. To the billiard-room I hastened: the click of balls and the hum of voices resounded thence; Mr. Rochester, Miss Ingram, the two Misses Eshton, and their admirers, were all busied in the game. It required some courage to disturb so interesting a party; my errand, however, was one I could not defer, so I approached the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side. She turned as I drew near, and looked at me haughtily: her eyes seemed to demand, “What can the creeping creature want now?” and when I said, in a low voice, “Mr. Rochester,” she made a movement as if tempted to order me away. I remember her appearance at the moment—it was very graceful and very striking: she wore a morning robe of sky-blue crape; a gauzy azure scarf was twisted in her hair. She had been all animation with the game, and irritated pride did not lower the expression of her haughty lineaments.
“Does that person want you?” she inquired of Mr. Rochester; and Mr. Rochester turned to see who the “person” was. He made a curious grimace—one of his strange and equivocal demonstrations—threw down his cue and followed me from the room.
“Well, Jane?” he said, as he rested his back against the schoolroom door, which he had shut.
“If you please, sir, I want leave of absence for a week or two.”
“What to do?—where to go?”
“To see a sick lady who has sent for me.”
“What sick lady?—where does she live?”
“At Gateshead; in ——shire.”
“-shire? That is a hundred miles off! Who may she be that sends for people to see her that distance?”
“Her name is Reed, sir—Mrs. Reed.”
“Reed of Gateshead? There was a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate.”
“It is his widow, sir.”
“And what have you to do with her? How do you know her?”
“Mr. Reed was my uncle—my mother’s brother.”
“The deuce he was! You never told me that before: you always said you had no relations.”
“None that would own me, sir. Mr. Reed is dead, and his wife cast me off.”
“Why?”
“Because I was poor, and burdensome, and she disliked me.”
“But Reed left children?—you must have cousins? Sir George Lynn was talking of a Reed of Gateshead yesterday, who, he said, was one of the veriest rascals on town; and Ingram was mentioning a Georgiana Reed of the same place, who was much admired for her beauty a season or two ago in London.”
“John Reed is dead, too, sir: he ruined himself and half-ruined his family, and is supposed to have committed suicide. The news so shocked his mother that it brought on an apoplectic attack.”
“And what good can you do her? Nonsense, Jane! I would never think of running a hundred miles to see an old lady who will, perhaps, be dead before you reach her: besides, you say she cast you off.”
“Yes, sir, but that is long ago; and when her circumstances were very different: I could not be easy to neglect her wishes now.”
“How long will you stay?”
“As short a time as possible, sir.”
“Promise me only to stay a week—”
“I had better not pass my word: I might be obliged to break it.”
“At all events you will come back: you will not be induced under any pretext to take up a permanent residence with her?”
“Oh, no! I shall certainly return if all be well.”
“And who goes with you? You don’t travel a hundred miles alone.”
“No, sir, she has sent her coachman.”
“A person to be trusted?”
“Yes, sir, he has lived ten years in the family.”
Mr. Rochester meditated. “When do you wish to go?”
“Early to-morrow morning, sir.”
“Well, you must have some money; you can’t travel without money, and I daresay you have not much: I have given you no salary yet. How much have you in the world, Jane?” he asked, smiling.
I drew out my purse; a meagre thing it was. “Five shillings, sir.” He took the purse, poured the hoard into his palm, and chuckled over it as if its scantiness amused him. Soon he produced his pocket-book: “Here,” said he, offering me a note; it was fifty pounds, and he owed me but fifteen. I told him I had no change.
“I don’t want change; you know that. Take your wages.”
I declined accepting more than was my due. He scowled at first; then, as if recollecting something, he said—
“Right, right! Better not give you all now: you would, perhaps, stay away three months if you had fifty pounds. There are ten; is it not plenty?”
“Yes, sir, but now you owe me five.”
“Come back for it, then; I am your banker for forty pounds.”
“Mr. Rochester, I may as well mention another matter of business to you while I have the opportunity.”
“Matter of business? I am curious to hear it.”
“You have as good as informed me, sir, that you are going shortly to be married?”
“Yes; what then?”
“In that case, sir, Adèle ought to go to school: I am sure you will perceive the necessity of it.”
“To get her out of my bride’s way, who might otherwise walk over her rather too emphatically? There’s sense in the suggestion; not a doubt of it. Adèle, as you say, must go to school; and you, of course, must march straight to—the devil?”
“I hope not, sir; but I must seek another situation somewhere.”
“In course!” he exclaimed, with a twang of voice and a distortion of features equally fantastic and ludicrous. He looked at me some minutes.
“And old Madam Reed, or the Misses, her daughters, will be solicited by you to seek a place, I suppose?”
“No, sir; I am not on such terms with my relatives as would justify me in asking favours of them—but I shall advertise.”
“You shall walk up the pyramids of Egypt!” he growled. “At your peril you advertise! I wish I had only offered you a sovereign instead of ten pounds. Give me back nine pounds, Jane; I’ve a use for it.”
“And so have I, sir,” I returned, putting my hands and my purse behind me. “I could not spare the money on any account.”
“Little niggard!” said he, “refusing me a pecuniary request! Give me five pounds, Jane.”
“Not five shillings, sir; nor five pence.”
“Just let me look at the cash.”
“No, sir; you are not to be trusted.”
“Jane!”
“Sir?”
“Promise me one thing.”
“I’ll promise you anything, sir, that I think I am likely to perform.”
“Not to advertise: and to trust this quest of a situation to me. I’ll find you one in time.”
“I shall be glad so to do, sir, if you, in your turn, will promise that I and Adèle shall be both safe out of the house before your bride enters it.”
“Very well! very well! I’ll pledge my word on it. You go to-morrow, then?”
“Yes, sir; early.”
“Shall you come down to the drawing-room after dinner?”
“No, sir, I must prepare for the journey.”
“Then you and I must bid good-bye for a little while?”
“I suppose so, sir.”
“And how do people perform that ceremony of parting, Jane? Teach me; I’m not quite up to it.”
“They say, Farewell, or any other form they prefer.”
“Then say it.”
“Farewell, Mr. Rochester, for the present.”
“What must I say?”
“The same, if you like, sir.”
“Farewell, Miss Eyre, for the present; is that all?”
“Yes.”
“It seems stingy, to my notions, and dry, and unfriendly. I should like something else: a little addition to the rite. If one shook hands, for instance; but no—that would not content me either. So you’ll do no more than say Farewell, Jane?”
“It is enough, sir: as much good-will may be conveyed in one hearty word as in many.”
“Very likely; but it is blank and cool—‘Farewell.’”
“How long is he going to stand with his back against that door?” I asked myself; “I want to commence my packing.” The dinner-bell rang, and suddenly away he bolted, without another syllable: I saw him no more during the day, and was off before he had risen in the morning.

"Early tomorrow morning."

"You need money—how much do you have? I haven’t paid your salary yet."

I showed him my purse: only five shillings. He laughed, then produced his wallet and offered me a fifty-pound note, though he owed me only fifteen.

I explained I had no change.

"Keep it; take your wages." 

I refused anything above my due. He scowled, then reconsidered. "You’re right. If I give you fifty, you might stay away three months. Here, take ten; isn’t that enough?"

"Yes, sir, but now you owe me five."

"Come back to get it; I’ll be your banker for forty."

"Sir, while I have the chance, let me raise another point of business."

"What is it?"

"If you’re soon to be married, Adèle should go to school."

"You suggest that to keep her from complicating my bride’s life? Sensible. Adèle must indeed go to school. And you’ll need to find another position?"

"Yes, sir; I’ll advertise when the time comes, but I won’t ask my relatives."

"Don’t you dare advertise! I should have given you less money. Give back nine pounds."

"I also need it, sir, and can’t spare it." 

"Stingy girl! How about five pounds?"  

"Not even five shillings, sir."

"Let me see the money, at least."

"No, sir; you’re not to be trusted." 

"Jane!"

"Sir?"

"Promise not to advertise, and to let me find you a new job."

"Gladly, if you promise Adèle and I can safely leave before your bride arrives."

"Agreed. So you go tomorrow?"

"Yes, early."

"Will you come to the drawing room after dinner?"

"No, I must prepare."

"So we say goodbye now?"

"I suppose."

"How do people say goodbye, Jane? Teach me—I’m not skilled in it."

"They say Farewell, or whatever they prefer."

"Then say it."

"Farewell, Mr. Rochester."

"Must I say the same?"

"If you wish, sir."

"Farewell, Miss Eyre. Is that it?"

"Yes."

"It feels meagre and cold. Couldn’t we add more—a handshake, perhaps? But even that’s not enough. Won’t you do more than say farewell, Jane?"

"That’s sufficient, sir; one sincere word conveys all goodwill."

"Perhaps, but it’s so cold—‘Farewell.’"

He lingered by the door as I wondered when I could start packing. Then the dinner-bell rang, and he left suddenly. I didn’t see him again that day, and I was gone before he woke the next morning.

events.title: Arrival at Gateshead Lodge and Warm Reunion with Bessie
detailed_summary: Jane arrives at the lodge at Gateshead in the early evening of May 1st.
The lodge is clean and welcoming, with a bright fire.
Bessie Leaven greets Jane warmly, nursing her youngest child, while her other two children play nearby.
Jane kisses Bessie and inquires about Mrs. Reed's condition.
Bessie confirms Mrs. Reed is alive, more lucid than before, but unlikely to recover, possibly lingering for a week or two, and had been wishing for Jane that morning.
Bessie persuades a tired Jane to rest and have tea, treating her with familiar, motherly care.
Jane feels a rush of nostalgia watching Bessie's bustling activity and her interactions with her children, noting Bessie retains her quick temper and good looks.
Bessie serves Jane tea by the fireside, a gesture reminiscent of childhood treats.

Jane describes her life at Thornfield Hall to Bessie, mentioning Mr. Rochester as rather ugly but a kind gentleman with whom she is content, and details the recent company at the house, which interests Bessie.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I reached the lodge at Gateshead about five o’clock in the afternoon of the first of May: I stepped in there before going up to the hall.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In such conversation an hour was soon gone: Bessie restored to me my bonnet, &c., and, accompanied by her, I quitted the lodge for the hall.

events.text_segment:
I reached the lodge at Gateshead about five o’clock in the afternoon of the first of May: I stepped in there before going up to the hall. It was very clean and neat: the ornamental windows were hung with little white curtains; the floor was spotless; the grate and fire-irons were burnished bright, and the fire burnt clear. Bessie sat on the hearth, nursing her last-born, and Robert and his sister played quietly in a corner.
“Bless you!—I knew you would come!” exclaimed Mrs. Leaven, as I entered.
“Yes, Bessie,” said I, after I had kissed her; “and I trust I am not too late. How is Mrs. Reed?—Alive still, I hope.”
“Yes, she is alive; and more sensible and collected than she was. The doctor says she may linger a week or two yet; but he hardly thinks she will finally recover.”
“Has she mentioned me lately?”
“She was talking of you only this morning, and wishing you would come, but she is sleeping now, or was ten minutes ago, when I was up at the house. She generally lies in a kind of lethargy all the afternoon, and wakes up about six or seven. Will you rest yourself here an hour, Miss, and then I will go up with you?”
Robert here entered, and Bessie laid her sleeping child in the cradle and went to welcome him: afterwards she insisted on my taking off my bonnet and having some tea; for she said I looked pale and tired. I was glad to accept her hospitality; and I submitted to be relieved of my travelling garb just as passively as I used to let her undress me when a child.
Old times crowded fast back on me as I watched her bustling about—setting out the tea-tray with her best china, cutting bread and butter, toasting a tea-cake, and, between whiles, giving little Robert or Jane an occasional tap or push, just as she used to give me in former days. Bessie had retained her quick temper as well as her light foot and good looks.
Tea ready, I was going to approach the table; but she desired me to sit still, quite in her old peremptory tones. I must be served at the fireside, she said; and she placed before me a little round stand with my cup and a plate of toast, absolutely as she used to accommodate me with some privately purloined dainty on a nursery chair: and I smiled and obeyed her as in bygone days.
She wanted to know if I was happy at Thornfield Hall, and what sort of a person the mistress was; and when I told her there was only a master, whether he was a nice gentleman, and if I liked him. I told her he was rather an ugly man, but quite a gentleman; and that he treated me kindly, and I was content. Then I went on to describe to her the gay company that had lately been staying at the house; and to these details Bessie listened with interest: they were precisely of the kind she relished.
In such conversation an hour was soon gone: Bessie restored to me my bonnet, &c., and, accompanied by her, I quitted the lodge for the hall.

Bessie was seated by the hearth, cradling her youngest child, while Robert and his sister played quietly in a corner. "Bless you! I just knew you'd arrive!" Mrs. Leaven exclaimed as I stepped inside. "Yes, Bessie," I replied after kissing her, "and I hope I haven't come too late. How is Mrs. Reed? I hope she's still alive." "Yes, she is still alive, and more lucid and composed than before. The doctor believes she might last another week or two, but he doesn't anticipate her eventual recovery." "Has she mentioned me recently?" "She was discussing you just this morning and wishing you would come, but she's asleep now, or at least she was ten minutes ago when I visited the house.
