events.title: Return to Gateshead Hall: Altered Cousins and Jane's New Resolve
detailed_summary: Accompanied by Bessie, Jane walks to Gateshead Hall, reflecting on her departure nine years earlier from a 'hostile roof' with a bitter heart.
She acknowledges her personal growth since then: increased self-trust, healed emotional wounds, and extinguished resentment, though her prospects remain uncertain.
Jane enters the breakfast-room, finding the furniture unchanged, even recognizing specific books on shelves.
She encounters Eliza and Georgiana Reed, who are profoundly altered.
Eliza is very tall, thin, with a sallow complexion and severe, ascetic appearance, dressed plainly in black with a crucifix.
Georgiana is now a plump, fair young woman with languishing blue eyes and ringlets, also dressed in black but in a more fashionable, flowing style.
Jane observes traits of Mrs. Reed in both daughters: Eliza's eye and Georgiana's jawline.
Both sisters rise and greet Jane coolly as 'Miss Eyre'; Eliza is abrupt and quickly disengages, while Georgiana makes superficial small talk, scrutinizing Jane's appearance.
Jane finds herself surprisingly unmoved by their coldness, her recent emotional experiences having fortified her.
When Jane inquires about Mrs. Reed, Georgiana expresses doubt about Jane seeing her that night, and Eliza states their mother dislikes evening disturbances.
Asserting her purpose, Jane states Mrs. Reed wished to see her and decides to ask Bessie to check if Mrs. Reed will receive her.
Reflecting on her past tendency to shrink from arrogance, Jane now feels a new resolve to stay until Mrs. Reed is better or dead, regardless of her cousins' attitudes.
She makes arrangements with the housekeeper for a room, indicating she might stay for a week or two.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was also accompanied by her that I had, nearly nine years ago, walked down the path I was now ascending.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I addressed the housekeeper; asked her to show me a room, told her I should probably be a visitor here for a week or two, had my trunk conveyed to my chamber, and followed it thither myself: I met Bessie on the landing.

events.text_segment:
It was also accompanied by her that I had, nearly nine years ago, walked down the path I was now ascending. On a dark, misty, raw morning in January, I had left a hostile roof with a desperate and embittered heart—a sense of outlawry and almost of reprobation—to seek the chilly harbourage of Lowood: that bourne so far away and unexplored. The same hostile roof now again rose before me: my prospects were doubtful yet; and I had yet an aching heart. I still felt as a wanderer on the face of the earth; but I experienced firmer trust in myself and my own powers, and less withering dread of oppression. The gaping wound of my wrongs, too, was now quite healed; and the flame of resentment extinguished.
“You shall go into the breakfast-room first,” said Bessie, as she preceded me through the hall; “the young ladies will be there.”
In another moment I was within that apartment. There was every article of furniture looking just as it did on the morning I was first introduced to Mr. Brocklehurst: the very rug he had stood upon still covered the hearth. Glancing at the bookcases, I thought I could distinguish the two volumes of Bewick’s British Birds occupying their old place on the third shelf, and Gulliver’s Travels and the Arabian Nights ranged just above. The inanimate objects were not changed; but the living things had altered past recognition.
Two young ladies appeared before me; one very tall, almost as tall as Miss Ingram—very thin too, with a sallow face and severe mien. There was something ascetic in her look, which was augmented by the extreme plainness of a straight-skirted, black, stuff dress, a starched linen collar, hair combed away from the temples, and the nun-like ornament of a string of ebony beads and a crucifix. This I felt sure was Eliza, though I could trace little resemblance to her former self in that elongated and colourless visage.
The other was as certainly Georgiana: but not the Georgiana I remembered—the slim and fairy-like girl of eleven. This was a full-blown, very plump damsel, fair as waxwork, with handsome and regular features, languishing blue eyes, and ringleted yellow hair. The hue of her dress was black too; but its fashion was so different from her sister’s—so much more flowing and becoming—it looked as stylish as the other’s looked puritanical.
In each of the sisters there was one trait of the mother—and only one; the thin and pallid elder daughter had her parent’s Cairngorm eye: the blooming and luxuriant younger girl had her contour of jaw and chin—perhaps a little softened, but still imparting an indescribable hardness to the countenance otherwise so voluptuous and buxom.
Both ladies, as I advanced, rose to welcome me, and both addressed me by the name of “Miss Eyre.” Eliza’s greeting was delivered in a short, abrupt voice, without a smile; and then she sat down again, fixed her eyes on the fire, and seemed to forget me. Georgiana added to her “How d’ye do?” several commonplaces about my journey, the weather, and so on, uttered in rather a drawling tone: and accompanied by sundry side-glances that measured me from head to foot—now traversing the folds of my drab merino pelisse, and now lingering on the plain trimming of my cottage bonnet. Young ladies have a remarkable way of letting you know that they think you a “quiz” without actually saying the words. A certain superciliousness of look, coolness of manner, nonchalance of tone, express fully their sentiments on the point, without committing them by any positive rudeness in word or deed.
A sneer, however, whether covert or open, had now no longer that power over me it once possessed: as I sat between my cousins, I was surprised to find how easy I felt under the total neglect of the one and the semi-sarcastic attentions of the other—Eliza did not mortify, nor Georgiana ruffle me. The fact was, I had other things to think about; within the last few months feelings had been stirred in me so much more potent than any they could raise—pains and pleasures so much more acute and exquisite had been excited than any it was in their power to inflict or bestow—that their airs gave me no concern either for good or bad.
“How is Mrs. Reed?” I asked soon, looking calmly at Georgiana, who thought fit to bridle at the direct address, as if it were an unexpected liberty.
“Mrs. Reed? Ah! mama, you mean; she is extremely poorly: I doubt if you can see her to-night.”
“If,” said I, “you would just step upstairs and tell her I am come, I should be much obliged to you.”
Georgiana almost started, and she opened her blue eyes wild and wide. “I know she had a particular wish to see me,” I added, “and I would not defer attending to her desire longer than is absolutely necessary.”
“Mama dislikes being disturbed in an evening,” remarked Eliza. I soon rose, quietly took off my bonnet and gloves, uninvited, and said I would just step out to Bessie—who was, I dared say, in the kitchen—and ask her to ascertain whether Mrs. Reed was disposed to receive me or not to-night. I went, and having found Bessie and despatched her on my errand, I proceeded to take further measures. It had heretofore been my habit always to shrink from arrogance: received as I had been to-day, I should, a year ago, have resolved to quit Gateshead the very next morning; now, it was disclosed to me all at once that that would be a foolish plan. I had taken a journey of a hundred miles to see my aunt, and I must stay with her till she was better—or dead: as to her daughters’ pride or folly, I must put it on one side, make myself independent of it. So I addressed the housekeeper; asked her to show me a room, told her I should probably be a visitor here for a week or two, had my trunk conveyed to my chamber, and followed it thither myself: I met Bessie on the landing.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I ascended the path accompanied by Bessie, just as I had walked down it with her nearly nine years prior. That previous occasion was a dark, damp, and biting January morning when I left a hostile home with a desperate and bitter heart, feeling like an outcast, almost damned, bound for the cold refuge of Lowood, a distant and unfamiliar place. Now, that same unwelcoming house appeared before me again; my future remained uncertain, and my heart still ached. Although I still felt like a wanderer, I had gained greater confidence in myself and my abilities, and my fear of hardship was less overwhelming. The deep wound from the injustices I had suffered was now entirely healed, and my anger had faded away. Bessie suggested, "You should enter the breakfast room first," as she led me through the hall. Moments later, I was inside. Every piece of furniture appeared exactly as it had the morning Mr. Brocklehurst was first introduced to me; the same rug he had stood on still lay by the fireplace. Looking at the bookshelves, I believed I could make out the two volumes of Bewick's British Birds still in their old spot on the third shelf, with Gulliver's Travels and the Arabian Nights positioned directly above them. The inanimate items were unchanged, but the people were transformed beyond recognition. Two young women stood before me. One was exceptionally tall, nearly as tall as Miss Ingram, and very thin, with a pale complexion and a stern expression. Her appearance had an ascetic quality, emphasized by her exceedingly plain, straight-cut black wool dress, a stiff linen collar, hair pulled back from her temples, and a simple, nun-like accessory: a string of black beads with a crucifix. I was certain this was Eliza, though I saw little likeness to the person she used to be in her long, pallid face. The other was undoubtedly Georgiana, but she was not the Georgiana I recalled – the slender, delicate girl of eleven. This woman was fully developed and quite plump, with skin as fair as wax. She possessed attractive, well-proportioned features, dreamy blue eyes, and golden hair styled in ringlets. Her dress was also black, but its style contrasted sharply with her sister's; it was much more flowing and flattering, appearing fashionable compared to Eliza's puritanical attire. Each sister displayed just one characteristic inherited from their mother. The thin, pale older daughter had her mother's distinct, stone-like eyes (Cairngorm eye). The vibrant and well-developed younger girl had her mother's jaw and chin shape, possibly slightly softened, but still adding a subtle, hard quality to a face that was otherwise so sensuous and full-bodied. As I came closer, both ladies stood up to greet me and addressed me as "Miss Eyre." Eliza's welcome was brief and sharp, delivered without a smile, after which she resumed her seat, fixed her gaze on the fire, and appeared to ignore me. Georgiana followed her "How do you do?" with a few conventional remarks about my journey, the weather, etc., spoken in a somewhat drawling manner. She also cast several side-long glances that scrutinized me from head to toe, examining the folds of my dull brown wool coat and lingering on the simple trim of my simple bonnet. Young ladies possess a remarkable knack for conveying that they consider you eccentric or odd without explicitly stating it. A certain haughtiness in their look, a cool demeanor, and an indifferent tone effectively communicate their feelings on the matter, without resorting to overt verbal or behavioral rudeness. However, neither hidden nor overt contempt held the sway over me it once did. Sitting between my cousins, I was surprised by how comfortable I felt despite the complete disregard from one and the slightly mocking attention from the other. Eliza did not humiliate me, nor did Georgiana irritate me. The truth was, my mind was occupied with other matters. In recent months, emotions far more powerful than any they could evoke had been stirred within me; I had experienced pains and joys far more intense and profound than anything they were capable of inflicting or giving. Consequently, their behavior did not affect me in any way, positive or negative. Soon, I calmly asked Georgiana, "How is Mrs. Reed?" She seemed to react stiffly to being addressed directly, as if it were an inappropriate familiarity. "Mrs. Reed? Oh, you mean Mama," she replied, "She is very unwell. I doubt you can see her tonight." I said, "If you wouldn't mind going upstairs just to inform her of my arrival, I would be very grateful." Georgiana looked visibly startled, her blue eyes opening wide in surprise. "I am aware she specifically wanted to see me," I explained, "and I don't wish to postpone fulfilling her wish any longer than absolutely necessary." Eliza interjected, "Mama doesn't like to be disturbed in the evening." Without waiting for permission, I promptly stood up, calmly removed my bonnet and gloves, and stated that I would go find Bessie, who I assumed was in the kitchen, and ask her to find out if Mrs. Reed was willing to see me that evening. I went, located Bessie, and sent her on my request. I then decided on my next steps. Previously, I would always recoil from arrogant behavior. Having been treated as I was today, a year ago I would have decided to leave Gateshead the very next morning. Now, it suddenly became clear to me that such a plan would be unwise. I had traveled a hundred miles to see my aunt, and I needed to remain with her until she recovered or passed away. As for her daughters' arrogance or foolishness, I had to disregard it and ensure I wasn't affected by it. Therefore, I spoke to the housekeeper, asked her to show me a room, informed her I would likely be staying for one or two weeks, had my trunk taken to my bedroom, and followed it myself. I encountered Bessie on the stairs.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Nearly nine years earlier, I had walked this same path with her, but at that time I was leaving behind an unwelcoming home, feeling desperate and outcast, searching for uncertain refuge at Lowood—a place distant and unknown to me. Now, as I returned, the same unfriendly house appeared before me and my future still seemed unclear, with my heart still aching. However, I was stronger now, with more confidence in myself and less fear of being oppressed. The pain of past injustices had finally healed, and my anger had faded away.

Bessie led me into the breakfast-room, saying the young ladies would be there. I noticed everything looked just as it had when I first met Mr. Brocklehurst—including the rug by the fireplace. The books—Bewick’s British Birds, Gulliver’s Travels, and Arabian Nights—were all in their usual places. The furniture hadn’t changed, but the people had.

Two young women greeted me: the first, very tall and thin with a pale, severe face—dressed plainly in a black dress and wearing a crucifix—was unmistakably Eliza, though she looked little like the girl I remembered. The second was clearly Georgiana, but she had changed from the slender girl I once knew into a plump, fair young woman, strikingly pretty with blue eyes and yellow curls. Both wore black, but Georgiana’s stylish dress contrasted sharply with Eliza’s severe attire.

Each sister bore a single feature from their mother: Eliza had her mother’s eyes, and Georgiana had inherited the shape of her jaw and chin, which gave an underlying hardness to her otherwise soft appearance.

As I entered, both women stood and greeted me as “Miss Eyre.” Eliza's welcome was brief and cold, after which she returned to the fire, ignoring me. Georgiana offered a few polite remarks about my journey and the weather, but her tone was lazy, and she surveyed me with critical glances, assessing my simple clothing. Young women have a talent for expressing disdain without overt rudeness—through their looks, manner, and tone they make their opinions clear.

Yet their coldness and condescension no longer affected me as it once did. I was surprised at how little I cared about their neglect or thinly veiled criticism. My recent experiences had made me feel deeper pain and greater happiness than they could ever give. Their attitudes simply didn’t matter to me anymore.

I soon asked after Mrs. Reed, directing my question calmly to Georgiana, who seemed surprised by my straightforwardness. She told me her mother was quite unwell and doubted I could see her that night. I insisted, asking her kindly to inform Mrs. Reed of my arrival, explaining that I didn’t want to delay fulfilling my aunt’s wish to see me. Both sisters were surprised, but Eliza only remarked that their mother disliked being disturbed in the evening.

Uninvited, I quietly removed my bonnet and gloves and told them I would ask Bessie to check if Mrs. Reed could receive me. I found Bessie in the kitchen and sent her on my errand. Previously, I would have felt intimidated and perhaps would have left the next day—but now I realized that would be silly. I had traveled a hundred miles to see my aunt and would stay until she was better or had passed away. I resolved to ignore her daughters’ pride and folly.

I spoke to the housekeeper, asked to be shown a room, told her I’d likely stay a week or two, and had my trunk brought to my chamber. On my way, I met Bessie on the landing.

events.title: First Encounter with the Dying Mrs. Reed: Unchanged Animosity and Troubled Ravings
detailed_summary: Bessie meets Jane on the landing, informing her that Mrs. Reed is awake and has been told of Jane's arrival.
Jane proceeds to Mrs. Reed's familiar bedroom, a place associated with past punishments, now with a shaded light.
She approaches the bed, recognizing Mrs. Reed's stern face, and feels a desire for reconciliation, devoid of her past bitterness and hate.
Jane kisses Mrs. Reed, who recognizes her and asks if she is Jane Eyre.
Jane addresses her as 'Aunt Reed,' breaking a childhood vow, but Mrs. Reed withdraws her hand and makes a cold remark, her antipathy unchanged.
Jane experiences a sequence of pain, anger, and then a strong determination to manage the situation and Mrs. Reed.
Mrs. Reed confirms Jane can stay, stating she has matters to discuss but is currently too weak to recall them.
Her demeanor then shifts to agitation as she laments the trouble Jane caused as a child, her incomprehensible nature, and expresses a shocking wish that Jane had died at Lowood.
Mrs. Reed rants about her late husband's favoritism towards Jane and his sister (Jane's mother), her own dislike for Jane from infancy, and her children's aversion to Jane.
She also complains bitterly about her son John's ruinous behavior and financial demands, expressing her shame and distress.
Bessie, present on the other side of the bed, suggests Jane leave, noting Mrs. Reed often talks this way at night.
Mrs. Reed stops Jane, speaking of John threatening her with death and her disturbing dreams, and anxiously questions how to obtain money.
Bessie with difficulty persuades Mrs. Reed to take a sedative, after which Mrs. Reed calms and dozes off, and Jane leaves.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Missis is awake,” said she; “I have told her you are here: come and let us see if she will know you.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Soon after, Mrs. Reed grew more composed, and sank into a dozing state. I then left her.

events.text_segment:
“Missis is awake,” said she; “I have told her you are here: come and let us see if she will know you.”
I did not need to be guided to the well-known room, to which I had so often been summoned for chastisement or reprimand in former days. I hastened before Bessie; I softly opened the door: a shaded light stood on the table, for it was now getting dark. There was the great four-post bed with amber hangings as of old; there the toilet-table, the armchair, and the footstool, at which I had a hundred times been sentenced to kneel, to ask pardon for offences by me uncommitted. I looked into a certain corner near, half-expecting to see the slim outline of a once dreaded switch which used to lurk there, waiting to leap out imp-like and lace my quivering palm or shrinking neck. I approached the bed; I opened the curtains and leant over the high-piled pillows.
Well did I remember Mrs. Reed’s face, and I eagerly sought the familiar image. It is a happy thing that time quells the longings of vengeance and hushes the promptings of rage and aversion. I had left this woman in bitterness and hate, and I came back to her now with no other emotion than a sort of ruth for her great sufferings, and a strong yearning to forget and forgive all injuries—to be reconciled and clasp hands in amity.
The well-known face was there: stern, relentless as ever—there was that peculiar eye which nothing could melt, and the somewhat raised, imperious, despotic eyebrow. How often had it lowered on me menace and hate! and how the recollection of childhood’s terrors and sorrows revived as I traced its harsh line now! And yet I stooped down and kissed her: she looked at me.
“Is this Jane Eyre?” she said.
“Yes, Aunt Reed. How are you, dear aunt?”
I had once vowed that I would never call her aunt again: I thought it no sin to forget and break that vow now. My fingers had fastened on her hand which lay outside the sheet: had she pressed mine kindly, I should at that moment have experienced true pleasure. But unimpressionable natures are not so soon softened, nor are natural antipathies so readily eradicated. Mrs. Reed took her hand away, and, turning her face rather from me, she remarked that the night was warm. Again she regarded me so icily, I felt at once that her opinion of me—her feeling towards me—was unchanged and unchangeable. I knew by her stony eye—opaque to tenderness, indissoluble to tears—that she was resolved to consider me bad to the last; because to believe me good would give her no generous pleasure: only a sense of mortification.
I felt pain, and then I felt ire; and then I felt a determination to subdue her—to be her mistress in spite both of her nature and her will. My tears had risen, just as in childhood: I ordered them back to their source. I brought a chair to the bed-head: I sat down and leaned over the pillow.
“You sent for me,” I said, “and I am here; and it is my intention to stay till I see how you get on.”
“Oh, of course! You have seen my daughters?”
“Yes.”
“Well, you may tell them I wish you to stay till I can talk some things over with you I have on my mind: to-night it is too late, and I have a difficulty in recalling them. But there was something I wished to say—let me see—”
The wandering look and changed utterance told what wreck had taken place in her once vigorous frame. Turning restlessly, she drew the bedclothes round her; my elbow, resting on a corner of the quilt, fixed it down: she was at once irritated.
“Sit up!” said she; “don’t annoy me with holding the clothes fast. Are you Jane Eyre?”
“I am Jane Eyre.”
“I have had more trouble with that child than any one would believe. Such a burden to be left on my hands—and so much annoyance as she caused me, daily and hourly, with her incomprehensible disposition, and her sudden starts of temper, and her continual, unnatural watchings of one’s movements! I declare she talked to me once like something mad, or like a fiend—no child ever spoke or looked as she did; I was glad to get her away from the house. What did they do with her at Lowood? The fever broke out there, and many of the pupils died. She, however, did not die: but I said she did—I wish she had died!”
“A strange wish, Mrs. Reed; why do you hate her so?”
“I had a dislike to her mother always; for she was my husband’s only sister, and a great favourite with him: he opposed the family’s disowning her when she made her low marriage; and when news came of her death, he wept like a simpleton. He would send for the baby; though I entreated him rather to put it out to nurse and pay for its maintenance. I hated it the first time I set my eyes on it—a sickly, whining, pining thing! It would wail in its cradle all night long—not screaming heartily like any other child, but whimpering and moaning. Reed pitied it; and he used to nurse it and notice it as if it had been his own: more, indeed, than he ever noticed his own at that age. He would try to make my children friendly to the little beggar: the darlings could not bear it, and he was angry with them when they showed their dislike. In his last illness, he had it brought continually to his bedside; and but an hour before he died, he bound me by vow to keep the creature. I would as soon have been charged with a pauper brat out of a workhouse: but he was weak, naturally weak. John does not at all resemble his father, and I am glad of it: John is like me and like my brothers—he is quite a Gibson. Oh, I wish he would cease tormenting me with letters for money! I have no more money to give him: we are getting poor. I must send away half the servants and shut up part of the house; or let it off. I can never submit to do that—yet how are we to get on? Two-thirds of my income goes in paying the interest of mortgages. John gambles dreadfully, and always loses—poor boy! He is beset by sharpers: John is sunk and degraded—his look is frightful—I feel ashamed for him when I see him.”
She was getting much excited. “I think I had better leave her now,” said I to Bessie, who stood on the other side of the bed.
“Perhaps you had, Miss: but she often talks in this way towards night—in the morning she is calmer.”
I rose. “Stop!” exclaimed Mrs. Reed, “there is another thing I wished to say. He threatens me—he continually threatens me with his own death, or mine: and I dream sometimes that I see him laid out with a great wound in his throat, or with a swollen and blackened face. I am come to a strange pass: I have heavy troubles. What is to be done? How is the money to be had?”
Bessie now endeavoured to persuade her to take a sedative draught: she succeeded with difficulty. Soon after, Mrs. Reed grew more composed, and sank into a dozing state. I then left her.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: She announced, "Your mistress is awake; I've informed her you're present: let's go see if she recognizes you." I didn't require directions to the familiar room, the place where I had so often been summoned for discipline or lectures in earlier times. I hurried ahead of Bessie, gently opening the door. A lamp with a shade cast a dim light on the table, as darkness was falling. The large four-poster bed with its amber hangings looked just as it used to; the dressing table, armchair, and footstool were still there – the very spot where I had been ordered countless times to kneel and ask forgiveness for wrongdoings I hadn't committed. I even glanced towards a nearby corner, half expecting to see the slender shape of a feared switch that once lurked there, ready to spring out like an imp and strike my trembling hand or sensitive neck. I approached the bed, pulled back the curtains, and leaned over the pile of pillows.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: "Missis is awake," Bessie told me, "and I've told her you've come: let's go see if she recognizes you." There was no need for Bessie to show me the familiar room where I’d been called numerous times for punishment when I was younger; I entered quickly, ahead of her. The room was dimly lit by a lamp—it was nearly night. The large, four-poster bed with its amber curtains was unchanged, as were the dressing table, armchair, and the footstool where I’d so often been made to kneel and beg forgiveness for things I hadn’t done. I glanced towards the corner where the thin rod used to lurk, ready to strike my hands or neck, and approached the bed, gently drawing aside the curtains and leaning over the pillows. I remembered Mrs. Reed’s face well and searched for the features I knew so well. It’s fortunate that time calms thoughts of revenge and quiets anger. Though I had left this woman feeling bitter and angry, I returned now feeling only pity for her suffering and a strong desire to forgive and be reconciled. Her face was the same: stern and unyielding, with that cold, commanding look, and an eyebrow expressing constant disapproval. This had often frightened me as a child, but now I bent over and kissed her. She looked at me. “Is this Jane Eyre?” she asked. “Yes, Aunt Reed. How are you, dear aunt?” I had once sworn I’d never call her aunt again, but I didn’t regret breaking that promise. I held her hand; had she returned the gesture kindly, I would have been truly happy. But someone as emotionally distant as her wasn't easily softened; she pulled her hand away and remarked on the warm night. She then looked at me with the same coldness, showing her opinion of me hadn’t changed. Her eyes were unmoved by kindness or emotion; she was determined to always think badly of me because recognizing my goodness would only hurt her pride. I felt hurt, then angry, then determined to win her over despite herself. Tears came as they did in my childhood, but I pushed them back. I took a seat by her pillow. “You asked for me,” I said, “and I’m here to see how you are.” “Oh, of course! Have you seen my daughters?” “Yes.” “Tell them I want you to stay for a while, so I can discuss some things with you—though tonight it’s too late, and I can’t remember them clearly. There’s something I meant to say—let me think—” Her unfocused look and faltering speech showed how weak she’d become. She shifted in bed, pulling the covers around her; my elbow, resting on the quilt, stopped her and she became annoyed. “Sit up! Don’t pin down the sheets. Are you Jane Eyre?” “I am Jane Eyre.” “That child has caused me more trouble than anyone would believe: such trouble left in my care—constantly annoying me with her strange moods, sudden tempers, always watching. Once she spoke to me like a mad thing, or a demon—no child ever behaved as she did. I was relieved to send her away. What happened at Lowood? There was a disease outbreak and many died. She survived, but I told people she hadn’t—I wish she had died!” “That is a strange wish, Mrs. Reed; why do you hate her?” “I always disliked her mother—she was my husband’s only sister, and he liked her best. He disagreed with the family for rejecting her after she married beneath her, and when she died, he grieved deeply, and insisted on taking the baby in, though I begged him to let someone else take care of her. I hated her as soon as I saw her, a sick, pathetic thing who whined all night. Reed pitied her and treated her as better than his own children. He wanted my children to be friendly with her, but they despised her, and he got angry at them. On his deathbed, he made me promise to look after her. I would have rather taken in a workhouse child—but he was weak. John is nothing like him, and I’m glad—John is like me and my brothers. I wish John would stop pestering me for money! I have none left: we’re becoming poor. I may have to let some servants go or rent out part of the house, but I can’t bear that. Most of my income pays mortgage interest. John gambles and always loses; he’s tricked by swindlers, degraded and shameful to see." She became more agitated. “I think I should leave her now,” I said to Bessie. “Perhaps you should, Miss: she often gets like this in the evening, but is calmer in the morning.” I got up. “Wait!” cried Mrs. Reed. “There was something else—I’m threatened by him all the time, threatened with my own death or his. I dream of him dead with a horrible face. I’m in a terrible situation. What can be done? Where will I get money?” Bessie tried to get her to take some medicine and eventually succeeded. Mrs. Reed then became more restful, and I left her.

events.title: Waiting at Gateshead: Art, Confidences, and Contrasting Natures
detailed_summary: Over ten days pass with Mrs. Reed remaining delirious or lethargic, with the doctor forbidding any excitement.
Jane manages to get along with Eliza and Georgiana, who are initially very cold.
Eliza spends her days silently sewing, reading, or writing.
Georgiana chatters to her canary but ignores Jane.
Jane occupies herself with drawing, using materials she brought with her.
She sketches various imaginative scenes and one morning sketches a face from memory, which turns out to be a very faithful representation of Mr. Rochester, a fact she conceals when Eliza inquires.
Georgiana also looks at the drawings; she dislikes the portrait of Rochester but is pleased by the others, and both sisters are surprised by Jane's artistic skill.
Jane offers to sketch their portraits, which puts Georgiana in a good mood.

Georgiana begins to confide in Jane, describing her social successes in London and hinting at a titled conquest, a theme she elaborates on daily, focusing entirely on herself and ignoring her family's current crises.
Eliza continues her rigidly structured, solitary routine: prayer (focusing on the Rubric), stitching a large crimson altar cloth, diary writing, gardening, and accounting.

Eliza reveals to Jane her profound affliction over John's conduct and the family's ruin, but states she has secured her own fortune and plans to enter a religious retirement after her mother's death, seeking a life of undisturbed, punctual habits away from the frivolous world.
She firmly states Georgiana will not accompany her, as they have nothing in common.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: More than ten days elapsed before I had again any conversation with her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I asked if Georgiana would accompany her.

events.text_segment:
More than ten days elapsed before I had again any conversation with her. She continued either delirious or lethargic; and the doctor forbade everything which could painfully excite her. Meantime, I got on as well as I could with Georgiana and Eliza. They were very cold, indeed, at first. Eliza would sit half the day sewing, reading, or writing, and scarcely utter a word either to me or her sister. Georgiana would chatter nonsense to her canary bird by the hour, and take no notice of me. But I was determined not to seem at a loss for occupation or amusement: I had brought my drawing materials with me, and they served me for both.
Provided with a case of pencils, and some sheets of paper, I used to take a seat apart from them, near the window, and busy myself in sketching fancy vignettes, representing any scene that happened momentarily to shape itself in the ever-shifting kaleidoscope of imagination: a glimpse of sea between two rocks; the rising moon, and a ship crossing its disk; a group of reeds and water-flags, and a naiad’s head, crowned with lotus-flowers, rising out of them; an elf sitting in a hedge-sparrow’s nest, under a wreath of hawthorn-bloom.
One morning I fell to sketching a face: what sort of a face it was to be, I did not care or know. I took a soft black pencil, gave it a broad point, and worked away. Soon I had traced on the paper a broad and prominent forehead and a square lower outline of visage: that contour gave me pleasure; my fingers proceeded actively to fill it with features. Strongly-marked horizontal eyebrows must be traced under that brow; then followed, naturally, a well-defined nose, with a straight ridge and full nostrils; then a flexible-looking mouth, by no means narrow; then a firm chin, with a decided cleft down the middle of it: of course, some black whiskers were wanted, and some jetty hair, tufted on the temples, and waved above the forehead. Now for the eyes: I had left them to the last, because they required the most careful working. I drew them large; I shaped them well: the eyelashes I traced long and sombre; the irids lustrous and large. “Good! but not quite the thing,” I thought, as I surveyed the effect: “they want more force and spirit;” and I wrought the shades blacker, that the lights might flash more brilliantly—a happy touch or two secured success. There, I had a friend’s face under my gaze; and what did it signify that those young ladies turned their backs on me? I looked at it; I smiled at the speaking likeness: I was absorbed and content.
“Is that a portrait of some one you know?” asked Eliza, who had approached me unnoticed. I responded that it was merely a fancy head, and hurried it beneath the other sheets. Of course, I lied: it was, in fact, a very faithful representation of Mr. Rochester. But what was that to her, or to any one but myself? Georgiana also advanced to look. The other drawings pleased her much, but she called that “an ugly man.” They both seemed surprised at my skill. I offered to sketch their portraits; and each, in turn, sat for a pencil outline. Then Georgiana produced her album. I promised to contribute a water-colour drawing: this put her at once into good humour. She proposed a walk in the grounds. Before we had been out two hours, we were deep in a confidential conversation: she had favoured me with a description of the brilliant winter she had spent in London two seasons ago—of the admiration she had there excited—the attention she had received; and I even got hints of the titled conquest she had made. In the course of the afternoon and evening these hints were enlarged on: various soft conversations were reported, and sentimental scenes represented; and, in short, a volume of a novel of fashionable life was that day improvised by her for my benefit. The communications were renewed from day to day: they always ran on the same theme—herself, her loves, and woes. It was strange she never once adverted either to her mother’s illness, or her brother’s death, or the present gloomy state of the family prospects. Her mind seemed wholly taken up with reminiscences of past gaiety, and aspirations after dissipations to come. She passed about five minutes each day in her mother’s sick-room, and no more.
Eliza still spoke little: she had evidently no time to talk. I never saw a busier person than she seemed to be; yet it was difficult to say what she did: or rather, to discover any result of her diligence. She had an alarm to call her up early. I know not how she occupied herself before breakfast, but after that meal she divided her time into regular portions, and each hour had its allotted task. Three times a day she studied a little book, which I found, on inspection, was a Common Prayer Book. I asked her once what was the great attraction of that volume, and she said, “the Rubric.” Three hours she gave to stitching, with gold thread, the border of a square crimson cloth, almost large enough for a carpet. In answer to my inquiries after the use of this article, she informed me it was a covering for the altar of a new church lately erected near Gateshead. Two hours she devoted to her diary; two to working by herself in the kitchen-garden; and one to the regulation of her accounts. She seemed to want no company; no conversation. I believe she was happy in her way: this routine sufficed for her; and nothing annoyed her so much as the occurrence of any incident which forced her to vary its clockwork regularity.
She told me one evening, when more disposed to be communicative than usual, that John’s conduct, and the threatened ruin of the family, had been a source of profound affliction to her: but she had now, she said, settled her mind, and formed her resolution. Her own fortune she had taken care to secure; and when her mother died—and it was wholly improbable, she tranquilly remarked, that she should either recover or linger long—she would execute a long-cherished project: seek a retirement where punctual habits would be permanently secured from disturbance, and place safe barriers between herself and a frivolous world. I asked if Georgiana would accompany her.

Meanwhile, I did my best to get along with Georgiana and Eliza. Initially, they were quite cold towards me. Eliza would spend much of her day sewing, reading, or writing, barely speaking to either me or her sister. Georgiana would chatter nonsensically to her pet bird for long periods, paying me no attention. Determined not to appear idle or bored, I used my drawing materials, which served both purposes. With my pencils and paper, I would sit separately by the window, sketching imaginative scenes that formed in my constantly changing thoughts. These included visions like the sea seen between rocks, the rising moon with a ship crossing it, a group of water plants with a naiad's head appearing among them, or a small elf perched in a bird's nest under a cluster of hawthorn flowers. One morning, I began sketching a face, not caring what kind it would be. I took a soft black pencil, sharpened it broadly, and started drawing. Quickly, I outlined a wide, prominent forehead and a strong, angular lower face shape; I liked this contour, and my fingers swiftly added the features. I drew strong horizontal eyebrows under the brow, followed by a well-defined nose with a straight bridge and full nostrils, then a seemingly flexible, fairly wide mouth, and finally a firm chin with a distinct vertical dimple. Of course, dark whiskers and some thick, wavy black hair over the forehead were necessary. The eyes were the last part, requiring the most care. I made them large and well-shaped, tracing long, dark eyelashes and large, bright irises. 'Good, but not quite right,' I thought, examining the result, 'they need more strength and intensity.' I darkened the shadows to make the highlights more brilliant, and a few successful touches finished it. There, I had the face of a friend before me; it didn't matter that the young ladies ignored me. I gazed at it, smiled at the striking resemblance, feeling engrossed and content. 'Is that a portrait of someone you know?' asked Eliza, who had approached quietly. I replied that it was just an imaginary head and quickly slipped it under my other papers. Naturally, I was lying; it was actually a very accurate likeness of Mr. Rochester. But that was irrelevant to her, or anyone but myself. Georgiana also came to look. She liked the other drawings very much but called the face sketch 'an ugly man.' Both sisters seemed impressed by my skill. I offered to draw them, and each sat for a pencil outline. Then Georgiana brought out her album. I promised to contribute a watercolour, which instantly put her in a good mood. She suggested we take a walk on the grounds. Within two hours of being outside, we were having a private conversation. She shared details of the exciting winter she had spent in London two years prior, describing the admiration she received and the attention she attracted, even hinting at a conquest involving a titled gentleman. Throughout the afternoon and evening, she elaborated on these hints, recounting romantic conversations and sentimental moments, essentially improvising a narrative of fashionable life for my entertainment that day. These discussions continued daily, always focusing on the same subject: herself, her romances, and her troubles. It was peculiar that she never once mentioned her mother's illness, her brother's death, or the family's current dire situation. Her mind seemed entirely preoccupied with memories of past pleasures and anticipation of future social events. She spent only about five minutes each day in her mother's sickroom. Eliza still spoke little, clearly having no time for talk. I never saw anyone seem busier than she was, though it was hard to say exactly what she did or discern any tangible results from her efforts. An alarm clock woke her early. I don't know how she occupied herself before breakfast, but after that meal, she divided her time into fixed segments, with each hour having its assigned task. Three times a day, she studied a small book which I found, upon inspection, was a Common Prayer Book. I once asked her what made the book so appealing, and she replied, 'the Rubric.' She spent three hours sewing a border with gold thread onto a large square of crimson cloth, explaining it was an altar covering for a new church recently built near Gateshead. She dedicated two hours to her diary, two to working alone in the kitchen garden, and one to managing her finances. She seemed to have no need for company or conversation. I believe she was content in her own way; this routine was enough for her, and nothing irritated her more than anything that disrupted its precise, clockwork regularity. One evening, when she was more inclined to talk than usual, she told me that John's conduct and the family's potential ruin had caused her deep sorrow, but she had now made up her mind and formed a resolution. She had secured her own finances, and when her mother died—which she calmly noted was very unlikely to involve either recovery or a prolonged period—she would carry out a long-held plan: finding a secluded place where her strict habits could be maintained without interruption, thereby creating firm boundaries between herself and a superficial world. I asked if Georgiana would go with her.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
It was over ten days before I spoke with her again. She remained either unconscious or in a state of delirium, and the doctor prohibited anything that might unnecessarily agitate her. Meanwhile, I managed as best I could with Georgiana and Eliza, who were both quite distant at first. Eliza spent much of her time sewing, reading, or writing in silence, barely acknowledging me or Georgiana. Georgiana, on the other hand, would spend hours chatting to her canary, ignoring me completely. Determined not to appear bored or idle, I made use of the drawing supplies I had brought and occupied myself with them.

Armed with pencils and paper, I would sit by the window, away from them, and lose myself in sketching imaginative scenes—perhaps a seascape glimpsed between rocks, the moon rising over a passing ship, reeds and water plants with a naiad's head, or perhaps an elf in a bird's nest entwined with blossom.

One morning, I started sketching a face without any definite idea in mind. Taking a soft pencil, I quickly drew a broad forehead and a strong jaw, which I found pleasing, and proceeded to add prominent eyebrows, a well-shaped nose, a full mouth, a dimpled chin, dark whiskers, and wavy black hair. I left the eyes for last, wanting to get them right. I drew them large and luminous, adjusting the shadows to give their gaze a lively brightness. When I finished, I was looking at a friend's face, and it didn't matter to me if the others ignored me; I was happily absorbed.

Eliza, approaching without my noticing, asked if it was a portrait of someone I knew. I replied it was just an imagined face and quickly covered it up—though in truth, it was a very accurate likeness of Mr. Rochester. But what concern was that of hers, or anyone's but my own? Georgiana also came to see, and while she liked the other drawings, she called this one 'an ugly man.' Both appeared impressed by my talent. I offered to sketch their portraits, and they each posed while I drew quick outlines. Georgiana then brought out her album, and I promised her a watercolor. This put her in good spirits, and she suggested a walk in the gardens. Within two hours, we were having an intimate conversation, during which she recounted her glamorous London winter two years earlier, the attention she received, and alluded to a noble admirer. The rest of the day she continued in this vein, filling it with romantic stories of her experiences, which became a regular topic—always focusing on her own affairs and feelings. Strangely, she never mentioned our mother's illness, our brother's death, or the family's grim situation. Her thoughts seemed absorbed by memories of past excitement and hopes for more. She visited her sick mother briefly each day—no more than five minutes.

Eliza remained reserved, focused on her many private tasks. I had never seen anyone so constantly busy, though it was hard to determine what she accomplished. She woke early with an alarm, followed a strict schedule, and allotted time to different activities. Three times daily she studied her Common Prayer Book, explaining that she was interested in the Rubric. She spent three hours stitching a gold-bordered cloth for the altar of a new church, devoted two hours to her diary, two to gardening, and another to keeping her accounts. She seemed content with her solitary regimented life and disliked any disruption. One evening, when she was more open, she confessed that John's behavior and the family's troubles had deeply saddened her, but she had resolved to protect her own inheritance and, after her mother's likely imminent death, intended to retreat to a place where she could enjoy undisturbed discipline and routine, sheltered from the superficial world. I asked if Georgiana would go with her.

events.title: A Bitter Confrontation Between the Reed Sisters
detailed_summary: Eliza responds that Georgiana will not join her retirement, as they share no common ground and she wouldn't be burdened by her.

Georgiana, when not confiding in Jane, complains about the dullness of Gateshead and wishes for an invitation to London from her aunt Gibson to escape until 'all was over,' presumably referring to her mother's death and funeral.
One day, Eliza abruptly confronts Georgiana, delivering a scathing critique of her character.
Eliza accuses Georgiana of being vain, absurd, useless, and dependent, seeking only to lean on others' strength and craving constant excitement.
She advises Georgiana to adopt a disciplined, structured life to achieve independence, offering this as her first and last advice.
Eliza declares that after their mother's death, she will completely sever ties with Georgiana, emphasizing their separation would be absolute even if they were the last two people on earth.
Georgiana retorts that Eliza is notoriously selfish and heartless, accusing her of spitefully ruining her romantic prospects with Lord Edwin Vere due to jealousy.
Following the exchange, Georgiana weeps for an hour, while Eliza remains cold and industrious.

The narrator reflects on the sisters' natures, one intolerably acrid and the other despicably savourless, both lacking generous feeling, and comments on the deficiencies of judgment without feeling and feeling without judgment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Of course not. Georgiana and she had nothing in common: they never had had.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Feeling without judgment is a washy draught indeed; but judgment untempered by feeling is too bitter and husky a morsel for human deglutition.

events.text_segment:
“Of course not. Georgiana and she had nothing in common: they never had had. She would not be burdened with her society for any consideration. Georgiana should take her own course; and she, Eliza, would take hers.”
Georgiana, when not unburdening her heart to me, spent most of her time in lying on the sofa, fretting about the dulness of the house, and wishing over and over again that her aunt Gibson would send her an invitation up to town. “It would be so much better,” she said, “if she could only get out of the way for a month or two, till all was over.” I did not ask what she meant by “all being over,” but I suppose she referred to the expected decease of her mother and the gloomy sequel of funeral rites. Eliza generally took no more notice of her sister’s indolence and complaints than if no such murmuring, lounging object had been before her. One day, however, as she put away her account-book and unfolded her embroidery, she suddenly took her up thus—
“Georgiana, a more vain and absurd animal than you was certainly never allowed to cumber the earth. You had no right to be born, for you make no use of life. Instead of living for, in, and with yourself, as a reasonable being ought, you seek only to fasten your feebleness on some other person’s strength: if no one can be found willing to burden her or himself with such a fat, weak, puffy, useless thing, you cry out that you are ill-treated, neglected, miserable. Then, too, existence for you must be a scene of continual change and excitement, or else the world is a dungeon: you must be admired, you must be courted, you must be flattered—you must have music, dancing, and society—or you languish, you die away. Have you no sense to devise a system which will make you independent of all efforts, and all wills, but your own? Take one day; share it into sections; to each section apportion its task: leave no stray unemployed quarters of an hour, ten minutes, five minutes—include all; do each piece of business in its turn with method, with rigid regularity. The day will close almost before you are aware it has begun; and you are indebted to no one for helping you to get rid of one vacant moment: you have had to seek no one’s company, conversation, sympathy, forbearance; you have lived, in short, as an independent being ought to do. Take this advice: the first and last I shall offer you; then you will not want me or any one else, happen what may. Neglect it—go on as heretofore, craving, whining, and idling—and suffer the results of your idiocy, however bad and insufferable they may be. I tell you this plainly; and listen: for though I shall no more repeat what I am now about to say, I shall steadily act on it. After my mother’s death, I wash my hands of you: from the day her coffin is carried to the vault in Gateshead Church, you and I will be as separate as if we had never known each other. You need not think that because we chanced to be born of the same parents, I shall suffer you to fasten me down by even the feeblest claim: I can tell you this—if the whole human race, ourselves excepted, were swept away, and we two stood alone on the earth, I would leave you in the old world, and betake myself to the new.”
She closed her lips.
“You might have spared yourself the trouble of delivering that tirade,” answered Georgiana. “Everybody knows you are the most selfish, heartless creature in existence: and I know your spiteful hatred towards me: I have had a specimen of it before in the trick you played me about Lord Edwin Vere: you could not bear me to be raised above you, to have a title, to be received into circles where you dare not show your face, and so you acted the spy and informer, and ruined my prospects for ever.” Georgiana took out her handkerchief and blew her nose for an hour afterwards; Eliza sat cold, impassable, and assiduously industrious.
True, generous feeling is made small account of by some, but here were two natures rendered, the one intolerably acrid, the other despicably savourless for the want of it. Feeling without judgment is a washy draught indeed; but judgment untempered by feeling is too bitter and husky a morsel for human deglutition.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Absolutely not. Georgiana and she shared nothing in common; they never had. For no reason would she tolerate Georgiana's company. She felt it would be much better, she said, if she could just get away for a month or two until everything was concluded. I didn't ask what she meant by 'everything being concluded,' but I presumed she referred to her mother's impending death and the sad events of the funeral that would follow. Eliza typically ignored her sister's idleness and complaints as if the complaining, lounging person wasn't even there. However, one day, after putting away her ledger and starting her embroidery, she suddenly attacked Georgiana verbally like this: "Georgiana," she began, "surely no creature more vain and foolish than you has ever been allowed to burden the earth. You shouldn't have been born, because you make no use of your life. Instead of living independently, for and with yourself, as a rational person should, you merely try to latch your weakness onto someone else's strength. If you can't find anyone willing to take on the burden of such a fat, weak, puffed-up, useless thing, you declare yourself ill-treated, neglected, and miserable. Furthermore, for you, life must be a constant stream of change and excitement, or the world feels like a prison. You need to be admired, courted, and flattered; you must have music, dancing, and social gatherings, or you wither away. Do you lack the sense to devise a system that would make you reliant only on your own efforts and will? Take one day; divide it into parts; assign a task to each part. Don't leave any moments, ten minutes, five minutes, unemployed—include everything. Perform each task methodically and consistently when its turn comes. The day will end almost before you realise it started, and you won't owe anyone anything for helping you pass a single empty moment. You won't have needed anyone's company, conversation, sympathy, or patience. In short, you will have lived as an independent being should. Follow this advice; it's the first and last I'll give you. Then, no matter what happens, you won't need me or anyone else. Ignore it—continue craving, whining, and idling as before—and suffer the consequences of your foolishness, no matter how severe and unbearable they are. I'm telling you this clearly, so listen: although I won't repeat what I'm saying now, I will consistently act upon it. After my mother's death, I will disassociate myself from you. Don't imagine that just because we happened to be born of the same parents, I will let you tie me down with even the slightest claim. I can tell you this—if the entire human race, except for us, were wiped out, and we two stood alone on Earth, I would abandon you in the old world and make my way to the new." She sealed her lips. "You could have saved yourself the trouble of delivering that rant," Georgiana replied. "Everyone knows you are the most selfish, heartless person alive; and I know your malicious hatred towards me. I've seen evidence of it before in the trick you played on me about Lord Edwin Vere. You couldn't stand the thought of me being elevated above you, having a title, being accepted into social circles where you wouldn't dare show your face, so you acted as a spy and informant and ruined my prospects permanently." Georgiana then took out her handkerchief and cried for a prolonged period; Eliza remained cool, unaffected, and diligently occupied with her work. True, noble feeling is sometimes disregarded by some, but here were two personalities rendered, one intolerably harsh, the other contemptibly weak, due to its absence. Feeling without good sense is indeed a watery drink; but good sense unspoiled by feeling is too bitter and rough a piece to swallow for humans.

events.title: Mrs. Reed's Deathbed Confession, Unchanged Animosity, and Demise
detailed_summary: On a wet and windy afternoon, with Georgiana asleep and Eliza at church, Jane decides to check on Mrs. Reed.
She finds the sick-room unwatched, the nurse absent, and Mrs. Reed lying still and lethargic.
Jane tends to the fire and bedclothes, then reflects by the window on death, her thoughts turning to Helen Burns and her faith.
A feeble voice from the bed asks, 'Who is that?' Jane approaches, and Mrs. Reed, initially confused and not recognizing her, asks for Bessie.
Mrs. Reed then remarks on Jane's familiar features, saying she resembles Jane Eyre, but expresses fear it's a mistake due to the passage of eight years.
Jane gently confirms her identity, and Mrs. Reed, now lucid, acknowledges she is very ill and wishes to ease her mind before dying.
She confesses to two wrongs: breaking her promise to her husband to raise Jane as her own child, and another she hesitates to reveal.
Urged by the thought of eternity, Mrs. Reed directs Jane to a letter in her dressing-case.
Jane reads the letter, dated three years prior, from her uncle, John Eyre of Madeira, expressing his intention to adopt Jane and make her his heir.
Mrs. Reed explains she concealed the letter and prevented Jane's good fortune because of her deep-seated dislike for Jane, stemming from Jane's passionate childhood outburst against her cruelty.
She admits to telling John Eyre that Jane had died of typhus at Lowood.
Jane urges her aunt to let go of these past events and forgives her for her passionate childhood language.
Mrs. Reed, unheeding, reiterates her inability to forget and claims Jane was born to be her torment.
She criticizes Jane's disposition as still incomprehensible to her.
Jane asserts her disposition is passionate but not vindictive, expresses her past desire to love Mrs. Reed, and her current longing for reconciliation, asking for a kiss.
Mrs. Reed refuses to kiss her, her hand shrinking from Jane's touch and her eyes avoiding Jane's gaze.
Jane then offers her full and free forgiveness, urging her aunt to seek God's forgiveness and find peace.
The narrator laments that it was too late for Mrs. Reed to change her ingrained hatred.
The nurse and Bessie enter. Jane lingers, but Mrs. Reed shows no sign of amity and relapses into stupor.
Mrs. Reed dies at midnight, with neither Jane nor her daughters present at the moment of death.
The next morning, Jane and Eliza view the body; Georgiana is too distressed to do so. Mrs. Reed's corpse appears rigid and inexorable.
Jane feels only a grating anguish for Mrs. Reed's woes and a somber dismay at such a death, not personal loss.
Eliza calmly observes that her mother's life was shortened by trouble. Neither Jane nor Eliza sheds a tear.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Neither of us had dropt a tear.

events.text_segment:
It was a wet and windy afternoon: Georgiana had fallen asleep on the sofa over the perusal of a novel; Eliza was gone to attend a saint’s-day service at the new church—for in matters of religion she was a rigid formalist: no weather ever prevented the punctual discharge of what she considered her devotional duties; fair or foul, she went to church thrice every Sunday, and as often on week-days as there were prayers.
I bethought myself to go upstairs and see how the dying woman sped, who lay there almost unheeded: the very servants paid her but a remittent attention: the hired nurse, being little looked after, would slip out of the room whenever she could. Bessie was faithful; but she had her own family to mind, and could only come occasionally to the hall. I found the sick-room unwatched, as I had expected: no nurse was there; the patient lay still, and seemingly lethargic; her livid face sunk in the pillows: the fire was dying in the grate. I renewed the fuel, re-arranged the bedclothes, gazed awhile on her who could not now gaze on me, and then I moved away to the window.
The rain beat strongly against the panes, the wind blew tempestuously: “One lies there,” I thought, “who will soon be beyond the war of earthly elements. Whither will that spirit—now struggling to quit its material tenement—flit when at length released?”
In pondering the great mystery, I thought of Helen Burns, recalled her dying words—her faith—her doctrine of the equality of disembodied souls. I was still listening in thought to her well-remembered tones—still picturing her pale and spiritual aspect, her wasted face and sublime gaze, as she lay on her placid deathbed, and whispered her longing to be restored to her divine Father’s bosom—when a feeble voice murmured from the couch behind: “Who is that?”
I knew Mrs. Reed had not spoken for days: was she reviving? I went up to her.
“It is I, Aunt Reed.”
“Who—I?” was her answer. “Who are you?” looking at me with surprise and a sort of alarm, but still not wildly. “You are quite a stranger to me—where is Bessie?”
“She is at the lodge, aunt.”
“Aunt,” she repeated. “Who calls me aunt? You are not one of the Gibsons; and yet I know you—that face, and the eyes and forehead, are quiet familiar to me: you are like—why, you are like Jane Eyre!”
I said nothing: I was afraid of occasioning some shock by declaring my identity.
“Yet,” said she, “I am afraid it is a mistake: my thoughts deceive me. I wished to see Jane Eyre, and I fancy a likeness where none exists: besides, in eight years she must be so changed.” I now gently assured her that I was the person she supposed and desired me to be: and seeing that I was understood, and that her senses were quite collected, I explained how Bessie had sent her husband to fetch me from Thornfield.
“I am very ill, I know,” she said ere long. “I was trying to turn myself a few minutes since, and find I cannot move a limb. It is as well I should ease my mind before I die: what we think little of in health, burdens us at such an hour as the present is to me. Is the nurse here? or is there no one in the room but you?”
I assured her we were alone.
“Well, I have twice done you a wrong which I regret now. One was in breaking the promise which I gave my husband to bring you up as my own child; the other—” she stopped. “After all, it is of no great importance, perhaps,” she murmured to herself: “and then I may get better; and to humble myself so to her is painful.”
She made an effort to alter her position, but failed: her face changed; she seemed to experience some inward sensation—the precursor, perhaps, of the last pang.
“Well, I must get it over. Eternity is before me: I had better tell her.—Go to my dressing-case, open it, and take out a letter you will see there.”
I obeyed her directions. “Read the letter,” she said.
It was short, and thus conceived:—
“MADAM,—
“Will you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane Eyre, and to tell me how she is? It is my intention to write shortly and desire her to come to me at Madeira. Providence has blessed my endeavours to secure a competency; and as I am unmarried and childless, I wish to adopt her during my life, and bequeath her at my death whatever I may have to leave.

I am, Madam, &c., &c.,
“JOHN EYRE, Madeira.”
It was dated three years back.
“Why did I never hear of this?” I asked.
“Because I disliked you too fixedly and thoroughly ever to lend a hand in lifting you to prosperity. I could not forget your conduct to me, Jane—the fury with which you once turned on me; the tone in which you declared you abhorred me the worst of anybody in the world; the unchildlike look and voice with which you affirmed that the very thought of me made you sick, and asserted that I had treated you with miserable cruelty. I could not forget my own sensations when you thus started up and poured out the venom of your mind: I felt fear as if an animal that I had struck or pushed had looked up at me with human eyes and cursed me in a man’s voice.—Bring me some water! Oh, make haste!”
“Dear Mrs. Reed,” said I, as I offered her the draught she required, “think no more of all this, let it pass away from your mind. Forgive me for my passionate language: I was a child then; eight, nine years have passed since that day.”
She heeded nothing of what I said; but when she had tasted the water and drawn breath, she went on thus—
“I tell you I could not forget it; and I took my revenge: for you to be adopted by your uncle, and placed in a state of ease and comfort, was what I could not endure. I wrote to him; I said I was sorry for his disappointment, but Jane Eyre was dead: she had died of typhus fever at Lowood. Now act as you please: write and contradict my assertion—expose my falsehood as soon as you like. You were born, I think, to be my torment: my last hour is racked by the recollection of a deed which, but for you, I should never have been tempted to commit.”
“If you could but be persuaded to think no more of it, aunt, and to regard me with kindness and forgiveness——”
“You have a very bad disposition,” said she, “and one to this day I feel it impossible to understand: how for nine years you could be patient and quiescent under any treatment, and in the tenth break out all fire and violence, I can never comprehend.”
“My disposition is not so bad as you think: I am passionate, but not vindictive. Many a time, as a little child, I should have been glad to love you if you would have let me; and I long earnestly to be reconciled to you now: kiss me, aunt.”
I approached my cheek to her lips: she would not touch it. She said I oppressed her by leaning over the bed, and again demanded water. As I laid her down—for I raised her and supported her on my arm while she drank—I covered her ice-cold and clammy hand with mine: the feeble fingers shrank from my touch—the glazing eyes shunned my gaze.
“Love me, then, or hate me, as you will,” I said at last, “you have my full and free forgiveness: ask now for God’s, and be at peace.”
Poor, suffering woman! it was too late for her to make now the effort to change her habitual frame of mind: living, she had ever hated me—dying, she must hate me still.
The nurse now entered, and Bessie followed. I yet lingered half-an-hour longer, hoping to see some sign of amity: but she gave none. She was fast relapsing into stupor; nor did her mind again rally: at twelve o’clock that night she died. I was not present to close her eyes, nor were either of her daughters. They came to tell us the next morning that all was over. She was by that time laid out. Eliza and I went to look at her: Georgiana, who had burst out into loud weeping, said she dared not go. There was stretched Sarah Reed’s once robust and active frame, rigid and still: her eye of flint was covered with its cold lid; her brow and strong traits wore yet the impress of her inexorable soul. A strange and solemn object was that corpse to me. I gazed on it with gloom and pain: nothing soft, nothing sweet, nothing pitying, or hopeful, or subduing did it inspire; only a grating anguish for her woes—not my loss—and a sombre tearless dismay at the fearfulness of death in such a form.
Eliza surveyed her parent calmly. After a silence of some minutes she observed—
“With her constitution she should have lived to a good old age: her life was shortened by trouble.” And then a spasm constricted her mouth for an instant: as it passed away she turned and left the room, and so did I. Neither of us had dropt a tear.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: It was a stormy afternoon with rain and wind. Georgiana was sleeping on the couch, a novel beside her, while Eliza had gone to attend a religious service. Eliza was extremely devout and always fulfilled her religious obligations punctually, regardless of the weather, attending church three times on Sundays and for weekday prayers. I thought it best to go upstairs and see how the dying woman was doing, as she lay there largely ignored. Even the servants paid little attention, and the hired nurse often left the room when unsupervised. Bessie was reliable but preoccupied with her own family and could only visit the house occasionally. As I anticipated, the sick-room was empty; there was no nurse present. The patient lay motionless and seemed sluggish, her pale face deeply set into the pillows, and the fire in the grate was fading. I restocked the fuel, straightened the covers, and looked for a moment at the woman who could no longer look back at me. Then, I moved to the window. The rain was heavily hitting the glass, and the wind raged violently. "Someone lies there," I reflected, "who will soon be beyond the turmoil of earthly elements. Where will that soul, currently struggling to leave its physical body, go once it is finally free?" Pondering this profound mystery, my thoughts turned to Helen Burns, remembering her final words, her unwavering faith, and her belief that souls were equal after leaving the body. I was still mentally replaying her familiar voice and picturing her frail, ethereal appearance, her wasted face and serene expression as she lay calmly dying, whispering her desire to return to her heavenly Father, when a weak voice from the bed interrupted: "Who is that?" Knowing Mrs. Reed hadn't spoken for several days, I wondered if she was getting better. I approached her bed. "It's me, Aunt Reed," I said. "Who... I?" she responded, staring at me with surprise and a hint of fear, though not appearing delusional. "Who are you?" she asked, adding, "You are completely unfamiliar to me. Where is Bessie?" I told her Bessie was at the lodge. "Aunt," she repeated thoughtfully. "Who calls me aunt? You aren't one of the Gibsons, and yet I know you. That face, those eyes and forehead, they are quite recognizable to me. You resemble... why, you look like Jane Eyre!" I remained silent, worried that revealing my identity might cause a shock. "Still," she continued, "I fear it's a mistake; my mind is deceiving me. I wanted to see Jane Eyre, and I'm imagining a resemblance where there is none. Besides, she must have changed so much in eight years." I then softly confirmed that I was indeed the person she believed and wished me to be. Seeing that she understood and was thinking clearly, I explained how Bessie had sent her husband to retrieve me from Thornfield. "I know I am very ill," she said after a while. "I tried to move myself a few minutes ago and found I couldn't move a single limb. It is best that I clear my conscience before I die. The things we dismiss when healthy weigh heavily on us at a time like this." She asked if the nurse was present or if only I was in the room. I assured her we were alone. "Well, I have wronged you twice, and I regret it now," she stated. "One wrong was failing to keep the promise I made to my husband to raise you as if you were my own child. The other..." She paused, then murmured to herself, "Perhaps it is not very important after all... and besides, I might recover, and humbling myself to her like this is difficult." She attempted to shift her position but couldn't. Her expression changed, and she seemed to experience some internal sensation, possibly the sign of her final struggle. "Well, I must reveal it," she declared. "Eternity awaits me; I should tell her." She instructed me, "Go to my dressing-case, open it, and take out a letter you'll find inside." I followed her instructions. "Read the letter," she commanded. It was brief and read as follows: "MADAM, Please be so kind as to send me the contact information for my niece, Jane Eyre, and inform me of her well-being. I intend to write to her soon and invite her to come live with me in Madeira. Providence has helped me achieve financial security, and as I am unmarried and have no children, I wish to adopt her during my lifetime and leave her whatever I possess upon my death. I am, Madam, etc., etc., JOHN EYRE, Madeira." The letter was dated three years earlier. "Why was I never told about this?" I asked. Mrs. Reed replied, "Because I disliked you so deeply and completely that I would never help you achieve good fortune. I could not forget how you behaved towards me, Jane—the intense anger you showed me that one time; the tone you used when you declared you detested me more than anyone in the world; the adult-like look and voice with which you insisted that the mere thought of me made you ill and claimed I had treated you with terrible cruelty. I could not forget how I felt when you suddenly stood up and unleashed your bitter feelings. I felt a fear, as if an animal I had hit or pushed had looked up at me with human eyes and cursed me like a man. Bring me some water! Oh, hurry!" As I gave her the water she needed, I said, "Dear Mrs. Reed, please don't dwell on all this. Let it leave your mind. Forgive my passionate words; I was just a child then. Eight or nine years have passed since that day." She paid no attention to what I said. However, after she had drunk the water and regained her breath, she continued, "I am telling you I couldn't forget it, and I got my revenge. The idea of you being adopted by your uncle and living comfortably was something I could not tolerate. I wrote to him and told him I regretted his disappointment, but Jane Eyre was dead; she had died of typhus fever at Lowwood. Now, do as you wish; write and correct my statement—expose my lie whenever you like. I think you were born to be my torment; my final moments are agonizing because of the memory of an action which, if it weren't for you, I would never have been tempted to commit." I pleaded, "If only you could be persuaded to stop thinking about it, aunt, and to look upon me with kindness and forgiveness..." "You have a very difficult nature," she responded, "one that I still find impossible to understand. How you could endure any treatment patiently and passively for nine years and then erupt with such fire and aggression in the tenth is something I can never comprehend." I replied, "My nature isn't as bad as you think. I am passionate, but I don't hold grudges. Many times, as a young child, I would have been happy to love you if you had allowed me, and I sincerely long to make peace with you now. Kiss me, aunt." I moved my cheek closer to her lips, but she refused to touch it. She claimed I was pressuring her by leaning over the bed and again requested water. As I helped her lie back down—for I had lifted and supported her on my arm while she drank—I placed my hand over her icy, damp one. Her weak fingers recoiled from my touch, and her glassy eyes avoided looking at me. "Then love me or hate me, as you choose," I finally said, "you have my complete and free forgiveness. Now, seek God's forgiveness and find peace." Poor, suffering woman! It was too late for her to change her deeply ingrained attitude. She had always hated me during her life, and she would continue to hate me as she died. The nurse entered, followed by Bessie. I lingered for another half-hour, hoping to see some indication of reconciliation, but there was none. She was rapidly sinking back into unconsciousness, and her mind did not recover its clarity. She passed away at midnight. I was not there when she died, nor were either of her daughters present. They informed us the following morning that she had died. By that time, she had been prepared for burial. Eliza and I went to see her; Georgiana, who was crying loudly, said she couldn't bring herself to go. There lay Sarah Reed's body, once strong and active, now stiff and motionless. Her hard eyes were closed under their cold lids, and her forehead and strong features still held the mark of her unyielding spirit. Her corpse was a strange and somber sight to me. I looked upon it with sadness and distress. It evoked nothing gentle, sweet, pitying, hopeful, or comforting; only a harsh sorrow for *her* suffering—not a sense of *my* own loss—and a dark, tearless sense of dread at the terror of death in such a manifestation. Eliza observed her mother calmly. After a few moments of silence, she commented, "Given her health, she should have lived to a great age. Her life was cut short by hardship." Then, a brief spasm tightened her mouth. As it subsided, she turned and left the room, and I followed. Neither of us had shed a tear.

Her body was laid out; Georgiana wept loudly and refused to view her, but Eliza and I did. Mrs. Reed’s body, once strong, was now cold and hard. Looking at her filled me with sadness for her suffering, dread for death in such circumstances, but not with grief for my own loss. Eliza observed that her mother’s life could have been longer if not for her troubles, showed a passing emotion, and then we both left the room without shedding a tear.

events.title: Extended Stay at Gateshead and Farewells to the Reed Sisters
detailed_summary: Jane's intended one-week leave from Thornfield extends to a month at Gateshead due to family circumstances.

Georgiana Reed successfully implores Jane to postpone her departure, expressing distress at the thought of being left alone with her sister Eliza and requiring Jane's help with preparations for her move to London.
