Jane internally reflects on her dynamic with Georgiana, acknowledging that if their living situation were permanent, she would insist on a more equitable distribution of labor, but she acquiesces due to the temporary nature of their association and the somber occasion of mourning.
Following Georgiana's departure for London, Eliza Reed then requests Jane to prolong her stay for another week.

Eliza explains she needs Jane to manage household affairs, see visitors, and handle condolence notes, as she herself is occupied with her own undisclosed plans, remaining secluded in her room organizing belongings and destroying papers.

Eliza eventually informs Jane she is free to leave, expressing formal gratitude for her efficient help and discreet behavior, and favorably contrasting Jane's self-reliance with Georgiana's dependency.

Eliza then reveals her intention to travel to the Continent and enter a religious house near Lisle, a nunnery, where she plans to study Roman Catholic doctrines and potentially take the veil if she finds the system compatible with her desire for order and decency.
Jane inwardly concurs that such a life would suit Eliza perfectly but offers no outward surprise or objection to this plan.
During their farewell, Eliza wishes Jane well, acknowledging her good sense.
Jane, in turn, offers a somewhat pointed comment about Eliza's future confinement in a French convent, a remark Eliza accepts without argument.

The narrator concludes this section by providing a brief update on the fates of both sisters: Georgiana secures a financially advantageous marriage to an older man of fashion, and Eliza indeed takes the veil, eventually becoming the superior of the convent she endowed with her fortune.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Rochester had given me but one week’s leave of absence: yet a month elapsed before I quitted Gateshead.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As I shall not have occasion to refer either to her or her sister again, I may as well mention here, that Georgiana made an advantageous match with a wealthy worn-out man of fashion, and that Eliza actually took the veil, and is at this day superior of the convent where she passed the period of her novitiate, and which she endowed with her fortune.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Rochester had given me but one week’s leave of absence: yet a month elapsed before I quitted Gateshead. I wished to leave immediately after the funeral, but Georgiana entreated me to stay till she could get off to London, whither she was now at last invited by her uncle, Mr. Gibson, who had come down to direct his sister’s interment and settle the family affairs. Georgiana said she dreaded being left alone with Eliza; from her she got neither sympathy in her dejection, support in her fears, nor aid in her preparations; so I bore with her feeble-minded wailings and selfish lamentations as well as I could, and did my best in sewing for her and packing her dresses. It is true, that while I worked, she would idle; and I thought to myself, “If you and I were destined to live always together, cousin, we would commence matters on a different footing. I should not settle tamely down into being the forbearing party; I should assign you your share of labour, and compel you to accomplish it, or else it should be left undone: I should insist, also, on your keeping some of those drawling, half-insincere complaints hushed in your own breast. It is only because our connection happens to be very transitory, and comes at a peculiarly mournful season, that I consent thus to render it so patient and compliant on my part.”
At last I saw Georgiana off; but now it was Eliza’s turn to request me to stay another week. Her plans required all her time and attention, she said; she was about to depart for some unknown bourne; and all day long she stayed in her own room, her door bolted within, filling trunks, emptying drawers, burning papers, and holding no communication with any one. She wished me to look after the house, to see callers, and answer notes of condolence.
One morning she told me I was at liberty. “And,” she added, “I am obliged to you for your valuable services and discreet conduct! There is some difference between living with such an one as you and with Georgiana: you perform your own part in life and burden no one. To-morrow,” she continued, “I set out for the Continent. I shall take up my abode in a religious house near Lisle—a nunnery you would call it; there I shall be quiet and unmolested. I shall devote myself for a time to the examination of the Roman Catholic dogmas, and to a careful study of the workings of their system: if I find it to be, as I half suspect it is, the one best calculated to ensure the doing of all things decently and in order, I shall embrace the tenets of Rome and probably take the veil.”
I neither expressed surprise at this resolution nor attempted to dissuade her from it. “The vocation will fit you to a hair,” I thought: “much good may it do you!”
When we parted, she said: “Good-bye, cousin Jane Eyre; I wish you well: you have some sense.”
I then returned: “You are not without sense, cousin Eliza; but what you have, I suppose, in another year will be walled up alive in a French convent. However, it is not my business, and so it suits you, I don’t much care.”
“You are in the right,” said she; and with these words we each went our separate way. As I shall not have occasion to refer either to her or her sister again, I may as well mention here, that Georgiana made an advantageous match with a wealthy worn-out man of fashion, and that Eliza actually took the veil, and is at this day superior of the convent where she passed the period of her novitiate, and which she endowed with her fortune.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Although Mr. Rochester had granted me only a week off, I ended up staying at Gateshead for an entire month. My initial intention was to leave right after the funeral, but Georgiana pleaded with me to remain until she could depart for London. She had finally received an invitation from her uncle, Mr. Gibson, who had come to oversee his sister's burial arrangements and sort out the family's affairs. Georgiana confessed she dreaded being left alone with Eliza, from whom she received no comfort for her sadness, no support for her anxieties, and no help with her packing. Consequently, I put up with her weak complaints and self-centered sorrow as best I could, diligently helping her by sewing and packing her clothes. It was true that while I worked, she did nothing. I found myself thinking, 'If we were to live together permanently, cousin, things would have to be managed differently. I wouldn't passively accept being the one who always gives way; I would insist you do your share of the work and make sure it was done, or it would simply remain unfinished. I would also require you to keep some of those drawn-out, somewhat insincere complaints to yourself. It's only because our time together is so brief and occurs during such a sad period that I am willing to be so patient and accommodating on my part.' Finally, I saw Georgiana off. However, then it was Eliza's turn to ask me to stay for another week. She claimed her upcoming plans required all her time and concentration. She was preparing to leave for some unknown destination and spent all day in her room with the door bolted, filling trunks, emptying drawers, burning papers, and avoiding contact with everyone. She needed me to manage the household, greet visitors, and respond to sympathy notes. One morning, she informed me I was free to go. She added, 'And I am grateful for your valuable assistance and sensible behavior! There is a noticeable difference between living with someone like you and someone like Georgiana; you handle your own responsibilities and are not a burden. Tomorrow,' she continued, 'I am traveling to the Continent. I will reside in a religious community near Lille—what you would call a nunnery. There I will find peace and quiet. I plan to dedicate some time to examining Roman Catholic doctrines and thoroughly studying how their system operates. If I conclude, as I partly suspect, that it is the best way to ensure everything is done properly and orderly, I will adopt the Roman Catholic faith and likely become a nun.' I showed no surprise at this decision and made no attempt to talk her out of it. 'That calling is absolutely perfect for you,' I thought, 'and I hope it brings you whatever good you seek!' When we said goodbye, she remarked, 'Farewell, cousin Jane Eyre; I wish you well. You possess some sense.' I replied, 'You are not without sense either, cousin Eliza, but I expect whatever sense you have will be effectively buried alive in a French convent within another year. However, it's not my concern, and as long as it suits you, I don't much care.' 'You are right,' she said, and with those words, we parted ways. As I won't need to mention either her or her sister again, I might as well state here that Georgiana made a beneficial marriage to a wealthy man of fashion who was past his prime, and Eliza did indeed take the veil. To this day, she is the superior of the convent where she completed her initial training, a convent she also provided with her financial means.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Mr. Rochester had granted me only a week off, but I ended up staying at Gateshead for an entire month. Though I wanted to leave right after the funeral, Georgiana begged me to remain until she could depart for London, having finally received an invitation from her uncle, Mr. Gibson, who had come to arrange his sister's funeral and handle family matters. Georgiana admitted she feared being left alone with Eliza, who offered her no comfort in her sadness, no support, nor any help in getting ready. So I tolerated her complaints and self-pity as best I could, helping with her sewing and packing. Admittedly, she didn't help much herself, and I thought, "If we had to live together long-term, things would have to change—I wouldn't be so patient or forgiving; I'd make sure she did her share of the work and didn't whine so much. But since our time together is brief and it's a sad occasion, I'm willing to put up with it for now." Eventually, I saw Georgiana off, but then Eliza asked me to stay another week while she made her own preparations to leave for a mysterious destination, spending her days alone, sorting her belongings and keeping to herself. She asked me to manage the house, receive visitors, and address letters of condolence.

One morning, Eliza told me I was free to go, thanking me for my help and noting the difference between living with me and Georgiana; I was independent and didn't trouble others. She said she was leaving for the Continent the following day to live in a religious house near Lisle—a nunnery—and intended to study Catholic doctrines, possibly even becoming a nun if she found the system worthy.

I neither objected nor showed surprise, thinking the life would suit her perfectly. When we parted, she wished me well, acknowledging my sense, and I replied that she too had sense, though soon it would likely be cloistered away in a French convent. We agreed this was her choice and parted ways. Since I won't mention them again, I should note that Georgiana married a rich but jaded man of fashion, while Eliza did indeed become a nun and eventually the head of the convent, to which she gave her inheritance.

events.title: Jane's Tedious Journey and Reflections on Homecoming
detailed_summary: Jane reflects on the concept of returning home, a sensation she has never truly experienced due to her past associations of returning with negative feelings or unfulfilled longings.
She notes that previous returns to Gateshead as a child or to Lowood from church were not pleasant and lacked any sense of magnetic pull towards a cherished destination.
Her journey back to Thornfield is depicted as long and monotonous, covering fifty miles each day over two days, with an overnight stay at an inn.

During the initial twelve hours of travel, Jane's mind is occupied with thoughts of Mrs. Reed in her final moments, the imagery of the funeral, and the contrasting personalities and prospective futures of Eliza and Georgiana.
The arrival in a large town in the evening serves to disrupt these somber reflections, causing her thoughts to shift from past events to anticipation of her return to Thornfield.
She acknowledges her destination is Thornfield but immediately questions how long her tenure there will last.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: How people feel when they are returning home from an absence, long or short, I did not know: I had never experienced the sensation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I was going back to Thornfield: but how long was I to stay there?

events.text_segment:
How people feel when they are returning home from an absence, long or short, I did not know: I had never experienced the sensation. I had known what it was to come back to Gateshead when a child after a long walk, to be scolded for looking cold or gloomy; and later, what it was to come back from church to Lowood, to long for a plenteous meal and a good fire, and to be unable to get either. Neither of these returnings was very pleasant or desirable: no magnet drew me to a given point, increasing in its strength of attraction the nearer I came. The return to Thornfield was yet to be tried.
My journey seemed tedious—very tedious: fifty miles one day, a night spent at an inn; fifty miles the next day. During the first twelve hours I thought of Mrs. Reed in her last moments; I saw her disfigured and discoloured face, and heard her strangely altered voice. I mused on the funeral day, the coffin, the hearse, the black train of tenants and servants—few was the number of relatives—the gaping vault, the silent church, the solemn service. Then I thought of Eliza and Georgiana; I beheld one the cynosure of a ball-room, the other the inmate of a convent cell; and I dwelt on and analysed their separate peculiarities of person and character. The evening arrival at the great town of —— scattered these thoughts; night gave them quite another turn: laid down on my traveller’s bed, I left reminiscence for anticipation.
I was going back to Thornfield: but how long was I to stay there?
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I was unfamiliar with the feelings people experience upon returning home after being away, whether for a short time or a long one, as I had never felt it myself. I knew what it was like as a child to come back to Gateshead after a lengthy walk and be criticized for appearing cold or unhappy; and later, what it was to return to Lowood from church, desperately wanting a substantial meal and a warm fire, neither of which I could obtain. Neither of these returns was pleasant or desired; no strong pull or attraction guided me towards a specific destination, intensifying as I got closer. My return to Thornfield was a new experience I had yet to undergo. My journey felt long and tiresome—a hundred miles covered over two days, with an overnight stop at an inn in between. For the first twelve hours, my thoughts were occupied with Mrs. Reed's final moments; I pictured her distorted and discolored face and heard her voice, so strangely altered. I contemplated the funeral day, the coffin, the hearse, the small procession of tenants and servants (with only a few relatives), the open grave, the quiet church, and the serious service. Then, I thought of Eliza and Georgiana; I imagined one as the life of a party and the other living in seclusion in a convent cell, and I pondered and analyzed their distinct physical appearances and personalities. Reaching the large town of ---- in the evening dispersed these thoughts; the night gave them a completely different direction: lying in my traveler's bed, I stopped dwelling on the past and began looking forward to the future. I was heading back to Thornfield, but I wondered how long I would actually stay there.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I had no experience of what people feel when they return home after being away, whether for a short or long period. As a child, I would go back to Gateshead after a walk, only to be rebuked for appearing cold or unhappy. Later, returning from church to Lowood, I would crave both a good meal and a warm fire—neither of which I could have. Those returns held little pleasure for me; nothing compelled me toward home with growing anticipation as I approached. I had not yet experienced what it would be like to go back to Thornfield.

The trip itself was quite wearisome: I traveled fifty miles in one day, spent the night at an inn, and covered another fifty miles the next day. For the first twelve hours, my mind dwelled on Mrs. Reed’s final moments—I pictured her altered appearance, heard her changed voice, and thought about her funeral, the coffin, the hearse, the somber group of tenants and servants, with only a few relatives present, the open vault, the quiet church, and the solemn ceremony. Then my thoughts shifted to Eliza and Georgiana—I imagined one as the center of attention at a ball, the other residing in a convent, and considered their differing personalities and looks. When I reached the large town that evening, these contemplations faded away, and night brought new musings. Lying in my bed as a traveler, I moved from memories to thinking about the future.

I was headed back to Thornfield, but for how long would I remain there?

events.title: Apprehensions about Thornfield and News of Mr. Rochester's Impending Marriage
detailed_summary: Jane feels a strong conviction that her upcoming stay at Thornfield will not be for an extended period.

She recalls information received via a letter from Mrs. Fairfax during her absence: the party at Thornfield Hall had dispersed, and Mr. Rochester had departed for London three weeks earlier, though he was expected to return within a fortnight.
Mrs. Fairfax had surmised that Mr. Rochester's trip to London was related to arrangements for his wedding, particularly his mention of purchasing a new carriage.
According to Mrs. Fairfax, while the idea of his marriage to Miss Ingram still seemed peculiar to her, widespread talk and her own observations made the event appear inevitable and imminent.
Jane internally agrees with this assessment, affirming her own lack of doubt regarding the impending marriage.
This certainty prompts the pressing question in Jane's mind about her own future and where she will go once the marriage takes place.
She recounts a disturbing dream where Miss Ingram symbolically bars her from Thornfield, directing her to another path, while Mr. Rochester observes with a seemingly sardonic smile.
Jane explains she had deliberately not informed Mrs. Fairfax of the precise day of her return, as she wished to avoid being met by any vehicle at Millcote.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Not long; of that I was sure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I had not notified to Mrs. Fairfax the exact day of my return; for I did not wish either car or carriage to meet me at Millcote.

events.text_segment:
Not long; of that I was sure. I had heard from Mrs. Fairfax in the interim of my absence: the party at the hall was dispersed; Mr. Rochester had left for London three weeks ago, but he was then expected to return in a fortnight. Mrs. Fairfax surmised that he was gone to make arrangements for his wedding, as he had talked of purchasing a new carriage: she said the idea of his marrying Miss Ingram still seemed strange to her; but from what everybody said, and from what she had herself seen, she could no longer doubt that the event would shortly take place. “You would be strangely incredulous if you did doubt it,” was my mental comment. “I don’t doubt it.”
The question followed, “Where was I to go?” I dreamt of Miss Ingram all the night: in a vivid morning dream I saw her closing the gates of Thornfield against me and pointing me out another road; and Mr. Rochester looked on with his arms folded—smiling sardonically, as it seemed, at both her and me.
I had not notified to Mrs. Fairfax the exact day of my return; for I did not wish either car or carriage to meet me at Millcote.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I was certain my absence would not be lengthy. While I was away, I had received correspondence from Mrs. Fairfax. She informed me that the gathering at the hall had ended; Mr. Rochester had departed for London three weeks prior but was anticipated to return in two weeks. Mrs. Fairfax speculated that he had gone to finalize plans for his wedding, mentioning his talk of buying a new carriage. She confessed that the idea of his marrying Miss Ingram still struck her as peculiar, yet based on general opinion and her own observations, she could no longer doubt that the event would occur soon. My inner thought was, “You’d have to be exceptionally disbelieving to still question it.” “I have no doubts.” The subsequent question that arose was, “Where would I go?” I dreamt of Miss Ingram throughout the night; in a vivid dream just before waking, I saw her obstructing my entry to Thornfield and indicating an alternative route, while Mr. Rochester observed, arms crossed, seemingly smirking sardonically at both of us. I had not given Mrs. Fairfax the precise date of my return because I did not want a vehicle, either a cab or carriage, waiting for me at Millcote.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I was certain it wouldn’t be long. While I was away, Mrs. Fairfax had written to me: the guests at the hall had left, and Mr. Rochester had gone to London three weeks before, but was expected back in about two weeks. Mrs. Fairfax guessed he went to arrange his wedding, since he had mentioned buying a carriage. She admitted that marrying Miss Ingram still seemed odd to her, but based on what she’d heard and seen, she couldn’t doubt it would happen soon. Internally, I thought that only someone extremely skeptical could question it—I didn’t. Then I wondered, “Where would I go?” That night, I dreamed constantly of Miss Ingram: at dawn I imagined her shutting the Thornfield gates on me, sending me away, while Mr. Rochester just stood by with folded arms, watching us with a mocking smile. I had not told Mrs. Fairfax my exact return date because I did not want a car or carriage to fetch me at Millcote.

events.title: Jane's Solitary Walk to Thornfield and Unexpected Sighting of Mr. Rochester
detailed_summary: Jane decides to walk the final stretch from Millcote to Thornfield by herself, seeking quiet solitude for her arrival.
After leaving her luggage at the George Inn, she sets off around six o'clock on a June evening, choosing an old, less-traveled road that passes mainly through fields.

The evening atmosphere is described as fair and gentle, though not brilliantly sunny; haymakers are seen working along the route, and the sky, despite some cloud cover, holds a promise of good weather.
The western sky is particularly beautiful, with a warm, golden-red glow emanating from behind marbled clouds, likened to a hidden fire or altar.
As the road shortens and she draws nearer to Thornfield, Jane experiences a strong sense of gladness, so profound that she pauses to question its meaning.

She consciously reminds herself that Thornfield is not her true home, nor a permanent haven, and that no loving friends are eagerly awaiting her, apart from the expected calm welcome from Mrs. Fairfax and Adèle's childish delight.
She recognizes that her joy is tied to the thought of another person—Mr. Rochester—who, she believes, is not thinking of her.

Despite this rational assessment, her youthful impetuosity and inexperience urge her to seize the chance to see Mr. Rochester again, even if only for a short time before their anticipated permanent separation.
Suppressing a surge of fresh pain, she quickens her pace.
Upon reaching the Thornfield meadows, she sees laborers concluding their haymaking for the day.
She observes the profusion of roses in the hedges but feels no desire to gather them, driven by an urgent wish to reach the house.
As she passes a distinctive briar and approaches a narrow stile with stone steps, she suddenly sees Mr. Rochester seated there, occupied with a book and pencil, writing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I proposed to walk the distance quietly by myself; and very quietly, after leaving my box in the ostler’s care, did I slip away from the George Inn, about six o’clock of a June evening, and take the old road to Thornfield: a road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I see the narrow stile with stone steps; and I see—Mr. Rochester sitting there, a book and a pencil in his hand; he is writing.

events.text_segment:
I proposed to walk the distance quietly by myself; and very quietly, after leaving my box in the ostler’s care, did I slip away from the George Inn, about six o’clock of a June evening, and take the old road to Thornfield: a road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented.
It was not a bright or splendid summer evening, though fair and soft: the haymakers were at work all along the road; and the sky, though far from cloudless, was such as promised well for the future: its blue—where blue was visible—was mild and settled, and its cloud strata high and thin. The west, too, was warm: no watery gleam chilled it—it seemed as if there was a fire lit, an altar burning behind its screen of marbled vapour, and out of apertures shone a golden redness.
I felt glad as the road shortened before me: so glad that I stopped once to ask myself what that joy meant: and to remind reason that it was not to my home I was going, or to a permanent resting-place, or to a place where fond friends looked out for me and waited my arrival. “Mrs. Fairfax will smile you a calm welcome, to be sure,” said I; “and little Adèle will clap her hands and jump to see you: but you know very well you are thinking of another than they, and that he is not thinking of you.”
But what is so headstrong as youth? What so blind as inexperience? These affirmed that it was pleasure enough to have the privilege of again looking on Mr. Rochester, whether he looked on me or not; and they added—“Hasten! hasten! be with him while you may: but a few more days or weeks, at most, and you are parted from him for ever!” And then I strangled a new-born agony—a deformed thing which I could not persuade myself to own and rear—and ran on.
They are making hay, too, in Thornfield meadows: or rather, the labourers are just quitting their work, and returning home with their rakes on their shoulders, now, at the hour I arrive. I have but a field or two to traverse, and then I shall cross the road and reach the gates. How full the hedges are of roses! But I have no time to gather any; I want to be at the house. I passed a tall briar, shooting leafy and flowery branches across the path; I see the narrow stile with stone steps; and I see—Mr. Rochester sitting there, a book and a pencil in his hand; he is writing.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I opted to walk the distance back alone at a calm pace. After leaving my luggage under the ostler’s supervision, I slipped away from the George Inn quite unobtrusively around six o'clock on a June evening and took the old path towards Thornfield. This route primarily traversed fields and was not heavily used at the time. It wasn't a particularly bright or magnificent summer evening, though it was pleasant and gentle. Haymakers were actively working alongside the road, and the sky, while not entirely clear, looked promising for the weather ahead. Its blue, where visible, was soft and settled, and the cloud layers were high and thin. The western horizon felt warm; no watery glint cooled it. It appeared as if a fire was burning, or an altar alight behind its screen of marbled clouds, with a golden-red light shining through openings. I felt happy as the journey shortened before me – so happy that I paused once to question the source of this joy and remind my rational mind that I was not returning to my actual home, a permanent dwelling, or a place where beloved friends awaited my arrival. 'Certainly, Mrs. Fairfax will greet you with a composed welcome,' I told myself, 'and little Adèle will clap her hands and jump excitedly to see you, but you know perfectly well your thoughts are focused on someone other than them, and he is not thinking of you.' But what is more impulsive than youth? What is more ignorant than lack of experience? These parts of me insisted that simply having the opportunity to see Mr. Rochester again was sufficient pleasure, regardless of whether he noticed me. They urged, 'Hurry! Hurry! Be with him while you still can; in just a few more days or weeks, at most, you will be separated from him permanently!' And then I stifled a burgeoning pain – a twisted feeling I couldn't bring myself to acknowledge or accept – and ran on. They are also making hay in the meadows at Thornfield, or rather, the workers are just finishing their labor and heading home with their rakes over their shoulders, precisely at the hour I arrive. I only have one or two fields left to cross before I reach the road and the gates. The hedges are overflowing with roses! But I don't have time to pick any; I am eager to reach the house. I passed a tall wild rose bush that stretched its leafy, blooming branches across the path. I see the narrow stile with stone steps, and there I see – Mr. Rochester sitting there with a book and a pencil in his hand. He is writing.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I decided to make the walk on my own in peace; so, after giving my box to the ostler for safekeeping, I quietly left the George Inn at around six in the evening on a June day and took the old road to Thornfield. This road went mostly through fields and was now rarely used. The evening was gentle and pleasant, though not particularly bright or spectacular; haymakers were busy along the route. The sky, though not completely clear, looked promising for the coming days; where it was blue, the color was soft and calm, and the clouds were high and thin. In the west, there was a comforting warmth, with no cold gleam dulling it—it looked as if a fire was glowing behind the marbled clouds, with golden-red light shining through. As I drew nearer to my destination, my happiness grew, and I paused for a moment to question and remind myself that I was not heading home, nor to a place of lasting welcome or loving friends. 'Mrs. Fairfax will receive you kindly,' I told myself, 'and little Adèle will be excited to see you; but you know who you are really thinking of, and he is not thinking of you.' Still, what could be more reckless than youth or as unaware as inexperience? These feelings insisted that just being able to see Mr. Rochester again was joy enough, whether or not he noticed me; and they urged me, 'Hurry! Make the most of your time with him, for it will not last. Soon, you’ll be separated from him forever.' With that, I forced down a pain I could not bear to acknowledge and hurried onward. The haymaking was ending at Thornfield as well; the workers were leaving, carrying their rakes home as I arrived. I had only a couple more fields to go before crossing the road to the gates. The hedges overflowed with roses, but I had no time to pick any; I was eager to reach the house. I passed a tall bramble stretching leafy, blossoming boughs across my path; then I saw the narrow stone stile, and there was Mr. Rochester, sitting with a book and pencil in hand, writing.

events.title: Jane's Overwhelming Reunion and Intimate Exchange with Mr. Rochester
detailed_summary: The sight of Mr. Rochester completely unnerves Jane; she feels a momentary loss of self-control, as if her very nerves have come undone.

She is taken aback by the intensity of her physical reaction—trembling and an inability to speak or move—and briefly contemplates retreating to avoid embarrassing herself, knowing another path to the house.
However, before she can withdraw, Mr. Rochester spots her, exclaims a greeting, and beckons her forward, setting aside his book and pencil.
Jane advances, acutely aware of her movements and striving to maintain an appearance of calm, especially struggling to control her facial expressions which threaten to betray her inner turmoil.
Mr. Rochester remarks on her unconventional arrival—on foot and at twilight—likening her to a supernatural being, and queries her activities during her month-long absence.
Jane informs him she was with her aunt, who has since passed away.

He playfully comments on her characteristic response, suggesting she has emerged from the realm of the dead, and teases her about her ethereal, elusive nature, comparing her to an elf or an ignis fatuus, before affectionately calling her a 'truant' for being away so long and supposedly forgetting him.
Jane finds immense comfort and pleasure in his words, particularly his implication that her absence was felt and his reference to Thornfield as her home.
She asks if he had been to London, which he initially attributes to her 'second-sight' before she clarifies Mrs. Fairfax had written to her.

When he asks if she knew the purpose of his London trip and she confirms, he invites her to inspect the new carriage intended for 'Mrs. Rochester,' asking for her opinion on its suitability and whether his future wife would look queenly in it.
He then wistfully asks Jane, his 'fairy,' if she can provide a charm to make him handsome.

Jane responds that such a transformation would be beyond magic, while silently thinking that a loving gaze is the only charm required and that his stern features possess a power surpassing mere beauty.

Mr. Rochester, despite sometimes being able to discern her unvoiced thoughts, does not comment on her inner reflection but bestows upon her a rare, genuinely warm smile, which Jane perceives as 'the real sunshine of feeling.'
He then makes space for her to pass the stile, addressing her as 'Janet' and inviting her to 'go up home' and rest at a 'friend's threshold.'
Impulsively, Jane turns back and expresses her profound gratitude for his kindness, declaring that wherever he is feels like her 'only home.'
She then hurries away from him at a rapid pace.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, he is not a ghost; yet every nerve I have is unstrung: for a moment I am beyond my own mastery.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I walked on so fast that even he could hardly have overtaken me had he tried.

events.text_segment:
Well, he is not a ghost; yet every nerve I have is unstrung: for a moment I am beyond my own mastery. What does it mean? I did not think I should tremble in this way when I saw him, or lose my voice or the power of motion in his presence. I will go back as soon as I can stir: I need not make an absolute fool of myself. I know another way to the house. It does not signify if I knew twenty ways; for he has seen me.
“Hillo!” he cries; and he puts up his book and his pencil. “There you are! Come on, if you please.”
I suppose I do come on; though in what fashion I know not; being scarcely cognisant of my movements, and solicitous only to appear calm; and, above all, to control the working muscles of my face—which I feel rebel insolently against my will, and struggle to express what I had resolved to conceal. But I have a veil—it is down: I may make shift yet to behave with decent composure.
“And this is Jane Eyre? Are you coming from Millcote, and on foot? Yes—just one of your tricks: not to send for a carriage, and come clattering over street and road like a common mortal, but to steal into the vicinage of your home along with twilight, just as if you were a dream or a shade. What the deuce have you done with yourself this last month?”
“I have been with my aunt, sir, who is dead.”
“A true Janian reply! Good angels be my guard! She comes from the other world—from the abode of people who are dead; and tells me so when she meets me alone here in the gloaming! If I dared, I’d touch you, to see if you are substance or shadow, you elf!—but I’d as soon offer to take hold of a blue ignis fatuus light in a marsh. Truant! truant!” he added, when he had paused an instant. “Absent from me a whole month, and forgetting me quite, I’ll be sworn!”
I knew there would be pleasure in meeting my master again, even though broken by the fear that he was so soon to cease to be my master, and by the knowledge that I was nothing to him: but there was ever in Mr. Rochester (so at least I thought) such a wealth of the power of communicating happiness, that to taste but of the crumbs he scattered to stray and stranger birds like me, was to feast genially. His last words were balm: they seemed to imply that it imported something to him whether I forgot him or not. And he had spoken of Thornfield as my home—would that it were my home!
He did not leave the stile, and I hardly liked to ask to go by. I inquired soon if he had not been to London.
“Yes; I suppose you found that out by second-sight.”
“Mrs. Fairfax told me in a letter.”
“And did she inform you what I went to do?”
“Oh, yes, sir! Everybody knew your errand.”
“You must see the carriage, Jane, and tell me if you don’t think it will suit Mrs. Rochester exactly; and whether she won’t look like Queen Boadicea, leaning back against those purple cushions. I wish, Jane, I were a trifle better adapted to match with her externally. Tell me now, fairy as you are—can’t you give me a charm, or a philter, or something of that sort, to make me a handsome man?”
“It would be past the power of magic, sir;” and, in thought, I added, “A loving eye is all the charm needed: to such you are handsome enough; or rather your sternness has a power beyond beauty.”
Mr. Rochester had sometimes read my unspoken thoughts with an acumen to me incomprehensible: in the present instance he took no notice of my abrupt vocal response; but he smiled at me with a certain smile he had of his own, and which he used but on rare occasions. He seemed to think it too good for common purposes: it was the real sunshine of feeling—he shed it over me now.
“Pass, Janet,” said he, making room for me to cross the stile: “go up home, and stay your weary little wandering feet at a friend’s threshold.”
All I had now to do was to obey him in silence: no need for me to colloquise further. I got over the stile without a word, and meant to leave him calmly. An impulse held me fast—a force turned me round. I said—or something in me said for me, and in spite of me—
“Thank you, Mr. Rochester, for your great kindness. I am strangely glad to get back again to you: and wherever you are is my home—my only home.”
I walked on so fast that even he could hardly have overtaken me had he tried.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Okay, he's not a ghost, yet every nerve I have is tense and trembling; for a moment, I can't control myself. What is happening? I didn't expect to shake like this when I saw him, or lose my voice and ability to move when he was near. I'll go back as soon as I can manage to stir. I don't need to make a complete fool of myself. I know a different route to the house. But it doesn't matter if I knew twenty routes, because he has seen me.

"Hello!" he shouts, putting away his book and pencil. "There you are! Come here, please."

I suppose I do walk towards him, though I'm not sure how; I'm barely aware of my movements, only focused on appearing calm and, most of all, controlling my facial muscles – which feel like they're insolently fighting against my will, struggling to show what I was determined to hide. But I have a veil pulled down, so maybe I can still manage to act with some decent composure.

"And you are Jane Eyre? Are you arriving from Millcote, and on foot? Yes, typical of your ways – not asking for a carriage and making a lot of noise coming through town and country like everyone else, but sneaking into the area near your home as dusk falls, just as if you were a dream or a spirit. What on earth have you been doing with yourself this past month?"

"I have been with my aunt, sir, who has passed away."

"A truly Jane-like answer! May good angels protect me! She comes from the other world – from where dead people reside – and tells me this when she meets me alone here in the twilight! If I dared, I'd touch you to see if you are real or just a shade, you little sprite! – but I'd sooner try to grab a glowing blue marsh gas light in a bog. Runaway! Runaway!" he added after a brief pause. "Away from me for a whole month, and completely forgetting me, I'm sure!"

I knew there would be happiness in seeing my employer again, even though it was overshadowed by the fear that he would soon no longer be my employer, and by the knowledge that I meant nothing important to him. But Mr. Rochester always seemed to possess (at least I thought so) such a great ability to spread happiness, that to experience even the tiny bits he gave to stray, unfamiliar people like me felt like a truly enjoyable feast. His last words were comforting; they seemed to suggest that it mattered to him whether I forgot him or not. And he had referred to Thornfield as my home – I desperately wished it were my home!

He remained by the stone steps, and I felt awkward asking to pass. I soon asked if he hadn't been to London.

"Yes; I assume you figured that out using second-sight."

"Mrs. Fairfax mentioned it in a letter."

"And did she tell you why I went?"

"Oh, yes, sir! Everyone knew why you were going."

"You must see the carriage, Jane, and tell me if you don't think it will be perfect for Mrs. Rochester; and whether she won't look like Queen Boadicea leaning back against those purple cushions. I wish, Jane, that I were slightly better looking to match her appearance. Tell me now, you fairy-like creature – can't you give me a charm, or a potion, or something similar to make me a handsome man?"

"That would be beyond the power of magic, sir;" and, to myself, I added, "A loving gaze is all the magic needed: to someone who loves you, you are handsome enough; or rather, your sternness has a power that surpasses beauty."

Mr. Rochester had sometimes understood my unspoken thoughts with a perception that I couldn't understand. In this instance, he didn't react to my sudden spoken reply, but he smiled at me with a unique smile of his own, one he used only on rare occasions. He seemed to consider it too precious for everyday use; it was the genuine warmth of emotion, and he directed it towards me then.

"Pass, Janet," he said, moving aside to let me cross the steps. "Go on home, and rest your tired little wandering feet at a friend's entrance."

All I had to do then was obey him in silence; there was no need for me to talk any further. I climbed over the steps without a word, intending to leave him calmly. An impulse held me still – a force turned me around. I said – or something inside me said for me, against my will –

"Thank you, Mr. Rochester, for your great kindness. I am strangely happy to be back with you again; and wherever you are is my home – my only home."

I walked away so quickly that even he would have found it difficult to catch me if he had tried.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Although he isn't a ghost, seeing him leaves me feeling nervous and almost unable to control myself for a moment. Why do I feel this way? I didn't expect to physically tremble, lose my voice, or be unable to move just because I saw him. As soon as I can, I'll go back—there's no need to look utterly foolish. I know another way to return to the house, but it doesn't matter, since he has already noticed me.

He calls, 'Hillo!' and puts his book and pencil away. 'There you are! Come here, if you please.'

I approach him, though I don't really know how I'm moving, only that I'm anxious to seem calm and especially to keep my face from revealing my true feelings—though the effort is difficult. Luckily, I'm veiled, so I might just manage to act with composure.

'And this is Jane Eyre? Have you come from Millcote, and all on foot? Trust you to do that—never sending for a carriage and arriving loudly like others, but sneaking quietly home with the twilight, like some specter or spirit. What have you been up to for the last month?'

'I was with my aunt, sir—she has died.'

'A typical Jane reply! Angels protect me! You come from the world of the dead, and inform me so here in the dusk! If I dared, I’d touch you to see if you're flesh or phantom, you elf! I might as well try grasping swamp lights. Truant! Gone for a whole month, forgetting me—I’m sure of it!'

I had anticipated it would be a pleasure to see Mr. Rochester again, though I was anxious over the thought that he would soon no longer be my employer, and that I meant nothing to him. Still, Mr. Rochester, I thought, had a remarkable ability to give happiness, and receiving just a little of his kindness felt like a feast. His last words were comforting; they hinted that it mattered to him whether or not I had forgotten him. He even called Thornfield my home—how I wish it truly were!

He remained at the stile, so I didn't like to ask to get by. I asked instead whether he had been to London.

'Yes; you must have guessed that with your second sight.'

'Mrs. Fairfax told me in a letter.'

'And did she tell you why I went?'

'Oh yes, sir. Everyone knew your purpose.'

'You must look at the carriage, Jane, and tell me if it won't be perfect for Mrs. Rochester. Won't she look like Queen Boadicea on those purple cushions? I wish I looked a little better beside her. Tell me, fairy, can’t you conjure some potion or spell to make me handsome?'

'No magic could do that, sir.' I thought, 'A loving gaze is the only charm needed; to them, you’re handsome enough—your fierceness is more powerful than beauty.'

Mr. Rochester often seemed to sense my unspoken thoughts, but this time he only smiled at me with that rare, special smile—sunshine from his heart that he seldom shared, but now bestowed on me.

'Go ahead, Janet,' he said, making space for me to cross the stile. 'Go home and rest your tired feet at a friend’s door.'

I obeyed silently—there was no need to say more. I crossed the stile and intended to leave quietly, but something compelled me to turn and say, 'Thank you, Mr. Rochester, for all your kindness. I’m truly glad to be back with you, and wherever you are is my only home.'

I hurried away so quickly that he could hardly have caught up even if he’d tried.

events.title: Warm Welcome at Thornfield and a Glimmer of Hope for the Future
detailed_summary: Upon Jane's arrival at Thornfield Hall, little Adèle greets her with unrestrained joy.
Mrs. Fairfax offers her usual calm and friendly welcome.
The servants, Leah and Sophie, also express pleasure at her return, with Sophie even bidding her a cheerful 'bon soir.'
Jane reflects on the deep happiness found in being cherished by others and knowing one's presence contributes to their comfort.
That evening, Jane makes a conscious effort to push aside anxieties about her future and warnings of impending separation and sorrow.
A tranquil domestic scene unfolds as Mrs. Fairfax knits, Jane takes a low seat beside her, and Adèle nestles affectionately close to Jane, creating an atmosphere of mutual affection and peacefulness.
In this moment of contentment, Jane offers a silent prayer that their little group might not be separated soon or by a great distance.
Mr. Rochester then enters the room unannounced and seems to observe their amicable gathering with pleasure.
He remarks that Mrs. Fairfax must be content now that her 'adopted daughter' (Jane) has returned and notes Adèle's evident fondness for her 'petite maman Anglaise.'

These comments from Mr. Rochester ignite a small spark of hope in Jane that he might, even after his marriage, find a way to keep her, Adèle, and Mrs. Fairfax together under his protection, not entirely banishing them from his presence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Little Adèle was half wild with delight when she saw me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I half ventured to hope that he would, even after his marriage, keep us together somewhere under the shelter of his protection, and not quite exiled from the sunshine of his presence.

events.text_segment:
Little Adèle was half wild with delight when she saw me. Mrs. Fairfax received me with her usual plain friendliness. Leah smiled, and even Sophie bid me “bon soir” with glee. This was very pleasant; there is no happiness like that of being loved by your fellow-creatures, and feeling that your presence is an addition to their comfort.
I that evening shut my eyes resolutely against the future: I stopped my ears against the voice that kept warning me of near separation and coming grief. When tea was over and Mrs. Fairfax had taken her knitting, and I had assumed a low seat near her, and Adèle, kneeling on the carpet, had nestled close up to me, and a sense of mutual affection seemed to surround us with a ring of golden peace, I uttered a silent prayer that we might not be parted far or soon; but when, as we thus sat, Mr. Rochester entered, unannounced, and looking at us, seemed to take pleasure in the spectacle of a group so amicable—when he said he supposed the old lady was all right now that she had got her adopted daughter back again, and added that he saw Adèle was “prête à croquer sa petite maman Anglaise”—I half ventured to hope that he would, even after his marriage, keep us together somewhere under the shelter of his protection, and not quite exiled from the sunshine of his presence.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Upon my return, little Adèle was overflowing with joy to see me. Mrs. Fairfax greeted me with her usual direct and pleasant manner. Leah smiled, and even Sophie cheerfully said "good evening" in French. This welcome was very comforting; there's no happiness quite like feeling loved by your fellow human beings and knowing your presence brings them contentment. That evening, I deliberately ignored thoughts of the future. I wouldn't listen to the inner voice warning me of impending separation and sadness. After tea, when Mrs. Fairfax had started her knitting, I took a low seat nearby, and Adèle, kneeling on the carpet, nestled close to me. A feeling of mutual fondness seemed to create a circle of calm, peacefulness around us. I silently prayed that we would not be parted widely or soon. However, as we were sitting like this, Mr. Rochester entered without announcement. He looked at us and seemed to take pleasure in the sight of such a harmonious group. When he said he presumed the old lady (Mrs. Fairfax) was fine now that her 'adopted daughter' was back, and added that he saw Adèle was ready to 'gobble up her little English mummy,' I cautiously allowed myself to hope that perhaps, even after his marriage, he might keep us together somewhere under his care, and not completely remove us from the warmth of his presence.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Little Adèle was overjoyed when she saw me, barely able to contain her excitement. Mrs. Fairfax greeted me with her usual straightforward kindness, Leah smiled, and even Sophie cheerfully wished me good evening. It was truly gratifying; there’s nothing quite like the happiness that comes from being loved by others and knowing that your presence brings them comfort. That night, I deliberately refused to think about what the future might bring—I ignored the inner voice warning me of our impending separation and sorrow. After tea, as Mrs. Fairfax took up her knitting, I sat in a low chair nearby, and Adèle knelt by the carpet, cuddling close to me. Surrounded by this affectionate atmosphere, I silently wished that we wouldn’t be forced apart anytime soon. Then, while we sat together, Mr. Rochester entered quietly, observed us, and seemed pleased by the harmonious scene. He remarked that Mrs. Fairfax must be content now that her adopted daughter had returned, and noted that Adèle was eager to enjoy the company of her English maman. In that moment, I dared hope that even after his marriage, Mr. Rochester might let us all remain together, sheltered under his care, and not completely banished from his presence.

events.title: A Fortnight of Uncertain Calm and Jane's Growing, Painful Hope
detailed_summary: Following Jane's return, a two-week period of 'dubious calm' settles over Thornfield Hall.
During this time, there is no discussion of Mr. Rochester's anticipated marriage, nor does Jane observe any preparations for such an event.
Jane regularly inquires with Mrs. Fairfax if any decisive news has emerged, but Mrs. Fairfax consistently reports nothing new.

Mrs. Fairfax shares that she once directly questioned Mr. Rochester about when he planned to bring his bride home, but he responded only with a jest and one of his characteristic 'queer looks,' leaving her uncertain of his intentions.

Jane finds it particularly noteworthy that Mr. Rochester undertakes no journeys to Ingram Park, nor receives any visits from there, despite the twenty-mile distance being insignificant for an ardent lover and skilled horseman like him.

This lack of activity causes Jane to begin cherishing hopes she feels she isn't entitled to: that the engagement might be called off, that the rumors were mistaken, or that one or both parties involved had experienced a change of mind.
She observes Mr. Rochester's demeanor closely, looking for signs of sadness or agitation, but finds his expression consistently clear of any negative emotions.
Furthermore, she notes that if she herself appears dispirited during the time she and her pupil, Adèle, spend with him, Mr. Rochester becomes notably more cheerful and engaging.
He calls for her presence more frequently than ever before and demonstrates an unprecedented level of kindness towards her.
Jane acknowledges, with a sense of sorrow, that as a result of his behavior, her love for him has grown deeper than ever.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A fortnight of dubious calm succeeded my return to Thornfield Hall.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Never had he called me more frequently to his presence; never been kinder to me when there—and, alas! never had I loved him so well.

events.text_segment:
A fortnight of dubious calm succeeded my return to Thornfield Hall. Nothing was said of the master’s marriage, and I saw no preparation going on for such an event. Almost every day I asked Mrs. Fairfax if she had yet heard anything decided: her answer was always in the negative. Once she said she had actually put the question to Mr. Rochester as to when he was going to bring his bride home; but he had answered her only by a joke and one of his queer looks, and she could not tell what to make of him.
One thing specially surprised me, and that was, there were no journeyings backward and forward, no visits to Ingram Park: to be sure it was twenty miles off, on the borders of another county; but what was that distance to an ardent lover? To so practised and indefatigable a horseman as Mr. Rochester, it would be but a morning’s ride. I began to cherish hopes I had no right to conceive: that the match was broken off; that rumour had been mistaken; that one or both parties had changed their minds. I used to look at my master’s face to see if it were sad or fierce; but I could not remember the time when it had been so uniformly clear of clouds or evil feelings. If, in the moments I and my pupil spent with him, I lacked spirits and sank into inevitable dejection, he became even gay. Never had he called me more frequently to his presence; never been kinder to me when there—and, alas! never had I loved him so well.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Following my return to Thornfield Hall, a period of two weeks unfolded with an uncertain tranquility. There was no discussion about the master's impending marriage, nor did I observe any preparations being made for such an event. Almost daily, I inquired of Mrs. Fairfax whether she had received any definitive news; her response was invariably negative. On one occasion, she mentioned having directly asked Mr. Rochester when he planned to bring his bride home, but he had only replied with a joke and one of his peculiar looks, leaving her bewildered. One particular point of surprise for me was the complete absence of travel back and forth, no visits to Ingram Park. While it was twenty miles away, located on the border of another county, such a distance would typically mean little to an impassioned lover. For an accomplished and tireless horseman like Mr. Rochester, it was merely a morning's ride. I began to harbor hopes I knew I had no right to entertain: perhaps the engagement had been called off, the rumors were inaccurate, or one or both individuals had reconsidered. I frequently studied my master's face, searching for signs of sadness or fierceness, but I couldn't recall a time when his expression had been so consistently free from gloom or ill temper. During the times my pupil and I spent with him, if I felt low-spirited and succumbed to unavoidable melancholy, he would become remarkably cheerful. He summoned me to his presence more often than ever before, was exceptionally kind to me when I was there—and tragically, my affection for him had never been stronger.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Two weeks of uncertain peace followed my return to Thornfield Hall. No one spoke about the master's marriage, and I noticed no preparations for it either. Nearly every day I asked Mrs. Fairfax if there was any news or decisions, but she always replied no. She once told me she had asked Mr. Rochester directly when he would bring his bride home, but he only replied with a joke and one of his strange looks, leaving her puzzled. I found it especially odd that there were no trips to or from Ingram Park—although it was twenty miles away in another county, the distance would be nothing for a devoted lover or someone like Mr. Rochester who was skilled and tireless on horseback. These circumstances led me to secretly hope—though I knew I shouldn't—that the engagement was off, that the gossip had been wrong, or that someone had changed their mind. I watched Mr. Rochester's expression for signs of sadness or anger, but I couldn't recall a time when he had seemed so consistently calm and free of dark moods. If, during the time I spent with him and my pupil, I felt low or despondent, he seemed all the more cheerful. He had never called me to see him more often, nor treated me with such kindness—and, sadly, I had never loved him more.

events.title: Jane Seeks Solitude in the Midsummer Orchard
detailed_summary: The narrative opens with a description of an exceptionally beautiful Midsummer period in England.
Adèle, having spent the day gathering strawberries, has retired to bed early.
Jane, after seeing Adèle asleep, seeks the tranquility of the Thornfield garden.
She reflects on the beauty of the twilight hour, with its fading sunset and the emergence of an early star.
While initially walking on the pavement, Jane detects the scent of Mr. Rochester's cigar emanating from the library window.
Aware she might be observed, she moves to the more secluded and picturesque orchard, a place she finds Eden-like and peaceful, wishing she could remain there indefinitely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A splendid Midsummer shone over England: skies so pure, suns so radiant as were then seen in long succession, seldom favour even singly, our wave-girt land.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Here one could wander unseen.

events.text_segment:
A splendid Midsummer shone over England: skies so pure, suns so radiant as were then seen in long succession, seldom favour even singly, our wave-girt land. It was as if a band of Italian days had come from the South, like a flock of glorious passenger birds, and lighted to rest them on the cliffs of Albion. The hay was all got in; the fields round Thornfield were green and shorn; the roads white and baked; the trees were in their dark prime; hedge and wood, full-leaved and deeply tinted, contrasted well with the sunny hue of the cleared meadows between.
On Midsummer-eve, Adèle, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay Lane half the day, had gone to bed with the sun. I watched her drop asleep, and when I left her, I sought the garden.
It was now the sweetest hour of the twenty-four:—“Day its fervid fires had wasted,” and dew fell cool on panting plain and scorched summit. Where the sun had gone down in simple state—pure of the pomp of clouds—spread a solemn purple, burning with the light of red jewel and furnace flame at one point, on one hill-peak, and extending high and wide, soft and still softer, over half heaven. The east had its own charm or fine deep blue, and its own modest gem, a rising and solitary star: soon it would boast the moon; but she was yet beneath the horizon.
I walked a while on the pavement; but a subtle, well-known scent—that of a cigar—stole from some window; I saw the library casement open a handbreadth; I knew I might be watched thence; so I went apart into the orchard. No nook in the grounds more sheltered and more Eden-like; it was full of trees, it bloomed with flowers: a very high wall shut it out from the court, on one side; on the other, a beech avenue screened it from the lawn. At the bottom was a sunk fence; its sole separation from lonely fields: a winding walk, bordered with laurels and terminating in a giant horse-chestnut, circled at the base by a seat, led down to the fence. Here one could wander unseen.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A magnificent Midsummer graced England: skies so clear and suns so bright as were seen in a long series rarely bless our island nation, even individually. It was as if a group of Italian days had traveled from the south, like a flock of beautiful migratory birds, and settled to rest on England's cliffs. The hay had all been harvested; the fields surrounding Thornfield were green and neatly mown; the roads were white and dried by the sun; the trees were in their full, dark foliage; the hedges and woods, dense with leaves and deeply colored, provided a pleasant contrast to the bright, sunny hue of the cleared fields between them. On the evening of Midsummer, Adèle, fatigued from picking wild strawberries in Hay Lane for half the day, had gone to bed with the setting sun. I watched her fall asleep, and after leaving her, I made my way to the garden. This was now the most delightful hour of the twenty-four: 'Day had exhausted its intense heat,' and cool dew settled on the thirsty ground and dried hilltops. Where the sun had set plainly, without the grandeur of clouds, a solemn purple color spread, glowing like a red jewel or furnace fire at one spot, on a single hill-peak, and extending high and wide, becoming softer and softer over half the sky. The east had its own charm in a lovely deep blue, and its own modest gem, a rising and solitary star; the moon would soon be visible, but it was not yet above the horizon. I walked for a while on the paved path; but a subtle, familiar scent—that of a cigar—drifted from a window; I saw the library window open just a handbreadth; I knew I might be observed from there; so I moved away into the orchard. No other place on the grounds was as secluded and as like paradise; it was filled with trees and blooming with flowers: a very tall wall separated it from the courtyard on one side; on the other, a line of beech trees screened it from the lawn. At the lower edge was a ha-ha (sunk fence), its only boundary from the isolated fields beyond: a winding path, lined with laurel bushes and ending at a giant horse-chestnut tree with a seat around its base, led down to the fence. Here, one could walk unseen.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
A glorious midsummer covered England, with days of clear skies and shining sun following one after another—weather rarely experienced, even occasionally, in this island nation. It felt as if a string of Italian days had flown up from the south, like beautiful migrating birds, and come to rest along England’s shore. All the hay had already been harvested; the fields around Thornfield were green and trimmed; the roads were pale and dry; the trees were thick with leaves, and both hedges and woods were deep in color, beautifully contrasting with the golden, sunny meadows in between.

On Midsummer Eve, Adèle, tired from spending much of the day picking wild strawberries along Hay Lane, had gone to bed with the sunset. I stayed with her until she fell asleep, and then I made my way to the garden.

That was the most pleasant moment of the day: the heat of the afternoon had faded, and a cool dew descended over the overheated land. In the west, the sun had set simply and grandly, without dramatic clouds—leaving a deep purple glow, flickering with the red of jewels and fiery light at one point on a distant hillside, spreading gently upwards across much of the sky. To the east, the sky was a rich, deep blue, showcasing a lone, rising star—a modest gem that would soon be joined by the moon, still hidden below the horizon.

I strolled along the path for a time, but then I caught a familiar scent of cigar drifting out from a slightly opened library window—I realized I could be observed from there. So I moved away into the orchard, the most hidden and idyllic spot on the grounds, filled with trees and blossoming flowers. A tall wall shielded it from the courtyard on one side, while a beech-lined avenue separated it from the lawn on the other. At the far end was a sunken fence, the only barrier from the open fields—a winding walkway flanked by laurels led down to a huge horse-chestnut tree encircled by a seat. Here, one could walk in solitude, away from being seen.

events.title: A Familiar Scent and an Encounter
detailed_summary: While Jane is immersed in the orchard's tranquility, her peace is disturbed by the unmistakable scent of Mr. Rochester's cigar.
Despite looking and listening, she initially cannot locate him, but the growing strength of the aroma signals his proximity.
Feeling an urgent need to avoid an encounter, Jane attempts to leave the orchard through a small gate.
Just as she reaches it, Mr. Rochester enters the orchard.
Jane quickly conceals herself within an ivy-covered alcove, hoping he will not linger and will depart without noticing her.
However, Mr. Rochester appears to be enjoying the evening air and the garden's ambiance as much as she is, leisurely examining the plants and fruits.
A large moth flutters near Jane and then settles close to Mr. Rochester, who bends down to inspect it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While such honey-dew fell, such silence reigned, such gloaming gathered, I felt as if I could haunt such shade for ever; but in threading the flower and fruit parterres at the upper part of the enclosure, enticed there by the light the now rising moon cast on this more open quarter, my step is stayed—not by sound, not by sight, but once more by a warning fragrance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He sees it, and bends to examine it.

events.text_segment:
While such honey-dew fell, such silence reigned, such gloaming gathered, I felt as if I could haunt such shade for ever; but in threading the flower and fruit parterres at the upper part of the enclosure, enticed there by the light the now rising moon cast on this more open quarter, my step is stayed—not by sound, not by sight, but once more by a warning fragrance.
Sweet-briar and southernwood, jasmine, pink, and rose have long been yielding their evening sacrifice of incense: this new scent is neither of shrub nor flower; it is—I know it well—it is Mr. Rochester’s cigar. I look round and I listen. I see trees laden with ripening fruit. I hear a nightingale warbling in a wood half a mile off; no moving form is visible, no coming step audible; but that perfume increases: I must flee. I make for the wicket leading to the shrubbery, and I see Mr. Rochester entering. I step aside into the ivy recess; he will not stay long: he will soon return whence he came, and if I sit still he will never see me.
But no—eventide is as pleasant to him as to me, and this antique garden as attractive; and he strolls on, now lifting the gooseberry-tree branches to look at the fruit, large as plums, with which they are laden; now taking a ripe cherry from the wall; now stooping towards a knot of flowers, either to inhale their fragrance or to admire the dew-beads on their petals. A great moth goes humming by me; it alights on a plant at Mr. Rochester’s foot: he sees it, and bends to examine it.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: As the evening dew settled, silence reigned supreme, and twilight deepened, I felt I could remain in such a shaded spot indefinitely. However, as I walked through the flower and fruit beds in the garden's upper area, drawn there by the light the newly risen moon cast upon this more open section, my movement stopped—not due to a sound or sight, but once again because of a distinct scent that served as a warning. Sweet-briar, southernwood, jasmine, pinks, and roses had already been releasing their evening perfumes for a while; this new smell, however, was not from a plant. It was—and I recognized it instantly—Mr. Rochester's cigar. I looked around and listened intently. I saw trees heavy with ripening fruit. I heard a nightingale singing in woods roughly half a mile away. No person was visible, and no footsteps were audible, but the fragrance intensified, making me feel I had to escape. I headed towards the small gate leading to the shrubbery and saw Mr. Rochester entering. I quickly stepped aside into the area hidden by ivy. He wouldn't stay long, I thought; he would soon return the way he came, and if I kept still, he would never notice me. But no, he found the evening just as pleasant and this old garden just as appealing as I did. He continued his stroll, at one point lifting the branches of a gooseberry bush to examine the fruit, which was as large as plums because the branches were so heavily laden. Then he picked a ripe cherry from the wall. Next, he bent down towards a cluster of flowers, either to inhale their fragrance or admire the dew drops on their petals. A large moth buzzed past me and landed on a plant near Mr. Rochester's feet. He saw it and leaned down to examine it closely.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: As the gentle evening fell, enveloped in peaceful silence and growing dusk, I felt I could linger in this shaded place forever. But as I wandered through the flower and fruit gardens drawn in by the moonlight illuminating this open section, my movement was suddenly halted, not by anything seen or heard, but by a familiar scent warning me. The sweet fragrances of sweet-briar, southernwood, jasmine, pinks, and roses had long filled the air, but this aroma was different—not from any blossom or shrub; I recognized it as Mr. Rochester's cigar smoke. I looked and listened: fruit-heavy trees surrounded me, a nightingale sang in the distant woods, but I saw no one and heard no footsteps—yet the scent grew stronger. I felt compelled to leave and headed for the shrubbery gate, just as I saw Mr. Rochester arriving. I hid in an ivy-covered nook, reasoning he wouldn't stay long and I could avoid being seen by sitting still. Yet rather than leaving, he lingered, evidently enjoying the evening and the old garden as much as I did. He wandered about, examining the gooseberry branches heavy with fruit, picking a ripe cherry from a wall, and bending towards a cluster of flowers, perhaps to inhale their scent or admire the dew on their petals. Suddenly, a large moth buzzed by me, landing on a plant near Mr. Rochester; he noticed and bent to observe it.

events.title: An Unseen Detection and a Reluctant Stroll
detailed_summary: Believing Mr. Rochester to be distracted by the moth and with his back turned, Jane tries to discreetly exit the orchard by walking on the grass to muffle her footsteps.
As she passes by his shadow, Mr. Rochester, without turning, calmly addresses her by name and invites her to observe the moth.
Jane is taken aback, wondering how he detected her presence as she had made no sound.
After a brief remark about the insect, which then flies off, Jane again attempts to leave.
Mr. Rochester detains her, suggesting it would be a pity to go indoors on such a beautiful night when sunset and moonrise are converging.
Jane feels acutely uncomfortable being alone with him in the shadowy garden but finds herself unable to formulate an excuse to depart, a recurring difficulty for her in moments of social pressure.
She reluctantly acquiesces and walks with him, her thoughts racing to find an escape, yet his composed and serious demeanor makes her feel that any perceived impropriety exists only in her own mind.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now, he has his back towards me,” thought I, “and he is occupied too; perhaps, if I walk softly, I can slip away unnoticed.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: his mind was unconscious and quiet.

events.text_segment:
“Now, he has his back towards me,” thought I, “and he is occupied too; perhaps, if I walk softly, I can slip away unnoticed.”
I trode on an edging of turf that the crackle of the pebbly gravel might not betray me: he was standing among the beds at a yard or two distant from where I had to pass; the moth apparently engaged him. “I shall get by very well,” I meditated. As I crossed his shadow, thrown long over the garden by the moon, not yet risen high, he said quietly, without turning—
“Jane, come and look at this fellow.”
I had made no noise: he had not eyes behind—could his shadow feel? I started at first, and then I approached him.
“Look at his wings,” said he, “he reminds me rather of a West Indian insect; one does not often see so large and gay a night-rover in England; there! he is flown.”
The moth roamed away. I was sheepishly retreating also; but Mr. Rochester followed me, and when we reached the wicket, he said—
“Turn back: on so lovely a night it is a shame to sit in the house; and surely no one can wish to go to bed while sunset is thus at meeting with moonrise.”
It is one of my faults, that though my tongue is sometimes prompt enough at an answer, there are times when it sadly fails me in framing an excuse; and always the lapse occurs at some crisis, when a facile word or plausible pretext is specially wanted to get me out of painful embarrassment. I did not like to walk at this hour alone with Mr. Rochester in the shadowy orchard; but I could not find a reason to allege for leaving him. I followed with lagging step, and thoughts busily bent on discovering a means of extrication; but he himself looked so composed and so grave also, I became ashamed of feeling any confusion: the evil—if evil existent or prospective there was—seemed to lie with me only; his mind was unconscious and quiet.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Believing, “He has his back turned to me now and is preoccupied,” I considered whether I could softly move away without being noticed. I walked on the grass lining the path so the sound of pebbles wouldn't give me away. He was standing a few feet from where I needed to pass, among the flowerbeds, seemingly focused on the moth. “I should be able to get by without trouble,” I mused. As I crossed his long shadow, cast across the garden by the moon that hadn't yet climbed high, he spoke quietly, without turning around—“Jane, approach and examine this creature.” I had made no noise; he lacked eyes in the back of his head—could his shadow detect me? I was taken aback at first, but then I drew nearer to him. “Observe its wings,” he said, “it reminds me somewhat of an insect from the West Indies; one doesn't frequently see such a large and colorful night-flying creature in England. Look! It has flown.” The moth departed. I was also hesitantly retreating; but Mr. Rochester followed me, and when we arrived at the gate, he instructed—“Return; it’s a pity to stay inside on such a beautiful night; and surely nobody would want to retire while sunset is meeting with moonrise in this manner.” It is a flaw of mine that although my speech is sometimes quick with a response, at other times it completely fails me when I need to form an excuse; and this lapse always occurs at a crucial moment, when a simple word or believable reason is particularly required to free me from awkward discomfort. I was reluctant to walk alone with Mr. Rochester in the dim orchard at this hour, but I could not devise a reason to offer for leaving him. I followed with hesitant steps, my thoughts intensely focused on finding a means of escape; but he himself looked so serene and serious that I became ashamed of feeling any unease. The problem—if there was any existing or potential problem—seemed to rest solely with me; his state of mind was tranquil and unaware.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: He had his back to me and seemed busy, so I thought I might be able to sneak away quietly if I walked carefully. I stepped onto the grass to avoid making noise on the gravel; he was just a short distance away, focused on a moth. I thought I would be able to pass by without him noticing, but as I crossed through his long shadow cast by the low moon, he called to me calmly, without even turning his head: "Jane, come look at this insect." I had been silent, and he couldn’t have seen me, so how did he know I was there? Startled, I approached him. He showed me the moth and compared it to a tropical insect, saying it was rare to see such a big, colorful night moth in England, and then it flew away. I began to slip off as well, but Mr. Rochester followed me. When we came to the gate, he asked me to return, saying such a beautiful night shouldn’t be spent indoors and that no one could want to go to bed while the sun was setting and the moon was rising. I have a fault: although I sometimes reply quickly, at crucial moments when I need an excuse most, my words fail me. I didn’t want to walk alone with Mr. Rochester in the dark orchard, but I couldn’t think of a reason to avoid it. I followed him reluctantly, searching for a way out, but since he seemed so calm and serious, I felt embarrassed by my own discomfort. If there was anything wrong in the situation, it seemed to be just my own feelings; he was completely at ease.

events.title: The Painful News of Jane's Dismissal
detailed_summary: As they stroll towards a horse-chestnut tree, Mr. Rochester initiates a conversation about Thornfield, acknowledging Jane's appreciation for its beauty and her developing attachments.
He notes her fondness for Adèle and Mrs. Fairfax, which Jane affirms.
When Jane admits she would regret leaving them, Rochester sighs and philosophizes about the impermanence of pleasant circumstances.
He then directly informs Jane that she will have to leave Thornfield.
Though inwardly shaken, Jane outwardly maintains her composure, asking if the time for her departure has arrived.
Rochester confirms that he must issue the directive that very night, explaining it is due to his forthcoming marriage.
He acknowledges, with a hint of teasing, her astuteness in deducing his intention to marry Miss Ingram.
He reminds Jane of her own earlier practical suggestion that she and Adèle should depart should he marry Miss Ingram, framing his current decision as an adoption of her wise counsel.
