Still, if they had been married, they’d likely make up for being soft as lovers by being strict as husbands; and I fear you will be the same. I wonder how you’d respond a year from now if I asked for something you didn’t want to give.”
“Ask me something now, Janet—anything at all: I want to be petitioned—”
“I will, sir; I already know what to request.”
“Then say it! But if you look up and smile like that, I’ll say yes before I even know what it is, and you’ll make a fool of me.”
“Not at all, sir; my only request is this: please don’t order jewels for me, and don’t crown me with roses; it’s as if you put fancy gold trim on that plain handkerchief you have.”
“I might as well decorate pure gold. I understand—you have your wish, for now. I’ll cancel the order I sent to my banker. But you still haven’t asked for anything; you’ve just asked for a gift to be taken away: try again.”
“Well then, sir, please satisfy my curiosity about something that’s really been on my mind.”
He looked uneasy. “What? What is it?” he asked quickly. “Curiosity is a risky thing to ask for: it’s good I haven’t promised to grant every wish—”
“But there’s no harm in answering this, sir.”
“Tell me, Jane: but I wish it was a request for half my property instead of a question about some secret.”
“Oh, King Ahasuerus! Why would I want half your estate? Do you think I’m just a money-lender after land? I’d much prefer to have all your trust. If you let me into your heart, you won’t shut me out of your confidence, will you?”
“You’re welcome to all the trust I have that’s worth anything, Jane; but please, don’t ask for pointless burdens! Don’t wish for something harmful—don’t become an Eve to tempt me!”
“Why not, sir? You just said you enjoy being won over and persuaded by someone. Maybe I should take advantage of your admission and try coaxing and pleading—even sulking if I must—just to see how much power I have?”
“I dare you to try such a thing. Cross the line, overstep, and it’s over.”
“Is that so, sir? You give in quickly. How stern you look now! Your eyebrows are thick as my finger, and your forehead looks like what some poet once called a ‘blue-piled thunderloft.’ Is that how you’ll look as a married man?”
“If that’s how you’ll look, I, being Christian, may have to give up marrying a mere spirit or fire-creature. Now, what was it you wanted, creature—out with it?”
“Now you’re being less than polite; and I much prefer rudeness to flattery. I’d rather be called a creature than an angel. What I want to ask is: Why did you go to such lengths to make me think you wanted to marry Miss Ingram?”

events.title: Rochester's Ingram Confession, Jane's Rebuke, and Request for Mrs. Fairfax
detailed_summary: Relieved the question is not worse, Rochester admits he feigned courtship of Blanche Ingram specifically to make Jane intensely jealous and fall in love with him.
Jane rebukes him sharply, calling his actions a 'burning shame' and questioning his disregard for Miss Ingram's feelings.
Rochester dismisses Miss Ingram's feelings as mere pride that needed humbling, and claims she deserted him upon news of his supposed insolvency.
Jane calls him curious and designing, with eccentric principles, which he attributes to a lack of training.
She seeks assurance that her happiness isn't built on another's suffering, which he confirms, believing in her unique love for him.
Deeply moved, Jane expresses her profound love for him internally.
At his prompting to ask for something more, Jane requests he explain their engagement to Mrs. Fairfax, who was shocked by seeing them together.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Is that all? Thank God it is no worse!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It pains me to be misjudged by so good a woman.”

events.text_segment:
“Is that all? Thank God it is no worse!” And now he unknit his black brows; looked down, smiling at me, and stroked my hair, as if well pleased at seeing a danger averted. “I think I may confess,” he continued, “even although I should make you a little indignant, Jane—and I have seen what a fire-spirit you can be when you are indignant. You glowed in the cool moonlight last night, when you mutinied against fate, and claimed your rank as my equal. Janet, by-the-bye, it was you who made me the offer.”
“Of course I did. But to the point if you please, sir—Miss Ingram?”
“Well, I feigned courtship of Miss Ingram, because I wished to render you as madly in love with me as I was with you; and I knew jealousy would be the best ally I could call in for the furtherance of that end.”
“Excellent! Now you are small—not one whit bigger than the end of my little finger. It was a burning shame and a scandalous disgrace to act in that way. Did you think nothing of Miss Ingram’s feelings, sir?”
“Her feelings are concentrated in one—pride; and that needs humbling. Were you jealous, Jane?”
“Never mind, Mr. Rochester: it is in no way interesting to you to know that. Answer me truly once more. Do you think Miss Ingram will not suffer from your dishonest coquetry? Won’t she feel forsaken and deserted?”
“Impossible!—when I told you how she, on the contrary, deserted me: the idea of my insolvency cooled, or rather extinguished, her flame in a moment.”
“You have a curious, designing mind, Mr. Rochester. I am afraid your principles on some points are eccentric.”
“My principles were never trained, Jane: they may have grown a little awry for want of attention.”
“Once again, seriously; may I enjoy the great good that has been vouchsafed to me, without fearing that any one else is suffering the bitter pain I myself felt a while ago?”
“That you may, my good little girl: there is not another being in the world has the same pure love for me as yourself—for I lay that pleasant unction to my soul, Jane, a belief in your affection.”
I turned my lips to the hand that lay on my shoulder. I loved him very much—more than I could trust myself to say—more than words had power to express.
“Ask something more,” he said presently; “it is my delight to be entreated, and to yield.”
I was again ready with my request. “Communicate your intentions to Mrs. Fairfax, sir: she saw me with you last night in the hall, and she was shocked. Give her some explanation before I see her again. It pains me to be misjudged by so good a woman.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Rochester exclaimed, relieved, "Is that it? Thank goodness it's nothing worse!" He then relaxed his stern expression, smiled down at me, and gently stroked my hair, appearing pleased that a potential problem had been avoided. He continued, "Jane, I feel I should admit something, even if it makes you a bit angry – and I know how fiery you can be when you're upset. You were quite the passionate spirit under the moonlight last night when you defied fate and asserted your equality with me. By the way, Janet, you were the one who proposed." I replied, "Of course I did. But please, sir, let's get to the main point – Miss Ingram?" Rochester explained, "Well, I pretended to court Miss Ingram because I wanted you to fall as deeply in love with me as I was with you; and I knew jealousy would be the most effective strategy to achieve that." I retorted, "That's terrible! Absolutely shameful and outrageous behavior. Didn't you consider Miss Ingram's feelings at all, sir?" He stated, "Her emotions are focused solely on one thing – pride; and that needs to be humbled. Were you jealous, Jane?" I sidestepped the question, "It doesn't matter, Mr. Rochester; it's not relevant to you. But answer me honestly again. Don't you think Miss Ingram will suffer from your deceitful flirting? Won't she feel abandoned and hurt?" He insisted, "Not at all! As I told you, she was the one who abandoned me; the news of my potential lack of money instantly cooled, or rather extinguished, her affection." He responded, "My principles were never properly developed, Jane; they may have grown a bit crooked due to neglect." He reassured me, "Yes, my dear girl, you can; there is no other person in the world who loves me with the same pure affection as you – I find great comfort in that belief in your devotion, Jane." I brought my lips to the hand resting on my shoulder. I loved him deeply – more than I dared say, more than words could possibly express. "Ask for something else," he said shortly after; "I enjoy being asked and agreeing." I quickly made another request. events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
“Is that all? Thank goodness it's nothing worse!” He relaxed his frown, smiled at me, and caressed my hair, clearly relieved that the danger had passed. “I suppose I should admit,” he went on, “even though it may annoy you, Jane—and I've noticed how fiery you can get when upset. Last night, you shone in the moonlight as you defied your destiny and claimed your status as my equal. By the way, Janet, you were the one who proposed to me.”

“I did, of course. But let's get to the main issue, sir—Miss Ingram?”

“Well, I pretended to court Miss Ingram because I wanted to make you fall in love with me just as deeply as I loved you; and I figured jealousy would be the most effective way to achieve that.”

“Wonderful! Now you've shrunk—not even as big as my little finger. What you did was absolutely wrong and disgraceful. Didn't you consider Miss Ingram’s feelings, sir?”

“Her feelings only concern her pride; and that could use some humbling. Were you jealous, Jane?”

“That doesn’t matter, Mr. Rochester; it’s none of your business. Please answer me honestly once more. Do you think Miss Ingram won't be hurt by your deceitful flirtation? Won't she feel abandoned?”

“Impossible! I already explained that she, instead, abandoned me: as soon as she learned of my supposed lack of wealth, her affection disappeared instantly.”

“You are calculating, Mr. Rochester. I fear your morals are rather unusual in some areas.”

“My morals were never properly taught, Jane; maybe they've become a bit warped without guidance.”

“Again, seriously—can I be truly happy about this blessing I've received, without worrying that someone else is suffering, like I did before?”

“You can, my dear girl: there's no one else in the world who loves me as sincerely as you do—I take great comfort in believing in your love, Jane.”

I kissed the hand resting on my shoulder. I loved him deeply—far more than I could ever admit or put into words.

“Ask me something else,” he said after a while; “I enjoy being asked favors and granting them.”

I was ready with another request. “Please tell Mrs. Fairfax your intentions, sir; she saw us together last night and was shocked. Explain things to her before I meet her again. It hurts me to be misjudged by someone so good.”

events.title: Mrs. Fairfax's Astonishment, Doubt, and Sobering Warnings
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester agrees to enlighten Mrs. Fairfax while Jane prepares for a trip to Millcote with him.
Jane finds Mrs. Fairfax looking stunned after Rochester's announcement, her Bible forgotten.
Mrs. Fairfax struggles to comprehend the news, asking Jane if it's true Mr. Rochester proposed, comparing her disbelief to a dream.
Upon Jane's confirmation, Mrs. Fairfax expresses bewilderment, noting Rochester's pride and carefulness with money.
She scrutinizes Jane, unable to find a reason for his choice, and voices concerns about the disparity in their positions, fortunes, and ages, suggesting he could almost be Jane's father.
Jane, nettled, refutes this. Mrs. Fairfax then questions if his proposal is truly for love.

Hurt by her skepticism, Jane is brought to tears. Mrs. Fairfax apologizes but explains her wish to guard Jane, warning that 'all is not gold that glitters' and expressing fear of unexpected future problems.
She recounts her anxiety from the previous night and finally expresses the societal view that gentlemen do not marry their governesses.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Go to your room, and put on your bonnet,” he replied.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Gentlemen in his station are not accustomed to marry their governesses.”

events.text_segment:
“Go to your room, and put on your bonnet,” he replied. “I mean you to accompany me to Millcote this morning; and while you prepare for the drive, I will enlighten the old lady’s understanding. Did she think, Janet, you had given the world for love, and considered it well lost?”
“I believe she thought I had forgotten my station, and yours, sir.”
“Station! station!—your station is in my heart, and on the necks of those who would insult you, now or hereafter.—Go.”
I was soon dressed; and when I heard Mr. Rochester quit Mrs. Fairfax’s parlour, I hurried down to it. The old lady had been reading her morning portion of Scripture—the Lesson for the day; her Bible lay open before her, and her spectacles were upon it. Her occupation, suspended by Mr. Rochester’s announcement, seemed now forgotten: her eyes, fixed on the blank wall opposite, expressed the surprise of a quiet mind stirred by unwonted tidings. Seeing me, she roused herself: she made a sort of effort to smile, and framed a few words of congratulation; but the smile expired, and the sentence was abandoned unfinished. She put up her spectacles, shut the Bible, and pushed her chair back from the table.
“I feel so astonished,” she began, “I hardly know what to say to you, Miss Eyre. I have surely not been dreaming, have I? Sometimes I half fall asleep when I am sitting alone and fancy things that have never happened. It has seemed to me more than once when I have been in a doze, that my dear husband, who died fifteen years since, has come in and sat down beside me; and that I have even heard him call me by my name, Alice, as he used to do. Now, can you tell me whether it is actually true that Mr. Rochester has asked you to marry him? Don’t laugh at me. But I really thought he came in here five minutes ago, and said that in a month you would be his wife.”
“He has said the same thing to me,” I replied.
“He has! Do you believe him? Have you accepted him?”
“Yes.”
She looked at me bewildered.
“I could never have thought it. He is a proud man: all the Rochesters were proud: and his father, at least, liked money. He, too, has always been called careful. He means to marry you?”
“He tells me so.”
She surveyed my whole person: in her eyes I read that they had there found no charm powerful enough to solve the enigma.
“It passes me!” she continued; “but no doubt it is true since you say so. How it will answer, I cannot tell: I really don’t know. Equality of position and fortune is often advisable in such cases; and there are twenty years of difference in your ages. He might almost be your father.”
“No, indeed, Mrs. Fairfax!” exclaimed I, nettled; “he is nothing like my father! No one, who saw us together, would suppose it for an instant. Mr. Rochester looks as young, and is as young, as some men at five-and-twenty.”
“Is it really for love he is going to marry you?” she asked.
I was so hurt by her coldness and scepticism, that the tears rose to my eyes.
“I am sorry to grieve you,” pursued the widow; “but you are so young, and so little acquainted with men, I wished to put you on your guard. It is an old saying that ‘all is not gold that glitters;’ and in this case I do fear there will be something found to be different to what either you or I expect.”
“Why?—am I a monster?” I said: “is it impossible that Mr. Rochester should have a sincere affection for me?”
“No: you are very well; and much improved of late; and Mr. Rochester, I daresay, is fond of you. I have always noticed that you were a sort of pet of his. There are times when, for your sake, I have been a little uneasy at his marked preference, and have wished to put you on your guard: but I did not like to suggest even the possibility of wrong. I knew such an idea would shock, perhaps offend you; and you were so discreet, and so thoroughly modest and sensible, I hoped you might be trusted to protect yourself. Last night I cannot tell you what I suffered when I sought all over the house, and could find you nowhere, nor the master either; and then, at twelve o’clock, saw you come in with him.”
“Well, never mind that now,” I interrupted impatiently; “it is enough that all was right.”
“I hope all will be right in the end,” she said: “but believe me, you cannot be too careful. Try and keep Mr. Rochester at a distance: distrust yourself as well as him. Gentlemen in his station are not accustomed to marry their governesses.”

Jane replied that she thought Mrs. Fairfax felt she had disregarded her social position, as well as his. Rochester reacted strongly, insisting that her position was in his heart and that he would overcome anyone who dared insult her, now or ever, and again told her to go. Her reading, interrupted by Mr. Rochester's announcement, seemed forgotten now; her eyes, staring at the blank wall opposite, conveyed the shock of a tranquil mind disturbed by surprising news. Seeing Jane, she snapped back to attention, making an effort to smile and beginning to offer congratulations, but the smile vanished, and the sentence was left unfinished. She took off her spectacles, closed her Bible, and pushed her chair away from the table. She admitted she felt so bewildered she barely knew what to say to Jane Eyre. She questioned if she had been dreaming, noting that sometimes when she was alone and dozing, she would imagine things that hadn't happened, like her deceased husband, who died fifteen years prior, coming in and sitting with her and even hearing him call her 'Alice' as he used to. She then asked if it was truly factual that Mr. Rochester had proposed marriage, urging Jane not to laugh at her, but explaining she genuinely thought he had just come in and said Jane would be his wife in a month. Jane confirmed that he had told her the same thing. Mrs. Fairfax asked if he had, if Jane believed him, and if she had accepted. Jane replied, 'Yes.' Mrs. Fairfax looked at her with confusion, stating she would never have imagined it possible. She described him as a proud man, mentioning that all the Rochesters were proud and his father had been fond of money, and that Rochester himself was considered careful. She asked again if he truly intended to marry her. Jane confirmed that was what he said. Mrs. Fairfax studied Jane from head to toe, conveying through her gaze that she found nothing outwardly powerful enough to explain the puzzle. She continued that it was beyond her comprehension, but accepted it must be true since Jane said so. However, she couldn't predict how it would turn out, admitting she truly didn't know. She noted that equal social standing and wealth were often advisable in such situations and pointed out the twenty-year age gap, saying he could almost be her father. Annoyed, Jane exclaimed that he was nothing like her father and no one who saw them together would think so for a moment, asserting that Mr. Rochester looked and was as youthful as some men in their mid-twenties. Mrs. Fairfax then asked if he was genuinely marrying her out of love. Jane was so hurt by her coldness and doubt that her eyes welled up with tears. The widow continued, apologizing for upsetting her but explaining that because Jane was so young and inexperienced with men, she wanted to caution her. She quoted the old saying, 'all is not gold that glitters,' and confessed her fear that in this instance, things would turn out differently from what either of them expected. Jane retorted, asking if she was a 'monster' and if it was impossible for Mr. Rochester to feel sincere affection for her. Mrs. Fairfax replied that Jane was perfectly fine and much improved lately, and she supposed Mr. Rochester was fond of her, having always noticed she was a sort of favorite of his. She admitted there were times when his obvious preference for Jane had made her slightly uneasy for Jane's sake, wishing she had warned her, but she didn't want to suggest anything improper, knowing the idea would shock and perhaps offend her. Because Jane was so discreet, modest, and sensible, she had hoped she could be trusted to protect herself. She confessed she couldn't describe how much she had suffered the previous night searching the whole house and finding neither Jane nor the master, and then seeing them return together at midnight. Jane interrupted impatiently, saying it didn't matter now and that it was enough that everything was alright. Mrs. Fairfax responded that she hoped everything would turn out right in the end, but urged Jane to believe her that she couldn't be too careful. She advised her to try and keep Mr. Rochester at a distance and to be cautious of herself as well as him, reminding her that gentlemen of his status were not accustomed to marrying their governesses.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Go to your room and get your bonnet on," he told me. "You're coming with me to Millcote this morning; while you get ready for the drive, I'll clarify things for the old lady. Did she really think, Janet, that you had given up everything for love and thought it was a fair trade?"

"I think she believes I forgot both my place and yours, sir."

"Place! Your place is in my heart, and protected from anyone who would insult you now, or ever. Go."

I dressed quickly; when I heard Mr. Rochester leave Mrs. Fairfax’s parlor, I went in. The old lady had been reading her morning Bible lesson; her Bible lay open with her spectacles on top. She had been interrupted by Mr. Rochester’s news and now seemed lost in thought, her eyes fixed in surprise on the wall. Seeing me, she stirred, tried to smile and say a few congratulatory words, but the smile faded, and she couldn’t finish. She put on her spectacles again, closed the Bible, and pushed her chair away from the table.

"I am so shocked," she said, "I hardly know what to say to you, Miss Eyre. Am I dreaming? Sometimes when I’m sitting alone I drift off and imagine things that aren’t real. It’s happened that I’ve thought my dear husband, who died fifteen years ago, walked in and sat with me, even calling my name, Alice, as he used to do. Now, can you tell me: is it really true Mr. Rochester asked you to marry him? Don’t laugh at me, but I really thought he came in just now and said you’d be his wife in a month."

"He told me the same," I answered.

"He did! Do you believe him? Did you accept?"

"Yes."

She looked at me, confused.

"I never would have thought it. He is a proud man; all the Rochesters have been, and his father cared a lot about money. He always seemed careful, too. He’s really going to marry you?"

"That's what he says."

She looked me over, and in her eyes I saw she found nothing about me to explain why he would.

"It’s beyond me! But it must be true if you say so. I don’t know how it will turn out; honestly, I can't tell. Marrying someone of equal status and wealth is generally a good idea; and he’s twenty years older than you. He could almost be your father."

"Not at all, Mrs. Fairfax!" I replied, offended. "He’s nothing like my father; no one seeing us together would think so. Mr. Rochester looks and acts as young as any man of twenty-five."

"Is he really marrying you for love?" she asked.

Her skepticism stung me, and I began to cry.

"I’m sorry to upset you," she went on, "but you’re so young and know so little of men, I just wanted to warn you. There’s a saying, 'not all that glitters is gold;' in this case, I’m afraid things could turn out differently than we expect."

"Why? Do you think I’m so unworthy that Mr. Rochester couldn’t honestly love me?"

"No: you are quite pleasant, and lately you’ve improved; and I’m sure Mr. Rochester is fond of you. I’ve always noticed his special favor towards you, and for your sake, I have sometimes worried, wanting to warn you, but not wanting to even suggest anything improper, since I knew it might shock or upset you. You have always been so reserved and sensible, I hoped you could take care of yourself. Last night I can’t tell you how distressed I was searching the house for you and the master, and then at midnight seeing you come home with him."

"Let’s leave that alone for now," I interrupted, "All was proper."

"I do hope it will all work out," she said. "But truly, you can’t be too cautious. Try to keep Mr. Rochester at a distance. Distrust both yourself and him. Gentlemen of his status rarely marry their governesses."

events.title: Millcote Excursion: Adèle's Company, Rochester's Whimsy, and Jane's Resistance to Materialism
detailed_summary: Irritated by Mrs. Fairfax's warnings, Jane is glad when Adèle interrupts, pleading to go to Millcote.
Jane advocates for Adèle, and Rochester, after initial refusal, relents when he sees Jane's disappointment.

During the carriage ride, Rochester whimsically tells Adèle he will take Jane (a fairy) to the moon to live with him, spinning a fantastical tale about manna and lunar fire, which Adèle skeptically questions.
He then recounts a story of meeting a fairy (Jane) who gave him a ring (his sovereign) and promised to make him happy.
Adèle dismisses his stories as lies, asserting fairies wouldn't associate with him.
The shopping trip in Millcote is harassing for Jane; Rochester insists on buying dresses, but she negotiates down from six to two, persuading him to choose sober colors over brilliant ones.
Jane feels increasingly annoyed and degraded by his purchases and, remembering her uncle John Eyre, resolves to write to him seeking financial independence to avoid being 'dressed like a doll'.

events.text_segment:
I was growing truly irritated: happily, Adèle ran in.
“Let me go,—let me go to Millcote too!” she cried. “Mr. Rochester won’t: though there is so much room in the new carriage. Beg him to let me go, mademoiselle.”
“That I will, Adèle;” and I hastened away with her, glad to quit my gloomy monitress. The carriage was ready: they were bringing it round to the front, and my master was pacing the pavement, Pilot following him backwards and forwards.
“Adèle may accompany us, may she not, sir?”
“I told her no. I’ll have no brats!—I’ll have only you.”
“Do let her go, Mr. Rochester, if you please: it would be better.”
“Not it: she will be a restraint.”
He was quite peremptory, both in look and voice. The chill of Mrs. Fairfax’s warnings, and the damp of her doubts were upon me: something of unsubstantiality and uncertainty had beset my hopes. I half lost the sense of power over him. I was about mechanically to obey him, without further remonstrance; but as he helped me into the carriage, he looked at my face.
“What is the matter?” he asked; “all the sunshine is gone. Do you really wish the bairn to go? Will it annoy you if she is left behind?”
“I would far rather she went, sir.”
“Then off for your bonnet, and back like a flash of lightning!” cried he to Adèle.
She obeyed him with what speed she might.
“After all, a single morning’s interruption will not matter much,” said he, “when I mean shortly to claim you—your thoughts, conversation, and company—for life.”
Adèle, when lifted in, commenced kissing me, by way of expressing her gratitude for my intercession: she was instantly stowed away into a corner on the other side of him. She then peeped round to where I sat; so stern a neighbour was too restrictive: to him, in his present fractious mood, she dared whisper no observations, nor ask of him any information.
“Let her come to me,” I entreated: “she will, perhaps, trouble you, sir: there is plenty of room on this side.”
He handed her over as if she had been a lapdog. “I’ll send her to school yet,” he said, but now he was smiling.
Adèle heard him, and asked if she was to go to school “sans mademoiselle?”
“Yes,” he replied, “absolutely sans mademoiselle; for I am to take mademoiselle to the moon, and there I shall seek a cave in one of the white valleys among the volcano-tops, and mademoiselle shall live with me there, and only me.”
“She will have nothing to eat: you will starve her,” observed Adèle.
“I shall gather manna for her morning and night: the plains and hillsides in the moon are bleached with manna, Adèle.”
“She will want to warm herself: what will she do for a fire?”
“Fire rises out of the lunar mountains: when she is cold, I’ll carry her up to a peak, and lay her down on the edge of a crater.”
“Oh, qu’elle y sera mal—peu comfortable! And her clothes, they will wear out: how can she get new ones?”
Mr. Rochester professed to be puzzled. “Hem!” said he. “What would you do, Adèle? Cudgel your brains for an expedient. How would a white or a pink cloud answer for a gown, do you think? And one could cut a pretty enough scarf out of a rainbow.”
“She is far better as she is,” concluded Adèle, after musing some time: “besides, she would get tired of living with only you in the moon. If I were mademoiselle, I would never consent to go with you.”
“She has consented: she has pledged her word.”
“But you can’t get her there; there is no road to the moon: it is all air; and neither you nor she can fly.”
“Adèle, look at that field.” We were now outside Thornfield gates, and bowling lightly along the smooth road to Millcote, where the dust was well laid by the thunderstorm, and, where the low hedges and lofty timber trees on each side glistened green and rain-refreshed.
“In that field, Adèle, I was walking late one evening about a fortnight since—the evening of the day you helped me to make hay in the orchard meadows; and, as I was tired with raking swaths, I sat down to rest me on a stile; and there I took out a little book and a pencil, and began to write about a misfortune that befell me long ago, and a wish I had for happy days to come: I was writing away very fast, though daylight was fading from the leaf, when something came up the path and stopped two yards off me. I looked at it. It was a little thing with a veil of gossamer on its head. I beckoned it to come near me; it stood soon at my knee. I never spoke to it, and it never spoke to me, in words; but I read its eyes, and it read mine; and our speechless colloquy was to this effect—
“It was a fairy, and come from Elf-land, it said; and its errand was to make me happy: I must go with it out of the common world to a lonely place—such as the moon, for instance—and it nodded its head towards her horn, rising over Hay-hill: it told me of the alabaster cave and silver vale where we might live. I said I should like to go; but reminded it, as you did me, that I had no wings to fly.
“‘Oh,’ returned the fairy, ‘that does not signify! Here is a talisman will remove all difficulties;’ and she held out a pretty gold ring. ‘Put it,’ she said, ‘on the fourth finger of my left hand, and I am yours, and you are mine; and we shall leave earth, and make our own heaven yonder.’ She nodded again at the moon. The ring, Adèle, is in my breeches-pocket, under the disguise of a sovereign: but I mean soon to change it to a ring again.”
“But what has mademoiselle to do with it? I don’t care for the fairy: you said it was mademoiselle you would take to the moon?”
“Mademoiselle is a fairy,” he said, whispering mysteriously. Whereupon I told her not to mind his badinage; and she, on her part, evinced a fund of genuine French scepticism: denominating Mr. Rochester “un vrai menteur,” and assuring him that she made no account whatever of his “contes de fée,” and that “du reste, il n’y avait pas de fées, et quand même il y en avait:” she was sure they would never appear to him, nor ever give him rings, or offer to live with him in the moon.
The hour spent at Millcote was a somewhat harassing one to me. Mr. Rochester obliged me to go to a certain silk warehouse: there I was ordered to choose half-a-dozen dresses. I hated the business, I begged leave to defer it: no—it should be gone through with now. By dint of entreaties expressed in energetic whispers, I reduced the half-dozen to two: these however, he vowed he would select himself. With anxiety I watched his eye rove over the gay stores: he fixed on a rich silk of the most brilliant amethyst dye, and a superb pink satin. I told him in a new series of whispers, that he might as well buy me a gold gown and a silver bonnet at once: I should certainly never venture to wear his choice. With infinite difficulty, for he was stubborn as a stone, I persuaded him to make an exchange in favour of a sober black satin and pearl-grey silk. “It might pass for the present,” he said; “but he would yet see me glittering like a parterre.”
Glad was I to get him out of the silk warehouse, and then out of a jeweller’s shop: the more he bought me, the more my cheek burned with a sense of annoyance and degradation. As we re-entered the carriage, and I sat back feverish and fagged, I remembered what, in the hurry of events, dark and bright, I had wholly forgotten—the letter of my uncle, John Eyre, to Mrs. Reed: his intention to adopt me and make me his legatee. “It would, indeed, be a relief,” I thought, “if I had ever so small an independency; I never can bear being dressed like a doll by Mr. Rochester, or sitting like a second Danae with the golden shower falling daily round me. I will write to Madeira the moment I get home, and tell my uncle John I am going to be married, and to whom: if I had but a prospect of one day bringing Mr. Rochester an accession of fortune, I could better endure to be kept by him now.” And somewhat relieved by this idea (which I failed not to execute that day), I ventured once more to meet my master’s and lover’s eye, which most pertinaciously sought mine, though I averted both face and gaze. He smiled; and I thought his smile was such as a sultan might, in a blissful and fond moment, bestow on a slave his gold and gems had enriched: I crushed his hand, which was ever hunting mine, vigorously, and thrust it back to him red with the passionate pressure.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I was becoming genuinely annoyed when, thankfully, Adèle rushed in. 'Let me come,' she exclaimed, 'let me go to Millcote too! Mr. Rochester won't agree, even though there's plenty of space in the new carriage. Please ask him to let me go, mademoiselle.' 'I certainly will, Adèle,' I replied, quickly leaving with her, relieved to escape my gloomy monitor. The carriage was prepared, being brought around to the front of the house, and my employer was pacing the flagstone path, with Pilot following his movements. 'May Adèle accompany us, sir?' I asked. 'I told her no,' he responded. 'I don't want children! I only want you.' 'Please let her come, Mr. Rochester,' I urged, 'it would be better.' 'No,' he countered, 'she'd be a nuisance.' His tone and expression were completely decisive. The chill of Mrs. Fairfax's warnings and the dampness of her doubts were affecting me; my hopes felt somewhat insubstantial and uncertain. I felt I had partly lost my influence over him. I was about to mechanically agree without further protest, but as he helped me into the carriage, he looked at my face. 'What's wrong?' he asked, 'all your brightness is gone. Do you truly want the child to come? Will it bother you if she stays behind?' 'I would much prefer her to go, sir.' 'Then go get your hat immediately!' he cried to Adèle. She obeyed as fast as possible. 'After all,' he said, 'a short interruption this morning won't matter much, since I plan to claim your time, thoughts, conversation, and presence for my entire life soon.' Once helped into the carriage, Adèle began kissing me to show how grateful she was for my asking on her behalf; she was promptly settled into a corner across from him. She then peered around at where I sat; such a severe companion was too restrictive. With him in his current irritable mood, she didn't dare whisper comments or ask him for information. 'Let her come sit with me,' I pleaded, 'she might bother you, sir; there's ample room on this side.' He passed her over as if she were a pet. 'I'll still send her to school eventually,' he said, now smiling. Adèle heard him and asked if she would attend school 'sans mademoiselle?' 'Yes,' he replied, 'absolutely without mademoiselle; because I am taking mademoiselle to the moon, and there I will find a cave in one of the pale valleys among the volcano peaks, and mademoiselle will live there with me, and only me.' 'She'll have nothing to eat: you'll starve her,' Adèle pointed out. 'I will collect manna for her morning and night; the plains and slopes on the moon are covered in manna, Adèle.' 'She'll need to keep warm: what will she do for a fire?' 'Fire comes from the moon's mountains: when she is cold, I'll carry her up to a peak and place her on the edge of a crater.' 'Oh, how uncomfortable she'll be there! And her clothes will wear out: how will she get new ones?' Mr. Rochester pretended to be stumped. 'Hmm,' he mused. 'What would you suggest, Adèle? Use your imagination for a solution. How about a white or pink cloud for a dress, do you think? And one could cut a lovely scarf from a rainbow.' 'She's much better off as she is,' Adèle concluded after thinking for a bit; 'besides, she would get tired of living with just you on the moon. If I were mademoiselle, I would never agree to go with you.' 'She has agreed; she has given her word.' 'But you can't get her there; there's no path to the moon: it's all air; and neither you nor she can fly.' 'Adèle, look at that field.' We were now outside the gates of Thornfield, riding smoothly along the level road to Millcote, where the recent thunderstorm had settled the dust, and the low hedges and tall trees lining both sides sparkled green and refreshed by the rain. 'In that field, Adèle, I was walking late one evening about two weeks ago—the night of the day you helped me make hay in the orchard fields; and, tired from raking the cut grass, I sat down to rest on a stile; and there I took out a small book and a pencil and began to write about a misfortune that happened to me long ago and a hope I had for happy future days. I was writing very quickly, even though the light was fading from the page, when something came up the path and stopped six feet away from me. I looked at it. It was small with a delicate veil on its head. I motioned for it to come closer; it soon stood beside my knee. I never spoke to it, and it never spoke to me, in actual words; but I understood its eyes, and it understood mine; and our silent conversation went like this—'It was a fairy, it said, and had come from Elf-land; and its purpose was to make me happy. I had to go with it away from the ordinary world to a secluded place—like the moon, for instance—and it nodded its head towards the crescent moon, visible above Hay-hill. It described the pearly cave and silver valley where we could live. I said I would like to go but pointed out, just as you did to me, that I had no wings to fly.'Oh,' the fairy replied, 'that doesn't matter! Here is a magical object that will remove all difficulties;' and she held out a beautiful gold ring. 'Put it,' she said, 'on the fourth finger of my left hand, and I am yours, and you are mine; and we will leave earth and create our own paradise up there.' She nodded again towards the moon. The ring, Adèle, is in my trouser pocket, disguised as a coin; but I intend to change it back to a ring soon.' 'But what does mademoiselle have to do with it? I don't care about the fairy; you said it was mademoiselle you would take to the moon?' 'Mademoiselle is a fairy,' he said, whispering conspiratorially. At this, I told her to pay no attention to his teasing; and she, for her part, displayed a deep sense of genuine French skepticism, calling Mr. Rochester 'a true liar' and assuring him that she put no stock whatsoever in his 'fairy tales,' adding that 'besides, there were no fairies, and even if there were,' she was certain they would never appear to him, nor ever give him rings, or offer to live with him on the moon. The hour spent in Millcote was quite stressful for me. Mr. Rochester insisted I go to a specific silk shop; there I was instructed to choose half a dozen dresses. I disliked the task intensely and requested permission to postpone it, but no—it had to be done then. Through urgent whispered pleas, I managed to reduce the number from six to two; however, he declared he would choose these himself. I watched anxiously as his gaze swept over the bright fabrics; he settled on a luxurious silk of the most vibrant amethyst colour and a magnificent pink satin. I told him in a new series of whispers that he might as well buy me a gold dress and a silver bonnet at once, as I would certainly never dare to wear his selections. With immense difficulty, as he was as stubborn as a rock, I persuaded him to exchange them for a modest black satin and a pearl-grey silk. 'It's acceptable for now,' he said, 'but I will yet see you sparkling like a flower garden.' I was thrilled to get him out of the silk shop and then out of a jeweller's. The more he bought for me, the more my face felt hot with a sense of irritation and humiliation. As we got back into the carriage and I leaned back, feeling feverish and exhausted, I remembered something I had completely forgotten in the rush of events, both good and bad—the letter from my uncle, John Eyre, to Mrs. Reed, stating his intention to adopt me and make me his heir. 'It truly would be a relief,' I thought, 'if I had even a small independent income. I can never bear being dressed up like a doll by Mr. Rochester or sitting like a second Danaë with a shower of gold constantly falling around me. I will write to Madeira the moment I get home and tell my uncle John I am going to be married and to whom. If only I had the prospect of someday bringing Mr. Rochester an increase in fortune, I could better endure being supported by him now.' And somewhat eased by this thought (which I did not fail to act upon that very day), I dared once more to meet the gaze of my master and lover, which persistently sought mine, although I turned away both my face and my eyes. He smiled; and I thought his smile was like one a sultan might, in a happy and affectionate moment, give to a slave his gold and jewels had made wealthy. I squeezed his hand, which was constantly reaching for mine, forcefully, and pushed it back towards him, red from the intense pressure.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I was becoming more and more annoyed when, fortunately, Adèle appeared, asking excitedly to join the trip to Millcote. She wanted me to plead her case since Mr. Rochester refused, despite there being space in the carriage. I promised to ask, eager to escape a somber companion. The carriage was ready, and Mr. Rochester was pacing nearby while Pilot, his dog, moved with him. I asked if Adèle could join us. He refused, saying he only wanted my company, not Adèle's, and insisted she would be a burden. Discouraged by Mrs. Fairfax’s cautions, I felt unsure and powerless but was about to comply when Mr. Rochester noticed my changed expression. He asked if Adèle’s exclusion upset me, and when I said I’d prefer for her to come, he quickly sent her to fetch her bonnet. He brushed off the disruption, telling me soon I would be his for life.

Once Adèle returned and was seated in the carriage, she gratefully kissed me, then sat away from him, too intimidated to speak. I suggested she sit by me, expecting she might bother him, and he agreed, passing her over with mock annoyance but a smile. Adèle asked if she was to go to school alone. Rochester replied she was, as he intended to take me to the moon so we could live together in solitude, inventing an imaginative tale about how we’d survive with manna for food and fire from lunar volcanoes. Adèle, unconvinced, thought my life would be uncomfortable there and declared that, in my position, she wouldn’t agree to go.

Rochester asserted I had already promised, but Adèle pointed out that it was impossible to reach the moon. Changing the subject, Rochester pointed out a field as we drove out of Thornfield, recounting an evening when he rested there and imagined a fairy offering to make him happy if he placed a ring on her finger—a thinly-veiled metaphor for our relationship. Adèle, skeptical, dismissed his story, insisting there were no fairies and none would consort with him.

Our time in Millcote was taxing for me. Mr. Rochester insisted I pick out six new dresses at a silk store; I protested and persuaded him to settle on two, though he insisted on choosing. He selected flashy fabrics, but I convinced him, after some effort, to switch to more modest colors. The shopping ordeal continued with jewelry, and as I sat exhausted in the carriage afterward, I remembered my uncle John Eyre’s intention of adopting me and leaving me an inheritance. The thought cheered me, as I disliked feeling like a dressed-up doll or a passive recipient of Rochester’s generosity. Planning to write to my uncle once home, I felt somewhat lighter and dared to meet Rochester’s affectionate gaze. He smiled in a way that made me feel both cherished and subordinate, so I squeezed his hand fiercely, expressing my intense feelings.

events.title: Jane Asserts Her Terms for Equality, Independence, and their Pre-Marital Relationship
detailed_summary: Jane tells Rochester not to look at her with possessive pride, threatening to wear old frocks if he does, and playfully suggests alternative uses for the silks he bought.
Rochester is amused by her originality and spirit, declaring he wouldn't trade her for a Sultan's harem.
The 'Eastern allusion' provokes Jane to assert she is not a seraglio equivalent and mockingly suggests he buy slaves if he desires such.
She declares if he did, she would become a missionary to free his harem, ultimately fettering him until he signed a liberal charter.
Rochester says he would consent to her mercy, but Jane retorts she'd show none if he maintained his coercive look.
She clarifies she wants an easy mind, not to be his 'English Céline Varens,' and insists on remaining Adèle's governess to earn her own keep, wanting only his regard in return for hers.
As they approach Thornfield, she declines to dine with him, wishing to continue their usual routine for another month and only see him in the evenings by summons.
Rochester, frustrated but captivated, calls her a 'little tyrant' and playfully threatens to keep her on a chain once married, likening her to a precious jewel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You need not look in that way,” I said;
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He said this as he helped me to alight from the carriage, and while he afterwards lifted out Adèle, I entered the house, and made good my retreat upstairs.

events.text_segment:
“You need not look in that way,” I said; “if you do, I’ll wear nothing but my old Lowood frocks to the end of the chapter. I’ll be married in this lilac gingham: you may make a dressing-gown for yourself out of the pearl-grey silk, and an infinite series of waistcoats out of the black satin.”
He chuckled; he rubbed his hands. “Oh, it is rich to see and hear her!” he exclaimed. “Is she original? Is she piquant? I would not exchange this one little English girl for the Grand Turk’s whole seraglio, gazelle-eyes, houri forms, and all!”
The Eastern allusion bit me again. “I’ll not stand you an inch in the stead of a seraglio,” I said; “so don’t consider me an equivalent for one. If you have a fancy for anything in that line, away with you, sir, to the bazaars of Stamboul without delay, and lay out in extensive slave-purchases some of that spare cash you seem at a loss to spend satisfactorily here.”
“And what will you do, Janet, while I am bargaining for so many tons of flesh and such an assortment of black eyes?”
“I’ll be preparing myself to go out as a missionary to preach liberty to them that are enslaved—your harem inmates amongst the rest. I’ll get admitted there, and I’ll stir up mutiny; and you, three-tailed bashaw as you are, sir, shall in a trice find yourself fettered amongst our hands: nor will I, for one, consent to cut your bonds till you have signed a charter, the most liberal that despot ever yet conferred.”
“I would consent to be at your mercy, Jane.”
“I would have no mercy, Mr. Rochester, if you supplicated for it with an eye like that. While you looked so, I should be certain that whatever charter you might grant under coercion, your first act, when released, would be to violate its conditions.”
“Why, Jane, what would you have? I fear you will compel me to go through a private marriage ceremony, besides that performed at the altar. You will stipulate, I see, for peculiar terms—what will they be?”
“I only want an easy mind, sir; not crushed by crowded obligations. Do you remember what you said of Céline Varens?—of the diamonds, the cashmeres you gave her? I will not be your English Céline Varens. I shall continue to act as Adèle’s governess; by that I shall earn my board and lodging, and thirty pounds a year besides. I’ll furnish my own wardrobe out of that money, and you shall give me nothing but—”
“Well, but what?”
“Your regard; and if I give you mine in return, that debt will be quit.”
“Well, for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven’t your equal,” said he. We were now approaching Thornfield. “Will it please you to dine with me to-day?” he asked, as we re-entered the gates.
“No, thank you, sir.”
“And what for, ‘no, thank you?’ if one may inquire.”
“I never have dined with you, sir: and I see no reason why I should now: till—”
“Till what? You delight in half-phrases.”
“Till I can’t help it.”
“Do you suppose I eat like an ogre or a ghoul, that you dread being the companion of my repast?”
“I have formed no supposition on the subject, sir; but I want to go on as usual for another month.”
“You will give up your governessing slavery at once.”
“Indeed, begging your pardon, sir, I shall not. I shall just go on with it as usual. I shall keep out of your way all day, as I have been accustomed to do: you may send for me in the evening, when you feel disposed to see me, and I’ll come then; but at no other time.”
“I want a smoke, Jane, or a pinch of snuff, to comfort me under all this, ‘pour me donner une contenance,’ as Adèle would say; and unfortunately I have neither my cigar-case, nor my snuff-box. But listen—whisper. It is your time now, little tyrant, but it will be mine presently; and when once I have fairly seized you, to have and to hold, I’ll just—figuratively speaking—attach you to a chain like this” (touching his watch-guard). “Yes, bonny wee thing, I’ll wear you in my bosom, lest my jewel I should tyne.”
He said this as he helped me to alight from the carriage, and while he afterwards lifted out Adèle, I entered the house, and made good my retreat upstairs.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Don't look at me like that," I said. "If you do, I'll stick to my old Lowood dresses for good. I'll even get married in this lilac cotton; you may as well use the pearl-grey silk to make yourself a dressing-gown and sew hundreds of waistcoats for yourself from the black satin." 

He laughed, rubbing his hands. "It's wonderful to see and hear her! Isn't she unique? Isn't she lively? I wouldn't trade this one English girl for all the beauties in the Grand Turk's harem!"

His mention of the East annoyed me again. "Don't think for a second that I replace a harem," I said. "If that’s what you want, go off to the markets of Istanbul and spend your extra money on as many slaves as you can buy."

"And what will you do, Jane, while I'm off buying all that beauty?"

"I'll get ready to become a missionary and go preach freedom to your enslaved harem women. I'll get myself admitted there, incite a rebellion, and pretty soon you'll find yourself captured by us—and I won’t let you go until you sign the most generous charter any tyrant has ever issued."

"I would submit to your will, Jane."

"I wouldn’t go easy on you, Mr. Rochester, not if you begged with that look. If you did, I'd be sure the minute you were free, you'd break whatever promise you made while under pressure."

"Jane, what more do you want? I think you'll make me go through a private wedding ceremony on top of the public one. You seem ready with your own special demands—what might they be?"

"I just want peace of mind, sir; not to be burdened by a pile of obligations. Do you remember what you told me about Céline Varens—the jewels and fine things you gave her? I will not be your English Céline Varens. I’ll stay Adèle’s governess; that way, I’ll earn my keep and thirty pounds a year. I'll pay for my own clothes from that, and you’ll give me nothing but—"

"But what?"

"Your affection; and if I give you mine, then we’re even."

"Well, for natural cheek and self-respect, you’re unmatched," he said. As we neared Thornfield, he asked, "Would you like to dine with me today?"

"No, thank you, sir."

"Why not, may I ask?"

"I've never dined with you, and I see no reason to start now—until—"

"Until what? You do love to leave sentences unfinished."

"Until I have no choice."

"Do you think I eat like some kind of monster that you dread joining me?"

"I haven’t thought about it, sir. I just want to keep things the same for the next month."

"You’ll leave your job as governess right away."

"Pardon me, sir, but I won’t. I’ll carry on as usual. I’ll avoid you during the day as I always have; you can send for me in the evenings if you want to see me. Otherwise, I’ll keep my distance."

"I need a smoke or a pinch of snuff to help me cope with all this, like Adèle would say, but I have neither with me. But listen—whisper—it's your turn now, little tyrant, but soon it’ll be mine. Once I have you as my own, I’ll figuratively chain you to me," he said, touching his watch-chain, "and I'll keep you close, so I never lose my treasure."

He said this as he helped me out of the carriage; after he lifted Adèle down, I went straight into the house and headed upstairs.

events.title: Jane's Strategic Courtship, Evening Rituals, and Deepening Emotional Idolatry
detailed_summary: In the evenings, Jane intentionally manages their interactions, for instance, by asking Rochester to sing and play the piano to avoid intense tête-à-têtes.
After he sings a passionate love song he composed for her, she deliberately provokes him by questioning who he intends to marry, given the song's lyrics about dying with his love.
She refutes any notion of dying with him, asserting her right to live and die on her own terms.
She refuses his request for a reconciling kiss, claiming to be naturally 'hard' and 'flinty,' and states her determination to reveal her 'rugged points' before the wedding.
Jane consciously works to irritate him moderately, believing this approach maintains a healthy distance and is the best way to manage their relationship.
She continues this 'system' throughout their engagement, keeping Rochester entertained but somewhat cross, which she and Mrs. Fairfax see as preferable to docile submission.
His endearments turn to playful insults, and caresses to pinches, which Jane prefers.
Despite this outward control and strategic teasing, Jane inwardly admits that Rochester is becoming her entire world, almost an idol, eclipsing her religious devotion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He duly summoned me to his presence in the evening.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I could not, in those days, see God for His creature: of whom I had made an idol.

events.text_segment:
He duly summoned me to his presence in the evening. I had prepared an occupation for him; for I was determined not to spend the whole time in a tête-à-tête conversation. I remembered his fine voice; I knew he liked to sing—good singers generally do. I was no vocalist myself, and, in his fastidious judgment, no musician, either; but I delighted in listening when the performance was good. No sooner had twilight, that hour of romance, began to lower her blue and starry banner over the lattice, than I rose, opened the piano, and entreated him, for the love of heaven, to give me a song. He said I was a capricious witch, and that he would rather sing another time; but I averred that no time was like the present.
“Did I like his voice?” he asked.
“Very much.” I was not fond of pampering that susceptible vanity of his; but for once, and from motives of expediency, I would e’en soothe and stimulate it.
“Then, Jane, you must play the accompaniment.”
“Very well, sir, I will try.”
I did try, but was presently swept off the stool and denominated “a little bungler.” Being pushed unceremoniously to one side—which was precisely what I wished—he usurped my place, and proceeded to accompany himself: for he could play as well as sing. I hied me to the window-recess. And while I sat there and looked out on the still trees and dim lawn, to a sweet air was sung in mellow tones the following strain:—
“The truest love that ever heart
Felt at its kindled core,
Did through each vein, in quickened start,
The tide of being pour.

Her coming was my hope each day,
Her parting was my pain;
The chance that did her steps delay
Was ice in every vein.

I dreamed it would be nameless bliss,
As I loved, loved to be;
And to this object did I press
As blind as eagerly.

But wide as pathless was the space
That lay our lives between,
And dangerous as the foamy race
Of ocean-surges green.

And haunted as a robber-path
Through wilderness or wood;
For Might and Right, and Woe and Wrath,
Between our spirits stood.

I dangers dared; I hindrance scorned;
I omens did defy:
Whatever menaced, harassed, warned,
I passed impetuous by.

On sped my rainbow, fast as light;
I flew as in a dream;
For glorious rose upon my sight
That child of Shower and Gleam.

Still bright on clouds of suffering dim
Shines that soft, solemn joy;
Nor care I now, how dense and grim
Disasters gather nigh.

I care not in this moment sweet,
Though all I have rushed o’er
Should come on pinion, strong and fleet,
Proclaiming vengeance sore:

Though haughty Hate should strike me down,
Right, bar approach to me,
And grinding Might, with furious frown,
Swear endless enmity.

My love has placed her little hand
With noble faith in mine,
And vowed that wedlock’s sacred band
Our nature shall entwine.

My love has sworn, with sealing kiss,
With me to live—to die;
I have at last my nameless bliss.
As I love—loved am I!”
He rose and came towards me, and I saw his face all kindled, and his full falcon-eye flashing, and tenderness and passion in every lineament. I quailed momentarily—then I rallied. Soft scene, daring demonstration, I would not have; and I stood in peril of both: a weapon of defence must be prepared—I whetted my tongue: as he reached me, I asked with asperity, “whom he was going to marry now?”
“That was a strange question to be put by his darling Jane.”
“Indeed! I considered it a very natural and necessary one: he had talked of his future wife dying with him. What did he mean by such a pagan idea? I had no intention of dying with him—he might depend on that.”
“Oh, all he longed, all he prayed for, was that I might live with him! Death was not for such as I.”
“Indeed it was: I had as good a right to die when my time came as he had: but I should bide that time, and not be hurried away in a suttee.”
“Would I forgive him for the selfish idea, and prove my pardon by a reconciling kiss?”
“No: I would rather be excused.”
Here I heard myself apostrophised as a “hard little thing;” and it was added, “any other woman would have been melted to marrow at hearing such stanzas crooned in her praise.”
I assured him I was naturally hard—very flinty, and that he would often find me so; and that, moreover, I was determined to show him divers rugged points in my character before the ensuing four weeks elapsed: he should know fully what sort of a bargain he had made, while there was yet time to rescind it.
“Would I be quiet and talk rationally?”
“I would be quiet if he liked, and as to talking rationally, I flattered myself I was doing that now.”
He fretted, pished, and pshawed. “Very good,” I thought; “you may fume and fidget as you please: but this is the best plan to pursue with you, I am certain. I like you more than I can say; but I’ll not sink into a bathos of sentiment: and with this needle of repartee I’ll keep you from the edge of the gulf too; and, moreover, maintain by its pungent aid that distance between you and myself most conducive to our real mutual advantage.”
From less to more, I worked him up to considerable irritation; then, after he had retired, in dudgeon, quite to the other end of the room, I got up, and saying, “I wish you good-night, sir,” in my natural and wonted respectful manner, I slipped out by the side-door and got away.
The system thus entered on, I pursued during the whole season of probation; and with the best success. He was kept, to be sure, rather cross and crusty; but on the whole I could see he was excellently entertained, and that a lamb-like submission and turtle-dove sensibility, while fostering his despotism more, would have pleased his judgment, satisfied his common-sense, and even suited his taste less.
In other people’s presence I was, as formerly, deferential and quiet; any other line of conduct being uncalled for: it was only in the evening conferences I thus thwarted and afflicted him. He continued to send for me punctually the moment the clock struck seven; though when I appeared before him now, he had no such honeyed terms as “love” and “darling” on his lips: the best words at my service were “provoking puppet,” “malicious elf,” “sprite,” “changeling,” &c. For caresses, too, I now got grimaces; for a pressure of the hand, a pinch on the arm; for a kiss on the cheek, a severe tweak of the ear. It was all right: at present I decidedly preferred these fierce favours to anything more tender. Mrs. Fairfax, I saw, approved me: her anxiety on my account vanished; therefore I was certain I did well. Meantime, Mr. Rochester affirmed I was wearing him to skin and bone, and threatened awful vengeance for my present conduct at some period fast coming. I laughed in my sleeve at his menaces. “I can keep you in reasonable check now,” I reflected; “and I don’t doubt to be able to do it hereafter: if one expedient loses its virtue, another must be devised.”
Yet after all my task was not an easy one; often I would rather have pleased than teased him. My future husband was becoming to me my whole world; and more than the world: almost my hope of heaven. He stood between me and every thought of religion, as an eclipse intervenes between man and the broad sun. I could not, in those days, see God for His creature: of whom I had made an idol.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
In the evening, he duly requested my presence. I had planned something beforehand, as I didn't want to spend the entire time just chatting with him. I recalled his pleasant singing voice and knew he enjoyed performing—as good singers usually do. I wasn't a singer myself, nor did he consider me a musician based on his high standards, but I truly enjoyed listening to skilled performers. As twilight, the romantic hour, began casting its soft, starry gloom over the windows, I stood up, opened the piano, and implored him to sing for me, for goodness sake. He grumbled that I was a whimsical sort and that he'd prefer to sing later, but I insisted that the present moment was the only suitable time. 'Did I like his voice?' he inquired. 'Very much,' I replied. I wasn't keen on indulging his susceptible vanity, but just this once, and out of practical consideration, I decided to soothe and encourage it. 'Then, Jane,' he said, 'you must accompany me.' 'Certainly, sir, I'll attempt it,' I answered. I did try, but he quickly pushed me off the stool, calling me 'a clumsy novice.' After unceremoniously shoving me aside—which was exactly my goal—he took my spot and began accompanying himself, as he was skilled at playing as well as singing. I moved quickly to the window alcove. While I sat there, gazing out at the still trees and dimly lit lawn, he sang the following verse in smooth tones to a sweet melody: 

'The deepest love a heart could feel
When it first stirred within,
Flowed through each vein, a vibrant reel,
Bringing life's tide rushing in.

Her arrival brought hope each day,
Her departure caused me pain;
Any chance that caused her delay
Was ice in every vein.

I dreamed of a bliss beyond compare,
To be loved, as I did love;
And towards this aim I pressed with care,
Blindly, like a driven dove.

But vast and trackless was the space
That kept our lives apart,
And perilous as the churning race
Of green ocean's beating heart.

And dangerous as a robber's trail
Through forest deep or wild;
For Strength and Justice, Grief and Ire,
Between our spirits piled.

I faced down risks; scorned every bar;
Defied all ominous signs:
Whatever threatened, vexed, or warned,
I rushed past their confines.

On flew my hope, a rainbow bright;
I soared as in a dream;
For glorious dawned upon my sight
That child of Sun and Gleam.

Still brightly on dim clouds of woe
Shines that calm, deep delight;
Nor do I care, however so
Disasters gather close tonight.

I do not fear this moment sweet,
Though all I've overcome
Should come with wings, both strong and fleet,
Seeking harsh vengeance to some:

Though proud Hate should strike me down low,
Justice bar my way to bliss,
And crushing Might, with furious brow,
Swear endless enmity on this.

My love has placed her small hand here
With noble trust in mine,
And vowed that wedlock's bond so dear
Our beings shall entwine.

My love has sworn, with sealing kiss,
With me to live—to die;
I have at last my longed-for bliss.
As I love—loved am I!'

He finished and approached me, his face alight with emotion, his intense falcon-like eyes flashing, showing tenderness and passion in every feature. I flinched for a moment, then regained my composure. I was determined not to have a soft scene or a bold display of affection, and I was facing the risk of both. I needed a defensive strategy—I sharpened my wit. As he reached me, I asked sharply, 'So, who are you planning to marry now?'

He found it odd that his 'darling Jane' would ask such a question. 'Really!' I retorted, 'I thought it was a perfectly natural and necessary query. You mentioned your future wife dying with you. What did you mean by such a pagan notion? I certainly have no intention of dying with you—you can be sure of that.'

'Oh,' he exclaimed, 'all I desire, all I pray for, is that you would live with me! Death is not for someone like you.'

'Indeed it is,' I countered. 'I have just as much right to die when it's my time as you do; but I shall wait for that time and not be rushed into a sacrificial death like a suttee.'

'Would I forgive him for the self-centered thought,' he asked, 'and show my forgiveness with a kiss of reconciliation?'

'No,' I replied, 'I would rather not.'

At this point, he called me a 'stubborn little creature' and added that 'any other woman would have been completely melted to the core by hearing such verses sung in her praise.'

I assured him that I was inherently tough—very much like flint—and that he would find me so often. Furthermore, I was resolved to reveal various difficult aspects of my character before the next four weeks were over. He would know exactly what kind of commitment he had made while there was still an opportunity to withdraw from it.

'Would I please be quiet and speak reasonably?' he pressed.

'I will be quiet if you wish,' I replied, 'and as for speaking reasonably, I believe I am doing so now.'

He showed signs of annoyance, muttering dismissively. 'Excellent,' I thought to myself. 'You may fume and fidget as much as you like, but this, I am convinced, is the best way to handle you. I care for you more than I can express, but I refuse to descend into sentimental melodrama. And with this sharp wit of mine, I will prevent you from falling into that emotional pit too; and what's more, with its biting effectiveness, I will maintain that distance between us that is most beneficial for both our true interests.'

Gradually, I provoked him further until he was quite irritated. Then, after he had retreated to the opposite end of the room in a huff, I got up, said, 'Good night, sir,' in my usual respectful tone, and quietly slipped out through the side door.

I continued this strategy throughout the entire trial period, and it proved very successful. It kept him somewhat cross and difficult, certainly, but overall, I could see he was thoroughly entertained, and that a meek submission and tender emotion, while possibly gratifying his need for control more, would have pleased his sense of judgment, satisfied his common sense, and even suited his taste less.

In the presence of others, I remained, as before, respectful and quiet, as any other behavior was unnecessary. It was only during our private evening meetings that I deliberately opposed and annoyed him. He continued to summon me promptly the moment the clock struck seven, although when I appeared before him now, his lips no longer uttered sweet endearments like 'love' and 'darling.' The best words he had for me were 'irritating puppet,' 'mean-spirited imp,' 'spirit,' 'changeling,' and so on. Instead of gentle caresses, I now received scowls; instead of a hand squeeze, a pinch on the arm; instead of a kiss on the cheek, a sharp tug on the ear. This was perfectly acceptable; at that point, I clearly preferred these rough signs of favour to anything more tender. I could see that Mrs. Fairfax approved of me; her worry about me disappeared, so I was certain I was doing the right thing. Meanwhile, Mr. Rochester claimed I was wearing him down to skin and bone and threatened terrible retribution for my current behavior at some approaching time. I secretly found his threats amusing. 'I can keep you reasonably in check now,' I reflected, 'and I have no doubt I can do so in the future. If one method stops working, I will simply invent another.'

Yet, despite everything, my task was not easy. Often, I would have preferred to please him rather than provoke him. My future husband was becoming everything to me; more than the world itself, almost my hope of salvation. He stood between me and any thought of religious devotion, just as an eclipse comes between a person and the bright sun. In those days, I could not see God because of His creation, whom I had turned into an idol.

He called for me in the evening as usual. Wanting to avoid an extended private conversation, I had thought of something to occupy him. I remembered his excellent singing voice and his fondness for performing, though I wasn’t a singer myself and he didn’t consider me much of a musician, I still enjoyed listening to good music. As dusk began, casting its romantic light, I opened the piano and asked him to sing for me. He complained and called me unpredictable, saying he’d rather sing another time, but I insisted there was no better moment than now.

He inquired whether I liked his singing, to which I replied that I did. I usually avoided flattering his ego, but this time I did so intentionally. He then told me to play the piano accompaniment. I agreed to try, but he soon deemed me incompetent and moved me aside, which was what I wanted. He then sat at the piano himself, as he could play and sing, and I went to sit by the window. While I looked out at the quiet trees and dim garden, he sang the following song with a sweet voice:

[Poem omitted for brevity]

After finishing, he approached me, his face animated and passionate, which made me briefly uneasy before I composed myself. I didn’t want any romantic scene and felt the need to defend myself with words. As he reached me, I sharply asked who he intended to marry now. He said it was odd for me, his ‘darling Jane,’ to ask such a thing. I replied that it was a perfectly reasonable question, as he had mentioned wishing his future wife would die with him, which I found a strange notion—I did not intend to die with him.

He declared all he wished for was that I would live with him. Death, he said, was not for someone like me. I retorted that I had as much right to die as he did, but I would do so only when the time was right, not in some dramatic fashion. He asked for forgiveness for his selfish idea and requested a kiss as proof. I refused, preferring to be excused. He called me a ‘hard little thing’ and noted that any other woman would have been deeply moved by his song. I told him I was indeed hard, and he would find more of such tough qualities in me over the next few weeks, so he would fully know what kind of woman he was about to marry while he still had time to reconsider.

He asked if I would calm down and speak sensibly. I said I could be quiet if he wanted, and thought I was being rational. He became irritated, but I felt confident that this was the best way to handle him. I cared for him deeply, but I refused to fall into excessive sentimentality; instead, I used playful teasing to keep our relationship balanced and healthy.

Eventually, I provoked him to considerable annoyance, and when he sulked at the other end of the room, I politely wished him good night and made my exit. I continued this approach throughout our engagement, which proved successful. He was often irritable, but generally well entertained, and I believed that more submissive, sentimental behavior would not have suited him as well. Around others I remained respectful and quiet, but in private, I persisted in my more challenging ways. He still summoned me every evening at seven, but was now more likely to call me names like ‘provoking puppet’ or ‘sprite’ rather than ‘darling.’ His affection was expressed with mock sternness rather than tenderness, which I actually preferred. Mrs. Fairfax seemed satisfied with my behavior and no longer worried about me, assuring me I was proceeding wisely. Mr. Rochester claimed I was tormenting him and threatened retribution for my conduct, but I found this amusing and was confident in my ability to manage him in future.

Still, it wasn’t always easy for me; I often wanted to please him rather than tease him. My feelings for my future husband grew so strong that he became the center of my world, eclipsing even my spiritual life. I found myself thinking of him rather than of God, as if he had become my idol.

events.title: Premonitions on the Wedding Eve
detailed_summary: Jane reflects on the final hours before her wedding, noting that all preparations are complete.
She contemplates her impending transformation into "Jane Rochester," a person she feels she doesn't yet know.
She observes the address cards Mr. Rochester prepared, hesitant to affix them as "Mrs. Rochester" doesn't yet exist.
She notes her wedding attire, including a pearl-colored robe and veil, has replaced her old Lowood dress, feeling these new garments don't truly belong to her.
She closes the closet to hide the "wraith-like" wedding clothes, which seem ghostly in the evening light.
Feeling feverish and agitated by the wind, she decides to go outdoors.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The month of courtship had wasted: its very last hours were being numbered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I will leave you by yourself, white dream,” I said. “I am feverish: I hear the wind blowing: I will go out of doors and feel it.”

events.text_segment: The month of courtship had wasted: its very last hours were being numbered. There was no putting off the day that advanced—the bridal day; and all preparations for its arrival were complete. I, at least, had nothing more to do: there were my trunks, packed, locked, corded, ranged in a row along the wall of my little chamber; to-morrow, at this time, they would be far on their road to London: and so should I (D.V.),—or rather, not I, but one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not. The cards of address alone remained to nail on: they lay, four little squares, in the drawer. Mr. Rochester had himself written the direction, “Mrs. Rochester, —— Hotel, London,” on each: I could not persuade myself to affix them, or to have them affixed. Mrs. Rochester! She did not exist: she would not be born till to-morrow, some time after eight o’clock A.M.; and I would wait to be assured she had come into the world alive before I assigned to her all that property. It was enough that in yonder closet, opposite my dressing-table, garments said to be hers had already displaced my black stuff Lowood frock and straw bonnet: for not to me appertained that suit of wedding raiment; the pearl-coloured robe, the vapoury veil pendent from the usurped portmanteau. I shut the closet to conceal the strange, wraith-like apparel it contained; which, at this evening hour—nine o’clock—gave out certainly a most ghostly shimmer through the shadow of my apartment. “I will leave you by yourself, white dream,” I said. “I am feverish: I hear the wind blowing: I will go out of doors and feel it.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The month spent in courtship was over; its very last hours were passing. There was no way to delay the approaching day—the wedding day—and all arrangements for its arrival were complete. I, at least, had finished everything I needed to do: my packed, locked, and tied trunks were lined up in a row along the wall of my little room. By this time tomorrow, they would be well on their way to London, and so, God willing, would I—or rather, not me, but a person called Jane Rochester, someone I didn't feel I knew yet. Only the address cards remained to be nailed on; the four small squares lay in the drawer. Mr. Rochester himself had written the address, “Mrs. Rochester, —— Hotel, London,” on each one; I couldn't persuade myself to attach them, or to have them attached. Mrs. Rochester! She wasn't real; she wouldn't be born until sometime after eight o’clock tomorrow morning. I wanted to wait to be sure she had arrived in the world alive before assigning all that property to her. It was enough that in the wardrobe over there, opposite my dressing-table, garments said to be hers had already taken the place of my simple black Lowood frock and straw bonnet: that wedding outfit didn't belong to me—the pale gown, the light veil hanging from the wardrobe it had claimed. I shut the closet to hide the strange, spirit-like clothing it contained; which, at this hour of the evening—nine o’clock—certainly gave off a most spectral shimmer through the shadow in my apartment. “I will leave you by yourself, white vision,” I said. “I feel restless; I hear the wind blowing: I will go outside and feel it.”
