The wedding day was fast approaching and could not be delayed; everything for the event was now finished. I, for my part, had nothing left to organize—my luggage was packed, secured, and lined up along my bedroom wall. By this time tomorrow, the trunks would be on their way to London, and so, in a sense, would I—though it felt as if it wouldn’t be me, but a new person called Jane Rochester, whom I had yet to meet. Only the address labels remained to be attached; they sat in the drawer, four small cards, each inscribed by Mr. Rochester with “Mrs. Rochester, —— Hotel, London.” I couldn’t bring myself to put them on, or let anyone else do it. The title, “Mrs. Rochester,” didn’t feel real yet—it wouldn’t become true until after eight o'clock tomorrow morning, and I wanted to wait until that new identity was certain before claiming it. In my closet, the bridal clothes—intended for Mrs. Rochester—had taken the place of my old Lowood dress and straw hat; but I didn’t feel those wedding garments belonged to me. I closed the closet doors to hide the unfamiliar, spectral-looking clothes, which, in the dim light of nine o’clock in the evening, seemed to give off an eerie glow. “I’ll leave you alone, white dream,” I murmured. “I am restless—I hear the wind outside; I’ll go out and feel it.”

events.title: An Unsettling Secret
detailed_summary: Jane reveals her feverish state is not solely due to wedding preparations or anticipation of her new life.
She admits a "third cause," a strange and anxious thought related to an incomprehensible event from the previous night, influenced her more significantly.
This event was witnessed only by her, as Mr. Rochester was away on business concerning a distant property, a trip necessary before their departure from England.
She eagerly awaits Mr. Rochester's return to share her secret and seek his explanation for the perplexing occurrence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was not only the hurry of preparation that made me feverish; not only the anticipation of the great change—the new life which was to commence to-morrow: both these circumstances had their share, doubtless, in producing that restless, excited mood which hurried me forth at this late hour into the darkening grounds: but a third cause influenced my mind more than they.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Stay till he comes, reader; and, when I disclose my secret to him, you shall share the confidence.

events.text_segment:
It was not only the hurry of preparation that made me feverish; not only the anticipation of the great change—the new life which was to commence to-morrow: both these circumstances had their share, doubtless, in producing that restless, excited mood which hurried me forth at this late hour into the darkening grounds: but a third cause influenced my mind more than they.
I had at heart a strange and anxious thought. Something had happened which I could not comprehend; no one knew of or had seen the event but myself: it had taken place the preceding night. Mr. Rochester that night was absent from home; nor was he yet returned: business had called him to a small estate of two or three farms he possessed thirty miles off—business it was requisite he should settle in person, previous to his meditated departure from England. I waited now his return; eager to disburthen my mind, and to seek of him the solution of the enigma that perplexed me. Stay till he comes, reader; and, when I disclose my secret to him, you shall share the confidence.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: My feeling of agitation wasn't solely due to the rush of getting ready or the anticipation of the big change—the new life starting tomorrow. Those factors certainly played a role in my restless, excited mood, which prompted me to go out into the twilight at this late hour. However, a third cause influenced my mind more significantly. I was troubled by a peculiar and unsettling thought. Something had happened the night before that I couldn't understand; only I had seen or knew about this event. Mr. Rochester was absent from home that night and hadn't come back yet; he had been called away on necessary business to a small property of two or three farms he owned thirty miles away, business he needed to handle in person before his planned departure from England. I was now waiting for his return, eager to tell him what had occurred and ask him to solve the mystery that perplexed me. Reader, wait until he arrives, and when I share my secret with him, you will know it too.

Certainly, both of these factors contributed to my nervousness and the restless state that drove me outside into the dusk so late. However, there was another, stronger reason troubling me. I was preoccupied with a peculiar and worrying thought. Something had occurred which was beyond my understanding; I was the only one who had witnessed it, and the incident had happened the night before. Mr. Rochester was away from home at that time and had not yet come back; he had urgent matters to attend to concerning a small property of his, some thirty miles away—a matter he needed to handle himself before leaving England as planned. Now, I was anxiously awaiting his return to unburden myself, hoping he could clarify the mystery that had unsettled me. Wait with me for his arrival, reader; once I reveal my secret to him, I will also share it with you.

events.title: Ominous Nature and a Symbolic Ruin
detailed_summary: Jane seeks refuge from the strong, persistent south wind in the orchard.
The wind intensifies as night approaches, bending the trees northward, while the sky remains overcast.
She finds a "wild pleasure" in running before the wind, feeling it mirrors her mental turmoil.
She confronts the storm-damaged chestnut tree, now split down the middle but still connected at the roots, a "ruin, but an entire ruin."
She speaks to the tree, acknowledging its tenacity and shared decay, noting its time of pleasure and love is over but it is not alone.
The moon appears briefly, blood-red and half-obscured, casting a "bewildered, dreary glance" before disappearing, accompanied by a distant, melancholy wail of the wind.
Feeling unsettled by these omens, Jane quickly moves on.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I sought the orchard, driven to its shelter by the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The wind fell, for a second, round Thornfield; but far away over wood and water, poured a wild, melancholy wail: it was sad to listen to, and I ran off again.

events.text_segment:
I sought the orchard, driven to its shelter by the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain. Instead of subsiding as night drew on, it seemed to augment its rush and deepen its roar: the trees blew steadfastly one way, never writhing round, and scarcely tossing back their boughs once in an hour; so continuous was the strain bending their branchy heads northward—the clouds drifted from pole to pole, fast following, mass on mass: no glimpse of blue sky had been visible that July day.
It was not without a certain wild pleasure I ran before the wind, delivering my trouble of mind to the measureless air-torrent thundering through space. Descending the laurel walk, I faced the wreck of the chestnut-tree; it stood up black and riven: the trunk, split down the centre, gasped ghastly. The cloven halves were not broken from each other, for the firm base and strong roots kept them unsundered below; though community of vitality was destroyed—the sap could flow no more: their great boughs on each side were dead, and next winter’s tempests would be sure to fell one or both to earth: as yet, however, they might be said to form one tree—a ruin, but an entire ruin.
“You did right to hold fast to each other,” I said: as if the monster-splinters were living things, and could hear me. “I think, scathed as you look, and charred and scorched, there must be a little sense of life in you yet, rising out of that adhesion at the faithful, honest roots: you will never have green leaves more—never more see birds making nests and singing idyls in your boughs; the time of pleasure and love is over with you: but you are not desolate: each of you has a comrade to sympathise with him in his decay.” As I looked up at them, the moon appeared momentarily in that part of the sky which filled their fissure; her disk was blood-red and half overcast; she seemed to throw on me one bewildered, dreary glance, and buried herself again instantly in the deep drift of cloud. The wind fell, for a second, round Thornfield; but far away over wood and water, poured a wild, melancholy wail: it was sad to listen to, and I ran off again.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Seeking refuge from the forceful and steady south wind that had been blowing all day without bringing rain, I went into the orchard. As evening approached, the wind didn't die down; instead, its intensity increased, and its noise grew louder. The trees consistently leaned in one direction, rarely twisting or tossing their branches back even once an hour, held under constant pressure that bent their heads towards the north. Clouds hurried across the sky from horizon to horizon, piling up rapidly; not a patch of blue had been visible on that July day.

I found a strange, wild enjoyment in running ahead of the wind, releasing my mental distress into the vast, roaring current of air rushing through space. Walking down the laurel path, I came upon the remains of the chestnut tree. It stood stark, black, and torn apart; its trunk was split down the middle, gaping horribly. The two severed halves hadn't separated completely because the sturdy base and strong roots kept them connected below, though their shared life was gone—sap could no longer flow. Their large branches on either side were dead, and future winter storms would surely bring one or both crashing to the ground. However, for now, they still resembled a single tree—a ruin, but an intact ruin.

"You did well to hold onto each other," I commented, speaking as if the massive splinters were alive and could hear me. "Despite how scarred, charred, and scorched you appear, I believe there's still a flicker of life in you, sustained by that connection at the loyal, firm roots. You'll never bear green leaves again, never again see birds building nests and singing peacefully in your branches; your time for joy and love is over. But you are not alone; each of you has a companion to share your decline." As I gazed up at them, the moon briefly appeared in the section of sky visible through the tree's split trunk. Its disk was blood-red and partly hidden by clouds; it seemed to cast a confused, desolate look at me before immediately disappearing back into the thick cloud cover. The wind momentarily calmed around Thornfield, but a wild, mournful cry echoed from a distance over woods and water. It was painful to hear, and I quickly ran off again.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Driven by the strong, persistent wind from the south, which had blown hard all day without delivering any rain, I sought refuge in the orchard. As night approached, instead of the wind calming down, it seemed to grow even more intense, making a deeper, more continuous noise. The trees were bent steadily in one direction, barely moving back, held under a constant strain that forced their branches northward. Clouds moved quickly overhead, covering the sky so completely that not a patch of blue was visible all day. Despite my troubles, there was a wild sort of thrill in running with the wind and letting it carry away my worries. Walking down the laurel path, I came face to face with the damaged chestnut tree; it stood upright but was split down the middle, looking grim and ghostly. The two halves remained connected at the base because of their strong roots, even though their shared life had ended—the sap no longer flowed. The heavy limbs on each side were dead and certain to fall in the coming winter’s storms; yet, for now, they still formed one complete, if ruined, tree.

I spoke to them as if they were alive: "You did well to cling to each other," I said. "Though you look scorched and lifeless, there must still be some sense of life coming from your faithful roots. You will never have green leaves again, nor see birds nest or hear their songs in your boughs; your days of happiness and love are over. But you are not alone: each of you has a companion to share in your decline." As I looked up, the moon briefly emerged in the gap between the two halves of the tree, its face red and partly hidden, casting a sorrowful glance my way before vanishing behind thick clouds. For a moment, the wind quieted around Thornfield, but far off in the distance, it made a wild, mournful sound. The sadness of it drove me to run on.

events.title: Restless Waiting and Rochester's Return
detailed_summary: Jane busies herself in the orchard and house, sorting apples and preparing the library for Mr. Rochester's arrival, ensuring a fire is lit.
Despite these preparations, her restlessness grows, and she cannot remain indoors as ten o'clock strikes.
She decides to walk towards the gates, hoping to meet Mr. Rochester and shorten her suspense, observing the moonlight intermittently lighting the road.
The road appears empty and solitary, causing a tear of disappointment and impatience.
As the moon hides and rain begins, she anxiously wishes for his arrival, fearing an accident and recalling the previous night's ominous event.
Determined not to wait passively, she sets out to meet him.
She soon hears hoofbeats and sees Mr. Rochester approaching on horseback with his dog, Pilot.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here and there I strayed through the orchard, gathered up the apples with which the grass round the tree roots was thickly strewn; then I employed myself in dividing the ripe from the unripe; I carried them into the house and put them away in the store-room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I obeyed: joy made me agile: I sprang up before him.

events.text_segment:
Here and there I strayed through the orchard, gathered up the apples with which the grass round the tree roots was thickly strewn; then I employed myself in dividing the ripe from the unripe; I carried them into the house and put them away in the store-room. Then I repaired to the library to ascertain whether the fire was lit, for, though summer, I knew on such a gloomy evening Mr. Rochester would like to see a cheerful hearth when he came in: yes, the fire had been kindled some time, and burnt well. I placed his arm-chair by the chimney-corner: I wheeled the table near it: I let down the curtain, and had the candles brought in ready for lighting. More restless than ever, when I had completed these arrangements I could not sit still, nor even remain in the house: a little time-piece in the room and the old clock in the hall simultaneously struck ten.
“How late it grows!” I said. “I will run down to the gates: it is moonlight at intervals; I can see a good way on the road. He may be coming now, and to meet him will save some minutes of suspense.”
The wind roared high in the great trees which embowered the gates; but the road as far as I could see, to the right hand and the left, was all still and solitary: save for the shadows of clouds crossing it at intervals as the moon looked out, it was but a long pale line, unvaried by one moving speck.
A puerile tear dimmed my eye while I looked—a tear of disappointment and impatience; ashamed of it, I wiped it away. I lingered; the moon shut herself wholly within her chamber, and drew close her curtain of dense cloud: the night grew dark; rain came driving fast on the gale.
“I wish he would come! I wish he would come!” I exclaimed, seized with hypochondriac foreboding. I had expected his arrival before tea; now it was dark: what could keep him? Had an accident happened? The event of last night again recurred to me. I interpreted it as a warning of disaster. I feared my hopes were too bright to be realised; and I had enjoyed so much bliss lately that I imagined my fortune had passed its meridian, and must now decline.
“Well, I cannot return to the house,” I thought; “I cannot sit by the fireside, while he is abroad in inclement weather: better tire my limbs than strain my heart; I will go forward and meet him.”
I set out; I walked fast, but not far: ere I had measured a quarter of a mile, I heard the tramp of hoofs; a horseman came on, full gallop; a dog ran by his side. Away with evil presentiment! It was he: here he was, mounted on Mesrour, followed by Pilot. He saw me; for the moon had opened a blue field in the sky, and rode in it watery bright: he took his hat off, and waved it round his head. I now ran to meet him.
“There!” he exclaimed, as he stretched out his hand and bent from the saddle: “You can’t do without me, that is evident. Step on my boot-toe; give me both hands: mount!”
I obeyed: joy made me agile: I sprang up before him.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I wandered through the orchard, picking up apples that lay thick on the grass around the trees. I sorted the ripe ones from the unripe, took them inside, and stored them away. Next, I went to the library to check if the fire was burning. Although it was summer, I knew on such a gloomy evening Mr. Rochester would appreciate a cheerful fire upon his return. Yes, the fire had been lit some time ago and was burning well. I moved his armchair near the fireplace, pulled the table closer, closed the curtain, and had the candles brought in, ready to be lit. Despite having finished these preparations, I felt more agitated than ever and couldn't stay still or even remain indoors. A small clock in the room and the old hall clock chimed ten simultaneously. "It's getting so late!" I thought. "I'll hurry down to the gates; the moonlight is visible occasionally, and I can see quite a distance along the road. He might be coming now, and meeting him will shorten this time of anticipation." The wind howled loudly through the large trees surrounding the gates, but the road, as far as I could see in both directions, was quiet and empty. Apart from the shadows of clouds passing over it when the moon briefly appeared, it was just a long, pale line with no sign of movement. A childish tear of disappointment and impatience welled up as I watched; feeling ashamed, I wiped it away. I lingered. The moon completely hid herself behind a dense curtain of clouds, and the night grew dark. Rain began to fall heavily, driven by the wind. "Oh, I wish he would come! I wish he would come!" I cried out, seized by anxious predictions. I had expected him before tea; now it was dark. What could be detaining him? Had something happened? The incident from the previous night came back to me, and I saw it as a sign of misfortune. I feared my hopes were too high to be fulfilled and felt that, after so much recent happiness, my good fortune must have peaked and was now destined to decline. "Well, I can't go back inside," I decided. "I can't sit by the fire while he's out in this bad weather. It's better to tire my legs than suffer with anxiety; I will go forward and meet him." I started walking quickly, but not far. Before I had gone a quarter of a mile, I heard the sound of hooves. A horseman approached at a full gallop, with a dog running alongside. Away with negative thoughts! It was him. Here he was, riding Mesrour and followed by Pilot. He saw me, as the moon had revealed a clear, watery-bright patch of sky and shone from it. He took off his hat and waved it above his head. I ran towards him. "There!" he exclaimed, reaching out his hand and leaning down from the saddle. "It's clear you can't manage without me. Step on my boot; give me both hands; get on!" I obeyed; joy made me nimble. I leaped up onto the horse in front of him.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I wandered around the orchard, collecting apples that had fallen thickly around the bases of the trees. After that, I sorted the apples, dividing the ripe ones from those not yet ready, and took them inside to be stored. Next, I went to the library to check if the fire was lit because, although it was summer, it was a gloomy evening and I knew Mr. Rochester would appreciate a warm fireplace when he arrived. The fire was already burning well, so I set up his armchair by the hearth, moved a table close by, lowered the curtain, and had candles brought in to be ready to light. Even after organizing everything, I felt restless and couldn’t settle down inside; soon, both a small clock in the room and the old hall clock struck ten. 

“How late it is getting!” I said to myself. Wanting to ease the wait, I decided to go down to the gates, reasoning that the intermittent moonlight would allow me to watch the road for his arrival, saving myself a few minutes of anxious waiting.

The wind howled through the tall trees by the gates. I looked up and down the road, but it was empty and quiet, only occasionally crossed by shadows from passing clouds as the moon peeked out. Staring at the long, pale stretch of road, I felt a childish tear of disappointment and impatience, which I quickly brushed away in embarrassment. I lingered as the moon disappeared behind thick clouds, the night grew darker, and rain began to lash down. 

“I wish he would come! I wish he would come!” I murmured aloud, feeling overcome by nervous anxiety. I had expected him before evening tea, but now that it was dark, I worried something had happened—perhaps an accident. Memories of the previous night added to my sense of foreboding, and I began to think my recent happiness might not last. 

Resolved not to simply wait by the fireside while he was out in the storm, I decided it was better to keep moving and went out to meet him. I walked quickly but had not gone far before I heard approaching hoofbeats. A horseman appeared at full speed, accompanied by a dog. Instantly, my worries vanished—it was Mr. Rochester, riding Mesrour with Pilot at his side. The moon's light broke through enough for him to see me; he tipped his hat and waved. I ran to him, and he greeted me warmly, offering his hand and telling me to step up so he could help me mount. Gladdened, I eagerly joined him.

events.title: A Damp Reunion and Lingering Unease
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester greets Jane with a kiss and playful boasting, helping her onto his horse.
He expresses concern, noticing her presence at such a late hour and her feverish condition, asking if something is wrong.
Jane explains she couldn't bear waiting in the house due to the weather and her anxiety over his delay.
Rochester notes she is soaked and wraps his cloak around her, again questioning if something is amiss due to her hot hands and cheeks.
Jane reassures him she is no longer afraid or unhappy but admits she had been, promising to explain later, suspecting he will laugh at her concerns.
Rochester vows not to laugh until after the wedding, calling her his uncertain prize, and likens her to a stray lamb returning to the shepherd.
They arrive at Thornfield, and he instructs her to change into dry clothes and rejoin him in the library quickly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A hearty kissing I got for a welcome, and some boastful triumph, which I swallowed as well as I could.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I found him at supper.

events.text_segment:
A hearty kissing I got for a welcome, and some boastful triumph, which I swallowed as well as I could. He checked himself in his exultation to demand, “But is there anything the matter, Janet, that you come to meet me at such an hour? Is there anything wrong?”
“No, but I thought you would never come. I could not bear to wait in the house for you, especially with this rain and wind.”
“Rain and wind, indeed! Yes, you are dripping like a mermaid; pull my cloak round you: but I think you are feverish, Jane: both your cheek and hand are burning hot. I ask again, is there anything the matter?”
“Nothing now; I am neither afraid nor unhappy.”
“Then you have been both?”
“Rather: but I’ll tell you all about it by-and-by, sir; and I daresay you will only laugh at me for my pains.”
“I’ll laugh at you heartily when to-morrow is past; till then I dare not: my prize is not certain. This is you, who have been as slippery as an eel this last month, and as thorny as a briar-rose? I could not lay a finger anywhere but I was pricked; and now I seem to have gathered up a stray lamb in my arms. You wandered out of the fold to seek your shepherd, did you, Jane?”
“I wanted you: but don’t boast. Here we are at Thornfield: now let me get down.”
He landed me on the pavement. As John took his horse, and he followed me into the hall, he told me to make haste and put something dry on, and then return to him in the library; and he stopped me, as I made for the staircase, to extort a promise that I would not be long: nor was I long; in five minutes I rejoined him. I found him at supper.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: He welcomed me with a warm hug and kiss, along with some self-satisfied boasting, which I tolerated as best I could. Stopping his cheerful display, he asked, "But is something wrong, Janet, that you're out meeting me at this hour? Is there a problem?" I replied, "No, but I felt like you would never arrive. I couldn't bear to wait inside the house for you, especially with this rain and wind." "Rain and wind, indeed! Yes, you're soaking wet like a water spirit; wrap my cloak around you: but I think you have a fever, Jane: your cheek and hand are both burning hot. I ask again, is there anything troubling you?" "Nothing now; I am neither afraid nor sad." "Then you were both?" "A little: but I'll tell you all about it eventually, sir; and I expect you'll just find my difficulties amusing." "I'll laugh wholeheartedly at you after tomorrow is over; until then I dare not: my success isn't assured. This is you, who has been as hard to catch as an eel this last month, and as sharp as a wild rose bush? I couldn't get near you without being hurt; and now it seems I've found a lost young sheep in my arms. You strayed from the group to find your protector, didn't you, Jane?" "I wanted you: but don't brag. We've arrived at Thornfield now: let me get off." He helped me down onto the walkway. While John took his horse, and he followed me into the entrance hall, he told me to hurry and put on dry clothes, and then come back to him in the library; and he stopped me as I moved towards the stairs to get a promise that I wouldn't take long: and I wasn't long; I returned to him in five minutes. I discovered him eating his evening meal.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I was warmly welcomed with a kiss and some proud words, which I accepted as best I could. He paused in his happiness to ask, “But is there something wrong, Janet, that you come out to meet me so late? Is something amiss?”
“No, but I was afraid you’d never arrive. I couldn't stand waiting inside for you, especially with this storm.”
“Yes, the weather! You’re soaked through; here, let me wrap my cloak around you. But you feel rather warm, Jane—your face and hand are burning. Are you sure nothing’s wrong?”
“Nothing now; I don’t feel scared or upset anymore.”
“So, you were both?”
“A little. I’ll explain everything soon, sir, though I’m sure you’ll laugh at me.”
“I’ll laugh plenty once tomorrow is over; until then, I can’t risk it. My prize isn’t secure yet. You’ve been so elusive and prickly this past month—it was impossible to touch you without being stung. Yet now, it’s as if I’ve picked up a lost lamb. Did you wander away to find your shepherd, Jane?”
“I wanted you; but don’t brag. We're at Thornfield now, so let me get out.”
He set me down on the pavement. As John took his horse, he followed me inside and told me to hurry and change into dry clothes, then come to him in the library. Just as I started up the stairs, he made me promise not to take too long; and I kept my word, returning to him in five minutes, where I found him having supper.

events.title: An Unreal Evening and Unspoken Fears
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester remarks it is nearly their last meal at Thornfield for a long time.
Jane sits with him but cannot eat, stating her prospects are unclear and her thoughts are muddled, feeling everything in life is unreal.
Rochester playfully asserts his own substantiality, offering his hand for her to touch.
Jane dismisses even him as dream-like, though she acknowledges the physical reality of his hand.
After supper, Jane stirs the fire and sits at Rochester's knee, noting it is near midnight.
Rochester reminds her of her promise to stay awake with him the night before the wedding, which she affirms.
He confirms his own preparations are complete and they will leave Thornfield soon after the ceremony.
He observes Jane's strange smile, flushed cheeks, and glittering eyes, questioning her well-being.
Jane claims she believes she is well but cannot articulate her feelings, wishing the present moment would last forever due to apprehension about the future.
Rochester attributes her state to over-excitement or fatigue, admitting he himself is not calm but is deeply happy.
He urges her to confide her fears, asking if she doubts his worthiness as a husband or fears her new life, which she denies.
He is perplexed by her sorrowful audacity and demands an explanation as midnight strikes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Take a seat and bear me company, Jane: please God, it is the last meal but one you will eat at Thornfield Hall for a long time.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “No, sir.” It struck twelve—I waited till the time-piece had concluded its silver chime, and the clock its hoarse, vibrating stroke, and then I proceeded.

events.text_segment:
“Take a seat and bear me company, Jane: please God, it is the last meal but one you will eat at Thornfield Hall for a long time.”
I sat down near him, but told him I could not eat.
“Is it because you have the prospect of a journey before you, Jane? Is it the thoughts of going to London that takes away your appetite?”
“I cannot see my prospects clearly to-night, sir; and I hardly know what thoughts I have in my head. Everything in life seems unreal.”
“Except me: I am substantial enough—touch me.”
“You, sir, are the most phantom-like of all: you are a mere dream.”
He held out his hand, laughing. “Is that a dream?” said he, placing it close to my eyes. He had a rounded, muscular, and vigorous hand, as well as a long, strong arm.
“Yes; though I touch it, it is a dream,” said I, as I put it down from before my face. “Sir, have you finished supper?”
“Yes, Jane.”
I rang the bell and ordered away the tray. When we were again alone, I stirred the fire, and then took a low seat at my master’s knee.
“It is near midnight,” I said.
“Yes: but remember, Jane, you promised to wake with me the night before my wedding.”
“I did; and I will keep my promise, for an hour or two at least: I have no wish to go to bed.”
“Are all your arrangements complete?”
“All, sir.”
“And on my part likewise,” he returned, “I have settled everything; and we shall leave Thornfield to-morrow, within half-an-hour after our return from church.”
“Very well, sir.”
“With what an extraordinary smile you uttered that word—‘very well,’ Jane! What a bright spot of colour you have on each cheek! and how strangely your eyes glitter! Are you well?”
“I believe I am.”
“Believe! What is the matter? Tell me what you feel.”
“I could not, sir: no words could tell you what I feel. I wish this present hour would never end: who knows with what fate the next may come charged?”
“This is hypochondria, Jane. You have been over-excited, or over-fatigued.”
“Do you, sir, feel calm and happy?”
“Calm?—no: but happy—to the heart’s core.”
I looked up at him to read the signs of bliss in his face: it was ardent and flushed.
“Give me your confidence, Jane,” he said: “relieve your mind of any weight that oppresses it, by imparting it to me. What do you fear?—that I shall not prove a good husband?”
“It is the idea farthest from my thoughts.”
“Are you apprehensive of the new sphere you are about to enter?—of the new life into which you are passing?”
“No.”
“You puzzle me, Jane: your look and tone of sorrowful audacity perplex and pain me. I want an explanation.”
“Then, sir, listen. You were from home last night?”
“I was: I know that; and you hinted a while ago at something which had happened in my absence:—nothing, probably, of consequence; but, in short, it has disturbed you. Let me hear it. Mrs. Fairfax has said something, perhaps? or you have overheard the servants talk?—your sensitive self-respect has been wounded?”
“No, sir.” It struck twelve—I waited till the time-piece had concluded its silver chime, and the clock its hoarse, vibrating stroke, and then I proceeded.

I sat down near him but explained I wasn’t able to eat.
“Is it because you have a journey ahead of you, Jane?” he asked. “Are you losing your appetite because you’re thinking about going to London?”
“Sir, I can’t clearly see what lies ahead tonight,” I replied. “And I barely know what’s going through my mind. Everything in life feels unreal.”
“Except me,” he said. “I am real enough—touch me.”
“You, sir, are the most like a ghost of all,” I countered. “You are just a dream.”
He held out his hand and laughed. “Is this a dream?” he asked, putting it close to my eyes. His hand was rounded, strong, and muscular, just like his long, powerful arm.
“Yes, even though I am touching it, it feels like a dream,” I said, moving it away from my face. “Sir, have you finished your meal?”
“Yes, Jane.”
I rang the bell to have the tray removed. Once we were alone again, I stirred the fire and then sat on a low stool near my master’s knees.
“It’s almost midnight,” I said.
“Yes, but remember, Jane,” he replied, “you promised to stay awake with me the night before my wedding.”
“I did, and I will keep that promise, for at least an hour or two. I don’t want to go to bed.”
“Are all your preparations finished?” he asked.
“All of them, sir.”
“And mine are too,” he responded. “I’ve arranged everything. We will leave Thornfield tomorrow, just half an hour after we get back from church.”
“Very well, sir,” I said.
He exclaimed, “What an unusual smile you had when you said ‘very well,’ Jane! There’s such a bright blush on each cheek! And your eyes are glittering so strangely! Are you feeling well?”
“I believe so.”
“Believe!” he repeated. “What’s wrong? Tell me how you feel.”
“Sir, I couldn’t. No words could express what I feel. I wish this moment could last forever. Who knows what fate the next hour might bring?”
“This is just nerves, Jane,” he said. “You’ve been overly stimulated or overworked.”
“Sir, do you feel calm and content?” I asked.
“Calm?—no,” he admitted. “But happy—deeply happy.”
I looked up at him, searching his face for signs of his great happiness. It was intensely flushed and passionate.
“Trust me, Jane,” he urged. “Relieve the weight on your mind by sharing it with me. What are you afraid of?—that I won’t be a good husband?”
“That thought is the furthest from my mind,” I replied.
“Are you worried about the new environment you’re about to enter?” he pressed. “About the new life you’re moving into?”
“No.”
“You’re confusing me, Jane,” he said. “Your look and tone, a mix of sadness and boldness, puzzle and distress me. I need an explanation.”
“Then, sir, please listen,” I began. “Were you away from home last night?”
“I was,” he confirmed. “I know that, and you hinted earlier about something that happened while I was gone—probably nothing major, but it has upset you. Tell me about it. Did Mrs. Fairfax say something, perhaps? Or did you overhear the servants talking? Was your sensitive self-respect hurt?”
“No, sir,” I answered. The clock struck twelve. I waited until the silver chimes of the timepiece and the deep, resonant strike of the clock had finished before I continued.

events.title: Jane's First Troubling Dream: Separation and Helplessness
detailed_summary: Jane begins her account by affirming her love for Rochester and her happiness about their future together, dismissing any fears about her new life.
She recounts her contentment the previous day, her trust in Providence, and her pleasant thoughts of Rochester.
She describes going inside as the weather turned, being called by Sophie to see her wedding dress and the veil Rochester had sent.
She reflects on teasing Rochester about his aristocratic tastes and her own humble origins.
She explains how the evening grew darker and the wind rose with an eerie sound, making her wish Rochester were home.
She describes her inability to sleep due to anxious excitement and a mournful sound she eventually identified as a distant dog howling.
She then narrates her first dream: she was on an unknown, dark road in the rain, burdened with a small, wailing child.
In the dream, she believed Rochester was far ahead and strained to catch up and call out to him, but her movements were restricted and her voice failed, while he seemed to retreat further.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “All day yesterday I was very busy, and very happy in my ceaseless bustle; for I am not, as you seem to think, troubled by any haunting fears about the new sphere, et cetera: I think it a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, because I love you.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: while you, I felt, withdrew farther and farther every moment.”

events.text_segment:
“All day yesterday I was very busy, and very happy in my ceaseless bustle; for I am not, as you seem to think, troubled by any haunting fears about the new sphere, et cetera: I think it a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, because I love you. No, sir, don’t caress me now—let me talk undisturbed. Yesterday I trusted well in Providence, and believed that events were working together for your good and mine: it was a fine day, if you recollect—the calmness of the air and sky forbade apprehensions respecting your safety or comfort on your journey. I walked a little while on the pavement after tea, thinking of you; and I beheld you in imagination so near me, I scarcely missed your actual presence. I thought of the life that lay before me—your life, sir—an existence more expansive and stirring than my own: as much more so as the depths of the sea to which the brook runs are than the shallows of its own strait channel. I wondered why moralists call this world a dreary wilderness: for me it blossomed like a rose. Just at sunset, the air turned cold and the sky cloudy: I went in, Sophie called me upstairs to look at my wedding-dress, which they had just brought; and under it in the box I found your present—the veil which, in your princely extravagance, you sent for from London: resolved, I suppose, since I would not have jewels, to cheat me into accepting something as costly. I smiled as I unfolded it, and devised how I would tease you about your aristocratic tastes, and your efforts to masque your plebeian bride in the attributes of a peeress. I thought how I would carry down to you the square of unembroidered blond I had myself prepared as a covering for my low-born head, and ask if that was not good enough for a woman who could bring her husband neither fortune, beauty, nor connections. I saw plainly how you would look; and heard your impetuous republican answers, and your haughty disavowal of any necessity on your part to augment your wealth, or elevate your standing, by marrying either a purse or a coronet.”
“How well you read me, you witch!” interposed Mr. Rochester: “but what did you find in the veil besides its embroidery? Did you find poison, or a dagger, that you look so mournful now?”
“No, no, sir; besides the delicacy and richness of the fabric, I found nothing save Fairfax Rochester’s pride; and that did not scare me, because I am used to the sight of the demon. But, sir, as it grew dark, the wind rose: it blew yesterday evening, not as it blows now—wild and high—but ‘with a sullen, moaning sound’ far more eerie. I wished you were at home. I came into this room, and the sight of the empty chair and fireless hearth chilled me. For some time after I went to bed, I could not sleep—a sense of anxious excitement distressed me. The gale still rising seemed to my ear to muffle a mournful under-sound; whether in the house or abroad I could not at first tell, but it recurred, doubtful yet doleful at every lull; at last I made out it must be some dog howling at a distance. I was glad when it ceased. On sleeping, I continued in dreams the idea of a dark and gusty night. I continued also the wish to be with you, and experienced a strange, regretful consciousness of some barrier dividing us. During all my first sleep, I was following the windings of an unknown road; total obscurity environed me; rain pelted me; I was burdened with the charge of a little child: a very small creature, too young and feeble to walk, and which shivered in my cold arms, and wailed piteously in my ear. I thought, sir, that you were on the road a long way before me; and I strained every nerve to overtake you, and made effort on effort to utter your name and entreat you to stop—but my movements were fettered, and my voice still died away inarticulate; while you, I felt, withdrew farther and farther every moment.”

I also continued to wish I was with you and felt a strange, sorrowful awareness of some obstacle separating us. Throughout my first sleep, I was following a winding, unfamiliar road. Complete darkness surrounded me, rain beat down on me, and I was burdened with the care of a small child—a very tiny creature, too young and weak to walk, shivering in my cold arms and crying pitifully in my ear. I thought, sir, that you were far ahead on the road, and I strained every muscle to catch up to you, trying repeatedly to call your name and beg you to stop. But my movements were restricted, and my voice kept fading away, unable to form words, while I felt you were moving farther and farther away with every moment.”

events.title: Rochester's Dismissal and Jane's Second Dream: Ruin and Loss
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester dismisses Jane's dream as a product of nerves, urging her to focus on real happiness and reaffirm her love for him.
He admits her earnest declaration of love penetrated him painfully, feeling it was too sublime and spiritual.
He asks her to be provocative and teasing rather than deeply moving, preferring anger to sadness.
Jane insists on finishing her story before engaging in teasing.
Mr. Rochester expresses surprise that there is more, showing apprehensive impatience, but tells her to continue, warning her of his skepticism.
Jane recounts her second dream: Thornfield Hall was a desolate ruin.
In this dream, she still carried the unknown child, unable to set it down, and wandered through the ruined grounds.
She heard Rochester's horse, realizing he was departing for a distant country for many years.
She frantically climbed a fragile wall to see him one last time, the child clinging to her.
From the summit, she saw him as a diminishing speck; the wall then crumbled, and she fell, losing the child, and woke up.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And these dreams weigh on your spirits now, Jane, when I am close to you?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I lost my balance, fell, and woke.”

events.text_segment:
“And these dreams weigh on your spirits now, Jane, when I am close to you? Little nervous subject! Forget visionary woe, and think only of real happiness! You say you love me, Janet: yes—I will not forget that; and you cannot deny it. Those words did not die inarticulate on your lips. I heard them clear and soft: a thought too solemn perhaps, but sweet as music—‘I think it is a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, Edward, because I love you.’ Do you love me, Jane?—repeat it.”
“I do, sir—I do, with my whole heart.”
“Well,” he said, after some minutes’ silence, “it is strange; but that sentence has penetrated my breast painfully. Why? I think because you said it with such an earnest, religious energy, and because your upward gaze at me now is the very sublime of faith, truth, and devotion: it is too much as if some spirit were near me. Look wicked, Jane: as you know well how to look: coin one of your wild, shy, provoking smiles; tell me you hate me—tease me, vex me; do anything but move me: I would rather be incensed than saddened.”
“I will tease you and vex you to your heart’s content, when I have finished my tale: but hear me to the end.”
“I thought, Jane, you had told me all. I thought I had found the source of your melancholy in a dream.”
I shook my head. “What! is there more? But I will not believe it to be anything important. I warn you of incredulity beforehand. Go on.”
The disquietude of his air, the somewhat apprehensive impatience of his manner, surprised me: but I proceeded.
“I dreamt another dream, sir: that Thornfield Hall was a dreary ruin, the retreat of bats and owls. I thought that of all the stately front nothing remained but a shell-like wall, very high and very fragile-looking. I wandered, on a moonlight night, through the grass-grown enclosure within: here I stumbled over a marble hearth, and there over a fallen fragment of cornice. Wrapped up in a shawl, I still carried the unknown little child: I might not lay it down anywhere, however tired were my arms—however much its weight impeded my progress, I must retain it. I heard the gallop of a horse at a distance on the road; I was sure it was you; and you were departing for many years and for a distant country. I climbed the thin wall with frantic perilous haste, eager to catch one glimpse of you from the top: the stones rolled from under my feet, the ivy branches I grasped gave way, the child clung round my neck in terror, and almost strangled me; at last I gained the summit. I saw you like a speck on a white track, lessening every moment. The blast blew so strong I could not stand. I sat down on the narrow ledge; I hushed the scared infant in my lap: you turned an angle of the road: I bent forward to take a last look; the wall crumbled; I was shaken; the child rolled from my knee, I lost my balance, fell, and woke.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: "So these dreams are affecting your mood even now that I am with you, Jane? My little sensitive friend! Forget these imaginary troubles and focus on true happiness! You told me you love me, Janet; yes, I won't forget that, and you can't deny it. Those words came out clearly. I heard them distinct and gentle: perhaps a bit serious, but lovely as music – 'I think it is a wonderful thing to hope to live with you, Edward, because I love you.' Do you still love me, Jane? Say it again." "I do, sir – I do, with all my heart." "Well," he said after a moment of quiet, "it's strange, but that phrase has touched me deeply and painfully. Why? I think it's because you spoke it with such sincere, heartfelt conviction, and because the way you look up at me now embodies the highest level of faith, truth, and dedication; it's almost like a spirit is near me. Look mischievous, Jane, as you know how to do so well: show me one of your spirited, shy, teasing smiles; tell me you dislike me – bother me, irritate me; do anything but make me feel emotional. I'd rather be angered than saddened." "I will tease and bother you to your heart's content once I've finished my story, but please listen to the rest." "Jane, I believed you had told me everything. I thought I had found the reason for your sadness in a dream." I shook my head. "What! There's more? But I refuse to believe it's anything important. I'm telling you now I'm skeptical. Go on." His troubled expression and somewhat anxious impatience surprised me, but I proceeded. "Sir, I dreamt another dream: that Thornfield Hall was a desolate ruin, a home for bats and owls. I imagined that of the entire grand facade, only a thin, very tall, fragile-looking wall remained. On a moonlit night, I walked through the grass-covered area inside: I tripped over a marble fireplace here, and a fallen piece of molding there. Still wrapped in a shawl, I carried the unknown little child from before; I could not set it down anywhere, no matter how weary my arms were or how much its weight slowed my progress, I had to hold it. I heard the sound of a horse galloping in the distance on the road; I was certain it was you, leaving for many years and a distant place. I climbed the thin wall in a desperate, dangerous rush, eager to catch a final sight of you from the top. The stones tumbled from beneath my feet, the ivy branches I gripped snapped, the child clung terrified around my neck, almost strangling me; finally, I reached the peak. I saw you as a tiny dot on a white path, shrinking every moment. The wind blew so strongly I could not stand. I sat down on the narrow edge; I comforted the frightened infant in my lap. You turned a corner on the road; I leaned forward for one last look; the wall crumbled; I was shaken; the child rolled from my lap, I lost my balance, fell, and woke up."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"And these dreams still trouble your mind, Jane, even though I am by your side? My sensitive little thing! Let go of these fanciful sorrows and focus on real happiness. You say you love me, Janet—and I won't forget that; you can't take it back. Those words were spoken clearly, not left unsaid. I heard them, solemn but lovely: ‘I think it’s a wonderful thing to hope for a life with you, Edward, because I love you.’ Do you love me, Jane? Say it again."

"I do, sir—I do, with all my heart."

After a pause, he continued, "It’s odd, but that declaration has struck me deeply and almost caused me pain. Why? I think it’s because you said it with such sincerity and devotion, and your look is so full of faith and truth that it feels almost otherworldly. Jane, look mischievous as you sometimes do; give me one of your sly, teasing smiles, say you hate me—anything to stir me up; I’d rather be annoyed than made sad."

"I’ll tease and vex you as much as you want, once I’ve finished my story—please just listen until I’m done."

"I thought you’d already told me everything, Jane. I thought your sadness came from a dream."

I shook my head. "There’s more. But don’t worry—it’s probably nothing important. I warn you, you might not believe it. Go on."

His slightly uneasy manner surprised me, but I continued. "I had another dream: I saw Thornfield Hall in ruins, abandoned to bats and owls. Nearly all the grand facade was gone except a high, fragile wall. I wandered in the overgrown grounds that night, tripping over rubble here and there. I was wrapped in a shawl, still holding the same unknown child, and though my arms ached and it slowed me, I couldn’t put the child down. I heard a distant horse, certain it was you, riding away for years to some far country. In my desperation, I scaled the crumbling wall, struggling to glimpse you; stones and ivy fell away beneath me, the frightened child clung to my neck, nearly choking me. At last, I reached the top and saw you as a fading dot on the road. The wind was so strong I had to sit, cradling the frightened child. You turned a corner and vanished; as I leaned forward for a final look, the wall collapsed, I slipped, lost the child from my knee, and fell—then I woke up."

events.title: The Terrifying Nocturnal Visitor
detailed_summary: Jane clarifies that her dreams were merely a prelude to the main event.
She describes waking from her second dream to a gleam of light, initially thinking it was daylight, but realizing it was candlelight.
She noticed the closet door, where her wedding dress and veil were hung, was open, and heard a rustling sound.
Calling out to Sophie and receiving no answer, she saw a figure emerge from the closet, take the light, and examine her wedding garments.
Overcome by surprise, then bewilderment, and finally a chilling fear, Jane realized the figure was not Sophie, Leah, Mrs. Fairfax, or even Grace Poole.
She describes the figure as a tall, large woman with long, thick, dark hair, wearing a white, straight garment of unknown type.
Initially unable to see the face, Jane watched as the woman took the veil, gazed at it, then draped it over her own head and turned to the mirror.
In the mirror's reflection, Jane saw a "fearful and ghastly," "discoloured," and "savage" face with red eyes and blackened, inflated features, reminiscent of a "Vampyre."
The woman then removed the veil, tore it in two, threw it on the floor, and trampled it.
After looking out the window, the figure approached Jane's bedside, thrust the candle close to her face, extinguished it, and Jane lost consciousness from terror.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now, Jane, that is all.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I became insensible from terror.”

events.text_segment:
“Now, Jane, that is all.”
“All the preface, sir; the tale is yet to come. On waking, a gleam dazzled my eyes; I thought—Oh, it is daylight! But I was mistaken; it was only candlelight. Sophie, I supposed, had come in. There was a light in the dressing-table, and the door of the closet, where, before going to bed, I had hung my wedding-dress and veil, stood open; I heard a rustling there. I asked, ‘Sophie, what are you doing?’ No one answered; but a form emerged from the closet; it took the light, held it aloft, and surveyed the garments pendent from the portmanteau. ‘Sophie! Sophie!’ I again cried: and still it was silent. I had risen up in bed, I bent forward: first surprise, then bewilderment, came over me; and then my blood crept cold through my veins. Mr. Rochester, this was not Sophie, it was not Leah, it was not Mrs. Fairfax: it was not—no, I was sure of it, and am still—it was not even that strange woman, Grace Poole.”
“It must have been one of them,” interrupted my master.
“No, sir, I solemnly assure you to the contrary. The shape standing before me had never crossed my eyes within the precincts of Thornfield Hall before; the height, the contour were new to me.”
“Describe it, Jane.”
“It seemed, sir, a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back. I know not what dress she had on: it was white and straight; but whether gown, sheet, or shroud, I cannot tell.”
“Did you see her face?”
“Not at first. But presently she took my veil from its place; she held it up, gazed at it long, and then she threw it over her own head, and turned to the mirror. At that moment I saw the reflection of the visage and features quite distinctly in the dark oblong glass.”
“And how were they?”
“Fearful and ghastly to me—oh, sir, I never saw a face like it! It was a discoloured face—it was a savage face. I wish I could forget the roll of the red eyes and the fearful blackened inflation of the lineaments!”
“Ghosts are usually pale, Jane.”
“This, sir, was purple: the lips were swelled and dark; the brow furrowed: the black eyebrows widely raised over the bloodshot eyes. Shall I tell you of what it reminded me?”
“You may.”
“Of the foul German spectre—the Vampyre.”
“Ah!—what did it do?”
“Sir, it removed my veil from its gaunt head, rent it in two parts, and flinging both on the floor, trampled on them.”
“Afterwards?”
“It drew aside the window-curtain and looked out; perhaps it saw dawn approaching, for, taking the candle, it retreated to the door. Just at my bedside, the figure stopped: the fiery eyes glared upon me—she thrust up her candle close to my face, and extinguished it under my eyes. I was aware her lurid visage flamed over mine, and I lost consciousness: for the second time in my life—only the second time—I became insensible from terror.”

When I woke up, a brightness caught my eye, and I initially thought it was sunrise. However, it turned out to be just candlelight. I assumed it was Sophie entering the room. A light was on the dressing table, and the door to the wardrobe where I’d hung my wedding dress and veil before bed was open. I heard a rustling sound from inside. I called out, ‘Sophie, what are you doing?’ There was no answer. Then a figure emerged from the wardrobe. It picked up the candle, held it high, and examined my clothing hanging on the luggage stand. ‘Sophie! Sophie!’ I called again, but it remained silent. I had sat up in bed and leaned forward. First, I felt surprise, then confusion, and finally, my blood ran cold. Mr. Rochester, it was not Sophie, nor Leah, nor Mrs. Fairfax. It was not—I am certain, and remain so—not even that peculiar woman, Grace Poole.” “It must have been one of them,” my master interrupted. “No, sir, I assure you solemnly that it was not. The figure standing there was someone I had never seen within the grounds of Thornfield Hall before; its height and build were completely unfamiliar to me.” “Describe her, Jane.” “She appeared to be a woman, sir, tall and large, with thick, dark hair that hung long down her back. I couldn’t tell what she was wearing; it was white and plain, but whether it was a gown, a sheet, or a burial shroud, I cannot say.” “Did you see her face?” “Not at first. But then she took my veil down, held it up, stared at it for a while, and then put it over her own head and turned towards the mirror. At that moment, I saw the reflection of her face and features quite clearly in the dark, oblong glass.” “And what did they look like?” “Terrifying and repulsive to me—oh, sir, I have never seen such a face! It was discolored and savage. I wish I could forget the movement of her red eyes and the horrifying, dark swelling of her features!” “Ghosts are usually pale, Jane.” “This one, sir, was purple. Her lips were swollen and dark, her brow was furrowed, and her black eyebrows were raised high over bloodshot eyes. May I tell you what she reminded me of?” “You may.” “The dreadful German spirit—the Vampyre.” “Ah! And what did she do next?” “Sir, she removed my veil from her thin head, ripped it in two, threw both pieces on the floor, and stamped on them.” “After that?” “She pulled back the window curtain and looked out, perhaps seeing the approach of dawn, because she then took the candle and went towards the door. The figure stopped right beside my bed. Her fiery eyes glared at me—she thrust her candle close to my face and put it out right before my eyes. I felt her ghastly face flaming over mine, and I lost consciousness. It was the second time in my life—only the second time—that terror made me faint.”

There was light on the dressing table, and the closet door—where I had hung my wedding gown and veil before bedtime—was open. I heard something moving inside. Mr. Rochester, I know it was not Sophie, nor Leah, nor Mrs. Fairfax; and I am sure it was not even Grace Poole, that strange woman." 

Mr. Rochester interrupted, insisting, "It must have been one of them." Jane answered solemnly, "No, sir, I assure you it was not. This person was someone I had never seen at Thornfield Hall—their height and shape were unfamiliar to me."

I couldn’t say exactly what she wore—it was white and straight, maybe a gown, maybe a sheet or a shroud, I wasn’t sure." Mr. Rochester asked if she had seen the woman’s face. I wish I could forget the rolling red eyes and the horribly swollen black features!" Would you like to know what she reminded me of?" Mr. Rochester said yes. Jane said, "Of the horrible German ghost—a Vampire." Mr. Rochester asked what the apparition did. Jane replied, "She removed my veil from her head, tore it in half, threw the pieces down, and trampled on them."

I saw her terrible face hovering over mine—and then I fainted. For only the second time in my life, I lost consciousness from fear."

events.title: Rochester's Explanation and Jane's Reluctant Acquiescence
detailed_summary: Jane recounts waking alone in daylight, feeling enfeebled but not ill, and resolving to tell only Rochester about the visitation. She asks him who the woman was.
Rochester dismisses the apparition as a product of Jane's "over-stimulated brain."
Jane insists her nerves were not at fault and the event was real.
Rochester challenges this by questioning the reality of her dreams – if Thornfield is a ruin, or if he is leaving her.
Jane counters that the day meant to unite them has begun, but she wishes she could believe the terrors were only mental, especially since he cannot explain the visitor.
When Rochester suggests its unreality because he can't explain it, Jane reveals the crucial evidence: upon waking, she found the wedding veil on the carpet, torn in two.
Mr. Rochester visibly starts and shudders, embracing Jane tightly and expressing relief that only the veil was harmed.
He then offers an explanation: a woman, likely Grace Poole, did enter her room. He suggests Jane's feverish, half-awake state caused her to perceive Grace Poole with distorted, goblin-like features.
He claims the tearing of the veil was real and characteristic of Grace Poole, promising to explain why he keeps such a woman in his house a year and a day after their marriage.
He asks if Jane accepts his solution. Jane reflects that it seems the only possible explanation; though not fully satisfied, she endeavors to appear so to please him and does feel somewhat relieved.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Who was with you when you revived?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And now, as it was long past one, I prepared to leave him.

events.text_segment:
“Who was with you when you revived?”
“No one, sir, but the broad day. I rose, bathed my head and face in water, drank a long draught; felt that though enfeebled I was not ill, and determined that to none but you would I impart this vision. Now, sir, tell me who and what that woman was?”
“The creature of an over-stimulated brain; that is certain. I must be careful of you, my treasure: nerves like yours were not made for rough handling.”
“Sir, depend on it, my nerves were not in fault; the thing was real: the transaction actually took place.”
“And your previous dreams, were they real too? Is Thornfield Hall a ruin? Am I severed from you by insuperable obstacles? Am I leaving you without a tear—without a kiss—without a word?”
“Not yet.”
“Am I about to do it? Why, the day is already commenced which is to bind us indissolubly; and when we are once united, there shall be no recurrence of these mental terrors: I guarantee that.”
“Mental terrors, sir! I wish I could believe them to be only such: I wish it more now than ever; since even you cannot explain to me the mystery of that awful visitant.”
“And since I cannot do it, Jane, it must have been unreal.”
“But, sir, when I said so to myself on rising this morning, and when I looked round the room to gather courage and comfort from the cheerful aspect of each familiar object in full daylight, there—on the carpet—I saw what gave the distinct lie to my hypothesis,—the veil, torn from top to bottom in two halves!”
I felt Mr. Rochester start and shudder; he hastily flung his arms round me. “Thank God!” he exclaimed, “that if anything malignant did come near you last night, it was only the veil that was harmed. Oh, to think what might have happened!”
He drew his breath short, and strained me so close to him, I could scarcely pant. After some minutes’ silence, he continued, cheerily—
“Now, Janet, I’ll explain to you all about it. It was half dream, half reality. A woman did, I doubt not, enter your room: and that woman was—must have been—Grace Poole. You call her a strange being yourself: from all you know, you have reason so to call her—what did she do to me? what to Mason? In a state between sleeping and waking, you noticed her entrance and her actions; but feverish, almost delirious as you were, you ascribed to her a goblin appearance different from her own: the long dishevelled hair, the swelled black face, the exaggerated stature, were figments of imagination; results of nightmare: the spiteful tearing of the veil was real: and it is like her. I see you would ask why I keep such a woman in my house: when we have been married a year and a day, I will tell you; but not now. Are you satisfied, Jane? Do you accept my solution of the mystery?”
I reflected, and in truth it appeared to me the only possible one: satisfied I was not, but to please him I endeavoured to appear so—relieved, I certainly did feel; so I answered him with a contented smile. And now, as it was long past one, I prepared to leave him.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. Rochester asked, "Who was present when you regained consciousness?" Jane replied, "Just the daylight, sir. I got up, washed my face and head, and drank deeply. I felt weak but not ill. I decided I would only share this vision with you. Now, sir, please tell me who that woman was and what she is." Rochester dismissed it, saying, "It was definitely the product of an overactive mind. I need to take care of you, my dear; your delicate nerves aren't suited for such shock." Jane insisted, "Sir, my nerves were fine; the event was real; it actually happened." Rochester countered, "And were your earlier dreams real too? Is Thornfield Hall in ruins? Are we separated by impossible barriers? Am I leaving you without tears, a kiss, or a word?" Jane responded, "Not yet." Rochester pressed, "Am I about to leave? Why, today is the day we are to be permanently united. Once married, these frightening mental experiences will stop, I promise." Jane protested, "'Mental terrors,' sir! I wish I could believe that's all they were. I wish it even more now, since you can't explain the mystery of that terrifying visitor." Rochester concluded, "And since I cannot explain it, Jane, it must not have been real." Jane argued, "But, sir, when I told myself that this morning after waking, and when I looked around the room in bright daylight for reassurance from the familiar surroundings, there – on the floor – I saw something that utterly contradicted my assumption: the veil, completely ripped in two!" Mr. Rochester flinched and shivered. He quickly wrapped his arms around her, exclaiming, "Thank God that if something harmful came near you last night, only the veil was damaged. Oh, the thought of what could have happened!" He gasped for breath and held her so tightly she could barely breathe. After a few moments of silence, he spoke again cheerfully, "Now, Janet, I'll explain everything. It was part dream, part reality. A woman did indeed enter your room, I'm sure, and that woman was – it must have been – Grace Poole. You yourself describe her as strange; based on what you know, you have reason to think so. What did she do to me? What did she do to Mason? In a state between sleep and wakefulness, you noticed her entering and acting, but being feverish, almost delirious, you imagined her as a monstrous figure unlike herself. The messy, long hair, the swollen black face, the exaggerated height were products of your imagination, the result of a nightmare. The malicious act of tearing the veil was real, though, and it's typical of her. I know you want to ask why I keep such a woman here. After we've been married a year and a day, I will tell you, but not now. Are you satisfied, Jane? Do you accept my explanation for the mystery?" Jane pondered, and it honestly seemed like the only plausible explanation. She wasn't truly satisfied, but she tried to appear so to please him. She did feel relieved, though, so she replied with a content smile. Then, as it was well past one o'clock, she prepared to leave him.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Who was with you when you came to?" 
"Nobody, sir, just the daylight. I got up, washed my head and face, drank a lot of water, and realized that although I was weak, I wasn't sick. I resolved that you alone should hear about what I saw. Now, sir, can you tell me who and what that woman was?"
"She was a product of an overstimulated mind, surely. I must be careful with you, my dear, your nerves aren’t suited for harsh treatment."
"Sir, please believe me, my nerves are not to blame; it really happened. It was real."
"And your earlier dreams—were those real as well? Is Thornfield Hall destroyed? Are we separated by impossible barriers, with me leaving you without sorrow, without a kiss, without a word?"
"Not yet."
"Am I about to? Today is the day we’ll be joined forever and when we’re married, these fears will vanish—this I promise."
"Fears of the mind, sir! I hope that was all it was; I hope it now more than ever, since you can’t explain that terrifying visitor."
"And since I can’t, Jane, it mustn’t have been real."
"But, sir, when I told myself that this morning and looked around to calm myself, I saw on the carpet evidence proving otherwise—the veil, ripped in two from top to bottom!"
Mr. Rochester started and trembled; he quickly hugged me. "Thank God! If any evil did come near you last night, it was only the veil injured. Who knows what could have happened!"
He breathed shakily and held me tightly. After some silence, he spoke more cheerfully—
"Now, Janet, let me explain. It was partly dream, partly real. Someone did come into your room: it was Grace Poole, I'm sure. She’s odd, and you know she’s capable of strange things—remember what she did to me, to Mason? In a dreamlike state, you noticed her but, being feverish and delirious, imagined her appearance as something monstrous: the wild hair, black face, exaggerated body were your imagination; the tearing of the veil, though, was real, and fits her. You’re wondering why I keep her here: after we’ve been married a year and a day, I’ll tell you—not now. Are you satisfied with this explanation, Jane?"
I thought about it, and it seemed like the only explanation. Though not satisfied, I pretended to be, to make him happy—I was at least relieved, so I smiled. Since it was already past one o’clock, I began to leave him.

events.title: Night-time Arrangements and a Moment of Calm
detailed_summary: As Jane prepares to leave, Mr. Rochester inquires if Sophie sleeps with Adèle.
He insists Jane share Adèle's bed for the night, concerned about her nervousness after the incident and wanting her not to sleep alone.
He instructs her to fasten the door securely and to wake Sophie under the pretext of needing to be roused early for wedding preparations.
He urges her to dismiss sombre thoughts, noting the wind has calmed and the rain has stopped.
He lifts the curtain to show her a lovely night, with clear skies and the moon shining peacefully as clouds drift away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Does not Sophie sleep with Adèle in the nursery?” he asked, as I lit my candle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The moon shone peacefully.

events.text_segment:
“Does not Sophie sleep with Adèle in the nursery?” he asked, as I lit my candle.
“Yes, sir.”
“And there is room enough in Adèle’s little bed for you. You must share it with her to-night, Jane: it is no wonder that the incident you have related should make you nervous, and I would rather you did not sleep alone: promise me to go to the nursery.”
“I shall be very glad to do so, sir.”
“And fasten the door securely on the inside. Wake Sophie when you go upstairs, under pretence of requesting her to rouse you in good time to-morrow; for you must be dressed and have finished breakfast before eight. And now, no more sombre thoughts: chase dull care away, Janet. Don’t you hear to what soft whispers the wind has fallen? and there is no more beating of rain against the window-panes: look here” (he lifted up the curtain)—“it is a lovely night!”
It was. Half heaven was pure and stainless: the clouds, now trooping before the wind, which had shifted to the west, were filing off eastward in long, silvered columns. The moon shone peacefully.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: As I lit my candle, he inquired, “Does Sophie share the nursery with Adèle?” Upon my affirmative response, he suggested, “There’s ample space in Adèle’s small bed for you. You should sleep there tonight, Jane. It's understandable that what you've experienced has made you uneasy, and I prefer you not to be by yourself. Please promise me you’ll go to the nursery.” I replied, “I would be very happy to do that, sir.” He added, “And ensure you lock the door securely from the inside. Wake Sophie when you head upstairs, pretending you need her to wake you promptly tomorrow, as you must be dressed and have eaten breakfast before eight. Now, dismiss these gloomy thoughts; cast aside your worries, Janet. Can you hear how gently the wind is blowing now? There's no more rain hitting the windows either. Look here” (he lifted the curtain) “—it's a wonderful night!” It truly was. Half the sky was clear and perfect, with the clouds, now driven by the wind which had shifted to the west, moving away eastward in long, gleaming formations. The moon offered a peaceful light.
