He then said there was enough space in Adèle’s little bed for me and insisted I share it with her tonight; he understood why recent events had made me anxious and would rather I wasn’t alone. He asked me to promise I’d go to the nursery. I agreed I would be happy to do so. He instructed me to securely fasten the door from inside and to wake Sophie when I went upstairs, pretending it was so she could wake me early the next morning, as I needed to be up, dressed, and have had breakfast before eight. He told me not to dwell on gloomy thoughts and to let go of my worries, noting how calm the wind sounded and that the rain had stopped. Pulling aside the curtain, he showed me that it was a beautiful night: the sky was mostly clear, clouds moving east under a peaceful moon.

events.title: A Sleepless Vigil and an Ominous Dawn
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester, observing the calm night, asks Jane how she feels.
Jane replies that the night is serene, and so is she.
Rochester predicts she will dream of happy love and blissful union, not sorrow.
This prediction is only partly fulfilled: Jane does not dream of sorrow, but she also does not dream of joy because she doesn't sleep at all.
She watches over the sleeping Adèle, holding her, and waits for the coming day, her entire being awake and stirred.
As soon as the sun rises, Jane rises too.
She recalls Adèle clinging to her as she left, kissing her, and crying with a strange emotion, leaving quietly to avoid disturbing Adèle's sleep.
She views Adèle as an emblem of her past life, and Mr. Rochester, whom she is about to marry, as the "dread, but adored, type" of her unknown future.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well,” said Mr. Rochester, gazing inquiringly into my eyes, “how is my Janet now?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She seemed the emblem of my past life; and he, I was now to array myself to meet, the dread, but adored, type of my unknown future day.

events.text_segment:
“Well,” said Mr. Rochester, gazing inquiringly into my eyes, “how is my Janet now?”
“The night is serene, sir; and so am I.”
“And you will not dream of separation and sorrow to-night; but of happy love and blissful union.”
This prediction was but half fulfilled: I did not indeed dream of sorrow, but as little did I dream of joy; for I never slept at all. With little Adèle in my arms, I watched the slumber of childhood—so tranquil, so passionless, so innocent—and waited for the coming day: all my life was awake and astir in my frame: and as soon as the sun rose I rose too. I remember Adèle clung to me as I left her: I remember I kissed her as I loosened her little hands from my neck; and I cried over her with strange emotion, and quitted her because I feared my sobs would break her still sound repose. She seemed the emblem of my past life; and he, I was now to array myself to meet, the dread, but adored, type of my unknown future day.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. Rochester looked closely into my eyes and asked, “So, how are you feeling tonight, Janet?” I replied, “The night is peaceful, sir, and so am I.” He wished me, “Then tonight you won't have sad dreams of being apart, but happy dreams of love and joyful togetherness.” His prediction was only partly right: I didn't have sad dreams, but I didn't dream of happiness either, because I didn't sleep at all. Holding young Adèle, I watched her childhood sleep, which was so calm, without passion, and pure, and waited for morning. My entire being felt awake and active within me, and as soon as the sun appeared, I got up as well. I recall Adèle holding onto me as I prepared to leave her; I remember kissing her as I gently removed her small hands from around my neck. I wept over her with an unusual feeling and left her room because I was afraid my crying might disturb her peaceful sleep. She seemed like a symbol of my life up to this point, while he, whom I was getting ready to face, represented the fearful yet beloved symbol of my uncertain future.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: "Well," Mr. Rochester said, looking searchingly into my eyes, "how are you, my Janet?" I replied, "The night is calm, sir, and so am I." He continued, "You won’t think of parting or sadness tonight, only of love and happiness together." However, this expectation was only partially met: I didn't dream of sadness, but nor did I dream of happiness; in truth, I couldn’t sleep at all. With little Adèle in my arms, I watched her peaceful, innocent sleep and waited for morning, feeling fully awake and restless. As soon as the sun rose, I got up. I recall Adèle holding onto me when I left, and I kissed her as I gently freed her arms from my neck. I wept over her, deeply moved, and left her because I feared my tears would disturb her restful sleep. She seemed to represent my past life, while the man I was preparing to meet—both feared and loved—symbolized the unknown future ahead of me.

events.title: Hasty Wedding Preparations and Tense Journey to Church
detailed_summary: Sophie assisted Jane in dressing for the wedding, taking a considerable amount of time.
An impatient Mr. Rochester sent a message inquiring about Jane's delay.
Jane, feeling like a stranger in her bridal attire after a quick glance in the mirror, hurried downstairs to Mr. Rochester.
Mr. Rochester expressed his intense eagerness and praised Jane's appearance effusively.
He allotted Jane a mere ten minutes for breakfast before ringing for a servant to confirm arrangements for the carriage and the clergyman, Mr. Wood.
The servant confirmed Mr. Wood was at the church, preparing.
Mr. Rochester specified the carriage was for their return journey, not for going to the nearby church.
Jane and Mr. Rochester proceeded to the church alone, without any bridesmaids, groomsmen, or relatives present.
As they passed through the hall, Jane saw Mrs. Fairfax but was unable to speak to her due to Mr. Rochester's firm grip and urgent pace.
Jane was struck by Mr. Rochester's uncharacteristically grim, resolute, and fiery-eyed demeanor, unlike any typical bridegroom.
Oblivious to the weather or her surroundings during their walk, Jane's entire being was focused on Mr. Rochester.
She intensely desired to comprehend the unseen focus of his fierce gaze and the internal conflict he seemed to be struggling against.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Sophie came at seven to dress me: she was very long indeed in accomplishing her task; so long that Mr. Rochester, grown, I suppose, impatient of my delay, sent up to ask why I did not come.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force he seemed breasting and resisting.

events.text_segment:
Sophie came at seven to dress me: she was very long indeed in accomplishing her task; so long that Mr. Rochester, grown, I suppose, impatient of my delay, sent up to ask why I did not come. She was just fastening my veil (the plain square of blond after all) to my hair with a brooch; I hurried from under her hands as soon as I could.
“Stop!” she cried in French. “Look at yourself in the mirror: you have not taken one peep.”
So I turned at the door: I saw a robed and veiled figure, so unlike my usual self that it seemed almost the image of a stranger. “Jane!” called a voice, and I hastened down. I was received at the foot of the stairs by Mr. Rochester.
“Lingerer!” he said, “my brain is on fire with impatience, and you tarry so long!”
He took me into the dining-room, surveyed me keenly all over, pronounced me “fair as a lily, and not only the pride of his life, but the desire of his eyes,” and then telling me he would give me but ten minutes to eat some breakfast, he rang the bell. One of his lately hired servants, a footman, answered it.
“Is John getting the carriage ready?”
“Yes, sir.”
“Is the luggage brought down?”
“They are bringing it down, sir.”
“Go you to the church: see if Mr. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk are there: return and tell me.”
The church, as the reader knows, was but just beyond the gates; the footman soon returned.
“Mr. Wood is in the vestry, sir, putting on his surplice.”
“And the carriage?”
“The horses are harnessing.”
“We shall not want it to go to church; but it must be ready the moment we return: all the boxes and luggage arranged and strapped on, and the coachman in his seat.”
“Yes, sir.”
“Jane, are you ready?”
I rose. There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait for or marshal: none but Mr. Rochester and I. Mrs. Fairfax stood in the hall as we passed. I would fain have spoken to her, but my hand was held by a grasp of iron: I was hurried along by a stride I could hardly follow; and to look at Mr. Rochester’s face was to feel that not a second of delay would be tolerated for any purpose. I wonder what other bridegroom ever looked as he did—so bent up to a purpose, so grimly resolute: or who, under such steadfast brows, ever revealed such flaming and flashing eyes.
I know not whether the day was fair or foul; in descending the drive, I gazed neither on sky nor earth: my heart was with my eyes; and both seemed migrated into Mr. Rochester’s frame. I wanted to see the invisible thing on which, as we went along, he appeared to fasten a glance fierce and fell. I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force he seemed breasting and resisting.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Sophie arrived at 7 AM to help me get dressed, and she took a very long time completing her task. She delayed so much that Mr. Rochester, presumably growing impatient with my slowness, sent someone up to inquire why I hadn't come down. She was just finishing fastening my veil (which, after all, was just a plain square of blond fabric) to my hair with a brooch. I quickly moved away from her hands as soon as I possibly could. "Stop!" she exclaimed in French. "Look at yourself in the mirror; you haven't even taken a peek." So I paused at the doorway and turned. I saw a figure dressed in a robe and veil, looking so unlike my usual self that it seemed almost like a reflection of a stranger. "Jane!" a voice called out, and I quickly hurried down. Mr. Rochester met me at the bottom of the stairs. "You are lingering!" he said, "my mind is burning with impatience, and you are taking such a long time!" He led me into the dining room, examined me intently from head to toe, pronounced me "as fair as a lily, and not only the pride of his life but also the object of his desire," and then told me he would only allow me ten minutes to eat some breakfast before ringing the bell. One of his recently hired servants, a footman, answered it. "Is John getting the carriage ready?" "Yes, sir." "Has the luggage been brought down?" "They are bringing it down now, sir." "Go to the church: see if Mr. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk are there: return and tell me." As the reader is aware, the church was located just beyond the gates; the footman returned quickly. "Mr. Wood is in the vestry, sir, putting on his surplice." "And the carriage?" "The horses are being harnessed." "We won't need it to go to church; but it must be ready the moment we return: all the trunks and luggage arranged and secured, and the coachman in his seat." "Yes, sir." "Jane, are you ready?" I stood up. There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait for or organize; only Mr. Rochester and me. Mrs. Fairfax was standing in the hall as we passed by. I wished I could have spoken to her, but my hand was held in a grip like iron; I was hurried along by a pace I could barely keep up with. Looking at Mr. Rochester's face made it clear that not a single second of delay would be tolerated for any reason. I wonder what other groom ever looked as he did—so intensely focused on a goal, so sternly determined; or who, under such steady eyebrows, ever revealed such blazing and intense eyes. I don't know whether the day was pleasant or unpleasant; as we went down the drive, I looked neither at the sky nor the ground. My heart was focused entirely on my eyes, and both seemed to be absorbed into Mr. Rochester's being. I desperately wanted to see the invisible thing upon which, as we moved along, he seemed to fix a fierce and intense gaze. I wanted to feel the thoughts whose power he seemed to be confronting and resisting.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: At seven, Sophie came to help me get dressed, taking much longer than usual; eventually, Mr. Rochester became impatient at my delay and sent someone to check on me. Sophie was just finishing attaching my simple veil to my hair with a brooch, and I hurried away from her as soon as I could. She called after me in French, telling me to look at myself in the mirror because I had not yet done so. I briefly glanced at my reflection by the door and saw a figure so different from my everyday appearance that I hardly recognized myself. Then, hearing Mr. Rochester call my name, I quickly went downstairs, where he greeted me at the foot of the stairs. He chided me for taking so long, claiming his impatience was overwhelming, and led me into the dining room. There, he examined me carefully, complimented my appearance, and declared I had only ten minutes to eat breakfast before ringing for a servant. Upon asking about the carriage and the luggage, and ensuring everything was prepared for our departure to the church, Mr. Rochester had the servant check whether Mr. Wood and the clerk were at the church, which was close by. The servant soon returned, confirming they were present and that the horses were being readied. Mr. Rochester said we wouldn’t need the carriage to get to the church, but it should be ready for our return, with all their belongings loaded and the coachman in place. When he asked if I was ready, I got up. There were no attendants or relatives—just Mr. Rochester and myself. Mrs. Fairfax watched as we passed, but Mr. Rochester’s firm grip hurried me along so quickly that I couldn’t stop to speak to her. He looked intensely focused and determined, more so, I thought, than any other prospective bridegroom. As we walked down the drive, I paid no attention to the weather or my surroundings; my thoughts and senses were entirely fixed on Mr. Rochester. I was captivated by whatever absorbed his intense and powerful gaze, wishing I could share in the emotions he seemed to be battling as we approached the church.

events.title: Arrival at the Church and Ominous Sightings
detailed_summary: Reaching the churchyard entrance, Mr. Rochester paused, noticing Jane's breathlessness from their quick pace, and showed a moment of tenderness.
Jane then observed her surroundings: the old grey church, a circling rook, a ruddy morning sky, and green grave-mounds.
She particularly noted two unfamiliar men among the graves who, upon seeing her and Mr. Rochester, moved around to the back of the church, as if to enter discreetly to witness the ceremony.
Mr. Rochester, preoccupied with Jane's pale appearance, did not notice these men.
After Jane regained her composure, Mr. Rochester gently led her up the path to the church porch.
They entered the quiet, humble church where the priest in his surplice and the clerk were waiting by the altar.
Jane saw that her suspicion was correct: the two strangers had already entered and were positioned near the Rochester family vault, examining the old tomb.
Jane and Mr. Rochester proceeded to take their places at the communion rails.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At the churchyard wicket he stopped: he discovered I was quite out of breath.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Our place was taken at the communion rails.

events.text_segment:
At the churchyard wicket he stopped: he discovered I was quite out of breath. “Am I cruel in my love?” he said. “Delay an instant: lean on me, Jane.”
And now I can recall the picture of the grey old house of God rising calm before me, of a rook wheeling round the steeple, of a ruddy morning sky beyond. I remember something, too, of the green grave-mounds; and I have not forgotten, either, two figures of strangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes graven on the few mossy head-stones. I noticed them, because, as they saw us, they passed round to the back of the church; and I doubted not they were going to enter by the side-aisle door and witness the ceremony. By Mr. Rochester they were not observed; he was earnestly looking at my face, from which the blood had, I daresay, momentarily fled: for I felt my forehead dewy, and my cheeks and lips cold. When I rallied, which I soon did, he walked gently with me up the path to the porch.
We entered the quiet and humble temple; the priest waited in his white surplice at the lowly altar, the clerk beside him. All was still: two shadows only moved in a remote corner. My conjecture had been correct: the strangers had slipped in before us, and they now stood by the vault of the Rochesters, their backs towards us, viewing through the rails the old time-stained marble tomb, where a kneeling angel guarded the remains of Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the civil wars, and of Elizabeth, his wife.
Our place was taken at the communion rails.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Stopping at the churchyard entrance, he noticed I was breathless. “Am I being too harsh in my affection?” he asked. “Pause for a moment; lean on me, Jane.” I can now recall the scene: the ancient, grey church standing serenely ahead, a rook circling the spire, and a warm morning sky behind. I also remember the green burial mounds and the two unfamiliar people wandering among the low grave-hills, reading the inscriptions etched on the few weathered gravestones. I observed them because they moved around to the back of the church when they saw us, and I assumed they intended to enter through the side door to watch the service. Mr. Rochester did not see them; he was intently gazing at my face, from which, I imagine, the colour had momentarily drained, as I felt my forehead damp and my cheeks and lips cold. Once I recovered, which I did quickly, he walked slowly with me along the path to the entrance. We went into the quiet, modest church; the minister, dressed in his white robes, waited at the simple altar with the clerk beside him. It was silent except for two shadows moving in a far corner. My suspicion was right: the strangers had entered before us and were now standing by the Rochester family tomb, their backs to us, looking through the railings at the old, stained marble monument where a kneeling angel guarded the remains of Damer de Rochester, who died at Marston Moor during the civil wars, and his wife, Elizabeth. We took our place at the altar railing.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
At the gate to the churchyard, he stopped and noticed that I was out of breath. "Am I being unkind because I love you?" he asked. "Wait a moment, Jane; lean on me." At that moment, I can recall the image of the calm, old, grey church in front of me, a rook circling the steeple, and the red glow of the morning sky in the background. I also remember the green mounds over the graves, and I have not forgotten two strangers wandering among the graves, reading the inscriptions carved on the aged, moss-covered headstones. I took note of them because, upon seeing us, they moved around to the back of the church, and I assumed they intended to enter through the side aisle to witness the ceremony. Mr. Rochester did not see them; he was focused intently on my face, from which, I imagine, the color had temporarily drained, as my forehead felt damp and my cheeks and lips cold. When I recovered, which I did shortly after, he gently walked with me along the path to the church porch.

We went inside the quiet, modest church, where the priest in his white robe was waiting at the simple altar, the clerk by his side. Everything was silent: only two moving shadows were visible in a distant corner. My assumption had been correct: the strangers had entered before us, and now stood near the Rochester family vault, their backs turned to us, looking through the rails at the old, weathered marble tomb protected by the figure of a kneeling angel, marking the resting place of Damer de Rochester—killed at Marston Moor during the civil wars—and his wife, Elizabeth.

We took our places at the communion rails.

events.title: The Wedding Ceremony Dramatically Interrupted
detailed_summary: As Jane and Mr. Rochester stood at the communion rails, Jane noticed one of the two strangers, a gentleman, advancing up the chancel.
The wedding service commenced with the customary explanation of the purpose of matrimony.
The clergyman then advanced and delivered the solemn charge, requiring anyone knowing of an impediment to the marriage to confess it immediately.
A traditional pause followed, rarely ever broken by a response.

Just as the clergyman, without looking up from his book, was about to ask Mr. Rochester the marriage vow, a clear and nearby voice declared that the marriage could not proceed due to an existing impediment.
The clergyman and the clerk were struck dumb by the interruption.
Mr. Rochester, though visibly disturbed as if by an earthquake, composed himself and firmly instructed the clergyman to continue.
A profound silence descended after Mr. Rochester's command, uttered in a deep but low tone.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hearing a cautious step behind me, I glanced over my shoulder: one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—was advancing up the chancel.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Profound silence fell when he had uttered that word, with deep but low intonation.

events.text_segment:
Hearing a cautious step behind me, I glanced over my shoulder: one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—was advancing up the chancel. The service began. The explanation of the intent of matrimony was gone through; and then the clergyman came a step further forward, and, bending slightly towards Mr. Rochester, went on.
“I require and charge you both (as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgment, when the secrets of all hearts shall be disclosed), that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not lawfully be joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it; for be ye well assured that so many as are coupled together otherwise than God’s Word doth allow, are not joined together by God, neither is their matrimony lawful.”
He paused, as the custom is. When is the pause after that sentence ever broken by reply? Not, perhaps, once in a hundred years. And the clergyman, who had not lifted his eyes from his book, and had held his breath but for a moment, was proceeding: his hand was already stretched towards Mr. Rochester, as his lips unclosed to ask, “Wilt thou have this woman for thy wedded wife?”—when a distinct and near voice said—
“The marriage cannot go on: I declare the existence of an impediment.”
The clergyman looked up at the speaker and stood mute; the clerk did the same; Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as if an earthquake had rolled under his feet: taking a firmer footing, and not turning his head or eyes, he said, “Proceed.”
Profound silence fell when he had uttered that word, with deep but low intonation.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Upon hearing careful steps approaching from behind, I looked back to see one of the visitors, obviously a gentleman, walking up the aisle towards the front. The wedding service then started. Following the explanation of the purpose of marriage, the clergyman took a step forward and, leaning slightly towards Mr. Rochester, continued. "I require and charge you both (knowing you will answer on the fearsome judgment day when hidden thoughts are revealed) that if either of you knows of any obstacle why you should not legally be married, you must state it now; because be absolutely sure that any who are joined together in a manner not allowed by God's Word are not truly joined by God, nor is their marriage legitimate." He paused, as is tradition. How often is that pause after this statement ever answered? Hardly once in a hundred years. And the minister, who hadn't lifted his eyes from his text and had held his breath for only a moment, was proceeding; his hand was already extended towards Mr. Rochester, as he was about to ask, "Do you take this woman as your wedded wife?"—when a clear voice nearby stated—"The wedding cannot proceed: I declare there is an existing impediment." The clergyman looked up at the speaker and fell silent; the clerk did the same; Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as though an earthquake had occurred beneath him, but steadied himself and, without turning his head or eyes, said, "Go on." Deep silence ensued after he spoke that word, in a low but intense voice.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
As I heard a quiet footstep behind me, I looked back and saw that one of the unfamiliar men—clearly a gentleman—was coming up the chancel. The ceremony started. The purpose of marriage was explained, and then the minister stepped a bit closer to Mr. Rochester, and, leaning slightly towards him, continued.

“I require and charge you both (as you will answer on the final day of judgment, when all secrets will be revealed), that if you know of any reason why you may not be rightfully married, confess it now; for understand that anyone joined together against the word of God are not truly married, nor is their union lawful.”

He stopped, as is customary. How often is this pause interrupted by a response? Probably less than once in a hundred years. The minister, without looking up from his book and after only a brief pause, was about to continue; his hand was extended towards Mr. Rochester and his mouth was opening to ask, “Will you take this woman as your wife?”—when a clear, nearby voice interrupted—

“This marriage cannot proceed: I announce there is an impediment.”

The minister looked up in silence at the speaker; so did the clerk. Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as if startled by an earthquake, but then braced himself, and without looking around or moving his gaze, said, “Go on.”

A deep silence followed his words, spoken in a quiet but intense tone.

events.title: The Impediment Revealed: Rochester's Prior Marriage
detailed_summary: Mr. Wood, the clergyman, stated he could not proceed with the ceremony without investigating the asserted impediment and verifying its truth.
The interrupting voice firmly stated that the ceremony was broken off and that an insuperable impediment to the marriage existed, which could be proven.
Mr. Rochester, though he heard, appeared to ignore the interruption, standing stubbornly rigid and tightening his grip on Jane's hand.
Jane noted his intensely hot grasp and his pale, massive, marble-like countenance, his eyes still watchful yet wild.
When Mr. Wood inquired about the nature of the impediment, hoping it might be resolved, the speaker asserted it was insuperable.

The speaker, identifying himself as Mr. Briggs, a solicitor, stepped forward and calmly, distinctly declared that the impediment was the existence of a previous marriage: Mr. Rochester already had a living wife.
Jane felt the words resonate through her with a subtle violence, more shocking than thunder, but she remained collected and did not faint.
She looked at Mr. Rochester, compelling him to meet her gaze; his face was like colorless rock, his eyes glinting like flint, showing no denial but rather a readiness to defy everything.
Without speaking or acknowledging Jane as a person, he merely tightened his arm around her waist, holding her fast to his side.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Presently Mr. Wood said—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Without speaking, without smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, he only twined my waist with his arm and riveted me to his side.

events.text_segment:
Presently Mr. Wood said—
“I cannot proceed without some investigation into what has been asserted, and evidence of its truth or falsehood.”
“The ceremony is quite broken off,” subjoined the voice behind us. “I am in a condition to prove my allegation: an insuperable impediment to this marriage exists.”
Mr. Rochester heard, but heeded not: he stood stubborn and rigid, making no movement but to possess himself of my hand. What a hot and strong grasp he had! and how like quarried marble was his pale, firm, massive front at this moment! How his eye shone, still watchful, and yet wild beneath!
Mr. Wood seemed at a loss. “What is the nature of the impediment?” he asked. “Perhaps it may be got over—explained away?”
“Hardly,” was the answer. “I have called it insuperable, and I speak advisedly.”
The speaker came forward and leaned on the rails. He continued, uttering each word distinctly, calmly, steadily, but not loudly—
“It simply consists in the existence of a previous marriage. Mr. Rochester has a wife now living.”
My nerves vibrated to those low-spoken words as they had never vibrated to thunder—my blood felt their subtle violence as it had never felt frost or fire; but I was collected, and in no danger of swooning. I looked at Mr. Rochester: I made him look at me. His whole face was colourless rock: his eye was both spark and flint. He disavowed nothing: he seemed as if he would defy all things. Without speaking, without smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, he only twined my waist with his arm and riveted me to his side.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. Wood then stated, "Before proceeding, I must investigate the claims made and determine their truth or falsity." The voice from behind added, "The ceremony is definitively cancelled. I have proof to support my statement: there is an insurmountable barrier to this wedding." Mr. Rochester heard but ignored this; he remained rigid and defiant, his only action being to tightly grip my hand. His hold was incredibly strong and hot, and at that moment, his pale, firm, and imposing face resembled roughly cut stone. His eyes, still vigilant yet with a wildness underlying them, shone intensely. Mr. Wood appeared uncertain, asking, "What kind of obstacle is this? Can it perhaps be overcome or explained away?" The response was, "Highly unlikely. I called it insurmountable and I stand by that statement after careful consideration." The speaker moved forward and leaned on the barrier. He continued, articulating each word clearly, calmly, and steadily, though not loudly: "It is simply that a prior marriage exists. Mr. Rochester is already married; his wife is alive." These quiet words affected my nerves more intensely than thunder ever had, and their subtle force impacted my blood more profoundly than extreme cold or heat; however, I remained composed and was in no danger of fainting. I looked at Mr. Rochester, compelling him to meet my gaze. His entire face was like uncolored rock; his eyes held both a spark and the hardness of flint. He didn't deny anything; he seemed ready to challenge everything. Without speaking, smiling, or even appearing to acknowledge me as a person, he simply put his arm around my waist and held me firmly against his side.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Soon Mr. Wood said, "I can't go on without looking into what's been claimed and seeing if it's true or not." A voice behind us added, "The ceremony cannot continue. I can prove what I said: there is an insurmountable obstacle to this marriage." Mr. Rochester heard this but ignored it; he stood firm and unmoving, only tightening his grasp on my hand—it was a hot, strong hold. His pale, broad face was stern, almost marble-like, and his eyes shone fiercely yet wildly beneath his brow. Mr. Wood appeared puzzled. He asked what the obstacle was, wondering if it could be resolved or explained away. The reply came, "Unlikely. I've called it insurmountable and I mean it." The speaker stepped forward, rested on the railing, and continued clearly and steadily, though not loudly: "The obstacle is simple: Mr. Rochester is already married; his wife is still alive." Hearing this, my nerves felt more shaken than by thunder; the shock ran through my blood more than fire or ice ever had. Yet I remained calm and in control. I looked at Mr. Rochester and made him look at me. His face was stone-pale, his gaze intense and unyielding. He did not deny anything; he seemed ready to defy everything. He said nothing, did not smile, nor acknowledge me as a person—he only wrapped his arm around my waist and held me tightly at his side.

events.title: Details of Prior Marriage Emerge and Witness Appears
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester demanded the identity of the man who interrupted, and the man introduced himself as Briggs, a solicitor from London.
Mr. Rochester sarcastically questioned if Briggs intended to force a wife upon him.
Briggs calmly responded that he was merely reminding Mr. Rochester of his legally recognized wife's existence.

When Mr. Rochester demanded an account of this wife, Briggs produced a paper and read an affirmation: Edward Fairfax Rochester had married Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason, fifteen years prior in Spanish Town, Jamaica.
Briggs stated that the marriage record existed and a copy was in his possession.
Mr. Rochester conceded that the document might prove a past marriage but argued it didn't prove the woman was still alive.
Briggs countered that she was alive three months ago.
When Rochester demanded proof, Briggs stated he had a witness whose testimony Rochester would find hard to dispute.
Upon Rochester's defiant command to produce the witness, Briggs called for Mr. Mason to step forward.
Hearing Mason's name, Mr. Rochester visibly tensed, experiencing a convulsive shudder of either fury or despair that Jane could feel.
The second stranger, who had remained in the background, came forward; it was indeed Mason himself, his pale face appearing over the solicitor's shoulder.
Mr. Rochester turned and glared intensely at Mason, his dark eyes showing a bloody light, his face flushing with a rising inner fire.
He seemed on the verge of striking Mason, who shrank back and cried out to God.
Mr. Rochester's passion suddenly cooled into contempt, and he merely asked Mason what he had to say.
Mason's initial reply was inaudible, his lips white with fear.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Who are you?” he asked of the intruder.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: An inaudible reply escaped Mason’s white lips.

events.text_segment:
“Who are you?” he asked of the intruder.
“My name is Briggs, a solicitor of —— Street, London.”
“And you would thrust on me a wife?”
“I would remind you of your lady’s existence, sir, which the law recognises, if you do not.”
“Favour me with an account of her—with her name, her parentage, her place of abode.”
“Certainly.” Mr. Briggs calmly took a paper from his pocket, and read out in a sort of official, nasal voice:—
“‘I affirm and can prove that on the 20th of October A.D. —— (a date of fifteen years back), Edward Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall, in the county of ——, and of Ferndean Manor, in ——shire, England, was married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason, merchant, and of Antoinetta his wife, a Creole, at —— church, Spanish Town, Jamaica. The record of the marriage will be found in the register of that church—a copy of it is now in my possession. Signed, Richard Mason.’”
“That—if a genuine document—may prove I have been married, but it does not prove that the woman mentioned therein as my wife is still living.”
“She was living three months ago,” returned the lawyer.
“How do you know?”
“I have a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will scarcely controvert.”
“Produce him—or go to hell.”
“I will produce him first—he is on the spot. Mr. Mason, have the goodness to step forward.”
Mr. Rochester, on hearing the name, set his teeth; he experienced, too, a sort of strong convulsive quiver; near to him as I was, I felt the spasmodic movement of fury or despair run through his frame. The second stranger, who had hitherto lingered in the background, now drew near; a pale face looked over the solicitor’s shoulder—yes, it was Mason himself. Mr. Rochester turned and glared at him. His eye, as I have often said, was a black eye: it had now a tawny, nay, a bloody light in its gloom; and his face flushed—olive cheek and hueless forehead received a glow as from spreading, ascending heart-fire: and he stirred, lifted his strong arm—he could have struck Mason, dashed him on the church-floor, shocked by ruthless blow the breath from his body—but Mason shrank away, and cried faintly, “Good God!” Contempt fell cool on Mr. Rochester—his passion died as if a blight had shrivelled it up: he only asked—“What have you to say?”
An inaudible reply escaped Mason’s white lips.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: He questioned the intruder, asking for his identity. The visitor replied, "My name is Briggs, a solicitor from a specific street in London." Rochester retorted, "And you intend to force a wife upon me?" Briggs answered, "Sir, I am here to remind you of your lady's existence, which the law acknowledges, even if you do not." Rochester demanded, "Furnish me with information about her - her name, her parents, where she resides." "Certainly," Mr. Briggs agreed calmly. He took a document from his pocket and read aloud in a somewhat formal, nasal tone: "I affirm and can prove that on October 20th in a year fifteen years ago, Edward Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall in a certain county, and of Ferndean Manor in --shire, England, was married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, the daughter of Jonas Mason, a merchant, and his wife Antoinetta, a Creole, at a church in Spanish Town, Jamaica. The record of this marriage is in that church's register, and I possess a copy of it. Signed, Richard Mason." Rochester responded, "That document, assuming it's genuine, might prove I was married, but it doesn't prove the woman mentioned as my wife is still alive." "She was alive three months ago," the lawyer stated. "How do you know?" Rochester pressed. "I have a witness to that fact," Briggs replied, "whose testimony you, sir, will find difficult to challenge." "Present him - or leave immediately!" Rochester ordered. "I will present him first - he is right here. Mr. Mason, please step forward." Hearing the name, Mr. Rochester clenched his jaw and experienced a strong, involuntary tremor. Standing close by, I could feel the violent surge of anger or despair pass through his body. The second stranger, who had been standing back until now, approached. A pale face appeared over the solicitor's shoulder - yes, it was Mason himself. Mr. Rochester turned and glared intensely at him. As I have often noted, his eyes were dark, but now they held a fierce, even bloodshot gleam within their darkness. His face flushed; his typically olive cheek and pale forehead glowed as if heated from within. He moved, raising his strong arm - he seemed ready to strike Mason, throw him to the church floor, perhaps even fatally injure him with a brutal blow. However, Mason flinched away, crying out weakly, "Good God!" Contempt settled calmly upon Mr. Rochester; his intense emotion died as if suddenly withered. He simply asked, "What do you have to say?" A response, inaudible to us, came from Mason's white lips.

Rochester retorted, "And do you intend to force a wife upon me?" Briggs answered, "I am here to remind you, sir, of your lawful wife’s existence—if you have forgotten, the law has not." Rochester demanded more details, asking for her name, background, and where she was residing. Briggs obliged, pulling out a document and reading aloud in a formal, nasal tone: "I declare and can prove that on October 20th, fifteen years past, Edward Fairfax Rochester of Thornfield Hall and Ferndean Manor, England, wed my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason, a merchant, and Antoinetta his wife, a Creole, at —— church, Spanish Town, Jamaica. The marriage is recorded in the church register; I have a certified copy. Signed, Richard Mason." Rochester replied, "That document—if genuine—proves only that I was married; it doesn’t prove my wife is still alive." The lawyer countered, "She was alive three months ago." "How can you be sure?" asked Rochester. Briggs said, "I have an eyewitness, whose statement you can’t dispute." "Bring this witness here, or leave me alone," said Rochester angrily. Briggs responded, "I will bring him; he is here now. Mr. Mason, please come forward." Hearing this, Rochester was overcome with fury or despair, trembling violently as Mason, the second stranger, stepped forward from the shadows, his face pale. Rochester glared at him, his dark eyes burning with intensity, and his face flushed with passion. He looked ready to strike Mason, but Mason recoiled, exclaiming weakly, "Good God!" Suddenly, Rochester’s anger subsided, overtaken by cold contempt. He asked Mason, "Well, what do you have to say?" Mason only managed a barely audible answer.

events.title: Mason's Testimony and Rochester's Explosive Confession
detailed_summary: After Mr. Rochester demanded a clear answer from the terrified Mason, the clergyman intervened, reminding Rochester of the sacred place, and gently asked Mason if Rochester's wife was still living.
Encouraged by Briggs, Mason stated more clearly that she was currently living at Thornfield Hall and that he had seen her there the previous April, identifying himself as her brother.
The clergyman exclaimed in disbelief, stating he was an old resident of the neighborhood and had never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at Thornfield Hall.
A grim smile appeared on Mr. Rochester's lips as he muttered that he had ensured no one would hear of her by that name.
After a brief period of internal reflection, Mr. Rochester decisively announced that all secrets would now be revealed.
He ordered Mr. Wood to close his book and remove his surplice, and John Green, the clerk, to leave the church, declaring there would be no wedding that day.
Mr. Rochester continued recklessly, admitting his intention to commit bigamy and attributing his failure to fate or Providence.
He confessed that the lawyer's and client's assertions were true: he was married, and his wife was alive.
He then revealed to Mr. Wood that the rumored mysterious lunatic at Thornfield was, in fact, his wife, Bertha Mason.
He proceeded to describe Bertha's madness and her family's history of insanity, claiming he was deceived into the marriage as these secrets were hidden from him.
He sarcastically recounted his miserable experiences in the marriage.
He concluded by inviting Briggs, Wood, and Mason to Thornfield Hall to visit Mrs. Poole's patient, his wife, stating that Jane knew nothing of this disgusting secret and was about to be trapped.
He urged them all to follow him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “The devil is in it if you cannot answer distinctly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Come all of you—follow!”

events.text_segment:
“The devil is in it if you cannot answer distinctly. I again demand, what have you to say?”
“Sir—sir,” interrupted the clergyman, “do not forget you are in a sacred place.” Then addressing Mason, he inquired gently, “Are you aware, sir, whether or not this gentleman’s wife is still living?”
“Courage,” urged the lawyer,—“speak out.”
“She is now living at Thornfield Hall,” said Mason, in more articulate tones: “I saw her there last April. I am her brother.”
“At Thornfield Hall!” ejaculated the clergyman. “Impossible! I am an old resident in this neighbourhood, sir, and I never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at Thornfield Hall.”
I saw a grim smile contort Mr. Rochester’s lips, and he muttered—
“No, by God! I took care that none should hear of it—or of her under that name.” He mused—for ten minutes he held counsel with himself: he formed his resolve, and announced it—
“Enough! all shall bolt out at once, like the bullet from the barrel. Wood, close your book and take off your surplice; John Green (to the clerk), leave the church: there will be no wedding to-day.” The man obeyed.
Mr. Rochester continued, hardily and recklessly: “Bigamy is an ugly word!—I meant, however, to be a bigamist; but fate has out-manoeuvred me, or Providence has checked me,—perhaps the last. I am little better than a devil at this moment; and, as my pastor there would tell me, deserve no doubt the sternest judgments of God, even to the quenchless fire and deathless worm. Gentlemen, my plan is broken up:—what this lawyer and his client say is true: I have been married, and the woman to whom I was married lives! You say you never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at the house up yonder, Wood; but I daresay you have many a time inclined your ear to gossip about the mysterious lunatic kept there under watch and ward. Some have whispered to you that she is my bastard half-sister: some, my cast-off mistress. I now inform you that she is my wife, whom I married fifteen years ago,—Bertha Mason by name; sister of this resolute personage, who is now, with his quivering limbs and white cheeks, showing you what a stout heart men may bear. Cheer up, Dick!—never fear me!—I’d almost as soon strike a woman as you. Bertha Mason is mad; and she came of a mad family; idiots and maniacs through three generations! Her mother, the Creole, was both a madwoman and a drunkard!—as I found out after I had wed the daughter: for they were silent on family secrets before. Bertha, like a dutiful child, copied her parent in both points. I had a charming partner—pure, wise, modest: you can fancy I was a happy man. I went through rich scenes! Oh! my experience has been heavenly, if you only knew it! But I owe you no further explanation. Briggs, Wood, Mason, I invite you all to come up to the house and visit Mrs. Poole’s patient, and my wife! You shall see what sort of a being I was cheated into espousing, and judge whether or not I had a right to break the compact, and seek sympathy with something at least human. This girl,” he continued, looking at me, “knew no more than you, Wood, of the disgusting secret: she thought all was fair and legal; and never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch, already bound to a bad, mad, and embruted partner! Come all of you—follow!”

Everyone—come, follow me!"

Now, come all of you—follow me!"

events.title: Confrontation and Struggle with Bertha Mason in Her Hidden Room
detailed_summary: Still firmly holding Jane's hand, Mr. Rochester led her and the three gentlemen out of the church.
At Thornfield Hall's front door, they found the carriage, which Mr. Rochester coolly ordered back to the coach-house, as it would not be needed.
Upon their entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Adèle, Sophie, and Leah approached to greet them, but Mr. Rochester harshly dismissed them, stating their congratulations were fifteen years too late.
He continued to lead the party, including Jane and the gentlemen, up the stairs to the third storey.
Using his master-key, he opened the low, black door to the tapestried room, reminding Mason that Bertha had attacked him there.
He then lifted a hanging to reveal a second, concealed door, which he also opened.
This led to a windowless room, lit by a guarded fire and a suspended lamp, where Grace Poole was cooking.
In the room's deep shade, a figure darted back and forth, initially appearing like a beast on all fours, growling and snatching, though clothed and with a wild mane of dark, grizzled hair.
Mr. Rochester greeted Mrs. Poole, who reported her charge was somewhat agitated but not violent.
A fierce cry from the figure seemed to contradict Grace's assessment, and the 'clothed hyena' rose to its feet.
Grace warned Mr. Rochester that Bertha had seen him and advised him not to stay long.
The maniac bellowed, pushed back her shaggy hair, and gazed wildly at the visitors; Jane recognized her purple, bloated face.
Mr. Rochester pushed Grace Poole aside, believing Bertha had no knife and that he was on guard, though Grace warned of Bertha's cunning.
Mason whispered they should leave, but Rochester dismissed him contemptuously.
As Grace cried a warning, the three gentlemen retreated, and Mr. Rochester pushed Jane behind him just as the lunatic sprang, viciously grappling his throat and biting his cheek.
A violent struggle ensued; Bertha, a large and powerful woman, nearly overpowered the athletic Mr. Rochester, who refrained from striking her, choosing only to wrestle.

Eventually, he subdued her arms, and with a cord provided by Grace Poole, he pinioned them behind her, then further bound her to a chair with more rope, all amidst her ferocious yells and convulsive movements.
Mr. Rochester then turned to the onlookers with a smile that was both acrid and desolate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Still holding me fast, he left the church: the three gentlemen came after.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Rochester then turned to the spectators: he looked at them with a smile both acrid and desolate.

events.text_segment:
Still holding me fast, he left the church: the three gentlemen came after. At the front door of the hall we found the carriage.
“Take it back to the coach-house, John,” said Mr. Rochester coolly; “it will not be wanted to-day.”
At our entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Adèle, Sophie, Leah, advanced to meet and greet us.
“To the right-about—every soul!” cried the master; “away with your congratulations! Who wants them? Not I!—they are fifteen years too late!”
He passed on and ascended the stairs, still holding my hand, and still beckoning the gentlemen to follow him, which they did. We mounted the first staircase, passed up the gallery, proceeded to the third storey: the low, black door, opened by Mr. Rochester’s master-key, admitted us to the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet.
“You know this place, Mason,” said our guide; “she bit and stabbed you here.”
He lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering the second door: this, too, he opened. In a room without a window, there burnt a fire guarded by a high and strong fender, and a lamp suspended from the ceiling by a chain. Grace Poole bent over the fire, apparently cooking something in a saucepan. In the deep shade, at the farther end of the room, a figure ran backwards and forwards. What it was, whether beast or human being, one could not, at first sight, tell: it grovelled, seemingly, on all fours; it snatched and growled like some strange wild animal: but it was covered with clothing, and a quantity of dark, grizzled hair, wild as a mane, hid its head and face.
“Good-morrow, Mrs. Poole!” said Mr. Rochester. “How are you? and how is your charge to-day?”
“We’re tolerable, sir, I thank you,” replied Grace, lifting the boiling mess carefully on to the hob: “rather snappish, but not ’rageous.”
A fierce cry seemed to give the lie to her favourable report: the clothed hyena rose up, and stood tall on its hind-feet.
“Ah! sir, she sees you!” exclaimed Grace: “you’d better not stay.”
“Only a few moments, Grace: you must allow me a few moments.”
“Take care then, sir!—for God’s sake, take care!”
The maniac bellowed: she parted her shaggy locks from her visage, and gazed wildly at her visitors. I recognised well that purple face,—those bloated features. Mrs. Poole advanced.
“Keep out of the way,” said Mr. Rochester, thrusting her aside: “she has no knife now, I suppose, and I’m on my guard.”
“One never knows what she has, sir: she is so cunning: it is not in mortal discretion to fathom her craft.”
“We had better leave her,” whispered Mason.
“Go to the devil!” was his brother-in-law’s recommendation.
“’Ware!” cried Grace. The three gentlemen retreated simultaneously. Mr. Rochester flung me behind him: the lunatic sprang and grappled his throat viciously, and laid her teeth to his cheek: they struggled. She was a big woman, in stature almost equalling her husband, and corpulent besides: she showed virile force in the contest—more than once she almost throttled him, athletic as he was. He could have settled her with a well-planted blow; but he would not strike: he would only wrestle. At last he mastered her arms; Grace Poole gave him a cord, and he pinioned them behind her: with more rope, which was at hand, he bound her to a chair. The operation was performed amidst the fiercest yells and the most convulsive plunges. Mr. Rochester then turned to the spectators: he looked at them with a smile both acrid and desolate.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Keeping a firm hold on me, Mr. Rochester exited the church, followed by the three gentlemen. At the main entrance of the hall, we encountered the carriage. “Return it to the coach-house, John,” Mr. Rochester instructed calmly. “It won’t be needed today.” As we entered, Mrs. Fairfax, Adèle, Sophie, and Leah came forward to greet and welcome us. “About-face, everyone!” the master shouted. “Away with your congratulations! Who wants them? Not me! They are fifteen years too late!” He moved past them and went up the stairs, still clutching my hand and gesturing for the gentlemen to follow, which they did. We ascended the first flight of stairs, walked through the gallery, and continued up to the third floor. The low, dark door, unlocked by Mr. Rochester’s master-key, granted us entry to the tapestried room containing a large bed and a painted cabinet. “You are familiar with this location, Mason,” our guide stated. “She attacked you here, biting and stabbing.” He lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering a second door, which he also opened. Inside a windowless room, a fire burned, protected by a tall, sturdy fender, and a lamp hung from the ceiling by a chain. Grace Poole was bent over the fire, seemingly preparing food in a pot. In the deep shadows at the room’s far end, a figure paced back and forth. At first glance, it was difficult to determine if it was a beast or a human being; it seemed to crawl on all fours, snatching and growling like a strange wild animal. However, it was clothed, and a mass of dark, greyish, untamed hair, like a mane, obscured its head and face. “Good morning, Mrs. Poole!” Mr. Rochester greeted. “How are you, and how is your charge today?” “We are reasonably well, sir, I thank you,” Grace replied, carefully moving the boiling mixture onto the hob. “She’s rather irritable, but not violent.” A fierce scream appeared to contradict her positive assessment. The clothed individual, described like a hyena, rose and stood upright on its legs. “Ah, sir, she sees you!” Grace exclaimed. “You should probably leave.” “Just a few moments, Grace; you must allow me a short time.” “Then be cautious, sir! For heaven’s sake, be careful!” The insane person roared; she pushed aside her shaggy hair from her face and stared wildly at her visitors. I clearly recognised that purplish face and those swollen features. Mrs. Poole stepped forward. “Stay out of the way,” Mr. Rochester commanded, pushing her aside. “She doesn’t have a knife now, I presume, and I am ready.” “You can never be certain what she possesses, sir; she is so sly. It is impossible for ordinary human judgment to understand her cunning.” “We should leave her,” Mason whispered. “Go to the devil!” was his brother-in-law’s reply. “Look out!” Grace cried. The three gentlemen instantly moved back. Mr. Rochester pushed me behind him. The madwoman leaped and viciously grabbed his throat, sinking her teeth into his cheek. They wrestled. She was a large woman, nearly his height and also stout; she displayed masculine strength during the struggle, almost choking him more than once, despite his athleticism. He could have subdued her with a single strong blow, but he chose not to hit her, only to grapple. Eventually, he gained control of her arms. Grace Poole handed him a rope, and he tied them behind her back. Using more rope that was accessible, he bound her to a chair. The entire procedure was carried out amidst intense shrieks and violent thrashing. Mr. Rochester then turned to the observers, looking at them with a smile that was both bitter and sorrowful.

As we came inside, Mrs. Fairfax, Adèle, Sophie, and Leah stepped forward to welcome us, but Mr. Rochester quickly dismissed their greetings, declaring that any congratulations were not only unwanted but also too late by fifteen years. All this was done amid violent shrieks and wild thrashing. When it was over, Mr. Rochester looked at the onlookers with a bitter, sorrowful smile.

events.title: Rochester's Bitter Justification and Dismissal of Onlookers
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester identified the bound and struggling Bertha as his wife.
He bitterly remarked that this violent encounter was the only form of marital affection he was destined to know and such were the endearments of his leisure hours.
Placing his hand on Jane's shoulder, he declared that she, this quiet and composed young woman observing the demonic display, was what he had wished for as a contrast to his horrific marriage.
He urged Wood, the priest, and Briggs, the lawyer, to observe the stark difference between Jane's clear eyes and gentle form and Bertha's 'red balls' for eyes and grotesque bulk.
He challenged them to judge him, reminding them that they too would be judged by their own standards.
He then curtly ordered them to leave, stating he needed to secure his 'prize'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “That is my wife,” said he.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Off with you now. I must shut up my prize.”

events.text_segment: “That is my wife,” said he. “Such is the sole conjugal embrace I am ever to know—such are the endearments which are to solace my leisure hours! And this is what I wished to have” (laying his hand on my shoulder): “this young girl, who stands so grave and quiet at the mouth of hell, looking collectedly at the gambols of a demon, I wanted her just as a change after that fierce ragout. Wood and Briggs, look at the difference! Compare these clear eyes with the red balls yonder—this face with that mask—this form with that bulk; then judge me, priest of the gospel and man of the law, and remember with what judgment ye judge ye shall be judged! Off with you now. I must shut up my prize.”

He explained that he wanted me specifically as a change from his wild and unstable wife ('that fierce ragout'). He then instructed Wood and Briggs to look at the clear difference between us, comparing my 'clear eyes' to her 'red balls,' my 'face' to her 'mask,' and my 'form' to her 'bulk.' He challenged them, one a clergyman and one a lawyer, to judge him based on this comparison, warning them to remember the principle of 'with what judgment ye judge ye shall be judged.' Finally, he dismissed them, stating he needed to secure his wife ('shut up my prize').
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: "That is my wife," he declared. "This is the only kind of affection I will ever have in marriage—these are the comforts to fill my empty moments! Yet this is what I truly desired," he continued, resting his hand on my shoulder, "this young woman, calm and composed while standing at the gates of suffering, watching the antics of madness. I longed for her as a contrast to the chaos I already knew. Wood and Briggs, look for yourselves! Compare her clear eyes to those red, wild ones over there—her face to that terrifying mask—her slender form to that overwhelming presence. Judge me now, you who represent the church and the law, but remember you'll be judged, too! Now go; I must secure what I value most."

events.title: Departures and Revelations About Jane's Uncle's Intervention
detailed_summary: As the group, including Jane, withdrew from Bertha's room, Mr. Rochester lingered behind to give further instructions to Grace Poole.
While descending the stairs, Mr. Briggs, the solicitor, spoke to Jane, informing her that she was cleared of all blame regarding the attempted marriage.
He added that her uncle would be glad to hear this, provided he was still alive when Mr. Mason returned to Madeira.
Jane, surprised, inquired about her uncle, whom she didn't know Briggs or Mason knew.
Briggs explained that Mr. Mason was acquainted with Mr. Eyre, Jane's uncle, who was a business correspondent for Mason's firm in Funchal, Madeira.
He recounted that when Jane's letter announcing her marriage plans reached Mr. Eyre, Mr. Mason happened to be in Madeira recuperating.
Mr. Eyre shared the news, knowing Mason was familiar with a Rochester, whereupon Mason, greatly distressed, revealed the truth about Rochester's existing marriage.
Briggs conveyed the unfortunate news that Jane's uncle was now severely ill with 'decline' and was unlikely to recover.
Unable to travel to England himself, Mr. Eyre had implored Mason to act swiftly to prevent the false marriage, referring him to Briggs for legal assistance.

Briggs expressed gratitude that he had intervened in time and advised Jane to remain in England until she received further news about her uncle, as his death was probable before she could reach Madeira.
Following this conversation, Mr. Briggs and Mr. Mason made a hasty exit from Thornfield Hall without formally taking leave of Mr. Rochester.
The clergyman, Mr. Wood, also departed after exchanging a few words, likely of admonition or reproof, with Mr. Rochester.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We all withdrew.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The clergyman stayed to exchange a few sentences, either of admonition or reproof, with his haughty parishioner; this duty done, he too departed.

events.text_segment:
We all withdrew. Mr. Rochester stayed a moment behind us, to give some further order to Grace Poole. The solicitor addressed me as he descended the stair.
“You, madam,” said he, “are cleared from all blame: your uncle will be glad to hear it—if, indeed, he should be still living—when Mr. Mason returns to Madeira.”
“My uncle! What of him? Do you know him?”
“Mr. Mason does. Mr. Eyre has been the Funchal correspondent of his house for some years. When your uncle received your letter intimating the contemplated union between yourself and Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason, who was staying at Madeira to recruit his health, on his way back to Jamaica, happened to be with him. Mr. Eyre mentioned the intelligence; for he knew that my client here was acquainted with a gentleman of the name of Rochester. Mr. Mason, astonished and distressed as you may suppose, revealed the real state of matters. Your uncle, I am sorry to say, is now on a sick bed; from which, considering the nature of his disease—decline—and the stage it has reached, it is unlikely he will ever rise. He could not then hasten to England himself, to extricate you from the snare into which you had fallen, but he implored Mr. Mason to lose no time in taking steps to prevent the false marriage. He referred him to me for assistance. I used all despatch, and am thankful I was not too late: as you, doubtless, must be also. Were I not morally certain that your uncle will be dead ere you reach Madeira, I would advise you to accompany Mr. Mason back; but as it is, I think you had better remain in England till you can hear further, either from or of Mr. Eyre. Have we anything else to stay for?” he inquired of Mr. Mason.
“No, no—let us be gone,” was the anxious reply; and without waiting to take leave of Mr. Rochester, they made their exit at the hall door. The clergyman stayed to exchange a few sentences, either of admonition or reproof, with his haughty parishioner; this duty done, he too departed.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Everyone except Mr. Rochester exited the room. Mr. Rochester paused momentarily to give further instructions to Grace Poole. As we descended the stairs, the solicitor spoke to me.
He stated, "You, madam, are absolved of any fault; your uncle will be pleased to learn this—that is, if he is still alive—when Mr. Mason returns to Madeira."
"My uncle! What about him? Do you know him?" I exclaimed.
"Mr. Mason does. For several years, Mr. Eyre has served as his firm's contact in Funchal. When your uncle received your letter announcing your planned marriage to Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason happened to be with him. Mr. Mason was recuperating in Madeira on his way back to Jamaica. Mr. Eyre mentioned the news because he was aware that my client knew a gentleman named Rochester. As you can imagine, Mr. Mason was shocked and distressed and disclosed the true situation. I regret to inform you that your uncle is currently very ill; given the nature and advanced stage of his disease, consumption, it is improbable he will recover. He was unable to travel to England himself to rescue you from the predicament you had fallen into, but he pleaded with Mr. Mason to take immediate action to prevent the illegitimate marriage. He directed him to me for assistance. I acted swiftly and am thankful I wasn't too late, as you must undoubtedly be as well. If I weren't completely convinced your uncle would be deceased before you could reach Madeira, I would recommend you accompany Mr. Mason back; but under the circumstances, I believe it's best for you to remain in England until you receive further news from or about Mr. Eyre. Do we have any other reason to linger?" he asked Mr. Mason.
"No, no—let's depart," Mr. Mason replied anxiously. Without waiting to say goodbye to Mr. Rochester, they left through the front door. The clergyman stayed briefly to exchange a few words, either advising or reprimanding his arrogant parishioner; having completed this duty, he also left.
