As we went down the stairs, the solicitor turned to me and said, “You are entirely innocent, madam; your uncle will be pleased to know this—if he is still living—when Mr. Mason gets back to Madeira.” I asked, surprised, “My uncle? What do you know of him?” The solicitor explained that Mr. Mason was familiar with my uncle, Mr. Eyre, who had served as his firm’s correspondent in Funchal for several years. When my uncle received my letter about my planned marriage to Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason was with him in Madeira, recovering his health before returning to Jamaica. Since Mr. Eyre knew my fiancé’s name, he discussed the news with Mr. Mason, who, shocked and upset, disclosed the truth of the situation. Sadly, my uncle was very ill with a disease from which he was unlikely to recover, so he couldn’t come to England himself to protect me, but he asked Mr. Mason to act quickly to stop the wrongful marriage, directing him to the solicitor for help. The solicitor hurried to take action, glad he wasn’t too late, and said I must be equally relieved. He added that since my uncle was probably dying and unlikely to survive until I could get to Madeira, there was little point in travelling there now, and I should wait in England for further news. The solicitor then checked with Mr. Mason if there was anything else to do, and Mr. Mason, anxious, insisted it was time to leave. Without saying goodbye to Mr. Rochester, they both promptly exited through the main door. The clergyman remained a short while to offer either advice or a stern word to Mr. Rochester, and then he, too, left.

events.title: Jane's Solitary Despair and Crushing Realization
detailed_summary: Having retreated to her own room, Jane heard the final guest depart, then shut and bolted her door.
She felt too calm for immediate weeping or mourning; instead, she mechanically removed her wedding dress and put on the plain gown she thought she had worn for the last time the previous day.
Sitting down, overcome with weakness and tiredness, she leaned on a table, her head in her arms, and finally allowed herself to think and process the morning's devastating events.

She reflected on the outwardly calm yet deeply disruptive nature of the church incident: the quiet objection, the brief interrogations, Mr. Rochester's admission, and the horrifying revelation of Bertha.
She found herself physically unaltered in her familiar room, yet the Jane Eyre of yesterday – hopeful and on the verge of becoming a bride – was gone, her life and prospects shattered.
Her existence felt suddenly cold and solitary, like a midsummer day struck by a winter storm, her hopes dead, akin to the first-born in Egypt struck by a sudden doom.
Her cherished wishes lay like lifeless corpses, and her love for Mr. Rochester, a feeling he had cultivated in her, shivered in her heart, blighted by the destruction of faith and confidence.

She realized Mr. Rochester was not the man she believed him to be; his stainless truthfulness was an illusion, and she knew she must leave his presence and Thornfield, anticipating he would no longer want her after this thwarted passion.
A sense of her own blindness and weakness overwhelmed her, as if sinking into an eddying darkness, awaiting an inevitable torrent of despair with no will or strength to resist.
Only the faint remembrance of God stirred within her, prompting an unuttered prayer for help in her profound trouble.
The full weight of her desolation – her lost life, love, hope, and faith – then crashed over her in an indescribable hour of bitter anguish and sorrow, feeling as if she were drowning in deep waters.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I heard him go as I stood at the half-open door of my own room, to which I had now withdrawn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That bitter hour cannot be described: in truth, “the waters came into my soul; I sank in deep mire: I felt no standing; I came into deep waters; the floods overflowed me.”

events.text_segment:
I heard him go as I stood at the half-open door of my own room, to which I had now withdrawn. The house cleared, I shut myself in, fastened the bolt that none might intrude, and proceeded—not to weep, not to mourn, I was yet too calm for that, but—mechanically to take off the wedding dress, and replace it by the stuff gown I had worn yesterday, as I thought, for the last time. I then sat down: I felt weak and tired. I leaned my arms on a table, and my head dropped on them. And now I thought: till now I had only heard, seen, moved—followed up and down where I was led or dragged—watched event rush on event, disclosure open beyond disclosure: but now, I thought.
The morning had been a quiet morning enough—all except the brief scene with the lunatic: the transaction in the church had not been noisy; there was no explosion of passion, no loud altercation, no dispute, no defiance or challenge, no tears, no sobs: a few words had been spoken, a calmly pronounced objection to the marriage made; some stern, short questions put by Mr. Rochester; answers, explanations given, evidence adduced; an open admission of the truth had been uttered by my master; then the living proof had been seen; the intruders were gone, and all was over.
I was in my own room as usual—just myself, without obvious change: nothing had smitten me, or scathed me, or maimed me. And yet where was the Jane Eyre of yesterday?—where was her life?—where were her prospects?
Jane Eyre, who had been an ardent, expectant woman—almost a bride, was a cold, solitary girl again: her life was pale; her prospects were desolate. A Christmas frost had come at midsummer; a white December storm had whirled over June; ice glazed the ripe apples, drifts crushed the blowing roses; on hayfield and cornfield lay a frozen shroud: lanes which last night blushed full of flowers, to-day were pathless with untrodden snow; and the woods, which twelve hours since waved leafy and fragrant as groves between the tropics, now spread, waste, wild, and white as pine-forests in wintry Norway. My hopes were all dead—struck with a subtle doom, such as, in one night, fell on all the first-born in the land of Egypt. I looked on my cherished wishes, yesterday so blooming and glowing; they lay stark, chill, livid corpses that could never revive. I looked at my love: that feeling which was my master’s—which he had created; it shivered in my heart, like a suffering child in a cold cradle; sickness and anguish had seized it; it could not seek Mr. Rochester’s arms—it could not derive warmth from his breast. Oh, never more could it turn to him; for faith was blighted—confidence destroyed! Mr. Rochester was not to me what he had been; for he was not what I had thought him. I would not ascribe vice to him; I would not say he had betrayed me; but the attribute of stainless truth was gone from his idea, and from his presence I must go: that I perceived well. When—how—whither, I could not yet discern; but he himself, I doubted not, would hurry me from Thornfield. Real affection, it seemed, he could not have for me; it had been only fitful passion: that was balked; he would want me no more. I should fear even to cross his path now: my view must be hateful to him. Oh, how blind had been my eyes! How weak my conduct!
My eyes were covered and closed: eddying darkness seemed to swim round me, and reflection came in as black and confused a flow. Self-abandoned, relaxed, and effortless, I seemed to have laid me down in the dried-up bed of a great river; I heard a flood loosened in remote mountains, and felt the torrent come: to rise I had no will, to flee I had no strength. I lay faint, longing to be dead. One idea only still throbbed life-like within me—a remembrance of God: it begot an unuttered prayer: these words went wandering up and down in my rayless mind, as something that should be whispered, but no energy was found to express them—
“Be not far from me, for trouble is near: there is none to help.”
It was near: and as I had lifted no petition to Heaven to avert it—as I had neither joined my hands, nor bent my knees, nor moved my lips—it came: in full heavy swing the torrent poured over me. The whole consciousness of my life lorn, my love lost, my hope quenched, my faith death-struck, swayed full and mighty above me in one sullen mass. That bitter hour cannot be described: in truth, “the waters came into my soul; I sank in deep mire: I felt no standing; I came into deep waters; the floods overflowed me.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I heard him leave as I stood by the partially open door of my room, where I had retreated. With the house now empty, I went inside, bolted the door to keep anyone out, and began – not to cry or mourn, as I was still too composed for that – but automatically to remove the wedding dress and put back on the plain fabric dress I had worn yesterday, believing it was for the last time. I then sat down, feeling weak and worn out. I rested my arms on a table and let my head fall onto them. And now I started thinking; until this point, I had merely reacted, observed, moved – simply following where I was directed or pulled – watching events unfold one after another, secrets being revealed progressively: but now, I was processing. The morning had been quite calm overall – apart from the brief incident with the madwoman. The events in the church hadn't been chaotic; there was no emotional outburst, no loud argument, no dispute, no challenge or defiance, no tears, no crying. Just a few words spoken, a calmly stated objection to the marriage was made, followed by some sharp, short questions from Mr. Rochester, answers, explanations given, proof presented, my master openly admitting the truth, and then the sight of the living evidence. The people who intervened were gone, and it was finished. I was in my room just as usual – physically, I seemed unchanged; nothing had struck me, scorched me, or injured me. Yet, where was the Jane Eyre from yesterday? Where was her life? Where were her prospects for the future? Jane Eyre, who had been a passionate, hopeful woman, almost a wife, was now just a cold, lonely girl again. Her life felt bleak, her future prospects desolate. It was like a harsh winter frost had arrived in midsummer; a snowstorm in December had swept through June. Ice covered the ripe apples, snowdrifts crushed the blooming roses. A frozen sheet lay over the hayfields and cornfields. The paths that were full of colourful flowers last night were today impassable with fresh snow, and the woods that twelve hours ago were lush and fragrant like tropical forests now stretched out, empty, desolate, and white like pine forests in a Norwegian winter. My hopes were all dead, struck down by a swift and final blow, similar to the doom that fell on all the first-born in Egypt in a single night. I looked at my cherished desires, so vibrant and bright yesterday; they lay lifeless, cold, pale bodies that could never be revived. I looked at my love, the feeling that belonged to my master, which he had created. It shivered in my heart like a suffering child in a cold crib; illness and pain had gripped it. It couldn't seek comfort in Mr. Rochester's arms – it couldn't get warmth from his chest. Oh, it could never turn to him again, because my trust was ruined – my confidence destroyed! Mr. Rochester was not the person he had been to me, because he was not the person I had believed him to be. I wouldn't accuse him of wickedness; I wouldn't say he deliberately deceived me, but the quality of absolute honesty was gone from how I saw him, and I understood clearly that I must leave his presence. I couldn't yet figure out when, how, or where, but I had no doubt that he himself would quickly remove me from Thornfield. It seemed he couldn't have had true affection for me; it must have only been fleeting passion, which was now stopped. He wouldn't want me anymore. I would even be scared to cross his path now; the sight of me must be hateful to him. Oh, how blind I had been! How foolish my actions had seemed! My eyes were covered and closed; a swirling darkness seemed to surround me, and my thoughts came in a similarly dark and jumbled rush. Feeling completely resigned, weak, and incapable, I felt as though I had collapsed into the dry riverbed of a great river. I heard a flood unleashed in distant mountains and felt the rush of the current coming. I had no will to get up, no strength to run. I lay there, faint and longing to die. Only one thought still felt alive within me – a memory of God. This prompted a silent prayer. These words wandered in my dark mind, like something that should be whispered, but I lacked the energy to express them aloud: "Do not be far from me, for trouble is near; there is no one to help." It was indeed near. And since I had not lifted any prayer to Heaven to prevent it – as I had neither clasped my hands, nor knelt down, nor moved my lips – it came. The torrent poured over me in a full, heavy surge. The entire weight of my ruined life, my lost love, my extinguished hope, my faith struck dead, hung powerfully and completely over me in one dark mass. That painful hour cannot be put into words. Truly, as the saying goes, "the waters came into my soul; I sank in deep mire: I felt no standing; I came into deep waters; the floods overflowed me."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I stood by the half-open door of my own room, listening to his departure before withdrawing inside. Once the house was empty, I locked myself in to ensure I wouldn’t be disturbed. I didn’t cry or grieve—I was still too composed for that. Instead, almost automatically, I removed the wedding dress and changed back into the plain gown I thought I’d worn for the last time the day before. Feeling drained, I sat down, rested my arms on the table, and lowered my head. Up to now, I'd only processed events as they happened, acted as I was directed, witnessing one shocking revelation after another. But now, I had the space to think. 

That morning had been calm overall, apart from the brief outburst with the madwoman. The scene at the church had been quiet—there were no tempers flaring, no loud arguments, no tears. Just a few words exchanged: an objection to the marriage stated, some short, stern questions, explanations, proof provided, and finally, Mr. Rochester himself admitted the truth. The evidence had been shown, the strangers had left, and it was over. 

Back in my room, everything seemed unchanged on the surface. I wasn’t physically hurt or changed. Yet, I questioned the fate of the Jane Eyre from the day before—her life and her hopes for the future. The woman who had been full of anticipation and on the verge of marriage was now alone and desolate again. All the promise and excitement had vanished; it was as if a harsh winter had descended in the middle of summer, destroying everything in its path. My hopes and dreams, vibrant and alive only yesterday, now seemed irreversibly dead. The love I felt, which Mr. Rochester had inspired in me, now felt cold and miserable—as if it were sick and suffering and could no longer be comforted by him. I could no longer trust him, because he was not the man I believed him to be. He hadn’t betrayed me maliciously, but he had lost the perfect honesty I saw in him, and I knew I had to leave. I didn’t know when or how, but I immediately sensed that he would want me gone from Thornfield now that his secret was out. Maybe his feelings for me had never been genuine love, just a fleeting passion that was now over. I even felt that he’d want to avoid seeing me, and I was ashamed at my own naiveté.

My eyes closed as confusion and dark thoughts overwhelmed me. I felt powerless, as if I were lying at the bottom of a dry riverbed, awaiting a torrent released from far away that I couldn’t escape or resist. I longed for oblivion. Only one thought remained: a sense of God, which stirred a silent prayer inside me—the words repeating silently: “Be not far from me, for trouble is near: there is none to help.” Trouble truly was close. Since I hadn’t prayed for its prevention, it came roaring over me, and the full painful realization of my situation crashed down. The despair of lost love, hope, and faith overcame me completely. The agony of that moment was beyond description; I felt emotionally submerged, trapped, and overwhelmed.

events.title: Jane's Inner Conflict and Collapse
detailed_summary: Jane grapples with the devastating realization that she must leave Thornfield and Mr. Rochester immediately.
She experiences an internal battle, where her desire to stay and avoid further pain is overpowered by her conscience, which dictates the necessity of her departure.
Her conscience, personified as a tyrant, warns her of deeper agony if she succumbs to her passion.
Feeling utterly alone and overwhelmed, Jane rises, her body weakened by emotional turmoil and lack of sustenance throughout the day.
She notes with a pang that no one, not even Adèle or Mrs. Fairfax, has checked on her, leading her to reflect on how friends forget the unfortunate.
As she attempts to leave her room, dizziness and feebleness overcome her, causing her to stumble and fall.
She is caught by Mr. Rochester, who had been waiting outside her door.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Some time in the afternoon I raised my head, and looking round and seeing the western sun gilding the sign of its decline on the wall, I asked, “What am I to do?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I looked up—I was supported by Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold.

events.text_segment:
Some time in the afternoon I raised my head, and looking round and seeing the western sun gilding the sign of its decline on the wall, I asked, “What am I to do?”
But the answer my mind gave—“Leave Thornfield at once”—was so prompt, so dread, that I stopped my ears. I said I could not bear such words now. “That I am not Edward Rochester’s bride is the least part of my woe,” I alleged: “that I have wakened out of most glorious dreams, and found them all void and vain, is a horror I could bear and master; but that I must leave him decidedly, instantly, entirely, is intolerable. I cannot do it.”
But, then, a voice within me averred that I could do it and foretold that I should do it. I wrestled with my own resolution: I wanted to be weak that I might avoid the awful passage of further suffering I saw laid out for me; and Conscience, turned tyrant, held Passion by the throat, told her tauntingly, she had yet but dipped her dainty foot in the slough, and swore that with that arm of iron he would thrust her down to unsounded depths of agony.
“Let me be torn away, then” I cried. “Let another help me!”
“No; you shall tear yourself away, none shall help you: you shall yourself pluck out your right eye; yourself cut off your right hand: your heart shall be the victim, and you the priest to transfix it.”
I rose up suddenly, terror-struck at the solitude which so ruthless a judge haunted,—at the silence which so awful a voice filled. My head swam as I stood erect. I perceived that I was sickening from excitement and inanition; neither meat nor drink had passed my lips that day, for I had taken no breakfast. And, with a strange pang, I now reflected that, long as I had been shut up here, no message had been sent to ask how I was, or to invite me to come down: not even little Adèle had tapped at the door; not even Mrs. Fairfax had sought me. “Friends always forget those whom fortune forsakes,” I murmured, as I undrew the bolt and passed out. I stumbled over an obstacle: my head was still dizzy, my sight was dim, and my limbs were feeble. I could not soon recover myself. I fell, but not on to the ground: an outstretched arm caught me. I looked up—I was supported by Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Late in the afternoon, I lifted my head. Seeing the sun's light painting the western wall, marking the day's end, I questioned, "What should I do?" However, the immediate and terrifying response from my mind, "Leave Thornfield immediately," was so overwhelming that I covered my ears. I declared I couldn't bear to hear those words then. I asserted that the least of my suffering was not being Edward Rochester's bride; I could endure the pain of waking from wonderful dreams to find them empty and meaningless. But, having to leave him permanently, instantly, and completely was unbearable. I insisted I couldn't do it. Yet, an inner voice asserted that I could and would do it. I fought against my own resolve. I wished to be weak to avoid the terrible future suffering I saw ahead. My conscience, acting like a tyrant, held Passion captive, sarcastically saying she had only just begun to experience the difficulty, and swore that with an unyielding grip, he would force her into unimaginable depths of pain. "Then let me be torn away!" I cried. "Let someone else help me!" The inner voice replied, "No, you will tear yourself away; no one will help you. You will sacrifice your own dearest part; you will sever your own strength. Your heart will be the victim, and you will be the one to pierce it." I suddenly stood up, frightened by the loneliness where such a harsh judge resided, and by the silence filled by such a terrifying voice. My head swam as I stood. I realised I was becoming ill from stress and lack of food, as I hadn't eaten or drunk anything all day. With a sharp ache, I thought how long I had been alone in my room without anyone sending a message to check on me or invite me downstairs. Not even little Adèle had knocked, nor had Mrs. Fairfax sought me out. "Friends always forget those whom fate abandons," I whispered as I unbolted the door and stepped out. I stumbled over something. My head was still spinning, my vision blurry, and my legs weak. I couldn't regain my balance quickly. I fell, but I didn't hit the floor. An outstretched arm caught me. I looked up and saw I was being supported by Mr. Rochester, who was seated in a chair just outside my room's doorway.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Later that afternoon, I lifted my head and, noticing how the sun in the west cast fading light across the wall, I wondered aloud what I should do. My mind immediately replied, urging me to leave Thornfield without delay—a response so frightening that I tried to block it out, insisting I couldn’t handle such an idea right then. I told myself that not being Mr. Rochester’s bride was only a small part of my pain. The true anguish was in waking from beautiful dreams and finding them empty, but what I truly couldn’t bear was the thought of leaving him completely and at once. Still, something inside me insisted that I not only could, but must, do it. I struggled with my determination, wishing I could be weak and avoid the pain I knew was ahead. But my conscience—the tyrant—overpowered my feelings, declaring that my suffering had only just begun and threatening to drag me through deeper agony. In desperation, I wished for someone to make the separation for me, but the inner voice insisted that I must do it myself, comparing it to tearing out my own eye or hand and being both the priest and the sacrifice. Suddenly, filled with fear at being alone with such pitiless self-judgment, I stood up, feeling dizzy and weak from lack of food, since I hadn’t eaten all day. I realized that no one had sent word to ask after me or invited me downstairs—not even little Adèle or Mrs. Fairfax had come. I reflected bitterly that people always abandon those whom misfortune strikes. Unlocking my door, I left my room, but stumbled from weakness; however, before I hit the ground, someone caught me. Looking up, I saw it was Mr. Rochester, seated in a chair at my doorway, supporting me.

events.title: Rochester's Anguish and Jane's Tacit Forgiveness
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester expresses his distress at Jane's solitary grieving and her apparent lack of tears, admitting he had been waiting and listening outside her door.
He wishes she had confronted him angrily rather than suffering alone.
He passionately expresses his profound remorse for wounding her, comparing his error to a man mistakenly slaughtering his beloved lamb.
Jane, witnessing his deep remorse, genuine pity, and unchanged love, forgives him completely in her heart, though she does not voice it.
Feeling physically exhausted and ill, Jane requests water.
Mr. Rochester carries her downstairs to the library, where she slowly revives by the fire with wine and food he provides.
Internally, she still feels the unbearable weight of her decision to leave him, despite her love.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You come out at last,” he said.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I must leave him, it appears. I do not want to leave him—I cannot leave him.”

events.text_segment:
“You come out at last,” he said. “Well, I have been waiting for you long, and listening: yet not one movement have I heard, nor one sob: five minutes more of that death-like hush, and I should have forced the lock like a burglar. So you shun me?—you shut yourself up and grieve alone! I would rather you had come and upbraided me with vehemence. You are passionate: I expected a scene of some kind. I was prepared for the hot rain of tears; only I wanted them to be shed on my breast: now a senseless floor has received them, or your drenched handkerchief. But I err: you have not wept at all! I see a white cheek and a faded eye, but no trace of tears. I suppose, then, your heart has been weeping blood?
“Well, Jane! not a word of reproach? Nothing bitter—nothing poignant? Nothing to cut a feeling or sting a passion? You sit quietly where I have placed you, and regard me with a weary, passive look.
“Jane, I never meant to wound you thus. If the man who had but one little ewe lamb that was dear to him as a daughter, that ate of his bread and drank of his cup, and lay in his bosom, had by some mistake slaughtered it at the shambles, he would not have rued his bloody blunder more than I now rue mine. Will you ever forgive me?”
Reader, I forgave him at the moment and on the spot. There was such deep remorse in his eye, such true pity in his tone, such manly energy in his manner; and besides, there was such unchanged love in his whole look and mien—I forgave him all: yet not in words, not outwardly; only at my heart’s core.
“You know I am a scoundrel, Jane?” ere long he inquired wistfully—wondering, I suppose, at my continued silence and tameness, the result rather of weakness than of will.
“Yes, sir.”
“Then tell me so roundly and sharply—don’t spare me.”
“I cannot: I am tired and sick. I want some water.” He heaved a sort of shuddering sigh, and taking me in his arms, carried me downstairs. At first I did not know to what room he had borne me; all was cloudy to my glazed sight: presently I felt the reviving warmth of a fire; for, summer as it was, I had become icy cold in my chamber. He put wine to my lips; I tasted it and revived; then I ate something he offered me, and was soon myself. I was in the library—sitting in his chair—he was quite near. “If I could go out of life now, without too sharp a pang, it would be well for me,” I thought; “then I should not have to make the effort of cracking my heart-strings in rending them from among Mr. Rochester’s. I must leave him, it appears. I do not want to leave him—I cannot leave him.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Rochester found Jane, saying, "You've finally come out." He explained he had been waiting and listening for a long time, hearing no sound, not even a sob. He confessed that five more minutes of that unnatural quiet and he would have broken down the door like a burglar. He accused her of avoiding him, shutting herself away to grieve alone. He preferred she had confronted him angrily, expecting an emotional outburst given her passionate nature. He was ready for a torrent of tears, only wishing they had been shed on his chest instead of the floor or a soaked handkerchief. However, correcting himself, he noted she hadn't cried at all, seeing only pallor and tired eyes, no sign of tears. He then speculated her heart must have been weeping blood.

He continued, "Well, Jane, no accusations? Nothing harsh or painful? Nothing to wound a feeling or provoke a strong reaction? You just sit calmly where I placed you, looking at me with a weary, resigned expression."

"Jane," he stated, "I never intended to hurt you like this. If a man who cherished his single little ewe lamb like a daughter, one that shared his food, drink, and slept in his arms, accidentally slaughtered it, he would regret his mistake no more than I regret mine now. Can you ever forgive me?"

Reader, I forgave him instantly. His eyes showed such profound remorse, his voice held such true pity, his manner such strong resolution; and beyond that, his entire appearance and demeanor revealed unchanged love—I forgave everything. Not with words, not externally, but deep within my heart.

After a moment, he asked wistfully, perhaps surprised by my continued silence and subdued state, which stemmed more from weakness than unwillingness, "You know I'm a scoundrel, Jane?"

"Yes, sir," I replied.

"Then tell me so plainly and sharply—don't hold back," he urged.

"I cannot," I said. "I am exhausted and unwell. I need some water." He let out a shaky sigh and, picking me up, carried me downstairs. At first, my vision was clouded, and I didn't know where he had taken me. Soon, I felt the restoring warmth of a fire; despite being summer, I had become icy cold in my room. He offered me wine, which I sipped and felt revived. Then I ate something he gave me and quickly felt like myself again. I was in the library, sitting in his chair, with him very close by. "If I could die now without too much pain, it would be best," I thought, "then I wouldn't have to make the effort of tearing my heart-strings away from Mr. Rochester. It seems I must leave him. I don't want to leave him—I can't leave him."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: He finally spoke, saying he had been waiting and listening for me, but heard no sounds, not even a sob; if the silence had lasted much longer, he would have broken in like a thief. He accused me of avoiding him, locking myself away to grieve alone, and said he would have preferred if I had confronted him angrily. He expected tears and a dramatic scene, hoping I would weep on his chest rather than the floor or into my handkerchief. But he saw no evidence that I had cried, just a pale face and tired eyes, so he guessed that my heart must be silently breaking. He observed that I made no complaints or accusations, but just sat passively and looked at him with exhaustion. He insisted he never wanted to hurt me, and compared himself to a man who had accidentally killed his beloved pet, saying his regret was just as great and he wondered if I could forgive him. I did forgive him instantly, moved by the genuine remorse and affection in his voice and manner, though I did not say so aloud—my forgiveness was silent and inward. He asked me if I believed he was a scoundrel, and I agreed, but could not muster the energy to reproach him, only saying I was tired and unwell. He sighed, carried me downstairs, and tried to revive me with wine and food until I recovered. I realized I was in the library with him close by, and thought that death would be easier than the pain of separating myself from Mr. Rochester, since it appeared we would have to part, though the idea was unbearable to me.

events.title: The Moral Impasse and Rochester's Desperate Proposals
detailed_summary: After Jane revives, Rochester attempts to kiss her, but she turns away, reminding him that such affections are now forbidden.
Rochester questions her rejection, assuming she views him as tainted by his marriage to Bertha Mason.
He interprets her stance as an intention to become a complete stranger, living under his roof merely as Adèle's governess.
Jane firmly states that all has changed and she must change too, announcing that Adèle will need a new governess, signifying her own departure.
Rochester reveals Adèle is already set to go to school and that neither he nor Jane will remain at the "accursed" Thornfield.

He explains his initial concealment of Bertha's existence, citing fear for Adèle's care and the unsuitability of Ferndean for Bertha's confinement due to its unhealthy location, asserting he wouldn't resort to indirect harm.
He describes his plans to confine Bertha at Thornfield with Mrs. Poole, detailing Bertha's violent tendencies with raw hatred.
Jane interjects, calling his vindictive antipathy towards the unfortunate Bertha cruel, as her madness is not her fault.

Rochester passionately clarifies that his hatred for Bertha stems not from her madness but her inherent nature, contrasting this with the unwavering love and care he would offer Jane if she were afflicted.
He speaks of taking Jane to a secure sanctuary, away from Thornfield's miseries.
When Jane suggests he take Adèle for companionship, Rochester reveals his true intention: Jane is to share his solitude and retirement.
Jane's mute dissent agitates Rochester, who threatens force if she doesn't listen to reason.
Jane calms him by agreeing to talk, then allows her tears to flow, which subdues him further. She continues to resist his physical closeness.
He laments that she must not love him if she recoils from his touch now that his marital status is known.
Jane confesses her enduring love but reiterates that she cannot indulge or show it, and this expression must be her last.
Rochester pushes back, suggesting she will become his wife "virtually and nominally" in a secluded life in France, not his mistress.

Jane stands firm, stating that since his wife lives, any union with him would indeed make her his mistress, a sophistry she rejects. Rochester grows increasingly agitated, and Jane involuntarily cries for divine help.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “How are you now, Jane?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The words “God help me!” burst involuntarily from my lips.

events.text_segment:
“How are you now, Jane?”
“Much better, sir; I shall be well soon.”
“Taste the wine again, Jane.”
I obeyed him; then he put the glass on the table, stood before me, and looked at me attentively. Suddenly he turned away, with an inarticulate exclamation, full of passionate emotion of some kind; he walked fast through the room and came back; he stooped towards me as if to kiss me; but I remembered caresses were now forbidden. I turned my face away and put his aside.
“What!—How is this?” he exclaimed hastily. “Oh, I know! you won’t kiss the husband of Bertha Mason? You consider my arms filled and my embraces appropriated?”
“At any rate, there is neither room nor claim for me, sir.”
“Why, Jane? I will spare you the trouble of much talking; I will answer for you—Because I have a wife already, you would reply.—I guess rightly?”
“Yes.”
“If you think so, you must have a strange opinion of me; you must regard me as a plotting profligate—a base and low rake who has been simulating disinterested love in order to draw you into a snare deliberately laid, and strip you of honour and rob you of self-respect. What do you say to that? I see you can say nothing: in the first place, you are faint still, and have enough to do to draw your breath; in the second place, you cannot yet accustom yourself to accuse and revile me, and besides, the flood-gates of tears are opened, and they would rush out if you spoke much; and you have no desire to expostulate, to upbraid, to make a scene: you are thinking how to act—talking you consider is of no use. I know you—I am on my guard.”
“Sir, I do not wish to act against you,” I said; and my unsteady voice warned me to curtail my sentence.
“Not in your sense of the word, but in mine you are scheming to destroy me. You have as good as said that I am a married man—as a married man you will shun me, keep out of my way: just now you have refused to kiss me. You intend to make yourself a complete stranger to me: to live under this roof only as Adèle’s governess; if ever I say a friendly word to you, if ever a friendly feeling inclines you again to me, you will say,—‘That man had nearly made me his mistress: I must be ice and rock to him;’ and ice and rock you will accordingly become.”
I cleared and steadied my voice to reply: “All is changed about me, sir; I must change too—there is no doubt of that; and to avoid fluctuations of feeling, and continual combats with recollections and associations, there is only one way—Adèle must have a new governess, sir.”
“Oh, Adèle will go to school—I have settled that already; nor do I mean to torment you with the hideous associations and recollections of Thornfield Hall—this accursed place—this tent of Achan—this insolent vault, offering the ghastliness of living death to the light of the open sky—this narrow stone hell, with its one real fiend, worse than a legion of such as we imagine. Jane, you shall not stay here, nor will I. I was wrong ever to bring you to Thornfield Hall, knowing as I did how it was haunted. I charged them to conceal from you, before I ever saw you, all knowledge of the curse of the place; merely because I feared Adèle never would have a governess to stay if she knew with what inmate she was housed, and my plans would not permit me to remove the maniac elsewhere—though I possess an old house, Ferndean Manor, even more retired and hidden than this, where I could have lodged her safely enough, had not a scruple about the unhealthiness of the situation, in the heart of a wood, made my conscience recoil from the arrangement. Probably those damp walls would soon have eased me of her charge: but to each villain his own vice; and mine is not a tendency to indirect assassination, even of what I most hate.
“Concealing the mad-woman’s neighbourhood from you, however, was something like covering a child with a cloak and laying it down near a upas-tree: that demon’s vicinage is poisoned, and always was. But I’ll shut up Thornfield Hall: I’ll nail up the front door and board the lower windows: I’ll give Mrs. Poole two hundred a year to live here with my wife, as you term that fearful hag: Grace will do much for money, and she shall have her son, the keeper at Grimsby Retreat, to bear her company and be at hand to give her aid in the paroxysms, when my wife is prompted by her familiar to burn people in their beds at night, to stab them, to bite their flesh from their bones, and so on—”
“Sir,” I interrupted him, “you are inexorable for that unfortunate lady: you speak of her with hate—with vindictive antipathy. It is cruel—she cannot help being mad.”
“Jane, my little darling (so I will call you, for so you are), you don’t know what you are talking about; you misjudge me again: it is not because she is mad I hate her. If you were mad, do you think I should hate you?”
“I do indeed, sir.”
“Then you are mistaken, and you know nothing about me, and nothing about the sort of love of which I am capable. Every atom of your flesh is as dear to me as my own: in pain and sickness it would still be dear. Your mind is my treasure, and if it were broken, it would be my treasure still: if you raved, my arms should confine you, and not a strait waistcoat—your grasp, even in fury, would have a charm for me: if you flew at me as wildly as that woman did this morning, I should receive you in an embrace, at least as fond as it would be restrictive. I should not shrink from you with disgust as I did from her: in your quiet moments you should have no watcher and no nurse but me; and I could hang over you with untiring tenderness, though you gave me no smile in return; and never weary of gazing into your eyes, though they had no longer a ray of recognition for me.—But why do I follow that train of ideas? I was talking of removing you from Thornfield. All, you know, is prepared for prompt departure: to-morrow you shall go. I only ask you to endure one more night under this roof, Jane; and then, farewell to its miseries and terrors for ever! I have a place to repair to, which will be a secure sanctuary from hateful reminiscences, from unwelcome intrusion—even from falsehood and slander.”
“And take Adèle with you, sir,” I interrupted; “she will be a companion for you.”
“What do you mean, Jane? I told you I would send Adèle to school; and what do I want with a child for a companion, and not my own child,—a French dancer’s bastard? Why do you importune me about her! I say, why do you assign Adèle to me for a companion?”
“You spoke of a retirement, sir; and retirement and solitude are dull: too dull for you.”
“Solitude! solitude!” he reiterated with irritation. “I see I must come to an explanation. I don’t know what sphynx-like expression is forming in your countenance. You are to share my solitude. Do you understand?”
I shook my head: it required a degree of courage, excited as he was becoming, even to risk that mute sign of dissent. He had been walking fast about the room, and he stopped, as if suddenly rooted to one spot. He looked at me long and hard: I turned my eyes from him, fixed them on the fire, and tried to assume and maintain a quiet, collected aspect.
“Now for the hitch in Jane’s character,” he said at last, speaking more calmly than from his look I had expected him to speak. “The reel of silk has run smoothly enough so far; but I always knew there would come a knot and a puzzle: here it is. Now for vexation, and exasperation, and endless trouble! By God! I long to exert a fraction of Samson’s strength, and break the entanglement like tow!”
He recommenced his walk, but soon again stopped, and this time just before me.
“Jane! will you hear reason?” (he stooped and approached his lips to my ear); “because, if you won’t, I’ll try violence.” His voice was hoarse; his look that of a man who is just about to burst an insufferable bond and plunge headlong into wild license. I saw that in another moment, and with one impetus of frenzy more, I should be able to do nothing with him. The present—the passing second of time—was all I had in which to control and restrain him: a movement of repulsion, flight, fear would have sealed my doom,—and his. But I was not afraid: not in the least. I felt an inward power; a sense of influence, which supported me. The crisis was perilous; but not without its charm: such as the Indian, perhaps, feels when he slips over the rapid in his canoe. I took hold of his clenched hand, loosened the contorted fingers, and said to him, soothingly—
“Sit down; I’ll talk to you as long as you like, and hear all you have to say, whether reasonable or unreasonable.”
He sat down: but he did not get leave to speak directly. I had been struggling with tears for some time: I had taken great pains to repress them, because I knew he would not like to see me weep. Now, however, I considered it well to let them flow as freely and as long as they liked. If the flood annoyed him, so much the better. So I gave way and cried heartily.
Soon I heard him earnestly entreating me to be composed. I said I could not while he was in such a passion.
“But I am not angry, Jane: I only love you too well; and you had steeled your little pale face with such a resolute, frozen look, I could not endure it. Hush, now, and wipe your eyes.”
His softened voice announced that he was subdued; so I, in my turn, became calm. Now he made an effort to rest his head on my shoulder, but I would not permit it. Then he would draw me to him: no.
“Jane! Jane!” he said, in such an accent of bitter sadness it thrilled along every nerve I had; “you don’t love me, then? It was only my station, and the rank of my wife, that you valued? Now that you think me disqualified to become your husband, you recoil from my touch as if I were some toad or ape.”
These words cut me: yet what could I do or I say? I ought probably to have done or said nothing; but I was so tortured by a sense of remorse at thus hurting his feelings, I could not control the wish to drop balm where I had wounded.
“I do love you,” I said, “more than ever: but I must not show or indulge the feeling: and this is the last time I must express it.”
“The last time, Jane! What! do you think you can live with me, and see me daily, and yet, if you still love me, be always cold and distant?”
“No, sir; that I am certain I could not; and therefore I see there is but one way: but you will be furious if I mention it.”
“Oh, mention it! If I storm, you have the art of weeping.”
“Mr. Rochester, I must leave you.”
“For how long, Jane? For a few minutes, while you smooth your hair—which is somewhat dishevelled; and bathe your face—which looks feverish?”
“I must leave Adèle and Thornfield. I must part with you for my whole life: I must begin a new existence among strange faces and strange scenes.”
“Of course: I told you you should. I pass over the madness about parting from me. You mean you must become a part of me. As to the new existence, it is all right: you shall yet be my wife: I am not married. You shall be Mrs. Rochester—both virtually and nominally. I shall keep only to you so long as you and I live. You shall go to a place I have in the south of France: a whitewashed villa on the shores of the Mediterranean. There you shall live a happy, and guarded, and most innocent life. Never fear that I wish to lure you into error—to make you my mistress. Why did you shake your head? Jane, you must be reasonable, or in truth I shall again become frantic.”
His voice and hand quivered: his large nostrils dilated; his eye blazed: still I dared to speak.
“Sir, your wife is living: that is a fact acknowledged this morning by yourself. If I lived with you as you desire, I should then be your mistress: to say otherwise is sophistical—is false.”
“Jane, I am not a gentle-tempered man—you forget that: I am not long-enduring; I am not cool and dispassionate. Out of pity to me and yourself, put your finger on my pulse, feel how it throbs, and—beware!”
He bared his wrist, and offered it to me: the blood was forsaking his cheek and lips, they were growing livid; I was distressed on all hands. To agitate him thus deeply, by a resistance he so abhorred, was cruel: to yield was out of the question. I did what human beings do instinctively when they are driven to utter extremity—looked for aid to one higher than man: the words “God help me!” burst involuntarily from my lips.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
“How are you feeling now, Jane?”
“Much better, sir; I expect to be fully recovered soon.”
“Drink some more wine, Jane.”
I did as he asked. He then placed the glass on the table, stood in front of me, and observed me closely. Suddenly, he turned away with an intense, emotional cry I couldn't quite make out. He paced quickly around the room before returning. He leaned towards me as if to kiss me, but I remembered that such expressions of affection were now forbidden. I turned my face away and gently pushed his head aside.
“What!—What’s the meaning of this?” he demanded quickly. “Ah, I understand! You won’t kiss the husband of Bertha Mason? You believe my embraces are already claimed and my arms occupied?”
“In any case, there is neither space nor justification for me, sir.”
“Tell me why, Jane? I’ll save you the effort of explaining; I’ll answer for you—Because I already have a wife, you would say. Am I right?”
“Yes.”
“If you believe that, you must have a bizarre impression of me; you must see me as a deceitful libertine—a base and vulgar rake who pretended genuine affection only to deliberately ensnare you and strip you of your reputation and self-respect. What do you think of that? I see you are unable to reply: firstly, you are still weak, barely able to breathe; secondly, you cannot yet bring yourself to condemn and insult me, and furthermore, your tears are ready to flow and would spill out if you spoke much; and you have no wish to argue, to scold, to cause a scene: you are considering how to act—talking, you believe, is pointless. I know you—I am prepared.”
“Sir, I have no desire to act against you,” I stated; the shakiness in my voice made me cut my sentence short.
“Not in your interpretation of the word, but in mine, you are planning my ruin. You have effectively stated that I am a married man—as a married man, you will avoid me, keep your distance: you just refused to kiss me. You intend to treat me like a complete stranger: to live under this roof only as Adèle’s governess; if I ever say something kind to you, if any warm feeling ever draws you to me again, you will tell yourself,—‘That man nearly made me his mistress: I must be utterly cold and unyielding to him;’ and you will indeed become cold and unyielding.”
I cleared and steadied my voice before answering: “My circumstances are entirely changed, sir; I must change as well—there is no doubt of it; and to prevent emotional instability, and constant battles with memories and associations, there is only one possible course—Adèle must have a new governess, sir.”
“Oh, Adèle will be sent to school—I’ve already arranged that; nor do I intend to torment you with the dreadful memories and associations of Thornfield Hall—this damned place—this cursed spot like Achan’s tent—this arrogant tomb, displaying the horror of living death to the open sky—this confined stone hell, with its single true demon, worse than a multitude of those we can imagine. Jane, you will not remain here, nor will I. It was a mistake to ever bring you to Thornfield Hall, knowing as I did its affliction. I instructed them to hide from you, before I even met you, any knowledge of the place’s curse; simply because I feared Adèle would never keep a governess if she knew the nature of the inmate she was housed with, and my plans did not allow me to move the madwoman elsewhere—though I own an old property, Ferndean Manor, even more isolated and hidden than this, where I could have lodged her securely enough, had not my conscience hesitated at the arrangement due to the unhealthiness of the location, deep within a wood. Those damp walls would probably have soon relieved me of her care: but every villain has his own vice; and mine is not a tendency towards indirect murder, even of what I detest most.
“Concealing the lunatic’s proximity from you, however, was akin to covering a child with a cloak and laying it near a poisonous tree: that demon’s presence is toxic, and always has been. But I will close up Thornfield Hall: I will board up the front door and cover the lower windows: I will pay Mrs. Poole two hundred pounds a year to reside here with my wife, as you call that terrifying woman: Grace is motivated by money, and she shall have her son, the attendant at Grimsby Retreat, to keep her company and be available to assist during the fits, when my wife is driven by her impulse to set people’s beds on fire at night, to stab them, to tear flesh from their bones, and so forth—”
“Sir,” I interrupted him, “you are merciless towards that unfortunate lady: you speak of her with hatred—with vengeful dislike. It is cruel—she cannot control her madness.”
“Jane, my dear little one (for that is what you are, and so I shall call you), you do not grasp the situation; you are mistaken about me again: I do not hate her because she is mad. If you were mad, do you believe I would hate you?”
“Yes, I truly do, sir.”
“Then you are wrong, and you understand nothing about me, and nothing about the depth of love I am capable of. Every part of your body is as precious to me as my own: in pain and illness, it would still be precious. Your mind is my treasure, and if it were broken, it would remain my treasure: if you raved, my arms would restrain you, not a straitjacket—your grip, even in anger, would hold a fascination for me: if you attacked me as wildly as that woman did this morning, I would hold you in an embrace, which would be both affectionate and restraining. I would not recoil from you with revulsion as I did from her: in your calm moments, you would have no one watching or nursing you but me; and I could lean over you with boundless tenderness, even if you offered no smile in return; and never tire of gazing into your eyes, even if they no longer held any recognition for me.—But why am I following that train of thought? I was discussing removing you from Thornfield. As you know, everything is prepared for immediate departure: you will leave tomorrow. I only ask you to endure one more night under this roof, Jane; and then, we say goodbye to its miseries and terrors forever! I have a destination to go to, which will be a safe refuge from hateful memories, from unwelcome intrusion—even from lies and slander.”
“And take Adèle with you, sir,” I interjected; “she would be company for you.”
“What do you mean, Jane? I told you I would send Adèle to school; and why would I want a child for a companion, and not even my own child,—a French dancer’s illegitimate daughter? Why do you pester me about her! Tell me, why do you propose Adèle as my companion?”
“You mentioned going into retirement, sir; and retirement and solitude are tedious: too tedious for you.”
“Solitude! solitude!” he repeated impatiently. “It is clear I must explain. I don’t know what enigmatic look is forming on your face. You are to share my solitude. Do you comprehend?”
I shook my head: it took considerable courage, given his increasing agitation, even to risk that silent gesture of disagreement. He had been pacing rapidly about the room, and he stopped, as if abruptly fixed to the spot. He looked at me for a long time with intensity: I averted my eyes from his, fixed them on the fire, and attempted to appear and remain calm and composed.
“Now for the flaw in Jane’s character,” he stated finally, speaking more calmly than his expression had led me to expect. “The spool of silk has unwound smoothly enough until now; but I always knew there would be a snag and a complication: here it is. Now comes annoyance, and irritation, and endless difficulty! By God! I yearn to use a fraction of Samson’s strength and break this entanglement like flimsy tow!”
He resumed pacing, but soon stopped again, this time directly in front of me.
“Jane! Will you listen to reason?” (he bent and brought his lips close to my ear); “because, if you refuse, I will resort to force.” His voice was rough; his expression was like that of a man on the verge of shattering an intolerable constraint and plunging recklessly into wild abandon. I saw that in another moment, and with one more surge of frenzy, I would have no power to control him. The present—the fleeting second—was all the time I had to control and restrain him: a movement of rejection, flight, or fear would have sealed my fate,—and his. But I was not afraid: not at all. I felt an inner strength; a sense of influence that supported me. The crisis was dangerous; but not without its appeal: perhaps like what the Indian feels when he navigates a rapid in his canoe. I took hold of his tightly clenched hand, gently uncurled his twisted fingers, and said to him, in a calming tone—
“Please sit down; I will speak with you for as long as you wish, and hear everything you have to say, whether it is sensible or not.”
He sat down: but he was not immediately permitted to speak. I had been struggling with tears for some time: I had made great efforts to suppress them, knowing he disliked seeing me cry. Now, however, I decided it was best to let them flow as freely and for as long as they needed. If the flood of tears bothered him, so much the better. So I gave way and cried heartily.
Soon I heard him earnestly pleading with me to compose myself. I said I could not while he was so agitated.
“But I am not angry, Jane: I simply love you too intensely; and you had hardened your little pale face with such a determined, icy look, I could not bear it. Quiet now, and wipe your eyes.”
His softened voice indicated that he was calmer; so I, in turn, became composed. He then attempted to rest his head on my shoulder, but I did not allow it. Next, he tried to pull me towards him: again, I resisted.
“Jane! Jane!” he said, with an accent of such bitter sorrow it sent shivers through every nerve; “So you do not love me, then? Was it only my social standing, and the status of my wife, that you valued? Now that you believe me unqualified to be your husband, you shrink from my touch as if I were some foul toad or ape.”
These words wounded me deeply: yet what could I do or say? I probably should have done or said nothing; but I was so tormented by a sense of guilt at hurting his feelings this way, I could not suppress the urge to soothe where I had hurt.
“I do love you,” I said, “more than ever: but I must not display or indulge that feeling: and this is the final time I must express it.”
“The final time, Jane! What! Do you think you can live with me, and see me every day, and yet, if you still love me, always remain cold and distant?”
“No, sir; I am certain I could not do that; and therefore, I see there is only one course of action: but you will be furious if I mention it.”
“Oh, speak it! If I get angry, you are skilled at weeping.”
“Mr. Rochester, I must leave you.”
“For how long, Jane? For a few minutes, while you smooth your hair—which is a little messy; and wash your face—which looks flushed with fever?”
“I must leave Adèle and Thornfield. I must separate from you for the rest of my life: I must start a new existence among unfamiliar people and places.”
“Of course: I told you that you should. I will disregard the irrational talk about parting from me. You mean you must become a part of me. As for the new existence, that is fine: you shall still be my wife: I am not married. You shall be Mrs. Rochester—both in reality and in name. I will be faithful only to you for as long as we both live. You shall go to a place I own in the south of France: a white-washed villa on the Mediterranean coast. There you shall live a happy, protected, and completely innocent life. Never fear that I intend to lead you astray—to make you my mistress. Why did you shake your head? Jane, you must be reasonable, or truly I shall become frantic again.”
His voice and hand trembled: his large nostrils flared; his eyes blazed: yet I dared to speak.
“Sir, your wife is alive: that is a fact you yourself admitted this morning. If I lived with you as you wish, I would then be your mistress: to claim otherwise is misleading—it is false.”
“Jane, I am not a mild-tempered man—you forget that: I am not patient; I am not calm and objective. Out of compassion for us both, feel my pulse, sense how it races, and—be careful!”
He exposed his wrist and offered it to me: the blood was draining from his cheeks and lips, they were becoming pale; I was distressed from all sides. To upset him so profoundly with a resistance he detested was cruel: to give in was impossible. I did what people instinctively do when pushed to their absolute limit—I sought help from a power greater than man: the words “God help me!” escaped my lips without conscious thought.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Rochester asked how I was feeling, and I assured him I was much improved and expected to recover soon. He urged me to drink some more wine, which I did. He observed me closely, then suddenly turned away, expressing a surge of strong emotion. He paced the room, returned, and bent as if to kiss me, but I reminded myself not to accept such gestures and turned away. He reacted with surprise, deducing that I could not bring myself to show affection to the husband of Bertha Mason — that I believed all his affection was already spoken for. I affirmed that there was no place for me any longer.

He concluded aloud that I rejected him because he already had a wife, and surmised that I must see him as a villain who deceitfully wooed me. He anticipated that I would not respond, as I was both weak and reluctant to accuse him. Tears welled up in me, preventing speech, and he perceived that my thoughts were on how to act, not what to say. When I finally spoke, I insisted I did not wish to harm him. He countered that my intention was nonetheless to avoid him as a married man. He lamented that I intended to remain at Thornfield in a strictly professional capacity, becoming distant and cold toward him. I agreed that everything around me had changed and I would have to leave as the only way forward.

He explained that Adèle would be sent away and that he meant to close Thornfield Hall, describing it with loathing as an unwholesome, haunted place. He admitted he had concealed the secret of his wife's presence out of self-interest and struggled with the idea of moving her elsewhere due to concerns about another estate's healthiness. He confessed that, though he hated his wife, he was not capable of indirect harm. He compared hiding her to putting a child near a poisonous tree, deciding instead to shut up the hall and pay Grace Poole well to care for his wife, even with the help of Grace's son.

I protested that he spoke unkindly about his afflicted wife, reminding him of her insanity. He insisted that it was not her madness that made him hate her and claimed he would still love me, even if I were in the same state. He described intensely how, even under the worst circumstances, his devotion to me would not waver.

Returning to the practical matter, he said that everything was in place for my swift departure, asking me to endure just one more night at Thornfield before leaving for good. He mentioned finding a new sanctuary for both of us. I suggested he bring Adèle for companionship, but he rejected the idea and clarified that he wished for me to share his future solitude. I shook my head, and he grew agitated as the underlying rift between us became apparent. He threatened that if reasoning failed, he would resort to force, but I managed to soothe him by asking him to sit so we could talk things through. Finally able to release my pent-up tears, I wept openly, which seemed to calm him.

Even so, he tried to embrace me but I refused. He expressed deep sadness, suspecting I no longer loved him and that my affections were only for his status. I confessed my enduring love but insisted it was no longer right to give it expression and that this must be the last time I admitted it. He wondered if I could continue living near him while hiding my feeling, but I said that was impossible and insisted I must leave altogether, starting a new life away from Thornfield and from him.

Rochester tried to reason with me, promising that I would be his only partner, that we could leave England and live blamelessly, but I refused, reminding him that his wife was still alive. To be with him on his terms would make me his mistress, a deception I could not accept. Rochester, his agitation apparent, pleaded for me to consider his feelings but I could not be swayed. Distressed by the pain I was causing him, I instinctively turned to God for strength.

events.title: Rochester's Harrowing Past: The Truth of His Marriage to Bertha Mason
detailed_summary: Rochester, realizing Jane's lack of understanding, decides to reveal the full history of his marriage to Bertha Mason.
He explains he was not the eldest son and his avaricious father, wanting to keep the estate intact for his brother Rowland, arranged a marriage for him with a wealthy West Indian heiress.
Sent to Jamaica, he was introduced to Bertha Mason, praised for her beauty, and admits he was naively dazzled by her and societal pressures, marrying her without true knowledge or love.
He recounts the shocking post-honeymoon discovery of Bertha's mother's madness and confinement, and that her younger brother was an "idiot."
He reveals his own father and brother were aware of the family's insanity but concealed it for the thirty thousand pound dowry.
He describes Bertha's nature as utterly alien to his own, her mind coarse and her temper violent, making their life together an unbearable torment.
He details his efforts to endure this, repressing his disgust and antipathy in secret.
He speaks of Bertha's rapid mental and moral deterioration over four years, her vices becoming so strong only cruelty could check them, which he refused to use.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I am a fool!” cried Mr. Rochester suddenly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Bertha Mason, the true daughter of an infamous mother, dragged me through all the hideous and degrading agonies which must attend a man bound to a wife at once intemperate and unchaste.

events.text_segment:
“I am a fool!” cried Mr. Rochester suddenly. “I keep telling her I am not married, and do not explain to her why. I forget she knows nothing of the character of that woman, or of the circumstances attending my infernal union with her. Oh, I am certain Jane will agree with me in opinion, when she knows all that I know! Just put your hand in mine, Janet—that I may have the evidence of touch as well as sight, to prove you are near me—and I will in a few words show you the real state of the case. Can you listen to me?”
“Yes, sir; for hours if you will.”
“I ask only minutes. Jane, did you ever hear or know that I was not the eldest son of my house: that I had once a brother older than I?”
“I remember Mrs. Fairfax told me so once.”
“And did you ever hear that my father was an avaricious, grasping man?”
“I have understood something to that effect.”
“Well, Jane, being so, it was his resolution to keep the property together; he could not bear the idea of dividing his estate and leaving me a fair portion: all, he resolved, should go to my brother, Rowland. Yet as little could he endure that a son of his should be a poor man. I must be provided for by a wealthy marriage. He sought me a partner betimes. Mr. Mason, a West India planter and merchant, was his old acquaintance. He was certain his possessions were real and vast: he made inquiries. Mr. Mason, he found, had a son and daughter; and he learned from him that he could and would give the latter a fortune of thirty thousand pounds: that sufficed. When I left college, I was sent out to Jamaica, to espouse a bride already courted for me. My father said nothing about her money; but he told me Miss Mason was the boast of Spanish Town for her beauty: and this was no lie. I found her a fine woman, in the style of Blanche Ingram: tall, dark, and majestic. Her family wished to secure me because I was of a good race; and so did she. They showed her to me in parties, splendidly dressed. I seldom saw her alone, and had very little private conversation with her. She flattered me, and lavishly displayed for my pleasure her charms and accomplishments. All the men in her circle seemed to admire her and envy me. I was dazzled, stimulated: my senses were excited; and being ignorant, raw, and inexperienced, I thought I loved her. There is no folly so besotted that the idiotic rivalries of society, the prurience, the rashness, the blindness of youth, will not hurry a man to its commission. Her relatives encouraged me; competitors piqued me; she allured me: a marriage was achieved almost before I knew where I was. Oh, I have no respect for myself when I think of that act!—an agony of inward contempt masters me. I never loved, I never esteemed, I did not even know her. I was not sure of the existence of one virtue in her nature: I had marked neither modesty, nor benevolence, nor candour, nor refinement in her mind or manners—and, I married her:—gross, grovelling, mole-eyed blockhead that I was! With less sin I might have—But let me remember to whom I am speaking.
“My bride’s mother I had never seen: I understood she was dead. The honeymoon over, I learned my mistake; she was only mad, and shut up in a lunatic asylum. There was a younger brother, too—a complete dumb idiot. The elder one, whom you have seen (and whom I cannot hate, whilst I abhor all his kindred, because he has some grains of affection in his feeble mind, shown in the continued interest he takes in his wretched sister, and also in a dog-like attachment he once bore me), will probably be in the same state one day. My father and my brother Rowland knew all this; but they thought only of the thirty thousand pounds, and joined in the plot against me.
“These were vile discoveries; but except for the treachery of concealment, I should have made them no subject of reproach to my wife, even when I found her nature wholly alien to mine, her tastes obnoxious to me, her cast of mind common, low, narrow, and singularly incapable of being led to anything higher, expanded to anything larger—when I found that I could not pass a single evening, nor even a single hour of the day with her in comfort; that kindly conversation could not be sustained between us, because whatever topic I started, immediately received from her a turn at once coarse and trite, perverse and imbecile—when I perceived that I should never have a quiet or settled household, because no servant would bear the continued outbreaks of her violent and unreasonable temper, or the vexations of her absurd, contradictory, exacting orders—even then I restrained myself: I eschewed upbraiding, I curtailed remonstrance; I tried to devour my repentance and disgust in secret; I repressed the deep antipathy I felt.
“Jane, I will not trouble you with abominable details: some strong words shall express what I have to say. I lived with that woman upstairs four years, and before that time she had tried me indeed: her character ripened and developed with frightful rapidity; her vices sprang up fast and rank: they were so strong, only cruelty could check them, and I would not use cruelty. What a pigmy intellect she had, and what giant propensities! How fearful were the curses those propensities entailed on me! Bertha Mason, the true daughter of an infamous mother, dragged me through all the hideous and degrading agonies which must attend a man bound to a wife at once intemperate and unchaste.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. Rochester abruptly exclaimed, "What an idiot I am! I keep telling her I'm not married but fail to explain why. I forget she doesn't know anything about that woman's character or the circumstances surrounding my miserable marriage to her. Oh, I am certain Jane will share my view once she knows everything I do! Just take my hand, Janet—so I have the physical confirmation as well as the visual proof that you are near me—and I will quickly explain the actual situation. Can you listen to me?" Jane replied, "Yes, sir; I can listen for hours if necessary." "I only need a few minutes," he said. "Jane, did you ever hear or know that I wasn't the oldest son in my family and that I had an older brother?" "I recall Mrs. Fairfax mentioning that once," she answered. "And did you ever hear that my father was a greedy, grasping man?" "I've gathered something to that effect," she said. "Well, Jane, because he was like that, he was determined to keep the property undivided; he couldn't stand the idea of splitting his estate and leaving me a substantial portion: he decided it should all go to my brother, Rowland. Yet, he also couldn't tolerate one of his sons being poor. I had to be provided for through a rich marriage. He started looking for a partner for me early on. Mr. Mason, a West India planter and merchant, was an old acquaintance. He was sure Mason's assets were real and extensive; he investigated. He found Mr. Mason had a son and daughter and learned he could and would provide the daughter with a fortune of thirty thousand pounds: that was enough. When I finished college, I was sent to Jamaica to marry a bride who had already been chosen for me. My father didn't mention her money, but he told me Miss Mason was celebrated in Spanish Town for her beauty: and that part was true. I found her to be a handsome woman, similar in style to Blanche Ingram: tall, dark, and imposing. Her family wanted to secure me because I came from a good lineage; she did too. They presented her to me at parties, dressed magnificently. I rarely saw her alone and had very little private conversation with her. She flattered me and openly displayed her charms and skills to please me. All the men around her seemed to admire her and envy me. I was captivated, stimulated; my senses were aroused; and being naive, raw, and inexperienced, I believed I loved her. There is no folly so utter that the senseless rivalries of society, the lust, the impulsiveness, the blindness of youth, won't drive a man to commit it. Her relatives encouraged me; competitors provoked me; she lured me: a marriage happened almost before I realized what was happening. Oh, I have no self-respect when I think about that act!—an intense feeling of self-contempt overcomes me. I never loved her, I never respected her, I didn't even know her. I wasn't certain of the existence of a single virtue in her character: I had observed neither modesty, nor kindness, nor honesty, nor refinement in her thoughts or actions—and yet, I married her:—what a crude, base, dim-witted fool I was! With less sin I might have—But let me remember who I am speaking to. I had never met my bride's mother: I understood she was dead. After the honeymoon, I discovered my mistake; she was merely insane and confined to an asylum. There was a younger brother, too—completely mentally deficient. The older one, whom you have seen (and whom I cannot hate, though I detest all his relatives, because he possesses some small capacity for affection in his weak mind, shown in his continued concern for his unhappy sister and also in a dog-like devotion he once showed me), will likely end up in the same condition eventually. My father and my brother Rowland knew all this; but they cared only for the thirty thousand pounds and participated in the scheme against me. These were terrible revelations; but except for the deceitful concealment, I would not have blamed my wife for them, even when I found her nature entirely different from mine, her tastes repulsive to me, her mindset common, vulgar, narrow, and remarkably incapable of being led to anything higher, expanded to anything broader—when I found that I could not spend a single evening, or even a single hour of the day with her comfortably; that pleasant conversation could not be maintained between us, because whatever topic I introduced, she immediately turned it into something simultaneously coarse and unoriginal, difficult and senseless—when I realized I would never have a peaceful or stable household, because no servant would tolerate the constant outbursts of her violent and irrational temper, or the annoyances of her absurd, contradictory, demanding orders—even then I controlled myself: I avoided reproaches, I limited protests; I tried to hide my regret and revulsion in secret; I suppressed the profound dislike I felt. Jane, I won't burden you with awful specifics: a few strong words will convey what I need to say. I lived with that woman upstairs for four years, and before that time she had truly tested me: her character matured and intensified with terrifying speed; her vices sprouted quickly and fiercely: they were so strong, only cruelty could restrain them, and I refused to use cruelty. What a tiny intellect she possessed, and what enormous urges! How dreadful were the curses those urges brought upon me! Bertha Mason, the true daughter of an infamous mother, dragged me through all the horrific and humiliating torments that must be endured by a man tied to a wife who is simultaneously intemperate and unfaithful.
