events.title: Rochester's Despair, Near Suicide, and Resolution for a New Life
detailed_summary: Rochester continues his story, explaining that after the deaths of his father and brother, he became wealthy but remained shackled to Bertha, whose madness had by then fully manifested, making legal separation impossible.
Jane expresses her profound pity, which Rochester accepts as genuine and a precursor to love.
He describes his near despair, feeling publicly dishonored but determined to maintain his personal integrity and distance himself from Bertha's "contamination."
He vividly recounts a night in the West Indies, tormented by Bertha's screams and an oppressive, stormy atmosphere, where he contemplated suicide with loaded pistols.
The suicidal impulse passed quickly, and a refreshing European breeze, followed by the dawn, brought him a moment of clarity and a new resolution.

He describes this "Wisdom" or "Hope" guiding him to return to Europe, confine Bertha secretly at Thornfield with proper care, and then seek a new life and new connections for himself, free from the blight of his past.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “My brother in the interval was dead, and at the end of the four years my father died too.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Place her in safety and comfort: shelter her degradation with secrecy, and leave her.’”

events.text_segment:
“My brother in the interval was dead, and at the end of the four years my father died too. I was rich enough now—yet poor to hideous indigence: a nature the most gross, impure, depraved I ever saw, was associated with mine, and called by the law and by society a part of me. And I could not rid myself of it by any legal proceedings: for the doctors now discovered that my wife was mad—her excesses had prematurely developed the germs of insanity. Jane, you don’t like my narrative; you look almost sick—shall I defer the rest to another day?”
“No, sir, finish it now; I pity you—I do earnestly pity you.”
“Pity, Jane, from some people is a noxious and insulting sort of tribute, which one is justified in hurling back in the teeth of those who offer it; but that is the sort of pity native to callous, selfish hearts; it is a hybrid, egotistical pain at hearing of woes, crossed with ignorant contempt for those who have endured them. But that is not your pity, Jane; it is not the feeling of which your whole face is full at this moment—with which your eyes are now almost overflowing—with which your heart is heaving—with which your hand is trembling in mine. Your pity, my darling, is the suffering mother of love: its anguish is the very natal pang of the divine passion. I accept it, Jane; let the daughter have free advent—my arms wait to receive her.”
“Now, sir, proceed; what did you do when you found she was mad?”
“Jane, I approached the verge of despair; a remnant of self-respect was all that intervened between me and the gulf. In the eyes of the world, I was doubtless covered with grimy dishonour; but I resolved to be clean in my own sight—and to the last I repudiated the contamination of her crimes, and wrenched myself from connection with her mental defects. Still, society associated my name and person with hers; I yet saw her and heard her daily: something of her breath (faugh!) mixed with the air I breathed; and besides, I remembered I had once been her husband—that recollection was then, and is now, inexpressibly odious to me; moreover, I knew that while she lived I could never be the husband of another and better wife; and, though five years my senior (her family and her father had lied to me even in the particular of her age), she was likely to live as long as I, being as robust in frame as she was infirm in mind. Thus, at the age of twenty-six, I was hopeless.
“One night I had been awakened by her yells—(since the medical men had pronounced her mad, she had, of course, been shut up)—it was a fiery West Indian night; one of the description that frequently precede the hurricanes of those climates. Being unable to sleep in bed, I got up and opened the window. The air was like sulphur-steams—I could find no refreshment anywhere. Mosquitoes came buzzing in and hummed sullenly round the room; the sea, which I could hear from thence, rumbled dull like an earthquake—black clouds were casting up over it; the moon was setting in the waves, broad and red, like a hot cannon-ball—she threw her last bloody glance over a world quivering with the ferment of tempest. I was physically influenced by the atmosphere and scene, and my ears were filled with the curses the maniac still shrieked out; wherein she momentarily mingled my name with such a tone of demon-hate, with such language!—no professed harlot ever had a fouler vocabulary than she: though two rooms off, I heard every word—the thin partitions of the West India house opposing but slight obstruction to her wolfish cries.
“‘This life,’ said I at last, ‘is hell: this is the air—those are the sounds of the bottomless pit! I have a right to deliver myself from it if I can. The sufferings of this mortal state will leave me with the heavy flesh that now cumbers my soul. Of the fanatic’s burning eternity I have no fear: there is not a future state worse than this present one—let me break away, and go home to God!’
“I said this whilst I knelt down at and unlocked a trunk which contained a brace of loaded pistols: I meant to shoot myself. I only entertained the intention for a moment; for, not being insane, the crisis of exquisite and unalloyed despair, which had originated the wish and design of self-destruction, was past in a second.
“A wind fresh from Europe blew over the ocean and rushed through the open casement: the storm broke, streamed, thundered, blazed, and the air grew pure. I then framed and fixed a resolution. While I walked under the dripping orange-trees of my wet garden, and amongst its drenched pomegranates and pine-apples, and while the refulgent dawn of the tropics kindled round me—I reasoned thus, Jane—and now listen; for it was true Wisdom that consoled me in that hour, and showed me the right path to follow.
“The sweet wind from Europe was still whispering in the refreshed leaves, and the Atlantic was thundering in glorious liberty; my heart, dried up and scorched for a long time, swelled to the tone, and filled with living blood—my being longed for renewal—my soul thirsted for a pure draught. I saw hope revive—and felt regeneration possible. From a flowery arch at the bottom of my garden I gazed over the sea—bluer than the sky: the old world was beyond; clear prospects opened thus:—
“‘Go,’ said Hope, ‘and live again in Europe: there it is not known what a sullied name you bear, nor what a filthy burden is bound to you. You may take the maniac with you to England; confine her with due attendance and precautions at Thornfield: then travel yourself to what clime you will, and form what new tie you like. That woman, who has so abused your long-suffering, so sullied your name, so outraged your honour, so blighted your youth, is not your wife, nor are you her husband. See that she is cared for as her condition demands, and you have done all that God and humanity require of you. Let her identity, her connection with yourself, be buried in oblivion: you are bound to impart them to no living being. Place her in safety and comfort: shelter her degradation with secrecy, and leave her.’
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
In the intervening time, my brother had passed away, and four years later, my father also died. I inherited wealth, but I felt desperately impoverished inwardly because I was legally tied to a person whose nature was the most crude, corrupt, and degraded I had ever encountered. Society and the law deemed her a part of me, and I couldn't escape this bond legally because doctors had by then diagnosed her as insane—her excessive behavior had accelerated the onset of madness. Jane, my story seems to upset you; you look unwell. Should I pause the rest for another day?”

“No, sir, please finish now. I genuinely feel for you; I truly pity you.”

“Jane, pity from certain individuals is a poisonous and offensive offering that one is justified in rejecting forcefully. However, that kind of pity comes from unfeeling, selfish hearts; it’s a self-centered discomfort at hearing of suffering, mixed with disdain for those who have endured it. But your pity, Jane, is different. It’s not that; it’s the sentiment that fills your entire face at this moment, that makes your eyes nearly overflow, that causes your heart to ache, and your hand to tremble in mine. Your pity, my dear, is the suffering mother of love; its pain is the very birth pang of that divine emotion. I accept it, Jane. Let this offspring of pity emerge freely; my embrace is ready for it.”

“Please continue, sir. What did you do after learning she was insane?”

“Jane, I was on the brink of despair; only a fragment of self-respect prevented me from falling into the abyss. In the world’s eyes, I was undoubtedly stained with deep disgrace, but I decided to remain pure in my own perception. To the very end, I rejected the taint of her misdeeds and distanced myself from her mental illness. Nevertheless, society continued to link my name and identity with hers. I still saw and heard her daily; her very breath seemed to pollute the air I breathed (it was repulsive!). Furthermore, I remembered that I had once been her husband—that memory was, and still is, utterly repulsive to me. Additionally, I knew that as long as she lived, I could never marry another, better wife. And despite being five years older than me (her family and father had even lied about her age), she was likely to live as long as I would, possessing a body as strong as her mind was fragile. Thus, at twenty-six, I felt utterly without hope.

“One night, her screams had woken me—(she had been confined since her diagnosis)—it was a scorching West Indian night, the kind that often precedes hurricanes in those regions. Unable to sleep, I got up and opened the window. The air was heavy and foul, like sulfur fumes—I found no relief anywhere. Mosquitoes buzzed in and droned gloomily around the room. The sea, audible from there, rumbled dully like an earthquake. Black clouds gathered above it. The moon was setting into the waves, large and red, like a hot cannonball, casting its final bloody light over a world trembling with the brewing storm. I was physically affected by the atmosphere and the scene, and my ears were filled with the curses the madwoman continued to shriek. In her cries, she repeatedly included my name with such demonic hatred and language! No professional prostitute had a fouler vocabulary than she did. Even though she was in a room two doors away, I heard every word; the thin walls of the West Indian house offered little barrier to her savage cries.

“‘This existence,’ I finally told myself, ‘is hell. This air, these sounds are from the bottomless pit! I have the right to free myself from it if I can. The suffering of this earthly life will be left behind with the heavy body that burdens my soul now. I don’t fear the fanatical idea of eternal burning. There is no future state worse than this present one. Let me break free and return to God!’

“I said this as I knelt down and unlocked a trunk containing a pair of loaded pistols. I intended to kill myself. The intention lasted only a moment, for being of sound mind, the peak of intense, pure despair that had prompted the wish and plan for self-destruction passed in an instant.

“A fresh wind from Europe swept over the ocean and rushed through the open window. The storm erupted, pouring rain, thundering, flashing, and the air became clean. It was then I formed and solidified a resolution. As I walked beneath the dripping orange trees in my wet garden, among its soaked pomegranates and pineapples, and as the brilliant tropical dawn illuminated my surroundings, I reasoned this way, Jane—and listen now, for it was true Wisdom that comforted me in that hour and showed me the correct path to take.

“The sweet wind from Europe still whispered through the refreshed leaves, and the Atlantic roared with glorious freedom. My heart, which had been dry and parched for so long, swelled in response to the sound and filled with fresh blood. My whole being yearned for renewal; my soul longed for a pure drink. I saw hope rekindle and felt regeneration was possible. From a flowery arch at the bottom of my garden, I gazed over the sea, bluer than the sky. The old world lay beyond, and clear prospects opened up like this:

“‘Go,’ said Hope, ‘and live again in Europe. There, no one knows the tainted name you carry or the terrible burden tied to you. You may take the madwoman with you to England; confine her at Thornfield with appropriate care and precautions. Then travel wherever you wish and form whatever new connections you desire. That woman, who so abused your patience, so defiled your name, so violated your honour, so ruined your youth, is not your wife, nor are you her husband. Ensure she is looked after as her condition requires, and you will have fulfilled all that God and humanity demand of you. Let her identity and her connection to you be buried in secrecy. You are not obligated to reveal them to anyone living. Place her in safety and comfort; conceal her degradation with secrecy, and leave her.’
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
My brother died in the meantime, and my father passed away four years later. Although I inherited enough to be wealthy, I felt utterly destitute—the most depraved and corrupt soul imaginable was legally and socially bound to me. I couldn’t separate myself from her through the law: for now the doctors determined my wife was insane—her excesses had brought on madness prematurely. Jane, I see you don’t enjoy my tale; you look ill—should I wait and finish this another time?

"No, sir, please continue; I sincerely feel sorry for you."

"Jane, sometimes pity from certain people is a poisonous and offensive thing, which one has every right to reject; but that kind of pity only comes from hardened, selfish hearts—a mix of egotistical pain at hearing of suffering and ignorant contempt for the sufferers. But that's not your pity, Jane; it's not the emotion filling your face right now, your eyes almost brimming over, your heart heavy, your hand shaking in mine. Your compassion, my dear, is pain that gives birth to love: its suffering is the very creation of the divine passion. I accept it, Jane; let love be born—my arms are ready to hold it."

"Go on, sir; what did you do when you learned she was insane?"

"Jane, I nearly lost all hope; only a shred of self-respect came between me and complete ruin. The world likely saw me as disgraced, but I decided to remain honorable in my own eyes—and I always rejected the taint of her crimes, and tried to separate myself from her mental illness. Still, society kept me connected to her; I saw and heard her every day: even the air I breathed seemed contaminated. What’s more, I remembered I'd once been her husband—a thought that was, and still is, utterly repulsive to me; and I knew that as long as she lived, I could never marry someone else, even though she was five years older than me (her family had lied even about her age), and likely to live as long as I, being physically robust despite her mental state. At twenty-six, I saw no hope for myself at all.

One night she woke me with her screams—since being judged insane, she was, of course, locked up. It was a sweltering West Indian night, the kind that comes before hurricanes. Unable to sleep, I got out of bed and opened the window. The air was thick and oppressive, there was no relief. Mosquitoes buzzed around, the distant sea rumbled like an earthquake, storm clouds gathered, the moon, blood-red, set into the sea—casting a final, ominous light as a storm brewed. Physically, I was affected by the scene, and her curses, laced with my name and vile hatred, filled my ears. Though two rooms away, I could hear every word—thin walls offered little protection from her wild cries.

At last I thought, 'This is hell: these are the sights and sounds of the underworld! I have the right to free myself if possible. Mortal suffering will end with this body. I don’t fear some fanatic’s eternal fire: nothing could be worse than this—I should break away and return to God!'

As I thought this, I knelt and opened a trunk with two loaded pistols—I intended to end my life. But I only considered it briefly; not being unbalanced myself, the sharpest despair passed quickly.

A fresh breeze from Europe swept in and cooled the air: the storm broke, thundered, lightning flashed, and the atmosphere was cleansed. I made a new resolve. As I walked through my rain-soaked garden, under orange trees and pomegranates, as dawn broke brilliantly around me, I reasoned with myself, Jane—listen, for this was true wisdom that comforted and showed me the right way.

The gentle European wind still whispered in the leaves, and the Atlantic roared freely; my heart, long numb, became alive again—my spirit yearned for renewal. Hope returned and I felt able to live anew. From a flowering arch in my garden, I looked over the sea—bluer than the sky—and possibilities opened up before me.

'Go,' said Hope, 'and live again in Europe: there, no one knows the stain on your name or the burden you carry. You can bring the madwoman to England, confine her safely at Thornfield, then go where you wish and seek new happiness. That woman, who has abused your patience, tarnished your honor, destroyed your youth, is not truly your wife. Care for her as her condition requires; that is all God and humanity ask. Cover her shame in secrecy, and leave.'"

events.title: Rochester's Post-Return Wanderings, Past Mistresses, and First Encounter with Jane
detailed_summary: Rochester explains he followed Hope's counsel, bringing Bertha to England and secretly lodging her in Thornfield's third story, with Grace Poole as her attendant—one of only two people privy to his secret.
He recounts Bertha's subsequent dangerous actions, including stabbing her brother, attempting to burn Rochester in his bed, and her terrifying visit to Jane's room.
He then describes his decade of restless wandering across Europe, seeking an intelligent and good woman he could love, a stark contrast to Bertha, but found no one suitable.
Disappointed and reckless, he admits to taking mistresses—Céline Varens, Giacinta, and Clara—but found these relationships degrading and ultimately unsatisfying.
Jane internally reflects that if she were to become his mistress, she would eventually be despised by him, reinforcing her resolve.
Rochester then narrates his return to England and his first, seemingly unremarkable sighting of Jane on a stile near Thornfield, having no premonition of her significance.
He recalls his surprise at her offering help after his horse, Mesrour, slipped, noting her quiet perseverance and authority despite her small stature.
He describes a new sensation upon touching her shoulder and his regret at seeing her vanish, realizing she belonged to his household.
He recounts observing her unseen the next day with Adèle, noting her patience, her pensive daydreams, and a shrewd smile that suggested an awareness of life's harsh realities despite youthful hopes.
He was vexed when she left his sight, eager to know her better.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I acted precisely on this suggestion.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I was vexed with you for getting out of my sight.

events.text_segment:
“I acted precisely on this suggestion. My father and brother had not made my marriage known to their acquaintance; because, in the very first letter I wrote to apprise them of the union—having already begun to experience extreme disgust of its consequences, and, from the family character and constitution, seeing a hideous future opening to me—I added an urgent charge to keep it secret: and very soon the infamous conduct of the wife my father had selected for me was such as to make him blush to own her as his daughter-in-law. Far from desiring to publish the connection, he became as anxious to conceal it as myself.
“To England, then, I conveyed her; a fearful voyage I had with such a monster in the vessel. Glad was I when I at last got her to Thornfield, and saw her safely lodged in that third-storey room, of whose secret inner cabinet she has now for ten years made a wild beast’s den—a goblin’s cell. I had some trouble in finding an attendant for her, as it was necessary to select one on whose fidelity dependence could be placed; for her ravings would inevitably betray my secret: besides, she had lucid intervals of days—sometimes weeks—which she filled up with abuse of me. At last I hired Grace Poole from the Grimbsy Retreat. She and the surgeon, Carter (who dressed Mason’s wounds that night he was stabbed and worried), are the only two I have ever admitted to my confidence. Mrs. Fairfax may indeed have suspected something, but she could have gained no precise knowledge as to facts. Grace has, on the whole, proved a good keeper; though, owing partly to a fault of her own, of which it appears nothing can cure her, and which is incident to her harassing profession, her vigilance has been more than once lulled and baffled. The lunatic is both cunning and malignant; she has never failed to take advantage of her guardian’s temporary lapses; once to secrete the knife with which she stabbed her brother, and twice to possess herself of the key of her cell, and issue therefrom in the night-time. On the first of these occasions, she perpetrated the attempt to burn me in my bed; on the second, she paid that ghastly visit to you. I thank Providence, who watched over you, that she then spent her fury on your wedding apparel, which perhaps brought back vague reminiscences of her own bridal days: but on what might have happened, I cannot endure to reflect. When I think of the thing which flew at my throat this morning, hanging its black and scarlet visage over the nest of my dove, my blood curdles—”
“And what, sir,” I asked, while he paused, “did you do when you had settled her here? Where did you go?”
“What did I do, Jane? I transformed myself into a will-o’-the-wisp. Where did I go? I pursued wanderings as wild as those of the March-spirit. I sought the Continent, and went devious through all its lands. My fixed desire was to seek and find a good and intelligent woman, whom I could love: a contrast to the fury I left at Thornfield—”
“But you could not marry, sir.”
“I had determined and was convinced that I could and ought. It was not my original intention to deceive, as I have deceived you. I meant to tell my tale plainly, and make my proposals openly: and it appeared to me so absolutely rational that I should be considered free to love and be loved, I never doubted some woman might be found willing and able to understand my case and accept me, in spite of the curse with which I was burdened.”
“Well, sir?”
“When you are inquisitive, Jane, you always make me smile. You open your eyes like an eager bird, and make every now and then a restless movement, as if answers in speech did not flow fast enough for you, and you wanted to read the tablet of one’s heart. But before I go on, tell me what you mean by your ‘Well, sir?’ It is a small phrase very frequent with you; and which many a time has drawn me on and on through interminable talk: I don’t very well know why.”
“I mean,—What next? How did you proceed? What came of such an event?”
“Precisely! and what do you wish to know now?”
“Whether you found any one you liked: whether you asked her to marry you; and what she said.”
“I can tell you whether I found any one I liked, and whether I asked her to marry me: but what she said is yet to be recorded in the book of Fate. For ten long years I roved about, living first in one capital, then another: sometimes in St. Petersburg; oftener in Paris; occasionally in Rome, Naples, and Florence. Provided with plenty of money and the passport of an old name, I could choose my own society: no circles were closed against me. I sought my ideal of a woman amongst English ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and German gräfinnen. I could not find her. Sometimes, for a fleeting moment, I thought I caught a glance, heard a tone, beheld a form, which announced the realisation of my dream: but I was presently undeceived. You are not to suppose that I desired perfection, either of mind or person. I longed only for what suited me—for the antipodes of the Creole: and I longed vainly. Amongst them all I found not one whom, had I been ever so free, I—warned as I was of the risks, the horrors, the loathings of incongruous unions—would have asked to marry me. Disappointment made me reckless. I tried dissipation—never debauchery: that I hated, and hate. That was my Indian Messalina’s attribute: rooted disgust at it and her restrained me much, even in pleasure. Any enjoyment that bordered on riot seemed to approach me to her and her vices, and I eschewed it.
“Yet I could not live alone; so I tried the companionship of mistresses. The first I chose was Céline Varens—another of those steps which make a man spurn himself when he recalls them. You already know what she was, and how my liaison with her terminated. She had two successors: an Italian, Giacinta, and a German, Clara; both considered singularly handsome. What was their beauty to me in a few weeks? Giacinta was unprincipled and violent: I tired of her in three months. Clara was honest and quiet; but heavy, mindless, and unimpressible: not one whit to my taste. I was glad to give her a sufficient sum to set her up in a good line of business, and so get decently rid of her. But, Jane, I see by your face you are not forming a very favourable opinion of me just now. You think me an unfeeling, loose-principled rake: don’t you?”
“I don’t like you so well as I have done sometimes, indeed, sir. Did it not seem to you in the least wrong to live in that way, first with one mistress and then another? You talk of it as a mere matter of course.”
“It was with me; and I did not like it. It was a grovelling fashion of existence: I should never like to return to it. Hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave: both are often by nature, and always by position, inferior: and to live familiarly with inferiors is degrading. I now hate the recollection of the time I passed with Céline, Giacinta, and Clara.”
I felt the truth of these words; and I drew from them the certain inference, that if I were so far to forget myself and all the teaching that had ever been instilled into me, as—under any pretext—with any justification—through any temptation—to become the successor of these poor girls, he would one day regard me with the same feeling which now in his mind desecrated their memory. I did not give utterance to this conviction: it was enough to feel it. I impressed it on my heart, that it might remain there to serve me as aid in the time of trial.
“Now, Jane, why don’t you say ‘Well, sir?’ I have not done. You are looking grave. You disapprove of me still, I see. But let me come to the point. Last January, rid of all mistresses—in a harsh, bitter frame of mind, the result of a useless, roving, lonely life—corroded with disappointment, sourly disposed against all men, and especially against all womankind (for I began to regard the notion of an intellectual, faithful, loving woman as a mere dream), recalled by business, I came back to England.
“On a frosty winter afternoon, I rode in sight of Thornfield Hall. Abhorred spot! I expected no peace—no pleasure there. On a stile in Hay Lane I saw a quiet little figure sitting by itself. I passed it as negligently as I did the pollard willow opposite to it: I had no presentiment of what it would be to me; no inward warning that the arbitress of my life—my genius for good or evil—waited there in humble guise. I did not know it, even when, on the occasion of Mesrour’s accident, it came up and gravely offered me help. Childish and slender creature! It seemed as if a linnet had hopped to my foot and proposed to bear me on its tiny wing. I was surly; but the thing would not go: it stood by me with strange perseverance, and looked and spoke with a sort of authority. I must be aided, and by that hand: and aided I was.
“When once I had pressed the frail shoulder, something new—a fresh sap and sense—stole into my frame. It was well I had learnt that this elf must return to me—that it belonged to my house down below—or I could not have felt it pass away from under my hand, and seen it vanish behind the dim hedge, without singular regret. I heard you come home that night, Jane, though probably you were not aware that I thought of you or watched for you. The next day I observed you—myself unseen—for half-an-hour, while you played with Adèle in the gallery. It was a snowy day, I recollect, and you could not go out of doors. I was in my room; the door was ajar: I could both listen and watch. Adèle claimed your outward attention for a while; yet I fancied your thoughts were elsewhere: but you were very patient with her, my little Jane; you talked to her and amused her a long time. When at last she left you, you lapsed at once into deep reverie: you betook yourself slowly to pace the gallery. Now and then, in passing a casement, you glanced out at the thick-falling snow; you listened to the sobbing wind, and again you paced gently on and dreamed. I think those day visions were not dark: there was a pleasurable illumination in your eye occasionally, a soft excitement in your aspect, which told of no bitter, bilious, hypochondriac brooding: your look revealed rather the sweet musings of youth when its spirit follows on willing wings the flight of Hope up and on to an ideal heaven. The voice of Mrs. Fairfax, speaking to a servant in the hall, wakened you: and how curiously you smiled to and at yourself, Janet! There was much sense in your smile: it was very shrewd, and seemed to make light of your own abstraction. It seemed to say—‘My fine visions are all very well, but I must not forget they are absolutely unreal. I have a rosy sky and a green flowery Eden in my brain; but without, I am perfectly aware, lies at my feet a rough tract to travel, and around me gather black tempests to encounter.’ You ran downstairs and demanded of Mrs. Fairfax some occupation: the weekly house accounts to make up, or something of that sort, I think it was. I was vexed with you for getting out of my sight.

I didn't realize it, even when, on the occasion of Mesrour's accident, it came forward and solemnly offered me help. Such a childlike and fragile creature! "Once I had pressed that delicate shoulder, something new – a fresh vitality and sensation – stole into my being. It seemed to say – 'My beautiful visions are all well and good, but I must not forget they are completely unreal. events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I followed this course of action exactly as suggested. My father and brother hadn’t announced my marriage publicly; when I first wrote to tell them of it, I was already beginning to feel deep regret and dread for what I’d gotten into and, predicting only a terrible future from what I knew of my wife’s background and temperament, I insisted they keep it completely quiet. Soon enough, my wife’s disgraceful behaviour was so mortifying, my father was ashamed to acknowledge her as part of the family. Rather than wanting to make our marriage known, he was as eager as I was to keep it secret.

I brought her with me to England—a dreadful journey, considering how wretched she was to travel with. When I finally brought her to Thornfield and had her locked away in that third-floor room—the one she’s turned into a kind of maddened animal’s lair for ten years—I felt some relief. It was hard to find someone trustworthy to look after her, since any slip could expose my secret, and in her bouts of clarity, she would spend days or weeks insulting me. Eventually, I hired Grace Poole from the Grimbsy Retreat. She and the doctor, Carter—who treated Mason when he was attacked—are the only ones I ever fully trusted with the truth. Mrs. Fairfax may have suspected something was amiss, but she had no clear facts. Grace Poole has been a capable keeper, though sometimes, out of her own carelessness—something she cannot seem to overcome—she’s failed in her vigilance. My wife is both spiteful and cunning and always found ways to exploit Grace’s lapses: once stealing the knife she used to stab her brother, twice getting hold of the key to her room and escaping at night. One time, she tried to set fire to my bed; another, she made that horrific visit to you. I thank God she only wrecked your wedding dress, which probably reminded her vaguely of her own wedding; but I shudder to imagine what might have happened instead. When I think about her attacking me this morning and hovering, wild-looking, by your bed, it chills my blood.

"And what did you do once you settled her here? Where did you go?" you asked.

"What did I do, Jane? I became a wanderer, drifting wherever fate took me. I traveled all over Europe, searching for a good and intelligent woman I could love—someone completely unlike the wife I’d left at Thornfield."

"But you couldn’t marry, sir," you reminded me.

"I decided, and persuaded myself, that I could and should. I didn’t intend at first to deceive, as I have with you; I planned to be open about my situation and make honest proposals. It seemed to me so clearly reasonable that I should be considered free to love and be loved, despite the curse that burdened me, that I never doubted I’d find a woman who could understand and accept my position."

"Well, sir?"

"Jane, your curiosity makes me smile. When you’re anxious for answers, your eyes light up and you move impatiently, as though words can’t come fast enough and you’re trying to guess what I’m thinking before I say it. But before I answer, tell me—what do you mean by your constant ‘Well, sir?’ You say it all the time and it always leads me into lengthy stories. I’m not sure why."

"I mean—what happened next? How did things proceed? What became of your quest?"

"Exactly. And now, what do you want to know?"

"Did you meet someone you liked? Did you propose to her? What did she say?"

"I can tell you if I met anyone I liked and whether I proposed, but her reply is still unwritten in fate. For ten years I wandered through many cities—St. Petersburg, Paris, Rome, Naples, Florence. With money and a respected name, I could enter any society. I searched for my ideal among English ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and German countesses, but couldn’t find her. Occasionally, I thought I glimpsed my dream, but was soon disappointed. It wasn’t perfection I wanted, just someone suited to me—the complete opposite of my wife—but I searched in vain. None of them, even if I had been truly free, would I have asked to marry me, knowing what I now do about marriage and regrets. This disappointment led me to reckless living. I tried distractions—never outright debauchery, which I despise. That was my wife’s vice, and my disgust for her and it kept me from vice, even when I was tempted. Any pleasure that seemed too wild reminded me of her and her sins, and I avoided it.

Still, I couldn’t bear solitude, so I tried keeping mistresses. My first was Céline Varens—you know the story and how that ended. After her were Giacinta, an Italian, and Clara, a German, both renowned for their beauty. But after only a short while, Giacinta’s lack of principles and temper made me end things. Clara was quiet and honest, but dull and uninspiring—she simply wasn’t my type. I was glad to give her enough money to start a business and part ways. But I can tell you aren’t thinking very highly of me right now. You probably consider me callous and unprincipled, yes?"

"Indeed, sir, I like you less than I have at other times. Didn’t it ever strike you as wrong to live like that—from one mistress to another? You speak of it as if it were completely normal."

"It was for me; though I disliked it. It was a degrading way of living, and I wouldn’t return to it. Having a mistress is almost as bad as owning a slave: they’re usually, by both nature and circumstance, beneath one’s own level, and living closely with inferiors is degrading. I now detest that period of my life with Céline, Giacinta, and Clara."

I believed the truth of his words, and drew a lesson from them: if I were ever persuaded—through any excuse or temptation—to become the successor of those women, he would eventually feel the same contempt for me that he now feels for their memory. I didn’t say this out loud, but I made sure to remember it well as a warning for the future.

"Now, Jane, you’re not saying ‘Well, sir?’ I’m not done yet. You look serious, still disapproving. But let me finish. Last January, finally rid of all mistresses, bitter and completely disillusioned after a lonely, wandering life, my mind soured against all people, especially women—I began to think the idea of a smart, caring woman was just a fantasy—I came back to England for business reasons.

"One cold winter afternoon, I saw Thornfield Hall from a distance—dreaded place! I expected no happiness there. At a gate on Hay Lane, I saw a small, quiet figure sitting alone. I paid it little attention—no more than to the old tree nearby. I had no premonition that the person I saw would become so important to me. I didn’t realize, even after the incident with Mesrour, when she quietly came to help me, what she would mean. She was fragile and young, but persistent and strangely authoritative. I needed her help, and she gave it.

"The moment I leaned on her thin shoulder, something new came into my life. It was good that I knew the ‘elf’ would return to Thornfield, or I would have regretted seeing her go. I heard you come home that night, Jane, though you didn’t know it. The next day, I watched you with Adèle as you played together inside because it was snowing. I observed, unseen, for half an hour. Although Adèle needed your attention, I could tell your thoughts were elsewhere; still, you were extremely patient and affectionate with her. Once she left, you fell into deep thought, pacing the hall, peering out at the snow, listening to the wind, and daydreaming. You seemed happy and hopeful, your eyes bright, not weighed down by gloom. Mrs. Fairfax’s voice woke you from your reverie, and you smiled knowingly at yourself, as if reminding yourself that daydreams aren’t reality; your life, outside your mind, would be challenging, with difficulties ahead. You promptly went to find some work—household accounts or something similar. I was annoyed to lose sight of you.

events.title: Rochester's Deepening Love for Jane and His Passionate Plea
detailed_summary: Rochester describes his formal summoning of Jane, her shy yet independent demeanor, and her quaint dress.
He found her full of contrasts: restricted by rule yet with a daring eye and ready answers, quickly becoming at ease with him.

He admits to initially treating her distantly, partly to prolong the novelty of their acquaintance and partly fearing to spoil her unique charm, not yet realizing her resilient nature. He also tested if she would seek him out if he shunned her.
He resumed his attentions, noticing her social heart and how kindness stirred her emotions, making her face and tones soften.
He recalls his fondness for chance meetings with her and her hesitant reactions to his unpredictable moods.
Jane, deeply pained by these reminiscences that make her impending departure harder, interrupts and asks him to stop.
Rochester dismisses the past, passionately declaring Jane his "sympathy," "better self," and "good angel," to whom he is bound by a powerful, all-consuming love.
He confesses his earlier deception about Bertha was due to fear of Jane's "stubbornness" and "prejudice," admitting it was cowardly.
He appeals to her nobleness, laying bare his tormented life and his profound need for her love, and asks her to pledge herself to him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Impatiently I waited for evening, when I might summon you to my presence.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Jane—give it me now.”

events.text_segment:
“Impatiently I waited for evening, when I might summon you to my presence. An unusual—to me—a perfectly new character I suspected was yours: I desired to search it deeper and know it better. You entered the room with a look and air at once shy and independent: you were quaintly dressed—much as you are now. I made you talk: ere long I found you full of strange contrasts. Your garb and manner were restricted by rule; your air was often diffident, and altogether that of one refined by nature, but absolutely unused to society, and a good deal afraid of making herself disadvantageously conspicuous by some solecism or blunder; yet when addressed, you lifted a keen, a daring, and a glowing eye to your interlocutor’s face: there was penetration and power in each glance you gave; when plied by close questions, you found ready and round answers. Very soon you seemed to get used to me: I believe you felt the existence of sympathy between you and your grim and cross master, Jane; for it was astonishing to see how quickly a certain pleasant ease tranquillised your manner: snarl as I would, you showed no surprise, fear, annoyance, or displeasure at my moroseness; you watched me, and now and then smiled at me with a simple yet sagacious grace I cannot describe. I was at once content and stimulated with what I saw: I liked what I had seen, and wished to see more. Yet, for a long time, I treated you distantly, and sought your company rarely. I was an intellectual epicure, and wished to prolong the gratification of making this novel and piquant acquaintance: besides, I was for a while troubled with a haunting fear that if I handled the flower freely its bloom would fade—the sweet charm of freshness would leave it. I did not then know that it was no transitory blossom, but rather the radiant resemblance of one, cut in an indestructible gem. Moreover, I wished to see whether you would seek me if I shunned you—but you did not; you kept in the schoolroom as still as your own desk and easel; if by chance I met you, you passed me as soon, and with as little token of recognition, as was consistent with respect. Your habitual expression in those days, Jane, was a thoughtful look; not despondent, for you were not sickly; but not buoyant, for you had little hope, and no actual pleasure. I wondered what you thought of me, or if you ever thought of me, and resolved to find this out.
“I resumed my notice of you. There was something glad in your glance, and genial in your manner, when you conversed: I saw you had a social heart; it was the silent schoolroom—it was the tedium of your life—that made you mournful. I permitted myself the delight of being kind to you; kindness stirred emotion soon: your face became soft in expression, your tones gentle; I liked my name pronounced by your lips in a grateful happy accent. I used to enjoy a chance meeting with you, Jane, at this time: there was a curious hesitation in your manner: you glanced at me with a slight trouble—a hovering doubt: you did not know what my caprice might be—whether I was going to play the master and be stern, or the friend and be benignant. I was now too fond of you often to simulate the first whim; and, when I stretched my hand out cordially, such bloom and light and bliss rose to your young, wistful features, I had much ado often to avoid straining you then and there to my heart.”
“Don’t talk any more of those days, sir,” I interrupted, furtively dashing away some tears from my eyes; his language was torture to me; for I knew what I must do—and do soon—and all these reminiscences, and these revelations of his feelings only made my work more difficult.
“No, Jane,” he returned: “what necessity is there to dwell on the Past, when the Present is so much surer—the Future so much brighter?”
I shuddered to hear the infatuated assertion.
“You see now how the case stands—do you not?” he continued. “After a youth and manhood passed half in unutterable misery and half in dreary solitude, I have for the first time found what I can truly love—I have found you. You are my sympathy—my better self—my good angel. I am bound to you with a strong attachment. I think you good, gifted, lovely: a fervent, a solemn passion is conceived in my heart; it leans to you, draws you to my centre and spring of life, wraps my existence about you, and, kindling in pure, powerful flame, fuses you and me in one.
“It was because I felt and knew this, that I resolved to marry you. To tell me that I had already a wife is empty mockery: you know now that I had but a hideous demon. I was wrong to attempt to deceive you; but I feared a stubbornness that exists in your character. I feared early instilled prejudice: I wanted to have you safe before hazarding confidences. This was cowardly: I should have appealed to your nobleness and magnanimity at first, as I do now—opened to you plainly my life of agony—described to you my hunger and thirst after a higher and worthier existence—shown to you, not my resolution (that word is weak), but my resistless bent to love faithfully and well, where I am faithfully and well loved in return. Then I should have asked you to accept my pledge of fidelity and to give me yours. Jane—give it me now.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
I eagerly awaited evening, when I could call you to me. I suspected you possessed an unusual, for me, an entirely new kind of character; I wanted to delve deeper and understand it better. You entered the room looking both shy and self-possessed, dressed in a peculiar way, much as you are now. I encouraged you to speak, and before long, I found you full of striking contradictions. Your clothes and demeanor seemed governed by rules; you often appeared hesitant, generally resembling someone naturally refined but completely inexperienced in social situations, and quite apprehensive of attracting negative attention with a mistake or awkwardness. Yet, when spoken to, you looked up at your questioner with sharp, bold, and bright eyes. There was insight and strength in every look you gave, and when pressed with detailed questions, you provided quick and clear answers. You seemed to grow comfortable with me very quickly; I believe you felt a sense of connection between you and your stern and difficult master, Jane, because it was astonishing how quickly a pleasant calmness settled over your manner. No matter how I scowled, you showed no surprise, fear, annoyance, or unhappiness at my bad temper. You watched me, and sometimes smiled with a simple but wise grace that I cannot describe. I was simultaneously satisfied and intrigued by what I saw; I liked what I had observed and desired to see more. Nevertheless, for a long time, I kept my distance and sought your company infrequently. I was like someone who savours intellectual delights, wanting to extend the pleasure of making this new and interesting acquaintance. Besides, I was for a while troubled by a persistent fear that if I handled this 'flower' too freely, its beauty would fade, losing its sweet, fresh charm. I didn't realize then that you were not a fleeting blossom, but rather the brilliant image of one, carved from an indestructible jewel. Furthermore, I wanted to see if you would seek me out if I avoided you—but you did not. You stayed as still in the schoolroom as your desk and easel. If we met by chance, you passed me quickly, showing only the minimal sign of recognition required by respect. Your usual expression in those days, Jane, was thoughtful; not sad, because you were not unwell, but not cheerful either, because you had little hope and no genuine happiness. I wondered what you thought of me, or if you ever thought of me, and resolved to find out. I began to observe you again. There was a joyful quality in your gaze and a warm friendliness in your manner when you spoke. I saw you had a social heart; it was the quiet schoolroom—the monotony of your life—that made you seem downcast. I allowed myself the pleasure of being kind to you; kindness soon awakened emotion. Your face became soft, your voice gentle; I liked hearing you pronounce my name with a grateful, happy tone. I used to enjoy chance meetings with you then, Jane. There was a peculiar hesitation in your behaviour; you glanced at me with a slight unease—a lingering uncertainty. You didn't know what my mood might be—whether I would act like the stern master or the benevolent friend. By this time, I was too fond of you to often pretend to be stern; and when I offered my hand warmly, such radiance, brightness, and joy appeared on your young, yearning face that I often had great difficulty preventing myself from pulling you into an embrace right there and then.”
“Don’t talk about those days anymore, sir,” I interrupted, secretly wiping away tears; his words were agonizing for me, because I knew what I had to do—and soon—and all these memories, and these revelations of his feelings, only made my task harder.
“No, Jane,” he replied, “why dwell on the Past, when the Present is so much more certain—the Future so much brighter?” I shivered hearing his deluded statement.
“You see how things stand now—don’t you?” he continued. “After a youth and manhood spent half in unspeakable misery and half in bleak solitude, I have for the first time found someone I can truly love—I have found you. You are my emotional connection—my better self—my good angel. I am tied to you by a powerful bond. I think you are good, talented, lovely; a fervent, a solemn passion has formed in my heart. It inclines towards you, pulls you to the core and source of my life, envelops my existence around you, and, igniting in a pure, strong flame, fuses you and me into one.
“It was because I felt and knew this that I decided to marry you. To say that I already had a wife is empty nonsense; you know now that what I had was merely a horrifying demon. I was wrong to try and deceive you, but I feared a stubbornness that is part of your character. I feared prejudices instilled early on; I wanted to secure you before risking confidences. This was cowardly; I should have appealed to your nobility and generosity from the beginning, as I am doing now—honestly revealed my life of suffering to you—described my intense longing for a higher, worthier existence—shown you, not my decision (that word is weak), but my irresistible impulse to love faithfully and well, where I am loved faithfully and well in return. Then I should have asked you to accept my promise of loyalty and give me yours. Jane—give it to me now.”

“Please stop talking about those days, sir,” I interrupted, discreetly wiping away tears; his words pained me, for I knew what I must soon do, and reminiscing only made my task harder.

“You see the situation now, don’t you?” he continued. “After a lifetime of misery and loneliness, I have finally found someone I truly love—you. You are my soulmate, my better half, my guiding spirit. I feel deeply connected to you; I think you are good, talented, and beautiful. I have a profound, solemn love for you; it pulls you to me and surrounds my life with yours, uniting us as one.
“It was this feeling that made me want to marry you. To say that I already have a wife is meaningless: what I had was a monster. Then I would have asked you for a mutual promise of loyalty. Give me that promise now, Jane.”

events.title: Jane's Agonizing Refusal and Steadfast Adherence to Principle
detailed_summary: Jane experiences a profound internal struggle, torn between her immense love for Rochester and her conviction that she must leave.
She firmly tells Rochester, "I will not be yours."
Rochester, with a grief-stricken gentleness that terrifies Jane, asks if she truly intends for them to go their separate ways. Jane confirms her resolve, even as he embraces and kisses her.
He calls her decision "wicked"; she retorts that obeying him would be wicked.
He pleads with her to consider his desolate future, but Jane advises him to trust in God and hope for a reunion in heaven.
When he accuses her of condemning him to a wretched life, she urges him to live sinlessly.
He argues that no one would be harmed if she stayed, and Jane's own feelings and reason momentarily tempt her to comply.

However, she powerfully reaffirms her self-respect and her unwavering commitment to God's laws and her own principles, especially when faced with such intense temptation, stating that these principles are her only anchor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A pause.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Preconceived opinions, foregone determinations, are all I have at this hour to stand by: there I plant my foot.”

events.text_segment:
A pause.
“Why are you silent, Jane?”
I was experiencing an ordeal: a hand of fiery iron grasped my vitals. Terrible moment: full of struggle, blackness, burning! Not a human being that ever lived could wish to be loved better than I was loved; and him who thus loved me I absolutely worshipped: and I must renounce love and idol. One drear word comprised my intolerable duty—“Depart!”
“Jane, you understand what I want of you? Just this promise—‘I will be yours, Mr. Rochester.’”
“Mr. Rochester, I will not be yours.”
Another long silence.
“Jane!” recommenced he, with a gentleness that broke me down with grief, and turned me stone-cold with ominous terror—for this still voice was the pant of a lion rising—“Jane, do you mean to go one way in the world, and to let me go another?”
“I do.”
“Jane” (bending towards and embracing me), “do you mean it now?”
“I do.”
“And now?” softly kissing my forehead and cheek.
“I do,” extricating myself from restraint rapidly and completely.
“Oh, Jane, this is bitter! This—this is wicked. It would not be wicked to love me.”
“It would to obey you.”
A wild look raised his brows—crossed his features: he rose; but he forebore yet. I laid my hand on the back of a chair for support: I shook, I feared—but I resolved.
“One instant, Jane. Give one glance to my horrible life when you are gone. All happiness will be torn away with you. What then is left? For a wife I have but the maniac upstairs: as well might you refer me to some corpse in yonder churchyard. What shall I do, Jane? Where turn for a companion and for some hope?”
“Do as I do: trust in God and yourself. Believe in heaven. Hope to meet again there.”
“Then you will not yield?”
“No.”
“Then you condemn me to live wretched and to die accursed?” His voice rose.
“I advise you to live sinless, and I wish you to die tranquil.”
“Then you snatch love and innocence from me? You fling me back on lust for a passion—vice for an occupation?”
“Mr. Rochester, I no more assign this fate to you than I grasp at it for myself. We were born to strive and endure—you as well as I: do so. You will forget me before I forget you.”
“You make me a liar by such language: you sully my honour. I declared I could not change: you tell me to my face I shall change soon. And what a distortion in your judgment, what a perversity in your ideas, is proved by your conduct! Is it better to drive a fellow-creature to despair than to transgress a mere human law, no man being injured by the breach? for you have neither relatives nor acquaintances whom you need fear to offend by living with me?”
This was true: and while he spoke my very conscience and reason turned traitors against me, and charged me with crime in resisting him. They spoke almost as loud as Feeling: and that clamoured wildly. “Oh, comply!” it said. “Think of his misery; think of his danger—look at his state when left alone; remember his headlong nature; consider the recklessness following on despair—soothe him; save him; love him; tell him you love him and will be his. Who in the world cares for you? or who will be injured by what you do?”
Still indomitable was the reply—“I care for myself. The more solitary, the more friendless, the more unsustained I am, the more I will respect myself. I will keep the law given by God; sanctioned by man. I will hold to the principles received by me when I was sane, and not mad—as I am now. Laws and principles are not for the times when there is no temptation: they are for such moments as this, when body and soul rise in mutiny against their rigour; stringent are they; inviolate they shall be. If at my individual convenience I might break them, what would be their worth? They have a worth—so I have always believed; and if I cannot believe it now, it is because I am insane—quite insane: with my veins running fire, and my heart beating faster than I can count its throbs. Preconceived opinions, foregone determinations, are all I have at this hour to stand by: there I plant my foot.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
There was a pause.
He asked, “Why are you quiet, Jane?”
I felt like I was undergoing a terrible trial: a burning metal hand seemed to grip my insides. It was a dreadful moment, filled with inner conflict, darkness, and intense pain! No person alive could ever wish to be loved more than I was; and I completely adored the man who loved me so much. Yet, I had to give up both this love and my idol. One harsh word summed up my unbearable duty—to "Leave!"
“Jane, do you understand what I need from you? Just this promise—‘I will be yours, Mr. Rochester.’”
“Mr. Rochester, I will not be yours.”
Another long silence followed.
“Jane!” he started again, with a gentleness that overwhelmed me with sadness and made me feel chillingly cold with a frightening sense of dread—because this quiet tone sounded like the heavy breathing of a rising lion—"Jane, do you intend for us to go our separate ways in the world?”
“I do.”
“Jane” (leaning towards me and holding me), “Do you still mean that now?”
“I do.”
“And now?” he asked, softly kissing my forehead and cheek.
“I do,” I replied, pulling myself free from his hold quickly and completely.
“Oh, Jane, this is painful! This—this is wrong. It wouldn’t be wrong to love me.”
“It would be wrong to obey you.”
A fierce look crossed his face and raised his eyebrows; he stood up, but held back for a moment. I put my hand on the back of a chair for support; I was trembling and afraid—but I was determined.
“Wait a moment, Jane. Think about my awful life after you are gone. All happiness will be taken away with you. What will be left? For a wife, I only have the madwoman upstairs; I might as well point you to a corpse in the nearby graveyard. What should I do, Jane? Where can I find companionship and some hope?”
“Do what I am doing: trust in God and yourself. Believe in heaven. Hope we can meet there again.”
“So you won’t give in?”
“No.”
“Then you are condemning me to live a miserable life and die feeling cursed?” His voice grew louder.
“I advise you to live without sin, and I hope you will die peacefully.”
“Then you are taking love and innocence away from me? You are forcing me back towards lust for passion and vice for something to do?”
“Mr. Rochester, I am no more forcing this fate on you than I am choosing it for myself. We were meant to struggle and endure—you just as much as I: do that. You will forget me before I forget you.”
“Your words call me a liar; they stain my honor. I said I couldn’t change; you are telling me directly that I will change soon. And what a twisting of your judgment, what a warped view you have, is proven by what you are doing! Is it better to drive another person to despair than to break a simple human law, especially when no one is harmed by the break? You have no relatives or acquaintances you need worry about offending by living with me?”
This was true; and as he spoke, my very conscience and reason seemed to turn against me, accusing me of a crime for resisting him. They spoke almost as loudly as my feelings, which were crying out wildly. “Oh, agree!” my feelings said. “Think of his suffering; think of his danger—look how he’ll be if left alone; remember how impulsive he is; consider the recklessness that follows despair—comfort him; save him; love him; tell him you love him and will be his. Who in the world cares about you? Or who will be hurt by what you do?”
Yet my answer remained defiant—“I care about myself. The more alone, the more friendless, the less supported I am, the more I will respect myself. I will obey the law given by God; approved by man. I will stick to the principles I accepted when I was sensible, not insane—as I feel now. Laws and principles are not meant for times when there is no temptation; they are for moments like this, when my body and soul rebel against their strictness; they are severe; they must remain unbroken. If I could break them whenever it was convenient for me, what value would they have? They do have value—I have always believed that; and if I cannot believe it now, it is because I am insane—completely insane: with fire running through my veins, and my heart beating faster than I can count its beats. My pre-formed opinions and past decisions are all I have to rely on right now: that is where I stand firm.”

There was a pause. "Why are you quiet, Jane?" I felt I was going through a trial — it was as if a burning, iron hand was gripping my innermost being. It was a dreadful moment filled with conflict, darkness, and agony. No one in the world could wish to be loved more than I was loved, and I adored him in return; yet I had to give up both love and my idol. One bleak word described the painful duty ahead: "Leave!" 

"Jane, do you know what I want from you? Just say, 'I will be yours, Mr. Rochester.'" 

"Mr. Rochester, I will not be yours." 

There was another long silence. 

He began again, now gently, and his tenderness made me feel overwhelmed with sorrow and a cold, haunting fear — because his quiet tone was like a ferocious beast ready to spring. "Jane, do you intend to go one way in life and let me go another?" 

"I do." 

"Jane," he said, as he leaned in and embraced me, "do you mean it now?" 

"I do." 

"And now?" he whispered, kissing my forehead and cheek. 

"I do," I replied, quickly freeing myself from his hold. 

"Oh, Jane, this is so painful! This is wrong. It wouldn't be wrong to love me." 

"It would be wrong to obey you." 

An anguished expression crossed his face; he stood up, though he restrained himself. I leaned on the back of a chair for support, shaking and afraid, but determined.

"Just a moment, Jane. Imagine how miserable my life will be when you're gone. All happiness will vanish with you. What's left for me then? My only wife is the madwoman upstairs — you might as well suggest I marry someone dead in the churchyard. What should I do, Jane? Where can I find companionship or hope?" 

"Do what I do: trust in God and yourself. Believe in heaven. Hope that we'll meet there." 

"So you won't give in?" 

"No." 

"So you condemn me to misery in life and doom in death?" he said, his voice rising. 

"I advise you to live a good life and wish for you a peaceful death." 

"So you take away love and innocence from me? You send me back to vice for comfort and temptation for company?" 

"Mr. Rochester, I don't wish that fate on you any more than I accept it for myself. Both of us are meant to struggle and endure — you as well as me. Do so. You'll forget me before I forget you." 

"You're making me out to be a liar by saying that: you stain my honesty. I said I'd never change; you tell me straight to my face that I will soon. Is it really better to push someone to despair than to break a human-made law, when no one would actually be harmed? You don't have family or friends who would judge you if you became mine." 

He was right; and as he spoke, my conscience and reason turned against me, accusing me of wrongdoing for resisting him. They almost drowned out my emotions, which screamed wildly: "Just say yes! Think of his suffering, his hopelessness, his reckless spirit — comfort him; save him; love him; tell him you'll be his. Who else cares for you? Who would be hurt by this choice?" 

Yet my reply remained unbreakable: "I care for myself. The lonelier, more friendless, and unsupported I am, the more I will respect myself. I will keep the law that comes from God as well as man. I will stand by the principles I learned when I was in my right mind, not as wild as I feel now. Laws and principles mean nothing if we only follow them when it's easy; they are for times like this, when every part of you wants to rebel. They are strict and must not be violated. If I could break them whenever it suited me, what good are they? They do have value — I've always believed that; if I can't believe it now, it's because I am in turmoil. All I have to hold onto are the beliefs and decisions I made before — and on those, I will stand firm."

events.title: Rochester's Final Desperate Struggle, Jane's Compassionate Farewell, and a Guiding Dream
detailed_summary: Recognizing Jane's unshakeable resolve, Rochester is overcome with fury and physically seizes her.
He exclaims over her simultaneous frailty and indomitable spirit, acknowledging that while he could physically dominate her, he could never conquer her soul, which is what he truly desires.
He realizes she must come to him willingly or she will elude him like an essence. He releases her, his sorrowful gaze proving more challenging to resist than his anger.
Jane moves towards the door, confirming her intent to leave despite his anguished questions about her forsaking him.
Rochester finally consents but begs her to remember his suffering. He collapses onto the sofa, crying out her name in despair.
Jane, moved by his anguish, walks back to him, kneels, turns his face to hers, kisses his cheek, and soothes his hair, offering a heartfelt blessing for his well-being.
Rochester responds that her love would have been his best reward and still believes she will give it, springing up with renewed hope, but Jane evades his embrace and quickly leaves the room.
Her heart cries "Farewell," while despair adds "Farewell for ever!"

That night, a vivid dream transports her to the red-room at Gateshead. A luminous, maternal figure appears and instructs her, "My daughter, flee temptation." Jane, in her dream, replies, "Mother, I will."

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I did.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Mother, I will.”

events.text_segment:
I did. Mr. Rochester, reading my countenance, saw I had done so. His fury was wrought to the highest: he must yield to it for a moment, whatever followed; he crossed the floor and seized my arm and grasped my waist. He seemed to devour me with his flaming glance: physically, I felt, at the moment, powerless as stubble exposed to the draught and glow of a furnace: mentally, I still possessed my soul, and with it the certainty of ultimate safety. The soul, fortunately, has an interpreter—often an unconscious, but still a truthful interpreter—in the eye. My eye rose to his; and while I looked in his fierce face I gave an involuntary sigh; his gripe was painful, and my over-taxed strength almost exhausted.
“Never,” said he, as he ground his teeth, “never was anything at once so frail and so indomitable. A mere reed she feels in my hand!” (And he shook me with the force of his hold.) “I could bend her with my finger and thumb: and what good would it do if I bent, if I uptore, if I crushed her? Consider that eye: consider the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage—with a stern triumph. Whatever I do with its cage, I cannot get at it—the savage, beautiful creature! If I tear, if I rend the slight prison, my outrage will only let the captive loose. Conqueror I might be of the house; but the inmate would escape to heaven before I could call myself possessor of its clay dwelling-place. And it is you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity—that I want: not alone your brittle frame. Of yourself you could come with soft flight and nestle against my heart, if you would: seized against your will, you will elude the grasp like an essence—you will vanish ere I inhale your fragrance. Oh! come, Jane, come!”
As he said this, he released me from his clutch, and only looked at me. The look was far worse to resist than the frantic strain: only an idiot, however, would have succumbed now. I had dared and baffled his fury; I must elude his sorrow: I retired to the door.
“You are going, Jane?”
“I am going, sir.”
“You are leaving me?”
“Yes.”
“You will not come? You will not be my comforter, my rescuer? My deep love, my wild woe, my frantic prayer, are all nothing to you?”
What unutterable pathos was in his voice! How hard it was to reiterate firmly, “I am going.”
“Jane!”
“Mr. Rochester!”
“Withdraw, then,—I consent; but remember, you leave me here in anguish. Go up to your own room; think over all I have said, and, Jane, cast a glance on my sufferings—think of me.”
He turned away; he threw himself on his face on the sofa. “Oh, Jane! my hope—my love—my life!” broke in anguish from his lips. Then came a deep, strong sob.
I had already gained the door; but, reader, I walked back—walked back as determinedly as I had retreated. I knelt down by him; I turned his face from the cushion to me; I kissed his cheek; I smoothed his hair with my hand.
“God bless you, my dear master!” I said. “God keep you from harm and wrong—direct you, solace you—reward you well for your past kindness to me.”
“Little Jane’s love would have been my best reward,” he answered; “without it, my heart is broken. But Jane will give me her love: yes—nobly, generously.”
Up the blood rushed to his face; forth flashed the fire from his eyes; erect he sprang; he held his arms out; but I evaded the embrace, and at once quitted the room.
“Farewell!” was the cry of my heart as I left him. Despair added, “Farewell for ever!”
That night I never thought to sleep; but a slumber fell on me as soon as I lay down in bed. I was transported in thought to the scenes of childhood: I dreamt I lay in the red-room at Gateshead; that the night was dark, and my mind impressed with strange fears. The light that long ago had struck me into syncope, recalled in this vision, seemed glidingly to mount the wall, and tremblingly to pause in the centre of the obscured ceiling. I lifted up my head to look: the roof resolved to clouds, high and dim; the gleam was such as the moon imparts to vapours she is about to sever. I watched her come—watched with the strangest anticipation; as though some word of doom were to be written on her disk. She broke forth as never moon yet burst from cloud: a hand first penetrated the sable folds and waved them away; then, not a moon, but a white human form shone in the azure, inclining a glorious brow earthward. It gazed and gazed on me. It spoke to my spirit: immeasurably distant was the tone, yet so near, it whispered in my heart—
“My daughter, flee temptation.”
“Mother, I will.”
