I had faced and defeated his fury; I had to escape his sorrow. I withdrew towards the door. "You are leaving, Jane?" "I am leaving, sir." "You are abandoning me?" "Yes." "You will not come? You will not be my comfort, my rescuer? My deep love, my intense suffering, my desperate plea mean nothing to you?" The pathos in his voice was beyond description! It was incredibly difficult to repeat firmly, "I am going." "Jane!" "Mr. Rochester!" "Then withdraw – I agree; but remember, you leave me here in agony. Go up to your own room; reflect on everything I have said, and, Jane, consider my suffering – think of me." He turned away and threw himself face down on the sofa. "Oh, Jane! my hope – my love – my life!" broke from his lips in anguish. Then came a deep, powerful sob. I had already reached the door, but, reader, I walked back – walked back with the same resolve as I had retreated. I knelt beside him, turned his face from the cushion towards me, kissed his cheek, and smoothed his hair with my hand. "God bless you, my dear master!" I said. "May God keep you from harm and wrong – guide you, comfort you – reward you generously for your past kindness to me." "Little Jane's love would have been my best reward," he answered; "without it, my heart is broken. But Jane *will* give me her love; yes – nobly, generously." Blood rushed to his face; fire flashed from his eyes; he suddenly sprang upright. He held out his arms, but I evaded the embrace and immediately left the room. "Farewell!" cried my heart as I departed. Despair added, "Farewell for ever!" That night, I never expected to sleep, but slumber overcame me as soon as I lay in bed. My thoughts carried me back to scenes from childhood. I dreamt I lay in the red-room at Gateshead, that the night was dark, and my mind was filled with strange fears. The light that had caused me to faint long ago, reappearing in this vision, seemed to float up the wall and pause trembling in the center of the dark ceiling. I raised my head to look: the roof dissolved into high, dim clouds. The gleam was like the moon's light on vapors she is about to separate. I watched her come – watched with the most unusual anticipation, as though some message of destiny were to be written on her surface. She emerged as no moon had ever burst from clouds before: first, a hand penetrated the black folds and waved them away; then, not a moon, but a white human form shone in the blue sky, inclining a glorious brow towards the earth. It gazed and gazed at me. It spoke to my spirit; the tone was incredibly distant, yet so close it whispered in my heart – "My daughter, flee temptation." "Mother, I will."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I did as he asked, and Mr. Rochester, seeing the expression on my face, realized it. He became as furious as possible and had to give in to his anger for a moment, regardless of the consequences. He strode across the room, grabbed my arm and waist, and looked at me with burning eyes. In that instant, I felt physically as weak as a piece of straw before a fiery furnace, but my mind remained clear, and I trusted that I would ultimately be safe. Fortunately, the soul often expresses itself honestly, even if unconsciously, through the eyes. I met his gaze, and, as I looked at his intense face, an involuntary sigh escaped me; his grip hurt, and I was nearly at the end of my strength.

"Never," he said, grinding his teeth, "have I seen something so delicate yet so unconquerable. She feels like nothing in my hand!" (He shook me as he said this.) "I could bend or even break her physically, but what would it matter? That look in her eye—wild, determined, and proud—defies me. Even if I destroy her body, the spirit inside would escape before I could ever possess it. What I want is your spirit, Jane—your will, your strength, your goodness and innocence—not just your fragile body. If you wanted, you could willingly come to me and let me comfort you; forced, you would vanish like air before I could hold you. Oh, come to me, Jane!"

He let go, but his look was even harder to withstand than his grasp. Still, I resisted; I had faced his anger, now I needed to avoid his sorrow. I withdrew towards the door.

"You're leaving, Jane?" he asked.
"I am, sir," I replied.
"You'll go and not comfort me, not rescue me? Do my love and sorrow mean nothing to you?"

His voice was full of such pain; it was so difficult to say again, "I am going."

"Jane!"
"Mr. Rochester!"
"Then go," he said. "But remember, you leave me in pain. Go to your room and think over what I have said. Think of my suffering."

He turned away and threw himself face-down on the sofa, crying out in anguish, "Oh, Jane—my hope, my love, my life!" Then he sobbed deeply.

I had reached the door, but then I returned, just as determinedly. I knelt beside him, turned his face toward me, kissed his cheek, and gently stroked his hair.

"God bless you, my dear master," I said. "May God keep you from harm, guide and comfort you, and reward you for your kindness to me."

He answered, "Jane's love would have been my greatest reward; without it, I'm broken. But Jane will give me her love—generously, nobly."

He flushed and his eyes lit up; he stood up with arms outstretched, but I avoided his embrace and left the room immediately.

"Farewell!" cried my heart as I left him. Sorrow added, "Farewell forever!"

I expected not to sleep that night, but fell into slumber as soon as I lay down. In my dreams, I was a child again, lying in the red-room at Gateshead, full of strange fears in the dark. The same light that once frightened me appeared again, glowing on the ceiling. I looked up as the ceiling transformed into distant, misty clouds and the light looked like moonlight about to split the clouds. I watched with a peculiar sense of anticipation, as though some fate was about to be revealed. The light parted the darkness and, rather than a moon, a shining white human figure appeared, gazing down at me. Its presence spoke to me, both distant and near, whispering, "My daughter, flee temptation."

I answered, "Mother, I will."

events.title: Jane's Resolute Departure from Thornfield into an Uncertain Future
detailed_summary: Awakened and guided by the dream's admonition, Jane rises before dawn, resolute in her decision to leave Thornfield.
She gathers a few essential personal items, deliberately leaving behind a pearl necklace from Rochester, as it belonged to a "visionary bride."
She silently glides past Mrs. Fairfax's door and glances towards Adèle's nursery, whispering farewells but not daring to enter for a final embrace.
She pauses at Rochester's door, hearing his restless movements and sighs. She acknowledges the "temporary heaven" she could choose by staying but masters the temptation and moves on.
She reflects on Rochester's anticipated reaction to her absence – his search, his sense of forsakenness, his suffering, and potential desperation – but remains firm.
She mechanically prepares for her journey, oiling the side-door key and lock for a silent exit, and taking some bread and water.
She slips out of Thornfield into the dim dawn, closing the gate behind her, now truly alone.
She heads towards an unfamiliar road, deliberately suppressing thoughts of the past or future.
The beauty of the summer morning is lost on her as she is consumed by the agony of what she has left behind, especially the image of Rochester awaiting her return.
She is tormented by the thought of his potential self-abandonment and feels a profound self-abhorrence for causing him pain, yet she cannot turn back, feeling divinely guided.
Overcome by weakness, she falls but rises again, determined to reach the road.
Upon reaching it, she hails a passing coach, inquires its destination (a place far from Rochester's connections), and negotiates a fare with her limited funds.
She enters the empty coach, which rolls away, carrying her into an unknown future.
The narrative voice concludes with a heartfelt wish that the reader never experiences such profound, heart-wrenching sorrow or the dread of being an instrument of evil to a loved one.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So I answered after I had waked from the trance-like dream.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: May you never appeal to Heaven in prayers so hopeless and so agonised as in that hour left my lips; for never may you, like me, dread to be the instrument of evil to what you wholly love.

events.text_segment:
So I answered after I had waked from the trance-like dream. It was yet night, but July nights are short: soon after midnight, dawn comes. “It cannot be too early to commence the task I have to fulfil,” thought I. I rose: I was dressed; for I had taken off nothing but my shoes. I knew where to find in my drawers some linen, a locket, a ring. In seeking these articles, I encountered the beads of a pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had forced me to accept a few days ago. I left that; it was not mine: it was the visionary bride’s who had melted in air. The other articles I made up in a parcel; my purse, containing twenty shillings (it was all I had), I put in my pocket: I tied on my straw bonnet, pinned my shawl, took the parcel and my slippers, which I would not put on yet, and stole from my room.
“Farewell, kind Mrs. Fairfax!” I whispered, as I glided past her door. “Farewell, my darling Adèle!” I said, as I glanced towards the nursery. No thought could be admitted of entering to embrace her. I had to deceive a fine ear: for aught I knew it might now be listening.
I would have got past Mr. Rochester’s chamber without a pause; but my heart momentarily stopping its beat at that threshold, my foot was forced to stop also. No sleep was there: the inmate was walking restlessly from wall to wall; and again and again he sighed while I listened. There was a heaven—a temporary heaven—in this room for me, if I chose: I had but to go in and to say—
“Mr. Rochester, I will love you and live with you through life till death,” and a fount of rapture would spring to my lips. I thought of this.
That kind master, who could not sleep now, was waiting with impatience for day. He would send for me in the morning; I should be gone. He would have me sought for: vainly. He would feel himself forsaken; his love rejected: he would suffer; perhaps grow desperate. I thought of this too. My hand moved towards the lock: I caught it back, and glided on.
Drearily I wound my way downstairs: I knew what I had to do, and I did it mechanically. I sought the key of the side-door in the kitchen; I sought, too, a phial of oil and a feather; I oiled the key and the lock. I got some water, I got some bread: for perhaps I should have to walk far; and my strength, sorely shaken of late, must not break down. All this I did without one sound. I opened the door, passed out, shut it softly. Dim dawn glimmered in the yard. The great gates were closed and locked; but a wicket in one of them was only latched. Through that I departed: it, too, I shut; and now I was out of Thornfield.
A mile off, beyond the fields, lay a road which stretched in the contrary direction to Millcote; a road I had never travelled, but often noticed, and wondered where it led: thither I bent my steps. No reflection was to be allowed now: not one glance was to be cast back; not even one forward. Not one thought was to be given either to the past or the future. The first was a page so heavenly sweet—so deadly sad—that to read one line of it would dissolve my courage and break down my energy. The last was an awful blank: something like the world when the deluge was gone by.
I skirted fields, and hedges, and lanes till after sunrise. I believe it was a lovely summer morning: I know my shoes, which I had put on when I left the house, were soon wet with dew. But I looked neither to rising sun, nor smiling sky, nor wakening nature. He who is taken out to pass through a fair scene to the scaffold, thinks not of the flowers that smile on his road, but of the block and axe-edge; of the disseverment of bone and vein; of the grave gaping at the end: and I thought of drear flight and homeless wandering—and oh! with agony I thought of what I left. I could not help it. I thought of him now—in his room—watching the sunrise; hoping I should soon come to say I would stay with him and be his. I longed to be his; I panted to return: it was not too late; I could yet spare him the bitter pang of bereavement. As yet my flight, I was sure, was undiscovered. I could go back and be his comforter—his pride; his redeemer from misery, perhaps from ruin. Oh, that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment—how it goaded me! It was a barbed arrow-head in my breast; it tore me when I tried to extract it; it sickened me when remembrance thrust it farther in. Birds began singing in brake and copse: birds were faithful to their mates; birds were emblems of love. What was I? In the midst of my pain of heart and frantic effort of principle, I abhorred myself. I had no solace from self-approbation: none even from self-respect. I had injured—wounded—left my master. I was hateful in my own eyes. Still I could not turn, nor retrace one step. God must have led me on. As to my own will or conscience, impassioned grief had trampled one and stifled the other. I was weeping wildly as I walked along my solitary way: fast, fast I went like one delirious. A weakness, beginning inwardly, extending to the limbs, seized me, and I fell: I lay on the ground some minutes, pressing my face to the wet turf. I had some fear—or hope—that here I should die: but I was soon up; crawling forwards on my hands and knees, and then again raised to my feet—as eager and as determined as ever to reach the road.
When I got there, I was forced to sit to rest me under the hedge; and while I sat, I heard wheels, and saw a coach come on. I stood up and lifted my hand; it stopped. I asked where it was going: the driver named a place a long way off, and where I was sure Mr. Rochester had no connections. I asked for what sum he would take me there; he said thirty shillings; I answered I had but twenty; well, he would try to make it do. He further gave me leave to get into the inside, as the vehicle was empty: I entered, was shut in, and it rolled on its way.
Gentle reader, may you never feel what I then felt! May your eyes never shed such stormy, scalding, heart-wrung tears as poured from mine. May you never appeal to Heaven in prayers so hopeless and so agonised as in that hour left my lips; for never may you, like me, dread to be the instrument of evil to what you wholly love.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Awakening from a daze, I responded. It was still nighttime, but July nights are short, with dawn breaking soon after midnight. I told myself it was not too early to begin the task I had to complete. I got up, already dressed except for my shoes. I knew where to find some linen, a locket, and a ring in my drawers. While searching for these, my hand touched the pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had insisted I take a few days earlier. I left it; it wasn't mine, but belonged to the imaginary bride who had vanished. I gathered the other items into a small bundle. My purse, containing twenty shillings—all the money I had—went into my pocket. I tied on my straw bonnet, pinned my shawl, took the bundle and my slippers (which I wouldn't put on yet), and quietly slipped out of my room. "Goodbye, kind Mrs. Fairfax!" I whispered as I crept past her door. "Goodbye, my dear Adèle!" I said as I glanced towards the nursery, knowing I couldn't possibly go in to hug her. I had to be silent; someone with a keen ear might be listening. I intended to pass Mr. Rochester's room without stopping, but my heart seemed to stop at the threshold, forcing my feet to halt as well. He wasn't sleeping; I heard him pacing restlessly back and forth inside, sighing repeatedly as I listened. I knew that if I chose, a temporary heaven could be mine in that room; I just had to enter and say, "Mr. Rochester, I will love you and live with you until death." Such words would bring me immediate joy. I considered this. That kind master, currently sleepless, was waiting anxiously for morning. He would send for me, only to find me gone. He would search in vain, feel abandoned, his love rejected; he would suffer and perhaps become desperate. I thought of this too. My hand moved towards the doorknob, but I pulled it back and continued on. With a heavy heart, I went downstairs, performing my actions automatically, knowing what I had to do. I found the key to the side door in the kitchen, along with a small container of oil and a feather; I oiled the key and the lock. I got some water and bread, anticipating a long journey that would require my strength, which had been severely tested recently. I did all this silently. I opened the door, stepped outside, and closed it softly. Dim dawn light filtered into the yard. The large gates were shut and locked, but a smaller gate within one of them was only latched. I left through this, closed it behind me, and was now outside Thornfield. A mile away, across the fields, lay a road leading in the opposite direction from Millcote. It was a road I had never traveled but had often seen, wondering where it led; this is where I headed. I was determined not to look back or forward, not to dwell on the past or the future. The past was a memory so wonderfully sweet yet so tragically sad that recalling even a single detail would shatter my courage and willpower. The future was a terrifying emptiness, like the world after a great flood. I walked alongside fields, hedges, and lanes until after sunrise. I believe it was a beautiful summer morning, though my shoes, which I put on after leaving the house, were soon soaked with dew. But I paid no attention to the rising sun, the pleasant sky, or the awakening nature. Like someone led to the scaffold through a lovely scene, I could only think of the execution block, the axe, the severing of bone and vein, and the waiting grave. Similarly, I thought only of desperate escape and homeless wandering—and oh, with agony, I thought of what I was leaving behind. I couldn't help it. I thought of him now, in his room, watching the sunrise, hoping I would soon come and tell him I would stay and be his. I longed to be his, to return; it wasn't too late. I could still spare him the cruel pain of loss. I was sure my departure was still undiscovered. I could go back and be his comfort, his pride, perhaps even save him from misery or ruin. Oh, the fear of his potential self-destruction—far worse than my own abandonment—how it tormented me! It was like a barbed arrowhead in my chest, tearing at me when I tried to remove it, sickening me when memory pushed it deeper. Birds began singing in the bushes and woods; birds were faithful to their partners, symbols of love. What was I? In the midst of my heartache and desperate adherence to principle, I despised myself. I found no comfort in self-approval, not even in self-respect. I had wronged, wounded, and left my master. I was hateful in my own eyes. Yet, I could not turn back or retrace a single step. God must have been guiding me. My own will and conscience were crushed and silenced by overwhelming grief. I wept uncontrollably as I walked my solitary path, moving rapidly, like someone delirious. A weakness, starting within and spreading to my limbs, seized me, and I fell. I lay on the ground for several minutes, pressing my face into the wet grass. I had a momentary fear—or perhaps hope—that I might die there. But I soon got up, first crawling on my hands and knees, then rising to my feet, as determined as ever to reach the road. When I got there, I had to sit and rest under the hedge. While I rested, I heard wheels and saw a coach approaching. I stood up and raised my hand; it stopped. I asked where it was going; the driver named a place far away, one I was certain Mr. Rochester had no connection to. I asked how much he would charge to take me there; he said thirty shillings. I replied that I only had twenty, and he agreed to make it work. He also allowed me to get inside, as the coach was empty. I entered, the door was closed, and the carriage began its journey. Kind reader, may you never experience what I felt then! May your eyes never shed such fierce, burning, painful tears as mine poured. May you never appeal to Heaven with prayers as hopeless and agonizing as those that left my lips in that hour, for may you never, like me, fear being the cause of harm to the person you love completely.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After awakening from a dream-like daze, I decided to act, realizing that even though it was still nighttime, July nights do not last long and dawn would soon arrive. Thinking it was not too soon to begin the task ahead, I got up; I was already dressed except for my shoes, which I had removed. I gathered some linen, a locket, and a ring from my drawer. While searching, I found the pearls Mr. Rochester had insisted I accept a few days before; I left them behind, feeling they belonged not to me, but to the imaginary bride who no longer existed. I packed the items into a bundle, placed my purse with my only twenty shillings in my pocket, put on my bonnet and shawl, took the parcel and my slippers, and quietly left my room.

As I passed Mrs. Fairfax’s door, I whispered my goodbye to her, and as I looked toward the nursery, I bid farewell to little Adèle; I couldn’t risk entering to embrace her, afraid someone might hear me. Passing by Mr. Rochester’s room, I meant to walk on, but stopped involuntarily at his door, listening to his restless pacing and repeated sighs. In that room was the promise of happiness if I only dared enter and promise to stay with him forever. I thought of the joy I could have, but also how he would feel upon discovering my absence—abandoned and rejected, perhaps driven to despair. My hand even reached for his door, but I restrained myself and moved on.

Descending the stairs, I mechanically proceeded with my plan, finding the side-door key in the kitchen and collecting a small bottle of oil and a feather to quietly open the lock. I also took some bread and water, fearing I might have to walk far and my weakened strength might fail me. I did all this silently, slipped outside, and softly closed the door. The gates were shut, but a small latched door allowed my exit. I closed it behind me and left Thornfield.

I headed toward a road beyond the fields, one I’d never traveled but often wondered about, avoiding any thoughts of past or future, as either would sap my resolve. The past was full of sweet memories now too painful to recall, and the future was a terrifying emptiness. I walked through fields and along hedges and lanes as the sun rose; although it was a beautiful morning and my shoes grew wet with dew, I noticed nothing, consumed as I was by the pain of leaving what I loved most. The analogy came to me of a condemned person led to execution, only able to think of suffering and death, not the beauty around them. I thought constantly of Mr. Rochester, imagining him waiting for me and longing for me to return, feeling the pain of possibly causing his despair. Still, I couldn’t turn back, no matter how much I desired to, feeling driven by a will greater than my own. Overwhelmed with grief, I wept openly, walking quickly and almost without control, until exhaustion forced me to fall to the ground. After regaining some strength, I crawled and then stood, determined to reach the road.

When I finally arrived at the road, I rested by a hedge. Hearing a carriage, I signaled for it to stop, and after asking the fare, found I had only enough money for the driver to accept to try to take me as far as my funds allowed. I boarded alone, and we departed.

Dear reader, I hope you never endure what I did then or feel anguish as deep or hopeless. May you never pray in such agony or fear causing pain to someone you love as deeply as I did.

events.title: Arrival at Whitcross and Utter Destitution
detailed_summary: The protagonist is left by the coachman at a desolate location called Whitcross, having exhausted all her funds.
She belatedly realizes she has left her parcel, containing her belongings, in the coach, rendering her utterly destitute.
Whitcross is described not as a town but as a remote stone pillar at a crossroads, with signs indicating distant towns.
The surrounding landscape is vast moorland and mountains, suggesting a sparsely populated area.
She feels profoundly alone and wishes to avoid any human interaction, fearing suspicion due to her inability to explain her predicament.
Feeling disconnected from human society, she resolves to seek refuge and solace in the natural world.
She walks into the heath and finds a concealed spot beneath a granite crag to shelter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Two days are passed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: High banks of moor were about me; the crag protected my head: the sky was over that.

events.text_segment:
Two days are passed. It is a summer evening; the coachman has set me down at a place called Whitcross; he could take me no farther for the sum I had given, and I was not possessed of another shilling in the world. The coach is a mile off by this time; I am alone. At this moment I discover that I forgot to take my parcel out of the pocket of the coach, where I had placed it for safety; there it remains, there it must remain; and now, I am absolutely destitute.
Whitcross is no town, nor even a hamlet; it is but a stone pillar set up where four roads meet: whitewashed, I suppose, to be more obvious at a distance and in darkness. Four arms spring from its summit: the nearest town to which these point is, according to the inscription, distant ten miles; the farthest, above twenty. From the well-known names of these towns I learn in what county I have lighted; a north-midland shire, dusk with moorland, ridged with mountain: this I see. There are great moors behind and on each hand of me; there are waves of mountains far beyond that deep valley at my feet. The population here must be thin, and I see no passengers on these roads: they stretch out east, west, north, and south—white, broad, lonely; they are all cut in the moor, and the heather grows deep and wild to their very verge. Yet a chance traveller might pass by; and I wish no eye to see me now: strangers would wonder what I am doing, lingering here at the sign-post, evidently objectless and lost. I might be questioned: I could give no answer but what would sound incredible and excite suspicion. Not a tie holds me to human society at this moment—not a charm or hope calls me where my fellow-creatures are—none that saw me would have a kind thought or a good wish for me. I have no relative but the universal mother, Nature: I will seek her breast and ask repose.
I struck straight into the heath; I held on to a hollow I saw deeply furrowing the brown moorside; I waded knee-deep in its dark growth; I turned with its turnings, and finding a moss-blackened granite crag in a hidden angle, I sat down under it. High banks of moor were about me; the crag protected my head: the sky was over that.

She soon discovered that she had forgotten to retrieve her parcel of belongings from the coach pocket where she had placed it for safety. Now left alone and a mile from the departing coach, she was completely broke and without possessions. Whitcross wasn't a village or town, but just a white stone post marking where four roads met, likely painted to be easily seen. It had arms indicating the direction and distance to various towns, the closest ten miles away, the farthest over twenty. From the names of these towns, she realized she was in a north-midland county, characterized by its dark moors and mountainous ridges, which she could see around her – vast moors nearby and waves of mountains beyond a deep valley. The area seemed sparsely populated, with no other travelers on the wide, empty roads that cut through the wild moorland where the heather grew thick to the edges. Hoping to avoid any chance encounters, as her presence there, looking lost and without purpose, would arouse curiosity and she had no believable explanation that wouldn't cause suspicion, she felt utterly disconnected from human society. Without any ties or hope calling her towards others, she decided to seek comfort in nature, her 'universal mother'. She walked directly into the heath, following a deep groove she saw on the brown moor side. Wading through the dense growth up to her knees, she followed the hollow's turns until she found a moss-covered granite rock in a secluded corner, where she sat down. High moorland banks surrounded her, the rock shielded her head, and the sky was visible above.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Two days have gone by. It's a warm evening in summer, and the coachman has dropped me off at a place named Whitcross; he couldn't drive me any further for the fare I'd paid, and I don't have a single other coin to my name. By now, the coach is already a mile away and I'm completely alone. At this point, I realize I've forgotten to retrieve my bundle from the seat pocket in the coach where I'd stored it for safekeeping; it's still there and I have no way to get it back—making me entirely penniless.

Whitcross isn't a village or even a small settlement; it's simply a stone post at a crossroads, covered in white paint to make it stand out at a distance, especially at night. At its top, four signposts point to different directions: the nearest town is, by the lettering, ten miles away; the furthest is over twenty. From the familiar place names, I understand which county I've arrived in—a northern, central county with moors and mountain ridges like those around me. Stretching behind, to each side, are wide moorlands; beyond the valley at my feet, I can see layers of mountains. Not many people must live nearby, as I don't see anyone traveling these roads, which go off to the east, west, north, and south—broad, pale, and deserted, carved through the wild moorland with thick heather growing right up to their edges. Even though a random traveler might appear, I sincerely hope that nobody sees me now; a stranger would likely wonder why I'm loitering by the signpost, looking aimless and lost. If confronted, I could only give answers that would seem unbelievable and raise suspicion. At this moment, I have no connection left to society—not a single tie, hope, or call draws me towards other people; no one who saw me would wish me well. My only connection now is with Mother Nature herself: I will turn to her for comfort and rest.

So, I began walking straight into the heath, following a deep trench I saw cutting into the brown slope of the moor. I pushed through knee-high rough vegetation, twisting along with the hollow until I found a moss-covered rock in a secluded spot. There, I sat down, sheltered by high banks of moorland and the stone behind me, with the open sky above.

events.title: Night on the Moor and Spiritual Contemplation
detailed_summary: Initially, Jane feels a sense of unease in her wild surroundings, worried about potential dangers like wild animals or discovery.
As night falls, the profound silence of the moor calms her, allowing her to reflect on her dire circumstances.
She is overwhelmed by the lack of options and the daunting prospect of finding help or shelter.
The natural environment, with the warm heath and clear sky, provides a sense of comfort, and she perceives Nature as a benevolent, maternal force.
She eats her last piece of bread with some wild bilberries, which temporarily satisfies her hunger.
After saying her prayers, she creates a makeshift bed in the dense heath.
Her rest is disturbed by intense sorrow and longing for Mr. Rochester, consumed by pity for his fate and a deep yearning for him.
Driven by these painful thoughts, she kneels to pray. The sight of the Milky Way fills her with a sense of God's immense power and care.
This experience reassures her that Mr. Rochester is under God's protection, and her prayer turns into one of thanksgiving.
Finding solace in this spiritual renewal, she returns to her resting place and finally falls asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Some time passed before I felt tranquil even here: I had a vague dread that wild cattle might be near, or that some sportsman or poacher might discover me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I again nestled to the breast of the hill; and ere long in sleep forgot sorrow.

events.text_segment:
Some time passed before I felt tranquil even here: I had a vague dread that wild cattle might be near, or that some sportsman or poacher might discover me. If a gust of wind swept the waste, I looked up, fearing it was the rush of a bull; if a plover whistled, I imagined it a man. Finding my apprehensions unfounded, however, and calmed by the deep silence that reigned as evening declined at nightfall, I took confidence. As yet I had not thought; I had only listened, watched, dreaded; now I regained the faculty of reflection.
What was I to do? Where to go? Oh, intolerable questions, when I could do nothing and go nowhere!—when a long way must yet be measured by my weary, trembling limbs before I could reach human habitation—when cold charity must be entreated before I could get a lodging: reluctant sympathy importuned, almost certain repulse incurred, before my tale could be listened to, or one of my wants relieved!
I touched the heath: it was dry, and yet warm with the heat of the summer day. I looked at the sky; it was pure: a kindly star twinkled just above the chasm ridge. The dew fell, but with propitious softness; no breeze whispered. Nature seemed to me benign and good; I thought she loved me, outcast as I was; and I, who from man could anticipate only mistrust, rejection, insult, clung to her with filial fondness. To-night, at least, I would be her guest, as I was her child: my mother would lodge me without money and without price. I had one morsel of bread yet: the remnant of a roll I had bought in a town we passed through at noon with a stray penny—my last coin. I saw ripe bilberries gleaming here and there, like jet beads in the heath: I gathered a handful and ate them with the bread. My hunger, sharp before, was, if not satisfied, appeased by this hermit’s meal. I said my evening prayers at its conclusion, and then chose my couch.
Beside the crag the heath was very deep: when I lay down my feet were buried in it; rising high on each side, it left only a narrow space for the night-air to invade. I folded my shawl double, and spread it over me for a coverlet; a low, mossy swell was my pillow. Thus lodged, I was not, at least at the commencement of the night, cold.
My rest might have been blissful enough, only a sad heart broke it. It plained of its gaping wounds, its inward bleeding, its riven chords. It trembled for Mr. Rochester and his doom; it bemoaned him with bitter pity; it demanded him with ceaseless longing; and, impotent as a bird with both wings broken, it still quivered its shattered pinions in vain attempts to seek him.
Worn out with this torture of thought, I rose to my knees. Night was come, and her planets were risen: a safe, still night: too serene for the companionship of fear. We know that God is everywhere; but certainly we feel His presence most when His works are on the grandest scale spread before us; and it is in the unclouded night-sky, where His worlds wheel their silent course, that we read clearest His infinitude, His omnipotence, His omnipresence. I had risen to my knees to pray for Mr. Rochester. Looking up, I, with tear-dimmed eyes, saw the mighty Milky-way. Remembering what it was—what countless systems there swept space like a soft trace of light—I felt the might and strength of God. Sure was I of His efficiency to save what He had made: convinced I grew that neither earth should perish, nor one of the souls it treasured. I turned my prayer to thanksgiving: the Source of Life was also the Saviour of spirits. Mr. Rochester was safe: he was God’s, and by God would he be guarded. I again nestled to the breast of the hill; and ere long in sleep forgot sorrow.

Feeling comforted, I lay down again and soon fell asleep, forgetting my sorrows for a while.

events.title: Despair and the Renewed Search for Sustenance
detailed_summary: Jane awakens to the pressing reality of hunger and her fundamental human needs.
She observes the beauty of the sunlit moor but recognizes it offers no sustenance for her.
For a moment, she wishes she were a creature that could easily survive in such wilderness.
Despite a fleeting desire that death had taken her during the night, she acknowledges her responsibility to live and endure her hardships.
She leaves her sheltered spot and begins her journey anew.
After returning to Whitcross, she chooses a road leading away from the sun's direction.
Following a long period of walking, when she is near complete exhaustion, the sound of a church bell offers a new direction and a spark of hope.
The distant view of a hamlet, a church spire, cultivated fields, and other signs of human presence reawakens her determination to persevere.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But next day, Want came to me pale and bare.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Human life and human labour were near. I must struggle on: strive to live and bend to toil like the rest.

events.text_segment:
But next day, Want came to me pale and bare. Long after the little birds had left their nests; long after bees had come in the sweet prime of day to gather the heath honey before the dew was dried—when the long morning shadows were curtailed, and the sun filled earth and sky—I got up, and I looked round me.
What a still, hot, perfect day! What a golden desert this spreading moor! Everywhere sunshine. I wished I could live in it and on it. I saw a lizard run over the crag; I saw a bee busy among the sweet bilberries. I would fain at the moment have become bee or lizard, that I might have found fitting nutriment, permanent shelter here. But I was a human being, and had a human being’s wants: I must not linger where there was nothing to supply them. I rose; I looked back at the bed I had left. Hopeless of the future, I wished but this—that my Maker had that night thought good to require my soul of me while I slept; and that this weary frame, absolved by death from further conflict with fate, had now but to decay quietly, and mingle in peace with the soil of this wilderness. Life, however, was yet in my possession, with all its requirements, and pains, and responsibilities. The burden must be carried; the want provided for; the suffering endured; the responsibility fulfilled. I set out.
Whitcross regained, I followed a road which led from the sun, now fervent and high. By no other circumstance had I will to decide my choice. I walked a long time, and when I thought I had nearly done enough, and might conscientiously yield to the fatigue that almost overpowered me—might relax this forced action, and, sitting down on a stone I saw near, submit resistlessly to the apathy that clogged heart and limb—I heard a bell chime—a church bell.
I turned in the direction of the sound, and there, amongst the romantic hills, whose changes and aspect I had ceased to note an hour ago, I saw a hamlet and a spire. All the valley at my right hand was full of pasture-fields, and cornfields, and wood; and a glittering stream ran zig-zag through the varied shades of green, the mellowing grain, the sombre woodland, the clear and sunny lea. Recalled by the rumbling of wheels to the road before me, I saw a heavily-laden waggon labouring up the hill, and not far beyond were two cows and their drover. Human life and human labour were near. I must struggle on: strive to live and bend to toil like the rest.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: However, the next day brought me face to face with severe need. It was long after the small birds were up and out of their nests, and long after the bees had arrived early in the day to collect honey from the heather before the morning dew had evaporated. The sun was high, the long morning shadows had shortened, and the sun's presence filled the landscape. I finally got up and surveyed my surroundings. What a calm, warm, and perfect day it was! This vast moorland seemed like a golden, sun-drenched desert. Sunshine was everywhere. I wished I could reside in this place and sustain myself from it. I noticed a lizard scurry over a rock and a bee busy among the sweet bilberries. At that moment, I would gladly have traded places with the bee or the lizard so that I could easily find sustenance and lasting refuge here. But I was human, with human necessities, and I couldn't remain where nothing could fulfill them. I stood up and glanced back at the spot where I had rested. Feeling hopeless about the future, I could only wish that my Creator had chosen to take my soul during the night as I slept, and that this tired body, freed by death from further conflict with destiny, could simply decompose peacefully and blend into the soil of this wild place. Yet, I still possessed life, with all its demands, hardships, and duties. The weight of existence had to be borne, the need had to be addressed, the suffering had to be endured, and the responsibilities had to be met. I began my journey. Upon reaching Whitcross again, I took a road that led away from the sun, which was now intensely hot and high. My choice of direction was dictated by nothing else. I walked for a considerable time, and just as I felt I had endured enough and could reasonably give in to the exhaustion that was nearly overwhelming me—to cease this forced movement and, sitting on a nearby stone, passively surrender to the numbness that was slowing my heart and limbs—I heard a church bell chime. I turned towards the sound and there, nestled amongst the picturesque hills whose changing appearance I had stopped noticing an hour before, I saw a small village and a church spire. The entire valley to my right was covered in pastures, grain fields, and woodlands; a sparkling stream meandered through the varied shades of green fields, the ripening crops, the dark woods, and the bright, sunny meadows. The sound of rumbling wheels on the road ahead brought my attention back, and I saw a heavily loaded wagon struggling up the hill, followed not far behind by two cows and their handler. Human activity and human labor were nearby. I had to keep going; I had to strive to live and accept the need to work, just like everyone else.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
But the following day, I was confronted with hunger and deprivation, stark and real. After the birds had already left their nests and the bees had begun their morning work collecting nectar, when the sun had risen high and illuminated everything, I finally got up and surveyed my lonely surroundings. The day was tranquil, hot, and beautifully clear; the moor stretched before me like a vast, golden expanse bathed in sunlight. I longed to live off the land, to feel at home in that radiant space. As I watched a lizard scurry over the rocks and a bee gathering from the berry bushes, I wished I could become one of those creatures, able to find sustenance and shelter right there. However, as a human, I had needs that could not be met on the moor. I could not stay where nothing could sustain me. I rose and looked back at where I had slept, wishing, in my hopelessness, that I had died quietly in my sleep so that my tired body could be at rest and merge with the earth in peace. But I was still alive, with all life's demands, pains, and duties. I had to bear my burdens, fulfill my needs, endure suffering, and accept my responsibilities. So I began walking again.

When I returned to Whitcross, I simply took a road away from the hot, glaring sun, letting nothing else guide my choice. I walked for a long time. Just as exhaustion overcame me and I considered giving in, sitting down on a nearby stone and surrendering to numbness, I heard a church bell ringing. Turning toward the sound, I saw, among the picturesque hills, a small village with a church spire. Below me lay a valley full of meadows, fields of crops, woods, and a shining stream winding through them all. Drawn by the noise of wheels on the road, I noticed a heavy wagon climbing the hill and, further along, two cows with their herder. I realized that people and their labor were nearby—I had to keep going, determined to live and work as others did.

events.title: Unsuccessful Pleas for Aid and Work in the Village
detailed_summary: Around two in the afternoon, Jane enters the village and is immediately drawn to bread displayed in a shop window, feeling an intense craving.
She contemplates bartering her silk handkerchief or gloves for food.
Inside the shop, shame overwhelms her, preventing her from offering her belongings for bread; instead, she merely asks to sit down due to fatigue, much to the shopwoman's disappointment.

Jane inquires about employment as a dressmaker or general workwoman, then asks if a servant is needed, but the shopwoman provides no helpful leads, mentioning that local work is primarily farm labor or male-only factory jobs.
Sensing the shopwoman's growing impatience, Jane leaves and wanders the village for over an hour, fruitlessly searching for any opportunity or assistance.
Exhausted and severely hungry, she briefly rests under a hedge but soon forces herself to continue her search for help.
She knocks at a well-kept house and asks a young woman for any kind of work, explaining her situation as a stranger, but is politely refused and the door is closed on her.
She feels too weak to seek shelter in a distant wood and is compelled by hunger to remain near human habitations.
Hoping the clergyman might offer assistance, she approaches the parsonage, only to learn from the housekeeper that he is away due to his father's recent death and will not return for some time.
Feeling unable to beg from the housekeeper, she departs once more.

In desperation, she returns to the shop and directly offers her handkerchief for a roll of bread, but the shopwoman eyes her with suspicion and refuses. Her subsequent offer of her gloves is also rejected.

The narrator pauses to reflect on the deep pain of these memories, acknowledging the blend of moral degradation and physical suffering, while also understanding why a well-dressed beggar would arouse suspicion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About two o’clock P.M. I entered the village.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Let me condense now. I am sick of the subject.

events.text_segment:
About two o’clock P.M. I entered the village. At the bottom of its one street there was a little shop with some cakes of bread in the window. I coveted a cake of bread. With that refreshment I could perhaps regain a degree of energy: without it, it would be difficult to proceed. The wish to have some strength and some vigour returned to me as soon as I was amongst my fellow-beings. I felt it would be degrading to faint with hunger on the causeway of a hamlet. Had I nothing about me I could offer in exchange for one of these rolls? I considered. I had a small silk handkerchief tied round my throat; I had my gloves. I could hardly tell how men and women in extremities of destitution proceeded. I did not know whether either of these articles would be accepted: probably they would not; but I must try.
I entered the shop: a woman was there. Seeing a respectably-dressed person, a lady as she supposed, she came forward with civility. How could she serve me? I was seized with shame: my tongue would not utter the request I had prepared. I dared not offer her the half-worn gloves, the creased handkerchief: besides, I felt it would be absurd. I only begged permission to sit down a moment, as I was tired. Disappointed in the expectation of a customer, she coolly acceded to my request. She pointed to a seat; I sank into it. I felt sorely urged to weep; but conscious how unseasonable such a manifestation would be, I restrained it. Soon I asked her “if there were any dressmaker or plain-workwoman in the village?”
“Yes; two or three. Quite as many as there was employment for.”
I reflected. I was driven to the point now. I was brought face to face with Necessity. I stood in the position of one without a resource, without a friend, without a coin. I must do something. What? I must apply somewhere. Where?
“Did she know of any place in the neighbourhood where a servant was wanted?”
“Nay; she couldn’t say.”
“What was the chief trade in this place? What did most of the people do?”
“Some were farm labourers; a good deal worked at Mr. Oliver’s needle-factory, and at the foundry.”
“Did Mr. Oliver employ women?”
“Nay; it was men’s work.”
“And what do the women do?”
“I knawn’t,” was the answer. “Some does one thing, and some another. Poor folk mun get on as they can.”
She seemed to be tired of my questions: and, indeed, what claim had I to importune her? A neighbour or two came in; my chair was evidently wanted. I took leave.
I passed up the street, looking as I went at all the houses to the right hand and to the left; but I could discover no pretext, nor see an inducement to enter any. I rambled round the hamlet, going sometimes to a little distance and returning again, for an hour or more. Much exhausted, and suffering greatly now for want of food, I turned aside into a lane and sat down under the hedge. Ere many minutes had elapsed, I was again on my feet, however, and again searching something—a resource, or at least an informant. A pretty little house stood at the top of the lane, with a garden before it, exquisitely neat and brilliantly blooming. I stopped at it. What business had I to approach the white door or touch the glittering knocker? In what way could it possibly be the interest of the inhabitants of that dwelling to serve me? Yet I drew near and knocked. A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman opened the door. In such a voice as might be expected from a hopeless heart and fainting frame—a voice wretchedly low and faltering—I asked if a servant was wanted here?
“No,” said she; “we do not keep a servant.”
“Can you tell me where I could get employment of any kind?” I continued. “I am a stranger, without acquaintance in this place. I want some work: no matter what.”
But it was not her business to think for me, or to seek a place for me: besides, in her eyes, how doubtful must have appeared my character, position, tale. She shook her head, she “was sorry she could give me no information,” and the white door closed, quite gently and civilly: but it shut me out. If she had held it open a little longer, I believe I should have begged a piece of bread; for I was now brought low.
I could not bear to return to the sordid village, where, besides, no prospect of aid was visible. I should have longed rather to deviate to a wood I saw not far off, which appeared in its thick shade to offer inviting shelter; but I was so sick, so weak, so gnawed with nature’s cravings, instinct kept me roaming round abodes where there was a chance of food. Solitude would be no solitude—rest no rest—while the vulture, hunger, thus sank beak and talons in my side.
I drew near houses; I left them, and came back again, and again I wandered away: always repelled by the consciousness of having no claim to ask—no right to expect interest in my isolated lot. Meantime, the afternoon advanced, while I thus wandered about like a lost and starving dog. In crossing a field, I saw the church spire before me: I hastened towards it. Near the churchyard, and in the middle of a garden, stood a well-built though small house, which I had no doubt was the parsonage. I remembered that strangers who arrive at a place where they have no friends, and who want employment, sometimes apply to the clergyman for introduction and aid. It is the clergyman’s function to help—at least with advice—those who wished to help themselves. I seemed to have something like a right to seek counsel here. Renewing then my courage, and gathering my feeble remains of strength, I pushed on. I reached the house, and knocked at the kitchen-door. An old woman opened: I asked was this the parsonage?
“Yes.”
“Was the clergyman in?”
“No.”
“Would he be in soon?”
“No, he was gone from home.”
“To a distance?”
“Not so far—happen three mile. He had been called away by the sudden death of his father: he was at Marsh End now, and would very likely stay there a fortnight longer.”
“Was there any lady of the house?”
“Nay, there was naught but her, and she was housekeeper;” and of her, reader, I could not bear to ask the relief for want of which I was sinking; I could not yet beg; and again I crawled away.
Once more I took off my handkerchief—once more I thought of the cakes of bread in the little shop. Oh, for but a crust! for but one mouthful to allay the pang of famine! Instinctively I turned my face again to the village; I found the shop again, and I went in; and though others were there besides the woman I ventured the request—“Would she give me a roll for this handkerchief?”
She looked at me with evident suspicion: “Nay, she never sold stuff i’ that way.”
Almost desperate, I asked for half a cake; she again refused. “How could she tell where I had got the handkerchief?” she said.
“Would she take my gloves?”
“No! what could she do with them?”
Reader, it is not pleasant to dwell on these details. Some say there is enjoyment in looking back to painful experience past; but at this day I can scarcely bear to review the times to which I allude: the moral degradation, blent with the physical suffering, form too distressing a recollection ever to be willingly dwelt on. I blamed none of those who repulsed me. I felt it was what was to be expected, and what could not be helped: an ordinary beggar is frequently an object of suspicion; a well-dressed beggar inevitably so. To be sure, what I begged was employment; but whose business was it to provide me with employment? Not, certainly, that of persons who saw me then for the first time, and who knew nothing about my character. And as to the woman who would not take my handkerchief in exchange for her bread, why, she was right, if the offer appeared to her sinister or the exchange unprofitable. Let me condense now. I am sick of the subject.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Around 2:00 PM, I arrived in the village. At the start of its single street, there was a small shop displaying some loaves of bread in the window. I desperately wanted one, believing it could restore some energy and make it possible to continue my journey. Being among people again reignited my desire for strength and vitality, and I felt it would be humiliating to collapse from hunger on the village path. I wondered if I had anything I could trade for a roll. I considered the small silk scarf tied around my neck and my gloves. I had no idea how completely destitute people typically managed, nor if these items would be accepted (likely not, but I felt I had to try). I went into the shop, where a woman was present. Seeing someone she assumed was a respectable lady, she approached me politely, asking how she could help. Shame overwhelmed me; I couldn't voice my planned request. Offering the worn gloves or crumpled scarf felt absurd, so I simply asked if I could sit down for a moment, explaining I was tired. Disappointed that I wasn't a customer, she coolly agreed and pointed to a seat, into which I sank. I was on the verge of tears but consciously held them back, knowing it was the wrong time. Soon, I asked her if there were any seamstresses or women who did plain sewing work in the village. She replied yes, saying there were two or three, which was sufficient for the available work. I thought about my situation. I was truly at rock bottom, facing stark necessity. I had no resources, no friends, and no money. I had to act, but where could I turn? I asked if she knew of any place nearby that needed a servant. She said she couldn't say. I then asked about the main occupations in the village and what most people did. She explained some were farm labourers, and many worked at Mr. Oliver's needle factory and the foundry. I asked if Mr. Oliver employed women, but she said it was men's work. 'And what do the women do?' I asked. 'I don't know,' she answered. 'Some do one thing, some another. Poor people just have to get by as they can.' She seemed tired of my questions, and I acknowledged I had no right to bother her. As neighbours entered and my chair was needed, I left. I walked up the street, scanning all the houses but finding no reason or opportunity to enter any. I wandered around the hamlet for over an hour, sometimes leaving and then returning. Greatly exhausted and now suffering intensely from hunger, I turned into a lane and sat under a hedge. However, after only a few minutes, I was back on my feet, compelled to search for a solution or at least someone who could help. At the end of the lane stood a lovely small house with a remarkably neat and vibrant garden. I stopped there. What justification did I have to approach the white door or touch the shining knocker? How could the residents possibly benefit from helping me? Yet, I approached and knocked. A gentle-looking young woman, neatly dressed, opened the door. With a voice that mirrored my despair and physical weakness—terribly quiet and trembling—I asked if they needed a servant. 'No,' she replied, 'we don't employ a servant.' 'Could you tell me where I might find any type of work?' I pressed on. 'I am a stranger here with no contacts. I need work, any work.' But it wasn't her responsibility to think for me or find me a job. Furthermore, my appearance, circumstances, and story must have seemed questionable to her. She shook her head, expressed regret that she couldn't assist me, and the white door closed, gently and politely, but it left me outside. I believe if she had left it open a moment longer, I would have begged for a piece of bread, as I was now truly desperate. I couldn't face returning to the grim village, especially since there was no visible hope of help there. I was tempted to go into a nearby wood that looked invitingly shaded, but I was too weak, too ill, and too consumed by hunger. Instinct kept me near houses where there was a chance of finding food. Solitude would offer no peace, nor rest any comfort, while the agony of hunger gnawed at me. I approached houses, left them, returned, and wandered away again, always held back by the feeling that I had no right to ask or expect anyone to care about my isolated plight. Meanwhile, the afternoon wore on as I roamed like a lost, starving animal. Crossing a field, I saw the church spire and headed towards it. Near the churchyard, in the center of a garden, stood a well-built but small house, which I assumed was the parsonage. I recalled that strangers needing work and lacking friends sometimes seek advice and assistance from the local clergyman. It's typically the clergyman's role to help, at least with guidance, those trying to help themselves. I felt I had some justification for seeking counsel here. Renewing my courage and gathering my remaining strength, I pressed on. I reached the house and knocked at the kitchen door. An old woman opened it. I asked if this was the parsonage. 'Yes.' 'Is the clergyman in?' 'No.' 'Will he be back soon?' 'No, he's away from home.' 'Far away?' 'Not too far—perhaps three miles. He was called away because of his father's sudden death; he is at Marsh End now and will likely stay for another two weeks.' 'Is there a lady of the house?' 'No, there's only me, and I'm the housekeeper.' Reader, I couldn't bring myself to ask her for the relief I desperately needed; I couldn't beg yet. So, I crept away once more. Again, I took off my handkerchief and thought again of the bread in the little shop. Oh, just for a crust! Just one mouthful to quiet the torment of starvation! Instinctively, I turned back towards the village. I found the shop again, went inside, and despite others being present besides the woman, I dared to ask, 'Would you trade a roll for this handkerchief?' She looked at me with clear suspicion. 'No,' she said, 'I never do business like that.' Almost completely desperate, I asked for half a cake; she refused again. 'How am I supposed to know where you got the handkerchief?' she asked. 'Would you take my gloves?' 'No! What would I do with them?' Reader, it's painful to recount these details. Some claim there is satisfaction in looking back on past suffering, but even now, I find it hard to revisit the times I'm describing. The combination of moral humiliation and physical pain is too distressing a memory to willingly dwell on. I didn't blame anyone who turned me away. I felt it was to be expected and unavoidable. An ordinary beggar is often viewed with suspicion; a well-dressed beggar is inevitably so. Of course, what I was asking for was employment, but whose responsibility was it to provide me with a job? Certainly not people who had just met me and knew nothing about me. And as for the woman who wouldn't trade her bread for my handkerchief, she was right if the offer seemed questionable or the exchange unprofitable to her. Let me summarize now. I am weary of this subject.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Around two in the afternoon, I arrived in the village. At the end of the village's only street was a small shop with loaves of bread displayed in its window. I longed desperately for one, believing that eating it might restore my strength; otherwise, it would be hard to continue. The sight of other people renewed my wish for energy, and I was determined not to collapse from hunger in public. I wondered if I had anything to trade for a roll—perhaps my silk handkerchief or gloves—but was unsure whether such items would even be accepted. Regardless, I felt I had to attempt it.

Upon entering the shop, the woman behind the counter, assuming I was a respectable lady, greeted me politely and asked how she could help. Embarrassed, I found myself unable to voice my request or offer the handkerchief or gloves, feeling it would be ridiculous. Instead, I merely asked to sit for a few minutes to rest, which she granted without enthusiasm. I was close to tears, but restrained myself, knowing now was not the time. After a moment, I inquired whether there were any dressmakers or needleworkers in the village, to which she replied that there were a few, but not much work for them.

Realizing I was at my limit, with no friends, no money, and no resources, I knew I needed to do something—apply for any work available. I asked the woman if she knew of any places nearby looking for a servant; she did not. I asked what jobs were common in the area: most people did farm work or were employed at the local factory or foundry, but only men worked there. She didn’t know what jobs the women did, noting only that poor people did what they could. She seemed uninterested in further questions, and as more people came in, I left the shop.

Walking through the village, I considered each house for any opportunity but found none. For over an hour, I wandered restlessly, becoming weaker with hunger and finally sat under a hedge in a country lane. Unable to rest, I got up and searched again for help. At the top of the lane stood a pleasant-looking house with a beautiful garden. Although I doubted anyone inside would help a stranger, I approached and knocked. A well-dressed young woman answered, and in a weak, desperate voice, I asked if they needed a servant. She said they did not, nor did she know anywhere I could find work. She closed the door gently but left me outside, feeling even lower.

I could not face returning to the unfriendly village. Though the woods nearby looked inviting, hunger forced me to keep hoping for human help. I loitered near houses, never daring to ask directly, painfully aware that I had no right to expect help. The afternoon wore on as I roamed the area like a lost and hungry street dog. Eventually, I saw a church spire and hurried toward it, reasoning that the parsonage might be nearby and that clergymen sometimes helped strangers. Summoning my last energy, I knocked on the kitchen door of the parsonage. An elderly woman answered, telling me the clergyman was not at home—he had gone to Marsh End due to his father’s death and would probably be gone several more weeks. There was no lady of the house, just the housekeeper. I could not bring myself to beg from her and left once more.

Again, desperate, I considered trading my handkerchief for a roll from the shop. Returning, I asked in front of other customers if the woman would give me bread for the handkerchief. She regarded me suspiciously and said she did not make exchanges like that, nor would she take my gloves, saying they were useless to her, and she had no idea where I acquired the handkerchief. 

It is unpleasant to recall all these details; some say there is value in remembering past suffering, but even now, thinking about the combination of moral and physical misery pains me. I did not blame those who refused to help; suspicion is expected toward beggars, especially those who appear well-dressed. I was only seeking work, but strangers are not obliged to offer it. I could not resent the shopkeeper who refused the trade: her concerns were understandable. I will summarize my experience now, as the memory is distressing.

events.title: Fleeting Charity and Another Night of Hardship
detailed_summary: As darkness approaches, Jane passes a farmhouse and, seeing the farmer eating, asks him for a piece of bread, explaining her extreme hunger.
The farmer, seemingly surprised, cuts a substantial slice from his loaf and gives it to her without speaking; Jane surmises he perhaps thought her an eccentric lady rather than a beggar.
Once out of his sight, she quickly eats the bread.

Failing to find any lodging, she spends another wretched night in the woods, where the ground is damp, the air is cold, and she is repeatedly disturbed by passersby, forcing her to change her resting spot multiple times.
Rain begins to fall towards morning, and the entire following day is wet.
She continues her desperate search for work but is consistently repulsed and remains starving.

The only sustenance she receives that day is some cold porridge which a little girl was about to discard for pigs; after Jane asks for it, the girl's mother allows her to have it, and Jane devours it ravenously.
As the wet twilight deepens, she finds herself alone on a solitary bridle-path, having walked for over an hour.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A little before dark I passed a farm-house, at the open door of which the farmer was sitting, eating his supper of bread and cheese.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As the wet twilight deepened, I stopped in a solitary bridle-path, which I had been pursuing an hour or more.

events.text_segment:
A little before dark I passed a farm-house, at the open door of which the farmer was sitting, eating his supper of bread and cheese. I stopped and said—
“Will you give me a piece of bread? for I am very hungry.” He cast on me a glance of surprise; but without answering, he cut a thick slice from his loaf, and gave it to me. I imagine he did not think I was a beggar, but only an eccentric sort of lady, who had taken a fancy to his brown loaf. As soon as I was out of sight of his house, I sat down and ate it.
I could not hope to get a lodging under a roof, and sought it in the wood I have before alluded to. But my night was wretched, my rest broken: the ground was damp, the air cold: besides, intruders passed near me more than once, and I had again and again to change my quarters: no sense of safety or tranquillity befriended me. Towards morning it rained; the whole of the following day was wet. Do not ask me, reader, to give a minute account of that day; as before, I sought work; as before, I was repulsed; as before, I starved; but once did food pass my lips. At the door of a cottage I saw a little girl about to throw a mess of cold porridge into a pig trough. “Will you give me that?” I asked.
She stared at me. “Mother!” she exclaimed, “there is a woman wants me to give her these porridge.”
“Well lass,” replied a voice within, “give it her if she’s a beggar. T’ pig doesn’t want it.”
The girl emptied the stiffened mould into my hand, and I devoured it ravenously.
As the wet twilight deepened, I stopped in a solitary bridle-path, which I had been pursuing an hour or more.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A bit before it got dark, I came across a farm. The farmer was sitting in the open doorway, having his dinner of bread and cheese. I stopped and asked, "Could you give me a piece of bread? I'm very hungry." He looked surprised, but without saying anything, he cut a thick slice from his loaf and gave it to me. I think he didn't see me as a beggar, but rather an odd kind of lady who just happened to like his brown bread. As soon as I was out of sight of his house, I sat down and ate it. I knew I couldn't find shelter indoors, so I looked for a place in the woods I mentioned earlier. However, my night was awful, and my rest was broken. The ground was wet, the air was cold, and people passed by close to me more than once, forcing me to move repeatedly. I felt no sense of safety or calm. It rained towards morning, and the entire next day was wet. Please don't ask me, reader, for a detailed account of that day. As before, I looked for work; as before, I was refused; as before, I was starving. Food only touched my lips once. At the entrance of a small house, I saw a little girl about to pour a bowl of cold porridge into a pig's feeder. "Will you give me that?" I asked. She stared at me. "Mother!" she called out, "there's a woman who wants me to give her this porridge." "Well, lass," a voice from inside answered, "give it to her if she's a beggar. The pig doesn't need it." The girl emptied the solidified porridge into my hand, and I ate it very quickly. As the damp evening light faded, I stopped on a solitary path for riders that I had been following for an hour or more.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Just before nightfall, I walked by a farmhouse where a farmer was sitting at his door, eating his supper of bread and cheese. I paused and asked him, "Would you please give me some bread? I'm very hungry." He looked at me with surprise, but silently cut a thick slice from his loaf and handed it to me. I think he didn't consider me a beggar, just an unusual lady with a taste for his brown bread. Once I was out of sight of the house, I sat down and ate the bread. I didn't expect to find shelter indoors that night, so I went into the woods I'd mentioned earlier. My night was miserable: the ground was wet, the air was cold, and several times people walked close by, forcing me to move about often. I never felt safe or at ease. It began to rain as morning approached, and it continued all the next day. Please don't ask for a detailed account of that day. As before, I looked for work, was turned away, and went hungry—except for one occasion. At the door of a cottage, I saw a young girl about to throw out some cold porridge for the pigs. I asked, "Could I have that?" She stared at me and called out, "Mother! There's a woman who wants me to give her this porridge." A voice from inside responded, "Go on, give it to her if she needs it. The pig doesn't want it." The girl then poured the cold porridge into my hand, and I ate it greedily. As the rainy dusk grew deeper, I found myself stopping on a lonely bridle-path where I'd been walking for over an hour.

events.title: Profound Despair and the Emergence of a Forlorn Hope
detailed_summary: Jane feels her physical strength rapidly diminishing, believing she cannot continue much longer.
She anticipates another night exposed to the elements as an outcast and considers the likelihood of dying before morning.
The thought of Mr. Rochester being alive makes her struggle against the acceptance of death, as perishing from want and cold feels unbearable while he lives.
In her desperation, she utters a fervent prayer for divine intervention and guidance.
Surveying the dim, misty landscape, she realizes she has wandered far from the village and is now near moorland again.
She reflects that dying on the open moor would be preferable to succumbing in a street or ending up in a workhouse.
While searching for a sheltered place to lie down on the desolate, level terrain, she notices the subtle variations in the moor's coloring.
As darkness fully sets in, she spots a steady light in the distance, shining from among the marshes and ridges.
Initially, she dismisses it as a misleading will-o'-the-wisp, then speculates it might be a bonfire, but its unwavering nature leads her to conjecture it could be a candle in a house.
Despite her doubts about reaching it or receiving a welcome, the distant light becomes her final, desperate hope, and she resolves to try and make her way towards it.
She momentarily collapses in despair, overcome by the harsh wind and rain, but the persistent glow of the light encourages her to rise and continue.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “My strength is quite failing me,” I said in a soliloquy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This light was my forlorn hope: I must gain it.

events.text_segment:
“My strength is quite failing me,” I said in a soliloquy. “I feel I cannot go much farther. Shall I be an outcast again this night? While the rain descends so, must I lay my head on the cold, drenched ground? I fear I cannot do otherwise: for who will receive me? But it will be very dreadful, with this feeling of hunger, faintness, chill, and this sense of desolation—this total prostration of hope. In all likelihood, though, I should die before morning. And why cannot I reconcile myself to the prospect of death? Why do I struggle to retain a valueless life? Because I know, or believe, Mr. Rochester is living: and then, to die of want and cold is a fate to which nature cannot submit passively. Oh, Providence! sustain me a little longer! Aid!—direct me!”
My glazed eye wandered over the dim and misty landscape. I saw I had strayed far from the village: it was quite out of sight. The very cultivation surrounding it had disappeared. I had, by cross-ways and by-paths, once more drawn near the tract of moorland; and now, only a few fields, almost as wild and unproductive as the heath from which they were scarcely reclaimed, lay between me and the dusky hill.
“Well, I would rather die yonder than in a street or on a frequented road,” I reflected. “And far better that crows and ravens—if any ravens there be in these regions—should pick my flesh from my bones, than that they should be prisoned in a workhouse coffin and moulder in a pauper’s grave.”
To the hill, then, I turned. I reached it. It remained now only to find a hollow where I could lie down, and feel at least hidden, if not secure. But all the surface of the waste looked level. It showed no variation but of tint: green, where rush and moss overgrew the marshes; black, where the dry soil bore only heath. Dark as it was getting, I could still see these changes, though but as mere alternations of light and shade; for colour had faded with the daylight.
My eye still roved over the sullen swell and along the moor-edge, vanishing amidst the wildest scenery, when at one dim point, far in among the marshes and the ridges, a light sprang up. “That is an ignis fatuus,” was my first thought; and I expected it would soon vanish. It burnt on, however, quite steadily, neither receding nor advancing. “Is it, then, a bonfire just kindled?” I questioned. I watched to see whether it would spread: but no; as it did not diminish, so it did not enlarge. “It may be a candle in a house,” I then conjectured; “but if so, I can never reach it. It is much too far away: and were it within a yard of me, what would it avail? I should but knock at the door to have it shut in my face.”
And I sank down where I stood, and hid my face against the ground. I lay still a while: the night-wind swept over the hill and over me, and died moaning in the distance; the rain fell fast, wetting me afresh to the skin. Could I but have stiffened to the still frost—the friendly numbness of death—it might have pelted on; I should not have felt it; but my yet living flesh shuddered at its chilling influence. I rose ere long.
The light was yet there, shining dim but constant through the rain. I tried to walk again: I dragged my exhausted limbs slowly towards it. It led me aslant over the hill, through a wide bog, which would have been impassable in winter, and was splashy and shaking even now, in the height of summer. Here I fell twice; but as often I rose and rallied my faculties. This light was my forlorn hope: I must gain it.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Speaking to myself, I said, “My strength is completely giving out.” I felt I couldn’t go much further. Would I be without shelter again tonight? With the rain pouring down like this, must I lay my head on the cold, soaked ground? I feared I had no other choice, for who would take me in? But it would be truly dreadful, with this sensation of hunger, weakness, cold, and profound loneliness—this utter loss of hope. In all likelihood, though, I would die before morning. And why couldn't I accept the prospect of death? Why was I struggling to hold onto a life that seemed worthless? Because I knew, or believed, Mr. Rochester was still alive; and furthermore, nature cannot passively accept dying from lack and cold. Oh, Providence! Support me a little longer! Help! Guide me!
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Feeling weak and exhausted, I spoke to myself, realizing I couldn't go on much longer. I wondered if I would have to spend another night as an outcast, forced to sleep on the wet, cold ground in the heavy rain. The prospect frightened me, especially as I was hungry, faint, cold, and utterly without hope. I imagined I might not survive the night, and questioned why I couldn't accept the thought of death, or why I clung to what seemed like a worthless life. I supposed it was because I believed Mr. Rochester was still alive, and that facing death from starvation and exposure was something my nature could not simply accept. Desperate, I called out to Providence to help and guide me.

My unfocused gaze drifted across the gloomy, mist-shrouded land. I realized I had wandered far from the village, which was nowhere to be seen, and even the cultivated fields nearby had disappeared. Taking side paths, I had once again come near the moors, with only a few fields—barely more fertile than the wild heath—separating me from a dark hill.

I decided that if I were to die, I would rather do so on the hill than on a public road. I thought it better if birds like crows or ravens picked my remains than for my body to end up in a pauper’s grave from a workhouse. With this thought, I headed for the hill and searched for a hollow to lie in, somewhere at least hidden, if not safe. But as I looked around, the terrain seemed flat except for some color changes: green where marshes were overgrown, black where only heath grew. Even in the deepening darkness, I could just make out these differences as patches of light and shade rather than color.

My eyes wandered over the restless land until, far in the marshes, I noticed a faint light appear.
