At first, I thought it must be a will-o’-the-wisp and expected it to disappear, but it continued to shine steadily. I wondered if it might be a newly lit bonfire, but it neither grew nor shrank. Then I considered it could be a candle in a distant house, though reaching it seemed impossible, and even if I did, I doubted I’d be welcomed.

Discouraged, I collapsed to the ground, burying my face and lying still while the rain beat down and the wind howled around me. I wished for the numbness that comes with death, but my living body still reacted to the chill. Eventually, I got up.

The light still glimmered steadily through the rain, and I forced myself to move toward it, dragging my weary limbs over the hill and through a vast, sodden bog that would have been impassable in winter, and was treacherous enough in summer. I stumbled and fell twice, but each time managed to get up and continue. That light was my last hope—I had to reach it.

events.title: Arrival at Moor House and Observation of its Inhabitants
detailed_summary: Jane arduously navigates a treacherous marsh, falling twice but propelled by the singular hope the distant light offers.
She eventually finds a track that leads directly to the light, which appears to emanate from a small knoll surrounded by trees.
As she draws nearer, the light is suddenly obscured by a low wall, palisades, and a dense hedge.
Groping her way along the barrier, she discovers a wicket gate and passes through it.
The house before her appears dark, and she fears its occupants have already retired for the night.
Upon turning a corner of the building, she sees the friendly gleam again, this time pinpointing its source: a very small, ivy-obscured latticed window close to the ground.

By stooping and moving aside the foliage, Jane is able to see clearly into the room: a meticulously clean kitchen with a sanded floor, a glowing peat fire, a walnut dresser with pewter plates, a clock, a table, and chairs. The candle that had been her beacon burns on the table.
She observes an elderly woman, rough-looking but scrupulously clean (Hannah), knitting by the candlelight.

More significantly, she sees two young, graceful women (Diana and Mary) dressed in deep mourning, seated near the hearth and engrossed in reading. A large pointer dog rests its head on one sister's knee, while a black cat is curled in the lap of the other.

Jane is struck by the refined appearance of these women in such a humble setting and feels an odd sense of familiarity with their features, though she would not describe them as conventionally beautiful due to their pallor and gravity.
They seem to be engaged in scholarly work, comparing smaller books with larger volumes, possibly for translation. The entire scene is remarkably silent.
The silence is broken when one sister (Diana) urges the other (Mary) to listen as she reads a passage aloud in a language Jane does not recognize (German), which she evidently finds powerful.
Mary repeats a line from the reading, a line Jane would come to understand later.

Hannah, the elderly woman, inquires about the language, and the sisters explain it is German, which they are studying with the aim of teaching it to improve their financial situation, acknowledging the difficulty of learning it without a tutor.
Diana notes it is ten o'clock and expresses a wish for their brother, St. John, to return home. She then asks Hannah to attend to the fire in the parlour.
Hannah's return from the parlour is marked by sadness as she mentions the loneliness of the room with their father's chair now empty, alluding to his recent death.

The sisters ask if their father mentioned them before he passed; Hannah explains his death was sudden, leaving no time for last words. She recounts his peaceful passing and comments on family resemblances, likening Mary to their mother and Diana to their father.
Jane, observing them, notes their shared fair complexions and intelligent faces, with subtle differences in hair color and style.

As Hannah begins to prepare supper, the sisters appear ready to move to the parlour. This impending change jolts Jane from her absorbed observation, and the full weight of her desperate situation crashes back upon her, appearing even more hopeless in contrast to the domestic peace she has witnessed.
She feels an overwhelming sense of impossibility at the thought of conveying her needs to the inhabitants or inducing them to offer her aid.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Having crossed the marsh, I saw a trace of white over the moor.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And how impossible did it appear to touch the inmates of this house with concern on my behalf; to make them believe in the truth of my wants and woes—to induce them to vouchsafe a rest for my wanderings!

events.text_segment:
Having crossed the marsh, I saw a trace of white over the moor. I approached it; it was a road or a track: it led straight up to the light, which now beamed from a sort of knoll, amidst a clump of trees—firs, apparently, from what I could distinguish of the character of their forms and foliage through the gloom. My star vanished as I drew near: some obstacle had intervened between me and it. I put out my hand to feel the dark mass before me: I discriminated the rough stones of a low wall—above it, something like palisades, and within, a high and prickly hedge. I groped on. Again a whitish object gleamed before me: it was a gate—a wicket; it moved on its hinges as I touched it. On each side stood a sable bush—holly or yew.
Entering the gate and passing the shrubs, the silhouette of a house rose to view, black, low, and rather long; but the guiding light shone nowhere. All was obscurity. Were the inmates retired to rest? I feared it must be so. In seeking the door, I turned an angle: there shot out the friendly gleam again, from the lozenged panes of a very small latticed window, within a foot of the ground, made still smaller by the growth of ivy or some other creeping plant, whose leaves clustered thick over the portion of the house wall in which it was set. The aperture was so screened and narrow, that curtain or shutter had been deemed unnecessary; and when I stooped down and put aside the spray of foliage shooting over it, I could see all within. I could see clearly a room with a sanded floor, clean scoured; a dresser of walnut, with pewter plates ranged in rows, reflecting the redness and radiance of a glowing peat-fire. I could see a clock, a white deal table, some chairs. The candle, whose ray had been my beacon, burnt on the table; and by its light an elderly woman, somewhat rough-looking, but scrupulously clean, like all about her, was knitting a stocking.
I noticed these objects cursorily only—in them there was nothing extraordinary. A group of more interest appeared near the hearth, sitting still amidst the rosy peace and warmth suffusing it. Two young, graceful women—ladies in every point—sat, one in a low rocking-chair, the other on a lower stool; both wore deep mourning of crape and bombazeen, which sombre garb singularly set off very fair necks and faces: a large old pointer dog rested its massive head on the knee of one girl—in the lap of the other was cushioned a black cat.
A strange place was this humble kitchen for such occupants! Who were they? They could not be the daughters of the elderly person at the table; for she looked like a rustic, and they were all delicacy and cultivation. I had nowhere seen such faces as theirs: and yet, as I gazed on them, I seemed intimate with every lineament. I cannot call them handsome—they were too pale and grave for the word: as they each bent over a book, they looked thoughtful almost to severity. A stand between them supported a second candle and two great volumes, to which they frequently referred, comparing them, seemingly, with the smaller books they held in their hands, like people consulting a dictionary to aid them in the task of translation. This scene was as silent as if all the figures had been shadows and the firelit apartment a picture: so hushed was it, I could hear the cinders fall from the grate, the clock tick in its obscure corner; and I even fancied I could distinguish the click-click of the woman’s knitting-needles. When, therefore, a voice broke the strange stillness at last, it was audible enough to me.
“Listen, Diana,” said one of the absorbed students; “Franz and old Daniel are together in the night-time, and Franz is telling a dream from which he has awakened in terror—listen!” And in a low voice she read something, of which not one word was intelligible to me; for it was in an unknown tongue—neither French nor Latin. Whether it were Greek or German I could not tell.
“That is strong,” she said, when she had finished: “I relish it.” The other girl, who had lifted her head to listen to her sister, repeated, while she gazed at the fire, a line of what had been read. At a later day, I knew the language and the book; therefore, I will here quote the line: though, when I first heard it, it was only like a stroke on sounding brass to me—conveying no meaning:—
“‘Da trat hervor Einer, anzusehen wie die Sternen Nacht.’ Good! good!” she exclaimed, while her dark and deep eye sparkled. “There you have a dim and mighty archangel fitly set before you! The line is worth a hundred pages of fustian. ‘Ich wäge die Gedanken in der Schale meines Zornes und die Werke mit dem Gewichte meines Grimms.’ I like it!”
Both were again silent.
“Is there ony country where they talk i’ that way?” asked the old woman, looking up from her knitting.
“Yes, Hannah—a far larger country than England, where they talk in no other way.”
“Well, for sure case, I knawn’t how they can understand t’ one t’other: and if either o’ ye went there, ye could tell what they said, I guess?”
“We could probably tell something of what they said, but not all—for we are not as clever as you think us, Hannah. We don’t speak German, and we cannot read it without a dictionary to help us.”
“And what good does it do you?”
“We mean to teach it some time—or at least the elements, as they say; and then we shall get more money than we do now.”
“Varry like: but give ower studying; ye’ve done enough for to-night.”
“I think we have: at least I’m tired. Mary, are you?”
“Mortally: after all, it’s tough work fagging away at a language with no master but a lexicon.”
“It is, especially such a language as this crabbed but glorious Deutsch. I wonder when St. John will come home.”
“Surely he will not be long now: it is just ten (looking at a little gold watch she drew from her girdle). It rains fast, Hannah: will you have the goodness to look at the fire in the parlour?”
The woman rose: she opened a door, through which I dimly saw a passage: soon I heard her stir a fire in an inner room; she presently came back.
“Ah, childer!” said she, “it fair troubles me to go into yond’ room now: it looks so lonesome wi’ the chair empty and set back in a corner.”
She wiped her eyes with her apron: the two girls, grave before, looked sad now.
“But he is in a better place,” continued Hannah: “we shouldn’t wish him here again. And then, nobody need to have a quieter death nor he had.”
“You say he never mentioned us?” inquired one of the ladies.
“He hadn’t time, bairn: he was gone in a minute, was your father. He had been a bit ailing like the day before, but naught to signify; and when Mr. St. John asked if he would like either o’ ye to be sent for, he fair laughed at him. He began again with a bit of a heaviness in his head the next day—that is, a fortnight sin’—and he went to sleep and niver wakened: he wor a’most stark when your brother went into t’ chamber and fand him. Ah, childer! that’s t’ last o’ t’ old stock—for ye and Mr. St. John is like of different soart to them ’at’s gone; for all your mother wor mich i’ your way, and a’most as book-learned. She wor the pictur’ o’ ye, Mary: Diana is more like your father.”
I thought them so similar I could not tell where the old servant (for such I now concluded her to be) saw the difference. Both were fair complexioned and slenderly made; both possessed faces full of distinction and intelligence. One, to be sure, had hair a shade darker than the other, and there was a difference in their style of wearing it; Mary’s pale brown locks were parted and braided smooth: Diana’s duskier tresses covered her neck with thick curls. The clock struck ten.
“Ye’ll want your supper, I am sure,” observed Hannah; “and so will Mr. St. John when he comes in.”
And she proceeded to prepare the meal. The ladies rose; they seemed about to withdraw to the parlour. Till this moment, I had been so intent on watching them, their appearance and conversation had excited in me so keen an interest, I had half-forgotten my own wretched position: now it recurred to me. More desolate, more desperate than ever, it seemed from contrast. And how impossible did it appear to touch the inmates of this house with concern on my behalf; to make them believe in the truth of my wants and woes—to induce them to vouchsafe a rest for my wanderings!
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: After traversing the marsh, I spotted a white line on the moor. As I approached, I saw it was a road or track that led directly towards the light, which was now coming from a slight elevation among a group of trees, apparently firs based on their shapes and foliage in the dim light. As I drew near, my guiding light disappeared, hidden by an obstacle. I reached out my hand to feel the dark shape before me and found the rough stones of a low wall, topped by something resembling vertical posts and a dense, spiky hedge inside. I moved along, feeling my way. Another pale object became visible ahead: a gate, a wicket gate. It swung open when I touched its hinges. Dark bushes, either holly or yew, stood on either side. Stepping through the gate and past the bushes, the outline of a house appeared, dark, low, and rather long, but the guiding light was no longer anywhere to be seen. All was dark. Had the residents gone to bed? I feared this was likely. Searching for the door, I turned a corner, and the welcoming gleam reappeared. It shone from a very small latticed window with diamond-shaped panes, barely a foot from the ground. It was made even smaller by thick ivy or some other creeping plant whose leaves clustered heavily over the wall where it was set. The opening was so narrow and obscured that curtains or shutters must have been considered unnecessary. When I stooped down and pushed aside the leaves covering it, I could see clearly into the room. I saw a room with a clean, sanded floor; a walnut dresser displaying rows of polished pewter plates that reflected the warm, bright glow of a peat fire. I could see a clock, a plain wooden table, and some chairs. The candle whose light had guided me burned on the table. By its light, an older woman, somewhat plain-faced but meticulously clean, like everything around her, was knitting a stocking. I only observed these things briefly; there was nothing unusual about them. A more intriguing group was seated near the hearth, still and peaceful in the rosy warmth it cast. Two young women, clearly refined ladies, sat there – one in a low rocking chair, the other on a low stool. Both wore deep black mourning attire of crape and bombazine, a dark dress that notably highlighted their very fair complexions. A large old pointer dog rested its heavy head on the knee of one young woman, while a black cat was cushioned on the lap of the other. This simple kitchen seemed a strange setting for such occupants! Who were they? They couldn't be the elderly woman's daughters, as she appeared rustic, while they were the picture of delicacy and refinement. I had never seen faces quite like theirs, yet as I looked, each feature felt strangely familiar. I couldn't call them beautiful; they were too pale and serious for that description. Both were absorbed in books, looking thoughtful almost to the point of sternness. A stand between them held a second candle and two large volumes they often consulted, comparing them, it seemed, with the smaller books in their hands, like people using a dictionary to assist with translation. The scene was as silent as if the figures were shadows and the firelit room a painting. It was so quiet that I could hear the cinders falling from the grate, the clock ticking in its dim corner, and I even imagined I could distinguish the subtle click of the woman's knitting needles. Therefore, when a voice finally broke the strange stillness, it was quite audible to me. "Listen, Diana," said one of the absorbed students. "Franz and old Daniel are together at night, and Franz is telling about a dream he woke from in terror – listen!" She then read something softly, but I could not understand a single word; it was in an unfamiliar language, neither French nor Latin. I could not tell if it was Greek or German. "That is powerful," she said when she finished. "I appreciate it." The other sister, who had raised her head to listen, repeated a line of what had been read while gazing at the fire. At a later time, I learned the language and the book, so I will quote the line here, although when I first heard it, it was just noise to me, like a strike on sounding brass, carrying no meaning: "'Da trat hervor Einer, anzusehen wie die Sternen Nacht.' Good! Good!" she exclaimed, her dark, deep eyes sparkling. "There, you have a mysterious and mighty archangel vividly presented! That line is worth a hundred pages of pompous writing. 'Ich wäge die Gedanken in der Schale meines Zornes und die Werke mit dem Gewichte meines Grimms.' I like it!" Both were silent once more. "Is there anywhere folks talk like that?" the old woman asked, looking up from her knitting. "Yes, Hannah," said one of the young women, "a much larger country than England, where they speak no other way." "Well, honestly, I don't know how they can understand one another," Hannah said. "And if either of you went there, you could understand what they said, I suppose?" "We could probably understand some of what they said, but not everything," replied the young woman, "for we are not as clever as you believe us to be, Hannah. We don't speak German, and we cannot read it without a dictionary to help us." "And what benefit does it bring you?" Hannah inquired. "We intend to teach it someday," one explained, "or at least the basic elements, as they say, and then we shall earn more money than we do now." "Very likely," said Hannah, "but stop studying now; you've done sufficient work for tonight." "I think we have," one agreed. "At least I'm tired. Are you, Mary?" "Extremely," Mary responded. "After all, it's hard work diligently studying a language with no teacher but a dictionary." "It is," the first woman agreed, "especially a difficult but wonderful language like this German. I wonder when St. John will return home." "Surely he won't be long now," Mary said, checking a small gold watch she pulled from her belt. "It is precisely ten. It is raining heavily, Hannah; would you be kind enough to check the fire in the parlour?" The woman rose and opened a door, through which I dimly saw a hallway. Soon I heard her attending to a fire in an inner room; she returned shortly. "Oh, children!" she sighed, "it truly saddens me to go into that room now. It looks so desolate with the chair empty and pushed back into a corner." She wiped her eyes with her apron. The two girls, who had been serious before, now looked sad. "But he is in a better place," Hannah continued. "We should not wish him back here. And truly, no one could have had a more peaceful death than he did." "You say he never mentioned us?" one of the ladies asked. "He did not have time, child," Hannah replied. "Your father was gone in an instant. He had been slightly unwell the day before, but nothing significant; and when Mr. St. John asked if he would like either of you to be sent for, he simply laughed at him. He felt a bit of a heaviness in his head again the next day – that was two weeks ago – and he went to sleep and never woke up. He was nearly stiff when your brother went into the room and found him. Ah, children! That is the last of the old generation – for you and Mr. St. John are of a different kind from those who are gone, even though your mother was much like you and almost as well-read. She was the image of you, Mary; Diana is more like your father." I thought them so similar I couldn't see the difference the old servant (for I now concluded that was her role) perceived. Both had fair complexions and slender builds; both possessed faces that showed intelligence and distinction. One, to be sure, had hair a shade darker than the other, and they styled it differently. Mary's pale brown hair was parted and smoothly braided, while Diana's darker tresses covered her neck in thick curls. The clock struck ten. "You will want your supper, I am sure," Hannah observed, "and so will Mr. St. John when he arrives." And she proceeded to prepare the meal. The ladies rose; they seemed about to retire to the parlour. Until this moment, I had been so engrossed in watching them, their appearance and conversation had sparked such strong interest in me, that I had partly forgotten my own desperate situation. Now it came back to me. By contrast, it seemed even more desolate and hopeless than before. And how impossible it felt to make the occupants of this house care about my plight, to convince them of the truth of my needs and sorrows, or to persuade them to offer me a rest from my wandering.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After crossing the marshland, I noticed a pale streak on the moor. As I got closer, I realized it was a road or pathway that led directly toward a light shining from a small hill among a cluster of trees, which I thought were firs based on their shapes and leaves seen through the darkness. The light disappeared as I approached, blocked by something. Reaching out, I touched a rough stone wall topped with something like a fence, and behind it, a tall, prickly hedge. I continued moving and soon saw a faintly white object ahead—a small gate that swung open at my touch, flanked by dark bushes, probably holly or yew.

Once through the gate and past the shrubs, the outline of a house appeared: it was long, low, and black against the night, with no sign of the light that had led me there—everything was dark. I wondered if everyone inside had gone to bed. Searching for the door, I rounded a corner and spotted the welcoming light again, shining from a tiny lattice window close to the ground, almost hidden by thick ivy or some climbing plant covering that section of the wall. The window was so thoroughly screened by foliage that no curtain or shutter was needed; when I brushed aside the leaves and bent down, I could see everything inside. The room was clean with a sanded floor, a walnut dresser lined with shining pewter plates catching the red glow from a peat fire. I saw a clock, a white wooden table, chairs, and a candle—the source of the guiding light—on the table, next to an elderly woman, plainly dressed but very tidy, busily knitting a stocking.

I only glanced briefly at these things, for none were truly remarkable. What caught my eye was a more interesting group by the cozy hearth: two elegant young women, unmistakably ladies, one seated in a rocking-chair, the other on a low stool. They wore deep black mourning clothes, which contrasted with their fair skin and features. A large old pointer dog rested its head on one girl’s knee, while a black cat curled up in the other’s lap. Their refined presence seemed out of place in such a simple kitchen—who could they be? Surely not the elderly woman's daughters, for she was rustic while they were delicate and cultured. I had never seen such faces, though they felt strangely familiar. They weren’t quite beautiful—too pale and serious—but appeared absorbed in their books, looking thoughtful to the point of severity. On a stand between them was another candle and two large volumes, which they consulted with the smaller books in their hands, like people translating with a dictionary. The scene was so still it felt like a picture: I could hear the fire crackle, the clock tick, and possibly the soft clicking of the woman’s needles. When a voice finally broke the silence, it was clear to me.

“Listen, Diana,” said one of the young women. “Franz and old Daniel are together at night, and Franz is describing a terrifying dream—listen!” She read aloud in a language I didn’t recognize—not French or Latin. Was it Greek or German, I wondered. When she finished, she commented on the strength of the passage, and her sister repeated a line, gazing into the fire. Later, I would come to know the language and book, but at that moment the words were meaningless—just sounds to me. The sister exclaimed on the power of the verse, and both girls fell silent again.

The old woman, looking up from her knitting, asked if there was anywhere people spoke like that. The girls replied that a country much larger than England used such language, though they admitted their understanding was limited—they needed a dictionary to read it. She asked what purpose the study served, and they explained they hoped to teach it and earn more money in time. The woman told them to end their studies for the night, and the girls agreed they were tired; one observed that learning a language by dictionary was hard work, especially one as difficult as German, and wondered when St. John would return. The other replied he’d be home soon, mentioning the time. The servant went to tend the fire in another room and returned, expressing how lonely the parlor felt since someone’s death. She wiped her eyes; the girls grew sad. Hannah, the servant, continued that the deceased was in a better place and had died peacefully. One girl asked if he’d mentioned them; Hannah replied that he hadn’t, passing quickly after feeling unwell, and that their brother found him already dead. She reminisced about the family, noting the girls’ differences; Mary took after their mother, Diana after their father.

I thought they looked much alike, although one’s hair was slightly darker and styled differently. The clock struck ten, and Hannah mentioned they and Mr. St. John would need supper, so she began to prepare the meal. The ladies seemed about to move to the parlor. Until then, I had been so absorbed in observing them—their appearance and conversation captivated me—that I had half forgotten my own dire predicament. Now it returned to me, making my loneliness and desperation feel even greater by contrast. How could I possibly move these people to care about my hardship, to believe my suffering, and offer me the refuge I so needed?

events.title: Rejection by Hannah and Unexpected Rescue by St. John
detailed_summary: Despite her feelings of hopelessness, Jane summons the courage to knock hesitantly at the door.
Hannah opens it, appearing surprised, and begins to question Jane about who she is, where she comes from, and her purpose for being there at such a late hour.
Jane identifies herself as a stranger in need of a night's shelter and a morsel of bread.

Hannah's face shows the distrust Jane had feared. She offers Jane a piece of bread (later a penny) but firmly refuses to grant her lodging, stating they cannot take in vagrants and that it isn't likely.

Jane pleads to be allowed to speak to Hannah's mistresses, but Hannah adamantly refuses, her suspicion growing. She accuses Jane of making an undue disturbance and implies she might have sinister intentions or be accompanied by wrongdoers.
With a final warning, Hannah claps the door shut and bolts it from within, leaving Jane outside in the storm.
This ultimate rejection marks the lowest point of Jane's suffering. Overwhelmed by anguish and despair, she collapses onto the wet doorstep, feeling utterly abandoned by her kind.
She attempts to compose herself and resolve to await God's will in silence.
At this moment, a man's voice (St. John Rivers) speaks from nearby, acknowledging that if she were to perish there of want, it would be a lingering and premature doom.
The newcomer then knocks loudly at the door. Hannah, recognizing the voice as Mr. St. John's, quickly opens it.
Hannah expresses concern for St. John's being out in the wild night and mentions the "beggar-woman" still present, urging her to leave.

St. John, however, silences Hannah, explaining that he overheard the entire exchange between her and Jane. He states that while Hannah fulfilled her duty in excluding the stranger, he will now fulfill his by admitting her, as he believes her case is peculiar and requires examination.
He then compassionately instructs Jane to rise and enter the house.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I groped out the door, and knocked at it hesitatingly, I felt that last idea to be a mere chimera. Hannah opened.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Young woman, rise, and pass before me into the house.”

events.text_segment:
As I groped out the door, and knocked at it hesitatingly, I felt that last idea to be a mere chimera. Hannah opened.
“What do you want?” she inquired, in a voice of surprise, as she surveyed me by the light of the candle she held.
“May I speak to your mistresses?” I said.
“You had better tell me what you have to say to them. Where do you come from?”
“I am a stranger.”
“What is your business here at this hour?”
“I want a night’s shelter in an out-house or anywhere, and a morsel of bread to eat.”
Distrust, the very feeling I dreaded, appeared in Hannah’s face. “I’ll give you a piece of bread,” she said, after a pause; “but we can’t take in a vagrant to lodge. It isn’t likely.”
“Do let me speak to your mistresses.”
“No, not I. What can they do for you? You should not be roving about now; it looks very ill.”
“But where shall I go if you drive me away? What shall I do?”
“Oh, I’ll warrant you know where to go and what to do. Mind you don’t do wrong, that’s all. Here is a penny; now go—”
“A penny cannot feed me, and I have no strength to go farther. Don’t shut the door:—oh, don’t, for God’s sake!”
“I must; the rain is driving in—”
“Tell the young ladies. Let me see them—”
“Indeed, I will not. You are not what you ought to be, or you wouldn’t make such a noise. Move off.”
“But I must die if I am turned away.”
“Not you. I’m fear’d you have some ill plans agate, that bring you about folk’s houses at this time o’ night. If you’ve any followers—housebreakers or such like—anywhere near, you may tell them we are not by ourselves in the house; we have a gentleman, and dogs, and guns.” Here the honest but inflexible servant clapped the door to and bolted it within.
This was the climax. A pang of exquisite suffering—a throe of true despair—rent and heaved my heart. Worn out, indeed, I was; not another step could I stir. I sank on the wet doorstep: I groaned—I wrung my hands—I wept in utter anguish. Oh, this spectre of death! Oh, this last hour, approaching in such horror! Alas, this isolation—this banishment from my kind! Not only the anchor of hope, but the footing of fortitude was gone—at least for a moment; but the last I soon endeavoured to regain.
“I can but die,” I said, “and I believe in God. Let me try to wait His will in silence.”
These words I not only thought, but uttered; and thrusting back all my misery into my heart, I made an effort to compel it to remain there—dumb and still.
“All men must die,” said a voice quite close at hand; “but all are not condemned to meet a lingering and premature doom, such as yours would be if you perished here of want.”
“Who or what speaks?” I asked, terrified at the unexpected sound, and incapable now of deriving from any occurrence a hope of aid. A form was near—what form, the pitch-dark night and my enfeebled vision prevented me from distinguishing. With a loud long knock, the new-comer appealed to the door.
“Is it you, Mr. St. John?” cried Hannah.
“Yes—yes; open quickly.”
“Well, how wet and cold you must be, such a wild night as it is! Come in—your sisters are quite uneasy about you, and I believe there are bad folks about. There has been a beggar-woman—I declare she is not gone yet!—laid down there. Get up! for shame! Move off, I say!”
“Hush, Hannah! I have a word to say to the woman. You have done your duty in excluding, now let me do mine in admitting her. I was near, and listened to both you and her. I think this is a peculiar case—I must at least examine into it. Young woman, rise, and pass before me into the house.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Fumbling my way to the door and knocking hesitantly, I felt that my last idea was just a fantasy. Hannah answered. "What do you want?" she asked, surprised, looking at me in the light of her candle. I replied, "May I speak with your mistresses?" She countered, "You should tell me what you need to say to them. Where are you from?" I said simply, "I am a stranger." "Why are you here at this hour?" she pressed. "I need a place to stay for the night, perhaps in an outbuilding or anywhere, and something small to eat." The very thing I feared, suspicion, showed on Hannah's face. After a pause, she said, "I'll give you some bread, but we cannot let a wanderer lodge here. It's not reasonable." "Please, just let me talk to your mistresses." "Absolutely not. What could they do for you? You shouldn't be wandering around at this time; it looks very bad." I asked desperately, "But where am I supposed to go if you turn me away? What will I do?" She scoffed, "Oh, I'm sure you know where to go and what to do. Just be careful not to do anything wrong, that's all. Here's a penny; now leave—" I pleaded, "A penny won't feed me, and I don't have the strength to go any further. Don't shut the door—oh, please, for the love of God, don't!" "I have to; the rain is coming in—" I begged, "Tell the young ladies. Let me see them—" Adamantly, she refused, "Indeed, I will not. You are not who you should be, or you wouldn't be making such a disturbance. Go away." "But I might die if you refuse me." "Not likely. I suspect you're plotting something bad, coming around people's homes at this time of night. If you have any accomplices—burglars or the like—nearby, you can tell them we are not alone in the house; we have a gentleman, dogs, and weapons." At this, the upright but unyielding servant slammed the door shut and bolted it from the inside. This was the absolute worst. A sharp stab of extreme pain—a moment of true hopelessness—tore and convulsed my heart. I was utterly exhausted; I couldn't take another step. I collapsed onto the wet doorstep, groaning, wringing my hands, and crying in complete agony. Oh, this terrifying image of death! Oh, this final hour, approaching with such dread! Alas, this isolation—this separation from my fellow human beings! Not only had the anchor of hope been lost, but my ability to endure had also vanished—at least momentarily; but I quickly tried to regain the latter. I told myself, "I can only die, and I trust in God. I will try to await His will silently." I not only thought these words but spoke them aloud; pushing all my suffering back into my heart, I forced myself to make it stay there—quiet and unmoving. "Everyone must die," a voice said very close by; "but not everyone is fated to face a slow, premature death like yours would be if you perished here from lack of help." "Who or what is speaking?" I asked, startled by the sudden sound and no longer capable of finding hope in anything that happened. A shape was near—but the total darkness and my failing sight prevented me from making out what it was. With a loud, prolonged knock, the newcomer rapped on the door. "Is that you, Mr. St. John?" Hannah called out. "Yes—yes; open quickly." "Well, you must be so wet and cold on such a terrible night! Come in—your sisters were quite worried about you, and I believe there are bad people around. There was a beggar woman—I can't believe she's still here!—lying right there. Get up! Shame on you! Move off, I said!" "Quiet, Hannah! I need a word with the woman. You have done your duty by keeping her out, now let me do mine by bringing her in. I was close by and heard both of you. I think this situation is unusual—I must investigate it. Young woman, please stand up and come into the house ahead of me."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
As I felt my way to the door and knocked on it uncertainly, I realized my last thought was just an illusion. Hannah answered the door.

"What do you want?" she asked, clearly surprised as she looked at me in the candlelight.

"Could I speak to your mistresses?" I requested.

"You’d best tell me what you want with them. Where do you come from?"

"I’m a stranger."

"Why are you here so late?"

"I just need somewhere to sleep for the night—a shed or something—and a bit of bread."

Suspicion, exactly what I’d feared, showed on Hannah’s face. After a short pause, she replied, "I’ll give you some bread, but we can’t let a vagrant stay here. That’s not possible."

"Please, let me speak to your mistresses."

"No, I won’t. What could they do for you? You shouldn’t be wandering around at this time—it looks bad."

"But where can I go if you send me away? What can I do?"

"Oh, I’m sure you know how to get by. Just don’t get into trouble, that’s all. Here’s a penny—now leave."

"A penny won’t feed me, and I’m too weak to go on. Please don’t close the door—please, for God’s sake!"

"I have to close it—it’s raining in."

"Please tell the young ladies. Let me see them—"

"No, I won’t. If you were decent, you wouldn’t make such a fuss. Move along."

"But if I’m turned away, I’ll die."

"Nonsense. I think you’re up to no good, showing up at people’s houses at this hour. If you’ve got anyone hiding—robbers or the like—let them know we’re not alone. There’s a gentleman here, and dogs, and guns." With that, the steadfast but honest servant slammed the door and locked it.

That was the breaking point. A sharp pain and overwhelming despair overtook me. I was completely exhausted—unable to move another step. I collapsed on the wet doorstep, groaned, wrung my hands, and wept in total misery. The idea of dying haunted me; the horror of this final moment, so dreadful, filled me with sorrow. Being so alone, so cast out from humanity! I had lost not only hope but even my courage—at least briefly, though I soon tried to regain it.

"All I can do is die," I said. "I believe in God. I must try to wait silently for His will."

I not only thought these words but said them aloud, pushing all my suffering back into my heart and forcing myself to contain it in silence.

"Everyone dies," spoke a voice very close by, "but not everyone has to face a slow and untimely death like yours would be if you starved here."

"Who’s there?" I asked, startled by the unexpected sound, unable now to hope for help from anyone. Someone stood nearby, but I couldn’t see who it was in the dark and with my weakened state. The newcomer rapped loudly on the door.

"Is that you, Mr. St. John?" Hannah called.

"Yes—it’s me. Open quickly."

"You must be soaked and cold out on such a stormy night! Come in—your sisters are worried about you, and I think there are bad people around. There was a beggar woman—I see she’s still there! Get up! Move on!"

"Wait, Hannah! Let me speak to her. You’ve done your part in keeping her out—now let me do mine by letting her in. I heard your conversation. I think this is a special situation; I must at least look into it. Young woman, stand up, and come into the house."

events.title: Admission into Moor House and Compassionate Care
detailed_summary: With considerable effort, Jane complies with St. John's instruction and steps into the warm, bright kitchen, acutely aware of her ghastly, wild, and weather-beaten appearance.
The entire household—St. John, his sisters Diana and Mary, and the servant Hannah—all fix their gaze upon her.
St. John explains he found her at the door. Hannah remarks on her extreme pallor.
Feeling faint, Jane nearly collapses but is guided to a chair. She retains her senses but is initially unable to speak.
The family members observe her emaciated and bloodless state, quickly surmising she is famished rather than ill.
Diana gently offers Jane some bread dipped in milk, her face expressing pity and sympathy. Mary also provides gentle encouragement, removing Jane's soaked bonnet and supporting her head.
Jane begins to eat, weakly at first, then with increasing eagerness. St. John cautions them not to give her too much at once.
When asked her name, Jane, still intent on concealing her true identity, provides the alias "Jane Elliott."
She remains silent when questioned about her home or friends and shakes her head when asked if they can contact anyone she knows.

Despite her physical weakness, the act of crossing the threshold and being among these people helps Jane shed the feeling of being an outcast. She begins to reclaim her natural manner and sense of self.
When St. John requests a full account of her circumstances, she replies that she is currently too weak to provide details.
When he asks what she expects from them, she answers, "Nothing."
Diana then interjects, asking if Jane means they have provided all necessary aid and can now dismiss her back into the stormy night.

Gazing at Diana's kind and powerful countenance, Jane feels a surge of courage. She expresses her complete trust in them, stating she knows they would not turn away even a stray dog, and asks them to do with her as they see fit, excusing herself from lengthy discourse due to her breathlessness.

After a moment of silent observation from all three siblings, St. John instructs Hannah to allow Jane to rest by the fire and to give her the remainder of the milk and bread in ten minutes. He then proposes to his sisters that they retire to the parlour to discuss the matter.
Shortly after they withdraw, one of the sisters returns to give some quiet directions to Hannah.
Soon, with Hannah's assistance, Jane manages to climb the stairs. Her drenched clothes are removed, and she is settled into a warm, dry bed.
Overwhelmed by a profound sense of exhaustion, yet experiencing a glow of grateful joy, Jane thanks God and quickly falls asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: With difficulty I obeyed him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I thanked God—experienced amidst unutterable exhaustion a glow of grateful joy—and slept.

events.text_segment:
With difficulty I obeyed him. Presently I stood within that clean, bright kitchen—on the very hearth—trembling, sickening; conscious of an aspect in the last degree ghastly, wild, and weather-beaten. The two ladies, their brother, Mr. St. John, the old servant, were all gazing at me.
“St. John, who is it?” I heard one ask.
“I cannot tell: I found her at the door,” was the reply.
“She does look white,” said Hannah.
“As white as clay or death,” was responded. “She will fall: let her sit.”
And indeed my head swam: I dropped, but a chair received me. I still possessed my senses, though just now I could not speak.
“Perhaps a little water would restore her. Hannah, fetch some. But she is worn to nothing. How very thin, and how very bloodless!”
“A mere spectre!”
“Is she ill, or only famished?”
“Famished, I think. Hannah, is that milk? Give it me, and a piece of bread.”
Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me) broke some bread, dipped it in milk, and put it to my lips. Her face was near mine: I saw there was pity in it, and I felt sympathy in her hurried breathing. In her simple words, too, the same balm-like emotion spoke: “Try to eat.”
“Yes—try,” repeated Mary gently; and Mary’s hand removed my sodden bonnet and lifted my head. I tasted what they offered me: feebly at first, eagerly soon.
“Not too much at first—restrain her,” said the brother; “she has had enough.” And he withdrew the cup of milk and the plate of bread.
“A little more, St. John—look at the avidity in her eyes.”
“No more at present, sister. Try if she can speak now—ask her her name.”
I felt I could speak, and I answered—“My name is Jane Elliott.” Anxious as ever to avoid discovery, I had before resolved to assume an alias.
“And where do you live? Where are your friends?”
I was silent.
“Can we send for any one you know?”
I shook my head.
“What account can you give of yourself?”
Somehow, now that I had once crossed the threshold of this house, and once was brought face to face with its owners, I felt no longer outcast, vagrant, and disowned by the wide world. I dared to put off the mendicant—to resume my natural manner and character. I began once more to know myself; and when Mr. St. John demanded an account—which at present I was far too weak to render—I said after a brief pause—
“Sir, I can give you no details to-night.”
“But what, then,” said he, “do you expect me to do for you?”
“Nothing,” I replied. My strength sufficed for but short answers. Diana took the word—
“Do you mean,” she asked, “that we have now given you what aid you require? and that we may dismiss you to the moor and the rainy night?”
I looked at her. She had, I thought, a remarkable countenance, instinct both with power and goodness. I took sudden courage. Answering her compassionate gaze with a smile, I said—“I will trust you. If I were a masterless and stray dog, I know that you would not turn me from your hearth to-night: as it is, I really have no fear. Do with me and for me as you like; but excuse me from much discourse—my breath is short—I feel a spasm when I speak.” All three surveyed me, and all three were silent.
“Hannah,” said Mr. St. John, at last, “let her sit there at present, and ask her no questions; in ten minutes more, give her the remainder of that milk and bread. Mary and Diana, let us go into the parlour and talk the matter over.”
They withdrew. Very soon one of the ladies returned—I could not tell which. A kind of pleasant stupor was stealing over me as I sat by the genial fire. In an undertone she gave some directions to Hannah. Ere long, with the servant’s aid, I contrived to mount a staircase; my dripping clothes were removed; soon a warm, dry bed received me. I thanked God—experienced amidst unutterable exhaustion a glow of grateful joy—and slept.

I soon found myself inside the clean, well-lit kitchen, standing right by the fireplace, trembling and feeling sick, acutely aware of looking utterly dreadful, wild, and battered by the weather. The two women, their brother Mr. St. John, and the elderly servant were all staring at me. I heard one of them ask, "St. John, who is this?" He replied, "I don't know; I discovered her at the door." Hannah commented, "She certainly looks pale." Another voice responded, "As pale as death or clay. She's going to collapse; let her sit." Indeed, my head was swimming; I fell, but a chair caught me. "Do you mean," she inquired, "that we have now given you all the help you need, and we may send you back out onto the moor into the rainy night?" I looked at her. I found her face remarkable, full of both strength and kindness. Sudden courage filled me. Responding to her compassionate gaze with a smile, I said, "I will trust you. If I were just a masterless stray dog, I know you wouldn't turn me away from your fire tonight; as it is, I truly have no fear. Do with me and for me as you see fit; but please excuse me from lengthy conversation—my breath is short—I feel a spasm when I speak." All three surveyed me, and all three were silent. "Hannah," Mr. St. John finally said, "let her sit there for now, and don't ask her any questions; in ten more minutes, give her the rest of that milk and bread. I thanked God—feeling a surge of grateful joy amidst profound exhaustion—and fell asleep.

events.title: Semi-conscious Recovery and Early Observations
detailed_summary: The narrator possesses only a hazy memory of the three days following her arrival, during which she was confined to bed, physically incapacitated but mentally aware.
She could perceive her surroundings, recognize her caregivers, and comprehend conversations spoken near her, though she was unable to respond or move.
Hannah, the servant, visited frequently; the narrator sensed Hannah's disapproval and lack of understanding towards her plight.

Diana and Mary also visited, their whispered conversations revealing their compassion, curiosity about her past suffering, and observations about her refined speech and appearance despite her condition.
The narrator found solace in the fact that her benefactors expressed no regret for taking her in, nor any suspicion or dislike towards her.
Mr. St. John visited only once, diagnosing her lethargy as a natural reaction to prolonged and excessive fatigue, rather than an illness, and deemed a doctor unnecessary.
He predicted that nature, left to itself, would bring about her recovery, which he expected to be swift once initiated.
He also commented on her distinctive facial features, noting they lacked vulgarity or signs of degradation.
Diana expressed a growing warmth and a desire to provide lasting assistance to the narrator.
Mr. St. John, more pragmatically, suggested the narrator was likely a young lady who had absconded after a dispute with friends and that their role might be to facilitate her return.
He noted indicators of a strong will in her face, making him doubtful of her compliance, and ultimately judged her to be sensible but inherently plain in appearance, irrespective of her health.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The recollection of about three days and nights succeeding this is very dim in my mind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The grace and harmony of beauty are quite wanting in those features.”

events.text_segment:
The recollection of about three days and nights succeeding this is very dim in my mind. I can recall some sensations felt in that interval; but few thoughts framed, and no actions performed. I knew I was in a small room and in a narrow bed. To that bed I seemed to have grown; I lay on it motionless as a stone; and to have torn me from it would have been almost to kill me. I took no note of the lapse of time—of the change from morning to noon, from noon to evening. I observed when any one entered or left the apartment: I could even tell who they were; I could understand what was said when the speaker stood near to me; but I could not answer; to open my lips or move my limbs was equally impossible. Hannah, the servant, was my most frequent visitor. Her coming disturbed me. I had a feeling that she wished me away: that she did not understand me or my circumstances; that she was prejudiced against me. Diana and Mary appeared in the chamber once or twice a day. They would whisper sentences of this sort at my bedside—
“It is very well we took her in.”
“Yes; she would certainly have been found dead at the door in the morning had she been left out all night. I wonder what she has gone through?”
“Strange hardships, I imagine—poor, emaciated, pallid wanderer!”
“She is not an uneducated person, I should think, by her manner of speaking; her accent was quite pure; and the clothes she took off, though splashed and wet, were little worn and fine.”
“She has a peculiar face; fleshless and haggard as it is, I rather like it; and when in good health and animated, I can fancy her physiognomy would be agreeable.”
Never once in their dialogues did I hear a syllable of regret at the hospitality they had extended to me, or of suspicion of, or aversion to, myself. I was comforted.
Mr. St. John came but once: he looked at me, and said my state of lethargy was the result of reaction from excessive and protracted fatigue. He pronounced it needless to send for a doctor: nature, he was sure, would manage best, left to herself. He said every nerve had been overstrained in some way, and the whole system must sleep torpid a while. There was no disease. He imagined my recovery would be rapid enough when once commenced. These opinions he delivered in a few words, in a quiet, low voice; and added, after a pause, in the tone of a man little accustomed to expansive comment, “Rather an unusual physiognomy; certainly, not indicative of vulgarity or degradation.”
“Far otherwise,” responded Diana. “To speak truth, St. John, my heart rather warms to the poor little soul. I wish we may be able to benefit her permanently.”
“That is hardly likely,” was the reply. “You will find she is some young lady who has had a misunderstanding with her friends, and has probably injudiciously left them. We may, perhaps, succeed in restoring her to them, if she is not obstinate: but I trace lines of force in her face which make me sceptical of her tractability.” He stood considering me some minutes; then added, “She looks sensible, but not at all handsome.”
“She is so ill, St. John.”
“Ill or well, she would always be plain. The grace and harmony of beauty are quite wanting in those features.”

I can recall some physical sensations during that time, but I formed few thoughts and performed no actions. I knew I was in a small room lying in a narrow bed. I felt as though I had become part of that bed; I lay completely still, like a stone, and pulling me away would have felt almost fatal. I paid no attention to the passage of time—the shift from morning to noon, or noon to evening. I did notice when someone entered or left the room; I could even identify them; I could understand what was said if the speaker was close to me, but I could not reply; opening my mouth or moving my limbs was equally impossible. Hannah, the servant, was my most frequent visitor. Her presence unsettled me. I felt she wanted me gone, that she didn't understand me or my situation, and that she held a bias against me. Diana and Mary appeared in the room once or twice a day. They would speak quietly at my bedside, saying things like: "It was a good decision to take her in." "Yes; she would certainly have been found dead by the door in the morning if she had been left outside all night. I wonder what she has endured?" "Great difficulties, I imagine—poor, thin, pale wanderer!" "She doesn't seem uneducated, I'd guess, based on how she speaks; her accent was very refined; and the clothes she removed, though muddy and wet, were not much worn and seemed of good quality." "She has a distinctive face; even gaunt and worn as it is, I rather like it; and when healthy and lively, I can imagine her appearance would be pleasing." Never once in their conversations did I hear any expression of regret for their kindness towards me, or any suspicion or dislike of me. This brought me comfort. Mr. St. John came only once; he observed me and stated that my sluggish state was the result of exhaustion from excessive and prolonged fatigue. He declared there was no need to send for a doctor, convinced that nature, if left alone, would manage the recovery best. He said that every nerve had been overly strained in some way, and the entire system needed to remain inactive for a while. There was no illness. He anticipated my recovery would be quite rapid once it began. He delivered these opinions briefly, in a calm, low voice, and added, after a pause, in the manner of a man unaccustomed to elaborate comments, "Rather an unusual appearance; certainly, not indicative of vulgarity or low breeding." "Quite the contrary," Diana responded. "To be honest, St. John, my heart feels rather warmly towards the poor girl. I hope we can help her out permanently." "That is quite unlikely," was his reply. "You will probably find she is some young lady who has had a disagreement with her acquaintances and has perhaps foolishly left them. We might be able to help her return to them, if she isn't stubborn; but I detect signs of resolve in her face that make me doubtful of her pliability." He stood observing me for a few minutes, then added, "She looks intelligent, but not at all attractive." "She is so ill, St. John." "Ill or well, she would always be plain. Those features entirely lack the charm and balance of beauty."

events.title: Regaining Strength and First Descent
detailed_summary: By the third day, the narrator's condition had improved, and on the fourth, she regained the ability to speak, move, and sit up in bed.
Hannah brought her gruel and dry toast, which, free of any feverish taste, she consumed with relish.
Feeling a resurgence of strength and a desire for activity, she was motivated to rise and dress.
She was initially apprehensive about appearing before her benefactors in her soiled and damp attire.
To her relief, she found her own clothes neatly laid out by her bedside, clean, dry, and mended.
After a laborious process, with frequent rests, she successfully dressed herself, her clothes hanging loosely on her wasted frame, but she managed a respectable appearance with a shawl.
Feeling clean and orderly once more, she carefully navigated the stone staircase down to the kitchen.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the third day I was better; on the fourth, I could speak, move, rise in bed, and turn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I crept down a stone staircase with the aid of the banisters, to a narrow low passage, and found my way presently to the kitchen.

events.text_segment:
On the third day I was better; on the fourth, I could speak, move, rise in bed, and turn. Hannah had brought me some gruel and dry toast, about, as I supposed, the dinner-hour. I had eaten with relish: the food was good—void of the feverish flavour which had hitherto poisoned what I had swallowed. When she left me, I felt comparatively strong and revived: ere long satiety of repose and desire for action stirred me. I wished to rise; but what could I put on? Only my damp and bemired apparel; in which I had slept on the ground and fallen in the marsh. I felt ashamed to appear before my benefactors so clad. I was spared the humiliation.
On a chair by the bedside were all my own things, clean and dry. My black silk frock hung against the wall. The traces of the bog were removed from it; the creases left by the wet smoothed out: it was quite decent. My very shoes and stockings were purified and rendered presentable. There were the means of washing in the room, and a comb and brush to smooth my hair. After a weary process, and resting every five minutes, I succeeded in dressing myself. My clothes hung loose on me; for I was much wasted, but I covered deficiencies with a shawl, and once more, clean and respectable looking—no speck of the dirt, no trace of the disorder I so hated, and which seemed so to degrade me, left—I crept down a stone staircase with the aid of the banisters, to a narrow low passage, and found my way presently to the kitchen.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: By the third day, I was feeling better, and on the fourth, I could speak, move, sit up, and turn over in bed. Hannah brought me some gruel and dry toast, which I believed was around the dinner hour. I ate it with pleasure; the food was good and didn't have the feverish taste that had previously tainted everything I ate. After she left, I felt considerably stronger and revitalized. Soon, having rested enough, I felt a need to be active. I wanted to get up, but my only clothes were the damp, muddy ones I had slept in on the ground and fallen into the marsh with. I was reluctant to appear before my kind helpers dressed in such a state. However, this embarrassment was avoided. On a chair next to the bed were all my own possessions, cleaned and dried. My black silk dress hung on the wall, the traces of the bog removed and the wrinkles from the wet smoothed out; it looked quite decent. My shoes and stockings too were cleaned and ready to wear. There were washing facilities in the room, along with a comb and brush for my hair. After a slow and tiring process, stopping to rest every five minutes, I managed to dress myself. My clothes were loose because I had lost a lot of weight, but I used a shawl to cover this. Clean and respectable again—without any trace of the dirt or disorder I detested, which felt so degrading to me—I cautiously descended a stone staircase, holding onto the banister, into a narrow, low passage, and soon found my way to the kitchen.

Hannah brought me some gruel and dry toast around noon, and I ate eagerly because the food tasted pleasant—unlike previously when my fever made everything taste bad. When she left, I felt much stronger and refreshed; soon, I grew tired of resting and was eager to do something. I wanted to get up, but had nothing to wear except my still wet and dirty clothes, which I had worn while sleeping on the ground and falling in the marsh. I was embarrassed at the thought of appearing before my helpers so dressed, but I was spared that shame. On a chair next to my bed I found all my own clothing, now clean and dry. My black silk dress was hanging on the wall, free from mud and with the wrinkles smoothed out; it looked fully presentable. Even my shoes and stockings were cleaned. There were washing supplies in the room, and a comb and brush for my hair. After a slow, exhausting process, pausing every few minutes to rest, I managed to get dressed. The clothes hung loosely on me as I had lost weight, but I used a shawl to cover up, and now, looking clean and decent—without any sign of dirt or the disorder I despised—I made my way slowly down a stone staircase, using the banister for support, along a small, low corridor and finally reached the kitchen.

events.title: Confrontation and Reconciliation with Hannah
detailed_summary: The kitchen was filled with the inviting aroma of fresh bread and the warmth of a large fire, where Hannah was busy baking.
Hannah, whose initial demeanor had been cold, showed a slight softening upon seeing the narrator clean and well-dressed, even offering her a seat by the hearth.
Hannah directly questioned the narrator about whether she had resorted to begging before arriving at their home.
The narrator, though momentarily offended, calmly but resolutely denied being a beggar.
Hannah persisted, pointing out the narrator's apparent lack of a home or financial resources.
The narrator countered that the absence of property does not inherently define someone as a beggar in the way Hannah implied.
Hannah then inquired about the narrator's education, to which she replied that she was highly educated, having spent eight years at a boarding school.
The narrator offered to assist with picking gooseberries for pies, an offer Hannah eventually accepted after some initial reluctance.
Observing the narrator's hands, Hannah remarked that she was clearly unaccustomed to servant's tasks and speculated she might have been a dressmaker.
The narrator deflected further personal inquiries, instead asking about the name of the house (Marsh End or Moor House) and details about Mr. St. John.
Hannah revealed that Mr. St. John was a parson merely visiting, that the house belonged to his late father, and that Morton was his parish.
Through this conversation, the narrator deduced the full names: Mr. St. John Rivers, and his sisters Diana and Mary Rivers.
She learned that their father had died recently from a stroke and their mother had passed away many years prior.
Hannah shared that she had served the Rivers family for thirty years, having nursed all three children.
The narrator commended Hannah's long and faithful service but also gently reproached her for initially calling her a beggar and wanting to refuse her shelter.
Hannah, taken aback, admitted her misjudgment, explaining it stemmed from a general distrust of strangers due to prevalent deceit.
The narrator then sternly criticized Hannah for making her poverty a reproach, arguing that many virtuous individuals have been destitute and that a Christian should not view poverty as a crime.
Hannah, acknowledging Mr. St. John had taught her similar principles, conceded her error and expressed a completely revised, positive opinion of the narrator.
The narrator extended forgiveness, they shook hands, and this marked the beginning of their friendship.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was full of the fragrance of new bread and the warmth of a generous fire.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She put her floury and horny hand into mine; another and heartier smile illumined her rough face, and from that moment we were friends.

events.text_segment:
It was full of the fragrance of new bread and the warmth of a generous fire. Hannah was baking. Prejudices, it is well known, are most difficult to eradicate from the heart whose soil has never been loosened or fertilised by education: they grow there, firm as weeds among stones. Hannah had been cold and stiff, indeed, at the first: latterly she had begun to relent a little; and when she saw me come in tidy and well-dressed, she even smiled.
“What, you have got up!” she said. “You are better, then. You may sit you down in my chair on the hearthstone, if you will.”
She pointed to the rocking-chair: I took it. She bustled about, examining me every now and then with the corner of her eye. Turning to me, as she took some loaves from the oven, she asked bluntly—
“Did you ever go a-begging afore you came here?”
I was indignant for a moment; but remembering that anger was out of the question, and that I had indeed appeared as a beggar to her, I answered quietly, but still not without a certain marked firmness—
“You are mistaken in supposing me a beggar. I am no beggar; any more than yourself or your young ladies.”
After a pause she said, “I dunnut understand that: you’ve like no house, nor no brass, I guess?”
“The want of house or brass (by which I suppose you mean money) does not make a beggar in your sense of the word.”
“Are you book-learned?” she inquired presently.
“Yes, very.”
“But you’ve never been to a boarding-school?”
“I was at a boarding-school eight years.”
She opened her eyes wide. “Whatever cannot ye keep yourself for, then?”
“I have kept myself; and, I trust, shall keep myself again. What are you going to do with these gooseberries?” I inquired, as she brought out a basket of the fruit.
“Mak’ ’em into pies.”
“Give them to me and I’ll pick them.”
“Nay; I dunnut want ye to do nought.”
“But I must do something. Let me have them.”
She consented; and she even brought me a clean towel to spread over my dress, “lest,” as she said, “I should mucky it.”
“Ye’ve not been used to sarvant’s wark, I see by your hands,” she remarked. “Happen ye’ve been a dressmaker?”
“No, you are wrong. And now, never mind what I have been: don’t trouble your head further about me; but tell me the name of the house where we are.”
“Some calls it Marsh End, and some calls it Moor House.”
“And the gentleman who lives here is called Mr. St. John?”
“Nay; he doesn’t live here: he is only staying a while. When he is at home, he is in his own parish at Morton.”
“That village a few miles off?
“Aye.”
“And what is he?”
“He is a parson.”
I remembered the answer of the old housekeeper at the parsonage, when I had asked to see the clergyman. “This, then, was his father’s residence?”
“Aye; old Mr. Rivers lived here, and his father, and grandfather, and gurt (great) grandfather afore him.”
“The name, then, of that gentleman, is Mr. St. John Rivers?”
“Aye; St. John is like his kirstened name.”
“And his sisters are called Diana and Mary Rivers?”
“Yes.”
“Their father is dead?”
“Dead three weeks sin’ of a stroke.”
“They have no mother?”
“The mistress has been dead this mony a year.”
“Have you lived with the family long?”
“I’ve lived here thirty year. I nursed them all three.”
“That proves you must have been an honest and faithful servant. I will say so much for you, though you have had the incivility to call me a beggar.”
She again regarded me with a surprised stare. “I believe,” she said, “I was quite mista’en in my thoughts of you: but there is so mony cheats goes about, you mun forgie me.”
“And though,” I continued, rather severely, “you wished to turn me from the door, on a night when you should not have shut out a dog.”
“Well, it was hard: but what can a body do? I thought more o’ th’ childer nor of mysel: poor things! They’ve like nobody to tak’ care on ’em but me. I’m like to look sharpish.”
I maintained a grave silence for some minutes.
“You munnut think too hardly of me,” she again remarked.
“But I do think hardly of you,” I said; “and I’ll tell you why—not so much because you refused to give me shelter, or regarded me as an impostor, as because you just now made it a species of reproach that I had no ‘brass’ and no house. Some of the best people that ever lived have been as destitute as I am; and if you are a Christian, you ought not to consider poverty a crime.”
“No more I ought,” said she: “Mr. St. John tells me so too; and I see I wor wrang—but I’ve clear a different notion on you now to what I had. You look a raight down dacent little crater.”
“That will do—I forgive you now. Shake hands.”
She put her floury and horny hand into mine; another and heartier smile illumined her rough face, and from that moment we were friends.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The room was filled with the scent of freshly baked bread and the comforting warmth from a strong fire. Hannah was in the midst of baking. It is widely acknowledged that ingrained prejudices are exceedingly difficult to remove from minds that have never been softened or cultivated by learning; they take root there as stubbornly as weeds growing among rocks. Hannah had indeed been distant and rigid at first; however, she had recently started to become a little less severe. When she observed that I had entered looking neat and properly dressed, she even smiled. “Oh, you’re awake!” she exclaimed. “You must be feeling better, then. Feel free to take a seat in my chair by the fireplace if you wish.” She indicated the rocking chair, and I occupied it. She continued her work, occasionally glancing at me out of the corner of her eye. As she removed loaves from the oven, she turned to me and asked directly, “Did you ever beg before you came here?” I felt a surge of indignation for a moment; however, reminding myself that anger was not appropriate and that I had certainly appeared like a beggar to her, I replied calmly, yet with a distinct firmness, “You are mistaken if you think I am a beggar. I am no more a beggar than you or the young ladies are.” After a pause, she commented, “I don’t understand that; you don’t seem to have a home or any money, I suppose?” “The absence of a house or money (by which I presume you mean ‘brass’) does not constitute a beggar in your understanding of the word.” “Are you educated?” she inquired shortly after. “Yes, very much so.” “But you’ve never attended a boarding school?” “I spent eight years at a boarding school.” Her eyes widened in surprise. “Then why on earth can’t you support yourself?” “I have supported myself, and I trust I will be able to do so again. What are you planning to do with these gooseberries?” I asked, as she brought out a basket of the fruit. “Turn them into pies.” “Let me have them, and I’ll prepare them.” “No; I don’t want you to do anything.” “But I need to be useful. Please let me have them.” She agreed, and she even provided me with a clean towel to protect my dress, stating, “So you don’t dirty it.” “I can tell by your hands you haven’t been used to servant’s work,” she observed. “Perhaps you were a dressmaker?” “No, that is incorrect. And now, please don’t concern yourself with what I have been; stop worrying about me. Just tell me the name of this house.” “Some call it Marsh End, and others call it Moor House.” “And the gentleman who lives here is called Mr. St. John?” “No; he doesn’t reside here permanently; he is only staying for a while. When he is at home, he is in his own parish at Morton.” “That village a few miles away?” “Yes.” “And what is his profession?” “He is a parson.” I recalled the response of the old housekeeper at the parsonage when I had asked to see the clergyman. “This, then, was his father’s home?” “Yes; the late Mr. Rivers lived here, as did his father, grandfather, and great-grandfather before him.” “So, the gentleman’s full name is Mr. St. John Rivers?” “Yes; St. John is his given name.” “And his sisters are named Diana and Mary Rivers?” “Yes.” “Their father is deceased?” “He died of a stroke three weeks ago.” “They don’t have a mother?” “The mistress passed away many years ago.” “Have you been with the family for a long time?” “I’ve lived here for thirty years. I cared for all three of them when they were children.” “That indicates you must have been a loyal and dedicated servant. I will grant you that much, even though you were impolite enough to call me a beggar.” She stared at me again with a surprised expression. “I believe,” she said, “I was completely mistaken in my opinion of you; but there are so many deceitful people around, you must forgive me.” “And furthermore,” I continued, somewhat sternly, “you wanted to turn me away from the door on a night when you shouldn’t have turned away even a dog.” “Well, it was difficult; but what else could one do? I was thinking more of the children than myself; poor things! They seem to have no one else to look after them but me. I have to be quite vigilant.” I remained silent and thoughtful for several minutes. “You shouldn’t think too poorly of me,” she remarked again. “But I do think poorly of you,” I stated, “and I will explain why—not so much because you refused me shelter or saw me as an imposter, but because you just now made it sound like a criticism that I had no ‘brass’ and no home. Some of the most virtuous people who ever lived were as impoverished as I am; and if you consider yourself a Christian, you should not regard poverty as a fault.” “No, I shouldn’t,” she agreed; “Mr. St. John tells me the same; and I see I was wrong—but my view of you is entirely different now than it was before. You appear to be a genuinely respectable little person.” “That is sufficient—I forgive you now. Let us shake hands.” She placed her hand, covered in flour and rough from work, into mine; another, more genuine smile illuminated her rugged face, and from that moment, we were friends.

events.title: Hannah's History of the Rivers Family
detailed_summary: As the narrator picked gooseberries and Hannah prepared pie pastry, Hannah became talkative, sharing extensive details about the Rivers family.
She described old Mr. Rivers as an unassuming man but a gentleman of ancient lineage, whose family had owned Marsh End for over two centuries.

Despite its humble appearance compared to grander local estates, Marsh End held historical significance for the Rivers family, who were gentry since the times of the Henrys, though the old master himself had simple tastes, enjoying shooting and farming.
The late Mrs. Rivers was portrayed as a scholarly woman, a great reader, whose passion for learning was inherited by her children.
The three siblings were described as unique in their region, deeply devoted to education from a very young age and possessing distinctive characters.
Mr. St. John was set to attend college and enter the clergy.
The daughters, Diana and Mary, intended to become governesses, as their father had suffered significant financial losses, leaving them without inheritances and necessitating self-sufficiency.
Hannah mentioned that the siblings had spent little time at home recently and were currently staying at Marsh End due to their father's death.
She emphasized their profound affection for Marsh End, Morton, and the surrounding moorlands, which they preferred over any grand cities they had visited.
Hannah concluded by highlighting the exceptional unity and harmonious relationships within the family, stating she knew no other family so closely bonded.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hannah was evidently fond of talking.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She did not know where there was such a family for being united.

events.text_segment:
Hannah was evidently fond of talking. While I picked the fruit, and she made the paste for the pies, she proceeded to give me sundry details about her deceased master and mistress, and “the childer,” as she called the young people.
Old Mr. Rivers, she said, was a plain man enough, but a gentleman, and of as ancient a family as could be found. Marsh End had belonged to the Rivers ever since it was a house: and it was, she affirmed, “aboon two hundred year old—for all it looked but a small, humble place, naught to compare wi’ Mr. Oliver’s grand hall down i’ Morton Vale. But she could remember Bill Oliver’s father a journeyman needlemaker; and th’ Rivers wor gentry i’ th’ owd days o’ th’ Henrys, as onybody might see by looking into th’ registers i’ Morton Church vestry.” Still, she allowed, “the owd maister was like other folk—naught mich out o’ t’ common way: stark mad o’ shooting, and farming, and sich like.” The mistress was different. She was a great reader, and studied a deal; and the “bairns” had taken after her. There was nothing like them in these parts, nor ever had been; they had liked learning, all three, almost from the time they could speak; and they had always been “of a mak’ of their own.” Mr. St. John, when he grew up, would go to college and be a parson; and the girls, as soon as they left school, would seek places as governesses: for they had told her their father had some years ago lost a great deal of money by a man he had trusted turning bankrupt; and as he was now not rich enough to give them fortunes, they must provide for themselves. They had lived very little at home for a long while, and were only come now to stay a few weeks on account of their father’s death; but they did so like Marsh End and Morton, and all these moors and hills about. They had been in London, and many other grand towns; but they always said there was no place like home; and then they were so agreeable with each other—never fell out nor “threaped.” She did not know where there was such a family for being united.
