events.title: The Siblings' Return and Move to the Parlour
detailed_summary: After completing her task with the gooseberries, the narrator inquired about the whereabouts of the Rivers siblings and learned from Hannah they were on a walk to Morton but would return soon for tea.
Diana, Mary, and St. John returned within the expected time, entering through the kitchen.
Mr. St. John offered a polite bow to the narrator as he passed through the kitchen.
Mary calmly expressed her gladness at seeing the narrator well enough to be downstairs.
Diana approached the narrator, took her hand, and gently chided her for venturing down without permission, expressing concern over her continued pallor and thinness.
The narrator was captivated by Diana's voice, which she found soothing like a dove's coo, and her charming gaze and overall appearance.
She perceived Mary as equally intelligent and pretty but noted her more reserved demeanor and distant manners.
Diana exuded an air of natural authority and a strong will, qualities the narrator felt an inclination to respect and yield to, within conscientious limits.
Diana then questioned the narrator's presence in the kitchen, asserting that as a visitor, her proper place was the parlour, not amidst Hannah's domestic activities.
Mary concurred, adding that the kitchen fire was too intense for the narrator.
Insisting on obedience, Diana held the narrator's hand, made her rise, and led her into the adjoining parlour.

She instructed the narrator to sit on the sofa while she and Mary prepared tea, explaining that preparing their own meals was a privilege they enjoyed in their moorland home, especially when Hannah was occupied with other chores.
Diana then departed, leaving the narrator alone in the parlour with Mr. St. John, who was engrossed in a book or newspaper.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Having finished my task of gooseberry picking, I asked where the two ladies and their brother were now.

events.text_segment:
Having finished my task of gooseberry picking, I asked where the two ladies and their brother were now.
“Gone over to Morton for a walk; but they would be back in half-an-hour to tea.”
They returned within the time Hannah had allotted them: they entered by the kitchen door. Mr. St. John, when he saw me, merely bowed and passed through; the two ladies stopped: Mary, in a few words, kindly and calmly expressed the pleasure she felt in seeing me well enough to be able to come down; Diana took my hand: she shook her head at me.
“You should have waited for my leave to descend,” she said. “You still look very pale—and so thin! Poor child!—poor girl!”
Diana had a voice toned, to my ear, like the cooing of a dove. She possessed eyes whose gaze I delighted to encounter. Her whole face seemed to me full of charm. Mary’s countenance was equally intelligent—her features equally pretty; but her expression was more reserved, and her manners, though gentle, more distant. Diana looked and spoke with a certain authority: she had a will, evidently. It was my nature to feel pleasure in yielding to an authority supported like hers, and to bend, where my conscience and self-respect permitted, to an active will.
“And what business have you here?” she continued. “It is not your place. Mary and I sit in the kitchen sometimes, because at home we like to be free, even to license—but you are a visitor, and must go into the parlour.”
“I am very well here.”
“Not at all, with Hannah bustling about and covering you with flour.”
“Besides, the fire is too hot for you,” interposed Mary.
“To be sure,” added her sister. “Come, you must be obedient.” And still holding my hand she made me rise, and led me into the inner room.
“Sit there,” she said, placing me on the sofa, “while we take our things off and get the tea ready; it is another privilege we exercise in our little moorland home—to prepare our own meals when we are so inclined, or when Hannah is baking, brewing, washing, or ironing.”
She closed the door, leaving me solus with Mr. St. John, who sat opposite, a book or newspaper in his hand.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: After I finished gathering gooseberries, I inquired about the location of the two young women and their brother. "They've gone for a walk towards Morton," came the reply, "but they're expected back in half an hour for tea." They returned exactly when Hannah said they would, entering through the kitchen. Mr. St. John, upon seeing me, simply acknowledged me with a bow and walked past. The two sisters paused. Mary, in a calm and gentle manner, briefly expressed her happiness that I was well enough to come downstairs. Diana took my hand, shaking her head as she looked at me. "You ought to have waited for my permission to descend," she said. "You still look very pale and so thin! My poor dear! Poor girl!" To my ears, Diana's voice was as gentle as a dove's coo. I loved looking into her eyes. Her face struck me as entirely charming. Mary's face was equally intelligent, and her features just as lovely, but her expression was more reserved, and her behaviour, though polite, was more distant. Diana spoke and acted with clear authority; she obviously had a strong will. I naturally found it pleasant to defer to authority like hers and to comply with an active will, provided it didn't conflict with my conscience or self-respect. "And what are you doing here?" she continued. "This isn't where you should be. Mary and I sometimes sit in the kitchen because at home we enjoy being completely relaxed, even unrestrained – but you're a guest, and you must go into the sitting-room." "I'm perfectly comfortable here." "Absolutely not, with Hannah busy and getting flour all over you." "Besides, the fire is too hot for you," Mary added. "Exactly," her sister agreed. "Come on, you must do as I say." Still holding my hand, she helped me up and led me into the adjoining room. "Sit here," she instructed, positioning me on the sofa, "while we take off our coats and prepare tea. It's another freedom we enjoy in our little house on the moors – getting our own meals ready when we feel like it, or when Hannah is occupied with baking, brewing, washing, or ironing." She closed the door, leaving me alone with Mr. St. John, who was seated opposite me, engrossed in a book or newspaper.

events.title: Observing the Parlour and Mr. St. John
detailed_summary: Left alone with Mr. St. John, the narrator first observed the parlour's appearance.
It was a relatively small room, plainly furnished yet comfortable, characterized by its cleanliness and orderliness.
The room contained well-polished old-fashioned chairs, a highly buffed walnut table, several antique portraits on the stained walls, and a glass-doored cupboard holding books and an old china set.

There were no unnecessary decorations, and only a few pieces of modern furniture like workboxes and a rosewood desk; everything, including carpet and curtains, seemed well-used but carefully preserved.
The narrator then turned her attention to Mr. St. John, who remained perfectly still, his eyes fixed on his reading material, making him easy to scrutinize.

She described him as young, between twenty-eight and thirty, tall and slender, with a face that commanded attention, resembling a classical Greek sculpture in its pure outlines, straight nose, and Athenian mouth and chin.
She reflected that his own harmonious features might make him notice the irregularity of hers.
His eyes were large and blue, fringed with brown lashes, and his high, ivory-like forehead was partly covered by stray locks of fair hair.
Despite this outwardly gentle appearance, the narrator sensed underlying traits of restlessness, hardness, or eagerness in his expression, particularly around his nostril, mouth, and brow.
He did not speak a word or even glance at her until his sisters re-entered the room.
Diana, while busy with tea preparations, briefly came in and offered the narrator a small cake, urging her to eat as she must be hungry.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I examined, first, the parlour, and then its occupant.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Diana, as she passed in and out, in the course of preparing tea, brought me a little cake, baked on the top of the oven.

events.text_segment:
I examined, first, the parlour, and then its occupant.
The parlour was rather a small room, very plainly furnished, yet comfortable, because clean and neat. The old-fashioned chairs were very bright, and the walnut-wood table was like a looking-glass. A few strange, antique portraits of the men and women of other days decorated the stained walls; a cupboard with glass doors contained some books and an ancient set of china. There was no superfluous ornament in the room—not one modern piece of furniture, save a brace of workboxes and a lady’s desk in rosewood, which stood on a side-table: everything—including the carpet and curtains—looked at once well worn and well saved.
Mr. St. John—sitting as still as one of the dusty pictures on the walls, keeping his eyes fixed on the page he perused, and his lips mutely sealed—was easy enough to examine. Had he been a statue instead of a man, he could not have been easier. He was young—perhaps from twenty-eight to thirty—tall, slender; his face riveted the eye; it was like a Greek face, very pure in outline: quite a straight, classic nose; quite an Athenian mouth and chin. It is seldom, indeed, an English face comes so near the antique models as did his. He might well be a little shocked at the irregularity of my lineaments, his own being so harmonious. His eyes were large and blue, with brown lashes; his high forehead, colourless as ivory, was partially streaked over by careless locks of fair hair.
This is a gentle delineation, is it not, reader? Yet he whom it describes scarcely impressed one with the idea of a gentle, a yielding, an impressible, or even of a placid nature. Quiescent as he now sat, there was something about his nostril, his mouth, his brow, which, to my perceptions, indicated elements within either restless, or hard, or eager. He did not speak to me one word, nor even direct to me one glance, till his sisters returned. Diana, as she passed in and out, in the course of preparing tea, brought me a little cake, baked on the top of the oven.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I first inspected the living room, and then the person occupying it. The living room was fairly small, furnished very simply, yet it felt comfortable due to its cleanliness and order. The vintage chairs were very bright, and the walnut table was so polished it reflected like a mirror. A few unusual, old portraits of people from past eras decorated the discolored walls; a cabinet with glass doors held some books and an antique china set. There were no unnecessary decorations in the room—nothing modern at all, except for two workboxes and a lady's rosewood desk placed on a side table: everything, including the rug and curtains, appeared both heavily used and well-maintained. Mr. St. John, seated as motionless as one of the faded pictures on the walls, with his eyes fixed on the book he was reading and his lips silently closed, was quite easy to observe. He couldn't have been simpler to study if he had been a statue. He was young, perhaps between twenty-eight and thirty, tall and slender; his face was captivating; it resembled a Greek face, with extremely pure lines: a perfectly straight, classical nose; a distinctly Athenian mouth and chin. It is truly rare for an English face to be as close to ancient ideals as his was. He might reasonably have been somewhat surprised by the unevenness of my features, given how balanced his own were. His eyes were large and blue, with brown eyelashes; his high forehead, as pale as ivory, was partly covered by casually arranged strands of fair hair. This description is gentle, isn't it, reader? Yet the man it portrays hardly gave the impression of a gentle, submissive, easily influenced, or even a calm nature. As still as he was sitting at that moment, there was something about his nostrils, mouth, and forehead that, to me, suggested underlying elements that were either restless, stern, or intense. He did not speak a single word to me, nor even look my way, until his sisters came back. Diana, while moving about preparing tea, brought me a small cake baked on the top of the oven.

events.title: St. John's Interrogation and Jane's Initial Defenses
detailed_summary: The narrator accepted Diana's offering of cake, her appetite having returned.
Mr. St. John then put down his book, moved to the table, sat, and fixed his gaze intently on the narrator.
His look was now direct, searching, and resolute, suggesting his previous aversion of gaze was due to intention, not shyness.
He commented on her evident hunger, which she confirmed succinctly.
He remarked that her recent low fever, by forcing abstinence, had likely been beneficial, preventing her from overindulging initially, but now she could eat, albeit moderately.
The narrator responded awkwardly, expressing a hope that she would not rely on their generosity for long.
Mr. St. John coolly proposed that if she provided the address of her friends, they could contact them to arrange her return home.
The narrator unequivocally stated that this was beyond her power, as she was entirely without home or friends.
The three siblings observed her, their expressions showing curiosity rather than distrust, particularly from the sisters; St. John's thoughts remained inscrutable.
His eyes seemed more like tools to probe others' minds than to reveal his own, a trait the narrator found more disconcerting than encouraging.
He inquired if she truly meant she was completely cut off from all personal connections.
She affirmed this, stating she had no ties to any living person and no right to shelter anywhere in England.
St. John described her situation as highly unusual for someone her age.
His attention then fell on her hands, and he asked if she had ever been married, specifically if she was a spinster.
Diana interjected with a laugh, noting the narrator couldn't be much older than seventeen or eighteen.
The narrator, deeply flustered and pained by the resurfacing of bitter memories associated with marriage, confirmed she was nearly nineteen and unmarried.
While Diana and Mary averted their eyes in empathy, St. John continued his scrutiny until her emotional distress brought tears.
He then asked for the location of her previous residence.
Mary gently protested his intrusive questioning, but St. John insisted on an answer with a piercing look.
The narrator concisely declared that the details of where and with whom she lived were her secret.
Diana voiced her support for the narrator's right to maintain her privacy.
St. John argued that without information about her or her past, he could not offer assistance, which she clearly needed.
The narrator acknowledged her need for help, specifying her desire for assistance in finding employment that would allow her to sustain herself, however basically.
St. John, while questioning his own philanthropic credentials, expressed his readiness to help her achieve such an honest goal and asked her to detail her past work experience and current skills.

events.text_segment:
“Eat that now,” she said: “you must be hungry. Hannah says you have had nothing but some gruel since breakfast.”
I did not refuse it, for my appetite was awakened and keen. Mr. Rivers now closed his book, approached the table, and, as he took a seat, fixed his blue pictorial-looking eyes full on me. There was an unceremonious directness, a searching, decided steadfastness in his gaze now, which told that intention, and not diffidence, had hitherto kept it averted from the stranger.
“You are very hungry,” he said.
“I am, sir.” It is my way—it always was my way, by instinct—ever to meet the brief with brevity, the direct with plainness.
“It is well for you that a low fever has forced you to abstain for the last three days: there would have been danger in yielding to the cravings of your appetite at first. Now you may eat, though still not immoderately.”
“I trust I shall not eat long at your expense, sir,” was my very clumsily-contrived, unpolished answer.
“No,” he said coolly: “when you have indicated to us the residence of your friends, we can write to them, and you may be restored to home.”
“That, I must plainly tell you, is out of my power to do; being absolutely without home and friends.”
The three looked at me, but not distrustfully; I felt there was no suspicion in their glances: there was more of curiosity. I speak particularly of the young ladies. St. John’s eyes, though clear enough in a literal sense, in a figurative one were difficult to fathom. He seemed to use them rather as instruments to search other people’s thoughts, than as agents to reveal his own: the which combination of keenness and reserve was considerably more calculated to embarrass than to encourage.
“Do you mean to say,” he asked, “that you are completely isolated from every connection?”
“I do. Not a tie links me to any living thing: not a claim do I possess to admittance under any roof in England.”
“A most singular position at your age!”
Here I saw his glance directed to my hands, which were folded on the table before me. I wondered what he sought there: his words soon explained the quest.
“You have never been married? You are a spinster?”
Diana laughed. “Why, she can’t be above seventeen or eighteen years old, St. John,” said she.
“I am near nineteen: but I am not married. No.”
I felt a burning glow mount to my face; for bitter and agitating recollections were awakened by the allusion to marriage. They all saw the embarrassment and the emotion. Diana and Mary relieved me by turning their eyes elsewhere than to my crimsoned visage; but the colder and sterner brother continued to gaze, till the trouble he had excited forced out tears as well as colour.
“Where did you last reside?” he now asked.
“You are too inquisitive, St. John,” murmured Mary in a low voice; but he leaned over the table and required an answer by a second firm and piercing look.
“The name of the place where, and of the person with whom I lived, is my secret,” I replied concisely.
“Which, if you like, you have, in my opinion, a right to keep, both from St. John and every other questioner,” remarked Diana.
“Yet if I know nothing about you or your history, I cannot help you,” he said. “And you need help, do you not?”
“I need it, and I seek it so far, sir, that some true philanthropist will put me in the way of getting work which I can do, and the remuneration for which will keep me, if but in the barest necessaries of life.”
“I know not whether I am a true philanthropist; yet I am willing to aid you to the utmost of my power in a purpose so honest. First, then, tell me what you have been accustomed to do, and what you can do.”

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Eat this now," she instructed me, adding that I must be hungry since, according to Hannah, I’d had only some gruel since breakfast. I didn’t turn it down, my hunger now sharp and real. Mr. Rivers put aside his book, came closer to the table, and sat down, fixing his striking blue eyes directly on me. His gaze, now unhesitant, was intense and searching, making it clear that what had previously kept him from looking at me wasn’t shyness, but intention. 

"You’re very hungry," he observed.
"Yes, sir," I replied simply, as was my nature to answer plainly and concisely when addressed in such a manner.

"It’s fortunate you were kept from eating much these last three days because of a mild fever; otherwise, indulging your appetite right away could have been dangerous. Now you can eat, but don’t overdo it."

"I hope I won’t be a burden on your hospitality for long, sir," I responded awkwardly.

"No," he retorted calmly, "once you tell us where your relatives live, we can write to them, and you can return home."

"I must be honest—that’s impossible. I have no home or friends."

All three regarded me, though not with suspicion—more with curiosity, especially the young women. St. John’s eyes, for all their clarity, were hard to interpret; it seemed he used them more to probe others’ thoughts than to reveal his own. The mix of scrutiny and restraint made me uneasy rather than reassured.

"Do you really mean," he asked, "that you’re entirely alone?"

"I do. I have no ties to anyone—no right to be welcomed under any roof in England."

"That’s quite an unusual situation for someone so young!" he noted, glancing at my hands folded on the table. I wondered at his interest, but his next words clarified it.

"You’ve never been married? You’re single?"

Diana laughed. "But St. John, she can’t be more than seventeen or eighteen!"

"I’m nearly nineteen, but I am unmarried."

A flush of shame and painful memories at the topic of marriage filled my face. They all noticed my discomfort. Diana and Mary soon looked away, giving me some relief, but St. John’s cool and serious gaze lingered until I was brought nearly to tears.

"Where did you last live?" he pressed.

Mary murmured that he was being too inquisitive, but he leaned forward, demanding an answer with another sharp look.

"Where and with whom I lived is my secret," I answered succinctly.

"And in my view," Diana said, "that’s your right to keep from St. John and anyone else."

"But if I know nothing of you or your past, I can’t help," he insisted. "And you do need help, don’t you?"

"I do, and that’s why I hope someone genuinely charitable can help me find honest work—something I’m capable of and for which I’ll be paid enough to survive, even if it’s a meager living."

"I can’t say if I’m truly charitable, but I’m willing to help as much as I can in such an honest aim. First, tell me what work you’ve done before, and what you are able to do."

events.title: Jane's Partial Autobiography and Plea for Understanding
detailed_summary: Having finished her tea, the narrator felt invigorated and better equipped to face Mr. St. John's scrutiny.
She addressed him directly, meeting his gaze openly, and began by expressing profound gratitude for the life-saving hospitality he and his sisters had shown her.
She acknowledged that this immense service entitled them to her gratitude and, to some degree, her confidence.
She offered to share parts of her story, as much as she could without jeopardizing her own or others' peace of mind and safety.

She revealed her orphaned status, her clergyman father, and her upbringing as a dependent in a charitable institution, specifically naming Lowood Orphan Asylum and its treasurer, Rev. Robert Brocklehurst.
Mr. St. John confirmed his familiarity with both Brocklehurst and the school.
She continued, explaining she had left Lowood about a year prior to become a private governess, a role in which she had found happiness.
She stated she was compelled to leave this position just four days before her arrival at their door.

She insisted that the reasons for her departure must remain undisclosed, characterizing them as pointless, perilous, and unbelievable to share, while firmly asserting her own blamelessness in the matter.
She admitted her current profound misery, resulting from a calamitous and strange event that forced her from a place she had considered a paradise.
Her escape required such speed and secrecy that she had to abandon all her possessions, except for a small parcel which she then inadvertently left on the coach to Whitcross.

This led to her arrival in their vicinity completely destitute, enduring nights in the open and days of wandering without food or shelter, until Mr. Rivers found her at his door on the brink of death.
She acknowledged her awareness of the care his sisters had provided during her apparent stupor and expressed equal gratitude for their genuine compassion and his 'evangelical charity.'
As she paused, Diana intervened, expressing concern that the narrator was not yet strong enough for such emotional exertion, and invited her to rest on the sofa, addressing her as 'Miss Elliott.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had now swallowed my tea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Don’t make her talk any more now, St. John,” said Diana, as I paused; “she is evidently not yet fit for excitement. Come to the sofa and sit down now, Miss Elliott.”

events.text_segment:
I had now swallowed my tea. I was mightily refreshed by the beverage; as much so as a giant with wine: it gave new tone to my unstrung nerves, and enabled me to address this penetrating young judge steadily.
“Mr. Rivers,” I said, turning to him, and looking at him, as he looked at me, openly and without diffidence, “you and your sisters have done me a great service—the greatest man can do his fellow-being; you have rescued me, by your noble hospitality, from death. This benefit conferred gives you an unlimited claim on my gratitude, and a claim, to a certain extent, on my confidence. I will tell you as much of the history of the wanderer you have harboured, as I can tell without compromising my own peace of mind—my own security, moral and physical, and that of others.
“I am an orphan, the daughter of a clergyman. My parents died before I could know them. I was brought up a dependent; educated in a charitable institution. I will even tell you the name of the establishment, where I passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher—Lowood Orphan Asylum, ——shire: you will have heard of it, Mr. Rivers?—the Rev. Robert Brocklehurst is the treasurer.”
“I have heard of Mr. Brocklehurst, and I have seen the school.”
“I left Lowood nearly a year since to become a private governess. I obtained a good situation, and was happy. This place I was obliged to leave four days before I came here. The reason of my departure I cannot and ought not to explain: it would be useless, dangerous, and would sound incredible. No blame attached to me: I am as free from culpability as any one of you three. Miserable I am, and must be for a time; for the catastrophe which drove me from a house I had found a paradise was of a strange and direful nature. I observed but two points in planning my departure—speed, secrecy: to secure these, I had to leave behind me everything I possessed except a small parcel; which, in my hurry and trouble of mind, I forgot to take out of the coach that brought me to Whitcross. To this neighbourhood, then, I came, quite destitute. I slept two nights in the open air, and wandered about two days without crossing a threshold: but twice in that space of time did I taste food; and it was when brought by hunger, exhaustion, and despair almost to the last gasp, that you, Mr. Rivers, forbade me to perish of want at your door, and took me under the shelter of your roof. I know all your sisters have done for me since—for I have not been insensible during my seeming torpor—and I owe to their spontaneous, genuine, genial compassion as large a debt as to your evangelical charity.”
“Don’t make her talk any more now, St. John,” said Diana, as I paused; “she is evidently not yet fit for excitement. Come to the sofa and sit down now, Miss Elliott.”

events.title: The Alias, Renewed Interrogation, and St. John's Conditional Promise of Aid
detailed_summary: The narrator was momentarily surprised upon hearing Diana use the alias 'Miss Elliott,' as she had forgotten her adopted name.
The ever-observant Mr. St. John immediately noticed her reaction and questioned her about the name 'Jane Elliott.'
She confessed that while 'Jane Elliott' was the name she currently chose to be known by, it was not her true name, and hearing it still felt unfamiliar.
She confirmed her intention not to reveal her real name, primarily due to an intense fear of discovery and a desire to avoid any disclosure that might lead to it.
Diana affirmed the narrator's right to this precaution and urged her brother to allow her some peace.
However, after a brief period of contemplation, St. John resumed his questioning with his characteristic imperturbability and sharp intellect.
He acknowledged her apparent wish to avoid prolonged dependence on their hospitality and charity, and her desire for independence.

The narrator reaffirmed this, reiterating her plea for assistance in finding work, which was her sole request before she would leave. She begged to be allowed to stay until then, expressing her terror of facing homelessness again.
Diana and Mary both earnestly assured her that she would indeed stay with them.
Mr. St. John remarked that his sisters found pleasure in keeping her, much like they would cherish a rescued bird, but he himself was more inclined to help her achieve self-sufficiency.

He offered his assistance but cautioned that his influence was limited to his role as a clergyman in a poor country parish, and thus his help would be modest, advising her not to disdain humble beginnings.

Diana interjected on the narrator's behalf, reminding St. John that she had already expressed willingness to do any honest work and teasing him about his 'crusty' nature, implying the narrator had little choice in helpers.
The narrator declared her readiness to undertake any honest labor, be it as a dressmaker, a plain-workwoman, a servant, or a nurse-girl, if nothing better was available.
Mr. St. John coolly approved of her determined spirit and promised to assist her in his own way and at his own timing.
He then picked up his book again, resuming his reading.
The narrator, having expended as much energy in conversation and sitting up as her current fragile strength allowed, soon withdrew.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I gave an involuntary half start at hearing the alias: I had forgotten my new name.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I soon withdrew, for I had talked as much, and sat up as long, as my present strength would permit.

events.text_segment:
I gave an involuntary half start at hearing the alias: I had forgotten my new name. Mr. Rivers, whom nothing seemed to escape, noticed it at once.
“You said your name was Jane Elliott?” he observed.
“I did say so; and it is the name by which I think it expedient to be called at present, but it is not my real name, and when I hear it, it sounds strange to me.”
“Your real name you will not give?”
“No: I fear discovery above all things; and whatever disclosure would lead to it, I avoid.”
“You are quite right, I am sure,” said Diana. “Now do, brother, let her be at peace a while.”
But when St. John had mused a few moments he recommenced as imperturbably and with as much acumen as ever.
“You would not like to be long dependent on our hospitality—you would wish, I see, to dispense as soon as may be with my sisters’ compassion, and, above all, with my charity (I am quite sensible of the distinction drawn, nor do I resent it—it is just): you desire to be independent of us?”
“I do: I have already said so. Show me how to work, or how to seek work: that is all I now ask; then let me go, if it be but to the meanest cottage; but till then, allow me to stay here: I dread another essay of the horrors of homeless destitution.”
“Indeed you shall stay here,” said Diana, putting her white hand on my head. “You shall,” repeated Mary, in the tone of undemonstrative sincerity which seemed natural to her.
“My sisters, you see, have a pleasure in keeping you,” said Mr. St. John, “as they would have a pleasure in keeping and cherishing a half-frozen bird some wintry wind might have driven through their casement. I feel more inclination to put you in the way of keeping yourself, and shall endeavour to do so; but observe, my sphere is narrow. I am but the incumbent of a poor country parish: my aid must be of the humblest sort. And if you are inclined to despise the day of small things, seek some more efficient succour than such as I can offer.”
“She has already said that she is willing to do anything honest she can do,” answered Diana for me; “and you know, St. John, she has no choice of helpers: she is forced to put up with such crusty people as you.”
“I will be a dressmaker; I will be a plain-workwoman; I will be a servant, a nurse-girl, if I can be no better,” I answered.
“Right,” said Mr. St. John, quite coolly. “If such is your spirit, I promise to aid you, in my own time and way.”
He now resumed the book with which he had been occupied before tea. I soon withdrew, for I had talked as much, and sat up as long, as my present strength would permit.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I was taken aback when I heard the name I had given as a false identity; I had forgotten I was using a new one. Mr. Rivers, ever observant, noticed my reaction immediately. 

“You said your name was Jane Elliott?” he asked.

“Yes, I did. That is the name I prefer to use for now, but it is not my real name. When I hear it, it feels unfamiliar.”

“And you will not share your real name?”

“No. More than anything, I fear being discovered. I avoid anything that might reveal my true identity.”

“You are absolutely right,” Diana reassured me. “Now, brother, please leave her in peace for a bit.”

After reflecting briefly, St. John continued, just as calm and sharp as before.

“You don’t wish to be dependent on us for long—you want to stop relying on my sisters’ kindness and especially my charity (and I understand and don’t take offense at the distinction—you are correct): you want to support yourself?”

“I do. I have said so already. Just show me how to work or find work. That’s all I ask—then let me leave, even if it’s only to the humblest cottage. But until then, let me stay here; I am terrified of being destitute and homeless again.”

“Of course you will stay here,” Diana said, placing her hand gently on my head. “You will,” Mary echoed sincerely.

“My sisters, as you see, take pleasure in having you here,” Mr. St. John explained, “just as they would in caring for a half-frozen bird blown in by a winter storm. I, however, feel it better to help you support yourself, and I will try to do so. But remember, my means are limited—I am merely the minister of a poor rural church, so what I offer will be simple. If you think what I can do is beneath you, look elsewhere for help.”

“She has said she’ll do any honest work she can,” Diana replied for me, “and as you know, St. John, she has no alternative but to make do with difficult people like you.”

“I’ll be a dressmaker, a seamstress, a servant, a nursemaid—whatever I am able to do,” I responded.

“Good,” said Mr. St. John calmly. “If you have that attitude, I promise I will help you when I am able.”

He then returned to his book. Soon after, I left, as I was too tired to continue talking or sitting up any longer.

events.title: Jane's Deepening Bond with Diana and Mary at Moor House
detailed_summary: Jane's health improves, allowing her to fully participate in life at Moor House.
She experiences a novel pleasure in the perfect alignment of tastes, feelings, and beliefs with Diana and Mary.
Jane finds herself sharing their literary preferences and revering what they approve.
She develops a deep affection for their secluded home and the surrounding wild moorland, understanding and sharing their enthusiastic attachment to the landscape.
The natural elements of the region hold the same powerful charm for Jane as they do for the sisters.
Indoors, their intellectual compatibility is strong; Jane eagerly learns from Diana and Mary, who are more well-read.
Evening discussions about her daily reading bring mutual satisfaction, with thoughts and opinions aligning perfectly.
Diana is identified as the subtle leader of the trio, possessing superior physical vitality and an impressive fluency in conversation that Jane admires.
Jane willingly becomes Diana's German student, finding the roles of instructor and scholar mutually pleasing.
Jane's drawing talent, surpassing theirs, delights the sisters, and Mary becomes her eager pupil.
Their days are filled with mutual learning and entertainment, making time pass quickly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The more I knew of the inmates of Moor House, the better I liked them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus occupied, and mutually entertained, days passed like hours, and weeks like days.

events.text_segment:
The more I knew of the inmates of Moor House, the better I liked them. In a few days I had so far recovered my health that I could sit up all day, and walk out sometimes. I could join with Diana and Mary in all their occupations; converse with them as much as they wished, and aid them when and where they would allow me. There was a reviving pleasure in this intercourse, of a kind now tasted by me for the first time—the pleasure arising from perfect congeniality of tastes, sentiments, and principles.
I liked to read what they liked to read: what they enjoyed, delighted me; what they approved, I reverenced. They loved their sequestered home. I, too, in the grey, small, antique structure, with its low roof, its latticed casements, its mouldering walls, its avenue of aged firs—all grown aslant under the stress of mountain winds; its garden, dark with yew and holly—and where no flowers but of the hardiest species would bloom—found a charm both potent and permanent. They clung to the purple moors behind and around their dwelling—to the hollow vale into which the pebbly bridle-path leading from their gate descended, and which wound between fern-banks first, and then amongst a few of the wildest little pasture-fields that ever bordered a wilderness of heath, or gave sustenance to a flock of grey moorland sheep, with their little mossy-faced lambs:—they clung to this scene, I say, with a perfect enthusiasm of attachment. I could comprehend the feeling, and share both its strength and truth. I saw the fascination of the locality. I felt the consecration of its loneliness: my eye feasted on the outline of swell and sweep—on the wild colouring communicated to ridge and dell by moss, by heath-bell, by flower-sprinkled turf, by brilliant bracken, and mellow granite crag. These details were just to me what they were to them—so many pure and sweet sources of pleasure. The strong blast and the soft breeze; the rough and the halcyon day; the hours of sunrise and sunset; the moonlight and the clouded night, developed for me, in these regions, the same attraction as for them—wound round my faculties the same spell that entranced theirs.
Indoors we agreed equally well. They were both more accomplished and better read than I was; but with eagerness I followed in the path of knowledge they had trodden before me. I devoured the books they lent me: then it was full satisfaction to discuss with them in the evening what I had perused during the day. Thought fitted thought; opinion met opinion: we coincided, in short, perfectly.
If in our trio there was a superior and a leader, it was Diana. Physically, she far excelled me: she was handsome; she was vigorous. In her animal spirits there was an affluence of life and certainty of flow, such as excited my wonder, while it baffled my comprehension. I could talk a while when the evening commenced, but the first gush of vivacity and fluency gone, I was fain to sit on a stool at Diana’s feet, to rest my head on her knee, and listen alternately to her and Mary, while they sounded thoroughly the topic on which I had but touched. Diana offered to teach me German. I liked to learn of her: I saw the part of instructress pleased and suited her; that of scholar pleased and suited me no less. Our natures dovetailed: mutual affection—of the strongest kind—was the result. They discovered I could draw: their pencils and colour-boxes were immediately at my service. My skill, greater in this one point than theirs, surprised and charmed them. Mary would sit and watch me by the hour together: then she would take lessons; and a docile, intelligent, assiduous pupil she made. Thus occupied, and mutually entertained, days passed like hours, and weeks like days.

There was a refreshing satisfaction in this companionship, a feeling I was experiencing for the first time – the joy that comes from a perfect alignment of preferences, feelings, and values. events.title: Jane's Perplexing Observations of the Distant St. John
detailed_summary: Jane's close bond with the sisters does not extend to their brother, St. John.
St. John is frequently absent, dedicating much of his time to pastoral duties among the poor and sick in his parish.
He pursues these duties regardless of weather conditions, viewing them as preparation for a self-proposed future, a notion that causes his sisters concern.
Beyond his absences, St. John's reserved, introspective, and brooding demeanor creates a barrier to friendship.
Despite his zealous ministerial work and blameless life, he appears to lack inner peace and contentment.
Jane observes him in moments of deep, perturbed thought, his eyes betraying inner turmoil.
Unlike his sisters, St. John does not seem to find profound joy in nature, expressing only a single, somber appreciation for his home and its surroundings.
He rarely seeks solace or delight in the moors.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As to Mr. St John, the intimacy which had arisen so naturally and rapidly between me and his sisters did not extend to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and never did he seem to roam the moors for the sake of their soothing silence—never seek out or dwell upon the thousand peaceful delights they could yield.

events.text_segment:
As to Mr. St John, the intimacy which had arisen so naturally and rapidly between me and his sisters did not extend to him. One reason of the distance yet observed between us was, that he was comparatively seldom at home: a large proportion of his time appeared devoted to visiting the sick and poor among the scattered population of his parish.
No weather seemed to hinder him in these pastoral excursions: rain or fair, he would, when his hours of morning study were over, take his hat, and, followed by his father’s old pointer, Carlo, go out on his mission of love or duty—I scarcely know in which light he regarded it. Sometimes, when the day was very unfavourable, his sisters would expostulate. He would then say, with a peculiar smile, more solemn than cheerful—
“And if I let a gust of wind or a sprinkling of rain turn me aside from these easy tasks, what preparation would such sloth be for the future I propose to myself?”
Diana and Mary’s general answer to this question was a sigh, and some minutes of apparently mournful meditation.
But besides his frequent absences, there was another barrier to friendship with him: he seemed of a reserved, an abstracted, and even of a brooding nature. Zealous in his ministerial labours, blameless in his life and habits, he yet did not appear to enjoy that mental serenity, that inward content, which should be the reward of every sincere Christian and practical philanthropist. Often, of an evening, when he sat at the window, his desk and papers before him, he would cease reading or writing, rest his chin on his hand, and deliver himself up to I know not what course of thought; but that it was perturbed and exciting might be seen in the frequent flash and changeful dilation of his eye.
I think, moreover, that Nature was not to him that treasury of delight it was to his sisters. He expressed once, and but once in my hearing, a strong sense of the rugged charm of the hills, and an inborn affection for the dark roof and hoary walls he called his home; but there was more of gloom than pleasure in the tone and words in which the sentiment was manifested; and never did he seem to roam the moors for the sake of their soothing silence—never seek out or dwell upon the thousand peaceful delights they could yield.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: My relationship with Mr. St. John did not develop with the same ease and speed as the one I formed with his sisters. A primary reason for the distance between us was his relative absence from home; a significant portion of his time was seemingly dedicated to visiting the sick and impoverished people living across his parish. Regardless of the weather, once his morning study hours were finished, he would take his hat and, accompanied by Carlo, his father's old pointer, set off on what I perceived as either a mission of love or duty—I was uncertain which. Sometimes, on particularly bad days, his sisters would plead with him to stay home. He would then reply with a specific smile, more serious than cheerful, saying, "If simple tasks like these can be interrupted by a gust of wind or a little rain, how can I prepare myself for the future I envision?" Diana and Mary typically responded to this question with a sigh and a few minutes of what seemed like mournful contemplation. However, beyond his frequent absences, another obstacle to developing a friendship was his apparently reserved, introspective, and even melancholy disposition. While he was zealous in his religious work and led an irreproachable life, he did not appear to possess the inner peace and contentment that should naturally reward a truly devout Christian and active philanthropist. Often, in the evenings, sitting by the window with his desk and papers before him, he would stop reading or writing, rest his chin on his hand, and become lost in thought of a nature I could not identify, though the restless and intense nature of these thoughts was clear from the frequent flashing and changing expression in his eyes. I also felt that he did not find the same delight in nature as his sisters did. He once expressed, only once in my presence, a strong appreciation for the rugged beauty of the hills and a deep affection for his old home with its dark roof and ancient walls; but the feeling was conveyed in a tone and words that held more sadness than joy. And he never seemed to wander the moors seeking their quiet serenity or take time to appreciate the countless small, peaceful joys they could provide.

On particularly unpleasant days, his sisters would try to persuade him to stay in, but he would answer with a serious smile that if he let minor obstacles like wind or rain keep him from his easy duties, he would not be ready for the future he planned for himself. In the evenings, he would often stop reading or writing, lean his head on his hand, and become absorbed in agitated thoughts, as evidenced by the restless look in his eyes. Unlike his sisters, he did not seem to find great joy in nature; he once spoke about the wild beauty of the moors and his affection for his home, but there was a note of sadness rather than happiness in his voice. He never appeared to wander the moors to enjoy their peace or dwell on the tranquility they offered.

events.title: St. John's Disquieting Sermon and Its Impact on Jane
detailed_summary: Jane gains her first significant insight into St. John's mind upon hearing him preach at Morton church.
She finds the sermon difficult to describe fully but notes its profound effect on her.
The sermon begins and remains calm in delivery, yet an intensely felt, though controlled, zeal quickly becomes apparent in his voice and choice of words.
The preacher's power both thrilled and astonished Jane, but did not bring comfort.
A pervasive bitterness and lack of gentle consolation characterized the sermon, with frequent, doom-laden references to Calvinistic doctrines like election and predestination.
After the sermon, Jane feels an inexpressible sadness, sensing that his eloquence originated from a place of deep disappointment, unfulfilled desires, and troubling ambitions.
She concludes that St. John, despite his virtuous life, has not found spiritual peace, a state she relates to her own unresolved sorrows.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Incommunicative as he was, some time elapsed before I had an opportunity of gauging his mind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I was sure St. John Rivers—pure-lived, conscientious, zealous as he was—had not yet found that peace of God which passeth all understanding: he had no more found it, I thought, than had I with my concealed and racking regrets for my broken idol and lost elysium—regrets to which I have latterly avoided referring, but which possessed me and tyrannised over me ruthlessly.

events.text_segment:
Incommunicative as he was, some time elapsed before I had an opportunity of gauging his mind. I first got an idea of its calibre when I heard him preach in his own church at Morton. I wish I could describe that sermon: but it is past my power. I cannot even render faithfully the effect it produced on me.
It began calm—and indeed, as far as delivery and pitch of voice went, it was calm to the end: an earnestly felt, yet strictly restrained zeal breathed soon in the distinct accents, and prompted the nervous language. This grew to force—compressed, condensed, controlled. The heart was thrilled, the mind astonished, by the power of the preacher: neither were softened. Throughout there was a strange bitterness; an absence of consolatory gentleness; stern allusions to Calvinistic doctrines—election, predestination, reprobation—were frequent; and each reference to these points sounded like a sentence pronounced for doom. When he had done, instead of feeling better, calmer, more enlightened by his discourse, I experienced an inexpressible sadness; for it seemed to me—I know not whether equally so to others—that the eloquence to which I had been listening had sprung from a depth where lay turbid dregs of disappointment—where moved troubling impulses of insatiate yearnings and disquieting aspirations. I was sure St. John Rivers—pure-lived, conscientious, zealous as he was—had not yet found that peace of God which passeth all understanding: he had no more found it, I thought, than had I with my concealed and racking regrets for my broken idol and lost elysium—regrets to which I have latterly avoided referring, but which possessed me and tyrannised over me ruthlessly.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Because he was so reserved, it took me a while to understand St. John Rivers' character and abilities. I first grasped the depth of his intellect when I heard him deliver a sermon in his church at Morton. I wish I could effectively describe that sermon, but I find myself incapable. I can't even accurately convey the impact it had on me. It began quietly, and even the manner and tone of his speech remained calm throughout; however, a deeply felt but strictly controlled passion quickly emerged in his clear pronouncements and fueled his intense language. This intensity grew into a powerful, focused, and disciplined force. His preaching stirred my emotions and amazed my mind, though it offered no comfort or solace. A strange harshness permeated the entire sermon; there was no gentle consolation. He frequently made stern references to Calvinist beliefs – including election, predestination, and damnation – and each mention of these topics sounded like a definitive sentence of doom. After he finished, instead of feeling uplifted, more peaceful, or more knowledgeable from his speech, I felt an inexpressible sadness. It seemed to me – and I'm unsure if others felt the same – that the powerful speaking I had just heard originated from a deep source filled with the murky residue of disappointment, stirred by unsettling urges of unfulfilled longings and troubled ambitions. I was certain that St. John Rivers, despite his virtuous life, his strong conscience, and his dedication, had not yet achieved the profound peace from God that is beyond comprehension. I believed he had no more found it than I had with my hidden and tormenting regrets over my shattered ideal and lost happiness – regrets I have recently tried to avoid thinking about, but which ruthlessly consumed and dominated me.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Because he was so reserved, it took a while before I could understand his mind. My first real insight came when I listened to his sermon in his own church at Morton. I wish I could describe what he said, but I lack the ability to do it justice. I cannot even fully express how it affected me. The sermon started calmly, and his delivery remained measured throughout; yet there was a passionate intensity kept firmly in check that could be heard in every clear word and energetic phrase. This intensity kept building—focused and restrained. I was left both moved and amazed by his preaching, but not soothed. The sermon was marked by a certain harshness; it lacked comforting kindness, and he often referenced stern Calvinist ideas like predestination and damnation, each time sounding as though he were passing a gloomy judgment. When he finished, rather than feeling uplifted or enlightened, I was overwhelmed with a deep sadness. It felt to me—though I cannot say if others felt the same—that his powerful words came from a place of unresolved longing and disappointment. I was convinced that St. John Rivers, despite his good, sincere, and dedicated nature, had not yet found the inner peace that faith can bring; I thought he was struggling with unrest just as I was, burdened by my own hidden griefs and lost happiness, pains I seldom spoke of but which still dominated me.

events.title: St. John Proposes a Humble Schoolmistress Position to Jane
detailed_summary: After a month, with Diana and Mary's departure imminent, Jane's need for employment becomes pressing.
She tentatively approaches St. John about the work he had mentioned.
St. John reveals he identified a role for her three weeks prior but hesitated to disrupt her happiness and the sisters' enjoyment of her company until their departure necessitated it.
He confirms the sisters will leave in three days, after which he will return to Morton parsonage with Hannah, and Moor House will be closed.
After a pause, Jane prompts him to elaborate on the employment.
St. John prefaces his offer by reminding Jane of his own poverty and obscurity, stating he can only offer a similarly humble service.
He describes his mission to improve Morton, having already established a boys' school and now intending to open one for girls.
He offers Jane the position of mistress for this girls' school, detailing the small salary, a two-room cottage furnished by a Miss Oliver, and assistance from an orphan girl.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meantime a month was gone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Will you be this mistress?”

events.text_segment:
Meantime a month was gone. Diana and Mary were soon to leave Moor House, and return to the far different life and scene which awaited them, as governesses in a large, fashionable, south-of-England city, where each held a situation in families by whose wealthy and haughty members they were regarded only as humble dependents, and who neither knew nor sought out their innate excellences, and appreciated only their acquired accomplishments as they appreciated the skill of their cook or the taste of their waiting-woman. Mr. St. John had said nothing to me yet about the employment he had promised to obtain for me; yet it became urgent that I should have a vocation of some kind. One morning, being left alone with him a few minutes in the parlour, I ventured to approach the window-recess—which his table, chair, and desk consecrated as a kind of study—and I was going to speak, though not very well knowing in what words to frame my inquiry—for it is at all times difficult to break the ice of reserve glassing over such natures as his—when he saved me the trouble by being the first to commence a dialogue.
Looking up as I drew near—“You have a question to ask of me?” he said.
“Yes; I wish to know whether you have heard of any service I can offer myself to undertake?”
“I found or devised something for you three weeks ago; but as you seemed both useful and happy here—as my sisters had evidently become attached to you, and your society gave them unusual pleasure—I deemed it inexpedient to break in on your mutual comfort till their approaching departure from Marsh End should render yours necessary.”
“And they will go in three days now?” I said.
“Yes; and when they go, I shall return to the parsonage at Morton: Hannah will accompany me; and this old house will be shut up.”
I waited a few moments, expecting he would go on with the subject first broached: but he seemed to have entered another train of reflection: his look denoted abstraction from me and my business. I was obliged to recall him to a theme which was of necessity one of close and anxious interest to me.
“What is the employment you had in view, Mr. Rivers? I hope this delay will not have increased the difficulty of securing it.”
“Oh, no; since it is an employment which depends only on me to give, and you to accept.”
He again paused: there seemed a reluctance to continue. I grew impatient: a restless movement or two, and an eager and exacting glance fastened on his face, conveyed the feeling to him as effectually as words could have done, and with less trouble.
“You need be in no hurry to hear,” he said: “let me frankly tell you, I have nothing eligible or profitable to suggest. Before I explain, recall, if you please, my notice, clearly given, that if I helped you, it must be as the blind man would help the lame. I am poor; for I find that, when I have paid my father’s debts, all the patrimony remaining to me will be this crumbling grange, the row of scathed firs behind, and the patch of moorish soil, with the yew-trees and holly-bushes in front. I am obscure: Rivers is an old name; but of the three sole descendants of the race, two earn the dependent’s crust among strangers, and the third considers himself an alien from his native country—not only for life, but in death. Yes, and deems, and is bound to deem, himself honoured by the lot, and aspires but after the day when the cross of separation from fleshly ties shall be laid on his shoulders, and when the Head of that church-militant of whose humblest members he is one, shall give the word, ‘Rise, follow Me!’”
St. John said these words as he pronounced his sermons, with a quiet, deep voice; with an unflushed cheek, and a coruscating radiance of glance. He resumed—
“And since I am myself poor and obscure, I can offer you but a service of poverty and obscurity. You may even think it degrading—for I see now your habits have been what the world calls refined: your tastes lean to the ideal, and your society has at least been amongst the educated; but I consider that no service degrades which can better our race. I hold that the more arid and unreclaimed the soil where the Christian labourer’s task of tillage is appointed him—the scantier the meed his toil brings—the higher the honour. His, under such circumstances, is the destiny of the pioneer; and the first pioneers of the Gospel were the Apostles—their captain was Jesus, the Redeemer, Himself.”
“Well?” I said, as he again paused—“proceed.”
He looked at me before he proceeded: indeed, he seemed leisurely to read my face, as if its features and lines were characters on a page. The conclusions drawn from this scrutiny he partially expressed in his succeeding observations.
“I believe you will accept the post I offer you,” said he, “and hold it for a while: not permanently, though: any more than I could permanently keep the narrow and narrowing—the tranquil, hidden office of English country incumbent; for in your nature is an alloy as detrimental to repose as that in mine, though of a different kind.”
“Do explain,” I urged, when he halted once more.
“I will; and you shall hear how poor the proposal is,—how trivial—how cramping. I shall not stay long at Morton, now that my father is dead, and that I am my own master. I shall leave the place probably in the course of a twelve-month; but while I do stay, I will exert myself to the utmost for its improvement. Morton, when I came to it two years ago, had no school: the children of the poor were excluded from every hope of progress. I established one for boys: I mean now to open a second school for girls. I have hired a building for the purpose, with a cottage of two rooms attached to it for the mistress’s house. Her salary will be thirty pounds a year: her house is already furnished, very simply, but sufficiently, by the kindness of a lady, Miss Oliver; the only daughter of the sole rich man in my parish—Mr. Oliver, the proprietor of a needle-factory and iron-foundry in the valley. The same lady pays for the education and clothing of an orphan from the workhouse, on condition that she shall aid the mistress in such menial offices connected with her own house and the school as her occupation of teaching will prevent her having time to discharge in person. Will you be this mistress?”

Diana and Mary were preparing to leave Moor House soon and go back to the very different surroundings and lives that awaited them. They worked as governesses in a large, fashionable city in southern England, each holding a position in affluent, arrogant households where they were seen merely as humble employees. Their employers neither knew nor cared about their inner worth, appreciating only their learned skills, just as they valued the ability of their cook or the taste of their lady's maid. Mr. St. John hadn't yet mentioned the job he had promised to find for me, but getting some kind of employment was becoming pressing. One morning, finding myself alone with him for a few minutes in the living room, I cautiously approached the area by the window – which served as his study, marked by his table, chair, and desk. I intended to speak, though I wasn't quite sure how to phrase my question, as it's always hard to break through the reserved nature of people like him. However, he spoke first, saving me the effort. Looking up as I came near, he said, 'You have a question to ask of me?' 'Yes,' I replied, 'I want to know if you have heard of any service I can offer myself to undertake?' 'I found or devised something for you three weeks ago,' he answered. 'But as you seemed both useful and content here – as my sisters had clearly grown fond of you, and your company gave them considerable pleasure – I thought it best not to disrupt your shared comfort until their approaching departure from Marsh End made your own exit necessary.' 'And they will leave in three days now?' I asked. 'Yes,' he confirmed. 'And when they leave, I shall return to the parsonage at Morton; Hannah will accompany me, and this old house will be closed up.'
