But he appeared to have fallen into a different train of thought; his expression indicated he was detached from me and my concerns. I was obliged to redirect him to a subject that was, out of necessity, of close and anxious interest to me. 'What is the employment you had in view, Mr. Rivers? I hope this delay will not have increased the difficulty of securing it.' 'Oh, no,' he said. 'Since it is an employment which depends only on me to give, and you to accept.' He paused again, seeming hesitant to continue. I grew impatient. A couple of restless movements and an eager, demanding look fixed on his face conveyed my feeling to him as effectively as words could have done, and with less effort. 'You need be in no hurry to hear,' he said. 'Let me frankly tell you, I have nothing eligible or profitable to suggest. Before I explain, recall, if you please, my notice, clearly given, that if I helped you, it must be as the blind man would help the lame. I am poor; for I find that, when I have paid my father’s debts, all the patrimony remaining to me will be this crumbling grange, the row of scathed firs behind, and the patch of moorish soil, with the yew-trees and holly-bushes in front. I am obscure: Rivers is an old name; but of the three sole descendants of the race, two earn the dependent’s crust among strangers, and the third considers himself an alien from his native country—not only for life, but in death. Yes, and deems, and is bound to deem, himself honoured by the lot, and aspires but after the day when the cross of separation from fleshly ties shall be laid on his shoulders, and when the Head of that church-militant of whose humblest members he is one, shall give the word, ‘Rise, follow Me!’' St. John delivered these words as he pronounced his sermons, with a quiet, deep voice; with an unflushed cheek, and a coruscating radiance of glance. He resumed—'And since I am myself poor and obscure, I can offer you but a service of poverty and obscurity. You may even think it degrading—for I see now your habits have been what the world calls refined: your tastes lean to the ideal, and your society has at least been amongst the educated; but I consider that no service degrades which can better our race. I hold that the more arid and unreclaimed the soil where the Christian labourer’s task of tillage is appointed him—the scantier the meed his toil brings—the higher the honour. His, under such circumstances, is the destiny of the pioneer; and the first pioneers of the Gospel were the Apostles—their captain was Jesus, the Redeemer, Himself.' 'Well?' I said, as he again paused—'proceed.' He looked at me before he proceeded: indeed, he seemed leisurely to read my face, as if its features and lines were characters on a page. The conclusions drawn from this scrutiny he partially expressed in his succeeding observations. 'I believe you will accept the post I offer you,' said he, 'and hold it for a while: not permanently, though: any more than I could permanently keep the narrow and narrowing—the tranquil, hidden office of English country incumbent; for in your nature is an alloy as detrimental to repose as that in mine, though of a different kind.' 'Do explain,' I urged, when he halted once more. 'I will,' he said; 'and you shall hear how poor the proposal is,—how trivial—how cramping. I shall not stay long at Morton, now that my father is dead, and that I am my own master. I shall leave the place probably in the course of a twelve-month; but while I do stay, I will exert myself to the utmost for its improvement. Morton, when I came to it two years ago, had no school: the children of the poor were excluded from every hope of progress. I established one for boys: I mean now to open a second school for girls. I have hired a building for the purpose, with a cottage of two rooms attached to it for the mistress’s house. Her salary will be thirty pounds a year: her house is already furnished, very simply, but sufficiently, by the kindness of a lady, Miss Oliver; the only daughter of the sole rich man in my parish—Mr. Oliver, the proprietor of a needle-factory and iron-foundry in the valley. The same lady pays for the education and clothing of an orphan from the workhouse, on condition that she shall aid the mistress in such menial offices connected with her own house and the school as her occupation of teaching will prevent her having time to discharge in person. Will you be this mistress?'
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
A month had passed, and it was nearly time for Diana and Mary to leave Moor House to resume their positions as governesses in a fashionable southern English city. In those households, they were treated merely as servants, valued only for their learned skills and not for their true characters, much like the staff they worked beside.

Meanwhile, Mr. St. John still hadn't approached me regarding the job he had intended to find for me, and I was increasingly in need of work. One morning, we were alone together in the parlour. I worked up the courage to approach him in his study space, unsure how to ask about employment, but before I could voice my question, he began the conversation himself. 

He looked up and asked if I had a question, and I replied that I wanted to know if he had found any position for me. St. John explained that he had found a role for me three weeks before, but since I seemed content and useful at Moor House and his sisters enjoyed my company, he had not wanted to disrupt our happiness until their imminent departure made it necessary.

I inquired if Diana and Mary would be leaving in three days, and Mr. St. John confirmed, saying that he would return to Morton’s parsonage with Hannah and the house would be closed. When St. John lapsed into thought, I pressed him again for details about the work, anxious that my wait might have made it harder to secure the position. He assured me that the job still waited for me and depended only on my acceptance, but he hesitated, warning that it was neither prestigious nor lucrative.

He reminded me that his own situation was humble—after settling his father’s debts, he was left with just the old house and meager land. He described the Rivers family as obscure, with two daughters working as dependents and himself feeling alienated from his homeland, valuing the day when he could devote himself fully to a life apart and in service. 

He added that because he himself was poor and unremarkable, he could only offer me similar work, perhaps even seen as degrading due to my refined background and tastes. However, he insisted that any work which improved humanity should be respected, and that the most difficult and unrewarding tasks carried special honor, like the early apostles who pioneered the Christian faith.

I encouraged him to continue. He looked at me closely and said he believed I would accept the post for a while, but not forever, just as he could not permanently fill the passive role of a country minister due to restless aspects in our natures.

He then explained the humble nature of the offer: since taking over Morton, he had created a boys’ school and now planned to establish a girls’ school. He had already rented a building with an attached, simply furnished cottage for the schoolmistress, whose salary would be thirty pounds a year. The cottage was furnished with the help of Miss Oliver, the daughter of the parish’s only wealthy man. Miss Oliver also sponsored an orphan girl to help the mistress with household and school duties. St. John asked if I would accept the position of schoolmistress.

events.title: Jane's Wholehearted Acceptance of the Morton School Post
detailed_summary: St. John delivers his offer quickly, anticipating a possible negative reaction from Jane.
Jane internally weighs the proposal: though humble, it offers safety and independence, which she values greatly over servitude in a wealthy household.
She finds the role not ignoble or mentally degrading and makes her decision.
Jane expresses her gratitude to St. John and accepts the position with genuine enthusiasm.
St. John questions if she truly understands the nature of the work—teaching basic skills to poor village girls—and how it might underutilize her intellect and tastes.
Jane assures him she will adapt, saving her other accomplishments for when they are needed.
Convinced of her understanding, St. John smiles with genuine pleasure and gratification.
Jane proposes to move into her new house the next day and open the school the following week, to which St. John agrees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He put the question rather hurriedly; he seemed half to expect an indignant, or at least a disdainful rejection of the offer: not knowing all my thoughts and feelings, though guessing some, he could not tell in what light the lot would appear to me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Very well: so be it.”

events.text_segment:
He put the question rather hurriedly; he seemed half to expect an indignant, or at least a disdainful rejection of the offer: not knowing all my thoughts and feelings, though guessing some, he could not tell in what light the lot would appear to me. In truth it was humble—but then it was sheltered, and I wanted a safe asylum: it was plodding—but then, compared with that of a governess in a rich house, it was independent; and the fear of servitude with strangers entered my soul like iron: it was not ignoble—not unworthy—not mentally degrading, I made my decision.
“I thank you for the proposal, Mr. Rivers, and I accept it with all my heart.”
“But you comprehend me?” he said. “It is a village school: your scholars will be only poor girls—cottagers’ children—at the best, farmers’ daughters. Knitting, sewing, reading, writing, ciphering, will be all you will have to teach. What will you do with your accomplishments? What, with the largest portion of your mind—sentiments—tastes?”
“Save them till they are wanted. They will keep.”
“You know what you undertake, then?”
“I do.”
He now smiled: and not a bitter or a sad smile, but one well pleased and deeply gratified.
“And when will you commence the exercise of your function?”
“I will go to my house to-morrow, and open the school, if you like, next week.”
“Very well: so be it.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: He quickly posed the question, seeming partly to expect an angry or at least scornful rejection of the offer. Not knowing all her thoughts and feelings, though guessing some, he couldn't predict how she would perceive the role. In truth, it was a modest position—but it offered shelter, which she needed. It involved simple, routine work—but, compared to being a governess in a wealthy home, it provided independence; and the fear of being in servitude to strangers felt like a sharp pain in her soul. It was not a base, unworthy, or mentally degrading job. She made her choice. "Thank you for the offer, Mr. Rivers," she said, "and I accept it wholeheartedly." "But you understand what it is?" he asked. "It's a village school: your students will only be poor girls—cottagers' children—at best, farmers' daughters. Knitting, sewing, reading, writing, and arithmetic will be all you have to teach. What will you do with your accomplishments? What about the largest part of your mind—your sentiments—your tastes?" "Keep them until they are needed. They'll be fine." "So you know precisely what you're taking on, then?" "I do." At this, he smiled, not a bitter or sad smile, but one of clear pleasure and deep satisfaction. "And when will you begin performing your function?" he inquired. "I will go to my house tomorrow," she replied, "and if you agree, I'll open the school next week." "Very well: let it be so."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He asked the question quickly, perhaps expecting me to refuse his offer indignantly or at least scornfully; since he didn’t know all my thoughts and feelings, only guessing at some, he couldn’t be certain how I would view the opportunity. Truly, it was an unassuming position—but it promised safety and shelter, which I needed. It involved steady, routine work—but compared to being a governess in a wealthy home, it offered more freedom; the idea of being a servant to strangers terrified me. The job wasn’t disgraceful or degrading to my mind, so I made my choice.

"Thank you for the offer, Mr. Rivers, and I sincerely accept it."

"But do you understand what I’m offering?" he asked. "It’s a village school; your students will be only poor girls—children of cottagers, or, at best, farmers’ daughters. All you’ll teach is knitting, sewing, reading, writing, and arithmetic. What of your other skills? What will you do with the greater part of your intellect, your feelings, your tastes?"

"I’ll keep them until they’re needed—they won’t be lost," I replied.

"So you know what you’re agreeing to?"

"I do."

He smiled now, this time not with bitterness or sadness, but with genuine pleasure and satisfaction.

"When will you begin?"

"I’ll move into my house tomorrow, and if you wish, I can open the school next week."

"Very well, let’s do that," he said.

events.title: St. John's Revelations about Jane's Nature and His Own Inner Turmoil
detailed_summary: After agreeing to Jane's start date, St. John observes her and predicts she will not remain at Morton for long.
He attributes this to something in her eyes that suggests a life not meant for an even, quiet tenor.
When Jane denies being ambitious, St. John is startled, acknowledges his own ambition, and then describes Jane instead as "impassioned."
He elaborates that Jane is powerfully influenced by human affections and sympathies and will not long be content with solitude and monotonous labor.
He then passionately reveals his own deep dissatisfaction with his current constrained life in the remote parish, feeling his God-given nature and talents are being stifled.
He acknowledges this contradicts his earlier preaching of contentment but states that his inner inclinations and established principles must find a way to reconcile.
He then leaves the room, leaving Jane feeling she has learned a great deal about his complex character in a short time, though he remains an enigma.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He rose and walked through the room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In this brief hour I had learnt more of him than in the whole previous month: yet still he puzzled me.

events.text_segment:
He rose and walked through the room. Standing still, he again looked at me. He shook his head.
“What do you disapprove of, Mr. Rivers?” I asked.
“You will not stay at Morton long: no, no!”
“Why? What is your reason for saying so?”
“I read it in your eye; it is not of that description which promises the maintenance of an even tenor in life.”
“I am not ambitious.”
He started at the word “ambitious.” He repeated, “No. What made you think of ambition? Who is ambitious? I know I am: but how did you find it out?”
“I was speaking of myself.”
“Well, if you are not ambitious, you are—” He paused.
“What?”
“I was going to say, impassioned: but perhaps you would have misunderstood the word, and been displeased. I mean, that human affections and sympathies have a most powerful hold on you. I am sure you cannot long be content to pass your leisure in solitude, and to devote your working hours to a monotonous labour wholly void of stimulus: any more than I can be content,” he added, with emphasis, “to live here buried in morass, pent in with mountains—my nature, that God gave me, contravened; my faculties, heaven-bestowed, paralysed—made useless. You hear now how I contradict myself. I, who preached contentment with a humble lot, and justified the vocation even of hewers of wood and drawers of water in God’s service—I, His ordained minister, almost rave in my restlessness. Well, propensities and principles must be reconciled by some means.”
He left the room. In this brief hour I had learnt more of him than in the whole previous month: yet still he puzzled me.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Getting up, he walked around the room. Pausing again, he directed his gaze towards me. He shook his head. "What do you disapprove of, Mr. Rivers?" I inquired. "You won't be staying at Morton for long: no, not at all!" "Why is that? What's your reasoning for saying so?" "I can discern it in your eyes; they don't possess the kind of expression that promises a life maintained at a consistent, unchanging pace." "I am not driven by ambition." He seemed taken aback by the term "ambitious." He repeated, "No. What made you consider ambition? Who is ambitious? I am, I know: but how did you figure that out?" "I was referring to myself." "Well, if you are not ambitious, you are—" He hesitated. "What?" "I was about to say, passionate: but perhaps you might have misinterpreted the word and been offended. I mean, that human emotions and relationships have a very strong influence over you. I am confident you cannot possibly be content for an extended period to spend your free time in solitude, and to dedicate your working hours to dull, repetitive labour entirely devoid of stimulation: any more than I can be content," he added with emphasis, "to reside here buried in marshland, confined by mountains—my natural inclinations, which God bestowed upon me, being suppressed; my abilities, given by heaven, rendered ineffective—made useless. You hear now how I contradict myself. I, who championed satisfaction with a modest situation, and justified the calling even of those performing the most basic tasks like cutting wood and drawing water in God’s service—I, His appointed clergyman, am practically raving in my restlessness. Clearly, natural tendencies and moral principles must find a way to coexist." He then left the room. In this brief period, I had gained a greater understanding of him than in the entire preceding month; yet, he continued to puzzle me.

He concluded that desires and principles needed to be balanced somehow. He then left, and in just this short time I had learned more about him than in the whole preceding month, though I still did not fully understand him.

events.title: The Rivers Siblings Confront Uncle John's Death Amidst Parting Sorrows
detailed_summary: As their departure nears, Diana and Mary grow increasingly melancholic and quiet.
They struggle to conceal their sorrow, with Diana expressing that this parting from St. John feels different and potentially permanent, given his long-held, unyielding resolves.

Diana describes St. John as hiding a "fever in his vitals" and being "inexorable as death" in some matters, despite his calm appearance, and feels her conscience prevents her from dissuading him from his path, even though it pains her.
Mary voices their sense of loss, having already lost their father and now facing the departure from home and brother.
At this moment, St. John appears at the window reading a letter and then enters.
He announces bluntly, "Our uncle John is dead."
The news seems to strike the sisters as significant rather than deeply saddening.
Diana repeats "Dead?" and gazes searchingly at her brother, asking, "And what then?"
St. John, maintaining a stoic expression, replies with a dismissive "Why—nothing," and tells her to read the letter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Diana and Mary Rivers became more sad and silent as the day approached for leaving their brother and their home.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “What then, Die?” he replied, maintaining a marble immobility of feature. “What then? Why—nothing. Read.”

events.text_segment:
Diana and Mary Rivers became more sad and silent as the day approached for leaving their brother and their home. They both tried to appear as usual; but the sorrow they had to struggle against was one that could not be entirely conquered or concealed. Diana intimated that this would be a different parting from any they had ever yet known. It would probably, as far as St. John was concerned, be a parting for years: it might be a parting for life.
“He will sacrifice all to his long-framed resolves,” she said: “natural affection and feelings more potent still. St. John looks quiet, Jane; but he hides a fever in his vitals. You would think him gentle, yet in some things he is inexorable as death; and the worst of it is, my conscience will hardly permit me to dissuade him from his severe decision: certainly, I cannot for a moment blame him for it. It is right, noble, Christian: yet it breaks my heart!” And the tears gushed to her fine eyes. Mary bent her head low over her work.
“We are now without father: we shall soon be without home and brother,” she murmured.
At that moment a little accident supervened, which seemed decreed by fate purposely to prove the truth of the adage, that “misfortunes never come singly,” and to add to their distresses the vexing one of the slip between the cup and the lip. St. John passed the window reading a letter. He entered.
“Our uncle John is dead,” said he.
Both the sisters seemed struck: not shocked or appalled; the tidings appeared in their eyes rather momentous than afflicting.
“Dead?” repeated Diana.
“Yes.”
She riveted a searching gaze on her brother’s face. “And what then?” she demanded, in a low voice.
“What then, Die?” he replied, maintaining a marble immobility of feature. “What then? Why—nothing. Read.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: As the date for leaving their brother and their residence drew near, Diana and Mary Rivers grew increasingly melancholy and quiet. Both attempted to act normally, but the sadness they struggled against was too deep to be fully overcome or hidden. Diana hinted that this separation would be unlike any they had experienced before. For St. John, it would likely mean being apart for many years, perhaps even for the rest of his life. She stated, "He is resolved to sacrifice everything, including natural affection and even stronger emotions, for his long-held objectives. Jane, St. John may seem calm, but inwardly he is burning with intensity. You might think him gentle, yet in certain matters he is as unyielding as death itself; and the hardest part is that my conscience barely allows me to try and talk him out of this difficult decision; I certainly cannot fault him for it. It is right, honorable, Christian, yet it breaks my heart!" Tears welled up in her lovely eyes. Mary bowed her head low over her needlework. She murmured, "We no longer have our father; soon we will be without our home and our brother." Just then, a minor event occurred, which seemed destined by fate to confirm the saying that 'troubles never arrive alone' and to add the frustrating setback of disappointment right before success to their existing worries. St. John walked past the window, reading a letter. He entered. "Our uncle John is deceased," he announced. Both sisters appeared startled, but not shocked or terrified; in their eyes, the news seemed more significant than distressing. "Dead?" Diana repeated. "Yes." She fixed a scrutinizing gaze on her brother's face. "And what is the consequence?" she asked softly. "What consequence, Die?" he replied, maintaining a stone-like expression. "What consequence? Well—none. Read it."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Diana and Mary Rivers became increasingly quiet and melancholy as the day approached when they would have to leave both their brother and their home. Although they made efforts to behave normally, the sadness they felt was too great to fully hide or overcome.
