She remarked, "He will give up everything for his long-held ambitions," adding that he would put aside family bonds and even deeper feelings for his purpose. Though St. John appeared calm, he was secretly burning with a hidden passion. Others might think him gentle, but in some respects he was determined and unyielding. The hardest part for Diana was that her conscience would not let her try to change his mind, nor could she blame him; she knew his decision was right, admirable, and Christian—though it broke her heart, and tears filled her eyes. Mary lowered her head over her sewing and softly said, "We have no father now, and soon we will be without our home and brother as well." At that moment, something happened that seemed almost fated to emphasize their troubles—a reminder that misfortunes rarely come alone. St. John entered the room carrying a letter and announced, "Our uncle John is dead." The sisters were clearly affected, but their reaction was more thoughtful than deeply distressed. "Dead?" Diana repeated. "Yes," he confirmed. She stared intently at him and asked quietly, "And what now?" St. John replied with a composed expression, "What now? Well—nothing. Read."

events.title: The Disinheritance Revealed: Uncle John's Will and the Family's Stoic Reaction
detailed_summary: St. John tosses the letter to Diana, who reads it and passes it to Mary.
After Mary reads it, all three siblings exchange dreary, pensive smiles.
Diana remarks that they can still survive, and Mary notes they are no worse off than before.
Mr. Rivers comments that the news starkly highlights what could have been versus their current reality.
He then locks the letter away and leaves.
After a silence, Diana explains the situation to Jane.
Their Uncle John, their mother's brother, had quarreled with their father long ago and had advised the disastrous speculation that ruined him.
The brothers parted in anger and never reconciled.
The uncle subsequently amassed a fortune of £20,000, was unmarried, and had no closer relatives than the Rivers siblings and one other person.
Their father had always hoped the uncle would bequeath his property to them as a form of atonement.
The letter confirms he left everything to the other relative, except for thirty guineas for the three siblings to buy mourning rings.

Diana acknowledges his right to dispose of his property as he wished but admits the news casts a momentary gloom, as even a small portion would have significantly helped them and St. John's charitable work.
The matter is not discussed further by the family.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He threw the letter into her lap.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This explanation given, the subject was dropped, and no further reference made to it by either Mr. Rivers or his sisters.

events.text_segment:
He threw the letter into her lap. She glanced over it, and handed it to Mary. Mary perused it in silence, and returned it to her brother. All three looked at each other, and all three smiled—a dreary, pensive smile enough.
“Amen! We can yet live,” said Diana at last.
“At any rate, it makes us no worse off than we were before,” remarked Mary.
“Only it forces rather strongly on the mind the picture of what might have been,” said Mr. Rivers, “and contrasts it somewhat too vividly with what is.”
He folded the letter, locked it in his desk, and again went out.
For some minutes no one spoke. Diana then turned to me.
“Jane, you will wonder at us and our mysteries,” she said, “and think us hard-hearted beings not to be more moved at the death of so near a relation as an uncle; but we have never seen him or known him. He was my mother’s brother. My father and he quarrelled long ago. It was by his advice that my father risked most of his property in the speculation that ruined him. Mutual recrimination passed between them: they parted in anger, and were never reconciled. My uncle engaged afterwards in more prosperous undertakings: it appears he realised a fortune of twenty thousand pounds. He was never married, and had no near kindred but ourselves and one other person, not more closely related than we. My father always cherished the idea that he would atone for his error by leaving his possessions to us; that letter informs us that he has bequeathed every penny to the other relation, with the exception of thirty guineas, to be divided between St. John, Diana, and Mary Rivers, for the purchase of three mourning rings. He had a right, of course, to do as he pleased: and yet a momentary damp is cast on the spirits by the receipt of such news. Mary and I would have esteemed ourselves rich with a thousand pounds each; and to St. John such a sum would have been valuable, for the good it would have enabled him to do.”
This explanation given, the subject was dropped, and no further reference made to it by either Mr. Rivers or his sisters.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
He tossed the letter into her lap. Diana quickly scanned it before handing it to Mary. Mary read it silently, then gave it back to her brother. All three looked at each other and shared a sad, thoughtful smile.

"Thank goodness! We can still make a living," Diana finally said.

"At least it doesn't leave us any worse off than we were before," Mary commented.

"It just rather forcefully brings to mind the thought of what *could* have been," Mr. Rivers remarked, "and contrasts it perhaps too sharply with what *is*."

He folded the letter, locked it in his desk, and went outside again.

For several minutes, nobody spoke. Then Diana turned to me.

"Jane, you must be puzzled by us and our secrets," she said, "and perhaps you think us cold for not being more upset by the death of a close relative like an uncle. But we had never met him or known him. He was our mother's brother. Our father and he had a major falling out years ago. It was on his advice that our father risked most of his money in the investment that ruined him. They blamed each other, parted angrily, and never made up. Our uncle later got involved in more successful ventures; it seems he accumulated a fortune of twenty thousand pounds. He never married and had no close family except us and one other person, who was no more closely related than we are. Our father always hoped he would compensate for his mistake by leaving us his property. This letter tells us he has left his entire fortune to the other relative, with the exception of thirty guineas, which are to be divided among St. John, Diana, and Mary Rivers, for the purpose of buying three mourning rings. Of course, he had the right to do as he pleased, but receiving such news temporarily dampens one's spirits. Mary and I would have considered ourselves wealthy with a thousand pounds each, and for St. John, such a sum would have been valuable for the good works it would have allowed him to do."

After this explanation was given, the topic was dropped, and neither Mr. Rivers nor his sisters referred to it again.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He tossed the letter into her lap. She skimmed it, then gave it to Mary, who read it quietly and handed it back to her brother. The three exchanged glances and shared a subdued, somewhat sad smile.

"Well, at least we're still alive," Diana said after a pause.

"It doesn’t really change our circumstances," Mary added.

"It just reminds us strongly of what could have been, and makes our reality seem even harsher by comparison," Mr. Rivers remarked.

He put the letter away in his desk and left the room. The group sat in silence for a few minutes. Then Diana addressed me: "Jane, you probably think it odd that we seem so unmoved by an uncle’s death, but we never knew or met him. He was our mother's brother, but he and our father quarreled years ago. In fact, it was he who convinced our father to invest in the business venture that led to our ruin. They blamed each other, parted on bad terms, and never made peace. Our uncle later did well for himself and apparently made a fortune of twenty thousand pounds. He stayed single and has no closer relatives than us and one other, who isn’t much more closely related. My father always hoped he’d make up with us by leaving us his wealth, but the letter says he’s left it all to the other relation, except for thirty guineas to be split between St. John, Mary, and myself for mourning rings. Of course, it was his right to do what he wanted with his money, but receiving such news is still a disappointment. Mary and I would have felt rich with just a thousand pounds each, and St. John could have done a lot of good with that kind of money."

With that explanation, they dropped the subject and didn’t mention it again.

events.title: Farewells and New Beginnings: The Dispersal from Moor House
detailed_summary: The day after the news about the uncle, Jane moves from Marsh End to her new home in Morton.
The following day, Diana and Mary depart for their governess positions in the distant city of B—.
Within a week, St. John and Hannah relocate to the parsonage at Morton.
Consequently, the old grange, Moor House, is left abandoned.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next day I left Marsh End for Morton.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In a week, Mr. Rivers and Hannah repaired to the parsonage: and so the old grange was abandoned.

events.text_segment: The next day I left Marsh End for Morton. The day after, Diana and Mary quitted it for distant B——. In a week, Mr. Rivers and Hannah repaired to the parsonage: and so the old grange was abandoned.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The day after this, I moved from Marsh End to Morton. The following day, Diana and Mary also departed Marsh End, heading for the distant place called B——. Within a week, Mr. Rivers and Hannah relocated to the parsonage. Thus, the old house, the grange, was left empty.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: The following day, I departed from Marsh End and went to Morton. The day after that, Diana and Mary also left, heading for faraway B——. A week later, Mr. Rivers and Hannah moved into the parsonage, leaving the old grange deserted.

events.title: A New, Humble Dwelling
detailed_summary: The narrator describes her newly acquired home as a modest cottage.

The primary downstairs room is characterized by its whitewashed walls and sanded floor, furnished sparsely with four painted chairs, a table, a clock, and a cupboard holding a few plates, dishes, and a set of delft teacups.
An upstairs chamber, identical in size to the kitchen below, contains a simple wooden bedstead and a chest of drawers.
Her wardrobe is minimal, making the storage space seem more than adequate, although kind friends have thoughtfully provided her with some necessary clothing items.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My home, then, when I at last find a home,—is a cottage; a little room with whitewashed walls and a sanded floor, containing four painted chairs and a table, a clock, a cupboard, with two or three plates and dishes, and a set of tea-things in delf.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Above, a chamber of the same dimensions as the kitchen, with a deal bedstead and chest of drawers; small, yet too large to be filled with my scanty wardrobe: though the kindness of my gentle and generous friends has increased that, by a modest stock of such things as are necessary.

events.text_segment: My home, then, when I at last find a home,—is a cottage; a little room with whitewashed walls and a sanded floor, containing four painted chairs and a table, a clock, a cupboard, with two or three plates and dishes, and a set of tea-things in delf. Above, a chamber of the same dimensions as the kitchen, with a deal bedstead and chest of drawers; small, yet too large to be filled with my scanty wardrobe: though the kindness of my gentle and generous friends has increased that, by a modest stock of such things as are necessary.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: When I eventually discover a place to call home, I envision it as a modest cottage. This home will likely have a small room downstairs featuring whitewashed walls and a sanded floor, furnished sparsely with four painted chairs, a table, a clock, and a cupboard containing a few plates, dishes, and a set of delf tea-things. Upstairs, a bedroom equivalent in size will contain a pine bedstead and a chest of drawers. Although this chamber is small, it will still be more than enough space for my scant collection of clothes, despite the fact that my kind and generous friends have helped expand it slightly by providing some necessary items.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: At last, when I finally find a place I can call my own, it turns out to be a cottage: a small room with whitewashed walls and a sandy floor, furnished simply with four painted chairs and a table, a clock, a cupboard holding just a few plates and dishes, and a set of china tea things. Upstairs, there is a bedroom the same size as the kitchen, with a basic wooden bed and a chest of drawers—still, it feels spacious for the few clothes I possess, although my kind and generous friends have added to my belongings with a modest amount of necessary items.

events.title: The Schoolmistress's First Day and Sober Reflections
detailed_summary: The narrator finds herself alone by the hearth in the evening, having paid and dismissed the young orphan girl who assists her.
She recounts the opening of the village school that morning, where she had twenty students.
She notes the students' limited literacy and numeracy skills: only three can read, and none can write or perform calculations, though some have basic knitting or sewing abilities.
A significant communication barrier exists due to the students' strong regional dialect.
She observes a mix of temperaments among the children: some are undisciplined and ignorant, while others show a pleasing eagerness to learn.
The narrator reminds herself of the inherent worth and potential of these peasant children, seeing it as her duty to cultivate their nascent talents.
She anticipates a life of modest fulfillment rather than great joy, hoping her efforts will provide her with enough to sustain her daily existence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It is evening.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Much enjoyment I do not expect in the life opening before me: yet it will, doubtless, if I regulate my mind, and exert my powers as I ought, yield me enough to live on from day to day.

events.text_segment: It is evening. I have dismissed, with the fee of an orange, the little orphan who serves me as a handmaid. I am sitting alone on the hearth. This morning, the village school opened. I had twenty scholars. But three of the number can read: none write or cipher. Several knit, and a few sew a little. They speak with the broadest accent of the district. At present, they and I have a difficulty in understanding each other’s language. Some of them are unmannered, rough, intractable, as well as ignorant; but others are docile, have a wish to learn, and evince a disposition that pleases me. I must not forget that these coarsely-clad little peasants are of flesh and blood as good as the scions of gentlest genealogy; and that the germs of native excellence, refinement, intelligence, kind feeling, are as likely to exist in their hearts as in those of the best-born. My duty will be to develop these germs: surely I shall find some happiness in discharging that office. Much enjoyment I do not expect in the life opening before me: yet it will, doubtless, if I regulate my mind, and exert my powers as I ought, yield me enough to live on from day to day.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: It is now evening, and I have sent away the young orphan girl who works as my helper, giving her an orange as her payment. I am sitting by myself near the fire. The village school started today. I have twenty students, but only three of them can read, and none can write or perform calculations. Some know how to knit, and a few can sew a little. They speak with the very strong local accent, making it difficult for us to understand one another currently. Some are ill-mannered, rough, stubborn, and uneducated; however, others are obedient, willing to learn, and show agreeable personalities that please me. I must remember that these poorly clothed children are just as human and capable of inherent excellence, refinement, intelligence, and kind feelings as those born into the most distinguished families. My duty will be to cultivate these potential good qualities, and I am sure I will find some satisfaction in performing this role. I don't expect a great deal of happiness in the life that lies ahead, but I trust that if I manage my thoughts and use my abilities as I should, it will provide me with enough to get by each day.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: It is now evening, and I have sent away the young orphan who assists me, giving her an orange as payment. I sit alone by the fireplace. Today was the first day of the village school, with twenty students attending. Only three of them can read, and none are able to write or do arithmetic. Some know how to knit, and a few can sew a little. They speak in a thick local accent, making it hard for us to understand each other at times. Some children are unruly, rough, and stubborn as well as uneducated, but others are obedient, eager to learn, and show a pleasing attitude. I must remember that these simply dressed peasant children are just as valuable as those from the finest families, and that qualities like natural intelligence, refinement, and kindness are just as likely to be found in them. It is my responsibility to nurture these qualities, and surely I will find some happiness in doing so. I do not expect much pleasure from the life ahead, but if I keep a good attitude and use my abilities properly, I should be able to find enough satisfaction to get by each day.

events.title: Confronting Inner Despair and Resolving to Persevere
detailed_summary: The narrator candidly assesses her emotional state during her first day at the school, admitting she did not feel cheerful or content.
She acknowledges profound feelings of desolation and a sense of degradation, fearing her new role was a step down socially.
The widespread ignorance, poverty, and coarseness she encountered deeply dismayed her.
However, she recognizes these feelings as wrong and is determined to overcome them, viewing this self-awareness as progress.
She expresses hope that her negative feelings will diminish over time, possibly transforming into gratification as she witnesses her students' improvement.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Was I very gleeful, settled, content, during the hours I passed in yonder bare, humble schoolroom this morning and afternoon?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In a few months, it is possible, the happiness of seeing progress, and a change for the better in my scholars may substitute gratification for disgust.

events.text_segment: Was I very gleeful, settled, content, during the hours I passed in yonder bare, humble schoolroom this morning and afternoon? Not to deceive myself, I must reply—No: I felt desolate to a degree. I felt—yes, idiot that I am—I felt degraded. I doubted I had taken a step which sank instead of raising me in the scale of social existence. I was weakly dismayed at the ignorance, the poverty, the coarseness of all I heard and saw round me. But let me not hate and despise myself too much for these feelings; I know them to be wrong—that is a great step gained; I shall strive to overcome them. To-morrow, I trust, I shall get the better of them partially; and in a few weeks, perhaps, they will be quite subdued. In a few months, it is possible, the happiness of seeing progress, and a change for the better in my scholars may substitute gratification for disgust.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Looking back on the hours spent in that plain, modest schoolroom this morning and afternoon, was I truly happy, settled, and content? To be honest, I must confess—No: I felt profoundly desolate. I felt—yes, how foolish I am—I felt a sense of humiliation. I doubted whether I had made a decision that lowered me socially instead of elevating me. I was somewhat disheartened by the lack of knowledge, the poverty, and the crude nature of everything I encountered around me. But I should not condemn myself too severely for these emotions; I know they are incorrect, which is a significant positive step. I will make an effort to overcome them. I hope to manage them better by tomorrow, and perhaps in a few weeks, they will be completely gone. It is possible that in a few months, the happiness of seeing my students progress and improve might replace my current feelings of disgust with satisfaction.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Was I truly happy, calm, or content during the time I spent in that plain, modest classroom earlier today? If I'm honest, the answer is no—I felt quite lonely. In fact, I even felt, foolishly, that I was somehow diminished by being there. I questioned whether this new choice had lowered rather than elevated my social standing. I was disheartened by the lack of knowledge, the poverty, and the roughness I noticed all around me. Still, I mustn't blame myself too harshly for these reactions; I recognize they're wrong, and realizing that is already progress. I will try to overcome these feelings. I hope that by tomorrow I will begin to feel better, and in a few weeks, perhaps they will disappear entirely. Maybe, after a few months, the joy of witnessing improvement and positive changes in my students will make me feel satisfied instead of repulsed.

events.title: Reaffirming Principle over Passionate Temptation
detailed_summary: The narrator engages in a self-interrogation, contrasting her current life with the hypothetical alternative of succumbing to temptation and becoming Mr. Rochester's mistress in France.
She acknowledges the depth of Mr. Rochester's love for her, a love she believes will be unique in her lifetime, and the loss of the admiration she received for her youth and beauty.
She questions whether a life of illusory bliss and subsequent remorse as a kept woman is preferable to her current existence as a free, honest village schoolmistress in rural England.
Ultimately, she affirms her decision to adhere to principle and law, expressing gratitude for divine guidance in making what she perceives as the correct choice.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meantime, let me ask myself one question—Which is better?—To have surrendered to temptation; listened to passion; made no painful effort—no struggle;—but to have sunk down in the silken snare; fallen asleep on the flowers covering it; wakened in a southern clime, amongst the luxuries of a pleasure villa: to have been now living in France, Mr. Rochester’s mistress; delirious with his love half my time—for he would—oh, yes, he would have loved me well for a while.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: God directed me to a correct choice: I thank His providence for the guidance!

events.text_segment:
Meantime, let me ask myself one question—Which is better?—To have surrendered to temptation; listened to passion; made no painful effort—no struggle;—but to have sunk down in the silken snare; fallen asleep on the flowers covering it; wakened in a southern clime, amongst the luxuries of a pleasure villa: to have been now living in France, Mr. Rochester’s mistress; delirious with his love half my time—for he would—oh, yes, he would have loved me well for a while. He did love me—no one will ever love me so again. I shall never more know the sweet homage given to beauty, youth, and grace—for never to any one else shall I seem to possess these charms. He was fond and proud of me—it is what no man besides will ever be.—But where am I wandering, and what am I saying, and above all, feeling? Whether is it better, I ask, to be a slave in a fool’s paradise at Marseilles—fevered with delusive bliss one hour—suffocating with the bitterest tears of remorse and shame the next—or to be a village-schoolmistress, free and honest, in a breezy mountain nook in the healthy heart of England?
Yes; I feel now that I was right when I adhered to principle and law, and scorned and crushed the insane promptings of a frenzied moment. God directed me to a correct choice: I thank His providence for the guidance!
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Allow me to pose a question to myself: Which option was preferable? To have yielded to temptation, followed my emotions without painful effort or struggle, essentially sinking into a seemingly pleasant trap and waking up in a warm place among the luxuries of a pleasure villa, living now in France as Mr. Rochester's mistress, often overwhelmed by his love? He would have loved me intensely for a time, and indeed he did; no one will ever love me that way again. I will never again know the sweet admiration given to beauty, youth, and grace, because no one else will ever see me as possessing these charms. He was fond and proud of me, something no other man will ever be. But where is my mind wandering, and what am I saying, and most importantly, feeling? I ask again, is it better to be a prisoner in a false paradise in Marseilles, burning with deceptive happiness one moment, only to suffocate with the deepest tears of regret and shame the next? Or to be a free and honest village schoolmistress in a refreshing mountain area in the healthy core of England?
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Meanwhile, I ask myself—which path would have been better? Should I have given in to temptation and desire, not fighting against them, but instead allowed myself to become ensnared by pleasure, enjoying comfort and luxury in a southern setting, living in France as Mr. Rochester’s mistress, swept away by his love—as I know he truly loved me, more than anyone ever will again. I’ll never again experience such devotion to my attractiveness and youth, because no one else will see me as he did. He cherished and was proud of me—feelings I doubt another man would have. But where is my mind running, and what am I really feeling? Ultimately, is it better to be trapped in a misguided, false happiness in Marseilles—elated one moment, tormented by guilt and shame the next—or to live honestly and freely as a village schoolteacher in the fresh, wholesome countryside of England? Now, I am certain I was right to stick to my principles and reject the wild urges of a passionate moment. I believe God guided me to make the right decision, and I am grateful for His help.

events.title: St. John's Unexpected Visit and Counsel
detailed_summary: Concluding her reflections, the narrator steps outside her cottage to observe the harvest sunset and the quiet fields.
Her initial sense of happiness gives way to tears as she mourns her separation from Mr. Rochester and worries about the despair his grief might drive him to.
Her reverie is interrupted by the appearance of Carlo, Mr. Rivers' pointer, followed by St. John Rivers himself at her garden gate, his expression grave.
St. John presents her with a small parcel from his sisters, likely containing art supplies, which she gratefully accepts.
He scrutinizes her face, noting her recent tears, and asks if her first day of work was more challenging than anticipated.
The narrator responds positively, expressing confidence in her ability to connect with her students over time.

When St. John remarks on the meagerness of her cottage and furnishings, she counters by expressing thankfulness for their cleanliness and sufficiency, emphasizing her improved circumstances compared to her recent state of destitution.
He then questions if she finds her solitude oppressive.
She replies that she has not yet had sufficient time to feel loneliness, let alone impatience with it.
St. John advises her to firmly resist any temptation to look back at her past and to steadily pursue her current path for at least a few months.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Having brought my eventide musings to this point, I rose, went to my door, and looked at the sunset of the harvest-day, and at the quiet fields before my cottage, which, with the school, was distant half a mile from the village.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It is what I mean to do,” I answered.

events.text_segment:
Having brought my eventide musings to this point, I rose, went to my door, and looked at the sunset of the harvest-day, and at the quiet fields before my cottage, which, with the school, was distant half a mile from the village. The birds were singing their last strains—
“The air was mild, the dew was balm.”
While I looked, I thought myself happy, and was surprised to find myself ere long weeping—and why? For the doom which had reft me from adhesion to my master: for him I was no more to see; for the desperate grief and fatal fury—consequences of my departure—which might now, perhaps, be dragging him from the path of right, too far to leave hope of ultimate restoration thither. At this thought, I turned my face aside from the lovely sky of eve and lonely vale of Morton—I say lonely, for in that bend of it visible to me there was no building apparent save the church and the parsonage, half-hid in trees, and, quite at the extremity, the roof of Vale Hall, where the rich Mr. Oliver and his daughter lived. I hid my eyes, and leant my head against the stone frame of my door; but soon a slight noise near the wicket which shut in my tiny garden from the meadow beyond it made me look up. A dog—old Carlo, Mr. Rivers’ pointer, as I saw in a moment—was pushing the gate with his nose, and St. John himself leant upon it with folded arms; his brow knit, his gaze, grave almost to displeasure, fixed on me. I asked him to come in.
“No, I cannot stay; I have only brought you a little parcel my sisters left for you. I think it contains a colour-box, pencils, and paper.”
I approached to take it: a welcome gift it was. He examined my face, I thought, with austerity, as I came near: the traces of tears were doubtless very visible upon it.
“Have you found your first day’s work harder than you expected?” he asked.
“Oh, no! On the contrary, I think in time I shall get on with my scholars very well.”
“But perhaps your accommodations—your cottage—your furniture—have disappointed your expectations? They are, in truth, scanty enough; but—” I interrupted—
“My cottage is clean and weather-proof; my furniture sufficient and commodious. All I see has made me thankful, not despondent. I am not absolutely such a fool and sensualist as to regret the absence of a carpet, a sofa, and silver plate; besides, five weeks ago I had nothing—I was an outcast, a beggar, a vagrant; now I have acquaintance, a home, a business. I wonder at the goodness of God; the generosity of my friends; the bounty of my lot. I do not repine.”
“But you feel solitude an oppression? The little house there behind you is dark and empty.”
“I have hardly had time yet to enjoy a sense of tranquillity, much less to grow impatient under one of loneliness.”
“Very well; I hope you feel the content you express: at any rate, your good sense will tell you that it is too soon yet to yield to the vacillating fears of Lot’s wife. What you had left before I saw you, of course I do not know; but I counsel you to resist firmly every temptation which would incline you to look back: pursue your present career steadily, for some months at least.”
“It is what I mean to do,” I answered.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: After concluding my thoughts for the evening, I stood up, went to my door, and observed the sunset of the harvest day, as well as the peaceful fields in front of my cottage. My cottage, like the school, was situated half a mile from the village. The birds were singing their final notes, the air was mild, and the dew felt soothing. As I watched, I initially felt happy, but I was soon surprised to find myself weeping. Why was I crying? Because of the fate that had separated me from my connection to my master; I was destined never to see him again. It was also for the profound sorrow and destructive rage resulting from my departure, which might now be potentially leading him away from the right path, perhaps too far for him ever to return. At this thought, I turned my face away from the beautiful evening sky and the secluded valley of Morton. I describe it as secluded because the only visible buildings in that section were the church and the rectory, partly hidden among trees, and far in the distance, the roof of Vale Hall, where the wealthy Mr. Oliver and his daughter resided. I covered my eyes and rested my head against the stone doorframe. However, a slight sound near the small gate that enclosed my tiny garden from the adjacent meadow soon prompted me to look up. A dog—old Carlo, Mr. Rivers' pointer, as I immediately recognized—was nudging the gate with his nose. St. John himself was leaning on it with his arms crossed; his brow furrowed, his gaze serious, almost indicating displeasure, fixed upon me. I invited him to come in. "No, I cannot stay," he replied. "I've only brought you a small package my sisters left for you. I believe it contains a box of paints, some pencils, and paper." I stepped closer to take it; it was indeed a welcome gift. As I approached, I felt he examined my face sternly; the traces of my tears were undoubtedly quite evident. "Have you found your first day's work more challenging than you expected?" he inquired. "Oh, no!" I answered. "Quite the contrary. I think I will get along very well with my students in time." "But perhaps your living situation—your cottage—your furniture—has disappointed you? They are rather basic, it's true; but—" I interrupted, "My cottage is clean and protects from the weather; my furniture is sufficient and practical. Everything I see makes me feel grateful, not discouraged. I am certainly not so foolish or materialistic as to regret the absence of a carpet, a sofa, or silver cutlery. Besides, only five weeks ago I had nothing—I was an exile, a beggar, a wanderer; now I have acquaintances, a home, a job. I am amazed by God's kindness, the generosity of my friends, and the bounty of my circumstances. I do not complain." "But do you feel solitude is oppressive? That small house behind you is dark and empty." "I've barely had enough time yet to appreciate a sense of peace, let alone become restless due to loneliness," I replied. "Very well," he said. "I hope you genuinely feel the contentment you express. At any rate, your good sense will tell you it is far too early to give in to wavering fears, like Lot's wife looking back. Of course, I don't know what you left behind before I met you, but I strongly advise you to firmly resist any temptation that might make you look back. Steadily pursue your current path for at least several months." "That is my intention," I responded.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: After reflecting on these thoughts, I stood up, opened my door, and gazed at the harvest sunset and the peaceful fields stretching before my cottage. My home, along with the school, was about half a mile from the village. As the birds sang their final songs, the gentle evening air felt soothing. In that moment, I realized I felt content, which unexpectedly brought me to tears. I cried because I mourned the loss that separated me from my master, whom I would never see again, and I worried that my leaving might have driven him into despair and caused him to stray beyond recovery. Turning away from the beautiful dusk sky and the secluded valley of Morton—where, in my view, only the church, the vicarage among trees, and far off, Vale Hall, home of Mr. Oliver and his daughter, were visible—I hid my face and leaned against the doorframe. Soon, a faint sound at the gate leading from my garden to the meadow caused me to look up. Mr. Rivers’ old dog Carlo was nosing the gate open, and beyond him stood St. John, arms folded, his expression stern and serious as he watched me. I invited him inside. He declined, saying he had only come to deliver a small package his sisters had left, likely containing art supplies. I gratefully accepted the gift. He studied me closely, noticing, I was sure, that I had been crying, and asked whether my first day’s work had been difficult. I assured him it had not, and that I thought I would manage well with my students. He wondered if my humble cottage or its sparse furnishings had disappointed me. I insisted my situation was clean, comfortable, and more than adequate for my needs. I reflected that, having once had nothing and being homeless, I now had friends, a home, and work, and was grateful rather than dissatisfied. St. John then questioned whether the solitude weighed on me, gesturing to the quiet house behind me. I replied that I had hardly had time yet to appreciate the peace, let alone become restless from loneliness. He told me that he hoped I was as content as I seemed, and advised me not to give in to doubts or look back at what I’d left behind—urging me to pursue my current path for several months. I agreed, assuring him that was my intention.

events.title: St. John's Revelation of His Missionary Calling
detailed_summary: St. John elaborates on the challenge of controlling one's natural inclinations, asserting from experience that it is achievable.

He posits that individuals are divinely endowed with the capacity to shape their destinies and can find alternative, possibly purer, sources of mental sustenance when their desires lead to forbidden paths.

He shares his own past struggles, describing a period of intense misery in the ministry a year prior, when he yearned for a more dynamic and worldly career as an artist, author, orator, politician, or soldier.
He recounts a transformative moment when, after a period of darkness, he perceived a divine call for his abilities, leading him to a new sense of purpose.
This revelation led him to decide to become a missionary, a role he believes requires the combined skills of a soldier, statesman, and orator.

He explains that this decision brought him profound mental liberation, and he is now preparing to leave Europe for the East once his affairs are settled, including resolving a final personal conflict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: St. John continued—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He said this, in his peculiar, subdued, yet emphatic voice; looking, when he had ceased speaking, not at me, but at the setting sun, at which I looked too.

events.text_segment:
St. John continued—
“It is hard work to control the workings of inclination and turn the bent of nature; but that it may be done, I know from experience. God has given us, in a measure, the power to make our own fate; and when our energies seem to demand a sustenance they cannot get—when our will strains after a path we may not follow—we need neither starve from inanition, nor stand still in despair: we have but to seek another nourishment for the mind, as strong as the forbidden food it longed to taste—and perhaps purer; and to hew out for the adventurous foot a road as direct and broad as the one Fortune has blocked up against us, if rougher than it.
“A year ago I was myself intensely miserable, because I thought I had made a mistake in entering the ministry: its uniform duties wearied me to death. I burnt for the more active life of the world—for the more exciting toils of a literary career—for the destiny of an artist, author, orator; anything rather than that of a priest: yes, the heart of a politician, of a soldier, of a votary of glory, a lover of renown, a luster after power, beat under my curate’s surplice. I considered; my life was so wretched, it must be changed, or I must die. After a season of darkness and struggling, light broke and relief fell: my cramped existence all at once spread out to a plain without bounds—my powers heard a call from heaven to rise, gather their full strength, spread their wings, and mount beyond ken. God had an errand for me; to bear which afar, to deliver it well, skill and strength, courage and eloquence, the best qualifications of soldier, statesman, and orator, were all needed: for these all centre in the good missionary.
“A missionary I resolved to be. From that moment my state of mind changed; the fetters dissolved and dropped from every faculty, leaving nothing of bondage but its galling soreness—which time only can heal. My father, indeed, imposed the determination, but since his death, I have not a legitimate obstacle to contend with; some affairs settled, a successor for Morton provided, an entanglement or two of the feelings broken through or cut asunder—a last conflict with human weakness, in which I know I shall overcome, because I have vowed that I will overcome—and I leave Europe for the East.”
He said this, in his peculiar, subdued, yet emphatic voice; looking, when he had ceased speaking, not at me, but at the setting sun, at which I looked too.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Changing one's natural tendencies and redirecting innate inclinations is difficult work, but I know from personal experience that it is possible. God has given us a certain power to shape our own destiny. When our energy seeks nourishment it cannot find, or our will strives for a path we are forbidden to take, we don't have to waste away or stand still in despair. Instead, we must find a different source of mental sustenance, one as powerful as the forbidden desire, and perhaps purer. We must carve out a path for our ambitious spirit that is as direct and broad as the one blocked by circumstances, even if it is rougher.

A year ago, I was intensely unhappy because I felt I had made a mistake by becoming a minister. The monotonous duties bored me completely. I longed for a more active life in the world – for the stimulating efforts of a literary career, or the fate of an artist, author, or speaker; anything but being a priest. Yes, under my minister's robe beat the heart of a politician, a soldier, someone who craved glory, fame, and power. I reflected that my life was so miserable it had to change, or I would die. After a time of darkness and struggle, clarity emerged, and relief came. My restricted life suddenly expanded into limitless possibility. My abilities felt a divine call to awaken, gather strength, spread their wings, and soar beyond ordinary sight. God had a purpose for me, one that required skill, strength, courage, and eloquence – the best qualities of a soldier, statesman, and orator – to carry it far and execute it well, as all these traits converge in a good missionary.

I decided I would be a missionary. From that moment, my mental state transformed; the chains broke and fell from every part of me, leaving only the painful mark of bondage, which only time can heal. My father did indeed influence this decision, but since his death, I have no legitimate obstacles to overcome. I just need to settle some affairs, find a replacement for Morton, break free from or cut through one or two emotional complications – a final struggle with human weakness that I know I will overcome because I have vowed to – and then I will leave Europe for the East.

He spoke these words in his distinctively quiet yet powerful voice, looking, when he finished, not at me but at the setting sun, which I was also watching.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
St. John went on to say—

"It's difficult to master our natural desires and change our inborn tendencies; yet I know from my own life that it is possible. God has given us, to some extent, the power to shape our own destinies. When we feel our energies craving something we cannot have—when our will wants to pursue a path we can't take—we don't have to waste away or fall into despair. Instead, we must look for a different mental nourishment that's just as fulfilling as what we've been denied, perhaps even better, and find a new road for ourselves, even if it's rougher than the one that's been blocked.

A year ago, I was deeply unhappy because I believed I had erred by becoming a minister; the routine of the job exhausted me. I longed for a more active role in the world—the stimulating work of a writer, the calling of an artist, an author, or a speaker; anything instead of being a clergyman. Inside, I felt like a politician, a soldier, someone driven by ambition and glory, thirsting for power, beneath my priest's robes. My misery was so great I felt I must either change my life or die. After a period filled with darkness and struggle, I finally found clarity and relief: my restricted life suddenly expanded before me; I felt my talents urged by a divine call to rise, reach their full potential, and aspire beyond limits. God had a purpose for me, one that required me to journey far and use all my abilities—courage, skill, eloquence, the very traits of a soldier, a leader, and a speaker—qualities needed in a true missionary.

So I decided to become a missionary. From that instant, my mindset transformed; my limitations fell away, leaving only the lingering pain of what had once been oppressive—pain which only time could cure. My father may have originally pushed me towards this path, but now, since his death, there are no real obstacles left. Once a few matters are arranged, a replacement is found for Morton, and I've resolved some emotional attachments—after one final struggle with personal weakness, which I know I'll overcome because I've determined to—I will leave Europe for the East."

He spoke these words in his usual calm, yet forceful manner; and when he finished, he looked, not at me, but at the setting sun, which I also turned to watch.

events.title: The Radiant Arrival of Rosamond Oliver
detailed_summary: As St. John concludes his speech, watching the sunset with the narrator, they are interrupted by a cheerful, melodious voice belonging to a young woman.
Carlo, the dog, recognizes the newcomer before St. John, who, though startled, maintains his westward gaze.
A beautiful young woman, clad in white, appears beside St. John; the narrator is struck by her perfect beauty, detailing her delicate features, expressive eyes, and overall graceful form.
The narrator silently admires this lovely creature, reflecting on nature's generosity in endowing her so bountifully.
She keenly observes St. John's reaction to the young woman, noting that he quickly averts his gaze from her to a patch of daisies, which he then crushes underfoot.
He remarks to the newcomer that it is late for her to be out alone.
The young woman, identified by the narrator as Miss Oliver, explains she has just returned from a nearby town and came to meet the new schoolmistress.
She engages the narrator in a series of polite inquiries about her impressions of Morton, her scholars, and her cottage, to which the narrator provides agreeable answers.
The narrator internally marvels at Miss Oliver's apparent good fortune, blessed with both wealth and natural beauty, and confirms that Alice Wood, her attendant, was well chosen.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Both he and I had our backs towards the path leading up the field to the wicket.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “You have indeed. She is teachable and handy.” (This then, I thought, is Miss Oliver, the heiress; favoured, it seems, in the gifts of fortune, as well as in those of nature! What happy combination of the planets presided over her birth, I wonder?)

events.text_segment:
Both he and I had our backs towards the path leading up the field to the wicket. We had heard no step on that grass-grown track; the water running in the vale was the one lulling sound of the hour and scene; we might well then start when a gay voice, sweet as a silver bell, exclaimed—
“Good evening, Mr. Rivers. And good evening, old Carlo. Your dog is quicker to recognise his friends than you are, sir; he pricked his ears and wagged his tail when I was at the bottom of the field, and you have your back towards me now.”
It was true. Though Mr. Rivers had started at the first of those musical accents, as if a thunderbolt had split a cloud over his head, he stood yet, at the close of the sentence, in the same attitude in which the speaker had surprised him—his arm resting on the gate, his face directed towards the west. He turned at last, with measured deliberation. A vision, as it seemed to me, had risen at his side. There appeared, within three feet of him, a form clad in pure white—a youthful, graceful form: full, yet fine in contour; and when, after bending to caress Carlo, it lifted up its head, and threw back a long veil, there bloomed under his glance a face of perfect beauty. Perfect beauty is a strong expression; but I do not retrace or qualify it: as sweet features as ever the temperate clime of Albion moulded; as pure hues of rose and lily as ever her humid gales and vapoury skies generated and screened, justified, in this instance, the term. No charm was wanting, no defect was perceptible; the young girl had regular and delicate lineaments; eyes shaped and coloured as we see them in lovely pictures, large, and dark, and full; the long and shadowy eyelash which encircles a fine eye with so soft a fascination; the pencilled brow which gives such clearness; the white smooth forehead, which adds such repose to the livelier beauties of tint and ray; the cheek oval, fresh, and smooth; the lips, fresh too, ruddy, healthy, sweetly formed; the even and gleaming teeth without flaw; the small dimpled chin; the ornament of rich, plenteous tresses—all advantages, in short, which, combined, realise the ideal of beauty, were fully hers. I wondered, as I looked at this fair creature: I admired her with my whole heart. Nature had surely formed her in a partial mood; and, forgetting her usual stinted step-mother dole of gifts, had endowed this, her darling, with a grand-dame’s bounty.
What did St. John Rivers think of this earthly angel? I naturally asked myself that question as I saw him turn to her and look at her; and, as naturally, I sought the answer to the inquiry in his countenance. He had already withdrawn his eye from the Peri, and was looking at a humble tuft of daisies which grew by the wicket.
“A lovely evening, but late for you to be out alone,” he said, as he crushed the snowy heads of the closed flowers with his foot.
“Oh, I only came home from S——” (she mentioned the name of a large town some twenty miles distant) “this afternoon. Papa told me you had opened your school, and that the new mistress was come; and so I put on my bonnet after tea, and ran up the valley to see her: this is she?” pointing to me.
“It is,” said St. John.
“Do you think you shall like Morton?” she asked of me, with a direct and naïve simplicity of tone and manner, pleasing, if child-like.
“I hope I shall. I have many inducements to do so.”
“Did you find your scholars as attentive as you expected?”
“Quite.”
“Do you like your house?”
“Very much.”
“Have I furnished it nicely?”
“Very nicely, indeed.”
“And made a good choice of an attendant for you in Alice Wood?”
“You have indeed. She is teachable and handy.” (This then, I thought, is Miss Oliver, the heiress; favoured, it seems, in the gifts of fortune, as well as in those of nature! What happy combination of the planets presided over her birth, I wonder?)
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: St. John and I were both facing away from the grassy path that crossed the field towards the gate. We hadn't heard anyone approaching on the quiet ground; the only sound was the gentle flow of water in the valley below, which created a peaceful atmosphere. This is why we were surprised when a cheerful voice, clear and lovely like a silver bell, suddenly called out— "Good evening, Mr. Rivers," she said. "And good evening, old Carlo. Your dog is faster at spotting friends than you are, sir; he perked up his ears and wagged his tail when I was still far down the field, while you're still facing away from me." This was accurate. Although Mr. Rivers had initially reacted to the sound of her melodious voice as if shocked by a sudden thunderclap, he remained in the same pose as when she first spoke – leaning on the gate with his face turned towards the setting sun – until the end of her statement. Finally, he turned around slowly and deliberately. It seemed to me as though a beautiful apparition had appeared beside him. Standing only about three feet away was a young, elegant figure dressed in white. Her shape was well-proportioned and graceful, full but with delicate lines. After she leaned down to pet Carlo and then raised her head, pushing back a long veil, a face of exquisite beauty was revealed as St. John looked at her. Describing someone as having "perfect beauty" is a strong statement, but I won't take it back or modify it here. Her appearance truly warranted the phrase: her features were as lovely as England's mild climate could shape; her complexion had the pure colours of rose and lily, nurtured and protected as if by the country's damp winds and misty skies. She lacked no appealing quality, and nothing about her seemed imperfect. The young woman possessed balanced and refined features; her eyes were large, dark, and expressive, shaped and coloured like those found in beautiful paintings; her long, dark eyelashes framed her lovely eyes with gentle allure; her well-defined brows added definition; her pale, smooth forehead contributed a sense of calmness to her vibrant complexion and sparkling eyes; her cheeks were oval, healthy-looking, and smooth; her lips were also full of life, red, healthy, and attractively shaped; her teeth were perfectly straight and bright; her chin was small and subtly dimpled; and she had an abundance of thick, luxuriant hair. In summary, she possessed every attribute that, when combined, creates the perfect image of beauty. As I gazed at this beautiful person, I felt a sense of wonder and wholehearted admiration for her. It seemed certain that Nature must have been in a particularly generous mood when creating her, casting aside her usual careful distribution of gifts and instead showering this favourite child with the immense generosity of a loving grandmother. I naturally asked myself what St. John Rivers' opinion was of this incredibly beautiful woman as I watched him turn and look at her. Equally naturally, I searched his expression for the answer. However, he had already looked away from her stunning face and was instead focused on a small cluster of common daisies growing near the gate. "It's a beautiful evening," he remarked, "but it's quite late for you to be out by yourself," saying this as he stepped on the white blossoms of the closed daisies. "Oh, I just arrived back this afternoon from S——" (she named a large town about twenty miles away). "My father mentioned that you had started your school and that the new teacher had arrived, so after tea, I put on my hat and hurried up the valley to meet her. Is this her?" she asked, gesturing towards me. "Yes, it is," St. John confirmed. "Do you believe you'll enjoy living in Morton?" she inquired of me directly, with a straightforward and simple way of speaking that was pleasant, although perhaps a bit childlike. "I certainly hope so," I replied. "There are many reasons for me to like it here." "Did you find your students as attentive as you thought they would be?" "Completely." "Do you like the house you're staying in?" "Very much indeed." "Did I furnish it well?" "Extremely well, yes." "And did I make a good selection for your helper in Alice Wood?" "You certainly did," I confirmed. "She learns quickly and is capable." (So, I realised, this must be Miss Oliver, the wealthy young woman; apparently blessed with both riches and natural beauty! I wondered what exceptionally fortunate celestial alignment must have occurred at her birth.)
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Both St. John Rivers and I were facing away from the path that came up the field to the wicket gate. We hadn’t heard anyone approach along that grassy track; the running water in the valley was the only sound in the otherwise quiet scene. It was, therefore, quite surprising when a cheerful voice, sweet and clear like a silver bell, suddenly called out:

"Good evening, Mr. Rivers. And good evening, old Carlo. Your dog notices friends sooner than you do, sir; he perked up and wagged his tail when I was still at the other end of the field, while you’ve only just now turned your back to me."

What she said was true. Although Mr. Rivers had been startled by the first notes of this melodious voice, as though lightning had flashed right overhead, he remained in the same position as when she surprised him—with his arm resting on the gate, looking out towards the west. Only eventually did he turn around, calmly and deliberately. To me, it was as if a vision had appeared at his side. Just a few feet from him stood a figure dressed in pure white—a young, graceful woman, her form both elegant and full—who, after bending to pet Carlo, stood up, lifted her head, and pushed back a long veil, revealing a face of extraordinary beauty. 'Perfect beauty' is a strong phrase, but I do not take it back: her features were as sweet as any shaped by England’s temperate climate, her complexion as pure as any nurtured by its moist air and gentle light. She had every charm and no flaw I could see; her features were regular and delicate; her eyes large, dark, and expressive as those in fine portraits, surrounded by long, shadowy lashes that lent them a soft allure; her brows were finely shaped, lending clarity; her forehead was smooth and white, providing calm to the vivid beauty of her coloring; her cheeks were oval, fresh, and smooth; her lips were healthy and perfectly formed; her teeth flawless and bright; her chin small and dimpled; and her hair thick and luxurious—all the qualities that together define the ideal of beauty were hers. As I gazed at this lovely creature, I couldn’t help but admire her with all my heart. It seemed that nature had been feeling especially generous when creating her and had given her more than its usual share of gifts.

Naturally, I wondered what St. John Rivers thought of this angelic young woman. I watched to see his reaction as he turned to look at her, but he had already glanced away from her to focus on a modest clump of daisies beside the gate instead.

"It’s a beautiful evening, but it’s late for you to be out alone," he remarked, pressing down the white flowers with his foot.

"Oh, I just came home from S——" (she named a large town about twenty miles away) "this afternoon. Papa told me you had opened your school and the new teacher had arrived, so after tea I put on my bonnet and hurried up the valley to meet her: is this her?" she asked, pointing at me.

"It is," replied St. John.

"Do you think you'll like Morton?" she asked me, with a straightforward and innocent manner that made her seem charmingly childlike.

"I hope so. I have plenty of reasons to."

"Were your students as attentive as you expected?"

"Completely."

"Do you like where you’re living?"

"Very much."

"Did I furnish it well?"

"Extremely well."

"And did I choose the right person to help you—Alice Wood?"

"Yes, you did. She’s willing to learn and very capable." (So, I thought, this is Miss Oliver, the heiress—apparently gifted in both fortune and beauty! What lucky stars must have shone the day she was born?)

events.title: Rosamond's Vivacity Clashes with St. John's Austerity
detailed_summary: Miss Oliver offers to assist the narrator with teaching sometimes, stating her fondness for change.
She exuberantly describes her recent social engagements in S——, mentioning dancing late with officers, whom she praises highly, contrasting them with local young men.
The narrator observes St. John's facial expression hardening and his gaze turning stern and searching as he listens to Miss Oliver's cheerful account.
Miss Oliver responds to his look with laughter, which suits her youthful charm.
She playfully teases St. John for his sternness and silence, contrasting him with his friendly dog, Carlo.

As Miss Oliver affectionately pets Carlo, the narrator witnesses a sudden rush of emotion on St. John's face; his eyes flare with resistless feeling, and his chest heaves, momentarily making him appear almost as beautiful as Miss Oliver before he visibly suppresses his reaction.
Miss Oliver then invites St. John to visit her father at Vale Hall, mentioning he is unwell and alone.
St. John curtly declines, stating the hour is unsuitable.
She counters, insisting it is the perfect time for a visit and questions his excessive shyness and somber mood.
Realizing her insensitivity, she apologizes, remembering that St. John is lonely due to his sisters' departure and the closure of Moor House, and reiterates her invitation with pity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I shall come up and help you to teach sometimes,” she added.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Not to-night, Miss Rosamond, not to-night.”

events.text_segment:
“I shall come up and help you to teach sometimes,” she added. “It will be a change for me to visit you now and then; and I like a change. Mr. Rivers, I have been so gay during my stay at S——. Last night, or rather this morning, I was dancing till two o’clock. The ——th regiment are stationed there since the riots; and the officers are the most agreeable men in the world: they put all our young knife-grinders and scissor merchants to shame.”
It seemed to me that Mr. St. John’s under lip protruded, and his upper lip curled a moment. His mouth certainly looked a good deal compressed, and the lower part of his face unusually stern and square, as the laughing girl gave him this information. He lifted his gaze, too, from the daisies, and turned it on her. An unsmiling, a searching, a meaning gaze it was. She answered it with a second laugh, and laughter well became her youth, her roses, her dimples, her bright eyes.
As he stood, mute and grave, she again fell to caressing Carlo. “Poor Carlo loves me,” said she. “He is not stern and distant to his friends; and if he could speak, he would not be silent.”
As she patted the dog’s head, bending with native grace before his young and austere master, I saw a glow rise to that master’s face. I saw his solemn eye melt with sudden fire, and flicker with resistless emotion. Flushed and kindled thus, he looked nearly as beautiful for a man as she for a woman. His chest heaved once, as if his large heart, weary of despotic constriction, had expanded, despite the will, and made a vigorous bound for the attainment of liberty. But he curbed it, I think, as a resolute rider would curb a rearing steed. He responded neither by word nor movement to the gentle advances made him.
“Papa says you never come to see us now,” continued Miss Oliver, looking up. “You are quite a stranger at Vale Hall. He is alone this evening, and not very well: will you return with me and visit him?”
“It is not a seasonable hour to intrude on Mr. Oliver,” answered St. John.
“Not a seasonable hour! But I declare it is. It is just the hour when papa most wants company: when the works are closed and he has no business to occupy him. Now, Mr. Rivers, do come. Why are you so very shy, and so very sombre?” She filled up the hiatus his silence left by a reply of her own.
“I forgot!” she exclaimed, shaking her beautiful curled head, as if shocked at herself. “I am so giddy and thoughtless! Do excuse me. It had slipped my memory that you have good reasons to be indisposed for joining in my chatter. Diana and Mary have left you, and Moor House is shut up, and you are so lonely. I am sure I pity you. Do come and see papa.”
“Not to-night, Miss Rosamond, not to-night.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: She added, “I’ll visit sometimes to help with the teaching. It will be a pleasant break for me to drop in occasionally, and I enjoy variety. Mr. Rivers, I’ve had such a wonderful time staying in S——. Just last night, or early this morning actually, I was dancing until 2 AM. The ——th regiment is stationed there since the disturbances, and their officers are the most charming men imaginable; they completely outshine our local young businessmen.” It seemed to me that Mr. St. John’s lower lip jutted out, and his upper lip momentarily curled. His mouth certainly appeared quite tight, and the bottom half of his face looked unusually grim and rigid as the cheerful young woman shared this news. He also lifted his eyes from the flowers and directed his gaze towards her. It was a serious, penetrating, and meaningful stare. She responded with another laugh, and laughter truly suited her youth, her healthy colour, her dimples, and her sparkling eyes. While he stood silent and solemn, she began stroking Carlo again. “Sweet Carlo loves me,” she said. “He isn’t severe and distant with his friends; and if he could speak, he wouldn’t stay quiet.” As she petted the dog’s head, gracefully bowing before his young, stern master, I saw a flush appear on that master’s face. I saw his serious eyes suddenly ignite with fire and tremble with uncontrollable feeling. Flushed and animated like this, he was almost as handsome for a man as she was beautiful for a woman. His chest rose once, as if his great heart, tired of being rigidly confined, had expanded despite his will and made a powerful leap for freedom. But I believe he controlled it, like a determined horseman would restrain a rearing horse. He did not respond with either words or actions to her gentle overtures. “Father says you never come to see us anymore,” Miss Oliver continued, looking up. “You’re quite a stranger at Vale Hall. He’s by himself this evening and isn’t feeling very well; would you come back with me and visit him?” “It’s not a suitable time to impose on Mr. Oliver,” St. John replied. “Not a suitable time! But I assure you it is. It’s exactly the hour when father needs company the most: when the factory is closed and he has nothing to occupy him. Please, Mr. Rivers, do come. Why are you so incredibly reserved and so very gloomy?” She filled the gap his silence created with her own explanation. “Oh, I forgot!” she exclaimed, shaking her lovely curly hair as if taken aback by herself. “I’m so flighty and thoughtless! Please forgive me. It had completely slipped my mind that you have good reasons for not wanting to join in my chatter. Diana and Mary have gone, and Moor House is closed up, and you must be so lonely. I genuinely feel for you. Please come and visit father.” “Not tonight, Miss Rosamond, not tonight.”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
She said, "I'll come and help you teach sometimes. Visiting you now and then will be a nice change for me; I enjoy something different. Mr. Rivers, I've had such a fun time while staying at S——. Just last night—or rather, this morning—I was dancing until two. The ——th regiment has been based there since the riots, and the officers are such delightful men—they put all our local young men to shame." 

When she told him all this while laughing, I noticed Mr. St. John's lower lip stuck out and his upper lip curled slightly. His mouth tightened and his expression became even more stern than usual. He looked away from the flowers and gazed at her seriously, with a look that was intent and meaningful, but without a smile. She simply laughed again in response, which suited her youthful beauty—her rosy cheeks, dimples, and sparkling eyes.

While he stood there, silent and serious, she started to pet Carlo again. "Poor Carlo loves me," she said. "He isn't stern or distant with his friends; and if he could talk, he wouldn't ignore me." Leaning gracefully over Carlo's head, I noticed a flush of feeling rise to St. John's face; his serious eyes suddenly brightened with passion, and he looked, in that moment, almost as handsome for a man as she was for a woman. He breathed deeply once, as if his heart, tired of being restrained, wanted to break free. But he quickly controlled himself, like a determined rider calming an unruly horse. He didn't say or do anything in response to her gentle approach.

"Father says you never come to see us these days," Miss Oliver went on, looking up at him. "You're a stranger at Vale Hall now. He's alone this evening and not feeling well—won't you come back with me to visit him?"

"It's not really a suitable time to bother Mr. Oliver," St. John replied.

"Not a suitable time? Oh, but it is! This is exactly when Papa wants company—when the work is done and he isn't busy. Please, Mr. Rivers, come along. Why are you always so shy and serious?" She answered her own question, filling his silence.

"Oh, I forgot!" she said, shaking her lovely curled hair as though scolding herself. "I'm so thoughtless and scatterbrained! Forgive me. I forgot you have good reasons not to join my chatter. Diana and Mary have left you, Moor House is closed up, and you must feel so lonely. I really feel for you. Please come and see father."

"Not tonight, Miss Rosamond, not tonight," he replied.

events.title: St. John's Painful Resolve and Departure
detailed_summary: St. John repeats his refusal to accompany Miss Oliver, his voice sounding almost mechanical, betraying the immense effort his denial costs him.
Acknowledging his obstinacy, Miss Oliver decides to depart, citing the falling dew.
She extends her hand, which he barely touches, echoing her 'Good evening' in a low, hollow tone.
After turning to leave, she briefly returns, struck by his pallid complexion, to inquire if he is well.
He affirms his well-being with a bow and then leaves the gate, walking in a different direction from Miss Oliver.
Miss Oliver looks back at St. John twice as she departs, while he strides away without a backward glance.
Witnessing this display of St. John's internal suffering and self-denial diverts the narrator's thoughts from her own troubles.
She recalls Diana Rivers' earlier description of her brother as 'inexorable as death,' concluding it to be an apt assessment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. St. John spoke almost like an automaton: himself only knew the effort it cost him thus to refuse.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She had not exaggerated.

events.text_segment:
Mr. St. John spoke almost like an automaton: himself only knew the effort it cost him thus to refuse.
“Well, if you are so obstinate, I will leave you; for I dare not stay any longer: the dew begins to fall. Good evening!”
She held out her hand. He just touched it. “Good evening!” he repeated, in a voice low and hollow as an echo. She turned, but in a moment returned.
“Are you well?” she asked. Well might she put the question: his face was blanched as her gown.
“Quite well,” he enunciated; and, with a bow, he left the gate. She went one way; he another. She turned twice to gaze after him as she tripped fairy-like down the field; he, as he strode firmly across, never turned at all.
This spectacle of another’s suffering and sacrifice rapt my thoughts from exclusive meditation on my own. Diana Rivers had designated her brother “inexorable as death.” She had not exaggerated.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Mr. St. John spoke in a manner that was almost mechanical, and only he truly understood the great effort required for him to refuse in this way. "Very well, if you are determined to be so unyielding," she said, "I must leave you now, as I don't dare to stay any longer; the dew is starting to fall. Good evening!" She offered him her hand. He merely touched it. "Good evening!" he repeated, his voice low and empty, like an echo. She started to turn away but immediately came back. "Are you alright?" she inquired. It was a sensible question, considering his face was as pale as her dress. "Quite well," he stated clearly, and with a slight bow, he exited the gate. She took one path, and he took another. She glanced back twice to watch him as she moved lightly down the field, while he walked steadily across it, never looking back once. Seeing this display of someone else's suffering and self-denial diverted my mind from focusing solely on my own issues. Diana Rivers had described her brother as being "as inflexible as death," and her assessment was accurate.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Mr. St. John spoke almost mechanically; only he truly understood how hard it was for him to refuse. "Well, if you're going to be so stubborn, I'll go; I can't stay any longer—it's starting to get damp. Good night!" She offered her hand to him, and he barely touched it. "Good night!" he echoed, his voice quiet and hollow. She walked away, but quickly turned back. "Are you alright?" she asked, understandably, as he looked as pale as her dress. "I'm quite well," he replied clearly, then bowed and left through the gate. They took different paths: she walked lightly through the field, glancing back at him twice; he marched steadily on, never looking back. Witnessing someone else's pain and self-denial shifted my focus from my own concerns. Diana Rivers had called her brother "unyielding as death," and she had not exaggerated.

events.title: Finding Purpose and Connection as a Village Teacher
detailed_summary: The narrator initially found her work as a village schoolteacher challenging, perceiving the untaught children as uniformly dull.
She soon discovered individual differences among them, similar to educated individuals, as they became familiar with each other.
Once the children's initial awe of her subsided, some proved to be quick-witted and obliging.
The narrator observed instances of natural politeness, self-respect, and excellent capacity in her students, earning her goodwill and admiration.
These promising students began to enjoy their work, maintain neatness, learn diligently, and adopt orderly manners.
Their progress was sometimes surprisingly rapid, filling the narrator with honest pride.
She developed personal affection for some of the best girls, and they reciprocated her liking.
Among her students were older farmers' daughters to whom she taught grammar, geography, history, and advanced needlework.
The narrator found admirable qualities in these young women, who were eager for knowledge and improvement, and she spent pleasant evenings in their homes.
The parents of these students showed her great attention and kindness, which she enjoyed and reciprocated with considerate regard for their feelings.
This mutual respect was a new and beneficial experience for the families, elevating their self-perception and encouraging them to merit the respectful treatment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I continued the labours of the village-school as actively and faithfully as I could.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: These soon took a pleasure in doing their work well, in keeping their persons neat, in learning their tasks regularly, in acquiring quiet and orderly manners.

events.text_segment: I continued the labours of the village-school as actively and faithfully as I could. It was truly hard work at first. Some time elapsed before, with all my efforts, I could comprehend my scholars and their nature. Wholly untaught, with faculties quite torpid, they seemed to me hopelessly dull; and, at first sight, all dull alike: but I soon found I was mistaken. There was a difference amongst them as amongst the educated; and when I got to know them, and they me, this difference rapidly developed itself. Their amazement at me, my language, my rules, and ways, once subsided, I found some of these heavy-looking, gaping rustics wake up into sharp-witted girls enough. Many showed themselves obliging, and amiable too; and I discovered amongst them not a few examples of natural politeness, and innate self-respect, as well as of excellent capacity, that won both my goodwill and my admiration. These soon took a pleasure in doing their work well, in keeping their persons neat, in learning their tasks regularly, in acquiring quiet and orderly manners.
