events.title: Inner Turmoil: Daytime Contentment Versus Haunting Dreams of Rochester
detailed_summary: The narrator felt she had become well-liked in the community, experiencing cordial greetings and friendly smiles wherever she went.
Living amidst such general regard, even from working people, brought her a sense of calm and sweetness, allowing serene inward feelings to flourish.
During this time, her heart was more often filled with gratitude than with dejection.
However, despite this peaceful and useful daytime existence, her nights were marked by vivid and agitated dreams.
These dreams were full of idealistic, stirring, and stormy scenarios, involving adventure, risk, and romantic possibilities.
In these dreams, she repeatedly encountered Mr. Rochester, always at a moment of exciting crisis.
The sensations of being in his arms, hearing his voice, meeting his eyes, touching him, and the mutual love they shared, along with the hope of a lifetime together, would be intensely rekindled.
Upon waking, she would recall her actual circumstances, feeling a profound sense of despair.
The quiet darkness of the night would then witness her emotional turmoil and passionate outbursts.
Nevertheless, by the next morning, she would be composed and ready to punctually resume her school duties.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The rapidity of their progress, in some instances, was even surprising; and an honest and happy pride I took in it: besides, I began personally to like some of the best girls; and they liked me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: By nine o’clock the next morning I was punctually opening the school; tranquil, settled, prepared for the steady duties of the day.

events.text_segment:
The rapidity of their progress, in some instances, was even surprising; and an honest and happy pride I took in it: besides, I began personally to like some of the best girls; and they liked me. I had amongst my scholars several farmers’ daughters: young women grown, almost. These could already read, write, and sew; and to them I taught the elements of grammar, geography, history, and the finer kinds of needlework. I found estimable characters amongst them—characters desirous of information and disposed for improvement—with whom I passed many a pleasant evening hour in their own homes. Their parents then (the farmer and his wife) loaded me with attentions. There was an enjoyment in accepting their simple kindness, and in repaying it by a consideration—a scrupulous regard to their feelings—to which they were not, perhaps, at all times accustomed, and which both charmed and benefited them; because, while it elevated them in their own eyes, it made them emulous to merit the deferential treatment they received.
I felt I became a favourite in the neighbourhood. Whenever I went out, I heard on all sides cordial salutations, and was welcomed with friendly smiles. To live amidst general regard, though it be but the regard of working people, is like “sitting in sunshine, calm and sweet;” serene inward feelings bud and bloom under the ray. At this period of my life, my heart far oftener swelled with thankfulness than sank with dejection: and yet, reader, to tell you all, in the midst of this calm, this useful existence—after a day passed in honourable exertion amongst my scholars, an evening spent in drawing or reading contentedly alone—I used to rush into strange dreams at night: dreams many-coloured, agitated, full of the ideal, the stirring, the stormy—dreams where, amidst unusual scenes, charged with adventure, with agitating risk and romantic chance, I still again and again met Mr. Rochester, always at some exciting crisis; and then the sense of being in his arms, hearing his voice, meeting his eye, touching his hand and cheek, loving him, being loved by him—the hope of passing a lifetime at his side, would be renewed, with all its first force and fire. Then I awoke. Then I recalled where I was, and how situated. Then I rose up on my curtainless bed, trembling and quivering; and then the still, dark night witnessed the convulsion of despair, and heard the burst of passion. By nine o’clock the next morning I was punctually opening the school; tranquil, settled, prepared for the steady duties of the day.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Their rapid progress in some instances was astonishing, and I felt a genuine and happy pride in it. Furthermore, I developed personal affection for some of the best students, and they reciprocated my feelings. Among my pupils were several daughters of farmers, who were nearly adult young women. They already possessed basic skills in reading, writing, and sewing. To these students, I imparted knowledge in the fundamentals of grammar, geography, history, and more intricate types of needlework. I discovered admirable qualities among them – individuals eager to learn and open to self-improvement – with whom I spent numerous enjoyable evenings visiting their homes. Their parents, the farmer and his wife, were exceedingly generous with their hospitality towards me. There was satisfaction in accepting their simple kindness and reciprocating it with thoughtful consideration – a meticulous attentiveness to their feelings – something they may not have always been accustomed to, which both delighted and benefited them. This was because it elevated their self-esteem and inspired them to strive to be worthy of the respectful treatment they received. I felt I was becoming well-regarded in the community. Whenever I went out, I was met with warm greetings and friendly smiles from everyone around me. Living among such general respect, even from ordinary people, is like 'sitting in sunshine, calm and sweet;' peaceful inner emotions blossom under its influence. During this period of my life, my heart was filled with gratitude far more often than it was weighed down by sadness. And yet, dear reader, I must confess, amidst this tranquil, productive existence – after a day spent in worthwhile effort among my students, followed by an evening peacefully spent alone drawing or reading – I would often experience vivid, unsettling dreams at night. These dreams were colorful, tumultuous, filled with idealism, excitement, and drama. In them, amidst unfamiliar settings and charged with adventure, risk, and romantic possibility, I repeatedly encountered Mr. Rochester, always at a moment of intense climax. Then, the sensation of being in his arms, hearing his voice, meeting his gaze, touching his hand and face, loving him, and being loved by him – the hope of sharing my life with him – would resurface with its original strength and fervor. I would then awaken. I would remember where I was and my present circumstances. I would rise from my humble bed, trembling and shaking. And then, the quiet, dark night would witness my desperate struggle and hear my passionate outcry. By nine o'clock the next morning, however, I would be promptly opening the school, composed, steady, and ready for the consistent duties of the day.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: My students made remarkable progress, sometimes even surprising me, and I felt genuinely proud of their achievements. I started to form personal bonds with some of the best pupils, who also grew fond of me. I found these students to be worthy and eager to learn, and spent many pleasant evenings with them at their homes, where their parents, grateful for my attentiveness, treated me kindly. I enjoyed both receiving their hospitality and giving back by respecting their feelings, which perhaps they were not used to; this consideration pleased and encouraged them, inspiring them to deserve such respectful treatment. I became well-liked in the area, greeted warmly wherever I went, and appreciated by everyone. Living with such general goodwill, even from working people, felt like basking in warm, gentle sunshine—my spirits were calm and grateful far more often than sad. Yet, to be honest, in the midst of this peaceful and productive life, after days spent teaching and quiet evenings alone, I would often fall into vivid, wild dreams at night—dreams filled with adventure and tumult, almost always involving Mr. Rochester at dramatic moments. On waking, reality would return, making me painfully aware of my circumstances, and I would be left shaken and despairing in the darkness of night. Yet by nine o’clock each morning, I was once again calmly and dutifully opening the school, ready for the day’s work.

events.title: Rosamond's Alluring Visits and St. John's Repressed Passion
detailed_summary: Rosamond Oliver fulfilled her promise to visit the narrator, typically arriving at the school during her morning horseback ride, accompanied by a servant.
Her appearance in her riding attire was described as exquisitely beautiful, captivating the village children as she moved through the schoolhouse.
Rosamond usually visited when Mr. Rivers was conducting his daily catechism lesson.
The narrator perceived that Rosamond's presence deeply affected the young pastor.
An instinct seemed to alert St. John to Rosamond's arrival even if he didn't see her; his complexion would change and his features, though outwardly composed, would betray a repressed fervour.
Rosamond was aware of her influence over St. John, as he could not hide his reactions.
Despite his stoic nature, when Rosamond addressed him with smiles, his hand would tremble and his eyes would show his inner turmoil.
His sad, resolute expression seemed to convey his love for her and his awareness of her preference, but also his inability to act due to a pre-existing commitment to a sacred cause.
Rosamond would react with childlike disappointment and transient petulance to his martyr-like demeanor, withdrawing from him.
The narrator understood that St. John, despite desperately wanting to keep Rosamond, would not sacrifice his heavenly aspirations or his broader mission for her love.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Rosamond Oliver kept her word in coming to visit me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I learnt so much from himself in an inroad I once, despite his reserve, had the daring to make on his confidence.

events.text_segment:
Rosamond Oliver kept her word in coming to visit me. Her call at the school was generally made in the course of her morning ride. She would canter up to the door on her pony, followed by a mounted livery servant. Anything more exquisite than her appearance, in her purple habit, with her Amazon’s cap of black velvet placed gracefully above the long curls that kissed her cheek and floated to her shoulders, can scarcely be imagined: and it was thus she would enter the rustic building, and glide through the dazzled ranks of the village children. She generally came at the hour when Mr. Rivers was engaged in giving his daily catechising lesson. Keenly, I fear, did the eye of the visitress pierce the young pastor’s heart. A sort of instinct seemed to warn him of her entrance, even when he did not see it; and when he was looking quite away from the door, if she appeared at it, his cheek would glow, and his marble-seeming features, though they refused to relax, changed indescribably, and in their very quiescence became expressive of a repressed fervour, stronger than working muscle or darting glance could indicate.
Of course, she knew her power: indeed, he did not, because he could not, conceal it from her. In spite of his Christian stoicism, when she went up and addressed him, and smiled gaily, encouragingly, even fondly in his face, his hand would tremble and his eye burn. He seemed to say, with his sad and resolute look, if he did not say it with his lips, “I love you, and I know you prefer me. It is not despair of success that keeps me dumb. If I offered my heart, I believe you would accept it. But that heart is already laid on a sacred altar: the fire is arranged round it. It will soon be no more than a sacrifice consumed.”
And then she would pout like a disappointed child; a pensive cloud would soften her radiant vivacity; she would withdraw her hand hastily from his, and turn in transient petulance from his aspect, at once so heroic and so martyr-like. St. John, no doubt, would have given the world to follow, recall, retain her, when she thus left him; but he would not give one chance of heaven, nor relinquish, for the elysium of her love, one hope of the true, eternal Paradise. Besides, he could not bind all that he had in his nature—the rover, the aspirant, the poet, the priest—in the limits of a single passion. He could not—he would not—renounce his wild field of mission warfare for the parlours and the peace of Vale Hall. I learnt so much from himself in an inroad I once, despite his reserve, had the daring to make on his confidence.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Rosamond Oliver followed through on her promise to visit me. Her visits to the school typically occurred during her morning horseback rides. She would gallop to the entrance on her pony, accompanied by a mounted servant in livery. Her appearance was remarkably elegant, dressed in a purple riding habit with a black velvet cap perched gracefully over her long curls that framed her face and fell to her shoulders. It was in this stunning manner that she would enter the simple schoolhouse and pass through the attentive lines of village children. She usually arrived when Mr. Rivers was giving his daily catechism lesson. I believe her presence deeply affected the young clergyman. He seemed to have an intuition of her arrival, even when he didn't see her; if she appeared at the door while he was looking elsewhere, his face would flush, and his typically impassive features, although remaining controlled, would subtly change, conveying a suppressed passion stronger than any outward action or look could show.Naturally, she recognized her influence over him; indeed, he couldn't, and didn't, hide it from her. Despite his disciplined Christian composure, when she approached him, spoke, and smiled cheerfully, encouragingly, and even affectionately at him, his hand would tremble and his eyes would burn with intensity. With his somber and determined expression, he seemed to communicate, even without speaking aloud, "I love you, and I know you prefer me. It is not a lack of confidence in success that keeps me silent. If I offered you my heart, I believe you would accept it. But that heart is already dedicated to a sacred purpose; it is surrounded by the preparatory fires and will soon be entirely consumed as a sacrifice."She would then show disappointment, like a child denied something; a thoughtful expression would temper her bright energy; she would quickly withdraw her hand from his and turn away briefly in frustration from his demeanor, which was both noble and self-sacrificing. Furthermore, he couldn't confine the full scope of his character—the explorer, the ambitious man, the pensive spirit, the devoted priest—within the bounds of a single romantic attachment. He could not, and would not, abandon his challenging missionary battlefield for the comfortable rooms and quiet life of Vale Hall. I discovered much of this from him personally during a time when, despite his usual reserve, I dared to seek his confidence.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Rosamond Oliver stayed true to her promise to visit me, often stopping by the school during her morning horseback rides. She would arrive elegantly, riding her pony and accompanied by a servant in livery. Her appearance in her purple riding outfit and stylish black velvet cap, with curls framing her face and shoulders, was strikingly beautiful and hard to imagine anything more lovely. She would enter the simple school building and walk gracefully past the astonished village children. She typically came when Mr. Rivers was teaching religious lessons to the students, and I suspect that her presence deeply affected him. Even when he wasn’t looking, he seemed to sense when she arrived, and the sight of her would bring color to his face and cause his usually calm features to show a strong, concealed emotion.

Despite trying to remain stoic, whenever she approached him and spoke with warmth and encouragement, his hand would shake and his eyes would light up. His expression seemed to say, even if his words did not: "I love you, and I know you care for me. But it's not fear of rejection that keeps me silent. My heart is already devoted to a higher purpose; it's committed to a sacred cause and soon will be consumed by it." 

When confronted with his self-restraint, Rosamond would sometimes react with childish disappointment, her cheerful energy dimming as she quickly withdrew from him, temporarily upset by his noble distance. While St. John probably ached to follow and comfort her after such moments, he would not sacrifice his spiritual ambitions or hopes for eternal reward for the sake of her love. In addition, he could not limit his complex nature—his adventurous, ambitious, poetic, and priestly qualities—to a single romantic relationship. He was unwilling to give up his calling as a missionary for a comfortable life at Vale Hall. I learned this much from him during a conversation where I boldly asked about his feelings, despite his natural reserve.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Oliver already honoured me with frequent visits to my cottage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I promised myself the pleasure of colouring it; and, as it was getting late then, I told her she must come and sit another day.

events.text_segment:
Miss Oliver already honoured me with frequent visits to my cottage. I had learnt her whole character, which was without mystery or disguise: she was coquettish but not heartless; exacting, but not worthlessly selfish. She had been indulged from her birth, but was not absolutely spoilt. She was hasty, but good-humoured; vain (she could not help it, when every glance in the glass showed her such a flush of loveliness), but not affected; liberal-handed; innocent of the pride of wealth; ingenuous; sufficiently intelligent; gay, lively, and unthinking: she was very charming, in short, even to a cool observer of her own sex like me; but she was not profoundly interesting or thoroughly impressive. A very different sort of mind was hers from that, for instance, of the sisters of St. John. Still, I liked her almost as I liked my pupil Adèle; except that, for a child whom we have watched over and taught, a closer affection is engendered than we can give an equally attractive adult acquaintance.
She had taken an amiable caprice to me. She said I was like Mr. Rivers, only, certainly, she allowed, “not one-tenth so handsome, though I was a nice neat little soul enough, but he was an angel.” I was, however, good, clever, composed, and firm, like him. I was a lusus naturæ, she affirmed, as a village schoolmistress: she was sure my previous history, if known, would make a delightful romance.
One evening, while, with her usual child-like activity, and thoughtless yet not offensive inquisitiveness, she was rummaging the cupboard and the table-drawer of my little kitchen, she discovered first two French books, a volume of Schiller, a German grammar and dictionary, and then my drawing-materials and some sketches, including a pencil-head of a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars, and sundry views from nature, taken in the Vale of Morton and on the surrounding moors. She was first transfixed with surprise, and then electrified with delight.
“Had I done these pictures? Did I know French and German? What a love—what a miracle I was! I drew better than her master in the first school in S——. Would I sketch a portrait of her, to show to papa?”
“With pleasure,” I replied; and I felt a thrill of artist-delight at the idea of copying from so perfect and radiant a model. She had then on a dark-blue silk dress; her arms and her neck were bare; her only ornament was her chestnut tresses, which waved over her shoulders with all the wild grace of natural curls. I took a sheet of fine card-board, and drew a careful outline. I promised myself the pleasure of colouring it; and, as it was getting late then, I told her she must come and sit another day.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Miss Oliver came to my humble home quite often. I had come to fully understand her personality, which was open and straightforward. While she could be flirtatious, she wasn't unkind; demanding, but not pointlessly self-centered. Though she had been spoiled since birth, she wasn't completely ruined. She was quick-tempered but maintained a good mood. She was clearly vain (and understandably so, given the beauty reflected in every mirror), but she wasn't artificial. She was generous with her money, free from any arrogance about her wealth, and genuinely honest. She was reasonably intelligent, cheerful, energetic, and tended to act without much forethought. In short, she was very captivating, even to a pragmatic observer of her own sex like me, but she wasn't someone with profound depth or lasting impact. Her way of thinking was quite different, for instance, from that of St. John's sisters. Nevertheless, I liked her almost as much as my student Adèle, although the bond developed with a child one has cared for and educated is naturally stronger than the affection one feels for an equally appealing adult acquaintance.
She took an immediate liking to me, a sort of pleasant whim. She remarked that I resembled Mr. Rivers, admitting, however, that I was certainly 'not even a tenth as handsome,' though 'a nice, neat little soul,' while he was 'an angel.' Still, she noted that I shared his positive qualities: I was good, intelligent, calm, and resolute. She declared me a 'lusus naturae' – a sort of natural oddity – for a village schoolmistress, confident that if my past were known, it would make a wonderful, romantic story.
One evening, displaying her usual childlike energy and her thoughtless yet not annoying curiosity, she began searching through my small kitchen's cupboard and table drawer. There, she first found two French books, a volume of Schiller, and a German grammar and dictionary. Then she discovered my art supplies and some sketches, which included a pencil drawing of a pretty, cherubic-looking little girl (one of my students) and various nature scenes drawn from the Morton Valley and the surrounding moorlands. Her reaction was initial astonishment, followed by sheer delight.
'Did you do these pictures? Do you know French and German? What a darling – what a marvel you are!' she exclaimed. 'You draw better than my master in the top school in S—.' She then asked, 'Would you sketch a portrait of me to show Papa?'
'With pleasure,' I responded, feeling an artist's thrill at the prospect of depicting such a perfect and radiant subject. She was wearing a dark-blue silk dress at the time, her arms and neck bare. Her only decoration was her flowing chestnut hair, which curled naturally over her shoulders with wild grace. I took a sheet of good cardboard and began a careful outline. I promised myself the satisfaction of adding color later. As it was getting late, I told her she would need to come back another day to finish sitting.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:

She was quick-tempered yet good-natured, vain due to her beauty but not pretentious, generous, not proud of her wealth, honest, adequately intelligent, cheerful, lively, and rather careless. Overall, she was delightful, even to a detached observer like myself, but she wasn't particularly deep or striking. Her mind was very different from St. John's sisters, for instance. Nonetheless, I liked her almost as much as my pupil Adèle, though the affection for a child one has nurtured is always greater than for a charming adult acquaintance.

She had developed a friendly liking for me, remarking that I resembled Mr. Rivers, though she admitted, "not nearly as handsome, though I was a tidy, neat person, but he was like an angel." Still, she considered me good, intelligent, calm, and steady like him. She called it a marvel that someone like me—serving as a village schoolmistress—could exist, and was convinced that my life story would make a fascinating novel.

One evening, displaying her usual lively, innocent curiosity, she started exploring my kitchen cupboards and drawers. He also insisted on the narrator spending the following evening at Vale Hall.
The narrator went to Vale Hall, a large, handsome residence indicative of its owner's wealth.
Rosamond was joyful throughout the narrator's stay, and her father was affable.
After tea, Mr. Oliver expressed strong approval of the narrator's work at the Morton school.
He voiced concern that she was too skilled for her current position and might soon leave for something more fitting.
Rosamond interjected that the narrator was clever enough to be a governess in a prominent family.
The narrator privately preferred her current situation to any high-status family employment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She made such a report of me to her father, that Mr. Oliver himself accompanied her next evening—a tall, massive-featured, middle-aged, and grey-headed man, at whose side his lovely daughter looked like a bright flower near a hoary turret.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Oliver evidently regarded the young clergyman’s good birth, old name, and sacred profession as sufficient compensation for the want of fortune.

events.text_segment:
She made such a report of me to her father, that Mr. Oliver himself accompanied her next evening—a tall, massive-featured, middle-aged, and grey-headed man, at whose side his lovely daughter looked like a bright flower near a hoary turret. He appeared a taciturn, and perhaps a proud personage; but he was very kind to me. The sketch of Rosamond’s portrait pleased him highly: he said I must make a finished picture of it. He insisted, too, on my coming the next day to spend the evening at Vale Hall.
I went. I found it a large, handsome residence, showing abundant evidences of wealth in the proprietor. Rosamond was full of glee and pleasure all the time I stayed. Her father was affable; and when he entered into conversation with me after tea, he expressed in strong terms his approbation of what I had done in Morton school, and said he only feared, from what he saw and heard, I was too good for the place, and would soon quit it for one more suitable.
“Indeed,” cried Rosamond, “she is clever enough to be a governess in a high family, papa.”
I thought I would far rather be where I am than in any high family in the land. Mr. Oliver spoke of Mr. Rivers—of the Rivers family—with great respect. He said it was a very old name in that neighbourhood; that the ancestors of the house were wealthy; that all Morton had once belonged to them; that even now he considered the representative of that house might, if he liked, make an alliance with the best. He accounted it a pity that so fine and talented a young man should have formed the design of going out as a missionary; it was quite throwing a valuable life away. It appeared, then, that her father would throw no obstacle in the way of Rosamond’s union with St. John. Mr. Oliver evidently regarded the young clergyman’s good birth, old name, and sacred profession as sufficient compensation for the want of fortune.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Rosamond spoke so favorably of me to her father that Mr. Oliver himself visited the following evening, accompanied by her. He was a tall man with strong features, middle-aged, and grey-haired, making his lovely daughter appear like a vibrant bloom beside a weathered castle turret. He struck me as reserved, perhaps even haughty, but he treated me with great kindness. He was highly pleased with the initial sketch of Rosamond’s portrait and requested a completed version. He also strongly urged me to come to Vale Hall the next day for the evening.
I accepted his invitation. Vale Hall proved to be a substantial and attractive estate, clearly belonging to a wealthy owner. Throughout my visit, Rosamond was full of joy and delight. Her father was gracious, and after tea, he conversed with me, expressing strong approval of my work at Morton school. Based on his observations and what he'd heard, he feared I was overqualified for the position and would soon leave for a more suitable one.
Rosamond exclaimed, “Indeed, Papa, she is intelligent enough to be a governess for a noble family.”
My own thought was that I preferred my current situation to working for any high-status family in the country. Mr. Oliver spoke of Mr. Rivers—the Rivers lineage—with considerable respect. He mentioned it was a very old name locally, that the family ancestors had been wealthy, and that they had once owned all of Morton. He believed the current descendant could still, if he wished, marry into the most prominent families. He considered it a pity that such a capable and gifted young man had decided to become a missionary, feeling it was a waste of a valuable life. It became clear, then, that her father would not object to Rosamond marrying St. John. Mr. Oliver apparently viewed the young clergyman's noble birth, ancient name, and sacred profession as sufficient compensation for his lack of fortune.

events.text_segment:
It was the 5th of November, and a holiday. My little servant, after helping me to clean my house, was gone, well satisfied with the fee of a penny for her aid. All about me was spotless and bright—scoured floor, polished grate, and well-rubbed chairs. I had also made myself neat, and had now the afternoon before me to spend as I would.
The translation of a few pages of German occupied an hour; then I got my palette and pencils, and fell to the more soothing, because easier occupation, of completing Rosamond Oliver’s miniature. The head was finished already: there was but the background to tint and the drapery to shade off; a touch of carmine, too, to add to the ripe lips—a soft curl here and there to the tresses—a deeper tinge to the shadow of the lash under the azured eyelid. I was absorbed in the execution of these nice details, when, after one rapid tap, my door unclosed, admitting St. John Rivers.
“I am come to see how you are spending your holiday,” he said. “Not, I hope, in thought? No, that is well: while you draw you will not feel lonely. You see, I mistrust you still, though you have borne up wonderfully so far. I have brought you a book for evening solace,” and he laid on the table a new publication—a poem: one of those genuine productions so often vouchsafed to the fortunate public of those days—the golden age of modern literature. Alas! the readers of our era are less favoured. But courage! I will not pause either to accuse or repine. I know poetry is not dead, nor genius lost; nor has Mammon gained power over either, to bind or slay: they will both assert their existence, their presence, their liberty and strength again one day. Powerful angels, safe in heaven! they smile when sordid souls triumph, and feeble ones weep over their destruction. Poetry destroyed? Genius banished? No! Mediocrity, no: do not let envy prompt you to the thought. No; they not only live, but reign and redeem: and without their divine influence spread everywhere, you would be in hell—the hell of your own meanness.
While I was eagerly glancing at the bright pages of “Marmion” (for “Marmion” it was), St. John stooped to examine my drawing. His tall figure sprang erect again with a start: he said nothing. I looked up at him: he shunned my eye. I knew his thoughts well, and could read his heart plainly; at the moment I felt calmer and cooler than he: I had then temporarily the advantage of him, and I conceived an inclination to do him some good, if I could.
“With all his firmness and self-control,” thought I, “he tasks himself too far: locks every feeling and pang within—expresses, confesses, imparts nothing. I am sure it would benefit him to talk a little about this sweet Rosamond, whom he thinks he ought not to marry: I will make him talk.”
I said first, “Take a chair, Mr. Rivers.” But he answered, as he always did, that he could not stay. “Very well,” I responded, mentally, “stand if you like; but you shall not go just yet, I am determined: solitude is at least as bad for you as it is for me. I’ll try if I cannot discover the secret spring of your confidence, and find an aperture in that marble breast through which I can shed one drop of the balm of sympathy.”
“Is this portrait like?” I asked bluntly.
“Like! Like whom? I did not observe it closely.”
“You did, Mr. Rivers.”
He almost started at my sudden and strange abruptness: he looked at me astonished. “Oh, that is nothing yet,” I muttered within. “I don’t mean to be baffled by a little stiffness on your part; I’m prepared to go to considerable lengths.” I continued, “You observed it closely and distinctly; but I have no objection to your looking at it again,” and I rose and placed it in his hand.
“A well-executed picture,” he said; “very soft, clear colouring; very graceful and correct drawing.”
“Yes, yes; I know all that. But what of the resemblance? Who is it like?”
Mastering some hesitation, he answered, “Miss Oliver, I presume.”
“Of course. And now, sir, to reward you for the accurate guess, I will promise to paint you a careful and faithful duplicate of this very picture, provided you admit that the gift would be acceptable to you. I don’t wish to throw away my time and trouble on an offering you would deem worthless.”
He continued to gaze at the picture: the longer he looked, the firmer he held it, the more he seemed to covet it. “It is like!” he murmured; “the eye is well managed: the colour, light, expression, are perfect. It smiles!”
“Would it comfort, or would it wound you to have a similar painting? Tell me that. When you are at Madagascar, or at the Cape, or in India, would it be a consolation to have that memento in your possession? or would the sight of it bring recollections calculated to enervate and distress?”
He now furtively raised his eyes: he glanced at me, irresolute, disturbed: he again surveyed the picture.
“That I should like to have it is certain: whether it would be judicious or wise is another question.”
Since I had ascertained that Rosamond really preferred him, and that her father was not likely to oppose the match, I—less exalted in my views than St. John—had been strongly disposed in my own heart to advocate their union. It seemed to me that, should he become the possessor of Mr. Oliver’s large fortune, he might do as much good with it as if he went and laid his genius out to wither, and his strength to waste, under a tropical sun. With this persuasion I now answered—
“As far as I can see, it would be wiser and more judicious if you were to take to yourself the original at once.”

It is smiling!” “Would possessing a similar painting comfort or pain you? Tell me that. When you are in Madagascar, or at the Cape, or in India, would having that reminder bring you solace? Or would seeing it bring back memories that would weaken and distress you?” He then subtly raised his eyes, glancing at me, appearing uncertain and troubled. He looked at the picture again. “That I would like to have it is clear; whether it would be sensible or wise is a different matter.” Since I had confirmed that Rosamond genuinely cared for him, and that her father was unlikely to object to their marriage, I—with less elevated goals than St. John—had felt strongly within my heart that they should be together. It seemed to me that if he were to inherit Mr. Oliver's substantial fortune, he could do just as much good with it as he could by going abroad and letting his talent wither and his strength be wasted under a tropical sun. With this belief, I now answered, “As far as I can see, it would be wiser and more sensible if you were to marry the original right away.”

It was November 5th, a holiday, and after my young helper finished tidying my home for the small wage of a penny, she left satisfied. My surroundings were clean and shining—scrubbed floors, gleaming fireplace, and polished furniture. Having made myself presentable, I now had the afternoon free. I spent the next hour translating some German, then decided to shift to a more relaxing task: completing a miniature portrait of Rosamond Oliver. The face was done; I only needed to finish details like the background, her clothing, a slight flush to her lips, and some touches to her hair and eyelashes. As I focused intently on these details, a quick knock announced the arrival of St. John Rivers, who entered my room.

He explained he wanted to see how I was spending my holiday and was glad I was occupied with drawing and thus not feeling lonely. He admitted to still worrying about my wellbeing, even though I had shown resilience, and gave me a new book—a poem—to enjoy in the evening. He praised the literary era and reassured me that poetry and genius endure beyond material concerns, their influence vital to our lives.

As I eagerly looked at the poem, which was “Marmion,” St. John examined my drawing. He seemed startled, avoided my eyes, and though I sensed his emotions, I felt calmer than he did and wanted to help him if I could. I thought to myself that, despite his discipline and composure, he suppressed all his feelings and would benefit from talking, especially about Rosamond, whom he believed he shouldn’t marry. I resolved to encourage him to open up.

I invited him to sit, but as usual, he said he couldn’t stay; internally, I was determined not to let him leave so easily. I wanted to find a way to gain his confidence and offer support. Bluntly, I asked him about the likeness of the portrait. Feigning disinterest, he reluctantly admitted it resembled Miss Oliver. I offered to paint him a copy of the portrait, on the condition that the gift would be welcome.

He looked at the painting longingly and admitted he would like to have it, though he wasn’t sure it would be wise. Having learned that Rosamond liked him and her father was unlikely to oppose their match, I felt—less idealistic than he was—that their marriage would be for the best. I believed he could do as much good in England with a fortune as he could abroad as a missionary. So I told him outright that he would be wiser to marry Rosamond herself.

events.title: St. John's Anguished Confession, Painful Renunciation, and Cryptic Departure
characters: Rosamond Oliver (as subject of discussion and portrait)
detailed_summary: St. John sat down, placing the portrait before him and resting his head in his hands, gazing at it fondly.
The narrator sensed he was neither angry nor shocked by her boldness; rather, he seemed to find relief and a new pleasure in discussing the subject openly.
She observed that reserved individuals often need frank discussion of their feelings more than expressive ones.
Standing behind him, she assured him that Rosamond liked him and her father respected him, suggesting he marry the somewhat thoughtless but sweet girl, for whom he had enough thoughtfulness.
St. John asked if Rosamond truly liked him, and the narrator confirmed it, stating Rosamond spoke of him constantly.
He found this pleasant and asked her to continue, even taking out his watch to time a quarter of an hour for this indulgence.
The narrator questioned the utility of continuing if he was merely preparing a rebuttal or strengthening his resolve against his feelings.

St. John urged her to imagine him yielding to human love, a fresh fountain overflowing his carefully planned life of self-denial, describing a vivid fantasy of blissful domesticity with Rosamond at Vale Hall.
He immersed himself in this vision, asking for silence as his heart filled with delight.
After the timed quarter-hour, he abruptly ended his reverie, declaring it a moment of delirium and delusion.
He acknowledged the allure of temptation but recognized its dangers—a burning pillow, a venomous asp in the garland, bitter wine, and false promises.

He confessed that while he loved Rosamond wildly, with the intensity of a first passion for a beautiful woman, he simultaneously knew she would not make him a good wife or suitable partner, and that rapture would be followed by lifelong regret.

He explained that while one part of him was drawn to her charms, another was acutely aware of her defects, which would prevent her from sympathizing with or co-operating in his life's work as a missionary's wife.
When the narrator suggested he could abandon his missionary scheme, St. John passionately affirmed that his vocation, his great work, and his hopes for heavenly reward were dearer than life itself.
Asked about Rosamond's potential sorrow, he coolly stated she would soon forget him and marry someone who could make her happier.
He attributed his own physical decline not to this conflict, but to anxiety over his unsettled prospects and delayed departure for his mission, which had just been postponed further.
When the narrator pointed out his physical reactions to Rosamond's presence, he was surprised by her audacity but admitted she was original and brave.
He then attempted to downplay his emotions for Rosamond as a mere 'fever of the flesh,' not a soul-deep convulsion, insisting his soul was fixed and that he was fundamentally a 'cold hard man'.
He declared that natural affection was the only sentiment with permanent power over him, with reason, not feeling, as his guide, and limitless ambition.

He explained that Christianity had cultivated his natural qualities, turning affection into philanthropy and ambition into a desire to spread his Master's kingdom, pruning but not eradicating his core nature.
Preparing to leave, he took his hat, looked once more at the portrait, murmured of Rosamond's loveliness, and refused the narrator's offer to paint a copy for him.
He then noticed something on the thin protective paper over the drawing, snatched it up, examined its edge, and gave the narrator a peculiar, incomprehensible glance.
He quickly tore a narrow slip from the paper's margin, concealed it in his glove, and vanished with a hasty nod.
The narrator, puzzled, examined the paper but found nothing significant, dismissing the unresolved mystery.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By this time he had sat down: he had laid the picture on the table before him, and with his brow supported on both hands, hung fondly over it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I pondered the mystery a minute or two; but finding it insolvable, and being certain it could not be of much moment, I dismissed, and soon forgot it.

events.text_segment:
By this time he had sat down: he had laid the picture on the table before him, and with his brow supported on both hands, hung fondly over it. I discerned he was now neither angry nor shocked at my audacity. I saw even that to be thus frankly addressed on a subject he had deemed unapproachable—to hear it thus freely handled—was beginning to be felt by him as a new pleasure—an unhoped-for relief. Reserved people often really need the frank discussion of their sentiments and griefs more than the expansive. The sternest-seeming stoic is human after all; and to “burst” with boldness and good-will into “the silent sea” of their souls is often to confer on them the first of obligations.
“She likes you, I am sure,” said I, as I stood behind his chair, “and her father respects you. Moreover, she is a sweet girl—rather thoughtless; but you would have sufficient thought for both yourself and her. You ought to marry her.”
“Does she like me?” he asked.
“Certainly; better than she likes any one else. She talks of you continually: there is no subject she enjoys so much or touches upon so often.”
“It is very pleasant to hear this,” he said—“very: go on for another quarter of an hour.” And he actually took out his watch and laid it upon the table to measure the time.
“But where is the use of going on,” I asked, “when you are probably preparing some iron blow of contradiction, or forging a fresh chain to fetter your heart?”
“Don’t imagine such hard things. Fancy me yielding and melting, as I am doing: human love rising like a freshly opened fountain in my mind and overflowing with sweet inundation all the field I have so carefully and with such labour prepared—so assiduously sown with the seeds of good intentions, of self-denying plans. And now it is deluged with a nectarous flood—the young germs swamped—delicious poison cankering them: now I see myself stretched on an ottoman in the drawing-room at Vale Hall at my bride Rosamond Oliver’s feet: she is talking to me with her sweet voice—gazing down on me with those eyes your skilful hand has copied so well—smiling at me with these coral lips. She is mine—I am hers—this present life and passing world suffice to me. Hush! say nothing—my heart is full of delight—my senses are entranced—let the time I marked pass in peace.”
I humoured him: the watch ticked on: he breathed fast and low: I stood silent. Amidst this hush the quartet sped; he replaced the watch, laid the picture down, rose, and stood on the hearth.
“Now,” said he, “that little space was given to delirium and delusion. I rested my temples on the breast of temptation, and put my neck voluntarily under her yoke of flowers; I tasted her cup. The pillow was burning: there is an asp in the garland: the wine has a bitter taste: her promises are hollow—her offers false: I see and know all this.”
I gazed at him in wonder.
“It is strange,” pursued he, “that while I love Rosamond Oliver so wildly—with all the intensity, indeed, of a first passion, the object of which is exquisitely beautiful, graceful, fascinating—I experience at the same time a calm, unwarped consciousness that she would not make me a good wife; that she is not the partner suited to me; that I should discover this within a year after marriage; and that to twelve months’ rapture would succeed a lifetime of regret. This I know.”
“Strange indeed!” I could not help ejaculating.
“While something in me,” he went on, “is acutely sensible to her charms, something else is as deeply impressed with her defects: they are such that she could sympathise in nothing I aspired to—co-operate in nothing I undertook. Rosamond a sufferer, a labourer, a female apostle? Rosamond a missionary’s wife? No!”
“But you need not be a missionary. You might relinquish that scheme.”
“Relinquish! What! my vocation? My great work? My foundation laid on earth for a mansion in heaven? My hopes of being numbered in the band who have merged all ambitions in the glorious one of bettering their race—of carrying knowledge into the realms of ignorance—of substituting peace for war—freedom for bondage—religion for superstition—the hope of heaven for the fear of hell? Must I relinquish that? It is dearer than the blood in my veins. It is what I have to look forward to, and to live for.”
After a considerable pause, I said—“And Miss Oliver? Are her disappointment and sorrow of no interest to you?”
“Miss Oliver is ever surrounded by suitors and flatterers: in less than a month, my image will be effaced from her heart. She will forget me; and will marry, probably, some one who will make her far happier than I should do.”
“You speak coolly enough; but you suffer in the conflict. You are wasting away.”
“No. If I get a little thin, it is with anxiety about my prospects, yet unsettled—my departure, continually procrastinated. Only this morning, I received intelligence that the successor, whose arrival I have been so long expecting, cannot be ready to replace me for three months to come yet; and perhaps the three months may extend to six.”
“You tremble and become flushed whenever Miss Oliver enters the schoolroom.”
Again the surprised expression crossed his face. He had not imagined that a woman would dare to speak so to a man. For me, I felt at home in this sort of discourse. I could never rest in communication with strong, discreet, and refined minds, whether male or female, till I had passed the outworks of conventional reserve, and crossed the threshold of confidence, and won a place by their heart’s very hearthstone.
“You are original,” said he, “and not timid. There is something brave in your spirit, as well as penetrating in your eye; but allow me to assure you that you partially misinterpret my emotions. You think them more profound and potent than they are. You give me a larger allowance of sympathy than I have a just claim to. When I colour, and when I shake before Miss Oliver, I do not pity myself. I scorn the weakness. I know it is ignoble: a mere fever of the flesh: not, I declare, the convulsion of the soul. That is just as fixed as a rock, firm set in the depths of a restless sea. Know me to be what I am—a cold hard man.”
I smiled incredulously.
“You have taken my confidence by storm,” he continued, “and now it is much at your service. I am simply, in my original state—stripped of that blood-bleached robe with which Christianity covers human deformity—a cold, hard, ambitious man. Natural affection only, of all the sentiments, has permanent power over me. Reason, and not feeling, is my guide; my ambition is unlimited: my desire to rise higher, to do more than others, insatiable. I honour endurance, perseverance, industry, talent; because these are the means by which men achieve great ends and mount to lofty eminence. I watch your career with interest, because I consider you a specimen of a diligent, orderly, energetic woman: not because I deeply compassionate what you have gone through, or what you still suffer.”
“You would describe yourself as a mere pagan philosopher,” I said.
“No. There is this difference between me and deistic philosophers: I believe; and I believe the Gospel. You missed your epithet. I am not a pagan, but a Christian philosopher—a follower of the sect of Jesus. As His disciple I adopt His pure, His merciful, His benignant doctrines. I advocate them: I am sworn to spread them. Won in youth to religion, she has cultivated my original qualities thus:—From the minute germ, natural affection, she has developed the overshadowing tree, philanthropy. From the wild stringy root of human uprightness, she has reared a due sense of the Divine justice. Of the ambition to win power and renown for my wretched self, she has formed the ambition to spread my Master’s kingdom; to achieve victories for the standard of the cross. So much has religion done for me; turning the original materials to the best account; pruning and training nature. But she could not eradicate nature: nor will it be eradicated ‘till this mortal shall put on immortality.’”
Having said this, he took his hat, which lay on the table beside my palette. Once more he looked at the portrait.
“She is lovely,” he murmured. “She is well named the Rose of the World, indeed!”
“And may I not paint one like it for you?”
“Cui bono? No.”
He drew over the picture the sheet of thin paper on which I was accustomed to rest my hand in painting, to prevent the cardboard from being sullied. What he suddenly saw on this blank paper, it was impossible for me to tell; but something had caught his eye. He took it up with a snatch; he looked at the edge; then shot a glance at me, inexpressibly peculiar, and quite incomprehensible: a glance that seemed to take and make note of every point in my shape, face, and dress; for it traversed all, quick, keen as lightning. His lips parted, as if to speak: but he checked the coming sentence, whatever it was.
“What is the matter?” I asked.
“Nothing in the world,” was the reply; and, replacing the paper, I saw him dexterously tear a narrow slip from the margin. It disappeared in his glove; and, with one hasty nod and “good-afternoon,” he vanished.
“Well!” I exclaimed, using an expression of the district, “that caps the globe, however!”
I, in my turn, scrutinised the paper; but saw nothing on it save a few dingy stains of paint where I had tried the tint in my pencil. I pondered the mystery a minute or two; but finding it insolvable, and being certain it could not be of much moment, I dismissed, and soon forgot it.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: By this time, he had taken a seat and placed the picture on the table in front of him, resting his forehead on both hands as he bent over it affectionately. I could tell he was no longer annoyed or surprised by my boldness. I even saw that being addressed so directly on a topic he considered inaccessible, and hearing it discussed with such freedom, was starting to feel like a new enjoyment—an unexpected source of relief. Reserved individuals often need open conversations about their feelings and troubles more than those who express themselves easily. Even the person who appears most stern is human beneath the surface, and boldly and kindly entering the 'silent sea' of their soul can frequently be the most valuable thing you can offer them.Standing behind his chair, I said, "I am sure she is fond of you, and her father holds you in high esteem. Moreover, she is a delightful girl, though perhaps a little impractical; but you would have enough good sense for both of you. You really ought to marry her.""Does she truly care for me?" he inquired."Certainly, more than anyone else. She talks about you constantly; there is no subject she takes more pleasure in or brings up more often.""It is very pleasant to hear this," he said, "very pleasant indeed; continue speaking for another fifteen minutes." He actually took out his watch and set it on the table to keep track of the time."But what is the point of continuing," I asked, "when you are probably preparing a harsh contradiction, or forging new emotional bonds to restrict your heart?""Do not imagine such difficult things. Picture me yielding and softening, as I am now: human affection rising like a newly discovered spring in my mind and sweetly flooding the entire area I have so carefully and diligently prepared—so devotedly sown with the seeds of good intentions and self-sacrificing plans. And now it is saturated with a delightful flow, drowning the young growth, a lovely poison corrupting them: now I see myself reclined on an ottoman in the drawing-room at Vale Hall at the feet of my bride, Rosamond Oliver: she is speaking to me in her sweet voice, looking down at me with those eyes your skilled hand has depicted so accurately, smiling at me with those coral lips. She is mine—I am hers—this current existence and fleeting world are enough for me. Quiet! Say nothing—my heart is overflowing with joy—my senses are enchanted—let the time I have set pass in peace."I indulged him; the watch continued to tick; he breathed quickly and softly; I stood silently. Amidst this quiet, the fifteen minutes passed quickly; he replaced the watch, put the picture down, rose, and stood by the fireplace."Now," he said, "that brief interval was given over to fantasy and self-deception. I rested my head on the breast of temptation, and willingly placed my neck under its beautiful but confining yoke; I tasted its pleasure. The comfort felt scorching; there is a hidden danger within the attraction; the delight has a bitter taste; her promises are empty—her offers false: I see and understand all of this."I stared at him in astonishment."It is strange," he continued, "that while I love Rosamond Oliver so intensely—indeed, with all the passion of a first love for someone incredibly beautiful, graceful, and captivating—I simultaneously possess a calm, clear awareness that she would not make me a suitable wife; that she is not the partner meant for me; that I would realise this within a year after marrying; and that twelve months of rapture would be followed by a lifetime of regret. I know this.""Truly strange!" I could not help exclaiming."While one part of me," he went on, "is acutely sensitive to her charms, another part is just as deeply aware of her flaws: they are such that she could not sympathise with anything I aspired to, nor cooperate in anything I undertook. Rosamond enduring suffering, working hard, being a female missionary? Rosamond as a missionary’s wife? Impossible!""But you are not required to be a missionary. You could abandon that project.""Abandon! What! My calling? My crucial work? My foundation laid on earth for a dwelling in heaven? My hopes of being counted among those who have merged all personal ambitions into the glorious one of improving their fellow humans—of bringing knowledge to regions of ignorance—of replacing conflict with peace—slavery with freedom—superstition with religion—the hope of heaven with the fear of hell? Must I give that up? It is more precious than the blood that runs through my veins. It is what I anticipate, and what I live for."After a considerable pause, I said, "And Miss Oliver? Are her disappointment and sorrow of no importance to you?""Miss Oliver is constantly surrounded by admirers and flatterers: in less than a month, my image will be erased from her heart. She will forget me, and will likely marry someone who will make her much happier than I ever could.""You speak quite calmly; but you are suffering in this struggle. You are looking quite thin.""No. If I am a little thinner, it is from anxiety about my future plans, which are still unsettled—my departure, which is continually put off. Just this morning, I received news that the person meant to replace me, whose arrival I have been expecting for so long, will not be ready to take my place for another three months; and perhaps those three months might extend to six.""You tremble and your face flushes whenever Miss Oliver enters the schoolroom."Again, the look of surprise appeared on his face. He had not imagined that a woman would dare to speak so directly to a man. As for me, I felt entirely comfortable in this kind of conversation. With intelligent, sensible, and refined individuals, male or female, I could never feel truly connected until I had broken through the barriers of conventional reserve, crossed the threshold of confidence, and secured a place close to their innermost selves."You are unique," he said, "and not timid. There is a bravery in your spirit, as well as keenness in your gaze; but allow me to assure you that you are partly misinterpreting my feelings. You believe them to be more profound and powerful than they are. You attribute more sympathy to me than I rightly deserve. When I flush and when I tremble before Miss Oliver, I do not feel pity for myself. I despise that weakness. I know it is ignoble: merely a physical reaction, not, I declare, a disturbance of the soul. My soul is as steadfast as a rock, firmly rooted in the depths of a restless sea. Understand me for what I am—a cold, hard man."I smiled disbelievingly."You have taken my confidence by storm," he continued, "and now you have it at your disposal. I am simply, in my true nature—stripped of the purifying influence with which Christianity covers human imperfection—a cold, hard, ambitious man. Only natural affection, of all the emotions, has lasting power over me. Reason, and not emotion, is my guide; my ambition is boundless; my desire to achieve more, to do greater things than others, is insatiable. I value endurance, perseverance, diligence, and talent, because these are the means by which people achieve great results and reach high positions. I observe your progress with interest because I consider you an example of a hardworking, disciplined, and energetic woman: not because I feel deep compassion for what you have experienced, or what you are still enduring.""You would describe yourself as simply a pagan philosopher," I said."No. There is this distinction between me and deistic philosophers: I believe, and I believe the Gospel. You missed the correct description. I am not a pagan, but a Christian philosopher—a follower of Jesus's teachings. As His disciple, I embrace His pure, merciful, benevolent doctrines. I champion them; I am dedicated to spreading them. Converted to religion in youth, it has cultivated my original qualities in this way: From the tiny seed of natural affection, it has grown the expansive tree of philanthropy. From the rough, fundamental core of human integrity, it has developed a proper awareness of Divine justice. The ambition to gain power and recognition for my insignificant self, it has transformed into the ambition to spread my Master’s kingdom, to achieve victories for the cause of the cross. This is the extent of religion's influence on me; making the best use of my inherent traits, refining and guiding my nature. But it could not eliminate nature itself, nor will it be eliminated 'until this mortal shall put on immortality.'"Having said this, he picked up his hat, which was on the table beside my painting palette. Once more, he looked at the portrait."She is lovely," he murmured. "She is truly well-named the Rose of the World!""And may I not paint one just like it for you?""To what end? No."He drew the thin sheet of paper I typically used to rest my hand on while painting, to keep the cardboard clean, over the picture. What he suddenly saw on this blank paper, it was impossible for me to determine; but something had caught his eye. He snatched it up; he examined the edge; then shot a glance at me that was incredibly peculiar and utterly baffling: a glance that seemed to quickly and sharply take note of every detail of my figure, face, and dress, as it scanned everything rapidly. His lips parted, as if to speak; but he stopped the words that were about to come out, whatever they were."What is the matter?" I asked."Nothing at all," was the reply; and, replacing the paper, I saw him skillfully tear a narrow strip from the edge. It disappeared into his glove, and with a quick nod and a "good-afternoon," he left. "Well!" I exclaimed, using a local expression, "that certainly takes the cake!"I, in turn, examined the paper carefully, but saw nothing on it except a few faint paint stains where I had tested colours for my brush. I thought about the mystery for a minute or two, but finding it impossible to solve and being certain it could not be very important, I dismissed it and soon forgot about it.

At this point, he had taken a seat and placed the portrait in front of him, resting his forehead in his hands as he gazed at it fondly. I noticed he was no longer upset or disturbed by my boldness. People who are reserved often crave open conversation about their feelings and troubles more than those who are naturally expressive. Even those who appear most stoic are human at heart, and bold, considerate conversation can provide them with invaluable comfort.

I told him, as I stood behind, that I was sure Miss Oliver liked him, that her father respected him, and she was a charming, if somewhat thoughtless, girl—but he would think enough for both of them, and so he should marry her. He expressed delight at this and even set his watch on the table, asking me to continue talking for another fifteen minutes. I questioned the point of continuing if he was just planning to rebuff my words or harden his own heart further.

He urged me not to suspect such harshness and asked me to imagine him softening, allowing himself to feel love—letting these feelings wash over everything he had carefully cultivated. He described imagining himself reclining at Vale Hall with Rosamond Oliver, his bride, at his side, fully content with this life. He wished for silence and to enjoy these feelings a while, and so I indulged him. Time passed quietly, until he got up and declared that he had allowed himself a brief fantasy, indulging in temptation. But he saw the dangers: the beauty hid pain, and the delight was fleeting and false. He realized this.

I was surprised. He explained that even though his feelings for Rosamond Oliver were strong and full of passion, he also clearly understood that she would not make him a suitable wife; her personality was such that she could not share or support his values and aspirations. He knew that after a brief period of happiness, long-term regret would follow.

I said this was strange, but he continued, acknowledging her attractions but also her incompatibility with his life. She could never be a sufferer, worker, or missionary’s wife.

I suggested he didn’t have to be a missionary, but he dismissed the idea, refusing to abandon his life’s purpose—his religious mission, which he valued above everything else, aiming to spread knowledge, peace, and faith.

After a pause, I asked if Miss Oliver’s heartbreak meant nothing to him. He replied that she was always surrounded by admirers and would soon move on, likely finding greater happiness with someone else.

I pointed out that he was clearly affected by the situation, but he claimed his worries were for his uncertain future, not love—delays in his plans weighed on him. When I mentioned his nervousness around Miss Oliver, he was startled that I would speak so directly, but I explained that I was comfortable discussing such things with people I respected.

He commented on my boldness and insight but insisted I misunderstood the depth of his emotions, claiming his affection was fleeting and his mind remained steadfast. He described himself as cold, hard, and led by reason rather than feeling, ambitious for achievement, and only truly moved by natural affection, not suffering.

I suggested he was like a pagan philosopher, but he corrected me, asserting that he was a Christian philosopher, motivated by faith and philanthropy. His religion had shaped his ambitions for a greater good beyond himself, but it had not and could not erase his true nature.

As he prepared to leave, he admired the portrait again, calling Rosamond the ‘Rose of the World.’ I offered to paint another picture for him, but he declined. While putting away the painting, he noticed something on a sheet of paper, examined it carefully with an intense look at me, but eventually dismissed it. I asked if anything was wrong, but he insisted there was not and, after tearing off a strip of the paper and hiding it, quickly took his leave. I checked the paper myself but found only paint stains, and after briefly wondering about the mystery, I decided it was unimportant and forgot about it.

events.title: St. John's Sudden Visit Amidst a Storm and Jane's Concern
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jane, is alone in her dwelling during a fierce snowstorm, finding solace in reading poetry.
St. John Rivers makes an entirely unexpected entrance, his figure cloaked and white with snow, resembling a glacier, startling Jane.
Jane, alarmed by his sudden appearance in such weather, immediately questions if he brings bad news or if something unfortunate has occurred.

St. John reassures her, remarking on her easy alarm, and explains his visit is motivated by a desire for conversation, as he grew weary of his solitude and was intrigued by a "half-told tale" he was eager to hear completed.
He mentions the difficulty of his journey through the deep snowdrifts.
Jane, unable to hide her surprise, directly asks him the reason for his visit.
St. John acknowledges her question might seem inhospitable but reiterates his need for company and his curiosity.

Observing St. John, Jane notes his strikingly handsome face, now appearing as still and defined as chiseled marble, and discerns a hollowness that suggests underlying care or sorrow, evoking her pity.
She expresses a wish that his sisters, Diana or Mary, could live with him, voicing concern for his solitude and his seemingly reckless disregard for his own health.
St. John dismisses her solicitude with an air of abstracted indifference, asserting that he takes care of himself when necessary and is currently well, effectively silencing Jane's concerns.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When Mr. St. John went, it was beginning to snow; the whirling storm continued all night.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I was silenced.

events.text_segment:
When Mr. St. John went, it was beginning to snow; the whirling storm continued all night. The next day a keen wind brought fresh and blinding falls; by twilight the valley was drifted up and almost impassable. I had closed my shutter, laid a mat to the door to prevent the snow from blowing in under it, trimmed my fire, and after sitting nearly an hour on the hearth listening to the muffled fury of the tempest, I lit a candle, took down “Marmion,” and beginning—
“Day set on Norham’s castled steep,
And Tweed’s fair river broad and deep,
    And Cheviot’s mountains lone;
The massive towers, the donjon keep,
The flanking walls that round them sweep,
    In yellow lustre shone”—
I soon forgot storm in music.
I heard a noise: the wind, I thought, shook the door. No; it was St. John Rivers, who, lifting the latch, came in out of the frozen hurricane—the howling darkness—and stood before me: the cloak that covered his tall figure all white as a glacier. I was almost in consternation, so little had I expected any guest from the blocked-up vale that night.
“Any ill news?” I demanded. “Has anything happened?”
“No. How very easily alarmed you are!” he answered, removing his cloak and hanging it up against the door, towards which he again coolly pushed the mat which his entrance had deranged. He stamped the snow from his boots.
“I shall sully the purity of your floor,” said he, “but you must excuse me for once.” Then he approached the fire. “I have had hard work to get here, I assure you,” he observed, as he warmed his hands over the flame. “One drift took me up to the waist; happily the snow is quite soft yet.”
“But why are you come?” I could not forbear saying.
“Rather an inhospitable question to put to a visitor; but since you ask it, I answer simply to have a little talk with you; I got tired of my mute books and empty rooms. Besides, since yesterday I have experienced the excitement of a person to whom a tale has been half-told, and who is impatient to hear the sequel.”
He sat down. I recalled his singular conduct of yesterday, and really I began to fear his wits were touched. If he were insane, however, his was a very cool and collected insanity: I had never seen that handsome-featured face of his look more like chiselled marble than it did just now, as he put aside his snow-wet hair from his forehead and let the firelight shine free on his pale brow and cheek as pale, where it grieved me to discover the hollow trace of care or sorrow now so plainly graved. I waited, expecting he would say something I could at least comprehend; but his hand was now at his chin, his finger on his lip: he was thinking. It struck me that his hand looked wasted like his face. A perhaps uncalled-for gush of pity came over my heart: I was moved to say—
“I wish Diana or Mary would come and live with you: it is too bad that you should be quite alone; and you are recklessly rash about your own health.”
“Not at all,” said he: “I care for myself when necessary. I am well now. What do you see amiss in me?”
This was said with a careless, abstracted indifference, which showed that my solicitude was, at least in his opinion, wholly superfluous. I was silenced.

The following day, a sharp wind brought heavy, blinding snowfalls; by dusk, the valley was completely drifted over and nearly impassable. I had closed my shutters, put a mat at the door to stop snow from blowing underneath, built up my fire, and after sitting by the hearth for almost an hour listening to the muffled roar of the tempest, I lit a candle, took down “Marmion,” and as I started reading the opening lines about a castle, I soon forgot the storm in the music of the poetry. I heard a sound; I thought it was the wind shaking the door. No; it was St. John Rivers, who lifted the latch and came in out of the freezing blizzard—the dark, howling wind—and stood before me. The cloak covering his tall frame was entirely white like a glacier. I was almost shocked, as I had so little expected any guest from the snowbound valley that night. “Any bad news?” I asked. “Has something happened?” “No. You are easily startled!” he replied, taking off his cloak and hanging it by the door, towards which he calmly pushed the mat back into place after his entry had displaced it. He stamped the snow off his boots. “I’m going to mark your clean floor,” he said, “but you must excuse me this one time.” He then approached the fire. “It was hard work getting here, I assure you,” he remarked, warming his hands over the flames. “One drift came up to my waist; thankfully, the snow is still quite soft.” “But why did you come?” I couldn’t help but ask. “Rather an unwelcoming question to ask a visitor; but since you ask, I simply came to have a little conversation with you. I got tired of my silent books and empty rooms. Besides, since yesterday, I’ve had the feeling of someone to whom a story has been only half-told, and who is eager to hear the rest.” He sat down. I remembered his peculiar behavior the previous day, and I began to worry that he might be losing his mind. However, if he was mad, his was a very controlled and calm form of madness. I had never seen his handsome face look more like sculpted marble than it did just then, as he pushed his snow-damp hair off his forehead and let the firelight shine on his pale brow and equally pale cheek, where I was saddened to notice the deep imprint of worry or sorrow now clearly etched. I waited, expecting him to say something I could at least understand, but his hand was on his chin, his finger on his lip; he was thinking. It struck me that his hand looked as thin as his face. A perhaps unasked-for wave of pity came over me, moving me to say, “I wish Diana or Mary would come and live with you. It’s too bad you have to be completely alone, and you are dangerously careless about your own health.” “Not at all,” he said. “I take care of myself when necessary. I am well now. What fault do you see in me?” He said this with a distant, indifferent air that showed my concern was, in his opinion at least, entirely unnecessary. I was silenced.

The following day was also bitterly cold, with strong winds causing more heavy and blinding snowfalls. By dusk, the valley was so filled with snowdrifts that it was nearly impossible to travel. I shut the shutters, placed a mat by the door to keep out the snow, tended to the fire, and, after spending almost an hour by the hearth listening to the muffled rage of the storm, I lit a candle and took down a copy of "Marmion." As I read its vivid verses, I soon became absorbed and forgot about the storm outside. Suddenly, I heard a sound, thinking it was the wind rattling the door, but it was actually St. John Rivers entering from the blizzard, nearly white from the snow. His unexpected arrival startled me, since travel seemed impossible that night. I immediately asked if anything was wrong, but he reassured me that all was well and teased me for being so easily alarmed. He hung up his snowy cloak, brushed his boots, and apologized for the mess. Warming himself by the fire, he remarked how difficult his journey had been, with one snowdrift reaching his waist, though the snow was still soft. I couldn't help but ask why he had come. He replied that although my question was not very welcoming, he simply wanted some company after getting bored with his books and empty rooms, and also felt restless after hearing only half of a story the previous day. The firelight revealed the signs of care or worry on his pale face, making me feel sorry for him. I wished aloud that his sisters would come live with him, since solitude and recklessness were taking a toll on his health. He simply replied that he took care of himself when needed and asked what seemed wrong with him, in a manner that made it clear he thought my concern was unnecessary, and I said nothing more.

events.title: An Awkward and Unsuccessful Attempt at Conversation
detailed_summary: St. John remains engrossed in his thoughts, his finger slowly tracing his lip and his gaze fixed on the fire, prompting Jane to try and break the silence.
Jane tentatively asks if he feels a cold draft from the door behind him, a question he answers with a short and somewhat irritable negative.
Feeling rebuffed, Jane mentally resolves to let him be and return to her reading if he remains unwilling to converse.
She resumes reading "Marmion," but her attention is soon drawn to St. John, who takes out a pocket-book and reads a letter in silence before relapsing into meditation.
Jane finds it impossible to concentrate on her book with the inscrutable St. John before her and, impatient with the silence, decides she must speak.
She inquires if he has recently heard from Diana and Mary, to which he replies negatively since the last letter he showed her.

She then asks about any changes to his travel plans, specifically if he might be leaving England sooner than expected; he responds with a somewhat pessimistic remark about such good fortune being unlikely for him.
Changing tactics, Jane talks about her school, mentioning a student's mother recovering and new pupils expected, partly funded by Mr. Oliver.
St. John's responses to these updates are notably brief and lacking in engagement, consisting of single words or short phrases like "Indeed!", "Does he?", and "I know."
When Jane inquires about the school's Christmas treat, St. John reveals it was his daughter Rosamond Oliver's idea, not his own.
The conversation once again lapses into a significant pause, broken only by the clock striking eight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He still slowly moved his finger over his upper lip, and still his eye dwelt dreamily on the glowing grate; thinking it urgent to say something, I asked him presently if he felt any cold draught from the door, which was behind him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Again came the blank of a pause: the clock struck eight strokes.

events.text_segment:
He still slowly moved his finger over his upper lip, and still his eye dwelt dreamily on the glowing grate; thinking it urgent to say something, I asked him presently if he felt any cold draught from the door, which was behind him.
“No, no!” he responded shortly and somewhat testily.
“Well,” I reflected, “if you won’t talk, you may be still; I’ll let you alone now, and return to my book.”
So I snuffed the candle and resumed the perusal of “Marmion.” He soon stirred; my eye was instantly drawn to his movements; he only took out a morocco pocket-book, thence produced a letter, which he read in silence, folded it, put it back, relapsed into meditation. It was vain to try to read with such an inscrutable fixture before me; nor could I, in impatience, consent to be dumb; he might rebuff me if he liked, but talk I would.
“Have you heard from Diana and Mary lately?”
“Not since the letter I showed you a week ago.”
“There has not been any change made about your own arrangements? You will not be summoned to leave England sooner than you expected?”
“I fear not, indeed: such chance is too good to befall me.” Baffled so far, I changed my ground. I bethought myself to talk about the school and my scholars.
“Mary Garrett’s mother is better, and Mary came back to the school this morning, and I shall have four new girls next week from the Foundry Close—they would have come to-day but for the snow.”
“Indeed!”
“Mr. Oliver pays for two.”
“Does he?”
“He means to give the whole school a treat at Christmas.”
“I know.”
“Was it your suggestion?”
“No.”
“Whose, then?”
“His daughter’s, I think.”
“It is like her: she is so good-natured.”
“Yes.”
Again came the blank of a pause: the clock struck eight strokes.
