Feeling compelled to break the silence, I soon asked him if he felt any cold air current coming from the door situated behind him. "No, no!" he responded curtly and somewhat annoyed. "Alright," I decided, "if you prefer silence, you can remain so; I will leave you undisturbed now and return to my book." Consequently, I trimmed the candle wick and resumed reading "Marmion." He stirred after a short while; my attention was immediately drawn to his movements. He simply pulled out a small leather pocket-book, extracted a letter from it, read it silently, folded it, replaced it, and sank back into thought. It was useless trying to read with such an unreadable, fixed figure before me; nor could I, in my impatience, agree to stay quiet. He could dismiss my attempts if he wished, but I intended to speak. "Have you received any recent news from Diana and Mary?" "Not since the letter I showed you a week ago." "There haven't been any changes to your personal plans? You won't be called upon to leave England earlier than you anticipated?" "I fear not, unfortunately; such a fortunate turn of events is too good to happen to me." Defeated on that topic, I shifted the conversation. I thought it best to talk about the school and my students. "Mary Garrett's mother is recovering, and Mary returned to school this morning. Also, I will have four new girls joining next week from the Foundry Close – they would have come today except for the snow." "Indeed!" "Mr. Oliver is paying for two of them." "Is he?" "He plans to give the entire school a treat at Christmas." "I know." "Was that your idea?" "No." "Whose was it, then?" "His daughter's, I think." "That is typical of her; she is so kind-hearted." "Yes." The emptiness of silence returned again. The clock chimed eight times.

events.title: St. John Narrates the Hidden History of the Lost Governess
detailed_summary: The sound of the clock striking eight seems to stir St. John from his reverie; he straightens up and asks Jane to put aside her book and move closer to the fire.
He announces a shift in roles, stating that instead of him being the listener for the sequel to a tale, he will now become the narrator, and she the listener.
He forewarns her that the story might sound clichéd, but suggests that familiar details can gain new freshness from a new teller, and assures her it will be short.
St. John begins his narrative, set twenty years prior, about a poor clergyman who fell in love with and married a wealthy man's daughter against her friends' advice, leading to her disownment.
He recounts that within two years, both the clergyman and his wife died, leaving behind an infant daughter.
This orphaned child, received by "Charity" as cold as the snowdrift he recently encountered, was taken to her affluent maternal relatives and raised by an aunt-in-law, Mrs. Reed of Gateshead.
Jane visibly reacts to the name, and St. John momentarily pauses, attributing any noise to rats in the adjoining schoolroom, a converted barn.
He continues, stating Mrs. Reed kept the orphan for ten years before transferring her to Lowood School, a place Jane knows well.
St. John notes the orphan's honorable career at Lowood, progressing from pupil to teacher, and observes striking parallels between her history and Jane's own experiences.
He describes how the orphan then left Lowood to become a governess, undertaking the education of Mr. Rochester's ward, at which point Jane interrupts, exclaiming Mr. Rivers's name.

St. John urges her to remain calm, explaining he is nearing the end of his account. He professes ignorance of Mr. Rochester's character beyond the fact that he offered marriage to the young governess, only for her to discover at the altar that he already had a living, albeit lunatic, wife.
He states that the governess's actions following this revelation are unknown, but she subsequently vanished from Thornfield Hall without a trace, despite extensive searches.

He concludes by revealing that finding this governess has become a matter of serious urgency, with advertisements placed in newspapers, and that he himself received a letter from a solicitor, Mr. Briggs, detailing these circumstances, then asks if it isn't an odd tale.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It aroused him; he uncrossed his legs, sat erect, turned to me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Is it not an odd tale?”

events.text_segment:
It aroused him; he uncrossed his legs, sat erect, turned to me.
“Leave your book a moment, and come a little nearer the fire,” he said.
Wondering, and of my wonder finding no end, I complied.
“Half-an-hour ago,” he pursued, “I spoke of my impatience to hear the sequel of a tale: on reflection, I find the matter will be better managed by my assuming the narrator’s part, and converting you into a listener. Before commencing, it is but fair to warn you that the story will sound somewhat hackneyed in your ears; but stale details often regain a degree of freshness when they pass through new lips. For the rest, whether trite or novel, it is short.
“Twenty years ago, a poor curate—never mind his name at this moment—fell in love with a rich man’s daughter; she fell in love with him, and married him, against the advice of all her friends, who consequently disowned her immediately after the wedding. Before two years passed, the rash pair were both dead, and laid quietly side by side under one slab. (I have seen their grave; it formed part of the pavement of a huge churchyard surrounding the grim, soot-black old cathedral of an overgrown manufacturing town in ——shire.) They left a daughter, which, at its very birth, Charity received in her lap—cold as that of the snow-drift I almost stuck fast in to-night. Charity carried the friendless thing to the house of its rich maternal relations; it was reared by an aunt-in-law, called (I come to names now) Mrs. Reed of Gateshead. You start—did you hear a noise? I daresay it is only a rat scrambling along the rafters of the adjoining schoolroom: it was a barn before I had it repaired and altered, and barns are generally haunted by rats.—To proceed. Mrs. Reed kept the orphan ten years: whether it was happy or not with her, I cannot say, never having been told; but at the end of that time she transferred it to a place you know—being no other than Lowood School, where you so long resided yourself. It seems her career there was very honourable: from a pupil, she became a teacher, like yourself—really it strikes me there are parallel points in her history and yours—she left it to be a governess: there, again, your fates were analogous; she undertook the education of the ward of a certain Mr. Rochester.”
“Mr. Rivers!” I interrupted.
“I can guess your feelings,” he said, “but restrain them for a while: I have nearly finished; hear me to the end. Of Mr. Rochester’s character I know nothing, but the one fact that he professed to offer honourable marriage to this young girl, and that at the very altar she discovered he had a wife yet alive, though a lunatic. What his subsequent conduct and proposals were is a matter of pure conjecture; but when an event transpired which rendered inquiry after the governess necessary, it was discovered she was gone—no one could tell when, where, or how. She had left Thornfield Hall in the night; every research after her course had been vain: the country had been scoured far and wide; no vestige of information could be gathered respecting her. Yet that she should be found is become a matter of serious urgency: advertisements have been put in all the papers; I myself have received a letter from one Mr. Briggs, a solicitor, communicating the details I have just imparted. Is it not an odd tale?”

After that, I don’t know what happened between them. But when an event made it necessary to look for the governess, it turned out she had vanished—no one knew when, how, or where she had gone. She left Thornfield Hall one night, and all searches for her were fruitless; nobody could find any trace. Yet her discovery has become very important: advertisements have been posted everywhere, and I even received a letter from a solicitor, Mr. Briggs, sharing these details. Isn’t it a strange story?”

events.title: Jane's Identity Confirmed and an Astounding Inheritance Revealed
detailed_summary: Jane urgently presses St. John for information about Mr. Rochester's condition and whereabouts, believing St. John must know more.

St. John claims complete ignorance regarding Mr. Rochester, stating the solicitor's letter only mentioned the attempted fraudulent marriage, and shifts focus to the governess's identity and the reason she is sought.
Jane inquires if anyone visited Thornfield Hall or saw Mr. Rochester; St. John supposes not, but confirms letters were sent.
She learns that the reply to Mr. Briggs's inquiry came not from Mr. Rochester but from Alice Fairfax, which plunges Jane into dismay, fearing the worst for her former master.
As Jane expresses her distress and warm defense of Mr. Rochester against St. John's implied criticism, St. John calmly states his mind is on finishing his tale.
He declares that since Jane won't ask the governess's name, he will provide it, taking out his pocket-book again.
From the pocket-book, he extracts a worn slip of paper, which Jane instantly recognizes from its texture and stains as the torn margin of her own portrait-cover.
St. John holds the paper for her to see, and she reads, in her own handwriting, the name "JANE EYRE."

He explains that Mr. Briggs wrote to him about a Jane Eyre, the advertisements sought a Jane Eyre, and though he knew a Jane Elliott, his suspicions about her true identity were confirmed only the previous day.
Jane affirms her name and renounces her alias, then immediately asks about Mr. Briggs and any knowledge he might have of Mr. Rochester.
St. John states Briggs is in London and likely uninterested in Rochester, then admonishes Jane for focusing on trifles and not inquiring why Briggs sought her.
He then delivers the crucial news: Mr. Briggs merely wanted to inform her that her uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, has died and left her his entire property, making her a wealthy woman.
Jane is utterly stunned by the revelation that she is rich.
St. John explains she must prove her identity to take possession of her fortune, which is invested in English funds and documented by Briggs.

Jane internally processes the immense change from indigence to wealth, acknowledging it as a fine but sobering reality, not a thrilling, idealistic one, and reflects on the concurrent news of her uncle's death—her only known relative, whom she had hoped to meet.
She feels the isolation of this fortune coming to her alone, without family to share the joy, though acknowledges independence will be glorious.
St. John observes her reaction, then prods her to ask about the amount of her inheritance.
When Jane asks, St. John casually reveals the sum: twenty thousand pounds.
Jane is again thunderstruck, having anticipated a much smaller amount, and the news momentarily takes her breath away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Just tell me this,” said I, “and since you know so much, you surely can tell it me—what of Mr. Rochester?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Twenty thousand pounds?”

events.text_segment:
“Just tell me this,” said I, “and since you know so much, you surely can tell it me—what of Mr. Rochester? How and where is he? What is he doing? Is he well?”
“I am ignorant of all concerning Mr. Rochester: the letter never mentions him but to narrate the fraudulent and illegal attempt I have adverted to. You should rather ask the name of the governess—the nature of the event which requires her appearance.”
“Did no one go to Thornfield Hall, then? Did no one see Mr. Rochester?”
“I suppose not.”
“But they wrote to him?”
“Of course.”
“And what did he say? Who has his letters?”
“Mr. Briggs intimates that the answer to his application was not from Mr. Rochester, but from a lady: it is signed ‘Alice Fairfax.’”
I felt cold and dismayed: my worst fears then were probably true: he had in all probability left England and rushed in reckless desperation to some former haunt on the Continent. And what opiate for his severe sufferings—what object for his strong passions—had he sought there? I dared not answer the question. Oh, my poor master—once almost my husband—whom I had often called “my dear Edward!”
“He must have been a bad man,” observed Mr. Rivers.
“You don’t know him—don’t pronounce an opinion upon him,” I said, with warmth.
“Very well,” he answered quietly: “and indeed my head is otherwise occupied than with him: I have my tale to finish. Since you won’t ask the governess’s name, I must tell it of my own accord. Stay! I have it here—it is always more satisfactory to see important points written down, fairly committed to black and white.”
And the pocket-book was again deliberately produced, opened, sought through; from one of its compartments was extracted a shabby slip of paper, hastily torn off: I recognised in its texture and its stains of ultra-marine, and lake, and vermillion, the ravished margin of the portrait-cover. He got up, held it close to my eyes: and I read, traced in Indian ink, in my own handwriting, the words “JANE EYRE”—the work doubtless of some moment of abstraction.
“Briggs wrote to me of a Jane Eyre:” he said, “the advertisements demanded a Jane Eyre: I knew a Jane Elliott.—I confess I had my suspicions, but it was only yesterday afternoon they were at once resolved into certainty. You own the name and renounce the alias?”
“Yes—yes; but where is Mr. Briggs? He perhaps knows more of Mr. Rochester than you do.”
“Briggs is in London. I should doubt his knowing anything at all about Mr. Rochester; it is not in Mr. Rochester he is interested. Meantime, you forget essential points in pursuing trifles: you do not inquire why Mr. Briggs sought after you—what he wanted with you.”
“Well, what did he want?”
“Merely to tell you that your uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that he has left you all his property, and that you are now rich—merely that—nothing more.”
“I!—rich?”
“Yes, you, rich—quite an heiress.”
Silence succeeded.
“You must prove your identity of course,” resumed St. John presently: “a step which will offer no difficulties; you can then enter on immediate possession. Your fortune is vested in the English funds; Briggs has the will and the necessary documents.”
Here was a new card turned up! It is a fine thing, reader, to be lifted in a moment from indigence to wealth—a very fine thing; but not a matter one can comprehend, or consequently enjoy, all at once. And then there are other chances in life far more thrilling and rapture-giving: this is solid, an affair of the actual world, nothing ideal about it: all its associations are solid and sober, and its manifestations are the same. One does not jump, and spring, and shout hurrah! at hearing one has got a fortune; one begins to consider responsibilities, and to ponder business; on a base of steady satisfaction rise certain grave cares, and we contain ourselves, and brood over our bliss with a solemn brow.
Besides, the words Legacy, Bequest, go side by side with the words, Death, Funeral. My uncle I had heard was dead—my only relative; ever since being made aware of his existence, I had cherished the hope of one day seeing him: now, I never should. And then this money came only to me: not to me and a rejoicing family, but to my isolated self. It was a grand boon doubtless; and independence would be glorious—yes, I felt that—that thought swelled my heart.
“You unbend your forehead at last,” said Mr. Rivers. “I thought Medusa had looked at you, and that you were turning to stone. Perhaps now you will ask how much you are worth?”
“How much am I worth?”
“Oh, a trifle! Nothing of course to speak of—twenty thousand pounds, I think they say—but what is that?”
“Twenty thousand pounds?”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
“Tell me this, please,” I insisted, “and since you’re so well-informed, you must surely know – what has become of Mr. Rochester? How is he, and where is he? What is he doing? Is he healthy?”
“I am completely unaware of anything regarding Mr. Rochester,” he responded. “The letter never mentions him except to describe the deceitful and unlawful attempt I referred to. You should rather inquire about the name of the governess – the reason the situation requires her presence.”
“So, did no one visit Thornfield Hall, then? Did no one see Mr. Rochester?”
“I presume not.”
“But they did correspond with him?”
“Naturally.”
“And what was his response? Who possesses his letters?”
“Mr. Briggs indicates that the reply to his communication was not from Mr. Rochester, but from a woman; it’s signed ‘Alice Fairfax.’”
A chill went through me, and I felt disheartened; my worst anxieties were likely true. He had most likely left England and rushed in desperate abandon to some former retreat on the Continent. And what solace for his profound suffering – what aim for his intense passions – had he pursued there? I did not dare to consider the answer. Oh, my poor master – who was once nearly my husband – whom I had so often affectionately called “my dear Edward!”
“He must have been a wicked individual,” Mr. Rivers remarked.
“You don’t know him – don’t make a judgment about him,” I said, with feeling.
“Very well,” he answered calmly; “and truly my thoughts are occupied with other matters than him. I have my story to conclude. Since you won’t ask for the governess’s name, I must provide it myself. Wait! I have it right here – it’s always more reassuring to see crucial information in writing, clearly put down in black and white.”
And the pocket-book was deliberately produced again, opened, and searched through; from one of its sections, he extracted a small, worn piece of paper, hastily torn off. I recognized its texture and the smudges of ultramarine, lake, and vermillion as coming from the ruined edge of the portrait cover. He stood up, held it close to my eyes, and I read, inscribed in Indian ink, in my own hand, the words “JANE EYRE” – likely the result of some moment of absent-mindedness.
“Briggs wrote to me concerning a Jane Eyre,” he said. “The advertisements sought a Jane Eyre. I knew a Jane Elliott. I admit I had my suspicions, but only yesterday afternoon were they definitively confirmed. Do you acknowledge this name and abandon the pretense?”
“Yes – yes; but where is Mr. Briggs? He might know more about Mr. Rochester than you do.”
“Briggs is in London. I doubt he knows anything whatsoever about Mr. Rochester; his interest is not in Mr. Rochester. Meanwhile, you are neglecting essential matters by focusing on trivial details: you are not inquiring why Mr. Briggs was searching for you – what he needed you for.”
“Well, what did he want?”
“Merely to inform you that your uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, is deceased; that he has left you all his assets, and that you are now wealthy – simply that – nothing further.”
“I! – wealthy?”
“Yes, you, wealthy – quite an heiress.”
A period of silence ensued.
“You must provide proof of your identity, of course,” St. John resumed presently; “a step which will present no difficulties; you can then take immediate control. Your fortune is invested in government securities; Briggs possesses the will and the necessary documents.”
Here was a completely unexpected development! It is a significant event, dear reader, to be instantly raised from poverty to riches – a very important thing; but not something one can fully grasp, or consequently, instantly relish. And then there are other experiences in life far more emotionally stirring and joy-inducing; this is concrete, a matter of the practical world, devoid of any idealistic qualities. All its connections are solid and sober, and its effects are the same. One does not leap, and bound, and cheer 'hurrah!' upon hearing they have acquired a fortune; one begins to consider responsibilities, and to ponder financial affairs; upon a foundation of steady satisfaction arise certain serious concerns, and we maintain our composure, and contemplate our good fortune with a serious expression.
Besides, the terms Legacy, Bequest, are associated with Death, Funeral. I had heard my uncle was dead – my only relative; ever since I became aware of his existence, I had held onto the hope of meeting him one day; now, I never would. And then this money came solely to me: not to me and a rejoicing family, but to my solitary self. It was undoubtedly a great blessing; and independence would be glorious – yes, I felt that – that thought expanded my heart.
“You are finally relaxing your brow,” Mr. Rivers observed. “I thought Medusa had looked upon you, and that you were turning to stone. Perhaps now you will ask how much your worth is?”
“How much am I worth?”
“Oh, a trivial amount! Nothing significant, of course – twenty thousand pounds, I believe they state – but what does that matter?”
“Twenty thousand pounds?”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"Just tell me this," I asked, "and given all you know, surely you can—what about Mr. Rochester? Where is he, what is he doing, is he well?" 
"I know nothing about Mr. Rochester. The letter only refers to him as part of describing the false and illegal action I already mentioned. Instead, you should be asking about the governess and why she needs to appear."
"So no one went to Thornfield Hall? No one saw Mr. Rochester?"
"I assume not."
"But they wrote to him?"
"Yes."
"And what did he reply? Where are his letters?"
"Mr. Briggs says that the response wasn’t from Mr. Rochester himself, but from a woman—it’s signed ‘Alice Fairfax.’"
I was struck by a chill and fear; it seemed my worst suspicions were likely true—that Mr. Rochester had probably left England and, in desperation, gone back to old haunts on the continent. What did he seek there to help his suffering or occupy his passionate nature? I didn’t dare guess. My poor master—almost my husband—whom I’d often called my dear Edward!

"He must have been a bad man," Mr. Rivers said.
"You don’t know him, so don’t judge him," I replied passionately.
"All right," he said calmly, "I have other things on my mind, anyway. Since you won’t ask who the governess is, I’ll tell you myself. Wait—I have it here. It’s always better to see such things written down."
He took out his pocketbook, opened it, searched through it, and pulled out a torn, shabby slip of paper. I recognized the stained, paint-marked edge as from the margin of the cover of my old portrait. He stood up, held it to my eyes, and I read, written in Indian ink in my own handwriting—“JANE EYRE”—clearly scrawled absentmindedly at some earlier time.

"Briggs wrote to me about a Jane Eyre," he said, "and the advertisements were for a Jane Eyre. I knew you as Jane Elliott. I suspected, but only confirmed it fully yesterday afternoon. Will you admit the name and give up your alias?"
"Yes, yes; but where is Mr. Briggs? Maybe he knows more about Mr. Rochester than you do."
"Briggs is in London, but I doubt he knows anything about Mr. Rochester—he isn't interested in him anyway. Meanwhile, you’re focusing on irrelevant things instead of the essentials: you haven’t asked why Mr. Briggs was looking for you—what he wanted from you."
"So what did he want?"
"Simply to tell you your uncle, Mr. Eyre from Madeira, has died and left you all his wealth. You are now rich—just that, nothing more."
"Me—rich?"
"Yes, you are now quite an heiress."
Silence fell for a moment.
"Of course, you’ll need to prove who you are," St. John continued, "but that won’t be hard. Then you’ll be able to claim your inheritance immediately. The money is in English funds, with Briggs holding the will and the paperwork."

This was quite a shock! It is quite something, reader, to be suddenly raised from poverty to wealth, a remarkable thing indeed—but not one you can take in or really enjoy all of a sudden. Besides, there are other moments in life that are far more exciting—this is all very literal, grounded, and practical, leaving no room for fantasy. You don’t start jumping for joy on hearing you’ve inherited a fortune; instead, you start thinking of your new responsibilities; your steady satisfaction is accompanied by weighty concerns, so you stay composed and reflect on your good fortune solemnly.

Moreover, words like ‘legacy’ and ‘bequest’ go hand in hand with ‘death’ and ‘funeral.’ My only relative, my uncle, was dead. Ever since I’d learned he existed, I’d hoped to meet him—and now I never would. And the money came to just me—not to me and a loving family, but to my solitary self. It was a magnificent gift, no doubt; independence would be glorious, and my heart swelled with the thought.

"You’re finally relaxing," said Mr. Rivers. "I thought you’d turned to stone, like you’d seen Medusa. Maybe now you’ll ask how much you’ve inherited?"
"How much do I have?"
"Oh, it’s only a trifle. Nothing too significant—twenty thousand pounds, I believe—but what is that?"
"Twenty thousand pounds?"

events.title: The Weight of Wealth and Jane's Lingering Questions for St. John
detailed_summary: Jane, still reeling from the news of her twenty-thousand-pound inheritance, feels like someone with average appetite facing a feast for a hundred.
St. John, witnessing her shock, remarks that she looks as aghast as if he'd told her a committed murder had been discovered.
Jane questions if there's a mistake in the large sum, but St. John confirms its accuracy, stating it was written in letters, not figures.
As St. John prepares to leave, noting the wildness of the night, he expresses a wish to send Hannah for company but deems it impossible due to the snow.
Just as St. John is about to depart, a sudden thought strikes Jane, and she stops him.
She expresses her puzzlement as to why Mr. Briggs would write to him about her, or how Briggs knew him or believed he could help, given St. John's remote location.
St. John offers a brief, somewhat evasive explanation, stating that clergymen are often consulted on unusual matters.
Jane declares his answer unsatisfactory, her curiosity further inflamed by his hasty and unrevealing reply.
She insists the business is very strange and that she must know more, but St. John attempts to defer the explanation to another time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here was a new stunner—I had been calculating on four or five thousand.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Another time.”

events.text_segment:
Here was a new stunner—I had been calculating on four or five thousand. This news actually took my breath for a moment: Mr. St. John, whom I had never heard laugh before, laughed now.
“Well,” said he, “if you had committed a murder, and I had told you your crime was discovered, you could scarcely look more aghast.”
“It is a large sum—don’t you think there is a mistake?”
“No mistake at all.”
“Perhaps you have read the figures wrong—it may be two thousand!”
“It is written in letters, not figures,—twenty thousand.”
I again felt rather like an individual of but average gastronomical powers sitting down to feast alone at a table spread with provisions for a hundred. Mr. Rivers rose now and put his cloak on.
“If it were not such a very wild night,” he said, “I would send Hannah down to keep you company: you look too desperately miserable to be left alone. But Hannah, poor woman! could not stride the drifts so well as I: her legs are not quite so long: so I must e’en leave you to your sorrows. Good-night.”
He was lifting the latch: a sudden thought occurred to me.
“Stop one minute!” I cried.
“Well?”
“It puzzles me to know why Mr. Briggs wrote to you about me; or how he knew you, or could fancy that you, living in such an out-of-the-way place, had the power to aid in my discovery.”
“Oh! I am a clergyman,” he said; “and the clergy are often appealed to about odd matters.” Again the latch rattled.
“No; that does not satisfy me!” I exclaimed: and indeed there was something in the hasty and unexplanatory reply which, instead of allaying, piqued my curiosity more than ever.
“It is a very strange piece of business,” I added; “I must know more about it.”
“Another time.”

"Well," he said, "if you had committed murder and I had just told you your crime was found out, you could hardly look more stunned." "It's a huge amount – don't you think there's a mistake?" I asked. "No mistake whatsoever," he replied. "Perhaps you've misread the numbers – maybe it's two thousand!" I suggested. "It's written in words, not digits," he corrected, "twenty thousand." I again felt somewhat like a person with a modest appetite sitting alone at a table laden with enough food for a hundred. Mr. Rivers now got up and put on his cloak. "If the night weren't so wild," he said, "I'd send Hannah down to keep you company; you look too terribly upset to be left alone. But poor Hannah couldn't navigate the snowdrifts as well as I; her legs aren't quite as long. So, I must indeed leave you to your troubles. Good night." He was reaching for the latch when a sudden thought struck me. "Wait just a minute!" I called out. "Yes?" he responded. "It perplexes me why Mr. Briggs wrote to you about me; or how he knew you, or could possibly imagine that you, living in such a secluded place, would be able to assist in finding me." Indeed, there was something in his quick and unelaborated reply that, rather than easing, heightened my curiosity more than ever. "This is a very peculiar situation," I added, "I need to know more about it." "Another time," he said.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
This revelation was completely shocking—I had expected the amount to be four or five thousand. The news literally left me speechless for a moment; Mr. St. John, who I had never known to laugh before, actually did so then. 

"Well," he said, "if I had told you your crime had been found out, you could hardly look more stunned, even if you’d just committed a murder."

"It’s such a large sum—are you sure there’s no error?"

"No error at all."

"Maybe you misread—it might be two thousand?"

"It is written out in words, not just numbers—twenty thousand."

Once again I felt as overwhelmed as someone of modest appetite faced with an enormous banquet meant for a hundred, yet expected to eat alone. Mr. Rivers stood up and put on his cloak.

"If it weren’t such a terrible night," he said, "I’d send Hannah to keep you company; you look wretched enough to need it. But poor Hannah couldn’t get through these snowdrifts as easily as I can, so you must face your troubles by yourself. Good night."

He was opening the door latch when a sudden idea came to me.

"Wait a moment!" I called out.

"Yes?"

"I don’t understand why Mr. Briggs wrote to you about me, or how he knew you—or why he thought you could help in finding me, considering how remote this place is."

"I am a clergyman," he replied; "and people often turn to the clergy about unusual matters." The latch rattled again as he prepared to leave.

"No; that doesn’t explain it!" I insisted, feeling that his abrupt reply only heightened my curiosity instead of easing it.

"This is a very odd situation," I added; "I really need to know more."

"Another time."

events.title: The Revelation of Family Ties: St. John Unveils Their Shared Ancestry
detailed_summary: Jane adamantly insists on receiving a full explanation from St. John immediately, physically blocking his exit.
She declares he will not leave until he has told her everything he knows.
St. John expresses a preference not to disclose the information just then, suggesting Diana or Mary would be better informants.
His reluctance only intensifies Jane's eagerness for the truth, and she makes her impatience clear.
St. John reminds her of his self-professed difficult nature, but Jane counters with her own determination, stating she is impossible to put off.
He further describes himself as cold and unsusceptible to fervor, to which Jane retorts that she is hot and fire can melt ice, using the melted snow from his cloak as an analogy.
She playfully demands he tell her what she wishes to know, as recompense for spoiling her clean floor.
St. John finally yields, attributing his concession to her perseverance if not her earnestness, and acknowledging she must know eventually.
After confirming her name is Jane Eyre, he asks if she is aware that he is her namesake, revealing his full name: St. John Eyre Rivers.
Jane is surprised, recalling seeing the initial 'E' in books he lent her but never inquiring about its meaning.
A profound realization begins to dawn on Jane as disparate facts rapidly connect in her mind, forming a clear picture of the situation even before St. John elaborates.
St. John explains that his mother's maiden name was Eyre and she had two brothers: one, a clergyman who married Miss Jane Reed (Jane's mother), and the other, John Eyre, the merchant of Madeira.

He recounts that Mr. Briggs, their Uncle John's solicitor, had informed his family of their uncle's death and his will, which left his property to his brother's orphaned daughter (Jane), overlooking the Rivers family due to an old quarrel between John Eyre and their father.
Briggs later wrote again when the heiress was lost, asking if the Rivers family knew anything of her, and a name casually written on a slip of paper (Jane's sketch) enabled St. John to find her.
Jane, internalizing this, seeks confirmation: St. John's mother was her father's sister, making her Jane's aunt.
She further clarifies that her Uncle John was also his Uncle John, and that he, Diana, and Mary are her cousins.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No; to-night!—to-night!” and as he turned from the door, I placed myself between it and him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “We are cousins; yes.”

events.text_segment:
“No; to-night!—to-night!” and as he turned from the door, I placed myself between it and him. He looked rather embarrassed.
“You certainly shall not go till you have told me all,” I said.
“I would rather not just now.”
“You shall!—you must!”
“I would rather Diana or Mary informed you.”
Of course these objections wrought my eagerness to a climax: gratified it must be, and that without delay; and I told him so.
“But I apprised you that I was a hard man,” said he, “difficult to persuade.”
“And I am a hard woman,—impossible to put off.”
“And then,” he pursued, “I am cold: no fervour infects me.”
“Whereas I am hot, and fire dissolves ice. The blaze there has thawed all the snow from your cloak; by the same token, it has streamed on to my floor, and made it like a trampled street. As you hope ever to be forgiven, Mr. Rivers, the high crime and misdemeanour of spoiling a sanded kitchen, tell me what I wish to know.”
“Well, then,” he said, “I yield; if not to your earnestness, to your perseverance: as stone is worn by continual dropping. Besides, you must know some day,—as well now as later. Your name is Jane Eyre?”
“Of course: that was all settled before.”
“You are not, perhaps, aware that I am your namesake?—that I was christened St. John Eyre Rivers?”
“No, indeed! I remember now seeing the letter E. comprised in your initials written in books you have at different times lent me; but I never asked for what name it stood. But what then? Surely—”
I stopped: I could not trust myself to entertain, much less to express, the thought that rushed upon me—that embodied itself,—that, in a second, stood out a strong, solid probability. Circumstances knit themselves, fitted themselves, shot into order: the chain that had been lying hitherto a formless lump of links was drawn out straight,—every ring was perfect, the connection complete. I knew, by instinct, how the matter stood, before St. John had said another word; but I cannot expect the reader to have the same intuitive perception, so I must repeat his explanation.
“My mother’s name was Eyre; she had two brothers; one a clergyman, who married Miss Jane Reed, of Gateshead; the other, John Eyre, Esq., merchant, late of Funchal, Madeira. Mr. Briggs, being Mr. Eyre’s solicitor, wrote to us last August to inform us of our uncle’s death, and to say that he had left his property to his brother the clergyman’s orphan daughter, overlooking us, in consequence of a quarrel, never forgiven, between him and my father. He wrote again a few weeks since, to intimate that the heiress was lost, and asking if we knew anything of her. A name casually written on a slip of paper has enabled me to find her out. You know the rest.” Again he was going, but I set my back against the door.
“Do let me speak,” I said; “let me have one moment to draw breath and reflect.” I paused—he stood before me, hat in hand, looking composed enough. I resumed—
“Your mother was my father’s sister?”
“Yes.”
“My aunt, consequently?”
He bowed.
“My uncle John was your uncle John? You, Diana, and Mary are his sister’s children, as I am his brother’s child?”
“Undeniably.”
“You three, then, are my cousins; half our blood on each side flows from the same source?”
“We are cousins; yes.”

events.title: The Overwhelming Joy of Kinship: A Greater Wealth Than Gold
detailed_summary: Jane contemplates St. John, realizing she has found not just a cousin, but someone she could consider a brother, alongside two sisters in Diana and Mary, whose qualities she had admired even as strangers.

She reflects on the profound irony that the people she had once gazed at with desperate longing from outside Moor House were her close kinswomen, and the man who saved her from near death was her blood relation.
This discovery of family is described as a glorious revelation for someone so lonely, a true wealth to the heart, far more vivid and exhilarating than the monetary inheritance.
Overcome with sudden joy, Jane claps her hands, her pulse racing and veins thrilling.
She exclaims her profound gladness at this newfound connection.
St. John smiles and gently teases her for neglecting essential points (like her inheritance) to pursue trifles, noting her seriousness about the fortune versus her current excitement over family.

Jane passionately refutes his assessment, explaining that family may be inconsequential to him who has sisters, but to her, who had nobody, gaining three relations (or two, if he doesn't count himself) is a momentous event, reiterating her gladness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I surveyed him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I say again, I am glad!”

events.text_segment:
I surveyed him. It seemed I had found a brother: one I could be proud of,—one I could love; and two sisters, whose qualities were such, that, when I knew them but as mere strangers, they had inspired me with genuine affection and admiration. The two girls, on whom, kneeling down on the wet ground, and looking through the low, latticed window of Moor House kitchen, I had gazed with so bitter a mixture of interest and despair, were my near kinswomen; and the young and stately gentleman who had found me almost dying at his threshold was my blood relation. Glorious discovery to a lonely wretch! This was wealth indeed!—wealth to the heart!—a mine of pure, genial affections. This was a blessing, bright, vivid, and exhilarating;—not like the ponderous gift of gold: rich and welcome enough in its way, but sobering from its weight. I now clapped my hands in sudden joy—my pulse bounded, my veins thrilled.
“Oh, I am glad!—I am glad!” I exclaimed.
St. John smiled. “Did I not say you neglected essential points to pursue trifles?” he asked. “You were serious when I told you you had got a fortune; and now, for a matter of no moment, you are excited.”
“What can you mean? It may be of no moment to you; you have sisters and don’t care for a cousin; but I had nobody; and now three relations,—or two, if you don’t choose to be counted,—are born into my world full-grown. I say again, I am glad!”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: As I looked at him, it felt as if I had found a brother—one I could be proud of and love; and two sisters whose admirable qualities had genuinely endeared them to me and won my respect, even when we were mere strangers. The two young women I had knelt on the wet ground to observe through the low, latticed kitchen window of Moor House, regarding them with such a painful mix of curiosity and hopelessness, were my close family; and the refined young man who had discovered me almost lifeless at his home was my blood relation. What a glorious realization for someone so alone! This was true wealth indeed—wealth for the heart—a deep source of pure, kind feelings. This was a bright, lively, and uplifting gift, entirely unlike the heavy fortune of gold: valuable and useful in its own right, but made serious by its weight. I suddenly clapped my hands in joy—my heart pounded, my blood rushed. “Oh, I am so happy! I am so happy!” I cried out. St. John smiled. “Didn’t I tell you that you overlook important things in favour of trivial ones?” he asked. “You remained calm when I informed you about your inheritance, but now you are excited about something inconsequential.” “What could you possibly mean? It might seem unimportant to you; you have sisters and aren’t bothered by a cousin; but I had no one; and now three relatives—or two, if you don’t wish to be included—have arrived in my life, fully grown. I repeat, I am happy!”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I looked at him and felt as if I had gained a brother whom I could both admire and love, along with two sisters whose admirable qualities had already won my heartfelt affection and respect, even before I knew we were related. The two young women I had once watched through the window of Moor House, feeling a bittersweet mix of hope and despair, were now revealed to be my close relatives, and the dignified young man who found me at his door when I was nearly dying was also my kin. What a wondrous realization for someone as lonely as I was! This was true wealth—a treasure of real, affectionate family bonds. This was a blessing, vivid and uplifting in a way that gold could never be—it was rich not in material value, but in warmth of heart. Overcome with happiness, I clapped my hands and felt my heart race and my whole body tingle with excitement. 

"Oh, I am so happy!" I cried.

St. John smiled and remarked, "Didn't I tell you that you pay attention to unimportant things rather than to what truly matters? You were serious when I mentioned you had inherited a fortune, but now you are excited over something insignificant."

"What do you mean? It may not mean much to you since you already have sisters and don't care for another cousin. But I was entirely alone, and now suddenly three family members—well, two, if you don't wish to count yourself—have arrived in my life. I say again, I am truly happy!"

events.title: Jane Envisions a Shared Future and Proposes Dividing Her Inheritance
detailed_summary: Jane paces the room, her mind racing with thoughts of the future possibilities and actions now open to her with her newfound family and wealth.
She envisions the blank wall as a sky full of stars, each guiding her towards a purpose or delight.
A powerful realization dawns: she can now tangibly benefit those who saved her life, freeing them from their constraints and reuniting them.

The concept of sharing her inheritance takes firm root; she believes that dividing the twenty thousand pounds equally among the four of them would provide five thousand each, achieving justice and mutual happiness.
This idea transforms the monetary bequest from a weighty burden into a legacy of life, hope, and enjoyment.
As these thoughts overwhelm her, St. John places a chair for her and gently tries to make her sit, advising her to compose herself.
Jane, scornful of any implication of helplessness, shakes off his hand and continues to walk about.
She instructs St. John to write to Diana and Mary the next day, telling them to come home, noting that five thousand pounds will make them very comfortable.
St. John, concerned by her agitation, offers to get her water and urges her to tranquillize her feelings, suggesting he was too abrupt in delivering the news.
Jane dismisses his concerns impatiently, asserting her rationality and accusing him of misunderstanding her intentions.
St. John mildly suggests that a fuller explanation from her might lead to better comprehension on his part.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I walked fast through the room: I stopped, half suffocated with the thoughts that rose faster than I could receive, comprehend, settle them:—thoughts of what might, could, would, and should be, and that ere long.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Perhaps, if you explained yourself a little more fully, I should comprehend better.”

events.text_segment:
I walked fast through the room: I stopped, half suffocated with the thoughts that rose faster than I could receive, comprehend, settle them:—thoughts of what might, could, would, and should be, and that ere long. I looked at the blank wall: it seemed a sky thick with ascending stars,—every one lit me to a purpose or delight. Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly, I could now benefit. They were under a yoke,—I could free them: they were scattered,—I could reunite them: the independence, the affluence which was mine, might be theirs too. Were we not four? Twenty thousand pounds shared equally would be five thousand each, justice—enough and to spare: justice would be done,—mutual happiness secured. Now the wealth did not weigh on me: now it was not a mere bequest of coin,—it was a legacy of life, hope, enjoyment.
How I looked while these ideas were taking my spirit by storm, I cannot tell; but I perceived soon that Mr. Rivers had placed a chair behind me, and was gently attempting to make me sit down on it. He also advised me to be composed; I scorned the insinuation of helplessness and distraction, shook off his hand, and began to walk about again.
“Write to Diana and Mary to-morrow,” I said, “and tell them to come home directly. Diana said they would both consider themselves rich with a thousand pounds, so with five thousand they will do very well.”
“Tell me where I can get you a glass of water,” said St. John; “you must really make an effort to tranquillise your feelings.”
“Nonsense! and what sort of an effect will the bequest have on you? Will it keep you in England, induce you to marry Miss Oliver, and settle down like an ordinary mortal?”
“You wander: your head becomes confused. I have been too abrupt in communicating the news; it has excited you beyond your strength.”
“Mr. Rivers! you quite put me out of patience: I am rational enough; it is you who misunderstand, or rather who affect to misunderstand.”
“Perhaps, if you explained yourself a little more fully, I should comprehend better.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
I quickly walked around the room, feeling almost choked by the thoughts that flooded my mind faster than I could grasp, understand, or organize them. These were thoughts about everything that could, might, would, and should happen, and soon. I looked at the bare wall; it seemed like a dense sky filled with rising stars, each one guiding me towards a purpose or a joy. I could now help the people who had saved my life, whom I had loved until this moment without being able to truly assist them. They were burdened by a difficult situation, and I could free them; they were apart, and I could bring them back together. The independence and wealth that was now mine could be theirs as well. Weren't there four of us? Twenty thousand pounds divided equally would be five thousand for each person, which was fair – more than enough, in fact. Justice would be served, and our mutual happiness would be certain. The wealth no longer felt like a burden to me; it wasn't just a simple sum of money, but a gift of life, hope, and happiness.

I don't know what I looked like while these ideas were overwhelming my spirit, but I soon saw that Mr. Rivers had placed a chair behind me and was gently trying to get me to sit down. He also advised me to calm myself. I resented the suggestion that I was helpless or losing control, pulled away from his hand, and started walking again.

"Write to Diana and Mary tomorrow," I said, "and tell them to come home immediately. Diana said they would consider themselves rich with just a thousand pounds, so with five thousand they will be very comfortable."

"Tell me where I can get you a glass of water," said St. John; "you really must make an effort to calm your feelings."

"Nonsense!" I exclaimed. "And what kind of effect will this inheritance have on you? Will it keep you in England, convince you to marry Miss Oliver, and settle down like a normal person?"

"You are rambling; your mind is becoming confused," St. John replied. "I must have been too sudden in sharing the news; it has upset you beyond your capacity."

"Mr. Rivers!" I said, completely out of patience. "I am perfectly rational; it is you who misunderstand, or rather who are pretending to misunderstand."

"Perhaps, if you explained yourself a little more fully, I might understand better," he suggested.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I hurried across the room, overcome by a rush of thoughts that I could barely keep up with or understand—imaginings about all the possibilities and changes that were now within reach. Staring at the blank wall, it appeared as a sky full of rising stars, each one symbolizing a new hope or goal. Those who had once saved me, people I had only passively loved before, were now within my power to help. I could free them from their burdens, bring them together, and share with them the wealth and independence I now possessed. There were four of us, so dividing the twenty thousand pounds gave each five thousand—a fair and generous amount, ensuring justice and shared happiness. The inheritance no longer felt like a burden or just money; it was now a source of life, optimism, and pleasure.

I don’t know what expression I wore while these thoughts swept over me, but I soon noticed Mr. Rivers trying to help me sit down, encouraging me to calm myself. Resisting his suggestion that I was overwhelmed, I shook him off and resumed pacing.

"Write to Diana and Mary tomorrow," I said, "and tell them to come home immediately. Diana said before that a thousand pounds would make them feel wealthy, so five thousand should more than suffice."

St. John offered to fetch me water and urged me again to calm down.

"Nonsense! And how will this inheritance affect you? Will it keep you here in England, motivate you to marry Miss Oliver, and settle down like everyone else?"

He pointed out that I was agitated and that his abrupt news had overly excited me.

"Mr. Rivers! You’re trying my patience; I’m perfectly sane—it’s you who misunderstand, or perhaps just pretend to."

He suggested that if I explained myself more clearly, he might understand me better.

events.title: Jane's Resolute Stand for Shared Inheritance and True Kinship
detailed_summary: Jane emphatically clarifies her intention: the twenty thousand pounds should be divided equally, giving five thousand to St. John and each of his sisters, as well as herself.

She passionately asserts that this is her unshakeable view, driven by her refusal to be selfish, unjust, or ungrateful, and her deep desire for a home and lasting connections with Moor House and her cousins.
She explains that five thousand pounds would be a benefit, but twenty thousand would be an oppressive burden and, in her view, not justly hers despite the law.
St. John cautions that she is acting on first impulses and should take time to consider such a significant decision.
Jane reassures him of her sincerity and appeals to his sense of justice in the matter.
St. John concedes a certain justice in her plan but notes its contrariness to custom and reiterates that the entire fortune is legally hers to keep with a clear conscience.

Jane responds that for her, the matter is as much about feeling as conscience, and she must indulge the rare opportunity to act on her feelings, particularly the desire to repay a great obligation and gain lifelong friends.
St. John argues she doesn't yet understand the power and societal advantages wealth offers, but Jane interrupts him.
She passionately expresses her profound craving for familial love, having never had a home or siblings, and declares her determination to have them now, asking if he is reluctant to accept her.

St. John assures her he and his sisters will be her siblings without requiring the sacrifice of her rights, but Jane vehemently rejects the idea of her being wealthy while they remain penniless and distant, calling it a mockery of equality and close union.

She dismisses his suggestion that she might find family ties through marriage, stating her aversion to it and her refusal to be a mere money speculation for a stranger, wanting instead true kindred spirits.
She asks him to sincerely repeat his earlier acceptance of her as a brother.

St. John, acknowledging his love for his own sisters is based on respect for their worth and talents, affirms that Jane possesses principle and mind, shares tastes with Diana and Mary, and her presence is agreeable to him, finding solace in her conversation. He declares he can easily and naturally make room in his heart for her as his third and youngest sister.
Jane expresses her contentment with his heartfelt acceptance for the night.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Explain! What is there to explain?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Thank you: that contents me for to-night.

events.text_segment:
“Explain! What is there to explain? You cannot fail to see that twenty thousand pounds, the sum in question, divided equally between the nephew and three nieces of our uncle, will give five thousand to each? What I want is, that you should write to your sisters and tell them of the fortune that has accrued to them.”
“To you, you mean.”
“I have intimated my view of the case: I am incapable of taking any other. I am not brutally selfish, blindly unjust, or fiendishly ungrateful. Besides, I am resolved I will have a home and connections. I like Moor House, and I will live at Moor House; I like Diana and Mary, and I will attach myself for life to Diana and Mary. It would please and benefit me to have five thousand pounds; it would torment and oppress me to have twenty thousand; which, moreover, could never be mine in justice, though it might in law. I abandon to you, then, what is absolutely superfluous to me. Let there be no opposition, and no discussion about it; let us agree amongst each other, and decide the point at once.”
“This is acting on first impulses; you must take days to consider such a matter, ere your word can be regarded as valid.”
“Oh! if all you doubt is my sincerity, I am easy: you see the justice of the case?”
“I do see a certain justice; but it is contrary to all custom. Besides, the entire fortune is your right: my uncle gained it by his own efforts; he was free to leave it to whom he would: he left it to you. After all, justice permits you to keep it: you may, with a clear conscience, consider it absolutely your own.”
“With me,” said I, “it is fully as much a matter of feeling as of conscience: I must indulge my feelings; I so seldom have had an opportunity of doing so. Were you to argue, object, and annoy me for a year, I could not forego the delicious pleasure of which I have caught a glimpse—that of repaying, in part, a mighty obligation, and winning to myself lifelong friends.”
“You think so now,” rejoined St. John, “because you do not know what it is to possess, nor consequently to enjoy wealth: you cannot form a notion of the importance twenty thousand pounds would give you; of the place it would enable you to take in society; of the prospects it would open to you: you cannot—”
“And you,” I interrupted, “cannot at all imagine the craving I have for fraternal and sisterly love. I never had a home, I never had brothers or sisters; I must and will have them now: you are not reluctant to admit me and own me, are you?”
“Jane, I will be your brother—my sisters will be your sisters—without stipulating for this sacrifice of your just rights.”
“Brother? Yes; at the distance of a thousand leagues! Sisters? Yes; slaving amongst strangers! I, wealthy—gorged with gold I never earned and do not merit! You, penniless! Famous equality and fraternisation! Close union! Intimate attachment!”
“But, Jane, your aspirations after family ties and domestic happiness may be realised otherwise than by the means you contemplate: you may marry.”
“Nonsense, again! Marry! I don’t want to marry, and never shall marry.”
“That is saying too much: such hazardous affirmations are a proof of the excitement under which you labour.”
“It is not saying too much: I know what I feel, and how averse are my inclinations to the bare thought of marriage. No one would take me for love; and I will not be regarded in the light of a mere money speculation. And I do not want a stranger—unsympathising, alien, different from me; I want my kindred: those with whom I have full fellow-feeling. Say again you will be my brother: when you uttered the words I was satisfied, happy; repeat them, if you can, repeat them sincerely.”
“I think I can. I know I have always loved my own sisters; and I know on what my affection for them is grounded,—respect for their worth and admiration of their talents. You too have principle and mind: your tastes and habits resemble Diana’s and Mary’s; your presence is always agreeable to me; in your conversation I have already for some time found a salutary solace. I feel I can easily and naturally make room in my heart for you, as my third and youngest sister.”
“Thank you: that contents me for to-night.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
“Explain what?” Jane replied, slightly astonished. “It’s perfectly clear, isn’t it, that twenty thousand pounds, the amount in question, when divided equally among our uncle’s nephew and his three nieces, gives five thousand to each? My wish is simply that you write to your sisters and inform them about the fortune that has come to them.”
“To you, you mean,” St. John corrected.
“I have already stated my perspective on this matter,” Jane responded firmly, “and I cannot adopt any other. I am not being brutally selfish, blindly unfair, or monstrously ungrateful. Furthermore, I am determined to have a home and family connections. I love Moor House, and I will live there; I love Diana and Mary, and I will be devoted to them for the rest of my life. Having five thousand pounds would be pleasing and beneficial to me; possessing twenty thousand would be a torment and a burden, and what’s more, it could never truly be mine by right, although legally it might be. I am therefore relinquishing to you what is entirely surplus to my needs. Let there be no opposition or discussion about this; let us reach an agreement among ourselves and settle the matter immediately.”
“This is an impulsive decision,” St. John argued. “You must take several days to consider such a thing before your word can be taken as final.”
“Oh, if the only thing you doubt is my sincerity,” Jane said with relief, “then I am at ease. You do see the justice of my proposal, don’t you?”
“I do see a certain fairness,” St. John admitted, “but it goes against all conventional practice. Besides, the entire fortune is legally yours. Our uncle earned it through his own efforts; he was free to leave it to whomever he wished, and he chose you. After all, justice allows you to keep it; you can, with a clear conscience, consider it absolutely your own.”
“With me,” I replied, “it is just as much a matter of deep feeling as it is of conscience. I must indulge my feelings; I have so rarely had the opportunity to do so. Even if you were to argue, object, and distress me for an entire year, I could not abandon the wonderful joy I have caught a glimpse of – the joy of partially repaying a significant debt and gaining lifelong friends.”
“You think so now,” St. John rejoined, “because you don’t know what it means to possess wealth, nor consequently to enjoy it. You cannot form any idea of the importance twenty thousand pounds would give you; of the position it would enable you to occupy in society; of the prospects it would open up for you; you cannot…”
“And you,” I interrupted, “cannot possibly imagine the intense longing I have for a brother’s and sisters’ love. I never had a home, I never had siblings. I must and will have them now. You are not reluctant to accept me and acknowledge me, are you?”
“Jane, I will be your brother, and my sisters will be your sisters, without demanding this sacrifice of your just rights.”
“Brother?” I exclaimed, disappointed. “Yes, but at a distance of a thousand miles! Sisters? Yes, toiling among strangers! While I am wealthy – gorged with gold I never earned and do not deserve! And you are penniless! What remarkable equality and camaraderie! What close union! What intimate attachment!”
“But, Jane, your desire for family ties and domestic happiness could be fulfilled through other means than the one you are considering. You could marry.”
“Nonsense, again!” I retorted. “Marry! I have no desire to marry, and I never will.”
“That is too absolute a statement,” St. John countered. “Such rash assertions are proof of the strong emotion you are currently experiencing.”
“It is not too absolute,” I insisted. “I know how I feel, and how strongly my inclinations are against the mere thought of marriage. No one would marry me for love, and I refuse to be viewed simply as a financial speculation. And I do not want a stranger – someone unsympathetic, alien, different from me. I want my family, those with whom I share a complete understanding. Please say again that you will be my brother. When you spoke those words before, I felt content and happy. Repeat them, if you can; repeat them sincerely.”
“I believe I can,” St. John said thoughtfully. “I know I have always loved my own sisters, and I know that my affection for them is based on respect for their character and admiration of their talents. You too possess moral principle and intellect; your tastes and habits resemble Diana’s and Mary’s; your presence is always agreeable to me; and in your conversation, I have for some time now found a beneficial comfort. I feel I can easily and naturally make room in my heart for you, as my third and youngest sister.”
“Thank you,” I said, feeling satisfied. “That is enough for me tonight.”

"You mean tell them about your inheritance."
"I've made my viewpoint clear: I can't see it any other way. I'm not selfish, unjust, or ungrateful. More than that, I want a home and family connections. I love Moor House and want to live here with Diana and Mary; I want to be close to them for life. Five thousand pounds will make me happy; twenty thousand would overwhelm me—and it's not rightfully mine, even if I could legally keep it. So I insist you take what I don't need. "I see it’s fair in a way, but it’s not customary. The inheritance is rightfully yours—our uncle earned his fortune and gave it to you. Morally and legally, it’s yours. You shouldn't feel obligated to give it away."
"For me," I replied, "it’s as much about emotion as conscience. I want to express my feelings for once—I rarely have the chance. Even if you argued for a year, I couldn’t let go of the joy I foresee: repaying a great debt and gaining lifelong friends."
"You only think this because you don’t know what it’s like to have or enjoy wealth; you can't imagine the opportunities twenty thousand pounds could provide for you—the place you could have in society."
"And you," I interrupted, "can’t imagine how much I long for family. I’ve never had a home, or brothers and sisters, but I want that now. You’re not unwilling to welcome me, are you?"

"Nonsense! Marry? I have no desire and never will."

"I believe I can. I’ve always loved my sisters—because of who they are and what they can do. You too have character and intellect. Your habits are like Diana's and Mary’s. I enjoy your company and find comfort in it. I can easily open my heart to you as my youngest sister."
"Thank you. That’s all I need for tonight."

events.title: St. John's Departure and the Legacy's Final Equitable Settlement
detailed_summary: Satisfied for the moment, Jane urges St. John to depart, lest he raise further mistrustful objections.
St. John inquires about the school, and Jane confirms her intention to retain her position as mistress until a suitable substitute can be found.
This decision meets with St. John's smiled approval; they shake hands, and he takes his leave.
Jane briefly narrates that settling the legacy according to her wishes involved further struggles and arguments.
She describes her task as very difficult but states her absolute resolve was key.
Eventually, her cousins recognized the unshakeable firmness of her intention to make a just division and likely felt the inherent equity of her plan.
They consented to put the matter to arbitration.
The chosen judges, Mr. Oliver and an able lawyer, both concurred with Jane's proposed division of the property.
Jane successfully carried her point, and the necessary legal instruments for the transfer of funds were drawn up.
As a result, St. John, Diana, Mary, and Jane each became financially independent, possessed of a competency.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now you had better go; for if you stay longer, you will perhaps irritate me afresh by some mistrustful scruple.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The instruments of transfer were drawn out: St. John, Diana, Mary, and I, each became possessed of a competency.

events.text_segment:
Now you had better go; for if you stay longer, you will perhaps irritate me afresh by some mistrustful scruple.”
“And the school, Miss Eyre? It must now be shut up, I suppose?”
“No. I will retain my post of mistress till you get a substitute.”
He smiled approbation: we shook hands, and he took leave.
I need not narrate in detail the further struggles I had, and arguments I used, to get matters regarding the legacy settled as I wished. My task was a very hard one; but, as I was absolutely resolved—as my cousins saw at length that my mind was really and immutably fixed on making a just division of the property—as they must in their own hearts have felt the equity of the intention; and must, besides, have been innately conscious that in my place they would have done precisely what I wished to do—they yielded at length so far as to consent to put the affair to arbitration. The judges chosen were Mr. Oliver and an able lawyer: both coincided in my opinion: I carried my point. The instruments of transfer were drawn out: St. John, Diana, Mary, and I, each became possessed of a competency.
