events.title: Closing Morton School and Articulating Domestic Ambitions
detailed_summary: As the Christmas season approached, Jane concluded her affairs at Morton school, experiencing gratification from her work and the clear affection her students showed at their parting.
She promised her rustic scholars that she would visit them weekly to provide an hour of instruction, a commitment stemming from the pleasure she took in their fondness for her.
After the sixty students had left, Mr. Rivers engaged Jane in conversation, inquiring if she felt her efforts had been adequately rewarded and if a life dedicated to service held appeal.
Jane acknowledged the value of such a life but asserted her immediate need to enjoy her own faculties and take a complete break from teaching, signaling her desire for a holiday.
When Mr. Rivers pressed her about her future intentions, Jane revealed her plan to enlist Hannah's help to travel to Moor House and meticulously prepare it for the upcoming arrival of Diana and Mary.

She enthusiastically described her detailed agenda: thoroughly cleaning Moor House from top to bottom, polishing it until it shone, arranging furniture with precision, maintaining warm fires, and, finally, engaging in extensive Christmas baking with Hannah to create an ideal welcome for her cousins.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was near Christmas by the time all was settled: the season of general holiday approached.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My purpose, in short, is to have all things in an absolutely perfect state of readiness for Diana and Mary before next Thursday; and my ambition is to give them a beau-ideal of a welcome when they come.”

events.text_segment:
It was near Christmas by the time all was settled: the season of general holiday approached. I now closed Morton school, taking care that the parting should not be barren on my side. Good fortune opens the hand as well as the heart wonderfully; and to give somewhat when we have largely received, is but to afford a vent to the unusual ebullition of the sensations. I had long felt with pleasure that many of my rustic scholars liked me, and when we parted, that consciousness was confirmed: they manifested their affection plainly and strongly. Deep was my gratification to find I had really a place in their unsophisticated hearts: I promised them that never a week should pass in future that I did not visit them, and give them an hour’s teaching in their school.
Mr. Rivers came up as, having seen the classes, now numbering sixty girls, file out before me, and locked the door, I stood with the key in my hand, exchanging a few words of special farewell with some half-dozen of my best scholars: as decent, respectable, modest, and well-informed young women as could be found in the ranks of the British peasantry. And that is saying a great deal; for after all, the British peasantry are the best taught, best mannered, most self-respecting of any in Europe: since those days I have seen paysannes and Bäuerinnen; and the best of them seemed to me ignorant, coarse, and besotted, compared with my Morton girls.
“Do you consider you have got your reward for a season of exertion?” asked Mr. Rivers, when they were gone. “Does not the consciousness of having done some real good in your day and generation give pleasure?”
“Doubtless.”
“And you have only toiled a few months! Would not a life devoted to the task of regenerating your race be well spent?”
“Yes,” I said; “but I could not go on for ever so: I want to enjoy my own faculties as well as to cultivate those of other people. I must enjoy them now; don’t recall either my mind or body to the school; I am out of it and disposed for full holiday.”
He looked grave. “What now? What sudden eagerness is this you evince? What are you going to do?”
“To be active: as active as I can. And first I must beg you to set Hannah at liberty, and get somebody else to wait on you.”
“Do you want her?”
“Yes, to go with me to Moor House. Diana and Mary will be at home in a week, and I want to have everything in order against their arrival.”
“I understand. I thought you were for flying off on some excursion. It is better so: Hannah shall go with you.”
“Tell her to be ready by to-morrow then; and here is the schoolroom key: I will give you the key of my cottage in the morning.”
He took it. “You give it up very gleefully,” said he; “I don’t quite understand your light-heartedness, because I cannot tell what employment you propose to yourself as a substitute for the one you are relinquishing. What aim, what purpose, what ambition in life have you now?”
“My first aim will be to clean down (do you comprehend the full force of the expression?)—to clean down Moor House from chamber to cellar; my next to rub it up with bees-wax, oil, and an indefinite number of cloths, till it glitters again; my third, to arrange every chair, table, bed, carpet, with mathematical precision; afterwards I shall go near to ruin you in coals and peat to keep up good fires in every room; and lastly, the two days preceding that on which your sisters are expected will be devoted by Hannah and me to such a beating of eggs, sorting of currants, grating of spices, compounding of Christmas cakes, chopping up of materials for mince-pies, and solemnising of other culinary rites, as words can convey but an inadequate notion of to the uninitiated like you. My purpose, in short, is to have all things in an absolutely perfect state of readiness for Diana and Mary before next Thursday; and my ambition is to give them a beau-ideal of a welcome when they come.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
It was almost Christmas when everything was settled, and the holiday season was approaching. I finished teaching at Morton school, making sure to leave a positive impression. Good fortune is wonderful because it makes both the hand and the heart generous; giving back when you've received a lot is simply a way to express overwhelming feelings. I had long been happy knowing many of my rural students liked me, and this was confirmed when we said goodbye; they clearly and strongly showed their affection. I was deeply pleased to see I truly held a place in their simple, honest hearts. I promised them I would visit their school every single week going forward and teach them for an hour.

Mr. Rivers came over after I had watched the classes, which now included sixty girls, walk out in front of me. I had locked the door and stood with the key, saying a few extra goodbyes to about half a dozen of my best students. They were as decent, respectable, modest, and knowledgeable young women as you could find among working-class British people. And that's saying a lot, because British working people are, on the whole, the best educated, most polite, and most self-respecting in Europe. Since then, I've seen country women in other places, and even the best of them seemed uneducated, rough, and dull compared to my girls at Morton.

“Do you feel you've been rewarded for your hard work?” Mr. Rivers asked when they were gone. “Doesn't knowing you've done some real good in your time and for your generation bring satisfaction?”

“Absolutely,” I replied.

“And you've only worked for a few months! Wouldn't a life dedicated to improving your community be time well spent?”

“Yes,” I said, “but I couldn't keep going like that forever. I want to use my own abilities and not just help others develop theirs. I need to enjoy mine now. Don't talk about the school anymore; I'm finished with it and ready for a complete break.”

He looked serious. “What's this? What's this sudden eagerness you're showing? What do you plan to do?”

“Be busy, as busy as possible. First, I need you to let Hannah go and find someone else to look after you.”

“Do you need her?”

“Yes, to come with me to Moor House. Diana and Mary will be home in a week, and I want everything ready for their arrival.”

“I see. I thought you were planning a trip somewhere. This is better. Hannah can go with you.”

“Tell her to be ready by tomorrow then. Here is the schoolroom key. I'll give you the key to my cottage in the morning.”

He took it. “You're giving it up very cheerfully,” he said. “I don't quite understand your happiness because I don't know what you plan to do instead of teaching. What is your goal, purpose, or ambition in life now?”

“My first goal will be to completely clean (do you understand how thorough I mean?) to scrub down Moor House from top to bottom. My next is to polish it thoroughly with beeswax, oil, and countless cloths until it shines. My third is to arrange every chair, table, bed, and rug perfectly. After that, I'll probably use up all your coal and peat keeping good fires going in every room. Finally, the two days before your sisters arrive will be spent by Hannah and me beating eggs, sorting currants, grating spices, mixing Christmas cakes, chopping ingredients for mince pies, and performing other cooking tasks so complex that words can't fully explain them to someone inexperienced like you. My purpose, in short, is to have everything absolutely perfect for Diana and Mary before next Thursday, and my ambition is to give them the warmest possible welcome when they return.”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
By the time everything was resolved, Christmas was near and the holidays were approaching. I closed Morton school, ensuring that my farewell was meaningful. Good fortune encourages generosity, and sharing what we have when we've been given much helps express the gratitude we feel. I had enjoyed seeing the fondness my village students had for me, and our parting confirmed their affection. Their open display of appreciation gave me the deep satisfaction of knowing I held a place in their sincere hearts. I promised to visit them weekly and offer an hour of lessons even after the school closed.

Mr. Rivers approached as I watched my sixty pupils leave and was saying special farewells to a few outstanding girls, who were respectable and intelligent—a fine representation of the British peasantry, whom I consider better educated and mannered than any I’d seen in Europe. 

Mr. Rivers asked if I felt that my efforts had been rewarded and if the sense of having done good was gratifying, to which I agreed. He wondered if giving one’s life to improving others would be worthwhile, but I replied that I also wanted to use and enjoy my own talents, not just nurture those of others. I was ready to leave school behind for a real holiday. 

He noticed my excitement and questioned what I planned to do. I explained that I intended to be as active as possible and asked for Hannah to be relieved from her duties so she could help me prepare Moor House for Diana and Mary’s homecoming next week. He agreed and accepted the schoolroom key, commenting on my cheerful demeanor, and wondered what my new purpose would be now.

I told him my immediate goal was to thoroughly clean Moor House, polish every surface, organize all furniture with care, keep fires burning in every room, and then, just before the sisters arrived, Hannah and I would be immersed in baking and preparing festive foods. In essence, I was determined that everything would be perfect to offer Diana and Mary the most wonderful welcome when they returned.

events.title: Jane's Domestic Efforts and St. John's Disapproval Leading to Jane's Realization
detailed_summary: St. John expressed a subtle dissatisfaction with Jane's focus on domestic preparations, indicating his hope that she would eventually pursue loftier goals beyond household comforts and joys.
Jane countered his sentiment by declaring domestic pleasures to be the finest things life offers, prompting St. John to caution her against seeking ultimate fulfillment or rest in worldly matters.
He conceded her a two-month period to savor her newfound relationships and financial ease but voiced his expectation that she would then aspire to objectives beyond Moor House and familial society.
Jane was taken aback by what she perceived as his almost malicious attempt to disrupt her contentment, questioning the purpose behind his unsettling words.

St. John clarified that his aim was for her to utilize her God-given talents effectively, warning that he would observe her closely and urging her to reserve her passion for causes more significant than common home pleasures.
Jane, however, dismissed his admonitions, resolute in her decision to find happiness in her current circumstances.

She and Hannah then dedicated themselves with great energy and cheer to the task of renovating Moor House. Jane travelled to S— to select new furnishings, aiming to create an inviting atmosphere for her cousins by thoughtfully integrating new items with existing beloved pieces.
The house was consequently transformed into an exemplar of bright, comfortable, and unpretentious domesticity.
Upon St. John's arrival before his sisters, Jane eagerly invited him to survey the results of her extensive labors.
He toured the revamped house with a polite but noticeable lack of enthusiasm, acknowledging the effort involved but offering no indication of pleasure at the improved appearance of his home.

His indifferent silence left Jane feeling disheartened, initially concerned that her changes might have disturbed cherished old associations, a notion he dismissed, instead implying she had perhaps devoted excessive thought to the matter.
He then disengaged by selecting a book and retreating to his usual window seat to read.

This prompted Jane to reflect deeply on St. John's inherently cold and austere character. She recognized his unsuitability for domestic life or a conventional marriage, finally understanding his earlier rejection of Miss Oliver as stemming from a love based merely on sensory attraction rather than deeper compatibility.
She concluded that St. John's true calling was not in the peaceful comforts of a home but in demanding, ascetic endeavors such as missionary work, for which his nature was far better suited.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: St. John smiled slightly: still he was dissatisfied.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He is right to choose a missionary’s career—I see it now.”

events.text_segment:
St. John smiled slightly: still he was dissatisfied.
“It is all very well for the present,” said he; “but seriously, I trust that when the first flush of vivacity is over, you will look a little higher than domestic endearments and household joys.”
“The best things the world has!” I interrupted.
“No, Jane, no: this world is not the scene of fruition; do not attempt to make it so: nor of rest; do not turn slothful.”
“I mean, on the contrary, to be busy.”
“Jane, I excuse you for the present: two months’ grace I allow you for the full enjoyment of your new position, and for pleasing yourself with this late-found charm of relationship; but then, I hope you will begin to look beyond Moor House and Morton, and sisterly society, and the selfish calm and sensual comfort of civilised affluence. I hope your energies will then once more trouble you with their strength.”
I looked at him with surprise. “St. John,” I said, “I think you are almost wicked to talk so. I am disposed to be as content as a queen, and you try to stir me up to restlessness! To what end?”
“To the end of turning to profit the talents which God has committed to your keeping; and of which He will surely one day demand a strict account. Jane, I shall watch you closely and anxiously—I warn you of that. And try to restrain the disproportionate fervour with which you throw yourself into commonplace home pleasures. Don’t cling so tenaciously to ties of the flesh; save your constancy and ardour for an adequate cause; forbear to waste them on trite transient objects. Do you hear, Jane?”
“Yes; just as if you were speaking Greek. I feel I have adequate cause to be happy, and I will be happy. Goodbye!”
Happy at Moor House I was, and hard I worked; and so did Hannah: she was charmed to see how jovial I could be amidst the bustle of a house turned topsy-turvy—how I could brush, and dust, and clean, and cook. And really, after a day or two of confusion worse confounded, it was delightful by degrees to invoke order from the chaos ourselves had made. I had previously taken a journey to S—— to purchase some new furniture: my cousins having given me carte blanche to effect what alterations I pleased, and a sum having been set aside for that purpose. The ordinary sitting-room and bedrooms I left much as they were: for I knew Diana and Mary would derive more pleasure from seeing again the old homely tables, and chairs, and beds, than from the spectacle of the smartest innovations. Still some novelty was necessary, to give to their return the piquancy with which I wished it to be invested. Dark handsome new carpets and curtains, an arrangement of some carefully selected antique ornaments in porcelain and bronze, new coverings, and mirrors, and dressing-cases, for the toilet tables, answered the end: they looked fresh without being glaring. A spare parlour and bedroom I refurnished entirely, with old mahogany and crimson upholstery: I laid canvas on the passage, and carpets on the stairs. When all was finished, I thought Moor House as complete a model of bright modest snugness within, as it was, at this season, a specimen of wintry waste and desert dreariness without.
The eventful Thursday at length came. They were expected about dark, and ere dusk fires were lit upstairs and below; the kitchen was in perfect trim; Hannah and I were dressed, and all was in readiness.
St. John arrived first. I had entreated him to keep quite clear of the house till everything was arranged: and, indeed, the bare idea of the commotion, at once sordid and trivial, going on within its walls sufficed to scare him to estrangement. He found me in the kitchen, watching the progress of certain cakes for tea, then baking. Approaching the hearth, he asked, “If I was at last satisfied with housemaid’s work?” I answered by inviting him to accompany me on a general inspection of the result of my labours. With some difficulty, I got him to make the tour of the house. He just looked in at the doors I opened; and when he had wandered upstairs and downstairs, he said I must have gone through a great deal of fatigue and trouble to have effected such considerable changes in so short a time: but not a syllable did he utter indicating pleasure in the improved aspect of his abode.
This silence damped me. I thought perhaps the alterations had disturbed some old associations he valued. I inquired whether this was the case: no doubt in a somewhat crest-fallen tone.
“Not at all; he had, on the contrary, remarked that I had scrupulously respected every association: he feared, indeed, I must have bestowed more thought on the matter than it was worth. How many minutes, for instance, had I devoted to studying the arrangement of this very room?—By-the-bye, could I tell him where such a book was?”
I showed him the volume on the shelf: he took it down, and withdrawing to his accustomed window recess, he began to read it.
Now, I did not like this, reader. St. John was a good man; but I began to feel he had spoken truth of himself when he said he was hard and cold. The humanities and amenities of life had no attraction for him—its peaceful enjoyments no charm. Literally, he lived only to aspire—after what was good and great, certainly; but still he would never rest, nor approve of others resting round him. As I looked at his lofty forehead, still and pale as a white stone—at his fine lineaments fixed in study—I comprehended all at once that he would hardly make a good husband: that it would be a trying thing to be his wife. I understood, as by inspiration, the nature of his love for Miss Oliver; I agreed with him that it was but a love of the senses. I comprehended how he should despise himself for the feverish influence it exercised over him; how he should wish to stifle and destroy it; how he should mistrust its ever conducting permanently to his happiness or hers. I saw he was of the material from which nature hews her heroes—Christian and Pagan—her lawgivers, her statesmen, her conquerors: a steadfast bulwark for great interests to rest upon; but, at the fireside, too often a cold cumbrous column, gloomy and out of place.
“This parlour is not his sphere,” I reflected: “the Himalayan ridge or Caffre bush, even the plague-cursed Guinea Coast swamp would suit him better. Well may he eschew the calm of domestic life; it is not his element: there his faculties stagnate—they cannot develop or appear to advantage. It is in scenes of strife and danger—where courage is proved, and energy exercised, and fortitude tasked—that he will speak and move, the leader and superior. A merry child would have the advantage of him on this hearth. He is right to choose a missionary’s career—I see it now.”

He commented that her current situation was acceptable for the moment, but he earnestly hoped that once the initial burst of enthusiasm passed, she would aspire to something loftier than simple domestic affection and the pleasures of home life. I interjected that those were the finest things in the world. He countered, 'No, Jane, this world is not meant for total gratification, so don't try to make it so; nor is it for rest, so don't become lazy.' I declared, on the contrary, that I intended to be active. St. John excused me for the present, granting me two months to fully enjoy my new circumstances and the delight of discovering my family connection. After that, he hoped I would start looking beyond Moor House, Morton, my sisters' companionship, and the self-centred tranquility and physical comfort of a prosperous, civilized existence. He hoped my energies would then stir within me with their strength once more. I gazed at him with surprise. I told St. John that I thought he spoke almost wickedly. I was inclined to be as content as a queen, and he was trying to incite restlessness in me! To what end? He explained the purpose was to make profitable use of the talents God had entrusted to my care, for which He would certainly demand a strict account one day. He warned me that he would be observing me closely and with concern. He urged me to try to control the excessive passion with which I engaged in ordinary home enjoyments. He advised me not to cling so tightly to family ties but to save my loyalty and intensity for a worthy cause, avoiding wasting them on insignificant, fleeting things. He asked if I understood. I replied that I did, but it sounded like Greek to me. I felt I had a perfectly good reason to be happy, and I *would* be happy. Goodbye! I was indeed happy at Moor House and worked diligently, as did Hannah. She was charmed by how cheerful I could be amidst the upheaval of a house turned upside down—how adept I was at brushing, dusting, cleaning, and cooking. And truly, after a couple of days of even worse confusion, it was wonderful to gradually summon order from the chaos we had created. I had previously travelled to S—— to buy new furniture; my cousins had given me complete freedom to make any changes I liked, and a specific sum had been allocated for this. I largely kept the usual living room and bedrooms as they were, knowing Diana and Mary would get more pleasure from seeing their familiar old tables, chairs, and beds again than from the sight of completely new things. Still, some newness was necessary to give their return the special flavour I wanted it to have. Dark, attractive new carpets and curtains, a display of some carefully chosen old ornaments in porcelain and bronze, and new coverings, mirrors, and dressing cases for the vanity tables achieved this goal; they looked fresh without being garish. I completely refurnished a spare sitting room and bedroom with old mahogany furniture and crimson upholstery. I laid down canvas in the passage and carpets on the stairs. When everything was complete, I thought the interior of Moor House was a perfect example of cheerful, modest comfort, just as its exterior, at that time of year, was a picture of wintry desolation and stark emptiness. The awaited Thursday finally arrived. They were expected around nightfall, and before dusk, fires were lit upstairs and down; the kitchen was in perfect order; Hannah and I were dressed, and everything was prepared. St. John was the first to arrive. I had specifically asked him to stay away from the house until everything was ready, and indeed, the mere idea of the commotion, which he saw as both vulgar and trivial, taking place inside was enough to keep him distant. He found me in the kitchen, monitoring the progress of some cakes for tea that were baking. Approaching the hearth, he asked if I was at last content with doing a housemaid's job. I replied by inviting him to accompany me on a tour to see the results of my work. I managed with some difficulty to get him to walk through the house. He just glanced through the doors I opened; and after he had gone upstairs and downstairs, he remarked that I must have undergone a great deal of tiredness and trouble to have brought about such significant changes in such a short time. But he did not say a single word indicating pleasure in the improved appearance of his home. This silence dampened my spirits. I thought perhaps the changes had disturbed some old memories he cherished. I asked if this was the case, no doubt in a somewhat disheartened tone. He replied, 'Not at all; on the contrary, he had noticed that I had carefully respected every old aspect. In fact, he feared I must have devoted more thought to the matter than it was worth. For instance, how many minutes had I spent arranging this very room?' By the way, could I tell him where a certain book was? I showed him the book on the shelf; he took it down and, retreating to his usual spot by the window, began to read it. Now, I did not like this, reader. St. John was a good man, but I was starting to believe him when he said he was hard and cold. The gentle human interactions and courtesies of life held no appeal for him; its peaceful satisfactions had no charm. He literally lived only to strive—certainly for what was good and great—but still, he would never rest himself, nor approve of others resting around him. As I looked at his high forehead, still and pale as a white stone, and at his sharp features fixed in concentration, I suddenly understood that he would likely not make a good husband; that it would be a very trying experience to be his wife. I understood, as if by inspiration, the true nature of his feelings for Miss Oliver; I agreed with him that it was merely a physical attraction. I understood how he could despise himself for the intense power it held over him; how he would wish to suppress and eliminate it; how he would doubt it could ever lead to lasting happiness for him or her. I saw he was made of the stuff from which nature creates her heroes—Christian and pagan—her lawgivers, her statesmen, her conquerors: a steady foundation for important causes to rely upon; but, by the fireplace, too often a cold, awkward pillar, looking grim and out of place. I reflected that this living room was not his proper element. The Himalayan peak or the African bush, even the plague-ridden swamp on the Guinea Coast, would suit him better. No wonder he avoids the peace of domestic life; it is not his sphere. There, his abilities stagnate; they cannot develop or show themselves to advantage. It is in situations of conflict and danger—where courage is demonstrated, energy is used, and endurance is challenged—that he will speak and act as the leader and superior. A cheerful child would be more at ease than he is on this hearth. He is right to choose a missionary's career—I see it clearly now.

I realized his feelings for Miss Oliver were only physical, and he resented the power those emotions held over him. events.title: Joyful Reunion with Diana and Mary, and St. John's Dutiful Sick Call
detailed_summary: Hannah burst in to announce the arrival of Diana and Mary, an event heralded by Carlo the dog's joyful barking.
Jane eagerly ran out to meet her cousins, and they exchanged warm, affectionate greetings and embraces under their bonnets.
Though weary and cold from their long journey from Whitcross, Diana and Mary's spirits were high, and they quickly moved into the welcoming warmth of the house.
They immediately asked for St. John, who then came out from the parlour to meet them.
He greeted each sister with a subdued kiss and a few quiet words of welcome, then, after a brief interaction, withdrew back to the parlour as if seeking refuge.

After Diana attended to hospitable arrangements for the driver, both sisters followed Jane upstairs and were genuinely delighted with the renovations and decorations in their rooms, expressing their appreciation without reservation.

The evening was characterized by Diana and Mary's animated storytelling and commentary, which effectively overshadowed St. John's characteristic reserve; he was genuinely pleased to see his sisters but seemed unable to partake in their exuberant joy.

Later that night, around nine o'clock, a young boy arrived with an urgent request for Mr. Rivers to visit his mother, who was dying nearly four miles away across treacherous moorland on a harsh, windy night.
Despite Hannah's concerns about the perilous journey and the severe weather, St. John promptly prepared to leave, showing no hesitation.

He departed without a word of objection and returned close to midnight, extremely tired and famished, yet appearing more content than when he left, having fulfilled a demanding duty and reaffirmed his inner strength.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “They are coming! they are coming!” cried Hannah, throwing open the parlour door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had performed an act of duty; made an exertion; felt his own strength to do and deny, and was on better terms with himself.

events.text_segment:
“They are coming! they are coming!” cried Hannah, throwing open the parlour door. At the same moment old Carlo barked joyfully. Out I ran. It was now dark; but a rumbling of wheels was audible. Hannah soon had a lantern lit. The vehicle had stopped at the wicket; the driver opened the door: first one well-known form, then another, stepped out. In a minute I had my face under their bonnets, in contact first with Mary’s soft cheek, then with Diana’s flowing curls. They laughed—kissed me—then Hannah: patted Carlo, who was half wild with delight; asked eagerly if all was well; and being assured in the affirmative, hastened into the house.
They were stiff with their long and jolting drive from Whitcross, and chilled with the frosty night air; but their pleasant countenances expanded to the cheerful firelight. While the driver and Hannah brought in the boxes, they demanded St. John. At this moment he advanced from the parlour. They both threw their arms round his neck at once. He gave each one quiet kiss, said in a low tone a few words of welcome, stood a while to be talked to, and then, intimating that he supposed they would soon rejoin him in the parlour, withdrew there as to a place of refuge.
I had lit their candles to go upstairs, but Diana had first to give hospitable orders respecting the driver; this done, both followed me. They were delighted with the renovation and decorations of their rooms; with the new drapery, and fresh carpets, and rich tinted china vases: they expressed their gratification ungrudgingly. I had the pleasure of feeling that my arrangements met their wishes exactly, and that what I had done added a vivid charm to their joyous return home.
Sweet was that evening. My cousins, full of exhilaration, were so eloquent in narrative and comment, that their fluency covered St. John’s taciturnity: he was sincerely glad to see his sisters; but in their glow of fervour and flow of joy he could not sympathise. The event of the day—that is, the return of Diana and Mary—pleased him; but the accompaniments of that event, the glad tumult, the garrulous glee of reception irked him: I saw he wished the calmer morrow was come. In the very meridian of the night’s enjoyment, about an hour after tea, a rap was heard at the door. Hannah entered with the intimation that “a poor lad was come, at that unlikely time, to fetch Mr. Rivers to see his mother, who was drawing away.”
“Where does she live, Hannah?”
“Clear up at Whitcross Brow, almost four miles off, and moor and moss all the way.”
“Tell him I will go.”
“I’m sure, sir, you had better not. It’s the worst road to travel after dark that can be: there’s no track at all over the bog. And then it is such a bitter night—the keenest wind you ever felt. You had better send word, sir, that you will be there in the morning.”
But he was already in the passage, putting on his cloak; and without one objection, one murmur, he departed. It was then nine o’clock: he did not return till midnight. Starved and tired enough he was: but he looked happier than when he set out. He had performed an act of duty; made an exertion; felt his own strength to do and deny, and was on better terms with himself.

"They are coming! They are coming!" Hannah exclaimed as she flung open the parlour door. At that instant, old Carlo barked with happiness. I rushed outside. It was already dark, but I could hear the sound of approaching wheels. Hannah quickly lit a lantern. The carriage had stopped at the gate; the driver opened the door and two familiar figures emerged. In moments, I was embracing them, first pressing my face to Mary’s soft cheek, then to Diana’s wavy hair. They were stiff from their long, bumpy journey from Whitcross and cold from the frosty night air, but their faces brightened at the sight of the cheerful fire. While the driver and Hannah carried in the luggage, they asked for St. John. At that moment, he came out of the parlour. Both girls immediately hugged him around the neck. He quietly kissed each sister, greeted them softly, stood with them a short while, and then, signaling that they would find him in the parlour, withdrew there to enjoy some solitude.

I had already lit candles for them to go upstairs, but Diana paused to give kind instructions for the driver’s comfort; once that was done, both followed me. They were delighted with the improvements and decorations in their rooms—the new curtains, fresh carpets, and colourful china vases—and expressed their pleasure warmly. I was pleased that my efforts suited their tastes, and that my preparations had made their homecoming even more joyful.

That evening was a happy one. My cousins, bubbling with excitement, were wonderfully talkative and entertaining, which helped to make up for St. John’s quietness. He was genuinely pleased to see his sisters, but he couldn’t quite share their lively joy. He was happy about their return, but the noise and exuberant atmosphere did not suit him, and I could tell he wished for the calmer day to come. In the midst of the cheerful evening, about an hour after tea, there was a knock at the door. Hannah entered to announce that a poor boy had come, at that late hour, to ask Mr. Rivers to visit his mother, who was near death.

"Where does she live, Hannah?"

"Up at Whitcross Brow, nearly four miles away, across moor and marsh all the way."

"Tell him I will go."

"I’m sure, sir, it’s not wise. It’s a terrible road after dark—there isn’t even a proper path across the bog. And it’s such a bitter night, with the coldest wind you can imagine. Perhaps it would be better if you sent word that you’ll come in the morning."

But he was already in the hall, putting on his cloak, and without a word of complaint, he left. It was nine o’clock then; he didn’t return until midnight. He came back cold and exhausted, but looking happier than when he’d left; he had done his duty, made a sincere effort, proven his own resolve to act and endure, and felt more at peace with himself.

events.title: Christmas Festivities, St. John's Aloofness, and News of Rosamond Oliver's Engagement
detailed_summary: Jane suspected that the entirely festive and unstructured nature of the ensuing Christmas week severely tested St. John's patience.

The liberating atmosphere of home and their improved circumstances had an uplifting effect on Diana and Mary, who were cheerful and engaging from morning till night, their witty and original conversation being a source of great pleasure for Jane.
St. John did not openly criticize their vivacity but frequently distanced himself by attending to his pastoral duties in his large and scattered parish.

During breakfast one morning, Diana, after a period of pensiveness, inquired if St. John's plans regarding his missionary work remained the same; he affirmed that they were fixed and unalterable, announcing his definitive departure from England in the coming year.
Mary then let slip a mention of Rosamond Oliver, a comment she immediately seemed to regret.

St. John, pausing his customary mealtime reading, calmly informed them that Rosamond Oliver was engaged to marry Mr. Granby, a man of excellent connections and heir to Sir Frederic Granby, news he had received from her father the previous day.
His sisters and Jane exchanged looks, then all observed St. John, who remained perfectly composed.
Diana remarked that the engagement must have been arranged very quickly.

Later, Jane considered asking St. John if this news caused him any distress but ultimately decided against it, recognizing his apparent self-sufficiency and noting the increasing emotional chasm between them, despite their formal kinship.

She mused that since being acknowledged as his relative and living under the same roof, the distance between them felt even greater than when she was merely the village schoolmistress, finding his current frigidity hard to reconcile with his past confidence in her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I am afraid the whole of the ensuing week tried his patience.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When I remembered how far I had once been admitted to his confidence, I could hardly comprehend his present frigidity.

events.text_segment:
I am afraid the whole of the ensuing week tried his patience. It was Christmas week: we took to no settled employment, but spent it in a sort of merry domestic dissipation. The air of the moors, the freedom of home, the dawn of prosperity, acted on Diana and Mary’s spirits like some life-giving elixir: they were gay from morning till noon, and from noon till night. They could always talk; and their discourse, witty, pithy, original, had such charms for me, that I preferred listening to, and sharing in it, to doing anything else. St. John did not rebuke our vivacity; but he escaped from it: he was seldom in the house; his parish was large, the population scattered, and he found daily business in visiting the sick and poor in its different districts.
One morning at breakfast, Diana, after looking a little pensive for some minutes, asked him, “If his plans were yet unchanged.”
“Unchanged and unchangeable,” was the reply. And he proceeded to inform us that his departure from England was now definitively fixed for the ensuing year.
“And Rosamond Oliver?” suggested Mary, the words seeming to escape her lips involuntarily: for no sooner had she uttered them, than she made a gesture as if wishing to recall them. St. John had a book in his hand—it was his unsocial custom to read at meals—he closed it, and looked up.
“Rosamond Oliver,” said he, “is about to be married to Mr. Granby, one of the best connected and most estimable residents in S——, grandson and heir to Sir Frederic Granby: I had the intelligence from her father yesterday.”
His sisters looked at each other and at me; we all three looked at him: he was serene as glass.
“The match must have been got up hastily,” said Diana: “they cannot have known each other long.”
“But two months: they met in October at the county ball at S——. But where there are no obstacles to a union, as in the present case, where the connection is in every point desirable, delays are unnecessary: they will be married as soon as S—— Place, which Sir Frederic gives up to them, can be refitted for their reception.”
The first time I found St. John alone after this communication, I felt tempted to inquire if the event distressed him: but he seemed so little to need sympathy, that, so far from venturing to offer him more, I experienced some shame at the recollection of what I had already hazarded. Besides, I was out of practice in talking to him: his reserve was again frozen over, and my frankness was congealed beneath it. He had not kept his promise of treating me like his sisters; he continually made little chilling differences between us, which did not at all tend to the development of cordiality: in short, now that I was acknowledged his kinswoman, and lived under the same roof with him, I felt the distance between us to be far greater than when he had known me only as the village schoolmistress. When I remembered how far I had once been admitted to his confidence, I could hardly comprehend his present frigidity.

events.title: St. John's Mysterious 'Victory' and Imposition of Hindostanee Studies
detailed_summary: Jane was taken by surprise when St. John, looking up from his desk, suddenly declared to her, "You see, Jane, the battle is fought and the victory won."

After a moment of hesitation, Jane cautiously questioned whether his triumph might have been too costly, but he dismissed this, asserting that the conflict's outcome was decisive and his path forward was now clear.

As their collective happiness settled into a more tranquil routine, St. John began spending more time in the same room with Jane, Diana, and Mary, often silently observing them as they engaged in their respective studies—Mary drawing, Diana reading encyclopedias, and Jane studying German.

Jane became aware of his habit of looking up from his Eastern language studies to watch them with a curious intensity, and she particularly noted his consistent satisfaction regarding her weekly visits to Morton school, especially his encouragement for her to go even in inclement weather, praising her resilience.

One afternoon, while Jane was at home recovering from a cold and reading Schiller, she realized St. John's ever-watchful blue eye was fixed on her, its gaze so keen and cold it made her feel superstitious.
He then abruptly instructed her to abandon her German studies and instead learn Hindostanee.

He explained his reasoning: teaching her the rudiments of Hindostanee would reinforce his own learning process for the language, which he found challenging to retain. He had chosen her over his sisters for this task because he perceived her as having the greatest capacity for sustained effort.

Feeling the unspoken pressure of his personality, Jane acquiesced to his request. When Diana and Mary returned, they laughingly agreed that St. John would never have convinced them to undertake such a demanding study.

Jane discovered St. John to be a very patient and forbearing, yet simultaneously exacting, teacher. He gradually established a significant influence over her, which she felt curtailed her mental freedom; his praise and attention became more restrictive than his previous indifference.

She found herself increasingly aware of his disapproval of her natural vivacity, falling under a "freezing spell" where she felt compelled to obey his commands—"go," "come," "do this"—but deeply resented this servitude, often wishing he had remained neglectful of her.

events.text_segment:
Such being the case, I felt not a little surprised when he raised his head suddenly from the desk over which he was stooping, and said—
“You see, Jane, the battle is fought and the victory won.”
Startled at being thus addressed, I did not immediately reply: after a moment’s hesitation I answered—
“But are you sure you are not in the position of those conquerors whose triumphs have cost them too dear? Would not such another ruin you?”
“I think not; and if I were, it does not much signify; I shall never be called upon to contend for such another. The event of the conflict is decisive: my way is now clear; I thank God for it!” So saying, he returned to his papers and his silence.
As our mutual happiness (i.e., Diana’s, Mary’s, and mine) settled into a quieter character, and we resumed our usual habits and regular studies, St. John stayed more at home: he sat with us in the same room, sometimes for hours together. While Mary drew, Diana pursued a course of encyclopædic reading she had (to my awe and amazement) undertaken, and I fagged away at German, he pondered a mystic lore of his own: that of some Eastern tongue, the acquisition of which he thought necessary to his plans.
Thus engaged, he appeared, sitting in his own recess, quiet and absorbed enough; but that blue eye of his had a habit of leaving the outlandish-looking grammar, and wandering over, and sometimes fixing upon us, his fellow-students, with a curious intensity of observation: if caught, it would be instantly withdrawn; yet ever and anon, it returned searchingly to our table. I wondered what it meant: I wondered, too, at the punctual satisfaction he never failed to exhibit on an occasion that seemed to me of small moment, namely, my weekly visit to Morton school; and still more was I puzzled when, if the day was unfavourable, if there was snow, or rain, or high wind, and his sisters urged me not to go, he would invariably make light of their solicitude, and encourage me to accomplish the task without regard to the elements.
“Jane is not such a weakling as you would make her,” he would say: “she can bear a mountain blast, or a shower, or a few flakes of snow, as well as any of us. Her constitution is both sound and elastic;—better calculated to endure variations of climate than many more robust.”
And when I returned, sometimes a good deal tired, and not a little weather-beaten, I never dared complain, because I saw that to murmur would be to vex him: on all occasions fortitude pleased him; the reverse was a special annoyance.
One afternoon, however, I got leave to stay at home, because I really had a cold. His sisters were gone to Morton in my stead: I sat reading Schiller; he, deciphering his crabbed Oriental scrolls. As I exchanged a translation for an exercise, I happened to look his way: there I found myself under the influence of the ever-watchful blue eye. How long it had been searching me through and through, and over and over, I cannot tell: so keen was it, and yet so cold, I felt for the moment superstitious—as if I were sitting in the room with something uncanny.
“Jane, what are you doing?”
“Learning German.”
“I want you to give up German and learn Hindostanee.”
“You are not in earnest?”
“In such earnest that I must have it so: and I will tell you why.”
He then went on to explain that Hindostanee was the language he was himself at present studying; that, as he advanced, he was apt to forget the commencement; that it would assist him greatly to have a pupil with whom he might again and again go over the elements, and so fix them thoroughly in his mind; that his choice had hovered for some time between me and his sisters; but that he had fixed on me because he saw I could sit at a task the longest of the three. Would I do him this favour? I should not, perhaps, have to make the sacrifice long, as it wanted now barely three months to his departure.
St. John was not a man to be lightly refused: you felt that every impression made on him, either for pain or pleasure, was deep-graved and permanent. I consented. When Diana and Mary returned, the former found her scholar transferred from her to her brother: she laughed, and both she and Mary agreed that St. John should never have persuaded them to such a step. He answered quietly—
“I know it.”
I found him a very patient, very forbearing, and yet an exacting master: he expected me to do a great deal; and when I fulfilled his expectations, he, in his own way, fully testified his approbation. By degrees, he acquired a certain influence over me that took away my liberty of mind: his praise and notice were more restraining than his indifference. I could no longer talk or laugh freely when he was by, because a tiresomely importunate instinct reminded me that vivacity (at least in me) was distasteful to him. I was so fully aware that only serious moods and occupations were acceptable, that in his presence every effort to sustain or follow any other became vain: I fell under a freezing spell. When he said “go,” I went; “come,” I came; “do this,” I did it. But I did not love my servitude: I wished, many a time, he had continued to neglect me.

events.title: The 'Experiment Kiss', Jane's Inner Conflict, and Unanswered Pleas for News of Rochester
detailed_summary: One evening, as Jane and his sisters bid St. John goodnight, Diana, in a playful mood, pointed out that he called Jane his third sister but didn't treat her as such, urging him to kiss Jane too.

St. John complied, bending his head and delivering a kiss that Jane perceived as an "experiment kiss," cold and emotionless, feeling like a symbolic confirmation of her growing subservience to him. This became a nightly ritual, performed with gravity by him and endured with quiescence by her.

Jane found herself increasingly driven to please St. John, yet she felt that doing so necessitated the suppression of half her personality and talents, forcing her to strive for an ideal she could never attain, which caused her constant distress.
Compounding her unhappiness was a persistent, gnawing anxiety about Mr. Rochester's fate, a suspense that drained her happiness.
She had never forgotten Mr. Rochester; his memory was an indelible part of her, and the desire to know his whereabouts and condition was a constant preoccupation.
Her inquiries to Mr. Briggs during their correspondence about her inheritance had yielded no information, as St. John had predicted.
Subsequently, she wrote to Mrs. Fairfax seeking news, initially confident of receiving a swift reply. However, weeks turned into two months without any word, plunging Jane into profound anxiety.

She wrote a second letter, hoping the first had been lost, and experienced a brief renewal of hope, but this too faded as no response came. After six months of futile waiting, her hope finally extinguished, leaving her in a state of deep despair.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One evening when, at bedtime, his sisters and I stood round him, bidding him good-night, he kissed each of them, as was his custom; and, as was equally his custom, he gave me his hand.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When half a year wasted in vain expectancy, my hope died out, and then I felt dark indeed.

events.text_segment:
One evening when, at bedtime, his sisters and I stood round him, bidding him good-night, he kissed each of them, as was his custom; and, as was equally his custom, he gave me his hand. Diana, who chanced to be in a frolicsome humour (she was not painfully controlled by his will; for hers, in another way, was as strong), exclaimed—
“St. John! you used to call Jane your third sister, but you don’t treat her as such: you should kiss her too.”
She pushed me towards him. I thought Diana very provoking, and felt uncomfortably confused; and while I was thus thinking and feeling, St. John bent his head; his Greek face was brought to a level with mine, his eyes questioned my eyes piercingly—he kissed me. There are no such things as marble kisses or ice kisses, or I should say my ecclesiastical cousin’s salute belonged to one of these classes; but there may be experiment kisses, and his was an experiment kiss. When given, he viewed me to learn the result; it was not striking: I am sure I did not blush; perhaps I might have turned a little pale, for I felt as if this kiss were a seal affixed to my fetters. He never omitted the ceremony afterwards, and the gravity and quiescence with which I underwent it, seemed to invest it for him with a certain charm.
As for me, I daily wished more to please him; but to do so, I felt daily more and more that I must disown half my nature, stifle half my faculties, wrest my tastes from their original bent, force myself to the adoption of pursuits for which I had no natural vocation. He wanted to train me to an elevation I could never reach; it racked me hourly to aspire to the standard he uplifted. The thing was as impossible as to mould my irregular features to his correct and classic pattern, to give to my changeable green eyes the sea-blue tint and solemn lustre of his own.
Not his ascendancy alone, however, held me in thrall at present. Of late it had been easy enough for me to look sad: a cankering evil sat at my heart and drained my happiness at its source—the evil of suspense.
Perhaps you think I had forgotten Mr. Rochester, reader, amidst these changes of place and fortune. Not for a moment. His idea was still with me, because it was not a vapour sunshine could disperse, nor a sand-traced effigy storms could wash away; it was a name graven on a tablet, fated to last as long as the marble it inscribed. The craving to know what had become of him followed me everywhere; when I was at Morton, I re-entered my cottage every evening to think of that; and now at Moor House, I sought my bedroom each night to brood over it.
In the course of my necessary correspondence with Mr. Briggs about the will, I had inquired if he knew anything of Mr. Rochester’s present residence and state of health; but, as St. John had conjectured, he was quite ignorant of all concerning him. I then wrote to Mrs. Fairfax, entreating information on the subject. I had calculated with certainty on this step answering my end: I felt sure it would elicit an early answer. I was astonished when a fortnight passed without reply; but when two months wore away, and day after day the post arrived and brought nothing for me, I fell a prey to the keenest anxiety.
I wrote again: there was a chance of my first letter having missed. Renewed hope followed renewed effort: it shone like the former for some weeks, then, like it, it faded, flickered: not a line, not a word reached me. When half a year wasted in vain expectancy, my hope died out, and then I felt dark indeed.

She gently pushed me towards him. I found Diana quite annoying and felt very flustered. While I was feeling this way, St. John lowered his head, bringing his face to my level. However, there might be experimental kisses, and his felt like one. After kissing me, he watched me to see my reaction. It wasn't dramatic; I definitely didn't blush. In my necessary correspondence with Mr. Briggs about the will, I asked if he knew anything about Mr. Rochester’s current address and health, but, just as St. John had guessed, he was completely unaware of anything concerning him. I then wrote to Mrs. Fairfax, begging for information on the matter. I was absolutely certain this step would succeed in getting me information and felt sure I would receive a prompt reply.
