events.title: Jane's Defiance of a Loveless Marriage, St. John's Ultimatum, and Their Cold Farewell
detailed_summary: Jane reflected that her previous fear of St. John stemmed from not understanding him; now, seeing his fallibilities in this conference, the veil of his perceived hardness and despotism fell, and she felt herself his equal, capable of arguing with and resisting him.

After her sarcastic remark, St. John paused, his expression one of stern surprise and keen inquiry, before gravely reminding her of the solemnity of the matter. He expressed his trust in her earnestness to serve God, arguing that their physical and mental union in marriage would provide significant impetus to their shared divine work, urging her to transcend personal feelings and enter this union.

Jane, internally, recoiled at the thought of being his wife—constantly restrained, her true nature suppressed. While she could endure hardships as his colleague, retaining her inner freedom, the prospect of marital subservience was unendurable.

She exclaimed St. John's name, and when he responded icily, she reiterated her willingness to go with him as a fellow-missionary, but unequivocally not as his wife, stating, "I cannot marry you and become part of you."

St. John steadily replied that she must become part of him, or the entire arrangement was void, citing the impropriety of a young man taking an unmarried young woman to India under such circumstances.
Jane asserted, with some disdain, that it would be perfectly acceptable, and that while she possessed a woman's heart, it held only a comrade's constancy for him, not romantic love.

St. John, speaking more to himself, acknowledged this was what he desired in a helper, but insisted the obstacles—her refusal to marry—must be overcome, repeating that they must marry and that enough love would follow to satisfy even her.
Rising, Jane scornfully rejected his concept of love and him for offering such a counterfeit sentiment.
St. John, masterfully controlling his expression, remarked that he scarcely expected such words from her and believed he had done nothing to merit scorn.
Jane, moved by his gentle tone, apologized for her unguarded words but attributed them to his introduction of the contentious topic of love, urging him to abandon his marriage scheme.

St. John refused, calling it a long-cherished plan essential to his ultimate goal. He announced his departure for Cambridge for a fortnight, granting her that time to reconsider his proposal, and delivered a final, solemn warning: rejecting his offer was tantamount to denying God and condemning herself to a life of selfish ease and barren obscurity, risking being numbered among infidels.

He then turned away, his silence conveying his profound disappointment and disapproval of her resistance. Jane understood his struggle: as a man, he wished to coerce her, but as a Christian, he patiently allowed her time for reflection.
That night, St. John pointedly omitted even shaking Jane's hand after kissing his sisters, a marked omission that deeply hurt her, bringing tears to her eyes.
Diana noticed the tension and encouraged Jane to reconcile with St. John, saying he was lingering in the passage expecting her.
Valuing happiness over dignity, Jane approached St. John at the foot of the stairs and bid him good-night. He replied calmly.

When she prompted him to shake hands, his touch was cold and loose, indicative of his deep displeasure. No warm reconciliation occurred; he remained patient and placid but unmoved. When asked if he forgave her, he stated he didn't cherish vexations and, not having been offended, had nothing to forgive.
His detached answer left Jane feeling desolate, wishing he had reacted with anger instead.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I will not swear, reader, that there was not something of repressed sarcasm both in the tone in which I uttered this sentence, and in the feeling that accompanied it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And with that answer he left me. I would much rather he had knocked me down.

events.text_segment:
I will not swear, reader, that there was not something of repressed sarcasm both in the tone in which I uttered this sentence, and in the feeling that accompanied it. I had silently feared St. John till now, because I had not understood him. He had held me in awe, because he had held me in doubt. How much of him was saint, how much mortal, I could not heretofore tell: but revelations were being made in this conference: the analysis of his nature was proceeding before my eyes. I saw his fallibilities: I comprehended them. I understood that, sitting there where I did, on the bank of heath, and with that handsome form before me, I sat at the feet of a man, erring as I. The veil fell from his hardness and despotism. Having felt in him the presence of these qualities, I felt his imperfection and took courage. I was with an equal—one with whom I might argue—one whom, if I saw good, I might resist.
He was silent after I had uttered the last sentence, and I presently risked an upward glance at his countenance. His eye, bent on me, expressed at once stern surprise and keen inquiry. “Is she sarcastic, and sarcastic to me!” it seemed to say. “What does this signify?”
“Do not let us forget that this is a solemn matter,” he said ere long; “one of which we may neither think nor talk lightly without sin. I trust, Jane, you are in earnest when you say you will serve your heart to God: it is all I want. Once wrench your heart from man, and fix it on your Maker, the advancement of that Maker’s spiritual kingdom on earth will be your chief delight and endeavour; you will be ready to do at once whatever furthers that end. You will see what impetus would be given to your efforts and mine by our physical and mental union in marriage: the only union that gives a character of permanent conformity to the destinies and designs of human beings; and, passing over all minor caprices—all trivial difficulties and delicacies of feeling—all scruple about the degree, kind, strength or tenderness of mere personal inclination—you will hasten to enter into that union at once.”
“Shall I?” I said briefly; and I looked at his features, beautiful in their harmony, but strangely formidable in their still severity; at his brow, commanding but not open; at his eyes, bright and deep and searching, but never soft; at his tall imposing figure; and fancied myself in idea his wife. Oh! it would never do! As his curate, his comrade, all would be right: I would cross oceans with him in that capacity; toil under Eastern suns, in Asian deserts with him in that office; admire and emulate his courage and devotion and vigour; accommodate quietly to his masterhood; smile undisturbed at his ineradicable ambition; discriminate the Christian from the man: profoundly esteem the one, and freely forgive the other. I should suffer often, no doubt, attached to him only in this capacity: my body would be under rather a stringent yoke, but my heart and mind would be free. I should still have my unblighted self to turn to: my natural unenslaved feelings with which to communicate in moments of loneliness. There would be recesses in my mind which would be only mine, to which he never came, and sentiments growing there fresh and sheltered which his austerity could never blight, nor his measured warrior-march trample down: but as his wife—at his side always, and always restrained, and always checked—forced to keep the fire of my nature continually low, to compel it to burn inwardly and never utter a cry, though the imprisoned flame consumed vital after vital—this would be unendurable.
“St. John!” I exclaimed, when I had got so far in my meditation.
“Well?” he answered icily.
“I repeat I freely consent to go with you as your fellow-missionary, but not as your wife; I cannot marry you and become part of you.”
“A part of me you must become,” he answered steadily; “otherwise the whole bargain is void. How can I, a man not yet thirty, take out with me to India a girl of nineteen, unless she be married to me? How can we be for ever together—sometimes in solitudes, sometimes amidst savage tribes—and unwed?”
“Very well,” I said shortly; “under the circumstances, quite as well as if I were either your real sister, or a man and a clergyman like yourself.”
“It is known that you are not my sister; I cannot introduce you as such: to attempt it would be to fasten injurious suspicions on us both. And for the rest, though you have a man’s vigorous brain, you have a woman’s heart and—it would not do.”
“It would do,” I affirmed with some disdain, “perfectly well. I have a woman’s heart, but not where you are concerned; for you I have only a comrade’s constancy; a fellow-soldier’s frankness, fidelity, fraternity, if you like; a neophyte’s respect and submission to his hierophant: nothing more—don’t fear.”
“It is what I want,” he said, speaking to himself; “it is just what I want. And there are obstacles in the way: they must be hewn down. Jane, you would not repent marrying me—be certain of that; we must be married. I repeat it: there is no other way; and undoubtedly enough of love would follow upon marriage to render the union right even in your eyes.”
“I scorn your idea of love,” I could not help saying, as I rose up and stood before him, leaning my back against the rock. “I scorn the counterfeit sentiment you offer: yes, St. John, and I scorn you when you offer it.”
He looked at me fixedly, compressing his well-cut lips while he did so. Whether he was incensed or surprised, or what, it was not easy to tell: he could command his countenance thoroughly.
“I scarcely expected to hear that expression from you,” he said: “I think I have done and uttered nothing to deserve scorn.”
I was touched by his gentle tone, and overawed by his high, calm mien.
“Forgive me the words, St. John; but it is your own fault that I have been roused to speak so unguardedly. You have introduced a topic on which our natures are at variance—a topic we should never discuss: the very name of love is an apple of discord between us. If the reality were required, what should we do? How should we feel? My dear cousin, abandon your scheme of marriage—forget it.”
“No,” said he; “it is a long-cherished scheme, and the only one which can secure my great end: but I shall urge you no further at present. To-morrow, I leave home for Cambridge: I have many friends there to whom I should wish to say farewell. I shall be absent a fortnight—take that space of time to consider my offer: and do not forget that if you reject it, it is not me you deny, but God. Through my means, He opens to you a noble career; as my wife only can you enter upon it. Refuse to be my wife, and you limit yourself for ever to a track of selfish ease and barren obscurity. Tremble lest in that case you should be numbered with those who have denied the faith, and are worse than infidels!”
He had done. Turning from me, he once more
“Looked to river, looked to hill.”
But this time his feelings were all pent in his heart: I was not worthy to hear them uttered. As I walked by his side homeward, I read well in his iron silence all he felt towards me: the disappointment of an austere and despotic nature, which has met resistance where it expected submission—the disapprobation of a cool, inflexible judgment, which has detected in another feelings and views in which it has no power to sympathise: in short, as a man, he would have wished to coerce me into obedience: it was only as a sincere Christian he bore so patiently with my perversity, and allowed so long a space for reflection and repentance.
That night, after he had kissed his sisters, he thought proper to forget even to shake hands with me, but left the room in silence. I—who, though I had no love, had much friendship for him—was hurt by the marked omission: so much hurt that tears started to my eyes.
“I see you and St. John have been quarrelling, Jane,” said Diana, “during your walk on the moor. But go after him; he is now lingering in the passage expecting you—he will make it up.”
I have not much pride under such circumstances: I would always rather be happy than dignified; and I ran after him—he stood at the foot of the stairs.
“Good-night, St. John,” said I.
“Good-night, Jane,” he replied calmly.
“Then shake hands,” I added.
What a cold, loose touch, he impressed on my fingers! He was deeply displeased by what had occurred that day; cordiality would not warm, nor tears move him. No happy reconciliation was to be had with him—no cheering smile or generous word: but still the Christian was patient and placid; and when I asked him if he forgave me, he answered that he was not in the habit of cherishing the remembrance of vexation; that he had nothing to forgive, not having been offended.
And with that answer he left me. I would much rather he had knocked me down.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Reader, I must admit that when I said that, there was likely a hint of suppressed sarcasm in my tone and the feeling behind it. Until this moment, my fear of St. John was silent because I didn't understand him. He had held me in respectful awe because he had been uncertain about me. Before now, I couldn't tell how much of him was genuinely saintly and how much was merely human; but during this conversation, things were becoming clear. His true nature was being revealed before my eyes. I saw his flaws and understood them. I realized that sitting there on the heath bank, with his handsome figure in front of me, I was in the presence of a man who was as imperfect as I was. The barrier created by his harshness and authoritarianism disappeared. Having recognized these qualities in him, I saw his imperfections and felt emboldened. I was dealing with an equal—someone I could argue with—someone I could even oppose if I thought it right.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I cannot promise, reader, that my previous words and emotions lacked a hint of concealed sarcasm. Until now, I had felt a cautious fear of St. John, which came from not understanding him. He intimidated me because he kept me uncertain. Previously, I could not decipher how much he was a saint and how much a fallible person; but as we conversed, his nature was becoming clearer to me. I saw his flaws and understood them. I realized that, sitting with him on the heath, before this striking figure, I was actually facing a man as prone to fault as myself. The façade of his rigidity and authoritarianism faded. Having sensed these traits in him, I acknowledged his imperfection and found the courage to see myself as his equal—someone who could argue or resist him if I chose. After I spoke, he was quiet for a moment, so I risked looking at his face. His gaze, bent on me, was sternly surprised and probing, as if to ask, “Is she being sarcastic towards me? What does this mean?”

He broke the silence, reminding me gravely that the matter was serious, not to be treated lightly, and hoped that I was sincere in wanting to dedicate my heart to God. That, he said, was all he wanted; once I redirected my heart away from human attachments to my Creator, the advancement of God's spiritual cause on earth would become my chief joy and goal, and I would be eager to do whatever helped that purpose. He insisted that a marriage between us would provide the essential foundation for such a mission, creating a lasting alignment of purpose, and that I should set aside minor feelings or uncertainties and hasten to accept the union.

I replied briefly, studying his face—handsome but intimidating in its unyielding calm, with a commanding brow, perceptive yet unsympathetic eyes, and an imposing figure—and imagined myself as his wife. I concluded that such a role would not suit me. As his assistant and companion, I could work alongside him cheerfully; I would traverse great distances, endure hardships, and admire his courage and energy, accommodating myself to his authority, tolerating his relentless ambition, distinguishing between the devout Christian and the man, esteeming one and forgiving the other. I knew that even as his partner in work, I would sometimes suffer, obeying him outwardly, but my inner self and feelings would remain free and untouched. There would be spaces of my mind he could never reach. However, as his wife—constantly at his side, always restrained—forced to suppress my true nature and keep my feelings hidden, the experience would be intolerable.

"St. John!" I cried, when I had reached this conclusion in my thoughts.

"Well?" he responded coolly.

I reiterated that I would gladly go with him as a fellow missionary, not as his wife; I could not marry and become merged with him.

He insisted that becoming a part of him through marriage was essential—otherwise, there could be no agreement. He could not, as a relatively young man, take a nineteen-year-old girl to India without her being his wife, nor could they live and travel together unwed.

I replied, somewhat curtly, that under such circumstances, it would be as acceptable as if I were his real sister, or a fellow male clergyman.

He pointed out that people knew I was not his sister, and he could not claim otherwise; trying to do so would bring harmful suspicion on both of us. And though I had the mind of a man, I had a woman's heart, and that would be a problem.

I answered dismissively that, when it came to him, I only felt a comrade's loyalty and honesty, a fellow-soldier's bond, and a student’s respect for a mentor—nothing more, so he should not worry.

He muttered to himself that this was what he wanted, but saw obstacles that needed to be dealt with. He was certain I would not regret marrying him, and insisted it must happen; he said enough love would follow to make the marriage proper.

I told him bluntly that I despised the type of love he offered, calling it false sentiment, and admitted I despised him for offering it. He looked at me with compressed lips, controlling his expression so that I could not tell whether he was angry or surprised.

He responded gently, saying he did not expect such words from me and did not believe he had done anything to deserve such scorn.

Moved by his mildness and composure, I apologized, blaming him for provoking me; our natures were too different to discuss love, as it was a source of discord between us. I urged him to give up the idea of marrying me.

He refused, saying it was a plan he had long cherished and the only route to achieving his goal; but he would not press the matter further for now. He was leaving for Cambridge the next day to say farewell to friends. He asked me to use the time while he was away to reconsider, warning that if I refused, it would be not just him but God I would reject. Only as his wife, he said, could I follow the noble path being offered; if I refused, I would remain in selfish comfort and obscurity, perhaps even count among those who deny the faith.

He left me then, turning away to look at the landscape, tightly controlling his emotions. As I walked home with him, I could sense his disappointment and disapproval—he was frustrated by my resistance when he expected submission and, as a man, likely wished he could bend me to his will; only his Christian values allowed him to be so patient and grant me time to reflect.

That night, after he had kissed his sisters, he refused even to shake my hand, leaving the room without a word. Although I lacked romantic love for him, I did esteem him as a friend, and his coldness hurt me deeply.

Diana observed that it seemed we had argued during our walk and encouraged me to reconcile with him; he was waiting in the hallway. Lacking pride in such moments and preferring happiness to dignity, I ran after him, finding him at the bottom of the stairs.

"Good-night, St. John," I said.

"Good-night, Jane," he replied calmly.

I requested a handshake; his touch was cold and indifferent, betraying his displeasure—he could not be warmed by kindness or moved by emotion. There would be no happy reconciliation, but he remained calm and patient. When I asked if he forgave me, he answered that he did not hold onto annoyance and had nothing to forgive. With this response, he left me, and I almost wished he had responded with anger instead.

events.title: St. John's Subtle Retribution and Jane's Isolation
detailed_summary: St. John postpones his planned departure for Cambridge by a full week, during which he subjects Jane to a period of severe emotional punishment for refusing his marriage proposal.
He achieves this without any overt acts of aggression or verbal reprimands, instead making Jane constantly feel that she has been entirely excluded from his good graces.

Jane understands that while St. John might have offered a formal or intellectual forgiveness for her earlier harsh words, he has not truly forgotten them, and they continue to cast a shadow over all their interactions.
His demeanor towards her transforms, becoming cold and devoid of personal warmth, making their conversations feel lifeless and stripped of any previous charm or approval.

Jane perceives this sustained emotional coldness as an exquisite and prolonged form of torment, leading her to feel that St. John's very righteousness could emotionally annihilate her if she were his wife.
Her attempts to bridge the gap and seek reconciliation are met with complete indifference from St. John.

He further emphasizes her isolation by displaying uncharacteristic kindness towards his sisters, Diana and Mary, using contrast to underscore Jane's banishment from his favor, an act Jane attributes to his principles rather than malice.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He did not leave for Cambridge the next day, as he had said he would.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And this I am sure he did not by malice, but on principle.

events.text_segment:
He did not leave for Cambridge the next day, as he had said he would. He deferred his departure a whole week, and during that time he made me feel what severe punishment a good yet stern, a conscientious yet implacable man can inflict on one who has offended him. Without one overt act of hostility, one upbraiding word, he contrived to impress me momently with the conviction that I was put beyond the pale of his favour.
Not that St. John harboured a spirit of unchristian vindictiveness—not that he would have injured a hair of my head, if it had been fully in his power to do so. Both by nature and principle, he was superior to the mean gratification of vengeance: he had forgiven me for saying I scorned him and his love, but he had not forgotten the words; and as long as he and I lived he never would forget them. I saw by his look, when he turned to me, that they were always written on the air between me and him; whenever I spoke, they sounded in my voice to his ear, and their echo toned every answer he gave me.
He did not abstain from conversing with me: he even called me as usual each morning to join him at his desk; and I fear the corrupt man within him had a pleasure unimparted to, and unshared by, the pure Christian, in evincing with what skill he could, while acting and speaking apparently just as usual, extract from every deed and every phrase the spirit of interest and approval which had formerly communicated a certain austere charm to his language and manner. To me, he was in reality become no longer flesh, but marble; his eye was a cold, bright, blue gem; his tongue a speaking instrument—nothing more.
All this was torture to me—refined, lingering torture. It kept up a slow fire of indignation and a trembling trouble of grief, which harassed and crushed me altogether. I felt how—if I were his wife, this good man, pure as the deep sunless source, could soon kill me, without drawing from my veins a single drop of blood, or receiving on his own crystal conscience the faintest stain of crime. Especially I felt this when I made any attempt to propitiate him. No ruth met my ruth. He experienced no suffering from estrangement—no yearning after reconciliation; and though, more than once, my fast falling tears blistered the page over which we both bent, they produced no more effect on him than if his heart had been really a matter of stone or metal. To his sisters, meantime, he was somewhat kinder than usual: as if afraid that mere coldness would not sufficiently convince me how completely I was banished and banned, he added the force of contrast; and this I am sure he did not by malice, but on principle.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: St. John delayed his scheduled departure for Cambridge, remaining for an entire week. During this period, he demonstrated the profound emotional distress that a virtuous but unyielding, principled yet inflexible individual can inflict upon someone who has offended them. Without resorting to open hostility or a single critical word, he managed to continuously impress upon me the certainty that I was completely excluded from his favor. This was not because St. John possessed an un-Christian desire for vengeance or would have harmed me physically had he the power. Both his character and beliefs elevated him above the petty satisfaction of retaliation. He had forgiven me for saying I scorned him and his feelings, but he had not forgotten my words, and he would never forget them as long as we both lived. I could see in his gaze when he looked at me that they were perpetually present between us; whenever I spoke, those words seemed to echo in my voice to his ears, and their reverberation colored every response he gave me. He did not cease speaking with me; he even maintained our routine of calling me to join him at his desk each morning. I suspect that a less pure, possibly flawed, part of his nature found a hidden pleasure, unshared by his pure Christian self, in displaying the skill with which he could, while acting and speaking seemingly as usual, remove all warmth of interest and approval from every action and word – a warmth that had previously given his manner a certain reserved appeal. To me, he felt no longer human, but like cold stone; his eye was a frigid, sparkling blue jewel, and his tongue merely an instrument for speech, nothing more. This entire experience was agonizing – a subtle, drawn-out torment. It fueled a slow-burning resentment and a painful, trembling sorrow that overwhelmed and crushed me. I understood how, if I were married to him, this good man, pure as a hidden spring, could quickly destroy me emotionally without shedding a drop of my blood or staining his clear conscience with the slightest sense of wrongdoing. This feeling was particularly strong when I attempted to make amends. My suffering met with no compassion from him. He showed no distress over our estrangement and no desire for reconciliation. And although, on more than one occasion, my rapidly falling tears marked the page we were both leaning over, they had no more impact on him than if his heart were literally made of rock or metal. Meanwhile, he was notably kinder to his sisters than usual. As if concerned that mere coldness wouldn't adequately convey how completely I was banished and excluded, he emphasized this by contrast, and I am certain he did this based on principle, not malice.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He did not depart for Cambridge the following day as he had planned; instead, he postponed his journey for a full week. During this period, he showed me how harsh a punishment a sincere but strict, principled but relentless man can inflict without resorting to direct anger or words of reproach. With subtle behavior alone, he continually made me feel as if I had been excluded from his approval. 

It was not out of an unchristian desire for revenge—St. John would never harm me, even if he had the authority to do so. He was naturally and morally above petty vengeance; although he had forgiven my rejection of him and his love, he could not forget those words, and I knew he never would. His eyes told me the memory lingered between us, coloring every exchange and shaping his responses regardless of what I said.

He did not avoid conversation with me; every morning he invited me as usual to his desk. Yet I suspected a part of him, less than pure, took pleasure in demonstrating how skillfully he could behave normally while simultaneously withdrawing every sign of interest or approval that once gave his demeanor a dignified appeal. To me, he seemed transformed from a man of flesh to one of stone—his gaze icy, his speech mechanical.

This quiet coldness mortified me; it tormented me slowly and left me overwhelmed with grief and frustration. I realized that, had I been his wife, his goodness—so pure, yet so unyielding—could destroy me without physical harm or a blemish on his conscience. This was especially clear whenever I tried to reconcile with him. My efforts were met with no compassion; he did not seem to suffer from our estrangement or long for a repair in our relationship. Even as my tears fell onto our shared work, they left him unmoved, as though he truly had a heart of stone or metal. Meanwhile, he treated his sisters more kindly than normal, as if to show—by contrast with his treatment toward me—just how thoroughly I was cast out. I believe he did this not out of spite, but because it was his chosen, principled course of action.

events.title: A Final, Fruitless Plea for Friendship
detailed_summary: On the evening preceding St. John's departure, Jane, moved by the memory of him saving her life and their kinship, decides to make a final effort to restore their friendship.
She approaches him in the garden as he leans over a gate, directly stating her unhappiness due to his continued anger and her desire for them to be friends.
St. John responds with detachment, claiming he hopes they are friends and wishes her no harm, all while his attention remains fixed on the rising moon.

Jane presses the point, asserting that their current relationship is not the friendship they once shared and that she, as his relative, hopes for more genuine affection than his general benevolence towards strangers.
He concedes that her wish is reasonable and that he does not view her as a stranger, but his cool and tranquil delivery of these words feels dismissive and perplexing to Jane.
Despite feelings of pride and anger urging her to leave, Jane's deep respect for St. John's character and principles, and the value she places on his friendship, compel her to persist.
She questions if they must truly separate on such terms and if he intends to leave for India without offering any kinder farewell.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night before he left home, happening to see him walking in the garden about sunset, and remembering, as I looked at him, that this man, alienated as he now was, had once saved my life, and that we were near relations, I was moved to make a last attempt to regain his friendship.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And when you go to India, will you leave me so, without a kinder word than you have yet spoken?”

events.text_segment:
The night before he left home, happening to see him walking in the garden about sunset, and remembering, as I looked at him, that this man, alienated as he now was, had once saved my life, and that we were near relations, I was moved to make a last attempt to regain his friendship. I went out and approached him as he stood leaning over the little gate; I spoke to the point at once.
“St. John, I am unhappy because you are still angry with me. Let us be friends.”
“I hope we are friends,” was the unmoved reply; while he still watched the rising of the moon, which he had been contemplating as I approached.
“No, St. John, we are not friends as we were. You know that.”
“Are we not? That is wrong. For my part, I wish you no ill and all good.”
“I believe you, St. John; for I am sure you are incapable of wishing any one ill; but, as I am your kinswoman, I should desire somewhat more of affection than that sort of general philanthropy you extend to mere strangers.”
“Of course,” he said. “Your wish is reasonable, and I am far from regarding you as a stranger.”
This, spoken in a cool, tranquil tone, was mortifying and baffling enough. Had I attended to the suggestions of pride and ire, I should immediately have left him; but something worked within me more strongly than those feelings could. I deeply venerated my cousin’s talent and principle. His friendship was of value to me: to lose it tried me severely. I would not so soon relinquish the attempt to reconquer it.
“Must we part in this way, St. John? And when you go to India, will you leave me so, without a kinder word than you have yet spoken?”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The evening before his departure, I saw him in the garden as the sun was setting. As I watched him, I remembered that this man, with whom I was now distant, had once saved my life, and that we were close relatives. This memory prompted me to try one last time to restore our friendship. I went out and approached him as he leaned by the small gate, speaking my mind immediately. "St. John," I said, "I'm unhappy because you're still upset with me. Let's be friends again." His reply was calm and unaffected: "I hope we are friends." He continued watching the moon rise, just as he had been doing when I came near. "No, St. John," I insisted, "we aren't friends like we used to be. You know that." "Aren't we? That's not right. For my part, I wish you no harm and only good things." "I believe you, St. John," I replied, "because I'm sure you couldn't wish anyone ill. But as your cousin, I'd prefer a bit more affection than the general kindness you show to strangers." "Of course," he said. "Your wish is reasonable, and I certainly don't consider you a stranger." This reply, delivered in a cool, quiet tone, was quite disheartening and frustrating. If I had followed the dictates of my pride and anger, I would have left him immediately. But something inside me was stronger than those feelings. I had deep respect for my cousin's abilities and principles. His friendship was precious to me, and losing it was very painful. I wasn't ready to give up trying to mend it so soon. "Must we say goodbye like this, St. John? And when you go to India, will you leave me without a warmer word than you've spoken so far?"
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
The evening before he was to leave, I saw him in the garden at sunset. As I watched him, I remembered that despite our current estrangement, he had once saved my life and we were close relatives. I felt compelled to try once more to restore our friendship. I went outside and found him leaning on the garden gate, and I addressed the issue directly. 

“St. John, I’m distressed that you’re still upset with me. Can we make peace?”
He answered, without emotion, that he hoped we were friends, not looking away from the moon he was observing as I came up.

"No, St. John, we’re not as close as we used to be. You know that,” I said.
He replied, “Aren’t we? That shouldn’t be. I harbor no ill will toward you and wish you only well.”

I responded, “I believe you mean that, St. John; I know you can’t wish harm on anyone. But since we’re family, I would hope for more warmth and affection than you show to strangers.”

He acknowledged, “Of course. That’s reasonable, and I certainly don’t see you as a stranger.”

But he said this calmly and coolly, which left me feeling hurt and frustrated. My pride and anger urged me to leave, but something deeper made me stay. I greatly admired my cousin’s talents and morals, and his companionship mattered to me. Losing it was painful, so I wasn’t ready to give up just yet.

“Is this how we’re going to part ways, St. John? Will you leave for India without even a kinder word than you’ve given now?”

events.title: Escalating Confrontation and Painful Accusations
detailed_summary: St. John fully turns to Jane, questioning her assumption that she will not be accompanying him to India.
He directly asks if she remains firm in her decision not to marry him.
Jane, sensing the intimidating coldness in his query, affirms her resolution.

When St. John presses her again for her reasons, Jane explains that initially it was because he did not love her, but now it is also because she feels he almost hates her and that marrying him would be emotionally destructive for her, stating he is already 'killing' her.

This accusation causes St. John to turn visibly pale; he denounces her words as extreme, unfeminine, and false, suggesting they stem from an unfortunate mental state but adding that it is a man's duty to forgive repeatedly.
Jane realizes with despair that instead of mending the offense, she has inflicted a new, deeper wound.
She expresses her fear that she has now made an irreconcilable enemy of him.
Observing the subtle tremor in his lip, Jane understands the truth in her words has caused him pain. She impulsively grasps his hand, trying to assure him she had no intention of causing him grief.
St. John responds with a bitter smile, decisively withdraws his hand, and after a significant pause, coldly inquires if she is now retracting her offer to go to India entirely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He now turned quite from the moon and faced me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “And now you recall your promise, and will not go to India at all, I presume?” said he, after a considerable pause.

events.text_segment:
He now turned quite from the moon and faced me.
“When I go to India, Jane, will I leave you! What! do you not go to India?”
“You said I could not unless I married you.”
“And you will not marry me! You adhere to that resolution?”
Reader, do you know, as I do, what terror those cold people can put into the ice of their questions? How much of the fall of the avalanche is in their anger? of the breaking up of the frozen sea in their displeasure?
“No. St. John, I will not marry you. I adhere to my resolution.”
The avalanche had shaken and slid a little forward, but it did not yet crash down.
“Once more, why this refusal?” he asked.
“Formerly,” I answered, “because you did not love me; now, I reply, because you almost hate me. If I were to marry you, you would kill me. You are killing me now.”
His lips and cheeks turned white—quite white.
“I should kill you—I am killing you? Your words are such as ought not to be used: violent, unfeminine, and untrue. They betray an unfortunate state of mind: they merit severe reproof: they would seem inexcusable, but that it is the duty of man to forgive his fellow even until seventy-and-seven times.”
I had finished the business now. While earnestly wishing to erase from his mind the trace of my former offence, I had stamped on that tenacious surface another and far deeper impression: I had burnt it in.
“Now you will indeed hate me,” I said. “It is useless to attempt to conciliate you: I see I have made an eternal enemy of you.”
A fresh wrong did these words inflict: the worse, because they touched on the truth. That bloodless lip quivered to a temporary spasm. I knew the steely ire I had whetted. I was heart-wrung.
“You utterly misinterpret my words,” I said, at once seizing his hand: “I have no intention to grieve or pain you—indeed, I have not.”
Most bitterly he smiled—most decidedly he withdrew his hand from mine. “And now you recall your promise, and will not go to India at all, I presume?” said he, after a considerable pause.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Turning completely away from the moon, he faced me directly. “When I depart for India, Jane, will I be leaving without you? What? You are not going to India?” I reminded him, “You stated I could only go if I married you.” He pressed, “And you still refuse to marry me? Are you holding firm to that decision?” I asked the reader if they knew, as I did, the chilling effect those cold individuals could impose through their questions, how much the force of an avalanche was in their anger, and the shattering power of a frozen sea breaking up was in their displeasure. I replied, “No, St. John, I will not marry you. I am sticking to my decision.” His anger, like an avalanche, had stirred and shifted slightly forward, but had not yet fully descended. “Explain your refusal once more?” he demanded. I answered, “Previously, it was because you did not love me; now, I state, it is because you practically despise me. Marrying you would destroy me. You are destroying me already.” His lips and cheeks turned completely white. He retorted, “‘I should kill you—I am killing you?’ Your words are unfit for use: they are aggressive, unfeminine, and untrue. They indicate an unfortunate mental state and deserve harsh criticism. They might seem unforgivable, were it not a person’s duty to forgive their fellow human being countless times.” I felt I had sealed my fate. While fervently wishing to remove the lingering effect of my earlier offense from his stubborn mind, I had instead left a new, much deeper mark there; I had etched it in. “Now you truly will hate me,” I said. “There’s no use trying to appease you; I see I have made you my lifelong enemy.” These words inflicted fresh pain, made worse because they contained truth. His pale lip trembled briefly with a spasm. I knew I had sharpened his cold fury, and I was deeply pained. Instantly taking his hand, I said, “You are entirely misinterpreting my words. I have absolutely no intention of causing you distress or pain.” He smiled with great bitterness and definitively pulled his hand away from mine. After a significant pause, he said, “And now, I suppose, you are retracting your promise and will not come to India at all?”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He turned away from looking at the moon and faced me directly. 
“When I head to India, Jane, will I leave you behind? What! Aren’t you going?”
“You told me I couldn’t go unless I became your wife.”
“And you still refuse to marry me? You’re determined?”
Reader, do you know, as I do, how chilling some people can make their questions, how much their anger can feel like an oncoming avalanche, or their displeasure like breaking ice?
“No, St. John, I won’t marry you. My decision hasn’t changed.”
His anger was mounting, but hadn’t totally burst forth.
“Again, why are you refusing?” he pressed.
“In the past,” I said, “it was because you didn’t love me; now, it’s because I sense that you nearly hate me. Marrying you would destroy me. You’re destroying me now.”
He blanched, his lips and cheeks turning pale.
“I would destroy you—I’m destroying you? You shouldn’t use such words; they’re harsh, improper, and false. They show a disturbed mind and deserve criticism. They would be unforgivable if it weren’t a man’s duty to forgive others endlessly.”
I had finished what I needed to do. In trying to erase my past offense, I had made a deeper mark instead; the impression was now permanent.
“Now you’ll hate me for sure,” I said. “There’s no point trying to appease you: I can see I’ve now made you my enemy for good.”
These words hurt him more because they contained some truth. His pale lips quivered with emotion; I recognized the anger I’d provoked and felt great pain.
“You’re misunderstanding me,” I said, grabbing his hand. “I never meant to upset or hurt you—truly, I didn’t.”
He smiled bitterly and firmly withdrew his hand from mine. After a long silence, he said, “So now you’re breaking your promise and won’t go to India at all, I suppose?”

events.title: Jane's Compromise Rejected, St. John's Alternative
detailed_summary: Jane clarifies her position: she is willing to go to India as St. John's assistant, but not as his wife.
A prolonged silence follows, during which Jane senses a significant internal conflict within St. John between his natural feelings and his religious principles.

He eventually speaks, dismissing her proposal by reminding her he had previously demonstrated the unsuitability of an unmarried woman of her age accompanying an unmarried man like him abroad, and expresses regret for her sake that she has revived the idea.

Jane interrupts him, urging him to adhere to common sense and accusing him of feigning shock at her words, arguing that his superior intellect should prevent him from misunderstanding her true meaning.
She firmly reiterates her willingness to serve as his curate, but never as his wife.
St. John, though again turning pale, maintains perfect control over his emotions. He calmly but emphatically states that a female curate who is not his wife would be unacceptable to him.

He then suggests that if her offer to serve is genuine, he will, while in town, speak to a married missionary whose wife requires assistance, a role Jane could undertake using her own fortune, thus supposedly sparing her the dishonor of breaking a commitment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Yes, I will, as your assistant,” I answered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Your own fortune will make you independent of the Society’s aid; and thus you may still be spared the dishonour of breaking your promise and deserting the band you engaged to join.”

events.text_segment:
“Yes, I will, as your assistant,” I answered.
A very long silence succeeded. What struggle there was in him between Nature and Grace in this interval, I cannot tell: only singular gleams scintillated in his eyes, and strange shadows passed over his face. He spoke at last.
“I before proved to you the absurdity of a single woman of your age proposing to accompany abroad a single man of mine. I proved it to you in such terms as, I should have thought, would have prevented your ever again alluding to the plan. That you have done so, I regret—for your sake.”
I interrupted him. Anything like a tangible reproach gave me courage at once. “Keep to common sense, St. John: you are verging on nonsense. You pretend to be shocked by what I have said. You are not really shocked: for, with your superior mind, you cannot be either so dull or so conceited as to misunderstand my meaning. I say again, I will be your curate, if you like, but never your wife.”
Again he turned lividly pale; but, as before, controlled his passion perfectly. He answered emphatically but calmly—
“A female curate, who is not my wife, would never suit me. With me, then, it seems, you cannot go: but if you are sincere in your offer, I will, while in town, speak to a married missionary, whose wife needs a coadjutor. Your own fortune will make you independent of the Society’s aid; and thus you may still be spared the dishonour of breaking your promise and deserting the band you engaged to join.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I responded, 'Yes, I will, as your assistant.' A lengthy silence followed. I couldn't determine the internal struggle between his innate nature and his devout principles during this period; I only observed strange glints in his eyes and unusual expressions crossing his face. Eventually, he spoke. He began by reminding me that he had previously shown me how inappropriate it would be for an unmarried woman of my age to propose traveling abroad with an unmarried man of his age. He believed his previous explanation had been clear enough to prevent me from mentioning the idea again and expressed regret that I had, for my own benefit. I interrupted him, feeling emboldened by his clear criticism. 'Be reasonable, St. John,' I urged, 'you're bordering on the absurd. You pretend to be taken aback by my words, but you aren't truly shocked. With your superior intelligence, you can't be so dull or arrogant as to misinterpret my meaning. I state again, I will be your fellow worker, if you like, but absolutely never your wife.' He again turned deathly pale, but as before, he kept his emotions perfectly in check. He replied with emphasis, yet calmly, that a female assistant who was not his wife would never suit him. Consequently, it appeared, I could not go with him. However, if my offer was genuine, while in town, he would speak to a married missionary whose wife needed help. My own financial resources would mean I wouldn't need support from the Society, thus allowing me to still avoid the disgrace of breaking my commitment and abandoning the group I had pledged to join.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: "Yes, I will, but only as your assistant," I replied. A prolonged silence followed. What internal conflict St. John experienced in those moments between his innate feelings and his moral convictions, I could not determine; I only saw unusual flashes in his eyes and odd shadows on his face. Finally, he spoke. "I previously showed you how foolish it would be for a single woman like yourself to travel abroad with a single man like me. I made this point so strongly that I thought you would never suggest it again. I'm sorry you've brought it up—for your own sake." I interrupted him; any direct criticism gave me immediate courage. "Be reasonable, St. John; you're being ridiculous. You claim to be scandalized by what I've said, but you can't genuinely be so, since you are too intelligent to misinterpret my intentions. Once more, I'll say: I will work as your assistant, but I will never be your wife." Once again, his face turned pale, but he kept his emotions in check and replied with emphasis but calmness: "A female assistant who is not my wife would not be acceptable for me. Your own financial resources will allow you to be independent from the Society's support, and in this way, you can avoid breaking your promise and leaving the missionary group you agreed to join."

events.title: Jane's True Allegiance Revealed, St. John's Dismay
detailed_summary: Jane firmly denies any dishonor, breach of promise, or desertion on her part, asserting she is under no obligation to travel to India, particularly with individuals she does not know.
She confesses she would have dared much to accompany him, driven by admiration, trust, and sisterly affection, but she is also convinced that the Indian climate would prove fatal to her health.
St. John retorts with a sneer, accusing her of being afraid of her own self.

Jane admits to this fear, stating that God did not give her life to be thrown away and that following his wishes feels tantamount to suicide. She also reveals a persistent, painful doubt that prevents her from definitively deciding to leave England.

When St. John demands clarification, he accurately discerns the object of her thoughts, accusing her of nurturing an improper and unholy affection for Mr. Rochester, an interest she should have suppressed long ago and should now be ashamed to mention.
Jane's silence serves as a confession to his accusation.
She then openly states her need to discover Mr. Rochester's current circumstances.

St. John concludes their conversation by stating he will remember her in his prayers, earnestly entreating God that she may not ultimately become lost to salvation. He expresses his prior belief that she was among the chosen, but resigns himself to God's will, then departs through the gate and disappears down the glen.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now I never had, as the reader knows, either given any formal promise or entered into any engagement; and this language was all much too hard and much too despotic for the occasion.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He opened the gate, passed through it, and strayed away down the glen. He was soon out of sight.

events.text_segment:
Now I never had, as the reader knows, either given any formal promise or entered into any engagement; and this language was all much too hard and much too despotic for the occasion. I replied—
“There is no dishonour, no breach of promise, no desertion in the case. I am not under the slightest obligation to go to India, especially with strangers. With you I would have ventured much, because I admire, confide in, and, as a sister, I love you; but I am convinced that, go when and with whom I would, I should not live long in that climate.”
“Ah! you are afraid of yourself,” he said, curling his lip.
“I am. God did not give me my life to throw away; and to do as you wish me would, I begin to think, be almost equivalent to committing suicide. Moreover, before I definitively resolve on quitting England, I will know for certain whether I cannot be of greater use by remaining in it than by leaving it.”
“What do you mean?”
“It would be fruitless to attempt to explain; but there is a point on which I have long endured painful doubt, and I can go nowhere till by some means that doubt is removed.”
“I know where your heart turns and to what it clings. The interest you cherish is lawless and unconsecrated. Long since you ought to have crushed it: now you should blush to allude to it. You think of Mr. Rochester?”
It was true. I confessed it by silence.
“Are you going to seek Mr. Rochester?”
“I must find out what is become of him.”
“It remains for me, then,” he said, “to remember you in my prayers, and to entreat God for you, in all earnestness, that you may not indeed become a castaway. I had thought I recognised in you one of the chosen. But God sees not as man sees: His will be done—”
He opened the gate, passed through it, and strayed away down the glen. He was soon out of sight.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: As the reader is aware, I had never made any formal promise or commitment, and St. John's language was far too harsh and authoritarian for the situation. I replied, "There's no dishonor, no broken promise, and I am not abandoning anyone. I am under no obligation at all to go to India, especially with strangers. I would have risked a great deal for you because I respect, trust, and love you like a sister, but I am certain that, no matter when I went or with whom, I would not survive long in that climate." "Ah! You're afraid of yourself," he said, sneering. "I am," I responded. "God did not give me my life to throw away, and I'm beginning to think doing what you want would be almost the same as committing suicide. Furthermore, before I finally decide to leave England, I must find out for sure if I can't be of greater use by staying here than by departing." "What do you mean?" he asked. "It would be pointless to try to explain," I said, "but there's something I've been painfully uncertain about for a long time, and I cannot go anywhere until that doubt is resolved in some way." "I know where your heart is focused and what it clings to," he stated. "The interest you hold is improper and not sacred. You should have suppressed it long ago; now you should be ashamed to even mention it. You're thinking of Mr. Rochester?" It was true. My silence confirmed it. "Are you going to search for Mr. Rochester?" he pressed. "I must find out what has become of him," I said. "Then," he replied, "all that remains for me is to remember you in my prayers and earnestly ask God that you do not truly become spiritually lost. I had thought I recognized in you one of the chosen. But God sees differently than man sees: His will be done." He opened the gate, walked through it, and wandered away down the valley. He was soon out of sight.

He accused me of being afraid for myself. I admitted as much, saying that life was a gift from God and not something to throw away; following his wishes seemed to me almost like committing suicide. He correctly inferred I was thinking of Mr. Rochester, which I admitted by remaining silent.
