He thought his love was sleeping peacefully; he finds she is stone dead. I looked with hesitant joy towards a grand house; I saw a burnt-out ruin.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
The idea made sense, but I couldn’t bring myself to follow it. I was terrified that the answer I received would leave me utterly hopeless. As long as I remained uncertain, I could still hang on to hope. Perhaps I would get to see the Hall illuminated once more by her presence. The stile lay ahead of me, and so did the same fields I had rushed through—confused, overwhelmed by vengeful anger—on the morning I escaped Thornfield. Before I realized it, I was back among them, walking and sometimes running quickly, looking eagerly for my first glimpse of the familiar woods. Each recognizable tree and view of the meadows and hills filled me with emotion. 

Eventually the woods appeared, the group of rooks gathered darkly, and their loud calls broke the calm of morning, filling me with a strange joy. I hurried onward. After crossing another field and passing through a lane, I finally saw the courtyard walls and the back buildings; the house itself, and the rookery, were still out of sight. Deciding that I wanted my first view of the house to be from the front—so I could take in its impressive battlements at once and maybe catch sight of my master’s window, perhaps even see him there, or walking in the orchard or on the front walk—I resolved to go around. Would I rush to meet him if I saw him, or would I hold back? I couldn’t be sure. And what harm could there be in experiencing the happiness his presence would bring me just one more time? Perhaps, though, he was far away, watching a sunrise in the Pyrenees or gazing at a southern sea.

I followed the outside wall of the orchard, turned the corner, and found a gate leading into the meadow between two stone pillars topped with stone balls. From behind one, I could carefully look out at the full front of the mansion, watching to see if any bedroom window shades were already open. From this hidden spot, I could see the battlements, the windows, and the grand facade.

Perhaps the crows above noticed me as I surveyed the house, wondering at first why I was so cautious and later why I became so bold—first just peeking, then staring, and finally stepping out into the open to gaze intently at the mansion. They might have questioned my earlier shyness and my later boldness.

Let me give a comparison, reader: Imagine a lover who discovers his beloved asleep on a mossy bank. He wants to admire her beauty without waking her, so he approaches quietly, pausing often, afraid even to be seen. When sure she’s still asleep, he gets closer, lifts a veil from her face, and prepares to be enchanted by her serene loveliness. His first glance is rushed, but soon he’s transfixed—then, suddenly, he realizes she is not asleep, but dead. Overcome by shock and despair, he embraces her and cries out because now he knows no noise will disturb her. 

In the same way, I approached the grand house with nervous anticipation, only to find nothing but a burnt-out ruin.

events.title: Confronting the Desolation of Thornfield Hall
detailed_summary: Jane immediately understood that her previous carefulness and fear of being observed were utterly pointless given Thornfield's condition.

The grounds were neglected and damaged, the main entrance gaped open emptily, and the facade of the house was merely a hollow shell with empty window sockets, devoid of a roof, battlements, or chimneys.
An overwhelming silence, like that of death, and the solitude of a deserted wilderness hung over the ruin, making it clear why letters sent there had remained unanswered.
The scorched blackness of the remaining stones unmistakably pointed to a destructive fire as the cause of the Hall's downfall.
Jane found herself pondering the unrevealed narrative of this catastrophe, the full extent of the destruction, and crucially, whether human lives had been lost alongside the property.

As she explored the shattered remnants of the walls and the desolated interior, she noticed signs that the disaster had not occurred recently, observing spring plants growing amidst debris that showed evidence of past winter snows and rains.
Her thoughts anxiously turned to Mr. Rochester, the 'hapless owner,' wondering about his fate, his current location, and even if he might be deceased and interred in the nearby churchyard.
Recognizing the urgent need for answers that the ruin itself could not provide, she resolved to go back to the inn.

At the inn, the host served her breakfast in the parlour; Jane requested him to close the door and sit, as she had questions, though the dread of potential answers made her hesitate, somewhat braced by the desolation she had just witnessed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No need to cower behind a gate-post, indeed!—to peep up at chamber lattices, fearing life was astir behind them!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The host was a respectable-looking, middle-aged man.

events.text_segment:
No need to cower behind a gate-post, indeed!—to peep up at chamber lattices, fearing life was astir behind them! No need to listen for doors opening—to fancy steps on the pavement or the gravel-walk! The lawn, the grounds were trodden and waste: the portal yawned void. The front was, as I had once seen it in a dream, but a shell-like wall, very high and very fragile-looking, perforated with paneless windows: no roof, no battlements, no chimneys—all had crashed in.
And there was the silence of death about it: the solitude of a lonesome wild. No wonder that letters addressed to people here had never received an answer: as well despatch epistles to a vault in a church aisle. The grim blackness of the stones told by what fate the Hall had fallen—by conflagration: but how kindled? What story belonged to this disaster? What loss, besides mortar and marble and wood-work had followed upon it? Had life been wrecked as well as property? If so, whose? Dreadful question: there was no one here to answer it—not even dumb sign, mute token.
In wandering round the shattered walls and through the devastated interior, I gathered evidence that the calamity was not of late occurrence. Winter snows, I thought, had drifted through that void arch, winter rains beaten in at those hollow casements; for, amidst the drenched piles of rubbish, spring had cherished vegetation: grass and weed grew here and there between the stones and fallen rafters. And oh! where meantime was the hapless owner of this wreck? In what land? Under what auspices? My eye involuntarily wandered to the grey church tower near the gates, and I asked, “Is he with Damer de Rochester, sharing the shelter of his narrow marble house?”
Some answer must be had to these questions. I could find it nowhere but at the inn, and thither, ere long, I returned. The host himself brought my breakfast into the parlour. I requested him to shut the door and sit down: I had some questions to ask him. But when he complied, I scarcely knew how to begin; such horror had I of the possible answers. And yet the spectacle of desolation I had just left prepared me in a measure for a tale of misery. The host was a respectable-looking, middle-aged man.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
There was no reason to hide behind a gate or peer cautiously at windows, wondering if life stirred within! No need to listen for sounds of doors opening or imagine footsteps on the paths or gravel! The lawn and grounds were trampled and ruined; the entrance stood empty. The front of the house was just as I had once seen it in a dream – a high, fragile-looking wall like a shell, pierced by windows without panes; the roof, battlements, and chimneys were gone, having all collapsed.

And surrounding it was the silence of death, the solitude of a remote wilderness. It was no surprise that letters sent to anyone here had never received a reply; you might as well send correspondence to a church crypt. The dark, ominous look of the stones revealed how the Hall had met its end – by fire. But how was it started? What was the history behind this disaster? What loss, besides the building materials, had resulted? Had lives been destroyed as well as property? If so, whose? A terrible question, and there was no one present to answer it, not even a hint or silent clue.

As I explored the broken walls and the ruined interior, I found proof that the catastrophe hadn't happened recently. I believed winter snows had drifted through the empty archway and winter rains had poured through the vacant window frames; for, amidst the soaked debris piles, spring had nurtured plant life: grass and weeds grew here and there among the stones and fallen timbers. And oh! where was the ill-fated owner of this wreckage during this time? In what country? Under what circumstances? My gaze instinctively drifted to the grey church tower near the gates, and I wondered, "Is he buried with Damer de Rochester, sharing the shelter of his small stone resting place?"

These questions demanded answers. I could only find them at the inn, and so, before long, I returned there. The innkeeper himself brought my breakfast to the parlor. I asked him to close the door and sit down, explaining that I had some questions. But when he complied, I hardly knew how to begin, so fearful was I of the potential answers. Yet, the scene of desolation I had just witnessed had, to some extent, prepared me for a story of misfortune. The host was a respectable-looking man in his middle years.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: There was no longer any need to hide or be afraid—no need to sneak glances at the windows or listen for signs of life, like footsteps or opening doors. The grounds were desolate, the entrance open and empty. The front of the house looked just as it had once in a dream: a tall, fragile wall with empty window frames, and everything else—roof, battlements, chimneys—had collapsed. The place was silent as a grave, secluded like a barren wilderness. It was no surprise that letters sent to this address never got replies; it would be as effective to write to a tomb. The sooty, blackened stones revealed the house had been destroyed by fire—but what started it? What was the full story behind the ruin? Was more than just the building lost—had lives been lost as well? If so, whose? There were no answers here, not even the slightest clue. As I wandered through the ruins, I realized the disaster hadn’t happened recently. Winters had passed, with snow and rain entering through the broken structure, and even now, grass and weeds grew among the stone and debris. I wondered where the unfortunate owner of this ruined house was—what had become of him? My gaze drifted to the gray church tower by the gates, and I wondered if he now rested in the family tomb. I needed answers, so I went to the inn. The innkeeper, a respectable middle-aged man, brought my breakfast and, at my request, sat down so I could question him—though I was afraid to hear what he might say. Still, the ruin I’d just seen had already prepared me for a sad story.

events.title: The Innkeeper's Initial Revelations and Jane's Fleeting Relief
detailed_summary: Jane finally managed to ask the innkeeper if he knew Thornfield Hall.
The host affirmed that he did, revealing he had once resided there.
He then specified his role as the butler to 'the late Mr. Rochester,' a phrase that struck Jane with the terrifying implication that her Mr. Rochester was dead, causing her to gasp in shock.
The host quickly clarified that he was referring to the father of the current Mr. Edward Rochester, which brought Jane profound relief, her circulation seemingly returning to normal.
Reassured that her Mr. Rochester was alive and designated as 'the present gentleman,' Jane felt a renewed capacity to face whatever further disclosures might come.
She then inquired if Mr. Rochester was presently living at Thornfield Hall, anticipating the answer but still seeking to postpone more direct and potentially distressing questions.
The host emphatically denied this, explaining that no one resided there because Thornfield Hall was now a ruin, having been destroyed by fire around harvest time the previous autumn.

He described the fire as a 'dreadful calamity' that resulted in the destruction of immense valuable property, noting that he himself had witnessed the terrifying spectacle of the building ablaze before fire engines could reach it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You know Thornfield Hall, of course?” I managed to say at last.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was a terrible spectacle: I witnessed it myself.”

events.text_segment:
“You know Thornfield Hall, of course?” I managed to say at last.
“Yes, ma’am; I lived there once.”
“Did you?” Not in my time, I thought: you are a stranger to me.
“I was the late Mr. Rochester’s butler,” he added.
The late! I seem to have received, with full force, the blow I had been trying to evade.
“The late!” I gasped. “Is he dead?”
“I mean the present gentleman, Mr. Edward’s father,” he explained. I breathed again: my blood resumed its flow. Fully assured by these words that Mr. Edward—my Mr. Rochester (God bless him, wherever he was!)—was at least alive: was, in short, “the present gentleman.” Gladdening words! It seemed I could hear all that was to come—whatever the disclosures might be—with comparative tranquillity. Since he was not in the grave, I could bear, I thought, to learn that he was at the Antipodes.
“Is Mr. Rochester living at Thornfield Hall now?” I asked, knowing, of course, what the answer would be, but yet desirous of deferring the direct question as to where he really was.
“No, ma’am—oh, no! No one is living there. I suppose you are a stranger in these parts, or you would have heard what happened last autumn,—Thornfield Hall is quite a ruin: it was burnt down just about harvest-time. A dreadful calamity! such an immense quantity of valuable property destroyed: hardly any of the furniture could be saved. The fire broke out at dead of night, and before the engines arrived from Millcote, the building was one mass of flame. It was a terrible spectacle: I witnessed it myself.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I finally managed to ask, "Surely you're familiar with Thornfield Hall?" The person responded, "Yes, madam, I used to reside there." "Indeed?" I thought internally, "You weren't there during my time; you're a stranger to me." He then clarified, "I served as the former Mr. Rochester's butler." "The former!" It felt as though the shock I had been attempting to avoid had hit me directly. "Former?" I stammered, gasping, "Is he deceased?" "I'm referring to the current owner's father, Mr. Edward," he explained. I could breathe freely again; my circulation returned to normal. These words completely reassured me that Mr. Edward—my Mr. Rochester (bless him, wherever he might be!)—was at least alive; he was, in essence, "the current owner." Such joyful news! It felt as if I could now hear whatever information was forthcoming—no matter how significant the revelations—with relative calmness. Since he was not dead, I believed I could cope with hearing he was living even on the other side of the world. I inquired, "Does Mr. Rochester currently reside at Thornfield Hall?" naturally anticipating the answer but wanting to put off asking directly about his actual location. "No, madam, absolutely not! No one is living there anymore. I assume you're not from this area, or you would know about the events of last autumn—Thornfield Hall is now completely ruined; it burned down around harvest season. It was a terrible disaster! So much valuable property was lost; almost none of the furnishings could be rescued. The fire started late at night, and before the fire engines could reach from Millcote, the entire structure was engulfed in flames. It was a horrifying sight; I saw it personally."

“No, madam—not at all! Thornfield Hall is empty. If you were from around here, you’d have already heard the news—last autumn there was a disaster. Thornfield Hall was almost completely destroyed by fire at harvest time. It was a terrible loss: so many valuable belongings lost, almost nothing could be saved. The fire started in the middle of the night, and before help could arrive from Millcote, the entire house was engulfed in flames. It was a dreadful sight; I saw it myself.”

events.title: Unveiling the Cause of the Fire and Rochester's Subsequent Despair
detailed_summary: Jane murmured her recognition that 'dead of night' was indeed a fateful time at Thornfield and pressed the host about the fire's origin.
The host stated it was definitively established that a 'lunatic' lady kept in the house was responsible for starting the fire.
Jane acknowledged having some prior knowledge of this individual.

The host elaborated on Bertha Mason's strict confinement and the general unawareness of her existence, recounting rumors that Mr. Edward had brought her from abroad, with some speculating she had been his mistress. He also alluded to the 'queer thing' (Jane's aborted wedding) that happened a year before.

When Jane redirected him from her personal history by asking specifically about 'this lady,' the host confirmed she was Mr. Rochester's wife, a fact revealed under strange circumstances involving a young governess.
Anxious to steer the conversation away from herself, Jane prompted him to detail the fire.
The host explained Bertha initiated the blaze, her actions enabled by Mrs. Poole's occasional heavy drinking, which allowed Bertha to secure the keys and wander the house.

He mentioned a previous incident where Bertha had nearly succeeded in burning Rochester in his bed. On the night of the major fire, she first ignited the draperies in the room adjacent to her own, then proceeded to the governess's former chamber (Jane's) and set fire to the bed, which fortunately was unoccupied at the time.
The host recounted that the governess (Jane) had departed two months prior to the fire. Mr. Rochester's intense and futile search for her had led to his transformation into a 'savage,' reclusive man.

Rochester had subsequently sent Mrs. Fairfax away (providing her with a lifetime annuity), placed Adèle in school, severed connections with local gentry, and isolated himself like a hermit at the Hall.

The host expressed his deep resentment towards 'Miss Eyre,' holding her responsible for Rochester's decline from a vibrant gentleman to a brooding figure, and harshly wished she had perished before ever arriving at Thornfield.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “At dead of night!” I muttered. Yes, that was ever the hour of fatality at Thornfield. “Was it known how it originated?” I demanded.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I knew him from a boy, you see: and for my part, I have often wished that Miss Eyre had been sunk in the sea before she came to Thornfield Hall.”

events.text_segment:
“At dead of night!” I muttered. Yes, that was ever the hour of fatality at Thornfield. “Was it known how it originated?” I demanded.
“They guessed, ma’am: they guessed. Indeed, I should say it was ascertained beyond a doubt. You are not perhaps aware,” he continued, edging his chair a little nearer the table, and speaking low, “that there was a lady—a—a lunatic, kept in the house?”
“I have heard something of it.”
“She was kept in very close confinement, ma’am; people even for some years was not absolutely certain of her existence. No one saw her: they only knew by rumour that such a person was at the Hall; and who or what she was it was difficult to conjecture. They said Mr. Edward had brought her from abroad, and some believed she had been his mistress. But a queer thing happened a year since—a very queer thing.”
I feared now to hear my own story. I endeavoured to recall him to the main fact.
“And this lady?”
“This lady, ma’am,” he answered, “turned out to be Mr. Rochester’s wife! The discovery was brought about in the strangest way. There was a young lady, a governess at the Hall, that Mr. Rochester fell in—”
“But the fire,” I suggested.
“I’m coming to that, ma’am—that Mr. Edward fell in love with. The servants say they never saw anybody so much in love as he was: he was after her continually. They used to watch him—servants will, you know, ma’am—and he set store on her past everything: for all, nobody but him thought her so very handsome. She was a little small thing, they say, almost like a child. I never saw her myself; but I’ve heard Leah, the house-maid, tell of her. Leah liked her well enough. Mr. Rochester was about forty, and this governess not twenty; and you see, when gentlemen of his age fall in love with girls, they are often like as if they were bewitched. Well, he would marry her.”
“You shall tell me this part of the story another time,” I said; “but now I have a particular reason for wishing to hear all about the fire. Was it suspected that this lunatic, Mrs. Rochester, had any hand in it?”
“You’ve hit it, ma’am: it’s quite certain that it was her, and nobody but her, that set it going. She had a woman to take care of her called Mrs. Poole—an able woman in her line, and very trustworthy, but for one fault—a fault common to a deal of them nurses and matrons—she kept a private bottle of gin by her, and now and then took a drop over-much. It is excusable, for she had a hard life of it: but still it was dangerous; for when Mrs. Poole was fast asleep after the gin and water, the mad lady, who was as cunning as a witch, would take the keys out of her pocket, let herself out of her chamber, and go roaming about the house, doing any wild mischief that came into her head. They say she had nearly burnt her husband in his bed once: but I don’t know about that. However, on this night, she set fire first to the hangings of the room next her own, and then she got down to a lower storey, and made her way to the chamber that had been the governess’s—(she was like as if she knew somehow how matters had gone on, and had a spite at her)—and she kindled the bed there; but there was nobody sleeping in it, fortunately. The governess had run away two months before; and for all Mr. Rochester sought her as if she had been the most precious thing he had in the world, he never could hear a word of her; and he grew savage—quite savage on his disappointment: he never was a wild man, but he got dangerous after he lost her. He would be alone, too. He sent Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, away to her friends at a distance; but he did it handsomely, for he settled an annuity on her for life: and she deserved it—she was a very good woman. Miss Adèle, a ward he had, was put to school. He broke off acquaintance with all the gentry, and shut himself up like a hermit at the Hall.”
“What! did he not leave England?”
“Leave England? Bless you, no! He would not cross the door-stones of the house, except at night, when he walked just like a ghost about the grounds and in the orchard as if he had lost his senses—which it is my opinion he had; for a more spirited, bolder, keener gentleman than he was before that midge of a governess crossed him, you never saw, ma’am. He was not a man given to wine, or cards, or racing, as some are, and he was not so very handsome; but he had a courage and a will of his own, if ever man had. I knew him from a boy, you see: and for my part, I have often wished that Miss Eyre had been sunk in the sea before she came to Thornfield Hall.”

I'd known him since he was a boy, you see. And personally, I've often wished that Miss Eyre had been swallowed by the sea before she ever came to Thornfield Hall."

"I've heard mention of it."

"She was kept under strict lock and key, ma'am; for years no one could say for certain she even existed. I dreaded hearing my own story retold, so I tried to bring him back to the main point.

"And this lady?"

"I'm getting to that, ma'am. Mr. Rochester was deeply in love with this young lady. The servants said they'd never seen anyone so smitten; he was always after her. "Tell me that part some other time," I said, "right now I want to hear about the fire. Was Mrs. Rochester, the madwoman, suspected?"

"You've guessed it, ma'am—it was certainly her who started it. She lit the bed there, but thankfully no one was in it—the governess had left two months prior. Mr. Rochester looked for her everywhere, valuing her above all else, but he never found her; it made him despondent, even dangerous. He became a recluse, sending Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, away but providing for her with a lifetime annuity—well-deserved, as she was a good woman. He sent his ward, Miss Adèle, to school, ended all social ties, and shut himself up at the Hall."

"He didn't leave England?"

"Leave England? Not at all, ma'am! He wouldn't step foot outside the house except to wander the grounds at night like a ghost, as if he'd lost his mind—which I think he had. Before that little governess crossed his path, you'd never meet a braver or more determined man. He didn't drink, gamble, or race horses, and he wasn't what you'd call handsome, but he had true grit and willpower. I knew him from his boyhood, and to be honest, I've often wished Miss Eyre had never come to Thornfield Hall."

events.title: Rochester's Heroism, Bertha's Fiery Demise, and the Hall's Destruction
detailed_summary: Jane sought confirmation from the host that Mr. Rochester had been at Thornfield when the fire erupted.

The host affirmed this, vividly recounting Rochester's heroic actions: he ascended to the attics, then engulfed in flames from above and below, to awaken the servants and personally assist them to safety.
After ensuring the servants' escape, Rochester returned into the inferno to retrieve his wife from her cell.
However, it was then shouted that Bertha was on the roof, where she was seen standing above the battlements, waving her arms and screaming so loudly she could be heard from a mile away.
The host, an eyewitness, described the dramatic scene: Bertha, a large woman with long, dark hair flowing against the backdrop of flames.
He and others witnessed Mr. Rochester make his way onto the roof through a skylight and heard him call out Bertha's name.
As Rochester approached her, Bertha shrieked, leaped from the battlements, and was instantly killed, her body 'smashed on the pavement' below.
Jane, aghast, asked if she was dead, and the host confirmed it unequivocally.
Following Bertha's suicide, the host explained, the house continued to burn until it was reduced to the ground, with only fragments of walls remaining.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Then Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, ma’am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are only some bits of walls standing now.”

events.text_segment:
“Then Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?”
“Yes, indeed was he; and he went up to the attics when all was burning above and below, and got the servants out of their beds and helped them down himself, and went back to get his mad wife out of her cell. And then they called out to him that she was on the roof, where she was standing, waving her arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till they could hear her a mile off: I saw her and heard her with my own eyes. She was a big woman, and had long black hair: we could see it streaming against the flames as she stood. I witnessed, and several more witnessed, Mr. Rochester ascend through the sky-light on to the roof; we heard him call ‘Bertha!’ We saw him approach her; and then, ma’am, she yelled and gave a spring, and the next minute she lay smashed on the pavement.”
“Dead?”
“Dead! Ay, dead as the stones on which her brains and blood were scattered.”
“Good God!”
“You may well say so, ma’am: it was frightful!”
He shuddered.
“And afterwards?” I urged.
“Well, ma’am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are only some bits of walls standing now.”

He climbed up to the attics while the fire raged both above and below, woke the servants, personally assisted them downstairs, and then returned to rescue his insane wife from her room. Then people yelled to him that she was on the roof, where she stood on the battlements, waving her arms and screaming so loudly she could be heard a mile away. I saw and heard her myself. She was a large woman with long black hair that we could see flowing against the fire. I, along with several others, saw Mr. Rochester climb onto the roof through the skylight. We heard him shout 'Bertha!' We saw him get close to her, and then, ma'am, she shrieked and jumped, and moments later, she was lying broken on the ground. Was she dead? Yes, dead as the stones where her brains and blood were spread. Good Heavens! It was indeed frightful, as you say, ma'am. He trembled. And what happened next? Well, ma'am, the house burned completely down afterward. Only some remnants of walls remain today.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"So Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire started?"
"Yes, he was; he went upstairs while the house was in flames, woke the servants and helped them escape, then returned to try to rescue his insane wife from her room. People called out to him that she was on the roof, standing above the battlements, waving her arms and shouting so loudly you could hear her from a mile away. I saw her myself—she was a large woman with long black hair, which was blown by the fire as she stood. Several of us saw Mr. Rochester climb onto the roof through the skylight; we heard him calling 'Bertha!' and saw him approach her. She screamed, leapt off the roof, and the next moment lay dead on the ground."

"Dead?"
"Yes, dead—her brains and blood scattered on the stones below."

"Good heavens!"
"You can imagine, ma'am, it was horrific!" He trembled.

"And what happened afterwards?" I pressed.

"Well, the house burned completely down—only a few walls are left standing now."

events.title: The Tragic Price of Rochester's Courage: Blindness and Maiming
detailed_summary: Jane inquired if any other lives had been lost in the devastating fire.
The host responded that no one else perished, but added with a somber tone that it might have been better if others had.

He expressed profound pity for 'Poor Mr. Edward,' noting that while some viewed the tragedy as a divine retribution for Rochester's concealed first marriage and his attempt to marry again, he personally felt compassion for him.
Jane, alarmed by his tone, urgently reconfirmed that Mr. Rochester was indeed alive.
The host affirmed Rochester's survival but ominously stated that many believe he would be better off dead, a remark that sent a chill through Jane.
As Jane pressed for details about Rochester's condition and his current location within England, the host finally delivered the devastating news: 'He is stone-blind.'
Jane, who had harbored fears that Rochester might have descended into madness, found a grim strength to inquire about the cause of this catastrophic injury.
The host attributed Rochester's condition entirely to his bravery and altruism, explaining that he refused to leave the burning house until every other person was safely out.
As Rochester was finally making his escape down the grand staircase, moments after Bertha Rochester had jumped from the battlements, the entire structure collapsed.

He was extricated from the rubble alive but grievously wounded: a fallen beam had offered some protection, yet one of his eyes was destroyed, and one hand was so severely crushed that the surgeon, Mr. Carter, had to amputate it immediately. Subsequently, inflammation developed in his remaining eye, leading to total blindness, rendering him helpless—'blind and a cripple.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Were any other lives lost?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He is now helpless, indeed—blind and a cripple.”

events.text_segment:
“Were any other lives lost?”
“No—perhaps it would have been better if there had.”
“What do you mean?”
“Poor Mr. Edward!” he ejaculated, “I little thought ever to have seen it! Some say it was a just judgment on him for keeping his first marriage secret, and wanting to take another wife while he had one living: but I pity him, for my part.”
“You said he was alive?” I exclaimed.
“Yes, yes: he is alive; but many think he had better be dead.”
“Why? How?” My blood was again running cold. “Where is he?” I demanded. “Is he in England?”
“Ay—ay—he’s in England; he can’t get out of England, I fancy—he’s a fixture now.”
What agony was this! And the man seemed resolved to protract it.
“He is stone-blind,” he said at last. “Yes, he is stone-blind, is Mr. Edward.”
I had dreaded worse. I had dreaded he was mad. I summoned strength to ask what had caused this calamity.
“It was all his own courage, and a body may say, his kindness, in a way, ma’am: he wouldn’t leave the house till every one else was out before him. As he came down the great staircase at last, after Mrs. Rochester had flung herself from the battlements, there was a great crash—all fell. He was taken out from under the ruins, alive, but sadly hurt: a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him partly; but one eye was knocked out, and one hand so crushed that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, had to amputate it directly. The other eye inflamed: he lost the sight of that also. He is now helpless, indeed—blind and a cripple.”

I cried out, "You said he was alive?" Yes, yes, he's alive, but a lot of people think death would be a mercy for him. My blood turned cold again. "Why? How?" I demanded. "Where is he? Is he in England?" Yes, yes, he's in England. I don't think he can leave England; he's stuck there now. This uncertainty was agonizing! And the man seemed determined to drag it out. Finally, he said, "He is completely blind. Yes, Mr. Edward is completely blind." I had feared something worse – that he had gone insane. I gathered my courage and asked what had caused this terrible misfortune. "It was due entirely to his own bravery, and you might say, his kindness, ma'am," he explained. "He refused to leave the house until everyone else was safely out. As he finally came down the main stairs, right after Mrs. Rochester jumped from the roof, there was a huge collapse – everything fell. He was pulled from the wreckage, alive but badly injured. A beam had fallen in a way that partially protected him, but one eye was destroyed, and one hand was so crushed that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, had to remove it immediately. His other eye became inflamed, and he lost the sight in that one too. He is now completely helpless – blind and disabled."

events.title: Learning Rochester's Secluded Whereabouts and Jane's Swift Resolve to Go to Him
detailed_summary: Upon learning of Rochester's catastrophic injuries, Jane immediately asked for his current location.
The host informed her that Mr. Rochester was now residing at Ferndean, a manor-house situated on a farm he owned, approximately thirty miles away, describing the place as 'quite a desolate spot.'
When Jane inquired who was caring for him, the host replied that only old John and his wife were with him, as Rochester refused any other company, adding that he was reportedly 'quite broken down.'
Hearing this, Jane's resolve was instant; she asked if the inn possessed any means of transport.
The host confirmed they had a chaise, which he described as being quite handsome.

Jane then gave decisive instructions for the chaise to be made ready at once, promising to pay double the standard fee to both the innkeeper and the post-boy if she could be driven to Ferndean before nightfall that same day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Where is he? Where does he now live?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Let it be got ready instantly; and if your post-boy can drive me to Ferndean before dark this day, I’ll pay both you and him twice the hire you usually demand.”

events.text_segment:
“Where is he? Where does he now live?”
“At Ferndean, a manor-house on a farm he has, about thirty miles off: quite a desolate spot.”
“Who is with him?”
“Old John and his wife: he would have none else. He is quite broken down, they say.”
“Have you any sort of conveyance?”
“We have a chaise, ma’am, a very handsome chaise.”
“Let it be got ready instantly; and if your post-boy can drive me to Ferndean before dark this day, I’ll pay both you and him twice the hire you usually demand.”

Jane then asked if they possessed any kind of vehicle. They confirmed they had a very fine carriage, a chaise. "Just old John and his wife—he refused to have anyone else. They say he’s in very poor condition."

"We have a very fine chaise, ma’am."
"Have it prepared at once. If your driver can get me to Ferndean before nightfall, I’ll pay you and him double your usual fare."

events.title: Jane's Arrival at Desolate Ferndean and Sobering Observation of Rochester
detailed_summary: Jane arrives at Ferndean, a remote and gloomy manor, during a dismal evening characterized by a sad sky, cold gale, and penetrating rain.
She finds the house deeply isolated and surrounded by thick, dark woods, matching its inhospitable reputation.
After a challenging final mile on foot and navigating a grass-grown track through the woods, she finally beholds the decaying and desolate-looking manor.
She witnesses Mr. Rochester emerge from the house; initially, she doesn't recognize him without his hat.
Observing him secretly, she notes his physical frame remains strong, but his countenance is marked by desperation and brooding, reminding her of a wronged, captive wild creature.
A mixture of sorrow and a nascent hope to comfort him fills her, yet she chooses not to reveal herself immediately.
She watches as he, evidently blind, attempts to gauge the weather by stretching out his hand and then tries to sense his surroundings, finding only empty space.
John, a servant, approaches to offer Rochester his arm due to an impending heavy shower, but Rochester curtly dismisses him.
Rochester then struggles to navigate by himself and gropes his way back into the house, closing the door behind him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity, moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He groped his way back to the house, and, re-entering it, closed the door.

events.text_segment:
The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity, moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood. I had heard of it before. Mr. Rochester often spoke of it, and sometimes went there. His father had purchased the estate for the sake of the game covers. He would have let the house, but could find no tenant, in consequence of its ineligible and insalubrious site. Ferndean then remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception of some two or three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the squire when he went there in the season to shoot.
To this house I came just ere dark on an evening marked by the characteristics of sad sky, cold gale, and continued small penetrating rain. The last mile I performed on foot, having dismissed the chaise and driver with the double remuneration I had promised. Even when within a very short distance of the manor-house, you could see nothing of it, so thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about it. Iron gates between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and passing through them, I found myself at once in the twilight of close-ranked trees. There was a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches. I followed it, expecting soon to reach the dwelling; but it stretched on and on, it wound far and farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was visible.
I thought I had taken a wrong direction and lost my way. The darkness of natural as well as of sylvan dusk gathered over me. I looked round in search of another road. There was none: all was interwoven stem, columnar trunk, dense summer foliage—no opening anywhere.
I proceeded: at last my way opened, the trees thinned a little; presently I beheld a railing, then the house—scarce, by this dim light, distinguishable from the trees; so dank and green were its decaying walls. Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a space of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a semicircle. There were no flowers, no garden-beds; only a broad gravel-walk girdling a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of the forest. The house presented two pointed gables in its front; the windows were latticed and narrow: the front door was narrow too, one step led up to it. The whole looked, as the host of the Rochester Arms had said, “quite a desolate spot.” It was as still as a church on a week-day: the pattering rain on the forest leaves was the only sound audible in its vicinage.
“Can there be life here?” I asked.
Yes, life of some kind there was; for I heard a movement—that narrow front-door was unclosing, and some shape was about to issue from the grange.
It opened slowly: a figure came out into the twilight and stood on the step; a man without a hat: he stretched forth his hand as if to feel whether it rained. Dusk as it was, I had recognised him—it was my master, Edward Fairfax Rochester, and no other.
I stayed my step, almost my breath, and stood to watch him—to examine him, myself unseen, and alas! to him invisible. It was a sudden meeting, and one in which rapture was kept well in check by pain. I had no difficulty in restraining my voice from exclamation, my step from hasty advance.
His form was of the same strong and stalwart contour as ever: his port was still erect, his hair was still raven black; nor were his features altered or sunk: not in one year’s space, by any sorrow, could his athletic strength be quelled or his vigorous prime blighted. But in his countenance I saw a change: that looked desperate and brooding—that reminded me of some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous to approach in his sullen woe. The caged eagle, whose gold-ringed eyes cruelty has extinguished, might look as looked that sightless Samson.
And, reader, do you think I feared him in his blind ferocity?—if you do, you little know me. A soft hope blent with my sorrow that soon I should dare to drop a kiss on that brow of rock, and on those lips so sternly sealed beneath it: but not yet. I would not accost him yet.
He descended the one step, and advanced slowly and gropingly towards the grass-plat. Where was his daring stride now? Then he paused, as if he knew not which way to turn. He lifted his hand and opened his eyelids; gazed blank, and with a straining effort, on the sky, and toward the amphitheatre of trees: one saw that all to him was void darkness. He stretched his right hand (the left arm, the mutilated one, he kept hidden in his bosom); he seemed to wish by touch to gain an idea of what lay around him: he met but vacancy still; for the trees were some yards off where he stood. He relinquished the endeavour, folded his arms, and stood quiet and mute in the rain, now falling fast on his uncovered head. At this moment John approached him from some quarter.
“Will you take my arm, sir?” he said; “there is a heavy shower coming on: had you not better go in?”
“Let me alone,” was the answer.
John withdrew without having observed me. Mr. Rochester now tried to walk about: vainly,—all was too uncertain. He groped his way back to the house, and, re-entering it, closed the door.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Ferndean Manor was an old, moderately-sized house, without any fancy architectural features, completely hidden within a dense forest. I was familiar with the name; Mr. Rochester frequently mentioned it and sometimes visited. His father had bought the estate specifically for hunting. He would have rented out the house, but its unsuitable and unhealthy location meant no one wanted to live there. Consequently, Ferndean remained empty and unfurnished, apart from a few rooms set up for the squire's use during hunting season. I arrived at this house just before nightfall on an evening characterized by a grey sky, chilly wind, and persistent fine, piercing rain. I covered the last mile on foot, having sent the carriage and driver away after paying them double what I owed. Even when I was very near the manor, I couldn't see it because the trees in the gloomy woods surrounding it grew so densely and darkly. Iron gates set between stone pillars marked the entrance, and stepping through them, I immediately entered the dim light beneath closely packed trees. A track overgrown with grass led down the forest path, winding between ancient, gnarled tree trunks under the canopy of branches. I followed it, expecting to quickly reach the house, but it went on and on, twisting further and further, with no sign of a building or cultivated land visible. I began to think I had taken a wrong turn and gotten lost. The darkness of both the approaching night and the dense woods enveloped me. I searched for another path but found none; everywhere was just tangled branches, straight tree trunks, and thick summer leaves—there was no break in the forest. I kept going; eventually, my path opened up, and the trees became less dense. Soon, I saw a railing, and then the house itself—which, in the poor light, was barely visible against the trees because its crumbling walls were so damp and covered in green growth. I entered through a doorway, which was only secured by a latch, and found myself in an enclosed area, with the woods curving away in a semicircle. There were no flowers or garden beds, just a wide gravel path surrounding a patch of grass, all framed heavily by the forest. The house had two pointed peaks at the front; the windows were narrow and had lattice panes; the front door was also narrow, with a single step leading up to it. As the innkeeper at the Rochester Arms had described, the entire place looked "quite a desolate spot." It was as quiet as a church on a weekday; the only noise nearby was the sound of rain tapping on the forest leaves. "Could anyone live here?" I wondered. Yes, there was some form of life, because I heard movement—that narrow front door was opening, and a figure was about to come out of the building. It opened slowly, and a shape emerged into the fading light and stood on the step; it was a man without a hat. He held out his hand as if checking whether it was raining. Despite the dimness, I recognized him instantly—it was my master, Edward Fairfax Rochester, and no one else. I stopped walking, almost holding my breath, and stood to watch him, observing him myself while remaining hidden and, sadly, invisible to him. It was an unexpected encounter, one where my intense joy was held in check by sorrow. I had no trouble preventing myself from crying out or rushing forward. His build was as strong and sturdy as ever; his posture remained upright, and his hair was still black as a raven. His facial features hadn't changed or become hollowed; no amount of grief in just one year could have weakened his powerful physique or damaged his robust health. However, I saw a change in his expression: it looked despairing and preoccupied—it brought to mind a wild animal or bird that had been wronged and trapped, someone dangerous to approach in his gloomy suffering. He looked like a caged eagle whose cruel treatment had blinded its keen eyes, or like the biblical Samson after he was blinded. And, dear reader, if you think I was afraid of him in his blind intensity, then you don't know me at all. A gentle hope mixed with my sadness that before long I would be brave enough to kiss that firm forehead and those lips so tightly closed beneath it; but not yet. I wouldn't speak to him just yet. He stepped down from the single step and moved slowly and cautiously towards the grassy area, feeling his way. Where was his confident stride now? He stopped, as if unsure which direction to go. He lifted his hand and opened his eyes, staring blankly, with a strained effort, at the sky and towards the surrounding circle of trees; it was clear that everything was empty darkness to him. He extended his right hand (keeping his injured left arm hidden inside his jacket); it seemed he was trying to understand his surroundings by touch. But he only met empty space, as the trees were several yards away from where he stood. He gave up the attempt, crossed his arms, and stood still and silent in the rain, which was now falling heavily on his bare head. At this moment, John came up to him from somewhere nearby. "Would you like my arm, sir?" John asked. "A heavy rain is starting; shouldn't you go inside?" "Leave me," was the reply. John left without noticing me. Mr. Rochester then tried to walk around, but couldn't; everything was too unstable for him. He felt his way back to the house and, going inside again, shut the door.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Ferndean Manor was an old house of moderate size with no noteworthy design, deeply concealed within a forest. I had heard about it previously, as Mr. Rochester often mentioned the place and occasionally visited it. His father had originally bought the property for the quality of its hunting lands but never managed to find a tenant for the house, since its location was both unhealthy and undesirable. As a result, Ferndean stayed unoccupied and unfurnished except for a few rooms prepared for Mr. Rochester’s occasional hunting trips.

I arrived at Ferndean just before nightfall, on an evening characterized by a gloomy sky, a cold wind, and persistent, soaking rain. I walked the final mile after dismissing the carriage and driver with extra payment as promised. Even when close to the manor, the thick and dark woods completely hid it from view. Granite pillars and iron gates marked the entrance to the property, leading me into a shadowy avenue formed by tightly growing trees. A grass-covered path stretched down between ancient trunks and under a canopy of boughs. I continued, expecting to see the house at any moment, but the path went on much further than I anticipated, without any sign of habitation.

I started to think I had taken a wrong turn and was lost, surrounded by both the natural dusk and the darkness of the dense trees. I searched for another way but saw only an unbroken wall of thick trunks and foliage.

Eventually, the path widened and the trees became sparser. Soon I spotted a fence and then the house itself, its decaying, damp green walls almost blending into the surrounding forest. Entering through an unlatched portal, I found myself in an enclosed area from which the forest retreated in a semi-circle. There were no flowers or garden beds, just a wide gravel walk encircling a grassy patch, all bordered by the dense woods. The house’s front had two pointed gables and narrow lattice windows, and the front door was also narrow, approached by only a single step. Altogether, it matched the description I had heard before: a truly desolate place. It was as quiet as a church during a weekday—the only sound was the steady fall of rain on the leaves.

I wondered, “Is there any life here?”

There was. I heard movement; the slim front door began to open and a figure appeared in the dim light—a hatless man who reached out as if to check for rain. Despite the gloom, I recognized him immediately: it was Mr. Rochester.

I stopped moving and barely breathed, watching him while remaining unnoticed myself; he, of course, could not see me. Our meeting was sudden, and though exciting, it was clouded by pain. I found it easy to remain quiet and still, restraining myself from rushing forward or calling out.

He remained as strong and solid in build as ever, still standing tall with jet-black hair and well-defined features. No sorrow of one year had diminished his physical power or youth. Yet, I noticed a change in his expression—one of deep despair and brooding, reminding me of a wronged, caged wild creature, dangerous and grieving. He resembled a blind and imprisoned eagle or Samson, proud but sightless.

And, reader, if you think I was afraid of him in his blindness and torment, you do not understand me. Amid my sorrow, I also felt a gentle hope that soon I might embrace him, but not yet. I would not reveal myself right away.

He stepped slowly off the porch, feeling his way toward the grass. Gone was his confident stride; he hesitated, uncertain where to turn. He raised his hand and eyelids toward the sky and trees, though it was clear that to him, everything was blank darkness. He reached out, trying to understand his surroundings by touch, but found only empty space—the trees were still some distance away. Abandoning the attempt, he folded his arms and stood in the rain, letting it fall heavily on his uncovered head. At that moment, John appeared.

“Would you like my help, sir? It’s about to rain heavily—maybe you should go inside?” John suggested.

Rochester replied, “Leave me alone.”

John went away, not noticing me. Mr. Rochester tried to move around by himself, but it was pointless; everything was too uncertain. He felt his way back to the house and closed the door behind him.

events.title: Jane's Cautious Re-entry and Orchestrated Meeting
detailed_summary: Jane approaches the manor and knocks; Mary, John's wife, opens the door and is visibly startled to see Jane.
Jane reassures Mary, briefly explaining that she learned of the events after her departure from Thornfield and has come to see Mr. Rochester.
She arranges for her trunk to be collected from the turn-pike-house and confirms with Mary that she can be accommodated for the night, deciding to stay.
Upon hearing the parlour-bell, Jane instructs Mary to inform Mr. Rochester that a person wishes to speak with him but to withhold her name.
Mary returns, conveying Rochester's reluctance and his demand for the visitor's name and purpose, noting he generally refuses all visitors.
As Mary prepares a tray with water and candles, she explains that Rochester always has candles brought in at dark, despite his blindness.
Jane, her heart pounding and hands trembling, volunteers to take the tray into the parlour herself.
Mary directs her to the parlour door, opens it for her, and then closes it, leaving Jane to face Rochester.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I now drew near and knocked: John’s wife opened for me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mary opened the door for me, and shut it behind me.

events.text_segment:
I now drew near and knocked: John’s wife opened for me. “Mary,” I said, “how are you?”
She started as if she had seen a ghost: I calmed her. To her hurried “Is it really you, miss, come at this late hour to this lonely place?” I answered by taking her hand; and then I followed her into the kitchen, where John now sat by a good fire. I explained to them, in few words, that I had heard all which had happened since I left Thornfield, and that I was come to see Mr. Rochester. I asked John to go down to the turn-pike-house, where I had dismissed the chaise, and bring my trunk, which I had left there: and then, while I removed my bonnet and shawl, I questioned Mary as to whether I could be accommodated at the Manor House for the night; and finding that arrangements to that effect, though difficult, would not be impossible, I informed her I should stay. Just at this moment the parlour-bell rang.
“When you go in,” said I, “tell your master that a person wishes to speak to him, but do not give my name.”
“I don’t think he will see you,” she answered; “he refuses everybody.”
When she returned, I inquired what he had said.
“You are to send in your name and your business,” she replied. She then proceeded to fill a glass with water, and place it on a tray, together with candles.
“Is that what he rang for?” I asked.
“Yes: he always has candles brought in at dark, though he is blind.”
“Give the tray to me; I will carry it in.”
I took it from her hand: she pointed me out the parlour door. The tray shook as I held it; the water spilt from the glass; my heart struck my ribs loud and fast. Mary opened the door for me, and shut it behind me.

The tray shook as I held it, causing water to spill from the glass; my heart beat loudly and quickly against my ribs. Mary opened the door for me and closed it behind me.

events.title: The Emotional Reunion in the Gloomy Parlour
detailed_summary: Jane enters a gloomy parlour where a small fire burns and Mr. Rochester leans against the mantelpiece; his dog, Pilot, lies nearby.
Pilot instantly recognizes Jane, jumping up with excited yelps and whines, nearly causing her to drop the tray.
Mr. Rochester, hearing the commotion but unable to see its cause, sighs.
He requests water, addressing whom he presumes to be Mary; Jane approaches with the now half-empty glass, Pilot following her excitedly.
Rochester questions the cause of Pilot's excitement. After Jane quiets the dog and he drinks, he asks if it is Mary.
Jane replies that Mary is in the kitchen.
He extends his hand, urgently demanding to know who is present, his sightless eyes making a distressing attempt to see.
Jane offers him more water, and her voice prompts further intense questioning.
She then reveals that Pilot, John, and Mary are aware of her presence, as she has only just arrived that evening.
Rochester exclaims in disbelief, questioning whether he is experiencing a delusion or madness.
Jane firmly reassures him of his sanity.
He desperately implores to be able to touch her, expressing that his heart might stop otherwise.
Jane gently takes his wandering hand, and he immediately recognizes her fingers.
He then pulls her close, recognizing her form and size; her voice finally confirms her identity.
Overcome, he utters her name, a mix of disbelief and profound emotion in his voice.
Jane affirms that it is indeed her and that she has returned to him.
Rochester struggles to accept her presence as real, fearing it is a dream like others he has had, where he has embraced her and felt her love.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This parlour looked gloomy: a neglected handful of fire burnt low in the grate; and, leaning over it, with his head supported against the high, old-fashioned mantelpiece, appeared the blind tenant of the room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My living darling! These are certainly her limbs, and these her features; but I cannot be so blest, after all my misery. It is a dream; such dreams as I have had at night when I have clasped her once more to my heart, as I do now; and kissed her, as thus—and felt that she loved me, and trusted that she would not leave me.”

events.text_segment:
This parlour looked gloomy: a neglected handful of fire burnt low in the grate; and, leaning over it, with his head supported against the high, old-fashioned mantelpiece, appeared the blind tenant of the room. His old dog, Pilot, lay on one side, removed out of the way, and coiled up as if afraid of being inadvertently trodden upon. Pilot pricked up his ears when I came in: then he jumped up with a yelp and a whine, and bounded towards me: he almost knocked the tray from my hands. I set it on the table; then patted him, and said softly, “Lie down!” Mr. Rochester turned mechanically to see what the commotion was: but as he saw nothing, he returned and sighed.
“Give me the water, Mary,” he said.
I approached him with the now only half-filled glass; Pilot followed me, still excited.
“What is the matter?” he inquired.
“Down, Pilot!” I again said. He checked the water on its way to his lips, and seemed to listen: he drank, and put the glass down. “This is you, Mary, is it not?”
“Mary is in the kitchen,” I answered.
He put out his hand with a quick gesture, but not seeing where I stood, he did not touch me. “Who is this? Who is this?” he demanded, trying, as it seemed, to see with those sightless eyes—unavailing and distressing attempt! “Answer me—speak again!” he ordered, imperiously and aloud.
“Will you have a little more water, sir? I spilt half of what was in the glass,” I said.
“Who is it? What is it? Who speaks?”
“Pilot knows me, and John and Mary know I am here. I came only this evening,” I answered.
“Great God!—what delusion has come over me? What sweet madness has seized me?”
“No delusion—no madness: your mind, sir, is too strong for delusion, your health too sound for frenzy.”
“And where is the speaker? Is it only a voice? Oh! I cannot see, but I must feel, or my heart will stop and my brain burst. Whatever—whoever you are—be perceptible to the touch or I cannot live!”
He groped; I arrested his wandering hand, and prisoned it in both mine.
“Her very fingers!” he cried; “her small, slight fingers! If so there must be more of her.”
The muscular hand broke from my custody; my arm was seized, my shoulder—neck—waist—I was entwined and gathered to him.
“Is it Jane? What is it? This is her shape—this is her size—”
“And this her voice,” I added. “She is all here: her heart, too. God bless you, sir! I am glad to be so near you again.”
“Jane Eyre!—Jane Eyre,” was all he said.
“My dear master,” I answered, “I am Jane Eyre: I have found you out—I am come back to you.”
“In truth?—in the flesh? My living Jane?”
“You touch me, sir,—you hold me, and fast enough: I am not cold like a corpse, nor vacant like air, am I?”
“My living darling! These are certainly her limbs, and these her features; but I cannot be so blest, after all my misery. It is a dream; such dreams as I have had at night when I have clasped her once more to my heart, as I do now; and kissed her, as thus—and felt that she loved me, and trusted that she would not leave me.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The parlour seemed dreary; a scant, neglected fire smouldered in the grate, and leaning above it, his head resting on the high, old-style mantelpiece, was the room's sightless inhabitant. His elderly dog, Pilot, lay to one side, out of the way, curled up as though fearful of being accidentally stepped on. Pilot perked up his ears at my entry; then, with a yelp and a whine, he leaped up and charged towards me, almost knocking the tray from my hands. I placed it on the table, then stroked him gently and murmured, "Lie down!" Mr. Rochester automatically turned to ascertain the source of the disturbance, but perceiving nothing, he turned back and sighed. "Give me the water, Mary," he instructed. I approached him with the glass, now only half full; Pilot trailed behind me, still agitated. "What's the matter?" he inquired. "Down, Pilot!" I repeated. He paused the glass on its way to his lips and appeared to listen; he drank and set the glass down. "This is you, Mary, isn't it?" "Mary is in the kitchen," I replied. He quickly extended his hand, but not seeing where I was positioned, he didn't touch me. "Who is this? Who is this?" he demanded, seemingly attempting to perceive with those unseeing eyes – a futile and heartbreaking effort! "Answer me – speak again!" he commanded, authoritatively and loudly. "Would you like a little more water, sir? I spilled half of what was in the glass," I said. "Who is it? What is it? Who is speaking?" "Pilot recognizes me, and John and Mary know I'm here. I only arrived this evening," I responded. "Great God! – what illusion has overcome me? What delightful madness has seized me?" "No illusion – no madness; your mind, sir, is too resilient for illusion, your health too robust for frenzy." "And where is the speaker? Is it just a voice? Oh! I cannot see, but I must touch, or my heart will cease and my mind explode. Whoever – whatever you are – let me feel you, or I cannot survive!" He fumbled; I intercepted his wandering hand and held it firmly in both of mine. "Her very fingers!" he exclaimed; "her small, slender fingers! If so, there must be more of her." The strong hand broke free from my grasp; my arm was seized, my shoulder – neck – waist – I was wrapped up and pulled into his embrace. "Is it Jane? What is this? This is her form – this is her height –" "And this her voice," I added. "She is entirely here: her heart, too. God bless you, sir! I am overjoyed to be this close to you again." "Jane Eyre! – Jane Eyre," was all he uttered. "My dear master," I replied, "I am Jane Eyre; I have sought you out – I have returned to you." "Truly? – in the flesh? My living Jane?" "You are touching me, sir – you are holding me, quite tightly: I am not cold like a corpse, nor insubstantial like air, am I?" "My living beloved! These are undoubtedly her limbs, and these her features; but I cannot be this fortunate, after all my suffering. It is a dream; such dreams as I have experienced at night when I have held her close once more, as I am doing now; and kissed her, like this – and sensed that she loved me, and believed that she would not abandon me."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
The room felt dark and unwelcoming, with only a small, unattended fire burning weakly in the fireplace. Mr. Rochester, the room’s blind occupant, was leaning against the high, old mantel, his head resting on it. His aged dog, Pilot, lay curled up to the side, clearly keeping out of the way to avoid being stepped on. When I entered, Pilot perked up, barked and whimpered with excitement, and rushed over to me, almost causing me to drop the tray I carried. I managed to place the tray on the table, patted Pilot, and quietly commanded him to lie down. Mr. Rochester, reacting mechanically to the disturbance, turned, but seeing nothing, sighed and turned back. 

He asked, “Give me the water, Mary.”

I brought him the glass, now only half full, with Pilot eagerly at my side.

“What’s going on?” he asked.

Again, I told Pilot to settle down. Mr. Rochester paused with the glass near his mouth, listening intently, then drank and put the glass back. “Is that you, Mary?” he asked.

“Mary is in the kitchen,” I replied.

He quickly reached out, searching for me but couldn’t find me, then anxiously asked, “Who is this? Who’s here?” He desperately tried to see me with his blind eyes, but in vain. “Answer me—say something!” he insisted urgently.

“I spilled some, would you like more water?” I replied, trying to calm him.

“But who are you? Who’s speaking?”

“Pilot recognizes me, and John and Mary know I arrived tonight,” I explained.

He was overwhelmed, exclaiming, “Great God! What trick is this? What sweet madness am I feeling?”

I assured him, “No trick, no insanity; your mind is too strong and your health too good for that.”

“And where are you? Are you just a voice? I can’t see, but I need to feel, or I’ll go mad!”

He reached out, and I took his hand in both of mine.

“My God, it’s really her fingers,” he gasped; “there must be more of her.”

He pulled free and seized my arm, then my shoulder and waist, wrapping me tightly in his arms.

“Is it Jane? Is it really her? The shape, the size—”

“And my voice, sir,” I added, “I am all here, heart and all. God bless you! I’m so glad to be close to you again.”

“Jane Eyre! Jane Eyre,” was all he managed to say.

“My dear master,” I replied, “I am Jane Eyre. I have found you and come back.”

“Truly? Are you really here, alive and in person?”

“You’re holding and touching me, sir—I’m not a ghost or just air, am I?”

“My living beloved! Yes, I feel your body and your face, but after so much suffering, can I really be this fortunate? It feels like a dream—just like the dreams I had of holding you again, of kissing you and being sure you loved me, and hoping you would never leave me.”

events.title: Jane's Steadfast Commitment and Newfound Independence
detailed_summary: Jane firmly vows that she will never leave Mr. Rochester again, directly addressing his fear that she is merely a transient vision.
She expresses her affection physically, kissing his eyes and brow, which helps him begin to accept the reality of her return.
He anxiously asks if she is truly alive and well, not suffering as an outcast.
Jane proudly informs him that she is now an independent woman.
She explains that her uncle in Madeira has passed away and left her an inheritance of five thousand pounds.
Rochester is visibly astonished and uplifted by this practical and unexpected news, remarking that it brings vitality to his weary heart.
He expresses a concern that her newfound wealth and independence might lead her to seek other companions and not devote herself to him, a blind and lame man.
Jane reassures him of her self-sufficiency and firmly states her intention to remain with him.
She offers to be his neighbor, nurse, housekeeper, and constant companion, promising that he will not be left desolate as long as she lives.
Rochester becomes quiet and thoughtful, his serious and abstracted demeanor causing Jane to worry that she has been overly forward or has transgressed social conventions with her declarations.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Which I never will, sir, from this day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He replied not: he seemed serious—abstracted; he sighed; he half-opened his lips as if to speak: he closed them again.

events.text_segment:
Which I never will, sir, from this day.”
“Never will, says the vision? But I always woke and found it an empty mockery; and I was desolate and abandoned—my life dark, lonely, hopeless—my soul athirst and forbidden to drink—my heart famished and never to be fed. Gentle, soft dream, nestling in my arms now, you will fly, too, as your sisters have all fled before you: but kiss me before you go—embrace me, Jane.”
“There, sir—and there!”’
I pressed my lips to his once brilliant and now rayless eyes—I swept his hair from his brow, and kissed that too. He suddenly seemed to arouse himself: the conviction of the reality of all this seized him.
“It is you—is it, Jane? You are come back to me then?”
“I am.”
“And you do not lie dead in some ditch under some stream? And you are not a pining outcast amongst strangers?”
“No, sir! I am an independent woman now.”
“Independent! What do you mean, Jane?”
“My uncle in Madeira is dead, and he left me five thousand pounds.”
“Ah! this is practical—this is real!” he cried: “I should never dream that. Besides, there is that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and piquant, as well as soft: it cheers my withered heart; it puts life into it.—What, Janet! Are you an independent woman? A rich woman?”
“Quite rich, sir. If you won’t let me live with you, I can build a house of my own close up to your door, and you may come and sit in my parlour when you want company of an evening.”
“But as you are rich, Jane, you have now, no doubt, friends who will look after you, and not suffer you to devote yourself to a blind lameter like me?”
“I told you I am independent, sir, as well as rich: I am my own mistress.”
“And you will stay with me?”
“Certainly—unless you object. I will be your neighbour, your nurse, your housekeeper. I find you lonely: I will be your companion—to read to you, to walk with you, to sit with you, to wait on you, to be eyes and hands to you. Cease to look so melancholy, my dear master; you shall not be left desolate, so long as I live.”
He replied not: he seemed serious—abstracted; he sighed; he half-opened his lips as if to speak: he closed them again.
