He spoke and looked with great eagerness, his usual impulsiveness resurfacing. 'We must become one flesh without any delay, Jane; the only remaining step is to get the license, and then we'll marry.' 'Mr. Rochester,' I responded, 'I've just noticed the sun is well past its peak, and Pilot has actually gone home for his dinner. Let me see your watch.' He told me to attach it to my belt and keep it from now on, saying he had no need for it. 'It's almost four o'clock in the afternoon, sir. Aren't you hungry?' I asked. 'Our wedding day must be the third day from today, Jane. Don't concern yourself with fancy clothes or jewels now; none of that matters in the least.' 'The sun has dried up all the rain, sir. The breeze has stopped; it's quite warm,' I commented. 'Did you know, Jane,' he said, 'that I currently have your small pearl necklace fastened around my neck under my tie? I've worn it since the day I lost my only treasure, as a reminder of her.' 'We should go home through the woods; that will be the most shaded route,' I suggested. He continued voicing his own thoughts, not listening to me. 'Jane! You probably think I'm an impious fellow, but right now my heart is filled with gratitude towards God. He doesn't see things the way humans do, but much more clearly; he doesn't judge as humans do, but far more wisely. I did wrong; I would have tainted my innocent flower – breathed impurity onto its purity; the Almighty took her away from me. In my stubborn rebellion, I almost cursed the divine arrangement; instead of accepting the decree, I defied it. Divine justice ran its course; misfortunes piled up on me: I was forced to go through great suffering. His punishments are severe, and one struck me that has humbled me forever. You know I was proud of my strength, but what is it worth now, when I must rely on others for guidance, like a child relies on help? Only recently, Jane – just lately – have I begun to recognise and acknowledge God's hand in my destiny. I started to feel remorse, repentance; the desire to be reconciled with my Maker. I even began to pray sometimes; my prayers were very short, but very sincere. A few days ago – no, I can count them – four days; it was last Monday night, a strange feeling came over me: one where grief replaced madness – sorrow replaced gloominess. I had long been convinced that since I couldn't find you anywhere, you must be dead. Late that night – perhaps between eleven and twelve o'clock – before I went to my miserable sleep, I prayed to God that, if it pleased Him, I might soon die and enter the next world, where there was still hope of being reunited with Jane. I was in my room, sitting by the open window; feeling the gentle night air was comforting, even though I couldn't see any stars and only sensed the moon's presence as a faint, glowing mist. I yearned for you, Janet! Oh, I longed for you with all my soul and body! I asked God, in both agony and humility, if I hadn't been lonely, afflicted, and tormented long enough, and if I might not soon taste happiness and peace again. I admitted that I deserved all I had endured, but pleaded that I could barely endure more; and the absolute core of my heart's desires burst out involuntarily from my lips in the words – 'Jane! Jane! Jane!'' 'Did you say these words aloud?' I asked. 'I did, Jane. If anyone had heard me, they would have thought I was insane; I said them with such wild intensity.' 'And it was last Monday night, around midnight?' I questioned. 'Yes; but the exact time doesn't matter; what happened next is the strange part. You will think I'm superstitious – I do have some superstition in my nature, and always have; nevertheless, this is true – at least it's true that I heard what I'm now telling you. As I cried out 'Jane! Jane! Jane!', a voice – I can't say where it came from, but I know whose voice it was – replied, 'I am coming: wait for me;' and a moment later, whispered on the wind the words – 'Where are you?'' It's hard to explain the idea, the image these words created in my mind, yet I'll try. As you see, Ferndean is hidden deep in a dense wood, where sound is muffled and doesn't echo. 'Where are you?' seemed to be spoken among mountains; for I heard a hill-sent echo repeat the words. At that moment, the breeze felt cooler and fresher on my forehead; I could have imagined that in some wild, solitary setting, Jane and I were meeting. In spirit, I believe we must have met. At that hour, Jane, you were no doubt in deep sleep; perhaps your soul left its body to comfort mine; for those were your precise words – as sure as I am alive – they were yours!' Reader, it was on that Monday night – near midnight – that I too had received the mysterious call; those were the very words I used in reply to it. I listened to Mr. Rochester's account but didn't share my own experience. The coincidence felt too profound and inexplicable to reveal or discuss. If I had said anything, my story would necessarily have made a deep impact on his mind, and his mind, still prone to sadness from his suffering, didn't need the added darkness of the supernatural. So, I kept these matters to myself then and reflected on them inwardly. 'Now you can understand,' my master continued, 'why, when you appeared before me so unexpectedly last night, I had difficulty believing you were anything more than just a voice and a vision, something that would disappear into silence and nothingness, just as the midnight whisper and mountain echo had vanished before. Now, I thank God! I know it's not so. Yes, I thank God!' He gently put me off his knee, stood up, and reverently lifted his hat from his head. Bending his sightless eyes towards the ground, he stood in silent prayer. Only the final words of his worship were audible. 'I thank my Creator that, in the midst of judgment, he has remembered mercy. I humbly ask my Redeemer to give me strength to lead a purer life from now on than I have done before!' Then he held out his hand to be guided. I took that dear hand, held it briefly to my lips, then let it rest around my shoulder; being much shorter than him, I served as both his support and his guide. We entered the wood and headed towards home.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Given our situation, we have no reason to delay: we should get married at once." Rochester spoke with great enthusiasm, his old passionate nature surfacing. "We must unite immediately, Jane, we only need to get the license—and then we’ll be wed." 

"Mr. Rochester, I’ve just noticed it’s late in the day, and even Pilot has gone home for his meal. May I see your watch?" 

"Attach it to your belt, Janet, and keep it from now on: I don't need it." 

"It’s almost four in the afternoon, sir. Aren’t you hungry?" 

"Three days from now will be our wedding day, Jane. Forget about fancy dresses and jewelry; those things are worthless now." 

"The sun has dried all the rain, sir. The air is calm and it’s quite warm." 

"Jane, I have your small pearl necklace tied around my neck beneath my scarf. I’ve worn it ever since I lost my most precious possession, as a memento of her." 

"Let’s walk home through the woods; it will be shadier there." 

He continued, lost in his own thoughts, paying little attention to me. 

"Jane, you probably think I’m not a religious man, but right now my heart is overflowing with gratitude to God. He sees better than any person and judges more justly. I behaved wrongly; I almost stained your innocence with guilt. God saved you from me. In my stubbornness, I nearly cursed His will instead of accepting it. Divine justice caught up to me—I faced disaster after disaster; I had to journey through deep suffering. God’s punishments are powerful, and one of them has humbled me forever. I used to take pride in my strength, but now I must rely on others, like a child. Only recently, Jane, have I started to recognize God's hand in my fate. I feel remorse, repentance, and hope to be reconciled with my Creator. I’ve begun to pray, though my prayers are short, they are heartfelt.

A few days ago—four to be exact, last Monday night—I was overcome by sadness instead of madness. I had started to believe you were dead since I couldn’t find you anywhere. That night, late, around eleven or twelve, before I went to bed, I prayed to God to let me die soon if it was His will, so I might see you again in the afterlife.

I was in my room by the window, which was open and letting in the soothing night air, even though I couldn’t see the stars and only sensed the moon’s presence from a faint glow. I longed for you, Janet, with every part of my being. In my pain and humility, I begged God: Hadn’t I suffered enough, couldn’t I finally know happiness again? I admitted I deserved my pain but pleaded that I could bear no more. My deepest desire burst from my lips: ‘Jane! Jane! Jane!’” 

"Did you say those words aloud?" 

"I did, Jane. Anyone who overheard would have thought I was mad—I called them out with such desperation." 

"And this was last Monday night, around midnight?" 

"Yes, but the time isn’t important—what happened next is what matters. You might think this is superstition, and perhaps I am a little superstitious; but this really happened, or at least I truly believe it did. As I cried ‘Jane! Jane! Jane!’ I heard a voice—I can't say where it came from, but I knew it was your voice—answer, 'I’m coming: wait for me.' Then, on the wind, I heard whispered, 'Where are you?' 

Let me try to share the feeling, the image those words brought to my mind, though it’s hard to explain: Ferndean is deep in the woods, where sounds are muffled and don’t echo. But ‘Where are you?’ seemed to echo off hills as if it were spoken among mountains. Immediately the wind on my face felt cooler and fresher; it seemed as though you and I were meeting in some wild, lonely place. In spirit, I believe we did meet. You were probably asleep then, Jane, perhaps your soul came to comfort mine—for those were your words, I’m certain!”

Reader, it was indeed at midnight on Monday that I, too, heard the mysterious call and replied with those same words. I listened to Rochester’s story, but told him nothing of my own experience. The coincidence felt too strange, too intense to discuss. If I said anything, my story would surely overwhelm him; his mind, already darkened by suffering, did not need more shadows. So I kept the secret and reflected on it alone.

“My dear,” he continued, “now you can understand why, when you appeared so suddenly last night, I could hardly believe you were real and not just another voice or vision, like the echo at midnight. But now, I thank God, because I know you’re truly here. Yes, I thank God!”

He set me off his lap, stood, respectfully removed his hat, and with bowed head and closed eyes, stood silently in prayer. Only the last words of his prayer reached me: “I thank my Maker that, even while judging me, He has also shown mercy. I humbly ask my Redeemer to help me live a better life from now on.”

He reached out for me to guide him. I took his beloved hand, kissed it, then placed it on my shoulder—being much shorter, I served both as his support and his guide. We walked into the wood and made our way home.

events.title: A Quiet Wedding and a Calm Reception
detailed_summary: Jane Eyre announces that she has married Mr. Rochester.
The wedding was a very private affair, with only Jane, Mr. Rochester, the parson, and the clerk in attendance.
Upon their return from the church, Jane informs Mary, the housekeeper, and John, a servant, about her marriage.
Mary and John, characterized as composed and unflappable individuals, react with understated surprise.
Mary briefly pauses her cooking, acknowledging the news with a simple, "Well, for sure!"
John expresses that he had anticipated this outcome, remarking that he knew Mr. Edward (Rochester) would not delay in marrying Jane, and extends his congratulations.
Jane presents John with a five-pound note from Mr. Rochester, intended for both him and Mary.

Subsequently, Jane overhears Mary remarking positively about the match, suggesting Jane's good nature makes her a better partner for Rochester than any grand lady, and that Rochester clearly finds her beautiful.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Reader, I married him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And again, “If she ben’t one o’ th’ handsomest, she’s noan faâl and varry good-natured; and i’ his een she’s fair beautiful, onybody may see that.”

events.text_segment:
Reader, I married him. A quiet wedding we had: he and I, the parson and clerk, were alone present. When we got back from church, I went into the kitchen of the manor-house, where Mary was cooking the dinner and John cleaning the knives, and I said—
“Mary, I have been married to Mr. Rochester this morning.” The housekeeper and her husband were both of that decent phlegmatic order of people, to whom one may at any time safely communicate a remarkable piece of news without incurring the danger of having one’s ears pierced by some shrill ejaculation, and subsequently stunned by a torrent of wordy wonderment. Mary did look up, and she did stare at me: the ladle with which she was basting a pair of chickens roasting at the fire, did for some three minutes hang suspended in air; and for the same space of time John’s knives also had rest from the polishing process: but Mary, bending again over the roast, said only—
“Have you, Miss? Well, for sure!”
A short time after she pursued—“I seed you go out with the master, but I didn’t know you were gone to church to be wed;” and she basted away. John, when I turned to him, was grinning from ear to ear.
“I telled Mary how it would be,” he said: “I knew what Mr. Edward” (John was an old servant, and had known his master when he was the cadet of the house, therefore, he often gave him his Christian name)—“I knew what Mr. Edward would do; and I was certain he would not wait long neither: and he’s done right, for aught I know. I wish you joy, Miss!” and he politely pulled his forelock.
“Thank you, John. Mr. Rochester told me to give you and Mary this.” I put into his hand a five-pound note. Without waiting to hear more, I left the kitchen. In passing the door of that sanctum some time after, I caught the words—
“She’ll happen do better for him nor ony o’ t’ grand ladies.” And again, “If she ben’t one o’ th’ handsomest, she’s noan faâl and varry good-natured; and i’ his een she’s fair beautiful, onybody may see that.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: My dear reader, I married him. Our wedding was a small, quiet affair; only Mr. Rochester and I, the minister, and the clerk were present. Upon returning from the church ceremony, I went into the kitchen of the manor-house. There, Mary was cooking dinner and John was polishing knives. I told them, "Mary, I married Mr. Rochester this morning." Both the housekeeper and her husband were remarkably calm and composed people, the sort to whom one can deliver surprising news without fearing loud exclamations or a lengthy outburst of astonishment. Mary did look up and stared at me. The ladle she was using to baste the roasting chickens remained suspended in the air for about three minutes, and John's knife polishing also paused for the same duration. However, Mary soon returned to tending the roast and simply said, "You did, Miss? Well, indeed!" A little while later, she added, "I saw you leave with the master, but I didn't know you were going to church to get married," and she continued basting. When I turned to John, he was smiling broadly. He commented, "I told Mary this is how it would be. I knew what Mr. Edward" (John was an old servant who knew Mr. Rochester when he was younger and often used his first name) "I knew what Mr. Edward would do, and I was sure he wouldn't delay it for long. And as far as I can tell, he's made the right decision. Congratulations, Miss!" He politely touched his forelock. "Thank you, John," I replied. "Mr. Rochester asked me to give this to you and Mary." I placed a five-pound note in his hand. Without waiting for further comments, I left the kitchen. Passing by the door of that familiar room later, I overheard them speaking. I caught the words, "She'll likely be better for him than any of the important ladies." And again, "Even if she isn't one of the most beautiful, she's not plain and is very kind; and in his eyes, she is truly beautiful, anyone can see that."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I married Mr. Rochester, dear reader. Our wedding was a modest affair, attended only by ourselves, the minister, and the church clerk. Upon returning from the ceremony, I went into the manor's kitchen, where Mary was preparing dinner and John was cleaning knives. I told Mary, "I was married to Mr. Rochester this morning." Both Mary and John were calm, unflappable people who took even surprising news in stride. Mary looked at me in surprise, her ladle midair, and John paused his polishing, but after a moment Mary simply replied, “Did you, miss? Well, that’s something!” Soon after, she commented that she had seen me leave with Mr. Rochester, but hadn’t realized we were going to church to be wed, then continued her work. John, meanwhile, beamed and said he had predicted this might happen, and offered his congratulations. I handed them a five-pound note from Mr. Rochester, then left. Later, as I walked past the kitchen, I overheard them remarking that I might suit Mr. Rochester better than any fine lady would, and though I might not be the most beautiful, I was pleasant-natured, and, in his eyes, very beautiful indeed.

events.title: News of Marriage Reaches Friends and Family
detailed_summary: Jane promptly communicated her marriage to her cousins at Moor House and Cambridge, providing a full explanation for her actions.
Diana and Mary Rivers offered their unreserved approval of Jane's decision.
Diana mentioned her intent to visit Jane after the honeymoon period concluded.
When Jane read Diana's letter to Mr. Rochester, he playfully remarked that their honeymoon would extend throughout their lives, implying Diana should not wait too long.
The narrator notes uncertainty about St. John Rivers's initial reaction, as he did not reply to the letter announcing the marriage.
Six months later, St. John sent a letter that was calm and kind, though serious, but it notably omitted any mention of Mr. Rochester or Jane's marriage.
Since then, St. John has maintained a regular, albeit infrequent, correspondence, expressing hopes for Jane's happiness and her continued faith.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I wrote to Moor House and to Cambridge immediately, to say what I had done: fully explaining also why I had thus acted.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He has maintained a regular, though not frequent, correspondence ever since: he hopes I am happy, and trusts I am not of those who live without God in the world, and only mind earthly things.

events.text_segment:
I wrote to Moor House and to Cambridge immediately, to say what I had done: fully explaining also why I had thus acted. Diana and Mary approved the step unreservedly. Diana announced that she would just give me time to get over the honeymoon, and then she would come and see me.
“She had better not wait till then, Jane,” said Mr. Rochester, when I read her letter to him; “if she does, she will be too late, for our honeymoon will shine our life long: its beams will only fade over your grave or mine.”
How St. John received the news, I don’t know: he never answered the letter in which I communicated it: yet six months after he wrote to me, without, however, mentioning Mr. Rochester’s name or alluding to my marriage. His letter was then calm, and, though very serious, kind. He has maintained a regular, though not frequent, correspondence ever since: he hopes I am happy, and trusts I am not of those who live without God in the world, and only mind earthly things.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I promptly wrote to the residents at Moor House and to St. John at Cambridge to inform them of my actions and fully explain my reasons. Diana and Mary gave their complete and immediate approval to my decision. Diana stated she would wait until our honeymoon was over before visiting me. When I read Diana's letter to Mr. Rochester, he commented that she shouldn't postpone her visit until after the honeymoon, adding that their "honeymoon" would last their entire lives, only ending with their deaths. I have no idea how St. John reacted to the news, as he never replied to my letter informing him. However, half a year later, he did write, though he completely avoided mentioning Mr. Rochester or my marriage. That letter was calm, serious in tone, but also kind. Since then, we have corresponded regularly, though not often. In his letters, he expresses hope for my happiness and trust that I am not living a worldly life devoid of faith.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I immediately sent letters to Moor House and Cambridge explaining what I had done and the reasons for my actions. Diana and Mary thoroughly supported my decision. Diana mentioned that she would come visit once my honeymoon was over, giving me some time first. When I read her letter to Mr. Rochester, he remarked that she shouldn’t delay her visit, since our honeymoon would last all our lives and would only end with death. As for St. John, I’m not sure how he reacted; he never replied to the letter where I shared my news. However, six months later he wrote to me—he didn’t mention Mr. Rochester or my marriage, but his letter was calm, serious, yet kind. Since then, he has written occasionally though not often, expressing his hope for my happiness and wishing that I do not become someone who lives without faith and is concerned only with worldly matters.

events.title: Ensuring Adèle's Happiness and Well-being
detailed_summary: Jane, not having forgotten little Adèle, sought and received Mr. Rochester's permission to visit her at the school where he had placed her.
Adèle's immense joy at seeing Jane again was very moving for Jane; however, Adèle appeared pale, thin, and confessed her unhappiness.
Jane assessed the school's environment and found its regulations overly strict and its academic curriculum too rigorous for a child of Adèle's age.
Consequently, Jane decided to bring Adèle back home with her.
Although Jane initially planned to resume her role as Adèle's governess, she quickly realized this was unfeasible as her time and attention were now fully dedicated to her husband.
Jane then found a more suitable school for Adèle, one with a more lenient system and conveniently located to allow for frequent visits and occasional stays at home.
She ensured Adèle lacked nothing that could contribute to her comfort.
Adèle thrived in this new setting, becoming very happy and making good progress in her studies.

As Adèle matured, a solid English education helped correct her French-influenced shortcomings, and upon leaving school, she became a delightful and considerate companion to Jane, characterized by her docility, good temper, and strong principles, repaying Jane's kindness with gratitude.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: You have not quite forgotten little Adèle, have you, reader?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: By her grateful attention to me and mine, she has long since well repaid any little kindness I ever had it in my power to offer her.

events.text_segment: You have not quite forgotten little Adèle, have you, reader? I had not; I soon asked and obtained leave of Mr. Rochester, to go and see her at the school where he had placed her. Her frantic joy at beholding me again moved me much. She looked pale and thin: she said she was not happy. I found the rules of the establishment were too strict, its course of study too severe for a child of her age: I took her home with me. I meant to become her governess once more, but I soon found this impracticable; my time and cares were now required by another—my husband needed them all. So I sought out a school conducted on a more indulgent system, and near enough to permit of my visiting her often, and bringing her home sometimes. I took care she should never want for anything that could contribute to her comfort: she soon settled in her new abode, became very happy there, and made fair progress in her studies. As she grew up, a sound English education corrected in a great measure her French defects; and when she left school, I found in her a pleasing and obliging companion: docile, good-tempered, and well-principled. By her grateful attention to me and mine, she has long since well repaid any little kindness I ever had it in my power to offer her.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Perhaps you haven't entirely forgotten the young girl, Adèle? I certainly remembered her. I soon requested and obtained permission from Mr. Rochester to visit her at the boarding school where he had sent her. Her intense happiness upon seeing me again deeply touched me. She seemed pale and thin and told me she was not content. I determined that the establishment's regulations were excessively strict, and its educational program was too difficult for a child her age. I brought her back to live with me. My intention was to become her governess once more, but I quickly realized this was impossible. My time and energy were now needed for another person—my husband required all of them. Therefore, I looked for a school run on a more relaxed system, and situated near enough so I could visit her often and bring her home sometimes. I ensured she never lacked anything that would enhance her comfort; she soon became accustomed to her new home, grew very happy there, and made good progress in her studies. As she matured, a proper English education significantly improved her French deficiencies; and when she finished school, I found her to be a likable and helpful companion: obedient, good-tempered, and well-behaved. Her grateful dedication to me and my family has long since fully compensated for any small favor I was ever in a position to offer her.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Have you completely forgotten about little Adèle, dear reader? I had not. I soon requested and received permission from Mr. Rochester to visit her at the school he had enrolled her in. Her overwhelming happiness at seeing me again touched me deeply. She appeared pale and thin and confessed to being unhappy. I realized that the school's rules were too strict and the academic demands too much for someone her age, so I brought her back home with me. Although I intended to resume my role as her governess, this proved impossible since my attention and responsibilities were now devoted to my husband. Therefore, I found a more compassionate and nearby school for her, allowing me to visit her often and bring her home occasionally. I ensured she had everything she needed to be comfortable. She quickly adjusted to her new school, became quite happy, and progressed steadily in her studies. As she matured, the thorough English education helped her overcome many of her French shortcomings, and upon leaving school, she became a delightful, agreeable companion—obedient, pleasant, and morally upright. Through her sincere care for me and my family, she has long since repaid any kindness I was able to show her.

events.title: A Decade of Profound Marital Happiness
detailed_summary: As her narrative approaches its conclusion, Jane reflects on her ten years of married life.
She describes experiencing a profound and complete happiness, living entirely for and with her husband, whom she loves above all else.
Jane considers herself exceptionally blessed, feeling a mutual devotion so complete that she is her husband's life as he is hers.
She emphasizes their extraordinary closeness, stating no woman could be more intimately connected to her partner.
Their companionship is constant and effortless; they are always together, yet this shared existence feels as liberating as solitude and as joyful as being in company.
They converse continuously, a practice Jane likens to a shared, audible stream of thought.
Complete trust is exchanged between them, and their perfectly matched personalities result in absolute harmony.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My tale draws to its close: one word respecting my experience of married life, and one brief glance at the fortunes of those whose names have most frequently recurred in this narrative, and I have done.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All my confidence is bestowed on him, all his confidence is devoted to me; we are precisely suited in character—perfect concord is the result.

events.text_segment:
My tale draws to its close: one word respecting my experience of married life, and one brief glance at the fortunes of those whose names have most frequently recurred in this narrative, and I have done.
I have now been married ten years. I know what it is to live entirely for and with what I love best on earth. I hold myself supremely blest—blest beyond what language can express; because I am my husband’s life as fully as he is mine. No woman was ever nearer to her mate than I am: ever more absolutely bone of his bone and flesh of his flesh. I know no weariness of my Edward’s society: he knows none of mine, any more than we each do of the pulsation of the heart that beats in our separate bosoms; consequently, we are ever together. To be together is for us to be at once as free as in solitude, as gay as in company. We talk, I believe, all day long: to talk to each other is but a more animated and an audible thinking. All my confidence is bestowed on him, all his confidence is devoted to me; we are precisely suited in character—perfect concord is the result.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: My story is nearing its conclusion. I will share a brief reflection on my married life and quickly mention the fates of the characters who appeared most frequently, and then I will be finished. I have now been married for ten years. I understand what it means to dedicate my entire existence to and live alongside the person I love most in the world. I consider myself immensely fortunate, blessed beyond words, because I am just as vital to my husband’s life as he is to mine. No woman has ever been closer to her partner than I am; we are truly inseparable, as if made of the same flesh and bone. I never grow weary of Edward’s presence, nor does he of mine, any more than we would tire of the beating of our own hearts; consequently, we are always together. For us, being together allows us to feel as unconstrained as if we were alone, yet as cheerful as if in company. I believe we talk virtually all day long; our conversations are simply a more lively and audible form of shared thought. I confide everything in him, and he in me; our personalities are perfectly compatible, resulting in absolute harmony.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: My story is almost finished: I will say a few words about my married life and briefly mention what has happened to the people most often mentioned in this account, and then I will end. I have been married for ten years now. I have experienced what it is to live completely for and with the person I love most in the world. I consider myself incredibly fortunate—so much so that words do not suffice—because my husband’s life is as bound up in me as mine is in his. No woman has ever been more closely connected to her husband than I am to mine; we are truly united in every way. I never grow tired of Edward’s company, nor does he ever tire of mine, any more than either of us grows weary of our own heartbeat; as a result, we are always together. Being together means for us the freedom of solitude and the joy of companionship at the same time. We talk constantly, I think: speaking to each other is just a livelier form of thinking aloud. I trust him with everything, and he does the same with me; we are perfectly matched in temperament, and complete harmony is the result.

events.title: Supporting Rochester Through Blindness
detailed_summary: Mr. Rochester remained blind for the first two years of their marriage.
Jane believes this period of blindness was a crucial factor in forging their exceptionally close and intimate bond.
During this time, Jane functioned as his vision and, as he often called her, his 'right hand' and 'the apple of his eye'.
She vividly described the world to him—nature, books, landscapes, and weather—translating visual experiences into spoken words.
Jane never grew weary of reading to him, guiding him, or assisting him with any task he needed.
She found immense and exquisite pleasure in these acts of service, a joy tinged with sadness, particularly because Rochester accepted her help without any sense of shame or humiliation.
His profound love for her meant he felt no reluctance in depending on her care, and he understood that her devoted attention was an expression of her deepest affection and wishes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Rochester continued blind the first two years of our union; perhaps it was that circumstance that drew us so very near—that knit us so very close: for I was then his vision, as I am still his right hand.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He loved me so truly, that he knew no reluctance in profiting by my attendance: he felt I loved him so fondly, that to yield that attendance was to indulge my sweetest wishes.

events.text_segment: Mr. Rochester continued blind the first two years of our union; perhaps it was that circumstance that drew us so very near—that knit us so very close: for I was then his vision, as I am still his right hand. Literally, I was (what he often called me) the apple of his eye. He saw nature—he saw books through me; and never did I weary of gazing for his behalf, and of putting into words the effect of field, tree, town, river, cloud, sunbeam—of the landscape before us; of the weather round us—and impressing by sound on his ear what light could no longer stamp on his eye. Never did I weary of reading to him; never did I weary of conducting him where he wished to go: of doing for him what he wished to be done. And there was a pleasure in my services, most full, most exquisite, even though sad—because he claimed these services without painful shame or damping humiliation. He loved me so truly, that he knew no reluctance in profiting by my attendance: he felt I loved him so fondly, that to yield that attendance was to indulge my sweetest wishes.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: During the initial two years of our marriage, Mr. Rochester was sightless. It might have been this condition that pulled us so intimately together, creating such a strong connection, for I was his eyes then, just as I continue to be his essential support. Literally, I was what he frequently referred to as his most cherished possession, his 'apple of his eye'. He experienced nature and read books through me; and I never tired of observing for his benefit and articulating the impact of fields, trees, villages, rivers, clouds, and sunbeams – the scene before us; the atmospheric conditions around us – communicating by sound to his ear what visual perception could no longer register on his eye. I never grew weary of reading aloud to him; I never grew weary of guiding him wherever he wished to go, of performing the actions he desired to be done. And there was a profound, utterly delightful satisfaction in serving him, despite the inherent sadness, because he accepted these services without painful embarrassment or diminishing his pride. He loved me so deeply that he felt no hesitation in accepting my care; he sensed my strong affection for him, understanding that providing that care was granting my most earnest wishes.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Mr. Rochester remained blind for the first two years we were married; perhaps that was what brought us so close together and bound us so tightly. During that time, I became his eyes—just as I am still his right hand. In truth, as he often said, I was the apple of his eye. Through me, he experienced nature and read books, and I never tired of observing the world on his behalf or describing to him the sights of the fields, trees, towns, rivers, clouds, sunlight, the scenery before us, and the weather around us—translating what he could not see into words he could hear. I never grew weary of reading to him or helping him get wherever he wished, or doing anything he wanted. There was a deep, even bittersweet joy in serving him, because he accepted my help without embarrassment or shame. He loved me so wholeheartedly that he had no hesitation in relying on my care; he knew how deeply I loved him, and that providing this care fulfilled my own greatest happiness.

events.title: A Glimmer of Hope: Rochester's Sight Partially Returns
detailed_summary: One morning, after two years of blindness, while Jane was writing for him, Mr. Rochester inquired if she was wearing a glittering necklace and a pale blue dress, indicating he could perceive them.
He then revealed that he had suspected for some time that the vision in one of his eyes was improving and was now certain of it.
Jane and Mr. Rochester traveled to London to seek the advice of a distinguished oculist.
Following the consultation and treatment, Mr. Rochester eventually regained partial sight in that one eye.
Although his vision remained limited—he could not read or write extensively—he regained the ability to navigate independently, and the world was no longer a blank to him.
A particularly poignant moment was when he could see his first-born son and recognize that the child had inherited his own distinctive eyes.
This experience led Mr. Rochester to acknowledge with deep gratitude how God had balanced judgment with mercy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One morning at the end of the two years, as I was writing a letter to his dictation, he came and bent over me, and said—“Jane, have you a glittering ornament round your neck?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On that occasion, he again, with a full heart, acknowledged that God had tempered judgment with mercy.

events.text_segment:
One morning at the end of the two years, as I was writing a letter to his dictation, he came and bent over me, and said—“Jane, have you a glittering ornament round your neck?”
I had a gold watch-chain: I answered “Yes.”
“And have you a pale blue dress on?”
I had. He informed me then, that for some time he had fancied the obscurity clouding one eye was becoming less dense; and that now he was sure of it.
He and I went up to London. He had the advice of an eminent oculist; and he eventually recovered the sight of that one eye. He cannot now see very distinctly: he cannot read or write much; but he can find his way without being led by the hand: the sky is no longer a blank to him—the earth no longer a void. When his first-born was put into his arms, he could see that the boy had inherited his own eyes, as they once were—large, brilliant, and black. On that occasion, he again, with a full heart, acknowledged that God had tempered judgment with mercy.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: After two years had gone by, during one morning when I was writing a letter as he dictated, Mr. Rochester approached and bent over me, asking, 'Jane, do you have a gleaming piece of jewelry around your neck?' I replied yes, as I was wearing a gold watch-chain. He then inquired, 'And is your dress a light blue?' It was. He then informed me that for some time he had felt the darkness obscuring one eye was diminishing, and now he was certain. He and I went to London to consult with a renowned eye doctor. Eventually, he regained the ability to see with that eye. His vision is still not completely sharp; he cannot read or write much, but he can navigate without someone guiding his hand. The sky and the world are no longer invisible blanks to him. When his first child was placed in his arms, he could see that the boy had eyes like his used to be — big, bright, and black. At that moment, with a full heart, he once more recognized that God had balanced punishment with mercy.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: One morning, about two years later, while I was writing a letter as he dictated, he leaned over me and asked, "Jane, are you wearing a shiny necklace?" I replied that I had a gold watch-chain. He then asked if I was wearing a pale blue dress, which I was. He told me that he had noticed the darkness over one of his eyes was lifting, and he was now certain of it. We traveled to London, where a renowned eye doctor examined him, and in time, he regained the sight in that eye. Although his vision remains somewhat limited—he can't read or write much—he can move around on his own: the sky and earth are no longer invisible to him. When he held our first child, he saw that the child had inherited his own eyes as they once were—big, bright, and dark. At that moment, overcome with emotion, he once again recognized that God had balanced justice with kindness.

events.title: Happy Marriages for Diana and Mary Rivers
detailed_summary: Jane affirms the happiness she shares with her husband, Edward, noting that their joy is amplified by the happiness of their loved ones.
Both Diana and Mary Rivers are happily married.
The two families maintain close relationships, visiting each other on an alternating annual basis.
Diana's husband is a captain in the navy, described as a gallant officer and a good man.
Mary's husband is a clergyman, a college friend of her brother St. John, and considered a worthy match due to his accomplishments and principles.
Both Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton are said to love their wives deeply and are loved in return.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My Edward and I, then, are happy: and the more so, because those we most love are happy likewise.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Both Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton love their wives, and are loved by them.

events.text_segment: My Edward and I, then, are happy: and the more so, because those we most love are happy likewise. Diana and Mary Rivers are both married: alternately, once every year, they come to see us, and we go to see them. Diana’s husband is a captain in the navy, a gallant officer and a good man. Mary’s is a clergyman, a college friend of her brother’s, and, from his attainments and principles, worthy of the connection. Both Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton love their wives, and are loved by them.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Edward and I are happy together, and our contentment is increased by the fact that those closest to us are also happy. Both Diana and Mary Rivers have married. They come to visit us once a year, and we visit them the following year, alternating visits annually. Diana's husband is a captain in the navy, a brave officer and a virtuous man. Mary's husband is a clergyman, a friend of her brother's from college, whose accomplishments and principles make him a worthy connection. Both Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton have deep affection for their wives, and are likewise loved by them.

Both Diana and Mary Rivers have married; we visit each other every year in turn. Diana's husband is a brave and respectable navy captain, while Mary's husband is a clergyman, who was her brother’s friend at college and is well-suited to her. Both Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton have happy, loving marriages with their wives.

events.title: St. John Rivers's Devoted Life and Anticipated Heavenly Reward
detailed_summary: St. John Rivers departed from England for India, fully committing to the missionary path he had chosen for himself.
He is portrayed as an exceptionally resolute and tireless pioneer, laboring amidst difficult and dangerous conditions.
Described as firm, faithful, devoted, energetic, zealous, and truthful, he works to improve the lives of the people he serves, striving to dismantle prejudices of creed and caste.
While acknowledging his potential sternness, exacting nature, and ambition, these qualities are framed as those of a noble warrior or a dedicated apostle.
His ambition is presented as spiritual, aiming for a distinguished place among the redeemed in heaven.
St. John remains unmarried and, Jane believes, will never marry, his life wholly dedicated to his work, which is now drawing to a close like a setting sun.
Jane describes the profound emotional impact of the last letter she received from him—it brought her human tears yet filled her with divine joy, as he wrote of anticipating his heavenly reward.
She expects the next news of him will be of his death, delivered by another's hand, and believes he will face his end without fear, his mind clear and his faith steadfast.
The chapter concludes with St. John's own words, expressing his eager and ready anticipation of Christ's return.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As to St. John Rivers, he left England: he went to India.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “My Master,” he says, “has forewarned me. Daily He announces more distinctly,—‘Surely I come quickly!’ and hourly I more eagerly respond,—‘Amen; even so come, Lord Jesus!’”

events.text_segment:
As to St. John Rivers, he left England: he went to India. He entered on the path he had marked for himself; he pursues it still. A more resolute, indefatigable pioneer never wrought amidst rocks and dangers. Firm, faithful, and devoted, full of energy, and zeal, and truth, he labours for his race; he clears their painful way to improvement; he hews down like a giant the prejudices of creed and caste that encumber it. He may be stern; he may be exacting; he may be ambitious yet; but his is the sternness of the warrior Greatheart, who guards his pilgrim convoy from the onslaught of Apollyon. His is the exaction of the apostle, who speaks but for Christ, when he says—“Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross and follow me.” His is the ambition of the high master-spirit, which aims to fill a place in the first rank of those who are redeemed from the earth—who stand without fault before the throne of God, who share the last mighty victories of the Lamb, who are called, and chosen, and faithful.
St. John is unmarried: he never will marry now. Himself has hitherto sufficed to the toil, and the toil draws near its close: his glorious sun hastens to its setting. The last letter I received from him drew from my eyes human tears, and yet filled my heart with divine joy: he anticipated his sure reward, his incorruptible crown. I know that a stranger’s hand will write to me next, to say that the good and faithful servant has been called at length into the joy of his Lord. And why weep for this? No fear of death will darken St. John’s last hour: his mind will be unclouded, his heart will be undaunted, his hope will be sure, his faith steadfast. His own words are a pledge of this—
“My Master,” he says, “has forewarned me. Daily He announces more distinctly,—‘Surely I come quickly!’ and hourly I more eagerly respond,—‘Amen; even so come, Lord Jesus!’”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: St. John Rivers left England and went to India, where he began and continues to follow the course he set for himself. One could not find a more determined, hardworking pioneer laboring among challenges and perils. Steadfast, loyal, and devoted, full of vigor, enthusiasm, and integrity, he works for his fellow humans, smoothing their difficult path towards progress; he powerfully removes the obstacles of religious and class bias that impede it. He may appear stern, demanding, or still ambitious, but his strictness is like that of the warrior Greatheart guarding his group of pilgrims from attack; his demanding nature is like an apostle speaking purely for Christ, telling followers to give up themselves, take up their cross, and follow him; and his ambition is like that of a high spiritual leader who aims for a top position among those saved from the earth, who stand without sin before God's throne, who partake in the Lamb's final great victories, and who are summoned, chosen, and true. St. John is unmarried and will never marry. He has been enough for the demanding work thus far, and that work is nearing its end; his notable life is approaching its conclusion. The last letter I got from him caused me human sorrow and tears, yet also filled my heart with divine happiness, as he foresaw his certain prize, his crown that will not perish. I expect that someone else's hand will write to me next, to report that the good and faithful servant has finally been called into the joy of his Lord. And why shed tears over this? No dread of dying will cast a shadow over St. John's final hour; his thoughts will be clear, his heart brave, his expectation sure, and his faith firm. His own statements confirm this: he says, 'My Master has informed me in advance. Every day He announces more clearly, "Surely I am coming soon!" and each hour I answer with greater eagerness, "Amen; yes, come, Lord Jesus!"'
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Regarding St. John Rivers, he left England for India, following the path he had chosen, and continues to pursue it. No one has worked more persistently or bravely among obstacles, rocks, and dangers. He is steadfast, loyal, and dedicated—full of life, enthusiasm, and honesty—as he works tirelessly to benefit others, removing obstacles and prejudices in their way like a strong man clearing a path. He may appear strict, demanding, or ambitious, but his severity is like that of a courageous protector defending his group from danger. His demands resemble those of an apostle who calls others to self-sacrifice and devotion, and his ambitions are those of a noble soul who wants to be among the righteous, faithful, and victorious at the end. St. John is still single and will remain so. He has managed his work alone, which is now nearing completion, and his life is drawing to a close. The last letter I received from him made me cry for human reasons but also rejoice spiritually; he looks forward to his eternal reward. I expect that soon a stranger will write to tell me that this devoted servant has passed on to his ultimate joy. There is no need to mourn, for St. John will face death without fear—clear-minded, courageous, hopeful, and faithful to the end. His own statements confirm this, as he says his Master warns him daily, “Surely I come quickly!” to which St. John eagerly replies, “Amen; even so come, Lord Jesus!”
